text: Thousands of people who are not accused of any crime or who have completed prison terms for minor crimes spent this Christmas -- and may spend the next -- in jails around the nation. They are immigrants detained by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which has filled its own detention centers and has now resorted to using local and county lockups.
title: The Immigrant Lockup

text: Hundreds of immigrants who are simply seeking political asylum share cells with people accused of violent crimes, and are often subject to abuse because they are foreigners. Keeping them in jails is cruel, unnecessary and a waste of money.
title: The Immigrant Lockup

text: The detentions have more than doubled since 1995 because Congress now provides money for the I.N.S. to rent beds in local jails. In addition, punitive new immigration laws kicked in this year that expand the categories of immigrants the I.N.S. must detain as they await possible deportation.
title: The Immigrant Lockup

text: Most of the 16,000 people in detention on any given day are immigrants, legal as well as illegal, who have committed crimes, including very minor ones such as marijuana possession or turnstile-jumping, even if their convictions were long ago. They are held by the I.N.S. after they have finished their prison terms. Another group comprises illegal immigrants rounded up in raids on workplaces.
title: The Immigrant Lockup

text: The third group is asylum-seekers. The new immigration laws provide that everyone who comes to America seeking asylum is detained before a first interview. Those who pass it are then often detained for months or even years as they wait for their asylum hearings. Many of them are victims of torture or other traumatic events whose problems are exacerbated by jail.
title: The Immigrant Lockup

text: The I.N.S. has not been able to assure decent conditions even in the centers under its control. In 1995 inmates at an I.N.S. detention center in Elizabeth, N.J., rioted over beatings and the use of shackles. The I.N.S. later criticized the private company that administered the center, Esmor, for ''inhumane'' conditions. Conditions in local jails are often far worse, and the I.N.S. cannot supervise them. Human Rights Watch has collected numerous allegations of beatings and other mistreatment. The I.N.S. has called for a government investigation of alleged torture of immigrants by electric shock in a Florida jail. Immigrants often have no access to lawyers or even someone who speaks their language. Worst off are the 1,800 people scheduled for deportations to countries that will not take them back, such as Cuba. They are jailed indefinitely, some for years.
title: The Immigrant Lockup

text: The main reason for I.N.S. detention is that the vast majority of people at risk of deportation skip their court dates and simply vanish, given the chance. The I.N.S. is beginning to study how to get people to keep their court appointments without locking them up. One pilot project run by the Vera Institute of Justice, a nonprofit group, keeps immigrants who seem unlikely to flee out of jail if they check in regularly and receive home visits from supervisors. Preliminary results show that compliance has soared -- at one-sixth of the $20,000 per year that detention costs.
title: The Immigrant Lockup

text: The I.N.S. should expand its search for alternatives to detention, including the use of bail. The 5,000 children detained each year should be put in group homes or foster care, not juvenile jails. Some people will require detention, but it should be in centers for immigrants. Congress should allow the I.N.S. to build its own facilities, which must be strictly supervised. Above all, the I.N.S. and Congress must abandon their punitive mentality. It is hard not to suspect that they are trying to deter immigration by making the process as harrowing as possible.
title: The Immigrant Lockup

text: When Nigem D., a college freshman, thinks about the kind of life he could be leading, he remembers his friend Burnell. The last time he heard about him, Burnell was in jail on charges of drug possession.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: They met at the Pleasantville Residential Treatment Center in Westchester County, N.Y., when both were 14. They had been sent there by the Administration for Children's Services -- New York City's child welfare agency -- after causing disciplinary problems while in foster care. After a year at Pleasantville, they moved on to a group home in the Midwood section of Brooklyn.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: ''That place was probably the nicest place I'd lived,'' Nigem, who is now 18, said of the group home. ''The furniture, the floors, the beds, the food -- it was all beautiful.''
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: For Nigem, who came to the attention of Children's Services after his mother left him home alone without food or electricity at age 7, moving to the Pleasantville center was a turning point. After an initial period of rebellion, he decided that he would be better off if he behaved, and he continued in that mind-set after he moved to the group home.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: But Burnell drifted back into the life of crime and drugs that they had both been exposed to from an early age, Nigem said.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: ''He was all straight and uptight at Pleasantville,'' he recalled. ''But once he was back in the city, he started buying marijuana with his allowance and hanging with gangster types in the neighborhood.''
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: Nigem did not follow that path. He used his experiences at Pleasantville, two group homes and a youth residence to escape the world of drugs and violence that his parents inhabited.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: All those temporary homes for teen-agers with troubled backgrounds are run by the Jewish Child Care Association, an affiliate of the UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: Nigem's story is a familiar one at the group homes and residential centers. He does not remember who found him in the dark apartment near Yankee Stadium when he was 7. But he does know that his mother, who was addicted to crack cocaine, had a history of neglecting him. And he knows that his father had been in and out of jail since Nigem was 4 months old.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: Nigem was sent to live with his aunt in an arrangement called kinship foster care. But Nigem's aunt lived in a tiny two-bedroom apartment in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn and had three children of her own. In 1990, two more cousins moved in after another aunt began using drugs.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: Nigem said the situation made it easy for him to hang out late into the night with friends drinking and using drugs. He also developed a violent temper and had fights with his cousins.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: By the time Nigem turned 14, his aunt had lost control of him, and she contacted Children's Services.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: When Nigem arrived at Pleasantville, he hated it: the strict curfews and a daily routine that was crammed from the time he woke up until he went to bed, with chores, counseling and classes. He talked back to the staff and on occasion was caught in the girls' rooms, which was against the rules. He said he often found himself placed on restriction -- in effect, grounded -- during the meager daily recreation time the residents were allotted.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: ''I got tired of getting in trouble,'' Nigem said. ''I realized that if I didn't get with their system, I'd eventually be kicked out and end up back in my old life. But there were things there I didn't want to give up.''
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: Basketball was one of them. Playing on the team at the treatment center helped him focus his energies in a positive direction, he said. Today, he continues to play as a guard on the team at the State University of New York at Old Westbury, where he just completed his first semester.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: Last March, Nigem moved to the Youth Residence Center on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Nigem credits the atmosphere there with helping him resist the temptations to drink and use drugs when he is out on his own.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: The center is meant to give young adults, ages 16 to 21, a taste of the freedom they will know as adults, said Richard Johnson, its director. The residents are allowed to come and go as they please as long as they are drug-free and employed or in school.
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: ''The main goal of all of our centers and group homes, is to teach the kids how to move on in life,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''Unfortunately, we only have the money to help a small percentage of those who need help, like Nigem did.''
title: The Neediest Cases; After a Troubled Start, a Teen-Ager Gets a Nudge Toward College

text: A Long Island-based rap artist better known for colorful antics than for violent behavior was arrested Sunday night in Manhattan and charged with criminal possession of a weapon after the police said they found a loaded, unregistered .45-caliber pistol in his 1995 Mercedes-Benz.
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: The performer, Trevor Smith, who goes by the stage name Busta Rhymes, faces up to seven years in jail if he is convicted of the weapons charge. His arrest comes a week after his new album made its debut at No. 13 on Billboard magazine's top 100 sales list.
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: Mr. Smith, 26, whose frenetic stage persona and cartoonish costumes set him apart from ''gangsta'' rap musicians who have been criticized for promoting violence, was stopped by the police on the West Side Highway near 18th Street in Chelsea at 11:30 P.M. on Sunday. Gerald Odom, 25, Mr. Smith's road manager, was riding in the performer's Mercedes-Benz at the time. Neither man has a criminal record, according to court documents.
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: After pulling Mr. Smith over for changing lanes three times without signaling, Officer Anthony Curtin looked in the back seat of Mr. Smith's car, prosecutors said. Using a flashlight, he was able to see a gun sitting in an open bag, they said. Mr. Odom was searched and found to be carrying a small bag of marijuana, the police said. He was charged with unlawful possession of marijuana and criminal possession of a weapon, the .45-caliber pistol.
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: The rap artist, the son of West Indian immigrants who moved to Long Island from Brooklyn in the early 1980's, told Officer Curtin, '' 'I got robbed twice -- that's why I have the gun,' '' prosecutors said.
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: Mr. Smith's lawyer, Robert Kalima, would not comment on the specifics of the case but said the performer was innocent. ''We are investigating what occurred,'' he said.
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: The arraignment of Mr. Smith, who has a part in ''The Rugrats Movie'' and is scheduled to be host of Black Entertainment Television's countdown of best videos of the year on New Year's Day, caused a brief stir in the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building yesterday. While court officers scratched their heads and struggled to pronounce Mr. Smith's stage name, some younger female court employees seemed to stir with excitement at the thought of seeing him.
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: After receiving assurances that Mr. Smith would appear in court again, Judge Thomas Farber released both men on their own recognizance and ordered them to return on Jan. 28.
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: Asked if he had anything to say as he left the courtroom, Mr. Smith grinned and said, ''Peace now.''
title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Possession of Unregistered Gun

text: Every winter, after flying south from the Eastern United States, millions of monarch butterflies festoon fir trees in the mountains of Mexico, creating one of the world's most dazzling and famous biological spectacles. But in spite of intense interest in these beloved insects, the details of their travels, like those of so many creatures that do not submit to tagging or to voyeuristic techniques like radio-transmitters, have largely remained a mystery.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: Now three new studies, including one released Dec. 22 on monarchs, herald the arrival of a powerful new technique that can identify, sometimes to within a few miles, where migrating animals -- from butterflies to mastodons to humans -- have been. The new technique takes advantage of different forms, known as isotopes, of chemical elements. Biologists have begun discovering that these isotopes, present in different amounts in different regions, can leave a distinctive chemical signature written in the feather of a bird or the wing of a butterfly.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: By pinpointing crucial places where animals spend their lives, for example the major breeding grounds of monarch butterflies, the studies are not only illuminating the paths of these travelers, but are showing where conservationists should be focusing their efforts. In the case of monarchs, much of their breeding ground now appears to be on some of the most heavily farmed regions, heavily sprayed with pesticides, in the United States.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: ''This has been a massive breakthrough,'' said Dr. Keith Hobson, a research scientist at the Canadian Wildlife Service in Saskatoon, who carried out the monarch work along with Dr. Len Wassenaar, a research scientist with Environment Canada, also in Saskatoon. ''These are questions we could get at no other way.''
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: Dr. Page Chamberlain, a geochemist at Dartmouth College and another of the leaders in this newly developing field, said that when he first heard that researchers were using isotopes to trace elephant movements, ''We thought, 'Hey, we can do that. We can do it with fish too.' Now within a couple of years we've gone from fish to birds to insects. It has a lot of promise.''
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: It turns out, to biologists' delight, that the world is peppered and painted with many different kinds of isotopes whose levels in a region vary depending on factors like temperature, rainfall, bedrock and soils.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: Hydrogen, for example, which comes in its standard form as well as the heavier form deuterium, shows a distinctive pattern of distribution. Depending on whether hydrogen in any particular molecule of water is heavy or light, the water will be heavy or light. When clouds move inland from over the ocean, heavy water rains out first and lighter water further inland, creating a stable gradient that can be mapped. Those differences get translated into plants that take up the water and then into insects that eat the plants, birds that eat the insects and so on, leaving an indelible mark on even the flightiest creatures.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: Researchers can refine their ability to pinpoint locations by using multiple isotopes with different specificities. Strontium, for example, an element that has been used to trace salmon movements, can vary greatly between streams just a few miles apart.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: To track monarchs, researchers used carbon and hydrogen, first developing a detailed isotope map. Working with Dr. Chip Taylor, an ecologist at the University of Kansas and the director of Monarch Watch, a nonprofit research and education group, Dr. Wassenaar and Dr. Hobson enlisted the help of 90 amateur butterfly enthusiasts, many of them schoolchildren. These volunteers around the country raised monarch caterpillars on milkweed plants, the insect's food plant, from their area. The carbon and hydrogen in the wings of the resulting butterflies revealed the variation in isotope ratios from the Rocky Mountains to the Atlantic -- the breeding range of the monarchs that migrate to Mexico.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: Researchers were then able to study the wings of monarchs that had died naturally in 13 wintering sites in Mexico. They showed for the first time that these butterflies dangling together like crowded Christmas tree ornaments came from all parts of the breeding range, flying in and mingling after having grown up as caterpillars in places as distant as Massachusetts, Illinois and Maryland. The work put to rest a theory that different roosts were populated by butterflies from distinct geographic regions.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: The new findings are a big step forward because earlier attempts to track the monarchs had been limited to tagging. ''The odds of recovery with little guys, like monarchs, are pathetically low,'' Dr. Wassenaar said, about one recaptured monarch for every several thousand tagged.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: The most surprising discovery, however, was that, while the monarchs' breeding range is quite large, half of all the butterflies collected from Mexico had come there from a fairly restricted and highly agricultural area including Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, Missouri, Wisconsin, Illinois, Michigan, Indiana and Ohio -- soybean and corn country. The bad news, said Dr. Lincoln Brower, a monarch researcher at Sweet Briar College, is that ''pesticides are killing milkweed plants on a grand scale in this very region, what they've shown is the most important breeding region for monarchs.''
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: More worrisome still, Dr. Taylor said, is the use of transgenic plants, genetically altered to withstand pesticide sprays that competing weeds, like milkweeds, cannot. Other transgenic plants, like those that produce toxins in their tissues, are of great concern to biologists who note that it remains entirely unknown what effect these novel plants might have on insects in these regions that are not targets, including monarchs.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: ''There is a revolution coming along in agriculture,'' Dr. Taylor said, ''that has great potential to eliminate a lot of milkweeds.''
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: The reach of the new isotope studies is becoming so broad that even the dead are not immune from these investigations.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: Dr. T. Douglas Price, archeologist at the University of Wisconsin, and an international team of colleagues are tracking the movements of ancient humans using strontium deposits in teeth and bones.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: ''The beauty of this is that in people, your tooth enamel forms at birth and doesn't change and your bone represents where you lived the last 10 years of your life,'' he said. ''If the ratios are different, we know that the person moved.'' Using such simple principles, Dr. Price said his team had just completed a study of the peoples of the Mexican city of Teotihuacan, testing the idea that different parts of the city were ethnic neighborhoods of people from different regions of Mexico. ''We've looked at their bones and they're definitely outsiders,'' Dr. Price said. ''The potential of this technique is really remarkable.''
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: In addition, others are tracking declining songbirds and salmon, and two paleontologists, Kathryn Hoppe at Princeton University and Dr. Paul Kock at the University of California at Santa Cruz, are reconstructing the movements of fossil mastodons and mammoths. Meanwhile, there remain many untapped isotopes and as many new questions to be asked.
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: ''I think we can look at just about any animal, you name it,'' Dr. Hobson said. ''Forensic applications are also quite possible. If someone wanted to know if marijuana was grown in the Southern United States or Canada, that would just be a piece of cake.''
title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

text: "So let me get this straight, you actually get paid to go to games?"
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: I have been hearing this question or a version of it since I became a sportswriter, and even if isn't altogether true — I actually get paid to write at warp speed after going to games — I always have liked the tone of it: sports as escapism; an Olympic-ringed circus to leaven our daily bread.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: But the tone of the question and the tone of my workplace have been diverging for quite some time, and although, dear reader, that is hardly your problem, there was usually something to take all our minds off the games in 1998.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: It started in January with Australian customs officials searching through the luggage of the Chinese swimmer Yuan Yuan as she arrived for the world swimming championships and finding vials of human-growth hormone, a banned substance.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: It continued in February when a Canadian named Ross Rebagliati received a lot more attention for testing positive for marijuana than for winning the first snowboarding gold medal in Olympic history.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: It accelerated in July with the world's greatest bicycle race degenerating into a police chase in the wake of more drug searches, seizures, arrests and — for a change — admissions, although Richard Virenque's was not among them.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: It extended into December with a full-blown Olympic bribery scandal and a National Basketball Association labor dispute that appeared it might be intractable enough to force cancellation of the season for the first time in history.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: Perhaps that is a harbinger of the post-modern sports world: one in which there are no games.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: But even if the NBA players' lawyers and the league's lawyers come to agreement, I have the lingering suspicion that the whole enterprise of sport, title sponsors and exclusive-rights holders is chugging steadily toward a cliff.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: Attribute it to what you will: the inevitable price of decadence; the overemphasis on manufactured and well-marketed heroes instead of real heroes, or human nature. But however one explains it, the bright moments for me in 1998 — John Elway and his Denver Broncos finally winning the Super Bowl; the cross-country skiier Bjorn Daehlie sprawling across the finish line to win his eighth Olympic gold medal; Alex Corretja's and Carlos Moya's friendly post-final embrace at the French Open; Zinedine Zidane's near-post headers in the World Cup final; Marion Jones sprinting down a track with imperfect form and nobody in front of her — are fighting a losing battle for space in my memory bank with the uglier moments.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: A few postcards, some sweet and some bittersweet, from the world of sports in 1998:
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: Jan. 22, Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy: In the streets, the dowagers in their furs are sharing space with the hoi polloi in their parkas. But inside a three-star hotel chosen expressly for its inconspicuousness, Alberto Tomba is running his hands nervously, compulsively across his face and through his thick curly hair as he talks about the upcoming Winter Olympics. Tomba looks trim; he looks tan, but he looks anything but tranquil as he describes the cumulative psychological effects of an ongoing tax investigation and the ongoing examination of his private life by the fourth estate. This will be the final season for the manchild whose charisma made skiing appealing to the masses.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: Feb. 13, Nagano, Japan: Sportswriters train themselves to control their emotions. Cheering in the press box is not allowed, not even for the team you used to live and cry for as a child, and I sometimes have to remind myself that it is completely acceptable to applaud at the theater. But on the morning of the much-delayed men's Olympic downhill race, my training fails me completely as I watch Hermann Maier of Austria attack a narrow turn with typical insouciance and then, most unexpectedly and spectacularly, hurtle off a lip and take flight. As the world's dominant skier heads toward the ozone layer, skis and poles akimbo, I am shouting with a mixture of surprise and dread, and I don't stop shouting until Maier has crashed and skidded through two security fences. Three days later, Maier would recover his balance and I my composure. He would win the first of two Olympic gold medals by dominating the Super-G.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: April 6, Bratislava, Slovak Republic: How many tennis fans, or even tennis fanatics, would pay to watch Dominik Hrbaty play Magnus Gustafsson? Precious few, but it was one of my favorite matches of the year. Hrbaty is a Slovak; Gustafsson is a Swede. And with this Davis Cup first-round match tied at 2-2, both men need a victory to put their team in the quarterfinals. The 31-year-old Gustafsson has spent the week in Bratislava in bed with a virus. The day before this match he was interviewing his Swedish teammates for television.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: But because of an injury to Mikael Tillstrom, the convalescent Gustafsson is on the other end of the camera today. After he wins in four nervy sets, in spite of a chronic cough and a lot of crowd support for Hrbaty, his fellow Swedes toss him into the air and rub his balding head. There is not an agent or spin doctor in sight, and eight months later, the Swedes would be rubbing Gustafsson's head again as he helped them win their third Davis Cup title in five years.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: May 6, Rome: I am sitting near the grandstand court at the Foro Italico, the one ringed with neoclassical nudes commissioned during the reign of Benito Mussolini. And when Venus Williams has finished working over her smaller, infinitely more unassuming Spanish opponent, she saunters over to the stands and begins signing autographs. An elderly, excited Italian man leans over the railing and shouts like an auctioneer: "Grande, Grande, Grande. You will be big, big, big, big!" The 6-foot-1 1/2 (1.85-meter) Williams looks up at the spectator with amusement in her eyes and begins to laugh loudly, the braces on her teeth flashing in the afternoon sun.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: June 11, Marseille: The man I am talking to in the hardscrabble housing project of La Castellane looks a lot like Zinedine Zidane. That is because he is Zidane's older brother, Farid, who, unlike Zinedine, still lives here. Farid is explaining that it is not easy for those of North African descent to find their place in contemporary France. His brother has managed quite nicely by controlling a soccer ball better than almost anyone on the planet, and as we walk around the concrete concourse where Zidane acquired some of his skills as a youngster, a rainbow coalition of teenagers gathers to answer queries on the eve of France's World Cup opener against South Africa. "Here it's not easy to succeed," one of the teenagers observes. "But with Zidane, at least people in La Castellane know that it is possible."
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: July 12, Paris: Zidane has just redefined French sporting success at the expense of Ronaldo and the and After writing into the night, I exit the ellipitical Stade de France, the newest national monument in a country overflowing with them. Outside, the crowd is still dense and we are soon packed tightly against each other as we inch toward the entrance to the metro.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: "On est les champions; On est les champions; On est, On est, On est les champions!"
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: Unlike the English or the Brazilians, the French don't have a trove of soccer songs, but they have improvised. On the Avenue des Champs-Elysees, they gather and sing by the tens of thousands as the faces of Zidane and other French players are projected onto the carved stone of the Arc de Triomphe.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: It has been a schizophrenic World Cup, the genuine and wholesome enthusiasm in the stands sometimes overshadowed by the rioting in the streets of Marseille and Lens.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: I had been in both those cities during the violence, and as I approach the Champs-Elysees on my bicycle in the early hours of July 13 to rejoin the revelry, I am content that my final image of the globe's most popular sporting event will be of joy, of release.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: But when I arrive at the Arc de Triomphe, red lights are flashing: ambulances, police cars, commotion. A panicked driver has accelerated through a crowd of pedestrians, injuring many. The party in this part of town won't be quite the same party again, and this flawed final World Cup evening is, unfortunately, in perfect harmony with a flawed World Cup.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: Aug. 8, Monaco: The Tour de France turned out to be an ad hoc seminar on morality and the hazards of EPO, an artificial hormone that increases the flow of oxygen to muscles. Michelle Smith-De Bruin, a triple gold medalist in swimming at the 1996 Summer Olympics, has been banned from competition for four years for tampering with her own urine samples. I am in Monaco for a track-and-field meet, and as I look down on Stade Louis II from the old city several hours before the competition begins, I realize how much more difficult it is to find the right tone in this climate of suspicion. Today's world-record holder could be tomorrow's pariah; today's bitter fourth-place finisher a vindicated medalist.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: How to leave room for revision without casting aspersions on everyone? How to do justice to a remarkable sporting feat without sounding unjustly skeptical?
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: September 7, New York: Pete Sampras is still in the running to match Roy Emerson's career record for Grand Slam victories at the United States Open, but as I walk through the American corner of the press room at Flushing Meadows, nearly all the televisions are tuned into a St. Louis Cardinals baseball game.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: A global sport has been trumped by the local, and as Mark McGwire's successful chase of the single-season home-run record continues, I meet regularly with foreign colleagues from France, the Czech Republic and Sweden who are looking for metaphors that work for their countrymen. I do my best.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: Imagine if some skier were closing in on Ingemar Stenmark's 88 World Cup victories, I suggest hopefully to the Swede. My foreign colleagues also want to know why androstenedione, the muscle-building supplement McGwire takes, isn't banned by Major League Baseball if it is banned by the International Olympic Committee. That one is much more difficult to answer.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: Nov. 23, Lake Kariba, Zimbabwe: I am in this struggling and lovely southern African nation to do a story on the Black children — Byron, Wayne and Cara — who grew up on a farm near the Zimbabwean capital of Harare and are all successful touring tennis professionals. After spending a few days with their family, I have come to this artificial lake that is a magnet for wildlife. This morning, I have rented a boat, and my driver is a young, lean Zimbabwean named Silas. We spot hippos and crocodiles near the shore. We spot cape buffaloes on an island. We find kudu and impala, kingfishers and jacanas. As we are relaxing and admiring a bull elephant as it approaches the lake to drink, Silas inquires about my line of work. I tell him, and Silas stays quiet a while before finally asking, "So what really happened to Ronaldo at the World Cup?" I look at Silas. I look at the elephant, and I start to laugh, a global villager adrift on Lake Kariba.
title: Drugs, Fan Violence and Strikes Dim Bursts of Athletic Brilliance : The Year in Sports, 1998 :Too Many Ugly Moments

text: WHAT a year. No space for a wordy introduction. Just look at the places a wandering columnist visited in 1998:
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: PASADENA, CALIF., Jan. 1. After growing up in chilly New York and listening to the Rose Bowl on the radio, I finally get to cover one. Even get caught in traffic from the parade. After the glorious sun goes down, Michigan holds off Washington State for an eventual share of the unofficial national title.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10. Michelle Kwan performs the skate of her life, winning the national title over Tara Lipinski.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA, Jan. 18. European skill players abound as the National Hockey League holds its All-Star Game, preparing for the Winter Games next month.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: NAGANO, JAPAN, Feb. 7. People attend opening ceremonies bareheaded, wearing light jackets, in hazy sunshine. Japan and the International Olympic Committee have defied Mother Nature by holding Winter Games closer to the Equator than ever before.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: NAGANO, JAPAN, Feb. 13. Ross Rebagliati of Canada gets to keep his gold medal for snowboarding after admitting he may indeed have inhaled marijuana -- but only secondary smoke months earlier at a party.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: NAGANO, JAPAN, Feb. 13. It is no disgrace for the United States to lose to Sweden in the opener of the first mostly professional men's hockey tournament in Olympic history. What will be a disgrace are the trashed dorms and grim silence from the Americans. American women will win their gold, and behave maturely.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: HAKUBA, JAPAN, Feb. 14. On a dismal, rainy day straight out of ''Akira Kurosawa's Dreams,'' two Norwegians in red suits materialize from the mist, as Thomas Alsgaard passes medal king Bjorn Dahlie in the stretch in the 15-kilometer cross-country race.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: NAGANO, JAPAN, Feb. 20. Tara Lipinski made an adult decision at 15: She would live in the athletes' village, she would march in the opening parade, she would have a blast. Tonight she skates exuberantly, winning the gold medal over a serene but tentative Michelle Kwan.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: NAGANO, JAPAN, Feb. 20. Taka Fukushima, the Buddhist priest at the historic Zenkoji temple, suggests tearing down the expensive buildings now that the Winter Games are over. The games are a modified success because of soupy weather and a sense that the Winter Games have grown too big.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: TOKYO, Feb. 23. The bullet train whisks us south from Almost Heaven, West Nagano, into the big city, in spring weather. My old neighbors from Long Island, the Usuzakas, take me for an exquisite dinner and good talk, and I make a pledge to come back soon.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: FLUSHING, QUEENS, March 31. Baseball tempts Mother Nature by opening earlier than ever before, but the temperature is 87 degrees for the Mets' opener. Is this an omen that baseball will luck out this season?
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: OAKLAND, CALIF., April 5. The Yankees finally win after losing their first three. Back home in Knee-Jerk City, the tabloids are already picking Joe Torre's successor.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: BRONX, N.Y., April 14. No game today because a beam fell in empty Yankee Stadium yesterday. Reports of a beefy perpetrator in blue blazer and gray slacks are unconfirmed.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: LOUISVILLE, KY., May 2. Marginalized by lotteries and the gerontological makeup of its fan base, racing derives much of its vestigial buzz from Derby Day. Real Quiet bursts to the front and Bob Baffert shouts his nickname, ''The Fish! The Fish!''
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: BRONX, N.Y., May 17. David Wells pitches the second perfect game ever by a Yankee. By some weird circumstance, Wells and Don Larsen both went to Point Loma High in San Diego. ''He'll think about it every day of his life, just like I do,'' Larsen predicts from Idaho.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: FLUSHING, QUEENS, May 23. Even millionaire free agents can suffer shock. His eyes baffled, Mike Piazza arrives at Shea Stadium, joining his third club in two weeks.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: ST.-JEAN D'ARDIERES, FRANCE, June 5. In the vineyards, the Beaujolais grapes are growing, but here in the rented chateau, there is nothing but sour whine as the American soccer team arrives for the World Cup.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: PARIS, June 6. Wearing a black tennis outfit to honor her father, who died on May 14, Monica Seles runs out of gas after a gallant run, losing to Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in the French final.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: PARIS, June 15. Germany performs a professional mugging in the first minutes, and commits a 2-0 massacre of the United States in the Americans' World Cup opener.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: LYONS, FRANCE, June 21. Affluent Iranian exiles wear T-shirts taunting the current Government, then gleefully celebrate a 2-1 victory over the United States.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: NANTES, FRANCE, June 25. The United States is put out of its misery, 1-0, by powerful Yugoslavia.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, FRANCE, July 3. With a total sense of impending doom, I sit in front of a cafe television and watch my Italians play 120 scoreless minutes with France. Then the Italians lose the shootout, as always.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: CASSIS, FRANCE, July 5. My wife and I climb over rugged hills to go swimming in a calenque, a fjord-like inlet on the Mediterranean. What a country.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: BONNIEUX, FRANCE, July 6. On a hilltop in the Vaucluse, the waiter suggests the Cavaillon melon wine, a local seasonal treat, unavailable in stores. What a country.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: MARSEILLE, FRANCE, July 7. Under a full moon, Taffarel of Brazil wins the goalkeeper lottery in the semifinal shootout over the Netherlands.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: ST.-DENIS, FRANCE, July 12. Clogging the streets, people chant ''Zee-dan! Zee-dan!'' in honor of Zinedine Zidane, of Algerian ancestry, who scored two headers as a polyglot French team stunned Brazil in the final, 3-0.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: REDMOND, WASH., Aug. 16. A friendly official at the Professional Golfers' Association Championship hands me a badge to walk inside the ropes, my first close exposure to top golf. I am amazed at the power and accuracy of Vijay Singh and Steve Stricker on the narrow fairways, as Singh wins the tournament.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8. Lovefest alongside the Mississippi. Mark McGwire hits his 62d homer and the fans cheer and Sammy Sosa runs in from right field to congratulate him and McGwire acknowledges the family of the late Roger Maris.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: FLUSHING MEADOWS, QUEENS, Sept. 13. Lindsay Davenport and Patrick Rafter are the singles champs at the United States Open, but the double-decker luxury boxes produce empty seats and sedate guests, the feeling of a high-tech morgue.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: HOUSTON, Sept. 27. As the dejected Cubs trudge into the clubhouse, they hear the San Francisco Giants have also let one get away. The Cubs will win a playoff tomorrow in Chicago, and Sosa will finish with 66 homers to McGwire's 70, with the charming, bilingual Sosa ultimately winning the most valuable player award.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: ARLINGTON, TEX., Oct. 2. A brutal rainstorm lasts 3 hours 16 minutes, but cannot deter the Yanks' sweep of the Rangers.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: BRONX, N.Y., Oct. 8. Chuck Knoblauch makes a gross mental error as the Yanks lose, but Orlando Hernandez -- El Duque -- will bail out the Yanks in Cleveland four nights later.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 21. The Yanks sweep the Padres in the World Series, to finish with 125 victories for the year, and consideration as one of the best teams of all time.
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: NEW YORK, NOVEMBER AND DECEMBER. Thanks to the greedy and the inept, the National Basketball Association disappears, giving me time and space to search for a bit of dignity and hope in sport. I hope the uplifting two months carry over into a happy
title: Sports of The Times; Postcards From 1998: Splendor On Ice to Silence on the Court

text: Shanika W., 15, did not get the Christmas gift she had wished for. She wanted to spend the holiday with her mother, but her mother is a drug addict and Shanika is not supposed to go home.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Instead, Shanika, 15, an outgoing and intelligent girl, spent Christmas at Geller House, a center for children ages 11 to 15 who have been removed from their foster homes because of disciplinary problems and have nowhere else to go. Their problems are evaluated, they receive counseling, and eventually, they move to a less stringently supervised residential treatment center.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: The children at Geller House are the borderline cases; none of them have been in trouble with the law but many have histories of parental abuse and drinking, using drugs, acting out and cutting school.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: ''These are the kids who have a chance,'' said Warren C. Lyons, 52, Geller House's administrative supervisor and a social worker by training. ''A kid who spent some time here a few years back and then went back to foster care is going to Columbia now, but we also have our fair share of alumni who've gained acceptance to Rikers Island.''
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Geller House, in Grasmere on Staten Island, is run by the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, an affiliate of the UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven charities supported by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Only nine of Geller House's 24 residents stayed for the holiday yesterday. They were the ones with no family to visit, or whose families were so troubled that the children could not go home.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Shanika has a family: two brothers, her mother and a half sister. But Shanika was taken from the family when she was 9, because her mother was using drugs and had been arrested a number of times for prostitution. In 1992, Children's Services placed Shanika with her grandmother and an aunt, in the Queensbridge Houses in Long Island City.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: ''My aunt tried to tell me what to do,'' Shanika said, ''but I was just looking at her. When I moved in with her she was like 16, pregnant and drinking and smoking and getting into all kinds of trouble. My grandmother had emphysema so she couldn't do much, and my mother was a drug addict. I was just doing what I'd seen.''
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Shanika said she may have been headed for the same kind of life when she arrived at Geller House in July. Last year, she started drinking and dating a man whom she characterized as a thug. He sold crack and marijuana and carried guns, Shanika said. She cut school to hang out with him, and by early summer, her aunt and grandmother decided they could no longer control her.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: This time, Children's Services placed Shanika at Geller House, where the staff tries to bring order to the lives of children who have known mostly disorder.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Christmas morning, that meant morning chores, from sweeping the floor to helping prepare their brunch of scrambled eggs, sausage and croissants.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Normally, classes would follow, but since it was Christmas the children were given the day off from the likes of algebra and the history of Latin America. Some boys played video games in the lounge while at the infirmary, Bonnie Holland, 52, the nurse, gave manicures. The menu for Christmas dinner was honey-glazed ham, candied yams, stuffing, apple cider and eggnog, with carrot cake and cookies for dessert.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: But most other days are a mix of school, counseling and chores for the children, while the staff evaluates their problems and determines where they should go next. Most graduate to a residential treatment center, where there is less supervision. After that, they move on to group homes and then back to a foster family until they are 18.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: At first, Shanika chafed under the strict rules of Geller House. During her first month there she left without permission, which is strictly against the rules, and got drunk.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Slowly, though, a transformation took place. Shanika is now one of Geller House's model residents. She credits the discipline, the respect each child is given and learning about other teen-agers with problems like her own.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: She has not left without permission in two months, and is doing well in all her classes.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Mr. Lyons, the administrative supervisor, said he hopes that Shanika will go to college and fulfill her dream of becoming a lawyer.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: ''When she got here she read at above a twelfth-grade level,'' he said. ''Her math skills were just as good, and she writes poetry in her spare time. She's one the smartest kids we've had around here. She's just got to keep on the right path,'' he said.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Shanika said she knows that path is not an easy one to follow. She points to her mother as an example of how hard it is to stay on the straight and narrow. In 1997, her mother stopped using drugs and Shanika returned home. But her mother fell back into her old habits and Shanika had to go back to her grandmother.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Shanika said she hopes the changes she has made will last.
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: ''There are a lot of times I want to be back hanging out with my friends and drinking,'' she said. ''Right now I'm in the middle of it; my life can go back or I can keep moving on.''
title: In New Surroundings, a Teen-Ager Is Thriving

text: Russia and Belarus Plan a Unified Currency
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Presidents of Russia and Belarus said they intended to begin unifying their currencies and much of their economies next year. That would stop just short of a political merger that would again extend Russian territory to the border of Poland. President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, above, said he hoped that the two countries would enter the millennium as one. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The three balloonists aboard the ICO Global Challenge ditched their craft 10 miles north of Oahu, in the Hawaiian Islands, after a flight of more than halfway around the world. The Coast Guard picked them up. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Western efforts to rescue a crumbling cease-fire achieved modest success when American diplomats persuaded ethnic Albanian rebel commanders and Yugoslav Army officers to pull back some forces. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: North Korea told the United States that it was prepared to launch another medium-range missile, despite a warning that that would jeopardize international aid promised to North Korea in exchange for the freezing of its nuclear weapons program. A11
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Initial test results on waste dumped in Cambodia by a Taiwanese company indicated that the mercury level was thousands of times higher than safety standards permit. A12
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Sierra Leone Capital Is Calmer
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A British airlift from Freetown, which evacuated dozens of foreigners on Thursday, found only one taker, with the capital relatively calm after the arrival of peacekeepers and a pro-Government militia. A5
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Pope offered a Christmas prayer that urged people to work against violence, weapons production, the death penalty and genocide. A4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Christian and Muslim worshipers crisscrossed Manger Square in Bethlehem and filled the churches and mosques in observances of Christmas and Ramadan. A4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Probably no priest or pastor outside Iraq opened a Christmas sermon as the Rev. Gabriel Marie did at the Church of Our Lady of Assumption in Baghdad: ''Thanks be to God that we have survived the bombing.'' A4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Insurance Plans Skirt Mental Health Provision
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Insurance companies and employers have found a way around a 1996 law that requires them to offer health care coverage for mental illness that is comparable to that for physical illness. The companies have replaced the dollar limits for mental health care with numerical limits on outpatient visits, treatment sessions or days in the hospital. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Republican Congressmen appointed as managers -- or prosecutors -- of President Clinton's impeachment trial in the Senate have as many questions as answers about the historic roles they are set to play. It is their job to argue and present the case for removing the President from office, but they have yet to decide how best to do that, in part because they are still dusting off the rules and rummaging through history for relevant guideposts. A25
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The rules of impeachment. A24
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton granted executive clemency to 33 people who had been convicted of a variety of offenses that included buying and detonating explosives, conspiring to manufacture marijuana and being AWOL in the Korean War. Three of the pardons were given to people who had been found guilty of lying to government agencies or to a bank. A28
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Effort to Head Off Wildfires
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Agriculture officials in Florida, who are facing more long-range drought conditions, want $35 million for an aggressive controlled-burning program to prevent a repetition of the wildfires that destroyed more than 500,000 acres last summer. The State Agriculture Department was criticized by agriculture groups and timber landowners for not being aggressive enough in using controlled burning before the fires last summer. A16
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Virginia is considering a voluntary program that would effectively certify the competence of high school graduates. State-supported colleges and universities spend $25 million a year to aid freshmen with remedial courses in reading, writing and arithmetic. The State Council of Higher Education is considering shifting the cost of such studies to the high schools that fail to produce freshmen who are ready to do college-level work. A19
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The first national storm of the winter brought down hundreds of utility poles and countless trees in southeastern Virginia on Thursday, depriving 240,000 residents of electricity and heat. More than 200,000 homes and businesses were also left without power in Tennessee, Louisiana, Mississippi and North Carolina. A14
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Icy Patch Led to Crash, Bus Driver Tells Officials
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The driver of the bus that crashed on the Garden State Parkway on Thursday said he was trying to avoid what looked like a patch of ice when he lost control of the vehicle, investigators said. But the officials refused to say how fast the driver, Valentin Viner, 52, said he was going at the time of the accident. The bus plunged down an embankment, killing 8 people and injuring 15, during the morning trip from New York to Atlantic City. B4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Some private and religious schools are resisting state efforts to have them adopt new standards intended to improve learning in public school classrooms. The nonpublic schools say they are worried about losing the autonomy that allows them to develop the nontraditional approaches that they believe are at the heart of their success. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Managers of office buildings throughout New York City are making contingency plans for a possible strike on New Year's Day, when the union contract covering 30,000 maintenance workers will expire. Neither side is predicting a strike, but both sides fear that if talks break off, there may be a replay of the monthlong strike three years ago. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Federal prosecutors are said to be investigating $100,900 in political contributions that a Long Island insurance conglomerate, the Robert Plan, and its president, Robert Wallach, made to the New York Republican State Committee before closing a deal with the state to take control of most of the assets of two nearly bankrupt insurance companies. B5
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Pakistani scholar Ayesha Jalal has angered her countrymen with assertions that that the revered founding father of Pakistan, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, had feet of clay and that he never really wanted a separate Muslim state. B7
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Fighter's Life, on Film
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, 61, who was freed from prison 13 years ago, after his murder conviction was twice overturned, is reaping the ultimate vindication: a movie is being made about him. B7
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A raft of doping scandals has contributed to a crisis of confidence in international athletics, leading many in sports to urge the International Olympic Committee to take decisive action against drug cheating when it holds a summit in February. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Japan's 17 biggest banks had $427 billion in problem loans as of March, a Government audit has found -- 12 percent more than they had reported. The Financial Supervisory Agency said it had determined that the banks' problem loans were 5.4 trillion yen more than the banks had calculated, though the size of that difference was in line with analysts' expectations. C3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Japanese stocks closed higher for the first time this week as a rise in Government bonds lessened worries that bank profits would shrink further. The Nikkei rose 91.22 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 13,797.95, leaving the benchmark index of 225 stocks 10 percent below its level of a year earlier. The world's other major financial markets were closed for Christmas. C3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Oil Production Slips in Russia
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Russian oil production fell 1 percent this year, less than expected, as the ruble's plunge offset low world oil prices and provided producers with cash to maintain output, the Deputy Fuel and Energy Minister said. C2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A writer and political advocate whose raw, emotional manifesto on injustice and violence became the intellectual foundation of the early Quebec separatist movement, he was 60. C6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Daily News columnist, who won a Pulitzer Prize for commentary this year for a series of columns on the brutalization of a Haitian immigrant in a police station in Brooklyn, was 41. C6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A prolific composer whose varied catalogue includes eight operas and many chamber, symphonic and choral works, he was 85. C6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Editorials: Chico Mendes's legacy; what price digital television? Dorothy J. Samuels on Chief Justice Rehnquist.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: By Compiled By Christopher S. Wren
title: World Briefing

text: Investigating judges have completed their inquiry into Roland Dumas, head of France's highest administrative tribunal, the Constitutional Council, and his relationship while he was Foreign Minister with Christine Deviers-Joncour, a lobbyist for Elf-Aquitaine, the oil company. The two, as well as four former Elf Aquitaine executives, have three weeks to respond before prosecutors decide whether to try them on bribery charges.
title: World Briefing

text: BRITAIN: CHARLES HEARS ABOUT MARIJUANA
title: World Briefing

text: Prince Charles, left, renewed a debate about marijuana when he asked a woman with multiple sclerosis whether she had tried using it to relieve pain. British newspapers reported that Charles, visiting a day-care center in Cheltenham, had told the woman, Karen Drake, that he had heard that marijuana could benefit people with multiple sclerosis. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: The Communist-dominated lower house of Parliament voted, 303 to 65, for initial approval for an austerity budget for 1999, after Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov had threatened to resign if the draft failed. The coffers are so bare that the budget calls for Government spending of $29 billion and revenues of $24 billion. The United States Government spends $30 billion a week. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: Russia conducted five subcritical nuclear tests at an Arctic testing range in the autumn, Deputy Nuclear Energy Minister Lev Ryabev said, contradicting previous denials. The Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty does not prohibit such tests, because the amount of plutonium used cannot create a nuclear explosion. But critics say that even limited tests could encourage full-scale tests. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: BOSNIA: MILITARY AND SCALE OF AID
title: World Briefing

text: The military consumes just about the total yearly aid to the country, said Ambassador Robert Barry of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Mr. Barry gave no specific figures. But Bosnia is receiving a $5.1 billion reconstruction package that international donors have agreed for the period from 1996 to 1999. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: CYPRUS: TALKS ON USING RUSSIAN MISSILES
title: World Briefing

text: President Glafcos Clerides will go to Athens next week for talks on whether to deploy a Russian-built missile system that Turkey has pledged to prevent on the divided island. Cyprus was said to be considering putting the S-300 missile systems temporarily on Crete, a move that Greece also reportedly favors. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: ISRAEL: BETHLEHEM SERVICE ON THE WEB
title: World Briefing

text: The International Christian Embassy, an evangelical Protestant group in Jerusalem, introduced its Virtual Holyland Web site in time for a Christmas service today from Shepherd's Field near Bethlehem. The page is www.virtualholyland.com. Deborah Sontag (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: The Roman Catholic Cathedral in Jakarta scrapped midnight Christmas Mass because of security fears after violence against the minority Christian population, an official at the Vatican Embassy said. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: The consumption tax will not rise despite an advisory panel's warning that an increase is inevitable, Chief Cabinet Secretary Hiromu Nonaka said. Former Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto was widely blamed for pushing the world's second largest economy into recession by raising the tax last year, from 3 to 5 percent. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: CHINA: 11 DRUG DEALERS EXECUTED
title: World Briefing

text: The special economic zone of Shenzhen executed 11 drug dealers, a local newspaper reported. The Intermediate People's Court sentenced 17 people for drug-related crimes, and the 11 given the death penalty were taken to be shot. Shenzhen, bordering Hong Kong, is a conduit for heroin refined in Yunnan. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: SIERRA LEONE: LIBERIANS ASSIST SECURITY
title: World Briefing

text: About 1,000 soldiers flew from Liberia to augment a West African intervention force around Freetown. The 5,000-member force is strengthening security after rebel attacks near the capital, United Nations observers said. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: A regional meeting in Lusaka on a cease-fire in Congo has been postponed because of the holiday season, an aide to President Frederick Chiluba said. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: MEXICO: INQUIRY ON PRI CAMPAIGN SPENDING
title: World Briefing

text: Electoral authorities named a commission to investigate accusations of illegal spending in the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, campaign of 1994 that led to President Ernesto Zedillo's election. (NYT) Compiled by Christopher S. Wren
title: World Briefing

text: For the pagan set, this year's celebration of the winter solstice was brewing with all the right energy. They had called out to Mother Earth while on the ferry to Staten Island. Sure, the forgotten borough was not the mythic Celtic paradise of Avalon, but its beaches were an acceptable stand-in for their annual rites.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: Chanting ''reverence, reverence, reverence'' to the ancient rhythms of their drums and tambourines, they had gathered Monday night to dance around a bonfire, seeking to consign to the flames all the bad from past year, and conjure up the good for the year to come.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: What they didn't anticipate was a visit by the New York City police. Within minutes of the festivities reaching their climax, the bonfire was out and 33 members of the group found themselves in their own commandeered bus, hauled down to the 122d Precinct to be charged with trespassing in a closed city park after dark. It was a New Age festivity bumping up against the city's crackdown on quality-of-life offenses, all on an otherwise deserted Staten Island beach.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: ''The bus driver was a Russian immigrant, and he kept saying 'Oh my God,' he couldn't believe this is America,'' said Donna Henes, the self-described ''urban shaman'' who has organized a similar happening every December for the past 24 years without incident. ''I suppose it is like this because of Giuliani, it's a quality-of-life thing. But the quality of life hasn't been so great lately.''
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: After being detained for about 90 minutes, half the time at the beach, South Beach, and half at the precinct, the 33 were issued summonses and now face $50 fines. (Seven managed to escape before then, organizers said.)
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: Edward Skyler, a spokesman for the Parks Department, said officers issued the summonses because the park had closed at dusk. The city has been increasingly enforcing curfews in parks.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: Even if the solstice worshipers had applied for a permit for their bonfire, he said, it would have been denied because it would have been considered a threat to the boardwalk.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: Officer Lee Ann Tracy, a police spokeswoman, said it was the fire that seemed to have triggered the attention of the police, who in the past had generally ignored the celebration. ''The reason this was done this year was because they had a 12-foot bonfire going on the beach,'' she said. She said the police frequently issue summonses at the beach for infractions ranging from marijuana use to loitering.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: Participants said the fire was small and controlled. They said they have asked the New York Civil Liberties Union for help.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: The press office of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did not return repeated phone calls seeking comment.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: Whether they call themselves Pagans or Wiccans or Naturists, for those who revere the planet, there is no more important day on the calendar. Astronomers calibrate the very minute when the sun reaches its farthest point from the earth and starts the long trek back. On Monday, it fell at 8:56 P.M.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: ''All these celebrations go back to the very primal human reactions to the retreat and the return of the sun,'' said Ms. Henes, 53, who lectures on the solstice in New York City schools. She believes the Hindu Divili, the Hopi Soyal -- not to mention Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanzaa -- all derived from marking the solstice.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: ''Even though it's the shortest day of the year and it's the beginning of winter, truly the worst is over,'' said Ms. Henes. ''Right after the solstice the days begins to lengthen.''
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: To get the solstice soiree right requires all the elements of nature. You need the sky, the earth and the ocean. In New York City, that mostly means Staten Island, although Ms. Henes said she has also done the events in Queens and Battery Park.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: On Monday, Ms. Henes shepherded 40 participants onto a bus. Heather Abramson went because it is a celebration of the season. Ed Green went because it is about ''celebrating God as a female deity as opposed to a male deity that is the most popular now.'' A couple of tourists showed up, apparently having read about the $28 evening in The New Yorker.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: On the ferry all 40 people were issued cardboard tubes slathered with Day-Glo paint and glitter and told to call into the wind to Mother Earth. Some chanted ''Maaaaaaaaa.'' Some ''Mooooooooother.'' Mr. Green said he was chanting ''Mom.''
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: ''It is basically calling on the female energy and trying to call that back up and paying reverence to it,'' said Mr. Green, 42, a specialist in Tibetan forms of hands-on healing who lives in Brooklyn.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: At South Beach they hauled wood out of the bus for the ritual fire symbolizing the sun's return. Decked out in face paint and glitter, festooned with netting or veiling or chiffon or tinsel, they were singing and drumming and clapping and jangling tambourines as they chucked things into the flames. Sage to cleanse the coming year. Cigarettes to purge a loved one's death from cancer. Glitter because it looked good.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: ''Every time you throw something into the fire it made a positive intention for the future,'' Ms. Henes said. ''I mean, I was not throwing things in to wish for a million dollars, not that kind of thing, but peace, hope, and harmony, that kind of positive intention.''
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: The arrival of up to 20 officers from the Police, Fire and Parks Departments abruptly ended their immediate hopes for peace, hope and harmony. (They also objected to the fact that officers referred to them as ''Martians.'') Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said he wanted the city to drop all charges before the Jan. 25 court date.
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: ''I think it is just another manifestation of the emerging anti-fun era of the Giuliani days,'' he said. ''What the city should be doing is accommodating these diverse religious, cultural and political events that help make up the zaniness of New York City. But instead of enhancing them, they are making it a crime.''
title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony

text: After the rancorous impeachment proceedings in the House of Representatives, the Senate must take care to avoid a replay, or worse. To do so, the Senate should make plain its commitment to conduct a trial that is truly fair to the President.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: Although impeachment precedents are few, an important one occurred nine years ago, when the Senate heard charges that a high official had lied to a grand jury. The defendant (and my client), Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. of Federal District Court in Mississippi, had been convicted on two perjury counts in a Federal prosecution relating to an investment made with a businessman whose son had been arrested for smuggling marijuana. At the time of the trial, he was serving a prison sentence.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: Despite these decidedly unfavorable circumstances, Judge Nixon insisted on his innocence and on his right to challenge the accusations against him in a Senate trial. Several precedents established in our case could be central in the proceeding against President Clinton.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: First, the Senate should refuse to consider any impeachment article that lumps together multiple instances of alleged misconduct.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: An article that combines different allegations may draw support from those senators who agree with the first subpart, and from other senators who agree with the second subpart, and so on.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: Prosecutorial logrolling of this kind unfairly lowers the bar for impeachment and removal. If Mr. Clinton faces removal for having committed a ''high crime or misdemeanor,'' a specific offense should be clearly framed, and the vote of each senator should be plainly understood, not shrouded in ambiguity.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: One of the articles brought against Judge Nixon presented an agglomeration of charges of perjury and obstruction of justice. We challenged that article as unfair, and the Senate voted not to convict on it, even though Judge Nixon had already been convicted of perjury in court.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: By that precedent, both the impeachment articles brought against Mr. Clinton should be dismissed, since they are simultaneously vague and compound.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: The first article describes four generic types of false grand jury testimony, but does not specify any single false statement. The second article lists seven supposed obstructions of justice between Dec. 17, 1997, and Jan. 26, 1998, permitting a senator to vote to convict based on any one of the seven.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: A further concern is that in any perjury case, jurors must evaluate the credibility of the central witnesses. We demanded that Judge Nixon have that opportunity even though the witnesses -- unlike those in the Clinton case -- had already testified and been cross-examined at a criminal trial and before a House subcommittee.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: For four days, all of the central witnesses testified and were cross-examined again. The President is entitled to no less.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: He is entitled, as well, to see the independent counsel's investigative files. Whenever an investigative target is prosecuted for denying he engaged in conduct that was legal if it occurred, there is a significant risk that prosecutors have set a perjury trap to contrive a crime. We needed to explore that issue. In response to a request from Senators Orrin Hatch and Wyche Fowler Jr., the Justice Department opened its files to us. Mr. Clinton's team deserves similar access.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: In addition, the Senate should not consider shortcuts that have been adopted in earlier impeachments, particularly the rule allowing a committee of 12 senators to hear all evidence.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: Trial by committee is an insult to the judicial and executive branches because it excuses all but a handful of senators from learning the facts in an impeachment case.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: Until 1986, impeachment trials were conducted before the entire Senate, as the Constitution requires, and the Senate should return to that practice.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: The Senate should also prescribe a single standard of proof for impeachment charges. That standard should be one, at least, of clear and convincing evidence.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate
