text: In 1989, the Senate reaffirmed that each senator may apply whatever standard of proof he or she deems appropriate in impeachment trials, an approach that contradicts the spirit of the impeachment clause. By limiting impeachment to ''treason, bribery and other high crimes or misdemeanors,'' the Constitution permits removal only for specific acts. Whether those acts occurred should be judged by a single standard, not left to the whim of each Senator.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: Finally, the Senate has never adopted rules of evidence for such core issues as relevance, materiality and hearsay. To insure a regular trial, the Senate should adopt Federal rules regarding the admission of evidence.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: If the second Presidential impeachment trial in our history becomes necessary, the Senate's paramount concern should be to guarantee its fairness.
title: What a 1989 Case Can Teach the Senate

text: After rising since the early 1990's, the use of marijuana and other drugs by teen-agers may be ebbing, however modestly, according to a new survey that is considered the most reliable gauge of substance abuse among secondary school students.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: The annual survey of nearly 50,000 students around the country, titled Monitoring the Future, was conducted at the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan and released on Friday. Though the levels of drug and alcohol use remain higher than several years ago, the survey reported, all grades studied showed a slight but often statistically significant drop in overall drug use in the previous 12 months.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: Last year, the institute's researchers found use of illicit drugs declining only among eighth graders. That trend continued this year, and drug use declined slightly among 10th and 12th graders, as well.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: ''I think this is the best news we've had to bring the country in some years,'' the principal researcher, Lloyd D. Johnston, said in a telephone interview. ''Young people seem to be appreciating more fully the dangers of various drugs, including alcohol and cigarettes.''
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: The overwhelming majority of adolescent drug use involves marijuana, which remained widespread. This year, 49 percent of 12th graders and 22 percent of 8th graders sampled said they had tried marijuana.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: But the number of 12th graders who smoked marijuana in the previous month declined to 22.8 percent from 23.7 percent, while the number of 8th graders using it dropped to 9.7 percent from 10.2 percent. The decline in regular use was more noticeable among 10th graders: 18.7 percent had smoked marijuana in the previous month, compared with 20.5 percent a year ago.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: ''We certainly are not back to levels at the beginning of the 90's and it's too soon to trumpet victory,'' Dr. Johnston said, ''but certainly it's very encouraging news that this upward trend has finally begun to reverse.''
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: The use of harder drugs, notably heroin and cocaine, remained statistically small and appeared to level off or decline for most groups surveyed. Among high school seniors, 2 percent acknowledged experimenting with heroin, marginally down from 2.1 percent a year ago. But 9.3 percent said they had tried cocaine at some point, compared with 8.7 percent last year.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: Asked about their use in the previous 30 days, 2.4 percent of the seniors said they had snorted or smoked cocaine, compared with 2.3 percent a year ago. And 0.5 percent said they had used heroin in the previous month, a statistic unchanged from last year.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: Alcohol, primarily beer, remains the substance most frequently abused by teen-agers, though even its use declined. Among eighth graders, 23 percent said they had drunk alcohol in the previous month, compared with 24.5 percent last year. Among 10th graders, monthly alcohol use dropped to 38.8 percent from 40.1 percent.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: But 8.2 percent of eighth graders admitted getting drunk in the previous month, a slight rise from the 8 percent who reported doing so a year ago. Among high school seniors, 32.9 percent said they had been drunk in the previous month, compared with 34.2 percent last year.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: The survey also showed tobacco use down slightly.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: Dr. Johnston and his fellow researchers, Jerald G. Bachman and Patrick M. O'Malley, attributed the changes in drug-seeking behavior to a reassessment by teen-agers of the risks and to stronger expressions of concern by parents and other adults.
title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says

text: Trucks are always being loaded and unloaded along Foster Avenue around East 86th Street, near the Brooklyn Terminal Market, people who work there say. Garages and shipping companies line the avenue, which is really a six-lane highway with two service roads.
title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder

text: But on the morning of Dec. 12, a Saturday, a cargo of something special arrived at Foster Avenue. The police said it appeared to be a shipment of marijuana.
title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder

text: According to the police, a truck pulled up to the service road off Foster Avenue just west of East 86th Street around 10 A.M. Five men began taking boxes off the truck and loading them into a van next to the truck, the police said.
title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder

text: The owner of a local business, who would not give his name or his workers' for fear of retribution, said, ''One of our guys called the police because it looked suspicious.'' He said that to some of his employees, the people with the truck ''didn't look like they belonged here.''
title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder

text: A police spokeswoman, Detective Madelyne Colon, said a patrol car from the 69th Precinct station house came right away. ''The police responded to an anonymous call of a tractor trailer dropping off boxes,'' Detective Colon said. ''Upon arrival they found five black males fleeing the location.''
title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder

text: The five men and the truck made off and were not apprehended, Detective Colon said, but the police did seize the van. Inside they found 17 boxes of what Detective Colon said appeared to be marijuana. She would not say how much of the substance there was or reveal the results of any tests on it.
title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder

text: ''They are still investigating,'' she said, and as of Friday, there had been no arrests.
title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder

text: The business owner said he was surprised by what happened. ''I've never seen anything like this before,'' he said. ''We have trucks with Christmas trees and trucks with watermelons. But I've never seen marijuana.'' EDWARD LEWINE
title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder

text: AS Benjamin Middleton Jr. and his son approach the corner of Marcus Garvey Boulevard and Hancock Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, their pace quickens. Casting an edgy glance around and noticing the drug dealers on their usual turf, Mr. Middleton automatically shifts his hand from his son's head and loops it protectively around his shoulder.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Until then, the banter between father and son on the short walk home from school had been playful, frisky.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''So how was your day today, guy?''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''You want me to carry your bag?''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Sure. I got 85 percent for my Beethoven project. Teacher says if I remember to bring in the CD's, she'll give me a 90.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Hmmm. You're a pretty smart guy. Kind of handsome, too.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Who asked you, guy? Don't you start getting conceited, guy.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: But now there is a tense lull as the two observe the unspoken rules of the gantlet: look straight ahead, show no fear, just go about your business. Mr. Middleton, 45, neatly dressed in a T-shirt and pressed jeans and wearing glasses, could have taken a safer route home. But he has strong feelings about the dealers who congregate on their corner.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''They stare me down like I'm some kind of disease, but I am not a runner,'' he said. ''I pay my rent, I try to be an upstanding citizen. They are the ones making the place unsafe for kids. They, not me, should be moved off.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: His son, 11, has been taught to be wary of the men who make the street their office. But the boy doesn't know exactly why, nor does he understand what those men actually do with the white powder they pass furtively in small cellophane bags. He doesn't know, either, that not too long ago his dad had more than a passing familiarity with such men and their world.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Until five or six years ago, Mr. Middleton, by his own admission, was a marijuana dealer, a habitual crack user, a small-time armed robber, a womanizer and an absent father. Then, gradually, he underwent a transformation. He ''took on fatherhood,'' physically, emotionally and financially. And as he did, his limp life took on purpose and straightened out like a windsock filling with air.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: What made him embark on the journey from gangster to loving dad? Was there a magical moment when the penny dropped?
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: It is the American way to admire a man's ability to rise above his demons as an extraordinary act of will, a triumph for the individual. Yet what makes Mr. Middleton's story rise above this oft-told tale is that, as he tells it, he has tended to be as much a follower as a leader, and perhaps more of a follower. Peer pressure played a critical role in shaping who he was, as well as who he has become.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: It may be that what happened to him reflects larger forces at play in urban neighborhoods, among them a new sensibility in which men who shun their responsibilities as fathers are disrespected on the street.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Up until five or six years ago, it was considered cool to dodge responsibility as a father among many young African-American males,'' said Ed Pitt, associate director of the Fatherhood Project at the Families and Work Institute, a nonprofit research group in Manhattan. ''The super-hip line of the man in the street was 'a player plays but never pays.' Today that attitude is uncool.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''We are witnessing a heightened sense of understanding among men of the consequences of that attitude for children, and it is resonating across ethnic groups, at every level, throughout the country,'' Mr. Pitt said. ''We see it in the increased number of fathers showing up at schools, day-care centers, health centers, parenting classes -- across the board. I don't mean to suggest that we have a total turnaround, but we are seeing a significant shift in the making, a shift toward more engaged fathering up and down the income spectrum.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Geoffrey Canada, whose work as president of the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families, in Harlem, brings him into daily contact with African-American fathers, said that from what he has seen in New York, the fatherhood message is ''just starting'' to penetrate the consciousness of men, both younger and older.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''For the first time, I am hearing conversations among men about their role as fathers,'' said Mr. Canada, who is the author of ''Reaching Up for Manhood.'' ''For the first time, I am seeing men visiting their friends and taking along their babies, spending quality time as groups of fathers and children together, just like mothers have always done. This is new, and it suggests that social relationships between men and children are changing to include nurturing as well as providing.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Men, especially poor men, never used to talk about being fathers in this way,'' Mr. Canada said. ''What we are witnessing is a revolution that is still in its infancy, that could easily be set back, but a revolution nonetheless that is changing the code of the streets and the code of manhood and which could have profoundly positive results for society.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Prof. Aisha Ray, an expert on African-American families at the Erikson Institute, a graduate program affiliated with Loyola University in Chicago that researches child development, said small-scale studies and anecdotal evidence tended to confirm the trend of African-American fathers becoming involved with their children. But no large representative studies have been done.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''As things stand, we have little hard data on what percentage of fathers are actually engaged, how that figure is changing over time and what critical interventions cause an absent father to return to his family,'' Professor Ray said. ''Is there a kind of epiphany? Is it family? Is it peer pressure? It really is a mystery.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: 'I Never Raised You To Be Like This'
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: The evening 11 years ago that his wife, Mary, went into labor, Mr. Middleton came home from work and went out as he usually did, he said, with one of his brothers. In a darkened hallway of a Bronx tenement, they lit up a crack pipe, starting another hedonistic binge of alcohol and cocaine. Mr. Middleton could smoke up to 20 vials of crack a night, he said, each $10 vial delivering a 15-minute rush. The drugs calmed him at first, but as the hours passed he started feeling paranoid and hallucinating. Imaginary shadows leaped from the darkness to ''get'' him, a sensation he didn't like. He wondered why he did it. ''Habit,'' he guessed. Light up. Inhale. Light up. Inhale. It gave a certain rhythm to his life.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: A few hours later, around the time that his baby boy entered the world, Mr. Middleton was otherwise engaged, he said, having sex with another woman.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: He remembers rolling home around 5 A.M., still woozy, and surprised to find his wife gone. He knew that she was ''very pregnant,'' but he hadn't paid attention to just how far along she was. His telephone answering machine was flashing, he said, and there were messages from his mother, each more exasperated than the last. He still remembers what she said: ''Ben, where are you? You have a son. I never raised you to be like this.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: His mother and other family members declined to be interviewed, his mother saying that she did not want to publicly relive a painful chapter in the life of her family.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Mr. Middleton grew up in Red Hook, Brooklyn, the eldest of five brothers and one sister. His parents were hard-working people, his father a mechanic for the post office, his mother a schoolteacher. ''I had magnificent parents,'' Mr. Middleton said. ''We never had a starving day in our life. My mother was the driving force behind us. My dad was a quiet man who never raised his voice, never lifted a hand to us.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: His sister has a degree from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. A brother went to Duke.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: But 30 years ago, when he was growing up, there was Red Hook to contend with, then a pressure cooker of a neighborhood where street survival was the name of the game and peer pressure smashed against parental influence. Crime was the currency.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: He recalled how he and his brothers were held up by local hoodlums: '' 'Give us your money; now drop your pants,' they instructed us. This was in broad daylight, with people around. That's how tough the neighborhood was. One of my brothers, he's stubborn, didn't want to give them his money so they pistol-whipped him. After they left, we got our rusty .38 pistol and went looking for them. My brother saw one and shot at him but the gun jammed. The other guy fired back and hit another one of my brothers in the stomach. I carried him home. He almost died in my arms.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Although Mr. Middleton is the oldest sibling, he called the brother a year younger than he ''the leader.'' He had a powerful influence over Mr. Middleton as a young adult. ''He was bigger, wittier and smarter than I was,'' he said. ''Boy, he made me laugh. He could have been a comedian. He had a way about him, a charisma, that was very influential.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: When Mr. Middleton was 16, he and his brother were expelled from school for chronic truancy. Around that time, he remembered, their mother discovered a five-pound stash of marijuana under their beds and issued an ultimatum: Either she flushed it down the toilet or they left the house.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: The brothers found an apartment on St. Marks Place in the East Village. To pay the rent, he said, they sold marijuana and committed occasional armed robberies in which they would dress up as telephone repair workers, donning hard hats, overalls and utility belts to gain entry into homes where they knew drugs were sold, and sticking up the dealers. They pulled off perhaps a half-dozen armed robberies, he said, sometimes emerging empty handed, other times making off with cash, drugs, jewelry, cameras and video and stereo equipment.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: They never really thought about what they would do if somebody resisted, which luckily never happened, Mr. Middleton said. But one day as they walked out of a building they had broken into, the police were waiting. The two brothers were arrested, he said, but the charges were later dropped because their victim, a drug dealer, would not cooperate with the authorities.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: As Mr. Middleton tells it, he was a comically bad robber. In his leather briefcase he hid a sawed-off shotgun with no firing pin and a stash of marijuana. One day, as he walked the street holding the briefcase overstuffed with reefers, the gun was pushed so tightly against the side that its imprint was clearly visible to a police officer driving by. The officer promptly apprehended him, and he did a short spell -- ''three days, perhaps a week'' -- at Rikers Island before luck again intervened. The case was dismissed, he said, on a technicality over the police search. A spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office said the arrest had occurred too long ago for her office to confirm it.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Mr. Middleton took the hint, he said, and quit as a petty hoodlum. He trained as an offset printer and went to work. His brother, he said, reckoned he could beat the odds, and ended up spending the next 15 years in and out of prison.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Daddy's Not Coming Back. Or Maybe He Is.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Fatherhood came to Mr. Middleton in his mid-30's, but he was not ready or willing to take it on. He and his wife had been married for eight years; until she got pregnant, he had concluded that they could not have children. ''It was an unwanted surprise,'' he said. ''I didn't want to be a father. I even told Mary that.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: When his son was around 2, he ran away. He caught a Greyhound bus to Atlanta, to visit a former girlfriend, telling no one that he was leaving or where he was headed. ''I still had wild seeds inside me,'' he said. He had intended to go for two weeks but stayed 18 months, never picking up the phone, or a pen, to tell his family where he was.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: His wife, he said, told their son, ''Your daddy's not coming back.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: But his son insisted: ''My daddy coming back. My daddy coming back.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Through a chance encounter with a friend on the streets of Atlanta, Mr. Middleton said, he heard that his father was seriously ill, so he caught a bus back to New York. By this time his son was nearly 4. ''I felt like manure,'' he said. ''I had missed a whole chunk of his life. At that moment, I knew that I had messed up. I thought he was going to hate me, that there might be another man in his life.'' Somewhere a penny rattled inside him, and almost dropped.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Mrs. Middleton, described by her husband as a religious woman who believed in forgiveness, found it within herself to take him back. He got a job, earning $700 a week in the printing room of an accounting firm, Deloitte, Haskins & Sells.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: But drugs and alcohol continued to dog him. ''I was what they called a functional addict,'' he said. ''I could do the drugs and then go to work and still function in my job.'' But he couldn't function in his family. On Friday, when he got his paycheck, he said, he headed straight for the streets. From Friday to Sunday, he cracked jokes, played chess and spent everything he had earned on getting high and gambling with friends, many of whom were also failing fathers. When he finally came home, he said, he would tell his wife, ''Honey, I don't have money for the rent.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Mrs. Middleton worked as a computer operator for the city's Department of Buildings, so they weren't penniless. But one Sunday, when he came home, it was not his wife's but his son's disappointment that he had to face.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Hi Daddy, hi Daddy, can you buy me a bag of potato chips?'' he remembered the boy asking.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: He couldn't. He had no money. ''I had just spent $700 on myself getting high and I didn't have 25 cents for my son to buy him a bag of potato chips,'' he said. ''I looked in my son's eyes. I saw that he had not given up on me, and I said to myself, 'Now this has got to stop, this doesn't make any sense.' I just kept telling myself, 'No, no, no, I'm not going to do this anymore.' ''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Was that when the penny dropped? ''The penny dropped several times,'' he said. ''I just never heard it fall.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Kicking Old Habits, Leaving the Streets
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: His cleanup act took place over two or three years, he said, as he moved first from spending his entire paycheck on drugs and alcohol to putting some aside to take care of his family's financial responsibilities. The next, much more difficult stage, was giving up his partying life style altogether, kicking his habits, leaving his street friends behind and taking on the role of father and husband in a qualitatively different way.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Perhaps he just grew up. ''I was just a boy, doing drugs, thinking only of my needs,'' he said. ''When I realized that I had a son and that he was relying on me and that I had to put him first, when I was able to throw that switch, that's when I became a man.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: But what made him realize that being a real man meant putting his child's interests before his own?
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: True, his parents had taught him the difference between right and wrong, given him a core set of decent -- though long-buried -- values.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: And his wife's decision to stick with him appears to have been significant. Research on fatherhood shows that a father's relationship with the mother of his child is one of the most important indicators of how engaged he will be as a parent. But Mr. Middleton had lived his life far less under the direct sway of his parents and his wife, and much more, he said, under the influence of his peers.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Elijah Anderson, a professor of sociology and social sciences at the University of Pennsylvania and the author of ''Code of the Street'' (to be published in April by W. W. Norton), argues that ''it is above all a desperate search for respect from peers that governs social relations among many inner-city African-American men.'' And, he said, ''this search for respect has spawned a code of the street that plays a significant part in socially organizing the community and defining manhood.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: During the years in which Mr. Middleton was undergoing his personal transformation, three new influences entered his life: two colleagues at work and his church pastor. All three men are dedicated fathers and vocal about it.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Mr. Middleton met Pedro Morales about six years ago, after getting a job as an offset printer with Warburg Dillon Read, the brokerage house, in Manhattan. Mr. Morales, his new supervisor, was a church-going man who became involved in the Promise Keepers, an evangelical Christian movement for men. A single father, he had reared a daughter since she was a toddler.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''When I first met Ben, he was always strung out, drinking and partying,'' Mr. Morales recalled. ''But I saw potential in him, so I started schooling him. I took him under my wing and tried to point him in the right direction, away from his old friends, getting him to put his family first.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Mr. Middleton remembered tagging along to one of Mr. Morales's Promise Keepers meetings at which fatherhood was at the top, middle and bottom of the agenda. At the same time, he developed a friendship with another printer at Dillon Read, Robert Lee. ''Robert had a cute, chubby little son who he used to bring to work every so often,'' Mr. Middleton said, adding that sometimes he would bring his own son along and ''at lunch we'd play chess and just shoot the breeze about our boys.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Just two guys sitting around, talking about their kids. Nothing special. Except that for Mr. Middleton, it was a different way of interacting with other men. He began noticing men who were committed to being fathers, he said, which made it easier for him to do the same. One day, he said, his son was sick, and he stayed home to care for him. A boss wondered why his wife didn't stay home with the child. Mr. Middleton was furious. ''Listen here,'' he remembered telling the man. ''Sometimes my wife does stay home. Now I'm going to tell you something else. I like working here, I appreciate the job, but if my son gets sick, nothing takes preference over him.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: At the Concord Baptist Church on Marcy Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, which his family attended regularly and to which Mr. Middleton returned, he was getting the fatherhood message in surround-sound. The new pastor, Gary V. Simpson, a father in his 30's, believes in leading the 4,000 congregants by word and deed. Besides sermonizing about responsible fatherhood and creating programs to help men connect with their children, like regular workshops and monthly meetings and an annual retreat for men, Mr. Simpson offered his own priorities for fathers to follow. ''Being a father is my first ministry,'' he said in a recent interview. ''Every day, between 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M., people know they can't make appointments with me because that's when I do my daughter's homework and prepare meals.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Mr. Simpson said that the Million Man March in Washington, which he attended in October 1995, ''was a catalyst for conversation and introspection in the African-American community about the proper role of fathers.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''It put the issue at the top of a lot of agendas,'' he said.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: The results of his church outreach programs have been positive, Mr. Simpson said, but incremental. ''I have small victories,'' he said. ''Family by family, one by one, fathers who were uninvolved deciding to come back. But in Bed-Stuy, 58 percent of families are headed by single mothers, according to the 1990 census, and so, candidly, we still have a heck of a long way to go.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Mr. Middleton represents one such small victory. ''I grabbed onto the reins thrown by Simpson and prayed,'' he said. It has helped that ''being an involved father has become socially acceptable on the street.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''I see many more young men taking care of their children than there used to be. I feel part of a norm,'' he added.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Changes in Federal welfare laws offer states a chance to play a role in this shift. ''Past philosophy has been to treat fathers only as economic providers of child support,'' said Stanley Bernard, a senior associate at the National Center for Children in Poverty, at Columbia University. ''Welfare reform allows states to set aside welfare-to-work dollars to train noncustodial fathers whereas previously only mothers could benefit. The funds can be used to help fathers get jobs and also for parenting training. There is an opportunity for states to play a role in redefining the role of fathers and acknowledge their noneconomic contributions. About 22 states have said they will consider it, although New York has not, but none have moved forward.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Recent events have been a test for Mr. Middleton, who lost his job at Dillon Read 14 months ago, when the company merged with United Bank of Switzerland and his department was downsized. Despite a vigorous job search, he says, he has picked up only seasonal work with the Postal Service. Professor Ray says research shows that one of the most common causes of fathers' disengaging from families is extended unemployment. But Mr. Middleton has held firm. And, he says, he has helped persuade the brother who was his partner in crime to enter a rehabilitation program. The wheel has come full circle.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Now I am the leader, the older brother,'' Mr. Middleton says. ''I look at myself in the mirror and I say, 'Ben, you're not a bad lookin' man.' Before, I couldn't even look at myself. I was always dirty or wired. I'm starting to like myself a lot more. It feels good to be doing the right thing.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: It is his son who makes him strong. ''When I came back into his life, he was timid. Now he's out of his shell, confident, his personality flowering,'' Mr. Middleton says. ''Maybe getting older played a part, or maybe it's because he feels more valued. Something inside him just connected.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: Their walk home from school is over. Mr. Middleton sits on the sofa in their small apartment in a brownstone and watches his son do his homework. ''He's an A student, hardly ever needs help,'' he says. A police siren blares, riding in on the breeze.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: The boy suddenly looks up and says, ''Dad, when I grow up, I want to be a pro wrestler or a lawyer.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''You'll make a fine lawyer,'' his father says, adding softly to himself, ''That's what I always wanted to be.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Why, guy?'' he asks his son. ''Why do you want to be a lawyer?''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ''Some people who get into trouble are actually innocent,'' the boy replies. ''I want to protect them.''
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: And so the evolution of Benjamin Middleton Jr., just another Brooklyn dad, rolls on.
title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?

text: ON one side of the aisle, dropping phrases like ''Christian country'' and ''the real America,'' lawmakers rued the decline of absolutes in a permissive age. On the other side, invoking images of ''lynch mobs'' and ''good old boys,'' they warned of a right-wing coup.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: From one camp came allusions to Watergate that found similarities between the transgressions of Presidents Nixon and Clinton. From the other came gasps that such analogies were ludicrous.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: As Republicans brought the country to the brink of impeachment and Democrats fought to resist it, the debate encompassed more than questions of whether Bill Clinton committed perjury and whether lies under oath warranted impeachment. It exposed a cultural rift, with people viewing each other suspiciously from across the divide. The debate also quibbled over history and whether the crisis that gripped the Presidency almost a quarter of a century ago applied to the situation now.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, said that some Republicans who were fighting for President Clinton's removal from office were motivated in part by his embrace of minorities, which they found threatening.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: ''They think that America should look like they look -- white,'' Mr. Rangel said in an interview last week. He noted that the Republican side of the House Judiciary Committee was all white with only one woman, while the Democratic side had five blacks, three women and an openly gay man.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: ''It's a political lynch mob,'' Mr. Rangel said of the Republicans pushing impeachment.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Republicans said accusations of racial or sexual animus were absurd. What propelled them, they said, was outrage over the specific actions alleged in the articles of impeachment against the President.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: But some Republicans' comments also reflected qualms about a departure from traditional mores in society symbolized by President Clinton, who avoided military service, smoked marijuana and repeatedly cheated on his wife. Representative Bob Inglis, Republican of South Carolina, used one of his speeches during the House Judiciary Committee hearings to attack moral relativism, which conservatives often attribute to liberals. ''One view is that there is absolute truth,'' Mr. Inglis said. ''The other view is that everything is relative.''
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: ''And really what we're seeing here in President Clinton, I believe, is the culmination of that,'' he said. ''He is the perfect embodiment of everything being relative.''
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: For several Republicans, there were clear parallels between President Nixon's abuse of power in covering up the burglary of a Democratic political office and President Clinton's attempts to keep secret his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Representative Robert L. Livingston, the incoming Speaker of the House, noted that Mr. Nixon tried to conceal the actions of others but President Clinton tried to conceal his own. ''So why was impeachment the remedy for Nixon and not for Clinton?'' he asked.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Yesterday, Mr. Livingston himself stepped aside following his admission that he had committed adultry.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Representative Thomas J. Bliley, Republican of Virginia, implied that President's Clinton's actions were graver than President Nixon's. ''In Watergate, the President did not commit perjury,'' Mr. Bliley said during the impeachment debate Friday.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Some Democrats wondered aloud if Republicans were engaging in a sort of payback for the 1974 House Judiciary Committee's vote to send articles of impeachment against Mr. Nixon to the full House. Mr. Nixon resigned before the House could vote.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: ''I have to believe that Speaker Livingston has not gotten over Watergate,'' Representative Martin T. Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts, said in an interview Wednesday. ''It appears that some on the Republican side still feel that Richard Nixon got a bad deal and that somehow the score needs to be evened.''
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: The advocates and opponents of the impeachment process were separated by cultural, racial and even regional rivalries and suspicions, which were made clear not only in the back-and-forth between lawmakers but also in the voices of Americans trying to be heard.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: The conservatives' language reflected a desire to keep at bay the hair-splitting, religion-flouting intelligentsia President Clinton sometimes turned to for counsel. Representative Bob Barr, a Republican from Georgia, best articulated that wish earlier in the month during a Judiciary Committee hearing, taking on several lawyers and scholars who testified on the President's behalf. Mr. Barr was not depressed by their arguments, he said, because ''I think there are two Americas, and there is a real America out there.''
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: ''And it is that America that I have great faith in, because it's that America that understands what perjury is,'' he added.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Last week, when Representative Bob Ney, a Republican from Ohio, spoke of America as a ''Christian country'' when announcing his support for impeachment, it seemed to echo Mr. Barr's sentiments.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: At the same time, many of the people protesting the impeachment process represented movements and groups demonized by conservatives.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: PROMINENT feminists marched on the office of Mr. Livingston last week to demand a meeting, after which one of them, Betty Friedan, called the leaders of the impeachment effort ''a bunch of dirty old white men.''
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Writers like Toni Morrison and E. L. Doctorow spoke at anti-impeachment rallies and, inevitably, Hollywood celebrities added their voices, with the actor Robert De Niro personally calling a politician or two to sway their vote.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: Like their political opponents, they had come to see impeachment as a referendum on something more than a series of actions by the President, and their positions were informed by something larger than party fidelity.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: The words of one Democratic Congresswoman during the House debate Friday captured their perspective well. ''This is indeed a Republican coup d'etat,'' said Representative Maxine Waters of California. ''Republicans are the vehicles being used by the right-wing Christian Coalition to direct and control our culture.'' Her audience, both inside and outside the Capitol, included people who felt that she and some Democrats were trying to seize the reins in just the same way.
title: The Nation; A Debate on Something Bigger Than Words

text: FOR Jaytin Bhaghat, 12, of Merrick, the thought of writing poetry for a class assignment was overwhelming. But his attitude changed after a private, two-hour tutoring session with a Hofstra University English literature major.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''It was cool,'' said Jaytin. ''But I don't think I would have been able to get it done without that help.'
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Jaytin is one of 300 l students who since October have attended a pilot after-school program in the Bellmore-Merrick Central High School District. The program, intended for seventh- and eighth-graders, is held from 3 to 6 P.M. Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays at the Grand Avenue and Merrick Avenue middle schools.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The district's superintendent, Marc F. Bernstein, said he developed the idea for the program two years ago after reading a magazine article that cited the growing risks for America's 19 million youngsters between the ages of 10 and 14. Millions of them, it said, come home each day to an empty house and spend at least 5 hours unsupervised after school.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The magazine pointed to a report of the Carnegie Council on Adolescent Development that found that between 1980 and 1992 there was a 120 percent increase in suicides in that age range. In addition, it said that between 1991 and 1994 there was a 30 percent increase in smoking among 13-year-olds, and that marijuana use had doubled.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The study indicated that young people are given increased autonomy at a time when they are most in need of a safe, supervised environment, Dr. Bernstein said. And in their quest for greater independence, he said, they sometimes get involved with older teenagers and end up ''hanging around delis, smoking, drinking and getting involved in vandalism. We know that this age group is prone to taking risks.''
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: He pointed out that normally, after-school clubs end at 3:15 and that intramural and interscholastic sports activities end an hour or so later.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Dr. Bernstein said that in the spring of 1997 he began to meet with county officials, the Nassau District P.T.A. and members of the Bellmore-Merrick Wellness Council, a group of 60 community leaders.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''The key to all of this was partnership,'' he stressed. ''The school district could not do it alone. We have limited experience with after-school programs, but the county Youth Board and community-based agencies like Tempo have had that experience.''
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Tempo is a not-for-profit substance-abuse outpatient agency that has an office in a building of the Bellmore-Merrick Central High School District. In return for that space, one of its social workers, Nancy Schandler, is serving as the overall coordinator of the after-school program.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The group was motivated by statistics showing a growing number of single-parent families. It also found that although crime in the county was down from 1990 to 1994, it remained unchanged among young people.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''There is an old myth that the suburbs don't have these needs because of old wealth and a father-knows-best environment in which the parents are always home after school,'' Dr. Bernstein said. ''That does not exist anymore. Many of the city's problems are also suburban problems.''
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Other partners in the after-school program are Hofstra University in Hempstead and Adelphi University in Garden City.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Laurie Johnson, coordinator of Hofstra's graduate program in counseling, said six Hofstra undergraduates were y enrolled as mentors, along with another seven who are graduate students pursuing master's degrees in counselor education.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''Being counselors in training, they are working with youngsters on their homework and study skills,'' said Dr. Johnson.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The Adelphi contingent at Bellmore-Merrick includes 4 graduate physical education students and 11 undergraduates who are planning to become elementary or secondary school teachers.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: It was one of those interns, Christa Wilson, an Adelphi junior from West Hempstead, who worked with Jaytin. Ms. Wilson is earning her bachelor's in English literature and her master's in education at the same time.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''He did a great job,'' she said of Jaytin. ''He just needed guidance and help to organize his thoughts. It was a learning experience for me. As a future teacher, it was good for me to learn what I needed to do to help him focus. There was a sense of accomplishment for me when he was finished; it made me feel good about myself.''
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Jaytin said the poetry assignment worked out so well that he planned to ask Ms. Wilson for help with his next assignment -- writing a story using expressive language. He said he used to get help from his sister, but that she went away to college this year. And he said his mother, a native of India, ''doesn't speak English that well.''
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Another student, Julius Fleschner, 12, of Merrick, said his mother worked as a nurse.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''If not for this program, I'd be going home to an empty house,'' he said as he stood next to a computer in the library.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Because the computer lab is open, Julius said he was able to type his homework before going home.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''My computer at home is really old and I can't use it,'' he said. ''If I couldn't use the computer here after school, my mom would have to drive me here before school started in the morning.''
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The after-school program is not all academics. Four of the students in the library were playing a card game, and downstairs in the cafeteria, dining room tables had been moved aside and a Ping-Pong table and air hockey game moved in.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Putting down his Ping-Pong paddle, Dennis Foley, 12, of Merrick, said he enjoyed the program because he was very good at Ping-Pong. He said that although his mother is home by 3:30 from her secretarial job, she often leaves him alone to go shopping.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: His opponent at the Ping-Pong table, Andrew Cafiero, 12, of Merrick, said his parents were divorced and his mother did not get home from her secretarial job until 4:30. On Tuesdays, when the after-school program is not held, he said he goes home, calls his mother at work, does his homework and walks to a friend's house.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''At the other kid's house nobody is home either, so we just hang out,'' he said.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The Bellmore-Merrick project took on countywide dimensions last December when Dr. Bernstein mentioned it to the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta. Mr. Gulotta appointed Dr. Bernstein to chair a committee of educators, county officials, P.T.A. representatives, and directors of not-for-profit service agencies that decided to begin additional pilot after-school programs in Long Beach and Uniondale. The county donated $25,000 to each district, and to Bellmore-Merrick, to help fund the project.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The Long Beach program started last week with about 70 students in the district's middle school. Karen Groening, the district's Safe and Drug Free School Coordinator, said the effort was targeted at sixth-graders. It is held Monday through Thursday from 2:30 to 5:30.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Teachers are available to provide youngsters with extra help in their work, and a community group, Long Beach Reach, staffs the after-school program with a clinical worker. In addition, a computer lab, a recreation room and an athletic room are all open.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: The Uniondale district's assistant superintendent, Eustace G. Thompson, said the after-school program was scheduled to begin next month for middle-school youngsters.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''We're looking at our risk population,'' he said, ''youngsters who may not be able to meet academic standards without additional support. We'll be looking at existing test results and new tests and then target those who have the greatest need.''
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Dr. Bernstein said the Community Partnership committee would meet early next year to assess the projects and file a report with Mr. Gulotta.
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: ''We want to help other districts recognize that the need exists for kids,'' he said. ''We hope we learn what works and how to structure the community partnerships so they can be generalized for all 56 districts in the county.''
title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help

text: Compiled by Christopher S. Wren
title: World Briefing

text: POLAND: OPENING SECRET FILES Polish legislators, overriding the veto of President Alexander Kwasniewski, pushed through a bill opening access to the files of the Communist-era secret police. The bill will allow Poles who felt they were the victims of Communist repression to see personal files compiled by the authorities before 1989 and determine if they were discriminated against and possibly who informed against them. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: GERMANY: A BREAK FOR DESERTERS Germany gave World War II deserters and their families another year to apply for a onetime payment of $4,500. Parliament offered compensation in May 1997 to men convicted by the Nazis of fleeing Hitler's army, after years of debate about whether they were heroes or traitors. Since then, 2,124 people have applied. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: GERMANY: A MEDICAL WALKOUT Thousands of German doctors and dentists went on a one-day strike protesting the Government's plans to cap medical spending. Health Minister Andrea Fischer charged that the demonstrators were confusing patients by saying the proposed changes would lead to cutbacks in medicine supplies. (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: SPAIN: AN OVERTURE TO BASQUE REBELS The Spanish Government said that it had made ''significant'' contacts with people close to the Basque separatist group E.T.A., which has observed a cease-fire since September in its 30-year fight for Basque independence. The Government also agreed to transfer 21 Basque separatist inmates to prisons closer to their homes, but two Basque nationalist parties called the gesture insufficient. (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: VATICAN: POPE JOHN PAUL HIT WITH FLU Ill with influenza, Pope John Paul II had to cancel all of his appointments on Friday, including a meeting with the Catholic patriarch of Iraq and an official of the Arab League. The Vatican said the 78-year-old Pope was scheduled to celebrate midnight Mass on Christmas Eve and deliver his annual address on Christmas Day. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: CONGO REPUBLIC: FIGHTING CONTINUES Automatic weapons fire rattled through a neighborhood of Brazzaville for a second day while refugees fled fighting between the army of President Denis Sassou Nguesso and a rogue militia group. The police fired on looters taking advantage of the disorder, witnesses said. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: ZIMBABWE: NEW OPPOSITION PARTY A new political party headed by an outspoken independent legislator, Margaret Dongo, will be started this weekend, party officials announced. The party, called the Zimbabwe Union of Democrats, will challenge President Robert Mugabe's ruling party in the elections due in 2000. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: ANGOLA: REBEL ATTACKS WIDEN Rebel fighters from Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola attacked the northeastern city of Malanje in a further sign of growing fighting in the country, Angolan radio stations reported. Fighting between Unita and Government troops erupted on Dec. 5 outside Kuito in Bie province, shattering the 1994 peace accords. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: INDIA: QUOTAS FOR PARTY POSTS The Congress Party, an increasingly powerful opposition in Parliament since its recent state election victories, set aside a third of its party positions for women and a fifth for religious minorities, including members of lower castes and tribes. The party president, Sonia Gandhi, left, said the changes would help rebuild its role as champion of the oppressed. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: SOUTH KOREA: NORTH'S APOLOGY REQUESTED South Korea demanded an apology from North Korea after South Korean warships and fighter planes sank an intruding North Korean vessel, killing at least one North Korean agent in a firefight off the southern coast. The body of the armed agent was found close to where the semisubmersible vessel, which resembles a dark speedboat, was sunk before dawn, a Defense Ministry spokesman said. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: AFGHANISTAN: A TALIBAN INVESTIGATION The United Nations Human Rights Commission based in Geneva said that it hoped to send a five-member mission to Afghanistan to investigate the reported massacre of civilians by Taliban fighters in two northern towns, Bamyan and Mazar-i-Sharif, in 1997 and this year. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: PHILIPPINES: TOP FUGITIVE KILLED The head of the feared Muslim extremist group Abu Sayyaf was killed in a gun battle with Government troops in the southern island of Basilan, the police said. The country's most wanted fugitive, Abdurajak Abubakar Janjalani, died with two other guerrillas and two police officers in the 40-minute firefight in Lamitan town. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: MIDDLE EAST ISRAEL: NEW NETANYAHU ROLE Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, after accepting the resignation of Finance Minister Yaacov Neeman on Wednesday, has decided to take over the sensitive portfolio himself, the Prime Minister's spokesman said. Mr. Neeman had criticized the poor functioning of the Government and its inability to push his 1999 budget legislation through parliament. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: BRAZIL: BACKTRACK ON PARDONS The Government will change a law granting pardons on Christmas to keep one of the killers of the defender of the Amazon rain forest, Chico Mendes, in prison. When President Fernando Henrique Cardoso signed the law on Christmas pardons in November, a spokesman said, he did not realize it might benefit Darly Alves da Silva, a rancher convicted of planning Mr. Mendes's murder. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: ST. VINCENT & GRENADINES: DRUGS DESTROYED About $1 billion worth of marijuana plants were destroyed during raids bitterly opposed by farmers on the island of St. Vincent, a United States Marine spokesman said. Marine helicopters carried agents from the United States Drug Enforcement Agency and the Regional Security System, a Caribbean police force, to uproot and burn about 996,000 mature plants and 167,000 seedlings during the 12-day operation. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: Like 50 to 100 other normally desk-bound day-shift police officers, Michael H. Hilliard showed up for the 5:39 roll call yesterday afternoon and was soon dispatched to the streets.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''We've shut down the administrative offices for 30 days,'' said Officer Hilliard, an administrative officer. ''We have 296 homicides, and the goal is to complete the year with no more.''
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: Standing before the men and women, Lieut. Donald E. Healy urged them to go after the drug dealers, who are responsible for three-quarters of those homicides. ''Shut them down and bring them in.''
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: With officer clerks and computer operators assisting regular officers assigned to high-crime areas, the department is hitting the streets, following the threads that lead from street-corner questionings to arrests for sales of $10 rocks of crack cocaine to whatever it is that makes this city one of the nation's most murderous.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: Baltimore, like other cities around the nation, has experienced a decline in crime. But throughout the 1990's, this city has defied the trend in one category of violent crime: homicide. Throughout the 1990's, it has recorded 304 to 353 homicides a year, three-quarters of them drug-related.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: Federal crime statistics show the Baltimore area, with 2.5 million residents, with a rate of 14.2 killings last year for every 100,000 residents. The rate is far above those of most other big cities, including New York and its suburbs, where the rate last year was 9.3.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: So early last week, Police Commissioner Thomas C. Frazier, who previously assigned his troops more overtime during the Christmas shopping season, started what he called an ''enhanced holiday deployment.'' He has shut down most administrative work for a month and assigned desk-bound officers to the streets and directed the regulars to concentrate on the high-crime areas.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''We're going to make every effort we can to bring in the crime rate as low as we can,'' Commissioner Frazier said. ''We're bringing in everyone who we can wring out of a non-enforcement assignment. I did 15 hours yesterday, and I will be on the street tonight.''
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: But even with the special deployment, the prospects of keeping the number of homicides under 300, the department's goal, are grim. Through October, it recorded 259 homicides, 5 more than by the same time last year, when 310 were recorded for the full year. Lately, the pace has continued, with a homicide a day.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: On Monday, the department reported No. 295. A man with multiple stab wounds was found partly covered with leaves in the back of a row house. On Tuesday, a woman in the trunk of a car that had been intentionally set on fire became No. 296. Thirty minutes after midnight today, No. 297, a man in his late 20's, was found shot in the back and sprawled on a sidewalk.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: After roll call, Officers Warren Smith and Tim Palmer, each married, each father of one child, both sinewy, proud members of Baltimore's SWAT team, hurried off in their new unmarked cruiser. They were given a single assignment, to seek out the furtive gestures and quick transactions of drug dealing.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: Twice tonight, with Officer Smith at the wheel, they turned their vehicle into a rocket of siren and light. But mostly they wove their way through the desolate streets of largely boarded-up row houses.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''Time out!'' they heard someone shout from a cluster of six people gathered at a corner as the well-recognized white Ford Crown Victoria approached. The six, indistinguishable by sex or age in their loose-fitting, hooded parkas, ambled off, hands in pockets. The officers left them alone.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: The officers headed across North Avenue and into the dark side streets. A woman about 50 crossed in front of them.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''What you got in your pocket?'' Officer Smith asked, getting out of the car with Officer Palmer.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''Nothing,'' she told them. Nonchalantly, she said she was on her way to buy something.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''Who are you dealing with?'' Officer Smith asked
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''Heavy,'' she replied, a man named Heavy. Heavy is nowhere around. The officers made note of his name and moved on.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: They spotted a group outside a corner store. Corner stores -- delis, take-out food stores, convenience stores -- are the only commercial establishments along the streets off the thoroughfares, like North and Pennsylvania Avenues.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''My pet peeve is the corner store,'' Officer Smith said. ''The stores give them an excuse to be on the corner. If you see people in the store, they're not buying anything.''
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: They told one cluster of young men to pull up their shirts, a way to find if they were carrying guns. Or they called, ''Show me your hands,'' a way of finding drugs. ''You look for somebody making a quick movement,'' Officer Palmer said.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: The law requires the police to ask before frisking anyone, but usually permission is granted.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: In front of a store on a corner on Edmonson Avenue, they spotted a transaction. Slowly, Officer Smith followed one of the people onto a side street. He turned on his search light and pulled up to a young woman in gray sweat pants, a blue parka and a gray knit hat.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: Frightened, just 17, she held a marijuana cigar, evidently not having learned to surreptitiously let it drop. They stood near a gray brick wall with ''R.I.P'' scrawled on it and the names Jeneen, Fade, Mark, Sean, Tish, Lance, Oscar and Reggie -- all slain.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: Officer Palmer asked what she was handing the man at the corner. ''I didn't give him nothing,'' she said, still holding the cigar. ''Fifty cents. I swear I gave him 50 cents.''
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: They took the cigar and asked to go through her pockets. They found two tiny bags of marijuana and called a patrol wagon to bring her in.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: After she was booked and briefed, she smiled easily and innocently, saying she is in the 10th grade, wants to be a lawyer or a basketball player and works in a Burger King part time. She will be held in a cell block for juveniles until her mother comes to get her.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''She's still reachable,'' Officer Palmer said. ''I'd rather lock up the adult who sold it to her.''
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: Still, she could be a link in the chain that leads to Baltimore's many homicides. As part of her debriefing, and those of the 10 other people arrested in the night, Detective Irvin Bradley of the homicide squad, suggested, without promising, that in return for leniency in court, they steer him to the guns and the dealers.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: Detective Bradley is particularly interested in leads to ''stick-up boys.''
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: ''They rob the drug dealers,'' he said. ''These drug dealers are not going to call the police and say, 'He stuck me up.' They handle it themselves, and the way they handle it is to kill them.''
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: He also wants locations of ''stash houses,'' places near the sites of their sales where dealers hide guns so they won't be caught with them and can still get to them. By late last night, he said he had collected the addresses of four.
title: Going From Desks to Mean Streets

text: An article in Science Times on Nov. 17 about drug testing kits associated one substance incorrectly with QuickScreen at Home, a test made by Phamatech. A telephone call from the company on Monday said that QuickScreen checks for marijuana, cocaine and heroin but not LSD.
title: Corrections

text: By David Stevens, International Herald Tribune
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: Mozart's last year, 1791, was a frantically prolific one for the composer, and it is the theme of the current visit to Paris of Jean-Claude Malgoire and his Grande Ecurie et la Chambre du Roy, at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees.
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: Primarily, of course, this means "The Magic Flute," which is being given by the same team — Pierre Constant as stage director, with Roberto Plate's sets and Emmanuel Peduzzi's costumes — that delighted the public two seasons ago with their integrated productions of the trio of operas written in collaboration with Lorenzo Da Ponte.
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: In this case there is a third collaborator, Gerard Fasoli and his Compagnie Accroche-Moi, which specializes in associating the aerial arts of the circus with other theatrical forms. The marriage is not always a happy one, with the frequent descents and elevations of ladders and trapeze bars from the flies being more distracting than enriching.
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: Still, the production had its moments. The Three Ladies arrive, like the serpent, with fish tails, out of which they squirm to lavish Tamino with their lascivious attention. Later they, like the Queen of the Night and Monostatos, are in form-fitting black leather. No question who is evil here.
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: But overall, the acrobatics and the omnipresent busy-ness of the Three Boys becomes seriously obtrusive to the opera's serious message. Too much Schikaneder and not enough Mozart.
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: Malgoire's musical direction was predominantly light and quick, and his cast was headed by a solid Tamino and Pamina in Christoph Genz and Olga Pasichnyk. Hubert Claessens was the rambunctious Papageno and Frederic Caton doubled as Sarastro and the Speaker.
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: The "final year" program has already offered a concert performance of "La Clemenza di Tito," and Saturday brings a repeat of a program of the "Ave Verum Corpus" motet, the Clarinet Concerto, and the Requiem.
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: Meanwhile, at the Salle Pleyel, the ongoing Beethoven series of the Orchestre de Paris under Wolfgang Sawallisch reached a pinnacle with a deeply expressive "Missa Solemnis."
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: The outstanding vocal quartet was Susan Anthony, Marjana Lipovsek, Wolfgang Buenten, and the seemingly inexhaustible Kurt Moll, whose bass seems as rich as ever after three decades.
title: An Acrobatic 'Magic Flute'

text: Yosef Y. Kazen, a Hasidic rabbi who pioneered the use of the Internet as a powerful recruiting and educational tool for the Lubavitch movement, died Dec. 1 at New York Hospital. He was 44 and lived in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: The cause was complications of non-Hodgkins lymphoma, said Moshe Kotlarski, his brother-in-law and the development director at the Lubavitch World Headquarters in Brooklyn.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: The Hasidic branch of Judaism is rooted in the mysticism of 18th century Eastern Europe, but the Lubavitch movement has long used modern means to propagate its teachings, and Rabbi Kazen staked a claim in cyberspace in the late 1980's, before the World Wide Web existed.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: An early user of computer bulletin boards, he was inspired by the notion of adding a 24-hour, on-line Web site to the movement's worldwide network of outreach and study centers. He digitized and made thousands of documents available on the Web, including an English translation of the Tanya, a seminal text of Jewish mysticism, and the writings of Rabbi Menachem Schneerson, the Lubavitcher spiritual leader, who died in 1994.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: With the growth of the Web's popularity, Rabbi Kazen's Internet site, Chabad-Lubavitch in Cyberspace, served as a model for other Jewish organizations, who created their own educational Web sites. Visitors to www.chabad.org can read articles on science and Judaism, listen to religious melodies and browse a gallery displaying the work of Hasidic artists.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: In addition to building a Jewish library on the Web, Rabbi Kazen sought to create an on-line congregation and to answer questions by E-mail, operating first from his own basement and later from a cramped office at the Lubavitch headquarters. His Internet activities varied from helping to organize a Passover service held on a boat near Antarctica to dispatching kosher recipes to Jews living far from centers of Jewish population.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: Rabbi Kazen developed automated responses to the most frequently asked questions and responded personally to some messages, like the E-mail from a student in New Mexico who wanted to know whether it was permissible to smoke marijuana on the morning of the Sabbath. ''I wrote him back that, within Judaism, the concept is that the prayer itself gives you the high,'' the rabbi told Jeff Zaleski, author of ''The Soul of Cyberspace'' (1997).
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: In his last months, Rabbi Kazen kept a laptop computer in his room at New York Hospital so he could continue his electronic correspondence.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: Rabbi Kazen was born in Cleveland and grew up there in a Yiddish-speaking household, the son of Russian immigrants and the youngest of seven siblings. He became a rabbi at the United Lubavitcher Yeshivoth in New York. A heavy-set man with a carrot-colored beard, he was also at the forefront of the more traditional Lubavitch outreach programs, which include the ''Mitzvah tanks,'' the vans and trucks that dispense both prayer books and tefillin (boxes containing passages from Scripture worn during prayer).
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: He saw distinct advantages in adapting new technologies to an ancient purpose.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: ''Some guy in a black hat and tefillin comes to you, and you have the stereotype,'' Rabbi Kazen said in an interview in The New York Times in 1994. ''When you go to the Internet and you read about Judaism, you go straight to the intellect and the stereotypes fall away.''
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: Rabbi Kazen is survived by his wife, Rochel; six children, Raizel, Michoel, Shmuel, Elchanan, Peretz and Sarah; his parents, Rabbi Zalman and Shifra Shula Kazen, of Cleveland; and six sisters, Esther Alpern of Sao Paulo, Brazil; Devorah Alevsky of Cleveland; Henya Laine of Brooklyn; Bluma Weinberg of Kansas City, Kan.; Rivkah Kotlarsky of Brooklyn, and Rochel Goldman of Johannesburg.
title: Yosef Kazen, Hasidic Rabbi And Web Pioneer, Dies at 44

text: Issuing a speeding ticket does not automatically give the police the authority to search the car, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today in rejecting the latest invitation from law-enforcement officials to expand the powers of the police in encounters with motorists.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: The Court held that the police in Iowa violated a driver's constitutional rights by conducting a full search of his car based on nothing more than a speeding violation, for which the police issued a citation. The search turned up marijuana and led to the man's conviction on state narcotics charges.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: An Iowa law, the only one of its kind in the country, authorizes the police to conduct the same kind of search after issuing a citation, for traffic or other offenses, that Supreme Court precedents permit as an aspect of a full custodial arrest. The Iowa Supreme Court upheld the law, and the search at issue in this case, by a 5-to-4 vote last year.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: In an opinion today by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, the Justices did not declare the Iowa law unconstitutional in all possible applications. But for a simple speeding offense, the Chief Justice said, the justifications for the Court's doctrine permitting a ''search incident to arrest'' simply do not apply.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: Twenty-five years ago, when the Court first announced, in United States v. Robinson, that the police could search the area under the control of a person they were arresting, the Justices offered two rationales for what was, in effect, an exception to the Fourth Amendment requirement that searches ordinarily be authorized by search warrants. The exception is justified by the need to protect the safety of the arresting officers and to prevent the suspect from destroying evidence, the Court said in its 1973 ruling.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: Writing for the Court today in Knowles v. Iowa, No. 97-7597, Chief Justice Rehnquist said the threat to the police from issuing a traffic ticket, which he called a ''relatively brief encounter,'' was ''a good deal less than in the case of a custodial arrest.'' And there is no further evidence to discover in a speeding case, he said, noting that once the driver was stopped for speeding, ''all the evidence necessary to prosecute the offense had been obtained.''
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches
