text: ''No further evidence of excessive speed was going to be found either on the person of the offender or in the passenger compartment of the car,'' he said.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: The defendant, Patrick Knowles, was driving 43 miles per hour in a 25 m.p.h. zone when the police stopped him in Newton, Iowa, in 1996. At a hearing after his arrest for marijuana possession, he challenged the constitutionality of the search. The officer testified that he had had no basis for suspecting an offense other than speeding but had conducted the search under the law authorizing searches ''incident to the citation.''
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: The case attracted considerable attention once the Court agreed in March to hear Mr. Knowles's appeal. The American Civil Liberties Union and the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers filed a brief for Mr. Knowles, while the National Association of Police Organizations entered the case on Iowa's behalf, stressing the inherent danger to the police from even routine traffic stops. It was evident from the briefs that if Iowa prevailed in this case, the practice of conducting searches after such traffic stops would become widespread.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: Chief Justice Rehnquist's opinion made clear that far from ignoring the issue of police safety, the Justices believed they had taken adequate account of it in other decisions.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: Last year, in Maryland v. Wilson, the Court ruled that the police may routinely order passengers out of a car they have stopped for a routine traffic violation; a 1977 decision had already given the police authority to order the driver out of the car.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: ''But while the concern for officer safety in this context may justify the 'minimal' additional intrusion of ordering a driver and passengers out of the car,'' Chief Justice Rehnquist said in today's opinion, ''it does not by itself justify the often considerably greater intrusion attending a full field-type search.''
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: Cases growing out of encounters between the police and motorists are a staple of the Court's docket, and the police win most of them. Two years ago, in Whren v. United States, the Court ruled unanimously that the actual motivation of police officers in making a traffic stop was irrelevant as long as there was probable cause to believe that traffic laws were being violated; it did not matter if the stop was really a pretext to check the car for drugs. In that case, large bags of crack cocaine were in plain view in the passenger's hands, and so the kind of search involved in the case today was not at issue.
title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches

text: A red bandanna is pinned over his bed, but 17-year-old Richard C. does not hang with the Bloods anymore. After five arrests and a probation violation, Richard was taken away from his gang a year ago and sent to a residential treatment facility called the Edwin Gould Academy.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Now the onetime gang member, tall and lanky with delicate features that disguise a hair-trigger temper, is a peer group leader. His 12 new ''brothers'' are a lot like the guys he knew on the street: truants and graffiti makers, drug dealers and addicts, car thieves and shoplifters. But the new group is striving to reform. And while staff members at Edwin Gould Academy support their efforts, it is the students who lead.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''If you have kids who are growing up like you, telling you what to do, it makes more sense,'' said Richard, who plans to join the Marines after graduating in June.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''Right now, they call me a juvenile delinquent,'' he said, ''but soon they'll be calling me Lieutenant.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Conversions like Richard's have won national praise for the Edwin Gould Academy, home to about 175 troubled New York City adolescents from 12 to 21. About a quarter of the students were charged with one or more misdemeanors. The remaining students were sent there by the city's Administration for Children's Services, at a cost of $79,000 a year per child, average for a residential center.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Most of the youngsters were placed on an emergency basis, after their parents or guardians died, or because they were abused or neglected. Others had already been in foster care families, other group homes or juvenile detention centers. They were placed at the academy by social workers as a final option before being sent back to a detention center or a psychiatric institution.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Last month, the academy, which opened eight years ago in a cluster of hills here in Rockland County, was one of 10 programs to win the Innovations in American Government Award. The honor, which includes a $100,000 prize from the Ford Foundation and Harvard University, recognizes government programs that have developed new ways to fight America's most critical problems.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The academy's work has been praised by advocates, who say that the city's system of looking after abused and neglected children, from investigating charges of abuse to finding permanent homes, is abysmal. The situation was so dire that advocates sued the city, and last week, the city agreed to have a panel of experts examine foster care records and policies and devise alternate ways to manage the caseload.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: While most residential treatment homes in the country have two staffs and two directors, for education and for social services, Edwin Gould has just one. Drug counselors, child psychologists and educators are joined in one agency, under the direction of Tom Webber, whose title is superintendent and executive director.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''This way, turf battles don't get in the way of serving the kids,'' Dr. Webber said.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The other strategy is that the students run their own group counseling and motivational sessions.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: On a recent Wednesday, Edgar M., 16, who lives in Malcolm X House, a campus dormitory, asked the group there for help to recover from a phone call from his mother, who had abused and abandoned him.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The last time Edgar saw her, he was 4. She had left him at an aunt's house and said she would be back after running a few errands. He never heard from her again.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Edgar, a native of Guatemala, told the group that he thought he was over the pain. But a few weeks ago, he said, his mother called. She was living in California, and now has a 4-year-old daughter.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The call sent him into a depression. He felt sad and did not want to go to his Narcotics Anonymous meetings.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''I worry that my mom is raising that little girl the same way she raised me,'' said Edgar, slumped forward. ''I can't seem to stop thinking about that little girl.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Otis R., 18., said, ''Maybe you are mad because your mother is able to raise her, and she didn't have nothing to do with you.'' His idea was echoed by others in the group. Because most of the residents are juveniles, they are identified only by their first names and last initials.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The room turned silent. Edgar rocked back and forth, as if trying to dodge the theories being tossed around him.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''You're just going to have to let this go, because there's nothing you can do about it,'' advised Otis, who was sent to the academy after a couple of arrests, and who worries about his own 9-year-old brother, who lives with his abusive father.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Administrators at Edwin Gould said that although they did not have the money to track what percentage of their graduates go on to become self-sufficient adults, the majority at least make a promising start.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Within the first eight months, the average student improves reading and math skills by more than 1.2 years. More than 50 percent of those who get high school diplomas here go on to college.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: And each year, Edwin Gould administrators said, the situation on their campus improves. From 1992 to 1993, students injured staff members 66 times, and half of the girls became pregnant. Last year, staff injuries were down to eight and pregnancies down to three.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''We need to get to the point where we have more Edwin Goulds out there,'' said Nicholas Scoppetta, Commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The Edwin Gould campus is surrounded by trees, and swarms with Canada geese. There are no security guards, bars or barbed wire.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The 45 girls live in two whitewashed three-story dormitories. The campus for the 128 boys, set on a hill to the west, is a series of two-story red brick cottages named for figures like Muhammad Ali, Tito Puente and Malcolm X.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: There are proms, assemblies and holiday meals, although the students say ''the food stinks.'' There are basketball, track and football teams. At the end of each year, the school publishes a yearbook and holds a graduation.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Dr. Webber said: ''We make it very clear to the kids. We are not a treatment center. We are not a juvenile justice facility. We are a school. We're here to educate. I really believe that education is the best treatment for these kids.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Each dormitory's residents, 12 or 13 students, gather in their living room each day for a meeting students call ''group,'' focusing on the person who seems to be stumbling the most. A counselor speaks only to keep the discussion going.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: During the day, students can also call informal meetings to confront someone who is misbehaving or who seems withdrawn. They do not go easy on one another. The sessions are blunt and serious.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''It's something new to me,'' Onasia B., 15, said of the peer sessions. She came to the academy last year after living in a group foster home on Staten Island, where she was sent by her mother for smoking marijuana, skipping school and staying away from home for days at a time.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''When adults tell you things,'' Onasia said, ''it's all about consequences, like you either do what they say or you get detention. But when peers talk to you, it's different.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The Malcolm X House, home to 13 adolescent boys from 15 to 19, is a microcosm of the school.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: One resident is Sean B., of Queens, a freckle-faced 17-year-old with a goatee who said he was sent to Edwin Gould because he was ''addicted to writing on walls.'' Julio N., 17, of the Lower East Side of Manhattan, was arrested last year for assaulting a police officer. His parents are dead.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Shaddid M., 18, said he and his six brothers and sisters had been separated since they were small, and were in and out of foster care. His mother, a drug addict, died of AIDS last year.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: William Aulet, homeroom teacher for the Malcolm X House, said that if life had been a little different, he could have grown up just like his students. He, too, was abandoned by his parents, who were drug addicts. But Mr. Aulet had the good fortune to be taken in by his best friend's parents.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Dr. Webber, the school administrator, a wisp of a man who says he grew up the only white child in his East Harlem neighborhood, once ran a storefront high school for dropouts and gang members kicked out of other schools. Those are the kinds of young people he wants at the academy, he said, although the school is not equipped to treat adolescents who are suicidal, heavily addicted to drugs or suffering from severe mental illness.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''Kids who have been pushed out of school,'' Dr. Webber said, ''and who have gotten themselves into a gang, or who are getting into trouble, those are kids who are trying to make something happen in their lives.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Jeffrey Erickson, 19, is one of the academy's most celebrated stories. After running away from one foster home after another, Mr. Erickson was sent to Edwin Gould five years ago.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''Restraint was my middle name,'' he said, referring to the many times he was held down by staff members to stop him from fighting.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Today Mr. Erickson, clean cut and confident, is studying business administration at Rockland Community College and works part time as a salesclerk at a music store. In the summer he plans to move out of the academy and into his own apartment.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: The students still have their share of troubles. LaQuawn K., 16, ran away from the school a couple of weeks ago and got shot in a fight in Brooklyn. He is back at the academy now, but he brags about the bullet, lodged next to his left lung.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Two weeks ago, Michael R., 16, yelled at and tried to provoke Pierre Fils, a teaching counselor.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''Informal!'' group members shouted, the standard call when a crisis occurs. ''We need an informal!''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: They rushed into Mr. Aulet's classroom and pulled chairs around a table. Michael, dragging his feet, took a seat at the front.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Three staff members were in the room, but they stayed quiet.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''Did anyone in the group see a problem with Mike?'' asked Richard, opening the meeting.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''Man, you were inconsiderate to self because you ain't been doing your work,'' Edgar said. ''And then when Pierre asks you about it, you try to get in his face.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Michael rolled his eyes. ''I don't accept,'' he said.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''I think you are trying to push Pierre away because he's the one always trying to help you,'' Sean said. ''You have authority problems.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: Michael mumbled back, ''I don't accept.'' Then he started to laugh.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''Right now, no one is laughing with you,'' said Julio, his wide face in a scowl. ''We're laughing at you. We're thinking you're a fool.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: After 15 minutes, the group was riled. But Michael's composure was intact. The students went back to their classes. But they were not done with Michael.
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: ''We're going to be here when you're ready to talk,'' Otis said. ''But you have to make the first step.''
title: School Takes On Others' Failures; Teaching the Delinquent and Abandoned With Success

text: By Compiled By Christopher S. Wren
title: World Briefing

text: The arrival of a World Bank team for more talks about loans did little to assuage fears that Russia will be left without foreign aid and may begin printing large sums of money to pay off a total foreign currency debt of $158.8 billion by January. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: BRITAIN: TORY BACKS DOWN ON KEY PLAN
title: World Briefing

text: William Hague, the leader of Britain's Conservatives, has abandoned plans to press for a new regional Parliament to represent England. The proposal, a centerpiece of his program at the annual party convention two months ago, was aimed at being a counterweight to the new Parliaments that the Labor Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair has created in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. Warren Hoge (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: GERMANY: CALL FOR EAST GERMAN AMNESTY
title: World Briefing

text: Leaders of the Party of Democratic Socialism, successor to the Communists who governed the former East Germany, have called for an amnesty on crimes committed under Communist rule. The party's leader, Lothar Bisby, questioned whether people carrying out the law of East Germany, from border guards upward, should be liable to prosecution. Nearly 1,000 people were killed trying to flee to the West. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: IRAN: KHATAMI SPEAKS OUT ON REFORMS
title: World Briefing

text: President Mohammad Khatami, who was elected last year on promises of ushering in political reforms, accused conservative and traditionalist forces of blocking reforms in Iran. ''We are facing the three currents of counter-revolution, traditionalists hostile to progressive religion and revisionists,'' he told an assembly hall packed with 10,000 student supporters at Sharif University, Teheran. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: The Ministry of Religious Endowments said it began putting into action a plan to control 6,000 ''zawya,'' or mini-mosques, in an attempt to put an end to Muslim fundamentalism. The ministry will appoint prayer leaders to the mosques, a spokesman said. (Agence France-Presse)
title: World Briefing

text: INDIA: STANDING FIRM ON KASHMIR
title: World Briefing

text: On his first visit to Kashmir since becoming Prime Minister of India in March, Atal Behari Vajpayee said India would never relinquish any of it to Pakistan. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: CHINA: ACID RAIN DAMAGE GROWS
title: World Briefing

text: China's rapid economic growth and reliance on coal have spread acid rain damage to 40 percent of the country, The China Daily reported. According to a new report by Chinese scientists, China emitted 23.5 million tons of sulfur dioxide last year, up 30 percent from 1993, and coal use doubled to comprise 75 percent of total energy consumption. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: NORTH KOREA: TALKS WITH U.S. CONTINUE
title: World Briefing

text: The United States and North Korea resumed talks in Washington on an American demand for access to an underground building site that could be connected with a revived nuclear program in North Korea. The negotiators met in New York on Friday and Saturday, with their agenda restricted to Washington's insistence that North Korea allow inspections of the site at the village of Kumchang-ri. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: JAPAN: ECONOMY IN 'SEVERE STATE'
title: World Briefing

text: The head of the Bank of Japan said Japan's economy remains in ''an extremely severe state.'' The central bank governor, Masaru Hayami, told Parliament that corporate earnings had slipped and industrial production had fallen. (AP)
title: World Briefing

text: SOUTH AFRICA: ELECTION PLAN CHALLENGED
title: World Briefing

text: The opposition National Party said it would ask the High Court to rule on the constitutionality of requiring citizens to have new ''bar-coded'' identity documents before they can register to vote in national elections next year. The ruling African National Congress is insisting on the documents, but that could result in fewer white voters getting to the polls because many have not applied for the new documents. Suzanne Daley (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: The brother of Uganda's President resigned as the nation's security adviser after admitting his involvement in a secret deal to buy a 49 percent interest in the Uganda Commercial Bank. Maj. Gen. Salim Saleh, a military adviser to his brother, President Yoweri Museveni, has been criticized for corruption and the military's support of the rebellion in Congo. Ian Fisher (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: ANGOLA: REBELS TELL OF ATTACKS
title: World Briefing

text: The rebel movement Unita said Government forces bombed its strongholds in the towns of Andulo and Bailundo in breach of a four-year peace treaty. Paulo Lukamba Gato, Unita's secretary general, told a Portuguese radio station that the attacks could signal a return to all-out fighting in Angola. (Reuters)
title: World Briefing

text: ST. VINCENT AND THE GRENADINES: MARIJUANA WAR
title: World Briefing

text: Caribbean troops backed by six United States Marine Corps helicopters are beginning a two-week campaign to eradicate an estimated 12,000 acres of marijuana on St. Vincent, BBC News reported. It said the island's marijuana growers' association, warning that the destruction of the crop would drive up the island's 40 percent unemployment rate, has written to President Clinton demanding compensation.
title: World Briefing

text: UNITED STATES: GORE'S GLOBAL CONFERENCE
title: World Briefing

text: Vice President Gore is inviting law enforcement and other officials from more than 60 countries to what his office calls the world's first conference on fighting corruption and safeguarding integrity among justice and security officials. The conference is scheduled from Feb. 24 to 26 at the State Department. (NYT)
title: World Briefing

text: Compiled by Christopher S. Wren
title: World Briefing

text: I'VE always been suspicious of cordless phones, imagining that someone with a high-tech eavesdropping device might be listening in. Well, I've finally been proved wrong. It doesn't take a high-tech listening device; a no-frills baby monitor will do.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: This was my unnerving discovery this year after my partner and I became fathers. One minute we were listening to the nocturnal stirring of our infant and the next we were hearing the clear voice of our neighbor engaged in what should have been a private phone conversation.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: That first time, admittedly, we listened without reservation. It took us only a few seconds to recognize that it was the voice of a woman who lived a few flights above us. I don't remember what she was talking about, but it was something ordinary, like confirming a date she had the next day. Still, ''Dial M for Murder'' passed through my mind, and I was waiting for her to reveal an impending crime, or something else momentous, like her first-hand knowledge of a new White House affair.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: When nothing shocking emerged, my partner and I both felt a little silly. Although we hadn't deliberately sought to invade our neighbor's privacy, we had done so nonetheless by not turning the monitor off or switching to the other channel. Next time, we promised ourselves, we would do better.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: We haven't always lived up to that promise. Again and again, voices have flashed over the monitor. The sound can be remarkably clear -- significantly sharper than the usually unintelligible snips of conversation that sometimes interfere with our own cordless phone calls. The words are one-sided, in that we hear only our neighbor, but they are no less revealing because of it.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: Usually, we turn the volume down or switch channels, although switching sometimes lands us in the middle of another conversation.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: Occasionally we listen. It's difficult to resist dwelling over these ''Rear Window''-like glimpses of other lives. I find it easier to walk away than my partner, who periodically fills me in on an anguishing dilemma faced by a neighbor, usually someone to whom I've never said more than hello.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: My partner isn't proud of his eavesdropping. In fact, he asked me not to use his name because he doesn't want people to know he does it. But I'm not ashamed to say that I've listened now and then. I think very few people could do much better.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: One night, my partner heard someone who had just moved in two floors below us. He was apparently subletting a room in a two-room apartment, but had been given the chance to move from one room to the other. So he called friends and relatives to help him decide whether or not to make the switch. One room was larger and $15 more a month, but you could smell the garbage from the cans outside the windows, he told everyone.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: Finally, he decided to keep the room he had -- the one that was smaller, cheaper and less smelly -- and my partner, who felt he'd gone through the decision-making process with him, told me it was the right choice.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: But then at midnight, the guy woke us up with a call to his landlord, whom he also apparently woke. After an awkward apology, he explained in a sad, fumbling voice that he'd changed his mind and wanted the larger room after all.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: ''No,'' my partner said, so upset that he sat up in bed. ''He was so sure of himself two hours ago. What happened?'' My partner had become so swept up in the drama of this stranger's life that he had trouble getting back to sleep. ''I just don't understand why he changed his mind,'' he said several times before we both drifted off.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: Confirming that New Yorkers are obsessed with their apartments, we heard that same night, on the other channel, a woman confessing to a friend that she'd lied about something relating to her last apartment in order to find someone to take over the lease quickly. On other occasions there was a woman complaining that her grandmother treated her mother badly, and another woman talking about how she hated so-and-so and still another woman talking about how fluently she speaks German.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: My partner recently heard an adolescent neighbor apparently planning to buy marijuana, and he wondered if he should tell the teen-ager's parents. So far, he's decided not to interfere since we both think the kid seems responsible and is probably only experimenting.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: That we listen, even if only for a few moments, says more about us than our neighbors, I think. The words I hear before I turn the volume down reassure me that my neighbors are like me, with problems that seem large to them but are not such a big deal when seen from the outside.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: I'd like to tell my neighbors that we can hear what they're saying, but don't know how to do it without angering them or embarrassing them as they try to remember everything they've ever said over their cordless phones. I for one have cut down on using our cordless phone, although with a baby in the house it's sometimes indispensable.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: My long-standing fear about eavesdroppers is now confirmed. And yet, I'm less anxious than I was before because I think that if someone is listening in, they're probably just like me, innocent victims of some technological mix-up, interested less in prying into my life than finding out that their neighbor isn't such a strange person after all.
title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener

text: David Hilton, the star point guard for the Hyde School Phoenix, never despairs when his basketball team falls way behind.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: He has been down before, and he knows how to engineer a comeback.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Three years ago, at age 16, David was thrown out of his home and shunned by his family after he disclosed some of his family's problems to his high school guidance counselor.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: As one of an estimated 20,000 homeless youths living on the streets of New York City, he had no interest in school, no hopes for the future, and nowhere to sleep except for an asphalt basketball court near his grandmother's house in Jamaica, Queens.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''I heard gunshots almost every night while I was sleeping,'' he said. ''I was sure I was going to be just another statistic.''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: David's experiences on the streets were harrowing, but far from rare. Although homeless populations are difficult to measure, experts say there may be as many as two million homeless youths in America. This population has expanded rapidly, in part because the first generation of children born into families ravaged by the twin epidemics of the 1980's, crack cocaine and AIDS, is just now coming of age.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: In past years, New York City earned a reputation as a magnet for these lost youths. Today, though, most experts agree that the overwhelming majority of youngsters sleeping on rooftops and in tunnels around the five boroughs are not small-town runaways.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''These kids are not from Utah; these are the children of New York City,'' said Tom Bundrick, a social worker at Safespace, a drop-in center for homeless teen-agers in Times Square.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: One local agency, the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, is determined to help these children of the city.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: The Jewish Board, a beneficiary of the UJA-Federation, relies on The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to support two centers in New York City that help homeless teen-agers from all religious backgrounds.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: One is Kaplan House, a group home on St. Marks Place in the East Village. There, 25 young men, ages 17 to 21, from broken or nonexistent homes live together and receive counseling, tutoring and job training while they learn what it takes to become a successful adult. The other is Break Free, an outpatient psychiatric center in southern Brooklyn that offers therapy and drug treatment programs to keep boys and girls off the streets.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Carl Siciliano, director of homeless-youth services for Safespace, said the need for such programs is urgent.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''There are no services for most of these kids,'' he said. ''They are too old for foster care and too young for adult shelters, so they fend for themselves any way they can. A lot of them end up on Rikers Island, or in the city morgue.''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: With the help of the Jewish Board, David Hilton instead wound up in prep school.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: He arrived at Kaplan House in October 1996 after a year on the streets. By June 1997 David had developed emotionally, academically and athletically to the point where he earned a scholarship to the Hyde School in Woodstock, Conn. David did not become a statistic, but his statistics shine, both on his report card and in the box scores. On the court, he averages 32 points per game. In the classroom, he averages 80 points per test.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: David will almost certainly receive an athletic scholarship to college in 2000, and he has the potential to one day become an All-Star in the National Basketball Association, coaches from New York City say.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Such happy endings for homeless teen-agers are hard to find. The teen-agers themselves, however, are everywhere.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Fleeing Abuse at Home For a Life on the Street
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Theresa T., a 17-year-old from the Bronx, arrived at Break Free in October 1997, four years after leaving home because she could no longer tolerate the daily abuse.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Theresa, who spoke on the condition that her full name not be used, said her mother beat her with belts, spoons and the cords of the Nintendo machine. Her uncles and cousins raped her repeatedly from the time she was a little girl, she said. Her father, who left when Theresa was 3, let Theresa stay in Brooklyn with him and one of his girlfriends occasionally, but after a few days, he always sent Theresa back to her mother's house. She ran away when she was 13, just two weeks before Christmas.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Theresa grew up quickly. At an age when other girls were still receiving weekly allowances, she earned pocket money baby-sitting the children of crack addicts. While other girls cuddled up with stuffed animals, she slept in abandoned buildings. And while other eighth graders strove to be accepted into the right clique, Theresa joined a street gang of women in their 20's. As part of her initiation, she allowed them to burn her with cigarettes.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''It was peaches and cream compared to home,'' she said.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: But street life was no cure for Theresa's depression, and she tried marijuana and hallucinogens like LSD and PCP to help her forget her present and her past.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''As long as you get high, you're not thinking of what happened to you, who raped you, who molested you, how your family is, and how nasty and ugly you feel,'' she said, ''and for a little while, everything's O.K.''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Yet even in her most abject moments, Theresa did not give up on herself entirely. She never used crack or heroin, and she never prostituted herself for a place to stay, she said.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Her refusal to engage in these risky behaviors may sound like common sense, but it is uncommon for youths living on the street. In desperation, many rely on a street economy that revolves around petty crime, drug dealing and prostitution.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''To feed themselves, clothe themselves and find a place to sleep, these kids are selling their bodies,'' said Michael C. Clatts, an AIDS expert at the National Development and Research Institutes, a nonprofit research and service agency based in Manhattan. ''It's survival sex.''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: But survival sex can be deadly. A July 1997 report by the institute estimated that 6 percent to 30 percent of homeless youths in New York City are H.I.V.-positive. The enormous range can be attributed to the difficulties in finding and testing young people who are most at risk, those who never make it to shelters.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Nor is AIDS the only threat. The New York City Police Department said it had no statistical breakdown on homicides of homeless teen-agers, but Mr. Clatts said that he personally knew six homeless youths who were killed on the streets this year.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Even when homeless teen-agers try to avoid crime and get jobs, they often find themselves stymied, because they lack job skills and have no telephone, permanent address or forms of identification.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: For these reasons and more, Theresa is relieved that she found Break Free. ''They helped me with everything,'' she said.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: She needed the help. Although Linda V., one of her father's former girlfriends, took an interest in Theresa and welcomed her into her apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, Theresa had developed a drinking habit, swallowing a bottle of rum a day.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: At a friend's Sweet 16 party in October 1997, she drank so much that she later passed out in the subway and was taken by the police to Long Island City Hospital.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Linda retrieved Theresa and called the Jewish Board, which recommended Break Free. It meets at 2020 Coney Island Avenue, in what was once a Con Edison substation. Today, a different kind of power surges through the building: the power of people who desperately want to change their lives.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''The program worked because Theresa was really ready,'' said Deborah Rivera, one of her counselors. ''She knew she was sick, but she saw a chance for a stable life and a decent future, and she took advantage of everything we offered.''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Theresa and Linda underwent family therapy, and Theresa also attended individual and group therapy. Talking revived many painful memories, but Theresa finally faced them without drugs or alcohol. She tried to cleanse her spirit through dance therapy, and channeled her anger and sadness into poetry.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Theresa has not taken a drink or used any drugs in over a year. Now a high school senior with an 84 average, she hopes to attend the State University of New York at Plattsburgh in the fall. She has left the gang and found new friends at school. Instead of hanging out all night, she comes home at 5 P.M. during the week, and at midnight on the weekends. In August, Linda became her legal guardian.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Theresa has no intention of drinking again, or going back out on the streets. ''There's more to life,'' she said. ''Why would I want to take a step back when I've made it all this way?''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Finding a Sense of Self Through Basketball
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Two weeks ago, David Hilton took a rare trip back to the old neighborhood.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: He pointed out his grandmother's old house, one of 18 places he has lived in his 19 years. He remembered his teen-age uncle Timothy Hilton dragging him to the basketball court at the end of the block. David wanted to play baseball instead, but his uncle was in charge. David's mother was only 14 when David was born, and she was often absent during his childhood.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Perhaps because he never met his father, David revered his uncle. Timothy hung out at the basketball court, and he made David compete against the park regulars while he sold drugs on the court's periphery.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: David was skinny, small and easily dominated. He thought Timothy was just trying to embarrass him.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Then, in 1993, Timothy was shot in the head and killed. David threw away his baseball glove and devoted himself to the sport his uncle had wanted him to play.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: David was still at home then, but he is reluctant to talk about what life was like there because the consequences of speaking to his guidance counselor were so severe. He will say only that there were ''problems.'' When his mother threw him out, he was confused. Even his grandmother would not let him in, because he had shared family secrets. He found some security at the basketball court, where he was determined to live up to Timothy's expectations.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: David rarely had enough food in his stomach, but he pushed himself nonetheless. He played full-court against one friend at a time for three hours a night to improve his stamina. He fired jump shot after jump shot through the iron rim, then chased the ball down because there was no net.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: When David was 17, a friend helped him get into a shelter for adults. For six weeks, he slept on a cot in a gymnasium with two dozen men, scores of rats and thousands of roaches. ''I wasn't comfortable there, and I didn't feel safe,'' David said.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: One day, he volunteered to work in the shelter's soup kitchen. As he fed the grizzled old men in their ragged clothes, he remembered something his mother had told him.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''She always told me I'd be nothing but a bum, but when I saw it in front of my face, I knew I wanted more for myself,'' he said.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: When he learned about Kaplan House, David moved there from the men's shelter. At Kaplan House, he had his own room with a comfortable bed and found a nurturing staff.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''We gave him a good foundation and let him know he could get advice, get counseling and basically get whatever he needed to help carry him into the future,'' said Vic Butler, a counselor at Kaplan House for 15 years.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: David made the most of his new home. He talked to Mr. Butler constantly, and rarely missed any of the free meals there.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: David joined the Boys Club of New York, where he played basketball for a team called the Academic All-Stars. He saw it as his ticket to prep school and a chance to escape the city. To remain on the team, he had to maintain a better than C average at John Bowne High School.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: He was smart, but he had never been a great student, and a stutter made it hard for him to speak in class. But he studied with the same determination he had shown on the basketball court night after night.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: David improved his grades and became a dazzling player. He was almost 6 feet tall now, and growing. With incredible quickness and a developing jump shot, he started dominating the competition.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: ''He can be one of our future stars of the N.B.A,'' said Jim Couch, a summer league coach from Inwood who has helped tutor N.B.A. All-Stars like Mark Jackson and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Last summer, David received his scholarship to the Hyde School.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: He arrived with little knowledge of mathematics, but consistently strode to the blackboard and tried to solve problems. By the end of last year he was tutoring classmates in algebra. Last month, without a stammer, he delivered an eloquent speech on the philosophy of Henry David Thoreau.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: After he graduates in 2000, David wants to attend college in Utah or Montana, although he cannot quite picture their landscapes. He would love to play in the N.B.A., but that is not his top priority.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: On a recent cloudless day, as he walked across the basketball court, he looked to the future and said: ''My goal is to be a good father. I don't need a million dollars. What's important is that whether I'm a lawyer, a doctor or a basketball player, my children will know they've got a home.''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: After a Childhood Lost, Seeking a Place to Belong
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Angel, 20, is still out on the streets.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: At 6, she lost her home in Nyack, N.Y., when her mother, father and twin brother, Adam, were killed by a drunken driver.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Child care agencies shifted Angel from foster home to foster home. ''I always wanted to stay,'' she said. ''I used to make pictures and hang them on the walls.''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Angel, who spoke on the condition that only her first name be used, attended eight high schools without ever getting her diploma and has been on the streets since she was 18. Her last home was in a vacant building on Canal Street. She shared it last winter with 20 other young people. On cold nights, she put on all the clothes she had found on the street or had been given at local churches.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Angel said a police officer occasionally ducked into the building to give them blankets and food. ''That felt great, because I knew somebody cared for me,'' she said in a near whisper.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Now the building is boarded up. Angel learns secretarial skills at Safespace and hopes they will one day find her a place to live. Unfortunately, most transitional housing is reserved for people with income from jobs or government benefits, and Angel has neither.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: She cannot move into Kaplan House because she is a woman, and the services at Break Free are tailored to young people with drug problems. But when a spokeswoman for the Jewish Board learned of Angel's plight on Friday, she promised that the agency would try to help her.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: For now, Angel spends her nights either on a friend's couch or in a chair at an adult drop-in center. When daylight comes, she visits libraries, often in search of ''Homecoming,'' a book by Cynthia Voigt about a mother who abandons her children in a car. Angel said she has read it seven times.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: For lunch she goes to Safespace on West 46th Street, then heads for the record shops in Times Square, where she listens to music for free. She likes ''Runaway Train'' by Soul Asylum, a song about ''finding all the runaways and throwaways,'' she said.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: When the shops close, the days start to feel long ''because when you're homeless, it's like you have nowhere to go, nowhere to stay,'' Angel said. ''You're like a nomad, wandering from place to place.''
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Church Street Station, P.O. Box 4100, New York, N.Y. 10261-4100
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: The Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions go directly to the charities, which use them to provide services and cash assistance to the poor.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Contributions to the fund are deductible on Federal, state and city income taxes to the extent permitted by law.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: To delay may mean to forget.
title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings

text: Bob Herbert's columns on the Lacresha Murray case (Dec. 3, Nov. 26, 22, 19 and 15), while illuminating what may be an egregious example of prosecutorial misconduct, point to a more widespread problem: the increasing tendency to incarcerate the very young.
title: U.S. War on Children

text: In January an 11-year-old boy in Louisiana was detained for fighting in school and, while in detention, was raped by a 15-year-old. Last year in Alabama a 13-year-old was incarcerated for weeks for possessing what the authorities thought was marijuana but turned out to be oregano. Pre-teen-agers and young teen-agers have been sentenced to lockups for crimes like making harassing phone calls, running away from troubled homes and throwing objects in their rooms.
title: U.S. War on Children

text: Lacresha Murray's case is emblematic of a war on children that the United States appears unaware it is fighting.
title: U.S. War on Children

text: Exec. Dir., Amnesty Intl. U.S.A.
title: U.S. War on Children

text: New York, Dec. 3, 1998
title: U.S. War on Children

text: Swiss voters today decisively defeated a measure to legalize marijuana, heroin and cocaine, turning aside arguments that a Government-managed narcotics network would curb drug-related crime.
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: The proposal would have turned Switzerland into a virtual free-drugs zone, with any resident older than 18 years able to buy narcotics at state-approved pharmacies, after consulting a doctor.
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: Nearly 74 percent of voters rejected the initiative, which had been expected to fail, but not to such an overwhelming extent.
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: ''It was a surprise,'' said Francois Reusser, spokesman for the committee that launched the initiative ''for a sensible drug policy.''
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: ''Voters reacted emotionally to the heroin aspect,'' he said. However, Mr. Reusser said, he hoped that lawmakers would still consider liberalizing the use of cannabis, which federal statistics indicate is regularly consumed by about 500,000 people in Switzerland, a nation of 7 million.
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: He said the committee, backed by Socialists, medical doctors, lawyers and drug experts, would consider a new campaign to collect the signatures necessary to force a ballot vote on legalizing cannabis.
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: Government officials said the vote confirmed Switzerland's policy of battling illicit drugs. The Alpine nation has an estimated 30,000 to 36,000 hard-drug addicts, one of the highest rates in Europe.
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: The Government had warned the scheme would give unfettered access to drugs and attract drug tourists looking for easy availability. Instead of eliminating the black market, the proposal would have created a new illegal drug trade and severed Switzerland's ties to international police assistance, said Thomas Zeltner, chief of the federal health department.
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: Mr. Zeltner said Switzerland was ready to review policies on soft drugs like marijuana and hashish. The Government is proposing that new laws on drugs be drawn up next year.
title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana

text: The railroad used to rumble through the cornfields and cow pastures here, braiding this southeastern South Dakota town into a necklace linked to the commercial cosmos of Chicago.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: But the freight trains don't come this way anymore. And increasingly, amid the wild oceans of lavender pasqueflower and buffalo grass and the fields of alfalfa and soybeans, the farm towns are fading as they lose their people and their pulse.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: A lot of people here are like Ethel Mingo, a 73-year-old widow who until recently was happily ensconced at 604 Henderson Avenue, a trim, whisper-yellow house on a red gravel road at the western hem of this mile-square town.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Mrs. Mingo has affection for this community of 850 or so people, even though, she says, ''you can't even buy a towel in Armour.'' But she thought her days here might be numbered after a ruptured disk, spinal fusion surgery and a ''triple aneurysm the size of a tennis ball'' left her legs beholden to a walker and her lungs harnessed to an oxygen tank.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: She could no longer make it to the basement to do the laundry or up the mud room steps to the kitchen. She feared that a retirement home in a larger town was her only option.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: But Mrs. Mingo was just the sort of person South Dakota's maverick Governor, William J. Janklow, had in mind when he came up with a way to address his state's worst problems: rural towns faltering as family farms went under, an exodus of young people, and too many older people with homes they could no longer handle.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Governor Janklow said he thought that if he could supply the elderly with smaller homes that were easier for them to manage, they could stay in their towns and turn their larger homes over to younger families, maybe luring some new blood to the rural communities.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: ''I wanted to help the small town maintain its viability,'' said Mr. Janklow, who said his state has a high percentage of elderly -- 16 percent -- and the nation's largest proportion of small towns -- 96 percent of the state's communities have fewer than 5,000 people.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: ''If people don't have the services they need in a small town,'' Governor Janklow said, ''they'll have to go to another town. I tell people, 'Quit dreaming for a General Motors plant when you're a town of 300 people and start maintaining the economic viability of your elderly.' ''
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: To implement his plan, Mr. Janklow tapped a resource that South Dakota and other states have in great supply: prison inmates. The Governor assigned prisoners to build single-story houses, complete with accessible entrances and bathrooms for the disabled. Anyone at least 62 years old or disabled, who lives in a town with fewer that 5,000 residents, can buy one of the houses, and have it delivered from the prison, all at cost.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Mrs. Mingo bought a 768-square-foot house last year for $19,000 and had it set it on a vacant lot across the street. She sold her old three-bedroom home for $35,000 -- less than its market value -- to Warren and Pam Parker, a couple moving into town because they could not afford to keep their hog farm.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Mrs. Mingo can peer out her front window and see Mrs. Parker tending the snow-on-the-mountain flowers that she had left in the front yard. And she can still drive the several blocks to her son's drugstore on Main Street where, she does the bookkeeping.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Mr. Janklow, a 59-year-old Republican with a reputation as a stubborn prairie populist who recently stopped Canadian agriculture trucks for inspections in a protest of Federal trade policies, was elected this month to his fourth term as Governor. He served his first two terms from 1978 to 1987, and was elected again in 1994. He believes in putting inmates to work, partly, he acknowledges, because of what he calls his ''juvenile delinquent'' past, in which he shot holes in the water tower of his hometown of Flandreau. He was expelled from high school, and a judge sent him to the Marines.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: ''I'm the toughest, most hard-nosed, right-wing conservative you've ever met,'' Mr. Janklow said. ''I believe in punishment, and I believe in retribution.'' But he said he also believed in preparing inmates for their release with job training that gives them ''dignity and self-respect.''
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: South Dakota inmates wire schools for computers, put out forest fires and build hunting cabins and outhouses for state parks. They raise beetles that destroy a weed called purple loosestrife. When a tornado leveled Spencer this spring, inmates were brought to the town to help families sift through the rubble.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Under a vast sky recently, about 60 inmates at the medium-security Springfield State Prison 116 miles southwest of here pounded nails and slapped on sheet rock inside a high fence topped with razor wire. Even murderers can join the work crews, but everyone has to apply for the jobs, which pay 25 cents an hour. Virgil Miller, the construction supervisor, says 275 inmates, of about 700 in the prison, are on a waiting list.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: ''Makes the time go by quick,'' said William Eutzy, 33, who is serving a three-year sentence for forgery. Mr. Eutzy, wiring the second bedroom of a house destined for the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, has earned an electrician's apprenticeship license at the Springfield prison. ''When I get on the streets, I'm going to get back on my feet,'' he said.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: In another house, Ron Huffaker, 29, sentenced to 10 years for selling marijuana, was installing oak cabinets made by inmates at another prison. ''Every once in a while, an elderly lady will write a letter,'' he said. ''Makes you kind of feel good that it's going for a good cause.''
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: The Governor's method of quality control is to exploit that feeling. ''I tell them, 'If you don't do a good job, you've got to understand you're not hurting me, you're hurting somebody's grandma,' '' Mr. Janklow said.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Still, when the first crews of inmates proudly affixed wooden plaques beside the front door that said ''Made by the Inmates of Team 267,'' Governor Janklow said that was taking things a bit too far. ''I made them take the plaques off of the front of the houses. Now, they can put them inside the closet.''
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: The inmates have also begun to build day care centers that are sold to would-be entrepreneurs in small towns, where a shortage of child care is one reason young families leave.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Governor Janklow neutralized opposition from home builders by making sure the houses were small and built in small towns so big companies would see no profit in building them. And small contractors get work building foundations and garages or other extras for the houses.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: So far, 263 houses have been sold to elderly and disabled people in 135 small towns. In Woonsocket, Edwina and Aleck Larson bought one after Mrs. Larson lost both of her legs to illness. In Menno, Alta Herman, her memory starting to slip, set one up on her daughter's land, so she can live on her own but be close to help.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Three houses have been sold in Armour, named for the meat-packing baron and, this time of year, rising from a blanket of autumn-exhausted cornfields.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: One went to Lyle and Janice Dierks, who have lived here for 35 years. After Mr. Dierks, 63, and his wife, 57, both learned they had cancer, they began looking for something easier to manage than their aging two-story house on Main Street. After a two-year search, the Dierkses, whose son has moved away, thought they might have to move to a city, until they saw the inmate-built homes on display at a state fair.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: They sold their big house to newcomers, Mike and Beth Adam, a young couple who plan to stay until their two young children are grown and who have redecorated with Mr. Adam's hunting trophies -- white-tailed deer heads and the pelt of a sleek black bear.
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: The Dierkses' new house is 10 blocks away on the south end of Main Street, where Mr. Dierks enjoys watching the harvest bustle at the Armour grain elevator across the street. Besides, he said, ''I'm right in the middle of my fishing lakes here. I'd hate to have to give that up.''
title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans

text: Blow to Hindu Nationalists In State Elections in India
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Voters in India outraged by rising food prices handed a humiliating defeat to the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party in a series of important state elections. The party lost in Delhi, the district that includes the nation's capital, and in the Hindi heartland state of Rajasthan. In a stunning resurrection, the Congress Party kept a firm hold on power in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, the country's largest. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Mayor of Buenos Aires, Fernando de la Rua, became the favorite to replace Carlos Saul Menem as President of Argentina by winning a landslide victory in a primary election to carry the banner of the center-left Alianza opposition coalition in the next general election. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The leaders of what have been Macedonia's most radical and antagonistic ethnic political parties are forming a coalition to govern the fragile former Yugoslav state. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Plea for Pinochet's Release
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Foreign Minister of Chile pressed an effort to persuade Britain to free Gen. Augusto Pinochet, saying the Chilean Government would pursue its own judgment of the former dictator. Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Insulza said 14 cases initiated by alleged victims of General Pinochet's dictatorship are in the hands of prosecutors in Santiago. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A meeting between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators on carrying out their latest accord ended in a dispute over Israel's insistence on freeing common criminals as part of the prisoner releases required by the agreement. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The United States will pledge hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to the Palestinians this week and is pressing other wealthy nations to dramatically increase economic assistance to encourage the Palestinians to stick to the peace process with Israel, senior Clinton Administration officials said. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Deutsche Bank is expected to provide multimillion-dollar incentives to a handful of top Bankers Trust and Deutsche executives to secure their services once the German banking giant completes its $9.67 billion purchase of Bankers Trust. A12
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Swiss voters decisively defeated a measure to legalize marijuana, heroin and cocaine. A4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Saddam Hussein's half-brother, Barzan al-Takriti, told reporters in Jordan that he was not at odds with the Iraqi President. Mr. Takriti said he was on his way home to Baghdad after 10 years as an envoy in Geneva, ending speculation that he was seeking political asylum in Europe. (AP)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Plan Would Give Disabled An Easier Return to Work
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton will propose expanding Medicaid and Medicare to allow tens of thousands of people with disabilities to retain their health benefits when they return to work, Administration officials say. Under current law, many of these people must, in effect, choose between working and keeping their health insurance coverage. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Wood Heating at 20-Year Low
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: National and regional statistics show wood heating at its lowest ebb since the numbers started to be tracked 20 years ago, out-run by other cheap fuels and increasingly abandoned by older, busier householders who do not want to cut, chop, split, stack, carry, load and sweep up anymore. The nadir follows a decade of decline in the popularity of the potbellied radiance that, to many, once meant more than just cheap heat. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The chief Republican vote counter in the House, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, accused President Clinton of trying to evade perjury charges ''on a technicality,'' and became the first member of the Republican leadership to predict that Mr. Clinton would be impeached. A19
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: While warm weather brought hordes of shoppers to malls during the Thanksgiving weekend, most department store executives expressed just cautious optimism about sales for the holiday season. A20
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Tensions over race boiled over at Dartmouth College and at the University of New Hampshire this month, and administrators at both are taking a hard look at how to better foster racial diversity and respect for differences. A18
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Two portraits have emerged of a man suspected in the shooting death of a bus driver in Seattle on Friday. The suspect, Steven Gary Coole, was found dead near the bus with an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound. A man believed to be Mr. Coole has been described as seeking redemption in a crowded homeless shelter in Seattle; another person portrayed him as an angry, alcohol-swigging man waiting for a bus. Ballistics results, expected today, could identify the gun that killed the driver, the police said. A third person died, and 17 remained hospitalized. (AP)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The grim shadowboxing these days as President Jiang Zemin of China travels around Japan on a six-day visit underscores the degree to which East Asia's history dominates the present. Last month, Japan had seemed to be making major progress in laying World War II to rest. History now roils the present. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Suburban Sharpshooters In War Against Deer
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Sharpshooting is the newest tactic in the suburban war against deer. For more than a decade, as populations of white-tailed deer have exploded on the fringes of many Eastern and Midwestern cities, the overrun suburbs have tried all kinds of ways to reduce the attendant threats of deer-car crashes, Lyme disease (which is carried by deer ticks) and damage to gardens, shrubbery and forests. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: New Test for Fourth Graders
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A new reading and writing test will be given to fourth graders across New York State early next year, and it is so different from traditional tests that teachers and parents can barely contain their panic. The test has pages and pages of blank lines for children to take notes on a story read aloud, write literary criticism and craft a personal essay -- and it is given over three days. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Livent Said to Find Lenders
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Livent, the corporate producer of the Broadway musical ''Ragtime,'' has found lenders willing to provide it with more money and save it from shutting down immediately, a person close to the company said. Livent, which sought protection from its creditors in bankruptcy court earlier this month, has said that a $5 million emergency loan from a group of its directors would pay the bills only through the end of November. B3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Archbishop of Honduras, Oscar Rodriguez Maradiaga, gave thanks and appealed for more assistance at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Archbishop told of the devastation a hurricane called Mitch had wrought on his country. Bishop Leopoldo Brenes of Nicaragua also spoke. More than 10,000 people in Honduras and Nicaragua were killed. B5
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A winning amateur competitor in hockey, squash and golf who became the controversial chairman of the Mets and enjoyed mixed success, he was 94. B10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The former Representative, a Florida Democrat, was 81. He was chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee from 1984 through 1992 and helped to oversee American policy on issues like arms control. B10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: When the 900 or so remaining blue-collar workers at Mobil's largest domestic refinery in Beaumont, Tex., heard that their company was discussing a possible merger with Exxon, it was like a siren warning them that an already suspect valve might be about to blow. They have already been downsized, cut back and re-engineered. A growing American economy that can make a billionaire out of someone with an unproven idea for Internet marketing is still sloughing off workers in older industries, in petroleum as much as any. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Met Life Plans to Reorganize
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Metropolitan Life Insurance, one of the country's biggest insurers, said that it was taking the first steps toward reorganizing in a way that would turn it into a stock-based corporation and provide a windfall of as much as $14 billion for its policyholders. The money -- profits that have accumulated for decades -- will be shared, according to a complex formula, by the mutual company's 12 million life insurance policyholders, who are its formal owners. C1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Clinton Administration is scheduled to release a long-awaited Internet report that argues for stronger consumer protection and privacy rights. The report, prepared by an interagency group headed by Ira Magaziner, the Presidential adviser, serves as the foundation of the Administration's new Internet commerce policy. The report insists that its goals be achieved through self-regulation by industries rather than Government mandate. C1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: GE Capital May Buy in Japan
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: GE Capital Services, the huge financial services arm of General Electric, may acquire the leasing arm of the troubled Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. A12
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: New York routed the Carolina Panthers, 48-21; New England defeated the Buffalo Bills, 25-21, with a touchdown after time had expired. D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Editorials: Subsidy for the stock exchange; confronting an unfair census; a warm holiday gift; Steven R. Weisman on fund-raising strategies.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Swiss are voting Sunday on whether to legalize everything from marijuana to heroin and cocaine, a measure that -- if passed -- would give Switzerland the most sweeping decriminalization of drug use, possession and production in Europe.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Government officials are warning that a yes vote could turn this tranquil Alpine nation into a ''paradise for the Mafia,'' and a magnet for ''drug tourists,'' attracted by readily available hard and soft drugs.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Proponents of the drug legalization initiative, led by a group of Socialists and medical doctors, argue that it could break up Switzerland's flourishing black market in drugs and save the country millions of dollars in law enforcement.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: They propose to give every Swiss resident over 18 an electronic credit card to withdraw a specified amount of drugs. The dosage would be set in consultation with a doctor or other medical professional, but no psychological or medical treatment would be mandated. Only those younger than 18 would be required to see a drug counselor before receiving an access card.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: The card, explained a Zurich physician, David Winizki, an originator of the concept, ''would be like making a withdrawal from a bank cash terminal.''
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: ''The dose would be programmed in,'' he continued. ''The consumer would run the card with its magnetic strip through the machine and the drug store would supply, for example, a gram of heroin for 12 Swiss francs.''
