A gram of heroin or cocaine currently costs about $36 on the street and 12 Swiss francs equal about $8.70.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Under the plan, a user could withdraw drugs daily, or up to one week's supply, for an amount lower than current street rates. Dr. Winizki, who lives near the area of Zurich once known as ''Needle Park'' for its gathering of heroin addicts, said he began working on the idea in 1992 when he saw ''people dying every day from overdoses and hepatitis and that made me very angry.''
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Opinion polls indicate that only about 40 percent of Swiss support the liberalization idea. That would suggest passage is unlikely. But the drug issue pervades Switzerland, where federal statistics count between 30,000 and 36,000 narcotics addicts, most of them using heroin.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Estimates indicate that 500,000 Swiss -- of a total population of 7 million -- routinely use cannabis, and initiative supporters believe that even if their measure is defeated on Sunday, the widespread debate over it will clear the way for legalization of cannabis.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: A leading Swiss magazine, L'Illustre, found in a recent poll that even among those polled who oppose Sunday's legalization initiative, 40 percent would back the legal sale of cannabis for people over 18, and 51 percent its sale for medical purposes.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Unlike other European countries that tolerate cannabis consumption, Switzerland pursues and punishes it. Last year, four out of five arrests were for marijuana and hashish use. Penalties range from one day to three months in jail for second-time users, and up to three years for heavy users, according to the federal police.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Government officials say they fear that drug liberalization would eviscerate their efforts to address Switzerland's serious drug problem. Figures from the European Monitoring Center for Drugs and Drug Addiction in Lisbon suggest that drug use in Switzerland is among the highest in Europe, rivaled only by Italy, Spain and tiny Luxembourg in drug use per 1,000 adults.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Switzerland's drug problems were exposed when authorities experimented with open access to drugs in Zurich beginning in 1989. When drug dealing and violence escalated, Swiss officials abandoned the free needles and syringes and began an experimental program to dispense heroin to a controlled group of hard-core addicts. This controversial effort survived a ballot challenge last year, when an unexpectedly high 71 percent endorsed it.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Federal officials say they fear, though, that legalization will make it harder to curb hard drug use.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: ''Switzerland would become a paradise for the Mafia,'' Thomas Zeltner, who heads the federal health department, said.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: The country would end up isolated from international crime-fighting efforts, and money laundering would increase, Valentin Roschacher, the federal anti-drug chief, said. ''You can't fight organized crime without partners,'' he said in a telephone interview from Bern, the Swiss capital.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Mr. Zeltner noted that the number of new drug users is down, treatment is up and overdose deaths, addict-related crime and new H.I.V. cases also have decreased markedly, and urged voters not to jeopardize such gains. The poll by L'Illustre suggested support for Sunday's measure rested largely on belief that it would curb crime.
title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs

text: Jewish Organizations Fight Over Swiss Bank Proceeds
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A battle is flaring between Jewish groups, plaintiffs' lawyers and concentration camp survivors over the $1.25 billion paid by Swiss banks to settle Holocaust-related lawsuits, and potentially billions more from claims against companies in Germany, Austria and other countries. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has conducted an extraordinary purge of his innermost circle, dismissing the leaders of the army, the air force and the intelligence service as well as one of his most trusted political commissars. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Swiss Vote on Legalizing Drugs
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Swiss are voting on whether to legalize everything from marijuana to heroin and cocaine, a measure that -- if passed -- would give Switzerland the most sweeping decriminalization of drug use, possession and production in Europe. 25
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Leaders of Congo and neighboring countries giving support to armed rebels there agreed under United Nations auspices to sign a cease-fire by mid-December. President Jacques Chirac said that United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan had secured promises in meetings with eight African leaders in Paris for a summit meeting. 27
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Italy's highest court overturned jail sentences for former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi and former Interior Minister Claudio Martelli on corruption charges. The court ruled that convictions of Mr. Craxi, Mr. Martelli and two other defendants were null and void and ordered a new appeals trial for the four. (Reuters)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: For Presidential Hopefuls, Fund-Raising Has Begun
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska is engaged in the first test of the 2000 Presidential campaign: proving his ability to raise money. Like other Democratic and Republican hopefuls, he will have to raise more money than ever, at least $22 million, and earlier than ever before. So Senator Kerrey and six other Presidential aspirants have turned to so-called soft money -- large unrestricted contributions from wealthy individuals, corporations and labor unions. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The longstanding debate over affirmative action in education, for years centered on universities and professional schools, is shifting to public school districts, where an increasing number of parents -- mostly white -- are complaining about policies they say are unfair to their children. Nearly a half-century after Brown v. Board of Education, the question of whether the educational value of diversity justifies race-conscious policies in public schools is an open one, never directly addressed by the United States Supreme Court. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: As the House impeachment inquiry enters its crucial final weeks, Republicans and Democrats are jockeying for an advantage that could influence President Clinton's fate. Beginning on Monday, committee Republicans aim to shore up their case against Mr. Clinton by taking several steps, including a public hearing on the consequences of lying under oath. 47
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton highlighted two new housing programs in his weekly radio address that will provide $822 million for low-income people who are elderly or disabled. 29
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Plastic Surgery for Teen-Agers Poses a Problem for Doctors
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A generation ago, it was not unusual for some teen-agers to have their noses straightened or ears pinned back, but more controversial procedures, like breast augmentation, liposuction and tummy tucks, are gaining popularity these days in this impressionable age group. Doctors say the teen-age girls now flocking to the suites of plastic surgeons from Park Avenue to Beverly Hills pose an ethical problem. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Takeover at Troubled Union
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The parent union of District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal union, said yesterday that it was taking direct control of the council, effective tomorrow, to put an end to a spiraling scandal that has involved vote fraud and embezzlement. Gerald McEntee, president of the parent union, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, named a trustee to run the council and said that Stanley Hill, the council's executive director, was taking a voluntary unpaid leave. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, has gone to unusual lengths to explain his decision to accept Connecticut's offer to build his team a new stadium, one of the richest stadium deals any sports mogul had ever negotiated. Mr. Kraft, a native of Boston and loyal fan before he bought the Patriots, took out full-page advertisements in the Boston newspapers asking fans to understand his decision. He doesn't just want Connecticut's money; he wants to be forgiven for taking it. The situation embodies the opposing impulses -- one economic, the other emotional -- that are throwing dozens of cities into spasms of subsidized stadium construction and leaving others, deserted by their teams, wishing they had. 49
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A British psychologist who analyzed his own brush with mental illness. He was 71. 59
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Dublin drug dealer was convicted today by a three-judge panel in the 1996 murder of Veronica Guerin, a prominent journalist known for her aggressive reporting on Dublin criminals.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: The man, Paul Ward, 34, denied helping to kill Ms. Guerin but admitted that he knew drug dealers who planned to do it. He acknowledged during the trial that he also dealt in drugs.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: Mr. Ward was sentenced to life in prison. Normally there is no parole before 14 years.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: There was no jury because the case was tried in the Special Criminal Court, established out of fear that criminals and terrorists could intimidate jurors.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: Ms. Guerin, 37, was shot five times in the chest on June 26, 1996, as she sat in her car at a traffic light on the outskirts of Dublin. The killers rode a motorcycle and used a Magnum .357 pistol. Mr. Ward was accused of disposing of the gun and the motorcycle. He was the first of several suspects to be tried in the case.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: The men accused of the actual shooting and of driving the motorcycle have been arrested and face trials in the spring. Another suspect, the head of the drug gang, is in England fighting an extradition order. The names of the three are widely known; though the court has forbidden journalists to report them public, some have ignored the order.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: Mr. Ward's girlfriend, Vanessa Meehan, is the sister of one of the men in jail, Brian Meehan, according to the police, who have also identified the suspected gunman as Eugene Holland.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: The chief Government witness against Mr. Ward was Charles Bowden, who testified that he and Mr. Ward made about $500,000 each selling cannabis in a two-year period. Mr. Bowden, who was placed in a witness protection program, said Mr. Ward was intimately involved with the planning and execution of the crime.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: The court decision, read this morning by Justice Robert Barr, first attacked as unproven the police assertions that Mr. Ward had confessed to getting rid of the gun and motorcycle. The judges said that the police had violated his rights by putting unjust psychological pressure on him, and that there was evidence that they had beat him around the neck.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: The police acknowledged that they had failed to videotape or record any confession, and said they had lost the notes of its details.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: With Ms. Guerin's husband, Graham Turley, and other family members sitting in the small courtroom during the two-hour presentation of the verdict, Justice Barr initially seemed on the verge of acquitting Mr. Ward.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: But he went on to say that Mr. Bowden, though a liar and criminal, now in prison on a six-year drug and weapons sentence, should be believed in his testimony on Mr. Ward's involvement. He said that Mr. Bowden was trying ''to extricate himself when cornered by the police,'' but that his testimony was not influenced by an offer of immunity from prosecution in the killing and placement in the witness protection program, which he will enter when he finishes his drug sentence.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: ''He was at high risk of being convicted of the murder and his bargaining position would have been reduced to zero,'' the Justice continued. Asking rhetorically if there was any reason to believe Mr. Bowden was lying about Mr. Ward, Justice Barr said, ''The court can find nothing in evidence that raises such suspicion.''
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: Legal experts here had said that such uncorroborated allegations rarely lead to convictions.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: There was no immediate statement that Mr. Ward would appeal the decision.
title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying

text: The Minnesota Vikings have no secret weapon. Their big play is the bomb. Every team throws it, but none use it with such devastating results.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: ''Everyone has it in their game plan, but we throw it even when it's covered,'' said Viking quarterback Randall Cunningham, the highest-rated quarterback in the National Football League. ''We have guys who are willing to go up and get it.''
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: The Vikings (11-1), who had already clinched a playoff spot, leveled the Dallas Cowboys (8-4) today with their weapon of choice. Using four touchdown passes of 50 yards or more and a 50-yard run by Leroy Hoard, the Vikings left the Cowboys in ruins, 46-36, before 64,366 in the traditional Thanksgiving Day game at Texas Stadium. The Cowboys had been 20-9-1 in Thanksgiving games entering today.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: The rookie receiver Randy Moss caught three passes for 163 yards, and all three went for touchdowns, of 51, 56 and 56 yards. He also set up a 12-yard touchdown run by Hoard by getting a 55-yard pass-interference call in the third quarter. Moss has the ability to make every deep throw a potential highlight clip.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: ''On that little hitch that he ran, I was blocking and I heard everybody cheering; he was gone,'' Hoard said, referring to Moss's third touchdown. ''I didn't know what happened. I had to look up at the scoreboard to see the replay of what happened.''
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: The Cowboy cornerbacks are still trying to figure out what happened, and they had advance film on Moss and his teammate Cris Carter, who caught a 54-yard touchdown pass. Dallas did not have cornerback Deion Sanders in its secondary, because Sanders has an injured big toe on his left foot.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: It would have been an interesting matchup between Moss and Sanders, because Sanders has great speed. The Vikings took advantage of his absence.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: ''Any time you have a premier player like Deion out of the game, the drop-off is tremendous,'' Carter said. ''That hurt their defense today and we were definitely on our passing game. It's tough for the defense when you've got 5-10 defensive backs challenging 6-3 and 6-4 receivers.''
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: Moss entered this game with a chip on his shoulder. He was still upset with Dallas and the other 18 teams that passed on him in last April's college draft. Many teams deemed Moss a risk because his college career was spotted with charges of marijuana possession and assault. He was drafted late in the first round by the Vikings. Moss left the field with a scowl on his face and refused to speak to reporters after the game.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: At this point the Vikings are happy that Moss is on their team. His ability has added another dimension to what Viking Coach Dennis Green describes as a multidimensional offense.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: ''I haven't seen a kid come into this league this good ever,'' said Brian Billick, who has been with the Vikings since 1992 and is the team's offensive coordinator. ''Until you've faced Randy, you don't know how good he is. The Green Bay defensive backs, you could see the looks on their faces like 'I can't believe he just made that catch' when we first faced them. His size and his speed and his jumping ability; you can't duplicate that in practice. You don't know what it's like until you face it.''
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: On the Vikings' first three possessions, Cunningham threw touchdown passes of 51 yards to Moss, 54 yards to Carter and 56 yards to Moss. Moss's second touchdown reception gave him 958 yards receiving and helped him break the Viking record for most yards receiving by a rookie, which was set in 1976 by Sammy White.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: Meanwhile, the Cowboys got field goals on their first two possessions and quickly found themselves behind by 21-6 with 2 minutes 41 seconds to play in the first quarter. The Cowboys were able to take advantage of the fact that the Vikings lost running back Robert Smith to a sprained knee in the second quarter. Hoard, who is not as swift as Smith and likes to run up the middle, replaced him in the lineup.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: Without that speedy threat in the backfield the Cowboys did not fear the rushing attack and were able to gamble with blitzes against Minnesota and knock them out of their offensive rhythm.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: The Cowboys' receivers were afflicted with a severe case of the drops, not holding on to six catches they should have made in the first half. Michael Irvin, normally a sure-handed receiver, dropped two passes and looked completely out of sync.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: The Cowboys displayed their own big-play capability with a 67-yard touchdown pass from Troy Aikman to receiver Patrick Jeffers in the second quarter, but the 2-point conversion failed. After a 45-yard field goal by Gary Anderson with 16 seconds to play in the half, Minnesota led by 24-12 at the half.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: The Cowboys opened the second half with an 11-play, 76-yard drive that was capped by a 2-yard run by Emmitt Smith, who passed Jim Brown on the N.F.L. career rushing list during the game, to help make it 24-19 Vikings.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: ''Sometimes as an offensive unit you have to go punch for punch if you can,'' Emmitt Smith said. ''We tried to do that today. They got off to a fast start and we hung in there for as long as we could.''
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: Smith's third touchdown of the game, a 4-yarder with 1:06 left, tied him with Marcus Allen for most rushing touchdowns (123).
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: The Cowboys blew a great opportunity late in the third quarter after Izell Reese intercepted a Cunningham pass and returned it to the Vikings' 32. The Cowboy offense moved the ball to the 17, and there was nearly a first-and-goal from the 7 after a pass from Aikman to receiver Billy Davis.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: But the play was wiped out when Dallas guard Flozell Adams was penalized for a chop block. The 15-yard penalty moved the ball to the 32-yard line, and Dallas wound up settling for a 48-yard field goal by Richie Cunningham that made it 32-22.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: Aikman was 34 of 57 for a career-high 455 yards.
title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going

text: LYNN ZIMMER wasn't even in the same room as a marijuana cigarette until 1980, when she was 33 years old.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: By then she already had two children and was working on her Ph.D. in sociology. Somehow, as the child of working-class parents in upstate Binghamton, she had sidestepped the turbulence of her generation, and its sweetly pungent perfume.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: ''When I graduated from high school in 1965, I had never even heard of marijuana,'' she said. ''By 1967 I had a child and was taking care of my family and going to school at night, and working in a day-care center mornings. So I had no interest in the 60's. I guess I saw it on television.''
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: But for all the frenzied experimentation and generational struggle that took place outside her window back then, the debate over marijuana has only grown in intensity in the ensuing decades. And suddenly, Ms. Zimmer finds herself in its dead center. Now teaching sociology at Queens College, she has become at once an academic authority on the drug and a passionate advocate of its decriminalization.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: Ms. Zimmer's arguments about marijuana's essential harmlessness, collected in a recent book co-written with a City University colleague, Dr. John P. Morgan, have become a flashpoint in the battle over legalization, which gained steam earlier this month when five Western states voted to permit the medical use of marijuana. Groups that favor liberalizing the nation's drug laws have been promoting the book, which bears the somewhat presumptuous title of ''Marijuana Myths, Marijuana Facts,'' as a kind of bible on the subject, saying it effectively shoots down the accepted wisdom that the drug is a physically harmful gateway to crack and the abyss.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: Academic experts have been far less kind, calling it a well-researched compilation of opinion that occasionally leaves out information that might cast marijuana in a negative light. Opponents of drug use have condemned it as an invitation to surrender in the war against drugs.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: ''There's no doubt marijuana leads to trouble and I can show you 10 books that prove that for every one like the one you just showed me,'' Police Commissioner Howard Safir, a former drug enforcement agent, told MSNBC earlier this year. ''The fact that these two professors are teachers leads me to wonder if they are fit to be leading a classroom.''
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: Under Mr. Safir and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, marijuana arrests in New York have soared to record levels this year, 30 years after the drug became the token of the counterculture, and the arrests are likely to reach 40,000 by the end of the year, eight times the number six years ago. Most of those arrested are charged with possession of the drug.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: To Ms. Zimmer, all this effort is a waste of taxpayer money, a misguided extension of the quality-of-life campaign that runs counter to a growing public perception, cherished by many baby boomers, that marijuana holds little intrinsic danger.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: ''We now are getting into the adult population many more people who have had experience with marijuana,'' she said, at the dining room table of her apartment in Chelsea. ''Many have children and are concerned about their children, so they're a little ambivalent, but I think they are questioning some of the exaggerated claims about marijuana's dangers and certainly questioning the utility of putting people in jail for engaging in a behavior that 70 million people have engaged in.''
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: Some of that perception has been fostered by several large foundations that are promoting the relaxation of drug laws, and Ms. Zimmer, 51, has been the beneficiary of some of their largesse. Her book was published by the Lindesmith Center, a group funded by the financier George Soros, who has made a worldwide campaign of finding a less punitive response to drug use than the current laws. She served for a time on the board of directors of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, known as Norml, and her book is dedicated to Dr. Lester Grinspoon, the Harvard professor who serves as chairman of the Norml Foundation's board.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: MS. ZIMMER said she first became interested in the subject after conducting a study in 1986 of Operation Pressure Point, an attempt by the Police Department to rid the Lower East Side of drugs, an effort that she and others judged ineffective. She later became more interested in the various claims being made about the dangers of marijuana, most of which she determined were exaggerated, and which she attempts to debunk in her book. But in the polarized world of the drug debate, the book inevitably came to be considered a partisan argument, particularly because it rarely acknowledges any downside to marijuana.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: ''The book puts forward as many myths as it debunks,'' said Mark A.R. Kleiman, a drug policy expert at the University of California at Los Angeles, who himself favors decriminalizing possession. ''If you didn't know anything and read the book and you're not too critical about methodology, you'd be impressed. Otherwise you sort of say, come on.''
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: But Ms. Zimmer, straightforward and almost prim in her love of research and statistics, remains confident that any thorough review of the scientific literature will produce the same conclusions. And no, she said, although she did smoke the occasional joint, she never seriously indulged.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: ''I was way too busy for that,'' she said.
title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate

text: Giants defensive tackle Keith Hamilton had little comment today on his Monday arrest on a charge of marijuana possession.
title: Giants' Hamilton Apologizes

text: ''I just want to apologize to the Giants' organization and to my family and to the fans,'' said Hamilton, who was stopped for speeding on the George Washington Bridge early Monday morning. The police said they found less than an ounce of marijuana and a pipe on Hamilton.
title: Giants' Hamilton Apologizes

text: Hamilton was also charged with driving an uninsured car and driving under the influence of a controlled dangerous substance.
title: Giants' Hamilton Apologizes

text: ''I've been in the league seven years and nothing like this has happened before,'' Hamilton said. ''We'll see how it ends up.''
title: Giants' Hamilton Apologizes

text: Defensive tackle Keith Hamilton had little comment yesterday on his Monday arrest on a charge of marijuana possession.
title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK

text: I just want to apologize to the Giants' organization and to my family and to the fans, said Hamilton, who was stopped for speeding on the George Washington Bridge early Monday morning. The police said they found less than an ounce of marijuana and a pipe.
title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK

text: Hamilton was also charged with driving an uninsured car and driving under the influence of a controlled dangerous substance.
title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK

text: ''I've been in the league seven years and nothing like this has happened before,'' Hamilton said. ''We'll see how it ends up.''
title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK

text: There won't be any flashy new logo with the Browns' helmets next season. The traditional orange helmets with the brown and white stripes are here to stay as long as the team's owner, Al Lerner, is around.
title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK

text: Lerner said that not long after he bought the Browns for $530 million, he was approached by National Football League officials with design ideas on how to liven up the Browns' helmets.
title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK

text: They thought the orange helmet was passe, Lerner said. They showed us these and said it was a good idea, and I said: 'Good. They should buy a football team and put a logo on it.' '' (AP)
title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK

text: A big flashing sign spelled out ''DRUGS'' on the stage of the Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday night. And Marilyn Manson, wearing a sparkly red outfit with garters, thigh-high boots and a codpiece-thong combination that left his buttocks bare, did his parody of a preacher, declaring that God spoke to him and said that Jesus Christ invented marijuana, cocaine and LSD. Determined to offend both church and state, Mr. Manson was trying hard to hold on to his role as the corrupter of American youth. American youth may have other ideas, like treating him as mere entertainment.
title: Not Easy to Keep Being Outrageous

text: Mr. Manson is already facing the predicament of anyone who builds a career on shock value: shocks wear off fast. Two years ago, when he released ''Antichrist Superstar'' (Nothing/Interscope), he titillated fans and scandalized fundamentalists by tearing up Bibles and miming sex acts, while Internet rumors built his aura by portraying his shows as orgies of raw sex and bloody sacrifices. It was easy to miss the skepticism -- about stardom, demagoguery and the hard sell -- that was also part of the songs, and Mr. Manson thrived on the notoriety. But he couldn't top it.
title: Not Easy to Keep Being Outrageous

text: His current album, ''Mechanical Animals'' (Nothing/Interscope), revives the artifices of glam-rock. As the songs lash out against dehumanization -- from drug-induced numbness to loveless sex to media brainwashing -- the music harks back to mid-1970's David Bowie and to early disco; it's more melodic than Mr. Manson's past songs, relying on tunes as well as howling and brute force.
title: Not Easy to Keep Being Outrageous

text: Onstage, Mr. Manson wore glossy costumes and feathered accessories, not the rags and stage blood of his Antichrist act. He was using the glittery trappings of show business to decry the hollowness of a show-business mentality.
title: Not Easy to Keep Being Outrageous

text: But a clean and shiny Manson just isn't as scary as the old one, even with a band whose guitars generate sternum-vibrating power chords while the drums summon an earth-shaking stomp. (The band's drummer, Ginger Fish, had a kit with three big bass drums, although he only had two feet.) Mr. Manson's listeners are used to show business that pretends to subvert or attack insincerity and materialism; it's the gimmick behind every other youth-oriented ad campaign.
title: Not Easy to Keep Being Outrageous

text: Compared to his old battle with all authority, distress over phoniness is a relatively minor concern, and his tales of alienation and anguish don't play as well as his old hostility. That's why, although songs like ''I Don't Like the Drugs (but the Drugs Like Me)'' are antidrug, he acted as if he were flouting taboos.
title: Not Easy to Keep Being Outrageous

text: The parts of the show that drew the biggest applause were revived from the Antichrist tour, including a song with Mr. Manson walking around on stilts and long canes, looking like a giant insect, and a song where he ranted from a pulpit and tore up one more Bible. He feigned sex with his backup singers; he rubbed his codpiece. At the end of the show, he pulled down the drum kit while the other musicians abused their own instruments. And it all seemed like a rerun -- one more step on the way to Mr. Manson's appearance, circa 2005, as one of the Hollywood Squares.
title: Not Easy to Keep Being Outrageous

text: Giants defensive tackle Keith Hamilton was stopped by Port Authority police for speeding on the George Washington Bridge early Monday morning and later charged with possession of marijuana, driving under the influence of a controlled dangerous substance and possession of drug paraphernalia, according to the Port Authority police spokesman Bill Cahill.
title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge

text: Hamilton was stopped at 1:30 A.M. for driving 71 miles an hour on the westbound lower level of the bridge, where the speed limit is 45 miles an hour, Cahill said. Hamilton was not carrying a driver's license or an insurance card, and the police said they found on Hamilton a bag that appeared to contain less than an ounce of marijuana and a pipe.
title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge

text: Subsequently, it was discovered that Hamilton's car insurance had expired. He was also charged with driving an uninsured car.
title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge

text: The police said Giants Coach Jim Fassel went to the George Washington Bridge Administration Building in Fort Lee, N.J., early Monday to assist in the release of Hamilton, who posted $750 bail. All charges against Hamilton are either traffic violations or misdemeanors.
title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge

text: Hamilton is scheduled to appear in Fort Lee Municipal Court on Dec. 15.
title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge

text: Giants officials said yesterday that they did not expect Hamilton, a fourth-round draft pick of the team who emerged last year as one of the Giants better players, to be suspended by the National Football League because it was Hamilton's first offense of this kind. Hamilton could be fined and the league could order a mandatory evaluation along with treatment or drug testing.
title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge

text: The team issued a statement:
title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge

text: ''We are aware of the situation, and we have talked to Keith about it. This matter is now in the hands of the judicial system and is covered under the National Football League's Collective Bargaining Agreement, and more specifically by the league's policy and program for substances of abuse, which the Giants strongly support.''
title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge

text: The Giuliani administration is wielding its power to grant or deny permits for parades, marches and protests as a political weapon, contend several groups that say they have struggled to get permits.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The administration vehemently denies the charge, asserting that hundreds of permits are awarded each year by police and parks officials without regard to the applicants' identities or messages.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: But the groups say that to secure permits for demonstrations that are at odds with the administration's political views, they have had to agree to curtail their criticism, stage events at remote locations or sue the city.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: ''It's selective and it's politically selective,'' said Sara Flounders, a coordinator with the International Action Center, which has fought to get permits to protest against American military interventions. ''Everything is done to discourage us.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Police officials said they issue 600 to 700 parade and march permits a year and that only a fraction, perhaps 5 to 10 percent, are denied, usually because another event is already scheduled in that area on that day.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: But in four cases during the last four months, Federal judges have found fault with the way the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has handled parade and rally permits.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: One judge suggested that city efforts this fall to prevent police brutality protesters from marching down Broadway had more to do with the group's message than with the Police Department's stated traffic concerns. The city said it sought only to keep the marchers on the sidewalk, not to block them altogether.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: A second judge ruled against the city's efforts to move the so-called Million Youth March out of Harlem to a more remote location, asserting that relocating the event would hinder the organizers' ability to ''get their message out.'' The city said it was concerned only with public safety in the neighborhood, where tens of thousands of marchers were expected to converge.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Last week, a third Federal judge struck down the city's parade permit law, ruling that it was unconstitutional because it contained no deadline by which police officials must act to approve or deny an application. The judge, Leonard B. Sand, said he was particularly concerned by extensive delays in the processing of applications for marches by two groups protesting police brutality.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: In the latest ruling against the Giuliani administration's restrictions on public demonstrations, a Federal district judge ordered the city yesterday to allow an AIDS service group to march down Broadway and to hold an event at City Hall to commemorate World AIDS Day on Tuesday.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The city's Corporation Counsel, Michael D. Hess, said the city would appeal the decision by Judge Harold Baer Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The case arose when the city, voicing concerns over security and the cost of the police, denied permits for the demonstrations sought by Housing Works, a nonprofit AIDS service group that has been feuding with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The group then sued to get the permits.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Judge Baer ruled that the city had undercut its own arguments by staging much larger events recently, with far greater security risks and police costs -- like the ticker tape parades and City Hall ceremonies for the Yankees and for Senator John Glenn. The police estimated 3.5 million people attended the Yankee parade, with as many as 6,000 admitted to a rally at City Hall Plaza.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Housing Works complained that the Mayor had more concern about baseball than about AIDS. The group estimated that its own parade would draw 1,000 people, and that its City Hall event would have 50 people on the front steps and 500 in the plaza.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The judge, citing the First Amendment, wrote: ''The recent willingness by the defendants to completely shut down Broadway for a significant portion of the day casts doubt on the argument that the plaintiff's more limited parade -- where only 1,000 participants are expected -- will cause an intolerable disruption.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: In another case, members of a group that wants marijuana legalized charged that the city conspired to block their rally in Washington Square Park by lying to them about when they could apply for a permit, and then, to thwart them, prodded a community group to submit an application for the same date.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: ''We really do have an ever more provable case,'' said Floyd Abrams, a lawyer who specializes in free speech cases, ''of a city administration that appears to be making decisions on who may speak by reviewing what they have to say.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The administration says that all it has tried to suppress is public disorder by insuring that demonstrations are safe and do not clog city arteries.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: ''The Mayor is a lawyer and he is extremely respectful of the First Amendment,'' said Lorna Bade Goodman, a senior litigator with the Law Department. ''To my knowledge, the city has never denied a permit to any group. What it has tried to do is negotiate with those groups to let those groups express their views without placing an undue burden on the citizenry.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: It is hard to say conclusively whether political interference plays a role in the permit process, because it is unclear in many cases whether the traffic and safety issues that police officials routinely raise to withhold permits are bona fide concerns or just convenient concoctions.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: But Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said these concerns never take center stage when the Mayor is interested in honoring the Yankees or letting Disney stage an event. ''If Disney or Warner Brothers with Mickey Mouse and Bugs Bunny want to do something in the street,'' he said, ''it could be just as noisy and crowded, but it's all right, because it fits into his vision of what the city should be about.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The Bronx Borough President's office said the city raised bogus concerns about police manpower and traffic in 1996 to discontinue a tradition of converting a section of the Grand Concourse into a pedestrian mall on Sundays. Borough President Fernando Ferrer, who organized the event, said the permit denial was based on his own political antagonism with the Mayor. ''It didn't happen because the Mayor didn't want it to happen,'' said Clint Roswell, Mr. Ferrer's spokesman.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The police raised traffic concerns again this year when civil rights advocates sought a permit to march down Broadway to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: To assuage the police, said an organizer, William Batson, the group agreed to march down Eighth Avenue instead and to keep statements about police brutality to a minimum. But he balked, he said, when police officials asked if the April 4 march, led by clergymen, could include a short prayer service outside an adult video store on West 43d Street, an area where the city has been clearing out sex businesses.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: ''Not only did they try to restrict our speech,'' Mr. Batson said, ''they began to try to impose speech on us.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Officials of the Police Department, which gave the march a permit, called Mr. Batson's account false. ''We are not in the business of telling people what to protest,'' said Inspector Michael Collins, a police spokesman.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Members of the Million Marijuana March, the group seeking the legalization of that drug, have accused parks officials of conspiring to block their rally from Washington Square Park this year.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The group has staged a rally, calling it a smoke-in, for more than two decades, usually in Washington Square. But officials, supported by many community residents, contend that the event, which is usually accompanied by widespread marijuana smoking and dozens of arrests, has grown too large and rowdy for that site and should be moved to Battery Park.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Last year, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern wrote the group a letter saying applications for 1998 park permits would not be accepted before January. But when the group showed up in January with its application for Washington Square Park, officials said their traditional date, May 2, had been claimed weeks earlier by a neighborhood family association. ''They picked it specifically to prevent us,'' Robert McDonald, one of the marijuana advocates, said. ''And it was done in coordination with the park district.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: The director of the neighborhood group acknowledged that the idea for holding an event to supplant the smoke-in was hatched at a meeting he had with the Manhattan Parks Commissioner, Adrian Benepe, last fall. The neighborhood group's director, Robert O'Sullivan, said Mr. Benepe suggested that conditions in the park would improve if someone dislodged the yearly gathering of marijuana smokers.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: ''If you want to do something to improve your park,'' Mr. O'Sullivan recalled Mr. Benepe's saying, ''why don't you do something to get them out?''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Mr. O'Sullivan said he agreed to hold a Family Day to stress the community's commitment to the park and because the marijuana group was ''not interested in free speech but in smoking dope.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Officials denied conspiring against the marijuana group, noting that the city had a prior court ruling upholding its right to keep the group out of the park because of previous arrests and damage to the park. ''There was no reason to resort to trickery because there was no reason to think that we would not win again,'' Mr. Stern said.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: In another court case filed by the marijuana advocates this year, a Federal judge last week struck down the city law that governs parade and rally permits, asserting it was unconstitutional because it did not set a deadline by which the police must act on a permit request. Instead of appealing, which the city has done in many permit cases, officials agreed to amend the law. Soon, applicants denied permits should have more time before a scheduled event to challenge those denials in court, said Richard L. Wilson, the lawyer for the marijuana advocates.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Mr. Wilson has little time to rest on that victory. Already the city has denied his client a permit to rally next year in Washington Square Park, and Mr. Wilson plans to file a new suit this week.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Troubled by this seemingly endless stream of permit litigation, a half-dozen civil rights lawyers are discussing whether to bring a broad-based ''pattern and practices'' lawsuit charging that the city's permit policy routinely violates free speech guarantees, according to one of the lawyers, Mr. Siegel of the New York Civil Liberties Union.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: In reality, few permits are actually denied by the city. Most parades or rallies are just assigned to sites or routes that police officials usually view as less congested and protest organizers usually find too remote.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: ''What Rudy is saying,'' said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, ''is: 'We don't want you to be able to irritate anybody. We want you to be hidden where no one can see you.' ''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Some demonstrators said they did not bother to apply for permits anymore because they were convinced that, for political reasons, they would be shunted to side streets. This month, Arab-Americans protested outside the Criterion Theater on Broadway at 45th Street to denounce perceived anti-Islamic sentiments in a new thriller, ''The Siege.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: Organizers said they did not seek a permit because, considering the city's official support of the film industry, they believed that it would have been a prolonged fight.
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: ''I think they might have given us a permit,'' said Wa'il Qattan, one of the organizers, ''but for a week later at a nondescript spot.''
title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits

text: GLORIA DENARD is a jazz singer, so she knows how to improvise. Thirty-one years ago she relied more on ingenuity than income to start Manna House Workshops, an East Harlem school dedicated to jazz and dance. Grants helped her buy a five-story building on East 106th Street, where the school occupies the first two floors and the rest are rented to tenants.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: One was Jason Adams, who moved there in 1989. Last year, he became the building's handyman, giving new meaning to that job title. He was a big brother to the school's students and took them to movies or on trips to the park. He bought flowers for the ladies in the building and tucked Christmas cards under everyone's door. Using his own money, he even paid the neighborhood youths who helped him clean the building.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: Mr. Adams was killed last month in his apartment, the police said, by two young men who stole his computer and video game system and some cash. He was stabbed more than 50 times. His death has Ms. DeNard improvising again, this time as building custodian. Unable to afford a replacement, she begins her days checking the halls for litter, putting out garbage bags and tending the boiler.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: Her new tasks sap her time and energy, since she is already busy writing grant proposals, promoting recitals and handling other school activities. A few volunteers help out, but she has learned that many are jittery about venturing to the neighborhood because of fears about crime. That leaves Ms. DeNard in a bind: the negative perceptions she hoped to fight with the transforming power of music have scared off the very people who could help her.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: ''I started Manna House to show we had a culture of our own, so people would value what we had to offer,'' Ms. DeNard said. ''We've been made to feel we're inferior, but the one thing I want to say is we are beautiful people with a creative spirit who can create anything we choose. But I can't create volunteers.''
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: Although as the handyman he got a break on his rent, Mr. Adams did more in return. Friends and neighbors remembered him as always smiling and willing to help, helping carry packages, looking after the younger students or lending an artistic touch to the classroom where neighborhood people gathered on Saturday nights for jukebox dances.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: ''He designed all the Christmas decorations,'' Ms. DeNard said. ''He designed a tree from lights that he put up on the wall. Just like you see downtown in the department stores.''
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: Whenever people passed by the building they waved to Mr. Adams. He was in front early each day to sweep away the scattered remains of cigars that had been gutted and stuffed with marijuana the night before by the get-high crowd right in front of the signs that read ''Say No to Drugs'' and ''No Trespassing.'' Perhaps he was too trusting, but he refused to think the neighborhood was beyond hope. He told Marjorie Roberson, Ms. DeNard's assistant, that everyone could change for the better.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: ''I asked him why he spent so much time with young kids,'' Ms. Roberson said. ''He said he wanted to keep them off the street, since they were not working and had time on their hands.''
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: PERHAPS the sight of some of those youths on the street kept volunteers away. They would not have seen the countless young people who have learned jazz and dance at the school and have gone on to appear on stage, in movies or in concert with musicians like Miles Davis or Lena Horne. Some do come by, but make a polite excuse and never come back. It has turned Ms. DeNard into a volunteer herself, since she pays herself a monthly stipend of only $150 so that her teaching staff won't have to take a pay cut.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: ''People don't express how they really feel,'' Ms. DeNard said. ''Who knows how many people have stayed away from working here because of what happened?''
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: Some people have suggested she move her school to someplace less threatening, but Ms. DeNard refuses even to consider a move that would be tantamount to admitting defeat. Instead, she is trying to find a way to finish some of the work Mr. Adams left undone: hallways that need painting, walls that need to be stripped, mailboxes that have to be replaced.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: One task remains. In a few days she will put a plaque in the lobby in honor of Mr. Adams, a friend, neighbor and employee who came and never left. She plans to put a spotlight on it, so people can see it from the street when they walk by. Maybe a few will stop.
title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.

text: A brief article in Science Times on Tuesday referred incorrectly to a research study on the medical uses of marijuana. The study, by Dr. Donald Abrams of the University of California at San Francisco, involves AIDS patients, not cancer patients. Participants in the study continue to take a regimen of anti-H.I.V. therapies; they are not required to forgo them. Recruitment for the study has been going as expected; it has not been difficult.
title: Corrections

text: Lawrence Gould used to settle into his midcourt seat at the old Coliseum in Cleveland as if it were a favorite easy chair. It was comfortable and familiar, and it made it easy to sit through a Cavaliers loss, no matter how lopsided, as long as he was surrounded by the friends he had been cheering beside for two decades.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: But like many teams in the National Basketball Association, the Cavaliers found it hard to resist the allure of fancier digs to woo the corporate dollar. The Gund Arena, a handsome structure that helped provide a facelift to downtown Cleveland, was opened in 1994. Soon Gould found himself in a plush $90 club seat in an arena filled with enough amenities to please a technophile.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: A Jumbotron looms over center court. In each corner, a ''Fanimation'' board, with color animation, provides game statistics. And yet, everywhere Gould looked, there were empty seats. Seats that had been sold but were vacant nonetheless because the businesses that bought them weren't what Gould called ''fans at the heart.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: To Gould, the current N.B.A. lockout -- a nearly five-month-old dispute over how wealthy owners and players will divide $2 billion in annual revenue -- only solidifies what many fans seem to feel: the league has sold its soul. The focus on money, whether by owners, the league or its athletes, has alienated fans and created a divide between them and a sport that has thrived for two decades on the popularity of its well-marketed stars. Suddenly the sport that boasts the slogan ''I Love This Game'' has left its fans asking themselves this question: What's to love?
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: Although he was there when the Cavaliers came into the league in 1970, Gould will not be at the games when the lockout ends. Gould did not renew his season tickets, because he has had enough.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''I used to buy and send my granddaughter things,'' Gould said, referring to Cavaliers merchandise. ''I don't anymore because I don't have the attachment to the team now. I just don't have it. It's the whole climate, which has become so money-oriented. I know it's a business. But to me, they've done something that might seriously affect the golden goose, the fans. Believe me, I'll go on living.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: While owners and players finally began compromising during talks on Friday, moving closer to a new collective bargaining agreement that would most likely allow games to begin in January, recent polls have shown that the average fan does not care if the N.B.A. season is canceled.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: A New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted in late October asked 1,118 adults about their level of interest in professional basketball, and only 13 percent said they were ''very'' interested while another 26 percent said they were ''somewhat'' interested.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: In an ESPN poll conducted Oct. 31-Nov. 1, just before games would have begun, 63 percent of sports fans and 37 percent of N.B.A. fans said they would not care if the season were canceled. In the same poll, 47 percent of N.B.A. fans said that if the lockout ended, they would attend fewer games, and 26 percent said they would watch fewer games on television.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: Perhaps the fans just don't miss it yet. But most people involved in the game believe there is more to it than that.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: A Lot of Resentment Among the Public
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''I think the general public, to an extent, resents athletes making large sums of money and being irresponsible while making it,'' said the veteran Knicks forward Buck Williams, a former president of the players union.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''They've had it up to their necks because they look at the image and see a lot of players getting into trouble. In the past, David Stern had Magic Johnson and Larry Bird to portray a wholesome image of, 'You'll be safe if you come to a game; it'll be a good experience and your kids will learn lessons about life from players they look up to.' Now, when they bring a kid to a game, who knows what they'll be subjected to?''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: Fans are turned off by the profanity from players, and even some coaches, during games. They have recoiled at the sight of scratch marks left on the throat of P. J. Carlesimo, coach of the Golden State Warriors, by the hands of one of his players, Latrell Sprewell. They have been angered when a player like Robert Horry throws a towel in his coach's face. They have been disappointed as players drive away from autograph seekers in their luxury cars and mystified by owners who continue to pay them an average of $2.6 million a year.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: They have grown detached from the very players who used to be the league's biggest selling point. That was the marketing genius of N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern. He helped transform a sport on the edge of collapse during the 1970's -- when the league's image was tainted by cocaine use among athletes -- into a pop-culture success story by marketing players as wholesome stars. But some are not living up to that billing.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''No question that Billy Hunter'' -- the union's executive director -- ''and the players are addressing some of these image issues in terms of marijuana and other off-court problems that they've had in the past,'' Williams said. ''But the N.B.A. has to do a better job in picking the players they market. They just can't market a guy because he's a good basketball player.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: Not every neophyte wonder deserves what Michael Jordan has earned. With his agent, David Falk, as the architect of his every commercial move, Jordan became not only the sport's greatest player, but also a league pitchman who transcended racial boundaries. But over the last few years, that sort of mass appeal has not been enjoyed by everyone in the league.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''There are some underlying racial issues,'' said Nick Anderson, a guard for the Orlando Magic. ''You look in the arenas and the fans are mostly white. Not everyone, but a few people see me with a nice watch and nice car and they think, 'Oh, he looks like he sells drugs.' It makes me feel terrible. You can't always tell what people think, but you know there's some resentment and bias because of the money.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''I think that can change, though. Players can reach out more. I've seen fans ask for an autograph and get told, 'Get out of my face.' But I've also seen fans approach in disrespectful ways. It has to go hand in hand. There has to be a mutual respect. But I feel we do have to do something to get the fans back when the lockout ends. Guys who used to not stop for autographs have to stop now.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: Some players are more approachable than others. Perhaps no N.B.A. player has been as visible as the free agent All-Star center Jayson Williams, the league's one-man relief effort. He has popped up on the set to amuse David Letterman's audience, and has been a guest star on ABC's ''Spin City.'' Less illuminated are his frequent appearances at local schools.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''I'm out there because I care about this game,'' said Williams, who was active in the community before he gained All-Star status with the Nets last season. ''We have a lot of knuckleheads in this game, and I used to be a knucklehead. A few years ago, I realized I could turn it around. Maybe if a kid sees me on a TV doing this or that, they'll watch a game.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''We're going to need some new fans, because we've ticked off the old ones. And they should be ticked off. They stuck with basketball in the 70's when it was drug-infested and no one was playing defense. Now, sports in general has become so 'me-me-me' that it ticks off the average person.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: Sports fans have been rankled before and returned. Major League Baseball left fans outraged when a strike forced the cancellation of the 1994 World Series. When players went on strike in August 1994, polls showed that 65 percent of fans had a lower opinion of Major League Baseball because of the strike.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: Slowly, baseball fans began to feel better about their sport. The healing process was accelerated this season by the home run chase between two embraceable sluggers, Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa. Both affable and grateful, they were like homing devices for fans lost during the strike.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''I had said the year before this past one that baseball was in the early stages of recovery,'' said Bud Selig, the commissioner of baseball. ''During spring training this year, I felt that we were in the middle. So, yes, what happened this season surprised me. But you have to have a little luck along the way. Our luck was having great races. We had McGwire and Sosa, and we had the Yankees' amazing season. There was Ken Griffey Jr., and David Wells pitching a perfect game. All of this was helpful. No question about it.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: History also helped. Unlike the N.B.A., baseball stirs the passion of fans because of its rich tradition and storied heroes. Baseball has inspired poetry and songs. Through the Depression, wars and natural disasters, baseball has provided a shoulder to lean on.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: If baseball is a part of Americana, what is the N.B.A.? Just a space filler?
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''It's like you wake up and get your same cup of coffee and doughnut in the same shop every morning, and those are habit businesses,'' Jayson Williams said. ''Right now, I think it's to the point that when this doughnut shop is closed, you can go right down the street to another one. In our case, you can go to college basketball. And maybe it's not that much out of the way.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''We're not in as much demand as we'd like to think we are. For a while, we were there. We had great athletes and great promoters of the game. Now we're off the map because we're not playing. A fan who is already feeling the sting of paying $10,000 on season tickets may decide to spend that money on something else. Maybe they'll go on a romantic cruise or spend that money on their kids. Maybe those people are saying, 'Why would I go back to the N.B.A.?' If that's the case, we'll have a problem.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: Just how big a problem may depend on the length of the lockout. Even if there is a quick resolution this week, the league will need a month's window to sign free agents and hold short training camps. An abbreviated season would probably not start until January.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''Assuming the lockout ends, I think the N.B.A. will have a quicker road to recovery than baseball did because there was no World Series, or what's comparable to that, lost in the process,'' said Richard Lapchick, the director of the Center for the Study of Sports in Society at Northeastern University. ''NBC doesn't even begin coverage until Christmas, and that's when, mentally, the season begins in all but the fanatical fan's mind.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: A schedule of 60 games may, in fact, be fine with some fans. Perhaps the long-running attitude about N.B.A. games -- you can show up for the last five minutes and not miss anything -- is reflected in the fans' nonchalant attitude toward the lockout.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''I think people might have a different attitude come January or February,'' said Steve Rosner, executive vice president of Integrated Sports International, a New Jersey sports marketing firm. ''I think the really big winner in this whole thing will be college basketball. When the N.B.A. season does start, the fans will have to decide if they want to go back and view the pro game.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: To the hard-core fan, there is no equal to the level of play in, and the entertainment provided by, the N.B.A. To the disenchanted, the lack of attention paid to the average fan by both owners and players discourages them from putting their money into the sport, via tickets or merchandise.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''It's gotten to the point where people are attaching their sense of decent values to players they used to look upon as heroes,'' Lawrence Gould, the Cavaliers fan, said. ''And they are not so much heroes anymore. The money side of it has detracted from the hero worship of players.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: ''The corruption of money, from all ends, has taken away from the sport. There seems to be such a disregard for fans. And that's a tragedy for everyone.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin

text: EDUCATORS and legal experts across Connecticut say that a recent ruling by a state hearing officer holding that the town of Trumbull school officials can expel an 18-year-old star athlete for an off-campus offense could set a precedent for other school districts.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: The student, Christopher Weiner, was convicted of sexually assaulting a female student, somewhere off the school grounds.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: In upholding the school board's decision to expel the student, who wanted to return to Trumbull High School for his senior year, the hearing officer, F. Owen Eagan, a former United States Magistrate, stated that Mr. Weiner's return would pose a ''serious disruption'' to the educational process.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: Mr. Eagan said in a 19-page decision that school officials provided ''a strong showing of factual link between the defendant's conduct and the day-to-day operations of Trumbull High School.''
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: Educators and legal experts said establishment of that link was the key to the decision.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: The state's Supreme Court had ruled this summer that in order to expel a student for behavior off-school grounds, school districts must show a ''clear and direct'' connection between the behavior and its impact on the school.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: ''This decision should set a standard in Connecticut and even beyond our state,'' said the Trumbull Associate Superintendent of Schools Ralph Iassogna. ''Our success should help other districts to avoid potentially dangerous situations involving the return of certain students to school.''
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: Mr. Iassagna said the decision ''sends a message that this kind of behavior on or off school grounds cannot and will not be tolerated.''
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: School officials around Connecticut said the ruling was crucial because they feared that if the decision went against Trumbull there would be a question of whether any off-campus act could be used as the basis for an expulsion.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: ''School administrators were extremely apprehensive about this case and we were watching it very closely because of its potentially far-reaching implications,'' said Patrice McCarthy, deputy director and general counsel for the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education, which represents 144 of the state's 166 school boards.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: Ms. McCarthy said that since the Supreme Court ruling this summer ''school districts have been far more reluctant'' to pursue expulsions for off-campus behavior. ''But this case should re-assure everybody that as long as they meet the standards established by the court, they will be able to expel students they deem to be dangerous or disruptive,'' Ms. McCarthy said.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: Mark Stapleton, who heads the state Department of Education's Office of Legal and Government Affairs, agreed that the decision should help schools officials, as long as they meet the standards set by the higher court this summer.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: ''The Supreme Court decision sent the message that you can't just expel students because you don't like their behavior off-school grounds, you have to present a strong case that clearly proves the student's presence to be seriously disruptive,'' Mr. Stapleton said. ''Trumbull can serve as a model.''
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: In the Trumbull case, Mr. Weiner, a standout member of the football and wrestling teams, wanted to attend his senior year at Trumbull High while out on appeal bond after being convicted this summer of sexually assaulting a 14-year-old female student at a party in 1997.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: Until the state Supreme Court ruling this summer schools had considerable leeway and desecration in expelling students for off-campus acts which they determined endangered students and staff at their schools.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: After the court ruling educators said they were confused at how much discretion they still had.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: The court's ruling was in response to a Thomaston case last year in which a Superior Court judge reversed a lower court's decision and ruled Connecticut's policy allowing school districts to expel students for a wide range of off-campus behavior was ''unconstitutionally vague.''
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: That case involved a Thomastan High School senior Kyle Packer, who was expelled for possession of two ounces of marijuana off school grounds. Mr. Packer was allowed back in school, where he graduated with honors in June.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: In the Trumbull case, Mr. Eagan decided that Mr. Weiner's sexual assault conviction does constitute a ''serious disruption'' to the educational process at Trumbull High School.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: He said the disruption existed at Trumbull High School and at an alternate school, which Mr. Weiner has attended since the start of the school year because at least one student has refused to attend the program as long as Mr. Weiner is there.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: Legal experts cautioned that the case may not be over yet. Mr. Weiner's lawyer, Frederick Paoletti, of Bridgeport, said he is planning to file an appeal in Superior Court asking the court for a temporary injunction that would allow his client to return to school and its athletic programs because barring him from school ''is a clear violation of his constitutional rights.''
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: ''I don't see how this decision can possibly hold up at the Superior Court level because it has the same problems as in the Packer case,'' said Mr. Paoletti. ''This was a sexual act that we still maintain was consensual that occurred off school grounds. I do not believe the school board showed a direct link between that behavior and a disruption to the school.''
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: Trumbull school officials say the two cases are far different in part because Mr. Weiner was convicted of an act of violence and because Mr. Weiners' supporters and detractors among both students and parents were sharply divided.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: '''We did not take the action to punish the student, but rather because of the devastating impact his return was having on the entire school system,'' said the school board vice chairman Arthur Kaiser. School officials also pointed out that Mr. Weiner, who is free pending an appeal of his conviction, will receive 10-hours of homebound instruction and will have the opportunity to graduate on time in June, though he will not be permitted to attend graduation ceremonies.
title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld

text: People who hold views unpopular with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his administration routinely have to go to court to win the right to hold marches in New York City. This week a Federal District Court judge struck down the city's parade permit law as unconstitutional. Judge Leonard Sand found that the law violated First Amendment rights because it sets no time limits on when the Police Department must act on a permit request.
title: Judicial Protection of Civil Rights; Delays in Parade Permits

text: In reviewing more than 20 parade requests, the court found that some groups got a quick response. But others were made to wait for weeks or months before getting an answer. In the case before the court, the Million Marijuana March Organization sought a parade permit last January and was finally denied the request in April. The court was particularly disturbed by the delayed treatment of two requests to march against police brutality. The lack of a time frame creates the danger that delay could be used to censor speech.
title: Judicial Protection of Civil Rights; Delays in Parade Permits

text: This is the third time in four months that Federal judges have ruled against Mr. Giuliani for suppressing constitutionally protected protests. The Mayor's impulse so far has been to lambaste the Federal judges making the rulings. Now that the ordinance has been invalidated, he had better turn his energies toward creating a process that safeguards the free-speech rights of his critics.
title: Judicial Protection of Civil Rights; Delays in Parade Permits

text: Arrests on marijuana charges have jumped to a record number this year, driven by the Giuliani administration's ''zero tolerance'' approach that has police officers pursuing anyone found possessing, selling or smoking even small amounts of marijuana.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: At its current pace, the New York City Police Department could arrest as many as 40,000 people by the end of the year on charges of possessing or selling marijuana, according to police statistics. That would be eight times the number of arrests just six years ago.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana
