text: The soaring tally is the result of routine sweeps by plainclothes police details through drug-dealing locations and unprecedented undercover efforts in which officers pose as street-corner ''smoke sellers'' to catch marijuana buyers, police officials said.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: The initiatives, part of a continuing assault on misdemeanor crimes that police officials credit for curtailing more serious offenses, have already led to the arrest of 31,330 people on marijuana charges for the first 10 months of this year. A vast majority of those arrested in the first half of the year -- 80 percent -- were accused of possessing, not selling, the drug.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: The surge in arrests is a drastic departure from the days, not so long ago, when smoking a marijuana cigarette in public often drew no more than an angry glare from a police officer.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: ''I don't think there is more marijuana on the street today,'' said Jack Ryan, the chief assistant District Attorney in Queens. ''There is probably less. But you don't have a situation anymore where you can smoke a joint on the subway and, if you do get caught, the cop just says, 'Throw it away.' ''
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: Most of those arrested today are held for arraignment and can spend 16 to 36 hours in custody before being released, in sharp contrast to the past, when those arrested on low-level possession charges were often given a summons and not taken into custody. Some critics called the tougher marijuana policy Draconian and inefficient.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: ''It is a waste of resources, a colossal waste,'' said Gerald Lefcourt, a criminal defense lawyer who serves on a legal committee for the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, or Norml, which seeks to end the criminal prohibition of marijuana. ''Most of the people who are arrested for marijuana are no threat to anybody.''
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: The increasing number of arrests in New York is part of a national trend by law enforcement agencies to curb marijuana use, which the Federal Government contends is a greater health threat than previously believed, especially regarding respiratory ailments, a position that some scientists challenge. Nationally, the number of marijuana arrests has nearly doubled to 642,000 in 1996, from 1992.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: National surveys indicate that marijuana use is up, but the increase is not nearly as steep as the surge in arrests. According to a University of Michigan study last year, half the high-school seniors surveyed nationwide said they had tried the drug, up from a third who said they had used it six years ago.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: In New York, the increase in arrests grew out of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's pledge last year to make the fight on drugs, including marijuana, a major goal of his second term. The city's efforts have been particularly visible in Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village. The park once resembled a farmer's market for marijuana sales, but now has its own police command post and is monitored by closed-circuit cameras.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: ''The community in general is tired of walking through the park and being hassled by having someone yelling 'Smoke, smoke' at them,'' said Arthur Strickler, district manager of Community Board 2 in the Village.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: So far this year, marijuana arrests have surpassed the previous record of 27,264 people in 1997, the police said. ''We have changed the traditional strategy,'' said Chief Martin O'Boyle, commander of the Organized Crime Control Bureau, which oversees drug enforcement efforts. He said officers now concentrate more on sting operations against buyers and less on having undercover officers buy from marijuana dealers, who even when caught do little jail time. ''Now we try to discourage the customers,'' Chief O'Boyle said.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: Although the arrest numbers are way up, those charged with misdemeanor possession of marijuana do not face more severe penalties. First offenders caught with as much as several ounces of the drug -- which sells for roughly $125 per ounce depending on the strength -- are eligible for a probation program known as adjournment contemplating dismissal, in which charges are dismissed if a defendant stays out of trouble for a set period of time.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: During the last six months, for example, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said that of 4,866 defendants whose low-level-possession cases were disposed of at arraignment, 63 percent were adjourned contemplating dismissal.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: But by the time the defendants were arraigned, several criminal defense lawyers said, their clients had already spent half a day or more in custody, being fingerprinted, strip-searched and checked for possible outstanding arrest warrants.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: ''We call that doing your jail time up front,'' said Tony Elitcher, a staff lawyer with the Legal Aid Society's criminal defense division. ''You are doing your sentence before you ever get in front of the judge.''
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: Even if the amount of marijuana involved is minuscule, police officials said, the warrant and fingerprint checks made on those arrested often turn up more serious offenses.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: Also, said Chief O'Boyle: ''We should not be in a position of determining who we arrest for breaking the law. We have to treat all of these folks equally.''
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: Court officials said that channeling everyone accused of misdemeanor offenses, such as marijuana possession, through the booking system had put a strain on the Criminal Court, although they said more efficient procedures had prevented the system from becoming overloaded.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: ''We are asking the Legislature for an increase of 23 judges citywide to address the larger caseloads,'' said Mai Yee, a spokeswoman for the Office of Court Administration.
title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana

text: A Federal judge struck down New York City's law governing permits for parades and rallies yesterday, saying it was unconstitutional because it lacked firm guidelines for when the police must respond to requests for permits.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled that the city law violated First Amendment guarantees of free speech because, without safeguards like specific time limits for a response to applications, the law does not sufficiently restrict the risk of censorship by city officials.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: The decision came in a case brought by a group called the Million Marijuana March Organization, which had applied unsuccessfully for a parade permit early this year to lobby for decriminalizing marijuana use.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: The decision is the third by a Federal judge in the last four months that has faulted the Giuliani administration's handling of parade permits.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: Previous court rulings on such permits took issue with the way the city had applied the law. Judge Sand's ruling yesterday was the first to declare the law itself unconstitutional.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: The latest decision came as New York was honoring Senator John Glenn with a parade up lower Broadway that was planned and approved within just a few days last week. Judge Sand, who made no reference to yesterday's event in his 29-page decision, said the fundamental defect of the city's approach was that, without time limits, the city had complete control over how quickly it chose to respond to requests for permits. He said the Police Department sometimes granted such requests rapidly, while other applicants, like the marijuana march organizers, often endured months of delays.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: The judge said he was ''particularly troubled'' by extensive delays in the Police Department's handling of two requests earlier this year for parades to protest police brutality.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: ''A scheme such as this one, where the Police Department may routinely grant applications either immediately or only after extensive delays, is dangerous precisely because it lacks consistency and predictability,'' Judge Sand wrote.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: ''The absence of standards, whether in the text of the statute or by the creation of consistent practice,'' the judge continued, ''hinders a reviewing court's ability to determine whether content-based considerations have infected the permit application process and results in a danger of censorship that the First Amendment does not tolerate.''
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: The case involved a request filed last January by Robert MacDonald, a member of the Million Marijuana March Organization, for a permit to hold a parade from Washington Square Park up Fifth Avenue to 96th Street on May 2 of this year. After the Police Department failed to respond to the permit request for two months, Mr. MacDonald filed his lawsuit on April 1. The city denied the permit six days later, offering an alternative route, said Mr. MacDonald's lawyer, Richard L. Wilson. The parade never took place.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: In the suit, Mr. MacDonald argued that the permit law was unconstitutional because it represented a prior restraint on speech. Judge Sand ruled in June against two of Mr. MacDonald's claims, saying that the city's law did not put excessive discretion in the hands of the Police Commissioner and that it did not restrict free speech based on the speech's content.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: But Judge Sand had reserved decision in June on Mr. MacDonald's third assertion: that the absence of time limits for the Police Department's response to parade applications risks the indefinite suspension of permissible speech.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: In his ruling yesterday, the judge analyzed 30 parade requests in the last two years. He said that in most instances, the police gave a timely response to applications. But he also noted a half-dozen instances in which groups filed requests months before a planned event, only to receive a response from the police a day or two before the scheduled parade.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: Judge Sand said he was particularly troubled by the Police Department's handling of two marches to protest police brutality.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: A group called the Coalition Against Police Brutality was denied a request to parade on March 30, the day before the planned event, the judge said.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: In the other case, a group called the October 22nd Coalition waited more than a month for the police to reject its application to march against police misconduct on Oct. 22. The group filed a lawsuit, and Judge John S. Martin Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan ordered the city to grant the parade permit, saying the delay in responding to the application was ''unconscionable'' and gave rise to the inference that the delay was caused by the content of the group's message.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: City officials declined to respond to yesterday's decision.
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: Marilyn Mode, a spokeswoman for Police Commissioner Howard Safir, said, ''We have just received Judge Sand's decision, and we're reviewing it.''
title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades

text: On a weekday afternoon in 1992, Sunny Cloud, an insurance saleswoman and single mother in Marietta, Ga., dropped by her home unexpectedly and found her 16-year-old son, Ron, smoking marijuana. Stunned, Ms. Cloud hustled the boy off to the nearest hospital emergency room, where she asked doctors to screen his urine.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: ''I was scared,'' she said recently, ''and I didn't know what else to do.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: The procedure was expensive, and embarrassing. So Ms. Cloud, still suspicious of her son, decided to do her own drug tests, sending him into the family bathroom in boxer shorts with instructions to come out with a cup full of urine that she could ship to a local laboratory for analysis.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: That is how Ms. Cloud began a cottage industry: the home drug testing business. As more teen-agers experiment with illicit drugs, a small but growing roster of companies, including Parents Alert, founded by Ms. Cloud in 1994, are marketing drug testing kits to parents. Last month, the Food and Drug Administration approved the latest of these kits, the QuickScreen at Home Drug Test made by Phamatech, a San Diego manufacturer of diagnostic tests. The company bills its product as the first to give parents a result at home. Phamatech says that when the kit hits drug stores in December, screening for marijuana, cocaine, LSD or heroin will be as simple as taking a home pregnancy test.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: But while advocates of the kits describe them as lifelines for parents struggling to keep their teen-agers away from illicit drugs, critics warn that the tests will turn parents into detectives, undermining the fragile trust essential in guiding children through the tumultuous teen-age years.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: ''If parents want the illusion of control, then I think they should scamper out and buy this kit and use it,'' said Dr. Daniel H. Gottlieb, a family therapist in suburban Philadelphia and an adviser to the Federal Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration. ''On the other hand, if they want a good relationship with their child, they need to talk to their child to find out what is going on in that child's life.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: Teen-age use of illicit drugs has risen steadily over the past six years, according to Monitoring the Future, a study by the University of Michigan that has examined drug abuse among high school seniors every year since 1975. Among the graduating class of 1992, 27.1 percent had used an illegal drug in the year before the survey; by last year, the figure had jumped to 42.4 percent. In 1997, Nearly half of 12th graders had tried marijuana by the time they graduated; 8.7 percent had tried cocaine; 13.6 percent had tried LSD and 2.1 percent had tried heroin.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: But those figures, while alarming, do not mean that drug dependency is rampant among teen-agers. Dr. David T. Feinberg, a child psychiatrist and expert in addiction at the University of California at Los Angeles, estimates that 5 percent of American teen-agers are addicted to drugs. Parents, he said, need to be able to tell dependency from the ''normal experimentation,'' that is part of the rite of passage to adulthood, a distinction a drug test cannot make.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: ''Parents should not be performing medical tests on their kids,'' Dr. Feinberg said. Nor, he added, should pediatricians. ''The way to determine if a kid has a drug problem is the way to determine if a kid has any problem, first by taking a history, then a physical,'' Dr. Feinberg said. Moreover, Dr. Feinberg says, the tests do not always tell the truth. Eating a poppy seed bagel can render a urine test positive; so, too, can taking certain over-the-counter cold remedies. The new test marketed by Phamatech cautions parents that while a negative result is proof that a child is not using drugs, a positive result is not conclusive and must be confirmed by a laboratory.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: ''Some people have said, 'Don't you think this is like Big Brother watching you?' '' asked Carl Mongiovi, Phamatech's director of operations and regulatory affairs. ''Neither myself nor my company is interested in getting into the family unit, telling people how to do things. But parents seem to need some help.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: Mr. Mongiovi and other proponents of the tests, including officials at the National Parents' Resource In Drug Education, a nonprofit group based in Atlanta, say talking with young people about drugs is hardly as easy as Dr. Feinberg and others suggest. They argue that when parents have suspicions that a child is using drugs, testing may be a good way -- in some cases, the only way -- to start a truthful dialogue.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: ''Many parents that I have talked to feel that it is hard for them to discuss this with their adolescents,'' said Dr. Herbert Kleber, medical director of the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University. ''These tests can help deal with that issue, if they are used as part of the communication between parent and child. If they are used as a club, they are going to cause harm.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: The kits come in various forms. Ms. Cloud's version, the Parents Alert Home Drug Test Service, sells for $44.95 and includes a urine collection bottle, a prepaid courier package to send to the lab and the toll-free number of a drug counselor. She says the counseling is essential. ''A drug test is just a tool,'' she said. ''It gives you information. What most people don't know is what to do with the information.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: Phamatech's test is designed to eliminate the laboratory, as much as possible. The company says its kit, which will cost between $25 and $35, will tell parents in about 10 minutes if their children are free of drugs. It is already used by employers.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: For those who do not like the idea of urine tests, there is an at-home hair analysis kit, marketed by the Psychemedics Corporation, a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass. Psychemedics bills the product as ''designed for parents concerned about drug abuse.'' The hair test costs $59.95, and has the advantage of surprise: A parent can take a snip of hair while a child is sleeping.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: It is difficult to determine how many of these kits are sold each year; most of the companies involved will not divulge sales figures. But Ken Adams, the owner of Parents Home Drug Testing, a company that is doing a brisk business selling unlicensed tests over the Internet, says he sells 1,000 kits a month. Dr. Bruce Burlington, director of the Center for Devices and Radiological Health at the F.D.A., said several companies have requested approval for tests similar to Phamatech's.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: Although Mr. Adams says his company operates in a ''gray area,'' Dr. Bruce Burlington of the F.D.A. says the food and drug agency considers the sale of unlicensed tests illegal. ''We are in the process right now of weighing what actions we should take,'' he said.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: The companies marketing these tests advocate that parents set up a ''family drug policy.'' ''Start when they are 11 or 12,'' Mr. Adams suggested. ''Say that part of the family drug policy is that there is going to be random drug testing. That doesn't mean I don't love you and I don't trust you. It means that this thing is too serious to take a chance.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: Mr. Adams and Ms. Cloud both argue that the at-home tests can give adolescents an easy out -- ''a good excuse to say no to peer pressure,'' in Ms. Cloud's words. Her son, Ron, now a 22-year-old junior at the University of Georgia, agrees. He said he smoked his first marijuana cigarette in the eighth grade, and by 10th grade he was smoking marijuana and taking LSD regularly.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: ''His grades slipped,'' Ms. Cloud said. ''He started getting belligerent.'' Mr. Cloud said that he stopped using drugs several years ago, after some ''major spiritual revelations'' that began four years ago, when he was a senior in high school. He said he had attended a concert by the heavy metal group Nine Inch Nails, had taken LSD and ''was pretty far out there.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: ''I felt like I was going into the depths of hell,'' he said. After the concert, he went home and woke up his mother. ''I told her I was sorry for the torture I was putting her through.'' Subsequently, he said, he turned to religion.
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: Although he initially resented the drug tests his mother forced him to take, Mr. Cloud said that they did ''play a role in putting me down a good path.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: ''I knew that I couldn't go out and get crazy.''
title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home

text: VITAL SIGNS: PRO & CON
title: Marijuana Votes: Bane or Benefit?

text: Q. Voters in Alaska, Arizona, Nevada, Oregon and Washington have approved initiatives to legalize marijuana for medical use. Does this application encourage marijuana abuse? ALISHA BERGER
title: Marijuana Votes: Bane or Benefit?

text: To answer that, you have to assume that there is medical marijuana. There is no scientific proof of that yet. It has not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration, and there have been no reputable studies that propose to demonstrate marijuana's medicinal qualities.. It has not gone forward because Dr. Donald Abrams at the University of California at San Francisco, who is conducting the only accepted study, has to recruit subjects for a double blind study. But the only thing participants can take while battling AIDS or cancer is marijuana. Naturally, participants' willingness is limited. In one study that compared marijuana to Marinol -- the active ingredient in the marijuana plant -- patients preferred Marinol. It is premature to refer to medicinal marijuana. The seduction of medical marijuana makes it seem that marijuana is both harmless and beneficial. That sends a bad message and encourages abuse. In the 1970's, Alaska allowed home use of marijuana. There was a marked increase of use by young people and a rise in child crime.
title: Marijuana Votes: Bane or Benefit?

text: Director of Strategy for the White House Drug Control Office
title: Marijuana Votes: Bane or Benefit?

text: Voters recognized a difference between the medical use of marijuana and abuse. As with other medicine, the distinction between abuse and legitimate use is clear. In addition, legitimate medical use of marijuana has been supported by The New England Journal of Medicine. Medical marijuana controls nausea for cancer and AIDS patients, reduces spasms for paraplegia and neurological diseases like multiple sclerosis and controls eye pressure for glaucoma patients. Among test patients in the Federal Investigational New Drug program, which dispenses medical marijuana, there have been no cases of abuse, and some patients have been receiving marijuana for two decades. In terms of the broader social ramifications, California is our best case study. Recent figures from the Department of Health and Human Services show that teen-agers in California are actually less likely to abuse marijuana: 6.9 percent of California teen-agers 12 to 17 used marijuana often, while 9.9 percent of teen-agers nationally used it frequently.
title: Marijuana Votes: Bane or Benefit?

text: Executive Director, National Council for Drug Control
title: Marijuana Votes: Bane or Benefit?

text: We’re sorry, we seem to have lost this page, but we don’t want to lose you. Report the broken link here.
title: AMERICAN TOPICS

text: A 34-year-old Dublin drug dealer accused of helping to murder a prominent Irish journalist said at his trial today that he had nothing to do with the killing.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: The journalist, Veronica Guerin, was shot five times in the chest in June 1996 by two men on a motorcycle as she sat in her car.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: Paul Ward, accused by the police of being involved in planning the killing and of getting rid of the .357 Magnum murder weapon and the motorcycle after the crime, denied police statements that he had confessed to the crimes.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: In a small, tightly guarded courthouse, Mr. Ward often refused to answer questions, citing his right not to incriminate himself.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: The trial, in its third week before a three-judge panel and no jury, has refocused national attention on the case, giving a sharp and unusual look into Dublin drug-dealing. It has also led to examination of Ms. Guerin's aggressive crime reporting for The Sunday Independent, Ireland's largest-circulation newspaper.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: A recent book about the crime suggests that her editors encouraged Ms. Guerin to take dangerous risks and did not censure her for tactics that included threatening criminals with defamatory articles in order to persuade them to give her information on other criminals. The newspaper denies any wrongdoing.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: Mr. Ward is the first person to be tried for the crime. The police have accused three other admitted drug dealers; two are in jail here and the other is in a British prison, fighting an extradition request. One of the men in jail here, Brian Meehan, has been identified by the police as the one who did the actual shooting. Mr. Meehan's sister, Vanessa, is Mr. Ward's girlfriend.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: The prosecution's chief witness, Charles Bowden, is also a convicted drug dealer.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: The gang that included Mr. Bowden and Mr. Ward, the two men testified, imported several tons of cannabis each year. Both men said they had earned about $500,000 in one 18-month period.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: Mr. Bowden said he had a $600-a-week cocaine habit and that he hid $50,000 in his home because he had not learned how to launder it. He also took his family on vacation to Spain.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: Mr. Bowden, a former soldier and nightclub bouncer, spent four days testifying that he and Mr. Ward were members of a gang that plotted the killing. He said Ms. Guerin was killed because a gang member thought she was about to give damaging information to the police.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: Mr. Bowden, who was given immunity from prosecution to testify against Mr. Ward, admitted loading the revolver and handing it to another gang member.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: He added: ''I knew what was going to happen that morning. I knew that Veronica Guerin was going to be shot or shot at, that something was going to happen to her. It sounds very naive, but I didn't know she was going to be killed. I didn't think they would be stupid enough to kill a journalist.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: ''If I had guts, I would have made a telephone call to somebody and told them what was going on.''
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: After his arrest, he said, the police showed him photographs of Ms. Guerin taken after the shooting.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: ''When I saw the photos of the girl lying in the car shot I went to pieces,'' Mr. Bowden said. ''I just couldn't handle it.''
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: At that point, he said, he decided to become a prosecution witness. Mr. Ward's lawyer says Mr. Bowden is lying to get favorable treatment. Mr. Bowden is the first person to be placed in Ireland's new witness-protection program.
title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist

text: For want of an estimated $1.64 in this city's perennial home-rule struggle with Congress, the Election Day result of a ballot initiative proposing the medicinal use of marijuana is being kept sealed as a secret from local voters.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: ''Every year, we sit and wait, wondering what Congress is going to do to us this time,'' said Mary Jane DeFrank, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of the National Capital Area. ''Now we know,'' she said, attacking Congress's 11th-hour move to void the Nov. 3 marijuana initiative by passing an appropriations amendment that bars the city from spending even the smallest amount of money to tally and promulgate the result.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: ''Every day we are not having these ballots counted, our rights are violated,'' John M. Ferren, the District's corporation counsel, told Judge Richard W. Roberts at a Federal District Court hearing on Tuesday. Mr. Ferren made the remarks as the city joined a lawsuit by the civil liberties group that charges Congress with violating Washington voters' First Amendment rights to vote and be heard.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: Mr. Ferren offered the court the $1.64 estimated cost of having a clerk push a computer button to let the people know the result of their choice. Judge Roberts has scheduled a Dec. 18 hearing.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: The appropriations amendment was sponsored by Representative Bob Barr, a Georgia Republican who said today that American taxpayers ''aren't interested in paying for Washington, D.C.'s, folly.''
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: ''From a medicinal standpoint, there is no legitimate use for marijuana,'' said Mr. Barr, who views the initiative as a ''thinly veiled'' attempt by recreational marijuana proponents to circumvent drug laws.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: Similar initiatives were approved last week by voters in Alaska, Arizona, Nevada, Oregon and Washington State, despite the Clinton Administration's opposition and warning that the medical effectiveness of marijuana had not been scientifically established. Proponents contend there is widespread evidence that marijuana eases the pain of people with diseases like AIDS and cancer.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: Beyond the issue's merits, city residents accuse Congress of interdicting the most precious process of citizenship. ''Democracy Held Hostage, Day 9,'' Steve Twomey, a Washington Post columnist, intoned today in summoning images of third world political abuse here at the heart of the Republic. Initially, the city indicated it would unofficially inform the voters of the tally, but election officials decided against it, citing ''pressure and mandate'' from Congress.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: ''Talk about a secret ballot,'' said Wayne Turner, who organized Initiative 59, the marijuana question, as local director of Act Up, the militant anti-AIDS group. ''Congress is prohibiting a local government from using local tax dollars in conducting an election,'' said Mr. Turner, who gathered 20,000 signatures across two years to secure the initiative.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: The budget route for trying to foil the initiative was doubly galling to city officials since Congress, as overseer of the capital, can veto most new District laws after they are approved. But opponents in the Republican-controlled Congress pre-emptively inserted the amendment, denounced by Mr. Ferren as a ''silly'' gambit, during this year's frenzied appropriations negotiations in the pre-election rush to recess.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: The budget action came after the initiative was already set. A total of 137,523 voters went to the polls, electing a Mayor and Council members and finding the marijuana question on their ballots. Mr. Turner said professionally conducted surveys of voters leaving the polls indicated that the initiative was approved by almost 7 in 10 voters. It would let residents use, cultivate and and distribute marijuana as a painkiller with a doctor's written approval.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: City officials have long complained that Congress forces unpopular choices and programs on the city. ''We're their political plaything,'' Ms. DeFrank said. She complained that Congress had widely prescribed details of city life best left to home rule, from barring meters in taxicabs to voting annually to bar all money for the city's clean needle program to protect drug addicts against AIDS.
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: In an earlier encounter, the City Council adopted a domestic partnership law to let homosexual couples register their relationships, a law that the Congress did not veto during its review period. After opponents realized this, they have acted annually to bar any spending by the District to enforce the law, Ms. DeFrank noted. ''So now people send in notifications of same-sex marriages by registered mail,'' she said. ''And they just pile up in some forgotten office where nobody dare touch them.''
title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital

text: A police report that is part of a dispute between prosecutors and a defense lawyer in the trial of a teen-ager accused of killing a 44-year-old man in Central Park in 1997 provides previously undisclosed details about the relationship between the victim and one of his attackers.
title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial

text: Arnold Kriss, the lawyer for the teen-ager, Christopher Vasquez, said on Tuesday that he wants parts of the report and other statements about the killing made by Mr. Vasquez's co-defendant, Daphne Abdela, read to the jury. But the lead prosecutor, Matthew Bogdanos, objected. Arguments on the issue are expected to be made today before Judge Michael Corriero in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial

text: Mr. Vasquez, 16, is being tried on second-degree murder charges in the death of Michael McMorrow, who was stabbed and eviscerated in Central Park on May 23, 1997. Ms. Abdela, also 16, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in March for her role and is serving a 39-month to 10-year prison sentence.
title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial

text: In her confession, which prosecutors are expected to read to jurors, Ms. Abdela blamed Mr. Vasquez for the killing. She said that she had knocked Mr. McMorrow's feet out from under him while Mr. Vasquez was attacking him with a knife. But she said that she did not intend for Mr. McMorrow to die.
title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial

text: But in his opening statement in the trial on Monday, Mr. Kriss contended that the evidence would show that Ms. Abdela committed the killing. He described her as ''out of control'' and said she challenged several people to fight on the night of the murder. Mr. Kriss described Mr. Vasquez as a follower. It was not clear how the defense intended to use the statements to support its contentions.
title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial

text: In the police report, Ms. Abdela blamed Mr. Vasquez for the killing, as she has in the past. But the report also includes a description of a previously undisclosed meeting in Central Park about two weeks before the killing. In this meeting, Ms. Abdela said, Mr. McMorrow gave her some LSD.
title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial

text: The report describes a June 19, 1997, statement to investigators in which she said she was sitting in the park smoking marijuana with friends on May 10, 1997, when Mr. McMorrow approached. He appeared to be drunk, she said. Ms. Abdela said she gave Mr. McMorrow a beer and he gave her cigarette rolling papers. She and Mr. McMorrow then talked about being Irish, drinking and their families, according to her statement.
title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial

text: When the conversation turned to drugs, Ms. Abdela said she had never taken LSD and asked if he had any. She said that Mr. McMorrow then gave her a sliver of LSD and she took it. Ms. Abdela said she began to hallucinate, became nervous and left the park. She said Mr. McMorrow left the park before she did and she did not see him again until the night of the killing.
title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial

text: A day after convicting Corey Arthur of second-degree murder in the shooting of his former teacher, Jonathan M. Levin, shaken members of the jury yesterday described two days of agonizing deliberations that culminated in the realization that they could not declare Mr. Arthur guilty of actually pulling the trigger.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: Three jurors said yesterday that the panel -- made up of nine women and three men -- was initially evenly divided over whether to convict him of the first-degree murder charge, which would have meant prosecutors proved he fired the fatal shot. But after 11 hours of debate, the jury unanimously agreed that Mr. Arthur could be convicted only on the lesser charge of second-degree murder because of the inconsistent testimony of the prosecution's lead witness, Carlethia Weeks, who said that Mr. Arthur told her he shot Mr. Levin.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: Mr. Arthur, 20, faces 25 years to life in prison on the second-degree murder conviction, which declared him guilty of taking part in the crime that resulted in Mr. Levin's death. Had he been convicted of the more serious charge of first-degree murder, he would have faced life in prison without parole.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: The jurors spoke about their deliberations on the condition of anonymity because of fear of retribution for the verdict. After the verdict was announced at 10:30 P.M. Wednesday, two panel members received threatening phone calls, the jurors said.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: Ms. Weeks's testimony was the primary evidence linking Mr. Arthur to the firing of the fatal shot. In discussing her testimony, the jurors acknowledged that they were troubled by the disclosure that Ms. Weeks has heard voices in her head since she was a child. But they said that the inconsistency of Ms. Weeks's statements was more important than her apparent psychiatric problems.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: ''There was a strong sense that he had performed the execution,'' one juror said. ''But without any corroborating evidence to back up her statements, we had to give the defendant the benefit of the doubt.''
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: The jurors who discussed their deliberations called their decision on the verdict a haunting one and described fighting off a nagging, gut sense that Mr. Arthur actually fired the shot that killed his former teacher on May 30, 1997. They also expressed a desire to severely punish Mr. Arthur for what they said was his indisputable role in torturing his former teacher for his bank card access code.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: ''We were making up other things we could charge him with,'' one juror said. ''I think we're all hoping he gets the stiffest penalty. We're all hoping he gets 25 years to life.''
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: One juror also accused the police of botching the investigation into Mr. Levin's murder -- one of the largest murder inquiries in the city in recent years.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: The juror described as stunning a police detective's statement that he did not thoroughly search a backpack found at the murder scene because he thought someone else had already done it. A lab technician later found a .22-caliber bullet -- the same size bullet that killed Mr. Levin -- in the knapsack. Defense lawyers seized upon the mistake to call into question the quality of the police work on the case.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: ''A 30-year police detective not checking that knapsack?'' the juror said. ''There was a lot that was botched.''
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: The juror also said that he believed the contention of defense lawyers that a third, or even a fourth person, may have been in Mr. Levin's apartment on the day of the murder, but was or were still at large. Defense lawyers argued that the discovery of a strain of DNA at the murder scene that could not be linked to Mr. Levin, Mr. Arthur or his 26-year-old co-defendant, Montoun T. Hart, was evidence that there was another person present at the murder scene.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: The juror said that he believed Mr. Arthur, who was Mr. Levin's student at William Howard Taft High School in the 1993-94 school year, went to Mr. Levin's apartment intending to rob him but not kill him. The juror said he believed that someone else may have shot Mr. Levin, or that Mr. Arthur may have done it after he smoked crack. But even if someone else fired the fatal shot, he said Mr. Arthur still deserved to be punished for his role in the crime.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: But the two other jurors who spoke about their deliberations said they believed the police had done an adequate job investigating the case. They said they believed that only Mr. Hart and Mr. Arthur carried out the crime, accepting the prosecution's argument that the unknown DNA strand could have been left at the scene by a friend of Mr. Levin's in the days before the murder.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: The three jurors were in complete agreement in their opinion of Mr. Levin, whom they described in glowing terms.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: ''The schools and the community have suffered a great loss,'' one juror said. ''As I left the courthouse last night, I couldn't believe that so many lives had been ruined over so little money.''
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: The jury, which included people whose professions ranged from secretary to high-technology business consultant, also uniformly rejected defense lawyers' attempts to suggest that the teacher had a drug problem. They called the issue irrelevant, saying they believed Mr. Levin's friends who said he only smoked marijuana occasionally. And even if Mr. Levin had used harder drugs, they said, it would not justify his murder.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: Jurors said they believed that whatever friendship Mr. Levin and Mr. Arthur had shared had eroded by May 1997. They pointed to statements by friends of Mr. Levin's that they had not seen Mr. Arthur with his former teacher in the year before the murder. And they said they thought Mr. Arthur succumbed to his own personal flaws and the poverty he grew up in.
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: ''Jonathan had an influence on him,'' one juror said. ''But I think outside factors were stronger.''
title: Haunting Choice for Jurors in Levin Case

text: A massacre in September in which 19 men, women and children were fatally shot in a driveway in Baja California was a result of a drunken argument between the chieftains of two rival marijuana-smuggling gangs that turned violent, the authorities said today.
title: Mexican Official Links Massacre To Drug Rivalry

text: In the murders on Sept. 17 in a seaside suburb of Ensenada, the authorities had previously identified a victim, Fermin Castro, as head of a gang that specialized in guiding drug planes to desert airstrips.
title: Mexican Official Links Massacre To Drug Rivalry

text: Today, the authorities said witnesses had told them that a rival of Mr. Castro who headed another smuggling group, Lino Quintana, visited Mr. Castro's house on Sept. 17, intending to collect a drug debt and steal marijuana stored there.
title: Mexican Official Links Massacre To Drug Rivalry

text: Mr. Quintana and his armed colleagues were drunk and high on cocaine, and their talk with Mr. Castro turned violent, with the gunmen's dragging Mr. Castro's family and two neighboring families from their beds, the Federal Attorney for Baja California, Gen. Jose Luis Chavez, said at a news conference. The victims were then shot to death. Three people have been arrested, but Mr. Quintana is at large.
title: Mexican Official Links Massacre To Drug Rivalry

text: A 19-year-old former student of Jonathan M. Levin was convicted yesterday of second-degree murder in the May 1997 slaying of Mr. Levin, a Bronx public high school teacher, in his Upper West Side apartment. But in a setback for prosecutors, the jury acquitted the defendant, Corey Arthur, of first-degree murder, apparently unconvinced that Mr. Arthur fired the fatal shot.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Mr. Arthur faces 25 years to life in prison. If he had been convicted of first-degree murder, he would have been sentenced to life in prison without parole.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Mr. Levin, the son of Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner, chose to be an English teacher at William Howard Taft High in the Bronx instead of living a life of privilege. He was praised by his students for giving to them selflessly and having an unusual ability to raise their self-esteem. Some of his students displayed a sign at Mr. Levin's funeral declaring, ''We are his kids.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Mr. Levin's mother, Carol Levin, expressed disappointment with the verdict last night in an emotional statement.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: ''I'm not happy about this,'' Ms. Levin said. ''There is no happiness in this.'' She added, ''John wouldn't have been happy with this verdict.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Jurors left the courthouse last night without commenting on their 11 hours of deliberations over two days, but it appeared that they rejected the testimony of the prosecution's lead witness, Carlethia Weeks. Ms. Weeks, Mr. Arthur's former girlfriend, had testified that he confessed the killing to her.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: But Ms. Weeks admitted under cross-examination that she had heard voices in her head since she was a child and had seen a psychiatrist about the problem. Prosecutors have not commented on whether they knew of Ms. Weeks's psychiatric problems when they placed her on the stand.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: The jury's ruling essentially meant that prosecutors proved only that Mr. Arthur and his 26-year-old codefendant, Montoun T. Hart, committed a crime that resulted in Mr. Levin's death -- torturing him until he gave them the code to his bank card and robbing him of $800. But they did not prove that Mr. Arthur personally killed Mr. Levin. Mr. Arthur was also convicted of two counts of armed robbery. Mr. Hart will be tried separately on second-degree murder charges in January.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: The guilty verdicts prompted cheers from friends of the victim and sobs from a friend of the accused. Mr. Arthur shook his head and muttered to himself when the verdicts were announced. His mother, Penny Bostick, sat motionless and Mr. Arthur's current girlfriend burst out weeping. Ms. Bostick said she had no comment on the verdict.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: But Ms. Levin, who spoke for the first time publicly after attending every day of the trial, praised her son's life and said his students still call her about him. She criticized defense lawyers for raising the issue of drug use at the trial. They suggested that drugs may have been a reason Mr. Arthur was in Mr. Levin's apartment that night. But an autopsy found no drugs in Mr. Levin's body.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: ''It hurt those who loved John very much to hear the defense spin fictions about his life,'' she said. ''John lived a noble life. He was a very honorable man.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Ms. Levin said that her son lived for his students and would not have been able to achieve what he did in life if he had used drugs. She said he gave selflessly to his students and that he responded to Mr. Arthur's phone call the day of the killing because that was his nature.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: ''He would probably be very disappointed in Corey Arthur,'' Ms. Levin said. ''The only reason he picked up that phone was because he couldn't do otherwise.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Defense lawyers called the verdict a victory and said they had to raise drug use as part of mounting a proper defense for Mr. Arthur. Defense lawyers attacked the credibility of friends of Mr. Levin who testified that he smoked marijuana occasionally but did not use hard drugs.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Mr. Goltzer apologized for any pain the defense team caused Mr. Levin's family. ''If we caused her any pain it's regrettable but it was unavoidable,'' Mr. Goltzer said. ''We had a client to protect. We did not go out of our way to aggressively attack Mr. Levin. He was a good man and a good teacher and the fact that he used a little marijuana does not change that.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Prosecutors, who had no comment on the verdicts last night, said during the trial that Mr. Arthur went to Mr. Levin's apartment to rob him.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: The killing of Mr. Levin led some public-school teachers to question how accessible they should be to their students outside of school, and turned Mr. Levin into a symbol of public service.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Mr. Arthur was a student in Mr. Levin's English class at Taft High School during the 1993-1994 school year, and the young teacher apparently took the troubled youth under his wing. At the time, at least, the two were close.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: In a two-page, handwritten thank-you note that Mr. Arthur wrote to Mr. Levin in 1993, he called the teacher his ''true and only friend in the world.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: ''You have shown me that it is alright to step in and help someone,'' he said in the letter. ''You have shown me not all people want to use and exploit me.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: The note concluded: ''Wherever I get in life, I owe it to you and for that I am entirely grateful. I am also lucky and most happy to call Jake or John Levin my friend. Thank you.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Mr. Levin wrote in a paper for a graduate school class he was taking at the time that Mr. Arthur showed promise and that reading the note from Mr. Arthur nearly brought him to tears. ''I have never met a 16-year-old who has been through and seen what he has, and seems incredibly rough and intimidating on the outside,'' Mr. Levin wrote, ''and yet, he harbors some positive goals and aspirations that he can share with no one, because most of his peers would find them ridiculous.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: He wrote that his relationship with Mr. Arthur was an inspiration: ''So much of what I am and what I want to do in this life, and profession, revolves around what I've established'' with him.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: But prosecutors and defense lawyers painted starkly different portraits of what happened next in their relationship. Defense lawyers said the two remained close and argued in the closing statements on Monday that Mr. Arthur would never have killed his former teacher. They argued that cuts Mr. Arthur suffered on his hand at the time of the murder occurred when he tried to stop an accomplice from stabbing Mr. Levin.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: ''There is no way on God's earth that he would kill him,'' George Goltzer, one of Mr. Arthur's defense lawyers, said in his closing statement. ''There is no way on God's earth he would harm him.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: But prosecutors said that Mr. Arthur and Mr. Levin had grown apart by May 30, 1997. The former student took advantage of his previous relationship with his former teacher to gain entrance to his apartment. Twice during the trial, prosecutors played a tape from Mr. Levin's telephone answering machine that recorded Mr. Arthur calling him at 4:55 P.M. on the day of the murder.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: ''Mr. Levin, this is Corey,'' the voice on the tape says. ''Pick up if you're there. It's important.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Mr. Arthur and Mr. Hart did go to visit Mr. Levin, and prosecutors said they attacked him and tied him up with duct tape. The teacher was tortured with a knife, including three cuts made across his throat, until he gave up the code to his bank card. At 5:15 P.M, a man identified by a witness as Mr. Hart withdrew $800 from Mr. Levin's bank account.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: But prosecutors portrayed Mr. Arthur as the leader of the two. His fingerprints were found on the roll of duct tape and his D.N.A. was found on the knife used to torture Mr. Levin. Blood from Mr. Levin was found on Mr. Arthur's clothes. While the gun that killed Mr. Levin was never recovered, prosecutors argued that Mr. Arthur was the only one with a motive to kill his former teacher because he could later identify Mr. Arthur to the police.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: In his closing statement, Mr. Hurley pointed out that Mr. Levin was shot in the head as he lay face down on the floor and that a piece of duct tape had been removed from his mouth. He speculated that Mr. Arthur allowed his former teacher to smoke one last cigarette but then forced Mr. Levin to lie face down on the ground before shooting him.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: ''One reason to make him lie down,'' Eugene Hurley, the lead prosecutor, said, ''is you don't want to look at his face.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Despite the grisly nature of the crime, the trial did not develop into the free-for-all that some feared. Defense lawyers worried that Mr. Arthur could not receive a fair trial after the case received so much publicity.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: In the end, the image of Mr. Levin as a dedicated young teacher remained intact throughout the trial. Defense lawyers expressed admiration for Mr. Levin, inside and outside the courtroom.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: The Jonathan Levin Foundation, a nonprofit organization established after the slaying, has created a new media center and athletic field at Taft High School. A nearby block has been renamed Jonathan Levin Way.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: Outside the courthouse last night, a friend of Mr. Levin's who spoke on the condition of anonymity expressed mixed emotions. He said he was disappointed that Mr. Arthur was acquitted of the first-degree murder charges, but said no verdict could change what happened.
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: ''He's going to spend a lot of time behind bars,'' he said. ''But it's not going to bring John back.''
title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher

text: An 84-year-old man's willingness to give his nephew and the nephew's girlfriend a ride evolved into a bizarre carjacking today in Newark that ended with the woman shot to death and the nephew mysteriously vanishing on the George Washington Bridge.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: Police officials said the shot that killed the woman was fired by a security guard at a Newark housing project who was trying to stop the carjacking. Her body was found in the car, a green Ford Taurus, after it was abandoned on the eastbound lanes of the bridge's lower level. The police identified her only as a New York woman in her 20's.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: No one saw the man leave the car or walk off the bridge, and at the end of an afternoon's search of the area by officers on foot and in patrol cars and helicopters, the Port Authority police said the man had vanished.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: Chief William Cafaro of the Port Authority police said the missing man, identified tonight as John Magee, 32, could have commandeered a car on the bridge, fled in an accomplice's car, jumped from the bridge into the Hudson River or simply managed to walk away from the car and his girlfriend's body before a Port Authority police officer reached the vehicle about 12:25 P.M.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: ''We can't assume anything at this point because we have no eyewitnesses,'' Chief Cafaro said at a news conference here late this afternoon.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: Later, Newark's police director, Joseph J. Santiago, said, ''Right now, we don't know where he is.''
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: The strange sequence began sometime this morning at the home of an 84-year-old widower, Maurice Troutman, in Union, N.J. Mr. Troutman's wife and Mr. Magee's mother had been adopted in childhood by the same couple and grew up as sisters. This morning, officials said, Mr. Magee and his girlfriend went to Mr. Troutman's home and asked to borrow money.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: Mr. Troutman refused the request, according to Sgt. Derek Glynn, a spokesman for the Newark police. The couple then asked Mr. Troutman for a ride to Pennsylvania Station in Newark so they could get a train to New York City. Mr. Troutman agreed.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: According to Newark and Port Authority police officials, this is what happened next:
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: On the ride from Union to Newark in Mr. Troutman's car, Mr. Magee and his girlfriend decided not to go to the train station and asked instead to be driven to University Hospital in Newark to see a friend. Mr. Troutman agreed to take them there.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: He parked his car on Cabinet Street, a short, quiet street that separates the hospital from a housing project, Georgia King Village. But angered by the changing requests, Mr. Troutman ordered the couple from his car at the hospital.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: ''I've had enough,'' the police quoted Mr. Troutman as saying. ''You're getting out.''
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: But as Mr. Troutman got out of the car, Mr. Magee climbed from the back seat into the driver's seat and started to drive away. Mr. Troutman reached in through an open window, trying to turn off the ignition. Mr. Magee rolled the window up on his arm and started to drive off. Mr. Troutman, trapped, ran alongside the car for a few seconds and then stumbled and was dragged for several hundred feet, shouting as the car proceeded along Cabinet Street.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: A security guard in the housing complex, David Alicea, 39, heard the shouting while he was on patrol at 11:45 A.M. and went into the street as the car approached him.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: Officer Alicea began waving at the car to stop. Mr. Magee, however, drove it toward Officer Alicea, with Mr. Troutman's arm still snared in the window, and then past the guard. At that, the guard fired at least one shot from his 9 mm service weapon. The bullet shattered the car's rear window and struck Mr. Magee's girlfriend in the back of the head, apparently killing her instantly.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: Officer Alicea, an employee of the Clark Security Company, is considered a ''special police officer'' in the Newark department, with powers to arrest and carry a weapon, because he has undergone training at the Newark Police Academy, Sergeant Glynn said. He was questioned tonight by detectives from the Newark internal affairs bureau. Officials said it appeared he was justified in firing his weapon at the car.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: ''He was in fear both for Mr. Troutman's life and his own,'' Sergeant Glynn said.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: About the same time as the shot, Mr. Troutman came free of the vehicle and fell to the pavement. He was later treated for bruises. With his dead passenger, Mr. Magee continued driving, stopping finally at the George Washington Bridge.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: The Newark police said early tonight that Mr. Magee had been arrested several times in recent months on various charges, including shoplifting, possession of marijuana, receiving stolen property and theft. Sergeant Glynn said that Mr. Magee's arrest record listed various addresses for him and that the authorities were trying tonight to learn his current one.
title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: 34 Arrested at Stadium, Mostly on Drug Charges

text: In a crackdown on quality-of-life offenses at New Jersey's arenas, undercover officers arrested 34 people, 21 of them on charges of smoking marijuana, during the Jets-Buffalo Bills football game Sunday at Giants Stadium, the police said.
title: 34 Arrested at Stadium, Mostly on Drug Charges

text: The arrests, mostly of men from New York and New Jersey in their 30's and 40's, were part of a campaign that began nearly a year ago, said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the State Police. Mr. Hagerty said that 17 people had been arrested at the stadium, mainly on drug charges, during the game between the Jets and the Atlanta Falcons on Oct. 25. Most face up to 30 days in jail or a $1,500 fine if convicted.
title: 34 Arrested at Stadium, Mostly on Drug Charges

text: Most of Sunday's 21 drug arrests occurred in the stadium's exterior spiral walkways, where cigarette smoking is permitted, Mr. Hagerty said.
title: 34 Arrested at Stadium, Mostly on Drug Charges

text: Robert Redford's adaptation takes the scenic route around some of the soapier elements of Nicholas Evans's novel. When Grace (Scarlett Johansson) and her horse are grievously injured in an accident, her mother, Annie (Kristin Scott Thomas), drives them to Montana, where they are taken in hand by Tom Booker (Mr. Redford, above), a genteel cowpoke. A chilly New York magazine editor, Annie has a hard time letting go in Big Sky country. Booker is a charming fellow in an admirably decent kind of way, which grows on Annie. But Mr. Redford's direction and restrained portrayal keeps the focus on nursing the girl and the horse, which doesn't slam the door on romance but keeps it on a reserved adult level. The film's one sin is its excessive length, which might be excused, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, by ''the material's uncompromising spirit and tranquil tone.''
title: New Video Releases

text: 1998. Universal. $107.37. 168 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.
title: New Video Releases

text: Survive one meteorite (''Deep Impact,'' available last week) and darned if another one isn't right behind it. This time it's the size of Texas, which is big even for a Jerry Bruckheimer production. Rallying around the flag, a rowdy bunch of oil drillers respond to their sensitive leader, Harry S. Stamper (Bruce Willis), whom we meet as he's trying to kill his daughter's boyfriend (Ben Affleck). With Stamper in command, the crew will ride a couple of space shuttles out to the incoming rock, drill a hole, pack it with explosive and kerblam. Patriotism swells around the old training camp as the crew gets outfitted in orange space suits. Then it's the boys vs. the boulder in action that's furious but not ''as scary as the prospect of raising a generation of Americans on movies like this'' (Maslin).
title: New Video Releases

text: 1998. Touchstone. $26.99. 150 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.
title: New Video Releases

text: When a small toy company is taken over by a big one, great ideas start flowing. Why not take advanced computer chips used in weaponry and put them in military figures for children, in effect turning G.I. Joes into crazed little supersoldiers. To give voices to such a gung-ho unit, Joe Dante's animated film employs the voices of some of the original ''Dirty Dozen'' cast: Ernest Borgnine, Jim Brown and George Kennedy. Tommy Lee Jones is the flat-topped platoon leader Chip Hazard. ''Meet death with honor, coward,'' he advises at one point. Offering opposition are the nicer Gorgonites, but though the computerized figures are impressive accomplishments, the story is ''too absurd to be frightening and too creepy for lighthearted fun'' (Maslin).
title: New Video Releases

text: 1998. Universal. $22.99. 99 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.
title: New Video Releases

text: Big films like ''The X-Files,'' ''A Perfect Murder'' and ''Hope Floats'' lead current best-renter lists. Here are a few smaller films that are at the top of Video Business magazine's list of best renters with a limited theatrical release, meaning that they played on no more than 475 theater screens.
title: New Video Releases

text: THE SPANISH PRISONER. No. 32 on the overall list of best renters, David Mamet's charming puzzler of a film is No. 1 on the list of smaller films. On a business trip to the Caribbean, an inventor (Campbell Scott) gets taken for a ride by the smooth, inscrutable Jimmy Dell (Steve Martin). 1997. Columbia Tri-Star. $99.36. 112 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.
title: New Video Releases

text: THE GINGERBREAD MAN. Robert Altman's adaptation of the John Grisham story is set in Savannah, where a divorced legal hotshot (Kenneth Branagh) finds trouble with a mysterious woman in fishnet stockings. 1998. Polygram. $102.96. 115 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
title: New Video Releases

text: THE LAST DAYS OF DISCO. In his usual high style, Whit Stillman captures the lives of a particular breed of privileged young woman in the brief time of free-spiritedness between college and career. 1998. Polygram. $104.16. 108 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
title: New Video Releases

text: HOMEGROWN. In the absence of their boss (John Lithgow), who has been shot dead, an erratic crew of marijuana farmers (Billy Bob Thornton, Hank Azaria and Ryan Phillippe) and their packager (Kelly Lynch) plot to harvest and sell the crop. 1998. Columbia Tri-Star. $105.77. 101 minutes. R.
title: New Video Releases

text: NIGHTWATCH. New on the job, a jittery young night watchman (Ewan McGregor) at a medical examiner's building finds himself accused of murdering local prostitutes and cutting their eyes out. And here he was just learning his rounds. 1998. Dimension. $103.11. 105 minutes. Closed captioned.
title: New Video Releases

text: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: THE STATES -- DRUG POLICY
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: Defying Federal officials, and often state legislators, voters approved initiatives on Tuesday to legalize the medical use of marijuana in Alaska, Arizona, Nevada, Oregon and Washington State.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: And in Colorado and the District of Columbia, where conservatives nullified medical marijuana initiatives at the last moment, surveys of voters leaving the polls on Tuesday indicated strong support for the measures.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: Drug policy analysts said today that the votes, in which every marijuana initiative on a state ballot was approved, demonstrated the sea change in attitudes that started with the approval of ballot measures in Arizona and California in 1996.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: ''I don't think any of these propositions would have passed five years ago,'' said Mark A. R. Kleiman, professor of policy studies at the University of California at Los Angeles. ''It is no longer possible to buffalo the American people by screaming drugs and having them run away.''
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: But the drives for the initiatives were bolstered by $5 million in advertising over the last year, estimated Ethan Nadelmann, director of the Lindesmith Center, a drug policy institute in New York. The campaign was financed by George Soros, the billionaire investor who financed the Lindesmith Center; Peter B. Lewis, a Cleveland insurance executive, and John Sperling, a Phoenix entrepreneur.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: The votes would give confidence to politicians who are afraid to publicly support allowing doctors to recommend marijuana to patients suffering from illnesses like glaucoma, cancer and multiple sclerosis, Mr. Nadelmann predicted.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: In Oregon and Arizona, the votes were direct slaps at State Legislatures that had voted curbs on marijuana.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: In Oregon, the State Legislature last year restored criminal penalties for marijuana possession. On Tuesday, Oregonians voted, 2 to 1, to make possession merely a violation carrying a fine, as it had been since 1973. They also voted, by a smaller margin, to approve the medical use of marijuana.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: In Arizona, the State Legislature had approved bills last year that essentially gutted the marijuana referendum votes of 1996. On Tuesday, Arizona voters easily approved two initiatives that restored the 1996 language.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: ''In two states, Arizona and Oregon, people overthrew the politicians on drugs,'' Sam Vagenas, leader of Arizona's medical marijuana movement, said today. ''This is the biggest grass-roots movement since term limits.''
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: Opposition to the medical marijuana movement has come from big-city police chiefs, Congress, and the White House's top drug policy official, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: In Senate testimony last summer, the general, who directs the Office of National Drug Control Policy, made a veiled reference to Mr. Soros: ''There is a carefully camouflaged, exorbitantly funded, well-heeled elitist group whose ultimate goal is to legalize drug use in the United States.''
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: Today, the general's office emphasized that the state measures ''in no way alter the status of marijuana under Federal law.''
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: ''We are concerned about the mixed message that children pick up on this,'' Jim McDonough, director of strategy for the White House drug control office, said today of the advertising campaigns to allow medical uses of medical marijuana. Noting that the number of marijuana users in the nation had dropped by half since 1980, to about 10 million today, he said that surveys indicated a recent increase among students.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: In the District of Columbia, Representative Bob Barr, a conservative Republican from Georgia, had inserted into the District's Federal appropriation bill an amendment to bar the District from counting votes in Tuesday's medical marijuana initiative. The American Civil Liberties Union is suing to overturn the ban.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: In Colorado, a medical marijuana initiative was also on the ballot, but Vikki Buckley, the Secretary of State and a Republican, said she would not count the votes because the initiative backers did not supply enough valid signatures to place the issue on the ballot. Backers are contesting her ruling in court.
title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana

text: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- WEST
title: WASHINGTON

text: Patty Murray, a Democrat who made a nationwide name for herself in 1992 campaigning as the ''mom in tennis shoes,'' won a second term in a tough race against Representative Linda Smith, a Republican who had backing from the Christian right.
title: WASHINGTON

text: In the third woman-versus-woman Senate race in history, Ms. Smith was known for down-to-earth sound bites, like when she spoke of ''fighting against leches in the workplace who hit on young women,'' a reference to President Clinton.
title: WASHINGTON

text: Ms. Smith paid a price for her longstanding support for campaign finance reform: the Republican organization gave her little money, and she was noticeably outspent early in the campaign.
title: WASHINGTON

text: Washington voters approved Initiative 200, an anti-affirmative action measure, modeled on California's, that will ban racial or gender preferences in government hiring, contracting or college admissions.
title: WASHINGTON

text: As in other states, Washington voters rejected a proposed ban on a type of late-term abortion. And, one year after vetoing a broader plan some thought might leave the door open to legalizing other drugs, voters approved a ballot initiative allowing the medical use of marijuana.
title: WASHINGTON

text: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: THE STATES -- INITIATIVES
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: In a vote expected to have national reverberations, Washington State residents dealt a stinging defeat to state-sponsored affirmative action. Voters in five Western states gave a resounding yes to the medical use of marijuana, while Alaska and Hawaii voters said a clear no to the idea of same-sex marriages.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: Massachusetts and Arizona voters approved public financing of political campaigns, while Colorado and Washington rejected proposals to criminalize late-term abortions. And Oregon, becoming the first state to do away with polling places altogether, will conduct elections entirely by mail.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: These were some of the highlights of votes on more than 200 initiatives and proposed constitutional amendments that were on state ballots on Tuesday. Supporters hail such initiatives as popular democracy in action, but critics call them a potentially dangerous subversion of representative government. Whatever its merits or flaws, the initiative process was very much in action on Tuesday in 16 states, perhaps most notably here in Washington, where voters also made theirs the first state in the nation to require annual minimum-wage increases linked to the inflation rate, and in California, where voters contended with a dozen major questions.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: In California, a proposal to raise cigarette taxes by 50 cents a pack and dedicate the money to early childhood and prenatal care programs, bitterly opposed by the tobacco industry, had passed by such a thin margin that it was probably headed for a recount. And in a battle that became the most expensive fight ever waged over a state initiative, the voters ignored an advertising campaign by Nevada casinos and broadly backed the expansion of casino gambling on Indian tribal lands in California. They also passed an initiative to spend $9.2 billion on measures to reduce crowding in the state's public schools and to repair aging classrooms.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: In all, voters nationwide passed 37 of the 61 initiatives and popular referendums before them, a higher percentage of yes votes than in any other election this decade. Some of the big winning issues were medical marijuana, campaign-finance reform and gambling, while the big losers included doctor-assisted suicide, tax credits for private school tuition, a late-term abortion procedure that opponents call partial birth abortion, and same-sex marriages.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: ''The voters addressed the tough issues that elected officials have been unwilling to deal with, as well as voted down those reforms they weren't ready for,'' said M. Dane Waters, the president and founder of the Initiative and Referendum Institute, a nonpartisan group that tracks the votes and generally supports the initiative process.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: But others said that many of the measures that passed were misleading to the voters, and that on no issue was there more debate about the meaning of the initiative than on Washington state's Proposition 200, which passed with 58 percent of the vote and will ban many state-supported forms of affirmative action originally enacted to remedy discrimination.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: Voters on Tuesday were asked whether government should be ''prohibited from discriminating or granting preferential treatment based on race, sex, color, ethnicity or national origin'' in public employment, education and contracting.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: They said yes by a wide margin, making Washington the second state, after California, to put such language into law.
