title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: ''It means that America is taking a great step forward to looking beyond race and minimizing its importance, rather than dwelling on it and magnifying its importance,'' said John Carlson, chairman of the group sponsoring the initiative. ''It also, I think, will hasten the transition of affirmative action from a program based on race and ethnicity and occasionally gender to a program that is based on people's circumstances.''
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: But the vote, far from clarifying the issue, is certain to spark lawsuits, as supporters of affirmative action argue that programs intended to provide equal opportunity for racial minorities or women do not constitute preferential treatment. They also point to polls indicating that while people endorse the language in measures like Proposition 200, which was taken from the Civil Rights Act of 1964, they will say no when asked whether they wish to eliminate affirmative action.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: In any event, the vote in Washington is clearly a boost to opponents of affirmative action and is likely to spur efforts to get similar measures on the ballots in other states.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: Gay rights measures were defeated in several states. Colorado residents rejected a proposal to grant homosexuals civil rights protection against discrimination. Hawaii voters gave the Legislature authorization to overturn a court ruling and ban same-sex marriages, while Alaskans voted 2 to 1 in favor of a constitutional amendment that defines marriage as a union between one man and one woman.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: Voters in South Portland, Me., passed an ordinance to ban discrimination based on sexual orientation, but in three other cities -- Fayetteville, Ark.; Fort Collins, Colo.; and Ogunquit, Me. -- such measures were defeated. The issue was especially charged in Fort Collins, which is near Laramie, Wyo., the city where Matthew Shepard, a gay man, was beaten and tied to a fence. Mr. Shepard was transferred to a hospital in Fort Collins, where he died.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: ''We recognize that the struggle for full equality is a long-term one,'' said Kerry Lobel, executive director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. ''And win or lose in Hawaii and Alaska, we will continue to fight for full equality, including the freedom to marry, until we succeed.''
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: The battle over California's proposed cigarette tax remained remarkably close this evening; with all the precincts reporting, 3,550,483 people voted for the tax, while 3,537,278 voted against it. A recount was almost certain in what has been dubbed the ''Marlboro vs. Meat head'' battle, pitting tobacco companies against a coalition led by Rob Reiner, the actor whose character in the ''All in the Family'' television series was nicknamed Meathead.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: In other votes, Michigan residents rejected a proposal to legalize doctor-assisted suicide, and South Carolinians chose to remove a 103-year-old passage in their Constitution that forbids marriage between a white and a black. The United States Supreme Court has already found it to be unenforceable.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: In Iowa, voters agreed to add the phrase ''and women'' to the constitutional guarantee that all men ''are, by nature, free and equal, and have certain inalienable rights.'' Floridians voted solidly to let counties impose waiting periods on firearms sold at gun shows. And voters in Massachusetts and California rejected efforts to block deregulation of the electric utility industry.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: In what is perhaps a reflection of Americans' positive perceptions about the economy, voters approved a record total of $20 billion in bond measures for schools and infrastructure projects like water and sewer line improvements. Sports stadiums in Denver, San Diego and Cincinnati were also approved.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: In one of the more unusual local issues to make it to the ballot box, voters in Newport, Me., rejected an ordinance that would have punished women for publicly displaying their breasts.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: The dispute began when a woman in that town got into the habit of mowing her lawn without a shirt, prompting complaints by her neighbor to the local authorities that she was violating decency laws. Maine law prohibits display of genitals or commission of sex acts in public, but town officials ruled that breasts were not genitals and that lawn mowing was not a sexual act, so they said they could not charge the woman with breaking any law. That prompted the irate neighbor to get enough signatures to put the measure on the ballot, but it failed.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: -------------------- Area for Slot Machines Widened
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Voters in Missouri decided on Tuesday to legalize slot machines on casinos floating in artificial basins, with 55 percent of the 1.54 million people who voted on it backing the measure.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: Such gambling was previously restricted to riverboat casinos on the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers.
title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

text: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- WEST
title: OREGON

text: Two incumbent Democrats, Gov. John Kitzhaber and Senator Ron Wyden, racked up big margins in their victories. But the contest for the state's First Congressional District remained too close to call.
title: OREGON

text: Governor Kitzhaber, who emphasized his support for education and the environment, soundly defeated the Republican, Bill Sizemore, who heads an anti-tax organization.
title: OREGON

text: In the Senate contest, Mr. Wyden easily overcame a challenge from State Senator John Lim, a Republican.
title: OREGON

text: In the First District, the Democratic candidate, David Wu, a business lawyer, was leading the Republican, Mary Bordonaro, a public relations consultant, in the race to succeed Representative Elizabeth Furse, a Democrat who is retiring. The Oregonian, a Portland newspaper, said the outcome would depend on absentee ballots.
title: OREGON

text: Voters also approved a measure allowing medical use of marijuana.
title: OREGON

text: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- BALLOT LINES
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: ''He lives for another four years to terrorize the political world,'' Raymond B. Harding, the leader of the Liberal Party, said yesterday.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: The terror in question was himself.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: For a time, things had looked dicey for Mr. Harding's candidate for Governor, Betsy McCaughey Ross, after her husband withdrew the several million dollars he had pledged to her campaign. That meant things also looked dicey for his party, which under state election rules needed 50,000 votes to keep its spot on state ballots for the next four years.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: But with 98 percent of election districts reporting, the New York State Board of Elections' unofficial tallies yesterday showed the Liberal Party's candidate with 75,870 votes, safely above the threshold to assure the party a place on all state ballots for the next four years. ''It makes me happy,'' Mr. Harding said.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: In Minnesota, Jesse Ventura, a former professional wrestler and the candidate of the Reform Party, shocked the political establishment on Tuesday when he defeated the two major-party candidates in the governor's race. Mr. Ventura won with slightly more than a third of the vote.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: None of the minor-party candidates for governor in New York approached that kind of performance, but collectively they demonstrated that a large number of voters are looking for alternatives to the major parties. According to unofficial and incomplete results, the 10 minor parties that ran candidates for governor tallied a total of 918,344 votes. By comparison, the Democratic Party, with Peter F. Vallone as its candidate, had 1.4 million votes.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., noted that minor parties tended to provide margins of victory to major-party candidates when turnout was high and races were close. But, he said, the parties had still showed their power to help or spoil the chances of such candidates this year.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: In the Senate race, for example, he estimated that 40 percent of the victory margin of Charles E. Schumer, the Democratic Party candidate, came from votes he also drew on the Independence Party line. And in the race for Attorney General, the more than 60,000 votes for Catherine Abate on the Independence Party line constituted what would have been a comfortable margin of victory for either the Democratic candidate, Eliot L. Spitzer, or the Republican incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco. The tally is still so close for Mr. Vacco and Mr. Spitzer that the Board of Elections has said that it cannot declare a winner until the remaining absentee ballots are counted next week.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: The Independence Party was clearly the major player among the minors this year. Bankrolled by some $15 million from its candidate for governor -- B. Thomas Golisano, a Rochester businessman -- the party pulled in 343,979 votes, according to the board's unofficial tallies. (That works out to about $44 per vote. In his first run for Governor in 1994, Mr. Golisano spent $6.6 million for 217,000 votes, or about $30 per vote. The Democrats, by comparison, spent about $4 per vote this year.)
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: The steep price may be worth it for Mr. Golisano: If the pattern holds when all the votes are tallied, his Independence Party will finish ahead of the Conservative Party, which so far has 304,354 votes, according to the board. That means the Independence Party will get the third line -- Line C, which the Conservative Party had this time -- on the ballot in all elections for the next four years.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: The position on the ballot is important because some voters do not bother to look over the entire list of candidates and parties before making their choice.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: Ballot lines are assigned according to vote totals in the Governor's race. One of the side effects of Governor George E. Pataki's sizable victory is that the Republicans will have Line A, the top line, on the ballot for the next four years.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: Laureen A. Oliver, the Independence Party's co-founder and its candidate for Lieutenant Governor, said the improvement in ballot position would make it easier to raise money for the party, even without Mr. Golisano's millions. ''I think we have a very bright future,'' she said.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: The Liberal Party was next, followed by the Right to Life Party, which, with 55,642 votes, insured its place on forthcoming ballots.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: Several parties -- Marijuana Reform, Unity, and Socialist Workers -- finished out of the running. Two others were on tenterhooks.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: With 98 percent of districts reporting and absentee ballots yet to be counted, the Green Party drew 48,251 votes for its candidate for governor, the 88-year-old Al Lewis -- better known as ''Grandpa Munster.'' The Working Families Party, a new party formed mostly by labor unions, also had Mr. Vallone, the Democrat, as its candidate, but he drew only 45,218 votes on that line.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: Lee Daghlian, a spokesman for the Board of Elections, said that when absentee ballots are counted next week, he expected the Green Party to secure the 50,000 votes, and the Working Families Party to fall short.
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: ''I'm elated,'' Mr. Lewis said. ''It's like an expansion team in baseball -- we're in the major leagues.''
title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes

text: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: THE NATION -- REFERENDUMS
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: Giving a major lift to critics of affirmative action, Washington State voters tonight appear to have soundly approved an initiative that would ban most state-supported forms of the policy. They did so two years after California voters made theirs the first state in the nation to do so, and the vote is almost certain to spur efforts in other states.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: With 38 percent of precincts reporting, the measure known as Initiative 200 was running ahead, 60 percent to 40 percent. Under the measure's wording, the state ''shall not discriminate against, or grant preferential treatment to, any individual or group on the basis of race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin'' in education, employment or contracting.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: The language was similar to that used in the Civil Rights Act of 1964, but critics of the measure, including the state's Governor, Gary Locke, a Democrat, warned that the measure had ''hidden consequences'' and would roll back gains made in programs that expand opportunities for women and minorities.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: In votes on other initiatives, Washington voters gave broad support to a measure that would legalize the use of marijuana for medical purposes and voted down a proposal to criminalize the late-term abortion procedure that critics call partial-birth abortion. In Colorado, a similar abortion measure was evenly split with 40 percent of precincts reporting.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: In Oregon, early returns suggested that state was poised to become the first in the nation to do away entirely with polling booths: if trends continue and the measure passes, the state will conduct all future elections entirely by mail.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: Michigan voters today soundly rejected a proposal to legalize doctor-assisted suicide. At 11:50 P.M., with 56 percent of precincts reporting, the measure was losing 70 percent to 30 percent.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: In California, surveys of voters as they left the polls and early returns indicated that voters were broadly supporting a measure to expand casino gambling on Indian tribal lands. The battle between the Indian tribes and Nevada casinos led to campaign spending of almost $100 million, by far the most money ever spent on an initiative in the nation's history.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: The previous record was $57.5 million for a 1996 securities fraud measure in California.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: In Massachusetts, voters backed a campaign-finance overhaul plan that would provide for public financing of most state election campaigns.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: These were among the more closely fought initiatives and proposed constitutional amendments on state ballots around the nation.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: South Carolinians were asked to decide whether to remove a 103-year-old passage in their constitution that forbids marriage between a white person and a black person, a provision that the United States Supreme Court has already ruled unenforceable. With 80 percent of precincts reporting tonight, 62 percent of voters were in favor of removing the language, while 38 percent voted not to remove it.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: In Michigan, where supporters of the assisted-suicide initiative hoped to follow the success of a similar movement in Oregon, voters were rejecting the idea by a better than 2 to 1. Support for the measure foundered in recent weeks when the nation's best-known advocate of doctor-assisted suicide, Dr. Jack Kevorkian, announced that he opposed the initiative: he said it imposed too many restrictions and too much bureaucracy on the process.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: The measure would have allowed terminally ill patients to petition the state for the right to take lethal drugs. In the first nine months of the Oregon program, state officials announced earlier this year, 10 people in that state were given the right to take such drugs: eight died after taking the medication and two others died before doing so.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: In Washington State, two years after voters in California and Arizona passed measures providing for the medical use of marijuana, residents passed a similar measure today, according to surveys at the polls. Voters in Nevada, Oregon and Alaska were also considering such measures today.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: Lawsuits and objections by the Clinton Administration have blocked the Arizona and California measures from taking effect.
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: Also in Washington, the voter surveys indicated that voters had rejected a proposal to criminalize the late-term abortion procedure that critics call ''partial-birth abortion.'' Abortion-rights supporters condemned the measure, saying its terminology was overly vague and might open the way for banning abortion in general. The question before the voters was: ''Shall the termination of a fetus' life during the process of birth be a felony crime except when necessary to prevent the pregnant woman's death?''
title: Voters Back End to State Preferences

text: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- WEST
title: WASHINGTON

text: Patty Murray, a Democrat, became the state's first female Senator in 1992 -- and made a nationwide name for herself -- campaigning as the ''mom in tennis shoes'' who understood family issues. This year she had tough competition from another woman, Representative Linda Smith, a Republican with backing from the Christian right who got to the House in 1994 by unseating another Democratic incumbent. And in this, the third woman-versus-woman Senate race in history, Ms. Smith had the down-to-earth sound bites about ''fighting against leches in the workplace who hit on young women,'' making President Clinton an issue.
title: WASHINGTON

text: Ms. Smith paid a price for her longstanding support for campaign finance reform: the Republican organization gave her little money, and she was noticeably outspent early in the campaign.
title: WASHINGTON

text: According to exit polls, Washington voters easily approved a ballot initiative that would allow the medical use of marijuana, and rejected a type of late-term abortion.
title: WASHINGTON

text: In a suburban Seattle district, Representative Rich White, a Republican, faced threats from former Representative Jay Inslee, a Democrat who wooed the liberal vote, and Bruce Craswell, a conservative.
title: WASHINGTON

text: The State of Iowa asked the Supreme Court today to uphold a state law that gives the police essentially blanket authority to search a car after issuing the driver a citation for speeding or another routine traffic violation.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: The Iowa Supreme Court upheld the law, the only one of its kind, by a 5-to-4 vote last year. But the Justices responded today with considerable wariness to the state's arguments. Justices across the ideological spectrum worried aloud that an expansion of the current rule, under which the police can conduct a search as an aspect of taking a person into custody in a formal arrest, would give the police too much power.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: The case is an appeal by a man who was stopped for driving 43 miles an hour in a 25-mile-an-hour zone. The police officer gave him a speeding ticket after determining that his license was valid and that there were no outstanding warrants for his arrest. Then the officer searched the car, finding a small quantity of marijuana and a pipe, and arrested him.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Twenty-five years ago, the Supreme Court validated a practice known as ''search incident to arrest,'' which is an exception to the ordinary Fourth Amendment requirement that a search be supported by probable cause, or at least some level of suspicion of a crime.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Once there was probable cause to make an arrest, the Court said then in United States v. Robinson, a search of the person arrested, and of the area under his control, would be deemed reasonable, without further need to establish probable cause to search. It made sense, the Court said in the 1973 case, to authorize such a search to preserve evidence and to protect the arresting officer's safety.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: In the argument today, several Justices, including the Court's more conservative members, suggested that the rationale of the ''search incident to arrest'' doctrine did not apply in a simple speeding ticket. With a speeding violation, ''the offense is complete when the car is brought to a stop,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said, adding, ''There is no more evidence to look for.'' Addressing Bridget A. Chambers, an assistant attorney general from Iowa, the Chief Justice said: ''If you'd come here on a second-degree burglary, it might have been different.''
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: The Iowa law, which dates to 1983, authorizes the issuance of a citation ''in lieu of arrest or in lieu of continued custody'' for a variety of offenses. The law then provides that police officers who issue such citations have the same authority to search that they would have if they made a formal arrest.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Paul Rosenberg, the lawyer for the arrested motorist, Patrick Knowles, told the Justices that while searches in connection with actual arrests have a long legal tradition behind them, that was not the case when no arrest took place. Mr. Rosenberg urged the Justices to maintain a clear distinction between the two situations, a proposition that several of them appeared to find attractive.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Addressing Ms. Chambers, the lawyer representing Iowa, Justice David H. Souter said: ''Would it make sense, in order to keep not only our constitutional categories but our constitutional protections in place, to require a custodial arrest?'' He answered his own question: ''Then we would all know where we stand.''
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said to Ms. Chambers, ''It does seem an enormous amount of authority to put in the hands of the police.''
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Several Justices raised the prospect that the police, given such authority, might manipulate the system by issuing a ticket, searching the car, and then making an arrest if the search turned up evidence of a crime. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy observed that rather than a search incident to an arrest, the state was seeking authority for ''arrest incident to search,'' inviting ''an abuse of authority'' by the police.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Ms. Chambers replied that while there ''could conceivably'' be such abuses, the public would respond so negatively that the state legislature would put an end to the practice.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: The case, Knowles v. Iowa, No. 97-7597, has attracted considerable attention, with organizations of police officers urging the Court to uphold the law. In a series of cases in recent years, the Court has steadily increased the authority of the police in traffic stop situations, giving police the power to order drivers and passengers out of a car and to seek consent for searches in routine traffic stops without advising the driver that consent may be withheld. So one question underlying the proceedings in the courtroom today was whether this case presented the Justices with a line they would not care to cross.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: In other action, the Court issued its first opinion of the new term, ruling unanimously that a labor union does not violate its duty to fairly represent its members when it negotiates a collective-bargaining agreement that appears to require all employees to join the union and pay full dues as a condition of employment.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Under Supreme Court precedents interpreting Federal labor law, employees cannot be required to join a union; they can be required to pay dues to support the union's collective-bargaining activities but not to support union political activities to which they object. But most collective-bargaining agreements include blanket ''union security'' clauses that do not spell out those distinctions and that the plaintiff in this case, Naomi Marquez of Woodinville, Wash., an actress who lost a job because she did not pay dues to the Screen Actors Guild, argued were inherently misleading.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: Writing for the Court today in Marquez v. Screen Actors Guild, No. 97-1056, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said the provisions of the standard contract had become ''terms of art'' that incorporated the relevant Supreme Court precedents and need not be spelled out further.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: The decision upheld a 1997 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco.
title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations

text: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: THE NATION -- THE SOUTH
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: In a remarkable night for a once dying breed, Southern Democrats regained governorships in Alabama and South Carolina, held on to the governorship of Georgia, defeated an incumbent Republican senator in North Carolina, and kept a Senate seat in South Carolina, according to partial vote tallies and surveys of voters leaving the polls.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Whether Tuesday's results suggest a new bipartisan balance or simply a pause in a two-decade trend toward Republicanization remains to be seen. Several of the Southern races were influenced by unique factors, including flawed Republican candidates and the one-time appeal of lotteries proposed by Democratic candidates. But at least here in Alabama, which had been all but written off as Republican turf, Democratic strength extended past the race for governor and into other contests for statewide offices and judgeships.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: As expected, Republicans won the governor's race in Florida, where Jeb Bush led throughout the campaign, and the United States Senate race in Georgia, where the incumbent, Paul Coverdell, defeated a cookie entrepreneur, Michael Coles, by a narrower margin than expected. But in all of the Southern races that had been considered competitive, Democrats prevailed.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: In Alabama, Lieut. Gov. Don E. Siegelman used a lottery proposal as a silver bullet to shoot down Gov. Fob James Jr. in the governor's race, becoming the first Democrat in 16 years to win the state's top job.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: In neighboring Georgia, where the most recent polls had shown the Republican candidate, Guy W. Millner, with a slight lead, the Democratic nominee, Roy E. Barnes, stormed to victory on the strength of heavy turnout by black voters. Mr. Barnes's success maintained Georgia's status as the only state that has not elected a Republican governor since Reconstruction.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Democrats hit the jackpot in South Carolina. The incumbent Republican governor, David Beasley, was ousted by Jim Hodges, the former minority leader of the state House of Representatives, and Senator Ernest F. Hollings fended off an aggressive challenge from Representative Bob Inglis, a 39-year-old Republican.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Like Mr. Siegelman, Mr. Hodges centered his campaign on a proposal for a lottery that would pay for college scholarships, pre-kindergarten programs and other educational improvements. He was aided by missteps by Mr. Beasley and by a large infusion of cash from the state's video poker industry, which considered Mr. Beasley its mortal foe.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: And in North Carolina, a charismatic trial lawyer and political novice, John Edwards, unseated Senator Lauch Faircloth, a one-term Republican. Mr. Edwards will become the fifth different occupant of the North Carolina seat in as many terms. The seat has switched parties in each of the last four elections.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Here in Alabama, Mr. Siegelman's victory seemingly ends Alabama's status as the only Southern state that has not elected a ''progressive'' governor from either party in the post-civil rights era, analysts said.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: It also presumably ends the quirky political career of Mr. James, a former Auburn football star and millionaire barbell manufacturer who has switched parties twice and served two terms as Governor, first from 1979 to 1982 and then from 1995 to the present. During his current term, Mr. James became a national icon for the Christian conservative movement because of his fervent support for returning prayer to the schools and his defiant disdain for Federal judges who have enforced the separation of church and state.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Mr. James's tactics, described as buffoonish by some, reminded many Alabamians, particularly business leaders who are sensitive to the state's national image, of the populist demagoguery practiced by former Gov. George C. Wallace. And on Tuesday, enough of those normally Republican voters abandoned their partisan loyalties, either because of dissatisfaction with Mr. James or the lure of the lottery, and joined Democrats in building a majority coalition for Mr. Siegelman.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Mr. Siegelman has said he shares Mr. James's view that teachers should be able to lead students in prayer. But he stressed that educational issues and not social issues will be his priority.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: William H. Stewart, the chairman of the political science department at the University of Alabama, said that Mr. James's defeat reflects a rejection of the Governor's style far more than of his stands on religion.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Although criticized as exceedingly political, Mr. Siegelman, 52, is as presentable and telegenic as Mr. James, 64, is rumpled and unpolished. A Mobile native, he began his political career as the student body president at the University of Alabama, earned a law degree at Georgetown and then studied international law at Oxford. He has run for statewide office every election cycle since 1978, and has served as Secretary of State, Attorney General and Lieutenant Governor. His only loss came in a 1990 campaign for Governor.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: This year, he ran a disciplined campaign that rarely veered from its focus on a proposed state lottery that would raise an estimated $150 million a year.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Mr. James has pumped money into the state's elementary and secondary schools, and pledged to infuse more if re-elected. But the lottery proved to be a dramatic vehicle that allowed a Democratic candidate to promise vast new spending on education without raising taxes.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: The lottery proposal placed Mr. James squarely on the defensive throughout the campaign, and he trailed in every poll taken during the last three months. He also depleted his campaign coffers in the Republican primary, when Winton Blount, a Montgomery businessman, forced him into a runoff. Mr. Siegelman, by contrast, won his primary with ease and managed to hoard most of the $7 million he raised for his assault on Mr. James.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: The final weeks of the campaign got a bit rough, with Mr. James calling Mr. Siegelman ''a liberal, slick politician'' whose ''eyes go two ways at once.'' Campaigning for Mr. James in Birmingham last week, former Senator Bob Dole urged voters not to elect ''another Bill Clinton,'' and an independent group supporting Mr. James ran television advertisements comparing the two Democrats, including their youthful experimentation with marijuana.
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: Mr. Siegelman, meanwhile, told supporters that voting for ''more Fob,'' as was suggested by the Governor's slogan, would be ''like asking for more disease or famine.''
title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South

text: For Washington State residents who step into the polling place here on Tuesday, deciding whom to vote for may be the simple part. Then there are the whethers: whether to ban most forms of state-sponsored affirmative action; whether to approve the use of marijuana for medical purposes; whether to make it a felony crime to terminate ''a fetus's life during the process of birth''; and whether to raise the state's minimum wage and, for the first time in any state, require automatic future increases tied to the inflation rate.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: In California, voters have another dizzying array of choices, including a measure to expand Indian casino gambling that has sparked the most costly campaign battle over a ballot initiative in the nation's history.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: In many other states, there are constitutional questions. Several states have so-called ''mini Equal Rights Amendment'' measures on their ballot, requiring more gender-neutral language in their constitutions.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: South Carolinians will decide whether to remove a 103-year-old passage in their Constitution that forbids marriage between whites and blacks, a provision that the United States Supreme Court has already ruled unenforceable.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: In South Dakota, voters will decide whether to change a technical oddity in that state's Constitution that allows anyone as young as 2 years old to be elected Governor. No toddler has ever managed to get elected to the post, but if voters agree, the official minimum age will be changed to 21.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: And in Oregon, voters will go to the polls Tuesday to decide, well, whether they will ever go to the polls again. If Oregonians approve this initiative, as they are widely expected to do, all future elections in the state will be conducted entirely by mail.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: Exactly 100 years after South Dakota became the first state in the union to allow direct citizen lawmaking through a process generally known as ''initiative and referendum,'' voters around the nation face many such measures this week, with the battles around some of them so intense that they have generated at least as much attention as Congressional races.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: All told, citizens in 16 states will decide on 61 such initiatives on Tuesday, while more than 170 other measures will deal with constitutional amendments and bond issues, according to the Initiative and Referendum Institute, a nonprofit organization based in Washington, D.C., that tracks the measures. About half the states, most west of the Mississippi where strong populist movements pushed for the right of citizens to make laws, have some method for getting initiatives on the ballot.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: Over the last 100 years, initiatives have been used to advance a disparate collection of causes, including women's suffrage, the minimum wage, the taxpayer revolt, freezes on nuclear-weapons production and term limits for public officeholders.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: In Alaska, initiatives would ban same-sex marriages; make English the state's official language; establish a term-limits pledge for political candidates; allow medical use of marijuana; ban billboards on state highways, and prohibit the trapping of wolves with snares.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: And even as the 1990's are the most prolific decade for initiatives in the nation's history, including 1994, when a record 102 initiatives appeared on state ballots, there are growing signs of a backlash. Many lawmakers have complained that initiatives that sound good on paper can wreak havoc with state budgets or establish onerous constraints. But proponents of the process argue that many legislators do not like initiatives because they represent a direct usurpation of their own power, especially with term limits, which have been forced into law in several states through the initiative process.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: In any event, in at least four states this year -- Mississippi, Missouri, Oregon and Wyoming -- there are measures on the ballot that would, in effect, limit the initiative process. Some of these measures would require ''super-majorities,'' such as a two-thirds vote, for initiatives to pass, while in Wyoming, lawmakers are asking residents to approve new rules that critics say may make it impossible to get any future initiatives on the ballot.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: Under the measure placed on the ballot by the Wyoming Legislature, supporters of future initiatives would be required to obtain signatures from 5 percent of all registered voters in at least two-thirds of the state's 23 counties.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: The initiative process is facing a major legal challenge as well. Just this month, the United States Supreme Court heard arguments in a Colorado case involving new regulations in that state that would require that all signature gatherers for initiative petitions be registered state voters and that they wear identification badges. If upheld, critics say, the regulations could spark restrictions in other states that would make getting initiatives on the ballot even more onerous and expensive.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: Still, with the proliferation of initiatives -- Oregon, California and Colorado all have at least seven this year -- there are concerns that the process could be overused. One measure that has aroused particular discussion is an Arizona initiative pushed by a tax-reform group hoping to influence the state's Presidential primary in 2000.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: The measure would allow candidates for Congress or the Presidency to sign a pledge vowing to work for the abolition of the Internal Revenue Service and replacement of the income tax with a national sales tax. Those who sign the pledge would then get a special designation reading ''Signed the I.R.S. Elimination Pledge'' next to their names on ballots and in voter guides.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: While critics in Arizona say the initiative could set a precedent leading to ballot chaos, with future candidates angling for special designations indicating their support for a range of other causes, like term limits or cancer research, a spokeswoman for the effort describes the tax designation as a valid way of ''holding politicians' feet to the fire'' on the tax issue. The pledges themselves would not be legally binding.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: Across the nation, the most controversial and closely fought initiatives this fall include the gambling measure in California and another measure, promoted by Rob Reiner, the actor and film director, that would increase tobacco taxes by 50 cents a pack and designate the proceeds for children's programs.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: Measures to restrict the late-term procedure that abortion opponents call ''partial-birth abortion'' are also being fiercely contested in Washington and Colorado. Voters in both states are being asked whether to criminalize the rarely used procedure, but abortion-rights advocates say the term ''birth'' is so vaguely defined that the measure could be used to impose much greater restrictions on abortion.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: In Washington, the question before the voters is: ''Shall the termination of a fetus's life during the process of birth be a felony crime except when necessary to prevent the pregnant woman's death?''
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: In Washington, D.C., Washington state, Oregon, Nevada and Alaska, voters will be asked whether to approve the use of marijuana for medical purposes. Such measures passed in California and Arizona in 1996 but have been blocked from implementation by Federal lawsuits. And while supporters say the drug is an effective way of alleviating pain for those who are ill, the Clinton Administration has come out four-square against the measures.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: Barry R. McCaffrey, the administration's chief anti-narcotics official, solicited letters of opposition to the measures from former Presidents George Bush, Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford, and this week Mr. McCaffrey denounced proponents of the ballot measures.
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: ''Let's have none of this malarkey on marijuana smoking by cunning groups working to legalize drugs,'' said Mr. McCaffrey, a former Army general. ''American medicine is the best in the world for pain management.''
title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions

text: Marcus Camby has confined himself to the grounds of a rambling estate he has rented near the Knicks' practice facility in Purchase, N.Y. Barely visible from the road, a stone-and-iron gate marks the passage to the walled-off world Camby seldom leaves at night.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: It is better this way. If there is anything Camby has learned in his turbulent two years in the National Basketball Association, it is this: It's harder for trouble to find you if it does not know where you are.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Although he is only a two-hour drive from his old neighborhood, a decayed pocket of Hartford known as the North End, Camby has allowed few people to know where he lives now.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: But there is one person from his past whom he still embraces as tight as a blanket in the cold: Tamia Murray.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray is a former hustler who sold drugs, mixed in a seamy nightclub scene and pulled countless scams in order to endure the streets of the North End.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: And during a sordid saga that played out at the University of Massachusetts, Murray played a prominent role in an agent scandal that left the school stripped of its 1996 Final Four appearance and left Camby's name disgraced. Murray was on the take as agents, including Wesley Spears and John Lounsbury, plied Camby and his friends with cash, gifts, rental cars and prostitutes at UMass.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Often, Murray has been considered a bad influence in Camby's life. But this is Camby's best friend. How do you ask a player to detach himself from the past? How can he commit a ghetto sin and turn his back on a confidant who helped him survive a neighborhood?
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''People say cut loose from the past, but they really don't know,'' Camby said, standing inside a gray mansion decorated with black-and-white photos of Muhammad Ali and Martin Luther King in the living room. ''I listen to what they are saying and stuff, but I don't pay attention to them. It's how I feel inside. Tamia is a guy who will always be in my corner, and I'll always be in his corner.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''I don't care what anyone says about him. People might say he's in my life because he can get this or that or because I'm this or that, but I don't see it that way.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: He sees Murray as one of the only people he can trust. And so Murray is never far away. Without an outside income, Murray drives Camby's cars, lives at the estate and has many of his expenses paid for by the Knicks' 24-year-old forward.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Although teams are prohibited from discussing players during the N.B.A.'s lockout, there are those within the Knicks' organization who have privately wondered if the friends from Camby's past, like Murray, could lead the team's newest player into some precarious situations.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: This issue is not isolated to the Knicks. The league is concerned about the growing number of its athletes, especially the younger players, who now have entourages. In the league's rookie orientation session, players are cautioned about associating with unsavory crowds.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Camby understands these concerns but believes he and Murray have it all worked out. In the past, particularly when caught up in the dizzying feel of the money that washed over Camby and Murray at UMass, Camby failed to consider the repercussions of his actions -- and those of his friends -- away from the court.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''You have so many people coming at you that you have to really sit down and think, 'O.K., what am I about to do here?' '' Camby said. ''That's the one thing I didn't do. I did things spontaneously, and I was going with the flow. Now, everything I do, I analyze it. Should I do it? Should I not? Is this a bad situation or not? Most of the time the answer is easy: I don't leave my house. I figure if I don't leave my house, I can't get into any trouble.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: It is hard to imagine Camby falling into trouble. He is an affable, well-spoken and respectful person. But he realizes that few see this side of him. He is out to prove that he can be not only a young asset for the aging Knicks, but also a decent and responsible person who has set up the CambyLand Foundation, which focuses on the educational needs of children.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: In all likelihood, his detractors will roll their eyes at this image reclamation project. Camby is still booed when he plays against the Celtics at the Fleet Center in Boston, where the fans believe he betrayed UMass by accepting money from agents, infractions punished by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Although Camby repaid UMass the $151,000 it lost in Final Four tournament money, he rankled some by saying he felt no guilt over his actions. He has been portrayed as a greedy kid without a moral compass.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: But those close to Camby paint a different picture. They see a kid who always tried hard to avoid trouble, to the extent that he turned his back on the men who used to gamble on his high school games at Hartford Public.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''I remember these guys who used to go to the games and bet other guys that Marcus would get 30 points by halftime,'' Camby's cousin, Reggie Jackson, said.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Some say the real trouble began when agents started using cash to get cozy with Camby's friends, like Boris Wray and especially Murray. While no one, including Camby, is making an excuse for his gross missteps at UMass, there is an explanation for how Camby, who grew up under the eye of a strict and loving mother, ended up with his name smeared in a scandal.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''Basically, it all comes back to me,'' Murray said recently as he sat in the driver's seat of Camby's Range Rover parked on the main drag of the North End. ''If I had never started taking cash from certain individuals, none of the bad stuff that went down would have ever happened.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: He wants the blame. Bring it on. As Murray explained himself, his rock-hard exterior, complete with two scars from the bullets he took at ages 11 and 14, began to melt. Unexpectedly, his eyes welled with tears.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''Of course I felt like I let him down,'' Murray said. ''Of course I felt bad. You care about someone, you're not wanting to hurt them.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''But you've got agents who have millions. And they are coming at individuals who have nothing. Marcus didn't know where the money was coming from. If I want to give someone in this neighborhood $10, they don't ask where it comes from. They take whatever they can get. If you can get cash, anyone would take it. Thing is, no one outside this jungle understands that mentality.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: A Homebody Star, A Streetwise Pal
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray and Camby grew up in the North End's unsightly Bellevue Square project, which has since been renamed and renovated. Although crime there has decreased 41 percent in the last four years, according to police department records, North End residents say children still hit the ground when a car backfires in fear of a drive-by shooting.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: In the first 10 months of this year, there have been 10 homicides. In 1994, a year after Camby graduated from Hartford Public, there were 17 murders, 48 sexual assaults, 488 robberies, 605 aggravated assaults and 799 burglaries in the North End, an area noted as the worst crime zone in the city.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Beneath the violence that has long scarred this neighborhood, there were two kids who were as tight as matches in a matchbook. Camby and Murray spent their days shooting hoops and unloading their energy with a game of tag through the hallways of the projects at night. As close as they were, they grew up very differently. Murray was the same age as Camby, but while he was on the streets trying to make a dime, Camby was performing in an elementary school play.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Same neighborhood, different worlds. Recently, Marcus's mother, Janice Camby, was sitting in the living room of a two-story brick home in a suburb of Hartford, with the smell of bacon floating in from a gourmet kitchen.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''Bellevue Square is a long way from here,'' she said, looking around the house her son bought for her after he signed a three-year, $8.4 million deal with the Toronto Raptors two years ago. ''When we were looking for a place, Marcus liked this house. He liked the high ceilings.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Any house would have been fine with her. This is not a woman wed to luxury, not when she still keeps a jar of pennies as a centerpiece in the living room ''because you never know when that rainy day is coming.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: She is wary by nature. She had to be in order to raise three children safely in the projects. So Janice made sure her son was bused to a school in the suburbs until he was in high school, wanting to send him as far away from the gangs as possible.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''It was so bad that my mom wouldn't even let me go to the courts,'' Camby said. ''I had to cut out the bottom of a milk crate and hang it up beside the house.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: The routine was simple: Camby walked in from school, called his mother, then sat with Ruby, his grandmother, and watched the soap opera ''Guiding Light.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''I was addicted to it,'' Camby said. Around 6 P.M., when his mother came home, he was allowed outside until the street lights came on.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Although his father was rarely part of his childhood, Camby had structure and the necessities. Working as a family advocate for Hartford's Community Renewal Team, for which she often tracked down welfare checks for families, Janice Camby could afford the two gallons of milk Camby consumed every three days. She earned enough to keep a tidy apartment filled with the staples for a growing boy, like shoes, clothes and Nintendo.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: It is a childhood that sounds almost normal until Murray interjects some reality.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''Truthfully, Marcus didn't have it better,'' Murray said. ''Everyone around here has mice and rats and roaches. The rats are as big as your foot. You turn over in your bed, and there's a rat in there with you. You pour cereal and roaches fall out. You're lucky if you have cereal. Most kids get grits because their moms are raising them alone and there's no money.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: And no hope. Murray played basketball and was athletic but was not marked with a gold star like Camby.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''When you're 6-11 and the tallest kid in New England, you've got potential,'' Jackson, Camby's cousin, said. ''People were always steering him in the right direction, like, 'Yo, man, don't get lost here, because you can make it.' He had a lot of people to push him.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray was one of them, one of his protectors. If there was a fight in a club, Murray made sure Camby was out of harm's way. If a gang-related shooting was known to be in the works, Murray told Camby to stay home. Murray watched out for Camby, but who was watching out for him?
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''Truthfully, I was a hustler my whole life,'' Murray said. ''I never really worked. I was more in the jungle than Marcus was. He was in it but near the gates. I was in the heart of it, doing whatever I had to in order to survive. I didn't have any money. So when individuals came up to me with money -- and all I know is the street -- I'd take it.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Paying the Price For Easy Money
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray was the perfect target for agents who want to woo future clients by getting close to a best friend or family members. With Camby projected to be a top draft pick out of UMass, his million-dollar future had agents counting money in their heads. There were a lot of unidentified agents, with names much bigger than Spears and Lounsbury, who were trying to pave a trail to Camby through Murray.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: During Camby's junior year, Murray, who made the hour drive to UMass from Hartford to attend each home game, began making the easiest money of his scrabbled life.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''There were situations when I'd go to games at UMass and certain individuals would ask me to walk to the bathroom, and they'd hand me cash,'' said Murray, referring to agents. ''Marcus didn't know at first. You've never had anything in your life, and guys are in front of you wanting to fulfill your every wish. What do you do?''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray played along. He became Camby's middleman, particularly with Spears. Often, Spears handed Murray the cash and gifts. Sometimes Camby saw the money, sometimes Murray just kept it. Although he may have been oblivious at first, Camby soon discovered how lucrative the agent fawning could be.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Then the party was crashed. Once Camby decided to sign with ProServ, which negotiated his $8.4 million rookie deal with the Raptors, the agents who had courted him felt jilted and the alleged stories of extortion were revealed.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Throughout the allegations, Murray could have left Camby on his own. Instead, he stuck by him, and the two friends came to an epiphany. Things had to change.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''I haven't hustled anyone since that situation with the agents,'' Murray said. ''I stopped doing anything that would draw negative attention to Marcus. I used to hustle from 10 A.M. to 1 A.M.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray used to cut deals on the very street where the Range Rover is parked on this fall day. It is early afternoon, but across the street, there is a man buying liquor cases out of the back of a van. About 50 yards away, a car parks next to another. A window rolls down and a package is exchanged for money.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''This is the ghetto; there's nothing you can't sell to make money,'' Murray said. ''Me, I was a hustler. Everyone knew that's how I got my money.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: As he sits in Camby's car, living off Camby's riches, a cynic would wonder if Murray was hustling Camby right now.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''I couldn't do that to Marcus,'' Murray said. ''I mean, you have to understand. I have a heart, too. I have a conscience. There are things I have done that are wrong, real wrong. But I'd never do anything to Marcus.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: As close as he is to Camby, he realizes that if there is a target on his back, his best friend could go down with him. That is why he purged himself from his past two years ago. But two years ago, on a visit back to the neighborhood, Murray didn't know that simply standing on the corner of Vine Street in the North End could cause trouble for Camby, as well. That was proved in an incident that is remembered by people on the streets.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: One night, a car crawled past Murray as he chatted with a woman on the sidewalk. A few minutes later, the three men who had been in the car stood before Murray with chrome pipes in one hand and revolvers in the other. The woman fled.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: This was not about some old scam Murray had pulled in the past.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''These people knew that me and Marcus were tight,'' Murray said. ''They put two and two together and knew that if they got me, they'd get some free cash. They knew that Marcus wouldn't go to the police. Around here, what goes on in the streets has to stay on the streets.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray said he knew if he bent to their demands to get in their car, no one would ever see him again. He said that despite being slapped with a gun and hit with a pipe, he kept his footing and darted away as one man shot at him. With this memory dancing in his head, Murray lets out a nervous laugh. ''I was Houdini that day,'' he said.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: As Camby's cousin Jackson said, ''You never know what Marcus would have gone through if Tamia hadn't gotten away.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray added: ''You know what you learn? Because of how tight I am to Marcus, I can't even stand on a street corner. If something happens to me, it happens to Marcus.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Workouts, Movies And Biding Time
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Together, Camby and Murray have mourned friends who have been murdered and have escaped close calls when it looked as if their own numbers were up. Together, they hang out in a mansion now, isolated from trouble.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: The circle around Camby has drastically closed in the last two years. It includes Murray, but not Wray. As one friend put it, ''Boris is doing things that probably aren't best for Marcus.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Murray has a room at the house where leather couches sprawl in front of television sets the size of department store windows. Movies and video games, that is how the two entertain themselves. Otherwise, Camby bides his time during the lockout by working out.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: He has added 20 pounds of muscle to his 6-11 frame, requiring his tailor to resize his suits. Right now, he is the young forward in wait after a June trade by the Knicks that sent Charles Oakley to Toronto.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''I'm jumping out of my skin,'' Camby said. ''I can't wait to get out there and play in the Garden and show people what I'm really all about.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: This is a fresh start for Camby. His injury-prone days in Toronto -- where he had to play while news of his misdeeds at UMass were exposed -- are in the past. And so, Camby promises, are the distractions.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''Tamia knows that I can't do things that I might want to do because I'm in the limelight,'' Camby said. ''The friends I do have know it's like, 'Hey, you can't do certain things because you're my friends.' ''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: This fact was clear three days after the N.C.A.A. handed down penalties to UMass in June 1997. That is when Camby was spotted weaving on a road in South Windsor, Conn., not far from the luxury home he bought for his mother.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: According to reports, police pulled him over, smelled marijuana in the car, found two burned ''roaches'' and arrested him. To avoid a marijuana possession charge, Camby agreed to perform community service.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: Those close to Camby say the marijuana was not his, but a friend's. If so, Camby's associations had hurt his name once again. And this was after the agent scandal, after Camby was thought to have learned from his past mistakes.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: No doubt, Camby will be watched carefully now. One false step in New York -- where heroes are showered in ticker tape and the fallen are ridiculed in headlines -- and Camby's future earnings could be jeopardized.
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

text: ''My past is behind me,'' Camby said. ''There aren't going to be any other distractions. I know that and the couple of friends I still have, they know that, too. Tamia and I have learned from the past.''
title: Troubling Ties That Bind

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories

text: Go to Home Page »
title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories

text: By day, this seaside resort town in southern Italy is a shuttered ghost town, with fewer than 700 inhabitants in the off-season.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: At night, the population mysteriously swells. When the sea is calm, as many as 500 boat people reach the neighboring coast. Many of the fugitives from Albania, Iraq and Kosovo are pushed or thrown from bobbing rubber rafts by ruthless Albanian smugglers eager to escape the police.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: Some manage to flee through the woods to seek their fortune as ''clandestini,'' or illegal aliens. Those who are rounded up are dried off, patched up and temporarily interned on the grounds of Regina Pacis, a former children's summer camp in San Foca. Others are less lucky. Last Saturday, two rubber rafts collided as they left the Albanian port of Vlore, about 45 miles away across the Adriatic. Six people were killed, including a 6-month-old baby.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: The growing number of refugees and would-be immigrants, their uncertain fate, and concern over the mafia-controlled and highly dangerous route they take to reach Italy have brought matters to a boiling point in a country that has become the preferred port of entry into the European Union for desperate people fleeing war, political unrest and economic distress.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: ''This is is the exact point where the poverty and wealth of the world collide,'' said the Rev. Cesare Lodeserto, 38, a Roman Catholic priest who runs Regina Pacis, currently Italy's largest refugee processing center.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: Built to house a maximum of 250 people, on some nights Regina Pacis crams in more than 600. It is run by the Catholic diocese of Lecce, the provincial capital, relying on volunteers and a state contribution of $18 a person -- significantly less than what the church, other charities and local authorities spend to feed, house, clothe and transport their charges.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: ''The Italian state is everywhere, and it is nowhere,'' Father Cesare said sarcastically, as volunteers ladled out macaroni and roasted chicken prepared by local nuns to a long line of refugees. ''But what are we supposed to do, leave them in the water?''
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: In the first first big exodus of boat people from Albania, in 1991, thousands of refugees were welcomed with vats of spaghetti by local Italians who viewed their arrival as an exciting and short-lived moment in history.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: That euphoria has worn off, and Italians increasingly view the constant new waves of refugees, some seeking asylum from war zones and many more fleeing poverty, as a national emergency and a direct local threat.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: So far this year, more than 10,000 refugees have been processed in the province of Lecce alone. On a hot July day, seven Kurdish refugees washed up on the beach of a popular Club Med in Otranto, startling the tourists who came out to sunbathe.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: ''At the beginning, they came by the hundreds, and we could help them,'' said Niceta Petrachi, 31, who as the watchman of the local fishing port has a nightly front-row view of rafts being pursued by Coast Guard helicopters and navy ships. ''Now there are too many.''
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: ''We already have huge unemployment here,'' he added. ''We cannot handle any more foreigners.''
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: Actually, almost all of the refugees waiting to be processed at the Regina Pacis center expressed no desire to stay in southern Italy, where jobs are scarce and government handouts scanty and available only for a limited time. Most said they had left Kosovo or Iraq or Afghanistan with Germany, Switzerland or Britain as their goal, and Italy merely the Ellis Island through which they had to pass.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: Nevertheless, Italy has many more refugees and immigrants now than ever before. In 1997, there were 1.2 million registered foreigners. The University of Milan's Institute for Statistics recently estimated that in April this year there were at least 235,000 illegal aliens. Many other experts suspect that there are many more.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: In southern Italy, where unemployment reaches 23 percent and the mafia is deeply rooted, immigrants are viewed as stealing jobs and bringing in more organized crime.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: Some local politicians and many residents say they want the Government to crack down hard on the smugglers who make a fortune by ferrying passengers across the Adriatic with the same ruthless efficiency they smuggle arms and marijuana. When the Italian police boats close in on them, the smugglers sometimes escape by throwing children into the water to force their pursuers to stop for rescue operations.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: ''We should do what they would do in America, shoot at the rafts from helicopters after they unload their passengers,'' Gianni Vergari, 41, a San Foca bar owner said grimly. ''The next time, those smugglers would think twice before coming back.''
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: The Italian Government is beginning to heed the rising tide of domestic panic. On Wednesday, the new Minister of the Interior, Rosa Russo Jervolino, flew to Tirana, the Albanian capital, and signed an agreement with her counterparts there to allow Italian police officers to work alongside Albanian law enforcement officials at the port city of Vlore, where most of the smugglers operate in full view of local policemen.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: But Italian refugee law -- or rather the lack of a clear one -- further complicates efforts to deal with the influx. Italy has an agreement with Albania that allows it to reject and repatriate Albanian illegal emigrants. Anyone can apply for political asylum, although ethnic Albanians from Kosovo stand a better chance than most because of the unrest there. A new asylum law drafted to help integrate refugees into society is stalled in Parliament.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: To deal with the waves of immigrants from Albania, the former Yugoslavia and now Kosovo, the Government has passed a series of temporary measures granting refugees short-term aid and asylum on humanitarian grounds.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: Longer term help comes from the church, private charities and the refugees' own survival skills.
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: ''I made it this far,'' said Fatmir Mustafaj, 25, a high-school teacher whose long, dangerous escape from Kosovo included being robbed at gunpoint by Albanian policemen before he took the boat. ''I'll ask for political asylum or I'll become a clandestino, but somehow I'm going to Germany to start a new life.''
title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People

text: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: They are fed up with the negative tone of the campaign. When attack ads appear on television, they turn them off. They feel deprived of any real debate on the issues, and some are even prepared to use their votes to push other political agendas.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: For the undecided, enthusiasm for a candidate will not play a large part as they vote on Tuesday for the United States senator from New York. And with the race locked in a dead heat since primary day, the factors that tip their vote in one direction or another could decide the election -- one of the most expensive and contentious political contests in the country.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Deborah Porter, a devout Baptist from Wappingers Falls, is as faithful about voting as she is about going to church. But the race between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican incumbent, and Congressman Charles E. Schumer, the Democratic challenger, has her dreading the election.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''Neither one of the candidates seem to represent my ideals,'' she said, sounding resigned. ''I probably won't know who I'm going to vote for until Election Day.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: The most recent New York Times/ CBS News Poll, conducted throughout New York State from Oct. 21 through Oct. 25, showed 44 percent of the voters supporting Senator D'Amato, the three-term incumbent. Another 44 percent support Representative Schumer, who has been a member of Congress for 18 years.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: About 10 percent of the voters polled had not made up their minds. Over the last three days, The New York Times conducted more extensive interviews with nearly 40 of those undecided voters. Many of them said they felt caught between a desire for change and a fear of it. Almost all said they felt a strong dislike for both candidates because their campaigns focused on attacks rather than on issues.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: But aware that the clock is ticking, the majority of those interviewed said they were beginning to lean toward one candidate. Some said they had decided to vote along party lines. Some said they had decided to vote for Mr. Schumer because they were appalled by Mr. D'Amato's performance in last weekend's debates and, in a private meeting, his use of a Yiddish vulgarism to attack his opponent. Others said they would vote for Mr. D'Amato because, just days before the election, they still feel Mr. Schumer is a stranger.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Neither candidate seemed to have more support than the other among the voters interviewed.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: One disaffected Democrat, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he had finally decided to support Mr. Schumer because of Senator D'Amato's alliance with House Speaker Newt Gingrich. And William Brunschmid, 71, a wavering Republican from Brockport, said he would vote for Senator D'Amato because Mr. Schumer had refused to support impeachment proceedings in the House against President Clinton.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''The battleground right now is for the hearts and minds of the undecideds,'' said Robert J. Spitzer, a political scientist at the State University of New York at Cortland. ''It seems like the pendulum is swinging toward Schumer, but D'Amato knows that these voters are still winnable for him.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: According to the most recent New York Times/CBS News Poll, undecided voters are as likely to be young as old. They are almost as likely to be white as black. And they are split almost equally among political parties.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: The poll also showed that a majority of the undecided voters live in upstate New York, and that they feel they know more about the campaigns -- from the many caustic commercials that fill the airwaves -- than they do about the candidates.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''I wish when they were out there shaking people's hands they would talk to the voters,'' said Nancy O'Brien, a 63-year-old bookkeeper from Maspeth, Queens. ''There's so much negative campaigning. I'm tired of it.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: At the time she was interviewed, on Wednesday, Ms. O'Brien, a registered Republican, still had not made up her mind. She said she knew too little about Mr. Schumer, except that he had missed a lot of Congressional votes. But she said she was reluctant to support her party's candidate.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''He's been acting like a clown,'' she said of Mr. D'Amato. ''All his name-calling is an embarrassment.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Mrs. Porter, the homemaker from Wappingers Falls, offered a glimpse of the ambivalence that has paralyzed some undecided voters.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''I'm anti-abortion, like D'Amato, but I am not anti-people,'' she said. ''Sometimes I feel the Democratic party is the more compassionate party.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''I believe that Schumer would help the needy,'' she said. ''But I don't think, like the Democrats, that the Government ought to be the only source of funding for such programs.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Then she remembered Mr. D'Amato's use of a Yiddish vulgarism and she changed her mind again.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''It reminds me of Mike Tyson biting Holyfield's ear off,'' she said. ''D'Amato's lost control.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Poll takers and political scientists said this kind of ambivalence keeps many undecided voters from casting ballots on Election Day. Although all of the voters interviewed by The Times promised that they were going to vote, some said they might abstain from choosing a senator.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: With the election only three days away, a majority of the voters interviewed had moved off the fence.
