Some said their decisions were based on the advice of friends: 71-year-old Shirley Stowell of Albany decided to vote for Mr. D'Amato because he was the choice of most people in her Bible study class.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Others chose the candidate of their political party.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Raymond Doucet, a 49-year-old Republican from Wantagh in Nassau County, said he had been disappointed in Mr. D'Amato's votes against legal abortion, but he thought that Mr. D'Amato had done a good job taking care of New York.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''I don't think it's negative that he is known as 'the pothole senator,' '' Mr. Doucet said. ''It shows that he takes care of problems big or small.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: And after weeks of vacillating, Mr. Doucet still did not sound convincing when he said he would stay loyal to his party.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''It may come down to choosing the conservative over the liberal,'' he said. ''If it gets down to crunch time, that's the way I may end up swaying.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Usually, Kathleen Kelly, a Republican, sways the same way. The 30-year-old Republican from Kerhonksen said she had voted her party's ticket for the last few elections. But she said that Senator D'Amato had made her feel embarrassed and that she had decided to dump him after watching last weekend's debates.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''All he seemed to be doing was slinging mud.'' Ms. Kelly said. ''That's the only thing he does with any passion.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Jeffrey Senecal, a 40-year-old Democrat from Albany, said he was so outraged by the negative tone of the campaign and the extraordinary amount of money spent by the candidates that he might turn against both major political parties.
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: ''I almost feel that we have to take a stand and say this is not going to be tolerated anymore,'' Mr. Senecal said. ''If one of these guys wins, it's just going to be a ticket for the next guy to come along and spend millions, sling mud and not talk about any issues.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Scanning a sample ballot printed in his newspaper, Mr. Senecal joked, ''Maybe I'll be voting for the Marijuana Reform Party.''
title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race

text: Even in Greenwich Village, no one knew quite what to make of it. It was a chilly Halloween night in 1974 and through the narrow streets came a procession that looked something like a cross between a Happening and a medieval mystery play.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: There was a man in a seven-foot-tall lobster suit, borrowed from a Sam Shepard play. There was a two-headed pig monster and a giant lizard. The 200 marchers paused to wage a mock battle between good and evil on the steps of the Washington Square Methodist Church, and then wandered across to the park and wondered what else to do.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: ''There were not many people around besides us -- maybe bums,'' said Ralph Lee, the mask and puppet designer who started the Village Halloween Parade. ''And here we were, all holding sparklers, kind of looking at each other.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: When the parade rolls through the Village tonight, a quarter of a century later, its opening announcement, ''Let the Celebration Begin!'' will be heard live on the radio in Japan, and the parade will be televised live in the city. The signature puppets, once made by Mr. Lee in his Village apartment with help from a theater company, will come from an upstate workshop, made with help from such corporate sponsors as Dunkin' Donuts and Snapple. The parade is estimated to bring neighborhood merchants more than $40 million.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: And consuming Avenue of the Americas from Spring Street to 22d Street will be more than 20,000 marchers and 2 million spectators -- a crowd roughly the population of greater Miami and about four times the size of the New Year's Eve celebration in Times Square.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: As things in New York tend to do, what started out small and homegrown has become an annual superlative: the biggest, the best, the most famous. But as with other big things in the city, the parade has also begun to acquire powerful enemies. Many gay participants who once figured prominently in the celebration now complain that it has not only lost its neighborhood spirit, but also its uniquely gay New York character.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: This is in part a reflection of changes in the city's gay population -- as Chelsea and other areas become new centers of gay life, and notions of a seamless ''gay community'' give way to a wider diversity of pursuits and opinions.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: But many gay leaders say the parade has begun to reflect something more troubling: a rise in anti-gay sentiment in the city and across the country. They say that for at least the last five years, it has attracted a sizable group of people who come simply to drink and, often, to taunt, threaten and hurt gay participants.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: ''I think there is just this sense that the parade once felt like a place where we could have fun with everybody,'' said Deven J. C. DeMarco, a gay 24-year-old sous-chef helping to organize a demonstration at the parade to condemn anti-gay violence. ''Now, the parade kind of feels like it's part of the problem,'' Mr. DeMarco said.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: This year, the parade occurs against a backdrop that focuses those feelings more than at any other time: an 81 percent rise in reported anti-gay bias crimes citywide and the killing of Matthew Shepard, a gay college student in Wyoming, which has prompted angry protests around the country.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: But the parade's organizers complain that the event has been unfairly targeted by a small but vocal group of gay men and lesbians. Jeanne Fleming, an artist and event planner who has organized the parade since 1985, says she thinks this may be because the group is seeking issues to reignite gay advocacy in the city.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: Or maybe, she says, it is simply for political gain: Christine Quinn, the executive director of the Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project and a parade opponent, is seeking the City Council seat of Thomas K. Duane, who is gay and who is leaving the council to run for the State Senate.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: The parade's organizers say that Mr. Duane, who supports Ms. Quinn, called for the parade to be canceled this year in part to make it an issue to distinguish Ms. Quinn. Mr. Duane denies any political motives and says that from his perspective, the parade has become ''a sea of homophobia.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: His concerns, the organizers say, are not only unfair but unfounded. They point out that there have been no anti-gay bias incidents reported during the last four years. They say they had no trouble gathering 17,000 signatures from Village residents, many of them gay, on a petition to support the parade.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: ''The people who are against the parade think it was 'ours' and now it isn't -- and that was really never true,'' Ms. Fleming said. ''I do think that's driving some of the sentiment against the parade.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: She added, ''It's being taken over or co-opted by some in the gay community, and I find myself in a very complex position.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: There is an additional layer of animosity from Village residents, both gay and not, who say the parade's main supporters these days are the bars and clubs that profit from it. They say it has simply outgrown the neighborhood and abandoned its modest roots.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: But this is often a matter of perception. At a press conference this week in which the parade organizers announced the issuance of a police permit, an elderly woman on the sidewalk spoke wistfully of the event's humble beginnings: ''This was something that was started for children in the Village,'' she said.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: In fact, says Mr. Lee, the founder, it really was not, and Village residents tend to over-romanticize the parade's beginnings. While many children were involved in the first parades, it was composed mostly of friends and friends of friends, and he got the idea after he staged a similar event for students at Bennington College in Vermont, where he was teaching in the theater department.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: ''I thought of it as a milelong theatrical event,'' he said.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: While he produced it on a shoestring, he added that it was also not exactly a spontaneous, ''Fame''-like outpouring of people onto the streets. From the very first year, Mr. Lee obtained parade permits from the police. And during the first parade, there was a single police scooter at the head of the parade and one at the end.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: But the parade caught on quickly. The next year it doubled in size, Mr. Lee said, and spectators began to line the streets. After first resisting, he soon accepted help from corporate sponsors as expenses escalated. (The parade organization is a nonprofit group, and sponsorship remains relatively small: the parade's budget this year is $43,000, less than half of which comes from big companies, Ms. Fleming said. The rest is from grants, from the city and from Village merchants and individuals.)
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: By 1985, when the parade had grown so large that the route was shifted off the side streets of the Village onto Avenue of the Americas, Mr. Lee said he no longer had the time or energy to organize it. ''What I really always wanted,'' he said, ''was for people to come and watch it and then go home to their own communities and have their own celebrations; but I knew that was never going to happen.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: Mr. Lee added that though there were gay participants during the first years, drag queens and overtly gay elements were not noticeable until several years later.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: Ms. Fleming said she estimated that by the mid-1980's, gay participation had grown to about 30 percent and was very visible.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: Men in drag and men and women wearing next to nothing shared the streets with Christian fundamentalists, Hare Krishna adherents, AIDS activists and people dressed as witches, goblins, shoes, nuns, urinals and tubes of lipstick.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: But by 1991 she remembered surveying the crowd and thinking, ''My God, I'm running a straight event.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: Even as large as the parade has grown, the police say it remains one of the tamer celebrations in the city for its size.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: Mike Singer, a community affairs officer for the Sixth Precinct, where most of the parade takes place, said that in 1997 the police issued 394 misdemeanor summonses for open alcohol containers, six for disorderly conduct, two for possession of marijuana, three for public urination and 29 for various other misdeeds. The police estimated that about 1.5 million people attended. The number of summonses represented a slight increase from 1996, but Officer Singer said that criminal activity had not risen consistently over the years.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: ''Crime is really very low the night of the parade,'' he said. ''Quality-of-life complaints are high.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: But some residents said that the low number of summonses reflects the fact that there are not enough police officers to catch wrongdoers and that the process of reporting crimes, especially anti-gay bias crimes, is difficult. (The police will not say how many officers patrol the parade, but they say the number will be larger this year.)
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: Matt Foreman, a past director of the Anti-Violence Project, said he remembered bottles being thrown at him and others when they marched in the parade in 1990 and 1991 with Queer Nation, a street protest group. ''But you're going to the precinct on Halloween night to spend several hours there reporting an incident where you're not seriously injured?'' he asked. ''Come on.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: Ms. Fleming -- who loves Halloween so much that she once got married on Halloween night -- said she has become accustomed to opposition over the last few years. And it has not ruffled her because the tradition of the parade itself has been one of dissent and radically opposed viewpoints.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: ''This is an event where literally every group is marching to a different drummer, and part of the fascination is to figure out how to keep it all together,'' she said early this week.
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: But by Thursday night, after long days of trying to calm nerves and rally support and figure out whether protesters would disrupt the parade, she added wearily: ''Right now, if I had a choice, I would say it's become too political and it's not for me anymore. I'm an artist.''
title: Bad Spirits Invade Village Parade; Minor Event Becomes Major and Causes Major Dissent

text: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr.
title: Political Briefing; Aiming the Big Guns At Drug Initiatives

text: With polls indicating that ballot initiatives to legalize marijuana for medical use might pass next Tuesday in some states, Barry R. McCaffrey, the retired Army general who is White House director of drug control policy, figured it was time to throw more troops into the fight. So he enlisted three former Presidents -- George Bush, Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford -- and asked them to write a ''Dear Fellow Citizen'' letter that would point out why the initiatives should be defeated.
title: Political Briefing; Aiming the Big Guns At Drug Initiatives

text: The letter arrived on Wednesday and is being distributed to news outlets and antimarijuana forces in Alaska, Oregon and Washington, where polls show most voters support the initiatives. It also has been sent to Nevada and the District of Columbia, where passage is more in doubt.
title: Political Briefing; Aiming the Big Guns At Drug Initiatives

text: The thrust of the letter is that until Government researchers can determine whether marijuana is medically effective, it should not be approved for medical use -- or, as one paragraph pointedly puts it, for ''alleged medical purposes.''
title: Political Briefing; Aiming the Big Guns At Drug Initiatives

text: ''These initiatives are not based on the best available science,'' the letter argues. ''Compassionate medicine must be based on science, not political appeals. Prejudging research through a political process would be irresponsible and is not in our national interest.''
title: Political Briefing; Aiming the Big Guns At Drug Initiatives

text: The three former Presidents then encourage voters in Arizona to pass a ballot initiative that would require the Food and Drug Administration to approve medical use of marijuana before Arizona doctors could prescribe it.
title: Political Briefing; Aiming the Big Guns At Drug Initiatives

text: In distributing the letter, General McCaffrey said: ''These great former elected national leaders, who we all respect so much, know that we cannot use the ballot box to determine what is safe and effective medicine. Nor should we send a terribly mixed message to our children.''
title: Political Briefing; Aiming the Big Guns At Drug Initiatives

text: After casting a last glance at his mother, a teen-ager accused of selling crack cocaine jumped out the window of a packed Manhattan courtroom yesterday and fell 16 stories to his death after a judge offered to give him a three- to six-year prison sentence if he agreed to plead guilty in the case, officials and witnesses said.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: The defendant, Derrick Smith, 19, rejected the plea bargain. Then, as court officers were leading him to a holding cell behind the courtroom, Mr. Smith, who was not handcuffed, broke free and jumped out an open window, shaken witnesses said.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: ''I thought his mother was going to have a nervous breakdown,'' said John Toliaferro, 44, a legal assistant who was in court. ''She kept saying, 'That's my son, that's my son.' ''
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: The suicide was a jarring interruption to the daily routine at Manhattan State Supreme Court, as lawyers, judges, jurors and even defendants crowded the sidewalks at lunchtime below the building at 100 Centre Street, which was once known as ''the Tombs'' for the faux-Egyptian architecture of a much smaller courthouse that stood there in the 19th century.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: It was supposed to have been a routine court date for Mr. Smith, who was arrested Sept. 19 and accused of selling crack cocaine on the corner of St. Marks Place and Second Avenue in the East Village, according to an indictment. Since his arrest, Mr. Smith had been held on Rikers Island because no one had paid the $2,500 bail to set him free.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Noting that Mr. Smith was already on probation for a 1995 drug case and that he had been arrested several times since then on charges of selling marijuana, Justice Budd G. Goodman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan revoked the offer of bail yesterday and ordered him sent back to Rikers Island.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Then, according to a transcript of the proceedings, he told Mr. Smith that the plea offer, ''for today only,'' was three to six years in prison.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Mr. Smith's lawyer, Frank Bari, rejected the offer, setting the wheels in motion for the case to go to trial.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Then Mr. Smith addressed the court. ''I'm 19 years old your honor,'' he said, according to the transcript. ''That is terrible. That's terrible.'' Then Mr. Smith asked to represent himself. Mr. Bari, his lawyer, advised him against this, and Justice Goodman ordered Mr. Bari to submit the next motions in the case.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Alfonso Wilson, 35, who was in the courtroom with a friend who had a court date, said that Mr. Smith then turned to face his mother. ''He looked at his mother,'' he said. ''He looked very discouraged. Their eyes met.''
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Court officers led Mr. Smith behind a glass partition that forms a sort of corridor along the outer wall of the courtroom and leads to an adjoining holding cell. The corridor is in view of at least part of the courtroom. As he passed a window, witnesses said, they heard a commotion.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Mr. Toliaferro said that Mr. Smith's mother jumped up. ''She ran back, behind the partition,'' he said. ''Then she saw what happened. She saw the open window, and the court officer there alone.'' Mr. Smith's mother, who was not identified by the authorities, was taken to a nearby hospital and treated for trauma.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: David Bookstaver, a spokesman for the Office of Court Administration, said that it is not unusual for defendants to be allowed to walk without handcuffs when they are in what are considered secure areas.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Jesse Drucker, who was sitting on a grand jury on the ninth floor of the building, said that he saw Mr. Smith fall past the window. ''We saw this black and blue mass fly by the window,'' he said. ''It was terrible. The first thing I thought was that it was a body.''
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Mr. Smith landed in a driveway -- known to Corrections Officers as the ''sallyport'' -- next to the court where Police Department and Corrections Department vans and buses take defendants to and from court. He hit a bus before hitting the ground, officials said.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Mr. Smith was convicted of drug possession in 1995 and sentenced to six months in prison and five years' probation. Since then he had been convicted several times of selling marijuana but had not been held for violating his probation.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: Jack Ryan, a spokesman for the Department of Probation, said Probation officials would review the case to make sure it had been handled correctly.
title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death

text: The illicit drug ecstasy may cause long-lasting nerve cell damage in the brains of heavy users, according to a report published yesterday by scientists at Johns Hopkins University.
title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug

text: The study compared the brain scans of 14 men and women who reported having used the drug from 70 to 400 times with the scans of control subjects who said they had never used it. The heavy users of ecstasy, or MDMA, showed a significant decrease in brain cells responsible for reabsorbing serotonin, a messenger chemical involved in mood, appetite, pain perception, sexual drive and memory. People who take ecstasy on a recreational basis ''are unwittingly putting themselves at risk,'' the scientists said.
title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug

text: The research team, led by Dr. George Ricaurte, a neurologist, developed a novel technique for tracking the cells, serotonin transporters, using positron emission tomography, or PET scanning. Transporter cells are embedded in nerve cell membranes at the tips of thin projecting fibers called axons. The reduction in serotonin transporters in heavy users, Dr. Ricaurte said, is an indication that serotonin nerve endings, where the transmitter is released, have been damaged.
title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug

text: It is still unknown whether people who have used ecstasy less frequently -- taking it a few times over the course of years, for example -- incur similar damage. Nor is it clear what if any effects the nerve damage caused by heavy use might have on behavior. But Dr. Ricaurte said his team found early indications that MDMA had some effects on memory. People who have taken ecstasy say it makes them feel closer to other people and puts them more in touch with their emotions. One psychotherapist described it as ''penicillin for the soul.''
title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug

text: Ecstasy is a hybrid of the stimulant methamphetamine and the hallucinogen mescaline. It was synthesized more than 80 years ago as an appetite suppressant, and became popular as a street drug in the 1970's and early 80's. The compound was banned in 1985 by the Drug Enforcement Administration after truck drivers began using it as a stimulant. Ecstasy still has a following in the all-night club scene and is valued by some psychotherapists, who say it helps break down psychological barriers.
title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug

text: The study, published in the medical journal Lancet, lends support to earlier work by the Johns Hopkins team, which found evidence of damage to serotonin nerve endings in primates and other animals given doses of ecstasy equivalent to those taken by some humans, when differences in body mass and other factors are taken into account, the researchers said. Subjects in the study were screened to make sure they had not used other drugs, like marijuana, cocaine and barbiturates, that could affect the results in the period immediately before the study.
title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug

text: The study's results leave open the question of whether the damage from MDMA is reversible in humans. In studies in baboons, brain alterations triggered by ecstasy were still present a year after the animals were given the drug.
title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug

text: The study offers ''a warning that this kind of drug use can produce long-lasting abnormalities in the brain,'' said Dr. John Mann, a Columbia University psychiatrist and chief of neuroscience at the New York State Psychiatric Institute. ''People take a lot of stuff that affects their brains thinking that it's harmless, and it might not be.''
title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug

text: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE MYSTERY
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Although nothing in politics is certain, least of all predictions, polls suggest that George E. Pataki will most likely win the race for Governor next Tuesday, and that Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic nominee, will finish a distant second.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: The real mystery is who will come in third.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Among the minor-party candidates jostling for that dubious honor are Thomas K. Leighton of the Marijuana Reform Party, which advocates a system of legal distribution of marijuana; the Green Party's Al Lewis, also known as Grandpa Munster, and Michael J. Reynolds of the Right to Life Party. In addition to carrying the Republican Party standard, Mr. Pataki is the candidate of the Conservative Party and Mr. Vallone counts on the support of the Working Families Party.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: But the two leading contenders for also-ran are a millionaire -- B. Thomas Golisano, a Rochester businessman who ran for governor on the newly formed Independence Party ballot line in 1994 and is doing so again -- and a millionaire's wife: Betsy McCaughey Ross, the formerly Republican Lieutenant Governor whose try for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination failed resoundingly after her husband, Wilbur L. Ross Jr., a financier, withdrew much of his financial support. Ms. McCaughey Ross is now on the Liberal Party line.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: The most recent New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows Mr. Golisano with 9 percent of 1,235 registered voters polled, and Ms. McCaughey Ross with 5 percent, to Mr. Vallone's 21 percent. Mr. Pataki is in front with 56 percent. Nine percent is undecided.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Given Mr. Pataki's sizable lead from the start, neither Mr. Golisano nor Ms. McCaughey Ross has exactly shaken up the race. But not constrained by hope or expectations, they have persisted with their quixotic campaigns, Mr. Golisano with considerably more enthusiasm. For both candidates, more than mere ego is at stake. Unless they win 50,000 votes, their parties will lose their official lines on the ballot in the next election.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Mr. Golisano's campaign strategy is simple: a few news conferences assailing Mr. Pataki's ''borrow-and-spend'' policies, and lots of money. His most recent financial disclosure form, filed Oct. 20, showed that he had lent his campaign just over $20 million, and that it had spent close to $12 million. He estimates that his spending will total $13 to $15 million.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: With paid media doing the work for him, Mr. Golisano is free to continue tending his payroll processing company, Paychex Inc., which he founded in Rochester in 1971. He and the political consultants and media concerns he has hired have papered the state's buses, trains and billboards with his slightly smiling visage and blitzed its television stations with witty political commercials.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Most of the ads needle Mr. Pataki about the state's growing debt. In 1994, Mr. Golisano ran on a range of issues, including massive tax cuts, and won 4 percent of the vote, but this year, he has made debt reduction the centerpiece of his campaign, saying that the Governor has irresponsibly increased state spending and ballooned its debt, particularly through ''back-door borrowing'' that is not approved by the voters. ''He's trying to create a false sense of euphoria about our state's economy,'' Mr. Golisano says of the Governor.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: The candidate's focus appears to be paying off. In an attempt to ride Mr. Golisano's financial coattails, aides say, Mr. Vallone has begun hammering the theme of debt reduction much harder. And on Sunday, The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle, which endorsed Mario Cuomo in 1994, endorsed Mr. Golisano, whom it described as ''beating the drums of fiscal responsibility.''
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Given the withdrawal of her husband's financial support, Ms. McCaughey Ross has had no choice but to keep a lower profile. She devotes most of her time to banging out Op-Ed articles and policy papers at her Manhattan office. ''She's spending a lot of time behind her laptop,'' said Cristina Page, an aide at the Lieutenant Governor's office. ''She usually spends her day with me in the office.''
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: As Ms. McCaughey Ross, who was plucked from political obscurity by Mr. Pataki in 1994 after writing several highly critical articles about President Clinton's health care plan, put it, ''I'm not a typical career street politician.''
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Her demeanor is not that of a desperate campaigner but of a beatific crusader. She, too, has adopted only a few issues: reproductive rights; the expansion of the state's prescription drug program for the elderly, and explaining to Congress, the public and anyone who will listen why the Republican Congress should not impeach Mr. Clinton. (''I'm a constitutional scholar,'' she says in explaining the issue's relevance to her.)
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: When Ms. McCaughey Ross does venture out, it is often unclear -- even to her own aides -- whether her appearances are as Lieutenant Governor or as a candidate. Last week, for instance, she visited a Chinese-American health care clinic, debated Dick Morris, a former presidential adviser, on the President's travails and showed up on a Saturday morning at 8:30 in a black suit and pearls to support a Brooklyn abortion clinic regularly visited by anti-abortion protesters.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: In part, the blurring of lines is a practical matter. As her campaign spokesman, Kevin Davitt, put it, ''Frankly, she has a little more oomph as Lieutenant Governor'' on the issues. ''Our problem is we're not as -- how shall we put it -- desirable as we were during the primary,'' Mr. Davitt said.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: While Ms. McCaughey Ross was one of the political dignitaries in last week's Yankee parade -- riding alone in a convertible -- she did not share the dais with the Governor and Mr. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council. (The Governor and the Lieutenant Governor essentially stopped speaking several years ago.)
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Her campaign has fallen to the Liberal Party and its chairman, Raymond B. Harding. His party cast its lot with Ms. McCaughey Ross in part because her husband had pledged several million dollars to her campaign. When he withdrew the bulk of that support less than two weeks before the primary, all bets were off, and the pressure was on Mr. Harding to raise enough cash to run something of a campaign.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: ''It is the first time the Liberal Party has had the 'privilege' of having to not only run the campaign but worry about the fund-raising angle of it,'' Mr. Harding said. Mr. Harding is a close mayoral ally and a partner in the lobbying firm of Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding and among the friends and clients he has tapped are some, like Donald Trump and David C. Walentas, the developers, whose real estate concerns are likely to be affected by the city.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Mr. Harding has raised enough money to get some television ads featuring Ms. McCaughey Ross on the air, and he says he is confident that the Liberal Party will win enough votes to secure its future.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Ms. McCaughey Ross said she was uncertain about her future past election day, but she said that another gubernatorial campaign was possible although she did not specify a party. Many politicians and analysts believe it is unlikely, after the events of this year, that she will ever again be a major party candidate for either party.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: The future of Mr. Golisano's party, which he founded about four years ago, seems assured as well, which he says is partly the reason he ran. The Independence Party now has 122,172 registered members. (The Liberal Party has 92,498 members, and the Conservative Party, 166,985.)
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: ''We're creating permanent competition with the Independence Party,'' Mr. Golisano said. ''With competition, the consumer wins.''
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Consciously or not, Mr. Golisano is also building his business: while he has spent millions of his own money, he and Paychex have also earned millions in free publicity. But Mr. Golisano said that the attention in New York State would not have a significant impact on his nationwide business.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Will he run again? ''I'm certainly going to keep an open mind to it,'' Mr. Golisano said, ''and I'm going to be very active in the next four years. There are some issues I still want to work on.''
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: Chief among them, he said, is campaign finance reform. If he had another way of reaching voters, he said, like debates or free air time or public financing, he would have preferred to give the $13 million or so to charity.
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: ''I wish we could take the money out of the campaigns,'' Mr. Golisano said. ''Peter Vallone might have had a better chance.''
title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross

text: The trial of the former student accused of killing Jonathan M. Levin turned to the intricacies of scientific evidence yesterday as a forensic expert testified that DNA evidence linked the student to the knife used in the attack and showed that his clothes had been stained with his former teacher's blood.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: But defense lawyers for the former student, Corey Arthur, 20, seized on another piece of the expert's testimony: that some of the DNA found on the knife could not have come from their client, another man charged in the attack or the victim. The defense has contended that other unknown people took part in the attack and shot Mr. Levin.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: Mr. Arthur and the other man charged, Montoun T. Hart, are accused of torturing Mr. Levin in his Upper West Side apartment on May 30, 1997, to force him to divulge the access code to his bank card so they could withdraw money from his account. Then, prosectors said, Mr. Arthur shot and killed Mr. Levin, his former English teacher.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: Mr. Arthur is facing first-degree murder charges.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: Mr. Levin, who was 31 when he was killed, was the son of Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner Inc. The younger Mr. Levin taught English at William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx, where he met Mr. Arthur.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: Lawrence Quarino, a forensic scientist at the office of the Chief Medical Examiner, testified that Mr. Arthur's clothes were stained with his own blood and with blood that contained DNA that matched Mr. Levin's. Only one in 3,600,000 white men have that precise DNA, he testified.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: Then, after putting on latex gloves, Mr. Quarino held up the knife that prosecutors say was used to torture Mr. Levin and explained that Mr. Levin's DNA was found in the blood that stained both sides of the blade.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: But there was a mixture of DNA on the handle of the knife, he said. Some matched Mr. Levin's and some matched Mr. Arthur's, but other samples of DNA found on the knife handle could not have come from either man or from Mr. Hart, Mr. Quarino testified.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: On Tuesday, one of Mr. Arthur's former girlfriends, Carlethia Weeks, testified that he had told her he shot Mr. Levin but that ''Monty tied the guy up and stabbed him.'' The trial of Mr. Hart, 26, on second-degree murder charges is set to begin on Jan 18.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: Mr. Quarino also testified that unidentified DNA found on a cigarette butt in Mr. Levin's apartment was also mixed with DNA consistent with Mr. Arthur's and Mr. Levin's.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: On cross-examination, George M. Goltzer, a defense lawyer, asked Mr. Quarino if it was possible that a fourth person had been in the apartment and left traces of DNA on the cigarette butt and the knife.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: ''It is possible,'' Mr. Quarino answered, adding that while the unidentified DNA found on the cigarette is consistent with the unidentified DNA found on the knife, it is not rare and could come from two different people.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: Bloodstains found on one of Mr. Arthur's black Timberland boots and on the left sleeve and right elbow of his Yankee jacket contained DNA consistent with Mr. Levin's, Mr. Quarino testified.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: In an apparent setback for the defense, Dr. Marina Stajic, the director of toxicology for the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, testified that tests found no signs that Mr. Levin had smoked marijuana or used cocaine in the days before he died.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: ''It is unlikely that any significant amount was used approximately within a week of his death,'' she testified.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: In a previous statement to the police, Mr. Arthur claimed that he had gone to his former teacher's apartment that day to sell him crack and that the two men had smoked the crack together immediately before two other men burst in and waged the attack.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: Dr. Stajic said that if Mr. Levin had smoked crack right before his death, its presence would have been detected on the toxicology tests her officer performed.
title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes

text: A former girlfriend of Corey Arthur, the young man accused of torturing and fatally shooting his former high school English teacher, testified yesterday that Mr. Arthur confessed the killing to her.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: The former girlfriend, Carlethia Weeks, 24, said that Mr. Arthur first alluded to the shooting of the teacher, Jonathan M. Levin, over the telephone, saying he had done ''something bad.'' Then, she said, she met with Mr. Arthur on June 4, 1997, and he admitted that he had fatally shot Mr. Levin in the teacher's apartment on the Upper West Side on May 30.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: ''He told me what he did,'' Ms. Weeks said. ''He told me he can't believe that he killed the teacher.''
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Mr. Levin, 31, the son of Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner Inc., was a popular English teacher at William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Prosecutors have argued that Mr. Arthur and an accomplice, Montoun T. Hart, tortured Mr. Levin to force him to divulge the access code to his automated teller machine card so they could withdraw money from his account.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Mr. Arthur's lawyers have acknowledged that their client was in Mr. Levin's apartment, but have claimed that Mr. Hart and others were responsible for the killing.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Mr. Arthur, 20, has been charged with first-degree murder. Mr. Hart, 26, has been charged with second-degree murder. His trial is to begin on Jan. 18.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Ms. Weeks testified yesterday that Mr. Arthur told her that he shot the teacher after Mr. Hart tied Mr. Levin up and stabbed him.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: An assistant district attorney, Eugene Hurley, then asked her, ''Did he tell you anything else?''
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Ms. Weeks replied: ''Oh, that he shot the guy, that he couldn't believe he shot the teacher. I told him I didn't believe him.''
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Some of Ms. Weeks's testimony appeared to be inconsistent with previous statements about the case. She said yesterday that she last saw Mr. Arthur and Mr. Hart on May 30, the evening Mr. Levin was killed, getting into a car near the intersection of Lexington and Lewis Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, not far from her house.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: But previous police reports said that Mr. Arthur and Mr. Hart took the subway into Manhattan that day. And prosecutors have said that Mr. Arthur called Mr. Levin from a pay phone in Manhattan at 4:55 P.M. that day. The prosecution said that Mr. Hart withdrew $800 from Mr. Levin's account that day at 5:15 P.M.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: The prosecution and the defense have agreed that Mr. Arthur suffered a cut on his hand around the time of the attack. On cross-examination yesterday, Mr. Arthur's lawyer, Anthony Ricco, asked Ms. Weeks whether she saw a cut on Mr. Arthur's hand on June 4. She said she did not remember.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Ms. Weeks, a high school dropout, said she raised her three children, 6, 3 and 2, with the help of welfare and disability checks she receives for asthma and other ailments. She said that when she was having a relationship with Mr. Arthur, they saw each about three times a week.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Asked whether she had strong feelings for Mr. Arthur, she said, ''Not really.''
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: After she testified, the issue of drug use resurfaced. Mr. Arthur told the police after his arrest that he was in Mr. Levin's apartment to sell him crack cocaine when two armed men arrived. Mr. Arthur, who has denied committing the killing, said he managed to escape.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Mr. Levin's friends have testified that he occasionally used marijuana, but not cocaine.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: Yesterday, three narcotics detectives testified that they searched Mr. Levin's apartment several months after the slaying and found a small amount of marijuana, cigarette papers and pieces of a pipe as well as a bottle with cocaine residue, a small bottle with a cocaine spoon chained to it and a blue plastic stopper often used on crack vials.
title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher

text: The meetings have not been billed emergency sessions, but with the National Basketball Association scheduled to announce the cancellation of more games today, negotiations between owners and players may go a long way toward settling the nearly four-month-old labor impasse and salvaging the season.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: Commissioner David Stern and representatives from all 29 teams will meet with Michael Jordan, Patrick Ewing and as many as 200 of their peers today at a midtown Manhattan hotel. The meeting represents the best hope for the two sides to try to work out a revenue-sharing plan.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: With three bargaining sessions in the past four days, there are clear signs that both sides are beginning to compromise. As the financial losses mount -- player losses in salary may reach $200 million if cancellations are announced today -- much of the rhetoric and posturing has begun to subside.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: The perception among many players is that the owners were merely waiting for the players to lose paychecks before genuinely exploring a deal. With an estimated 200 players standing firm for the moment, the question now is whether the two sides can agree on numbers in time to avert losing the season.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: The owners have pulled back on their insistence on a hard salary cap, while the players have offered alternatives to help the owners bring salaries in line with the league's revenue growth.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: Stern and his deputy commissioner, Russ Granik, have indicated that an agreement needs to be in hand by early December to prevent losing the entire season. The league lost its first two weeks on Oct. 13, the first time games were canceled in the N.B.A.'s 52-year history. Barring a settlement, the rest of the November schedule -- and probably some December games -- will most likely be canceled today.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: Billy Hunter, the union's executive director, Ewing, its president, and other players met with N.B.A. legal representatives yesterday at a Manhattan law firm. The two sides discussed non-economic issues relating to player conduct, including discipline and adding marijuana and performance-enhancing drugs to the list of banned substances.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: ''We're trying to salvage as much of the season as possible,'' Hunter said. ''I'm optimistic we're going to get a deal. I can't say it's going to happen this week.''
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: Meanwhile, the owners' labor relations committee held its own meetings and was apprised of developments from Monday night's marathon bargaining session in New York.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: Like two armies massing and moving toward the front, the two parties fortified their positions yesterday.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: ''The good news is we're talking and we seem to be talking about the same thing,'' said Danny Schayes, a member of the union's executive committee. ''The most important economic things are the things we're farthest away on. But there is some hope.''
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: Schayes was one of 13 players who took part in Monday night's talks, a session that several participants said was the most productive since the lockout began July 1.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: The key development seemed to be an agreement on an economic framework that could be used to divide revenue and could lead to the signing of a new collective bargaining agreement, a precursor for starting the season.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: If approved, it would entail a hybrid from proposals on both sides. For the first two years of the deal, a luxury tax would be employed to bring salaries in line with revenue growth. The next two years would involve the league's plan for an escrow fund.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: ''We need a system that eventually gets to where there's a set percentage for the players and a set percentage for the owners,'' Granik said. ''I don't think it has to be a hard cap, and in fact some of the things we're talking about now are not hard caps.''
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: The owners want a system in which the percentage of basketball-related income devoted to player salaries is reduced from 57 percent to 48 percent by the 2002-03 season. Their insistence on an eventual 48 percent payout is the biggest stumbling block to a settlement, Hunter said. The players have countered proposals that would give them 63 percent of the total revenue.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: There are reservations on both sides over whether the system would work, but the fact that the owners and players seem to be closing in on a concept represented initial hope that the season could begin before next year.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: The owners have also asked for other economic concessions, including establishing a maximum salary, reducing performance bonuses and reducing the maximum length of contract from seven years to five or six.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: After the league's board of governors convenes at 8:30 A.M. today, nearly half the league's 400-plus players are expected to file into a midtown hotel for their own meetings. Both sides plan to face off sometime in the afternoon.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: Aside from the executive committee, most players will observe the talks rather than participating directly in the bargaining.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: Yesterday's meeting on player-conduct issues was the first time both sides talked at length about issues other than economics since late last spring.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: The players, as concerned as the league about the image problems of some of their peers, have made several concessions on behavioral matters. Few specifics were agreed on, however.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: ''We talked about a lot of issues, but I can't say we made a lot of progress,'' said Jeffrey Mishkin, the league's chief legal counsel.
title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating

text: A man who was shot to death by the police on Sunday night after walking bare-chested into a Queens station house and attacking officers with a screwdriver and a kitchen knife had a long history of psychiatric problems and had recently complained to his mother about ''the Devil,'' law enforcement officials said yesterday.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: The troubled life of the man, Kevin Cerbelli, 30, ended shortly before 9 P.M., just minutes after he walked into the 110th Precinct station house at 91-41 43d Avenue in Elmhurst, stabbed one officer in the back with the screwdriver, lunged at others with the knife and ignored several orders to drop his weapons, said Inspector Michael Collins, a police spokesman.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: Investigators said yesterday that they were not sure what led Mr. Cerbelli, who lived in Elmhurst, to mount his attack, but noted that he had been in and out of group homes and mental hospitals for years and that he was on probation after being convicted of reckless endangerment in connection with a 1994 arson in Queens.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: Shortly before Sunday's attack, Mr. Cerbelli telephoned his mother, Loretta Cerbelli, 56, and told her that he had been using cocaine and marijuana, talked about the Devil and said he believed that he would be arrested soon, said a law enforcement official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The official added that Mr. Cerbelli was not wanted by the police.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: A telephone call to Mrs. Cerbelli's home in Queens was not answered yesterday.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: Just before 9 P.M. Sunday, Mr. Cerbelli -- wearing sweat pants but no shirt -- walked into the station house and stabbed Sgt. Michael Baretto in the back with a screwdriver, the police said. Sergeant Baretto, who is assigned to a task force that combats crime along Roosevelt Avenue, was protected by his bulletproof vest and suffered only a bruise on his right shoulder, the police said.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: Speaking incoherently, Mr. Cerbelli continued walking through the station house and stopped in front of the main desk, the police said. Some officers backed into a room where arrested suspects are processed to keep Mr. Cerbelli away from them, the police said, and other officers surrounded him and ordered him to drop his weapons.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: One officer tried to subdue Mr. Cerbelli with a Taser -- an stun gun -- but it had no effect, the police said. When Mr. Cerbelli refused repeated orders to drop the weapons and made several feints at officers with the knife, the police said, Officer Paul Valdes, 29, opened fire. He was soon joined by two other officers, James Williams, 29, and Robert Ehmer, 35, the police said. They fired a total of eight shots; the police believe that Mr. Cerbelli was struck seven times. He was later pronounced dead at Elmhurst Hospital.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: Lieut. William McBride, 29, suffered minor injuries when he was struck in the groin by a bullet that ricocheted during the fusillade, the police said. He and Sergeant Baretto were treated at Elmhurst Hospital and released.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: The police said they were not sure whether Mr. Cerbelli's attack was a case of ''suicide by cop,'' a phenomenon in which troubled people goad police officers into shooting them to death.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: Mr. Cerbelli had been in trouble with the law before. Family members told investigators that he had struggled with drug addiction and that he was ''paranoid, schizophrenic and has dreams that he thinks come true or tries to live out,'' said another law enforcement official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. His mother once took out an order of protection against him, the official said.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: In 1994, Mr. Cerbelli was arrested on arson charges after the group home where he lived, at 143-12 Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, burned down, officials said. Ruth Lopez, his downstairs neighbor then, told investigators that after she rebuffed his romantic overtures, he told her on April 28, 1994, that he had dreamed that their building was going to catch fire and that she and her children would burn, the second law enforcement official said.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: Ms. Lopez said Mr. Cerbelli told her again about the dream on April 29 and on April 30, the official said. Later that night, the house went up in flames.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: After spending two years in jails and mental hospitals awaiting trial, officials said, Mr. Cerbelli was convicted of reckless endangerment and sentenced to five years' probation, with the condition that he seek mental help. Jack Ryan, a spokesman for the city Department of Probation, said Mr. Cerbelli had continued to meet with his probation officers when he was not in the hospital.
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: His neighbors in Elmhurst described Mr. Cerbelli as withdrawn, often playing chess by himself in the park. ''He seemed like a loner -- kind of quirky, in his own world,'' said Michael Rosado, 37, his next-door neighbor. ''It was just my instinct, but if he was outside when my kids were around I'd watch them very closely.''
title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems

text: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN -- THE DEMOCRAT
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Chuck Schumer had just graduated from Harvard Law School, earning a passport to the kind of wealth and freedom from worry that his parents could only imagine, when he broke the news to them that he had hatched a different plan.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: As the family drove from the courtyards of Cambridge, Mass., back to their narrow three-bedroom house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, Abe and Selma Schumer's oldest son announced that he would not hunker down to study for the bar exam. Instead, he would wake before dawn to stand outside subway stations. He would stay out past dusk to ring doorbells.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: There was an open seat representing his area of Brooklyn in the New York State Assembly, and Mr. Schumer intended to win it.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Only partly in jest, Selma Schumer urged her friends not to vote for him. ''We thought he was crazy,'' she said, speaking for both herself and her husband, who worked as an exterminator. ''He had wonderful job offers. With good money! We were impressed.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: But her son was intent, instinctively sensing what he really wanted and knowing that he could get it. He was just 23 years old, and he never looked back.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer won that election, and every one after it. He left the State Assembly to enter Congress when he was only 30. Now 47, he is waging the most critical campaign of his career, trying to do what several other Democrats before him failed to: unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican who has represented New York in the United States Senate for 18 years.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: And he is bringing to that quest the same confidence, sense of purpose and knack for political positioning that he carried with him on that ride back from Cambridge in the summer of 1974. He is also bringing a set of sharp political tools that he has honed ever since. One is the ability to master complex issues and make them understandable to average voters, as he demonstrated in the televised debates with Mr. D'Amato this last weekend. Another is an eagerness to take credit for successful initiatives, even those for which he is not entirely responsible.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer has never been ambivalent about his goals and, like his rival, he has never been less than cunning in attaining them. His political ascent has been steady and methodical; his political evolution has been just as canny.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He entered the Assembly as something of a reformer, a youthful antidote to the corruption epitomized by Watergate. A proud bearer of liberal Democratic standards in the late 1970's and 1980's, he emphasized more moderate positions in the 1990's, as liberalism fell out of vogue and he contemplated a run for governor or senator.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Either race would require the favor of a statewide electorate more conservative than the constituents in his Congressional district in New York City, and Mr. Schumer's recent record suggests that he appreciated that.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He became an ardent crime fighter, a zealous consumer advocate and a stubborn enemy of fraud and waste in the food stamps program, seizing issues that appealed to a broad range of voters across the political divide.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer said any change in his political persona was a response to the needs and concerns of the people in Brooklyn and Queens whom he represented and the result of growing older.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''Am I more conservative than I was 20 years ago?'' he wondered aloud one recent morning as he ate a bowl of oatmeal in the dining room inside the United States Capitol. ''Sure. But it's been a gradual process.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He added that few people remained utterly fixed in their opinions through time, and portrayed his flexibility as something preferable to the intellectual rigidity of some politicians. ''I don't like people who think they got the message from on high,'' he said. ''I don't like ideologues from the left or the right.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: But many colleagues and political analysts said there has been obvious calculation in the arc of Mr. Schumer's career, a painstaking preparation for this moment.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''I think he's cherry-picked some issues very, very carefully to prevent himself from being pigeonholed as a stereotypical liberal,'' said Charles E. Cook Jr., editor of The Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan journal.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Cook pointed to Mr. Schumer's support for the death penalty, which he opposed earlier in his career. ''This is something that would be absolutely unacceptable for any good liberal,'' Mr. Cook said.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: The unquestioned constants through Mr. Schumer's career have been his formidable intelligence and, perhaps even more so, his determination to prevail. That extraordinary drive has not always won him the affection of colleagues, some of whom dislike Mr. Schumer for what they and their staff members describe as an egomania and a crass self-promotion that stand out even on Capitol Hill.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer is far from the most popular legislator there. But even those peers who find his intensity off-putting respect what he has accomplished and agree that it has been pivotal in his success as a legislator and politician.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He may not have followed the precise course his parents hoped for, but he stayed true to the size of their ambitions for him.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: In a 1986 book, his sister, Fran Schumer, a journalist, wrote: ''Ever since he was 8, my older brother has wanted to recreate in the world his position in our family -- president of the Schumers, favorite son of the United States.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''His first bid for higher office, to be president of our junior high school, failed,'' she continued. ''But he beefed up his act so it would never happen again.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: When a young Mr. Schumer discussed his decision to run for elective office, he characterized politics less as a calling than as a career choice, a profession that he felt would suit his personality.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Finding such a fit was vitally important to him, because he and his siblings had watched their father, the owner of a small exterminating company, toil six days a week at a job that gave him security but no pleasure.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''Compared to the tragedies that other people had in their lives, it was nothing,'' Mr. Schumer acknowledged. ''But it had a real impact on me. My father was such a decent man and he had this huge albatross around his neck, which was the business.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: The Schumer family, Jewish and solidly middle class, lived on a street where all of the houses looked pretty much alike. Charles Ellis Schumer, born on Nov. 23, 1950, was the oldest of three children, followed by Fran and then a younger brother, Robert. Selma Schumer stayed home to raise the children and went to work as a teacher only after they grew older.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer excelled from the start. He reliably aced tests, graduated first in his class at James Madison High School and won admission to Harvard, which he began in the fall of 1967.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: It was a time of heated political activity, the apogee of protests over the Vietnam War and racial discrimination, and Mr. Schumer was quickly swept up in that heady moment. He joined the Young Democrats Club, rising to its presidency in his junior year.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Several classmates recalled that it was trendier to belong to the Students for a Democratic Society, a radical group. But they said Mr. Schumer was never one to storm barricades or occupy buildings.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Even then, they said, he was suspicious of such righteousness, pragmatic and committed to working within the system, not trying to overthrow it. He was also a bit of a square, rooted firmly in Flatbush and holding tightly and proudly to its accent and a frumpy manner that sometimes drew ribbing from peers.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Carol Kellermann, who met him at Harvard, worked in his Congressional office and remains one of his closest friends, said she could not remember him even wearing jeans.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer said he did not smoke marijuana either. ''It was illegal,'' he explained.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: As his fascination with politics grew, he chose social studies as a major, wrote his senior thesis on ways that Congress could function more efficiently and sought internships with legislators and political groups. He was falling into a career without fully realizing it.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He said politics promised to indulge his interest in solving problems and helping people, his affinity for debate and his desire to educate. Friends said it promised to indulge something else as well: Mr. Schumer's yen for attention.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''He very much thrives on approval from the outside world,'' Ms. Kellermann said. ''He likes being noticed.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: In both his bid to enter the Assembly and the niche he carved for himself there, Mr. Schumer cast himself as a reform Democrat, eager to restore integrity to government and make it more responsive to people's needs.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He also displayed the signature traits that colleagues attribute to him to this day: a conspicuous assertiveness, an obvious conviction in his own abilities and a skill for seizing issues in a manner that got his name in the newspapers and face on television.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Older Assemblymen like Mel Miller and Stanley Fink, who each subsequently served as Assembly Speakers, did not know quite what to make of him. ''He was a snot-nose,'' Mr. Miller said. ''Stanley said to me, 'We got to get rid of this snotty kid.' ''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: But gradually, they revised that opinion of Mr. Schumer. ''When you got past the somewhat pushiness and the somewhat arrogance,'' Mr. Miller said, ''there was talent there and a willingness to work.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer's Assembly office was a veritable mill of exhaustively researched reports on subjects ranging from the slow response time of ambulances in New York City to the high prices that asphalt contractors charged the city. Simultaneously, he forged an identity as an ardent defender of civil liberties and ally of tenants bucking what they saw as the tyranny of landlords.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: While Mr. Schumer's energy usually served his purposes, it at times threatened to undermine them. After his election to the United States House of Representatives in 1980, he became the target of Federal and local investigations into accusations that he had improperly used his Assembly staff to work on his Congressional campaign.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Some former Congressional staff members said the investigations, which were ultimately dropped, were fueled in part by the resentments of exhausted employees whom Mr. Schumer had pushed to the brink. They described Mr. Schumer as a sometimes overbearing boss with an untempered desire to get ahead.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer acknowledged that he was eager to make his mark.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''Congress was a revelation to me,'' he said. ''Huge areas of endeavor had no experts. I said, 'I'm going to become the expert in housing, in banking.' And there were no real experts in Congress.'' In a subsequent interview, Mr. Schumer recalled his thrill at becoming ''the expert, in the whole United States Congress.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''And knowledge,'' he said, ''was power.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer had run for Congress in part on a pledge to bring more Federal dollars back home, and as a young Congressman, he was often a champion of better programs and more consideration for poor and middle-class people in his district.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Among his earliest accomplishments was helping to fight off a Senate attempt to cut housing subsidies to cities with rent control and helping to write a housing rehabilitation bill that promoted home ownership in poor neighborhoods.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: But colleagues said that in Congress, as in college, Mr. Schumer never truly embraced the left. And there were striking examples of moderation in his record from the 1980's, like his key support for a bill that toughened restrictions against illegal immigration.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: It was in the 1990's, however, as the Republican revolution brewed, President Clinton emerged as a new-style Democrat, and Mr. Schumer eyed statewide office, that his more moderate streak truly came to the fore.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: To a large extent, the alteration of Mr. Schumer's persona was a function of emphasis as much as philosophical conversion. Across a wide spectrum of issues, he was still among the House's more liberal Democrats.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He consistently drew the same high ratings that he had in the 1980's from such liberal advocacy groups as the Americans for Democratic Action, and he consistently drew the same low ratings from conservative groups that promoted tax cuts.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He voted against both the balanced-budget amendment and the 1996 bill that restricted welfare benefits. His record on women's rights and abortion rights, which had always been strong, remained so.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: But there were certain crusades -- most notably, crime prevention -- that placed him closer to the center.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer's growing attention to crime was logical, given his assignment from 1991 to 1995 as the chairman of the House's crime subcommittee. But he used that position to adopt a number of tough-on-crime stances not typically associated with liberals.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer said he was heeding the frustrations of voters in his district. ''I felt the anger and the anguish of my constituents -- beautiful, hard-working people,'' he said. ''Their car would be stolen, their home would be burglarized, someone would be mugged. I said, 'Let's try to stop the crime problem.' It was one of my goals from the day I got to Congress, but I didn't have enough seniority until I became head of the crime committee.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: The sweeping 1994 crime bill that Mr. Schumer helped write expanded the applicability of the death penalty to scores of Federal crimes, provided billions of dollars for new prison construction and put tens of thousands of additional police officers on the nation's streets. But it also stressed prevention, funneling money to programs like drug counseling for inmates.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He fought for the inclusion of a ban on the sale of assault weapons in the crime bill and also spearheaded passage of the Brady Bill, which required a waiting period for the purchase of a handgun.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: There were additional positions that cast Mr. Schumer in a moderate light. He supported the line-item veto and voted in favor of a bill to ban the recognition of marriages between homosexuals.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Meanwhile, in interviews, he took to berating the Democratic Party for losing touch with ordinary Americans and to describing himself as an ''angry centrist.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Several political analysts said he was restyling himself for purely political purposes, a charge fueled by his demonstrated fondness for self-promotion.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: His colleagues and their staff members even coined a phrase for what they said was Mr. Schumer's habit of trumping or pre-empting colleagues' efforts: to Schume.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: But many of them declined to discuss their true feelings about Mr. Schumer for attribution, noting that he could soon be in a position to make them regret it.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Other colleagues countered that Mr. Schumer was the object of envy, an assessment with which he seemed to agree.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''That's one of my little plights in life,'' he said. ''People have always been, you know, jealous.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: But it may not be that simple.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: For a while in 1995, he and former Representative Susan Molinari, a Republican from Staten Island, shared a recurring spot on a New York City newscast.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate
