text: Ms. Molinari recalled that on one program, when she was about to tell viewers that she was expecting a baby, Mr. Schumer interrupted, handing her a baby gift and congratulating her.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''I was announcing being pregnant,'' Ms. Molinari said, ''and Chuck stole the line.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Although Mr. Schumer's profile has grown dramatically over the last two decades, his demeanor has changed little. He still carries Flatbush in his voice and his parents' unpretentious, thrifty ways in his life style.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He presents a fascinating dichotomy, at once striving to move beyond his origins and staying comfortably tethered to them.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: For a while, when he was younger, Mr. Schumer flirted with glamour, going out with women who were richer and blonder than the ones with whom he had grown up. In the late 1970's, he briefly dated the gossip reporter Claudia Cohen, who had a widely publicized romance with Mr. D'Amato just a few years ago.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: But Mr. Schumer settled down in 1980 with Iris Weinshall, a cabdriver's daughter who was also raised in Brooklyn. She works as a deputy commissioner in the New York City Department of Citywide Administrative Services, and the couple live with their two daughters, Alison, 9, and Jessica, 14, in a 10th-floor, three-bedroom apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, that they bought in 1983 for just $157,000.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer is content to slurp down a bowl of cold cereal for dinner and has been known to wear the same suit day after day. Mrs. Schumer said he constantly forgets to make appointments to get his hair cut.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Earlier in his career, before she intervened, he would sometimes grab a pair of ordinary scissors and trim the misbehaving tufts himself.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''Even now, I see him looking in the mirror and bemoaning not being able to get a haircut,'' Mrs. Schumer said. ''And I say, 'Don't even think about it.' ''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer admitted it was somewhat out of character when several years ago he got a modest hair transplant to fill denuded patches toward the front of his scalp.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: He prides himself on abhorring ostentation, and his living arrangement in Washington, a city he deliberately flees every weekend to rejoin his family, reflects that.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: When Congress is in session, he shares a small town house on Capitol Hill with three other lawmakers, with his rent of $500 a month buying him a fraternity-style atmosphere and no privacy at all.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Representative George Miller, a Democrat from California, and Senator Richard J. Durbin, a Democrat from Illinois, each sleep in one of the two upstairs bedrooms; Mr. Schumer shares the downstairs living room with Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat from Connecticut.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Mr. Schumer's roommates say he is almost always the last one to leave his office and return to the town house at night; he is sometimes the first one up in the morning as well. There are always new tasks to tackle, new missions to launch, and Mr. Schumer never does anything halfway.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Anthony D. Weiner, a New York City Councilman who once worked on Mr. Schumer's Congressional staff, remembered how the softball games between ''Schumer's Boomers'' and the staffs of other lawmakers would grind to a temporary halt whenever Mr. Schumer dropped by.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: ''We'd always have to suspend the game,'' Mr. Weiner said, ''because he would want to bat over and over again until he got a great hit.''
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: Grounding out was patently unacceptable. Sometimes even a single would not suffice. Mr. Schumer would remain standing over home plate, swinging and swinging for something big.
title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: 250 People Arrested In Statewide Drug Sweep

text: In a coordinated effort to keep drug dealers from simply moving their operations, the authorities throughout the state arrested about 250 people yesterday morning in raids on suspected outdoor drug markets, State Attorney General Peter G. Verniero announced.
title: 250 People Arrested In Statewide Drug Sweep

text: The police seized 30 handguns, 16 vehicles, $81,000 and marijuana, cocaine, heroin, LSD, ecstasy and other drugs, Mr. Verniero said.
title: 250 People Arrested In Statewide Drug Sweep

text: Mr. Verniero said the arrests during the raids were in addition to normal drug enforcement activity throughout the state, where there was an average of 180 drug arrests a day in 1997, according to the State Police Uniform Crime Report.
title: 250 People Arrested In Statewide Drug Sweep

text: In a ruling that will limit the way police departments conduct some sting operations involving marijuana, the State Court of Appeals in Albany yesterday reversed a Monroe County Court decision that allowed people who believed they were buying marijuana to be charged with criminal solicitation.
title: Court Ruling Puts an End to Some Marijuana Sting Operations

text: The case involved 54 defendants who bought small amounts of what they believed to be marijuana, but which was actually oregano, from police officers in Rochester, N.Y., who were acting as drug sellers.
title: Court Ruling Puts an End to Some Marijuana Sting Operations

text: Because undercover officers are not allowed to sell real marijuana, the buyers could not be charged with possession of marijuana, a violation that carries a maximum fine of $100. Instead, they were charged with criminal solicitation, which carries a maximum sentence of 15 days in jail.
title: Court Ruling Puts an End to Some Marijuana Sting Operations

text: The State Court of Appeals ruled that they could not be charged with criminal solicitation because of an exemption in the penal code that states ''a person is not guilty of criminal solicitation when his solicitation constitutes conduct of a kind that is necessarily incidental to the commission of the crime solicited.''
title: Court Ruling Puts an End to Some Marijuana Sting Operations

text: David Steinberg, the chief assistant public defender in Dutchess County, said, ''Basically it's a legal exemption, a defense to a charge of criminal solicitation, when the conduct complained of is part and parcel to the commission of the crime that is being solicited.'' Mr. Steinberg is now appealing a criminal solicitation conviction in a reverse sting case in which his client tried to buy crack cocaine from an undercover officer in July 1997.
title: Court Ruling Puts an End to Some Marijuana Sting Operations

text: Yesterday's ruling spells an end to reverse sting operations involving marijuana, according to Thomas Rainbow Morse, an assistant district attorney who represented the state, but not to all reverse sting drug operations. Other drugs carry higher penalties than marijuana. Although cocaine buyers may no longer be charged with criminal solicitation, they can be charged with attempted possession of cocaine, a Class B misdemeanor. ''Attempted possession of marijuana is not an offense,'' said Edward J. Nowak, the Monroe County public defender, who represented the 54 defendants.
title: Court Ruling Puts an End to Some Marijuana Sting Operations

text: Mr. Morse said that he was not giving up and that he hoped to change the criminal solicitation statute. ''We're going to move the halls of justice to the corridors of the legislature,'' he said. ''We hope to find a sponsor in the next session of the legislature.''
title: Court Ruling Puts an End to Some Marijuana Sting Operations

text: Defense lawyers and prosecutors jousted for the first time yesterday over the defense's charges of drug use by Jonathan M. Levin, the popular Bronx high school teacher who prosecutors say was killed by a former student.
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: The former student, Corey Arthur, told the police after his arrest that he was in Mr. Levin's apartment to sell him crack cocaine when two armed men arrived. Mr. Arthur, who has denied committing the killing, said he managed to escape from the apartment when the gunmen came in.
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: Cleo Tejada, a fellow teacher and former girlfriend of Mr. Levin's, said in response to a question from prosecutors yesterday that Mr. Levin occasionally smoked marijuana but never used crack. She went on to say that Mr. Levin had reported a fellow teacher who was using crack to his supervisors at William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx and later praised the dismissal of the teacher.
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: But under cross-examination, Mr. Arthur's lawyer, Anthony Ricco, produced a police report from June 1997 in which police officers quoted Ms. Tejada as saying Mr. Levin smoked marijuana on a ''daily basis.'' Ms. Tejada denied making the statement, saying that was not a term she would have used.
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: Mr. Ricco asked Ms. Tejada if she would lie to protect Mr. Levin's reputation. ''No -- I'm Catholic and I swore on the Bible,'' she said, referring to the oath she took before testifying.
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: Earlier in the day, the courtroom was hushed, and Mr. Levin's mother, Carol Levin, was brought to tears as prosecutors played a cassette tape from her son's telephone answering machine. The tape includes a message Mr. Arthur left at 4:55 P.M on May 30, 1997, a Friday.
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: ''Mr. Levin, this is Corey,'' a voice on the tape says. ''Pick up if you're there. It's important.''
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: According to prosecutors, Mr. Levin then let Mr. Arthur, 20, and Mountoun T. Hart, 26, into his apartment. The two youths then robbed and tortured the teacher, prosecutors say, and Mr. Arthur shot him.
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: The two dozen messages that followed transfixed the jury. The messages, from Mr. Levin's friends and students, progressed from cheerful weekend greetings for ''Jake'' -- Mr. Levin's nickname -- to frantic pleas for him to call and say he was all right.
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: ''We're worried about you,'' Ms. Tejada says on a message left on May 31. ''Please call and let us know you're all right.''
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: On Sunday, June 1, a woman who identifies herself as Karen calls repeatedly. By Monday, panic creeps into her voice. ''We are all so terribly worried about you,'' she says. ''Where are you? ''Call and say something as soon as you come in the door. Call.''
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: The final message played silenced the courtroom. ''Hello, this is the medical examiner,'' a voice says. ''Are any officers there? Hello?''
title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher

text: The pop makeover of the year belongs to Vanilla Ice, the rapper and one-album wonder of the early 1990's. As late as the summer of 1997, he was still performing his hit ''Ice, Ice Baby'' the way he did it in 1991, when he joined M. C. Hammer as a dancing, grimacing rapper packaged for MTV. In his brief heyday as a rapper for teeny-boppers, he sold millions of albums, but at the price of becoming a hip-hop punch line. Now there's a setup for a new joke: Vanilla Ice, the tormented rocker. As a pre-emptive strike, his new album is called ''Hard to Swallow'' (Republic/Universal).
title: Ditching Rap for More Hardcore Metal

text: Groping for credibility, Vanilla Ice unveiled his hard-rock persona on Tuesday night at CBGB, a club chosen for its history as a punk and hardcore epicenter. He had a new look, from his goatee and short, blond-frosted hair to his sleeveless CBGB T-shirt; luckily, tattoos are still apropos for what he called skate rock. And while he had a disk jockey scratching records behind him, Vanilla Ice was also backed by a funk-metal band that churned, stomped and squealed.
title: Ditching Rap for More Hardcore Metal

text: Vanilla Ice has two essential gifts for a pop star: boundless chutzpah and an instinct for trends as they surface commercially. In the early 1990's, hardcore rock and rap were testing a merger based on their shared belligerence, noise and elimination of melody. But Vanilla Ice has picked up rap-metal when bands like Korn zoom to the top of the charts.
title: Ditching Rap for More Hardcore Metal

text: His potent band, including members of Electric Love Hog and Cellophane, crunches efficiently at various speeds and tops the sputtering beat with fulminating guitars or swooping synthesizer lines. And as long as a rapping sidekick, Rod J., and the bassist Doug Ardito are shouting along, Vanilla Ice has enough vocal heft for the style.
title: Ditching Rap for More Hardcore Metal

text: But he doesn't have verbal content to match. Hip-hop and hard-rock rappers face no competition from a rhymer whose gift for simile runs to imagery like ''I'm as wicked as a witch on a broomstick'' or the oxymoronic ''crazy like Prozac.'' Some of Vanilla Ice's new songs are leftover hip-hop come-ons set to incongruously malevolent riffs; there are also boasts about how he's battling ''the industry'' and an obligatory pro-marijuana song.
title: Ditching Rap for More Hardcore Metal

text: True to the new rap-metal genre's requirements, he also has songs that lash out and declare his victimhood. One encourages listeners to denounce the old Vanilla Ice, while ''A.D.D.'' (short for attention deficit disorder, he explained) blurts, ''I just can't hide from myself!'' The most earnest new song, ''Scars,'' condemns an abusive father. The sentiments would sound more genuine if Korn hadn't gotten there first.
title: Ditching Rap for More Hardcore Metal

text: Vanilla Ice and his band went through enough hardcore motions to get some audience members to stage dive. But after his rap-metal remake of ''Ice, Ice Baby,'' now called ''Too Cold,'' the crowd assumed he was done; he returned for encores after a dearth of applause. If history is any guide, Vanilla Ice's adoption of rap-metal means that hard rock is about to move on.
title: Ditching Rap for More Hardcore Metal

text: There are two things that listening to ''Electro-Shock Blues,'' the second album by the Eels, makes one want to say when talking to E (formerly Mark Oliver Everett), the band's singer, songwriter and guitarist. The first is ''I'm sorry''; the second is ''congratulations.'' The first response is out of sympathy for the recent tragedies that inspired the album: the suicide of his sister, the diagnosis of terminal cancer for his mother, the deaths of several friends and, years earlier, the heart attack of his father, whom E discovered dead. The second response is out of admiration that E, on the verge of becoming the only surviving member of his immediate family, managed to create such a beautiful, profound and moving album out of these losses.
title: THE POP LIFE

text: '' 'I'm sorry, congratulations,' is the card I'd like to get from people,'' E said in an interview on Tuesday. ''That's why I called it 'Electro-Shock Blues.' The electro-shock part is based on the experiences my sister had in the mental hospital, and the blues part is because -- though it's not blues music per se -- it's what blues singers do. They take seemingly negative situations and turn them into something positive by processing them and telling people the story.''
title: THE POP LIFE

text: ''Congratulations is also the right response,'' he continued, ''because when you have tragedy in your life, you have two choices. You can get weighted down by it and give up, whether by killing yourself or numbing yourself. Or you can let it make you stronger. It's a thin line. I've accepted that I'm an inch away from going crazy.''
title: THE POP LIFE

text: The harrowing result, ''Electro-Shock Blues'' (released this week on Dreamworks), is a concept album in the best sense of the word, a testament not to self-pity but to self-awareness. It is a grim journey that begins in the mind of E's sister as she loses consciousness for the last time on her bathroom floor. As the album moves through birthday parties and funerals, hospitals and sanitariums, E spares no details about chemotherapy, hospital food and coffins. But E arrives at a happy ending, affirming, ''Maybe it's time to live.''
title: THE POP LIFE

text: ''That part's really genuine,'' E said. ''I really have a lust for life that keeps me going -- just barely. When you have all these tragedies happen, you figure out what's really important. That's why I made a record like this rather than what people would have wanted me to make, which is something that didn't have the word cancer in it so many times.''
title: THE POP LIFE

text: The Los Angeles trio's previous album, ''Beautiful Freak'' from 1996, was a slightly more upbeat affair, spawning the hit ''Novocaine for the Soul.'' A much more revealing and unsettling project, ''Electro-Shock Blues'' is filled with strings, brass, turntable scratching, samples of past Eels songs, meditations on everything from the meaning of life to the meanness of life, and, most disturbing, the process of a human being coming to terms with the death of a loved one and arriving at important realizations too late.
title: THE POP LIFE

text: ''The songs about my sister are the truest tributes I can do because they're not some 'Candle in the Wind' thing,'' E said. ''I'm doing songs from her point of view because I think I understand. We grew up together. We have a lot of the same problems in common. I wanted to see how difficult it was for her, and I don't blame her. I think that's an amazing tribute.''
title: THE POP LIFE

text: The Eels are to perform at Mercury Lounge in Manhattan on Sunday and Monday nights.
title: THE POP LIFE

text: In contemporary rock, the presence of political-activist organizations amid the concession stands, notably on Lollapalooza tours, has become a staple at festivals. More recently, the political sideline of Lollapalooza has become the driving concept of festivals like the Beastie Boys' Tibet Freedom Concert and Sarah McLachlan's Lilith Fair. At the University of California's Berkeley campus on Sunday, the idea was taken to its extreme by the Spitfire Tour, which drew 1,000 people.
title: THE POP LIFE

text: Like the other festivals, the Spitfire Tour was conceived by a musician, Zack de la Rocha of Rage Against the Machine. The difference is that Spitfire is a music festival with hardly any music. The performers -- Amy Ray of the Indigo Girls, Michael Franti of Spearhead, Exene Cervenka of X and the former Nirvana bassist Krist Novoselic -- perform few or no songs. They mainly speak about political issues that mean something to them -- race, sexuality, environment, personal responsibility and political representation -- hoping to spark a social consciousness in their fans. Besides musicians, other speakers include the actor Woody Harrelson, the MTV personality Kennedy, the medical marijuana advocate Todd McCormick and the environmental activist Julia (Butterfly) Hill, who has been living in an endangered redwood tree for 10 months, a real-life equivalent of the protagonist in the Italo Calvino novel ''The Baron in the Trees.''
title: THE POP LIFE

text: Like the Lilith Fair, which tested its concept with smaller concerts before planning a big tour, Spitfire is experimenting. Berkeley was one of just four dates at colleges this month (the final stops will be in Nashville on Monday and Gainesville, Fla., on Tuesday) as a trial run for a 30-to-40-date tour in the spring. Will students and fans show up for speeches without an entertaining concert to help the medicine go down?
title: THE POP LIFE

text: So far, said Sarah Haynes, one of the tour's organizers, the results have been encouraging. At the tour's first stop at Clemson University in South Carolina, protesters accused tour organizers of holding the event to proselytize for homosexuality, but 3,000 people showed up. Tickets range from free to $3. After the addresses, the speakers have in-depth discussions with interested members of the audience.
title: THE POP LIFE

text: ''The objective of creating the tour is to educate and entertain at the same time, to make learning fun, and to speak about topics that aren't necessarily brought up in college,'' Ms. Haynes said. ''We want to make an impact, to instigate action, and to show people what they can do without fame and money.''
title: THE POP LIFE

text: A Four-and-a-Half Minute Speech Reveals This President's Entire Life
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: 110 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Bill Clinton and the Assault on American Ideals
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: 154 pages. The Free Press. $20.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: The more David Maraniss writes about Bill Clinton the more he seems to dislike him.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: In a series of articles for The Washington Post in 1992, Mr. Maraniss wrote of candidate Clinton's ''political stamina,'' his ''natural and deserved'' popularity, his ''empathetic personality,'' his ''intense desire to listen to people.'' ''The loyalty and deep feelings of respect that Clinton has engendered in scores of friends,'' he added, ''cannot be overstated.'' Though these articles formed the basis of Mr. Maraniss's 1995 biography of Mr. Clinton, ''First in His Class,'' that book evinced a significant shift in tone. The President's ''lifelong sense of purpose'' now read, more clearly, as ambition; his distaste for conflict, as glibness and a need to present people with ''the version of himself he thought each would most admire.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: In his new quickie book, ''The Clinton Enigma,'' Mr. Maraniss's portrait of Mr. Clinton is even darker. He describes the President as ''a dissembler'' and ''one-man darkness unit,'' ''a personality that explained and rationalized compulsively,'' a man whose traits include a ''lack of normal standards of self-control'' and ''a reliance on aides, friends and family to shield him from the public consequences of his behavior.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: While Mr. Maraniss has always regarded Mr. Clinton as ''a protean character who constantly adapted to his environment,'' he argues that at a deeper level, the President seems ''incapable of learning and changing.'' Indeed, the President now reminds him of ''Gen. George Armstrong Custer as described by biographer Evan Connell before the Battle of Little Bighorn, his fate determined by the immutability of his character, reacting predictably to the same stimuli again and again and again.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: In ''The Clinton Enigma,'' Mr. Maraniss uses this thesis to deconstruct the President's four-and-a-half minute speech, delivered hours after his grand jury testimony on Aug. 17. In his view, that brief, combative speech embodied themes and patterns evident throughout Bill Clinton's career: it underscored his penchant for ''lawyerly evasion'' and ''biblical semantics,'' his tendency to use carefully chosen words to manipulate and mislead. It also highlighted, Mr. Maraniss says, the President's proclivity for seeing everything in political terms, and for going on the attack -- in this case, assailing Kenneth Starr -- instead of examining his own culpability.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Certainly these observations will be familiar to anyone who has read a newspaper or watched television in the last two months. What lends Mr. Maraniss's observations added interest is his ability to put the speech (and its subtext) in context with Mr. Clinton's entire life by drawing upon the enormous amount of material he accumulated in the course of writing ''First in His Class.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Mr. Maraniss does not simply point out the most famous corollaries to Mr. Clinton's slyly couched denials of sex with Monica Lewinsky (his waffling on questions concerning his smoking of marijuana and his draft status during the Vietnam War), but goes back through the President's entire life to show us his ongoing vacillation between idealism and opportunism, empathy and narcissism.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: He suggests that Mr. Clinton's penchant for playing the victim (while lashing out at his enemies) stems from the random beatings he received from his alcoholic stepfather (who whipped him ''in moments of drunken rage, not as a means of correcting the young man's behavior''); he argues that the President's ability to compartmentalize different aspects of life, like his delusions of invincibility, stems from a highly developed ability to practice denial -- a skill honed, as a boy, growing up with an alcoholic.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Stonewalling, it seems, also came naturally. Over the years, Mr. Maraniss writes, Mr. Clinton instinctively learned to withhold information as a means of reconciling ''the tension between reality and image, between what he is and what he wants to be'' -- a tension, clearly, that has never been so pronounced as it is today.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: While David Maraniss sees the President's Aug. 17 speech as a kind of Rosetta stone to his life, the conservative commentator William J. Bennett sees the Monica Lewinsky scandal as ''a perfect snapshot'' revealing ''the essence of Bill Clinton'' and a telling index of America's growing embrace of the ''culture of permissiveness.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: As Mr. Bennett sees it, Mr. Clinton is a ''corrupt, and corrupting, President,'' and the current scandal (along with Filegate, Travelgate, Whitewater and questions about campaign finance violations) reveals the worst elements of Mr. Clinton's character: ''reckless and irresponsible private behavior; habitual lying; abuse of power.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Mr. Bennett's best-selling book, ''The Death of Outrage,'' looks at the most popular arguments advanced by the President and his defenders and examines their implications.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: When Mr. Bennett puts aside his tendency to moralize and simply applies common sense to the task at hand, the results can be persuasive. To begin with, he makes the obvious point that the current crisis is not just about sex, but involves serious allegations of ''perjury, obstruction of justice and job offers for silence.'' He goes on to deftly expose the hypocrisy of feminists who were quick to assail Clarence Thomas but who have stood by Mr. Clinton on grounds that the President's overall record on women's issues trumps allegations of sexual misconduct.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Mr. Bennett also eviscerates arguments that the President's current problems have had no effect on his ability to govern, even quoting a brief in which Attorney General Janet Reno wrote that the independent counsel's investigation of matters involving Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones ''has had a substantial impact on the President's performance of official duties.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Too often, however, Mr. Bennett overplays his hand, resorting to hectoring language and partisan logic. ''By his actions,'' he writes of the President, ''we are witnessing an assault on American ideals.'' And: ''Bill Clinton is a reproach. He has defiled the office of the Presidency of the United States.'' His repeated enumeration of the many parallels between the current Lewinsky scandal and Watergate are not matched by a similar examination of the many differences between the two cases.
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Mr. Bennett writes that the tactics employed by Mr. Starr, including his decision to subpoena Monica Lewinsky's mother and demand sales receipts of books Ms. Lewinsky had purchased at local Washington bookstores, are ''arguably less aggressive'' than those employed by Lawrence Walsh, the Iran-contra independent counsel during the 1980's. In another chapter, he tries to rationalize Linda Tripp's secret taping of conversations with her friend Monica Lewinsky, arguing that ''there were compelling reasons that would justify her actions.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: In addition, Mr. Bennett tends to oversimplify the arguments of his adversaries, reducing them, in summary, to paper tigers he can easily shoot down. He writes that Clinton advocates see the President's continued support in the polls as reflecting ''a wiser understanding of human nature and the ways of the world, a welcome liberation'' -- a sign that we are achieving the ''sophisticated sensibility long ago achieved by Europeans.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Such arguments are as unnecessary as they are specious, and they undermine the more valid points Mr. Bennett wants to make in this book. In fact, they ratify David Maraniss's observation that ''one of the many ironies of the Clinton tragedy'' is that ''he was always his worst enemy, while his enemies, by overreacting, were often, unwittingly, his strongest allies.''
title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder

text: Three firefighters and a city sanitation worker were among 47 people arrested yesterday during early morning narcotics raids at a cluster of sports bars on Staten Island, the police said. All four men face drug possession charges, the authorities said.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: Officers made the arrests at Mug Shots Bar, Annex Bar, Jack's Bar and the Rockaway Cove bar, all of which are on or near Victory Boulevard, after a more than monthlong investigation into drug sales at the locations, according to the police.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: The bars first drew the notice of the police because of rowdy conduct both in and outside the establishments, behavior that sometimes included noisy early-morning brawls. But when undercover officers began frequenting the establishments, they noticed that drugs were sometimes being sold by patrons there, the authorities said.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: The raids were conducted around 1 A.M., after officers obtained three search warrants and four nuisance abatement warrants, based partially on drug buys the undercover officers had previously made at the bars. Some suspects were arrested on the sidewalk or at vehicle checkpoints that were set up on the streets outside, the police said.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: The suspects face charges ranging from loitering with the intent to buy drugs to possession of drugs, weapons and counterfeit currency, the police and prosecutors said. Officers recovered two loaded 9-millimeter handguns and a loaded 22-millimeter handgun during the raids as well as approximately $6,200 in counterfeit bills, the authorities said.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: But the Staten Island District Attorney's office has already declined to prosecute 10 of those arrested on charges of loitering to buy drugs or of standing near where drugs are being sold, said Marlene Markoe-Boyd, a spokeswoman for the District Attorney, William L. Murphy. She said it was unclear how many of the arrests will be prosecuted.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: Ron Kliegerman, a lawyer representing all three firefighters arrested, called the sweep ''a complete outrage.'' He added: ''They just took everybody who was in the bars; they didn't care if you were there for only a few minutes or even if you had anything on you.'' Mr. Kliegerman said prosecutors have charged Firefighter Richard Ferrigno, 39, of Staten Island, with misdemeanor possession of marijuana and tampering with evidence. Lieut. Neil MacIntyre, 43, and Firefighter Edward Painter, 39, also of Staten Island, both face misdemeanor charges of possession of cocaine, said Officer Joseph Cavitolo, a Police Department spokesman.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: He added that a sanitation worker, William Laidlaw, 43, of Parlin, N.J., faces a misdemeanor charge of possession of cocaine.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: Paula Young, a spokeswoman with the Department of Sanitation, said her office had made no decision on the fate of Mr. Laidlaw's job but said the sanitation worker could face an administrative hearing. Michael Regan, a spokesman for the Fire Department, said that the firefighters had been suspended pending an administrative investigation.
title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island

text: Michael Massing has been writing about drug issues in the United States for a decade. He believes the central problem to be the hard-core users of heroin and cocaine, who are ''disproportionately poor, unemployed and members of minority groups.'' Although hard-core users are only a fifth of total users, they consume three-fourths of the cocaine and heroin used in this country and are responsible for most of the pathological behavior that elicits public and governmental responses. If we could provide appropriate treatment to anyone in this population who wanted it, Massing maintains, the whole drug problem would diminish, as would the illness and crime associated with it. The result of Massing's investigation is ''The Fix,'' a balanced and significant analysis of the American drug problem that carries specific, practical recommendations for reform.
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: He separates himself from the ''legalization/harm-reduction camp'' that asserts that drug-related diseases and social pathology are the fault of drug-control laws themselves. Having spent long periods observing drug treatment centers, roaming the streets of Harlem and hanging out with drug users, he has experienced a ''real-life rebuttal to the rosy accounts of addiction offered by the revisionists.'' Regardless of the drug laws, addiction and drug use create terrible conditions: child abuse reports in New York rose from 36,000 in 1985 to 59,000 in 1989 when the crack epidemic hit the city. Massing's approach contrasts with recent books like Mike Gray's ''Drug Crazy,'' which calls for a radical revision of our drug laws. Gray describes a golden age of drug use prior to the Harrison Narcotic Act of 1914, when ''the country had looked upon addicts as unfortunate citizens with a medical problem.'' To right current wrongs, he recommends that we put the provision of drugs ''back in the hands of doctors and pharmacists.''
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: Massing also distances his position from apostles of draconian penalties and those who put their faith in interdiction. His middle way has one clear emphasis, and that is comprehensive treatment. He knows this would work because we had such a program once; it succeeded wonderfully, but we let it slip away. We were therefore unable to mount a powerful defense against cocaine and crack in the mid-1980's, and now we have 10 times as many hard-core users as we faced during the Nixon Administration.
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: Nixon's strategy aimed directly at reducing crime in anticipation of the 1972 election. Treatment was part of a broad program that included foreign policy to shut down the Turkish-French connection; the Office of Drug Abuse Law Enforcement to attack street crime; the Internal Revenue Service to go after illicit profits. That crime reduction held first place among Nixon's priorities -- not the care of addicts -- is illustrated by the Administration's surprising willingness to adopt methadone, a synthetic opiate, as its preferred treatment for heroin users. At the time, a high-ranking official in the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs told me that the bureau would hand out heroin if it thought that would cut crime. This attitude was surprising because the substitution of one addiction by another contradicted the previously adamant stand by Nixon's adherents against any drug use.
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: How did Nixon come to approve the financing of methadone treatment for tens of thousands of addicts? Massing draws on interviews with key actors and internal Government documents to provide an answer. The most persuasive element was the methadone program developed in Washington by Robert DuPont, later the Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. Heroin use was skyrocketing; crime was rampant. In his 1968 campaign Nixon had declared that ''D. C. should not stand for disorder and crime.'' Washington became the laboratory for national drug policies. In 1970 DuPont, with support from the White House, established the Narcotics Treatment Administration, which was soon flooded with applicants. Although nondrug treatment was also offered, methadone appeared to cut the crime rate quickly, and that impressed the President and his aides. By the 1972 election crime had fallen by 50 percent in the District of Columbia, an achievement that was widely broadcast.
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: Of course, the methadone program was only one of the actions taken to reduce crime in Washington. Even Egil Krogh, the Nixon aide most responsible for creating the political will for this ambitious national treatment program, did not know if the program was responsible for the drop in crime, but he knew that from a political perspective, ''it was a slam-dunk great success.''
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: Massing has no doubts about the success of the treatment program. His conviction comes from his encounter with Nixon's drug expert, Jerome Jaffe, a psychopharmacologist and psychiatrist plucked in 1970 from the University of Chicago, where he had established a treatment program that employed a range of options, including drug-free therapy. He was asked first to head a committee of experts from outside the Government to come up with a response to drug addiction. His report was practical rather than theoretical and named methadone as the best treatment for heroin addiction (the major addiction at that time) and the best way to reduce crime. Following the adoption of what was basically his proposal, Jaffe entered Government service.
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: His first big administrative assignment was to deal with addicted Army personnel coming back from Vietnam. This he did with ingenuity and dispatch, and then began work as the ''drug czar,'' the first head of the Special Action Office for Drug Abuse Policy. Jaffe was neither a good administrator nor an adept politician -- he was a scientist. Many of his psychiatric and scientific colleagues distrusted him for working with Nixon. Some critics lambasted him in the most vitriolic terms for advocating methadone; they described the program as an enslavement of minorities. In Massing he has found a vindicator.
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: Massing advocates Jaffe's ''code,'' a set of principles that summed up his approach to drug use: ''Chronic drug users are at the heart of the nation's drug problem; a diverse array of services is required; Government must assure their availability and efficacy; law enforcement is an adjunct to rehabilitation and, always, reducing demand for drugs through education and treatment must take precedence over law enforcement efforts to reduce the supply of drugs. Massing says the Nixon Administration, following the Jaffe prescription, managed to bring a ''serious heroin epidemic'' under control ''in a few short years.''
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: Massing recommends setting up an organization like the Special Action Office for Drug Abuse Prevention that would engage only in reducing demand for illicit drugs, to be headed by a ''C. Everett Koop-type figure'' and backed in the White House by a facsimile of Egil Krogh -- that is, a high-ranking White House official whose special province would be drug abuse. A comprehensive national treatment program for drug and alcohol abuse should be established. In Massing's view, the most unfortunate mistake in the recent history of drug programs was the Government's shift of emphasis from heroin to marijuana, in response to increased complaints by parents, during the latter half of the Carter Administration. Treatment for the hard core shriveled. During the Reagan Administration the amount spent for treatment in real dollars fell to less than a quarter of what had been provided in the Nixon Administration.
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: Massing's powerful arguments for more treatment programs, especially metha-
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: done, must be put into a larger historical context. The 1970's witnessed the climax of a long-simmering reaction against law enforcement as the chief tool against drug abuse. That era of toleration, however, peaked about 1980, and since then we have been on a slope leading toward intolerance of drug use. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attack on methadone maintenance is a recent example of opposition to any drug use by former users. As valuable as methadone may be for some (and I believe it can be helpful), it is an uphill battle to justify it to those who have zero tolerance for drugs. Can a national policy that was feasible in 1970 be resurrected three decades later in a less friendly climate?
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: Finally, remarkable claims for treatment in the early 1970's must be tempered by the knowledge that most people in trouble with drugs were taking heroin, for which methadone is a stabilizing replacement. Today, cocaine users are the vast majority of the hard-core population, a problem for which methadone is useless. Massing's recommendations are too valuable to be oversold.
title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough

text: With voter referendums gaining an ever more prominent role as adjuncts to ordinary lawmaking, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on how far states may go in regulating the process of getting such measures on the ballot.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: The case is an appeal by the State of Colorado, where a Federal appeals court invalidated a law requiring people who circulate petitions to wear badges identifying themselves and to disclose to potential signers whether they are volunteers or paid workers.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: While the state argued that the law was necessary to deter fraud in signature collection, the appeals court held that the disclosure requirements, as well as other regulations challenged in the case, curbed political expression in violation of the First Amendment.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: Twenty-four states, nearly all in the Midwest and West, provide for voter referendums, and the Colorado case is being watched by state election officials and by organizations involved in the business of obtaining sufficient support to get often far-reaching measures on state ballots.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: One political consulting firm, National Voter Outreach, of Carson City, Nev., told the Justices in a brief opposing Colorado that it had conducted more than 150 signature drives in 36 states, collecting more than 18 million signatures. It said that professional management, including paid workers to circulate petitions, were often necessary because states have established such detailed qualifications and tight deadlines that amateur signature collectors risked having their work invalidated through such minor errors failing to get a ''Junior'' or ''Senior'' after a name.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: In New York, which does not provide for voter referendums, the process of getting candidates' names on the ballot is equally perilous. But the Colorado regulations do not apply to candidate petitions, and the Justices did not address that issue today.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: A brief filed on Colorado's behalf by the Council of State Governments and other state and local government organizations, criticized what it described as the ''hucksterism'' attendant with the ''initiative industry.''
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: ''The initiative process has become dominated by wealthy special interests,'' the government groups said, drawing a contrast to the spirit of the Progressive era of the early 1920's when the referendum approach was devised as a way of outflanking legislatures that were controlled by special interests.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: ''We are seeing the development of bands of people who go from state to state simply to circulate petitions,'' Gale Norton, Colorado's Attorney General, told the Court today.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: Ms. Norton said the disclosure provisions and the requirement that signature collectors be registered Colorado voters, were necessary ''to protect the integrity of the process.''
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver, ruled last year that the registered-voter requirement also violated the First Amendment, as did a requirement for sponsors to file monthly reports with the state disclosing the identities of signature collectors and the amount of money spent on the petition drive.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: The Colorado law was challenged by an organization interested in promoting voter referendums, the American Constitutional Law Foundation, and by a group of individual Colorado voters interested in supporting referendums on such subjects as legalizing marijuana and authorizing school vouchers. The plaintiffs' lawyer, Neil D. O'Toole, told the Justices that the state's concern about fraud was merely a ''talismanic invocation'' and that the real goal was ''to hinder the collection of signatures.''
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: An earlier Colorado law had made it a crime to pay people to collect signatures for referendum petitions. In a 1988 decision, Meyer v. Grant, the Supreme Court unanimously declared that law unconstitutional and said that the process of collecting signatures to bring a measure before the voters was ''core political speech'' that could not be limited without proof of a compelling state interest.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: To salvage its current regulations, Colorado has to persuade the Court to look at this case, Buckley v. American Constitutional Law Foundation, No. 97-930, differently from the prohibition it struck down in 1988. Some Justices were openly unreceptive to the state Attorney General's efforts. For example, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor challenged her defense of the requirement that signature collectors be registered voters, rather than simply state residents.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: ''Why can't someone who is an adult resident of Colorado perform that function as well as a registered voter?'' Justice O'Connor asked, adding, ''It's very hard for me to understand the justification.''
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: Ms. Norton replied that because petition drives were part of the state's ''lawmaking process,'' it made sense to require signature gatherers to demonstrate a commitment to the state by being registered voters. In addition, she said, the state could then use its voter lists to track people down in case questions arose about the validity of the signatures they had collected.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: A challenge in this case, for the Justices as well as the lawyers, is that it stands at the intersection of two somewhat contradictory lines of Court precedent: cases dealing with political expression, in which a state's regulatory role is sharply limited, and cases about ballot access and election rules, where the Court has given states considerably more leeway.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: Justice Stephen G. Breyer captured this tension when he told Ms. Norton: ''I think there's a lot of speech involved in this case, but it's important that the state can regulate the process.'' Could the Attorney General offer any precedents that might reconcile these two concerns, he asked. Although Ms. Norton mentioned several cases, each appeared to fall in one camp or the other.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: If Ms. Norton did not allay Justice Breyer's concerns, neither did the other side's lawyer. If the Court agreed with Mr. O'Toole that the disclosure requirements were unconstitutional, Justice Breyer wanted to know, what might be the implications for campaign finance cases down the line, given that the Court has already upheld disclosure requirements for contributions in Federal elections.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: ''I'm quite concerned over deciding for you here,'' Justice Breyer said, as the argument drew to a close leaving his concerns apparently unallayed.
title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process

text: The National Basketball Association, embroiled in a labor dispute with its players, yesterday canceled the first two weeks of the 1998-99 season. It is the first time in the league's 51-year history that it will lose regular-season games.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: The N.B.A.'s deputy commissioner, Russ Granik, announced the cancellation after nearly three and a half hours of meetings with the players' union ended at a Manhattan hotel.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: The decision to cancel 99 games between Nov. 3 and Nov. 16 -- with no plans to play them later in the season -- came after the players association proposed the implementation of a system in which money would be taken from upper-echelon salaries with the expectation that it would be distributed to low-revenue teams. The owners said they would respond to that proposal by Friday.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: The dispute involves the distribution of about $2 billion in leaguewide income. The main sticking point has been the owners' insistence on a salary cap -- or ceiling on wages -- without exceptions, to bring player salaries in line with revenue.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: ''We tried our best today to try to do what was possible to salvage the season,'' said Alonzo Mourning, the Miami Heat center. ''Unfortunately, it didn't work out.''
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: After 35,001 games without a blemish, the N.B.A. now joins the National Hockey League, the National Football League and Major League Baseball in having lost games to a labor dispute. Taking into account that a three- to four-week period would be needed for training camp and free-agent signings before the season started, the league said it would decide in two weeks whether to make further cancellations.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: ''I'm very sad and disappointed,'' N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern said. ''I consider it to be a collective failure, but I honestly don't know what else we could have done. I do things that I like to think are in the best interests of the game. And I believe this is.''
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: The decision came after what both sides agreed were the most substantive talks since the owners imposed a lockout on the players July 1 and subsequently canceled the exhibition season.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: The talks featured what the players association suggested were concessions to accommodate the league's desire to swing the revenue pendulum back toward the owners.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: While the players did not discuss the elimination of the Larry Bird exception -- a clause that allows a player to secure any amount of money he wants in re-signing with his current team -- they did address the exception in their key proposal. A 50 percent levy, called a luxury tax, would be imposed on salary earned above $18 million, a clause that would affect only a few players who exercised their Bird rights. For example, if a player made $20 million, the team would be forced to put $1 million into a fund that would most likely be distributed to low-revenue teams.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: ''There could be provisions made for some players,'' said Jeffrey Kessler, the chief outside counsel for the union. ''We don't want to do anything that would discourage Chicago from getting Michael Jordan back. And I think the league feels the same way.''
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: The proposal is similar to the luxury tax proposed by the union in 1995 during negotiations, but it would not be nearly as liberal.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: A salary cap credit would go into effect if the league pays out more than 63 percent of revenues in salary. Amounts over that number reduce the salary cap the next year.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: Teams would get a right of first refusal on free agents after the fourth year for incoming rookies, meaning a player would be contractually obligated to the same team for the first four years of his deal. Currently, the rookie scale is three years and includes a clause that enables a player to exercise his Bird rights after two seasons. Kevin Garnett parlayed that clause into a $126 million deal last year with Minnesota.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: The players agreed to make marijuana a banned substance. Details of testing have not been negotiated and no specific discussions took place regarding testing for performance-enhancing drugs, a provision the owners included in their last proposal.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: In return for the concessions, the players want an increase in the minimum salary -- currently $272,500 -- and creation of an average salary exception. This would allow every team above the salary cap being able to sign one free agent per year for the average salary -- currently $2.6 million.
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: ''We're buoyed by the fact for the first time they've decided to submit a counterproposal,'' the union's executive director, Billy Hunter, said. ''I don't know if I'm more optimistic, but I can earnestly say we can look our ballplayers in the eye and say we made a valiant effort.''
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: Asked whether the players would finally be tested financially with the cancellation of games, Hunter added: ''It's not about us blinking. We want to reach an agreement. We're tired of the rhetoric, we're tired of the game-playing. Our position all along has been we don't want to accept a bad deal.''
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: Granik said refunds to fans would be made at end of the calendar month and that the first refund would include monies for canceled preseason games. He estimated that the losses would be in the ''hundreds of millions of dollars.''
title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS

text: A 15-YEAR-OLD resident of Leake and Watts Services, a child-care agency here for troubled young people, was talking about his life before he came to live on the agency's campus.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: ''I was in foster homes, and this one foster home I didn't like, so I took a knife and put it under my bed,'' he said. ''If I'd known that just doing that, just putting a knife under my bed, would have gotten me here, I wouldn't have done it. I have a really bad temper. My temper doesn't have to do with my mouth. It's my hands. I break stuff. I break windows with my hands. But I'm working on it. I'm working on it, and I'm working it out on the ABC course.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: ABC stands for adventure-based counseling, and it is supposed to do exactly what it is doing for this teen-ager. Youngsters and adult counselors scale walls as if they were climbing rocks, shinny up poles, put on blindfolds and lead one another over rough terrain. Doing so, they are learning to talk over problems, gain confidence, trust other people. Leake and Watts serves young people with problems ranging from drug and alcohol abuse to feelings of alienation and unbridled rage. Adventure-based counseling is one of the many programs offered at the agency, which also has day programs.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: On a recent crisp afternoon, three teen-agers, 13, 15 and 16, gathered on a grassy height on the campus overlooking the Hudson. They spoke openly and warmly to visitors, but at times their gazes seemed to turn inward, their eyes clouding with some private emotion. In each boy, the juxtaposition of vulnerability and toughness was striking, but throughout the exercises there was a friendliness and eagerness to please.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: Tom Kirkland, director of adventure-based program development at Leake and Watts; Lester Harper, director of substance abuse services, and Bo Sween, substance abuse counselor, showed the teen-agers how to wrap themselves in a Studebaker harness -- a complicated arrangement of nylon rope, used in rock climbing, which looks the same from back and front (hence the name Studebaker, a reference to the appearance of some of the company's postwar models). Later, they attached more lines and buckles to the harnesses and used them to hoist themselves up a 45-foot wall studded with little climbing rungs. In real rock climbing, each climber relies on his belayer, who is holding the ropes; a belayer and a climber, Mr. Kirkland said, depend on each other, sometimes in life-and-death situations.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: ''I'm afraid of heights,'' one teen-ager said, ''but with these guys here, knowing my life is in their hands, I'm O.K.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: Hearing this, Mr. Harper beamed and said: ''The trick is transferring the skill of how to connect with people in his setting to connecting with people in other settings -- by trusting and communicating, telling what you need. We try to teach trust and communication. Teach them to tell each other what they need. Lack of trust is one of the reasons people use drugs and alcohol. They get burned by someone they trusted. They get unhappy. They think to themselves, 'I'm going to trust nobody now,' and they use drugs to ease the pain of that loneliness. We all need people to be in our lives.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: Mr. Kirkland added: ''It takes less effort to cop a drug and take it than to build a skill. But at adventure-based counseling, we can build skills. We can show the kids they can have a positive experience, then reflect on that experience and learn to apply it to their lives.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: Even if the activity is not a dangerous one, camaraderie can be built doing simple tasks. As the boys dug a hole, into which a 10-foot pole would fit, they joked together.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: ''I like digging with a shovel,'' one said. ''I'm strong.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: ''Jose, I have lots of white on me,'' said another pretending to protest. ''I'm wearing white, be careful with that dirt.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: The first teen-ager said, ''Well, looks like you gonna get dirty,'' but his laugh was gentle and his smile friendly.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: The second one replied: ''O.K. O.K. My sneakers got dirty, but that's O.K.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: Later, the youths talked about themselves. The 13-year-old said he had been hospitalized for mental illness and has to take two prescription drugs to control mood swings. ''I had a temper problem, but these pills slow me down,'' he said. ''I think I can cope a little better now.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: The 15-year-old said: ''I got here because my mother had a big fight with me. I took a stick, and I said to her, 'I dare you to hit me' and she did. I said, I'm just going to call the cops, and I did. I had a great big mark on my back.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: ''I'm on the same prescription drugs as Juan. They make me more relaxed. I'm trying to control this temper. And this ABC program is great. Did you know that we get paid to do it? We get paid $5 an hour, like it's a job. And who doesn't want a job? I can go out and buy nice things now.'' The participants in the nonprofit organization, which gets state and local financing, can get paid up to four hours a day.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: The 16-year-old smiled, and sighed. ''I've been living here on campus two months,'' he said. ''I've been hospitalized for depression. Did I do street drugs? Yeah -- and that wasn't even for my depressions. That was just because those drugs were, you know, there -- marijuana and alcohol. But I tried to avoid it, I really did.
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: ''I still get angry sometimes when I think about having to live here. I get real upset. But then I do things like the ABC course, and I think things are getting better already.''
title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure

text: CALL me a glutton for pampering. We'd been in Tampa to visit a favorite uncle, but now my husband, Bill, and I yearned for the sybaritic life. Why not a spa hop? The Don CeSar Beach Resort and Spa on St. Pete Beach was better known for its luxe appointments than go-for-the-burn workouts, but there'd be enough in the way of wraps and scrubs to keep us purring. Half an hour away, Safety Harbor Resort and Spa along Tampa Bay had a solid reputation on the spa circuit.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Which is why I was pumping a Gearbell underwater in a tepid pool in February, accompanied by a salsa version of the Beach Boys' ''Surfin' U.S.A.'' Water aerobics is one of two dozen or so fitness classes offered at Safety Harbor -- everything from boxercise to tai chi.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Roger, the instructor, had insisted the class was for novices, but I was beginning to think otherwise. My companions were a couple of well-honed women in their 50's and 60's, a mother and daughter and my husband, Bill, the lone male. First we'd ''jogged'' around the 20-by-35-foot indoor pool to warm up, then we'd grabbed the water Gearbells, plastic spheres 10 inches in diameter with handles like motorcycle grips. We started with two-handed up-and-down thrusts, also underwater, and then segued into long curving sweeps, one arm at a time. Until the very end, when tendons and ligaments turned tingly and sore, it was a pleasant way to exercise -- no sweating or grunting and groaning.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: The muscles were about ready for that pampering when Roger's boom box fell silent an hour later, and Bill and I made a beeline for the soothing power jets of the whirlpool a few steps away. Pool and whirlpool are on the lower level of the resort complex, and sunlight was streaming in from a bank of windows. Both are filled with mineral water from Safety Harbor's own springs that has been treated with ozone purifiers, reducing the need for chemicals like chlorine. Back in the early 1900's the waters were bottled and shipped worldwide as a cure for kidney, liver and skin ailments. Today the resort makes no claims other than to comment that the water, which is also used for drinking, is mineral-rich, and its slightly metallic taste seemed to attest to that.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: The explorer Hernando De Soto decided he had found the real ''fountain of youth'' missed by Ponce de Leon, when he came upon Safety Harbor's five springs in 1539. Safety Harbor opened as a health spa to overnight visitors in 1944, but its low-rise baby-aspirin-orange buildings dating from the 1950's, along with a newer six-story tower built in the 1970's, were renovated in the last two years. The 50,000-square-foot spa and fitness center encompasses treatment rooms, workout studios, locker rooms and spacious gyms with free weights, Nautilus, Badger Magnum machines, treadmills, rowers, Stairmasters and Lifecycles. Here, too, is the Center for Holistic Health, plus nutritional seminars and counseling.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: We'd checked into the 22-acre resort the day before and spent the afternoon lounging on the outdoor pool patio, scattered with potted palms and tropical flowers, overlooking the bay. When the sun began slinking behind the horizon, we retired to our airy deluxe room on the second floor. Done in restful tones of blue and cream, it had two double beds, a loveseat, honey-colored wood furniture, a sisal rug and a large gleaming bath with green, yellow and white tile and a tub with shower. On the walls were prints of old Florida.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: My $99 Stress Away half-day package included a 25-minute facial, 25-minute massage, a choice of aroma hydrotherapy or herbal wrap and use of sauna, steam, whirlpools, pools and exercise equipment. I sprang for an extra half-hour on the massage, an additional $35.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: For the facial it was off to the spiffy teal and purple women's lockers to get out of my wet suit and slip into the waffle cotton robe and slippers lent to spa guests. Both men and women traipsed to the dining room with its windowed dome for breakfast and lunch in this uniform, the sartorial statement that separates serious spas from the increasing number of hotels and resorts -- like the Don CeSar -- that offer spa services. Padding from the fitness wing down a long hallway hung with colorized vintage photographs, I sighed with contentment as I came upon the spa fountain splashing on granite slabs and took in the new reception area, done in black marble and beechwood with wicker furniture and butter-yellow walls.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: The cleansing, toning and exfoliating ritual felt marvelous. Then there was a deep cleaning masque, more toner and a slick of moisturizer at the end.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: During my massage, billed as Swedish, my Amazon-armed masseuse borrowed from neuromuscular and shiatsu techniques to iron out the ever-present kinks in my neck and back with mildly scented jojoba, pat chouli and lavender oils. Had my next date been for anything but aroma hydrotherapy, I probably would have rebelled and refused to budge. After the massage, it was a bit of a letdown, a glorified personal whirlpool scented with lemon and thyme in a brown and yellow tiled room with five other similar tubs in a semicircle. Afterward came a refreshing shower and a cool glass of water. Herbal tea would have been preferable, but the samovar in the spa salon was empty.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Even so, I'd revived sufficiently to notice it was way past lunchtime. The night before at dinner in the immense circular claret-and-white dining room, I had kept to the spa menu, though the Cafe's New American roster is also available. Raspberry marinated artichokes with farmer's cheese and red pepper vinaigrette were delicious, even if the artichokes did taste canned. My penne with red and yellow tomatoes, asparagus and basil, and Bill's whole wheat linguine with chicken, wild mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes were also good. The food may not have been as inventive as the spa cuisine at some pricier places, but it was satisfying and made me feel virtuous, a rare combination. Breakfast had been fresh orange juice and a bagel with low-fat cream cheese. Now I was craving calories.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Though it was a breezy 70 degrees, Bill and I headed for the outdoor pool patio leading to a grassy bayfront expanse fancifully named Serenity Beach. (In fact, no one swims there.) Bill had taken a stretch-relaxation class, then returned to the whirlpool, and now had a look of utter bliss on his face.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: SHIVERING in our robes, we warmed ourselves with conch chowder that reminded us of Manhattan clam, followed by lump crabcakes with fried plantains, and shrimp and papaya salad with greens and champagne dressing. Every once in a while we'd hear the swat of a tennis ball from the resort's courts, spy a sailboat gliding up to the small dock, or pick up a bit of corporate jargon from the dressed-for-success group meeting nearby. This afternoon was shaping up as a repeat of yesterday's: reading by the pool and maybe a swing in one of the hammocks on Serenity Beach. At some point, though, we'd have to tool over the Pinellas Bayway to the turreted pink 1920's castle known as the Don CeSar, on St. Pete's powdery beach.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: I'd heard about the Don CeSar. A friend who grew up in Tampa said all the little girls in town wanted to become princesses when they grew up so they could live there. Pulling up the semicircular drive, I could see why.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Built by the real estate mogul Thomas Rowe to resemble the renowned Royal Hawaiian on Waikiki Beach, the Don, as it was known, opened in 1928 and lured a Gatsby esque crowd including F. Scott Fitzgerald, Clarence Darrow, Lou Gehrig and Al Capone. After falling on hard times during the Depression and World War II, the Don served for a time as a convalescent center for battle-fatigued veterans. It was rescued from the wrecking ball in the late 60's and reopened as a luxury resort in 1973. Renovations in the 1980's streamlined the ornate Spanish-style interiors, and the 4,000-square-foot beach club and spa opened in 1994.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: We arrived just in time for yoga, which, along with aerobics, water aerobics and body sculpting, is offered two or three times a week. Usually taught on the hotel beach, the class that night was held in a meeting room indoors because of the cool weather. We'd just gotten through the feisty Warrior pose, touted by the instructor as a ''natural antidepressant,'' when we were uprooted by a conference group and sent to the fifth floor. By the end of the hour, all eight of us seemed transported.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Back in our suite, I soaked in the tub before dinner. The bathroom was cramped but lovely, done in white Carrara marble with a combination tub and shower and a scale. Green and pink predominated in the bedroom, sheets on the king-sized bed were doubled Euro-style, and artwork centered on shell motifs. In the living room, there was a small foldout couch and table; each room had its own TV. From our tiny terrace on the fourth floor, we could see the beach below and the promenade of evening power-walkers.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: The Maritana Grille, right off the lobby, is the more elegant of the hotel's two restaurants, with its modern convex wall tanks of vivid tropical fish and subdued lighting. But the casual Sea Porch Cafe, on the lower level near the pool, with french doors open to a breezy courtyard, colorful ceramics and exotic greenery, was more beachy. Settling into a cushy banquette, we tucked into a smoked duck pizza, garlic mashed potatoes and steak with port, chocolate souffle and banana bread with cinnamon ice cream -- there are only a few low-fat choices at each restaurant, and I wasn't in the mood for pasta with roasted vegetables and chervil broth.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Back on the main floor, Lito Cortez was playing standards on the baby grand in the grand salon known as the Lobby Bar. With twinkling crystal chandeliers, green marble floors, and oversized vases of fresh flowers, it seemed more convivial than Sunsets' Lounge, the smoky pub downstairs.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: The next morning, feeling guilty about my culinary excesses -- and being on a tight treatment schedule -- I downed a room service papaya smoothie for breakfast and headed downstairs to the pale pink spa lobby. The four-year-old spa is Lilliputian next to the one at Safety Harbor, but has four pretty treatment rooms done in pink, aqua and white, a small gym with Cybex equipment and free weights, locker rooms and a coed sauna, whirlpool and steamroom scented with eucalyptus. Treatments are limited to scrubs, wraps and massages. Nutritional consultations and personal trainers are also available.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: I'd chosen the Restore Package, a $180 two-hour lineup including an aromatherapy massage, a sea exfoliating or softening scrub, and a sea botanical wrap. The massage was first -- in a pale aqua room with shell sconces refracting dim light, where I was kneaded with unguents: long deep strokes and intense short ones on my calves, neck and scalp.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: THE masseuse mine for all three treatments, handed me a paper thong, left while I changed, then came back and scrubbed me pink with a loofah mitt and grainy sea salt till my skin was glowing. Then it was off to the showers in the locker room to rinse off while she changed the linens and piled up fresh towels.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Next she painted on a cool green-tinged sea botanical cream that smelled of low tide, which made me wonder just what was in it. Then I was mummified in a sheet and crinkly foil astro wrap. Noticing I was shivering, she laid another sheet on me. After eight minutes like King Tut, I was back in the showers. The final salve was milkweed cream that stung under my arms, but otherwise left me with a tingly feeling.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: I'd decided during one of my showers to add a pedicure to the proceedings and test the state-of-the-art whirlpool chairs in the salon across the spa. The thronelike seat had magic electronic fingers massaging my neck and back and a whirlpool for my lower calves and feet. Another woman came in for a facial -- facials and masques are considered salon treatments -- but otherwise the place was fairly quiet.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: All I needed now was lunch. Strolling outside to the Sea Porch's beachside deck, I spotted Bill at a sunny table. Windblown and hungry after lazing on the beach, he'd ordered a burger and shrimp Cobb salad, and let me have the burger. We decided to top off the afternoon with a swim in each of the two outdoor pools, play a round of shuffleboard and experiment with one of the water toys, maybe an aqua bike, an ungainly conveyance that you pedal over the waves out to sea. It was going to be pretty strenuous. Good thing we knew where to get a massage.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Soaking and stretching along the Gulf Coast
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: At both resorts I was lucky to be able to upgrade my accommodations at check-in for a modest fee ($10 at Safety Harbor, $25 at the Don CeSar); this option may be open to guests if the hotel is uncrowded, and the cost may vary.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Safety Harbor Resort and Spa, 105 North Bayshore Drive, Safety Harbor, Fla. 34695; (888) 237-8772 or (727) 726-1161; fax (727) 726-4268. Double rooms range from $129 to $149 through Dec. 19, from $159 to $179 from Dec. 20 to Jan. 2; from $99 to $169 Jan. 3 to Feb. 7; $119 to $189, through April 10.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: A seven-night, eight-day Spa and Fitness package including a double room, three spa meals per night's stay, use of spa facilities, fitness classes and daytime tennis, $100 in spa services per night, including gratuity for spa, salon and meal plan, is $1,429 to $1,619 a person for a double deluxe room through Dec. 19; $1,849 to $2,288 from Dec. 20 to April 10. Rates do not include 17.5 percent service and tax.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Shorter packages are available, as are spa-only packages and a la carte treatments, including a 50-minute Swedish massage, $70; 25-minute aroma hydrotherapy, and a 25-minute herbal wrap, each $35. In season, making spa appointments four weeks ahead is recommended.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: There are around 30 classes a day in winter season, including water aerobics, which the resort is known for, boxercise, total body conditioning, stretch relaxation, yoga, tai chi and power abs. There is also a corporate Outward Bound program.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas
