text: The Spa Dining Room, open for a la carte breakfast, serves a four-course prix fixe lunch, $16.50, and four-course prix fixe dinner, $27.50. The Cafe, open for lunch, dinner and Sunday brunch, offers a New American menu with such items as beef tenderloin with brandy cream sauce, $17.50, and shellfish pasta with bouillabaisse sauce, $13.50. At lunch,
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: a hamburger is $5.95, a lump crabcake, $7.95, and conch chowder,
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: Don CeSar Beach Resort and Spa, 3400 Gulf Boulevard, St. Pete Beach, Fla. 33706, (800) 282-1116, (727) 360-1881, fax (727) 367-6952. Double rooms range from $194 to $294 through Nov. 30, $139 to $254 Dec. 1 through Dec. 24. One-bedroom gulfside suites range from $384 to $434 through Nov. 30, $344 to $394 Dec. 1 through Dec. 24. Rates have not yet been announced for the Christmas season or for 1999, though they will be higher. Room rates do not include 11 percent Florida tax. A $7.50 daily resort fee covers local telephone calls, use of whirlpool, sauna and steam rooms in the spa, and a housekeeping gratuity.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: The three-night, four-day Pink Palace Refresher package, including sea scrubs and back massages for two, breakfast or lunch for two at the Sea Porch Cafe, a gulfside double at the main resort or a condo-style Beach House suite, costs $949 to $1,069 through Dec. 24. This rate includes tax and gratuity.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: A la carte spa treatments include: a 50-minute aromatherapy massage, $85; 25-minute honeysuckle sea scrub, $50; and a 50-minute firming wrap, $80. Spa-only packages run from the $100 Refresh Spa Package, which includes a sea exfoliating scrub or sea softening scrub and a half-hour back massage, to the $180 Restore Spa Package, which includes a sea botanical wrap, aromatherapy massage and a sea exfoliating scrub or sea softening scrub.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: The spa also offers a coed whirlpool, steam and sauna, plus Cybex equipment, treadmills, Stairmasters, Lifecycles and free weights and a total of seven to nine classes a week in aqua aerobics, aerobics, body sculpting and yoga. There are two outdoor pools and an outdoor Jacuzzi. Watersports equipment is available on the beach for an additional fee.
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: The upscale Maritana Grille, serving dinner only, has a New American menu with dishes like marinated sea bass with curry vinaigrette, $26, and wood grilled rack of lamb with wild mushrooms, $29.50. Wines start at around $24. The Sea Porch Cafe, serving breakfast, lunch and dinner, has a more casual menu with offerings such as pizzettas with toppings such as chevre cheese, eggplant, sun-dried tomatoes and shrimp, $9. CYNTHIA HACINLI
title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas

text: American officials announced today that drug and money-laundering charges had been filed against Vicente Carrillo Fuentes, the brother of a Mexican trafficker who died last year, and they said Mr. Carrillo had assumed control of the drug-smuggling cartel once led by his brother.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: But some American law-enforcement officials disputed the suggestion that a 15-month struggle for control of the cartel has ended, arguing that several violent factions continue to battle for control.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: The cartel, which smuggles billions of dollars' worth of cocaine, heroine and other drugs each year into Texas through Ciudad Juarez, across from El Paso, was led by Amado Carrillo Fuentes until his death in July 1997 at age 41. Vicente Carrillo, 35, was one of several lieutenants.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: In August 1997, a Federal grand jury in El Paso handed down a 27-count indictment against Vicente Carrillo on drug and money-laundering charges, Bill Blagg, the United States Attorney in El Paso, disclosed today. The indictment had been sealed, apparently to protect an investigation.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: Mr. Carrillo is believed to live in Mexico, where American authorities say his organization pays millions of dollars each month to Mexican law-enforcement officials for protection. The main effect of the announcement today appeared to be to increase pressure on Mexican authorities to arrest Mr. Carrillo.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: The indictment charges Mr. Carrillo with smuggling more than four tons of cocaine and nearly five tons of marijuana into West Texas between 1985 and 1997.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: Prosecutors leading the grand jury proceedings originally sought charges against Amado Carrillo, Vicente Carrillo and Lino Herrera, another lieutenant, an American official said. But before the indictment came down, Amado died of a medication overdose after plastic surgery.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: Within weeks, a succession struggle broke out, beginning when gunmen firing at Mr. Herrera sprayed a popular Juarez restaurant with bullets, killing Mr. Herrera and five bystanders. Mexican authorities said they believed the mastermind of that attack was Rafael Munoz Talavera, another cartel leader seeking control. Dozens of killings followed as factions led by Mr. Munoz, Vicente Carrillo and perhaps others fought for control. Last month, Mr. Munoz was found killed in Juarez.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: ''The United States is seeking the man Federal authorities believe is now in control of the Juarez cartel,'' the Justice Department said in a statement today. ''Authorities believe that as a result of the deaths of Amado Carrillo Fuentes and Rafael Munoz Talavera, Vicente Carrillo has assumed the leadership role of the Juarez cartel.''
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: But Bobby Castillo, the agent in charge of the Drug Enforcement Administration's division in El Paso, said the struggle continues. ''I'd never say Vicente is the top dog now,'' he said. ''Vicente's a major player, but there are other factions around.''
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: Mexico was once dominated by a handful of well-defined cartels, he said. When leaders died or were arrested, new chieftains quickly seized control. In contrast, the drug underworld now appears to be fragmenting into smuggling armies who work with scores of sub-contractors.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: ''Before, there wasn't so much doubt about who is in charge,'' Mr. Castillo said. ''Now these organizations break into factions and it's not so easy to identify leaders.''
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: Washington has requested Mr. Carrillo's extradition, but Mexican judges have never ordered the extradition of a major trafficker.
title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs

text: BY THE LIGHT OF MY FATHER'S SMILE
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: 225 pages. Random House. $22.95.
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: Alice Walker's best-known novel, ''The Color Purple,'' for which she won the Pulitzer Prize and the American Book Award in 1983, placed her in the literary pantheon, as a writer who spoke in searingly dramatic terms of the struggle of black women against both racism and the violence of patriarchal society. Ms. Walker has continued, with less noteworthy results, to spin variations on this theme. Her latest offering, ''By the Light of My Father's Smile,'' is a strong indication that, if she hasn't exhausted the subject, she is exhausting her readers with what has by now become a mannered and tendentious litany of New Age cliches.
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: Ms. Walker's new novel recounts the interwoven experiences of several women, though the underlying message of the book, hammered home in frequent passages of sophomoric didacticism, is that most men are not very admirable, that sex is spiritual and that primitive civilizations are morally and sensually superior to technologically advanced ones.
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: Ms. Walker never loses an opportunity to make these points, though mostly she does so by putting opinions into the mouths of half-formed characters rather than developing ideas through the action of the story itself. ''We believe only in the unavoidable horror of hurting others and of likewise being hurt,'' intones a member of a Mexican tribe of Indians, demonstrating the point about moral superiority. ''Being sorry and not being sorry. Forgiving or not forgiving. Our Story is one that continues only for as long as it takes us to do these things.''
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: The person speaking, Manuelito, goes on to describe the source of Western colonialist violence against the indigenous peoples as a harshly puritanical repudiation of the Indians' ritualistic celebration of their children's sexuality. ''They did not appreciate the idea of a mother and father touching the breasts and kissing the vulva and phallus of their grown children, even to bless them,'' Manuelito explains of the Christian missionaries who came to his tribe. ''Because we practiced this, they raided our villages, hacked off our heads with machetes, enslaved us to work in the gold and silver mines. Burned our children alive.''
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: Anthropologists will be surprised to learn that Indian mothers and fathers kissed the sexual organs of their newly married children and that the practice prompted Cortez's genocidal attack on the Aztecs. But a kind of rapturously wrongheaded rewriting of scholarly visions is not the only fault in Ms. Walker's new book. Other problems include characters whose shared chief feature is bland self-satisfaction and the almost complete absence of narrative drive or, indeed, of dramatic structure. Ms. Walker seems to have substituted the heartfelt concerns that motivated ''The Color Purple'' for a mediocre sort of spiritualist philosophizing that is both cloying and predictable.
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: Ms. Walker's main characters are two sisters, Susannah and Magdalena Robinson. Susannah is a striking middle-class woman whose first appearance is described by her father, speaking to us (as does Manuelito) after his death. Robinson Sr., observing Susannah from the afterlife, describes her in the midst of a vigorous erotic encounter with her lover of the moment, Pauline, a gray-haired 55-year-old who, during the course of the book, extols the virtues of marijuana, of having contempt for men and of sensualist liberation. Another of the main characters is Irene, an ostracized dwarf whom Susannah meets while on a visit to a Greek island and who later in the novel turns out to have a lot of the same ideas as Pauline.
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: The story told in ''By the Light of My Father's Smile'' is one of discord and reconciliation among the members of the Robinson family. Susannah and Magdelena grew up in a remote village in Mexico where their anthropologist parents went to study the Mundo tribe, a half-black, half-Indian group that escaped North American slavery centuries ago. Lacking research grants, the Robinsons pretend that they are Christian missionaries so that they can be sent to the land of the Mundo. Their presence among their subjects, in other words, takes place under false pretenses, which, unbeknownst to them, the Indians have understood all along.
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: The seminal moment in this family story comes when the girls' father, concerned that 14-year-old Magdalena's romance with the young Manuelito is making a bad impression, beats her with his belt. That act turns all the other members of the family against him. Magdalena, known as Mad Dog by the Indians, becomes sullen and obese. Susannah, forced to take sides, blames her father for estranging her from Magdalena. The girls' mother, Langley, sleeps in another room, though the father wins her back. ''There was no warmth without her, no fire,'' the father recalls. ''No rebellion of my own angel to enjoy. No surprise.''
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: The Robinson family story is told by several narrators -- the father, Susannah, Magdelena and Langley, as well as Pauline and Manuelito, all of them echoing the well-worn themes of Ms. Walker's victim politics. ''So much beauty in a world indifferent to their ways, a green and gentle and supple world that was actually repelled by the mountainous thickness of the pale male body,'' says Susannah of one people she visits as a tourist. That is actually one of the more stylistically compelling of the pronouncements in a book replete with sappier ones. ''Anyone can see that woman is the mother/of the oldest man on earth/ is it not then a prayer/to bow before her?'' goes a Mundo poem taught by Manuelito to Robinson Sr. after the two of them have met up in the afterlife. ''Did you ever wonder why we bothered with you, Senor?'' Manuelito asks the former missionary. ''It is because you were always making love to your wife,'' he replies to his own question.
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: Even at the story's most intense moment, when Magdalena, in a jealous rage, attacks and almost kills her sister, Ms. Walker fails to create a sense of emotional urgency, letting the episode slip quickly into the narrational and intellectual limpness that infuses this whole book.
title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico

text: Clyde Haberman (NYC column, Oct. 2) calls Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to task for his incivility in referring to Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House drug policy director, as a ''disaster'' as well as for using such language to describe a man who was ''the youngest four-star general, as well as the most highly decorated Army general on active duty, when President Clinton appointed him to the drug post.''
title: Methadone Is Just Another Drug

text: Yet whatever importance one attaches to civility in public discourse, the wrongheadedness of Mayor Giuliani's attack on General McCaffrey's endorsement of methadone use has less to do with the general's military record than with the fact that the attack was wrong on its merits.
title: Methadone Is Just Another Drug

text: On the other hand, were the Mayor to turn his attention to General McCaffrey's resistance to the use of marijuana for medical purposes, now there's a policy for which the word ''disaster'' would be none too strong.
title: Methadone Is Just Another Drug

text: New York, Oct. 3, 1998
title: Methadone Is Just Another Drug

text: MARC LEVIN'S feature film ''Slam'' is a vivid marriage of ideas usually seen as contradictions: documentary and fiction, action and poetry, black and white. ''Slam,'' which opens here on Friday after being shown at the New York Film Festival, is the story of a young black performance poet, Raymond Joshua (Saul Williams), who is imprisoned on a petty drug charge but who manages to establish his identity and his voice within the maelstrom of a Washington jail.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: As indicated by the punning title, the premise of ''Slam'' is itself unusual: not often are jail (the ''slammer'') and the spoken-word scene (''slams'' are competitive poetry performances) linked together. The film is actually fiction, though it gains a graphic documentary quality from having been shot mainly at the District of Columbia's Detention Facility. Both hard-driving and entertaining, with its poetry and a hip-hop soundtrack, ''Slam'' won prizes at both the Sundance and Cannes film festivals.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: ''For a lot of people, the experience of 'Slam' feels really fresh,'' said Geoffrey Gilmore, Sundance's director of programming. ''We all have seen films about young struggling kids from a minority background who end up in jail. The difference with 'Slam' is that the film goes beyond this to talk about creativity and the exploration of one's soul, no matter what the environment.''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: The story of how ''Slam'' was made is as striking a narrative as the film itself, due to the film's cast of characters and to the collaborative way in which it was created. Marc Levin, one of the film's producers and writers as well as its director, is an award-winning documentary film maker. Richard Stratton, another of the film's producers and writers, is a novelist and journalist who served eight years in a Federal penitentiary for importing marijuana. Henri M. Kessler, a third producer, is a former club owner and party promoter.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: Mr. Levin, Mr. Stratton and Mr. Kessler are all white, but the three principal actors whom the film introduces, and who all crafted their own parts, are black. Both Saul Williams, who plays the central figure of Ray, and Sonja Sohn, who plays his lover and mentor Lauren, are poets and actors, while Bonz Malone, who plays the prison leader Hopha, is a writer and former graffiti artist who has also served time.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: How these larger-than-life personalities came together to form the patchwork quilt of ''Slam'' is a story that starts with Mr. Levin's own background. Born in New York and reared in New Jersey, the son of political activists, Mr. Levin, 47, owes his sensibility partly to the ferment of the late 1960's, when he came of age.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: The dynamic gray-haired director has made a career of filming documentaries that explore such issues as the drug war and race relations. When asked about the challenges he has faced as a white film maker exploring this terrain, he said, ''That's always been the spot I've been drawn to in American culture -- the place where black and white cultures meet.''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: Nowhere do these worlds collide more than in Washington, where, as Mr. Levin says, ''there is one of the highest rates of incarceration for young black men, and yet it is also our nation's capital.'' He was drawn there to make a documentary within the Washington jail system in 1997 because of a wish to expose what he calls ''the waste of all these lives. We've written off a generation of young black men, because as a society we've reached a place where rehabilitation and compassion are no longer on the page.''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: The resulting HBO documentary, ''Thug Life in D.C.,'' will be playing in limited theatrical release this fall and led directly, for Mr. Levin, to the birth of ''Slam.'' While shooting ''Thug Life'' in the spring of 1997 at the D.C. Detention Facility (familiarly dubbed the D.C. Jail), it occurred to Mr. Levin that he might have finally found the locale for a feature film.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: He and his partners, Mr. Stratton, Mr. Kessler, and David Peipers had formed Offline Entertainment Group in 1994 with the aim of making feature films, and Mr. Levin had been considering the story idea of an artistic black kid who goes to jail. This character became a poet when Mr. Levin saw Saul Williams performing at a poetry slam in April of 1996 and cast him as his lead.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: Denied access to New York's Rikers Island, the film makers turned to the Washington prison administrators they knew from the documentary; those administrators took the startling step of approving the filming of ''Slam'' in their jail. ''The director of the D.C. Department of Corrections was Margaret Moore, and the warden of the jail was Pat Jackson,'' Mr. Levin said, ''strong, intelligent black women who are torn apart because they're putting away their own people.''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: Pat Jackson, who has since moved on to another prison, said, ''Marc and his crew wanted people to know about the whole process and were really ultimately concerned with 'How can we make this change?' ''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: In structuring ''Slam,'' Mr. Levin allowed his actors to create their own lines and decided to shoot in a spontaneous, documentary-like style that was dubbed, by his crew, ''drama verite.'' The actors spent nine months developing the story and their characters before filming started. Much of the dialogue was to be improvised on camera.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: In the film, Raymond Joshua (Mr. Williams) manages to stave off a beating in jail by a dazzling poetry performance that literally disarms his enemies. The charismatic prison leader Hopha (Bonz Malone) pays Raymond's bail so that he can spread a message of nonviolence on the streets. Once out, Ray embarks on a romantic relationship with the writing teacher whom he had met while in prison, as he grapples with the reality that he will most likely still have to serve time.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: When Mr. Levin got in touch with Mr. Malone, a longtime friend, to ask him to play the role of Hopha, he found him serving a four-month sentence on Rikers Island for assault. ''As it turns out, it was role rehearsal,'' Mr. Malone said.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: A slight 30-year-old whose business card reads ''consigliere,'' Mr. Malone is a combination of ambassador and impresario. By age 18, he was writing a column for Spin magazine, and he now writes a monthly column for Vibe magazine called ''Tuph St.'' ''I ran with gangs since I was 12, been in jail in and out since I was 15,'' he said.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: His experiences have made him embrace what he says is ''Slam's'' uplifting message. '' 'Slam' is about a young poet who goes to jail and finds his voice -- first how to free himself, and then how to free others,'' he said. ''It's about bettering your life situation even in a harder place. I've been there.''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: Mr. Williams, 26, who as Ray performs his own poetry throughout the film, has, in contrast, an almost otherworldly sense of calm and a majestic way of speaking. Rangy and dreadlocked, he grew up in upstate New York, the son of a Baptist pastor and a schoolteacher. He has a master's in fine arts degree from New York University. ''In preparing to play Ray, my through-line was 'How many spells can I cast through poetry?' '' he said.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: Ms. Sohn, who plays Lauren Bell, has her own fervor. Tall, half Korean and half black, she grew up in projects in Virginia and knows the terrain of ''Slam'' well. In one scene, Lauren, teaching a workshop in the jail, breaks down in tears as she mentions her dead brother -- a detail Ms. Sohn took from her own life. ''I hope the film gives a reality to those stereotyped faces and lives that people think they know,'' she said.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: After getting approval from the prison administrators, the team drove down to Washington in late July of 1997 for a two-week guerrilla-style film shoot. The financing of ''Slam,'' which cost a little over a million dollars, only fell into place at the end: until then, Mr. Kessler had maxed out his credit card.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: The film has sly humor, notably in the scene where Marion Barry, the former mayor of Washington has a cameo role as an anti-drug judge. The film makers also cast some of the real inmates in various roles, all the while improvising and working under time constraints. This gave rise to scenes such as the one where Mr. Williams, playing Ray in his jail cell, embarked on an extended verbal riff with an actual prisoner, Bay, in the cell next door. ''We were freestyling back and forth, for 45 minutes,'' Mr. Williams said. ''They didn't even say, 'Cut.' They just changed the film and let us keep going.''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: But perhaps the most galvanizing scene to shoot was the one where Ray faces his enemies down in the jail yard. The warden unexpectedly closed down the shooting that night, but then allowed the crew to shoot again the following day -- only for an hour, though, and with more inmates in the yard, many of whom were not aware that Mr. Williams was not a real prisoner. ''I was getting these 'new kid' looks from people,'' Mr. Williams recalled. ''When it came time for people to start gathering around me, some of them actually did want a piece of me.'' He smiled. ''But the poetry stopped them.''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: In this volatile environment, Mr. Levin kept his cool. ''Marc knows that life itself is unscripted,'' Mr. Malone said.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: The ''Slam'' team attributes the acclaim that the film subsequently attracted at festivals to the nature of Ray's odyssey. Despite the sobering questions the film poses about the justice system, it also presents the idea of freedom as a metaphysical, rather than a literal, state.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: I THINK the key to 'Slam' is in that line which Lauren says: 'Freedom isn't out here, it's in here,' '' said Ms. Sohn, pointing to her head. '' 'Never give anyone the power to take away your freedom.' ''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: There are no easy answers in the film, only many heated arguments. ''The film is about choices,'' Mr. Malone said. ''It's foolish to think that this is just one race or class of people affected.''
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: Meanwhile, the film seems to have set in motion a string of other projects. Mr. Levin has just finished shooting ''White Boys,'' partly financed by Fox Searchlight Pictures, which was shot on location in Iowa and Chicago.
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: ''White Boys,'' starring Danny Hoch and written by Mr. Hoch and Mr. Levin, among others, is a dramatic comedy about white teen-agers in the Midwest who emulate black hip-hop culture. Not only does Mr. Levin intend to sustain his drama verite methods in his next films, he also intends to continue exploring the questions that he raised with ''Slam.'' ''We've been so stuck in definitions -- liberal and conservative, black and white,'' he said. ''That's one of the great things about the hip-hop generation: there's a new dialogue of race. We have to find a new way of thinking about black and white. You have to get in and mix it up and tell people, 'This is what I want to say.'
title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression

text: Eager to prevent more teen-agers from poisoning themselves by eating jimson weed seeds, Monmouth County officials plan to meet Monday to discuss removing the plants from Farmingdale and Howell Township and starting a campaign to criminalize use of the seeds.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: Jimson weed is increasingly being used by teen-agers to obtain a quick high, area officials say, and five local youths were hospitalized this week after eating the seeds.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: James Wasser, Superintendent of Schools, said he wanted the New Jersey Legislature to make the plant a controlled dangerous substance, like marijuana, and create stiffer penalties for possession. Ingesting the seeds is now a disorderly person's offense, which is comparable to a misdemeanor in other jurisdictions.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: ''It's a slap on the hand, and to kids that doesn't mean anything,'' Mr. Wasser said. ''It does nothing to deter them.''
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: Jimson weed can cause severe hallucinations, dilated pupils and rapid heartbeat. One of the five teen-agers who were hospitalized after eating the toxic seeds was discharged today from the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. Two others remain in critical condition and two are listed as stable.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: Mr. Wasser said officials believed all five got the seeds from plants growing wild in a cornfield across the street from Howell Township High School. He said school officials today contacted a farming company that leases the field and made arrangements to remove the plants.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: The meeting on Monday will explore ways to clear away other patches of jimson weed growing wild in Farmingdale and in Howell, the two communities where the five students live and attend school.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: William Bamka, an agriculture extension agent in Burlington County who is an herbicide specialist, said there are at least 30 herbicides that can control jimson, including some used specifically in cornfields. But he said finding and spraying all the plants would be difficult.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: ''A better way to attack it is an education program to make people alert,'' Mr. Bamka said.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: Besides local school and government officials, representatives of the county Health Department, Substance Abuse office and the Prosecutor's office are to attend Monday's meeting.
title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed

text: Until very recently, the pitch for a contemporary movie celebrating the life-saving power of poetry would have been laughed out of every Hollywood studio. Hail, hail, the conquering poet? Please, you must be kidding. But the rising popularity of competitive ''slams,'' in which poetry, rap, performance art and stand-up comedy converge and ignite has redefined a literary form traditionally associated with bearded bohemians and nebbishy bookworms.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: And in much the same way that ''Saturday Night Fever'' created a boom by conferring a macho glamour on disco, Marc Levin's stirring pop fable ''Slam'' elevates rhythmically charged, fervently incantatory street poetry into a redemptive sport.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: Especially for young disenfranchised blacks, the movie suggests, catching the slam spirit can be as life-transforming as success on the basketball court or in the recording studio. Disgorging your inner life in rhapsodic spoken dream-songs that set audiences cheering may be the secular equivalent of the gospel experience. At least that's the way ''Slam'' portrays it.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: Ray Joshua (Saul Williams), the charismatic young hero of ''Slam,'' is the Washington inner-city equivalent of working-class screen heroes like Tony Manero or Rocky Balboa. As played by Mr. Williams, one of the stars of the slam movement, Ray exudes a sanctified fervor reminiscent of the reggae legend Bob Marley, along with a mild-mannered almost academic politesse. Wiry, sad-eyed and soft-spoken, Ray stands out from his tough-talking peers in his neighborhood housing project, which has acquired the nickname Dodge City. He is such a mythic being that the movie doesn't bother to give him a past or a family or even a best friend. When Ray is arrested for possession of a quarter pound of marijuana, jailed and told his best hope is to cop a plea that will yield him a two-to-three-year (instead of an 8-to-10-year) sentence, you shudder at how brutally the justice system has slammed the door on his future.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: While in prison, Ray keeps himself sane by writing verses on a yellow legal pad and reciting them to himself. One day in the prison yard, he explodes into poetry so incendiary that his fellow prisoners stand back in awe of his verbal magic. Fortunately, an attractive young woman named Lauren Bell (Sonja Sohn), who runs the prison writing program, watches Ray's performance and invites him to her writing class. Once Ray makes bail, he visits her, and they begin an affair. Lauren, he learns, has been through her own hell and emerged whole, with the help of poetry. One night, at the end of a poetry slam, she invites Ray onstage to perform. In the language of stand-up comedy, he ''kills.''
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: ''Slam'' arrives at the New York Film Festival (with screenings today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 7:15 P.M) already decorated with the grand prize at the Sundance Film Festival and the award for best first film at Cannes. The director, who has made a number of documentaries about prison life, filmed a number of scenes inside a Washington prison using its population as extras. And these pungent prison sequences lend parts of the movie a scary credibility.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: But in many other ways, ''Slam'' is as much a rose-colored up-from-the-streets Hollywood fantasy as ''Saturday Night Fever'' or ''Rocky.'' Mr. Williams's cultivated, beautifully spoken Ray is certainly charismatic. But the notion that this saintly mild-mannered esthete could have sprung full-blown from Washington's meanest streets seems far-fetched. He simply doesn't share the same language (either verbal or body) with his peers. And the idea that his impromptu prison yard rap, which is fairly lofty and not easy to follow, would command instant respect in the prison yard is also questionable.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: What ''Slam'' possesses is real passion, and that is in short supply in movies these days. The movie may be a crude Hollywood fable, but the director and Richard Stratton, his collaborator on the story, obviously care a lot about their characters, the slam scene and the self-transcendence that it can offer performing poets who have the gift.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: Like any enjoyable pop fable, ''Slam'' relentlessly hammers home an uplifting, if simplistic message. Our toughest prisons aren't outside ourselves but inside, it insists. The only meaningful real freedom we can achieve is to be found inside.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: ''Slam'' is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has scenes of violence and abundant profanity.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: Directed by Marc Levin; written by Mr. Levin, Richard Stratton, Bonz Malone, Sonja Sohn and Saul Williams, based on a story by Mr. Levin and Mr. Stratton; director of photography, Mark Benjamin; edited by Emir Luis; music by DJ Spooky; produced by Henri M. Kessler, Mr. Levin and Mr. Stratton; released by Trimark Pictures. Saturday at 6 P.M. and Sunday at 7:15 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall as part of the 36th New York Film Festival. Running time: 92 minutes. This film is rated R.
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: WITH: Saul Williams (Ray Joshua), Sonja Sohn (Lauren Bell), Bonz Malone (Hopha), Lawrence Wilson (Big Mike), Beau Sia (Jimmy Huang), Andre Taylor (China), Momolu Stewart (Bay/Jail Rapper), Ron Jones and Reamer Shedrick (Do Wop Cops), Allan E. Lucas (Chief C.O.), Dominic Chianese Jr. (Officer Dom) and Mayor Marion Barry Jr. (Judge).
title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds

text: AT first glance, Russ Smith does not look as if he belongs in the Chelsea offices of The New York Press, the pugnacious, profane weekly newspaper that turned 10 years old this spring.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: The beige offices are ''very Lou Grant,'' Mr. Smith says, but they have unmistakable Lou Reed overtones: the sound of a pounding guitar drifts from somewhere, piles of books and papers litter the floors, and young editors meet in well-worn concert T-shirts.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: Mr. Smith, 43, the newspaper's majority owner and its editor in chief, wears a pinstriped Paul Stuart suit and shiny gold cuff links. He could easily be a father who has come up from Wall Street to take his bohemian daughter to lunch at a place she can't afford.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: But then Mr. Smith puts his feet up, lights a Merit and launches into a lazy, obscenity-laced diatribe against the evils of the establishment. He rails against excessive taxes, government regulations and powerful media companies that are obsessed with celebrity culture.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: He reminisces about when he was a ''20-year-old drug-taking hippie,'' says he still supports the legalization of marijuana, and describes proudly how the police showed up at the newspaper's last raucous party. Then he talks glowingly about former President George Bush.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: If Mr. Smith is an improbable set of walking contradictions, he is the perfect embodiment of his free newspaper. Founded with the sole objective of knocking The Village Voice off its alternative pedestal, The New York Press has long sought to attract readers mainly by infuriating them with its eclecticism.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: Its columnists include Alexander Cockburn, a former Village Voice writer with a pronounced Marxist viewpoint, and Christopher Caldwell of The Weekly Standard, the conservative Washington magazine. Its sex columnist recounts her bedroom encounters in vivid, sometimes excruciating detail on one page while the next page features a column on obscure historical facts.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: Besides having plowed $3.7 million of his own money into the paper, Mr. Smith also contributes a dyspeptic column called Mugger, in which he has excoriated everyone from President Clinton to Tina Brown to waiters at expensive restaurants near the Tribeca loft he shares with his wife and two young sons.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: ''I want our readers to turn to one column and say, 'I just hate this guy, and I'm never going to read him again,' and then turn to another one and say, 'Man, I love this!' '' Mr. Smith says. ''I want that kind of passion.''
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: IT is a kind of passion he believes The Voice no longer inspires. Growing up in Huntington, N.Y., the youngest of five sons of a carwash owner, Mr. Smith fell in love with journalism reading The Voice in the late 1960's, and he says he modeled his first weekly newspapers, in Baltimore and Washington, after it. (He sold those papers in 1987.)
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: But now, he says, The Voice has become ossified, full of ''stuck-in-the-70's, left-wing stuff'' and pompous writing. ''What about the 20-year-old who just wants to hear about the Smashing Pumpkins' new album,'' he asked, ''and doesn't want a four-paragraph discourse on Baudelaire or Thomas Carlyle?''
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: (Donald H. Forst, the editor of The Voice, declined yesterday to debate Mr. Smith point by point, saying only: ''The man does foam at the mouth.'')
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: Mr. Smith deftly dodged every question about revenues, profits and salaries, but he said his paper became profitable two years ago and was slowly gaining ground on The Voice, which switched to free distribution in Manhattan in 1996.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: This summer, The Press expanded from tabloid size to include a full-size front section that is wrapped around the tabloid. When it started in 1988, Mr. Smith said, it had 5 full-time employees and published 24 pages a week. It now employs 55 people, 10 of them on the editorial side and the rest in sales and management, and its most recent issue was 120 pages. Every Tuesday, it distributes 110,000 copies, a little less than half of The Voice's circulation.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: Its rivalry with The Voice provides a glimpse into what remains of the great city newspaper wars of yesteryear. Far from trying to scoop The Voice on news, The Press has avoided conventional reporting, Mr. Smith said. Its boldest competitive move so far came about six weeks ago, when Mr. Smith dispatched an editor and a cartoon artist to sneak into a picnic for The Voice's staff and write about it.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: Beneath The Press's masthead, the paper bills itself modestly as ''New York's Free Weekly Newspaper,'' facts that are all true but that make no grand promises about what is inside. And despite Mr. Smith's criticisms of The Voice as moribund, he does not enumerate any high journalistic goals for The Press, except that it remain interesting and its opinions honest.
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: ''Being free is very liberating,'' he said. ''We know why people pick up our paper. It's for the listings. It's for the classifieds. It's for the adult ads. It's for the astrology column. And for some people, it's for the actual stories. Because of that, as journalists, we can print anything we want.''
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: ''I am not presumptuous enough to think that I can force The Voice out of business,'' he said. ''I just want to be the No. 1 paper, and in many ways right now, I guess, we are still the No. 2 paper.''
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: He paused and then added defiantly, ''Of course, in many ways I think we're the No. 1 paper.''
title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly

text: It has been a roller-coaster year for Germany's environmentalist Greens. They have zigzagged on German troop deployment in Bosnia, called for a near-tripling of gasoline prices, only to shelve the idea, gone back and forth on what to do about NATO and finally found themselves a likely member of Germany's new government.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: ''We have shown a certain amount of chaos,'' said Harald Handel, a spokesman for the party that seems almost certain to form a ''Red-Green'' coalition with the Social Democrats of Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroder. ''The chaos was a reflection of a lack of organization, and we now intend to change that.''
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: But can the Greens, founded in 1979 as a loose coalition of pacifists, environmentalists, socialists and feminists, evolve from the freewheeling ways of opposition into a cohesive party of government that speaks with a single voice?
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: Mr. Schroder, who is to begin coalition talks with the Greens on Friday, clearly has concerns. ''The Social Democratic Party stands for economic stability, law and order and continuity in foreign policy,'' he told the mass-circulation newspaper Bild in an interview published today. ''This is not negotiable.''
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: In other words, closing nuclear power stations that produce a third of Germany's energy -- a Green demand -- is incompatible with ''economic stability.'' Legalizing soft drugs like marijuana -- a Green demand -- is incompatible with ''law and order.'' Opposing NATO expansion -- a Green demand -- is incompatible with ''continuity in foreign policy.''
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: In Washington, officials indicated, some of Mr. Schroder's concerns are shared, although it is widely believed that the Greens, hungry for a power they have never tasted, will prove pragmatic, allowing the party's most influential figure, Joschka Fischer, a possible Foreign Minister, to hold his eclectic followers to NATO policies.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: The United States therefore expects periodic irritations -- protests from some party members on NATO expansion, hesitations over any NATO military action in Kosovo, resolute opposition to imports of American foods that have been genetically modified -- rather than any serious confrontation with the Greens.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: Sensing the unease over the unpredictability they have shown this year, the Greens today announced a reorganization of the party aimed at wresting some power from local organizations and increasing centralized control.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: In the past, such moves have been resisted, because they smacked of excessive hierarchy. Even the term ''leader'' has been shunned because it was a far cry from the sandal-wearing spontaneity of the party's birth. ''We want to carry out structural reforms that will lead to a truly federal party,'' Heide Ruehle, the party manager, said in a radio interview. ''At the moment we are a kind of loose collective of very strong local groups with their own rules and funding, who have pushed the central party around a bit.''
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: Up to now, about 80 percent of the party's financing has gone to state units of the Greens, and only 20 percent to the central organization. As a result, Mr. Handel said, the party had little central control, and ''we have been talking with different tongues.''
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: This was evident at a party congress in Magdeburg in March that turned into a fiasco, when, despite Mr. Fischer's pleas, the party came out against the continued participation of German troops in the NATO mission in Bosnia. To Mr. Fischer's horror, the congress also voted for the taxes that would sharply increase gasoline prices.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: Both those positions were later revised as their unpopularity and the obstacles they would pose to an alliance with the Social Democrats became clear.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: But the old split between ''Fundis'' and ''Realos,'' the die-hard pacifists and the pragmatists, remains, as does a rivalry between Mr. Fischer and Jurgen Trittin, another leading figure whose criticism of the German Army caused an outcry early this year.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: Immediately after the election, for instance, Mr. Trittin called for the closing of Germany's 20 nuclear power plants ''as soon as possible.'' Mr. Fischer was silent on the subject.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: The Greens now plan to set up a 20-member committee that will provide greater central control and insure that the positions of the party's various leading figures are closely coordinated, party members said.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: Mr. Handel, the spokesman, said: ''We want to be serious partners for our European and Atlantic allies. There are treaties, and these treaties must be respected. We do not want to turn back the tide of history.''
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: Thus, while the party has taken a position against NATO expansion, it recognizes that a decision has been taken and will abide by it, he said. ''In the long term,'' he added, ''we would like to see the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe take over many tasks from NATO, but that, I repeat, is a long-term aim.''
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: In the short term, it seems clear that the Greens will work hard to agree on a solid four-year government program with Mr. Schroder and to disprove departing Chancellor Helmut Kohl's repeated warning during the campaign: ''The Green Party platform represents a major security risk for Germany.''
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: It will be a major adjustment for a party unused to the strictures of government or central organization. The adjustment will have to made quickly. Officials said today that Mr. Schroder wanted to be sworn in by Oct. 22 so he can attend a European Union summit meeting in Austria later that week.
title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?

text: ''Mom is drunk!'' they screamed. ''Mom is drunk!''
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: It was already the sixth inning at Yankee Stadium, but Theresa Hales, a k a Mom, wasn't really drunk, no matter what the other Bleacher Creatures were chanting. Sure, she'd had a sip or two of the frozen cocktail that somebody was passing around in souvenir plastic cups. But if she was reeling a little -- and she was not the only one -- it might have been from the hot afternoon sun.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Truth to tell, everyone in Section 39 was staggering a little yesterday, and not just from the free-flowing beer or the marijuana fumes that wafted over from Section 41. For the Yankees, the 8-3 defeat of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays was a tuneup for the playoffs that will begin Tuesday. But for many hard-core, longtime fans who prefer the benches of the shadeless right-field bleachers, it was the season's last hurrah.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Under a new playoff ticket distribution system, the Yankees rewarded season-ticket holders and other fans with many of the seats in the bleachers, leaving the rest to the winners of a lottery of sorts held on Sept. 19. Many of the Creatures will be at each Yankees home game through the playoffs, but they will be scattered throughout the stadium. Some even gave in and bought the much more expensive box seats -- which under normal circumstances would be considered an act of treason.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: ''It's definitely a semisweet day,'' said Paul Kaplan, 31, of Manhattan, a five-year veteran of the bleachers. ''We always had the playoffs to look forward to.''
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Tina Lewis, the dean of the Creatures, who says she has been a regular since 1985, was too worked up about the situation to talk much about it. She said she still held out hope that the Yankees would do the right thing when the World Series begins in the Bronx -- a foregone conclusion, of course -- and set aside a big enough cluster of seats cheap enough for the Creatures to make their raucous voices heard.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Because that is what Bleacher Creatures do.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: They yell ''Jump!'' or ''Throw your young!'' at people in the upper deck who make the mistake of peering down over the rail. They jeer at anyone stupid enough to show up in a Mets hat until the cops down in front helpfully suggest that the offending fan remove it. They sing a warped version of ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game'' that could make Kenneth Starr blush.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: The uninitiated -- mothers and fathers watching from the right-field box seats and loges, for instance -- often smile bemusedly at these loud-mouthed, happy-go-lucky freaks in pro-wrestling shirts, Yankee tattoos and Yankee pendants on gold chains.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Then they begin to make out the words -- nearly all of which are unprintable, at least in context. Locker-room humor doesn't come close to Bleacher Creature humor.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: There is an entire repertory devoted to the visiting team's right fielder, who would be well advised to have a thick skin or at least a pair of earplugs. There are chants, challenges and taunts for the bozos in the box seats who paid $23 for a view no better than the one from the $7 bleachers.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: And there are riffs on the stadium special effects, like that annoying accelerating drumbeat. While lesser, sheeplike fans clap along anemically, the go-it-alone Creatures yell ''Tom! Tom! Tom!'' while the portly Tom Brown, 30, of Astoria, Queens, bumps, grinds and all but dislocates his pelvis.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: ''I love these people,'' Mr. Brown said, recovering from his exertion with a cold one. ''And these people need loving. We're like the biggest dysfunctional family in the world.''
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: He was not kidding. Take John McCarthy, 19, of the Woodlawn section of the Bronx. All game long, he filled out a score card, compulsively tracing over each entry 15 times or more in ballpoint ink. ''To keep it from fading,'' he explained, still etching away in his inch-thick book of score cards. ''I'm going to keep this locked up in a safe when I'm finished, to protect it from sunlight.''
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Mr. McCarthy has his reasons for obsessing. ''I missed only seven home games this year, but the first one was David Wells's perfect game,'' he said. ''I was devastated. I had to go to a family celebration, for my first cousin's 25th anniversary of his ordination as a priest. Nothing against my cousin, but if it was up to me, I'd be here.''
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Who needs blood relatives, after all, when you bleed Yankee blue?
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Mr. Kaplan, an investment banker in Manhattan who was at his 67th game yesterday (nine of them were on the road), explained that those effete types in the box seats, who sometimes yell ''Welfare seats!'' at the Creatures, just don't get it.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: ''I, for one, choose to sit here,'' he said. ''I've sat in box seats, and I don't have as much fun. I know that I can do no wrong here. And I'm accepted. We're all the same here.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: ''Besides, there's always a common enemy to hate.''
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Like Mets fans. Security guards. Clueless people who stand up before there are two strikes and two outs on the opposing team. Rally killers who run to the bathroom in the middle of an inning. Those halfhearted, so-called fans who slink off in the seventh inning to beat the traffic. Anyone who tries to start the Wave.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: For years, the Creatures were a small but hardy lot. Then a Daily News sportswriter began chronicling their emotional highs and lows, and soon Section 39 was overrun with wannabes and hangers-on, all bragging about showing up for a mere 15 or 20 games a year.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: As their media star has climbed, the Creatures have risen to the occasion, coming up with one new rousing yell after another. The best-known G-rated one is Roll Call: After the first pitch is thrown, the Creatures chant the names of nearly every Yankee player -- and of the team's two radio announcers -- until each doffs a cap or waves in response.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Listening, singing and shouting along to even the raunchiest chants are a few young children and their parents -- like Ms. Hales, the Creature known as Mom, and her 12-year-old son, Stan. A cook at a public school in the West Farms section of the Bronx, Ms. Hales said she figured her son would hear foul language at school anyway.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: She said she had been going to Yankee games for 40 years when she took Stan to a right-field box for a game in 1996.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: ''In the box seats, it's so quiet,'' she said. ''He heard all the rowdiness, and he started liking it.''
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: Apparently, so did his mother.
title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats

text: WELCOME back to school, children. Lesson No. 1: The world is a dangerous place, filled with creeps, poisons and predators. Beware!
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: The American classroom today echoes with dire warnings about dangers and evils that seemingly lurk everywhere, from marijuana peddlers to child molesters.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: The old notion of sticking to basic education, in the view of some safety advocates, belongs in a dreamily outdated age of innocent, white picket-fence childhoods. What good are the three R's, after all, to a child trapped in the trunk of an abductor's car, a scenario actually discussed in some child safety programs around the nation. (The recommended response: Unhook the taillight wires to alert the police.)
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Among the many worries of parents, illegal drugs rank near the top. In declaring a virtual war on drug abuse, Americans have responded for more than a decade with drug-education programs that cost hundreds of millions of dollars and consume precious classroom time.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: By far the biggest of these efforts, Drug Abuse Resistance Education, or DARE, is used in about 70 percent of the nation's public schools and has generally won overwhelming approval from students, parents, teachers and the police officers who conduct the classes. DARE, which relies on workbook teaching and promotes kinship with the police, is one of about 50 antidrug and safety campaigns in schools.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: There's just one problem: these programs generally don't work.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Several studies have found that children who attend drug-education classes are just as likely to use illegal drugs as students who do not participate.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Until now, officials of nonprofit drug prevention programs have dismissed the studies with claims that the findings were colored by the political agendas of academics and researchers. But the latest study, released early this year, was conducted by Dennis Rosenbaum, a professor who had been a DARE supporter, and was financed by the Illinois State Police, a champion of the program.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Among other discouraging findings, this study found that DARE has even unwittingly encouraged some young people to try drugs, especially students in the suburbs, according to Mr. Rosenbaum, a criminal justice professor at the University of Illinois in Chicago. DARE has defended its results and points to endorsements from many school districts.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: School-based anti-drug programs remain popular despite such findings, though an increasing number of skeptical voices have been raised. A number of cities have even quit DARE, including Oakland, Omaha, Spokane, Wash., and Fayetteville, N.C.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Earl Wysong, an Indiana University professor at the Kokomo campus, whose research has found DARE programs to be ineffective in curbing drug use, said people were starting to become ''a little less enthusiastic'' about the program.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Some critics of drug-education efforts say students learn quickly that they are being given a message -- and that a message is different from education. Moreover, if students come to see any part of an anti-drug campaign as propaganda, they tend to distrust the entire message.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Despite these concerns, Mr. Wysong said, critics find it difficult to speak out. ''You leave yourself open to charges that you're not on the team in fighting this plague,'' he said.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Anti-drug programs often go far beyond warnings about illegal drugs, alcohol and cigarettes, teaching children to be wary of unfamiliar adults and giving them specific game plans for escape.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: During the weeks before Halloween, for example, many parents will be warned about the risks of trick-or-treating, and virtually all of them will be told not to let their children eat anything that isn't factory-wrapped. For many parents, giving a shiny red apple to a child on Halloween nowadays is about as thoughtless as offering a cigarette.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Some parents and child psychologists have raised concerns that children are being scared needlessly, noting that kidnappers hiding in the bushes are actually exceedingly rare. But such cases are the stuff of made-for-television movies and lurid accounts on local newscasts. The fact is that children are far more likely to be abused by a family member.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Drug-education programs have also raised some concerns among civil libertarians, who feel uneasy about classrooms being turned over to uniformed police officers. In the case of DARE, a question box sits in the classroom during the program, so children can talk anonymously about anything -- including the drug-taking habits of friends or family members.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: The DARE officer will not listen to specific allegations, but instead encourages the children to report such activity to a school official. And when a child goes to a teacher or counselor with knowledge of such drug-taking -- for example, a parent who smokes marijuana -- the school is bound to go to the legal authorities.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: Loren Siegel, director of public education for the American Civil Liberties Union, said the organization had no official position on programs like DARE.
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: But, she added, ''Anything that encourages surveillance -- reporting on your family members or friends -- cannot be good for a democracy.''
title: The Nation: Just Say Maybe; Second Thoughts on Cops in the Class

text: WHILE waiting for Mr. Livestock last week, I felt the anger rise in my throat like mercury in a thermometer. I have bigger problems these days, so it helped to fixate on a small one like Mr. Livestock's inspection of my building for a new insurance policy. As the co-op board president, I had arranged the inspection, but I also had a more personal stake; the old policy did not cover sewer or flood damage, both of which I have suffered lately. I assumed Mr. Livestock would find faults in the building, write it off as 12 units of self-mismanagement, a ship of fools whose elected captain, me, couldn't steer a shopping cart into a checkout lane.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: Mercury rising, I would have canceled his visit, but when he called that morning to re-confirm I was at the Wiz, winding up to throw my new cordless phone through the store's front window. Only two weeks old, the phone had made what I considered a pointed decision: it turned me mute. I could hear clearly enough, but no one heard me. It did little for my mood that a Mr. Oswald Samuels, politely and professionally, gave me a new phone with the briefest of discussions. No release of rage there.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: So now I was awaiting Mr. Livestock, whose inspecting eyes would flick over the lobby carpet, ingeniously stained by animals, vegetables and minerals. Why insure anyone who lived here? He would raise eyebrows at the child's bike and the tree-in-a-tub on the upper floors. He would wonder why the board couldn't teach co-op members to deal with their garbage in a responsible manner. I was not about to admit that in a time of panic we had accepted children of the rich, and British stockbrokers who soon fled back to Asia, and sublet.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: Mr. Livestock arrived four minutes early, a trim, tanned, merry man with curly gray hair. He looked younger than 66. He introduced himself as Ray, and said, ''Bob and Ray, remember them?'' I tried not to laugh with him, and failed.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: We bounced around the building, which seemed to delight him. Since the 1960's, he told me, when he stopped being a real estate broker, he has inspected more than 12,000 buildings. He loves looking at New York from its rooftops, he said, especially when he finds marijuana plants. Which he did at a rental building of yuppies on the Upper West Side, he said, and he suggsted to the landlord that he lock the door to the roof. Once, in a basement, Mr. Livestock said, he found an electric chair from Sing Sing. It had been used in the filming of a Jimmy Cagney movie. He brought it to the owner's attention, but has no idea what happened to it.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: He shrugged at the bike and the tree. Co-ops make their own rules, he said, but if there were ''children or seniors'' living here who could stumble against them in the dark during a fire, it would be a good idea to get rid of them.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: I wouldn't mind getting rid of a few residents, I told him, including one of the subletters and a young woman whose almost-famous mother bought her the apartment. Despite signs and letters, they can't seem to understand that garbage doesn't go in the recycling bins. Or care. It seems like such a ''drop dead'' to the rest of us in the building. I began to rant: ''I'm tired of taking care of other people's children. If it takes a village, let it be Greenwich Village, not here.''
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: Mr. Livestock nodded and chuckled. Obviously, he had heard everything from everybody.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: ''That's right,'' he said. ''The idea of a co-op is self-government. Nixon couldn't get a co-op in the city. He had to move to New Jersey. Who would want him in the building? I figure Bill will be looking for an apartment pretty soon. Think he could get into a co-op?''
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: I imagined our board meeting on the Clintons, and by the time we got back down to the basement, I couldn't remember what I had been so cranky about.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: Mr. Livestock seemed delighted with the building. He said we were in good shape, far better than most. He thought we'd get a good insurance rate. Especially since he didn't think we had underground streams.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: ''Undergound streams?'' I tried to remember who was the straight man, Bob or Ray.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: ''Good water,'' he said. ''Drinkable.''
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: ''We could bottle it, sell it as Gramercy Park Springs.''
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: He laughed. ''Of course, you know, this is earthquake country.''
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: That stopped me. ''Can I get insurance for that?''
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: He shook his head. ''But I wouldn't worry, it's a long shot. The buildings here are pretty solid.'' He was finished and leaving. ''Besides, this is New York. When the earthquake hits, people will just shrug and say, 'There go the subways again.' ''
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: Now I've got something new to fixate on, remote but bigger than any of my other problems.
title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.

text: SAUL WILLIAMS walked into the Antique Boutique in Greenwich Village as though it were his old neighborhood. He had the same comfortable, long-limbed stride his poet-rapper character in ''Slam,'' this year's Sundance grand prize winner, used while walking around the projects in Washington. Brushing past rows of sweaters and pants in all the New York colors -- black, charcoal, gray -- he stopped in the middle of the floor, at a rack he seemed to know well.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: ''This is it,'' he said, pulling a house-brand sweatpants-gray, wool-blend sweater with a zippered neck from out of the pack.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: Just then, a young saleswoman in a Morticia Addams-ish clingy black dress approached.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: ''Hi,'' she said, giving him a hug and a peck on the cheek. ''How's that sweater you bought?''
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: ''Actually, I'm thinking of exchanging it,'' Mr. Williams said, still holding the twin of the sweater he had in his shoulder bag.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: He had spent a good long time at the store the week before, mulling the virtue of this sweater. Still, he did exchange it, for a pair of gray wool baggy pants with a drawstring waist. ''These are so dope,'' he said, holding the pants against him. ''They look really comfortable, and I like that, too.''
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: Mr. Williams doesn't look as though he spends much time figuring out his wardrobe. But he does. He is, after all, an actor, well aware that he has an image to project. And lately, that has been especially important, sitting for one interview after another -- usually at his favorite hangout, the celebrity-studded Time Cafe on Lafayette Street -- to promote ''Slam,'' which opens in New York on Oct. 9.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: Already a star in New York's spoken-word scene as the 1996 winner of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe grand slam championship, Mr. Williams is on the verge, as the Hollywood types say. His performance in ''Slam'' has made him a darling of the film festival circuit and winner (with his co-star Sonja Sohn) of the Independent Feature Project's first Perry Ellis Breakthrough award.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: When ''Slam'' opens nationally, on Oct. 16, and Mr. Williams inevitably crosses the great divide between anonymity and celebrity, he plans to do it looking like what he is, both street smart and artsy. ''I do like clothes,'' he said the other day, after yet another interview at the Time Cafe.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: Runner skinny, with a lean face and longish hair that he was wearing pulled back, he looked very downtown in his black overdyed cargo pants from Canal Jeans, a vintage white cotton-blend button-down shirt that accented his narrow waist and a pair of clunky sneakerlike shoes (''They're called Campers,'' he said), which he bought in London.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: At 26, a year after getting his master's degree in acting from New York University, Mr. Williams is poised for all kinds of success. While his first feature role has received hosannas, his writing and spoken-word performances are also getting their shot in the limelight.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: He received credit as a screenwriter for helping to create his character in ''Slam,'' a sensitive type facing prison time on a petty drug charge, and for writing the poetry that he performs in the film.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: His first volume of poetry, ''Seventh Octave'' (Moore Black Press), has hit the stores, and he has recordings of his spoken-word performances on Mouth Almighty/ Mercury Records, Ninja Tunes and Rawkus Records.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: ''I was never really into slams,'' he said, of the competitive poetry readings that have hovered on the edge of both faddishness and obscurity for about a decade. ''A lot of the poetry in these performances is all about performing, and not about poetry. To me, poetry has to work on the page. I did slams because of what I thought they could do for me. Once I won the grand slam, I stopped. I had nothing else to prove.''
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: It was at a poetry performance at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe that Mr. Williams met Marc Levin, the director of ''Gang War: Bangin' in Little Rock,'' a 1993 HBO documentary. Mr. Levin, who would go on to direct ''Slam,'' had run into a friend on the street, Bonz Malone (who ended up playing a Washington jail gang leader in ''Slam''), who told him he simply had to see the young Mr. Williams perform.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: ''Slam'' was born out of weekly workshops the director conducted over a period of months with several collaborators, including Mr. Williams.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: ''There's no doubt in my mind that 'Slam' is going to be huge,'' Mr. Williams said, between bites of a veggie burger at the cafe.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: ''It's a film about the power of language,'' he said earnestly. ''People are going to see this and get blown away.''
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: In this urban fable, Mr. Williams's character, Raymond Joshua, is thrown into the District of Columbia jail after being caught by police with enough marijuana to land him a mandatory prison sentence, even though it's a first offense.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: He uses his talent for writing and performing poetry to stop a budding rumble in the jail yard in its tracks, and he is transformed by the experience. Later, he persuades an old friend who was blinded by an enemy not to retaliate. He also falls for a poet, a prison writing teacher played by Ms. Sohn, and for the growing spoken-word movement in little clubs, while out on bail.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: To hear Mr. Williams talk about it, ''Slam'' is more than a movie. ''There's a reason I named my character Raymond Joshua,'' he said. ''Joshua in the Bible marched around Jericho, and the walls came tumbling down after he marched around seven times with his trumpet. If 'Slam' plays in 700 theaters at the same time, the walls of Babylon will come tumbling down.''
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: After hearing this, it is no surprise to learn that Mr. Williams is the son of the Rev. Saul Williams, a Baptist minister in Newburgh, N.Y., and that he grew up doing raps for his father's youth rallies. ''I used to go through the dictionary looking for big words that I could use in my rapping,'' he said.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: After getting acting lessons for his 13th birthday, Mr. Williams was hooked. He majored in both acting and philosophy at Morehouse College. He also helped start a literary magazine. ''Poets are the soothsayers of the new age,'' he said solemnly.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: He still performs his poetry. Sometimes, he collaborates with his girlfriend, Marcia Jones, a painter, with whom he lives in Harlem with their daughter, Saturn, 2. During their performances, as Mr. Williams recites poetry, Ms. Jones paints. ''She's a performance painter,'' he said.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: The two have made themselves part of the downtown arts scene. On a second shopping trip through the Village to hunt for something Mr. Williams would wear for the premiere of ''Slam,'' the couple stopped at least half a dozen times to say hello to friends and acquaintances.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: They also joked with the salesman at Omari, the SoHo shoe boutique, where Mr. Williams bought a pair of blue suede, crepe-sole shoes to match a blue vintage shirt he had bought at the Antique Boutique possibly to wear to the premiere.
