(''I just hope this works with black leather pants,'' he said.)
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: Between all the interviews and greetings, Mr. Williams and Ms. Jones plan to perform at CBGB's next weekend.
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: Mr. Williams is also making the usual rounds of auditions. ''I went on an audition for what turned out to be another drug-dealer role,'' he said, shaking his head. ''I knew when I walked in that I wasn't going to take the part.''
title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: 2 Officers Back on Duty After Scuffle at Casino

text: Two of three Atlantic City police officers who were suspended this month after scuffling with a casino patron returned to active duty yesterday after a hearing determined they were not a risk to the public.
title: 2 Officers Back on Duty After Scuffle at Casino

text: The two officers, William Warner and Keith Ferguson, requested the hearing and were assigned to desk duty, the Atlantic City Police Department said. The third officer, Thomas DiLorenzo, did not request a hearing and remains suspended without pay, the police said.
title: 2 Officers Back on Duty After Scuffle at Casino

text: The police and Atlantic County prosecutors are still investigating the incident, in which Jack Hagopian Jr., 21, of Newark, Del., was arrested at the Trump Marina Resort and Casino on Aug. 22 and accused of smoking marijuana. The three officers and casino security guards struggled with Mr. Hagopian for nearly 10 minutes in a casino holding area.
title: 2 Officers Back on Duty After Scuffle at Casino

text: Officers Warner and Ferguson were present for only the last few seconds of the struggle, said Peter Bruso, a lawyer for Officer Ferguson.
title: 2 Officers Back on Duty After Scuffle at Casino

text: The police said investigators were trying to determine whether any officer had used excessive force.
title: 2 Officers Back on Duty After Scuffle at Casino

text: After five centuries of killing and pestilence that began with the Spanish conquest, only a few hundred of Baja California's indigenous people are left alive. And now they are being hunted down and killed by drug traffickers.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: The violence began two years ago when the leader of an indigenous village that resisted traffickers' efforts to take over communal lands for drug cultivation was gunned down, along with another Indian, in an ambush along a rural road.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: While some have resisted, other Indians have been seduced by the quick fortunes that can reward those who manage desert airstrips or offer other services to the drug cartels. And that has resulted in a string of killings in the Indian communities that cling to the arid hills 60 miles south of the California border.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: The violence took on horrifying new dimensions last week when two entire families of Indians from the Pai-Pai ethnic group, along with a household of neighbors, were dragged from their homes and shot to death in a driveway in Ensenada, a coastal city to which some Indians have migrated. It was Mexico's worst incident of drug-related bloodshed in memory.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: ''We're not many Pai-Pai, and this has devastated our community,'' said Armando Gonzalez, the commissioner of communal lands in Santa Catarina, waving a gnarled hand across the horizon of wooden huts and cactus that make up this desert hamlet where seven of the massacre victims were buried on Sunday. ''For us there's never been anything so calamitous.''
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: Few institutions or communities in Mexico are being spared the effects of the multibillion-dollar drug industry, and even the most remote indigenous communities are no exception.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: ''The traffickers are taking advantage of the traditional conflicts that have plagued these communities, and that is undermining the fragile sense of cohesion that exists,'' said Everardo Garduno Ruiz, a graduate student at Arizona State University who wrote a book about Baja California's indigenous communities.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: The Jesuit missionaries who explored Baja California in the 16th century estimated the native population at 50,000. The Catholic Church persecuted the Pai-Pai and speakers of four other indigenous languages, labeling their traditional healers as pagans. The Indians resisted all efforts to transform them into sedentary farmers until the 1930's, when the Government finally forced them onto communal lands. Today only about 1,000 Baja California natives are left, Mr. Garduno said.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: Until recently, tuberculosis, alcoholism and emigration were among the main causes of decline, but the disintegration quickened a decade ago when drug traffickers began to muscle in on the communities.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: San Isidoro, a Pai-Pai village 30 miles southeast of Santa Catarina, has nearly disappeared since 1987, when the Government loosened restrictions on the sale of communal properties and traffickers and their representatives began to buy the Pai-Pai's lands. Many of San Isidoro's Pai-Pai have moved into the nearby town of Valle de Trinidad.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: Nonetheless, in 1996 San Isidoro still had Marcelino Murillo Alvarez, a Pai speaker, as its community land commissioner. After the army found marijuana plantations around the village that year, Mr. Murillo told the authorities that he was willing to sign a document swearing that he and other Pai-Pai were uninvolved in the drug cultivation, Mr. Murillo's brother Federico said in an interview.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: Weeks later, on May 29, 1996, gunmen blocked Marcelino's car and shot him to death along with a passenger, Federico said.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: Four months ago, on May 18, there was a killing near Valle de Trinidad. Ramon Valenzuela, the president of the vigilance council of another, smaller group of indigenous people known as the Kiliwa, was gunned down along a farm road. A Valle de Trinidad police official, Roberto Gonzalez, said none of the murders had been solved. ''The Valle de Trinidad has turned into a valley of death,'' Federico Murillo said.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: The killings of the Indians near Trinidad have attracted renewed attention since the drug-related massacre of 18 men, women and children on Sept. 17 near Ensenada. The police said after that crime that the target had been Fermin Castro, 38, a Pai-Pai from Santa Catarina who was shot during the attack and is in a coma. He grew wealthy in the last decade, ostensibly as the owner of a rodeo production company. The police said Mr. Castro had headed a small trafficking organization.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: The Ensenada killings have also caused people in Santa Catarina to rethink their views on another spectacular killing last year. To the horror of spectators at a rodeo in May 1997 that Mr. Castro produced near Santa Catarina, a gunman on horseback galloped up to Eufemio Sandoval, the Pai-Pai Indian who worked for Mr. Castro as the rodeo announcer, shot Mr. Sandoval to death at point-blank range, rode off to a waiting jeep and escaped into the desert.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: People here originally viewed Mr. Sandoval's killing as part of a longtime family vendetta. But two people said they now believed that it had been related to Mr. Castro's narcotics activities.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: Scores of Pai-Pai attended two memorial services, one last Saturday in El Sauzal, the Ensenada suburb where the Sept. 17 massacre took place, and the other on Sunday in Santa Catarina's cemetery. There, five of the seven dead were children aged 6 to 13. But no one spoke.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: ''I guess nobody could find the words to express their feelings about this,'' said Cruz Lopez Ochurte, one villager.
title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja

text: In a new case raising friction between American and Mexican law enforcement officials, two Mexican drug enforcement agents are in jail here on kidnapping charges that appear to have been trumped up by corrupt police officers working with traffickers.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: The two Mexican agents, part of an elite anti-drug unit that works closely with United States officials, were preparing to buy a ton of marijuana from Tijuana traffickers as part of a buy-and-bust operation when they were arrested by Baja California state policemen who were summoned by one of the traffickers.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: The traffickers, a father and son, have made protection payments to the state police who came to their rescue, according to sworn testimony and Mexican and American Government documents in court files here.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: ''The whole thing smells,'' said an American official familiar with the case. Several United States officials portrayed the arrest as the latest example of how pervasive corruption frustrates attempts to work with Mexican law enforcement.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: The United States officials are particularly perplexed because several Mexican Federal Police took part alongside the state police in arresting men who are, technically, their own colleagues.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: [Mariano Herran Salvatti, who heads Mexico's Federal anti-narcotics agency, said in an interview in Mexico City on Thursday that he believed corrupt Baja state police were seeking vengeance against the two federal agents because, since their 15-member intelligence unit arrived in Tijuana in early September, it has already made several large drug seizures.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: [Baja state police, who have visited the two agents in jail, have asked them to name their undercover colleagues and commanders and to divulge the address of their undercover offices, Mr. Herran said. The state police have also threatened to kill the federal agents, he said.]
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: The commander of the Baja California state police, Alvaro Castilla Gracia, insisted that the agents must stand trial, although he acknowledged in an interview that circumstances surrounding their arrest were more consistent with an undercover drug operation than a kidnapping.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: Since the agents' arrest on Sept. 11, he said, other kidnapping complaints have been filed against them. The two incidents for which the state authorities provided dates occurred before the federal agents say they arrived in Tijuana, however.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: The two agents, Eligio Garcia Reyes, 29, and Nicolas Carrillo Jimenez, 24, were recruited about a year ago into Mexico's elite anti-narcotics force, the Special Prosecutorial Agency for Drug Crimes, known by its Spanish acronym FEADS, as part of an effort to rejuvenate Mexico's discredited drug enforcement agencies with honest young agents.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: After passing lie detector tests and other examinations of their integrity, they were trained in investigative and intelligence procedures by Drug Enforcement Administration officers at an American training center in Leesburg, Va., Mr. Garcia and American officials said.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: Back in Mexico, the two were first assigned to the state of Guadalajara, where they took part in investigations that led to the successful prosecution of Mexico's foremost methamphetamine ring, an American official said.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: This month they were transferred to Tijuana to work in a drug intelligence unit that cooperates closely with American officials, Mr. Garcia said. Several undercover informants with whom the two agents had worked in Guadalajara, including Jose Luis Rodriguez Gonzalez, also traveled to Tijuana to continue their undercover operations there, Mr. Garcia said.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: Mr. Rodriguez Gonzalez has testified in the court proceedings that once he arrived in Tijuana he met Victor Manuel Monge Gonzalez, 50, and his son, Julio Monge Ochoa, 21, in a bar. They offered to sell Mr. Rodriguez a ton of marijuana, Mr. Rodriguez has testified.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: In several face-to-face negotiations, the traffickers assured Mr. Rodriguez that their drug organization was protected by corrupt Baja California state police officers, according to Mr. Rodriguez's court testimony. One one occasion Mr. Monge boasted that in exchange for a load of marijuana, he had given a house to one of the officers, Luis Humberto Gamez Lazcano, according to the testimony.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: On Sept. 11 Mr. Rodriguez called Agent Garcia and said he was about to meet with Julio Monge at Tijuana's Terranova Hotel to test a sample of the ton of marijuana. Mr. Garcia told the informant he would meet him, informed his commanding officer, and with his fellow agent, Mr. Carrillo, traveled to the hotel.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: Almost immediately after arriving at the hotel, the two federal agents, three informants the agents said were working with them on the sting operation, and three bystanders were seized by state, federal and Tijuana municipal police, and taken to jail on kidnapping charges, according to police reports. Mr. Garcia and Mr. Rodriguez said they were beaten by the state police. The three bystanders were later released.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: The police seized six pounds of marijuana from the room in which Mr. Rodriguez was arrested, and in which Mr. Monge later testified he was being held in a kidnapping. When the police found Mr. Monge he was not bound in any way, was wearing his watch and several items of gold jewelry, and hotel records show he had made several phone calls from the hotel.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: Baja California authorities trumpeted the arrest in several front-page newspaper stories in Tijuana as a spectacular rescue of a kidnapping victim.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: The two agents, in the meantime, appear to have received little attention from their superior officers within the vast bureaucracy headed by Mexico's Federal Attorney General, although their commander did hire a lawyer for them.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: ''We can't tell how much our chiefs are trying to help us, because we haven't seen the support,'' Mr. Garcia Reyes said in a telephone interview from prison.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: According to American law enforcement documents, the Monges were convicted on drug charges in 1995 and deported to Mexico after crossing into the United States in cars loaded with marijuana.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: But the Baja state judge who is trying the kidnapping case said the drug arrest records of the supposed kidnapping victims had little bearing on the case.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: ''We're not here to rule on the conduct of the kidnapping victims, only the conduct of the accused kidnappers,'' the judge, Blanca Estela Avalos Favela, said in an interview.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: The agents' arrest comes days after United States-Mexican relations over narcotics matters were strained by two other reports of top-level corruption in Mexican law enforcement units.
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

text: ''We can't intervene -- its not our deal,'' said an American official speaking on the condition of anonymity. ''But what kind of message does this send to these guys? The first little thing they do, they're in jail.''
title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft

The two Mexican agents, part of an elite anti-drug unit that works closely with United States officials, were preparing to purchase a ton of marijuana as part of a buy-and-bust operation when they were arrested by police officers summoned by one of the traffickers. A12

text: A Rebound for Clinton, A Backlash for Congress
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton's standing with Americans has rebounded broadly in the days since the release of his videotaped testimony before a grand jury, and there are stirrings of a backlash against the Republican-controlled Congress and the House Judiciary Committee as it presses forward with an impeachment inquiry, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. The poll said 78 percent of Americans, and 65 percent of Republicans, said the tape should not have been released. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones and Mr. Clinton said they were in serious discussions on a financial settlement to end her sexual-misconduct suit. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Representative Henry J. Hyde, left, said it was he, not Speaker Newt Gingrich, who would preside over impeachment deliberations and played down suggestions that Republicans were seeking to broaden the inquiry beyond Monica S. Lewinsky. A23
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Clintons have been contacting members of Congress as they seek support and comfort during the President's predicament, White House and Congressional aides said. A23
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Lewinsky scandal has produced a sharp increase in Republican campaign contributions for the November elections, an official said. A20
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, mostly because of reductions in poverty among black and Hispanic families, the Census Bureau reported. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The death toll from Hurricane Georges rose to at least 250. The storm crossed Cuba, turned northward and took aim at southern Florida, where 750,000 people were advised to evacuate. A14

text: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE INQUIRY
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: Even as the nation watched President Clinton on videotape today, many members of Congress on both sides of the aisle had already decided that he lied under oath. Now the question, which Congress is already starting to debate, is whether that is grounds for impeachment. Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, certainly seemed to think so. In his report to Congress, he held that perjury and obstruction of justice by any citizen ''are profoundly serious matters'' and that ''when such acts are committed by the President of the United States, we believe these acts 'may constitute grounds for an impeachment.' ''
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: But the Constitution's description of an impeachable offense as treason, bribery and other ''high crimes and misdemeanors'' is subject to continual reinterpretation.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: That constitutional ambiguity has sent Congress looking through precedent, law, public opinion polls and Mr. Clinton's parsings to decide whether his attempt to cover up his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky should bring his removal from office.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: Representative Charles T. Canady, a Florida Republican, said today: ''The President cannot go before a grand jury and say things that are not true. What will happen to the rule of law if he did that?''
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: But he is only one member of the House Judiciary Committee, which is in the vanguard of impeachment deliberations. And while many members of the committee now say they are certain to recommend that the House open an impeachment inquiry, the spectrum among its 37 members shows that the ultimate decision on whether to impeach Mr. Clinton is not likely to be clear or easy.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: It may be the preponderant view in Congress that Mr. Clinton lied. But is that perjury? Not every committee member agrees. Nor do all members of the Judiciary Committee put the same weight on the President's deposition in the sexual harassment case brought by Paula Corbin Jones as on the four hours of grand jury testimony, which was broadcast today. In fact, some members of Congress are asking whether a perjury case based on Mr. Clinton's Jones deposition is one that most prosecutors would bring to court.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: Representative Lindsey O. Graham, a South Carolina Republican, draws a distinction, for example, between Mr. Clinton's testimony before the grand jury and his earlier deposition in the Jones case. The Jones civil case was ultimately dismissed.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: ''That's always bothered me,'' said Mr. Graham, a Judiciary Committee member who was once an Air Force prosecutor. ''Would I as a prosecutor spend time and money to prosecute a guy who lies in a deposition in a case that was dismissed?
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: ''My goal is to set the standard that if the average citizen engaged in like conduct they would have severe legal consequences.''
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: Representative Bill McCollum of Florida, one of Mr. Graham's Republican colleagues, does not share his qualms about the Jones deposition. ''I have no doubt in my mind, based on other cases,'' Mr. McCollum said, ''that it doesn't make any difference if the case was thrown out.''
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: Yet on the other side, Representative Jerrold Nadler, Democrat of New York, is not even certain that a prosecutor would bring a perjury case against Mr. Clinton based on the grand jury testimony.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: ''It's, 'he said, she said,' '' Mr. Nadler said. He noted that Mr. Starr had presumed that Ms. Lewinsky had been the one telling the truth when her testimony deviated from the President's. ''It's all based on Monica Lewinsky's testimony,'' he said. While Mr. Starr found that Ms. Lewinsky's testimony matched contemporaneous accounts she gave to 11 friends of her affair, Mr. Nadler said that she may have been exaggerating to all her friends.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: To sort through precedent and the Framers' intent, the Republican and Democratic staffs of the Judiciary Committee have independently given their members extensive legal research. The panel's members say they are studying the writings of legal scholars, the report on impeachment drawn up by the Judiciary Committee staff in the Watergate proceedings and other documents. But impeachment proceedings have been so infrequent that even these materials can lead to different interpretations.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: Representative Zoe Lofgren, Democrat of California, who was an aide to the House Judiciary Committee in 1974, has posted on her Web site the 1974 report on Constitutional Grounds for Presidential Impeachment. In a sign of her own thinking, she pointed her constituents toward its observations and its conclusion as ''pretty relevant today.''
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: ''Not all Presidential misconduct is sufficient to constitute grounds for an impeachment,'' that 1974 report concluded. ''Because impeachment of a President is a grave step for the nation, it is predicated only upon conduct seriously incompatible with either the constitutional form and principles of our government or the proper performance of constitutional duties of Presidential office.''
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: That might seem to suggest that evasions about illicit sex would not rise to the level of impeachment. But Mr. Canady looks elsewhere for a model: the precedent set by Congress in the impeachment and conviction of Judge Walter L. Nixon of Federal District Court in Mississippi in 1989 for perjury.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: Mr. Nixon had been criminally convicted of lying to a grand jury about his talks with a prosecutor in a marijuana-smuggling case. He had been accused of concealing his attempt to help the son of a business partner. ''He was impeached and removed from office because he committed perjury,'' Mr. Canady said, ''and the interesting thing is he committed perjury before a grand jury on matters where if he simply told the truth there would have been no legal responsibility.''
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: Should a judicial impeachment be considered relevant to a President? Federal judges are not elected but under the Constitution have lifetime tenure subject to ''good behavior'' in office. ''It's certainly the case that impeaching a judge and impeaching a President has two different standards,'' said Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts.
title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision

text: When the first babies were born to crack addicts in the mid-1980's, images of trembling infants with tubes up their noses led to fears that such children were irreversibly damaged and doomed to grow into violent misfits.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: The dire predictions failed to materialize by the early 1990's, prompting a different conclusion: that cocaine causes no lingering effects on children born to drug-addicted mothers. Instead, it was asserted, whatever problems the children had could be attributed to poverty and other environmental factors.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Now many pediatricians and other child development specialists who work with these children believe that the complex truth lies in between.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: ''We run the risk of the pendulum swinging the other way and saying, no, it's not cocaine, it's all the environment,'' said Dr. Barry M. Lester, a professor of psychiatry and pediatrics at Brown University School of Medicine. ''That would be a tremendous disservice to thousands of children out there who need special intervention.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: While the specialists disagree about the extent and duration of the damage caused to infants by cocaine, they do agree that early intervention can help reverse any damage, whether it is caused by drugs or bleak surroundings.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: ''These are not doomed children,'' said Dr. Evelyn Davis, a behavioral development pediatrician at Harlem Hospital Center.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: The studies of these children have been hindered by the mothers' often rootless lives and the scattering of children into adoptive and foster homes. But the lack of authoritative research has not stopped one state, South Carolina, from prosecuting women for using crack cocaine while pregnant.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: The issue is hardly academic for New York City, where crack cocaine remains the most common street drug, and 15,371 newborns tested positive for cocaine from 1988 to 1994, according to the City Department of Health. They accounted for 1 percent of the city's recorded births in 1994, down from a high of 2.3 percent of the births in 1988.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: The National Institute on Drug Abuse has estimated that in 1992, 45,000 women nationwide used cocaine during their pregnancies.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: ''In the last year or so, it has become clear that cocaine can affect the developing brain,'' said Dr. Alan I. Leshner, the institute's director.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Dr. Leshner said the evidence emerged after researchers who tested the effect of cocaine on laboratory animals compared notes with clinicians who examine children for medical, learning and behavioral disorders.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: The problems can be treated, Dr. Leshner said. ''We don't want to stigmatize these kids as a lost cause, but at the same time we should not ignore that some of them have serious problems that need to be addressed.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: It has been difficult to isolate crack's effect on babies exposed in the womb because mothers who use cocaine also often ingest alcohol, marijuana or even heroin. Pregnant addicts also tend not to eat properly or get prenatal care.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: ''These issues alone, without cocaine, could cause children to develop poorly,'' Dr. Lester said. ''What cocaine becomes is a form of double jeopardy.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: The picture may become clearer within a few years, after the National Institutes of Health completes a wide-ranging maternal life style study involving 1,400 children born to drug users.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: In the meantime, previous smaller studies have yielded sometimes contradictory evidence. For example, Brown University School of Medicine conducted a study in 1996 of 1- and 2-day-old babies of 57 mothers, 20 of whom smoked crack during pregnancy. The study found that the cocaine left infants tense and jittery after the sound of a rattle or bell, or, alternatively, lethargic and indifferent. But the study found no proof that cocaine in the womb inflicted hemorrhages, lesions or other physical damage to the infants' brains.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Another New York doctor, Daniel R. Neuspiel, followed 250 babies exposed to cocaine, tracking them for three to six years at North Central Bronx Hospital, before his program ran out of money. He found that the newborns were irritable, showed a quicker heartbeat and had trouble eating and sleeping, but he said these symptoms wore off after 72 hours.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: ''I really haven't observed persistent problems related to cocaine,'' said Dr. Neuspiel, now a pediatrician at Beth Israel Medical Center. ''The only consistent findings I've seen have been more in their growth -- reduced birth weight, premature labor, smaller head circumference.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Dr. Lester, who maintains a computer database of published research, drew a somewhat different conclusion. He cited a statistical summary concluding that the I. Q.'s of children exposed before birth to drugs like heroin and cocaine run an average 3.26 points lower than those of other children. The disparity is doubled, he said, in measuring the children's ability to understand and express language.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Some pediatricians who work with inner city children have noticed similar problems. From 1987 to 1996, Dr. Davis saw 530 young children at Harlem Hospital Center who were exposed to cocaine in the womb. Nearly half the children were born prematurely, a condition to which she attributed at least some of their abnormal behavior.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Dr. Davis reported that a third of the children experienced sleep disturbances, nearly two-thirds had delayed language skills and slightly more than half had delayed motor skills. One-third also suffered from hyperactivity and attention deficit disorder, and two out of five displayed behavioral disturbances. Only 12 percent of the children were still with their mothers, she said.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Cocaine does not ravage every pregnancy where it is detected, any more than alcohol does, but there is evidence that it can cause problems, said Dr. Herbert D. Kleber, an addiction psychiatrist who served in the Office of National Drug Control Policy during the Bush Administration. He is now a cocaine researcher and a professor of psychiatry at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Specialists generally agree that cocaine increases the risk of premature birth. Dr. Farrokh Shahrivar, the chairman of neonatology at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and Beth Israel Medical Center, has examined newborns after delivery for 30 years. ''The devastating effect of crack causes premature labor, separation of the placenta, higher morbidity and mortality, a low birth weight and other problems related to prematurity,'' he said.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Dr. Kleber cited numerous studies showing that cocaine distorts the sensitivity of receptors in the brain. And the immaturity of a fetus's central nervous system, he said, makes it more vulnerable to chemicals than an adult's.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: The effects are real but subtle, Dr. Kleber said. ''They could be worsened or improved by many environmental factors, but that's true of many conditions,'' he said.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: The vulnerability of such children has prompted the intervention of programs like Hale House in Harlem, which has provided a home and treatment to more than 3,000 infants exposed to illegal drugs.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: ''They certainly do manifest problems,'' said Lorraine E. Hale, a child development specialist who is president of Hale House. ''They are cranky and, as they get older, their tendency is to get quite moody.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: But Dr. Hale has also marveled at their resilience. ''We thought that the children would be a heck of a lot more damaged,'' she said. ''We were pleasantly surprised.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: At Dreitzer Women and Children's Treatment Center in East Harlem, which is run by Project Return, a drug rehabilitation network, the debate has not been lost on the mothers themselves.
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: When Glenda C., a patient at Dreitzer, was pregnant and smoking crack, she did not need a study to convince her that cocaine was bad for her baby. ''I said, God, please encamp angels around my unborn child,'' Glenda said. ''Every time I got a hit, I would throw up. It was like she was rejecting it.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Her observations about her 17-month-old daughter echo the sometimes ominous, sometimes heartening findings of the medical studies. ''They say that babies whose mothers are using crack are very sensitive and easily upset,'' she said. ''I notice that my daughter is sensitive.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: And yet, she added, ''I look at all the kids around here and most of them seem to be doing just fine.''
title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

text: Heroin use and the injection of drugs have declined sharply among young people who were arrested in Manhattan and some other urban centers, according to a survey of their drug habits.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: The survey by Dr. Bruce D. Johnson and Dr. Andrew Golub, sociological researchers who chart the drug culture of New York City's streets, was presented this weekend at a conference of policy specialists, historians and medical experts, who gathered at Yale University to review the notorious rise of heroin since it was introduced to the world 100 years ago as a cough syrup.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: The finding that more young suspected offenders, who tend to be black or Hispanic and poor, were shunning heroin surprised some conference participants, because it conflicts with reports that heroin is increasingly popular nationwide among young users who consider it glamorous.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: But Dr. Johnson, who directs a unit of the nonprofit National Development and Research Institutes in Manhattan, warned against comparing his survey with more sweeping studies like the Federal Government's annual National Household Survey on Drug Abuse. The two surveys use different methods and analyze different populations of drug users. They also vary in measuring the patterns and extent of drug use.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: The latest Federal survey released in August estimated that 171,000 Americans tried heroin for the first time in 1996, compared with 141,000 new users in 1995. They have also grown younger, the study found, with 90 percent of new initiates to heroin not yet 26 years old.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: One hypothesis advanced by Dr. Johnson and several other experts is that young people growing up in impoverished neighborhoods may be choosing not to inject or smoke heroin because they have seen too many relatives and older friends become addicted and contract the AIDS virus after shooting up.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: ''They have had a hard enough experience that they do not want to get involved with heroin,'' Dr. Johnson said. ''They do not want to get involved with injection; they do not want to get AIDS.'' But he added, ''I can't say anything about heroin use by people outside that pool of arrestees.''
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: With no such personal experience, more affluent adolescents are tempted to try heroin because its greater availability and purity make it easy to snort or smoke. The heroin chic portrayed in films, rock music and fashion also entices younger users, said Jill Jonnes, the author of ''Hep Cats, Narcs and Pipe Dreams,'' an American history of illegal drug use.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: Dr. David Nurco, a research professor at the University of Maryland Medical School, said that 40 percent of heroin users had never been arrested, and that it took an average of five years from the onset of addiction until the first arrest.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: The survey by Dr. Golub and Dr. Johnson relied on the findings of the Arrestee Drug Abuse Monitoring Program, better known by its acronym ADAM, which monitors illicit drug use by arrestees in 23 urban areas across the country.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: The program, which was previously called Drug Use Forecasting, is run by the National Institute of Justice, a research arm of the Justice Department. It collected data from 13,000 arrestees booked for criminal offenses in Manhattan from 1987 to 1997, using interviews and urine tests to verify their drug use.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: Dr. Johnson and Dr. Golub studied so-called ''birth cohorts'' of inner-city residents who share attitudes that set them apart them from other generations of drug users. Among Manhattan arrestees born in 1949, 52 percent reported injecting drugs, mainly heroin, compared with 15 percent of those born in 1965 and only 1 percent of those born in 1977. But 62 percent of the arrestees born in 1977 tested positive for marijuana, compared with 12 percent of those born in 1949.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: Dr. Johnson said his findings in Manhattan could change when the Justice Department expands its program to include New York City's four other boroughs. Heroin use by suspected offenders has also declined noticeably in Chicago, Los Angeles and Washington, among other cities.
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: Dr. David Musto, the child psychiatrist and heroin expert at Yale Medical School who organized the conference, told the participants, ''Our nation's involvement with heroin over the past century teaches us not to underestimate its attraction.''
title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan

text: We seem minutes away from an all-''Dateline'' channel, and show-business gossip is a growth industry; no wonder two of the season's most likable sitcoms are set behind the scenes of fictional quasi-news programs and take a shrewd look at television itself. The sharply written ''Sports Night'' (beginning tomorrow) and the goofy ''Brian Benben Show'' (which has its premiere tonight) have radically different styles, but share a media-savvy attitude. The freshness of their comic approaches can be measured by how far they have come from ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' still the godmother of all sitcoms that find humor in an associate producer's job.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: A comedy laced with sincerity, ''Sports Night'' is about a cable show by that name, resembling ESPN's ''Sports Center,'' but it works perfectly well for viewers who can't tell a Met from a Yankee (trust me).
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: The hosts of the fictional ''Sports Night'' are Dan (Josh Charles) and Casey (Peter Krause), who in the first episode is newly divorced and worn down by too many stories about millionaire athletes getting into bar brawls. ''I've turned into a P.R. man for punks and thugs,'' Casey says, as the show deftly brings sports into more general terrain. These actors are smooth, but so far their characters are less vivid than those of the staff around them and less bracing than the traces of cynicism in the air.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: Isaac (Robert Guillaume), their executive producer, says he's close to firing everyone because Casey's slump is hurting the show.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: ''But you won't because we're all family here and I'm just like a daughter to you,'' says Dana (Felicity Huffman), the show's brisk producer, with an acknowledgment that they have inherited the Mary Richards and Lou Grant roles.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: ''No, this is a television show here and you're very much like an employee to me,'' Isaac says. That is partly true, but it is also the kind of smoke screen Lou would have created. The entire staff protects Casey (and next week Dan) from the network suits, today's equivalent of bad guys in black hats.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: The series is acted with razorlike timing. In the first episode's funniest, snappiest scene, Dana interviews Jeremy (Joshua Malina), an endearingly insecure sports geek, for a job as a researcher.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: And the attention to crisp dialogue sets this show apart from most others. ''Sports Night'' was created by, and the first two episodes written by, Aaron Sorkin, with a swift rhythm to its language, and even a staccato echo of his play and screenplay for ''A Few God Men.''
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: Yet at times Mr. Sorkin spells out clumsily what real people would never say. ''I love producing 'Sports Night,' '' Dana tells Casey. ''I live from 11 to midnight and the rush is so huge I don't come down till 3 o'clock in the morning.''
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: In the second episode, Dan is asked to apologize on the air for saying in a magazine interview that marijuana should be legal. That leads to a speech and a slightly mawkish ending. What saves this immensely appealing series from its own preachy impulses is that we can always feel its awkwardly phrased ''rush'' of energy.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: The more lightweight ''Brian Benben Show'' is built on a common but true assumption: the Ted Baxters of the world have taken over local news, that broadest and most irresistible of television targets.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: Mr. Benben, best known as the fantasizing Martin Tupper of the HBO series ''Dream On,'' inspires sympathy here as a character named Brian Benben. He has been pushed aside as an anchor at a Los Angeles station in favor of two young, plastic airheads. ''Ken and Barbie have entered the building,'' Benben's colleagues say when they spot the new anchors. Benben is handed a fluffy human-interest segment called ''L.A. Story.''
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: In a mini-homage to the famous ''Mary Tyler Moore'' episode in which Chuckles the Clown, dressed as a peanut, is crushed to death by an elephant, we see Benben's predecessor on ''L.A. Story'' meet his end. He does a story at the zoo and is crushed to death by a lovelorn ape. His funeral is crammed with people he has covered, including Professor Kazoo and Miss Garlic. Now all that is Benben's.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: Beneath this silliness, though, Benben shares much of the sardonic attitude of Martin Tupper. The series' tone is set by his vindictive attitude toward his gloating replacement, Chad Rockwell (Charles Esten), who is evil but happens to have great hair. With its surface giddiness and sight gags and its undertone of mordant wit, ''The Brian Benben Show'' plays better than it sounds and is much sharper than CBS's lame promos for it suggest. It is not the most hyped series of the season, but could turn out to be one of the most enjoyable.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: (Channel 2 in New York)
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: Robert Borden, creator, executive producer and writer (pilot); Brian Benben, co-executive producer; Pamela Grant, producer; Mark Heyes, music. A production of Warner Brothers Television in association with CBS Productions.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: WITH: Brian Benben (Brian Benben), Susan Blommaert (Beverly Shippel), Charles Esten (Chad Rockwell), Wendell Pierce (Kevin La Rue), Luis Antonio Ramos (Billy Hernandez), Lisa Thornhill (Tabitha Berkeley) and Lisa Vidal (Julie).
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: ABC, tomorrow night at 9:30.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: (Channel 7 in New York)
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: Brian Grazer, Ron Howard, Tony Krantz, Aaron Sorkin, Rob Scheidlinger and Thomas Schlamme, series executive producers; Tim Doyle, Matt Berry and Jeff Lowell, series co-executive producers; John Amodeo, series producer; premiere written by Aaron Sorkin; premiere directed by Thomas Schlamme; premiere produced by John Amodeo. A production of Imagine Television in association with Touchstone Television.
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: WITH: Josh Charles (Dan Rydell), Peter Krause (Casey McCall), Felicity Huffman (Dana Whitaker), Robert Guillaume (Isaac Jaffee), Joshua Malina (Jeremy Goodwin) and Sabrina Lloyd (Natalie Hurley).
title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles

text: SOME schools on Long Island have new computers; others have new courses.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: The Sayville School District, in the aftermath of an ugly and frightening incident at a school dance last year, has a Breathalyzer.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: As part of a new zero-tolerance policy toward alcohol consumption, which was adopted by the school board in July, a student suspected of drinking alcohol during school or at an event sponsored by the school -- or who appears to have been drinking before showing up -- can be asked to take a Breathalyzer test.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: If the test, given by a school administrator, gives a positive result, the student will be detained and the parents or guardian of the student will be notified and asked to remove the youth from campus. In addition, the student will be referred to the principal or superintendent for further action.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: A student who refuses to take a Breathalyzer test is presumed to have consumed alcohol and the matter proceeds as if a positive test was obtained.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: Syaville officials say theirs is the only school district on Long Island with a policy that includes the use of a Breathalyzer.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: Not everyone agrees with the new policy. Barbara Bernstein, executive director of the Nassau County chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, said the policy was disturbing.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: ''This creates a law enforcement policy out of a school policy, and is overkill,'' Ms. Bernstein said. ''If a behavior is punishable, then punish the student for that behavior. And if a school official suspects a student of drinking, all he has to do is put his nose in front of the student's face and smell him. This policy escalates a situation that could be solved without such strong measures.''
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: But school officials contend that the policy was adopted only after advice from lawyers, and was intended to withstand any legal challenges.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: The Breathalyzer has yet to be used on any of the 1,000 students at Sayville High School, said John C. Murphy, the district superintendent.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: ''It is our hope that we'll never have to use the device, but that the presence of the policy will deter alcohol consumption,'' Mr. Murphy said.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: The district was moved to initiate the policy after an incident in March at a high school scholarship fund-raising dance.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: Joseph Buderman, principal of the high school, said 17 students who had been binge-drinking showed up at the dance.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: ''By the time they arrived, they were totally intoxicated,'' he said. ''Several of them were extremely sick and had to be taken to the hospital, including one student who needed I.V.''
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: All 17 were banned from school activities for the remainder of the year, including athletic teams, school clubs and theater groups, Mr. Buderman said. Nor were they permitted to attend class trips, the Junior Banquet or the Senior Prom.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: In addition, the principal said, they were required to attend counseling sessions.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: ''Some of the parents were critical of such a tough punishment for one episode,'' he said, ''but we knew we had to draw the line.''
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: The situation put into focus a problem that, while not unique to Sayville, needed to be addressed, said Mr. Murphy, the superintendent.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: ''It served as a catalyst for the community to adopt a policy that took a zero-tolerance approach to the issue of student drinking,'' he said.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: Indeed, it didn't take long to come up with a policy. In July, the Board of Education approved use of the Breathalyzer.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: Despite the school board's evident enthusiasm for the new policy, response among students has been mixed.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: ''The district had to do something,'' said Heather Dunleavy, a senior at the high school. ''The dance last March was a horrible night and this is one way to crack down on students.''
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: But another senior, Meryl Glenn, said the policy had stirred concerns among students over how school officials will reasonably determine if a student should be tested.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: Mike Atkinson, a junior, said: ''It is too subjective. The policy allows teachers and administrators to pick out whoever they choose to submit to a Breathalyzer test.''
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: According to the policy, Breathalyzer tests are supposed to be administered only the situation meets stated criteria including admitted drinking, reliable statements of others, alcohol on the breath, impairment of motor control and other outward signs of alcohol use or intoxication.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: Other students said that while the policy might deter drinking, it could encourage the use of drugs, for which there is no testing policy.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: ''If kids feel that they can't drink, they'll find a replacement,'' Miss Dunleavy said.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: Mr. Buderman dismissed such concerns. ''We don't think that marijuana will become an issue becasue it has a definite odor and easily recognizable symptoms such as dilated pupils,'' he said.
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: At any rate, he said, ''We had to start somewhere, and hopefully we'll work on other issues next.''
title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer

text: United States border inspectors searched slightly more than a million commercial trucks and railway cars entering the United States from Mexico last year. They found cocaine stashed in cargo compartments on only six occasions, said Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House director of drug control policy.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: He cites the dispiriting statistic in pressing for an overhaul of the strategy for stanching the flow of illegal drugs into the United States. Slightly more than half of the cocaine smuggled into the United States, and much of the heroin, marijuana and methamphetamines, comes through Mexico.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: General McCaffrey is proposing that interdiction operations along the 2,000-mile-long southwestern border be coordinated by a single Federal official, who would assume responsibility for all counter-drug efforts by a half-dozen Government departments and no fewer than 22 Federal agencies.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: But General McCaffrey, who holds Cabinet-level rank as the Administration's top drug-control official, is getting a cool response from other Government institutions like the Justice and Treasury departments, where spokesmen said this week only that his proposal was under review.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: Several officials who follow drug policy in Washington said that the proposal failed to spell out whom a new border drug ''czar'' would report to and who would control actual operations. Some departments and agencies fear that the proposal could infringe on their authority and their budgets. General McCaffrey presides over a Federal drug-control budget exceeding $16 billion this year, but actual allocations are proposed and controlled by the departments and agencies involved.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: General McCaffrey said in an interview that his proposal harbors no hidden agenda. He said that more efficient cooperation and superior technology were needed to interdict illegal drugs at the southwestern border and its 24 ports of entry and 39 other sanctioned crossing points.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: ''This isn't a big deal,'' General McCaffrey said. ''It's organizing 39 places so that manpower, technology and intelligence make it very risky to smuggle things that are, by weight, more valuable than gold.''
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: For the proposed border czar, General McCaffrey said he envisioned a politician, lawyer or law-enforcement professional who speaks Spanish, is highly regarded in the border community and favors close cooperation with Mexico. He did not mention any names.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: Buying more sophisticated radar, scanning and night-vision equipment, he said, would cost a fraction of the $2 billion that the Government already spends annually to combat border smuggling.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: ''I'm not talking about the Marshall Plan,'' General McCaffrey said. ''I'm talking about better organization.''
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: More than 11,000 American inspectors, agents and other officials are deployed along the border with Mexico. But their resources are strained by the cross-border traffic that has burgeoned since the North American Free Trade Agreement was carried out nearly five years ago. Such traffic amounted to 254 million crossings by people, most of them in 75 million cars, and 3.5 million trucks and railway cars entering the United States from Mexico in 1996.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: Information about border smuggling is so fragmented and incomplete, General McCaffrey said, that it leaves some drug operations running blind. ''Whether we and the traffickers end up at the same point is all too often left to luck and gritty, individual police work,'' he said in a speech in El Paso on Aug. 26. A draft summary of General McCaffrey's proposal, which has been sent to some members of Congress as well as to other Government officials, identified some specific obstacles to be overcome in fighting drug smuggling along the border:
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: *Communications systems used by different agencies are sometimes incompatible, leaving them isolated or relying on ''jerry-built solutions'' to keep in touch with law-enforcement operations working the border.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: *Agencies collecting intelligence often fail to share it with other organizations in a position to catch drug smugglers and sometimes cannot reach everyone in their own ranks in time to stop a drug shipment.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: *Efficient technology for screening vehicles for smuggled drugs without a time-consuming physical search is seriously lacking. Only three devices capable of scanning trucks for hidden compartments are deployed along the border. ''Traffickers quickly adjust to the construction of such devices and shift drugs elsewhere,'' the summary said. As a result, the report said, the number of cocaine seizures at checkpoints and traffic stops last year was less than half the number made in 1995. Cocaine seizures as a result of investigations were only one-quarter of those in 1995.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: On Wednesday, Attorney General Janet Reno picked a Federal attorney in New Mexico, John J. Kelly, as her representative for the southwest border region. Ms. Reno created the post in 1995 to coordinate the efforts of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Border Patrol, which all fall under the Justice Department.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: This arrangement does not include the Customs Service, which conducts most border inspections, and the financial crimes units of the Treasury Department, which tracks money laundering. The State Department and the Pentagon run their own anti-drug programs in Latin America. The Department of Transportation watches cross-border traffic and supervises the Coast Guard.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: Conscious of looking tough on drugs in an election year, Congress disregarded other advice from General McCaffrey.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: On Wednesday, the House of Representatives approved its version of a new Western Hemisphere Drug Elimination Act, which calls for an 80 percent cut in the flow of illicit drugs into the United States by the end of 2001 and authorized $2.6 billion that has yet to be appropriated.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: In testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the Senate Caucus on International Narcotics Control, General McCaffrey called the target of 80 percent ''completely unrealistic.'' He has set a target of a 10 percent reduction for the same period.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico

text: TWO of the cast members are small, with elaborate beards, pirate-style bandanas, enough leather to upholster a couch. One has a nose ring and a silver tooth up front. One wears jeans beneath leather pants strategically cut out to show off both his denimed bottom and his front.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Turns out they are not what they seem but drag kings, or female performers who cross-dress as men: Sharon Niesp, who's appeared in several of John Waters's films, and Maureen Fischer, better known as Mo B. (for Bodacious) Dick. Well, you don't expect Miss Manners on a John Waters set.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: This film is ''Pecker,'' filmed in Mr. Waters's hometown of Baltimore, where he has made all 13 of his movies, most famously ''Pink Flamingos,'' his 1972 cult classic. ''It's about a photographer called 'Pecker,' '' the publicity agent explained one day on the set in December. ''No,'' he went on, though no one had objected, ''it's not what you think. He used to peck at his food as a child.'' Of course.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: ''Pecker,'' which opens on Friday, is a comedy about a young fellow (Edward Furlong) who's a short-order cook in a sub shop and takes pictures all the time, of rats caught in flagrante delicto (Mr. Waters often employs rats for his films), a woman shaving her thighs on a bus, his own sweetly dysfunctional working-class family, that sort of thing. When he is ''discovered'' by a chic Manhattan art dealer (Lili Taylor) and becomes the sensation of the New York art world, Pecker's everyday Baltimore life, including his relationship with his girlfriend (Christina Ricci) who runs -- well, rules -- the local laundromat, is threatened.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Mr. Waters has earned respect by being outrageous, though his more recent films are no longer quite so tasteless -- not, shall we say, so regressed. (When I mentioned to him that someone had recently raved to me about his 1988 film ''Hairspray,'' he smiled a wry smile and said, ''I accidentally made a family movie.'') His last two films, ''Cry Baby'' and ''Serial Mom,'' were official selections at the Cannes Film Festival. His films, considered hip, do well abroad. ''Bad taste,'' he says, ''is universal.''
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: On the set, in a Baltimore bar, Mr. Furlong gives his real-life girlfriend Jackie -- she tutors the 8-year-old Lauren Hulsey, who plays Pecker's little sister -- a swift smack on the lips before heading into the movie's thrift shop, the Bargain Hut. One of the drag kings is casing out the clothes on a rack, especially a man's V-neck sweater, but falls back into character as Mr. Waters calls out ''Full Pecker!'' Mr. Furlong straightens up and swaggers a bit.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Mr. Waters, Baltimore's riposte to propriety, is 52 years old, six foot one inch tall, downtown-casually dressed, and thin, but not so thin as his moustache, which looks as if it was drawn by an eyebrow pencil. On a two-room set, he watches the actors in the next room on a black-and-white television monitor, falling into director's body English, waving his hand deprecatingly at the action when he doesn't like it. (''Keep it manly,'' he shouts at one of the drag kings in the other room; she shakes her head ''no'' at him on the monitor.) Even when he's been waving he reassures the cast: after parceling out lots of instructions, he says, ''Otherwise, everything was grand!'' During his early films, when characters were competing to be vile, he'd be yelling, ''Louder! Louder! Meaner!,'' but even then he'd be laughing.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: The people on this set are happier with their director than Harriet was with Ozzie. They say he's gentle, kind, compassionate, exacting but easy, laid back, fun, funny, a riot. To protect the little girl in the cast, he has people say ''beep'' when the script calls for foul language. The closest he gets to angry is: ''You don't have gum in that scene, do you? It drives me crazy with that gum. Oh, it's carrots?'' Then, glumly, ''I have gum paranoia now.'' The carrots are for little sis, a rabid sugar addict who has been converted to a vegetable addict. Mr. Waters is directing her on how to ''snort a radish.''
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: No one has ever seen him tense. Asked about this, he says: ''In high school I always had N's. 'Needs improvement in self-control.' I had straight N's.' '' At New York University, he was thrown out on suspicion of smoking marijuana (when he realized the campus police had been stationed by his room, he called The Daily News to tip them off) but has since been asked back to lecture twice, which he says makes his parents quite happy.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Now Mr. Waters is setting up a crowd scene. ''Just get them there, Bobby,'' he tells Robert Stevens, his director of cinematography. ''Geography, not filmmaking.'' To the actors, he says in a mocking tone, ''If one person looks at the camera, I promise you, I'll take billboards and write your name on them.'' Then as an aside, ''That's my Miranda warning.''
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: It was natural for Mr. Waters to make a film about a photographer: he is one himself and has had shows here and abroad. In July, Gavin Brown's Enterprise, a gallery in the West Village, showed Mr. Waters's pictures of the floors marked with colored tapes to indicate where the actors should stand in ''Pecker.'' His first photographs were of movie moments on the television screen; he recombined them into short sequences of images he thought were truly memorable, which sometimes meant the credits, or the countdown before them. ( ''Director's Cut,'' a book of these pictures, was published last year.)
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: To make Pecker's photographs, he hired Chuck Shacochis, who works at the Baltimore shop where Mr. Waters has his own photographs developed. He showed Mr. Shacochis pictures by Matt Mathurin, Weegee and Diane Arbus to give him an idea what he was looking for, then told him to do his own thing. To make the pictures suitably beat up, Mr. Shacochis printed them through an old piece of scratched-up glass.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Mr. Waters uses a lot of local talent. ''You go all around the country,'' he says, ''and then it's right at home, like the Wizard of Oz.'' He says the extras are better in Baltimore, which he long ago dubbed the ''Hairdo Capital of the World.'' ''These people look like real people. In Hollywood, they all look like actors who can't get jobs. They all look ludicrously handsome.'' A house was found that was just right for Pecker's family, but the owner's son was on home detention and wearing an electronic bracelet, and they had to get the parole board's permission to move everybody. Then they had trouble getting a hotel to take him.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Across from the bar, the crew remodeled an abandoned house as the Pelt Room, a lesbian strip club. When the sign went up saying ''We Take It All Off!,'' people tried to pay to get in and children were peeking through the window. In Maryland, it's illegal to have both liquor and pubic hair (at least on view) in the same establishment, so in the film the club gets closed down.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: This is a low-budget film, about $6.5 million. But Mr. Waters has more leeway than he used to have. Van Smith, his costume designer, says that in some of the early pictures, Divine's costumes were glued or stapled together; for ''Pecker,'' Todd Oldham and Comme des Garcons helped dress the New York art-world denizens. Mr. Waters once modeled for Comme des Garcons in Paris; he felt, he says, ''like Don Knotts meets 'Mahogany' '' (a reference to the designer played by Diana Ross in a movie you may have forgotten). Still, a lot of the actors wear their own things. Patricia Hearst, who plays a New York art collector, has been in three of his movies and arrived on the set with two outfits by Claude Montana.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Mr. Waters, prized by his public -- he says that when ''Pink Flamingos'' was released on video in 1997 and he made an appearance in New York, the line was three blocks long, and everyone in it was 22 years old -- is prized by actors as well. Lili Taylor says, for example, she signed on to ''Pecker'' even before reading the script.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Edward Furlong did read it, and says it's really rare to find one that makes him laugh. And besides, he'd never worked on a film that wasn't dark. (He's appeared in ''The Grass Harp,'' ''Little Odessa'' and ''American Heart.'') Christina Ricci's mother was such a John Waters fan herself that she showed her daughter some of his movies and had her read his articles at the age of 10 or 11.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: Mr. Waters has already written the script for his next film, ''Cecil B. DeMented,'' about teen-age Hollywood terrorists attacking the film industry. Mr. Waters always writes his own scripts because, he says, ''I don't want to do anything from someone else's obsessions.'' While Hollywood has endured assaults on many fronts, John Waters can be counted on to add insult -- and laughter -- to injury.
title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste

text: PICTURE audience members in their underwear. That's an old trick. Makes them less intimidating.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Fall down as you come onstage. That's an odd trick. Not recommended. But it saved the pianist Vladimir Feltsman, when he was a teen-ager back in Moscow. The veteran cellist Mstislav Rostropovich tripped him purposely to cure him of preperformance panic, Mr. Feltsman said. ''All my fright was gone. You already fell. What else could happen?''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Musicians report all manner of strategies against stage fright and its curses: icy fingers, shaky limbs, racing heart, blank mind. Teachers and psychologists offer strategies, too. In recent years, schools have started addressing anxiety in courses dealing with performance techniques or career preparation. The Juilliard School offers a class in stage fright. Medical circles are also interested.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: The attention began in the early 1980's, as people began talking more openly about health problems. In 1983, Dr. Alice G. Brandfonbrener organized what became an annual symposium in Aspen, Colo., on the medical problems of musicians, and she edits a journal on the subject. Since physical and emotional difficulties are so often linked, Dr. Brandfonbrener said, anxiety drew increasing notice.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: One cause of the attention, and the anxiety, is a tight job market. So the field of performance psychology is burgeoning, and sports psychology is attracting musicians. Don Greene, a psychologist who used to work with Olympic divers, has been working exclusively with musicians for the last five years, and has been asked to create a graduate course in ''performance enhancement'' next year at Juilliard.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: With government financing of the arts limited in the United States, not only are orchestra positions scarce, but even jazz players can't find work, said Louise Montello, a jazz pianist and psychotherapist who gives seminars in New York and abroad on coping with performance stress.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: ''People feel like they have to be the absolute best in order to get a job, and if they make one mistake in an audition, they feel they've completely failed,'' Ms. Montello said. ''It's so debilitating for a lot of musicians that they really give it up. Or they get into compulsive behaviors. A lot of them are taking drugs, and there's a lot of alcoholism.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: The prescription drugs of choice are beta blockers like Inderal; they reduce the fight-or-flight effects of adrenaline. Dr. Brandfonbrener said she had often prescribed small doses to musicians, with great success. Unlike valium, alcohol or marijuana, she said, beta blockers do not destroy judgment. Still, they are not for everyone.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Especially not the violinist Elmar Oliveira. Untroubled by stage fright, Mr. Oliveira took Inderal once on the advice of a cardiologist, to counter a rapid heartbeat. Although his performance of the Beethoven Violin Concerto went well, he said, ''I felt like I was completely detached from the fiddle.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Teachers and therapists offer wide-ranging advice, from basics like learning pieces inside out to mental disciplines: visualizing a performance, for instance, and taking steps to relax. Don't deny that you're jittery, they urge; some excitement is natural, even necessary for dynamic playing. And play publicly often, for the experience.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Diane Nichols, a psychotherapist who calms a stage-fright class in Juilliard's evening division, suggests steps for the moments before performance, if circumstances allow: ''Take two deep abdominal breaths, open up your shoulders, then smile,'' she said. ''And not one of these 'please don't kill me' smiles. Then choose three friendly faces in the audience, people you would communicate with and make music to, and make eye contact with them.'' She wants to counter notions of the audience as judge.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Mr. Greene, the sports psychologist, teaches a ''centering'' strategy that combines Eastern ideas of focusing and breathing with Western ideas of psychology. He finds his switch to music natural, he said, since athletes and musicians both perform ''complex, difficult, challenging skills under extreme pressure.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Julie Landsman, a principal horn player in the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra who teaches at Juilliard, likens auditions to Olympic trials. ''For those 10 minutes that you are given, you need to show your stuff,'' she said. ''You have to be hot from the minute you walk in the door, and keep their attention. That's a very specific skill that I, as a student at Juilliard from 1971 to 1975, was never taught. It took me 20 auditions before I figured out on my own what I had done wrong in the previous 19, so that I could win the 20th. I wasn't a better player by that time. But I learned to play the game.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Whatever they share, though, athletes and musicians differ in a key goal. ''If you tell yourself you're a winner, a great champion,'' the cellist Lynn Harrell said, ''you're going to close yourself off to some aspect of the vulnerable, soft-belly side of what music is about. There's a need to feel a great deal of confidence, but you have to be very sensitive to the inward, frightened, timid side of human nature.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Mr. Harrell suffered extreme stage fright some 30 years ago in the Cleveland Orchestra, where, with George Szell as music director, he became the principal cellist. ''Szell had a way of making people very nervous,'' he said. ''He wanted to control them, and he knew so much more than any musician I'd ever known, he was rather intimidating. In very subtle ways he helped you to develop, but at the expense of feeling this natural self-assurance.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright
