text: ''There were times when I got so nervous I was sure the audience could see my chest responding to the throbbing. It was just total panic. I came to a point where I thought, 'If I have to go through this to play music, I think I'm going to look for another job.' ''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Recovery, he said, involved developing humility -- recognizing that whatever his talent, he was fallible, and that a marred concert was not a disaster. He also worked on focus. ''When you see a film of Heifetz playing,'' he said, ''you see a concentration and ferocity of intense living-in-the-present.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Extreme demands by mentors or parents are often at the root of stage fright, says Dorothy DeLay, Juilliard's best-kwown violin teacher. She tells young teachers under her wing to pace demands so that students can always achieve them.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: It is not only young artists who suffer, of course. Vladimir Horowitz's nerves were legendary. ''The great tenor Franco Corelli, they had to push him on stage,'' the soprano Renata Scotto recalled.
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Actually, success can make things worse. ''In the beginning of your career, when you're scared to death, nobody knows who you are, and they don't have any expectations,'' the soprano June Anderson said. ''There's less to lose. Later on, when you're known, people are coming to see you, and they have certain expectations. You have a lot to lose.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: ''I never stop being nervous until I've sung my last note,'' said Ms. Anderson, who considers herself a circus performer doing ''my tightrope act without the net.'' Breathing exercises help, she finds. ''Years ago, my nerves would force my breath to go high, and I'd be breathing in a shallow way,'' she said. ''Now, even when I'm petrified, I can keep my breath down, and hopefully my lunch, too.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: The pianist Louis Lortie can't predict stage fright, he said. ''It could happen in the middle of a phrase. You have a silly thought, or you feel the instrument is not responding exactly as you'd like.'' Memory slips may result. In a Mozart concerto recently, Mr. Lortie got lost momentarily, lapsing into a theme from another concerto in the same key. ''It lasted a few seconds and I was back on track,'' he said, ''but it seemed it lasted hours.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Anxiety is heightened, Mr. Lortie said, by unrealistic expectations in the age of the CD. Before the development of splicing techniques, recordings often contained wrong notes, and it was standard for live performers to hit them, too. Not now. ''We were brought up with the idea that there shouldn't be mistakes,'' said Mr. Lortie, who is 38. ''Technical obsession was a part of the upbringing of my whole generation.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Touring pianists often play in a hall with unfamiliar acoustics and an unfamiliar keyboard. ''I try to remember from the rehearsal how the piano reacts, imagine as accurately as possible a performance of that piece and the conditions where you're going to perform,'' Mr. Lortie said. ''You feel less estranged. You're trying to put yourself in a kind of womb up there on stage.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: The soprano Barbara Bonney eases anxiety with self-suggestion techniques she learned years ago. ''For instance,'' she said, ''you say that your heart is calm and beating regularly and your breath is relaxed and deep, and that your solar plexus is relaxed and warm and your arms are warm, and you breathe gently, sort of a yoga breath. And between each of these suggestions you just say, 'I'm calm, and I feel loved and secure.' I must say I use that an awful lot.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Ms. Bonney said she is shy, troubled by the thought of ''people looking at me.'' Yet she likes lieder recitals, partly because she can see the audience and communicate with it. In opera, ''there's a void out there,'' she said. And in lieder she is in control. ''It's when you have to be what other people expect you to be -- they create this character they want you to be -- that's when I get into the most trouble.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Vivica Genaux, a mezzo-soprano who made a calm debut in ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' at the Metropolitan Opera last December on short notice, gets rehearsal fright, not stage fright, she said. ''I get really tense and stressed out in rehearsals. When everybody else is freaking out, then I'm O.K., because I've been through it so many times.''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: The soprano Harolyn Blackwell takes fright in the wings. She's O.K. once she makes her entrance, thanks, perhaps, to a little owl. It resides in her purse backstage, providing protection, along with a card representing St. Anthony, whom she described as ''the patron saint for losing things.'' Maybe he will prevent her from losing the owl as well as her clothes, which, she said, tend to fall off on stage. She dropped her hat, then her sash (twice) as Oscar in the Met's ''Ballo in Maschera'' a few years ago. And her fan flew into the orchestra pit recently as she sang ''Glitter and Be Gay'' in ''Candide.'' (The conductor fanned himself with it.)
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: Knock wood, it's not only owls that keep things under control. Renata Scotto, who won't go on stage under a ladder, wear purple or say certain words, does ''many, many, many other stupid things,'' like every other performer, she said. ''I don't believe a person who says, 'I'm not superstitious.' ''
title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright

text: The father of a 9-year-old Brooklyn girl was arrested yesterday on suspicion that he drowned his young daughter late Thursday night because she was taking too long washing herself in the bathtub, the police said.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Anthony Smith, a paroled robber who was once arrested but not convicted in the scalding of one of his sons, called the police to his Crown Heights home at 11:10 P.M., telling the operator that his daughter had stopped breathing, the police said. When officers and emergency medical technicians entered the apartment at 1226 Lincoln Place, the police said, they found Antoinette Smith's nude body resting in a tub of water, where the young girl appeared to have drowned.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Attempts to revive Miss Smith failed. She was pronounced dead at St. Mary's Hospital 20 minutes after the 911 call was received, the police said. Mr. Smith, 35, was then taken into custody. He faces a charge of second degree murder, which carries a sentence of 25 years to life in prison upon conviction, said Patrick B. Clark, a spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Law enforcement officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that no charges were expected against Mr. Smith's wife, Angela, saying it appeared she was not involved.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: According to one of the officials, Mrs. Smith, 35, had left four of her children, ranging in age from 5 to 11, at home that night when she went to visit a relative.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Apparently Mr. Smith started arguing with Antoinette shortly after she got home from school, and his anger erupted when she spent too long in the bathroom, the official said. As the other children sat in the apartment's living area, the police said, Mr. Smith drowned his young daughter and then called 911.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: ''He became unhappy with the length of time it was taking her to shampoo her hair,'' the officer said. ''So he held her head under water and drowned her.''
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Thursday's killing came after a decade of reported abuse and neglect in the family, according to Nicholas Scoppetta, Commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services. Five of Mrs. Smith's children spent time in foster care from 1988 to 1995 due to her inadequate guardianship and drug use, he said, noting that it did not appear Mr. Smith was in the home during those years. For most of that time, he was incarcerated on a robbery charge, the police said.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Mrs. Smith gained custody of all of her children following the completion of a drug treatment program in 1995. When Mr. Smith returned to the family in 1996, the couple took classes in parenting skills and received drug treatment and family counseling from Graham-Windham, a social services agency that contracts with the city, Mr. Scoppetta said. But reports of abuse continued to filter out of the home.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Mr. Scoppetta said that Mr. Smith was accused of inadequately caring for and excessively punishing one of his sons in June 1996. In February of the following year he was accused of scalding the same son, who the police say was 8 years old at the time. Both reports of abuse were substantiated by the agency, Mr. Scoppetta said.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Mr. Smith was arrested after the scalding incident, according to Mr. Clark of the District Attorney's Office. But he added that the case was not criminally prosecuted because ''the evidence was legally insufficient to sustain the filing of a criminal charge.''
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Mr. Smith remained in the home, as did the children. City officials said that they were now conducting an investigation into Antoinette's death that they hoped, among other things, would explain why the children had not been removed from the home after the 1997 scalding incident.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Mr. Smith, who is awaiting arraignment in Brooklyn Criminal Court, has a lengthy record of convictions dating back to 1992 for criminal sale of marijuana, grand larceny, fraud and robbery, according to the police.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: Thomas P. Grant, a spokesman for the State Division of Parole, said that Mr. Smith was currently on parole until May 24, 2000, for a 1990 robbery conviction. He said Mr. Smith had served six years of a 5-to-10 year sentence for the robbery -- his second in eight years -- and was paroled in May 1996. If he had been convicted under the current, stricter, sentencing guidelines, Mr. Smith would not have been eligible for parole until the middle of 1999.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: ''He'd still be in jail,'' Mr. Grant said.
title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns

text: It sounds like a typical child welfare dispute: The foster parents who have reared a 2 1/2-year-old boy almost since birth want to adopt him. The boy's mother, who lost him because of addiction but has since stopped using drugs, wants him back.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: But when the foster parents are a powerful city alderman and a prominent judge, accusations of political favoritism are bound to bubble up. And because the couple are white and the child is black, the case has also brought a small petition drive and a protest vigil led by a black minister outside the alderman's office.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: The state's effort to terminate the birth mother's parental rights, which goes to court next month, has already seen its share of legal skirmishing. With the mother's lawyers arguing that she could not get a fair hearing in Cook County because both foster parents held positions of influence here, the State Supreme Court responded by assigning the case to a judge from another county.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: State officials deny any political favoritism and say they are acting in the best interests of the child.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: ''The handling of this case is consistent with the direction that child welfare systems across the nation are moving in,'' said Maudlyne Iherjirika, a spokeswoman for the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. ''Children cannot be allowed to linger in foster care while parents are given chance after chance after chance to get their acts together.''
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: The case dates from February 1996, when Alderman Edward M. Burke, who has been on the City Council for nearly 30 years and is chairman of its Finance Committee, and his wife, Anne, an Illinois appellate judge, took in an 8-day-old foster child, whom officials call Baby T.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: The boy's mother, Tina Olison, 36, had a long pattern of cocaine, marijuana and PCP use, and her son was born with drugs in his system. Two other sons had previously been removed from her care, the first in 1989 after she had disciplined him by putting two five-pound sacks of sugar on his arms and so pinning him on his back, the second in 1994 because of her drug use.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Both of those children were placed in foster care with Ms. Olison's mother, Cecile, who decided not to take Baby T, thinking that if Ms. Olison was separated from him, she would have incentive to stop using drugs.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: The tactic apparently worked. Ms. Olison spent 18 months in drug rehabilitation programs, and state drug tests, administered to monitor her progress toward becoming a fit mother, have turned up no trace of drugs since. She also went to school, became a certified nursing assistant and now works for an agency that cares for elderly patients.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Ms. Olison, who is single, and her lawyer, Anita Rivkin-Carothers, say her turnaround entitles her to get her son back.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: ''I overcame my drug addiction,'' Ms. Olison said in an interview. ''I have my own apartment. I don't depend on any state income. I'm a member of a church. I'm reliable and responsible now, and I'm ready to be a mother to my child.''
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Initially the Department of Children and Family Services intended to reunite Baby T with his mother. But in August 1997, the agency changed its mind and recommended that the boy be placed for adoption.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: State officials say their decision was based on an evaluation of Ms. Olison by an outside agency, which concluded that ''serious deficits remain in terms of her ability to safely and adequately carry the primary responsibilities of parenting.'' The agency said Ms. Olison had reacted angrily to the evaluators, and Donald Jonker, a lawyer for the child services department, said the ''report has concluded that the mother's volatile and potentially dangerous anger would be directed at her children.''
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Ms. Olison said she had accused the evaluators of ''being racist,'' of ''being a part of the conspiracy to keep me away from my child'' and of ''being bribed by the Burkes.'' She spoke that way to the evaluators, she said, because she believed that they had already made up their minds and she was upset at the prospect of losing her child.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Ms. Olison and her supporters say they believe the real reason for the department's change of heart is that about a month before the evaluation, the Burkes began expressing interest in adopting the boy.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Judge Burke, reached at home, said that neither she nor her husband could discuss the case because it was in litigation and involved issues of confidentiality.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: ''What matters here,'' she said, ''is a little boy's life.''
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: By all accounts, the Burkes, both 54, have been dutiful, loving foster parents, caring for Baby T in the Tudor house on a leafy street on the Southwest Side of Chicago where they reared four of their own children, now grown, and briefly cared for another foster child.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: And at a time when Illinois and other states are trying hard to find permanent homes for foster children, the Burkes, a wealthy, well-educated couple willing to take a child born with medical problems, seem to some like a rare find.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Even Ms. Olison says her boy has been well cared for, although she says that Judge Burke does ''certain things that I wouldn't do'' and that the judge is unsure of certain ''cultural things,'' like how to care for his hair.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: In any case, Ms. Olison says, she is being denied a chance to rear her son, because, she maintains, the state has been unfairly swayed by the Burkes' credentials.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: In addition to her job on the bench, which entails ruling on appeals filed in Cook County, Judge Burke was appointed Gov. Jim Edgar's special counsel on child welfare in 1994, working for a year for the Department of Children and Family Services.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Her husband, a lawyer and former police officer, has been a Democratic alderman in the 14th Ward since 1969, occupying a seat once held by his father. He is a savvy political insider who sits on the Cook County Democratic committee that selects judicial candidates.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Some of Ms. Olison's supporters say they would consider Mr. Burke's adoption of the child particularly upsetting because he represents a ward with few African-Americans and was known as a vigorous opponent of Chicago's first black mayor, Harold Washington. (Mr. Burke has always said that his opposition to Mayor Washington was motivated not by race but by politics.)
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: ''Their family has a pattern of not being sensitive to the African-American community,'' said the Rev. Albert Sampson, a South Side minister who fasted for 40 days this summer and led a small protest outside the Alderman's office, pushing an empty baby carriage. Mr. Sampson accused the Burkes of trying to ''steal the child, his legacy and identity, and allow the child to live in one of the most segregated wards in the city.''
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: ''There are enough Irish Catholic children,'' Mr. Sampson said, ''for Burke to adopt his own.''
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Mainstream black political leaders here have not jumped into the fray. And under state and Federal law, race cannot be the determining factor in the placement of a child.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Patrick Murphy, the Cook County Public Guardian, who represents the interests of Baby T, said that although the Burkes might never have asked for special treatment, he believed that their prominence had led the state to bend in their favor. The outspoken Mr. Murphy has tangled with state officials before but initially recommended that Baby T be adopted. Then one of his office's own psychiatric evaluators concluded that Ms. Olison was a fit mother, and Mr. Murphy has said he now plans to change his stance and support her.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Mr. Murphy, who is white, said he believed that Ms. Olison's backers were making a mistake in raising racial issues. But he also said:
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: ''It's clear that the mom has done everything the agency asked of her. It's also clear that D.C.F.S has treated this mother differently from other mothers and that it's clearly for political reasons.''
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: The Department of Children and Family Services has tried unsuccessfully to have Mr. Murphy removed from the case, saying he has undermined his credibility by flip-flopping.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: As for his charge of politics, Ms. Iherjirika, the department's spokeswoman, said they had played no role.
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: ''There's nothing sinister here,'' she said. ''We gave this mother a chance.''
title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics

text: Gunmen dressed in black and carrying assault rifles pulled three families from their homes early this morning and shot at least 20 men, women and children against a wall in what the police described as a drug-related slaying.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: The killings, which occurred in a suburb of this city, 60 miles south of the California border, surpassed any previous drug-related violence in the border cities that are the focus of Mexico's billion-dollar narcotics industry. They approached in ferocity the massacres in southern Mexico that have accompanied a bitter Indian insurgency.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: The executions took place in the concrete driveway of a two-story stucco home on a hillside in Vista al Mar, a cluster of houses a mile from the Pacific Ocean. Soldiers from the Ensenada army garrison and Baja State judicial police officers refused to let reporters enter the walled compound this afternoon as detectives stood staring at a pool of blood in the driveway.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: Killed or wounded in the attack were Fermin Castro, 38, his wife and 2-year-old son; his brother-in-law, Francisco Flores Altamirano, 30, Mr. Flores's 52-year-old mother, his sister, his wife and five children aged 4 through 13, and a family of seven neighbors, including a pregnant teen-ager and a 1-year-old child.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: The killings came hours after Mr. Castro produced a rodeo for an Independence Day celebration near Ensenada, a relative said.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: State officials said at least 17 victims died immediately. Two women and a man were left wounded, and one of the women has since died, according to a bulletin issued by Baja California State authorities.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: Mexico's Attorney General, Jorge Madrazo, said in an interview that 19 people were killed in the attack by gunmen armed with AK-47 and 9-millimeter weapons.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: Mr. Madrazo said Fermin Castro, had been under federal investigation on suspicion of working with a top lieutenant of the drug smuggling gang run by the Arellano Felix brothers, which is based here in Baja California State.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: The Government press agency Notimex today quoted the State Attorney General, Marco Antonio de la Fuente Villarreal, as saying Mr. Castro grew marijuana for the Arellano Felix group, which has been known as one of Mexico's most violent.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: Mr. Castro's fate was not clear. The state bulletin listed him as one of 19 dead in the attack. But the same bulletin said he had been taken to an Ensenada hospital and had survived.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: A relative of Mr. Castro, who insisted she not to be identifed, said tonight that he was alive.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: She said she had received a call at 8 A.M. from her sister-in-law, who said ''there had been a shootout in my brother's house and that they had killed everybody, but they weren't sure if anybody had been left alive or who had done it or why.''
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: Asked if she was sure Mr. Castro had not been involved in illegal activities, the relative said, ''If he did things we didn't know about, he must have had it all pretty hidden.''
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: She said he was a former teacher who moved here 20 years ago from another part of the state and had a rodeo company based in Tijuana.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: Friends of Mr. Castro interviewed outside his home today said he had grown wealthy in recent years as a cattleman, and he is well known in Ensenada as an organizer of rodeo events. Eighteen horses grazed in an enclosure behind his home today.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: Armando Contreras, a contractor who said he had done construction work for Mr. Castro, said, ''I think what caused this killing was just the envy of people jealous because Fermin had so many cattle.''
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: One teen-age girl reportedly survived the attack by hiding in a closet.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: In the interview, Attorney General Madrazo said Mr. Castro was suspected of being an associate of Ismael Higuera Guerrero, a lieutenant in the Arellano Felix organization said to have become increasingly important as the brothers have been forced to operate from hiding. Mr. Higuera has been using Ensenada as a trafficking base.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: In December, when federal authorities intensified efforts to apprehend or suppress the Arellano Felix gang after several high-profile slayings were attributed to it, prosecutors sought to obtain a search warrant for Mr. Castro's property here, known as El Rancho del Rodeo, but were apparently denied the warrant by a judge.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: The Baja State bulletin said that authorities in Ensenada received a call at 5 A.M. reporting that ''it appeared that there were from 10 to 12 persons dead, that it could be caused by firearms, and that they were members of three families.''
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: ''At 5:20, on arriving at the place, we realized that at one side of the patio there were 18 bodies lying on the ground, 17 apparently dead, and one of them, of the feminine sex, still alive,'' the bulletin said. ''But once transported to the Hospital del Carmen by an ambulance, she died at 7:50 A.M.''
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: A Mexican law-enforcement official said today that one hypothesis was that the executions were related to the slaying of a major trafficker, Rafael Munoz Talavera, on Sept. 11 in Ciudad Juarez. He formed an alliance with the Arellano Felix brothers last year during a violent attempt to take control of the cartel based in Cuidad Juarez.
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: But the authorities acknowledged that they were still largely baffled by today's killings. ''What really happened there?'' one official asked out loud. ''At this point, who knows?''
title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs

text: By R. W. Apple Jr.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Larry Walden doesn't look or sound very much like a villain.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: This afternoon, he stood in his corrugated steel barn near here, just down the road from Mammoth Cave, and tried patiently to explain the economics, the emotions and the politics of growing tobacco, which he has done for a living for the last 30 years, since he was 12 years old.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Above his head, stalks of ocher-colored tobacco, drying in the late-summer breeze, hung from laths, sticks to those in the trade. The air inside was as opulently perfumed as a fine Havana cigar.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: ''We may be headed for nowhere,'' Mr. Walden said. ''I think the price supports for tobacco may be finished in a year or two, and if that happens, these little towns around here will just dry up and blow away. I don't know what I'd do, but I know there's no other crop that would bring me as much income.''
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Mr. Walden is the biggest tobacco grower, he thinks, in Barren County, which produces more tobacco than any other county in the state. But he is no tycoon, and neither are many of the other Kentucky growers, most of whom produce flavor- and nicotine-rich burley tobacco. The state, second in annual production to North Carolina, has more tobacco-dependent counties than any other, with 60,000 farmers averaging an income from tobacco of about $12,000 a year.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: A trim, bearded, laconic man in Cat hat and aviator glasses, Mr. Walden clutched a beer, encased in an insulating cylinder called a ''hugger,'' as he talked to a visitor.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: He conceded that he himself no longer smoked or chewed tobacco. His wife, he said, had told him, ''If you stop, it might help your health.'' But that, he insisted, had nothing to do with his decision to give up.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: ''I made up my own mind to quit,'' Mr. Walden said rather defensively, like a man determined to defend his picture of himself as a rugged individualist.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: For all the research projects and all the antismoking publicity in the last decade or so, he said he was still not convinced that smoking is harmful to health. His father, he said, smokes three or four packs of cigarettes a day. When his father had open heart surgery not long ago, in his 70's, the surgeon said that half his patients smoked and half did not, Mr. Walden reported.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Alice Baesler, the Kentucky Department of Agriculture's tobacco expert, said that most growers, like Mr. Walden, had grown up in the business. Families, she said, ''have existed for this for generations, with tobacco at the center of their lives, so much so that in the fall, they are drawn to the fields at harvest time, whatever and wherever their everyday jobs may be.''
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: It is undeniably a beautiful crop, with the broad leaves turning green-gold in the fields before the stalks are cut, mounted six to a stick and hung in old red barns, many of them covered with wild morning glories, with loose boards to let the air through.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: It is undeniably a profitable crop. Mrs. Baesler, whose husband, Scotty, a Democrat, represents the Lexington area in the House of Representatives, said that an acre of tobacco produced a gross income of about $4,000 in good years, while corn or soybeans produced no more than $500. ''Nothing else, except marijuana, brings in the kind of money that tobacco does in Tennessee, Kentucky and the Carolinas,'' Mr. Walden said. ''Flat nothing.''
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Mr. Baesler is running for the Senate this fall against Representative Jim Bunning, the Hall of Fame pitcher nominated by the Republicans.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Over the years, everything from green peppers to wheat has been proposed as a supplemental or replacement crop for tobacco, without much success. In July, the University of Kentucky's Center for Business and Economic Research said that cultivating and processing hemp, a cousin of marijuana that can be used in paper products and textiles, could produce $17.6 million a year in worker income, less than tobacco but a lot more than most other products. But growing hemp remains illegal.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Both Mr. and Mrs. Baesler are loudly critical of President Clinton's tobacco policies, particularly his first-term proposal to finance health-care reform with a tobacco tax. Most Kentucky politicians feel that way. Representative Ron Lewis, a Republican whose district includes Larry Walden's farm, attended a 1994 smokers' rights rally where Hillary Rodham Clinton was burned in effigy. It was an ''inappropriate'' act, he said, a ''desperate'' bid to draw attention to a righteous cause.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Mr. Walden said he resented Mr. Clinton as well as former President Ronald Reagan, whom he blamed for driving Government-supported prices down so far that only now, 18 years later, were tobacco revenues returning to their former levels.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: But his deepest scorn was reserved for the four big cigarette companies, whom he accused of profiteering and price manipulation. It is they, Mr. Walden said, ''who give the farmer a real licking, year in and year out.''
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: He will produce 175,000 pounds of tobacco this year, using Government quotas (the acreage the Government allows a farmer to use to grow tobacco and it can bought, sold or leased) for his own land as well as the quotas of other landowners who do not grow tobacco, which he leases. It is hard, manual work, from the time the seedlings are transplanted through the summer harvest and until the leaves are finally stripped from the stalks at a rotating table, after they have dried in the barns for eight weeks.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Sometimes, Mr. Walden is optimistic. He sees how much revenue tobacco produces for the Government in taxes, and how many sporting events it supports, and concludes that ''they'll never put the growers out of business.'' Other times, he thinks the game is up and wonders about expanding his dairy herd.
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: ''It never occurs to me,'' he said, ''that I'm doing anything wrong. Nobody forces people to smoke cigarettes. It's their choice.''
title: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

text: Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, who built his political career on segregation and spent a tormented retirement arguing that he was not a racist in his heart, died last night in Montgomery, Ala. He was 79 and lived in Montgomery.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace died of respiratory and cardiac arrest at 9:49 P.M., said Dana Beyerly, a spokeswoman for Jackson Hospital in Montgomery. Mr. Wallace had been in declining health since being shot in his 1972 Presidential campaign by a 21-year-old drifter named Arthur Bremer.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace, a Democrat who was a longtime champion of states' rights, dominated his own state for almost a generation. But his wish was to be remembered as a man who might have been President and whose campaigns for that office in 1968, 1972 and 1976 established political trends that have dominated American politics for the last quarter of the 20th century.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: He believed that his underdog campaigns made it possible for two other Southerners, Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton, to be taken seriously as Presidential candidates. He also argued ceaselessly that his theme of middle-class empowerment was borrowed by Richard M. Nixon in 1968 and then grabbed by another Californian, Ronald Reagan, as the spine of his triumphant populist conservatism.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: In interviews later in his life, Mr. Wallace was always less keen to talk about his other major role in Southern history. After winning his first term as Governor in 1962, he became the foil for the huge protests in which the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. destroyed segregation in public accommodations in 1963 and secured voting rights for blacks in 1965.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: As a young man, Mr. Wallace came boiling out of the sun-stricken, Rebel-haunted reaches of southeast Alabama to win the governorship on his second try. He became the only Alabamian ever sworn in for four terms as Governor, winning elections in 1962, 1970, 1974 and 1982. He retired at the end of his last term in January 1987.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: So great was his sway over Alabama that by the time he had been in office only two years, other candidates literally begged him for permission to put his slogan, ''Stand Up for Alabama,'' on their billboards. Senators John Sparkman and Lister Hill, New Deal veterans who were powers in Washington and the national Democratic Party, feared to contradict him in public when he vowed to plunge the state into unrelenting confrontation with the Federal Government over the integration of schools, buses, restrooms and public places in Alabama.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: It was a power built entirely on his promise to Alabama's white voting majority to continue the historic oppression of its disfranchised and largely impoverished black citizens. And it was snapshots of the peak moments of Mr. Wallace's campaign of racial oppression that burned him into the nation's consciousness as the Deep South's most forceful political brawler since Huey Long of Louisiana.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: First, on Jan. 14, 1963, there was his inaugural address, written by a known Ku Klux Klansman, Asa Carter. In it, Mr. Wallace promised to protect the state's ''Anglo-Saxon people'' from ''communistic amalgamation'' with blacks and ended with the line that would haunt his later efforts to enter the Democratic mainstream: ''Segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace's next signature moment came on June 11, 1963, when he mounted his ''stand in the schoolhouse door'' to block two black students, Vivian Malone and James Hood, from enrolling at the University of Alabama. Within days, it was convincingly reported that Mr. Wallace, fearing jail for defying a Federal court order, had privately promised President John F. Kennedy that he would step aside if first allowed to make a defiant speech.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace's in-state critics denounced him for a ''charade'' that embarrassed the state. But the cold splash of reality did not dampen his plans to use Alabama as a stepping stone to the national political arena and to the anti-Big-Government speeches by which he obsessively longed to be remembered by history.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace talked of running for President in 1964 as a neo-Dixiecrat candidate. But he backed off when the Republican nominee, Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, came out against the bill that later became the 1964 Civil Rights Act. Mr. Goldwater's move undercut Mr. Wallace's trademark assertion that ''there's not a dime's worth of difference'' between the two main parties on race.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: After the election, Mr. Wallace regretted his timidity because he thought Mr. Goldwater had run a campaign of comical ineptitude, and when 1968 came around, he invented a party, drafted the eccentric retired Air Force general Curtis LeMay as his running mate, and began draining away the lunch-pail vote from Mr. Nixon.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: One reason for his success was that Mr. Wallace always campaigned ''with the tense urgency of a squirrel,'' in the memorable description of one biographer, Marshall Frady. Another reason was that his message worked among disaffected whites everywhere, not just in the South.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace's political radar had picked up signals that Rust Belt workers and urban white ethnic Americans from Boston to Baltimore felt disgruntled about black students in their neighborhood schools and black competitors in the workplace. He cleaned up his language, but he used an expurgated list of demons -- liberals, Communists, the Eastern press, Federal judges, ''pointy-headed intellectuals'' -- to tap out in code words an updated version of his fire-hardened message from the Heart of Dixie. It was race and rage.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: This blend of color prejudice and economic grievance appealed to enough voters to win him more than 13 percent of the popular vote and five states in the 1968 Presidential election.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Tormented by Thorn In Flesh and Psyche
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: In the 1972 race, he was running even stronger in the Democratic Presidential primaries. He rattled the party's establishment with a second-place finish in Wisconsin and a rapid ascent in the polls. He also won primaries in Maryland and Michigan on May 16, but got the news in a hospital bed, having been shot and paralyzed on the day before the balloting.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: The injury from Mr. Bremer's bullet became a ''thorn in my flesh,'' Mr. Wallace later said, and the truncated campaign became a thorn in his psyche. He died believing that had he not been shot, popular appeal would have forced the Democratic Party to put him on the ticket in 1972 to keep Mr. Nixon from sweeping the Sun Belt and blue-collar enclaves in the Middle West and Northeast.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace ran again in 1976. From the start, aides noticed that the applause dwindled once crowds saw his shiny wheelchair. Mr. Wallace noticed it, too, and in private he disputed friends who reminded him that Franklin D. Roosevelt had won despite crutches and wheelchair.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: ''Yeah,'' Mr. Wallace told his confidant Oscar Adams, ''they elected Roosevelt, but they didn't watch him on television every night getting hauled on a plane like he was half-dead.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: The death of Mr. Wallace's Presidential dream came just before the Illinois primary, when he dropped out and endorsed a more modern Southerner with no segregationist baggage, Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace wanted to be remembered for his shining moment in 1972 and the Main Street themes he brought to prominence. Dan Carter, a professor of history at Emory University and author of the most detailed Wallace biography, ''The Politics of Rage,'' supports the claim.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: ''It is difficult to conceive of what American politics of the 1960's, 70's and 80's would be like without George Wallace,'' Mr. Carter said in a 1994 interview. ''I don't think there's a single issue that Nixon and Reagan talk of in terms of social issues that he doesn't get to first.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: In this view, Mr. Wallace's Presidential campaigns prefigured, in an especially abrasive way, a large portion of the country's politics of later years. Mr. Wallace was the first major political figure in his generation to exploit the antipathy toward Washington that went on to be a prime force in politics from coast to coast.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: He was also surely the first in his generation to galvanize the white, working-class voters later labeled as Reagan Democrats. And he was the first nationally known politician of that generation to put such raucous emphasis on race, crime, welfare and other issues that still loom large, if less crudely, on the political landscape.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: After he retired as Governor, Mr. Wallace used interviews to push relentlessly at the theme that he was the real inventor of Reaganism. Starting in 1979, he also undertook a campaign of apology and revisionist explanation intended to erase the word ''racist'' from his epitaph.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: He argued that his early devotion to segregation was based on his reading of the Constitution and the Bible and was misinterpreted as a racist hatred of black people.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: ''I made a mistake in the sense that I should have clarified my position more,'' he said in his last term as Governor. ''I was never saying anything that reflected upon black people, and I'm very sorry it was taken that way.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: That Mr. Wallace died haunted by race is appropriate to his life story -- one of Faulknerian perversity embodying the old themes of guilt and a steady, if clumsy, Snopsian aspiration.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Whetting a Taste For Underdog Politics
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: George Corley Wallace Jr. was born on Aug. 25, 1919, in Clio, Ala., a cotton town in Barbour County, where mule-drawn wagons were as common as cars on the unpaved main street. His father was the wastrel son of a beloved local doctor. His mother, Mozelle Smith Wallace, had survived abandonment by her mother and a depressing girlhood in an Episcopal orphanage at Mobile.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Like his father, George Jr. was quick with his fists and drawn to politics. Calling himself the ''Barbour Bantam,'' he won two Golden Gloves titles while in high school.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: As a 15-year-old legislative page at the Capitol in Montgomery, he stood on the gold star marking the spot where Jefferson Davis was sworn in as president of the Confederacy and where, by tradition, Alabama governors have taken the oath of office ever since. It was the seminal moment of his youth. Man and boy, George Wallace revered that spot, so much so that as Governor he ordered state troopers to encircle it so that a visitor, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, could not put a desecrating Yankee foot atop it.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: It was in 1937, on the oak-shaded Tuscaloosa campus of the University of Alabama, that George Wallace began to define what he would become politically. He arrived in the same shiny suit he had worn as a page in Montgomery, but Tuscaloosa was a congenial place for poor, ambitious country boys. And by tradition, it was a virtual boot camp for future governors and senators. Young Wallace won election as president of the freshman class.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: He never won another student office, but his campaign to beat the fraternity machine with a coalition of independents and out-of-state students whetted his permanent taste for underdog politics.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: The other leitmotifs of his Alabama career -- cronyism and betrayal -- emerged at the university. He acquired the hangers-on who staffed his later efforts, and he made an unlikely, but ill-fated friendship with Frank Johnson, a handsome law student from Winston County, a Unionist stronghold in northern Alabama that seceded from Alabama when Alabama left the Union. Mr. Johnson was a Republican, Mr. Wallace an ardent New Deal Democrat. Mr. Johnson joked about someday being a Federal judge and Mr. Wallace about being governor. But the big wheels on campus tended to dismiss Mr. Wallace's ambitions as comical.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: For in those days, too, Mr. Wallace impressed people by his frenetic energy and tireless pugnacity rather than by any inherent attractiveness. He waited tables and drove taxis and slid through law school, cramming from borrowed books. Frank Johnson's wife, Ruth, was worried by Mr. Wallace's habit of chasing innocent high school girls, although she thought him more interested in the adoration than sexual conquest. Finally in 1943, at the age of 23, he decided to marry one of his naive admirers, a 16-year-old dime store clerk named Lurleen Burns.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: It was wartime and Mrs. Wallace and their baby daughter, Bobbi Joe, born in 1944, followed wherever Mr. Wallace's flight training in the Army Air Forces took him. He shipped to the Mariana Islands as a flight engineer in the spring of 1945, assigned to fly bombing missions over Japan.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: The biographer Dan Carter found fellow crew members who remembered Mr. Wallace's barracks lectures defending segregation in Barbour County. ''I don't hate them,'' Mr. Wallace was reported to have said. ''The colored are fine in their place. But they're just like children, and it's not something that's going to change. It's written in stone.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace had been through nine combat missions by the time the war ended. He was discharged with a 10 percent disability for combat-induced ''psychoneurosis,'' diagnosed after he refused orders to fly dangerous training missions when his unit returned to California after the Japanese surrender. Years later, Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, disclosed Mr. Wallace's wartime psychiatric history. Mr. Wallace responded that unlike his liberal attacker, he could prove that he was 90 percent sane.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: After the war, Mr. Wallace began climbing up the political ladder with remarkable speed. Using his Barbour County connections, he was named an assistant to Alabama's Attorney General in 1946. The next year he won election to the Alabama Legislature. He allied himself with the racially moderate populist Gov. James E. Folsom and prevailed on Mr. Folsom to appoint him as a trustee of all-black Tuskegee Institute.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: As a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1948, Mr. Wallace refused to join the walkout by segregationist ''Dixiecrats,'' a move that placed him firmly in the progressive, racially moderate wing of a state Democratic Party that still had ''White Supremacy'' emblazoned on its ballot emblem.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: After this blooding in state and national politics, Mr. Wallace settled in as an elected district judge in his home county, serving from 1953 to 1958 and all the while laying plans to run for governor in 1958.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: It was in the preparation of that race and its aftermath that Mr. Wallace committed two betrayals -- one personal and one political -- that blemished his reputation for life, but also gave him a generationlong stranglehold on Alabama politics.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: The first came after 1958, when Mr. Wallace's surprisingly strong dark-horse candidacy failed. He had followed the tolerant racial line laid down by Governor Folsom and lost to John Patterson, whose devotion to massive resistance to court-ordered integration won him the following of the Ku Klux Klan. There were only about 5,000 Klan members, Mr. Patterson later recalled, but they helped him paper the state with campaign literature.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Later, Mr. Wallace, in a quotation whose authenticity he long disputed, was recorded as saying that no one ''will ever out out-nigger me again.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Race Issue Is Played For All It Is Worth
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Even if not literally true, the remark defined the strategy Mr. Wallace would use to ride to power. He started the very next year when his law school friend Frank Johnson, now a Federal judge with a strong civil rights record, ordered Mr. Wallace's court to surrender voter-registration records to the United States Civil Rights Commission. Mr. Wallace denounced Judge Johnson in public as a Federal dictator, but conspired secretly to avoid being jailed on Federal contempt charges by having a local grand jury surrender the records on his behalf.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Judge Johnson ruled that Mr. Wallace had used ''devious means,'' but had nonetheless obeyed the Federal court order. Never one to be embarrassed by the facts, Mr. Wallace labeled Judge Johnson a ''carpet-bagging, scalawagging liar'' who wanted to mount ''a second Sherman's March to the Sea.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace had lost a friend but gained a nickname, ''The Fighting Judge,'' that would help make him Governor in 1962 as an all-out segregationist with Klan backing. As Judge Johnson later told the Alabama writer Frank Sikora, Mr. Wallace had also established the tactical blueprint of his career: ''misleading the people of Alabama for the purpose of pursuing his political career.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace, of course, did not see it that way. He described himself as devoted to the economic development of his state and to advancing the causes of limited government and middle-class values in national politics. The reality was both uglier and more complicated.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: In his four terms as Governor, Mr. Wallace saw an era of unparalleled corruption that operated through a crony system centered on his brother Gerald, a lawyer who died in 1993. With the Governor's approval, Gerald Wallace and his close associate, Oscar Harper, went into business selling the state office supplies, printing, vending machines and building leases. Gerald Wallace and Mr. Harper established an asphalt company with $1,000 in capital. In a year and half, the infant company garnered more than a million dollars in state contracts.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: It is one of the paradoxes of Southern history that Alabama's ''Fighting Judge,'' by trying to revive the antebellum doctrine of states' rights, instead enabled the civil rights movement to reach its high-water mark. The Birmingham demonstrations in 1963 led to the passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act. Two years later the Selma march led to the passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Despite these triumphs, it was a dangerous time for blacks and whites who supported the civil rights movement. During the Wallace years, at least 10 people died in racially motivated killings in Alabama. Governor Wallace and his flamboyantly inept and drug-addled public safety director, Al Lingo, responded mainly by disrupting the Federal investigations into crimes like the bombing that killed four little girls at the 16th Street Baptist Church on Sept. 15, 1963.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Leaders of Alabama's business and educational establishment, always sensitive to the state's image, came to regard Mr. Wallace as an embarrassment.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: But George Wallace was a creature of the storm who always had wind beneath his wings, and that wind was the adoration of the white farmers and factory workers and rural courthouse bosses who counted the votes and doled out patronage.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: They loved it when Mr. Wallace waved his cigar, flooded his food with ketchup and said that the guy pumping gas at an Alabama crossroads knew more about Communism than the State Department.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: When a surprisingly strong anti-Wallace faction in the Legislature refused to alter the state Constitution to allow him a second term, Mr. Wallace put his ailing wife Lurleen on the ballot in 1966. She won easily in a heart-rending campaign that demonstrated the scope of his ambition. Only a few weeks before her husband announced her candidacy, Mrs. Wallace had surgery and radiation treatment for the aggressive intestinal cancer that would kill her in 1968.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Political writers predicted that Alabamians would punish Mr. Wallace for his cynical use of a sick woman. But he was only shifting gears. He reclaimed the governorship in 1970 with the most flagrantly racist campaign of his career, warning that his progressive opponent, Albert Brewer, was using a black ''block vote'' to install a regime of Federal oppression. With Mr. Wallace's clear approval, the Klan circulated fliers falsely accusing the clean-living Mr. Brewer and his wife and daughters of sexual perversions and miscegenation.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: It was a historic election for Alabama in two ways. First, Alabama was resisting the epochal progressive wave that swept the region in 1970 and installed New South governors like Jimmy Carter in Georgia and Reubin Askew in Florida. Secondly, Mr. Wallace was openly committing himself to the Presidential race track.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: By Mr. Wallace's reckoning, his appeal to blue-collar voters outside the South had ''shaken the eyeteeth'' of both major parties in 1968. Indeed, President Nixon so feared Mr. Wallace's disruptive potential in 1972 that he supplied $400,000 to Mr. Wallace's opponent in the 1970 campaign for governor. But Mr. Wallace won with his racist attacks and his invitation to Alabamians to ''send them a message'' by launching him toward the 1972 Presidential race.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: For a few months, Mr. Wallace was the hottest thing going. Gone were the pomaded hair and the bargain-store threads. His stylish new wife, Cornelia Ellis Snively, a niece of former Governor Folsom, decked out Mr. Wallace in modish, wide-lapel suits and taught him to use a blow dryer. Mr. Wallace talked less about race because he could afford to. His attacks on school busing let conservative whites know where he stood.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: As Mr. Wallace moved toward victory in the Florida primary, President Nixon himself made an anti-busing speech that was regarded as a tribute to Mr. Wallace's growing appeal. Mr. Wallace finished second behind Senator George McGovern in the Wisconsin primary and second to former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey in Indiana. Having established himself as a force in the Democratic Party, he was topping the polls in the primary campaigns of Maryland and Michigan.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: But on the afternoon of May 15, at an unnecessary campaign rally in Laurel, Md., Mr. Wallace overruled the Secret Service and moved into a crowd for a final round of handshaking. ''Hey, George, let me shake hands with you,'' shouted Arthur Bremer. Frustrated in an earlier ambition to kill Mr. Nixon, Mr. Bremer, had been stalking the Governor for weeks. From a range of three feet, the gunman shot Mr. Wallace three times, severing his spine and paralyzing him for life. Mr. Bremer is now in prison in Maryland, serving the 63-year sentence given him in June 1972.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Never-Ending Pain And Marital Trouble
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Although his Presidential hopes ended, Mr. Wallace won two more terms as Governor by appealing to white loyalty and catering to the thousands of new black voters. But Mr. Wallace now behaved more like a pensioner than a chief executive. The constant pain from his wound -- ''the thorn in my flesh'' -- limited his concentration and resulted in a dependence on methadone and other painkillers. He went through a messy divorce from his wife, Cornelia in 1978. Then she encountered her own problems with substance abuse.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace's hope to found a dynasty foundered when his son, George Jr., could not progress beyond minor state offices. Mr. Wallace married again to a failed country singer named Lisa Taylor. That marriage, too, generated sour publicity before they divorced in 1987.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: He is survived by his sister, Marianne Dauphin Montgomery; four children from his first marriage: his son, of Montgomery; three daughters, Lee Dye of Greenville, Ala., Bobbie Jo Parsons of Birmingham and Peggy SueKennedy of Montgomery; a brother, Jack, of Clayton, Ala.; and several grandchildren.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Mr. Wallace won his last election as Governor in 1982, but it was historical revision that occupied his last years. Starting in 1977, he began giving interviews in which he said that political philosophy rather than racism drove his career.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: In a typical interview, he said: ''The New York Times, the Eastern establishment newspapers never did understand that segregation wasn't about hate. I didn't hate anybody. I don't hate the man who shot me. When I was young, I used to swim and play with blacks all the time. You find more hate in New York, Chicago and Washington, D.C., than in all the Southern states put together.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: As part of his rehabilitation effort, Mr. Wallace sought meetings with civil rights figures like the Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Representative John Lewis, whose beating on ''Bloody Sunday'' at Selma galvanzied the voting-rights crusade. Sometimes he even managed to use the magic words ''I'm sorry.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: After Mr. Wallace left office in 1987, Alabamians continued to support him through a figurehead position at Troy State University. By the time he died, Republicans had taken over the governorship, and Mr. Wallace's main legacy, a statewide system of trade schools, junior colleges, and small four-year institutions, was regarded as a monument to educational waste and redundancy that a poor state could ill afford.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: One of his last public appearances was in the Spike Lee documentary ''Four Little Girls,'' which tells the story of the 16th Street Baptist Church bombing. In his interview, Mr. Wallace insists that his best friend was a black orderly. He keeps tugging the obviously uncomfortable orderly into the frame. In public showings, that passage usually drew laughter.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: So ended the public career that saw Mr. Wallace move from being the most feared politician of his era to a pitiable relic. It is a career whose moral arc seemed, in retrospect, utterly predictable and utterly of a piece with the Faulknerian idea of racism's ineradicable curse. At the height of his powers, George Wallace denied moral responsibility for the violence in his state. And in his Bible-haunted state, many said a terrible judgment had been visited upon him.
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: Brandt Ayers, the liberal editor of The Star newspaper in Anniston, put it this way: ''The Governor we Alabamians knew was a man of primal passion: sincere champion of the working class, cynical manipulator of their resentments, a sorcerer summoning the beast in our nature, a man of deep insecurities, tenderness, and finally, humility.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: He added, ''When he came to my office in 1974 campaigning for governor, I told him: 'George, you always claimed to stand up for the little man, but everybody knows that the real underdog is the black man. We stood up for him. You didn't. Why?' He did not answer. He just looked down at his legs for what seemed a very long time.''
title: George Wallace, Segregation Symbol, Dies at 79

text: WHEN the State Supreme Court issued a ruling this summer that students may be expelled for behavior off school grounds only if such behavior ''markedly interrupts or severely impedes the day-to-day operation of a school,'' educators said they feared it would be much tougher to keep even the most potentially violent students out of school.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: School officials insist that aggressive use of the state policy sanctioned by the Attorney General's office in the late 1980's and passed into law by the General Assembly two years ago -- and recently updated -- has allowed schools to keep gang leaders, drug dealers and violent teen-agers out of their classrooms and hallways.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: Under the policy, schools have had considerable discretion in expelling students for off-campus acts which they determined ''endangers students and staff'' at their schools.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: Now, with schools back in session barely a week, it won't take long for the educators' theory to be tested.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: Trumbull school officials were preparing last week for an expulsion hearing involving a 17-year-old convicted sex offender. He is Christopher Weiner, a football player and wrestler at Trumbull High School who was recently sentenced to three years' mandatory prison time, part of a seven-year sentence for sexually assaulting a 14-year-old female student during a 1997 party.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: The conviction is currently under appeal, and Mr. Weiner's lawyer, Frederick Paoletti Jr. of Bridgeport, is seeking a new trial. A hearing on that issue is scheduled to continue on Tuesday in Superior Court in Bridgeport. Mr. Paoletti has cited the Supreme Court ruling in arguing that his client cannot be expelled for the conviction while it is under appeal, and because the crime occurred at a party away from school.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: ''The State Supreme Court just ruled on this in August, that schools have got to prove that a student's behavior off school grounds would be seriously disruptive of the educational process in order to expel him,'' said Mr. Paoletti. ''In this case that would be pretty tough to do because my client attended school all of last year, and they're only moving to expel him now because of the court case.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: Trumbull school officials say they believe Mr. Weiner's presence in the school after being convicted of a sexual assault would represent a serious disruption to the school, which has 1,600 students, but admit they're not sure what a state hearing officer will decide in light of the higher court's recent ruling.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: ''We're going to be a test case, no doubt about that,'' said Trumbull's associate superintendent of schools, Ralph Iassogna. ''I think because of this case we're all going to find out pretty quickly what the long-term impact will be of the Supreme Court's decision.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: School administrators say they are fearful of the impact and they are scrambling to interpret the complex ruling.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: The head of the State Department of Education's office of legal and governmental affairs, Mark Stapleton, said, ''Not only will school districts be forced to be much more specific about exactly what types of behavior off school grounds will result in student expulsions, they are going to have to make sure that students are informed and understand the guidelines.'' ''The ruling is a mixed bag,'' said Mr. Stapleton. ''We are relieved the court rejected the argument that the statute is unconstitutional, but the ruling is likely to greatly limit the number of expulsions across the state.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: The state's Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, said he believes the ruling, in rejecting the argument that the law was unconstitutional, was a victory for the state.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: ''This decision is good news for local school officials because the Court has upheld their powers and discretion to expel students whose conduct is seriously disruptive of the educational process,'' said Mr. Blumenthal. ''Our goal was to insure that whatever the outcome of this particular student's case, school districts retain their authority to protect schools against misconduct that markedly impedes the educational environment, whether it occurs on or off campus.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: But some say Mr. Blumenthal is just trying to put a positive spin on what was clearly, at best, a disappointing ruling for the state.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: The lawyer who last year represented a senior at Thomaston High School, Kyle Packer (whose case led to the higher court's ruling), says his client is ecstatic with a ruling he believes sets a precedent and protects students not only in Connecticut but also across the country.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: Mr. Packer was expelled for possession of two ounces of marijuana off school grounds -- but then successfully challenged his local school board, claiming the statute was unconstitutionally vague.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: ''It was important that we challenged this statute and we are very happy the court agreed it was far too arbitrary and vague,'' said Mr. Packer's lawyer, William A. Conti of Torrington.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: ''Schools should not be allowed to expel students just because they don't like something a student did off school grounds,'' Mr. Conti said. ''The potential for abuse by school officials who may not like a particular student is far too great.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: Earlier this year a Superior Court judge reversed a lower court's decision and ruled that Connecticut's policy-turned-law allowing school districts to expel students for a wide range of off-campus behavior was ''unconstitutionally vague.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: While the Supreme Court disagreed, saying the statute wasn't unconstitutional, it did rule that the way it was applied in Mr. Packer's case did violate his constitutional rights.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: The court made it clear that in order to expel a student for behavior off school grounds, school districts are going to have to show a clear and direct connection between the behavior and its impact on the school, Mr. Conti said.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: For nearly a decade school boards in the state have been expelling students for off-campus behavior they deemed ''seriously disruptive of the educational process.'' That behavior could range from possession of drugs or gang involvement to committing violent acts, as in the Trumbull case.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: Schools' discretionary power changed when the Litchfield Superior Court Judge, Walter Picket, ruled that Mr. Packer, a 17-year-old honor student and soccer star at Thomaston High School, could return to school because his expulsion was based on a law that is unconstitutional. While the Supreme Court upheld the law's constitutionality, it did rule that the way the law was applied in the Packer case violated his constitutional rights because it failed to notify him that ''two ounces of marijuana in the trunk of his car, off school grounds (in another town), after school hours, without any tangible nexus to the operation of Thomaston High School, would subject him to expulsion,'' Chief Justice Robert J. Callahan wrote in his decision.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: In a dissenting view, Justice Francis M. McDonald wrote that ''The majority finds that possession of marijuana might not be recognized by students as conduct 'seriously disruptive of the educational process.' To the contrary, it can be said that illegal drugs are disrupting America . . . . Unfortunately, this decision serves neither the public interest in education nor students.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: The Thomaston Schools Superintendent, George Counter, agreed.
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: ''This ruling sets a dangerous precedent, especially for small towns like ours where students will now know they can act out in a variety of ways off school grounds and not be expelled,'' said Mr. Counter. ''I can't see how this ruling will help anybody, and it makes students like this a role model and hero to the other kids.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: But the chief justice addresses that in his majority opinion. ''We do not mean to pin any medals on (Mr. Packer) or condone his destructive behavior in any way,'' Mr. Callahan wrote. ''The school expulsion statute, as applied to this set of facts, however, is simply too vague to be constitutionally enforceable.''
title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling

text: HEADLINES from Iraq, the former Soviet republics and Korea are a constant reminder of U.S. and international action to curb nuclear proliferation and terrorism involving nuclear, biological and chemical weapons of mass destruction.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: The success of these efforts, experts say, depends not only on diplomacy but on the skills of scientists and technicians to safely move, store, detect and render harmless materials that make up these weapons.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: And these and other techniques and new technologies to increase international security will depend on training a new generation, said Dr. Mark Sakitt, the director of its newly created Center for International Security Studies at Brookhaven National Laboratory.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: Similar centers exist at Stanford University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But the new Brookhaven center marks a new direction for the lab, a facility for advanced scientific research where national security projects account for about $25 million of the $400 million annual budget.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: Dr. Sakitt, formerly an assistant director of planning and policy at the lab, said the center planned programs to encourage students and others with technical skills to pursue careers in national security. He said it would also involve scientists in solving technical problems.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: ''We would like to see another generation of people go into this field and not feel all our problems were solved with the end of the cold war,'' Dr. Sakitt said. ''The dragon in the forest is slain, but there are lots and lots of poisonous snakes out there and it is still a very dangerous time.''
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: The center will be part of the lab's Department of Advanced Technology, where scientists work on a number of nonproliferation programs for government and international organizations.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: These include programs to prevent theft and diversion of materials from dismantled nuclear weapons that could be reused in new weapons. They also include programs to help prepare and verify technical aspects of treaties for eliminating chemical weapons and reducing and dismantling stockpiles of nuclear weapons.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: Some of the work involves fissile materials, or materials that can be used in nuclear weapons, in former Soviet states including Russia. International concern is focused there because economic crisis has left workers in nuclear facilities unpaid for months and vulnerable to the temptations of stealing and selling these fissile materials.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: Department scientists involved in these and other programs will assist in the new center. ''We will try to compliment this very technical work with an outreach to the academic community to involve academic people in discussions about these issues,'' Dr. Sakitt said.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: He said the center would be financed by private foundations. He said a workshop next spring would expose teachers at four-year colleges to ''all the issues and technologies involved in the nonproliferation of nuclear material.''
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: ''When they go back home to their institutions they'll have been exposed to all these concepts and they'll take back materials that will be useful for teaching courses,'' said Dr. Sakitt.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: Targeted students would have training or background in engineering or physical sciences. In addition to technical training, they would also study arms control treaties.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: The center also plans programs for select groups of students in political science to acquaint them with nonproliferation technologies. ''When they go into policy areas of national security, they will then have enough understanding that they can converse with the military and scientists and not be completely ignorant of how these technologies work,'' Dr. Sakitt said.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: Such knowledge, he said, would help assure that nonproliferation treaties for chemical and biological weapons included provisions that improved verification.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: ''We have treaties or conventions banning chemical and biological weapons that are very good,'' Dr. Sakitt said. ''But the question is, how do you actually carry out verification with a very high degree of reliability? That's the challenge.''
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab
