text: Experts on international security say grave threats come from terrorist and sub-national groups like one headed by Osama Bin Laden, the Islamic fundamentalist and exiled Saudi businessman suspected by the United States in conventional-explosive attacks on American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last month that killed more than 200 people.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: With many experts predicting these groups will attempt attacks within the United States, Dr. Sakitt said the center planned a lecture series by experts describing threats from terrorism in U.S. urban areas involving nuclear, chemical or biological weapons.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: He said one area for technical innovation involved new equipment that detected materials for these weapons at ports of entry. ''It's not obvious we can detect a nuclear-type system coming over the American border,'' he said. ''There's an old joke that if you want to smuggle in nuclear weapons, put them in a bale of marijuana.''
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: Dr. Marvin Resnikoff, a physicist and a senior associate at Radioactive Waste Management Associates in Manhattan, said the lab center should offer programs tracing how the ''Atoms for Peace'' programs begun in the 1950's during the Eisenhower Administration had spread technology to other countries intended for peaceful uses of the atom, but turned, over time, back to bomb-making.
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: ''We have really come full circle here,'' said Dr. Resnikoff, who is not associated with the center. ''And there really need to be groups that are not a part of government to do these kinds of security studies.''
title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab

text: Offering new evidence that treating drug addicts works in the long term, a Government survey has reported that addicts who undergo treatment are considerably less likely to consume drugs or commit crimes to support their use, even after five years.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: Adolescents were the conspicuous exception. Their overall drug use did not drop significantly after treatment, the study said, and the number who smoked crack cocaine and abused alcohol actually rose.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: But adolescents have also been identified as the highest risk-taking age group, while adults tend to quit using drugs as they get older. The new survey confirmed that older people were more likely to curtail drug use and criminal behavior than younger ones. It also reported that women responded better to treatment than men.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: The national survey, which was released on Wednesday by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration of the Department of Health and Human Services, surveyed 1,799 people five years after their discharge from drug abuse treatment programs in 1989 and 1990. Their responses on drug use were verified using urinalysis for traces of drugs.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: Relapse often occurs after treatment, but the study found that the number of people using any illicit drug dropped by 21 percent. The number of powder cocaine users decreased by 45 percent, while the number of crack smokers decreased by just 17 percent. The number of heroin users went down by 14 percent and marijuana users by 28 percent. The number of those using alcohol declined by 14 percent.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: Addicts who were treated with methadone, a synthetic heroin blocker, showed the most significant drop. Twenty-seven percent of those surveyed stopped using heroin.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: As for criminal behavior, the study reported that 56 percent fewer addicts stole cars and 38 percent fewer committed burglaries after completing treatment. The number of prostitutes and their procurers declined by 30 percent, the study said.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the retired Army general who is the White House's director of national drug policy, called the newest study ''extremely important'' in showing that treatment was cost-effective.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: In looking at what happened to graduates of treatment programs, General McCaffrey said in a telephone interview: ''You'd expect some pretty bad results. Instead, you find that you've got a significant drop in drug-using behavior.''
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: Though Federal spending for treatment has increased 33 percent since the 1993 fiscal year, the Government continues to spend far more to interdict and seize drugs and arrest and imprison dealers and addicted felons. According to the White House's 1998 National Drug Control Strategy, drug treatment is available for barely 52 percent of the Americans who immediately need it.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: The survey released on Wednesday is formally called the Services Research Outcomes Study and was conducted by the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago. General McCaffrey is sure to cite it in his effort to persuade Congress to approve the Administration's requests for $200 million more in drug treatment financing and for another $85 million to treat addicted offenders caught in the criminal justice system. The requests, for the 1999 fiscal year, have been blocked in Congressional committee.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: ''This is a litmus test of rational drug policy,'' said General McCaffrey, who said he would join the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, in lobbying Congress for more treatment money.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: Camille Barry, the acting director of the Government's Center for Substance Abuse Treatment, said the study confirmed the long-term effectiveness of drug treatment.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: ''We know that the longer you stay in treatment the better the outcome,'' Ms. Barry said.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: Yet 58 percent of the people surveyed had undergone treatment for the first time and 44 percent had spent a month or less in a treatment programs. ''To have the results come out the way they did is very positive,'' Ms. Barry said.
title: Study Finds Treatment Aids Addicts

text: With the arrests of two cruise ship employees yesterday as their vessel docked in Manhattan, Federal law enforcement officials revealed the existence of an unusual drug ring that they said used luxury ocean liners to funnel cocaine, hashish and marijuana from New York City to the island of Bermuda.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: These officials estimated that the operation, which involved slightly more than a dozen people with code names like Fidel, 007, Ratty and Puny, accounted for 25 percent to 50 percent of the illegal drugs flowing into Bermuda in recent years.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: And they said the method of smuggling was strikingly atypical, thrusting a high-stakes, illegal activity into an atmosphere associated with pleasure and escape from the grittier side of life.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: ''You never think that while you're on vacation, you're in the midst of serious drug smuggling,'' said Jodi Avergun, an assistant United States attorney prosecuting seven of the defendants in the case. ''You think you're safe and secure on a cruise to Bermuda but, in fact, there are drug smugglers serving you lunch or making your meal.''
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: Diane T. Ingalls, a spokeswoman for the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, which was involved in the investigation, said that 8 of the 13 people arrested between March and yesterday in connection with the operation held jobs with Celebrity or Norwegian cruise lines, most of them in low-paying kitchen positions. Ms. Ingalls stressed that the cruise lines had cooperated fully in the investigation.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: The remaining five defendants coordinated drop-offs and money transfers in either New York or Jamaica, law enforcement officials said. All have been charged with conspiracy to distribute narcotics; an additional three people are still being sought by investigators, Ms. Ingalls said.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: Officials identified the mastermind of the operation as Delroy Andrews, 43, of Brooklyn. Mr. Andrews, they said, orchestrated the transport of drugs from Jamaica to New York City and then to Bermuda.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: Ms. Avergun said it was unclear whether the cruise line workers carrying drugs from New York to Bermuda and money from Bermuda back to New York had been recruited before or after they took jobs aboard the ships. But she said that ship workers in general attract less scrutiny, and go through less rigorous inspections, than tourists traveling the same route do.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: Ms. Ingalls noted a second clever rationale behind the smuggling scheme. ''You're losing a certain amount of overhead by using someone who has a legitimate means to be on the boat,'' she said.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: The operation began to come to light two years ago, when one of those involved in it was spotted with drugs by Bermudian authorities and arrested. Using information he provided, Bermudian and American authorities conducted surveillances, wiretaps and posed undercover as drug customers in Bermuda to catch others involved in the scheme.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: The couriers usually carried relatively small quantities of the drugs, sometimes tucking them inside thickly folded bedsheets and then carrying them off the ships in shopping bags during the hours or days that the vessels were docked in Bermuda, officials said.
title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says

text: AS state governments experiment with drug law reform, Connecticut is emerging as an innovator. The state was one of the first to allow needle-exchange programs, which offer intravenous drug users clean syringes in exchange for used ones. Such programs were started in Connecticut in 1988, after they were shown to be effective in slowing the spread of AIDS, said David D. Biklen, executive director of the Connecticut Law Revision Commission, which researches drug and substance-abuse issues and drug policy options, and makes recommendations to the General Assembly's public health committee.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Connecticut is beginning allowing convicted drug offenders or criminals whose crimes are the result of alcohol or drug abuse to avoid prison time on the condition they undergo frequent testing for drug or alcohol abuse. (The state is said to be the first to do so.)
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: The state is expanding its drug court system, which monitors drug offenders' efforts to rehabilitate themselves and these courts will be the arbiters of the new policy. (Drug courts are in New Haven, Bridgeport, Hartford and Waterbury.)
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: During the last session of the General Assembly a law was passed to allow emergency room personnel to screen and assess trauma patients for alcohol and substance abuse, and to refer such patients for treatment. ''The gap between the hawks and doves is closing,'' says State Representative Robert Farr, from West Hartford, who is the ranking Republican on the General Assembly's judiciary committee.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Drug policy had been polarized between those who regarded drugs as a criminal justice issue and advocated tough laws, and those who regarded drugs as a public health issue and wanted to liberalize the laws or decriminalize drugs, says Mr. Farr. The hawks thought that incarceration was the answer to the problem, the doves favored voluntary rehabilitation.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: But advocates in both camps have come to agree that it is necessary to rise above ideology, to find a solution.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Incarceration alone or voluntary rehabilitation by itself will not stop substance abuse, Mr. Farr said. About 70 percent of those arrested and incarcerated for drug offenses become repeat offenders within five years. The rate of recidivism for voluntary rehabilitation is also about 70 percent.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Mr. Farr also said the gap between hawks and doves is closing because it is becoming apparent there must be legal consequences, that substance abusers must take responsibility for their actions. When drug users are arrested, however, hawks and doves agree it is far more cost-effective to treat than to simply incarcerate.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Keeping a drug offender behind bars costs about $25,000 a year, says Mr. Farr. The testing program will mean an outlay of $3,000 a year plus probation costs, he said.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Nationwide, four out of five prisoners are behind bars because of direct or indirect involvement with drug or alcohol abuse, according to a recent study by the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: The way to fight the war on drugs is to avoid politicizing the discussion and maintaining flexibility and common sense, says State Representative Michael P. Lawlor, a Democrat of West Haven. ''It's obvious to everyone that you can't arrest or incarcerate your way out of the drug problem,'' said Mr. Lawlor, who is co-chairman of the General Assembly's judiciary committee. ''Incarcerating drug offenders has caused the state's prison population to explode from 3,600 in 1980 to over 16,000 now,'' he said.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: A 1974 state law allows doctors to write prescriptions for marijuana for a range of conditions from multiple sclerosis to lack of appetite and wasting caused by chemotherapy and by AIDS.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: But Mr. Farr argues that marijuana has become a much more potent, dangerous drug, that there are other drugs that can accomplish what it does without its harmful effects. He said he opposed the legalization of marijuana for medicinal use.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Mr. Lawlor says there is little enforcement of the marijuana laws when it comes to people who can argue that they are using marijuana for medicinal reasons.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Over the past 200 years, Americans have twice accepted and then vehemently rejected drugs, says David F. Musto, professor of psychiatry at the Yale Child Study Center and professor of the history of medicine at Yale. A century ago, he said, cocaine was touted by people like Freud much like Prozac or Viagra is regarded today as being helpful in meeting the challenges of everyday life. But with drugs like cocaine or heroin, he noted, the casualties have been high indeed. So politicians began demonizing drugs and passing harsh laws calling for long mandatory incarceration because it is politically astute to do so.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: ''Phases of intolerance,'' Mr. Musto said, ''have been fueled by such fear and anger that the record of times favorable toward drug taking has been either erased from public memory or so distorted that it becomes useless as a point of reference for drug policy formation.'' Politicians and government policy makers are unable to learn from the past, he said. American society has not made up its mind about marijuana, he said. Its use is a continuing social experiment. Although a point has been reached where everyone knows or knows of people who use marijuana, it's not clear to many people whether marijuana users are casualties of drug abuse, he said.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Overall marijuana use is declining in all age groups except for young people. But alcohol consumption is also declining for all age groups except for young people, he said. ''This is a symptom of American society's attempt to avoid risk of all sorts,'' said Mr. Musto. It is part of the same trend toward eating things believed to be healthy, trying to keep physically fit, restricting smoking and requiring people to wear seat belts.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: In California and Arizona referendums allowing for medicinal use of marijuana have been passed. But what few people realize is that the active substance in marijuana is legal for medicinal use across the country, Mr. Musto said. Dronabinol, which is sold under the brand name Marinol, is available in all states with a doctor's prescription.
title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

text: Only several days ago, the acrimony between Minnesota Vikings Coach Dennis Green and the team's new owner, Red McCombs, seemed thicker than cement. McCombs had rejected two contract proposals from Green's agent, Ray Anderson, with the latest rejection coming just last week. It increasingly looked as if Green was going to leave the Vikings at the end of the season.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Then Anderson received a shocking call from representatives of McCombs on Wednesday -- they wanted to make a deal. For the next 48 hours the two sides hammered out an agreement and now Green has what he wanted and what many around the National Football League say he deserved: a long-term contract and security.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Early yesterday, Green signed a multiyear extension that makes him one of the richest coaches in the National Football League. While exact figures were unavailable, it is believed Green will earn at least $1.5 million a year. Despite one of the best track records of any active coach, Green had been severely underpaid. He is 57-45 as Vikings coach, has made the playoffs five of the past six years, won two division titles, and last year led the Vikings over the Giants in one of the biggest playoff comebacks in history, yet his $900,000 salary made him among the 10 lowest-paid coaches.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Green is the only coach in the National Football Conference Central with a winning record against the Green Bay Packers in the 1990's, still, he was the lowest paid coach in the division. Green's huge salary bump is yet another indication that coaches are becoming more powerful. Kansas City Coach Marty Schottenheimer, who made less than $400,000 as coach of the Cleveland Browns in 1988, now makes more than $2 million a year.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Coaches have become more powerful because they are required to do more as free agency has led to players moving from team to team in conveyor-belt like fashion. For a team to have cohesion, a good coach must make that talent gel. Most teams recognize this. Denver Broncos Coach Mike Shanahan recently signed the richest head coaching contract in N.F.L. history; a deal that will pay him more than $2.4 million a season. According to coaching salary information obtained from various sources, Shanahan is among a growing number of coaches who will make at least $2 million a year.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Others include Bill Parcells of the Jets ($2.4 million a season), Mike Ditka of New Orleans ($2 million), and Jimmy Johnson of Miami ($2 million).
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: In addition to receiving bonuses for getting to a playoff or Super Bowl, coaches have lucrative deals for local television and radio shows. Wannstedt and Bill Cowher of Pittsburgh each receive $250,000 a year for media rights and expenses; Johnson $300,000.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: When Rod Woodson of the Baltimore Ravens violated the league's substance abuse policy by refusing to take a second drug test, it set off an intense debate between officials with the N.F.L. and the players association.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Last month Woodson passed a routine drug test for illegal substances such as cocaine and marijuana. Then, as part of the league's program of random testing for performance enhancing drugs like steroids or androstenedione, Woodson was again requested to give a sample of his urine. According to several team executives, Woodson was upset that he had already given a sample only one day earlier. Even though Woodson eventually did give the second sample, his initial refusal counts as a positive test.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Thus, Woodson, who team executives said has never tested positive for any illegal or banned substances, is in Stage 1 of the league's substance abuse policy. It calls for an evaluation by a psychiatrist, as well as an increase in random drug testing.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: The league and union are in negotiations about what to do. The union believes that since Woodson, a future Hall of Famer who is a member of the league's 75th anniversary team, eventually took the second test, he should be given a break. The league thinks that if it bends the rules for Woodson, it would set a bad precedent for other players.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Giants General Manager Ernie Accorsi has quietly made two key moves in recent months that show why he has been such a highly regarded executive.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: First, he drafted U.C.L.A. defensive back Shaun Williams. At the time, the pick was questioned because the Giants already had a number of players at the position, but Accorsi now looks like a genius because cornerback Jason Sehorn is lost for the season and Williams gives them depth at Sehorn's position.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: Second, Accorsi is following the practice of his predecessor, George Young, by continuing to lock up young players to long term contracts. Last week both quarterback Danny Kanell and young tackle Scott Gragg agreed to long-term contract extensions.
title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid

text: In the final months of the Hole, anarchy was everywhere. The Hole, the most oppressive section of Chicago's notorious Robert Taylor Homes housing project, was coming down.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Gang members shot at a moving van outside one of the Hole's three high-rise buildings. Moving crews tried to hurry out each day before drug dealers commandeered the elevators.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Lenzie Jones packed his grandchildren's clothes for the movers but did not know what to do with their mother's belongings. She had fled a few days before, after the drug gang she hawked heroin for accused her of stealing and beat her with a baseball bat and a two-by-four.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Angela Smith frantically swatted cockroaches and attacked stains in her kitchen. An inspector from the building she wanted to move into was coming to scrutinize her housekeeping. If she failed, she would lose the apartment she had set her heart on.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Katie Sistrunk, who at 45 had reared 13 children in the Hole, had no idea where she would go, days before her building was to be emptied. Juanita Williams, 74, was so paralyzed over leaving her apartment of 25 years that she stayed after the water and gas were shut off, until police officers removed her.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: On a scale not seen in decades, the Federal Government is helping cities clear slums again, but this time they are slums it helped create: public housing projects crippled by flawed policies and mismanagement and overwhelmed by poverty and crime.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: From Hartford and Newark to Denver and San Francisco, 100,000 apartments in the nation's worst public housing projects are being razed under a Federal program called Hope VI. The plan is to replace them with smaller developments that mix families of different incomes, while moving thousands of tenants into privately owned buildings.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In Chicago, where high-rise housing projects are corrosive landmarks of poverty and racial segregation, the demolition will be nothing less than seismic: the city wants to raze 11,000 apartments, nearly 40 percent of its public housing for families, over the next 15 years.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: And in a city whose housing projects contain 11 of the nation's 15 poorest census tracts, and where buildings in five large projects are being demolished, nowhere is the challenge greater than at Robert Taylor, the nation's largest housing project, much of which is ''considered the worst slum area in the United States'' according to its landlord, the Chicago Housing Authority.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: The Hole, at the project's southern end, was the first section to go, demolished in July. But the authority wants to tear down all of the project's 28 high-rises, all 4,321 apartments.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: The challenge is not just for the 11,000 people who will leave Robert Taylor, a population 99 percent black, so poor that nearly half of the adults live on less than $5,000 a year, and so isolated that many are unfamiliar with life beyond the grim monoliths that shadow the Dan Ryan Expressway on the South Side for nearly two miles.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: It is a test for Chicago as housing officials try to eliminate a ghetto by placing most of Robert Taylor's tenants in private apartments. The goal is to disperse the project's concentrated poverty without introducing or aggravating social problems in the new neighborhoods. Success will require communities to accept as neighbors people they have long been happy to have out of sight. But already a pattern is emerging of tenants from housing projects being moved mainly to poor black neighborhoods, some as rundown and unsafe as the high-rises they left.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Ninety-six percent of Robert Taylor adult residents are unemployed and little may change if they are simply moved. So a second goal of Hope VI is to ease tenants off Government dependence. In Robert Taylor, the housing authority is spending $1.5 million of its initial $25 million Hope VI grant on social services, trying to place as many residents as possible in high school equivalency courses, training programs and jobs.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Some tenants need more basic help: clothes to wear to interviews with prospective landlords, help arranging electric and gas service, classes on such housekeeping skills as cleaning carpets and operating garbage disposals.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: The distance between Robert Taylor and the outside world is not lost on the tenants. ''Goddamn public aid penitentiary,'' Esther Jones, 41, said in June as she left the project after 12 years.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Other complications in relocating residents reflect the conditions at Robert Taylor.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Residents who needed temporary housing could not move for weeks because they were identified with the Mickey Cobras, the gang that controlled the Hole, while the apartments available were in a Robert Taylor building controlled by a rival gang, the Black Gangster Disciples.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Some tenants had criminal records, drug problems or erratic rent-paying habits that had been tolerated at Robert Taylor but could disqualify them for new housing.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Citywide, housing officials are trying to help tenants get the support they need, without stigmatizing them. They are also trying not to arouse community opposition to the newcomers. ''I don't really need a not-in-my-backyard backlash right now,'' said Wanda White, the housing authority official supervising the relocation.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Difficult Move To Private Sector
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Angela Smith, 23, hauled out of her apartment anything broken or filthy: ice cube trays, baby shoes, a radio. She asked friends who were smoking marijuana to leave. The housekeeping inspector was coming.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''I got nowhere for people to sit,'' she fretted. She threw out her cockroach-infested couch and chairs a year ago. She and her children shared one bed and sat on milk crates and the hood of a large hair dryer. But roaches persisted. They crawled over her newborn son.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Like most people in the Hole, Ms. Smith was desperate to leave, but not for another housing authority apartment. Virtually all of the Hole's residents wanted Federal rent subsidies known as Section 8 certificates, which would allow them to rent their own housing.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Nationally, Hope VI wants Section 8 and the private market to replace 60 percent of the destroyed units, though some advocates for the poor worry that will worsen already severe shortages of housing and leave tenants with undesirable places to live. New York has largely ignored Hope VI because demand for its public housing is so high.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Robert Taylor is unusual because no new public housing will be built on the cleared site. Instead, smaller mixed-income developments and an industrial area are planned. Some public housing is planned nearby.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: The demand for Section 8 housing makes relocating tenants harder. The housing authority's success in finding enough landlords willing to accept them in enough communities to avoid reconcentrating them has been limited since it began moving tenants from other housing projects in 1995.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: According to an analysis by The Chicago Reporter, a monthly magazine that focuses on racial issues, the great majority of Section 8 placements have been in poor black neighborhoods on the South and West Sides.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Already some Robert Taylor tenants have had to move twice because of disputes with landlords or perilous conditions.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Aldermen have begun calling to say that their constituents are concerned about Section 8 tenants moving in, Ms. White said.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: To find apartments for the Hole's tenants, the housing authority contracted with a private relocation agency in February. The agency's job included taking tenants to see apartments and helping with things like applications, credit checks and arranging utilities.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: But tenants must satisfy landlords' expectations for cleanliness and conduct, and the housing authority expected the agency to be a hand holder: coaching tenants on how to dress for interviews, or making sure they were prepared for housekeeping inspections.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Ms. White said that after several months she replaced the agency for showing homes in too few neighborhoods and for not giving tenants enough help.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: The agency's president, Pam Gecan, said her staff had expected the authority to give that help to difficult tenants. She said gunfire in the Hole sometimes made her workers afraid to visit clients. It was the tenants, she said, who tended to request certain neighborhoods, because they were familiar.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Billy Kimmons, for example, a 23-year-old former gang member who now works as a school patrol officer, was rejected by several landlords and finally moved near a church he attended in a poor minority neighborhood on the far South Side. Ms. Smith chose Woodlawn, a struggling neighborhood near Robert Taylor, because her grandmother lived there.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Ms. Smith was a typical Robert Taylor tenant, a young single mother. She said she left her mother's home at 17 because of problems with her stepfather, living on her own at Robert Taylor since. She had three children, Nathaniel, 5, Keosha, 3, and Shamari, 4 months. Her younger sister, Aderonke Akanni, who said she left home at 13 after her stepfather abused her, also lived with her.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Life in the Hole was chaotic. Ms. Smith said the father of her children beat her. She struggled on welfare, falling behind on her $44 monthly rent. She did not permit her children to play outside the apartment because gang violence made even hallways dangerous.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''It's scary,'' she said. ''They shoot just to shoot.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Despite the turbulence, Ms. Smith and her sister were driven to improve their lives. Ms. Smith, petite and spirited, is studying for a high school equivalency diploma and plans to study nursing. Ms. Akanni, 18, works at a Lady Footlocker store and takes classes toward her equivalency diploma.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Applying for a Section 8 apartment, Ms. Smith was organized and efficient. She quickly assembled birth certificates, Social Security cards and her son's report card to prove he attended school.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: But the housekeeping inspector for her new landlord was unimpressed. Ms. Smith said he complained about writing on the walls, lack of furniture and her friends -- who had moved their marijuana smoking to the hallway. Just weeks before her building was to be emptied, she failed the inspection.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Crestfallen and angry, she had to search for an apartment again, while living with her mother. Finally, in July, she got one.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''Weren't nobody smoking weed in my house,'' she said about failing the inspection. ''And nobody going to be fixing up this raggedy place when you're fixing to move. They know this is the projects, right?''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Public Housing Becomes Hell Hole
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: The Robert Taylor Homes, named for Chicago's first black housing authority chairman, was among the last housing projects built in the city. Begun in 1959, it completed a four-mile corridor of public housing along State Street. While its new high-rises were welcome replacements for a shantytown, they quickly became the nation's largest government-sponsored ghetto.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Housing projects in Chicago are starkly identified with race and poverty. From the beginning, city officials used them, along with the expressways being built at the same time, to contain the city's growing population of poor blacks. Of Chicago's 67,000 public housing families, 97 percent are black.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In 1969, six years after completion of the last buildings, the three that became known as the Hole, Congress changed public housing policy with disastrous results for projects nationally. Instead of a fixed rent, tenants would pay a percentage of their income.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: At Robert Taylor, working families moved out as their rent rose while neighbors on welfare paid almost nothing. Housing officials, wary of discrimination suits, stopped screening tenants. Single mothers as young as 16 were given apartments.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: As the project filled with impoverished people, rent income fell and maintenance had to be cut. Tenants threw things off exterior gangways that linked apartments, so they were covered with steel grating, like a prison. Leaks and broken windows went unfixed. Elevators and hallways reeked of urine.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In Chicago's projects, ''everything that could have gone wrong went wrong,'' said Joseph Shuldiner, the executive director of the housing authority, who was brought in to fix an agency so inept the Federal Government took it over in 1995.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''Once you get a population that is beginning to create problems, then you have trouble attracting people,'' he said. ''The managers said, 'They're not letting me screen -- the heck with it.' Then your maintenance stinks. It just becomes a steamroller effect.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In a housing project with 20,000 residents at its peak but few men, gangs got an early hold. Violence and drugs devastated generations. As families moved out, vacant apartments became havens for drug dealers. Gangs ripped out metal detectors installed at entranceways and cut the wires of intercoms intended to screen visitors.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In the Hole, clusters of drug dealers brazenly hawked heroin and cocaine, forming gantlets in the entranceways. The wind whipped crack vials like shrapnel.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: The police were frustrated by gang lookouts and the ability of dealers to vanish into high-rise hideouts. Dealers became so cocky that recently a gang member waved a roll of money at a group of housing officials and offered to buy the Hole for $1 million.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''I guess that's why they call it the Hole,'' said Deborah Mardis, a resident for 20 years. ''You fall in and you never get out.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Ms. Mardis managed to leave in 1994, but her son Dequan, a gang member, kept returning. In January, visiting a girlfriend at a rival gang's building, he was shot six times. He survived.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: After a shooting the next day, parents kept children home from the elementary school across a parking lot from the Hole, then formed patrols to escort them to class.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In February, a man was killed crossing from the Hole to Disciple territory. In March, postal workers did not deliver mail for a day because of shooting. One April weekend, a man was killed and another wounded. In June, a 9-year-old was shot. In August, a police officer investigating drug dealing was critically wounded. A 16-year-old and two 17-year-olds were charged.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''A long time ago, I decided that to survive here, you had to be crazy, chemically saturated, Christian, or some kind of character,'' said a woman called Cat Lady, a squatter in the Hole who rescued cats trapped in vacant apartments. ''If we could gather the children, I'd do that.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Mary Bee Christian handed her sons vanilla cones she had bought from an ice cream truck and made a beeline for the bedroom with what she had bought for herself: $5 worth of crack and $20 of heroin. Using a lottery ticket to scoop the heroin and a tube from a light fixture as a crack pipe, Ms. Christian snorted and smoked her speedball.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: When Willie, 7, shouted that the boys had finished eating, Ms. Christian replied, ''Then watch some cartoons.'' When her lighter ran out of fluid, she told Willie and his brother, Jhonell, 6, to go to their room, so they would not see her light her crack pipe at the kitchen stove.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Her father, Lenzie Jones, at 61 stooped and leather-faced, watched helplessly. ''Oh, Mary,'' he said, ''Do you have to do that now?''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: One of the toughest questions facing housing officials is how to deal with intensely troubled families. Their problems could not only cripple their adjustment to a new home but could also harm their new neighborhoods.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''You have to make it better for the people you are relocating,'' said Ms. White, the housing authority official, ''but you also have to make it better for the people who will be their neighbors.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Robert Taylor has two devoted and savvy relocation specialists to work with families. In early 1997, they began untangling complications for the nearly 300 families in the Hole. Now they are doing the same in the next two buildings scheduled to come down.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Making repeated visits, sometimes working nights and weekends, they sort out who is on each lease -- and therefore entitled to new housing -- tell tenants of problems such as unpaid rent, and explain their options: Section 8 subsidies, another housing project, or ''scattered site'' apartments, which are managed by the authority but are not in a project. They also arrange moves, pay security deposits and visit families in their new homes.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: But the authority's relocation workers face many of the same problems as the private agencies. Tenants miss appointments, waffle on housing choices, misunderstand instructions. Because few have telephones, it is difficult even to check on them.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Once families move, visiting them can take two months, because of the staff's workload.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: When the relocation specialists encounter problems like drug abuse and child neglect, they refer them to the housing authority's social services department, which arranges for help from government agencies.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Responses are slow, said Ms. White, who is making improvements intended to insure families' problems are monitored closely.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Another challenge is determining if some families are so troubled that they should be turned out of public housing entirely.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Under a Federal court order in the 1970's and 1980's, Chicago moved 7,100 families out of segregated public housing and into rent-subsidized apartments. Central to the highly praised program was intensive counseling for families and its ability to screen out troubled people.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: That kind of screening is much harder when entire buildings are being emptied. ''That was a huge criticism, that we have people not being compassionate and it's just the get-them-out syndrome,'' Ms. White said. ''On the flip side, you have the fear that we're just transferring problems.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In the Hole, Mr. Jones and his daughter presented one of the toughest situations. As a result, they were among the last people to leave their building, and then they moved only to temporary housing with about 25 other families with difficulties.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Trying to protect Mr. Jones and his grandchildren from his drug-addicted daughter, housing officials split them up in April. They knew that in March Ms. Christian's boyfriend hit Mr. Jones with a crowbar to make him give up the children's welfare money.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Mr. Jones was given an apartment in another Robert Taylor building for himself and the children. Ms. Christian was supposed to stay away.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Housing officials could have tried to evict Ms. Christian from the project because of her drug use. But one of the relocation specialists, Brenda Hunter, who grew up in Robert Taylor, said she knew Ms. Christian would then impose on her father, so instead she was given an apartment of her own -- rent-free, because she had no legal income.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: But Ms. Christian's apartment was in the same building as her father's, and she began staying with her father and children, planning to rent or lend her apartment.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Like so many other tenants, Mr. Jones wanted a private apartment, so Ms. Hunter and her partner, Sonya Franklin, arranged an interview with CHAC Inc., the agency hired by the housing authority to see that tenants qualify financially for rent subsidies. On a late April day, he dressed up in a white hat with a yellow feather from a church giveaway, but the interview did not go well.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Since the apartment in the Hole had been leased in his daughter's name, he was told, the Section 8 program could not help him until the housing authority added his name to the lease. And because his daughter owed $250 in back rent, no one living there could get a rent subsidy until the debt was paid.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''This is the Government,'' the interviewer, Patrice Halliburton, said apologetically. ''You can't bend the rules.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Mr. Jones wilted, bewildered by the red tape. He went back to his temporary apartment, where later that day his daughter came in with the ice cream for her boys and the drugs.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: A well-meaning but overwhelmed man who had spent most of his life in housing projects, working at jobs like spray painting barrels, Mr. Jones had trouble asking for help. He had no phone. When a gang war broke out in June, even Ms. Hunter and Ms. Franklin were afraid to visit.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Once, Mr. Jones fetched the police to stop Ms. Christian and her boyfriend from stealing his furniture, clothes and the children's food. The next day, he armed himself with a meat cleaver when they tried to return.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Having lost what she called her ''advertising job,'' shouting out to drug buyers ''Hurricane'' and ''Chaos,'' the names of heroin, Ms. Christian turned to prostitution.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Ms. Christian blames herself for ravaging her family and sometimes she resolves to stop using the drugs. In June, she checked into a short-term detoxification program, then came home and read stories to her son. At other times she said, ''All I know is to go out there and do my hustle and get myself some wake-up so I can function.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: By late July, the family owed nearly $500 in rent and Mr. Jones's welfare payments had been cut in half because he had missed an appointment with a caseworker.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In early August, housing officials met with each of the temporarily relocated families, most of whom were behind on rent. At least four were told they would be evicted, Ms. Hunter said. No family will be permanently moved until back rent is paid.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Ms. Hunter said Mr. Jones had told her he was going to try to pay his rent so that she could begin trying to get him a Section 8 subsidy. The rent has not been paid, but Ms. Hunter said she was not giving up.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''We definitely don't want him to get left behind,'' she said.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Katie Sistrunk was packing, getting ready to move any day. Then, in January, the letter came.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: The private agency screening people for the apartment she wanted had rejected her. The letter cited ''many problems with this family,'' including ''gang affiliation'' and ''poor rent-paying habits.'' It said two of her teen-agers had quit school ''to pursue a career in crime, i.e. robbing and stalking innocent people.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Much of the letter was wrong. In part, it confused Ms. Sistrunk with a sister arrested on drug charges. It was just the first hitch in her effort to maneuver her large and complicated family through the housing bureaucracy and out of the Robert Taylor Homes.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: With gravelly voice, Ms. Sistrunk is a passionate advocate for herself, 13 children, 28 grandchildren and dozens more relatives. Her family is so identified with the Hole that one son, 27-year-old Henry, wears a tattoo of the three high-rises.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: But the Sistrunks also illustrate the complexities of many families in Robert Taylor. One family may have members who have succeeded against bleak odds and members whose criminal behavior could result in eviction under public housing rules, or could prevent them from getting private housing.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Over 27 years in the Hole, the Sistrunks made undeniable strides. They relied little on welfare, living mostly on income from Ms. Sistrunk's former husband. Amid squalor, the children ironed their jeans and T-shirts. Three children have attended college. One, on a basketball scholarship, expects to graduate with an architecture degree. But five of Ms. Sistrunk's grown children have criminal records, some involving weapons or drugs, court documents show.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''They've got tons of problems,'' Brenda Hunter, the relocation specialist, said, ''but they got a lot going for them, they do.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Ms. Hunter does not volunteer sensitive information like arrests to prospective landlords. And she tried to get the private agency that rejected Ms. Sistrunk to reconsider.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''Our approach is toughness combined with natural mercy and humanity,'' said Joseph Shuldiner, the authority's executive director. ''We have to be realistic.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: In moving, Ms. Sistrunk wanted dignity and choices for her family.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: She lobbied housing officials until six of her grown children got rent-subsidized apartments. Then her 24-year-old son, Joe, was charged with cocaine possession and her two youngest children, ages 16 and 17, were charged with interfering with the police during the arrest.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Charges against the teen-agers were dropped, but Joe was in jail the day he was to sign his lease. The family sent his girlfriend to sign for him.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: For herself and her two youngest children, Ms. Sistrunk wanted one of the housing authority's new scattered-site apartments. She rejected one. Twice, she accepted apartments but was told they had been taken. She phoned high housing officials. Two days before her building was to be emptied, she rounded up other tenants and threatened not to leave.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''They tell me about one thing, then they switch it,'' she thundered.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Finally, Wanda White, while on vacation, guaranteed Ms. Sistrunk a place that she wanted so she would not have to move to temporary quarters. Aware of the Sistrunks' complicated history, Ms. White decided they had great potential to succeed.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''You have to have some flexibility to look at people individually,'' Ms. White said.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Ms. Sistrunk moved out in June carrying an urn with the ashes of her former husband, who died in March, salt for good luck, and her daughter's prom glass, a proud symbol of her high school graduation.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: She passed a drug dealer yelling ''Bubble on State,'' code that the police were nearby.
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: ''I am so sick of that 'Bubble on State,' '' she whispered. ''What they should have did is torn it down many years ago and saved a lot of mothers' sons.''
title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

text: Victoria Louise Shaw, a daughter of Marijane Shaw and Donald H. Shaw, both of Manhattan, is to be married this afternoon to James Gerard Williamson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Williamson of North Babylon, N.Y. Bishop Catherine S. Roskam, the Episcopal Suffragan of New York, is to perform the ceremony at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn.
title: Ms. Shaw, Mr. Williamson

text: The bride is the head of the European decorative arts department at Christie's East, the auction house in Manhattan. She graduated from Connecticut College. Her father is a partner in Shaw & Markstein, a Manhattan law firm. Her mother is a certified financial planner in Manhattan. The bride is also a stepdaughter of Carol Henning Shaw.
title: Ms. Shaw, Mr. Williamson

text: The bridegroom is a sound engineer at WNYC, the public radio station in Manhattan, and is a recording engineer for concerts and films. He graduated from the Institute for Audio Research in Manhattan. His mother, Nora Williamson, is a clerk at the North Babylon Public Library.
title: Ms. Shaw, Mr. Williamson

text: Don't let rudolph giuliani fool you: methadone works. Since its introduction in the mid-1960's, studies have consistently shown that the synthetic narcotic cuts addicts' craving for heroin, enabling onetime street junkies to restart their lives. In so doing, methadone helps boost employment, inhibit the spread of H.I.V. and cut crime. That's why the New York City Mayor's recent attacks -- he denounced methadone as a chemical that's used to enslave people and promised to abolish it from the city over the next few years -- have left experts scratching their heads.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: The Mayor appears driven by a moral conviction that complete abstinence from drugs is the only acceptable course. Yet if Giuliani were truly interested in promoting abstinence from drugs, he would have not simply condemned methadone but also announced a major expansion of treatment programs whose express goal is to wean addicts from the substance. (The city has virtually no such programs now.) He would also have announced the creation of more residential programs that seek to change addicts' behavior. The Mayor's failure to do any of this raises the suspicion that it is not just methadone he dislikes -- but drug treatment in general.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: In this respect, Giuliani reflects a national mood. For nearly 20 years, the United States has waged a relentless war on drugs, with treatment discounted as a weak weapon. Instead, the Government has sent spy planes swooshing over the Caribbean, built a paramilitary base in Peru, mounted coca-eradication programs in Bolivia -- and invaded Panama. On the home front, narcotics agents have infiltrated hundreds of drug gangs and busted countless drug dealers. In 1996, more than 1.5 million people were arrested for drug offenses; the nation's prisons, which in 1980 housed fewer than 30,000 drug offenders, today harbor nearly 300,000.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: But this punitive approach has failed. Cocaine is cheaper than ever, and heroin is selling at purity levels three times greater than those of the mid-1980's. And drug abuse remains rampant. In 1996, the number of cocaine-related visits to hospital emergency rooms topped 144,000, an all-time high. This despite an increase in the Federal antidrug budget from $1 billion in 1981 to $16 billion in 1998.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Looking at numbers like these, it may seem as if the nation's drug problem is all but intractable. But it isn't. Our penchant for punishment has blinded us to the most effective strategy for combating drug use: offering comprehensive treatment to every addict who requests it.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Unfortunately, the case for expanding our commitment to treatment programs frequently gets drowned out by more extreme voices. Law-and-order types like Giuliani call for ever more police dragnets and undercover investigations. On the opposing side, reformers push for drastic measures like drug legalization. Legalize drugs, they say, and the vast criminal networks that traffic in them will disappear -- much like the repeal of Prohibition led to the demise of speak-easies and bathtub gin. The end of Prohibition, however, also led to a sharp rise in alcohol use. Between 1934 and 1944, per capita consumption in the United States rose from 0.97 gallons to 2.07 gallons. (Today it is 2.25 gallons.) If illicit drugs were suddenly legalized, might not consumption similarly rise?
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: By now, the risks of legalization have become so evident that many onetime advocates have flocked to a new standard: harm reduction. Drugs, it is argued, are here to stay, and society needs to learn how to live with them. Our goal should be to reduce the harm that drugs cause. To that end, they advocate a variety of reforms, like expanding needle-exchange programs and creating safe injection rooms as alternatives to shooting galleries.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Some of these ideas clearly make sense. Needle-exchange programs, for one, have been shown to reduce the transmission of H.I.V. Yet harm reduction has serious limitations. For the most part, it does not seek to get people off drugs but merely to help them use drugs more safely. To express disapproval of addiction would, in the harm reductionists' view, reinforce society's intolerance of drug addicts. While promoting tolerance is admirable, the harm reductionists take it too far: if you should not stigmatize addicts, neither should you condone addiction. And with its learn-to-live-with-drugs approach, harm reduction offers no guidance on how to bring down the appallingly high levels of drug addiction in this country.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Harm reduction does, at least, acknowledge one key fact: helping chronic users should be the target of drug policy. Washington doesn't understand this. From recent actions in the nation's capital -- like Congress's decision to earmark $1 billion for antidrug advertising aimed at teen-agers -- you might logically conclude that the threat drugs pose to the nation consists mainly of adolescent use. In fact, teen-age drug use, while up some in recent years, remains well below the peak levels of the late 1970's. What's more, most of that increase consists of marijuana use. And while pot is not harmless, and young people should be discouraged from using it, it is not the problem heroin and cocaine are.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: In contrast to teen-age pot smokers, adults who regularly use heroin, cocaine and crack do pose problems: they commit muggings, abuse children, suffer overdoses and spread disease. In all, there are an estimated 3.6 million hard-core users in the United States. While these addicts constitute only 20 percent of all drug users in the country (most of the rest being casual, occasional users), they consume about three-fourths of all the cocaine and heroin used here.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Who are these problem users? Contrary to the many media accounts of strung-out stockbrokers and models, addicts tend to be found not in posh condominiums or suburban split-levels but in the housing projects of urban America. Heavy users are disproportionately poor, unemployed and members of minority groups. No headway can be made in alleviating the nation's drug problem without finding a way to get such users off drugs.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: A good place to begin is suggested by a 1994 RAND study. The researchers C. Peter Rydell and Susan Everingham set out to compare the effectiveness of four types of drug-control programs: source-country efforts (attacking drug production abroad), interdiction (seizing drugs in transit to the U.S.), domestic law enforcement (arresting and incarcerating sellers and buyers) and drug treatment. How much additional money, they asked, would the Government have to spend on each approach to reduce national cocaine consumption by 1 percent? Rydell and Everingham developed a model of the national cocaine market, then fed into it more than 70 variables, from seizure data to survey responses.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: They were amazed at the results. Relying solely on domestic law enforcement, the Government would have to spend an additional $246 million to reduce U.S. cocaine consumption by 1 percent. Relying on interdiction, it would have to spend $366 million, and on source-country programs, a whopping $783 million. Relying solely on drug treatment, however, the Government would have to spend just $34 million more. In other words, treatment was 7 times more cost effective than domestic law enforcement, 10 times more effective than interdiction and 23 times more effective than attacking drugs at their source.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Such results contradict the conventional wisdom that treatment does not work. Many Americans know of someone who entered a program and did well while in it, only to relapse afterward. Nevertheless, failed treatments do not cost very much and so do not dilute the cost-effectiveness of treatment overall. More important, study after study has demonstrated the efficacy of treatment.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: In one recent analysis, the Government tracked the performance of 4,400 clients who entered treatment between July 1993 and October 1995. Those clients were interviewed at the time they began treatment, at the time they finished and a year later; the accuracy of their responses was checked by random drug tests. Seeking to study the most severe cases, the researchers concentrated on programs serving people in public housing, on welfare and in the criminal-justice system. The number of clients saying they used crack dropped from 39.5 percent prior to treatment to 17.8 percent a year later; for heroin, the number went from 23.6 percent to 12.6 percent. All told, drug consumption decreased by roughly 50 percent.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Well, skeptics will say, treatment might be effective for addicts who receive it, but how many really want it? Junkies, it's commonly believed, simply do not want help. And to an extent, that's true. Drugs not only impart intense pleasure but also provide great comfort to people coping with various crises in their lives. Yet for many, the point eventually comes when the drugs themselves begin to cause problems, from physical ailments to family quarrels to legal troubles. And when that happens, addicts are often open to help. That openness, however, is usually quite fleeting, and unless it is exploited immediately, most will end up back on the streets.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Alas, help is rarely available immediately. Consider the situation in New York State. An estimated 1.6 million residents have a drug or alcohol problem serious enough to require treatment. In any given year, roughly 25 percent of that number, or 400,000, will seek help. To serve them, the state has 121,000 publicly funded slots. With those slots turning over throughout the year, the state can accommodate nearly 300,000 people annually. That leaves more than 100,000 people a year unable to get help.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Scarcity is just the start of the problem. In the world of New York health care, drug treatment is the Balkans: a chaotic realm full of internal strife and rivalries. Each treatment program features a different regimen and serves distinct populations. Not every program is right for every individual. Yet the city has no central place where addicts can go to apply for admission. There is not even a registry listing openings. If a Holiday Inn is full, it will at least call the Ramada down the street to see if it has a vacancy; not so two treatment programs. As for addicts who do enter the system, there's no one to monitor their progress and make sure they stay on course.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Fortunately, there exists a remedy to such problems: central intake units, places where addicts can go to get immediate attention. Appearing here, addicts would meet with the first available counselor to discuss the nature of their problem and the best way to address it. After deciding on the proper therapy -- a detox, a methadone program, a residential facility -- the counselor would consult a computerized directory of openings. Once a specific program was selected and the client accepted for admission, central intake would arrange transportation and assign an escort. If a program didn't work out, central intake could arrange an alternative. While such units might seem to constitute yet another layer of bureaucracy, their coordinating role would actually help reduce red tape.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: In addition, central intake could dispatch outreach teams into drug markets to recruit addicts into treatment. Approaching users on the street, such workers would inform them of the services available and encourage them to visit central intake. If these teams worked in the early morning hours, when many addicts are coming down from their drugs, they could significantly boost the number of people entering the system.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Of course, recruiting addicts into treatment will accomplish little if there is nowhere to put them. And sadly, the treatment shortages present in New York are common throughout the country. According to the U.S. Office of National Drug Control Policy, fully half of the nation's hard-core users -- 1.7 million people -- cannot get help due to the lack of slots. (Methadone is in particularly short supply, with just 115,000 of the 800,000 chronic heroin users receiving it. In New York City, only 35,000 out of 200,000 users do.)
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: During the 1992 Presidential campaign, Bill Clinton promised to rectify this. In a Clinton-Gore Administration, Federal assistance will help communities dramatically increase their ability to offer drug treatment to everyone who needs help, he wrote in Putting People First. Six years later, the nation is no closer to reaching that goal. Under Clinton, fully two-thirds of the Federal drug budget goes for law enforcement and interdiction, with the remainder going for treatment and prevention -- the same proportion as under the Bush Administration. The current drug czar, Barry R. McCaffrey, is a retired four-star general who before taking office had no experience with drug treatment, and while he has frequently acknowledged the importance of treatment, he has made this a low priority. And so the treatment gap persists.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: That a focus on treatment can work is apparent from the one time it was actually tried -- during the Nixon Administration. A staunch advocate of law and order, Nixon deferred to no one in his strident pronouncements on drugs, but during the 1968 campaign he promised to bring down the nation's crime rate, and once in office, he faced the need to deliver.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: At the time, the nation was in the throes of a raging heroin epidemic; if something could be done to sap it, Nixon's advisers believed, the crime wave might abate. One obvious approach was to try to reduce the flow of heroin into the country. At the time, the main conduit was the French Connection, a 5,000-mile pipeline originating in Turkish poppy fields and passing through France. The Nixon Administration began pressing the French and Turkish Governments to crack down on local drug trafficking.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: But the more Nixon's drug officials looked into the problem, the more they became convinced that reducing the supply of drugs would prove futile unless something was also done to reduce the demand. On that front, a new weapon was available: methadone. Early studies showed that addicts maintained on methadone were much more likely to hold jobs and far less likely to commit crimes. At the time, methadone, like drug treatment in general, was largely unavailable in most cities. An exception was Chicago, where a young psychopharmacologist named Jerome Jaffe had set up a network of treatment programs that was helping get addicts off the streets. A central intake unit was opened in downtown Chicago, and addicts appearing at it were assigned to the type of program they needed -- detox, residential, methadone maintenance, methadone-to-abstinence and so on.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Impressed, President Nixon announced in 1971 the creation of a Drug Abuse Prevention office; to head it, he brought in Jaffe from Chicago. Once in place, Jaffe found that about 30,000 people were on treatment waiting lists; resolving this problem became his top priority. He faced resistance from many quarters, including Congress, the bureaucracy and his fellow mental-health professionals, but Jaffe -- a brilliant if prickly iconoclast -- managed to outmaneuver them all. By the fall of 1972, treatment was available to all those who wanted it.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: The impact was immediate. In New York City, the crime rate in 1972 dropped 18 percent, and in Washington, 26.9 percent. Nationally, the crime rate fell by 3 percent, the first decline in 17 years. Declines were also recorded in the rate of heroin-overdose deaths, hepatitis transmission and drug-related hospital visits -- strong testimony to the efficacy of a national treatment system.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Yet from the moment it was created, that system came under attack. And so in the 1972 Presidential campaign, Nixon began shifting the focus back toward drug enforcement. During the Ford and Carter years, the treatment budget suffered from the effects of both inflation and neglect. The real turning point came under Reagan. In his view, addicts were morally responsible for their behavior and therefore undeserving of Government help. As Nancy Reagan toured the country, urging Americans to just say no to drugs, her husband slashed the funding for drug treatment and boosted it for drug enforcement. By the time crack hit in the mid-1980's, the treatment system Jaffe built had been gutted, and addicts -- showing up at clinics desperate for help -- were regularly turned back onto the streets, there to commit more crime.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: It was not until the late 1980's that the Federal Government finally began pumping more funds into treatment. In fact, the nation's treatment budget is now larger than it was in the 1970's. Sadly, our drug problem is larger as well, as long waiting lists attest. It is time to follow the example of Jerome Jaffe and make elimination of those lists a top priority.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: But how much would that cost? According to in-house calculations by the drug czar's office, filling the nation's treatment gap would require increasing the Federal treatment budget by $3.4 billion a year. Of the $16 billion Washington now spends to fight drugs, $10.6 billion goes for supply reduction and $5.4 billion for demand reduction. If the overall budget was held constant but the allocation for these two areas equalized at $8 billion, the demand side would receive an additional $2.6 billion -- close to the sum in question. But the Clinton Administration -- worried about looking soft on drugs -- seems little interested in making such a transfer.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: By itself, of course, such a change would not solve the nation's drug problem. Rooted as it is in low-income communities, that problem is inseparable from the nation's other social ills, like inadequate housing, poor schooling and unemployment. Until these conditions are addressed, drug abuse will remain a fixture of American life. But by following the public health approach outlined here, Washington could reduce that problem to a far more manageable scale. When it comes to drug policy, Americans need not choose between their hearts and their heads; in this area, compassion is itself cost effective. Clearly, the war on drugs is not.
title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All

text: Intent on preventing any outbreaks of violence, the Police Department plans to saturate the site of today's scheduled rally in Harlem with more than 250 officers along each of the six blocks set aside for the event.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: And police officials say they intend to clear the streets promptly at the demonstration's court-ordered finish at 4 P.M., whether or not the event -- being billed as the Million Youth March -- has ended.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: ''I'm in charge,'' Police Commissioner Howard Safir declared a few days before the rally. Its chief organizer, Khallid Abdul Muhammad, has promoted the event as an expression of unity for black youths. But Mr. Muhammad has also said that he will bring to the event gang members interested in ending lives of violence.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: ''Large or small,'' Commissioner Safir said, ''we'll have a sufficient number of personnel and a plan to insure that both marchers and the public are safe.''
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally
