text: While the Commissioner refused to divulge specific security plans, a senior law enforcement official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the police were preparing to station more than 1,600 officers at the site of the rally, on Lenox Avenue from 118th Street to 124th Street, with a nearly equal number of officers in surrounding areas.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: The large deployment is planned even though city officials now expect fewer than 10,000 people to show up, far less than even the revised figure of 50,000 offered by Mr. Muhammad.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: The rally today comes after weeks of vitriolic exchanges among the event's organizers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and public officials of Harlem.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: Mr. Giuliani has repeatedly denounced the rally and all those who might participate. His comments have prompted several leaders in Harlem to criticize him as insensitive. Mr. Muhammad has peppered his comments with the sort of antiwhite and anti-Semitic remarks which he has often been criticized.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: The city had objected to the timing and location of the rally, saying it would be too big and costly to manage, and had refused to grant the organizers a permit.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: The organizers sued, contending that the city's action was unconstitutional and accusing city leaders of racism.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: After weeks of acrimonious exchanges in which Mayor Giuliani repeatedly denounced the rally as a ''hate march,'' a Federal appeals court panel on Tuesday gave final clearance for the event, but significantly curbed its scope. What Mr. Muhammad originally envisioned as a 12-hour rally drawing between 150,000 and 3 million people to a 29-block area was scaled back to four hours along six blocks.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: If the crowd estimate of 10,000 holds, the police deployment would provide about 1 officer on the scene for every 7 participants, compared with 1 officer for every 30 to 50 participants, the usual ratio for a rally or parade. In addition, the police plan other precautions, including the use of heavier metal barricades instead of the more common wooden ones, which can be broken apart and used as weapons or projectiles.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: To prevent provocative confrontations, the police plan to avoid making arrests for minor offenses like smoking marijuana, officials said. And the officers will be under tighter command than normal, with 1 supervisor for every 4 officers rather than the usual 1-to-8 ratio, officials said.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: Even with assurances from both the rally organizers and the police that every effort has been made to keep the event peaceful, some elected officials expressed concern that the overwhelming ratio of police to civilians and the lack of dialogue between the two sides is a recipe for disaster.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: State Senator David A. Paterson, whose district encompasses the rally's site, said that because the police have kept their plans secret, rumors have run rampant in the neighborhood that the police would be bringing in tanks and artillery. Although police officials denied that last night, the Senator was advising people to reconsider attending the event at all.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: ''In any event I can remember, I've never seen two sides who know so little about what the other is doing,'' Senator Paterson said. ''With the lack of dialogue, and the superfluous amount of police, at best it breeds suspicion. At worst it breeds mayhem.''
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: The deployment comes on a busy Labor Day weekend in which the 37,000-member department is expected to run up more than $1 million in overtime costs. In addition to the Harlem rally, there are more than 100 other special events taking place around the city. And the department's manpower has been stretched further in recent weeks by fears of terrorism, with hundreds of officers stationed around new concrete barricades set up around City Hall, Federal courthouses and other government buildings in downtown Manhattan, including Police Headquarters. The additional manpower scheduled for the weekend is the equivalent of 14,000 officers, said Lieut. Sean Crowley.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: Despite the court ruling, legal skirmishes over the rally continued yesterday, with the city's Corporation Counsel, Michael D. Hess, releasing a letter to reporters that accused the organizers of having failed to secure contracts or permits to build a stage or install a sound system or arrange for electricity from Con Edison. In addition, Mr. Hess said, the organizers were still broadcasting advertisements and distributing fliers asking participants to show up at 8 A.M. rather than noon.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: Mr. Hess warned Michael Warren, the organizers' lawyer, that this was an ''unacceptable and dangerous invitation to confusion and possible confrontation.''
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: Neither Mr. Muhammad nor the other organizers of the rally could be reached for comment yesterday.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: The rally is set for noon to 4 P.M. on the part of Lenox Avenue known as Malcolm X Boulevard. One lane of the boulevard is to be kept off-limits as a corridor for emergency vehicles.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: ''We don't want to inflame the crowd,'' said the senior law enforcement official. ''But if the people want to stand firm and not leave at 4 o'clock, then the commanders will announce that they are taking the podium down. Once the podium is down, officers will announce they are reopening the street for traffic and direct people to leave for the sidewalk. And if they don't do that, then the details will form up and push them onto the sidewalk.''
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: The official added, ''With all the rhetoric going back and forth, the Mayor's not about to say, 'Let's handle them with kid gloves and go easy.' So when the time comes to move these people, we want enough supervisors to make sure the cops handle it in as orderly a way as possible.''
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: Four subway stations near the rally site on the No. 2 line will be closed to avoid overburdening the line.
title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally

text: Rod Woodson of the Baltimore Ravens, a member of the National Football League's 75th anniversary team, violated the league's substance-abuse policy last month, refusing to take a second random drug test, according to executives from several teams.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: Woodson, one of the best cornerbacks to play the game, relented and took the test a day later and passed it. However, according to the league's drug policy, a refusal to take a drug test counts as a failure. Therefore, Woodson entered Stage 1 of the league's substance-abuse program. It calls for an evaluation by a psychiatrist, as well as an increase in random drug testing.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: If Woodson, who has never failed a drug test, refuses to take another random test, he could be suspended for four games.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: Because of the secrecy of its drug program, no one in the N.F.L. is allowed to comment, and neither are officials from the players association. Woodson could not be reached for comment and his agent, Eugene Parker, did not return phone calls.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: Players are randomly selected by the league's computer for testing for illegal substances such as marijuana or cocaine and performance-enhancing substances such as steroids and androstenedione. Woodson was tested and, according to N.F.L. team executives, passed the test.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: But the following day, Woodson's name was again randomly generated by the computer. The league executives said some players during the season are randomly selected four, five or even six times and most do not complain or refuse to take the test. Each player in the N.F.L. is randomly tested each season at least once.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: Woodson was infuriated when he was selected again, saying that he had already been tested just a day earlier and that he was not going to be tested again, several team executives said. He stormed out of the testing area and, one team executive said, ''was very nasty.''
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: Several days later, after Woodson had calmed down, he took the second test and again did not test positive for any illegal or banned substances.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: Still, the N.F.L. was upset with Woodson for refusing to take the test at first. The league felt that someone of his stature -- a future Hall of Famer -- should have taken the test and not set a bad example for other players.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: The Ravens' owner, Art Modell, said he had no knowledge of Woodson's situation. The N.F.L. and players association have been discussing the matter.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: There are three things that could happen:
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: 1. Woodson remains in Stage 1, is evaluated by a therapist who determines he does not have a problem, and since he has not failed any tests, he is released from the program.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: 2. The N.F.L. could reach a compromise with the union on Woodson's behalf and Woodson could be reprimanded or fined in place of being in the drug program.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: 3. The N.F.L. could stick to the letter of the law and Woodson would remain in the program. Woodson could then appeal and an arbitrator would either uphold the N.F.L.'s decision or throw it out.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: Woodson, however, will play in the team's opener against his old team, the Pittsburgh Steelers, on Sunday.
title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing

text: HOLLYWOOD — Film actor Robert Mitchum, actress Lila Leeds and dancer Vicky Evans were arrested on a narcotics charge by police who raided a marijuana party. "This is the bitter end of everything — my career, my home and my marriage," Mitchum said. He surrendered calmly as he was taken into custody by officers who said they caught him smoking a marijuana cigarette. Their sentences could range from ninety days to ten years.
title: 1948: Mitchum Held : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO

text: With the Democratic primary for United States Senate still a race in search of some sizzle, Representative Charles E. Schumer focused on a trademark issue yesterday, proposing anticrime measures to stem illegal interstate gun sales.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: He did not cross paths with his principal opponents -- Geraldine A. Ferraro and Mark Green -- but all three stuck to familiar and relatively safe Democratic ground.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: Ms. Ferraro picked up the endorsement of two gay Democratic clubs, using the occasion to stress her commitment to civil rights and nondiscrimination. Mr. Green, the New York City Public Advocate, went to Harlem to call for a nationwide expansion of the city's Beacon School program of after-school activities and vocational training.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: Mr. Schumer, speaking at New York University, returned to a favorite topic with his address on crime fighting. On the national and local levels, crime still ranks as one of the top issues of public concern, and polls have shown broad support for the Federal ban on assault weapons and the waiting period for handgun purchases, laws that Mr. Schumer helped write and pass in 1994.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: Ms. Ferraro, a former Representative from Queens, and Mr. Green are also strong supporters of gun control, while their ultimate quarry, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, has opposed such legislation in the past.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: Mr. Schumer's crime speech, which his aides billed as a major address, wove together two of his principal campaign pitches: that he has a proven record of legislation and a wealth of new ideas.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: He said that in 1994, as chairman of a House subcommittee on crime, he was able to achieve bipartisan agreement on a major crime bill by moving beyond ideological arguments and focusing on measures that had been shown to work on the local level, like increasing the number of police officers on the street.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: ''I know how difficult it is to move legislation through Congress,'' he added. ''I know about inertia.''
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: He said the 1994 crime bill, which was passed when the House of Representatives was controlled by Democrats, could use an update. He suggested changes in the juvenile court system to give judges more flexibility in punishing youngsters convicted of minor crimes. In response to a question from a reporter, he said he might support some decriminalization of marijuana, especially to allow use of the drug for medical purposes.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: On the other hand, he said, he would like to increase the penalties for illegal interstate sales of handguns and to restrict the number of guns one person can buy in a month. The goal is to crack down on the ''monsters'' who buy carloads of guns in states like Florida, where gun control laws are relatively weak, and sell them to criminals in New York, he said.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: Although Mr. Schumer's language is dramatic, his gun proposals are not entirely new. And they are not a top priority for some groups that have supported his anticrime measures in the past.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: ''There's a good deal of debate as to whether those big-time gunrunners really exist,'' said Jim Pasco, executive director of the Fraternal Order of Police in Washington. ''I agree that a significant number of the weapons used in crimes in major metropolitan areas were purchased in states with weaker laws. But they are not purchased by the hundreds or thousands, but by small-time entrepreneurs who may do 10 or 15 at a time. There is no Al Capone out there moving guns.''
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: Ms. Ferraro appeared at City Hall with supporters from two Manhattan-based gay and lesbian groups -- the Millennium Triangle Democratic Club and the Pride Democrats -- and proclaimed her support for national legislation currently under consideration that would ban employment discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: ''I will also be there seeking to get some sort of recognition of domestic partners,'' she said. ''We'll move to make sure that where there is discrimination, discrimination is ended.'' Mr. Green and Mr. Schumer have been endorsed by some gay groups.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: While Ms. Ferraro said she supported Federal legislation that would guarantee employment-related benefits to domestic partners without regard to sexual orientation, she opposed the formal recognition of gay marriages. She said that was an issue for states, not the Federal Government, to decide.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: Mr. Green, who has criticized the lack of child care for single mothers in New York, endorsed after-school programs during an appearance with former Mayor David N. Dinkins at the playground of Intermediate School 88, on 115th Street in Harlem.
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: He said the Beacon School program, which Mr. Dinkins established, was a success that should be copied nationwide, a proposal he acknowledged would cost about $3 billion a year. ''If it works here in Harlem,'' he said, ''it can work in every school district in America.''
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: Mr. Green said the money could come from a tax on cigarettes and savings from cutbacks in programs for ''weapons that don't work against enemies that don't exist.''
title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground

text: An armed robbery at a Brooklyn gas station was foiled yesterday by an off-duty police sergeant who witnessed the robbery, chased down the suspect and shot him once in the leg during a furious struggle before arresting him, the police said.
title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion

text: Sgt. Raymond Martinez, a 10-year veteran who was promoted to sergeant on Friday, was driving to his post at the department's Housing Bureau at 6:30 A.M. yesterday when he saw a robbery in progress at a Citygas Station on Atlantic Avenue near Hale Street in the Highland Park section, the police said.
title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion

text: During the robbery, the gas station attendant, Xavinder Singh, 26, was shot once in the foot before the gunman fled on a bicycle, said Sgt. Gerry Falcon, a department spokeswoman. Sergeant Martinez chased the suspect in his car and caught him a few blocks away, the police said.
title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion

text: In a struggle, Sergeant Martinez shot the suspect once in the left shin, the police said. The suspect, David Golden, 35, of Brooklyn, was arrested, and a .380-caliber handgun was seized from him at the scene, Sergeant Falcon said.
title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion

text: Mr. Golden was charged with assault, robbery, weapons possession and possession of stolen property. He was listed in stable condition at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, Sergeant Falcon said.
title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion

text: Mr. Golden, who has over 20 arrests on his record, was released from prison in May after serving six years for a drug conviction. Denied parole, he got a conditional release under parole supervision after serving as much of his sentence as state law allowed, said Tom Grant, a spokesman for the Parole Division.
title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion

text: Mr. Golden has been arrested twice since his release in May, for selling marijuana and drug possession, the police said. Mr. Grant said it was unclear last night why Mr. Golden had not been returned to prison.
title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion

text: Mr. Singh, the attendant, was treated for his foot wound at Brookdale and released, the police said. Sergeant Martinez was treated at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center for back injuries, the police said.
title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion

text: Joanne Donovan remembers how Gary Evans, her friend and lover for eight years, ate. He was like a 10-year-old, she said, subsisting on gallons of milk and boxes of Cocoa Puffs and Freihofer's chocolate-chip cookies.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Robbin Evans, his sister, remembers how he skateboarded with her son and bounced on a trampoline as joyously as a child.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Several other women who knew Mr. Evans described him as quiet, gentle and caring. He bolstered their confidence. He liked to draw mountains and write poems about freedom and the stars and pure love.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: But the police in Rensselaer County say something very different: that Gary C. Evans, a professional antiques thief, was a brutal multiple murderer who killed five men as coldly and deliberately as an executioner.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Jailed in May on charges relating to a theft, Mr. Evans, 43, confessed to each of these killings over the summer, the police say, revealing the details bit by bit and directing officers to the graves he had dug. Reports about the Evans case appeared all summer in local newspapers and on the TV news. To people in Troy, a once-thriving industrial center about 15 miles north of Albany, and throughout Rensselaer County, the story was riveting.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: And two weeks ago, on the way from an Albany courthouse to the jail in Troy, Mr. Evans provided a spectacular ending. Shackled hand and foot, he kicked out the window of a police van, jumped out, hobbled to the edge of a bridge, and plunged 65 feet to his death in the rocky shallows of the Hudson River. In a note to his lawyer, opened after his death, he had written: ''Stars surround me and peace and love are mine. They cannot be taken or touched. I win.''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Later, an autopsy revealed that Mr. Evans had hidden a handcuff key in one nostril and a sliver of razor in the other. The bizarre tale was reported around the country -- often with an old photo of Mr. Evans, naked to the waist, displaying the physique of a bodybuilder. At home, the most common reactions were anger and relief. Some people were outraged that a killer in custody had managed to orchestrate his death under the noses of police guards, but nearly everybody was relieved to be rid of him.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Amid the exclamations, however, some quieter voices emerged: a dozen or more women who had been Mr. Evans's friends, and, in some cases, lovers. They expressed shock and horror at the killings. The person they were mourning, from their descriptions, was the opposite of a ruthless killer.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Of course, Mr. Evans would not be the first killer with female friends and relatives who loved him and knew his better qualities. But the range of Mr. Evans's behavior was unusual, according to professionals who work closely with murderers. They say he killed with the easy viciousness of a disturbed child dismembering a bug.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Yet his female friends remember him as a sympathetic listener who went out of his way to encourage and help them. ''A woman and kid protector,'' said Ms. Evans, his sister.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Ms. Donovan, 34, said: ''He was very affectionate and sweet to my daughter. He liked to play Nintendo with her. He was always happy, always energetic. He made me feel good.''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Women who knew him as a teen-ager said that in some ways he was as wholesome as a Boy Scout. At parties, when others were drinking beer and smoking marijuana, he would bring a quart of milk to drink, one woman said. Then and later, he refused to touch meat or alcohol or drugs, even aspirin.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: ''We called him Owl, the wisest,'' said one 39-year-old woman, a state administrator in Albany.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Shortly after the death of Mr. Evans, a 34-year-old woman, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, described an affair she had with him 10 years ago. She was a young mother trapped in a bad marriage when she met him at a local pub and agreed to see him. He took her to art museums and bought her son a red tricycle. But mainly, he urged her to leave her abusive husband and discussed the logistics of finding an apartment, a job and drawing up a budget.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: ''He gave me the courage to go out and make a new life for myself and my son,'' she said. After nine months, she left her husband. Within a week or so, Mr. Evans disappeared, she said.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Now, she said, she is happily remarried and has a good job. ''This man made me believe in myself again,'' she said. ''I was going down the tubes. He gave me back my self-esteem. I could never repay him.''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: At the time that he was restoring her confidence, Mr. Evans committed his first murder. The victim, Michael Falco, 30, had grown up in his neighborhood and occasionally lent him a hand during thefts. After shooting Mr. Falco in the head to keep him from talking about a burglary, he stuffed the body in the trunk of his car, drove to Lake Worth, Fla., and buried it. Investigators found the body this summer.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Mr. Evans's long-ago lover said she felt numb, trying to fit the killer with the caring friend she knew.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: ''It's night and day, good and evil,'' she said. ''I feel so much sympathy for those victims. But I can't envision him as a murderer. How can he be so kind and yet so brutal?''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Mr. Evans had grown up with brutality, his sister said. Their father frequently beat both children and their mother, who tried many times to kill herself. When her brother was 7, Ms. Evans said, he grabbed a butcher knife and tried futilely to stab his father, who had been beating their mother.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: By all accounts, all of Mr. Evans's friends, even in high school, were women; later, all of his victims were men.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Whatever the causes of his violence, one expert said that Mr. Evans's seeming kindness was as cold and calculated as his killings. James Merikangas, a Yale neurosurgeon and forensic psychiatrist, said that a killer like Mr. Evans was ''incapable of feeling human emotions.''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: ''They may appear to be caring,'' he said. ''But it's a practiced deception.'' It is not possible, he added, for anyone to feel empathy and also callously commit murder. The actions of a sociopath like Mr. Evans, he said, are attempts to manipulate and control anyone he deals with.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: According to law-enforcement authorities, Mr. Evans killed to silence witnesses -- three partners in thievery and two shopkeepers during burglaries -- who might testify against him.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: But what did he gain by being kind to women -- and, for that matter, children and animals? Probably it made him feel powerful, Dr. Merikangas said. All the women he befriended were in vulnerable situations. From the number of friends and the strength of their feelings, it seems that Mr. Evans was able to mime sympathy much more convincingly than most killers.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: He convinced Ms. Donovan when Damien Cuomo, an antiques thief and her live-in lover, disappeared in 1989. ''He'll be back,'' Mr. Evans assured her. ''He'll be back sometime.''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Shattered at her lover's apparent desertion, Ms. Donovan came to look forward to Mr. Evans's increasingly frequent visits. ''I started to like him as a friend,'' she said.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: After a while, Mr. Evans practically moved in with her, and eventually she realized she was in love with him. ''He was easy to get along with,'' she said. ''He would lay on the couch and not talk. He liked swimming and laying in the sun and relaxing.''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: He showed off his daredevil stunts for her, like diving 80 feet into a lake. They went antiquing in Massachusetts. ''He bought me things to make me laugh,'' she said. ''A stupid metal flower for $15 -- ugly, ugly, ugly. I said, 'Why?' And he started laughing and I started laughing.''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: He talked to her about the dream house in Vermont that he was going to build, on a mountaintop. And, to her distress, about his thefts, confiding in greater detail as the months passed.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: Then, last year, after seeing an extremely agitated Mr. Evans drive off with Timothy Rysedorph, another Troy friend, and return, frantic and crazy-eyed, in Mr. Rysedorph's car alone, she figured it out. That fall weekend in 1997, Mr. Evans fled Troy, violating his probation and becoming a fugitive
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: When a police investigator approached Ms. Donovan a few weeks later about Mr. Rysedorph's disappearance, she agreed to help. The thefts did not particularly bother her, but murder did.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: It was months before she was able to turn Mr. Evans in. But in the spring, he finally called her and asked her to meet him in St. Johnsbury, Vt., where he was living the rugged life of a survivalist.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: When it was over -- when the police who accompanied her to Vermont had arrested Mr. Evans before she could even give him a hug -- Ms. Donovan felt ''crushed.'' With seven felony convictions, and facing life imprisonment, Mr. Evans began confessing to the killings. One victim was Mr. Cuomo, whom Mr. Evans had forced to a remote area, handcuffed and shot several times in the head.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: ''I protected him all those years,'' Ms. Donovan said. ''But how was I going to protect him when he killed my boyfriend?''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: But Mr. Evans, it seems, facing a life in prison -- even before any murder charges -- had given up hope of life and was planning his death. If he committed suicide in prison, Ms. Donovan said, he thought they would have won. But if he could kill himself outside, he would win.
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: ''He had nothing to lose,'' she said. ''He wanted to go out with a bang. He wanted to win.''
title: Women Baffled by 'Gentle' Friend's Murderous Side

text: THE exhibition of sculpture by Bisa Washington at the Morris Museum contains 23 separate works. But with the help of a little explanation from Ms. Washington, they conspire to make up an epic that is both cosmic and local.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: An artist's statement posted on the wall says, ''African and Oceanic art are the sources of constant inspiration.'' A viewer readily detects both influences: the pieces have the grandeur and authority associated with African sculpture, but they also have the sharp confrontational aspects of art from New Guinea. With one notable exception, each piece is black, but the exhibition is never solemn.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: Ms. Washington dedicates her work to two saints of the Yoruba people of western Nigeria: Eshu-Elegbara, ''the key to open every door'' and ''the master of multiplicity and power,'' and Ogun the Blacksmith, the ''force in nature that represents the desire of all forms of consciousness to survive and evolve.''
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: What unites the exhibition is the way these two gods weave in and out in different guises. Several pieces are hung with house keys, either real or symbolic ones. By simply adding objects that are meaningful to her, Ms. Washington is imitating the making of fetish figures. A work becomes imbued with real force.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: She can make the power relevant to contemporary life. The most tender work in the show is ''Promise Not to Tell,'' which takes the form of a small shack with a tin roof plastered with three photocopied images of a group of children. What stands out boldly, however, is the dwelling's fist-sized imitation-crystal doorknob with a keyhole underneath it, waiting for Eshu to come and work his secret magic.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: It is not surprising that Ogun should manifest himself as phallic, with a generative organ shaped like a rhinoceros horn. On the other hand, ''Ogun's Daughter'' stands tall, proud and silent. In some ways the piece resembles a statue of the Virgin Mary. A lifelike mask of a woman's face is placed atop a body that looks as if it's made of raffia, a twinelike fiber. But the base of this figure is encircled by a chain.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: All the works are labeled mixed-media. The lack of specificity is vexing, but the main materials can be identified: fibers that are braided in a variety of ways or left hanging loose; woven canvas strips that usually make the background of a relief work or shrine; paper, metal, beads and cowrie shells.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: Even when the pieces are not specifically figurative, they often allude to the figure. The cone-shaped and diminutive ''Oriki Eshu'' is a rudimentary face with cowrie shells for eyes and a washer for an open mouth. Since the piece has Eshu in the title, keys hang from it.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: Some departures from the main theme of the show, the manifestation of the two gods, work to reinforce it. Death is the opposite of Ogun's mission, and ''Land Mine Engaged and Dismantled'' is therefore a disturbing intrusion on Ms. Washington's saga. Chaotically emerging from a round core is an abundance of thin braids that are probably the insides of the explosive. Or they could be an octopus's tentacles. (Artistic license allows for more than eight.)
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: Ms. Washington's statement is almost a skeleton key. In it she says, ''Words are the catalyst for many of my sculptures.'' Two esoteric words, mojo and juju, inspired separate pieces. An approximation of mojo's complex meaning is shamanistic charm. Ms. Washington's ''Mojo Muse'' features an abundance of found objects tumbling from the individual plastic letters that form the potent word.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: The Random House Dictionary of American Slang succinctly says a juju is a marijuana cigarette. If this is what Ms. Washington means, the word's placement on a field of sequins that resembles an evening purse gives the work some sassiness. What complicates matters, though, is that another piece called ''Are You Ready for Juju?'' is full of slips of paper stamped ''Return to Sender.'' In the Oxford English Dictionary, a juju is an amulet or other fetish, and here it might be capable of reversing power.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: Always tantalizingly recondite, Ms. Washington veers into Spanish in the titles of two works. What translates as ''Chorus of the Black Siren'' is a wall work of a figure in the fetal position. It wears a hat with a large brim, and perhaps Ms. Washington is referring to the stereotypical Mexican man wearing a sombrero and leaning against a cactus. Another work with a Spanish title has a piece of bone shaped like a bird in flight against a solid background. The title is an aphorism, and its English approximation is ''Whoever Gives You a Bone Doesn't Want To See You Dead.''
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: Ms. Washington lives in Newark, and she pays tribute to that city in three works from her ''Newark Smokestacks'' series. Out of her arsenal of materials, she conjures cunning chimneys that spout a variety of materials.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: Morris Museum, 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: Through Sept. 26. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.; Mondays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays to 8 P.M.
title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints

text: MARK SYLVERS had just lost a game of chess in Bryant Park recently and was being consoled by his opponent. ''You're pretty good,'' said Laura Ross, who will turn 10 this week. ''It was really close.'' But moments earlier, her face, under butterfly barrettes, had the look of a killer as she grabbed pieces from the 43-year old.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: A crowd had gathered around them during the game. ''She's so tiny,'' a woman said. ''Who would think a little girl like that could play chess?''
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: This is a scene from chess al fresco in New York -- a world that is part Broadway, part Bowery, part retirement colony, depending on the location and the participants. Recently Laura, who is ranked third among all players age 10 and under by the United States Chess Federation, viewed three popular sites, Bryant Park, Washington Square Park and the Brighton Beach boardwalk, from her height of 4 feet 2 inches.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: The toniest spot was at Bryant Park. When Laura, who is from Forest Hills, Queens, visited during a busy lunchtime, many in the mostly male crowd looked as if they had stepped out of the window at Barneys. Most had time only for ''blitz,'' with each player allowed 5 or 10 minutes for the whole game. A sign reading ''sociable games arranged'' stresses the prohibition on gambling, said Steven Manning, president of New York Chess and Backgammon, which runs the Bryant Park games.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Laura used to play here at the Chess for Kids games held on Saturdays. ''Now, she's beating adults like crazy,'' Mr. Manning said. In fact, she rarely plays against children anymore, although this fall she is to represent the United States for a second year at the International Youth Tournament. When not seeking to boost her 1725 rating at tournaments, she spends an hour a day studying chess tactics and another hour learning from her father, Philip, a skilled player and an editor at Forbes magazine.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Laura also finds opponents on the Internet, who do not know her gender or age -- though her electronic chatter about the Spice Girls may tip them off.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: At Bryant Park, Laura was pleased to run into Asa Hoffmann, a well-known local chess figure. ''The people hanging around here won't play me because I'm a famous master,'' said Mr. Hoffmann, 55, who was portrayed by the actor Austin Pendleton in the 1993 movie, ''Searching for Bobby Fischer.'' Laura was not eager to face him either, but did so gamely.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Mr. Hoffmann won, but not before Laura's playing attracted an admiring audience. And the victor said he is envious of Laura, whom he called ''a great talent.''
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: ''Her father is a strong player, and he teaches her,'' Mr. Hoffmann said. ''My father was a strong player, but didn't encourage me.''
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Such distinctions meant little to Laura, though. She had not enjoyed the game. ''He killed me,'' she said.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Laura expressed some envy of adult players in general, because, she said, many can play psychological tricks better than she can. ''When they make a really bad move they'll look like it's fine, so you'll ignore it.''
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: She said she tries not to show her emotions, but it is hard. And while the problem disappears on the Internet, she said, ''other times you want to deal with, like, humans.''
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Laura next went to Washington Square Park, where a shabbily dressed man sweeping paths with a worn broom was the self-appointed social director, offering to pair players for a price. He called himself Sweetpea and declined to divulge his real name. Asked if some might call him a hustler, he replied, ''That's exactly what I am.''
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Sweetpea is not the only money hunter there. Regulars station themselves at the chess tables in the early morning and spend the day ''renting'' the tables for a fee and charging for games they call ''chess lessons,'' said Patrick Lewis, 30, whom Laura was pleased to see at the park.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Mr. Lewis, who greeted Laura with a smile and a request for her current rating -- ''very good,'' he said, ''but you still can't beat me'' -- has been playing in Washington Square Park since childhood.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Laura had not planned to play here. She said her dad had told her about the hustling. But she agreed to two free games with Mr. Lewis, after he paid a scowling man for rental of a chess clock. Mr. Lewis won both.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: ''I thought she had me on the first game, but she missed a winning move,'' said Mr. Lewis, who noted that he tried his best because a reporter was present.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Laura, sizing up some of the other players at the scene, said, ''It's really mixed strengths.'' Bryant Park, she said, ''might be a little stronger.'' But the funkiness at this park did not put her off.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: ''It's not like a dangerous place,'' she said. ''It's fine, and it's good for playing.'' She did not recognize the scent of marijuana in the air.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Drinking tea afterward at a cafe with her mother, Jenny, Laura said she liked to watch ''All My Children'' in the summer, when P.S. 101, where she is about to enter fifth grade, is out. Juvenile actors, like the ones who play youngsters on the soap, interest her, perhaps because they, too, are children striving for success in an adult world.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: She shares an interest in the show with her mother, who teaches English as a second language at La Guardia Community College. Ms. Ross, a knowledgeable chess parent although not a player, sees benefits to Laura's hobby beyond the game.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: ''She has met people from all walks of life, outside her usual circle,'' Ms. Ross said.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Several days after the visit to Washington Square Park, Laura went to the Brighton Beach boardwalk in Brooklyn, where tables for games sit under a metal canopy. On that weekday morning, the tables were taken up by domino players, Sunday being the day when chess is king. Only two chess games were in progress, both played by elderly Russian-speaking men on benches.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: About the first game, Laura said, ''I can see that they're not, like, horrible, but they made a tactical mistake.'' The second game, though, impressed her. She said she would be willing to play either opponent. They waved off overtures, but a bystander, Isaak Tulman, who said he was a master from the former Soviet republic of Georgia, offered to play her.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: But no chess set was available, the day was hot, and Laura had brought a swimsuit, so the chess prodigy ended her day in the waves.
title: Laura's Adventures in Street Chess

text: Fila USA's decision to end the endorsement contract of Chris Webber, the Sacramento Kings forward who was reported to have been detained recently at a Puerto Rico airport for marijuana possession, was applauded yesterday by Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House drug czar.
title: White House Cheers Webber Decision

text: We congratulate Fila USA on its commitment to help take drugs out of sports, McCaffrey said in a statement.
title: White House Cheers Webber Decision

text: Meredith Geisler, a spokeswoman for Fila, would not comment on Webber, but said she had confirmed the company's decision to the White House.
title: White House Cheers Webber Decision

text: But L. Fallasha Erwin, Webber's lawyer, said Fila does not have the right to unilaterally drop the player. There's a process that has to be followed before termination, said Erwin, who was surprised by the White House statement.
title: White House Cheers Webber Decision

text: I'm disappointed the White House would issue a statement or Fila would confirm anything to the White House until we go through the process, he said yesterday. He denied the account of Webber's detainment, that he had paid a fine or acknowledged possessing the marijuana. The Washington Post reported that Erwin said a woman with Webber claimed possession of the marijuana and paid the fine.
title: White House Cheers Webber Decision

text: Webber was traded by the Washington Wizards last May and signed a three-year deal with Fila in early 1997. RICHARD SANDOMIR
title: White House Cheers Webber Decision

text: Mangling some Arthur Miller dialogue, Joe (Matthew Modine) lands an assignment in a Madonna video. Meanwhile, his girlfriend (Catherine Keener) takes self-defense classes and helps primp a supermodel named Sahara (Bridgette Wilson) for spreads shot by Blair (Marlo Thomas), a voraciously intense fashion photographer who knows all about taking pictures but nothing about what they represent. Finally, there's Joe's friend Bob (Maxwell Caulfield, above with Daryl Hannah), a smirky, sex-obsessed type on the prowl for a genuine blonde. Using a sharp satirical eye, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, Tom DiCillio ''directed this shrewd comedy with a sharp notion of exactly what he wants to skewer.''
title: New Video Releases

text: 1997. Paramount. $29.99. 101 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
title: New Video Releases

text: In Bertrand Tavernier's film, the fiery, war-loving Conan (Philippe Torreton) has trouble accepting the fact that World War I is at an end and that he must disband his French irregulars fighting on in the Balkans. Providing a temperamental and philosophical counterpoint is the intellectual Lieutenant Norbert (Samuel Le Bihan), the story's resident ethicist. While a hand-held camera probes everywhere during trench warfare, memorably ambiguous characters carry out an elaborate moral inquiry in a ''vast yet subtle film'' (Maslin).
title: New Video Releases

text: 1996. Kino. $79.95. 130 minutes. French with English subtitles. No rating.
title: New Video Releases

text: Brooklyn streets are ingrained in the brand of basketball and the people who play it in Danielle Gardner's pulsating documentary. At the center of the story are the blustering Kenny Jones, organizer and patriarch of Kenny's Kings, and his star guard Ed (Booger) Smith. A tireless self-promoter, Mr. Jones is macho mother hen to his players off the court and their loud, crude advocate on it. Booger, on the other hand, coolly slides by and for a short time becomes the New York playground prize of an Arizona junior college. Soon, though, he's back in Brooklyn, swallowed up by the big city from which he came in a film that lacks the sociological impact of ''Hoop Dreams'' and ''remains predominantly upbeat and utterly nonjudgmental'' (Stephen Holden).
title: New Video Releases

text: 1997. Xenon. $59.99. 100 minutes. No rating.
title: New Video Releases

text: When Malcolm (John Lithgow), an affluent grower of marijuana, is shot dead, his three stooges (Billy Bob Thornton, Hank Azaria and Ryan Phillippe) scoop up all the weed they can carry and flee to Lucy (Kelly Lynch), who is the operation's packager. Later the trio notices that the entire crop still stands unmolested by rippers (thieves) and ripe for the selling. From then on in Stephen Gyllenhaal's film, everybody has ''a high old time huffing and puffing through this happy sermon on the wages of greed'' (Lawrence Van Gelder).
title: New Video Releases

text: 1998. Columbia Tri-Star. $105.77. 101 minutes. R. Release date: Tuesday.
title: New Video Releases

text: Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a theater release at one time or appeared on television.
title: New Video Releases

text: NANOOK OF THE NORTH. Long a staple in the silent-film public domain, Robert Flaherty's famous 1920 documentary (or photoplay, as it was called then) about the hardships of an Eskimo hunter and his $Sfamily in the Hudson Bay region of Canada has undergone a cutting-edge modernization with its first digitally mastered edition. Kino. $24.95. 70 minutes.
title: New Video Releases

text: THE BRIDGE. During the last few days of World War II in Europe, the Nazis rounded up seven teen-age boys from a high school, threw them into uniform and sent them out to defend a bridge in the path of the advancing Allies. Actually, the Germans had planned to withdraw them before the attack arrived and blow up the bridge, but the sergeant who knew that information was killed before he could so inform the students, who are left to be mowed down. It's not pretty. If combat scenes in ''Saving Private Ryan'' are stomach-churning, Bernhard Wicki's film, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, ''has let us have it right between the eyes.'' 1961. VCI. $19.98. 102 minutes.
title: New Video Releases

text: THE DEVIL RIDES OUT. That's the English title for ''The Devil's Bride,'' as it's known in the United States, one of the better films from Britain's Hammer Studios. When young Simon gets involved with a Satanic cult ruled by the malicious Mocata, the Duc de Richelieu -- despite his title, this is a modern drama -- springs to the rescue with a potent ritual (and it had better work). 1968. Anchor Bay. $14.98. 95 minutes.
title: New Video Releases

text: With Hurricane Bonnie bearing down on the Eastern Seaboard and rough surf advisories in effect, it was just the type of emergency call that rescue workers had been bracing for. Kimberly Kuda flagged down a police officer in Point Pleasant Beach just after 7:30 P.M. Monday to say her future husband had been swept into the Atlantic.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: As a Coast Guard helicopter and rescue boats frantically searched the dark, gnashing ocean, Ms. Kuda, 21, appeared so distraught, Detective Sgt. Harry DiCorcia of the Point Pleasant Beach police said, that an emergency psychiatric team was brought in to help. But now, after two unexpected twists, investigators say her fiance, Antonio Mandarino Jr., is still alive and that his drowning and her distress were a hoax.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: First, a telephone caller suggested to the police that Mr. Mandarino, 23, who has a long criminal record, might have faked his drowning to avoid prosecution on several charges in Bergen County. Then, Ms. Kuda also disappeared. Police officials said she was apparently the only person to witness Mr. Mandarino's alleged drowning. So today, the authorities again mounted a search.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: But this time, they have no need for the Coast Guard's help. Instead, the Point Pleasant Police Department and the Bergen County Sheriff's office are trying to find the couple, particularly Mr. Mandarino, who has previously been arrested in at least a half dozen northern New Jersey towns on charges including marijuana and gun possession, assault, aggravated assault, passing bad checks, shoplifting and receiving stolen property.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: Tonight, Detective Sergeant DiCorcia said that Mr. Mandarino's father told the police that his son had contacted him. But, the detective sergeant said, the police were ''no closer'' to finding Mr. Mandarino tonight.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: The Bergen County Sheriff, Jay Alpert, said that Mr. Mandarino was scheduled to appear in Bergen County Superior Court in Hackensack on Sept. 14 to face a charge of eluding the police. Fred Schwanwede, the first assistant prosecutor in Bergen County, said Mr. Mandarino had escaped from a detective who was trying to stop him for questioning in Saddle Brook, N.J. Officials would not say what the detective wanted to question Mr. Mandarino about.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: The apparent hoax, Sheriff Alpert said, ''goes beyond just a false police report.''
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: ''You have people that risked their lives,'' he said. ''Divers that were down there, going into rough surf, looking for somebody they thought was there, which is something that is almost incomprehensible.''
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: The search took place from the air and on the sea. It included a Coast Guard HH-65 Alpha Dolphin helicopter with a crew of four and rescue workers in boats, including a 41-foot Coast Guard utility boat and a rigid-hull inflatable craft, said Petty Officer Mike LaPearl of the Coast Guard's Manasquan Inlet Station. The helicopter costs $3,638 an hour to operate, he said, the utility boat costs $313 an hour and the rigid-hull inflatable $233 an hour. In all, officials estimated the cost of the rescue effort at more than $20,000.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: Sheriff Alpert said that he and his wife had watched news accounts of Mr. Mandarino's drowning and that their hearts had gone out to the heartbroken fiancee. ''It evokes all kinds of emotions,'' he said. ''A young couple supposed to get married in November, she's sitting on the beach and sees her fiance whisked away by a wave. Now, she has disappeared and is presumably with him.''
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: Detectives from the missing persons squad were searching for the couple, he said, and officers from both the Sheriff's Department and the Point Pleasant Beach police were searching for Ms. Kuda's silver 1997 Mercury Tracer, with New Jersey license plate RF394H.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: Officials said Ms. Kuda left Point Pleasant police headquarters about 1:30 A.M. Tuesday and returned to the house in Oakland, N.J., where she lived with her fiance and his father. Late that morning, she gave an interview by telephone to The (Hackensack) Record.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: ''He went into the water, and I saw a wave come and take him in,'' she told the newspaper. She also said they had gone to the shore because they could not afford to take a vacation.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: Mr. Mandarino's father, Antonio Mandarino Sr., has told local newspapers that he believes his son may still be alive. Reached by telephone today, before he told the police that his son had called him, he said he did not know where the couple might be or what had happened to his son. ''He's not here,'' the father said. ''I don't know where he is. You got to talk to his girlfriend. If you could find her, she knows everything. I don't know anything.''
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: According to the police, the couple had been on Jenkinson's Beach in Point Pleasant Beach, when Ms. Kuda flagged down an officer for help shortly after 7:30 P.M. on Monday, saying her fiance had been standing in knee-deep water. Ms. Kuda reported that ''a wave knocked him down and took him into the ocean and that was the last she saw of him,'' Detective Sergeant DiCorcia said.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: Ms. Kuda was interviewed at police headquarters and then turned over to the team of emergency psychiatric workers, Detective Sergeant DiCorcia said. ''They maintained contact with her and stayed with her for approximately four hours,'' he said. While Ms. Kuda was at the police station, rescue teams from the Coast Guard and the local fire department, including a special team of divers, were out in the ocean, struggling through six-foot waves.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: If Mr. Mandarino is found and faces the Bergen County charge of eluding the police, he could face 5 to 10 years in prison if convicted. But if the distress call is proved to have been a hoax, officials said, he and Ms. Kuda could face considerably more serious charges.
title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police

text: Police officials yesterday staunchly defended the shooting of a Brooklyn teen-ager by two officers who mistook his water gun for the real thing, but the youth's distraught family demanded answers about why the officers fired at him 17 times.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: The injured youth, Michael Jones, who was hit in the legs with six of the shots, took a turn for the worse last night and was taken into emergency surgery moments after his family -- and the Rev. Al Sharpton, who took up his cause -- visited him at his bedside at Kings County Hospital Center, where they found him unconscious and breathing through a tube. Michael was listed in critical condition last night after the surgery.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Michael, 16, was shot at 2:40 A.M. Sunday by two plainclothes officers who were responding to a call about a gunman riding a bicycle, the police said.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: The police, meanwhile, charged Michael with more offenses. Initially charged with menacing, because of complaints that he had pointed the water gun at people, he was charged yesterday with possessing a realistic-looking toy gun, which violates the city's administrative code, and with possession of marijuana, the police said.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Police Commissioner Howard Safir defended the shooting yesterday at a news conference at Police Headquarters. He held aloft Michael's water pistol in his left hand and a similar-looking machine pistol in his right hand. ''It certainly looks like a real weapon,'' he said.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: But Mr. Sharpton, acting as a spokesman for Michael's grandmother and guardian, Adeline Jones, asked at a news conference at the hospital why the officers were so quick to shoot and why toy manufacturers would make such lethal-looking replicas. ''It's premature to say who's liable,'' he said. ''The toy manufacturer may be liable. But officers firing 16 or 17 shots -- it sounds more like a showdown at the O.K. Corral than public safety.''
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Friends said that Michael had been at a block party on Saturday spraying neighbors with the water gun. The gun, a replica of a Tec-9, a favorite of drug dealers, was so realistic that its manufacturer stopped producing it 15 years ago. It was realistic enough, officials said, to fool the police and passers-by.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Two plainclothes officers were sent to Clifton Place and Bedford Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant after a 911 caller reported seeing a bicyclist with a gun and an off-duty officer drove to the 88th Precinct station house to report that a bicyclist had pointed a gun at him, the police said.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: As Michael and two friends pedaled up to them, Officer David Gross, 26, got out of an unmarked police car and took cover behind it, while his partner, Sgt. Michael Jacobellis, 43, took cover behind the passenger side door. When the youths got to within 45 to 50 feet, the police said, Officer Gross fired all 16 shots from his service pistol, a 9-millimeter semiautomatic, and Sergeant Jacobellis fired once.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Officers are trained to use lethal force only when they feel their lives or those of others are in imminent danger, and they are told to aim for the torso. The police said Michael was hit six times, all in the legs.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Commissioner Safir said that the police officers ordered Michael to drop his gun and that he refused. ''They have not been interviewed yet, but it is our information that they asked Michael to drop the weapon,'' he said. ''He did not.''
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: But a teen-ager who was with Michael gave a different account, said a law enforcement official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The teen-ager said that Michael never pointed the water pistol at the police, the official said. Another friend said he did not see the sequence of events clearly, the official said.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: In an interview on Sunday, a teen-ager who was bicycling with Michael, Jermain Congress, said Michael had either dropped the pistol or was dropping it when he was shot.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday that he would convene a grand jury to investigate the shooting.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: The incident was the latest in a chain of shootings in which police officers have mistaken toy guns for the real thing. Congress has ordered toy manufacturers to paint water guns bright colors in an effort to prevent just this kind of incident.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Al Davis, a spokesman for the Larami Corporation, which made the Tec-9 water gun, said that the company had stopped producing realistic guns 15 years ago -- making the toy at least almost as old as Michael, and perhaps older. ''The law said that all toy guns had to have bright orange tags on them,'' he said. ''Not only do we have bright orange tags, but we now make all our toy guns in neon colors.''
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: New information surfaced yesterday about both Michael and Officer Gross. The police initially said that Michael, a sophomore at Wingate High School, had no criminal record. But yesterday, a police official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that Michael had been arrested in June for the sale of marijuana, but that the record had been sealed.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Officials described Officer Gross as an active policeman who has made 81 arrests and been in 2 shootings -- both found to be justified -- in his six years on the force.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Officer Gross, who has spent his entire career in the 79th Precinct in Bedford-Stuyvesant, was involved in two shootings in a three-week period in October 1995. The number is unusual on a force in which most officers never fire their weapons off the practice range, but Mr. Safir said that both shootings were found to be justified.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: The first took place on Oct. 6, when he fired a single shot at a gunman who was firing a gun 100 feet away, the police said. The gunman was arrested after a short chase, they said. The second shooting occurred on Oct. 21, when Officer Gross fired three shots at a man who pointed a gun at him, the police said. A .25-caliber handgun was recovered and the man was later arrested, the police said.
title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy

text: Becky Gatling will never forget her introduction to the real National Basketball Association. It was November 1991 and she and her husband, Ray, were waiting outside a locker room for their son Chris, then a rookie with the Golden State Warriors. The game had been over for nearly an hour and while most of the fans had filed out of the arena, Becky Gatling was amazed by how many were still hanging around, waiting for the Warriors.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: ''I was saying, 'Oh, this is great, look at all these family members,' '' she recalled. ''Then a player came up to me and said: 'Mrs. Gatling, these are not family members. These are hoochie mamas.' ''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: The hoochie mamas, as the player called the female groupies, were looking for Chris Gatling and his teammates. One interrupted Becky Gatling's conversation with a player by jamming a card with her phone number scribbled on it into the player's hand. Outside in the parking lot, another ran after a player driving away in his truck, screaming and waving her arms in a desperate attempt to get his attention.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: ''I thought, 'This is a crazy place,' '' Becky Gatling said, still seeming stunned at the thought. ''I told my husband, 'This is really an education.' It was like, welcome to the N.B.A.!''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: She shared that tale this weekend at the second annual Mothers of Professional Basketball Players convention, held at a hotel here on the shores of the Mississippi River. She was one of 75 women, most with sons in the N.B.A. and also a handful whose children play for the Women's National Basketball Association, the American Basketball League and even the Harlem Globetrotters, who turned out to laugh and learn, and to share with one another the joys and pains of having a rich, famous and often relentlessly scrutinized child.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: ''There's a bond between all of us because we've had a lot of the same experiences and can relate to one another,'' said Georgia West, mother of the free-agent point guard Kevin Johnson. ''Before, I felt alone with my feelings because my girlfriends didn't understand, because their sons aren't in the N.B.A., but these ladies do. We're like a support group. It's awesome.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: The mothers group was the brainchild of Charlotte Brandon, whose son Terrell is a two-time All-Star point guard for the Milwaukee Bucks. While attending the 1996 All-Star Game in San Antonio, she was struck by the isolation of the players' mothers. Hardly any of them knew each other and many, Brandon said, appeared to be lonely and uncomfortable in the midst of the adoration poured on their sons.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: That weekend, she tossed the idea around with a few other moms, and six months later, 23 mothers, including those of the stars Grant Hill, Gary Payton, Anfernee Hardaway, Shaquille O'Neal and Mark Jackson, met in New York City to found the Mothers of Professional Basketball Players.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: Today, the group's 90 members call themselves a sisterhood and offer examples of the powerful bond they share: how Becky Gatling received calls from nearly 30 mothers in a two-month period while recovering from breast cancer surgery last spring, and how Margje van der Weide, the mother of Indiana Pacers center Rik Smits, flew all the way from the Netherlands to attend last year's inaugural convention in Las Vegas, Nev.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: Becky Gatling said she spoke with either Charlotte Brandon, Marie Jackson, Helen Mashburn or Lucille Harrison, the mother of Shaquille O'Neal, every day. Charlotte Brandon, whose cancer of the colon and liver was diagnosed in 1993, was extremely helpful to Becky Gatling, sharing stories of how prayer and faith helped her overcome the disease. The two built such a bond that their frequent telephone conversations are beginning to infringe on Chris Gatling's time with his mom.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: ''The group is great except for the fact that now when I call my mother, she puts me on hold a lot of times because she's talking to Mrs. Brandon,'' he said in jest.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: Since he entered the league seven years ago, Chris Gatling, now a forward with the Nets, has called his parents after every game. And he is not alone. Nearly every mother said she spoke with her son at least every other day during the season.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: ''I would be willing to bet that almost every player calls their mother every day,'' said Janet Hill, the owner of a Washington consulting firm and mother of Grant Hill. ''That's not true of most 20- to 30-year-old men, but because they have to deal with the pressures of being traded, being a free agent, living in a foreign city, being expected or even wanting to play when they're injured, and being in the relentless media spotlight, they have the need for constant sustenance. I talk to my son five out of seven days. He calls me. There are mothers who would die to speak with their adult sons that often.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: The mothers say the camaraderie they enjoy stems from being able to relax and not worry about one of the bitter fruits of their sons' success: strangers who try to befriend them in hopes of gaining access to the players' money.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: ''Here, the other mothers don't feel threatened, and I don't feel threatened,'' said Carolyn Cato, whose son Kelvin was a rookie with the Portland Trail Blazers last season. ''They're not out to get me. I'm not out to get them.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: Drawing inspiration from the basketball moms, Cassandra Sneed Ogden, mother of Baltimore Ravens lineman Jonathan Ogden, started the Professional Football Players Mothers Association earlier this year.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: While comforting one another is a major goal, the basketball moms are more than a social group. Life in the N.B.A. is as much business as it is basketball, and the mothers feel compelled to tackle the off-the-court issues that can cause their sons problems. At last year's convention, they had Horace Balmer, the league's vice president of security, address them about the women and men who prey on the players in a social scene that can sometimes be out of control. Balmer told them about a woman who, after having sex with players, would save the condom, freeze the sperm and give it to her friends so they could try to get pregnant.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: And this weekend, Yolanda Brooks, a sports psychologist, and Lonise Bias, a motivational speaker and the mother of the Maryland star Len Bias, who died of a drug overdose after being drafted by the Boston Celtics in 1986, spoke about how the mothers can help their sons navigate N.B.A. life.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: In the eyes of the mothers, one of those dangers is the news media. The rash of negative publicity that N.B.A. players have received within the past year -- including a report last year in The New York Times that up to 70 percent of the players smoke marijuana and drink excessively, and a Sports Illustrated article last spring about players who have fathered numerous children out of wedlock -- had the moms on the defensive. Some even said they stopped watching Oprah Winfrey's television show after she followed the Sports Illustrated article with an episode on professional athletes, many of whom were in the N.B.A., being negligent fathers.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: Brandon, whose son Terrell has a 7-year-old son who was born out of wedlock, said of the Sports Illustrated article: ''I didn't like it, and none of the mothers liked it, because what they didn't report was that while some of the men may have children out of wedlock, some of these men are real fathers and not just with their money. A lot of these men really love their children and are taking care of them. I say if you're going to tell the story, tell the whole story. But they're just looking for the dirt. All they want is dirt.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: Marie Jackson, the mother of Indiana point guard Mark Jackson, added: ''This is a new day and a new era, and there are millions of children born out of wedlock in society today, so why focus on these players who are just living in what society dictates today? I don't condone the behavior, but I do condone their right to privacy.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: Despite their unhappiness with the coverage, the women were not blind to the actions of many of the players. Indeed, Brooks, the sports psychologist, drew cheers when she implored the mothers in a Saturday morning seminar to ''teach your sons and daughters the importance of parental responsibility, and that any male can make a child but it takes a man to raise one.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: Becky Gatling said: ''We know that these guys out here are not angels. I tell Chris point blank, 'You know, you need to zip it up and keep it in your pants unless you've got all of this money you want to give away.' I tell him to use a condom or don't do it at all. I don't want any more grandchildren until I'm ready.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: The mothers' words can still fall upon deaf ears. Chris Gatling has a 4-year-old daughter out of wedlock and two paternity suits pending, his mother said. But it's not because he wasn't warned.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: ''One thing about the N.B.A. is that when players achieve their fame and notoriety, immediately somebody is in there trying to tear down everything it took you 17, 18, 20 years to instill in your child,'' said Pamela Martin, the mother of Los Angeles Clippers guard Darrick Martin. ''That's why it's extremely important for you to stay connected to him, whether he wants it or not at that time. You have to continue to make the comments that they may not want to hear. You can't forget that you're their mother, not their friend.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: The mothers are also working collectively to advise players who join the N.B.A. without graduating from college to return to earn their degrees. And they have prepared literature offering guidelines on what to look for in an agent, and when the red flags should go up.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: The moms involved other family members in this year's convention, bringing the total number of participants in New Orleans to 273, including 28 players. Chris Gatling, Terrell Brandon, Malik Sealy and others sat on a panel discussing the stresses of N.B.A. life and came away impressed by the mothers' unity, ambition and willingness to address weighty issues.
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: ''This is a shock to me,'' Minnesota guard Stephon Marbury told the women. ''I thought it was just going to be a bunch of mothers hanging around and eating. But now I think every mother should come to this, and every player should come. It should be a big event because you all really have it going on.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL: Trying to Lift Up Each Other's Arms; Pro Players' Mothers Help Themselves Cope

text: American law-enforcement officials regard Charles Miller as one of the most dangerous and powerful drug traffickers in the Caribbean and have been seeking his extradition for two years. Now the stakes are higher than ever: the State Department says he has threatened to kill American college students enrolled here if the local Government hands him over to the United States.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: Having furnished Mr. Miller with his freedom and the identity he now uses, the American authorities have every reason to take that warning seriously. Less than a decade ago, when he was a police informer called Cecil Connor, Mr. Miller was granted full immunity to testify in a case against Jamaican drug gangs operating in Florida and New York. He acknowledged involvement in nine drug-related slayings and was placed in the Federal witness-protection program.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: Since returning, with American passport, to this country, which he left as a teen-ager, Mr. Miller has been linked by law-enforcement officials to a series of drug-related cases, among them the killings.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: Along with two associates, Mr. Miller, who gives his age as 38, is now wanted in Miami on charges of smuggling nearly a ton of cocaine to Florida. In 1996, a magistrate here refused to allow Mr. Miller to be extradited to the United States, but his decision was overturned by a higher court earlier this year, and new hearings on the petition are scheduled for October.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: ''This is an extremely violent and unstable individual who has acquired a great deal of wealth and exercises a great deal of power,'' said a foreign official with long experience in the region. ''He will stop at nothing to keep from falling into American hands.'' And since St. Kitts and Nevis is the smallest nation in the Western Hemisphere, the official noted, with only 46,000 people, ''Just a little bit of effort goes a long way.''
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean
