text: Mr. Miller's case is emblematic of the difficulties that the mini-states of the Caribbean face in their efforts to combat drug trafficking. More than one-third of the cocaine now consumed in the United States is believed to be shipped through the region, and traffickers are increasingly blatant in their efforts to corrupt governments and encourage local consumption of their product.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: At Ross University and in neighborhoods where the school's 280 veterinary students live, protection has been noticeably beefed up, with agents of the American and local governments as well as private security. University officials said they hoped the 54 students who have withdrawn from classes and gone back to the United States will return when the fall term begins.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: The State Department and the Government of St. Kitts and Nevis, which depends heavily on tourism, have emphasized that no blanket warning to Americans to stay away has been issued. In an interview here, Prime Minister Denzil Douglas said his Government was cooperating fully with the United States and other nations to ''increase and improve security,'' adding that the local police ''continue to keep the suspect under surveillance.''
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: Mr. Miller did not respond to telephone messages left for him. But in a long interview last year, he dismissed the accusations against him as politically motivated and said he had worked for American and British intelligence.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: ''This Government, the British and the Americans, they all wish Charles Miller would be run over or drop dead,'' he said, because of his knowledge of ''all the Machiavellian moves that have been happening here.''
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: As Mr. Miller tells it, he moved to Jamaica in the mid-1970's and was recruited as a political enforcer by the Jamaica Labor Party. He says that the C.I.A. trained him and later helped him flee the Jamaican prison where he was serving a 75-year sentence for armed robbery.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: ''Such allegations are utter nonsense,'' Mark Mansfield, a spokesman for the C.I.A. said in a telephone interview from the agency's headquarters in Virginia. ''This individual has never been employed by or affiliated with the C.I.A.''
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: Once in the United States, court records indicate, Mr. Miller linked up with a Jamaica-based gang to sell cocaine and marijuana in Miami and Rochester. But after being arrested, he turned on the gang to cooperate with prosecutors, giving testimony that led to the conviction of top leaders of the group, and abandoned his identity as Cecil Connor.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: St. Kitts and Nevis has signed a new treaty, awaiting approval by the United States Congress, that would considerably simplify any future extradition proceedings. But the measure is not retroactive, and Government officials here say that any attempt to move against Mr. Miller for the threats made here would only further complicate the existing extradition proceedings.
title: A Turncoat Now Turning On Americans In Caribbean

text: AS you may have heard, Spike Lee is planning to make a movie about ''Son of Sam,'' the serial killer who fatally shot six New Yorkers and wounded seven others between July 1976 and July 1977. Two incidents occurred in my old neighborhood, Forest Hills, Queens. Before he was finally captured, and identified as David Berkowitz, the city was caught up in mass hysteria. Seeing his photo again in connection with the film revived a defining moment of my life, when I was involved with his reign of terror.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: In the summer of 1977, I was 24, and working at my first job when the boss, Arthur, called me in. Arthur was on the phone. He covered the mouthpiece and said: ''David, It's the police on the line. Don't worry, I told them you were a very nice boy.''
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: He handed me the phone. It was a detective from the 109th Precinct in Flushing. He told me to go there immediately. The 109th had been set aside for the Son of Sam investigation. I was scared.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: When I arrived, I identified myself and was whisked off to a room with only a long table and four chairs. The bare white walls looked like soundproofing tiles. I guessed that the tiles would help contain my screams during my upcoming interrogation and rubber hosing. (I loved gangster movies.) On the table was a folder with my name on it. I peeked inside and discovered they were my school records. My first thought was surprise that there really was such a thing as a permanent record. The second was that I was not being called in on a whim. They had been investigating me.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: The door swung open and two detectives introduced themselves. The first one was about 35, with greasy black hair. The other guy, about 55, had a crew cut. I asked them what this was all about, and the younger guy said I had confessed to being Son of Sam.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: When I asked who said that, he said they wished to remain anonymous. For two hours they peppered me with questions. In a calm voice, the older detective asked, ''Do you like girls?'' and ''Do you ride subways?''
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: After my answers, the younger guy screamed, ''Where were you on the night of Feb. 11?'' After I caught my breath, I told him I had no idea. As the interrogation continued, it became apparent that they had been following me for weeks. They knew my friends, Zelmo, Quinder, Joey Hams, the Raccoon and the Baron, and that I smoked pot at Austin Street Playground in Forest Hills. When they were finished, they asked if it would be O.K. to take pictures of me to show to women around my neighborhood. I was too afraid to say no. I just wanted to leave.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: On the way home I realized that I was having dinner at my parents' apartment that night. I decided not to tell them what happened. Before I got a chance to ring the doorbell, the door flew open, my mom pulled me inside and double locked the door. She told me that she knew all about what had happened because she'd had a visitor that afternoon.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: When she asked who it was, the response was ''Homicide.'' She thought I was dead. The cops calmed her down and asked if they could search my old room. She refused, knowing her rights from ''Dragnet,'' and they left. When I asked her why she didn't let them in she said she did not want them to find my marijuana bong. Even though she hated that I smoked pot, she always made sure my bong was clean. She also told me she had not told Dad and was not going to. It would upset him too much and he'd start calling the Borough President and scream at him.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: The next day was my first date with Diane, the accountant from work. We were seeing Led Zeppelin, and my pals Zelmo, Quinder and the Baron were next to us. I was looking forward to showing her off in front of them. Diane was a very pretty Italian girl with jet-black hair. She never showed up and I spent the concert being ridiculed about my imaginary hot date. A call to Diane on Sunday went unanswered. I did, however, run into the wacko old lady from my parents' building, who ran away when she saw me, unusual behavior even for her. I had wondered if she were the anonymous culprit who told the police I could be Son of Sam. Her running away ended my wondering.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: On Monday at work I headed to Diane's office to find out what had happened. The receptionist headed me off and told me that Diane didn't show up because she was scared that I was Son of Sam. It was the hot gossip at work. It never occurred to me that anyone who knew me might believe I was Son of Sam.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: On Aug. 10 the police arrested the real Son of Sam, partly through a parking ticket he had received. It turned out that he was named David, was 24 and was Jewish, all of my credentials. (We were born five days apart in June 1953.) Diane tearfully apologized and we made plans for another date.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: I'm a little embarrassed to admit that once I got over the initial shock of being accused of mass murder, I kind of enjoyed my new-found dangerous status. It was a change of pace from being a sweet and harmless guy.
title: SOAPBOX; One Man's Summer of Sam

text: Despite its merry tunes and brightly colored exterior, the ice cream truck that plied the streets of Bensonhurst was not your typical dispenser of summertime treats for the boys and girls of Brooklyn.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: For one thing, the truck was known to bear down on frightened children riding their bikes, according to a neighborhood resident. For another, there were often three or four teen-agers inside, more than was needed to dole out ice cream cones and Popsicles.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: All this may have made the truck just another neighborhood oddity, were it not for the other things it sold. The hottest items for customers in the know, according to the police, were not the Batman bars, creamy Fudgsicles, or Rocket pops kept in the bins, but the marijuana and hashish sitting in a backpack on the truck's floor. And on Thursday, the police said they had arrested seven people on charges of either buying or selling drugs from the ice cream truck.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: ''It was full service: ice cream, bonbons and weed,'' said Sgt. Richard W. Miller of the 62d Precinct, who led a sting operation that finally put the truck out of business.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: The police said they got wind of the drug truck when undercover officers tried to make a purchase from some dealers at Satellite Park two weeks ago. The dealers said they were out of stock, and suggested that the buyers instead wait for ''the good humor man.''
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: When the truck failed to show, the police went searching, finally catching up with it at Seth Low Park around 6:15 P.M. on Thursday. Among the seven people arrested were the truck's driver, Alexey Zagrebin, 20, and his helper, James LaPointe, 19.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: The five others happened to be in line to buy drugs at the truck with the undercover officers. Two 17-year-old boys in front of the officers bought two $10 bags of hash, then resold them to three 15-year-old boys waiting on the curb.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: ''I don't know if it was an age requirement or what,'' Sergeant Miller said, chuckling. ''They just wouldn't sell to the 15-year-olds. But when our officers got up, they had no problem selling to them.''
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: The police said that Mr. Zagrebin, Mr. LaPointe and the two 17-year-old boys have been charged with criminal sale of a controlled substance, which carries a prison term or juvenile-detention term of no more than six years. They said the three 15-year-old buyers were charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance, which carries a term in juvenile detention of not more than one year.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: The police seized six $10 bags of marijuana and 12 similar bags of hash from the truck at the time of the raid. Mr. Zagrebin told the police that his mother had bought the truck for him in hopes that he would get a job.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: According to the police, Mr. Zagrebin and Mr. LaPointe traveled a daily route around the neighborhood schools and three local parks just in time for children to be getting out of class. And for four months, they were making good money at their illegal trade, Sergeant Miller added, noting that Mr. Zagrebin ''claimed to be making only $200 a day on ice cream, while getting $300 a day for drugs.''
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: Residents around Seth Low Park agreed that the ice cream men had a following, though few had suspected the full extent of the offerings. Mark de Marco, a 27-year-old landscaper, said he often saw the truck around the park when he played basketball with friends. He said one of the men in the truck was rude, barking at those standing in line requesting ice cream.
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: Angel Caro, 30, said that one day he was helping his 4-year-old son, Eduardo, along the park's edge, when the truck began speeding toward some children riding bicycles nearby. ''I was coming out with him, and one guy in the truck started to accelerate very quickly, to chase a couple of kids,'' he said. When he went to chastise the driver, the man said he was just ''trying to knock them over.''
title: Ice Cream Truck Also Did Drug Business, Police Say

text: U.S. Claims Some Success In Cruise-Missile Attacks
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Clinton Administration made measured claims of success for the cruise-missile attacks in the Sudan and Afghanistan on Thursday, saying the attack on a mountainous redoubt in Afghanistan would disrupt training and, possibly, future attacks by terrorists sponsored by Osama bin Laden. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Many Muslims, in mosques, on street corners and from some government ministries, voiced fury over the American missile strikes and predicted that the assault would beget more violence. President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia said he was ''outraged,'' but European leaders generally offered support. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Islamic government of the Sudan invited foreign diplomats to tour the ruins of the plant destroyed by the attack in Khartoum, the capital. But it remained unclear whether the site made precursors for nerve gas, as Washington claims, or whether it was purely a medical manufacturing facility, as Sudan contends. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Pakistan Government condemned the American attack on neighboring Afghanistan, calling it a violation of the norms of international behavior. A7
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Albanian secret police, under the direction of American intelligence operatives, combed Albania for Islamic terrorists suspected of using charity organizations to cover their operations. A7
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: In explaining the decision to strike targets in Afghanistan and the Sudan, the Clinton Administration has been careful to say that the United States was aiming at terrorist organizations and their bases, not at Islam and its adherents worldwide. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Visa Denied to Irish Woman
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The United States Embassy in Dublin said the State Department had denied a visa request from Bernadette Sands McKevitt, a prominent Catholic Republican leader who is widely believed to have contacts with the Real I.R.A., the terrorist group that took responsibility for the car bombing that killed 28 people last Saturday. Ms. McKevitt wanted to seek money from Americans against the Northern Ireland peace agreement. A4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A South African court found former President P. W. Botha guilty of contempt for repeatedly refusing to testify before the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission about atrocities during his rule. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Nelson Mandela of South Africa announced plans for weekend talks with the leaders involved in the civil war in Congo. Aides to President Laurent Kabila said they might participate in the negotiations. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Relief workers have just begun the task of providing food, water, health care and housing to the millions who have been displaced by the floods, even as battles against raging flood waters continue in parts of China. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Public Gives High Marks To President, Not the Man
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton continues to draw high ratings from the American public for his job performance, but his acknowledgment of an improper relationship with Monica S. Lewinskky has produced signs of a darkening public view of both the President's moral character and his overall personal image, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows. Hillary Rodham Clinton is now viewed more approvingly than her husband. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton gave Monica S. Lewinsky more than a half-dozen ''going-away'' presents during their last White House meeting, on Dec. 28, said lawyers familiar with Mr. Clinton's grand-jury testimony. The 20-minute meeting occurred while Ms. Lewinsky was under subpoena in the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit, the lawyers said. At the time, Ms. Lewinsky was preparing to leave for a job in New York that Vernon E. Jordan Jr. was helping her arrange. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A lawyer for President Clinton, warning of a constitutional crisis, asked the Supreme Court to overturn a lower-court ruling that some of the President's advisers must testify in the Lewinsky investigation. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Democrats questioned Speaker Newt Gingrich's decision to attend a free public picnic today that is intended to promote Republican candidates in Washington State. The host is Thomas J. Stewart, a wealthy Seattle businessman who pleaded guilty this year to violating Federal campaign laws and paid nearly $5 million in fines. A9
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Ex-Klan Leader Guilty of Murder
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A jury of six blacks, five whites and one Asian-American in Mississippi convicted Sam H. Bowers, a former Klan leader, of murder for a 1966 firebombing that killed Vernon Dahmer Sr., a black man whose store was used to register black voters. Mr. Bowers, 73, was sentenced to life in prison. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Call for Action in Ramsey Case
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Three former friends of the Ramsey family have asked for a special prosecutor to take over the stalled 20-month-old investigation of the killing of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey. They said the District Attorney in Boulder, Colo., had dragged his feet in prosecuting the case and had overly accommodated the Ramseys. A9
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Drug use by young people increased last year, led by rising marijuana smoking among teen-agers who view it as a ''soft drug,'' a Government survey showed. A11
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Texas Awaits Storm, and Relief
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A tropical storm promised relief to drought-stricken South Texas, but also left residents bracing for strong winds, high tides and flooding. Named Charley, the storm became the first tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico this season. A tropical storm warning extended more than 400 miles, from Brownsville to Cameron, La., while small craft warnings extended from Brownsville to the Mississippi River. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Anti-radiation Drug To Be Distributed
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is preparing to distribute to states with nuclear power plants a drug, potassium iodide, that would block a type of radiation that causes thyroid cancer. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut dismissed a child welfare supervisor and transferred five managers in response to a case in which a 6-year-old New Haven boy who was being monitored by child welfare workers was found dead with signs of abuse. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The debate on the Million Youth March is spreading from government and the news media to the streets and stoops of Harlem, where the organizers plan to hold the event next month. Many residents express support for the idea behind it, but there are also concerns about the potential for violence, talk of shuttered businesses on a busy shopping day, and ambivalence about one of the march's primary organizers. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A gasoline tanker truck created a traffic nightmare when it overturned near Exit 41 on the Long Island Expressway, near Jericho and Hicksville. Homes within a half-mile of the accident were evacuated as a precaution. The driver was slightly injured, the police said. B5
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Views From a Queens Mosque
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The American bombings in Afghanistan and the Sudan did not come up at all during juma -- traditional Friday prayers -- at Masjid Alfalah, a mosque in the Corona section of Queens that is attended by Muslims from many nations. But afterward, it was clear the raids were on everyone's minds. And the feeling among the immigrant worshipers was almost universal: the attacks launched by their adopted country were cruel and plainly wrong. B3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The heightened security measures for public buildings that were ordered by Mayor Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir went almost unnoticed. B3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The man who sold a Long Island memorabilia dealer baseballs supposedly used in David Wells's perfect game said that he wrote the letter authenticating the balls, and then forged the signature of the American League umpire Al Clark. The man, Rich Gressle, said he got six balls directly from Wells about a week after the Yankee pitcher's perfect game on May 17, but was not certain that the balls were from that game. C3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The St. Louis Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire, who has 51 home runs this season, uses a testosterone-producing nutritional supplement, Androstenedione, that is legal in baseball but has been banned in the N.F.L. and the Olympics. C1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Elastic Day on Wall Street
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A volatile day of trading ended with stocks only moderately down. The Dow plunged 280 points just before noon, then bounced back to end the day at 8,533.65, a loss of 77.76 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent. The Nasdaq closed down 34.84 points, or 1.9 percent, at 1,797.61. D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The stocks of big money center banks were down 4.52 percent as a group for the week, while large regional banks plunged 3.14 percent as a group. D3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: AMP, a leading maker of electronics equipment, rejected a $10 billion bid from Allied Signal, igniting a hostile takeover battle. AMP, which dismissed Allied Signal's all-cash offer as too low, also overhauled its top management and appointed Robert Ripp, formerly executive vice president, as chairman and chief executive. D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, which has come to symbolize the problems of Japan's banking system and the Government's slowness in addressing them, announced a revamping that paves the way for an injection of public funds and increases the likelihood of an eventual merger with Sumitomo Trust and Banking. D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Backing Out of the Market
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: After a weeklong buying spree to prop up the slumping stock market, the Hong Kong Government let the free market take over, and stocks promptly tumbled. D2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Editorials: Taking on the terrorists; Russia's environmental dissident; due process for Medicare patients; young Mr. Lincoln?
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Columns: Frank Rich, Thomas L. Friedman.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr.
title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation

text: It was called Proposition 200 and it seemed straight-forward enough when it appeared on Arizona ballots in the fall of 1996. Backed by a well-financed grass-roots organization that called itself Arizonans for Drug Policy Reform, it proposed allowing doctors to prescribe marijuana and other illegal drugs for medical use by grievously ill and dying patients.
title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation

text: The Arizona Legislature, one of the most conservative in the country and in no mood to have the state join California and Washington in the much-debated national push to legalize illegal drugs for medical use, saw the proposition as a legislative end run by a special interest group that had more in mind than just compassion for the sick. Legislative leaders said that while marijuana was the drug most talked about by Proposition 200's proponents, the measure as written, would also permit doctors to prescribe other illegal drugs like heroin, LSD and PCP.
title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation

text: The legislature then amended the measure, adding a rider that said Arizona doctors could not prescribe a drug not on the Federal Government's list of approved drugs. That amendment effectively gutted the measure.
title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation

text: But the fight did not end there.
title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation

text: Arizonans for Drug Policy Reform, having renamed itself The People Have Spoken, now has another drug proposal for voters to consider. Labeled Proposition 300 and scheduled to be on this fall's election ballot, it would restore Proposition 200 to its original form and instruct the legislature not to modify it again.
title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation

text: Fighting back, state lawmakers are making sure that this time around, the official ballot description of the proposition is worded so voters will understand that they are deciding not whether to legalize not only the use of marijuana for medical purposes but also other illegal drugs.
title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation

text: Two weeks ago, The People Have Spoken, whose major supporters include George Soros, the international investor whose interests include major social issues, asked a judge to throw out the lawmakers' description of the measure, arguing that it was unfair for the legislature to be in a fight in which it alone wrote the rules of engagement. The court refused and the pamphlets now are being readied for distribution.
title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation

text: In boxing there are lists of the top boxers and lists of the boxers the top boxers will not fight. Among welterweights, Jose Luis Lopez, ranked No. 2 by the World Boxing Association, is at the top of both lists.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Oscar De La Hoya, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, said that Lopez is the fighter he would least like to face.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: ''It's a logical way of thinking,'' Lopez said following a workout at Marciano's Gym here Wednesday afternoon. ''He knows I am one of the toughest opponents he will face and I Swill beat him.''
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: He added later: ''No one has really punched him the way he needs to be punched. No one has put the pressure on him the way he needs to be pressured. No one has fought him.''
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Lopez (41-3-2 with 32 knockouts) does not lack confidence, but with two nuclear warheads at the end of both arms, he should not. Lopez will meet Ed Goins on the undercard of the Arturo Gatti-Ivan Robinson show at Bally's Park Place in Atlantic City on Saturday night as part of HBO's ''Boxing After Dark'' series. Fernando Vargas, the brilliant young junior middleweight, will fight Darren Maciunski on the same card.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Lopez said he does not know anything about Goins, and that is one of the things that the veteran trainer Lou Duva likes about Lopez.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: ''He's the only fighter I've handled who doesn't care who he's fighting,'' said Duva, who co-manages Lopez. ''He'll fight anybody, whether it's De La Hoya or Trinidad.''
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Lopez put Ike Quartey on the canvas twice during their world championship bout last Oct. 17 at Foxwoods Casino in Connecticut, and fought to a 12-round draw. He calls it a wasted opportunity. Two months later at Foxwoods, Lopez scored a five-round technical knockout against Ronnie Johnson, but tested positive for marijuana. In his next fight he scored a second-round technical knockout over Sammy Fuentes on May 9 in Sacramento, Calif.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Lopez presented a piece of paper written in Spanish, showing that he was clean during a test for marijuana that was conducted at a lab in California on Aug. 14. Lopez said he is voluntarily taking the test to show his promoters, Main Event, that he is clean and is giving his all to win a championship.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Prince Naseem Hamed and his London-based promoter, Frank Warren, have ditched Kennedy McKinney as the opponent for Hamed's Oct. 31 bout in Las Vegas, Nev. Wayne McCullough, a native of Belfast, Northern Ireland, who lives in Las Vegas, has replaced McKinney.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: It's a raw deal for McKinney, who has been waiting for eight months through on-and-off negotiations and delays to fight Hamed. The July 18 bout between the two was postponed, because Hamed was said to have hurt his hand in training. But many believe he put off the fight because he wanted to spend time with his new baby. McKinney was to make $750,000 for the bout.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: ''The Prince is scared of Kennedy McKinney or Frank Warren is the worst individual I've met in this game,'' said Murad Muhammad, McKinney's promoter. ''It's got to be one or the other. I can't put any intelligence to anything else.''
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Certainly, the match is a strange move considering Hamed's stated reason for fighting here was to face America's best featherweights. A bout between Hamed of Sheffield, England and McCullough, who won a silver medal for Ireland in the 1992 Olympics, in London or Dublin would have been a major box office draw in Britain.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Ike Quartey's headaches got worse Wednesday. The World Boxing Association stripped him of his welterweight title, because he could not make his mandatory defense against the No. 1 contender, Andrei Pestriaev of Russia. Quartey of Accra, Ghana was supposed to fight Pestriaev today, but pulled out of the fight because he was diagnosed with malaria.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: A vacant title could open the way for Pestriaev and Jose Luis Lopez, the No. 2 contender, to fight for the championship. Quartey has a Nov. 14 date with Felix Trinidad, the International Boxing Federation champion. If it does not come off, it won't be because Quartey doesn't have his title. It will be because a Federal judge in Manhattan would not grant Trinidad an injunction against the promoter Don King.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Trinidad and King are involved in a legal wrangle over the validity of Trinidad's contract with the promoter. Trinidad recently signed a contract with Main Event as his promoters and with HBO.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Negotiations are under way for a Dec. 5 bout between Roy Jones, Jr. and Graciano Rocchigiani of Germany. A possible site for the bout would be Biloxi, Miss. . . . Miguel Angel Gonzalez and Kostya Tszyu will fight for the World Boxing Council junior lightweight championship on Oct. 24. David Reid and James Coker will meet in a junior middleweight bout on the undercard.
title: Lopez Pokes Words at De La Hoya

text: Fame easily finds a place like this, with its climate so embracing, its surroundings so inspiring and its population leavened so liberally with artists and new immigrants.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Yet, as a fortune cookie in one of Vancouver's countless Chinese restaurants might read, fame is fleeting, and what is fabulous one day can turn very foul the next.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Vancouver is quickly gaining a reputation as a haven for illicit drugs and those who use them. From the brazen addicts shooting up and buying heroin and cocaine around the intersection of Hastings and Main Street to the enormous amount of high-potency marijuana that is raised, sold and openly smoked on streets and in cafes, Vancouver's tolerance of drugs is attracting attention.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''I heard that you could smoke and nobody bothered you,'' said Adam, a lanky 19-year-old from Seattle who came with two friends for an overnight trip. They easily bought marijuana on the street around Hastings, then -- somewhat shyly -- entered the Cannabis Cafe, a marijuana mecca for many west coast Americans.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: While one friend picked at a green salad mixed with a few hemp seeds, Adam took out a joint and, somewhat uneasily, lit it. Soon he relaxed. ''It's a good environment cause you can't smoke cigarettes, you can only smoke marijuana,'' he said. ''You don't have the smoky bar atmosphere, just a pleasant smell.''
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Other customers casually lit up their joints and the smell of marijuana was as inescapable as popcorn at a movie theater.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''Vancouver is the most tolerant spot in Canada when it comes to different life styles and cultures,'' said Sister Icee, a 38-year-old Toronto woman once known as Shelley Francis who has owned the cafe, and the Hemp BC store next door, since April.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Although the police have raided the place three times (once since she took over and twice last year under a different owner), the Cannabis Cafe still celebrates marijuana. On the wall is a painting of the Virgin of Guadalupe, Mexico's patron saint, who stands serenely in her starred gown, surrounded by tall marijuana stalks. The menu put together by the chef, Christopher Anstee, features pasta with hemp pesto, salads with hemp dressing and quesadillas that use hemp tortillas made by a man named Melvin.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''There's no harm in it,'' said Sister Icee. Lighting an oversized, filtered joint, she said she lived for most of the 1980's in the West Indies, where she became a Rastafarian, getting her new name and her introduction to marijuana, ''the weed of wisdom.''
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''Marijuana is a plant,'' she said. ''You can't prosecute people for smoking flowers. It shouldn't be regulated any more than parsley or broccoli.''
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: For city officials, the Cannabis Cafe is a public-relations nightmare.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''We don't like the reputation that things like that bring to the city,'' said Bruce S. Chambers, chief constable of the Vancouver police department.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: After the last raid in April, the police charged Sister Icee with selling drug paraphernalia in the Hemp BC store. On a recent visit, the store carried shoes, shirts and snowboards all made with hemp, along with pipes, bongs and rolling papers.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Now, the city intends to deny Sister Icee the licenses she needs to run the store and cafe, working through the City Council, not the courts.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''They're going to be toast by September,'' said Vancouver's Mayor, Philip Owen.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Cannabis Cafe is only one part of Vancouver's problem.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''Vancouver has been called Vansterdam, and we're not proud of it,'' said Ken Doran, an inspector with the Police Department's drug unit.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: The police have raided and shut down 82 hydroponic marijuana growing operations this year, confiscating $14 million worth of pot. The growers use basements, attics, sometimes entire houses to put out high-yield crops, Chief Chambers said.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Police analysts say the pot is grown under such favorable conditions that it is high in tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC -- the chemical compound that gives marijuana its punch. The THC content is 25 to 28 percent, compared to the 2 percent or less that was common just a few years ago, the police said.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: British Columbia marijuana has become so popular that United States Customs Service agents have increased patrols to try to slow down the cross-border trade.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Beyond marijuana, Vancouver estimates that there are as many as 15,000 IV drug users in British Columbia, most of them in Vancouver.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Almost any time, the area around Hastings and Main crawls with addicts, many drawn by the cheap rooms or the free needle-exchange program that gives out about 2.5 million needles a year in an effort to fight AIDS. The police say the all-night grocery stores in the area that carry a few cans of soup and packages of cookies are just fronts for drug buys.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: In recent weeks, the province's coroner announced that drugs had killed a record 201 people in the first half of 1998, the majority of them in Vancouver. Then a medical report indicated a vast need for treatment programs and proposed that hard-core addicts be given free heroin to keep them from robbing to support their habits, a position Chief Chambers conditionally supported.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''It's time somebody steps forward and says the war on drugs is lost,'' said Chief Coroner Larry Campbell.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: The national police force, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, is unwilling to concede defeat. Richard Barszczewski, who heads the Mounties' drug awareness program in British Columbia, noted however that law enforcement alone cannot solve the drug problem.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: The city itself is divided by the drug problem and unsure of what to do next. Mayor Owen and Chief Chambers say that prosecutors and judges are just too soft on people convicted of drug charges.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''We give sentences that we believe are appropriate,'' said Robert W. Metzger, chief judge of the provincial court, in response to the criticism. ''People like to point to judges because we're easy targets. But this seems to be a social and political problem.''
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Libby Davies, the member of Parliament who represents the area around Hastings and Main, calls for more national funds to cope with Vancouver's drug epidemic. She supports not only providing free heroin to hard-core addicts, but clinics where they can safely inject.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: Ms. Davies is not concerned that such programs, already tried in Europe, might cement Vancouver's reputation as the Amsterdam of North America.
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: ''The situation at Hastings and Main couldn't get worse,'' she said. ''This is not about the city's reputation. It's about saving lives.''
title: Vancouver Journal; A Laid-Back Place Overdoses on Drug Culture

text: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE BACKGROUND
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: On Jan. 20, 1997, as an ebullient Bill Clinton took the oath of office for the second term that he hoped would secure his place in history, he returned to a theme that had been at the core of his claim to be a new kind of Democrat, declaring: ''Each and every one of us, in our own way, must assume personal responsibility, not only for ourselves and our families but for our neighbors and our nation.''
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: One year later, Mr. Clinton learned that Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, was investigating accusations that the President had started a sexual relationship with a White House intern in 1995 and then tried to cover it up.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: Had the man who won the Presidency by speaking out for the people who ''play by the rules'' once more surrendered to a lifelong compulsion to bend and break them? Tonight, in the most painfully personal public confession of his life, and perhaps in American political life, Mr. Clinton was forced to acknowledge, in tight and reluctant tones, that he had.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: ''I must take complete responsibility for all my actions, both public and private,'' Mr. Clinton said, adding that he had answered ''questions about my private life, questions no American citizen would ever want to answer.''
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: How someone of such surpassing intellect and such protean political talents could indulge in such reckless conduct at a time when he knew a special prosecutor was already scrutinizing his Administration and when his own re-election still hung in the balance remains the most puzzling question about William Jefferson Clinton. But it is not a new question, and in some ways it was predictable that this President should have come to this pass, his promise once again shadowed by his shortcomings.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: For Mr. Clinton has always been convinced that he could outsmart, out-talk, out-charm and outlast any adversary, and very often, enough to confirm that conviction, he has. In the darkest days of the 1992 primaries, he dared to campaign on a platform of personal responsibility, despite widespread questions about his own marital fidelity, marijuana use and draft record, and widespread doubt that his answers were candid or complete. In his first term, he shifted ground so many times that even his best friends sometimes said they did not know where he stood.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: Time and again in the risky running melodrama of his public life, Mr. Clinton has treated the truth as an a la carte menu.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: On Jan. 21, as news of the accusations involving Monica S. Lewinsky came out, Mr. Clinton told National Public Radio: ''I don't know any more about it than I've told you, and any more about it, really, than you do.''
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: Even tonight, Mr. Clinton insisted that when he testified under oath in January that he had not had a sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, his answers were ''legally accurate,'' though he added: ''I did not volunteer information.''
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: In the end, such sweeping elisions of reality lie far beyond the ken of conventional political analysis. But professionals who have studied the arc of Mr. Clinton's life and career have suggested some answers.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: ''Most people wish to think well of themselves,'' wrote Stanley A. Renshon, a political scientist and psychoanalyst at New York University in his 1996 study of Mr. Clinton, ''High Hopes.'' ''However, Bill Clinton appears to have come to believe the best of himself and, either to avoid or discount evidence from his own behavior, that all is not as he believes it to be. He attributes to himself the most sincere and best of motives. His errors, when acknowledged, are the result of basically correct efforts gone temporarily awry, misunderstandings that, if one knew more of what he knew, would disappear or be mitigated, or else are attributable to naivete and inexperience.''
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: Mr. Clinton may have come by his capacity for denial and compartmentalization naturally. They were among the qualities that allowed his widowed mother, Virginia Kelley, to persevere after Mr. Clinton's father died three months before he was born, and that allowed Mr. Clinton to make what most critics regarded as a splendid State of the Union address just days after the intern scandal broke.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: ''When bad things do happen, I brainwash myself to put them out of my mind,'' Mrs. Kelley wrote in her autobiography, published after her death in 1994 under the President's review. ''Inside my head, I construct an airtight box. I keep inside it what I want to think about and everything else stays behind the walls. Inside is white, outside is black: The only gray I trust is the streak in my hair.''
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: But gray is Mr. Clinton's favorite weapon. It has been central to his successes and to his setbacks. As Governor of Arkansas and then as a Presidential candidate, he succeeded in blurring old distinctions of ideology, proclaiming himself neither liberal nor conservative but ''new.'' As President, he at first promised both a tax cut and new spending, then raised taxes instead. Two years later, he apologized for raising taxes too much, claiming that Congress had forced him to do so, a claim at sharp variance with the facts.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: This is the man who pledged not to raise taxes ''to pay for my programs'' (he raised them to cut the deficit), who said he had never ''broken the laws of my country'' (he tried marijuana as a Rhodes Scholar in England), who defended his campaign finance practices by saying he had never ''changed Government policy solely because of a contribution.'' His reputation for shading the truth grew so encrusted that he faced semi-serious questions from reporters over trivial matters, from his golf scores to whether he really shot two ducks on a New Year's outing in Arkansas, or just carried some that were shot by others.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: Many times, Mr. Clinton has accepted responsibility and forsaken blame. After his 1980 defeat after one term as Governor of Arkansas, his political consultant Dick Morris advised him to apologize for past mistakes, like raising taxes and car license fees. Mr. Clinton resisted repeated entreaties to say he was sorry, devising his own folksy formulation for a television commercial: ''When I was a boy, my daddy never had to whip me twice for the same thing.''
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: In fact, the only daddy Mr. Clinton knew was an alcoholic stepfather who sometimes beat his mother, not him. And the President has spent a great part of his life being whipped, often quite publicly, for repeating his own mistakes. In his very first run for office, in 1974, his girlfriend, Hillary Rodham, reportedly sent her father and brother to help on his Congressional campaign because she worried about the rumors of his multiple romances on the road.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: In 1992, faced with accusations by Gennifer Flowers of a 12-year sexual affair, Mr. Clinton said, ''That allegation is false,'' acknowledged causing pain in his marriage and largely put to rest an issue that had derailed the 1988 campaign of Gary Hart. But under oath in his deposition in the Paula Corbin Jones civil suit this year, Mr. Clinton acknowledged sexual contact with Ms. Flowers.
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: Over the years, Mr. Clinton has occasionally articulated a personal hierarchy of relative wrongdoing, once blurting out in a conversation with reporters aboard Air Force One -- apropos of nothing -- that it was the money-changers in the temple who really made Jesus mad, not the adulterous woman, of whom Jesus said in the Book of John: ''He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone at her.''
title: Strong at Politics, Weakened by Lapses

text: Headlines are calling it the moment of truth. We'll see.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Presidential candidate Bill Clinton went on the ''60 Minutes'' program right after the Super Bowl in late January 1992 to clear up the Gennifer Flowers mess. The idea was to tell the truth, to be straight with the American people, and thus save his damaged candidacy. Here's what happened. With more than 30 million viewers looking on, and with Hillary Clinton at his side, he lied.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: It worked. The Flowers story, replete with taped conversations between Ms. Flowers and Mr. Clinton, was so sordid the press was uncomfortable with it and the public soon grew sick of it. When Mr. Clinton came in second in the New Hampshire primary in February, he dubbed himself ''the comeback kid.''
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Within weeks of the ''60 Minutes'' appearance, Mr. Clinton was facing new questions about how he had avoided the draft during the war in Vietnam. He didn't want to be seen as a draft dodger. If he won the nomination, he would be facing George Bush, who had a strong record of service in World War II. So, as he so often does, Mr. Clinton gave the truth the slip.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Had he received a draft notice or not? Did he escape simply by virtue of a high number in the draft lottery or had he pulled strings? Was he a committed anti-war activist willing to pay a price for sticking by his principles, or just a coward willing to let others fight and perhaps die in his place?
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Who knew? The candidate told so many stories, crafted so many evasive answers, came up with so many lame excuses that he gave everybody a headache. The public got tired of the matter and the story went away.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: It took Mr. Clinton years to come up with the classic ''I didn't inhale'' response to questions about marijuana. He danced around that issue like Fred Astaire, saying he hadn't broken this law, or violated that statute. We've gotten used to it. It's as if the idea of a straight answer to a difficult question is completely alien to the man.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Now he is going before a Federal grand jury in an effort to salvage what remains of his Presidency. Just about every question he'll be asked will be tough. The danger is that he has woven so many lies he'll be trapped in his own insidious web.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: The issue at the moment is not about impeachment. The Republicans have neither the clout nor the inclination, based on what is now known, to remove Mr. Clinton from office. Rather than fiddling with the dangerously unpredictable bomb of impeachment, the Trent Lotts, Newt Gingriches and Orrin Hatches of the world would much rather see the President, the hope of so many Democrats, sitting humiliated in the White House through the year 2000.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: The real issue is the President's relationship with the American people. Mr. Clinton's poll numbers may be high but the nation's sense of trust in its President is collapsing. He lied about Gennifer Flowers. He seems to have lied about Monica Lewinsky. Why would it not be plausible to believe he lied about Paula Jones and Kathleen Willey? Or, for that matter, about delicate foreign policy issues, or legislative deal-making, or favors granted to fund-raisers?
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Mr. Clinton's strength in the polls, I think, is the result of an economy that is going well, the contemptible qualities of so many of his enemies, the reluctance of a large number of Americans to turn even more power over to the ideologues in the Republican Party, and certain personal qualities that have long benefited Mr. Clinton -- his charm, intelligence, good looks, work ethic, resilience and toughness.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: None of this will matter if he lies to the grand jury, or if he looks the public in the eye and lies again about that woman, Ms. Lewinsky.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Mr. Clinton is getting advice, solicited and unsolicited, from many quarters. Most of his longtime advisers and close friends are urging him, directly or indirectly, to tell the full truth to the grand jury and the public.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Is he capable of telling the truth when the going gets tough? Who knows. If it turns out he's not, the last two years of his already damaged Presidency won't be worth much. At some point the public will lose its patience, even with Bill Clinton.
title: In America; Clinton's Own Web

text: Chris Webber of the Sacramento Kings was fined $500 for carrying a small amount of marijuana that was detected by dogs at the airport in San Juan, Puerto Rican customs officials said yesterday.
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: Webber had 11 grams of marijuana in his luggage when he was detained during his layover in San Juan. He then resumed his trip from the Dominican Republic to Barbados. Webber was traveling with Jerry Stackhouse of the Detroit Pistons and other athletes on a trip sponsored by the sporting goods company Fila.
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: The customs department said that because of the small amount of marijuana involved, Webber was not cited for smuggling and would not be prosecuted for possession.
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: This is the latest in a series of legal problems for Webber, who was traded in May from the Washington Wizards to Sacramento. Webber is awaiting trial for a January arrest that stemmed from a traffic stop on his way to practice with the Wizards in Maryland. He faces charges of marijuana possession, second-degree assault and resisting arrest.
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: The National Basketball Association and its players are in the midst of a lockout. Only heroin and cocaine are currently covered in the drug agreement between the N.B.A. and its players union. (AP)
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: Maravich's Son Plans to Walk On
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: Jaeson Maravich, the 18-year-old son of the late basketball great Pistol Pete Maravich, has decided to play for Alabama, arriving as an invited walk-on.
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: The 6-foot-5-inch Maravich averaged 17 points and 6 rebounds as a senior at St. Paul's High School in Covington, La., two seasons ago. Hoping to hone his skills and get a Division I scholarship, he transferred to New Hampton Prep School in New Hampshire last year but a back injury forced him to miss the entire season.
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: His father was named one of the N.B.A.'s 50 greatest players for its first 50 years. The elder Maravich died in 1988 of heart failure when Jaeson was 8.(AP)
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: Suzie McConnell Serio scored a career-high 19 points last night to lead the playoff-bound Rockers to a 90-71 victory over the Washington Mystics in Cleveland, again dropping the Liberty a half-game back in the Eastern Conference standing.
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: Cleveland (19-10) can claim the Eastern Conference championship and second seeding in the playoffs with a victory tomorrow night at New York (18-10). A victory by New York would give the Liberty the conference title.
title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure

text: The rolling fields of Max Yasgur's old farm are once again swathed in a psychedelic quilt of tie-dye-clad music fans. This time, though, the fans are carrying cellular telephones, and the automatic teller machines are just a few steps away.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: ''I think high-tech is kind of infringing on the hippies,'' said Kevin Carter, who was working at a one-hour photo development stand, one of the many commercial vendors at a three-day concert called ''A Day in the Garden,'' on the site of the original Woodstock festival. ''Some of the die-hard Woodies are having problems with it.''
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: It was 29 years ago this weekend that hundreds of thousands of flower children flocked here for a three-day festival of peace, free love and music that defined the era and turned these hayfields into a pilgrimage site for generations of Americans.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: In 1969, they drove, walked or danced into the fields, guided only by the spirit of the moment. Today, a clicking, fluorescent highway sign beckoned concertgoers off Route 17. From there, the New York State Police directed traffic. The edge of the concert area was marked by a line of ticket booths, where the Gerry Foundation, which now owns the Yasgur fields and organized this weekend's event, charged $35 per person per day. (Admission was free for children under 12.)
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: Event organizers said that 12,000 tickets had been sold for Friday and that 4,000 to 6,000 children had come in free. They estimated that 22,000 people attended today's performances, including about 6,000 children. State troopers estimated a slightly smaller crowd today, about 18,000 to 20,000. As it is currently set up, the Woodstock site can accommodate 30,000 fans.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: The performers today included some brand-name 1960's stars like Richie Havens, Lou Reed, Joni Mitchell and Pete Townshend of the Who. Organizers, however, said they expected the largest attendance on Sunday when 90's bands, including Goo Goo Dolls and Third Eye Blind, are scheduled to play.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: This weekend's event was so carefully orchestrated -- with prearranged traffic patterns, dedicated parking, security and medical personnel -- and the crowd, including many parents with young children, was so mellow, that this hardly seemed the same place immortalized by marijuana-smoking hippies dancing naked in the mud.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: To get down the hill to where the musicians were performing on a state-of-the-art stage (the same one Garth Brooks used last summer in Central Park), concertgoers had to pass by a wide area of vendor tents.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: For $20, Cornelius Alexy was selling peace sign necklaces fashioned from pieces of the ''original'' chain-link fence that surrounded the Yasgur property in 1969 -- complete with a certificate of authenticity. Across the way, pastrami sandwiches could be bought for $7 each. Beer cost $3. For the more health conscious, there was a fruit and juice bar.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: More than a mile away, at Max Yasgur's old farmhouse, hundreds of stalwart defenders of Woodstock Nation gathered to protest the commercialism. They said the corporate takeover of Yasgur's farm had robbed them of their annual pilgrimage to the '69 concert site.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: ''These are the people who were at the original Woodstock,'' said Rebecca Swan, 55, who drove from Texas to the original concert and now travels the country living in an old yellow school bus. ''These are the people who wish they were at the original Woodstock or people who love the idea of the original Woodstock. These are people who are being prevented from making their pilgrimage and expressing their beliefs by rich people and the government.''
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: Ms. Swan acknowledged the irony in the battle that is currently brewing between the Gerry Foundation, which owns the original concert site, and another group, Woodstock Ventures, which owns the name and the rights to the original Woodstock event. At the same time, some of the fans who attended the '69 concert have a lawyer pressing their case for free access to the site.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: Such controversy, however, did not intrude on the concertgoers who were enjoying the modern-day amenities. As the folk singer Melanie began to play this morning, there were already lines at a bank of Bell Atlantic public telephones and at the portable A.T.M.'s that were trucked in by Fleet Bank.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: Concert organizers said they tried to modernize without undermining the event's hippie soul. ''We developed 10,000 parking spaces,'' said Michael J. DiTullo, a vice president of the Gerry Foundation. ''Not with blacktop, of course, with green, with grass.'' He said the foundation has big dreams for Bethel, including possibly developing rock-and-roll resort hotels. ''This will be the venue of the next millennium,'' he said.
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: Most importantly, the fans said, they came for the music. ''We came in on Thursday and set up the tent, and Don Henley was tuning up,'' said Mike McGrath, 43, of Newburgh, N.Y. ''It was great.''
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: Gwynne Watkins, an 18-year-old Joni Mitchell fan from Richmond, N.J., said she came to recapture the essence of a bygone era. ''There aren't enough concerts like this,'' she said. ''Everything is always enclosed, where you can't meet anybody and you can't see anybody.''
title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's

text: I did not like the letter written by Derek Sherman (Mailbox, Aug. 9). It is typical of much of the derisive, surface-scratching-only drivel chasing Coach John Thompson and Georgetown around the country. Let me give you some facts and some logic, not Sherman's misrepresentations.
title: Thompson's Record

text: In his first 13 years as Georgetown's coach, Thompson was 297-107 for a .735 winning percentage; the second 13 years: 292-126 (.699). He has reached three Final Fours and three championship games, winning one of them. In the last 13 years, Georgetown has reached the final eight three times (1987, '89, '96), not once, as Sherman claims.
title: Thompson's Record

text: Sherman discusses talent next. He mentions Mourning and Mutombo and Smith and Williams and Wingate and Iverson. How about Turner, Tucker, Tate, Edwards, Harrison, Harrell, Myles, Bell, Butler, et al.? Those are some of the ones who wrecked the integrity, the chemistry, the planning, the teamwork of those they left behind. Don't talk to me about ''talent'' and ''plenty of it'' and the failure to reach the Final Four, unless you're prepared to talk about the quitters. Maybe they wouldn't study; much of it comes down to that, doesn't it? They just couldn't hack it. No excuses; I just want performance on and off the court. That is what life is about.
title: Thompson's Record

text: Sherman talks about ''player conduct'' and brings up Victor Page, Kenny Brunner, Ed Sheffey and Allen Iverson. Page, pure and simple, was not a student; he flunked out. Is it that big a deal? As for attacking another player while in the pros, nothing like this happened while Page was at Georgetown. Sheffey: when he was caught speeding (and marijuana was in the car), Coach Thompson immediately pulled the kid's scholarship. You take responsibility for your actions at Georgetown. Brunner? He was at Georgetown for five months, and he transferred out to Jerry Tarkanian at Fresno State. Need I say more?
title: Thompson's Record

text: Maybe Sherman's most deceitful diatribe is about Iverson, a kid whose biggest shortcoming may be his ability or inability to choose friends. Because Iverson has had some off-court problems in the pros, Sherman draws the conclusion that players are not receiving ''effective guidance during or after their stays at Georgetown.''
title: Thompson's Record

text: Sherman concludes that you ''end up with a picture of inner city kids used for their athletic skills, and then dumped back into the world.'' That statement flies in the face of everything Thompson has stood for. Sherman has chosen a couple of players who have had some problems, and he has painted the entire program as being tainted. By doing so, he has flaunted history and reality.
title: Thompson's Record

text: Coach Thompson has given opportunity where none existed, to some who never knew the meaning of the word. He has created hope and understanding; he has protected and shielded and taught, and there isn't a soul in the world who has come in contact with him who isn't better off for it.
title: Thompson's Record

text: The Olympic gold medalist Gary Hall Jr., suspended after testing positive for marijuana, is free to compete again.
title: Suspension Is Lifted On Gold Medalist

text: FINA, the Swiss-based International Swimming Federation, informed Hall by letter Wednesday that it lifted the suspension. The letter was signed by FINA's honorary secretary, Gunnar Werner.
title: Suspension Is Lifted On Gold Medalist

text: I am pleased that the situation with FINA has been resolved, Hall said in a statement yesterday. It allows me to concentrate properly on what I believe I do best -- competitive swimming.
title: Suspension Is Lifted On Gold Medalist

text: Hall, 23, was suspended last month by FINA, which said he tested positive for marijuana during a May 15 competition in Phoenix. FINA's decision prevented Hall from participating in the recent Goodwill Games in New York.
title: Suspension Is Lifted On Gold Medalist

text: The Phoenix resident had tested positive for marijuana during the 1996 Olympics. FINA added marijuana to its banned list just before the Atlanta Games, but the rule did not take effect until after the competition.
title: Suspension Is Lifted On Gold Medalist

text: The City Council today designated the Oakland Marijuana Buyers' Cooperative as officers of the city, an effort to shield the group from Federal civil and criminal prosecution.
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: The Department of Justice had won a temporary restraining order in May against the Oakland cooperative and five other medical marijuana providers in Northern California, claiming that they were in violation of Federal laws. Three of cooperatives shut down, while the others, including the one in Oakland, have defied the Federal court ruling.
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: Oakland officials and the cooperative had worked together since the passage of a 1996 state initiative that allowed medically prescribed marijuana to be distributed to any ''seriously ill'' Californian. Last month, the council voted to allow each medical user up to a pound and a half of prescribed marijuana, which the council views as a three-month supply.
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: ''We decided we needed to be out on the frontier, to ease the suffering of those in need,'' Councilman Nate Miley said at a brief ceremony at Oakland City Hall. ''We're delighted to offer the cooperative all the support we can, and hope that other cities will follow suit.''
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: Jeff Jones, the executive director of the cooperative, accepted the designation on behalf of his group, which distributes the drug to more than 1,500 people to treat the effects of illnesses like cancer and AIDS.
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: ''This is a great day for our patients and a great day for Oakland,'' Mr. Jones said.
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: Federal officials had no immediate comment on the designation. But Gregory King, a spokesman for the Justice Department said, ''We're aware of the decision, and we're in the process of reviewing it.''
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: Lawyers for the cooperative were less guarded.
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: ''Today's designation will permit the Oakland Cannabis Buyers' Cooperative staff to distribute medical cannabis within Federal law,'' said Gerald F. Uelmen, a professor at Santa Clara University School of Law. ''That means the Federal Government has no case.''
title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana

text: F.B.I. Finds Pieces Of Nairobi Bomb Truck
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The F.B.I. agent in charge of investigating the bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi said fragments of the truck that carried the explosives had been found, and that the bureau was piecing together a picture of what happened in the seconds before the bomb went off. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The remains of 10 Americans killed in Nairobi were flown home, accompanied by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright; President Clinton received the flag-draped coffins at a solemn ceremony at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: After initial surmises that the bomb that exploded outside the American Embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, was attached to an embassy-owned water truck, investigators are shifting their attention to other possibilities. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Rebels knocked out all electrical power to Kinshasa and tightened their hold on a strategic region outside the Congolese capital after seizing the Inga dam, by far Africa's largest hydroelectric generator. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Stock and bond prices in Russia plunged, jarring Russian hopes that the Government could avert a depletion of its finances and a meltdown of the banking system. Capping a week of ominous declines, the major blue-chip index dropped as much as 15 percent before the Federal Securities Commission stepped in and halted trading. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The American Government, which had steadfastly refused to finance programs to help Colombia's coca growers switch to legal crops, is now shifting course and agreeing to pay for so-called alternative development under the country's new administration. A2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The ethnic Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova named a team to negotiate peace with the Serbs that did not have the ingredient that diplomats consider essential to success: representatives of all ethnic Albanian political forces. It lacks any representatives of the rebel army fighting Serbia's rule of Kosovo, meaning its authority to reach agreements is doubtful. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Clinton Administration has retreated from its pledge of immediate military punishment if Iraq interferes with arms inspectors. Instead, senior Administration officials said, the act that would bring retaliation from Washington had shifted to Iraq moves to produce weapons of mass destruction or to threaten its neighbors. A4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A $1.25 billion settlement between Holocaust survivors and Swiss commercial banks accused of profiting from the Nazi era led officials in several states to cancel sanctions against Swiss financial interests, even though the disbursing of the money will take a long time. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Clinton Said to Discuss Acknowledging Sexual Act
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton has discussed with his inner circle a possible strategy of acknowledging to a grand jury on Monday that he had a specific type of sexual encounter with Monica S. Lewinsky, while still maintaining that he told the truth in January when he testified in a deposition that he and Ms. Lewinsky had never had ''sexual relations,'' because of how that term had been defined, senior advisers said. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Prosecutors briefly questioned several more Secret Services officers before the grand jury investigating the Lewinsky matter. A16
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Federal appeals court in California has ruled that Medicare patients are entitled to immediate hearings and other protections when they are denied care by H.M.O.'s. It also said Medicare officials had failed to enforce their own rules and had improperly renewed contracts with H.M.O.'s that violated the rules. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A judge in Chicago ruled that two boys, ages 7 and 8, who are charged with killing an 11-year-old girl could return home to await trial, but must wear electronic monitoring devices and stay inside 24 hours a day. A12
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Seven Succumb to Desert Heat
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The bodies of seven people were found in Southern California near the Mexican border, apparently victims of the heat as they tried to enter the United States illegally. A12
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The relatives of two Holocaust victims reached agreement with a pharmaceutical company heir over ownership of a Degas landscape apparently looted by the Nazis during World War II, in the first such case to be settled in the United States. The Art Institute of Chicago will acquire the work, with both sides receiving credit when it is on display. A17
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The City Council in Oakland, Calif., designated the Oakland Marijuana Buyers' Cooperative officers of the city in an effort to shield the group from Federal civil and criminal prosecution. A15
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Web Site Accused of Deception
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The F.T.C. said the Geocities Web site lied when it told two million adult and child subscribers that it would not disclose personal information without permission. A15
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Federal officials are investigating whether an air traffic control center in Cleveland has routinely hidden evidence of operational errors, in which planes are mistakenly ordered to fly too close to each other, after discovering three such incidents on June 23 that went unreported. A19
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Danger to Fish and Humans
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Pfiesteria piscicida, a toxic microbe blamed for killing millions of fish in the Chesapeake Bay region, can cause a serious but reversible neurological syndrome in humans, researchers said. A14
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Reading Exam Scores Drop In City's Public Schools
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The percentage of New York City public-school children who passed this year's state reading exam for third, sixth and eighth graders fell sharply from last year. Officials were stumped by the results, considering that schoolchildren posted impressive gains on the city reading exam taken two weeks earlier. B3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Project of Joy and Sorrow
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Mayor Giuliani and other officials celebrated the opening of the Third Water Tunnel and somberly recalled the 24 people -- tunnel diggers (called sandhogs), engineers, inspectors and a child who fell into a shaft -- who died during the more than two decades of construction. B3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Governor Pataki questioned whether the State Board of Regents had the authority to approve or reject a plan by the City University of New York to bar remedial students from CUNY's senior colleges. B5
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Call for Financial Diversity
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: New York City's economy is more heavily dependent on Wall Street's fortunes than it was before the stock market crash in 1987, according to a report by the office of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall. He said the city and the state should further diversify their economies. B8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Tyson Shifts Focus to Nevada
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Mike Tyson withdrew his application for a boxing license in New Jersey one day before the State Athletic Control Board was to render a decision. Tyson instead applied to Nevada -- the state that revoked his license last year after he bit off a piece of Evander Holyfield's ear. C1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Cendant, struggling to regain investor confidence during an accounting scandal, reported that profits for the first half of 1998 were robust -- but that more than $640 million of the profits reported for the last three years were fictional. D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Kmart and the Gap reported quarterly earnings that were better than expected, aided by the strong economy and a return to the basic fashions favored by their customers. D2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Excluding automobiles, retail sales rose for the sixth time in seven months. D2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Russia Gives Market the Jitters
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Concern over Russia's economy helped push American markets lower. The Dow closed at 8,459.50, down 93.46 points, or 1.1 percent. The S.& P. 500 fell 9.31 points, to 1,074.91, and the Nasdaq lost 22.99 points, closing at 1,802.54, a 1.3 percent decline. D9
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Editorials: Saddam Hussein makes his move; reviewing CUNY's admissions policy; the staggering Russian economy; Verlyn Klinkenborg at a Yankees game.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Lucian K. Truscott 4th has never been shy about pointing -- or, more precisely, wagging -- his finger at his hallowed alma mater, which looms tall and imposing above the Hudson River here.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: In a quarter century of novels, newspaper articles and television appearances, and most famously in his best-selling 1978 mystery ''Dress Gray,'' Mr. Truscott has chided the United States Military Academy and the Army for secrecy and chastised them for sexism and homophobia, describing flawed societies too often governed by prejudice and personal ambition.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: That holds true in Mr. Truscott's new novel, ''Full Dress Gray,'' published by William Morrow & Company last month. Once again, the academy's immaculate grounds are suffused with the stench of foul play. Once again, its Gothic edifices are cauldrons of duplicity and deceit, bubbling over with sexual violence.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: The surprise is not what's in the pages of Mr. Truscott's potboiler. It's the academy's response.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: The academy bookstore has set up two signings for Mr. Truscott on Friday. The superintendent has invited him over for coffee before the first one. The academic dean has asked him to dinner after the second.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater
