text: ''I thought I would never be welcome up there again,'' Mr. Truscott, who graduated from the academy in 1969, said in a telephone interview the other day from his home in Los Angeles. ''Now they're in the process of milling a whole new red carpet to run out for me.''
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: That may be a bit of an overstatement. But Mr. Truscott is certainly getting a reception unlike any he has experienced in the past, and his trip to West Point this week reflects a larger, longer journey that the academy itself has taken, traveling over recent years toward greater openness and a more measured, sophisticated response to criticism.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: ''It's a different era in the evolution of West Point,'' said Brig. Gen. Fletcher M. Lamkin Jr., the academic dean, in an interview here today.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: General Lamkin, dressed in an olive and forest green camouflage uniform, was all warm smiles as he spoke of his keen interest in meeting Mr. Truscott. ''I find him interesting,'' General Lamkin said.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Besides, he added, ''There's nothing wrong with bringing controversial people to West Point,'' pointing out that during the last academic year, both the folk singer Pete Seeger, who protested vigorously against the Vietnam War, and the gender-bending pundit Camille Paglia, whose sexual candor rivals Madonna's, gave speeches at the academy.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Although the academy's current administrators were not around when ''Dress Gray'' was published, they said their understanding was that it was greeted with a less tolerant, less sanguine attitude. Mr. Truscott certainly remembers it that way, and news reports from the time back him up.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Although the bookstore carried the novel, active duty officers were reportedly forbidden to make public comments about ''Dress Gray,'' which imagined the murder of a gay cadet at the academy and an elaborate cover-up by officers to conceal what had happened.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: The official academy newspaper ran a prepublication review, written by a public affairs officer, that described ''Dress Gray'' as an effort to ''foist a story of perversion and intrigue on a setting totally at odds with such a set of happenings.'' When the book was subsequently made into a TV mini-series, the setting was changed to a fictive military institution in part to ward off cries of protest from West Point.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, who was the superintendent of the academy when ''Dress Gray'' was published, said that he could not recall any official policy regarding the book, but that it was generally considered an ''assault on West Point.'' He never contemplated meeting Mr. Truscott, he said.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: ''He was then regarded as an enemy of West Point,'' General Goodpaster, now retired and living in Alexandria, Va., said in a telephone interview.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: But most cadets interviewed at random at the academy today had heard little or nothing about ''Full Dress Gray,'' and the current superintendent, Lieut. Gen. Daniel W. Christman, talked about Mr. Truscott in relatively flattering terms. ''I've been very impressed with his writing,'' General Christman said.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: General Christman said that in ''Full Dress Gray,'' Mr. Truscott correctly reasons that ''institutions that stay hog-bound to tradition for no other reason than that it's tradition quickly become irrelevant.''
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: ''It's a wonderful read on those issues,'' General Christman said.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: His complimentary words can be attributed in part to subtle differences between ''Full Dress Gray'' and its predecessor. The tone of the new book is less heated, and its protagonist, Ry Slaight, who was a cadet bucking a corrupt power structure in ''Dress Gray,'' is now part of that power structure, proving that there are heroes and good intentions in high places.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Still, there is plenty for the academy to loathe in ''Full Dress Gray,'' which involves the mysterious death of a female cadet; a senior officer engaged in adultery with another officer's wife; brutal misogyny among male cadets, and intimations of gang rape.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: The salient change from ''Dress Gray'' to ''Full Dress Gray'' is in the climate surrounding each book. Senior officers at the academy said that in the late 1970's, the academy was smarting from a widely publicized cheating scandal in 1976. Also, like the Army for which it was training officers, the academy was still reeling from an anti-military sentiment in the United States that had carried over from the 1960's.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: ''It was a tough time,'' General Christman said. ''Everything was tarnished by Vietnam and the overtones of that.''
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: But the more positive public reaction to America's most recent war, with Iraq, has relaxed the military's defensiveness. And the less obvious role of the military in the aftermath of the Cold War behooves it to take a friendlier approach toward public relations.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: ''I think there's a real knowledge and understanding that at a time when we are at peace in the world, when there is no massive, solid support for the military and people question the need for it, you've got to be more sophisticated in dealing with the public and the press and critics,'' said Dave Palmer, a retired lieutenant general who was the academy's superintendent from 1986 to 1991.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Indeed, the academy gives more access to reporters and camera crews than it ever did in the past, though it does not throw caution entirely to the wind. Public affairs officers emphasized that administrators interviewed for this article were expressing personal opinions about ''Full Dress Gray'' and not any official academy position.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: The academy's relatively unbothered reaction to ''Full Dress Gray'' may also acknowledge that while some of the scenarios in Mr. Truscott's novel are riper than reality, the sexual tensions and transgressions he describes merely echo a spate of actual scandals in recent years.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: And the liberalization of the Army as it pursues better integration of men and women has nudged many officers closer toward the end of the political spectrum from which Mr. Truscott has always fired off his critical salvos.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Mr. Truscott, 51, the descendant of high-ranking Army officers, wrote for The Village Voice when he was at West Point, belonged to a group of cadets who mounted a successful legal challenge to the constitutionality of compulsory chapel services and was considered a leftist rabble-rouser.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: His relations with superiors in the Army were so bitter that he was released from his obligation of service and given an other-than-honorable discharge about a year after he left West Point.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: He described the academy and the military then as sometimes bullying and mean-spirited societies rife with suspicion toward anyone with dissenting political views. Academy officials, looking back at Mr. Truscott's record, said he was a nonconformist who later admitted, in his writing, to using marijuana as a cadet and mescaline as an Army officer.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: ''He probably should have been at Berkeley, not West Point,'' General Lamkin said.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Less than a year ago, the two men met electronically on a restricted Internet chat group for West Point alumni and faculty, and they struck up something of a cyberfriendship, finding at least one common cause: the defense of West Point against accusations from the right that the academy, which began admitting women in 1976, has suffered from the feminization of its warrior culture.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Although the civilian managers of the bookstore were the ones who actually invited Mr. Truscott to the academy, General Lamkin and General Christman seized the opportunity to meet him.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: Mr. Truscott said that perhaps the passage of time and the softening of his voice had made academy administrators understand that his intention was not to vilify West Point but to make it a better place.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: But he also divined a possible strategy behind the academy's hospitality.
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: ''They know I do the 'Today' show,'' he said. ''They know the kind of visibility I've got. I think they've concluded that it's better to have me inside the tent than outside the tent yelling at them. That's simply the way institutions, when they grow up and get smart, behave.''
title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater

text: In my 1960's youth, America couldn't stop talking about -- or taking -- a drug that promised sexual ecstasy and a sensory trip. If memory serves, it was called marijuana and, though widely available, was illegal. Three decades later, the new national drug of choice also promises sexual ecstasy and, as a potential side effect, what the Food and Drug Administration describes as mild temporary perceptual ''changes in blue/ green colors.'' It is called Viagra, and not only is it a legal prescription medication, but anyone with a credit card can score some over the Internet without even seeing or speaking to a doctor. I know because I did.
title: Journal; Electric Kool-Aid Viagra

text: Viagra is the emblem of our fin-de-millennium drug culture. On the market only since April, it has spawned a cottage industry in humor, not unlike all the stoned comedy of the 60's, and is minting money for Pfizer, its manufacturer. Pfizer ''has refined the art of publicizing a 'blockbuster drug' . . . not unlike the way Hollywood releases a summertime action flick,'' writes the journalist Greg Critser in his Salon magazine report on the sprawling Viagra industry. ''It's kind of off the charts,'' said a Pfizer spokeswoman last week, sounding very Hollywood as she talked about Viagra's box-office.
title: Journal; Electric Kool-Aid Viagra

text: The same spokeswoman assured me that ''we don't have a sense that there is any kind of widespread abuse of this product.'' She also said that ''You can't go into a pharmacy and talk your way into a Viagra tablet without a prescription.'' Nonetheless, it's not hard to find anecdotal evidence that Viagra is being used, however improperly, as a recreational aphrodisiac by both men without erectile dysfunction and by women (for whose use it has not been cleared by the F.D.A.). An Internet site titled ''How and Where to Obtain Viagra'' advises: ''If you can't get it from your doctor, try your local junior high school!! The girls in the junior high school near to where I live have it and are selling it to each other.''
title: Journal; Electric Kool-Aid Viagra

text: If you go into the widely used Web search engine Infoseek -- in which Disney owns a big stake -- and merely type in the word ''Viagra,'' an ad immediately starts flashing ''Free Viagra'' and leads to an on-line purveyor. At another site promoting the Viagra-hyping book ''The Virility Solution'' by Steven Lamm, an assistant professor at the New York University School of Medicine, a link speeds you to a cyberstore called The Pill Box Pharmacy. There you click agreement to a waiver of liability, fill out a simple questionnaire any way you wish, pick your own dosage and -- party on!
title: Journal; Electric Kool-Aid Viagra

text: Though Pill Box wouldn't fill my order when I clicked ''no'' to erectile dysfunction, it did accept a deliberately vague boilerplate description of some ''problem.'' The pills soon arrived by UPS from San Antonio, Tex. I was charged an additional $85 for a ''consultation'' with a doctor whose name I learned only from the pill bottle. He not only didn't talk to me, but he didn't consult with my primary-care physician to verify my purported medical history or see if I was telling the truth when I said I was not taking medications known to interact dangerously with Viagra.
title: Journal; Electric Kool-Aid Viagra

text: I asked Michael Risher, of the Lindesmith Center, the drug-policy research group, why our national drug warriors look the other way at such flagrant Viagra madness while railing against, say, the medical use of marijuana. He said that ''perception'' rules: Viagra, after all, has the fatherly imprimatur of the irreproachable Bob Dole. (We all know which national figure is the poster boy for marijuana.) Yet even as drug use among the young is being fought by a Clinton-and-Gingrich-endorsed ad blitz costing taxpayers nearly $1 billion, what kind of mixed messages are adults sending kids? The same ad industry that is making the anti-drug spots speaks out of the other side of its mouth by pushing grown-up-sanctioned drugs like alcohol and nicotine, not to mention an exponentially increasing number of prescription pharmaceuticals.
title: Journal; Electric Kool-Aid Viagra

text: A drug culture is a drug culture is a drug culture, whether the illicitly obtained gateway high of choice for a teen-ager is marijuana or any legal, heavily promoted medicine that's perceived as life style enhancing, no matter what its side effects or long-term consequences. Viagra brings benefits to many legitimate patients, not to mention stand-up comics, but who's the real butt of the jokes? Call it an acid flashback to the 60's, but I'm taking my phone off the hook to avoid all the friends coming after my stash.
title: Journal; Electric Kool-Aid Viagra

text: With an absent father and a single mother who could not control her five sons, Shatiek Johnson fell into a world of drugs and gangs and angry shootouts long before he was old enough to vote.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: His father is a convicted drug dealer. So is his oldest brother. Another brother was involved in a wild gunfight. Violence was never too far away in the Staten Island public housing projects where the family lived. Two gangs, the Bloods and the Wolfpack, competed to control the local market for marijuana and crack cocaine.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Now charged with the shooting death of Police Officer Gerard Carter, Shatiek Johnson is the teen-ager whose sullen face, framed by chocolate-colored dreadlocks, is flashed regularly on the television news. To Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, the 17-year-old ex-convict symbolizes the failings of the state's prison early release program. To the police who arrested him, and who mourn the death of Officer Carter, he is a remorseless thug who they say killed without conscience.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: The dysfunctional picture of Mr. Johnson that emerges from interviews with police investigators, prosecutors, neighbors and friends is of a teen-ager described as once being a ''nice kid'' who loved to play basketball. But by age 15, he had been convicted of manslaughter for the beating death of a homeless man. Now, in addition to Officer Carter's fatal shooting, Mr. Johnson will soon be indicted in the killing of a rival gang leader.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: On Thursday morning, when a reporter knocked on the front door of the sixth-floor West Brighton Houses apartment where Mr. Johnson lived, his mother, Betty Johnson, refused an interview, shouting, ''Get away from my door!'' Affixed to the door were two stickers from the rap supergroup Wu-Tang Clan. The members of the group were raised in Staten Island housing projects, and their lyrics depict a bitter world of ''stickup kids, corrupt cops and crack rocks.''
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: It is that world that residents say can be found in West Brighton Houses and a neighboring public housing complex, Markham Gardens Houses, the world that produced Shatiek Johnson. Here, there are scores of hard-working people trying to raise families. Many of the children play in a softball league organized by the police, including the late Officer Carter.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: But, two longtime residents said, young men also come and go from prison in bunches, like seasonal harvests. The drug trade is so active that another tenant said customers often just drop money out of their apartment windows to waiting sellers.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: So deep is the distrust of outsiders, particularly the media, and so genuine is the fear of retribution for speaking out, that few residents interviewed were willing to give more than first names. And in an eerie example of the interconnectedness of people in the neighborhood, the police and local residents say that Mr. Johnson and Officer Carter, the man he is charged with killing, were once briefly related by marriage.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Residents, police investigators and prosecutors depicted the two neighborhoods, though relatively benign in appearance, as increasingly menaced by the Bloods in Markham Gardens and the Wolfpack in West Brighton. Once considered little more than teen-age wannabes -- local girls used to mock them as ''fake'' Bloods -- these gangs had grown more violent recently, fighting over who would control turf to sell crack and marijuana.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: ''They know that whenever we collide out here, there's going to be a war, and there are going to be more bodies,'' said Chris, a 28-year-old resident of Markham Gardens who identified himself as a member of the Bloods. He said the Bloods sell crack in ''the Markham'' while the Wolfpack controls the drug market in ''the Projects,'' as West Brighton Houses is known. Police detectives also confirmed this balance of power.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: According to Chris and to police investigators, Shatiek Johnson was a member of the Wolfpack. Until he turned 10, he had lived in Markham Gardens, but housing officials said the family moved into a bigger apartment in West Brighton Houses in March 1991. It was far from a stable atmosphere. Shatiek's father, Tony Lovett, did not live with the family; one neighbor said he peddled hats and shirts on the side of the road. Mr. Lovett was an avid Knicks fan and, according to some, a likable guy. But he also sold drugs.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: The two oldest brothers, Tarsheen and Karscine, also ran into trouble. Now 26, Tarsheen is serving 6 to 12 years in prison after a string of convictions for burglary, sodomy and criminal sale of controlled substances. Karscine, 24, was linked to a 1995 shootout in front of Scotty's, a graffiti-splattered convenience store situated between the two housing complexes. He was charged with fatally shooting two men -- including Robert Young, the biological father of his baby sister, Josslyn -- but he pleaded guilty to a lesser weapons charge in 1996 after witnesses recanted their testimony. Last week, Karscine Johnson was arrested on an outstanding warrant for drinking in public.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Friends of Betty Johnson describe her as a well-intentioned mother. ''She did her best for her kids,'' said Jamila Pass, 21, who said she had known the family for years. ''She's a single parent raising six kids by herself.''
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: But Ms. Pass and others say Ms. Johnson could not control her family. One neighbor described loud shouting matches. On some nights, the neighbor said, teen-agers spilled out of the Johnson apartment, smoking so much marijuana that the fumes seeped beneath his closed door. Complaints had been filed with the Housing Authority, which had already banned Tarsheen and Karscine from public housing. Ms. Johnson was also threatened with eviction.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: ''The whole family,'' said Hilly Gross, a Housing Authority spokesman, ''seems to be problematic.''
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: On March 25, 1996, Shatiek Johnson and a friend, Kinte Carter, walked to a local liquor store, Papa Joe's. It was Shatiek's 15th birthday. Outside the store, the two friends fought with Richard Martin, described in a police report as a homeless alcoholic.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: David Lehr, chief assistant district attorney in Richmond County, said the dispute was over $10. In his confession, Mr. Carter said he struck Mr. Martin only in self-defense; he also said that Mr. Johnson had tried to break up the fight. Mr. Martin died the next day, and though his death was initially attributed to natural causes, an autopsy found that his spleen had been ruptured and his ribs cracked.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Witnesses told the police that Mr. Johnson had helped Mr. Carter kick the victim as he lay helpless on the ground. Though not considered the aggressor, Mr. Johnson pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was given a one- to three-year sentence at a youth detention center. He was denied parole in February 1997 but was released last April 10 because of state guidelines that mandate freeing any prisoner who has served two-thirds of his sentence without any major infractions in prison.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Mr. Johnson returned to West Brighton Houses and at some point became a member of the Wolfpack. ''He wasn't one of the tough guys,'' said a West Brighton Houses tenant who said he has known the family for more than a decade. ''He was a very nice guy. I don't know what changed him.'' Maybe, the tenant said, ''he wanted to be down with the guys. He got involved and he got caught up in it.''
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: The rivalry between the Bloods and the Wolfpack had intensified with the coming of summer, but it exploded on July 16 with the slaying of Eric Trotman at Markham Gardens. Police investigators described Mr. Trotman as a member of the Bloods. He was discovered shot 14 or 15 times.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: ''Trotman had a gun, this kid had a gun,'' Mr. Lehr said. ''He kills Trotman before Trotman kills him. That's allegedly what happened.'' Nicknamed ''Confidential,'' Mr. Trotman was considered a ''superior,'' or leader, of the local Bloods gang, according to Chris, the Bloods member. When word spread through Markham Gardens that Mr. Johnson was the shooter, Chris said the Bloods quickly put out a ''contract'' on him.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: ''We wanted Shatiek,'' Chris said.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: The police released a picture of a youth suspected in the Trotman slaying. Ten days later, on the evening of July 26, Officer Carter and his partner, Eric Storch, were patrolling the courtyard in West Brighton Houses when they saw a youth who fit the description of the suspect. Police officials said the two officers kept driving, again checking the picture before returning to the courtyard. Without warning, the police said, the youth fired through the windshield, striking Officer Carter in the head.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Early the next morning, an emergency services police unit captured Mr. Johnson inside a West Brighton Houses apartment after an armed standoff. When Officer Carter died four days after the shooting, Mr. Johnson's grim image was broadcast all over New York City as a teen-age cop killer. Another suspect in the Trotman killing, Jason Walker, was arrested on Tuesday, the police said.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Charged with second-degree murder in the slayings of Officer Carter and Mr. Trotman, Mr. Johnson faces 25 years to life on each count. He is not eligible for the death penalty because he is not yet 18. His lawyer, Alex Shulman, said Friday morning that he would fight to suppress a confession in which Mr. Johnson reportedly admitted to both slayings. Mr. Shulman said he might have Mr. Johnson submit to a psychiatric evaluation. Mr. Shulman also described his client as ''respectful and cooperative.''
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: In the aftermath of the shootings, West Brighton Houses residents say the police are now constantly patrolling -- and harassing -- tenants. One mother said she was awakened early in the morning last week by officers searching for someone who had stolen a child's bicycle. In Markham Gardens, two young mothers said they have been stopped by police officers and asked why they were wearing red clothing, considered the color of the Bloods.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Chris, the member of the Bloods, said the police presence has pushed the gangs into hiding. But he also noted that the ''contract'' on Mr. Johnson remains in effect, even while he is in prison. For now, Mr. Johnson is under protective custody at Rikers Island, but a police detective noted that ''he's got a problem when he goes into the population of a jail.'' As for Mr. Johnson's family, they seem to want only to be left alone. His mother has avoided the media. And on Wednesday, the youngest brother, 14-year-old Ramik, rode around West Brighton Houses on a bicycle.
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: ''Why don't you just leave us alone?'' he told a reporter. ''The man is locked up now. Just chill.''
title: In a Violent Place, a Violent Life; Gangs and Guns Shaped Suspect in an Officer's Death

text: Jewish teen-agers with yarmulkes stuck firmly to their heads were diving off the stage in the Ali Baba room at the Aladdin Hotel, their fringes flying and their fists raised in joy.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: ''Awesome!'' shouted one, falling into the melee of dancers below.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: Onstage, Yosi Piamenta and the Mizrahi Rockers were ripping through what they billed as their first ''all-night rave,'' a marathon self-promoted concert for which they charged $12 a head. It drove hundreds of their fans into a frenzy of whooping, stomping, Jewish rock-and-roll ecstasy that lasted until 5 A.M.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: Outsiders -- and plenty of older-generation insiders -- might well be puzzled at the partying in the heart of this Orthodox Jewish community in the Catskill Mountains. But for those familiar with Mr. Piamenta's heavy metal Hebrew jams, the music is a natural outgrowth of their religious exuberance.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: ''My father's a rabbi in Denver, and he's cool with this,'' said Basi Twerski, 25, an elementary-school teacher in Brooklyn. ''Maybe I shouldn't be saying this, but most of the people here probably listen to rock radio and everything. This is just a way to do it that's kosher.''
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: Mr. Piamenta, an Israeli-born rock guitarist who became a Hasid, shrugged at the notion of a conflict between an all-night rave and his Orthodox faith, which prohibits women from joining their boyfriends on the dance floor or even from moving to the music by themselves.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: This was, he said, not a rave in the typical drug-induced, dance-party sense. There were no blinding strobe lights or bumping and grinding couples.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: ''Hey, you can't wear the tsitsith and say, 'Come on, baby,' '' Mr. Piamenta said, laughing and pointing at the fringes worn to remind Orthodox Jews of God's commandments.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: Widely acknowledged by rock critics as a guitar virtuoso, Mr. Piamenta, who now lives in Brooklyn, delights in swinging his Fender Stratocaster behind his head and playing backward, a la Jimi Hendrix, while he sings in Hebrew.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: His set list ranges from Hebrew versions of popular hits like the 1982 tune ''Down Under'' by Men at Work to his own religiously themed jams. ''The music is maybe a little scary to some people, but the message is kosher,'' said Rebecca Lillian, 39, a rabbi from Skokie, Ill., who has been a Piamenta fan since the 1970's, when she heard him in Israel.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: Saturday happened to be the first Sabbath, known as Shabbos Nachamu, after a three-week period during which Orthodox Jews do not eat meat, drink wine, celebrate in any way or listen to music. Now they were ready to cut loose.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: ''Miss it?'' said Michelle Newman of Brooklyn. ''It drove me crazy not hearing music for so long.''
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: ''It's really not surprising to see this,'' said a 36-year-old diamond dealer from Great Neck, N.Y., who was watching the frenzy. ''The Orthodox are not afraid to be spiritual.''The dealer added, ''And hey, it's as close to Jerry Garcia as Orthodox Judaism's going to get, right?''
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: Mentioning the late guitarist and leader of the Grateful Dead appears to be unavoidable at Mr. Piamenta's concerts. With his full beard, tie-dyed shirt (adorned, of course, with religious fringes) and a psychedelically embroidered skullcap, the ''Sephardic Santana,'' as he is sometimes called, makes no apologies for embracing the trappings of the counterculture.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: ''For 20 years I've been doing concerts for Jews, when really my thing is rock-and-roll,'' Mr. Piamenta said. ''I'm a Jewish rock-and-roller.''
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: Still, Mr. Piamenta, 46, who has six children, admitted to feeling ''dead'' the morning after his all-night show. His working weekend was not over yet. In the afternoon he would be back in Brooklyn to play another concert, and in the evening, a bar mitzvah in New Jersey. (For years, weddings and bar mitzvahs have been Mr. Piamenta's main means of support, though he recently broke into the New York City club scene with gigs at the Knitting Factory and Wetlands, both in TriBeCa.)
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: ''He's good, real good,'' said Police Officer Jason Berger, 28, of Fallsburg. ''I'm the only Jewish cop anywhere around here, so I had to stop by and check it out.''
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: There was no hint of marijuana in the air, no underage drinking, and other than hundreds of fans smoking cigarettes, no evidence of any typical rock show vices.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: Rock fans will be rock fans, however, even here. While they restrained themselves from leaping onto the dance floor, the women grooved quite expressively from their wooden chairs.
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: ''In our culture,'' Ms. Newman said, ''we can't really go out there, but we love the music.''
title: Rocking All Night, in Hebrew

text: From the morning at church to the afternoon barbecue of ribs, chicken and shish kebabs, Reginald Washington's entire day has led up to this singular Sunday ritual, the cruise.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: Mr. Washington's car, a blue and beige Ford Bronco with gleaming mag wheels and tinted windows, was washed and waxed in the morning. And before he meets up with fellow members of the Hustler Nation car club in the afternoon to caravan to the cruise, he polishes the tires and knocks the dust off.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: As the crown jewel of the urban social scene, the cruise draws parents and children, blacks and Latinos, teachers and students, and gang members who set aside their rivalries for a day to celebrate cars in the capital of car culture.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: But Mr. Washington will not be cruising the south Los Angeles hallmark spot, Crenshaw Boulevard, glorified by the movie ''Boyz N the Hood'' and rap music videos. Instead, he is in the parking lot of a social services building more than 60 blocks to the south. As with the earlier, great cruising scenes of Hollywood, the San Fernando Valley and East Los Angeles, the authorities are cracking down on cruising Crenshaw, remembered by one lowriding historian as the last cruise in Los Angeles. About the only cars cruising there now on Sunday nights are black and white, and they say POLICE on the side.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences held a 25th anniversary party last month for ''American Graffiti,'' a celebration of cruising and coming of age. But some Crenshaw residents and business owners do not share the enthusiasm for the movies' real-life counterpart, disliking the noise, the traffic and the reputation that cruisers say is undeserved as a draw for crime.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: The police have been trying to rid Crenshaw of cruisers for at least the last two years. It has become virtually impossible to cruise because the police have been pulling over drivers on Crenshaw on Sunday nights for the slightest infractions.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: But cruising endures, as best it can, by becoming more a park than a cruise, though it moves to a nearby intersection after dark.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: Once he arrives at the parking lot, Mr. Washington, 29, known to friends as Double R, and his friend, Roderick Davis, survey the scene: muscular rap beats boom from car stereos to compete with the busy strains of salsa as hundreds of people pass the late afternoon into the evening flossing -- showing off -- their cars, flirting, catching up with friends and sipping Corona beer. With the drifting scent of marijuana in the air, some bet on dice games and hop competitions, seeing which cars, powered by trunks full of batteries and hydraulic suspensions, can bounce the highest.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: ''It's just about cruising,'' Mr. Washington said. ''It's California. California swinging.''
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: But losing Crenshaw disappoints Mary Sneed, a 60-year-old retired collection agency worker better known as Moms. She has been cruising since she was a member of the Lowriding Mamas of Compton three decades ago. She said cruising was a positive way for young people to channel their energy.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: Though the new spot lacks the glory of Crenshaw, Mr. Washington said, it is better because it will give cruisers a place to go without being bothered by the police. But that, too, is now in question. One day last month, the parking lot was closed to Sunday cruisers, and officers issued about 70 traffic tickets. The crackdown came one week after three people were shot during the cruise.
title: Los Angeles Cruising Enthusiasts Gather, Despite Roadblocks

text: A Flower Child might not recognize the place.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: Here at Haight and Ashbury Streets, ground zero of the 1960's counterculture revolution, a Ben & Jerry's ice cream store now stands on one corner, a Gap clothing store on another.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: They are hardly the only reminders of mainstream America's plunge into The Haight, a neighborhood that threw open its psychedelic arms to the hippies and misfits whose Summer of Love more than 30 years ago became part of the national conscience.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: But along with the trendy stores, specialty restaurants and nearby Victorian houses that sell for $1 million and more is perhaps The Haight's most compelling change, one that is less discernible to the roving eye. While the now romanticized flower children were painted as being spiritually connected by political ideology and the haze of a marijuana high, many young people on the same streets today share the common pain of broken lives and harder drugs.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: ''It's like the kids back then came here, to something, and it was a dream for many of them,'' said Jim Beck, president of the Haight Ashbury Neighborhood Council, a citizens' organization. ''Kids here today are running from something, and for a lot of them it's the nightmare in their past.''
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: A 19-year-old who calls herself Froggy sat on a newspaper rack in front of Ben & Jerry's. Reared by foster parents, she said she found her biological mother when she was 9 and lived with her for four years. She then set out on her own and hitchhiked here from Los Angeles.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: ''She didn't want me in the first place,'' Froggy said, with a sad expression. ''So I took off.''
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: She wears a tall, red hat and makes her way in the world by selling drugs, which she said she intends to do until she saves enough money to buy a house in Montana. She sleeps nearby in Golden Gate Park.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: Froggy said she liked life on the streets of The Haight. But Beth, who is 18, does not. Beth said she came here from Austin, Tex., with her boyfriend ''two and a half lousy months ago'' because they had never seen California.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: ''Then he got sent to jail on four counts of assault with a deadly weapon,'' she said. She also sleeps in Golden Gate Park and begs for money until she gets disgusted with doing that.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: ''People throw three pennies in your face and tell me to get a job,'' she said. ''I hate this place.''
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: Thomas, 23, has the hollow eyes of a ghost and wears a hood over his head. Another Texan, he said he just got out of a hospital after overdosing on drugs. Unlike Froggy and Beth, he has a place of his own to sleep -- his car. He said he made money by selling drugs, but now had no idea what he was going to do.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: ''I wish I was back home,'' he said.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: The streets are filled with people like Froggy, Beth and Thomas among the chronic homeless who are everywhere in San Francisco and constitute a major problem for city agencies. Local officials say that at night as many as 5,000 people need shelter, and the city can accommodate fewer than half of them.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: But here in The Haight, the roaming population of homeless teen-agers, many of whom buy and use drugs like heroin, cocaine and methamphetamine, is trying the patience of a community that has prided itself on tolerance, understanding and the social services it provides, like medical care from the Haight Ashbury Free Clinics, founded in 1967 to help low-income families.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: A flier on the front window of the Haight Ashbury Music Center says: ''Take Back The Haight. Enough of the constant mess. No more begging, stealing, littering, hopelessness, despair and bad drugs.''
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: It was written by Steven Capozzola, a resident of Ashbury Street, who asked business owners to display the flier because he had ''grown tired of the mess -- of coming home from work and encountering an endless barrage of chaos, filth and waste.''
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: ''I just had enough,'' he said.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: Ed Pasqualin, the manager of the music store and a longtime resident of The Haight, said complaints about the street life were cyclical. He and other residents say they have grown loud again because area businesses are doing well, but the Froggys of the world are creating an edginess to the daily routine that annoys residents and could drive away customers.
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: ''The Haight has always been tolerant of the freedom of personal expression. Even people who own the fancy homes support that,'' Mr. Pasqualin said. ''But when you reach a point where people have no respect for the life style others want to live, and working folks feel harassed because they can't walk the streets, that's when it gets pretty frustrating.''
title: San Francisco Journal; Wayward Youth Try Patience of Haight-Ashbury

text: A Quick Killing in Art.
title: Hyped to Death

text: Illustrated. 385 pp. New York:
title: Hyped to Death

text: PHOEBE HOBAN leaves little to the imagination in her unsettling biography of the painter Jean-Michel Basquiat. Maybe that is as it should be, since Basquiat, who died in 1988 of a drug overdose at the age of 27, was emblematic of an age of mass media and a culture of reproduction in which nothing is left to dream over or speculate about -- the sound bite is all.
title: Hyped to Death

text: Basquiat began as a teen-age graffiti artist, ''Samo,'' who scrawled cryptic sayings on public buildings around Manhattan. Eventually he scavenged and recycled television images, comic-book heroes, fragments from the Bible, slogans; he appropriated everything into his work. Today, critics remain divided about his value. Robert Hughes maintains: ''He seemed to have some kind of graphic zip. But the stuff became incredibly repetitious.'' However, Arthur Danto insists: ''I thought the way he put paint on canvas was a gift. Basquiat had not just an eye, but a touch. . . . He left behind a substantial body of work, and would have been a significant painter in any era.''
title: Hyped to Death

text: Basquiat's meteoric rise and fall coincided with the emergence of other artists, like Julian Schnabel and David Salle, who were producing vast quantities of work very quickly to satisfy the inflated art market of the 1980's. ''Basquiat's life spanned an historic shift in the art world,'' Hoban writes, ''from Pop to neo-Expressionism, from hip to hype.'' Hype is the operative word. Hype and its nasty manipulations are explored ad infinitum in this book. Hype made Basquiat, and hype distorted his career. The greedy art dealers who bought and sold and resold his work had voracious appetites coupled with very short attention spans.
title: Hyped to Death

text: ''Basquiat: A Quick Killing in Art'' is not an authorized biography. It has not been endorsed by Basquiat's father, Gerald, or by his mother, Matilde. But they talked, anyway, and so have scores of other people close to Basquiat -- friends, teachers, colleagues, dealers, collectors, drug pushers and lovers (including Madonna). The resulting vignettes read like pulp fiction. ''He was dark, and soft and passionate,'' one lover told Hoban. He enjoyed both sexes.
title: Hyped to Death

text: Basquiat was born in Park Slope, Brooklyn, on Dec. 22, 1960. His father was an accountant, originally from Haiti, a womanizer who loved jazz and tennis. Basquiat's mother was from Puerto Rico. Exotic and cultivated, she spoke French, Spanish and English and took her son to theater and museums. By the time he was 4, Hoban reports, he was drawing maniacally. A car hit him when he was a small boy, and his spleen was removed. While he was hospitalized, his mother gave him a copy of Gray's Anatomy. Later he would make visual references to that book in his paintings, as well as to his accident, and he would also refer to another favorite book, ''Junky,'' by William Burroughs.
title: Hyped to Death

text: His parents' marriage broke up when Jean-Michel was 7, after his mother began suffering from depression. Jean-Michel and his two sisters, Lisane and Jeanine, were subsequently raised by their father in a brownstone in Boerum Hill. Hoban writes that his father beat Jean-Michel constantly and once stabbed the boy in the buttock (Basquiat later claimed the attack came after he was caught having sex with a male cousin). In school, he drew all the time. Teachers remembered him as uncommonly talented but very angry.
title: Hyped to Death

text: At 15, he ran away from home and lived in Washington Square Park, tripping on LSD and other drugs. To support himself, he sold painted T-shirts and handmade postcards on West Broadway, and he made friends with other struggling young artists like Keith Haring and Kenny Scharf. The three became part of the graffiti movement that flourished in the East Village in the late 1970's and was part of an energizing street culture. But Basquiat's graffiti stood out -- witty, poetic ''Samo'' sayings decorated with a copyright logo, which he scrawled all over SoHo and TriBeCa. Everybody loved Samo. ''It's a tool for mocking bogusness,'' Basquiat would say. He gained an underground celebrity.
title: Hyped to Death

text: Nobody could ignore him. He wore a green trench coat and a blond Mohawk. His feet were bare. ''His eyes could eat your face,'' Hoban writes. He was smart and funny and charming, and he had phenomenal energy. Heroin and cocaine were making him alternately euphoric and paranoid.
title: Hyped to Death

text: His first big break came in a 1981 show in which his work created a stir: 15 pieces on found lumber and foam rubber -- childlike drawings, cars, cartoon characters, ''kind of smeared, and everything was very violent and frenetic,'' in the words of one viewer. The paintings sold immediately, and the demand for Basquiats began. Everyone wanted to buy one. They sold faster than he could paint them, at $5,000 to $10,000 apiece. He seemed to be living his paintings. He slept on them, walked over them, ate on them, scribbled phone numbers on them, made lists. There would be a mound of cocaine on a table near his paint buckets. The smell of marijuana was in the air. Collectors would come and gawk, and then, as one of them told Hoban, ''He quickly became a commodity: 'Come and watch the artist perform.' ''
title: Hyped to Death

text: In March 1982 he had a sold-out show that garnered much attention from the news media. He was immediately tapped by Larry Gagosian, the first of a series of powerful art dealers who wheeled and dealed for him. Hoban writes that Gagosian, whose clients included Si Newhouse and David Geffen, knew he could make a lot of money on Basquiat. Meanwhile, Basquiat's output was phenomenal, and he continued to produce, fueled by drugs. Sometimes he would complete up to eight paintings a week. But he would fly into rages about being pressured to paint; sometimes he slashed his canvases to bits.
title: Hyped to Death

text: Gagosian arranged for him to have a show in Los Angeles in April 1982. Every painting was sold in a matter of minutes. By November, he had another show at the Fun Gallery in New York, some of the best paintings he ever did, with ''a rough energy and nasty edge,'' Hoban writes. There were portraits of his heroes -- Charlie Parker, Jackie Robinson, ''St. Joe Louis, surrounded by snakes.'' In other paintings, she writes, ''boys never become men, they become skeletons and skulls. . . . Basquiat is obsessed with deconstructing the images and language of his fragmented world.'' Basquiat secretly hid some of his best work so it could not be sold. The canvases were found after his death, in a warehouse in Washington Heights.
title: Hyped to Death

text: At the heart of this book is the story of Basquiat's collaboration with Andy Warhol, orchestrated by Bruno Bischofberger, the quintessential art dealer of the 1980's, who handled Basquiat's work worldwide. He was a master of hype and buying art in bulk, and organized shows for Basquiat in Tokyo, Paris and Madrid. (Today, he owns the best collection of Basquiat.) Bischofberger persuaded Warhol to work with Basquiat. Warhol was inspired by Basquiat's energy and youth. Basquiat idolized Warhol -- the artist who more than any other seemed to embody contemporary culture. He desperately needed and wanted Warhol's approval. The two became inseparable, working and partying together for months. Warhol never took drugs; he was appalled and fascinated by Basquiat's excesses.
title: Hyped to Death

text: Their joint show at Tony Shafrazi's gallery in September 1985 was a glittering media event, followed by a wild, noisy party at the Palladium, but the show itself drew universal pans. ''Everything . . . is infused with banality,'' one critic wrote. ''The real question is, who is using whom here?''
title: Hyped to Death

text: The end of the friendship came about because Warhol could not deal with Basquiat's drug addiction. And, in the final analysis, Hoban is telling the story of a drug addict. Her best passages reflect the addict's life, his hallucinations, his nocturnal wanderings, his hunger for the needle.
title: Hyped to Death

text: A not-so-minor quibble: Much of this book seems disorganized. Although Hoban, a magazine journalist writing her first book, is a terrific reporter, she needed to shape her wonderful research and put everything into proper perspective. Key elements of the great story she has unearthed lie buried beneath undigested material.
title: Hyped to Death

text: That said, the book remains compulsively readable. There is enormous value in it, especially in Hoban's depiction of the glitzy 1980's art world, which is sharply etched and deadly accurate. She describes a place where sex, imagination and intelligence have been so brutalized by greed and celebrity the cumulative effect is numbing.
title: Hyped to Death

text: Basquiat himself maintained that all he wanted was to be famous. He could learn to draw later, he said. He got his wish, of course, but his dream of fame turned into a nightmare.
title: Hyped to Death

text: In life, one must sometimes distinguish between a man's reputation, earned in the past, and his present reality. There are many reasons that Georgetown Coach John Thompson should not be admitted to the Basketball Hall of Fame.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: Thompson has not reached the Final Four in 13 years (and the final eight only once in that time). Compare this record to, say, Jim Boeheim, who has continued to coach successful teams at Syracuse even in years of lean talent.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: And talent is something Thompson has had plenty of. During these 13 years, he coached Alonzo Mourning, Dikembe Mutombo, Reggie Williams, Charles Smith, David Wingate, Allen Iverson and Don Reid, to name but a few. What's holding him back? Not recruiting. Not his schedule, which is cream puff. So, what is it?
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: As for Thompson's record at Georgetown mentioned in Earl Graves's letter (Mailbox, The Times, July 26), as most fans know, Thompson intentionally plays Division III schools in November and December to pad a career coaching record. (One joke on campus is that the Hoyas are playing ''Champions Bar and Grill'' next November.) Luckily, the Hall of Fame voters see through such a tactic.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: Far more seriously, Thompson has overseen the sad decline of Georgetown's once lauded athletic practices and player conduct. Where does Mr. Graves get the idea that Georgetown players are ''mandated to be serious students?'' In the past two seasons, Georgetown players have been arrested for drug possession, assault and armed robbery. They have attacked people with swords (Kenny Brunner), brooms (Victor Page) and guns (Brunner again).
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: Ed Sheffey, the starting point guard for 1997-98, was suspended last year and subsequently transferred to New Mexico State, after being arrested and charged with speeding, reckless driving and marijuana possession. Anthony Perry, the team's No. 1 recruit, was declared academically ineligible by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, and never played a game.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: Last year, Page, then the team's leading scorer, had to leave school early after his grade-point average dropped below N.C.A.A. minimums. He ended up in the Continental Basketball Association, where he was suspended for eight games after attacking another player with a broomstick. Iverson's post-Georgetown legal run-ins should convince most anyone that Thompson's players do not receive effective guidance during or after their stays at Georgetown. Moreover, the number of junior college transfers to the team has doubled in three years.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: You end up with a picture of inner city kids used for their athletic skills, and then dumped back into the world. That suits Nebraska football more than the student-athlete image of Georgetown.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: If similar behavior occurred at Stanford and Princeton (both of whose teams blew right by Thompson's into berths in the '98 N.C.A.A. tournament), those coaches would be fired. Immediately.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: Once Georgetown stood with Stanford and Duke as schools that proved you can insist on academic and social achievement, and still win.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: Michael Jackson, '89, who also wrote a letter in support of Thompson's Hall of Fame inclusion (Mailbox, The Times, July 19), was a starting guard for him and went on to Harvard Business School. But that was long ago. Not coincidentally, it was also long ago that Thompson won tournaments. That is not what I look for in a Hall of Famer.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: The writer graduated from Georgetown in 1989.
title: Take Into Account The Present Reality

text: A child welfare supervisor was arrested yesterday when he tried to walk into the Brooklyn Family Court building with 31 small plastic bags of marijuana, city officials said.
title: Marijuana Charges at Family Court

text: The supervisor, Israel Rodriguez, 39, was supposed to examine computers in the courthouse, at 283 Adams Street in downtown Brooklyn. But court officers, who followed routine by searching Mr. Ramirez as he walked into the building shortly after 4 P.M., arrested him when they discovered the bags of marijuana and five marijuana cigarettes, officials said.
title: Marijuana Charges at Family Court

text: Mr. Rodriguez, who has worked for the city since 1991, was arrested on charges of possession of and intent to sell marijuana.
title: Marijuana Charges at Family Court

text: Jennifer Falk, a spokeswoman for the Administration for Children's Services, said that Mr. Rodriguez -- whose salary is $40,435 a year -- was suspended without pay.
title: Marijuana Charges at Family Court

text: The Manhattan District Attorney's office is investigating allegations that the construction industry consultants who guide architects, engineers and contractors through the complicated web of city permits have bribed city officials and construction contractors, investigators said.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: The investigation, part of a vast, years-old inquiry into corruption in the construction and real estate industries, is focusing on reports that the consultants, known as expediters, have paid off officials of the Buildings Department to speed up the permitting process and bribed contracting companies to win jobs, the investigators said.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: Expediting is a job unique to New York and a few other large cities with complicated building regulations.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: ''New York's building codes and zoning regulations are long and complex -- the most stringent in the country,'' said Ted Birkhahn, a spokesman for the Buildings Department. Both the building and zoning handbooks are hundreds of pages long, he said.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: ''Expediters come in and stand on line and do the application process,'' he said. ''They're experts in the paperwork.'' Mr. Birkhahn would not comment on the investigation.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: The city's 1,500 expeditors must obtain licenses and are regulated by the Buildings Department.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: The Manhattan prosecutors' wide-ranging investigation of the city's $60 billion buildings industry in 1994 resulted in the indictments and guilty pleas of more than 80 building managers and companies for corrupt dealings with condominiums and cooperatives. The dealings included demands for kickbacks from roofers and plumbers and other tradesmen who service buildings.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: Earlier this year, officials from a handful of interior construction companies pleaded guilty to charges of bid-rigging on scores of major corporate renovation jobs throughout the 90's.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: The investigation of more than a dozen expediting companies has resulted in one arrest so far. Law enforcement officers arrested one company executive on June 16 as they seized company records. Ronald Lattanzio, 40, president of two companies -- A & E Consulting and All Safe Consultants, both in Manhattan -- was charged with tampering with evidence.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: Mr. Lattanzio, after hearing about the impending investigation, ordered an employee at A & E Consultants to hide a computer containing business records in the basement, a law enforcement official said. The employee, who obeyed, subsequently told the story to the officers.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: Mr. Lattanzio's lawyer, Norman A. Bloch, said the arrest was based on a misunderstanding, which will be explained in court.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: In 1986, Mr. Lattanzio, then assistant commissioner of the Buildings Department, resigned after accusations that he and other employees had used cocaine and marijuana during parties at the agency's office.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: Now his arrest in June has cost him another job. All Safe Consultants was hired to supervise safety compliance for part of the 48-story Conde Nast building in Times Square. But after telling the general contractor, Tishman Realty and Construction Corporation, about the arrest, Mr. Lattanzio agreed to withdraw from the job.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: All Safe Consultants' job did not include inspection of the scaffolding that collapsed on July 22, killing one woman and shutting down Times Square for days.
title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings

text: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and its players met constructively, they thought, for nearly two hours yesterday morning. Then they broke for lunch, and each side had to wonder what was in the water the other side had with its food.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: Within 15 minutes after the negotiators returned from lunch, the owners' group abruptly ended the session, dismissing a union proposal as economically perilous. Both sides accused the other of deliberately torpedoing the meeting and the immediate chance for progress in the off-season lockout.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: ''They were like my 4-year-old,'' said Karl Malone, who traveled from Alaska for his first taste of collective bargaining. ''I don't want to play anymore so I'm going home.''
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: The half-dozen owners who were in the conference room of a midtown Manhattan law office, on the other hand, were described as stunned and insulted by post-lunch developments.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: ''We thought the best thing to do to preserve any semblance of a bargaining balance for continuity would be to end discussions right there,'' said Commissioner David Stern, who with his deputy and chief negotiator, Russ Granik, expressed disappointment and sadness at yesterday's developments.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: The negotiators were meeting for the first time since June 22, and the first time since the league imposed its lockout on July 1, suspending all N.B.A. business, including the signing of free agents and the payment of salary that teams contractually owe players for the 1998-99 season.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: No further bargaining sessions are scheduled, though lawyers for the league and the players will meet today with an arbitrator, John D. Feerick, to schedule a hearing on the union's grievance over the teams' failure to pay guaranteed salaries. Feerick's decision in that case is expected to have a major impact on the future of talks.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: League officials, in fact, suggested that the union strategy centered not on negotiations but on the salary grievance and an unfair labor practice charge it filed with the National Labor Relations Board.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: ''The strategy here is to litigate, arbitrate and make no concessions,'' said Granik. Billy Hunter, the union chief, countered by saying that the players will use every avenue available to them to undermine the lockout, but that they want to negotiate a new agreement.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: At the morning session, the owners who were present engaged in back-and-forth dialogue with the 13 players who were at the large table. Stern called the exchange constructive. Hunter said at least part of it was acrimonious, particularly an early exchange between Malone and Jerry Colangelo of the Phoenix Suns.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: But the exchange prompted the union to make a post-lunch proposal. Jerry Kessler, one of the union's outside lawyers, said: ''Colangelo said we had to address the drug agreement, rookie issues and a hard salary cap. They want to slow the growth of salaries.''
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: So the union returned from lunch with a proposal that would change the 20 percent salary increase veterans receive in new contracts, grant clubs the right of first refusal on players ending their three-year rookie contracts and would add marijuana to the drug-testing list if all economic issues were resolved first.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: But the owners viewed the overall effect of the elements of the economic proposal as perilous. The union's ideas, they said, could increase, not decrease, the percentage of revenue that would go to players' salaries. In addition, the owners took offense at remarks made by Kessler.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: ''When they lecture you on the grave risk you face if you don't take their proposal, that's when it's time to leave,'' Stern said. ''That's not the tone in which we address the players.''
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: Kessler said he wasn't lecturing the owners.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: ''When they were about to storm out of the meeting,'' he said, ''I suggested that they recognize there are going to be some very important legal decisions to be made rather quickly and it might be in their interest to negotiate seriously before those decisions come down.''
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: Patrick Ewing, the union's president, said the players felt they were making progress with their proposal and the owners ''showed disrespect by getting up and walking out.''
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: At the morning session yesterday, one of the participants said, the owners raised a salary cap idea they had previously discussed with variations. They proposed implementing a hard salary cap for the future, though current players would not be affected by it.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: The players rejected the idea, and then everyone went to lunch and drank the water.
title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

text: Elected officials and their professional handlers are forever condemning reporters and historians for focusing on politicians' character and personality. But over time, the study of the shaping influence of personal history has proved a reliable way to judge fitness for office and make reasonable predictions about performance under pressure. Thus the real suspense in Washington these days is not over what, if any, indiscretions President Clinton might confess, but in whether he can gather himself to meet his crisis.
title: The War Inside Bill Clinton

text: This mode of analysis will not appeal, of course, to those who see Mr. Clinton as a victim. Our view is that history will depict him as the architect of his situation in a way that illustrates how a President's inner reality shapes his destiny.
title: The War Inside Bill Clinton

text: Admittedly, there is always a limit to what we can learn from observing occupants of the Oval Office. But who can doubt that there was something in Ronald Reagan's rootedness that let him compensate for not being the brightest bulb in town? Similarly, it was the dark ceremonies of Richard Nixon's psyche, not some colossal international blunder, that destroyed a true foreign-policy intellectual. Lyndon Johnson's idealized personality was that of a social healer. But that part of his nature shaped by the macho code of the frontier destroyed his legacy and millions of lives.
title: The War Inside Bill Clinton

text: With Mr. Clinton, the drama seems of a less momentous order. But that does not mean that the struggle within him now is not a passionate one. Even his most dogged Congressional defenders and most loyal former aides are urging him to tell the truth, whatever it is. Yet Mr. Clinton's entire public record -- on the draft, marijuana, Whitewater, Filegate, Travelgate, Monica Lewinsky -- is one of avoiding full and factual disclosure even when that was the smart play. This is, in sum, behavior crafted as much by the nexus of inclination and experience as by advice of counsel.
title: The War Inside Bill Clinton

text: In its latest trash-the-critics operation, the White House has said that the mere act of calling on the President to tell the truth means that Mr. Clinton has been unfairly prejudged. It means something quite different, of course. Commentators and millions of skeptical citizens are basing their advice on six years of observation and a longing for candor. This is a President who has been delivered into crisis by the agency of his own evasions.
title: The War Inside Bill Clinton

text: Today he travels to the Capitol to meet with the House Democrats who must defend him against any impeachment efforts. They lack the numbers and, in some cases, the stomach for the task. They will advise honesty in the interests of their party's fate, Mr. Clinton's survival and repairing the Presidency. Whether Mr. Clinton agrees with that advice is a suspenseful question. Whether he could ever act on it is an even deeper and more mysterious one.
title: The War Inside Bill Clinton

text: THERE is a brand new recipe for a healthy life. The basic ingredients are a low-fat diet, regular exercise -- and marriage.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Countering conventional wisdom that marriage is bad for women but good for men, a University of Chicago researcher says she has found that marriage brings considerable benefits to both women and men. It lengthens life, substantially boosts physical and emotional health and raises income over that of single or divorced people or those who live together, she says.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: The researcher, Dr. Linda J. Waite, a professor of sociology, presented her findings in July at the second annual Smart Marriages Conference in Washington.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: ''This is definitely a public health issue,'' Dr. Waite said. ''People need to know the facts so they can make good decisions. Marriage is good for everyone. But I'm battling a deeply entrenched, if dangerous and false, belief.''
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: The notion that marriage damages women's emotional well-being derives from the 1972 publication of ''The Future of Marriage'' (Yale University Press) by the sociologist Jessie S. Bernard, who died in 1996 at the age of 93. In it, she reported that married men are better off than single men on four measures of psychological distress: depression, neurotic symptoms, phobic tendency and passivity. But married women, she said, score higher on these negative traits than single women.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Although the findings were never replicated and were disputed even then, they entered the lore of the field and of popular culture. ''They helped de-romanticize marriage'' at a time when that was needed, said Dr. William J. Doherty, a professor of psychology at the University of Minnesota. ''They matched the then-evolving belief that marriage is an oppressive institution for women.''
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Since the 1970's, researchers have come up with better measures of emotional health, and on these, married women and men generally score very well. Further, in the last two years several large studies that tracked people in and out of relationships over a long period have produced evidence that marriage actually causes psychological well-being in both sexes.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: By contrast, Dr. Bernard's material consisted of one-time glimpses of people's lives. While both Dr. Bernard and Dr. Waite based their conclusions on data from many studies, reducing the likelihood that either was reporting a fluke, marriage itself has changed in the intervening years in ways that generally make women happier.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Dr. Waite told the conference that her curiosity was aroused four years ago when she stumbled across ''the marriage mortality benefit'' -- statistics showing that married men and women live longer.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: In a large national sample of adults followed for 18 years beginning at the age of 48, slightly more than 60 percent of divorced and never-married women made it to 65, as opposed to nearly 90 percent of married women. Widowed women, for reasons not entirely clear, fared almost as well as married women. Among men, however, those unmarried for any reason -- whether widowed, divorced or never married -- had only a 60 to 70 percent chance of living to 65, versus 90 percent for married men.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Since then, Dr. Waite has found that ''marriage changes people's behavior in ways that make them better off.'' Married partners monitor each other's health, for example. They also drink less alcohol and use less marijuana and cocaine.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: From detailed reports on 50,000 men and women followed from their senior year in high school to the age of 32 by University of Michigan researchers, Dr. Waite discerned a steep increase in ''bad behaviors'' among those who stayed single, but a ''precipitous drop'' in bad behaviors like the use of alcohol or illegal drugs among those who married.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Drawing heavily on a study of 13,000 adults assessed in 1987 and 1988 and again in 1992 and 1993, Dr. Waite demonstrated the positive impact that marriage has on mental health. The study, conducted by two psychologists at the University of Wisconsin, Nadine F. Marks and James D. Lambert, will be published in November in The Journal of Family Issues.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: It is not just that people who remained married reported significantly higher levels of happiness than those who remained single. The data showed that those who separated or divorced over the five-year period became, in Dr. Waite's word, miserable.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Men and especially women who married for the first time during the course of the study experienced a sharp increase in happiness. Remarriage, however, brought only a modest increase in happiness.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Dr. Waite noted that Dr. Bernard similarly found married women happier than single women, but relegated that fact to her book's appendix.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: In addition, marriage appeared to reduce the degree of depression. Men and especially women whose marriages ended over the five-year period experienced high levels of depression compared with those who stayed married. Single men as a group were depressed at the outset of the study and became more depressed if they stayed single.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Compelling as he found these data, Dr. Doherty, the University of Minnesota professor, noted that they represent population-based averages. They do not mean that everyone is better off married than single, or that people are bound to be happy and healthy if they marry the wrong person.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Dr. Shirley P. Glass, a clinical psychologist from Baltimore who is recognized for her research on infidelity, echoed those caveats. One reason women are generally happier today, she added, is that they are working more like men. In addition, they are reaping more satisfaction from roles other than wife and mother.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Emotional health also hinges on satisfaction with sex, and in this realm marriage serves both men and women, but delivers a special bonus to women. First of all, Dr. Waite said, married people have sex twice as often as single people. Unmarried couples who live together also have an active sex lives but, like unmarried people, get less emotional satisfaction from it than married people, the studies found.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: For married men, satisfaction hinges on sexual frequency, fidelity and emotional commitment to the relationship. For women, these elements are equally important, but just the fact of being married added an extra kick to their sexual satisfaction.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: ''Men make an investment in pleasing their partner because of their ongoing relationship,'' Dr. Waite said. ''People who are committed to a partner get more than sex out of sex.''
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Married people also have more money.
