From her own analysis of a National Institute of Aging survey of 12,000 people 51 to 61 years of age, Dr. Waite found that married people have more than twice as much money, on average, as unmarried people. Married couples not only save more while enjoying some economies of scale, but married men also earn up to 26 percent more than single men.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Similarly, married women earn more than unmarried women, but only if they have no children. When they have children, ''they trade some time earning for time with their children,'' Dr. Waite said. If the women continue to work, she added, they have difficulty getting child care, and experience stress trying to balance two sets of demands.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Married women are not only happier and wealthier than single women, Dr. Waite found, they are also safer. Moderate domestic violence (defined as as hitting, shoving or throwing things at a partner) occurred half as often with married couples and cohabiting couples engaged to marry than it did with cohabiting couples not planning to marry.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: The findings suggest that there is more to marriage than just a social bond. There appears to be something specifically protective about the long-term commitment that marriage entails.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Committed gay couples are likely to enjoy many of the same benefits, Dr. Waite said, as long as they promise to stay together and receive social support from others for staying together.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: All told, marriage seems to be ''an unmitigated good'' for men, Dr. Waite added. For women, marriage indeed brings increased life satisfaction and happiness, but those benefits are ''part of a package'' that also includes family demands that are sometimes burdensome.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: Perhaps, she suggested, this was what Jessie Bernard really meant.
title: Debunking the Marriage Myth: It Works for Women, Too

text: SUNDAY, AUGUST 2, 1998: YOU ARE THERE
title: The Rainbows Are Coming!

text: Once a summer since 1972, a loose-knit group of hippies called the Rainbow Family has converged on various plots of publicly owned land to pray for world peace. . .and party wildly. The Rainbow gathering started small, but it has grown into a sprawling, messy, weeks-long bash for hordes of anti-establishment revelers. This year, some 25,000 Rainbows descended on Springerville, Ariz. (population 1,900), setting up in a sensitive meadow in the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest. Springerville is a conservative town, and residents and U.S. Forest Service staff braced for the worst, based on rumors and reports from previous Rainbow gatherings about environmental destruction, wildfires, burglary, rampant public nudity and drugs. How bad was it? Here's a look.
title: The Rainbows Are Coming!

text: THE PARTY: Hundreds of acres of woods and rolling meadow have been transformed into a mud-trampled commons. Several thousand people, many of them nude, mill about, sit in mud puddles, beat on drums, dance. A man who calls himself Amazing Dave is whispering into a walkie-talkie. ''We've got a brother who took some bad medicine,'' he says. ''Let's go check it out.'' Dave is a member of the Rainbow Family's self-appointed peace-keeping force, the Shanti Sena. Exciting emergency: An irate man runs up, claiming, ''There's a child molester named Woody on the loose.''
title: The Rainbows Are Coming!

text: THE LAW: In Springerville proper, Round Valley Middle School has been turned into a makeshift outpost for all the extra county, state and Federal law-enforcement officers -- called the Unified Command -- brought in to monitor Rainbow activities. The Forest Service spent almost $500,000 to beef up the effort. Officers stand on the front steps smoking cigarettes, weary from responding to constant nuisance calls and minor violations: driving without a license, panhandling, possession of marijuana. ''People complain about their tax money being spent on the Rainbows, but what's the alternative?'' says Bill Fox, a Forest Service special agent.
title: The Rainbows Are Coming!

text: THE MESSES: One afternoon, Jim Cooley, resource adviser for the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest, is surveying the enviro-mayhem at the gathering site. ''This will have to be rehabilitated,'' he says, staring forlornly at Carnero Springs, which is running gray and bubbly with soap suds.
title: The Rainbows Are Coming!

text: THE REACTION: During the siege, commercial restrooms in town were closely monitored thanks to reports of ''aggressive'' bathing tactics -- in convenience-store restrooms, for instance. Local merchants ended up fairly happy, though. ''Business picked up a lot,'' says a mechanic at Springerville Automotive. He is bent over a water pump that he is repairing on (surprise) a VW bus belonging to a Rainbow person. ''There's been a big need for patched tires.''
title: The Rainbows Are Coming!

text: The Hamptons didn't exactly offer President Clinton a red carpet and a clamorous ovation this weekend. The greeting was more confused than that, more complicated, muted.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Yes, there were the high-profile parties, being thrown by the likes of the investment banker Bruce Wasserstein and the actors Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger, where the President is expected to raise some $2 million for the Democratic National Committee. And there was the hospitality of Steven Spielberg, who offered the President and First Lady his Georgica Pond estate, arguably as desirable a place to spend the night as the Lincoln bedroom.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: But those were the celebrities and big-money folks who give the Hamptons their reputation and cachet. The ordinary affluent weekenders who give the Hamptons their crowds and soaring real estate prices, and the year-rounders, who generally can't wait for September, responded with a more layered enthusiasm.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: They seemed glad enough to bask in the President's glow, but that may be because there wasn't too much inconvenience involved. Even the guests who paid $250 -- the cheap tickets -- to attend the Basinger-Baldwin party and had to wait in the sun for a shuttle bus to take them a mile or so down Town Lane to the house weren't grumbling. (Though, apparently, those who paid $5,000 for the privilege of entering the house, or $1,000 to enter a backyard tent, where Hootie and the Blowfish were entertaining, were. ''That's the difference between our party and the Republicans,'' said one of the few elected officials in attendance, who insisted on anonymity. ''The Republicans at least understand V.I.P. treatment and the class system.'')
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: In any case, for most people, it was a weekend like any other.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Here in East Hampton, glamour and power are no big deal; they come with the territory. Hence, not a lot of bunting or ardent flag-waving. For a party, the Barefoot Contessa, a gourmet food market, baked about 80 vanilla cupcakes with American flags done in marzipan. That was about it for patriotic display.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: In Amagansett, just to the east, a smaller town in both size and character, things were a bit different. But then that was where the President gave his weekly radio address today at the firehouse. This morning, Main Street was lined with American flags to welcome the Presidential motorcade. Even so, the crowd dispersed quickly, and before noon the Hamptonites were behaving like Hamptonites, shopping at the farmer's market just down the road and filling the beaches on a glorious beach day.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Besides, even in Amagansett, the biggest welcoming sign was neither political nor patriotic. It was on the side of the Stephen Talkhouse, a music club, where Jefferson Starship, a band from the era when Mr. Clinton was not inhaling marijuana, played on Friday night. The enormous sign, on behalf of a 17-year-old chef at the club, Eiji Shiga, read: ''Welcome Bill and Hillary. Please help keep our friend, Eiji, out of jail.''
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Mr. Shiga, who is awaiting sentencing for a series of robberies, is a well-spoken, contrite young man who admits he deserves to go to prison but hopes for a lenient sentence.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: A lot of people expressed their lack of interest by not showing up this weekend, fearful, perhaps, of a traffic nightmare. Route 27, the main east-west road through the South Fork of Long Island, was uncharacteristically unclogged all day Friday.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Though it was the site of the Basinger-Baldwin and Wasserstein bashes, as well as the President's weekend radio address, Amagansett, which is generally sleepy to begin with, never really woke up. And maybe most amazing, downtown East Hampton and Sag Harbor, ordinarily mobbed with shoppers, have both been reasonably navigable.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: ''This is the only time I ever got a parking space in front of the Red Horse Market,'' said Tara Newman, a year-round resident of Sag Harbor, referring to another high-end food store in East Hampton.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Of course, no place is so inured to glitz and indulgence that the President fails to make an impression. By the time he arrived, the rumors of where he would eat (the Bridgehampton Cafe?), golf (the Atlantic Golf Club?) and shop (Newtown Lane?) had been circulating for days. On Friday afternoon, when he arrived at East Hampton Airport by helicopter from Westhampton (where Air Force One had landed), a crowd of maybe 200 people had pulled their cars off Route 27 and waited for a glimpse of him as his motorcade made its way to Mr. Spielberg's house.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: It was an amused gathering on the side of the road, including Michael J. Silberkleit, the publisher of Archie Comics, whose wife, Nancy, wore an oversize Archie head; Corey Watson, a college student from California working as a pool man for the summer, who held up a small sign that said, ''Legalize Marijuana,'' and the housekeeping and maintenance staff of the financier Ronald O. Perelman, whose driveway opens on the motorcade route. Mr. Perelman himself passed on the parade; he is in Europe, his staff members said.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: On the street, in restaurants, it was easy to overhear the conversations about Mr. Clinton, his sex life and whether he lied about it and encouraged others to do so. And here, as elsewhere, there was both titillation and shame, as people argued over what the President's strategy should be or would be when he testifies for the grand jury later this month. Apologize to his wife and family and the American public? Or deny, deny, deny?
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: ''I've always said, even if she catches you in bed with the sheets down, say, 'Honey, you got it wrong,' '' said Derek Ford, who may or may not have been joking. ''It's very hard to say, if you're a man in a powerful position, to say, 'No, no, no' to all the opportunities,'' said Mr. Ford, who owns a chain of women's clothing stores in Canada and was visiting the Hamptons with his wife and teen-age daughter. ''I've been married four times for that reason.''
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Racy speculations over just what went on between the President and Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern, often led to head-shaking lamentations over the fact that alleged sex acts and a dress that may have semen stains have become the focus of a special prosecutor investigating the nation's chief executive, not to mention the focus of the nation's discourse. And poor Hillary! Poor Chelsea!
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: For many the issue is not whether there was sex play in the White House, but whether it matters. Is Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, a symbol of the democratic system or a simply a zealot?
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: ''I think it's outrageous; it's sexual McCarthyism,'' said David Oestreich, a Manhattan businessman who was a house guest in East Hampton. ''It occurred to me recently that maybe there's some entrapment involved here.''
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: The opposite view was expressed on a roadside billboard in front of the Southampton Full Gospel Church, where each week a line of Scripture is posted for the benefit of weekenders arriving in the Hamptons on Route 27. This week's selection is from Hebrews: ''Whoremongers and adulterers, God will judge.''
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: ''Our sign is an indication of the moral quality of our society,'' said the Rev. Donald Havrilla, the leader of the congregation.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Asked if the sign was not simply discourteous to an important visitor, Mr. Havrilla replied: ''Religious leaders have a responsibility to weigh in on Mr. Clinton's behavior, and from what I've seen I'm not impressed. If the shoe fits, he should wear it. If not, then it shouldn't bother him.''
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: It was, perhaps, at the Amagansett Fire House that the prevailing local attitude toward the weekend was best expressed. There, on Friday evening, the department's second assistant chief, Kent Howie, was putting black patches embroidered with the company insignia, normally for shirt sleeves, on the department's red flag. The flag was supposed to hang on the wall behind the President, but there were stains on it.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: Mr. Howie couldn't say he was a political supporter of Mr. Clinton.
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: ''But he's still the most powerful man in the world,'' Mr. Howie said. ''And we're glad to have him here.''
title: In the Hamptons, High-Profile Parties for Clinton

text: A Novel of the Civil War.
title: No Glory

text: Owl/Henry Holt & Company. Paper, $12.
title: No Glory

text: HOWARD BAHR'S first novel was published in hardcover last year by a small press in Baltimore, but despite being nominated for several awards it escaped the attention of most reviewers and readers. Now appearing in paperback, it's being republished as if it were new. The success of ''Cold Mountain'' certainly has something to do with this, since ''The Black Flower,'' like that surprising best seller, is, as its subtitle reminds us, ''A Novel of the Civil War.'' Let me promise right now not to compare Bahr's bold effort with ''The Red Badge of Courage,'' ''The Killer Angels,'' the film ''Glory'' or a certain public television documentary. Forget Margaret Mitchell, Shelby Foote and even Charles Frazier. Bahr's novel is too eccentric and too uneven to support such comparisons. And at moments it's almost too good to support them.
title: No Glory

text: ''The Black Flower'' follows a group of Confederate soldiers from Cumberland, Miss., into battle at Franklin, Tenn., on the last day of November 1864. Although Bahr sometimes goes back and forth in time, the swift pace of this fairly short book keeps him moving chronologically through a period of about two days. His characters immediately confront ''the black flower'' (as, we are told, Hawthorne called death) when they begin their assault across a broad plain on an entrenched Federal line. The rest of the book takes place after the battle at a plantation house that has been turned into a field hospital.
title: No Glory

text: Pvt. Bushrod Carter, a graduate of the University of Mississippi and ''a veteran of all the campaigns of the Army of Tennessee since Shiloh,'' has survived with his comrades to this late stage of the war. His brigade began as the Cumberland Rifles, but all that remains of his fellow townsmen are his friend Jack Bishop, three of their officers, a chaplain and a member of the band who believes himself to be the Archbishop of Canterbury. By the end of the book, even this list is sadly diminished.
title: No Glory

text: One reason Bahr's novel doesn't compare well with earlier books is that it has a post-Vietnam ferocity about it. You might expect blood and guts in a Civil War novel, but here are the actual gray, ropy entrails, the smell of corpses lying in the fields. You might expect a disquisition on the chaos and futility of battle, but Bahr also insists on its grotesque malignity.
title: No Glory

text: Vietnam gave us not just a tolerance for the grossest details of warfare but a firm sense that these details are the proper antidote to any lingering tendency to glorify war. In this sense, ''The Black Flower'' is a deeply moral book, its perspective clear from the moment a bumbling comrade discharges his rifle (and its ramrod) into the skull of one of Bushrod's ''pards'' until the next day, when the dead man's rigid arms must be broken so he'll fit into a grave. Bahr can only bring his own historical perspective to this material, but the cynicism of his characters feels anachronistic, as if the remnants of the Army of Tennessee were wreathed in marijuana smoke at firebases in the Central Highlands.
title: No Glory

text: The book has other problems, including a tendency to swerve into melodrama. On the stairs of the mansion, a young woman brusquely confronts a man who turns out to be Gen. Nathan Bedford Forrest. He treats her with stereotypical courtesy, bestowing an ostrich feather plucked from his hat and telling her (in a sample of Bahr's frequently problematic dialogue) that ''there ain't any shame in bein afraid. Not ever.'' It's a remark his soldiers would have responded to with rude sounds.
title: No Glory

text: In contrast to these sorts of scenes is a set piece of startling originality, a three-page description of a wasp's freeing itself from a pool of blood on the floor of the plantation house, slowly climbing the wounded Bushrod's body, then launching itself from the bridge of his nose. ''He flew in perfect linear flight to the lantern again and began to knock his head against the glass. Tink. Tink. Tink. After a while he fell, straight down, like a dropped match.''
title: No Glory

text: Here, however unexpectedly, Bahr succeeds in capturing the pointlessness of war.
title: No Glory

text: IT would be easier for Chris Schwartz, rap music producer and high school dropout, to reveal the secrets of his success if his cellular phone would stop ringing. Or if he would stop answering it. Not that he's not apologetic.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: ''I really am sorry, '' Mr. Schwartz says. Then, to a distressed artist on the other end of the line who one suspects is the singer Lauryn Hill, about to come out with her first solo album: ''No, he didn't say you were going to look like an icon; he's afraid that's what people are going to think.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Pause. ''I think it's very roots, very cool, everybody digs it.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Pause. ''You just have to look where he is in the corporate culture.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Where is Mr. Schwartz, C.E.O. and co-founder of Ruffhouse Records, in the corporate culture?
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: The discussion is taking place in the Manhattan offices of Sony (which owns Columbia Records, which distributes Ruffhouse), but Mr. Schwartz's phone style, which is more colorful and direct than his interview style, leans toward the street: ''Yo, man,'' or ''Dude, I know nothing about it.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Then again, as this is the music business, maybe street talk is the correct corporate style.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Whatever, Mr. Schwartz, 37, is certainly doing something right. Operating out of Conshohocken, Pa., Ruffhouse Records, which Mr. Schwartz and his partner, Joe Nicolo, founded nine years ago with $400, has been home to some of the biggest names in hip-hop: Kriss Kross, Cypress Hill and the Fugees. The Fugees' ''The Score,'' with sales of 17 million copies, is the all-time best-selling album by a rap group. Mr. Schwartz is now a millionaire.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: What makes Mr. Schwartz special, however, is his salesmanship.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Mr. Schwartz began his career managing the Philadelphia gangsta rapper Schoolly D, one of the first rap artists to cross over to a mainstream audience. Mr. Schwartz also claims to have been the first producer to take to the streets to sell his records, giving records and stickers to club deejays and teen-agers, rather than depending on radio play.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: The tactics proved a little aggressive for New York -- last winter, the leader of one of Ruffhouse's promotional street gangs was arrested on charges that he was illegally posting stickers for the group Sporty Thiev$. Columbia Records executives were publicly displeased, and Mr. Schwartz is enough of a corporate creature to decline to discuss the incident.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Nor does Mr. Schwartz consider the subject of his race important.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: ''It doesn't matter if you're black or white,'' Mr. Schwartz says. ''What's important is to sign the right people, to get your stuff out there. I do that. I make it happen.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: SCHOOLLY D is recalling how he hooked up with Mr. Schwartz: ''You know West Philly? It's a black neighborhood. When Chris called, I thought he was a black dude pretending to be white. It was rap, it was hip-hop, I didn't know anybody white who was even remotely interested. This is '84, '85, it's a black thing, yada, yada, yada.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: ''Warren, my attorney at the time, never told me Chris was white. I'm in the shower, Chris is ringing my bell, I go downstairs, say, 'Who are you?' I let him in. I'm just sitting there in my towel. We start talking, we start laughing. Anybody who can make me laugh is all right with me.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Does Schoolly D have a given name he uses?
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: ''Only around my mother,'' he says.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: The New York Times is somewhat like one's mother.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: ''The 30 or 40 guys around us, we were the only two who had the killer look in our eyes,'' Schoolly D says regarding the old days. ''Everybody else just wanted drugs or they were chick hounds, typical rock 'n' roll. When it was time to be real and the smoke cleared, he was standing over there and I was standing over here.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Perhaps there is a gene for salesmen. This seems to be the case with Mr. Schwartz. He was born in Devon, Pa., his father was a furniture salesman, and all but one of Mr. Schwartz's nine brothers and sisters would grow up and go into sales. Mr. Schwartz dropped out of school in 10th grade and joined the Navy at 17. He also formed a band, which set up on the deck of an aircraft carrier.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: ''We were like the warm-up act for the Blue Angels,'' Mr. Schwartz says.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Mr. Schwartz worked as a musician, then hooked up with Schoolly D. Mr. Schwartz persuaded the owners of a small record company in New Jersey to produce records on credit -- a move that was particularly impressive because the company produced children's records and Schoolly D, a gangsta rapper, was not producing material that was Disneyesque.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: Ruffhouse was created in 1989. Cypress Hill, a Los Angeles group that championed marijuana, was the label's first success, with a debut album that was on the Billboard charts for more than 100 weeks.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: ''They had a more alternative following than core hip-hop, and we took advantage of that,'' Mr. Schwartz says. ''We put them on the cover of High Times magazine. But our promotions are always changing. When you sell a record, you are vying for a slice of a kid's awareness. With all the media glut, it's hard to hold somebody's attention.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: What does Mr. Schwartz believe it takes to be a good salesman?
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: His answer puts the street talk in perspective.
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: ''You've got to be able to read people.''
title: Hip-Hop Style: It's a Way to Run a Company

text: THE medical use of marijuana is controversial for a simple, obvious reason: In addition to the benefits, like relief for cancer-related nausea, patients get high. But one marijuana ingredient may have significant therapeutic value without the psychoactive effect, according to a study by Government neuroscientists, among them a Nobel laureate.
title: Marijuana and Stroke

text: In test tube experiments, the ingredient, cannibidiol, prevented more than half of the brain cell death associated with stroke, according to results published in the July issue of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Cannibidiol proved to be a powerful antioxidant, neutralizing some of the ravages caused by strokes. The effect was far greater than that of other antioxidants, including vitamins A and C.
title: Marijuana and Stroke

text: It is not known whether cannibidiol can preserve brain function in stroke patients, or save lives, because the research involved only rat brain tissue. But a follow-up study to look at the effects of cannibidiol on rats with experimentally induced stroke looks promising, said Dr. Julius Axelrod, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in medicine who contributed to the research. ''So far, cannibidiol looks nontoxic and effective,'' he said.
title: Marijuana and Stroke

text: But he discouraged stroke patients from smoking marijuana. ''We have no idea whether smoking marijuana would be beneficial against stroke,'' he said. ''Cannibidiol varies very much in marijuana, depending on the source.'' SUSAN GILBERT
title: Marijuana and Stroke

text: The third annual Smokin' Grooves tour, which came to the PNC Bank Arts Center here tonight, might as well have been called the Hip-Hop Holdouts tour. It assembled groups that insist, against the commercial tide, that hip-hop isn't exclusively about ''playas'' who brag about their wealth, their women, their brand-name possessions and their unsavory pasts while borrowing the melodies of pop hits.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: For three of the groups on the bill -- Public Enemy, Gang Starr and Wyclef Jean's Refugee Camp -- hip-hop is still a way to address social issues, using the beat to carry messages. ''It might feel good, it might sound a little somethin'/But damn the game if it don't mean nothing,'' Chuck D. intones in ''He Got Game,'' the title track from Public Enemy's current album. The other headliners, Cypress Hill and Busta Rhymes with the Flipmode Squad, also stand outside the ''playa'' realm. Cypress Hill sticks to its narrow obsessions with marijuana and guns, and Busta Rhymes single-mindedly incites a party.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: For all the groups, hip-hop isn't just a star trip; it's a display of camaraderie, an employment program and an opportunity for empire-building. While rock groups may talk about community, they keep their stage shows clear of nonmusicians; hip-hop groups perform amid friends, hangers-on and affiliated talent, bringing the neighborhood to the stage in what can look like near-chaos. The image of block-party fraternity -- nearly all the participants were male -- is as important as what the rappers say.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: Public Enemy, the headliners, has reunited after drug rehabilitation for Flavor Flav, Chuck D.'s partner and the group's comic relief. The set also had a guest rap from Professor Griff, who had been dismissed from Public Enemy in 1989 after declaring that Jews were responsible for ''the majority of wickedness that goes on across the globe.'' His thankless job here was to follow the pro-marijuana raps of Cypress Hill with the admonition, ''We can't stay high forever.''
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: With Security of the First World, its dancing drill team, Public Enemy has long been one of hip-hop's most capable live acts; Chuck D. strides around the stage, Flavor Flav strikes jokey poses, and the disk jockey Terminator X oversees booming rhythm tracks. The set depended on past glories, from the late 1980's and early 90's, when Public Enemy articulated rage and resistance in music that bristled with sonic irritants and language so dense it begged to be decoded. In more recent songs Chuck D. has grown didactic, as if he no longer trusted his listeners to make an effort to understand.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: ''He Got Game'' gives in to the Puff Daddy style of pop hip-hop; the song appropriates Buffalo Springfield's ''For What It's Worth.'' But the older material -- ''Bring the Noise,'' ''911 Is a Joke,'' ''Fight the Power,'' ''Can't Truss It'' -- was a reminder of how many remarkable songs Public Enemy contributed to hip-hop.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: Cypress Hill reunited B-Real, its lead rapper, with D.J. Muggs and Sen Dog, and it also relied on older songs. Unfortunately its material has grown threadbare: tales of pot smoking, paranoia and gunplay delivered in B-Real's nagging singsong voice. Back in 1991, Cypress Hill managed to push titillating hot buttons with songs like ''Hand on the Pump,'' but it soon reduced them to a formula, with diminishing returns. Two songs from the band's fourth album, due in October, were largely unintelligible; one taunted, one leered. B-Real had to exhort the crowd to stand up, something Busta Rhymes never had to mention.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: Mr. Rhymes was as much a cheerleader as a rapper: bounding across the stage, constantly touting his five-member Flipmode Squad and getting the crowd to shout along with the party chants of songs like ''Woo-hah!'' Gang Starr had more serious intentions; its rapper, Guru, paid tribute to Chuck D. and preached self-respect. Where Gang Starr's albums use a light, slightly jazz-tinged backups, onstage Gang Starr harked back to rap's old school, with deep, basic beats from D.J. Premier. Gang Starr also had guests, including Freddie Foxx and M.O.P.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: Mr. Jean's set had diverse intentions: showing off his skills as singer, guitarist and rapper; mixing Caribbean and American music, and plugging his associates Pras Michel (of the Fugees), John Forte and Canibus. True to rap's demotic ideals, Mr. Jean made his entrance like a street-level fan: he clambered up on stage and wrestled with a security man like a stage crasher.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: For many concertgoers, myself included, the opening acts, Black-Eyed Peas and Mya, were sacrificed to a 75-minute wait for what turned out to be a nonexistent security check. The Arts Center has presented previous Smokin' Grooves shows; by now, it ought to be better organized.
title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast

text: CAPITOL HILL SLAYINGS: THE ILLNESS
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Russell E. Weston Jr., the suspect in the fatal shootings of two police officers in the nation's Capitol, may have chosen an unusually public place to explode. But his history of mental illness has much in common with other delusional mentally ill people who become violent, illustrating both the cracks in the nation's mental-health system and its difficulty in compelling treatment, even for those at risk of becoming violent.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Mr. Weston's illness was well-known to family and mental health officials. But because of the closing of state mental hospitals across the country and the failure to build a promised network of local clinics as a replacement, the treatment of choice for him, as for the vast majority of mental patients, was the honor system: counting on him to give himself the often unpleasant antipsychotic drugs prescribed for his paranoid schizophrenia.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: With Mr. Weston, the problem was compounded by living in rural areas where psychiatric treatment and monitoring are extremely limited. He also traveled between two states, Montana and Illinois, encouraging at least one to solve his long-term care by sending him back to the other, leaving no one in charge.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: And when Mr. Weston became violent, recent research shows, the sources of his behavior were typical of the small group of mentally ill people who become violent. He was not taking his medication, he may have been using other drugs, and he had paranoid delusions: in his case that the Government was out to get him, using satellite dishes aimed at his cabin or assigning Navy Seals and Central Intelligence Agency operatives to pursue him.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Dr. E. Fuller Torrey, a psychiatrist and president of the Treatment Advocacy Center in Arlington, Va., said, ''Mr. Weston is an absolutely textbook case of what some of us have been saying for years'': the dangers inherent in leaving untreated someone with paranoid schizophrenia who does not understand he is ill.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Dr. Torrey estimated that 100,000 people with schizophrenia nationwide were not being treated.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: The problem is preventable, Dr. Torrey said, given the development of powerful drugs that can stabilize patients with severe mental illnesses. With the advent of these drugs in the 1960's, states began to close mental hospitals because the drugs offered a more humane way to treat the mentally ill and to save huge amounts of money. That approach, however, required a network of community clinics to make sure patients took the drugs, and it was not built.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: As a result, many people with schizophrenia, manic-depression and severe depression stop taking their drugs and regress, and about 200,000 a day end up being held in jails or prisons because of the bizarre behavior that results.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Dr. Torrey's advocacy group seeks to improve treatment of the seriously mentally ill and to change laws that make it difficult to commit mental patients against their will.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: These problems exist in almost all parts of the country. In Westchester County, N.Y., Michael B. Laudor, a Yale Law School graduate who had won book and movie deals for the story of his successful battle against schizophrenia, was charged last month with stabbing his fiancee to death. His medications had become ineffective, friends said, but he had not been hospitalized.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: But the mental-health net is especially thin in rural areas, where the nearest psychiatrist may be a hundred miles away and there is an aversion to Government spending.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: In Montana, where Mr. Weston lived in a cabin much of the past 20 years, ''It is so hard to get psychiatric treatment, you usually have to get arrested to get treatment,'' said Wesley Alcorn, a member of the state board of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, a group made up of relatives and friends of mentally ill people.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: In fact, under Montana law, for a person to be committed to the state hospital at Warm Springs, he must pose an imminent threat to himself or others, ''which is usually interpreted to mean he must be pointing a gun at himself or someone else,'' Mr. Alcorn said. Many people with mental disorders are simply put in the local jail, he said.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Mr. Weston was ordered committed to the Warm Springs hospital by a judge, for 53 days in 1996, apparently after making a threat against President Clinton and being interviewed by the Secret Service.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Then, after being put on medication, he was released on Dec. 2, 1996, because the hospital ''deemed him no longer a threat to himself or others,'' according to a spokesman for Gov. Marc Racicot. A hospital employee drove him to his cabin in nearby Rimini, the spokesman said, and made arrangements for him to receive further treatment at a mental health center in Waterloo, Ill., near his parents' rural home outside Valmeyer in Southern Illinois.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Mr. Alcorn described this as ''Greyhound therapy,'' buying Mr. Weston a one-way ticket on the bus out of the state, a way to save Montana money.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: In a series of interviews on Sunday, Mr. Weston's parents and sister, April Callahan, said that he had returned to Illinois with three medications, whose names they did not remember, and that he stopped taking them about a week later, despite their protests. While they described their growing concern over his paranoid delusions, they also seemed to understand little about how to seek help for him, or what treatment was available.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: The only community mental health clinic in Waterloo is Human Support Services, a state-financed center. But a spokesman for the clinic, Rob Singer, refused to say today whether Mr. Weston had been seen there after his return from Montana. Mr. Singer said the center had been advised by both its lawyers and the office of the Governor of Illinois not to disclose any information.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Last November, a similar killing by a mental patient took place in Montana, the state where Mr. Weston was treated and then sent back to Illinois, and a state heavily criticized by mental health advocates for the quality of its care.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: A man suffering from schizophrenia, who was off his medication, burst through the door of the motel room below his one night, firing a stolen pistol and killing a mother and narrowly missing her 4-year-old son. The authorities and family members said that the man, identified as Kurtis Willetts, who had been in and out of psychiatric clinics in Montana and California, had delusions that the woman was broadcasting messages from her television set into his brain that the Mafia was trying to kill him.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Preventing a shooting like that attributed to Mr. Weston is particularly difficult because advocates for the mentally ill do not want to stigmatize them by suggesting that they are any more violent than healthy people. Many experts have been cautious even about publicizing new research suggesting that the emotionally disturbed are indeed more violent than other people, in certain situations.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Among the situations are when a person has strong paranoid symptoms that someone is out to get him or hears a voice telling him to kill, said Bruce Link, a professor at Columbia University School of Public Health. Another is when a patient fails to show up for treatment or is off his medication, said Jeffrey Sawnson, an assistant professor of psychiatry at Duke University.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Last May, a MacArthur Foundation study found a third risky situation: that mental patients are no more violent than others unless they are abusing drugs or alcohol. Mr. Weston is said by friends to have smoked marijuana when he was in high school, and he was arrested on suspicion of selling drugs in 1991.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: Professor Swanson said it is important to remember that the mentally ill are responsible for only about 4 percent of overall violence, making mental illness a smaller risk factor than being young, male or poor. But in a sign of how the experts disagree on the subject, Dr. Torrey stressed that mentally ill people commit 1,000 homicides a year.
title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill

text: THE nearly empty room at Riverhead Town Hall was silent as the officers of the court entered on a recent Wednesday to decide the fate of a 15-year-old boy charged with possession of marijuana.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: Leading the procession was the judge, Sabina Sapienza, in her black robe. All of the other court officers wore blue golf shirts with gold letters and an emblem of the scales of justice.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: The judge is 18 and a recent Shoreham-Wading River High School graduate. None of the others is old enough to take a legal drink.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: But it was not a mock trial; this was real justice being dispensed. It was the third case ever tried by the new Riverhead Youth Court, a judicial innovation in which minors who choose to plead guilty to misdemeanors are given the option of being sentenced by their peers.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: The defendant decided to go before the Youth Court when given the option upon his arrest by the Riverhead police. ''I figured this was better than a real court,'' the defendant said while waiting outside the courtroom during deliberations by the jury, which on this night included three officers of the newly formed Town of Brookhaven youth court, who who had come to get a taste of participation in a real trial.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: Three youth courts have been established on Long Island with funding through Federal grant money administered by the New York State Division of Criminal Justice Services.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: Youth court defendants are juveniles who agree along with their parents to have their cases heard using the unconventional method. They must be first-time nonviolent offenders who plead guilty to nothing more than a misdemeanor. Cases can be referred through the probation department and other sources such as a local school district.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: ''The feedback that we've gotten on the youth courts has been overwhelmingly positive,'' said Scott Sandman, a spokesman for the State Division of Criminal Justice.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: ''It's a movement that's going around the country,'' said Vincent Iaria, the Suffolk County Director of Probation. ''If you have peer involvement not only will people learn about the system and take it seriously, they'll also have to do meaningful punishment decided by their peers. It helps the delinquent to see it's a crime against the community. It's a crime against all of us, including their fellow peers.''
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: Besides the defendant in the Riverhead marijuana case and his mother, who sat next to him throughout the session, the case involved two prosecuting attorneys, two defense attorneys, the five jurors, a clerk and the judge. The only adults with any significant role in the proceedings were Dan Rodgers and John Shields, volunteer attorneys who coached the young prosecution and defense teams and answered questions asked by the jurors during deliberations. The two adults have the right to intervene in case of some miscarriage of justice.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: ''The toughest critics on kids are the kids,'' said Mr. Rodgers, a criminal attorney in Riverhead who volunteered to be a mentor to Youth Court members and said he found the process rewarding and worthwhile. ''The message gets across loud and clear.''
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: ''I think it's fantastic,'' said Mr. Shields, another volunteer mentor and also a Southampton Town deputy town attorney. ''I've seen some performances here that are equal if not better than law competitions I've seen.''
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: The defendant's two young attorneys argued for leniency after presenting three witnesses, including the defendant, to testify that the 15-year-old was cooperative, helpful at home, active in sports and not planning to break the law again.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: ''He has admitted that he made a stupid mistake,'' said Lauren Paladino, a recent Riverhead High School graduate, issuing her closing statement for the defense. ''I'm sure most of you have been in the same spot.''
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: From the stand, the defendant told the jury that his desire for a career in law enforcement was strengthened by the experience. ''I want to stop kids from messing up like me,'' he said. When asked if he would be a repeat offender, he said: ''I was arrested and handcuffed. That scared me a lot.''
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: Officer Scott Wicklund of the Riverhead Town Police also took the witness stand to testify about the arrest and the defendant's cooperation. ''I really firmly believe in this,'' Officer Wicklund said of the court, adding that he felt more nervous testifying in youth court than he did in the conventional court system.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: During deliberations, where Mr. Rodgers and Judy Doll, who supervises the youth court program for Riverhead Town, dispensed advice and answers, the jury talked about how they wanted to be sure the defendant learned from the experience and did not get in trouble again. They did not buy the defense's requested sentence: 10 hours of community service working with the defendant's choice group, the elderly. Instead they went with the suggestion of the prosecuting attorney Ed Libassi, a recent Shoreham-Wading River High School graduate who will attend John Jay College in New York in September to pursue a police science degree. He recommended 25 hours of community service.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: The defendant was given 10 hours of cleaning and washing Riverhead Town Police vehicles, 8 hours working inside the police department and 7 hours at the town's animal control center. The defendant was also ordered to take a tour of the local jail and serve as a juror on a later case.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: Outside in the hallway throughout the trial was a woman whose daughter was serving as a juror as part of a shoplifting sentence handed down in an earlier youth court session. The daughter had also been sentenced to four hours of community service and was sent to a recovery program on shoplifting.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: ''I think it means more to them when they're told through their peers,'' the mother said.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: The mother of a another youth court defendant whose case was being heard that night said she noticed a positive change in her son even before the trial.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: ''I think that he got a lot out of it because he met with an attorney who was in his peer group,'' the mother said. ''I don't think he would have responded if he had gone before a judge. I've been living with the kid for the past 10 days, and it's been a pleasure.''
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: Thirty-one youth court grants were awarded throughout the state, with the Riverhead program getting $26,500, Brookhaven $24,000 and Southampton $26,500. But for now, the Riverhead program is the only one on Long Island to have tried a case.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: State Assemblywoman Patricia Acampora, a Republican from Mattituck, helped procure funding for the Riverhead Youth Court and said she would like to see the teen-agers get more cases. According to her, there has been some resistance from the family court system because of a lack of state legislation that would establish clearer lines of accountability in case something went wrong with a youth court case. The supervising judge of the Suffolk County Family Court, David Freundlich, declined to comment.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: Although she can understand the concern and is in the process of researching the possibility of a future bill, Ms. Acampora believes that going through a lengthy legislative process would be difficult. ''Let's not make it more complicated,'' she said, citing youth courts that have been operating successfully in other parts of the state.
title: Now, Justice Is Served By Youths, For Youths

text: CAPITOL HILL SLAYINGS: THE SUSPECT
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: This article was reported by James Brooke, Pam Belluck and John Kifner
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Russell Eugene Weston Jr. was a quiet loner who drifted back and forth between a cabin in the Montana mountains and a modest house in rural Illinois, all the while becoming an increasingly troubled figure who eventually was hospitalized two years ago after writing threatening letters to government officials, said officials and people who knew him.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''He had something against'' President Clinton personally and the government, said Jerry Swihart, an employee of the Warm Springs State Mental Hospital in Montana. ''He was possessed by it. He went on and on.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Sheriff Daniel Kelley of Monroe County, Ill., after speaking to the suspect's family there, said they had told him that their son had been diagnosed by a medical professional as a paranoid schizophrenic.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Mr. Weston, the suspect in the Capitol building shootout that killed two police officers on Friday, was involuntarily committed to Warm Springs by court order on Oct. 11, 1996, according to Andrew H. Malcolm, a spokesman for Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana. He was released on Dec. 2, 1996, because the hospital ''deemed him no longer a threat to himself or others,'' Mr. Malcolm said. After Mr. Weston was released, a hospital employee drove him to his cabin here with the understanding that he would close it for the winter and return to his parents' home outside Valmeyer, Ill., where he had a series of appointments at a mental health center in nearby Waterloo. But it remained unclear today whether he kept those appointments.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Earlier that year, Mr. Weston's anti-government statements, including an accusation that officials had planted land mines on his property in Montana, were virulent enough to attract the attention of the Secret Service, Federal officials said. Mr. Weston was questioned by agents in April 1996, and the service's Presidential Protective Detail has maintained a slim file on him ever since.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: That May, the Secret Service classified him as a minor threat -- a probably harmless but potentially dangerous man, law-enforcement officials said. The Secret Service made the assessment after reviewing interviews with Mr. Weston conducted by local mental health authorities, they said.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: The portrait of the 41-year-old Mr. Weston emerging from interviews with the few people who noticed him in the two tiny towns where he lived -- Rimini, a former gold mining hamlet 17 miles southwest of Helena, Montana's capital, and Valmeyer, a Mississippi River town south of St. Louis -- was of a withdrawn, introverted loner who grew increasingly angry and alienated over the years.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Indeed, when invitation letters went out for a 20-year reunion of the 63 members of his 1974 graduating class at Valmeyer High School, his came back scrawled with obscenities and a warning never to contact him again.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''There were a few expletives,'' said Gary Baum, whose wife, Sandy, was the class president. ''Basically, he said you could put the letter where the sun doesn't shine.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: The anger apparently finally exploded when he drove his battered red pickup truck to Washington, officials said, and stormed past a metal detector into the Capitol, firing a .38-caliber revolver and killing the two officers.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: In Rimini, an old prospector's haunt in a thickly forested valley on the eastern shoulder of the Continental Divide -- not far from where the convicted Unabomber, Theodore J. Kaczynski, lived unremarked upon by his neighbors -- residents said they generally steered clear of Mr. Weston but thought he was harmless.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''When he was on his medication, he was fine, he would wave and talk,'' said May Moore, a longtime resident, as she stood this morning on the village's main street, a dirt road leading to the Helena National Forest.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''When he was off the medication, he was paranoid, you just didn't know,'' Mrs. Moore said as F.B.I. agents began to search the cabin where Mr. Weston spent most of his summers. ''His grandmother and his parents used to check in on him with the lady next door.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Kenneth D. Moore, her husband, pointed to his nine-foot television satellite dish and recalled that Mr. Weston used to accuse him of aiming it at his cabin.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''He would say, 'That's pointing at my house, they're watching me,' '' said Mr. Moore, the settlement's unofficial mayor, who added that while he was not afraid of Mr. Weston, he generally preferred to avoid him.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''Everybody was a little leery,'' he said. ''He was never violent, but you never know.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Around Valmeyer, whose population of about 900 was cut in half by the great Mississippi river flood of 1993, Mr. Weston, known as Rusty, was remembered only vaguely; his family lived out in a rural, unincorporated area a half dozen miles north of town. Townspeople said he moved to Montana soon after getting out of high school in 1974 and only returned once in a while to visit his family.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''You have to understand, it was the early 70's when we were in high school and graduated,'' said Mr. Baum, his old classmate. ''It was the end of the Vietnam War. We were way out in the sticks and a little bit behind the rest of the country with the whole drug scene.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: He remembered Mr. Weston from the seventh grade on, mostly as ''one of the forgotten middle kids, kind of on the fat side, not a sports guy, never went out with any girls. Only had a couple of friends.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Then around the 11th grade, Mr. Baum recalled, ''he started getting into the drug scene, smoking marijuana. He and a group of other kids, they all went out to this place in Montana. They wanted to get away, to be free. It was to be some kind of self-sufficient commune. I heard he had a gold claim out there.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Elaine Knobloch, who was a senior at the 200-student high school in 1974, when Mr. Weston was a freshman, said, ''He was not a person who participated in sports or music or anything.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''He was just a quiet, shy kid,'' she remembered after leafing through her high school yearbook, The Pirate. ''Not a troublemaker. He didn't stand out as anything.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Mrs. Knobloch said her husband, Dennis, a high school classmate who as Mayor and later village administrator was a major force in rebuilding the destroyed town above the flood plain, could not remember having seen Mr. Weston since they graduated. But she, too, remembered the talk about Mr. Weston falling in with the clique of marijuana smokers that developed in the mid-'70s.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Alberta Reichman, whose son, Perry, went to school with Mr. Weston, remembered him as ''a chunky kid in school, with curly hair'' looking different from the gaunt visage on the Montana license she saw on television.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: In the Montana mountains today, a bomb disposal squad from the Air Force was searching through the lot where Mr. Weston lived. April Callahan, Mr. Weston's sister, bought the property, a former gold-mining claim known as the Minnie Lea Lode, in the early 1990's. The lot, on the site of an old railroad turntable, has three weather-beaten shacks and is littered with three trucks and a car.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Roger Siewert, 54, a self-employed construction worker and prospector, whose land abuts the lot, said he last saw Mr. Weston in mid-June. He said he had talked to Mr. Weston several times over the last four years. Conversations always started out normally, he said, but quickly turned to talk that the C.I.A. and F.B.I. were out to kill him.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''He was paranoid but not violent,'' Mr. Siewert said. ''Everyone and everything was out to get him. Satellite dishes were messing up his mind. He said he had been an inside member of the Kennedy clan, and for some reason the F.B.I. and C.I.A. were out to assassinate him.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''He was paranoid about people breaking into his house. I had some surveyors up here setting some pins on the land, and he claimed they broke into his house and were going through his stuff. I checked with the surveyor, and he said no way.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Rimini grew up as a mining town in the 1880's with a population that once numbered 3,000, but that has dwindled to about 30 in the winter. But with its 5,300-foot altitude, offering cool air, meadows of clover and daisies and hillsides of spruce and lodgepole pine, the village is undergoing a minor boom in the construction of log cabins.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''The community is changing, where people like him are leaving,'' said Ted Topolski, a real estate investor here, referring to Mr. Weston
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: . Mr. Weston was arrested in Helena on suspicion of selling drugs on Aug. 7, 1991, but no formal charges were filed.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Some 20 miles south of here, near Clancey, Mr. Weston had another run in with the authorities, recalled Tim Campbell, undersheriff of Jefferson County.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: In the mid-1980's, Mr. Weston threatened the undersheriff and several other county officials. ''He confronted me and said something along the lines of 'you better watch your back,' '' Mr. Campbell said this morning.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''But he never made it intimidation. He knew where to stop.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: The threats stemmed from an incident in 1983 when an 86-year-old woman, Dorothy Cole, hit Mr. Weston on the head with her cane while trying to evict him from a cabin he was renting from her. Similar to the cabin here, it had no sewer hookup.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: In 1986, Mr. Weston sued Mrs. Cole, but the suit was thrown out on the ground that he had waited too long -- three years -- to file. He appealed to the Montana Supreme Court, but the lower court ruling was upheld in 1988. At the time, Mr. Weston protested by calling a radio talk show and by sending letters to local newspapers and to Mr. Racicot, then Montana's attorney general. He was angry at Jefferson County officials because they refused to file charges in the assault.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: In Valmeyer, people who knew Mr. Weston said that when he returned home in recent years, he mainly kept to himself. He spent much of his time in the family home on B Road, an isolated rural route where the frame houses are stitched together by vast fields of soybeans and corn.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: He spent a lot of time gardening and chopping up some of the hundreds of dead trees that are the detritus of the flood of 1993, when virtually all of Valmeyer was washed away and the town, to save itself, moved to higher ground. Unlike many of their neighbors, the Westons, who have lived for at least 50 years on the land here, about six miles north of Valmeyer, stayed behind after the flood.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Mr. Weston was close with his sister, Ms. Callahan, whose nickname was Becky. They frequently talked on the phone, said Joe Schellhardt, who knew Mr. Weston when he was younger. Ms. Callahan and her husband, Ron, live in a pale yellow frame house with an American flag out front, next door to a grain elevator, in Fults, a two-street town about 15 miles from the family home. They were not home today.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: Mr. Schellhardt and neighbors of Ms. Callahan in Fults also said that Mr. Weston and a group of other young men, including Mr. Schellhardt's brother Michael, headed to Montana soon after high school.
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: ''They got menial jobs and lived in a cabin,'' Mr. Schellhardt said. ''They went to have fun like young men do. No women went.''
title: Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters

text: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI'S pronouncement last week that New York City should abolish methadone treatment for heroin addicts by the year 2000 drew fire from many drug-abuse experts. They insist that methadone is the best tool they have to help addicts reduce heroin use, stay out of jail and get back to work. In fact, some said, they wished they had something like it to treat cocaine addiction.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: That's some endorsement for a treatment that simply replaces one addictive substance with another. Methadone, a morphine-related drug taken orally to mute an addict's cravings as well as heroin's effect, doesn't even help everyone who tries the treatment. And while it helps others to kick heroin, it often doesn't wean them off drugs completely.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: Why, at a time of impressive biomedical progress, is this 30-year-old treatment the best weapon medicine has to offer against addiction?
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: The question isn't academic, given the toll that addiction takes on society. The National Institute on Drug Abuse estimates that there are four million drug addicts in the United States, two million to three million of whom are hooked on cocaine. Another 800,000 are heroin addicts. Millions more, though not addicted, use illegal drugs. According to a recent report by the General Accounting Office, the Government will spend $3.2 billion in 1998 to treat addicts. Other costs, for prevention, drug-related crime and lost productivity, total more than $60 billion a year.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: But there has been a notable lack of progress in developing new treatments for addiction, and a big reason is money, acknowledges Dr. Alan Leshner, director of the institute on drug abuse.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: ''A lot of it has to do with the fact that the pharmaceutical industry has not seen the treatment of drug addiction as a viable market, until recently,'' he said. It can cost $200 million to $400 million to develop a new drug, he said -- the type of outlay that drug companies worry won't be recovered from a market of addicts, who are typically poor and dependent on Medicaid, the Federal insurance program, which limits payments. And there is still ''a terrible stigma around addiction,'' Dr. Leshner added.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: ''I think some companies didn't want to be associated with it,'' he said. ''Many still don't want to get into this business.''
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: But things have begun to change. In the past decade, Dr. Leshner said, research in neurobiology has identified structures in the brain that might be targets for anti-addiction drugs.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: ''We have come to understand how every major drug of abuse works in the brain,'' he said. ''We've identified receptors in the brain and cloned them. We know the circuits in the brain that they activate and we know some of the common elements that may relate to the essence of addiction.''
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: Some small drug companies have become interested, both as a result of such advances and because, since the early 1990's, the institute on drug abuse has been collaborating with industry, spending $100 million a year to help test new drugs to treat addiction.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: ''Over the next few years you'll see additional medications come out, not only for heroin, but for cocaine and amphetamine addiction as well,'' Dr. Leshner said. For instance, more than 30 compounds, as well as a vaccine, are being studied as possible weapons against cocaine addiction. ''It's a top priority because we have nothing for overdose or addiction to cocaine,'' Dr. Leshner said.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: Dr. George Bigelow, a professor in the department of psychiatry and behavioral sciences at Johns Hopkins Medical School in Baltimore, said the antidepressant drug Prozac and related drugs were also being studied to determine whether they might help relieve cocaine addiction.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: But Dr. Bigelow added a note of caution. ''A lot of things have been studied for cocaine, and nothing has yet been identified that's clearly effective,'' he said. ''It has been a real frustration.''
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: Much of the research, Dr. Bigelow said, has focused on dopamine, a brain chemical that plays an important role in movement, thought, emotion and addiction. Dopamine is a neurotransmitter, a molecule released by one brain cell to signal another. Many drugs of abuse, including cocaine, amphetamines, opiates, marijuana and nicotine, act on a dopamine system that runs along the base of the brain. Activating that system by taking drugs can provoke feelings of intense pleasure.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: Dr. Bigelow said there was a potential problem with drugs that target the dopamine system. ''It might be the final common pathway for all kinds of rewarding things, food and sex and the joys of music and art,'' he said. ''So it's probably not a pathway we want to eliminate. We need to find a way to block cocaine and let people enjoy other rewards.''
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: And even if the action of cocaine can be blocked so that people no longer get high from it, that may not take care of the cravings that former users feel, often for many years even after they have quit.
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: ''One thing that makes addiction so difficult is that there is a big learning basis, and we don't have any way of making it go away,'' Dr. Bigelow said. ''People learn to get high by using drugs, and they never forget the experience. It's a burden that addicts carry for life.''
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: ''To me, that's one of the strongest arguments for prevention, and for avoiding even experimental use,'' he said, ''because you risk having experiences that you don't forget and that continue to control and manipulate you in ways you do not want.''
title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction

text: He had won the 1996 Copper Bowl with the University of Wisconsin, then quickly spent New Year's Eve partying with friends in Las Vegas. Soon it was mid-January and John Hall figured it was time to take a break from college and head home to Port Charlotte, Fla. Besides, he had received no invitation to attend the National Football League scouting combine that February. So Hall trucked his way home and stayed for nearly three weeks, and there the 6-foot-3-inch, 225-pound place-kicker ballooned to 238 pounds.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: He developed plenty of gut, he said, for his seven siblings and for his parents, Barbara and Fred, to love.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: He found himself at home savoring a few things he loves -- eating alligator tail, fishing, gigging frogs and hunting wild hogs and turkeys. Oh, and surfing, too. Typical stuff for your typical 24-year-old kicker?
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: Not quite. There was, and is, little that is typical about the witty and amusing Hall. When he returned to college in late January 1997 after his carefree spree, he said enough of the laziness. He opted for a workout. And in his locker he found mail: an invitation to the scouting combine that had sat there for weeks. He read the letter at 1 P.M. His deadline to reply was 4:30 that day.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: ''God must have been with me,'' Hall said at the Jets' training camp this week, marveling once again at the timing. ''I called. I got cleared for the combine. I got some buddies together and started kicking every ball in sight. I started running, trying to get my gut down. I only had about eight days to get ready and I lost 12 pounds in that time.''
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: His combine performance was average. That April he was not drafted. But a few teams were interested, and Hall settled on being a free-agent signee with Arizona. That was when Jets Coach Bill Parcells called -- in the manner that only Parcells could.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: ''I figured I was going to Arizona, but I didn't have a clue on how to make the decision,'' Hall recalled. ''I didn't have an agent. I was like a kid in a candy store trying to pick the sweetest piece. Coach Parcells called me and said: 'You're not going to Arizona! You go there or to any of these other teams that have talked to you and you'll be a backup, just watching. You come here and you're going to get a chance to kick. You're coming here!' ''
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: And Hall answered, ''All right.''
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: And that is how he became a Jet.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: Last season, his first in the N.F.L., he set the modern record for touchbacks on kickoffs by booming 29 out of the end zone. He tied with three others kickers for the longest field goal of the season (55 yards). He made four field goals of 50 or more yards. He also scored 120 points, fifth best in the league.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: As a rookie, John Hall grabbed the alligator by the tail. And now, as he enters his second pro season, Hall epitomizes the Jets -- young, hungry and expected to accomplish so much more. ''I know how to relax and to have fun,'' Hall said as he and the Jets began taxing two-a-day training-camp workouts at the team's facility at Hofstra University last week. ''Everybody that plays this game has lost at it. But you don't fear that as much as you hate losing. Last year we almost made the playoffs. This year we want to finish what we start and be champions, right now. We found out what it's all about. We are expected to do more. I expect that of myself.''
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: More, for the Jets, means improving from a 1-15 record in 1996 to 9-7 in 1997 to maybe winning the American Conference East, or at least earning playoff berth, in 1998.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: More for Hall means connecting on more short-range field goal attempts. He was 28 of 41 in all attempts (68.3 percent), which put the Jets near the bottom in that category in the American Conference, with only Oakland worse. But Hall and his teammates on special teams will be hard pressed to improve in other areas. The Jets' opponents started their average drive from just inside the 24-yard line, which made the Jets, along with Miami, best in the league in that category; that was largely because Hall booted kickoffs out of the end zone and prevented returns. The Jets complemented that by being best in the league on their own drive starts (30.8 yards). Their special teams scored four touchdowns. Over all, each Jets special-teams unit sparkled under assistant coach Mike Sweatman.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: In part it was because of commitment. Unlike other N.F.L. clubs, the Jets incorporate special-teams work into their team practices, instead of doing it afterward. Everybody watches the work and thus, everybody is in some way a participant.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: As the Jets prepare for their preseason opener on Aug. 6 at Philadelphia and for their regular-season opener on Sept. 6 at San Francisco, this is a foundation on which they will build. And Hall stands smack in the middle of it.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: His first off season as a pro was marred by an arrest for marijuana possession on Valentine's Day. Hall was driving with a friend near his home in Florida and was pulled over by police officers, who found a small portion of the drug in the car. Hall is mum about it, except to say it was not his and that the charge was dropped. Under league rules, however, he has had to enter the N.F.L. drug program and is being closely monitored. Thus far, there have been no more problems, he said. Just bad timing. But he knows that he has a knack for good timing, too.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: ''The guys joke about the kickers around here -- we're big and we lift weights like everyone else,'' Hall said. ''We run pass routes for the defense. We do tackling drills and we do stripping drills. We're the new millennium kickers.''
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: He said that, laughing, as if it were a tall alligator tale from a free spirit, from the special kicker that he is.
title: Hall Has Atypical Leg and Tastes

text: A PIRATE LOOKS AT FIFTY
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: ARE you a Parrothead? If so, you may love this book. If not -- and especially if you don't even know what a Parrothead is -- ''A Pirate Looks at Fifty'' requires some background.
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: Jimmy Buffett is a rock star, and a terrific lyricist. His songs include the barroom classics ''(Wastin' Away Again in) Margaritaville'' and ''Cheeseburger in Paradise,'' not to mention ''My Head Hurts, My Feet Stink and I Don't Love Jesus.'' His books of fiction, ''Tales from Margaritaville'' and ''Where Is Joe Merchant?,'' were both best sellers. He is known, it says on this new book's jacket, to have some of ''the most devoted fans in the music industry'' -- viz., the Parrotheads.
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: In ''A Pirate Looks at Fifty,'' Buffett takes the occasion of his 50th birthday to tell us about himself, and he does so with candor and modesty. The person who emerges is not the sort of rock star who trashes hotel rooms and slugs paparazzi, but a charming, decent, wry, kind and contemplative man. If it weren't for those millions of Parrotheads, however, I would be very surprised if this book could ever have been published.
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: Among the number of bookish conventions with which ''A Pirate Looks at Fifty'' seems to have dispensed are continuity, structure and editing. What makes it a book are the configuration (cover, pages, etc.), the quantity of verbiage, the celebrity of the author and not much else. There is no story as such. Buffett goes on vacation with his family (in not one but two private airplanes -- ''My Citation II jet was too small''); he reminisces; and on his trusty laptop he records whatever crosses his mind, apparently in whatever order it crosses and no matter how trivial.
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: He spends three pages shopping for a backpack. He discourses at length on his deep commitment to unpacking, even for short stays. He shares his observations: ''We find ourselves in the middle of the crowded dining room full of vacationing families.'' He remembers a thing, and then another thing, which reminds him of something else. This is a particular surprise coming from a songwriter whose densely rhymed lyrics are models of economy and structural strength.
