In the course of a few paragraphs we jump from Javier the Costa Rican bellhop in 1997 to a teacher of French in Mississippi in the 1960's to a French film producer's chateau in 1974 to the island of St. Bart's in 1976 -- occasions linked only by Buffet's embarrassment at not speaking foreign languages well. ''My writing style,'' he tells us, ''is a rather unrefined stream of consciousness.'' And how.
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: Although Buffett has renounced recreational drugs, as a young man, we read, he had quite an enthusiasm for them, and the narrative vividly portrays the run-on self-fascination of cocaine and the why-do-you-think-they-call-it-dope dissociations of marijuana. Coke seems to make the most banal events take on sub-effable deep meanings; pot reinforces that sense of nonspecific significance, but then you forget what it was that was so important that you were talking about it.
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: In this narrative, everything seems to be of about the same importance. ''We chat while the crew unloads the bags.'' Costa Rica ''has a thriving and varied economy,'' also an ''overabundance of natural resources.'' ''The trip from the front desk of the hotel to our room the night before had been an adventure all its own, sorting through a confusing system of floor and room numbers.'' The friend who recommended Costa Rica ''works at Stuart Surfboards in Laguna Beach.''
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: The tone stays similarly colorless most of the time, but every so often the superior position of the author peeks through: ''We are all citizens of the world. You'd better come to terms with that concept or get ready to spend your life behind a fast-food counter.''
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: Parrotheads may not mind such advice. They may not mind crashing through thickets of cliches -- ''my lovely wife,'' ''the winds of fate,'' ''the rest is history,'' ''the hills and valleys of my life journey,'' ''in my family and friends I have discovered treasure more valuable than gold.''
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: A dart flung onto the best-seller list at random, after all, has favorable odds of nailing equally well-wrought English; there are many book lovers whose fun such language does not spoil. Complaining about it makes me feel rather the fussbudget, like the sniffy interior decorator who is the only guest at the party to notice how ugly the curtains are and won't shut up about it.
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: ''A Pirate Looks at Fifty'' is, in fact, a party of a kind, and the birthday boy is a very nice guy. He loves his airplanes and his children and his work. He credits his success, which is truly immense, to luck. He tells some fine anecdotes, the best of them set in the days when the ''shy ex-altar-boy from Alabama'' was playing street corners and discovering ''the kind of work I not only wanted to do, but was best at -- performing.'' Buffett's evocation of the languid, louche Key West of the 1970's draws on the same well of affection as his best songs. His reconciliation with his father, as the hard-crusted old man fades into the shapeless fog of Alzheimer's, is compassionate and courageous.
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: Buffett writes that he has been ''detained by customs, strip-searched and bribed by various law enforcement agencies, shot at by a SWAT team while I went to lunch, chased by Apache helicopters,'' but he tells us none of those stories. I would particularly have liked to hear how the cops bribed him, but that one didn't make the cut: ''In writing a book of reminiscences like this, you always hit the high points and wonderful stories that make for good reading.'' Buffet's idea of a high point and wonderful story, then, would be (for example) the one about being delayed for more than five hours in the airport at Barranquilla, Colombia. He gets so hungry he is reduced to eating peanut-butter crackers; he is rescued from starvation by a bureaucrat named Barbarella ''in a lime green see-through blouse and a white miniskirt''; there are flies in the restaurant, and it smells; it also serves ''the worst club sandwich in the world.''
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: Faithful Parrotheads may be fascinated by this sort of thing. A really, really faithful Parrothead may not even mind ''Like a thunderstorm cloud out over the Gulf, the bottom fell out of my dreams.''
title: Wastin' Away Again

text: TWO years ago, on Mother's Day, a Trumbull police officer, George Coleman, stopped a black male motorist in a van and told him he needed to check his license and registration.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Unaware that the motorist was State Senator Alvin W. Penn, a Democrat of Bridgeport, the officer returned the license and registration and, said Mr. Penn, asked if he knew which town he was in. ''I asked why I was being stopped and why I needed to be aware of which town I was in; I wanted to know what difference that made,'' said Mr. Penn, recalling how he got lost that day trying to find a short cut to the Trumbull Shopping Park and was turning around on a dead-end street when the officer blocked his van with a patrol car.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''The officer said he didn't have to give a reason for stopping me and said if I made an issue of it, he would say I was speeding,'' said Mr. Penn, now Deputy President of the State Senate.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: At the time, the Trumbull Police Chief, Theodore J. Ambrosini, publicly supported the officer, insisting he had ''made a legitimate stop,'' and denied that racial profiling -- pulling someone over based on their racial appearance -- had ever been employed in Trumbull, where about 2 percent of the 31 residents are black. But Mr. Ambrosini is now on the hot seat. A memorandum written by him in 1993 that was leaked last month by officers in the all-white 68-member department not only condones racial profiling, they say, but also contains coded references that encourage officers to do it. In the memo, Mr. Ambrosini describes a series of armed robberies in town and urges officers to take the offensive. ''One form of deterrence might to develop a sense of proclivity toward the type of persons and vehicles which are usually involved in these crimes,'' the memo says. It concludes: ''not only is it our obligation to enforce the motor vehicle laws, but in doing so, we are provided with a profile of our community and those who travel within its boundaries.''
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Mr. Ambrosini, while suggesting there is nothing wrong with keeping an eye out for strangers in the community, strongly denies that the memo encourages racial profiling.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''When I wrote that memo there was never any malice intended toward any race,'' he said. ''I have nothing against blacks, and I don't believe there is a racist officer in this department.''
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: N.A.A.C.P. leaders dismiss such denials by law enforcement officials, and say that until the police admit the practice exists -- and that it constitutes racial bias -- there is little chance for change.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: They say that after years of trying to prove that profiling exists, the Trumbull memo is a form of validation, being the first police document in the state that proves not only its existence but also its sanction by police authorities.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: The Trumbull episode and others have prompted a Justice Department review and demands by civil rights leaders for an F.B.I. investigation. ''They're calling us liars when they say that profiling doesn't exist and we won't tolerate it any longer,'' said the state president of the N.A.A.C.P., Roger Vann, at a recent rally preceding a 50-car caravan drive from Bridgeport to Trumbull; the motorcade ended with a drive around the police headquarters in Trumbull.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Mr. Penn says he is planning to introduce state legislation similar to a bill pending in Congress that would require the Justice Department to collect racial and ethnic statistics on traffic stops, in an effort to make the police more sensitive about the issue.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: N.A.A.C.P. leaders and others say the issue goes far beyond Trumbull, insisting that black and Hispanic motorists are targeted in suburban towns and rural areas across the country.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: In April, along the New Jersey Turnpike, two state troopers shot 11 times into a van carrying three students, two black and one Hispanic, after their van was pulled over for what officials later determined were questionable reasons. The shootings led Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to issue an order that state troopers install cameras to record all traffic stops.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''Anyone who is black and has driven a car knows all too well that this is something that continues to happen all across this nation,'' said Mr. Vann. The recent N.A.A.C.P. convention in Atlanta approved a resolution that racial profiling be the focus of scrutiny by all the state chapters, and that motorists be encouraged to report profiling incidents.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: As a result of the death last year of Malik Jones, a 21-year-old black man from New Haven shot by East Haven police after a chase and traffic stop, Mr. Vann began a statewide reporting program, ''Operation Blind Justice,'' that is encouraging people to report any instance of profiling they encounter. So far, more than 300 reports have been made.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Noel McGregor Jr., formerly a detective with the Hartford Police Department who served for years as president of the Hartford Guardians, a group of minority police officers, said the use of ''border patrols'' is a common practice of suburban towns to keep out minorities from nearby cities.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''Anyone who has been involved in law enforcement knows this happens, and to say it doesn't is ridiculous and ingenuous,'' said Mr. McGregor. ''It can be nothing more than just stopping a motorist and running a check on their license, or issuing a summons for a minor infractions . . . but the overall goal is to keep people of color out of their towns.''
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: One of those towns near Hartford is Avon, where a 1994 investigation found that two police supervisors had for years ordered the targeting of minority motorists driving though the predominately white town.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: The investigation was prompted when the town's first black police officer, Alvin Schwapp, filed a discrimination suit against the department, a case that is still in the Federal courts and expected to resume in September.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''When I was hired, officers in the department told me that racial profiling had been a routine practice and that it was still something espoused by some supervisors,'' said Mr. Schwapp, who quit the Avon Police Department in 1994 and joined the Bloomfield Police Department. ''For any police official to deny that profiling exists is a joke.''
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Some police officials, however, say that while they disagree with racial profiling, officers need to have some leeway to act on instinct and stop cars when they suspect criminal activity.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Col. John F. Bardelli, the state's Deputy Commissioner of Public Safety who heads the State Police, cited the recent case of a state trooper who stopped a motorist driving just over the speed limit -- and ended up finding 170 pounds of marijuana in the car.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''I really believe we are color blind in this agency, and that when a trooper stops a car he or she knows they have to have a reason for it,'' said Colonel Bardelli. He added that he would not favor legislation to mandate troopers to collect data from motorists on their race and ethnicity.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''That could very well create more racial tensions and problems than it would solve,'' he said. Colonel Bardelli noted that 15 percent of the state's 1,000 state troopers are members of minority groups.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Bridgeport Police Chief Thomas Sweeney agreed that while officers should never employ racial profiling, they need to be able to stop a motorist -- white or black -- when they have a reason to suspect possible criminal activity.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''We don't condone racial profiling in this department and there has to be a valid reason to stop someone,'' said Chief Sweeney. ''But when an officer sees something he or she believes is suspicious, they would not be doing their job if they didn't at least check it out. That doesn't have to have anything to do with profiling.''
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: But black people say too often it does.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Wayne Winston says it happened to him in Trumbull about two months ago while driving from his girlfriend's home to Bridgeport.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: Mr. Winston said a police officer stopped him, asked for his license, and told him he had decided to run a check on his registration -- even though it was up to date and there was no outward sign of a problem.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: When the officer advised him the registration sticker was for the wrong car, an embarrassed Mr. Winston said he immediately realized he had mistakenly placed a new sticker from his girlfriend's car on his vehicle; he said he corrected his mistake the next day.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: But Mr. Winston insists the real issue is why he was stopped in the first place.
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: ''I was stopped because a police officer saw a black man driving in his all-white town,'' said Mr. Winston, adding that it had happed on numerous occasions. ''I admit I made a mistake, but that's not why I was stopped.''
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: When the officer looked into the car ''all he saw was a black man,'' said Mr. Winston, who is communications director for the Greater Bridgeport-Stratford chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. ''They stop us to send a message, and the message is clear -- stay out of our town.''
title: Policing The Police: On Racial Profiling

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: School Manual Intended To Combat Drug Abuse

text: State officials yesterday released a 273-page manual of guidelines intended to help school districts guard against drug abuse by students within legal limits.
title: School Manual Intended To Combat Drug Abuse

text: According to the manual, released jointly by Attorney General Peter Verniero and the state Education Commissioner, Leo F. Klagholz, random drug testing of student athletes is permissible, but the results cannot be turned over to prosecutors; smelling marijuana or alcohol on a student's breath constitutes just cause for a search, and drug-sniffing dogs can be unleashed on lockers, but not on students themselves.
title: School Manual Intended To Combat Drug Abuse

text: Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, said boards have been keenly interested in search procedures, particularly for weapons, in the wake of shootings at schools elsewhere.
title: School Manual Intended To Combat Drug Abuse

text: Lawrence S. Lustberg, a civil liberties lawyer and board member of the Education Law Center in Newark, said the guidelines would be as good as the people who interpret them. ''Arbitrariness always stems from the absence of guidelines,'' he said. ''However, how those are implemented will always tell the tale.''
title: School Manual Intended To Combat Drug Abuse

text: 461 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: After the heyday of the American musical theater, which began with Irving Berlin, the Gershwins and Cole Porter and lasted for half a century, Stephen Sondheim is the only composer and lyricist with an original vision and a flourishing body of work. With ''Company,'' ''A Little Night Music,'' ''Sweeney Todd'' and other shows, he has set the standard for all who have followed him. The sound of Sondheim is pervasive -- from him and from those he has influenced.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: In the company of other innovative artists, he is often misunderstood. His brilliance can be mistaken for mere cleverness; his musicality can be obscured by the unusual context of the material: the soaring melody of ''Johanna'' intentionally juxtaposed with barbaric events. He has said that ambivalence is his favorite subject and that it ''allows for dramatic contrast,'' as in the motif of the song ''Sorry-Grateful.'' With his innate wit and musical acumen, Mr. Sondheim writes songs that are self-sustaining as well as dramatically meaningful within a show. His scores, in common with the man himself, are exceedingly complex.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: In her intriguing biography ''Stephen Sondheim: A Life,'' Meryle Secrest -- with the help of Mr. Sondheim -- tries to pierce the enigmatic exterior of this very private person. Perhaps, considering the nature of the subject, this is all we will be privileged to see.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: The author provides new information about Mr. Sondheim's fragmented childhood. We learn about his father, a businessman who loved to play the piano and was known with his partner as ''the Rodgers and Hart of Seventh Avenue,'' and, especially, about his domineering, unstable mother, Janet Fox (Foxy) Sondheim, with whom he lived after his father left her for another woman. He says that his mother treated him ''like dirt'' at the same time that she expressed incestuous inclinations toward him.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: As has been previously reported, she once wrote to him that ''the only regret I have in life is giving you birth.'' Here we have his response, an agreement to continue supporting her coupled with the statement ''I don't want to see you anymore.'' When she died (at 95), he was in London and did not return for the funeral.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: The reader also finds out that Mr. Sondheim ''was never easy with being a homosexual'' and had close relationships with Lee Remick and Mary Rodgers, both of whom apparently wanted to marry him. When he speaks about his life, he is revealing, for example, in comparing himself to ''the boy in the bubble,'' protected and isolated by his background and his success. Still, when he says that he has a great capacity for liquor and that it (and also marijuana) stimulates his mental processes, one wants a more thoughtful consideration of the reasons for and the effects of his apparent dependency.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: Fortunately for Mr. Sondheim, as a teen-ager he came under the tutelage of Oscar Hammerstein 2d, who was both mentor and surrogate father. It was Hammerstein who said about Mr. Sondheim's otherwise well-received schoolboy musical, ''By George,'' ''It's the worst thing I've ever read,'' adding, ''I didn't say it was untalented.'' Hammerstein's frank criticism was a turning point for the hopeful young composer, as was his suggestion that for an apprenticeship his pupil should write four very different musicals, adaptations as well as an original.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: From people with whom he has worked (Harold Prince, James Lapine, Mandy Patinkin) there are interesting observations about his professional life. In that regard the book acknowledges a debt to Craig Zadan's ''Sondheim & Co.,'' which focuses on the individual musicals. But there are also missed opportunities in discussing his various creative relationships. For example, the section on ''West Side Story'' insufficiently explores the eclecticism with which Leonard Bernstein and Mr. Sondheim wrote their score (borrowing from ''Candide,'' as well as other Bernstein sources).
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: The book is also marked by a kind of passive acceptance of what individual people say, like the author's casual crediting of the screenplay of ''The Snake Pit'' to Arthur Laurents. Mr. Laurents worked on the screenplay but not enough to have a share of the credit, which went to Frank Partos and Millen Brand.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: In any case, the comment is extraneous and distracting, as are the frequent quotations from unrelated sources ranging from Kenneth Clark (a subject of a previous Secrest biography) to Edgar Allan Poe. We also want to know less about peripheral matters like the culinary prowess of the composer's resident cook, who suddenly, late in the book, is identified by Mr. Sondheim as ''the equivalent of a wife.''
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: Against this is weighed an evenhanded portrait of a sensitive but essentially solitary man compulsively immersing himself in a very collaborative art form in which the initial ideas for shows generally come from other people. Often, as in his collaborations with Mr. Lapine, this works out to Mr. Sondheim's advantage.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: But when he worked with Hammerstein's partner, Richard Rodgers, on ''Do I Hear a Waltz?,'' it was a disastrous collision of egos and temperaments, provoking Mr. Sondheim's memorable comment that Hammerstein was a man of limited talent but infinite soul and Rodgers was a man of infinite talent but limited soul.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: Though few would question Mr. Sondheim's talent, there are those who might question the depth of his emotions. This heart-mind issue is persuasively answered by his lyrics, many of which are reprinted in the book. They are as poetic as they are personalized.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: Naturally when he writes closest to his feelings he is at his most moving: in ''Company,'' about a man of charm who holds himself at a remove from commitment; in ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' in which an artist struggles to find an image with which to express his art. ''Opening Doors,'' in ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' is, he says, the only ''consciously autobiographical'' song he has written. In her book, Ms. Secrest stresses the passion that Mr. Sondheim brings to his highly disciplined profession, and when it is pertinent she relates the life to the work.
title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius

text: In all the talk about Viagra, there is one question that hasn't been properly explored: if men use the drug ''recreationally'' and not to treat a medical condition (impotence), shouldn't the Federal Government consider putting it on its list of controlled substances?
title: Controlling Viagra-Mania

text: The Federal Controlled Substances Act regulates drugs that have a ''potential for abuse'' and can cause physical or psychological dependence. Controlled substances that the Government deems not to have any medical use, like heroin and marijuana, are simply illegal. Controlled drugs that have an accepted medical value -- including painkillers like Tylenol with codeine, Valium and other relaxants, and anabolic steroids -- are legal only when distributed or possessed under strict regulation.
title: Controlling Viagra-Mania

text: People who don't follow these regulations -- a doctor, for example, who prescribes steroids to a body-builder solely to promote muscle gain -- are subject to criminal prosecution. But a doctor who prescribes Viagra to anyone who walks through the door is not regulated under Federal law.
title: Controlling Viagra-Mania

text: Yes, Viagra has an accepted medical use. For men with serious impotence problems, like those who have had prostate surgery, it may be the best way ever for them to have a ''normal'' sex life or bear children.
title: Controlling Viagra-Mania

text: But many men -- both the 70-year-olds who want to regain part of their lost youth and the 25-year-olds who want to enhance their performance -- are simply interested in purchasing the ability to have more sex. This nonmedical use of a substance is what the law considers abuse.
title: Controlling Viagra-Mania

text: Indeed, there are striking similarities between the recreational use of Viagra and of, say, anabolic steroids and tranquilizers. It is legally considered drug abuse if a man ingests steroids simply to look virile. So why isn't it illegal to take a pill to become virile?
title: Controlling Viagra-Mania

text: One might distinguish Viagra from other controlled drugs on the ground that it is safer. But the long-term health effects are unknown. One side effect is a temporary vision impairment. There are even reports of a few deaths in men using Viagra, although none of the deaths were directly related to the drug.
title: Controlling Viagra-Mania

text: Will the Government, then, put Viagra on its list of controlled substances, even at the low level of regulation that governs steroids? Probably not. Historically, the Federal motivation for controlling drugs has been sociological rather than pharmacological. Viagra has obvious appeal to rich and powerful men. And you can be certain that they're not going to jail.
title: Controlling Viagra-Mania

text: By Don van Natta Jr.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: THEY commit their crimes with alarming frequency, emboldened by the knowledge that it is unlikely they will ever get caught. They are scammers and grifters, and the police often do not have the time or the patience to pursue them.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: But what happens when the con artist leaves a few dead bodies buried in a trail of ingenious scams and old liens? Is that enough to get the attention of the police?
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: In the case of Sante and Kenneth Kimes, the mother-and-son grifter team suspected in the disappearance of Irene Silverman, a wealthy woman in New York City, it was an Utah arrest warrant issued last April for a bad check that led to their arrest this month. The police suspect that the Kimeses committed a series of minor and major crimes over the past several years -- theft, arson, fraud and perhaps even the murders of Mrs. Silverman and two others.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: The Kimes case forcefully demonstrates that it can take a lot for the authorities to team up and search the country for suspected swindlers. It also raises questions about whether the police should put a higher priority on tracking down the more prolific scam artists -- particularly those who move around the country -- before they graduate to more serious crimes.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: ''The problem is, the con is like the marijuana of the fraud world,'' said Tom Cash, a 30-year Federal investigator who now works in the Miami Office of Kroll Associates, a corporate investigations firm. ''It just isn't worth chasing because there's so damn much of it.''
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: And the police can be less than sympathetic toward the victims of con artists, Mr. Cash said. ''After all, it's not the downtrodden who normally get ripped off. They don't have any money to lose. It is usually the well-to-do -- the lawyers, the stockbrokers and the supposed intelligentsia. And the way society sees it, most of that group can afford to get ripped off and should have known better anyway.''
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: Criminologists say that the public has high, often unrealistic expectations that the police can easily track down fugitives, even petty thieves and scammers. As one police officer who works on such cases said: ''Everybody believes there is a great big computer database that tracks everyone's movements. People have watched too much TV.''
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: Still, the police have become far more sophisticated in tracking down fugitives in recent years. A task force in Minnesota was searching for a man wanted in the 1995 Valentine's Day murder of his ex-girlfriend, but learned from acquaintances that he had fled to Mexico. Because obtaining an international arrest warrant is time consuming and difficult, the police tried something else. They floated a bogus story to the man's acquaintances to lure him back to the United States. They would not divulge the details of the ruse, but said it worked. The man returned to his sister's home in Virginia, where he was arrested. It took just six weeks.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: Some scams are so complicated, or so scattered around the globe, that the authorities have difficulty unraveling them. For example, some international scam artists manufacture their products in the Virgin Islands, operate telemarketing rooms in South Florida and are incorporated in Liechtenstein. So it is not that the cases are small; their complexity chases away all but the most patient, dedicated sleuths.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: In the Kimes's case, the authorities did not begin to pay serious attention until 1996, when some acquaintances of the Kimeses started to disappear. Syed Bilal Ahmed, a banker in the Bahamas who had dinner with Mrs. Kimes in September, 1996, has not been seen since. Last March, the body of another associate, a Los Angeles businessman named David Kazdin, was found in a Dumpster at Los Angeles International Airport.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: It was only then that Los Angeles and Federal authorities formed a task force to catalogue the activities of the Kimeses, who continued to elude and confound them with aliases and an uncanny sense of when to skip town. Although the Kimeses still only face charges for writing a single bad check, officials believe they were responsible for a string of crimes in the Bahamas, Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Utah, Louisiana, Washington, D.C., Florida and, finally, New York.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: The authorities fear they may have been only a matter of hours late in arresting the Kimeses in New York City. Mrs. Silverman was reported missing just hours before the Kimeses were taken into custody. Detectives found her passport and other papers in the Kimeses' possession, and believe they were attempting to take possession of her East Side townhouse.
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: ''There is a lesson in there for the professional scam artist,'' said Mr. Cash, of Kroll Associates. ''If you want to stay under the radar screen and keep making a living by ripping people off, don't kill anybody.''
title: The Nation; For Con Artists, It's Easy to Fly Under the Radar

text: An assistant Brooklyn district attorney was arrested outside Madison Square Garden on Thursday night on charges of possession of marijuana and hashish, the police said early yesterday.
title: A Brooklyn Prosecutor Faces Drug Charges

text: The assistant district attorney, Jason Friedman, 30, was arrested by narcotics officers from the Midtown South precinct about 9:30 P.M. on a night when Jimmy Page and Robert Plant, the surviving members of Led Zeppelin, were performing in a reunion concert at the Garden.
title: A Brooklyn Prosecutor Faces Drug Charges

text: Also arrested were William Rumbold, 32, of Rochester; Michael Krebs, 30, of Brooklyn; Michael Chrumba, 32, of Huntington Station, N.Y., and Scott Rawiszer, 32, of Suffern, N.Y., said Officer Dennis Laffin, a Police Department spokesman.
title: A Brooklyn Prosecutor Faces Drug Charges

text: Officer Laffin said police officers observed the five passing a marijuana cigarette and smoking it. When officers approached, Mr. Friedman tossed a bag and metal object onto the ground, Officer Laffin said.
title: A Brooklyn Prosecutor Faces Drug Charges

text: That bag contained hashish and the metal object was Mr. Friedman's district attorney's shield, Officer Laffin said. Investigators speaking on the condition of anonymity said that it was the first time in recent memory that someone from a district attorney's office had been arrested on drug charges.
title: A Brooklyn Prosecutor Faces Drug Charges

text: It was about 9 on a recent Wednesday night, and the crowds had already started gathering around the West Village piers. More than three dozen young men lingered at the waterfront just off the West Side Highway, talking and smoking cigarettes and marijuana. Dozens more milled in front of a pornographic video store across the highway at Christopher Street.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Men in expensive cars cruised by. Frequently they stopped, exchanging brief, hushed words with youths who approached, climbed into the cars and rode away.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Kris Hernden, 21, and a friend, James Richardson, 23, marveled at the bustling scene. Two weeks before, each had stuffed some clothes into backpacks, bought a $26 one-way bus ticket and left Baltimore for New York City. Both dream of becoming actors. But for now they are on the piers of the West Village, part of a loose band of young people, most of them gay and many of them homeless runaways, who have increased their presence in the area in the last two years.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Other neighborhoods might call in the police to drive these youths away, but officials at Community Board 2 in the West Village -- with the support of residents, community organizers and business owners -- are extending an embrace, and seeking to open a 20-bed emergency shelter for them.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Organizers acknowledge that 20 beds would not come close to housing the 500 or so homeless youths who gather at the piers. What is more important is the services the shelter would offer, including AIDS education, life skills training and mental health and substance abuse counseling, said Ruth M. Sherlip, chairwoman of the youth services planning committee of Community Board 2.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: So far, there is no organized opposition to the idea of a shelter. Business owners along Christopher Street, a thriving commercial strip that cuts through the heart of the Village, agree that a shelter should be opened, but away from the center of the neighborhood, which is crowded with tourists, said Michael C. Mirisola, co-chairman of the Christopher Street Merchants Association and a member of Community Board 2.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: The shelter proposal is far from complete, and an array of questions has yet to be resolved. Where will it be? Who will pay for it and run it? And will youths use it?
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Another difficult question is the extent of the homeless problem. Experts estimate that there are about 20,000 homeless youths in the city, but no count has been conducted since 1973. On a hot summer night there may be hundreds of young people gathered on the piers, but there is no way of knowing just how many are truly homeless and how many are simply hanging out. Youths on the streets and those from the suburbs frequently look and dress alike.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: While a dozen or so young people can usually be spotted sprawled out on benches at the piers at daybreak, most homeless youths avoid sleeping outdoors by selling sex in exchange for shelter, said Christopher Rodriguez, a spokesman for the Hetrick-Martin Institute, a nonprofit agency that serves gay youths.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Nonetheless, more and more youths are gathering on the piers as what was once their main hangout, Times Square, is rebuilt.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Mr. Rodriguez said that outreach workers who used to find hundreds of youths in Times Square barely see dozens today. The population, he said, has spread out to Central, West and East Harlem; Prospect Park in Brooklyn; Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens; along the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, and, of course, the piers, where Mr. Hernden and Mr. Richardson have been sleeping.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Both men grew up in the McCullough Houses, a sprawling housing project on Baltimore's West Side, but came to New York for different reasons.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Mr. Hernden dropped out of high school in the 11th grade because he was tired of school, he said. He also became a drug addict, he said.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: ''Some days, I would be so binged up and hyped up on crack that I would have to sniff heroin to be bring me down,'' he said. ''Every day, I said I wasn't going to do it again, but I did.''
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Mr. Hernden said he became depressed when confronted with the reality that few doors were open to him without a high school diploma. He began to work as a prostitute.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: ''I just had to leave,'' he said. ''I was basically working here and there. I got tired of that. I'm 21. I should be stable by now.''
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: At the time, Mr. Richardson was homeless, turning tricks on the streets of Baltimore in exchange for a place to sleep, he said. Mr. Richardson said he told his mother and sisters he was gay, and then endured a year of homosexual slurs from his family.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: The names got to be too much. Taking a drag off a cigarette, he said, ''I just got up and left.''
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Mr. Hernden, who told his mother he was gay when he was 16, lowered his head as he listened to his friend. The pain of his friend's story still cuts through him, he said, even though he has heard it a hundred times.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: One night, Mr. Hernden recalled, he hit rock bottom. He talked to Mr. Richardson about moving to the storied West Village, a place they had longed to live. Between the two of them, they could buy bus tickets and have $100 left over for expenses.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: ''It sounded good to me,'' Mr. Richardson said. ''We each bought one-way tickets. We wanted to make sure we didn't go back.''
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Mr. Hernden hopes a bench will not be his bed for long. He recently found a job at a McDonald's in Chinatown and wants to save up enough money to rent an apartment. Mr. Richardson has not found a job.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: The prospect of having to work as prostitutes frightens them both. ''I'm scared of the streets of New York from the things I've heard,'' Mr. Hernden said. ''But I just pray every night and I don't worry about it.''
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Just how many homeless young people like Mr. Hernden and Mr. Richardson there are in New York is unclear, said Margo Hirsch, director of the Empire State Coalition of Youth and Family Services, a network of 60 nonprofit programs that serve homeless and runaway youth in New York State. A count has not been conducted since the 1973 survey by the police department, she said, and the figure of 20,000 used by experts is an estimate.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: But social service workers agree there are not nearly enough shelters. The city has about 500 emergency shelter beds for homeless youths -- 80 percent of which are paid with private dollars through the Covenant House New York, a nonprofit agency, officials said.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, which has come under fire because it left $1.3 million of its $3.1 million budget to help homeless youth unspent last year, has indicated that it would work with Community Board 2 to ''study the possibility of opening a shelter,'' said Samantha I. Lugo, a spokeswoman for the Mayor.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: The City Council's Youth Services Committee held the first of a series of public hearings two weeks ago to determine the extent of the homeless youth problem in the West Village and throughout the city.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: City Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher, the Brooklyn Democrat who heads the committee, said he was perplexed by the administration underspending and questioned why services for homeless youth are so fragmented. The Division of Homeless Services has beds in the adult shelter system for 18- to 24-year-olds, while adolescents under 18 fall under the responsibility of the Administration for Children's Services or the Department of Youth and Community Development.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: But even if more beds were available, some young homeless people, like Nicholas Mitchell, say they would be averse to using them. Mr. Mitchell, 21, recently leaned his skinny 6 foot, 3 1/2 inch frame against a phone booth outside the video store as he took in the scene.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: He hangs out in the Village, he said, because he feels comfortable. He generally turns a blind eye to prostitution and drug sales, he said, though he has friends who are involved in both.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: Mr. Mitchell said he left home three months ago because of family problems and moved in with a transsexual he calls his ''gay mother.'' But even if he were homeless, he probably would avoid a shelter.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: ''If there was a shelter here, I can't say I would use it,'' Mr. Mitchell said.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: But a formerly homeless 21-year-old, Bobby Williams, warned against that attitude. ''As a veteran of the streets, I try to tell these other kids that they need to be careful,'' Mr. Williams said as he was hanging out on the West Side Highway near Christopher Street.
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: ''If a shelter opens, they should go. I've done all of that other stuff, selling drugs and working as a prostitute. It doesn't pay.''
title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services

text: The Netherlands had its jaw tightly set today for the arrival of Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the outspoken commander of the American war on drugs. Several days ago the general prepared for his visit by dealing a few public punches against the Dutch and their tolerance for narcotics.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: General McCaffrey is on an eight-day tour of European cities, looking at how Europeans fight and cope with drugs. That includes the Netherlands, which more than any other country has painstakingly developed a division between ''soft'' and ''hard'' drugs. It is where over the counter one can buy small bags of ''space cake,'' ''northern light'' or ''zeropolm'' -- all forms of marijuana -- and not go to jail.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: The Dutch policy to disconnect cannabis from the criminal underground of so-called hard drugs by allowing small quantities of marijuana to be sold in cafes has earned it the envy of some countries and the derision of others. General McCaffrey has made it clear that he belongs to the critics.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: In recent days he has called the permissive Dutch policy ''an unmitigated disaster.'' He further said, mistakenly, that the Dutch murder rate far outstripped that of the United States, and his office issued a statement that all but scolded the Dutch Government.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: Government officials expressed their annoyance publicly. The Foreign Minister called in the American Ambassador.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: The fracas has made the general the talk of the nation, not just in Government offices, but also in ''soft drug'' bars. One newspaper headline returned the criticism, saying it was the general who was ''an unmitigated disaster'' for drug policy.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: Today he returned to more conventional diplomacy by praising his hosts and saying that he had gained valuable insights from meetings with the police, doctors, social workers and policy makers in several cities. He said he had appreciated the chance to learn of experiments in treating heroin and cocaine addicts.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: ''I came here to listen and see what I can borrow,'' the general said. ''Most important for me is to discover how to use methadone as a tool to deal with heroin addiction. The Dutch have 20 years of experience doing that, and we want to watch that carefully.''
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: Programs to treat addicts are more thorough in the Netherlands than in the United States, General McCaffrey said. And Dutch treatment projects ''also have a much higher rate of contact with addicts than we have,'' he added.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: General McCaffrey visited a pilot project in Rotterdam where heroin addicts in a supervised center receive free heroin in an effort to reduce drug-related crimes and reduce their exposure to H.I.V. But the general clearly disapproved of such projects, which are also under way in other European countries, including Switzerland and Germany.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: Supplying heroin may reduce crimes and AIDS rates, he said, but the users remain addicts, marginalized from society and, perhaps, discouraged from joining methadone programs.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: The general did not visit any of the 800 or so cafes that the country licenses to sell marijuana and hashish in small quantities for private use. An aide said he was convinced that they were dangerous for young people because they made drug use seem normal. Besides, the aide said, the general would not want to glamorize such places.
title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program

text: For anyone who has followed the career paths of the defenders on the French World Cup team, it is no surprise that they have been the finest in the world for the past month. What is a surprise is that between them, they have managed to outscore Ronaldo: 5 goals to 4.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: Ronaldo, the Brazilian striker with the muscular thighs and wicked first step, has no intention of being overshadowed in Sunday's World Cup final against France, but even at age 21, he has seen enough tactical systems and hard tackles to know excellence.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: ''It's true that they are very, very solid defensively,'' he said. ''They have hardly shown any weaknesses.''
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: It will be strength against strength in the Stade de France: Ronaldo, Rivaldo, Bebeto and Brazil's two offensive-minded outside fullbacks, Cafu and Roberto Carlos, against the French back line and defensive midfielders.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: Whoever wins that struggle probably wins the game, and according to the French, they do not intend to win it by sticking a single bold defender on Ronaldo. They will share the responsibility: switching, adjusting, double-teaming when necessary and pushing forward when possible.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: Since the knockout round of this World Cup began, all three of France's goals have been scored by players whose customary role is to make it difficult for opposing strikers. Central defender Laurent Blanc scored the first golden goal in World Cup history to break a scoreless tie against Paraguay in the second round. Right back Lilian Thuram scored twice against Croatia in the semifinals after having never scored before in 37 previous international appearances.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: Blanc will not play on Sunday -- a major loss -- because he received a questionable red card against Croatia. But there are plenty of world-class defenders left in the French half of the field. Seven men will try to keep Brazil from having a fifth title to celebrate.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: POSITION: Left back. AGE: 28. INTERNATIONAL MATCHES: 38. CLUB: Bayern Munich (Germany).
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: A Basque who played for the quintessential Basque club, Athletic Bilbao, in Spain before moving to Munich last season, Lizarazu is short, extremely fast and the most consistently offensive of the French defenders. The player called Liza was in danger of losing his spot on the team after missing the early season with an injury, but Coach Aime Jacquet kept the faith and Lizarazu has done nothing to make him lose it this summer.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: POSITION: Central defender. AGE: 30. INTERNATIONAL MATCHES: 15. CLUB: Chelsea (England).
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: Marcel Desailly's future teammate was relatively unknown when he left for England two years ago. On the other side of the channel, Leboeuf has become a star and occasional newspaper columnist. Adept in the air and at man marking, he also has a way with a free kick, but he does not have the presence, speed or international experience of Blanc. Expect the Brazilians to test him often.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: POSITION: Central defender. AGE: 29. INTERNATIONAL MATCHES: 48. CLUB: AC Milan (Italy).
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: Desailly has arguably been France's finest player in this World Cup. He has not lost a duel yet, and though he has yet to score a goal, he hopes to rectify that against Brazil. He is sensitive, occasionally abrasive and powerful on land and in the air. Desailly was born in Ghana and moved to the French mainland at the age of 6 after his mother, a Ghanian, married a Frenchman. Like Barthez, he was part of the Marseilles club that won France's first European Champions Cup title in 1993. Desailly won a Champions League title with Milan in 1994 playing in midfield. He will be leaving AC Milan for Chelsea in England next season. Lucky Chelsea.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: POSITION: Goalkeeper. AGE: 27. INTERNATIONAL MATCHES: 19. CLUB: Monaco.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: Barthez won his spot over the veteran goalkeeper Bernard Lama, who like Barthez served a several-month suspension after testing positive for marijuana. Barthez is an imposing presence: excellent in the air but less adept at distribution. In 1993, he was the goalkeeper on the Olympique Marseilles team that won France's first European Champions Cup title. In this tournament, Barthez has given up only two goals in six games (one on a penalty kick), and his shaved head has become a French talisman. Blanc has kissed it on the field before every game, and despite his suspension, Blanc plans to kiss it again on Sunday.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: POSITION: Defensive midfielder. AGE: 29. INTERNATIONAL MATCHES: 75. CLUB: Juventus of Turin (Italy).
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: He is the captain and one of the few links to the French team that failed to qualify for the last World Cup. Deschamps, a Basque like Lizarazu, plays with the French playmaker Zinedine Zidane at Juventus, the club owned by the Agnelli family, which owns Fiat. Small and smart, Deschamps covers enormous ground and is a fine tackler and clogger of passing lanes. He quit soccer for six months as a teen-ager after his older brother died in an airplane crash. Deschamps is a close friend of Desailly -- he is the godfather of one of his children -- and a distant cousin of the Wimbledon women's finalst, Nathalie Tauziat.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: POSITION: Right back. AGE: 26. INTERNATIONAL MATCHES: 26. CLUB: Parma (Italy).
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: Even before he became a national savior against Croatia, Thuram was considered France's finest defender. A central defender with his club, his effectiveness and confidence have increased substantially since he left Monaco for Italy two years ago. Fast, agile and likable, he is now giving the three-time Olympic gold medalist Marie-Jose Perec a run for the title of most popular athlete from the French island of Guadeloupe. Raised by his mother, he moved to the Paris suburbs at 9.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: POSITION: Defensive midfielder. AGE: 27. INTERNATIONAL MATCHES: 25. CLUB: Arsenal (England)
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: As recently as last spring, the swashbuckling Petit was considered unlikely to make the 22-man French team, but his fine season at Arsenal under the French Coach Arsene Wenger earned him a spot in the starting lineup. A phenom as a teen-ager, he later lost his way after a divorce and, like Deschamps, the death of a brother, but Petit has learned to think and play positively again.
title: France Is Depending on Its Seven Blocks of Defense

text: President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich made a rare joint appearance today in Atlanta to crusade against illegal drug use, even as their parties are preparing to club each other with that issue in the Congressional campaigns this fall.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: Before flying here to console the families and praise the firefighters who are grappling with Florida's fires, Mr. Clinton stopped in Atlanta to unveil an anti-drug advertising campaign that he said was devised to ''knock America upside the head.''
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: Displaying a bipartisan front -- if a rather cool one -- before hundreds of schoolchildren in a conference center auditorium, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Clinton described how drugs had affected them. The Speaker said the sister of one of his aides had been left in a coma by a drug slipped into her drink; the President said that his brother, Roger, ''nearly died from a cocaine habit.''
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: But the sense of shared purpose did not last. Immediately after Mr. Gingrich finished hailing the commercial's ''bipartisan basis,'' an aide to Senator Paul Coverdell, Republican of Georgia, handed a statement to reporters in the auditorium that sharply criticized Mr. Clinton's drug policy.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: After the anti-drug event, Mr. Clinton moved on to criticize Republicans at a $500,000 fund-raising lunch for Michael Coles, a Democrat who is challenging Mr. Coverdell this fall.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: Here in Florida, the President visited with families who lost most of their possessions to fire.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: Then the President spoke under a tent to several hundred firefighters and other emergency workers at the Daytona International Speedway, which has served as a staging area.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: ''I'm here,'' he said, ''because I think it's important that every American knows that this summer, notwithstanding the great movies, the real American heroes are not up in space fighting asteroids, they're in Florida fighting fires.''
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: After covering the short distance to the speedway from the airport, Mr. Clinton and his motorcade took a stately quarter-lap on the 2.5-mile oval. The last car of the three-dozen-vehicle motorcade had barely reached the track as the first vehicle left it.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: As in Georgia, Mr. Clinton combined his official duties in Florida with political ones. He flew to Miami for an $800,000 dinner on behalf of Congressional candidates at the home of the actor Sylvester Stallone.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: Presenting Mr. Clinton with the boxing gloves he wore in ''Rocky,'' Mr. Stallone compared him to the title character, saying he ''has an uphill battle but doggedly asks for one more round just to keep punching, keep punching, keep punching until finally he gets his point across.''
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: Mr. Stallone concluded: ''It's been a grand evening. I shan't forget it.''
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: The President thanked Mr. Stallone for the gift and said: ''I think I've established that I can take a punch. Now the time has come for me to deliver a few.''
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: The new advertising campaign, supervised by the Campaign for a Drug-Free America, is financed this year with $195 million in Federal money that organizers expect to be matched by media organizations. Some commercials have already been broadcast in test markets; the national campaign begins tonight.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: In Atlanta, Mr. Clinton described learning from his brother that he had started drinking beer and smoking marijuana in high school.
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: He told the audience: ''There's somebody like my brother back at your school who is a good kid, just a little lost. You can save them.''
title: Clinton and Gingrich Unite Against Drugs

text: Dalkeith McIntosh, an indigent 38-year-old Jamaican immigrant, was convicted today of murdering two women, making it possible that he could be the state's second man condemned to die by lethal injection.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: After deliberating for 14 hours over three days, the jury found that after a domestic quarrel, Mr. McIntosh gunned down his estranged wife, Francine Williams, 47, and her 23-year-old daughter, Eunice, in the summer of 1996 as they sat in a car here.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: The jury of eight men and four women also found that in the same incident, he had shot Anthony Williams, a 6-year-old boy whom he had raised as a son, but the child survived and eventually testified against him.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: The state's 1995 capital-punishment law provides for death in a case that meets any of certain criteria, and prosecutors said Mr. McIntosh's case met more than one.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: He was accused of multiple first-degree murders, and he was convicted of killing one person to keep her from being a witness against him. The law also provides for death in particularly heinous crimes, and the presence of the child was considered such a factor, though the prosecution has not emphasized it.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: Next week, the trial will enter the penalty phase, involving a decision on either death by lethal injection or life in prison. Mr. McIntosh's lawyer, William M. Tendy, will begin pleading for his life by presenting witnesses to testify about his character and background growing up in Jamaica.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: Like the jurors in the Brooklyn trial of Darrel K. Harris, who deliberated for 11 hours over two days before convicting Mr. Harris of capital murder on June 6, the jury here worked with surprising speed, sometimes right through meals, before delivering the verdict to Judge George D. Marlow of Dutchess County Court at about 12:30 P.M. One juror, a young woman, left the courtroom later, visibly distraught.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: The jurors had spent the last four weeks listening to often emotional testimony. Today, the small fourth-floor courtroom was silent and Mr. McIntosh stared straight ahead without registering emotion as the foreman tolled off guilty verdicts to all 10 counts in the indictment. Mr. McIntosh sat motionless, seemingly numb, as his lawyer tried to comfort him.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: ''He's very, very upset,'' Mr. Tendy said later of Mr. McIntosh. ''We will spend a lot of time in the next few days talking to him. That's really all we can do right now.''
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: On one count, the jurors found Mr. McIntosh guilty of second-degree murder, not first-degree, because they did not believe the prosecution had proved that he killed his wife, Francine, to prevent her from testifying against him in a pending assault case. They did, however, believe that he had killed Eunice Williams to eliminate her as a witness to the slaying of his wife.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: Visibly crushed by the guilty verdict, Mr. Tendy said he had let his client down and doubted whether he would ever undertake another defense in a capital case. ''I don't think I could ever go through this again,'' he said. ''If I hadn't let him down, then we wouldn't have the verdict we have right now. This was my responsibility. If somebody's got to be blamed, it's me.''
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: During a month of testimony from 52 witnesses, Mr. Tendy had pointed out many reasons that might cause a jury to doubt Mr. McIntosh's guilt.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: There were no fingerprints on the gun presented as the murder weapon, and no way to connect it definitively to the defendant or the shootings. Nor was there a drop of blood on Mr. McIntosh's skin or clothes when he was caught by the police, although all three victims were shot at point-blank range. Mr. McIntosh has insisted on his innocence from the first, and the defense maintained that the police had the wrong man. Mr. Tendy appeared stunned that his defense had not swayed the jury.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: For his part, the prosecutor was relieved. ''The speed of the verdict in this case is simply a reflection of the strength of the evidence,'' said William V. Grady, the Dutchess County District Attorney. ''But I will not say I'm not surprised.''
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: The key, he said, had been Anthony Williams. Now 8, the only surviving witness to the slayings had testified for an hour. He said he had been in the car, watching as ''Keith'' shot his grandmother, Francine, in the head. The small boy testified that the man whom he often called ''Daddy'' had then turned the gun on him, shooting him in the mouth, then shot Anthony's aunt, Eunice Williams, in the head, and fled. All these grisly details he recounted with chilling calm to jurors. Finally, the boy pointed at Mr. McIntosh when asked who had committed the murders. ''Anthony Williams is the only eyewitness and he provided the jury with firsthand testimony,'' Mr. Grady said. ''We cannot overemphasize the significant role that he played.''
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: In the penalty phase, Mr. Tendy, said he would put Mr. McIntosh's relatives on the stand, though he would not say which ones. Mr. McIntosh has two young children and other relatives still living in Jamaica, as well as a sister in Texas. Mr. Tendy said he would use them to try to show ''what this man's life was, so that they see him as a human being.''
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: During the trial, it was established that Mr. McIntosh came to the United States in the late 1980's, did not have a regular job, and had been found in possession of marijuana. ''Who cares about a poor, black Jamaican immigrant,'' Mr. Tendy said to the all-white jury in his closing statement. ''You know what the answer is -- nobody, and that's the truth.''
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: Trying to show that his client was poor, Mr. Tendy said, ''He's buying nickel bags for 40 bucks, he's got $10 in his pocket, he's riding around on a bicycle, and he's living in a flea-bag room with a mattress on the floor.''
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: No relatives of Mr. McIntosh or any of the victims were present. Some of the victims' relatives attended during the boy's testimony and opening statements, but otherwise were rarely in court.
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: Mr. Grady said, ''It's unfortunate that the families of the victims are not here to share what I know would be a great sense of relief and satisfaction that this offender has been held fully accountable for this crime.''
title: New York Man Is Convicted In 2 Killings

text: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: If ever there was a party for Johann Moore, it is the Green Party.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: Mr. Moore is the founder of the New York City Medical Marijuana Buyers' Club, a group that advocates the legalization of the narcotic for medicinal use and that distributes it -- illegally -- to those suffering from AIDS, cancer and other illnesses.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: It is not an easy job. Mr. Moore claims that he was pistol-whipped in November during a robbery at the club.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: But a new occupation may be on the horizon. On Thursday, Mr. Moore, 36, became a candidate for state Attorney General on the Green Party ticket, a slate that includes Al Lewis, a former star of ''The Munsters,'' as the choice for Governor.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: Mr. Moore, who has been arrested dozens of times, says he is running to promote his ardent belief that marijuana can be a humane treatment for the terminally ill.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: ''I'm running for the people's right to use whatever medical substances people feel benefit them,'' he said in a telephone interview from his apartment-cum-campaign headquarters.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: Mr. Moore says he himself suffers from a chronic gastric disorder that is helped by the drug. But he adds that he recently quit smoking marijuana after its side effects became ''detrimental.''
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: And while the notion of an admitted outlaw running for the state's highest law enforcement position may inspire giggles, there are serious issues at stake for the Greens in the elections this fall.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: Under state law, any party that tallies 50,000 votes in the gubernatorial election automatically qualifies for a ballot line for the next four years, without having to petition for ballot placement.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: Mr. Moore says his goals if elected include promoting a civil rights law for gay men and women and ''a reconstruction of law enforcement apparatus,'' including a law mandating that police officers be elected by community residents.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: ''That way if you have a thug in your neighborhood, you can vote him -- or her -- out of office,'' he said.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: Still, Mr. Moore harbors no illusions about his prospects for defeating Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco. ''I'm not stupid enough to think I'm going to be A.G. in September,'' he said. (He was then reminded that the election is in November.)
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: But despite the long odds, Mr. Moore is enthusiastic about the coming race.
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: ''I want to get out there and talk to people and let people know we're out there,'' he said. JESSE McKINLEY
title: A Philosophical Breacher of Law Seeks a Law Post

text: Down a dusty, rocky trail and through a knot of pine trees, past a naked guy chewing leaves, a fully clothed Christian choir and a retired Jewish pie thrower, is the meadow where the Rainbow Family is holding its 27th annual gathering to party and pray for peace.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: Thousands of members of this family of old hippies and young converts, of blacks and whites, of American Indians and recent immigrants, of babies and grandparents, have come from across the country to the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest, just west of this two-stoplight town near the New Mexico border, for an annual gathering that lasts for about three weeks. They gather to tune in love and to tune out what some Rainbow members call Babylon, the outside world of stock markets, guns, wars and drug tests.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: ''We don't want our children to see guns,'' said Barry Adams, 53, of Missoula, Mont., one of the founders of the family. ''We want our children to see tools and paint brushes and peace.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: A 24-year-old woman whom everyone calls Maddog said: ''Coming here is like medicine for my spirit. This is like my family reunion.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: In the past, the site of the gathering, which is held in a different national park or forest each year, was spread by word of month. Now, word is largely spread through the Web.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: ''We aren't stuck in the 60's,'' Mr. Adams said with a wink.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: The United States Forest Service has dispatched a National Incident Team and a contingent of at least 40 officers and other staff members to keep an eye on the Rainbows, who have been known to fill their peace pipes with marijuana.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: The Apache County Sheriff, the Arizona Department of Public Safety and four towns, including Eagar, have sent in officers to patrol the edges of the sprawling encampment.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: ''All the extra law enforcement in town is causing more tension than the Rainbows,'' said Francies Leyba, 40, a night manager at the Best Western motel in Eagar. ''The police are stopping everybody.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: Mrs. Leyba, who has not been to the camp and has no intention of going, said she was stopped by the police the other day for making a turn without signaling. That has never happened before, she said.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: ''I don't know what all the fuss is about,'' she added. ''It's just a bunch of hippies playing music and drinking beer.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: The Rainbows are also using water that the Forest Service and another nearby town, Springerville, insist they are not entitled to. The Rainbows have set up a series of pipes leading from a nearby spring to their makeshift kitchens on the edge of the meadow.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: The Forest Service says the water belongs to Springerville and two private owners. The Rainbows say the water is in a national forest and therefore, at least some of it belongs to the people.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: Citing their First Amendment rights of peaceable assembly and free speech, the Rainbows have also refused, as they usually do, to seek or sign a permit to use the park for gatherings of more than 75 people. Two of their members volunteered to receive Forest Service citations; if convicted, they could be jailed for six months for not having a permit.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: [By the Fourth of July, the peak of the Rainbow reunion, 20,000 men, women and children were camping out in tents, tepees or under the stars. More than 50 people, primarily Rainbows, had been arrested or had been given citations, mostly for possessing marijuana or for minor traffic violations, officials said.]
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: Faith Duncan, a spokeswoman for the Forest Service, said dealing with the Rainbows was often a challenge. ''Tempers can flare,'' she said.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: But Ms. Duncan said the main concern of the Forest Service was that the park not be damaged by the hundreds of cars and vans and the thousands of people converging on it.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: This year there is an added concern: fire. The forest is dry and a camp-fire restriction is in effect.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: The Rainbows say they are being exceedingly careful. They also say they have been holding so many rain dances that their feet are sore. Drake Beacon, a family member from New York City who said he attended his first gathering 20 years ago, when he was 3 years old, patrols the camp site every night with a group of volunteers, putting out any camp fires. Other groups are assigned to clean up and stay for weeks after every gathering to restore whatever park or forest they use.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: During a three-hour walk through the camp on Wednesday, past some jugglers under a tree and an Indian on horseback, only a few people were seen smoking cigarettes and even fewer were smoking marijuana, although one man walked through the crowd pleading for some marijuana.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: ''Sometimes it's just like New York City around here,'' said a man called Peace Eagle. ''You've got a few con men on the fringes and the cops running around making everyone nervous.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: The camp is divided into more than a dozen smaller camps, including Carnivore Cafi, Musical Veggie Cafi, Haight Street Camp, Hobo Hilton and Little Rascals Hideaway. There also is Anonymous Camp, which is for recovering alcoholics and drug addicts.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: And there is a camp for children called Kiddie Village, where a woman from Tucson who calls herself Bird Song was helping to cook. Bird Song had brought two of her three children, including her 15-year-old son, who was helping care for the smaller children in the camp.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion
