text: ''There are no single parents here,'' Bird Song said. ''They say it takes a village to raise a child. This is a village.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: The campers in Kiddie Village are an eclectic group that includes people who cannot remember the last time they had a job as well as people like Lynne Reister, a 56-year-old marine surveyor from Seattle who says she cannot remember the last time she did not have a job.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: The village is also home to Aaron Kay, one of several Jews in the camp who have set up a kosher kitchen. Mr. Kay is from New York City, where he was known as the Pie Man because of his propensity for throwing pies into the faces of public figures, including former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California. ''He's the only one I ever apologized to,'' Mr. Kay said, ''because he went in a more progressive direction.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: But Mr. Kay, 48, said he had not thrown a pie at anyone since 1992. ''I've retired,'' he said. ''I can't run anymore.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: People greet each other with hugs, smiles and the Rainbow Family's motto, ''Welcome Home.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: Last year was Cora Lee's first Rainbow reunion. When she made the trip from her home in Amherst, Mass., she did not know what to expect from so many hippies gathered in one place this side of 1969. But after a few days, she said, she felt comfortable walking through the woods with nothing on but her smile.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: ''I never felt any danger,'' she said. ''I never felt I had to be afraid of men. This is a place of love.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: But Eric Baca, 50, who has been attending Rainbow reunions for several years, said there were some people who brought their racist and sexist attitudes with them. He also complained that some of the younger Rainbows did not seem as willing to help with chores.
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: ''Every family has a few problems,'' he said. ''That doesn't mean you stop being a family.''
title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion

text: Already Dead: A California Gothic
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: By Denis Johnson. Harper Perennial, $13.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: In this creepy novel populated by a large cast of petty crooks and wack jobs, an alcoholic marijuana grower facing the twin threats of disinheritance and retaliation for a cocaine deal gone bad cooks up a wild scheme with a Nietzsche-quoting drifter. ''Once Johnson gets his hooks into you -- it takes about two sentences -- it's . . . pretty much impossible to stop reading,'' David Gates wrote here last year.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: Making the Declaration of Independence
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: By Pauline Maier. Vintage, $14.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: This feisty and highly original study, selected as one of the best books of 1997 by the editors of the Book Review, presents the Declaration of Independence as the embodiment of the American mind and colonial experience rather than as a product of Thomas Jefferson's pen or the expression of some philosophy of natural rights. By placing the document in the context of 90 previous declarations issued throughout the Colonies, the author ''offers Americans a fresh perspective on their most treasured national relic,'' Richard Alan Ryerson wrote here last year. Angel in the Whirlwind: The Triumph of the American Revolution, by Benson Bobrick (Penguin, $15.95), reminds readers that the Revolutionary War was full of amazing stories and characters -- led by a heaven-sent hero (George Washington) and a world-class villain (Benedict Arnold). Bobrick ''has studied his subject deeply and writes about it with real understanding and verve,'' Frederick Allen said in these pages in 1997. In The Long Affair: Thomas Jefferson and the French Revolution, 1785-1800, by Conor Cruise O'Brien (University of Chicago, $15), an Irish author locates a strain of visionary violence in Jefferson's near-religious defense of the Revolution. In 1996 Richard Brookhiser said this ''cranky and sweeping'' narrative ''goes a long way to show that the bust has shoulders of clay.''
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: By Sam Tanenhaus. Modern Library, $16.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: The accuser of Alger Hiss gets sympathetic, but not hagiographic, treatment in this copious biography, which sheds new light on its famously enigmatic protagonist, especially his post-Hiss existence. Last year in the Book Review, Arthur Schlesinger Jr. called this a ''serious and absorbing work.''
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: By Alice Adams. Washington Square/Pocket Books, $14.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: The author demolishes the divine right of American doctorhood by having her 40-ish heroine wonder whether her crushing headaches are an allergic reaction to her physicians -- all of them men. Last year our reviewer, Deborah Mason, lamented the unrelenting doctor-bashing but said the novel ''in many ways . . . is representative of the bracing frankness and tart ironies of the Adams oeuvre.'' The same publisher has reissued Superior Women ($14), a melancholy group portrait that follows five mismatched Radcliffe girls -- rich, poor, fat, thin -- through four decades of growing disappointment and crises of midlife and identity. In 1984 in these pages, Lois Gould admired Adams's ''elegant, rhythmic style'' and ''fine, wry logic.''
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: The Last Gift of Time: Life Beyond Sixty
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: By Carolyn G. Heilbrun. Ballantine, $12.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: Turning 70, a feminist pioneer and scholar looks back on the unexpected pleasures, friendships and rewards of her 60's. This buoyant collection of revelations and reflections is ''like a letter to a friend, the kind you don't lie to,'' Rebecca Pepper Sinkler wrote here in 1997.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: By Ida Fink. Translated by Philip Boehm and
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: These spare, lucid tales about everyday life among the Jewish bourgeoisie in Nazi-era Poland mix normalcy with terror, revealing the avid need of accountants, housewives and piano students to live fully even in the shadow of death. ''Fink's gift is for the delicate miniature, the oblique detail that freezes the reader's heart,'' Fernanda Eberstadt said here last year.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: Our Guys: The Glen Ridge Rape and the Secret Life
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: By Bernard Lefkowitz. Vintage, $15.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: This disturbing account of the highly publicized rape of a mentally retarded girl by a group of teen-age athletes suggests that similar crimes are being committed across the nation and that much of the fault lies in America's cult of the sports hero. Last year in the Book Review, Russell Banks called this ''a calm, methodical, painstakingly researched book . . . that should be read by parents and educators alike.''
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: By Paul Theroux. Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $12.
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: A British mother and her 43-year-old son living in Hong Kong confront the imminent ''Chinese take-away'' with passive rage and resentment in this novel. ''Theroux's astringent misanthropy and narrative momentum are powerful propellants,'' Thomas Keneally wrote here in 1997. Many of the 60-odd tales in Theroux's Collected Stories (Penguin, $15.95) are inhabited by ordinary no-nonsense people who find themselves immersed in Gothic goings-on, or solitary narrators whose anonymity is threatened by outside forces. ''Theroux displays . . . a remarkable ear,'' William H. Pritchard wrote here last year. ''He . . . inhabits his sentences in a rewardingly comic way.'' Scott Veale
title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

text: THESE summer weekends reveal my most embarrassing weakness. As my neighbors head down to the beach, loaded with coolers, towels and bottles of expensive grease, I lurk at home. I feel as guilty as an atheist at morning service time. But the sad truth is, I just don't believe in the beach.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: This is unfortunate, because Long Island is really just a large beach with strip malls. We're never very far from the sea, just as we're never very far from a pizza slice. But most of the time, the ocean exists only as a geographical concept. We know it's there, but we can't see it because almost every inch of the shoreline is built up, fenced off and marked with signs saying ''Private.''
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: However, I mustn't complain about being cut off from the pleasures of the beach, because we live in what is strangely called a ''beach community,'' although it's nothing like ''Gilligan's Island.'' We have a special key to a long flight of secret steps leading down the cliff to a small patch of rocks and pebbles, with a charming view over to Bridgeport. When the tide comes in, the beach vanishes entirely, and you have to balance your lounger on a large inner tube moored to one of the rocks.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: Every time there is a big storm, the steps are blown down, and beach-worshippers have to detour through the state park (parking $4), down to the public beach and back along the shoreline to reach our patch of private beach, easily recognizable by the wreckage of the steps.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: This year, however, they are in fine shape, apart from the last few feet, which are a bit wobbly but can be jumped by a fairly athletic person not carrying a 10gallon cooler. So I have no excuse not to go to the beach. It's the big July 4 weekend, when beach sitting is practically a patriotic duty. But I haven't done it yet.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: I would like to justify my beach phobia as a sign of maturity. Now that I've more or less grown up, I have put away such childish things. But some of my even more mature neighbors go there every day in summer, so age is no excuse.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: Even as a child, I detested the beach. My family used to take me on long vacations to dismal resorts, where we would sit on the sand for hours, alternately soaked with rain and broiled in the sun, and bored out of our minds. My only diversion was to dig large holes in the sand, concealing them as best I could, in the hope that an unwary adult would fall into one. When I did snare an elegant, strolling gentleman or a matronly lady, I felt the same thrill our ancestors must have felt when a mammoth stepped into one of their traps.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: On the great public beaches of Long Island, even such innocent amusements are not allowed. At the entrance to every public beach is a huge sign: ''No lifeguard; no ball games; no radio; no alcohol; no elephant traps; no heavy breathing'' and so on.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: The only entertainment available on most beaches is watching other people, and listening to their carefully selected music blending together from a thousand boom boxes, like a Schoenberg symphony orchestrated by Guns 'n Roses. The outfits are amazing, and some young women are obviously very dedicated indeed to their beach duties, their costumes being worn down almost to nothing with use. On the great beaches of the Hamptons, you can see more surface area of more beautiful people than anywhere else in the world. If you are over 40 and out of shape, I recommend the North Shore beaches as less depressing.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: My main complaint about beach life is not the scenery, but the fact that it's so uncomfortable. You lie there on the pebbles, rocks seaching out the most painful points in your spine, head rolling back at an unnatural angle, watching out of the corner of your eye for teen-agers on all-terrain vehicles. It's just not relaxing. It's not a safe or suitable place to develop intimate relationships, although some young people seem unaware of this. And the beach is less hygienic than even the messiest yard or deck. Everything from the sea arrives sooner or later on the beach. Broken lobster pots, old tires, boat fenders, the bodies of nasty-looking marine creatures and enough soda and beer cans to start a recycling plant.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: A couple of generations ago, people would go to the seaside for their health -- the ozone, the sunshine and seawater were all held to be bracing and invigorating. Now we must cover ourselves against the sun like the more conservative ladies of Saudi Arabia. We look at the dark waters of the ocean with deep suspicion, and ozone is a five-letter word.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: The beach is at its best after everyone has gone home. Then, in a moonlight walk along the edge of the surf, you might recapture some of the magic that drew the human animal to the shore in the first place. The only problem here in summer is that not everybody does go home. A midnight stroll on the beach, where fires flicker in hidden clefts of the cliff and the scent of marijuana drifts on the air, may teach you things you never learned in biology class. But romantic it is not.
title: Life Needn't Be a Day at the Beach

text: Hillel Bodek hurtled through the interstices of 100 Centre Street, the voluminous State Supreme Court building in Manhattan where criminal cases are heard, muttering to himself his signature refrains, ''It is what it is'' and ''What can I tell you.'' Even at his fleet pace, he never gets far before someone flags him down.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Kevin Hynes, a lawyer with a client facing drug charges, buttonholed him. ''Hillel, I want my client to wear a sweater in court instead of a leather jacket,'' he said. ''How do I do that?''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Mr. Bodek gave his standard response: ''I'll take care of it.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Getting things accomplished in the criminal justice system -- really getting them accomplished -- requires a certain felicitousness. It requires a certain sagacity. It requires an acute knowledge of how creaking bureaucracies work. To some extent, it requires an obnoxiousness.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Often when things, both big and little, need to get done, judges and lawyers in New York turn to one particular individual. He is a loquacious, unkempt, quirky man of 45 who proudly wears a pocket protector for his pens. He wears a windbreaker and keeps a black nylon backpack strapped to his back. He looks like someone you might meet at the bowling alley, or who would show up to repair the dishwasher.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: New York is full of people who operate in the shadows to make those in the limelight look better. These are people who get things done. In the maddening world of criminal justice, Hillel Bodek gets things done. He makes the slow wheels of justice turn just a little faster.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Technically, Mr. Bodek is a freelance clinical social worker, who spends most of his time evaluating the mental state of and recommending the appropriate care for indigent mentally and physically impaired defendants. But he is also something of a judicial handyman who is appointed by judges to do almost anything that needs doing to hasten the process of justice and see that the system works as it is intended to.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: He will accelerate the transfer of documents and help assure the protection of witnesses. He will check that a defendant gets dutiful care in jail. Recently, a man named Tirso Salcedo, on trial on drug charges, complained that he couldn't hear the proceedings, and asked that the trial be stopped. Mr. Bodek helped get him treated for an ear infection and fitted with a hearing aid. The jury was deadlocked, and Mr. Salcedo was retried. At the second trial, he said he couldn't hear, he needed a new battery, the jail wouldn't give him one, stop the trial. The judge handed him a fresh battery from the two-month supply that Mr. Bodek had provided her. Mr. Salcedo was convicted of conspiracy to sell drugs.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: ''Judges say, get Bodek, because Bodek knows how to get things done,'' Mr. Bodek said, intending not so much to be immodest as to be accurate.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: In carrying out his functions, Mr. Bodek routinely works 60 to 70 hours a week. He produces evaluation reports commonly 10 times as long as those of fellow experts. His compensation handily qualifies him as one of the highest-paid social workers in America. Last year, he earned $314,000 (about $60,000 of which went to expenses), grudgingly paid by the city, which has long lamented that he charges way too much. His earnings well eclipse those of the judges and many of the lawyers he works with, not to mention those of the Mayor. Steven Fishner, the Mayor's Criminal Justice Coordinator, whose office processes Mr. Bodek's fees, calls the situation ''absolutely crazy,'' but must pay what the trial judges approve.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: There is no one quite like Mr. Bodek in the system, and he elicits wide-ranging emotions. The dozen or so criminal court judges who regularly use him find him indispensable. Some lawyers, though, grumble that he is pro-defense. Far more rant that he is pro-prosecution. Then again, many people familiar with him would agree with Gerald Labush, a defense lawyer and former prosecutor, who sums up his posture as ''Bodek.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: ''He just takes a Bodek stance on things.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Defense lawyers, in particular, often thrive on the inefficiencies of the system, and look on an expediter like Mr. Bodek as a threat. In some instances, he is hired by a prosecutor or defense lawyer to deliver an expert opinion. They take their chances, because, as Larry Goldman, a defense lawyer, put it, ''He's disgustingly honest.'' At times, Mr. Bodek will say the exact opposite of what the lawyer paying him hoped he would say, and then the lawyer will petition the court to have Mr. Bodek's conclusions tossed out. Such a turn of events is known to lawyers as getting Bodeked.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Mr. Bodek's principal habitats are 100 Centre Street and the companion building at 111 Centre Street, the 19th-floor psychiatric prison ward at Bellevue Hospital and the Manhattan Detention Center. In these places, he is well known. Most mornings, he is at the courthouse. He gallops from courtroom to courtroom, frequently announcing, ''O.K., next mess.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: He bounded in to see Justice Budd G. Goodman, who remarked, ''Our court system would not function half as well without Hillel.'' Judge Goodman had asked Mr. Bodek to straighten out a foul-up in which a marijuana misdemeanor was put on a defendant's arrest record rather than the robbery charge he was indicted on. The police could not unravel it. Mr. Bodek found out that, through a police clerical error, the robbery charge was listed on the record of another man who had been arrested on the same day for the marijuana offense. (Mr. Bodek loves to tell of the bungle in which an arrested man identified himself to the police officer as Donald Duck. The officer duly processed him as Mr. Duck.)
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: He gets things done because he knows the city's unfathomable systems so well, -- the prison system, the court system, the health and mental health systems -- but often, it seems, people do what he wants simply to get rid of him. ''Follow-up prevents foul-up'' is one of his maxims, and does he follow up. Dealing with him is like being assaulted by a sandblaster. ''I don't take anything from bureaucrats,'' Mr. Bodek said. ''I insist that things be done the right way.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Any number of court workers describe him as one of the most difficult men on earth. He combines tenacity with a glaring absence of social niceties. ''He's very condescending and domineering,'' said Bruce Thurston, the mental health attorney in the criminal defense division of the Legal Aid Society. ''He doesn't seem to appreciate that spatial need that many of us have not to be talked to too closely. He really gets in your face.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Mr. Bodek was born in Providence, R.I., on April 21, 1953. (''A great day in American history,'' is how he characterizes it. ''A very famous day.'') His father was a grade-school teacher, and his mother was a homemaker. When Mr. Bodek was 7, the family moved to Cedarhurst, on Long Island. Mr. Bodek was always interested in helping people, which steered him to social work. He got his college degree as expeditiously as he could, graduating from Queens College in three years, and then acquired a master's degree from Adelphi.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Rocking the Boat And Making Waves
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: He briefly worked at a small agency that advocated for the developmentally disabled. In 1980, he conceived a program that he ran in the prison ward of Bellevue Hospital in which he evaluated and helped find treatment for criminal offenders with disabilities. His abrasive personality irritated some Bellevue doctors.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Then Mr. Bodek began complaining to city investigators about inappropriate behavior and mismanagement in the prison ward, alleging that some of his colleagues were shirking their duties. In 1983, he found himself out of a job when New York University decided not to continue his program. Judges, however, continued to hire him to do the same things on a freelance basis. And in 1984, a city report largely confirmed his allegations of mismanagement at Bellevue, though it also cited complaints that Mr. Bodek's behavior was disruptive and inappropriate.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: His prodigious compensation has always been a point of dispute with the city. The suggested fee for a court-appointed social worker is $45 an hour, and state law limits the maximum outlay in a case to $300, although it gives judges latitude to approve higher sums if there are ''extraordinary circumstances.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Mr. Bodek, who maintains that the mental health cases he specializes in are by their nature extraordinary, bills at $125 an hour and averages about $8,000 per case. In the Royster case, in which he conducted several evaluations, monitored Mr. Royster's mental state and arranged for a witness to come here from Japan, he was paid $49,888.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Though he does not fault Mr. Bodek's competence, Mr. Fishner, the Criminal Justice Coordinator, said that many things he does can be done by paralegals and are hardly worth $125 an hour. ''There is absolutely no doubt he is overcompensated,'' he said. ''No private client would sign off on these numbers of hours for these tasks.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: In 1986, the city asked the District Attorney to investigate Mr. Bodek's billing. It essentially concluded that he worked inhuman hours -- days, nights, weekends -- and cleared him. In 1993, the city refused to pay Mr. Bodek his entire fee, and spent years battling him in the courts. In December 1995, the Court of Appeals ruled that he had to be paid in full. In effect, the city was Bodeked.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Mr. Bodek lives in a two-bedroom co-op in Brooklyn Heights with his wife, Seok-Hoon, who is a social science assistant with the Security Council of the United Nations. He keeps an office on East 50th Street, where he sees clients in the evenings, many of them referred by the courts.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Growing Weary Of the Battles
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Even after all these years, he still longs for his old Bellevue job, or some position that puts him in the system rather than outside it, an official sanction. ''I'm sick and tired of who's the next person who's going to take a potshot at me,'' he said. ''Who's going to investigate me next? It takes its toll. I don't know what I did to these people other than open up my big mouth.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: He said he is seriously pondering giving up his work next year, if he can find an acceptable health care position. At the same time, he knows that his nettlesome manner and his whistleblower history make him difficult to employ.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Meanwhile, it is what it is. He does what he does.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Skittering through the hallways, he mumbled: ''This is an uncontrolled circus. Seven rings. Ten rings.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: He had a word with Justice Carol Berkman. Recently, she was having difficulty with the case of Jose Rodriguez, a man arrested in 1989 and accused of multiple rapes. For years, he had been declared incompetent to stand trial. Not long ago, however, psychiatrists declared him fit. Yet he tried to swallow batteries. He ate his flesh. He licked the defense table. Judge Berkman felt he was faking it. ''The only way I could get him to trial was if I had him under close observation, so if I heard he tried to flush his head down the toilet I didn't have to order another evaluation,'' she said. She appointed Mr. Bodek to monitor him. A few months ago, as his trial finally began, Mr. Rodriguez pleaded guilty.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: Mr. Bodek barreled in to confer with Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder. A short while ago, she assigned him to talk sense to a man awaiting trial on charges that he killed another man because he had delusions that the man had murdered his brother. The suspect had already served longer than the minimum sentence he faced if he pleaded guilty. ''He wouldn't plead,'' Mr. Bodek said. ''He said: 'Kill me. Give me 25 years.' So I asked the other inmates to talk to him. They often carry more clout. They said, 'You moron, you've served enough, plead.' So he said he will plead. Now he's a happy duck.'' The other week, he pleaded guilty.
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: The morning tumbled into afternoon. Departing the courthouse, Mr. Bodek needed to go uptown. He hailed a cab. He said: ''What can I tell you? It is what it is.''
title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair

text: In august 1996, jerry mcginnes, a sulking, brooding 18-year-old, awaited sentencing in a Fort Collins, Colo., courtroom. His tattoos -- the sun and a cross on his forearms and unintelligible markings on his knuckles, a result of a drunken evening -- lent Jerry an air of defiance. The Juvenile Court magistrate, Joseph Coyte, asked if he had anything to say. Jerry, who had dropped out of school, had been on probation for stealing a car when he cut off his ankle monitor and fled for San Diego to live with his sister. There, he smoked marijuana and hung out until deciding he'd had enough of being on the run. He then turned himself in. The prosecutor asked that the judge send him to a youth prison. Jerry rose; his hands, manacled and shaking, clutched a penciled four-page letter he had written. He read it aloud.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: About four months ago, I decided to move to San Diego. While I was there I was exposed to the hole [sic] drug scene for a while it was fun, but it soon got old and reality began to set in. I decided to come back and turn my self in.. . .
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Your Honor I'm asking you to grant my wish to attend school at Eagle Rock High School.. . . This is it I can choose my future from here. Graduate from Eagle Rock or live my life behind locked doors.. . .
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Judge Coyte made a deal: Jerry could attend Eagle Rock, but if he dropped out he faced the possibility of prison.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Eagle Rock School, lodged on 640 acres bordering Colorado's majestic Rocky Mountain National Park, is nestled in a valley at the bottom of a steep, winding road. Like sentries, four mountain ridges stand guard over the campus. The effect, not unintentional, is that you feel protected from the pulls and temptations of the outside world, no small matter given the school's population: kids who, for whatever reason, haven't been able to conform to the more traditional setting of a public school. Some have dropped out or were regularly truant or simply uninterested in their studies. A handful, including Jerry McGinnes, have been in trouble with the law. A considerable number have taken refuge in drugs and drink. They are what some people might impoliticly refer to as throwaway kids, teen-agers who skate along the margins of mainstream society. It is a swelling population. Nationwide, 485,000 teen-agers dropped out of school last year, according to the U.S. Department of Education. In cities like Chicago and New York, barely one of every two entering freshmen graduates in four years. And these numbers don't include the multitudes who crawl into class indifferent, tired and just plain angry. The Carnegie Council on Adolescent Development has estimated that one in four young people -- or seven million -- is ''extremely vulnerable to multiple high-risk behaviors and school failure.''
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: This story might feel familiar -- tough-love school tucked away in the wilderness turns wayward kids around -- except that Eagle Rock, set up by a major corporation and run by a former hippie, is as singular as the landscape. At a time when so much of the discussion about education is centered on standards and testing, Eagle Rock has focused on personal growth and building community. At a time when schools are expelling a growing number of students as a result of zero-tolerance policies, Eagle Rock is embracing those same kids. Most leave with a moral compass and a piercing inquisitiveness. And so this still-fledgling school -- it's five years old -- has caught the eye of educators around the country.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: My introduction to Eagle Rock was at the daily morning gathering in the main lodge, where the school's 69 students find a space on the carpeted floor fronting a stone hearth. They wear the defiant icons of teen-agedom: nose rings, mohawks, sagging jeans, bandannas, unlaced high-tops and platform shoes. The early-morning sun that streams through the windows warms the groggy adolescent bodies, as does the fact that the kids are wrapped in each other's arms. Some have their heads in friends' laps. One girl massages the shaved head of a boy. A boy combs the curls of the girl seated in front of him. At first glance, Eagle Rock, as one teacher said to me, appears to be ''a very quaint, kind of 1960's touchy-feely type place.'' They're kids from Chicago's public housing, from the relatively privileged burg of Boulder and from a Wisconsin Indian reservation. A computer hacker and a gang member, a cowboy who is a recovering alcoholic and a football player who lost his bearings after busting his knee. But their commonality is simple: they are kids who couldn't, didn't, wouldn't -- you pick the verb -- fit in at their public schools.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: First impressions matter little here. As I sat in at that morning gathering, noting the frequent hugs and oft-repeated idioms -- ''outside my comfort zone'' was one of the more recurrent -- I chafed at this feel-good approach to communal living. But as I soon learned, it masks a painstakingly considered philosophy of education.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Robert Burkhardt, the school's director and one of its primary architects, sits at the foot of the hearth. At 57, the former high-school and college swimmer has retained his solid build. Burkhardt lives on campus with his wife and two young children, so his presence is a constant, and the students compete for his enveloping embraces and dread his disapproving glares. This day, his attire -- V-neck sweater, chinos and Vibram-soled topsiders -- seemed a far cry from his days running a free school in San Francisco in the early 1970's. It would be too easy, though, to define Burkhardt by this well-traveled path since he is also a Shakespearean scholar and Princeton graduate.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Burkhardt had been directing the San Francisco Conservation Corps, a program that promotes service work among youth, when in 1990, American Honda approached him about helping to develop a school in the Rocky Mountains. Honda, which had been doing business in this country for 30 years, wanted to expand its philanthropic efforts and, after much deliberation, believed it could best contribute to American education, and more specifically assist teen-agers who have become disengaged from school. There is surprisingly little out there. Traditionally, parents who could afford it might ship their children off to military school; for the less fortunate, there are the alternative schools, which are often nothing more than a storefront and a bank of computers. And of course, there are special-education classes, frequently a dumping ground for emotionally uncentered teen-agers. So, at a cost of $17 million, Honda built Eagle Rock, a resortlike campus that in addition to six housing units includes a gym, complete with basketball court, weight room and swimming pool; a full-length soccer field; three classroom buildings; a main office, and the all-purpose lodge, where the kids eat, watch TV and attend the morning gatherings. Honda still invests $3.5 million a year, guaranteeing free tuition for each student.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Burkhardt, whose career has also involved stints as a circus juggler, a plumber, a high-school teacher and a Peace Corps volunteer in Iran, had a clear vision for the school. Given his belief in experiential learning, Burkhardt sends newly arriving students off on a three-week wilderness expedition. In an effort to cultivate a sense of community, each teen-ager averages 500 hours of service both on and off campus each year. An environmental-science class called Riverwatch measured the health of the local Big Thompson River for the state's Division of Wildlife. But Eagle Rock's most distinctive characteristic -- and what has drawn educators there -- is Burkhardt's effort to create community, a place where students take responsibility for one another and for themselves. This necessitated keeping the school small (it can handle 96 students) as well as teaching values, a loaded concept in a political climate that associates building character with religious moralism.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: ''Schools say they don't want religious values or ethical values because that's the province of the family,'' he told me one day over lunch. ''They beguile themselves on that. Every school has values. Where's your hall pass? What's the value behind that? I don't trust you to walk down the halls and go to the bathroom. So what happens when I don't trust you? Well, your response is, 'I'll give you something not to trust me about,' which is where so many of our students came from.'' What most strikes visitors to the school is the students' sense of belonging and purpose, traits not typical of whirling, self-absorbed adolescents.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Consider the morning gathering. Burkhardt asked if there were any announcements. Mat Kasper, a refugee from a New Jersey prep school who was decked out in sport coat and penny loafers, along with a ring through his chin, raised his hand to apologize to Kevin Skipper, an African-American boy from Brentwood, Calif. As a joke, Mat had shut off his housemate's alarm clock, making him miss the weekly 6:30 A.M. three-mile run. A petite girl raised her hand next, and confessed that she didn't rise for the morning jog, and so pledged to run it that night at 9, her earliest block of free time. (''There are no secrets at Eagle Rock,'' Burkhardt later told me.) And finally, to outstretched arms Burkhardt threw used paperbacks, from Rita Mae Brown's ''Rubyfruit Jungle'' to ''A Death in the Family,'' by James Agee. Jerry McGinnes, reclining on the floor, rose briefly to snare a copy of Orwell's ''1984.''
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Jerry was not well liked at Eagle Rock -- at least at the beginning. ''Jerry was a royal pain,'' Burkhardt remembered. ''He didn't much care about other people. Is there a word between violent and vicious?'' In his first few weeks at the school, Jerry and some other students hiked Twin Sisters peak nearby, a four-and-a-half-mile steep climb. One of the girls in the group, Monique, stopped every 10 minutes for water. It frustrated Jerry, who is built of gristle and was unaffected by the high altitude. At the summit, it started to rain and turn cold, so Jerry urged everyone to snap their photos and get the hell down the mountain. In their rush, Monique twisted her ankle, slowing down the group even more. Turning to one of the other guys, he suggested, half-jokingly, that they push her off the ledge.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: And not too much later, Jerry and some other boys named their group after a rap song that referred to women derisively. They carved the names of girls they didn't like on a stick, and soon word of the list got out. At that point, Burkhardt wasn't sure Jerry would last.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Not every student who enters Eagle Rock is as clearly agitated and troubled as Jerry, but almost all arrive with the view that learning is nothing more than a torturous rite of passage. So, how to engage these students -- both in the school community and in the classroom? To understand Eagle Rock's educational philosophy you must look no farther than the artifacts scattered about Burkhardt's alcove. Below his desk lies a box of tattered paperbacks to hand out to students, as well as a pair of Nike high-tops (he plays on one of the intramural basketball teams), his trumpet and a pair of ice skates. The shelves above his desk are lined with books, from four biographies of Gandhi to Stanley Lombardo's new translation of the ''Iliad.'' ''Instruct by pleasing,'' he says, referring to the educator Homer Lane, who once wrote that we make moral progress when we're happy.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: The school year, which runs the full 12 months, is divided into trimesters, during which students take four to six classes, all of them imaginatively titled and pieced together. In one class, appropriately named Beloved, students spent 12 weeks reading Toni Morrison's novel, as well as essays on slavery and on creative writing. In another class, Cabin, Sweet Cabin, students rebuilt a turn-of-the-century homestead (a little math coupled with some carpentry) while also learning about that historical period. Once students feel they have mastered their studies, they petition for graduation, and as a result commencement ceremonies can occur at the end of any trimester. There are no grades and few tests, and a student's maturation is considered almost equally with his or her academic progress. A gifted student who had met the academic requirements for graduation was asked to return for an additional trimester because the staff felt that she was socially immature.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: One afternoon as I walked through the lodge I ran into Tara Trimmer-Jewell, a slender girl from Grand Rapids, Mich., who dropped out of school after becoming involved with the city's street gangs. She was pitched onto the dining-room table, her brunet hair falling across her face, hiding the book she was reading. Tara volunteered that while at Eagle Rock she had become enamored of William Blake's poetry. ''He's so blunt,'' said Tara, whose dream is to attend Wellesley College. ''There's nothing about him that walks around the subject. He's like right down to it. I admire him for being a rebel, I guess.'' Another student, James Masters, came to Eagle Rock after years of being shunted aside in special-education classes because of his dyslexia. ''It was definitely clear they didn't think I'd go anywhere,'' he said of his public-school teachers. ''Robert constantly threw books at me,'' he said. James became enamored of the existentialists, and constantly pulled aside visitors to talk philosophy. He is now a student at Berea College in Kentucky. Sixteen of the school's 31 other graduates have gone on to college as well. (Of the remaining, all but two or three are either working or in the military.)
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Not all Eagle Rock students match James's and Tara's academic rigor and curiosity. Some arrive with grade-school reading levels; some rarely read. Indeed, some staff members are concerned that with all the emphasis on community and personal growth, the kids have not been held to a similar discipline in their studies. At the end of each trimester, students are required to give a ''Presentation of Learning,'' a public exhibition to fellow students, the staff and visitors. I attended a dozen presentations, and while some informed, like 18-year-old Rachel Curran's lucid explanation of the Riverwatch class's findings, others lazily skimmed along their studies. One student, Brandie Pacheco, a painfully shy 17-year-old from New Mexico, presented slides of her classmates hamming it up while refurbishing the turn-of-the-century homestead; she made no mention of what she had learned.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Some teachers have suggested that the failure to earn any credits in a trimester should be reason for expulsion. ''At the beginning I said it would take a full five years to get the culture down to where we wanted it,'' Burkhardt said. ''The culture's getting fairly strong, but the second five years are redefining and refining the academics.'' Many students, with the school's encouragement, pursue studies independent of the classroom, especially in the arts.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: That's what ultimately engaged Jerry McGinnes. Jerry let down his guard slowly. He built a swing on campus and attended an anger-management group. He enchanted elementary-school kids from nearby Estes Park to whom he taught navigational skills. And he admitted to an epiphany of sorts. From the top of a nearby mountain, he witnessed a glorious sunset. ''Yeah, I've seen a million and one sunsets,'' he told me. ''But I was sitting there thinking, Travis'' -- a friend from Fort Collins -- ''is in jail and he can't even enjoy this now. That's when I realized, Wow, look at what I've got. I can't be such a jerk to everyone. Something just came to me. Wake up, Jerry.''
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Then one night last fall after 10 P.M. curfew, a group of boys snuck into the dorm of a frail boy they didn't like. They woke him up by pummeling him. The boys tried to get Jerry to join in, but he refused -- though he had actually got dressed and then at the last minute bowed out. Weeks later at the morning gathering, the students were called on their misconduct. Jerry got up, his back against the wall, his hands clutching his shaven head. He rocked back and forth. ''I was weak,'' he told his classmates. ''I don't know why I didn't step up, hold you to your commitment.''
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: At that moment, Burkhardt knew that Jerry had bought into Eagle Rock's values, its sense of community. Moreover, in the intervening months Jerry found an outlet for his anger: drawing. He began to paint exquisite watercolors, mostly of sunsets, and so Burkhardt asked Jerry to create a mural in the lodge. Jerry erected scaffolding above the entranceway to the kitchen and spent most days 30 feet off the ground, dressed in white painter's pants and apron, listening to the Grateful Dead, painting.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Jerry also began to re-establish a relationship with his parents, who adopted him when he was 6. ''The 12 or so years we lived together, Jerry really never wanted to talk with us,'' his father, Darrel, told me. ''This summer he called and we talked for 45 minutes.'' They talked mainly about the Global Positioning System, since Darrel McGinnes had given Jerry a G.P.S. instrument for his 19th birthday. While Jerry used to discard his gifts, he became obsessed with this offering, writing his senior paper on the subject.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: During my first stay at Eagle Rock, Jerry's parents visited to view their son's mural. They stood beneath the painting of a rising sun that hovered over three wise men and an angel, the work not yet complete. Jerry nervously bounced from foot to foot. ''Well, Jerry, I'm impressed,'' his mother, Carolyn, said. ''Where are you putting your signature?'' Jerry shrugged. He was scheduled to graduate in six weeks, but his parents were clearly anxious. ''Always in the past when he made successes,'' his mother said later, ''he'd make sure they wouldn't last.'' I noticed that she had her fingers crossed.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: You would be hard pressed to identify tight cliques at Eagle Rock, which is especially unusual in a place as diverse and self-contained as it is here. Roughly half the students are nonwhite. Jerry's close friends range from a girl from Trenton's inner city to a boy who lived in a trailer park out west. ''I was just blown away,'' said one visiting educator who was awed by how nurturing the students were of one another.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: And the students develop a firm sense of right and wrong. The school has strict behavioral limits, expelling students for committing what it calls ''nonnegotiables'' -- fighting, taking drugs, smoking, having sex, anything that could harm the integrity of the community. The school permits, even encourages, expelled students to reapply for admission, and as many as one-third of the students at any given time are second-chancers. But equally interesting is that Burkhardt and his staff rarely have to be the bad guys; the students usually own up to their sins -- often at the morning gatherings.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Halfway through last fall's trimester rumors spread of students who had committed nonnegotiables. At one gathering, a veteran student, Willow Moore, an avid kayaker from rural Wisconsin who had dropped out of school, admitted to having had sex four months earlier and to drinking whisky and smoking cigarettes. ''I wanted it off my chest,'' she told me later. Afterward she confronted a housemate, Danielle Williams, a new student from the hardscrabble streets of Chicago, who she knew had also had sex with another student. ''You know you're cheating yourself and the community,'' she told Danielle, who then burst into tears. Willow kissed her on the forehead, assuring her, ''It's going to be all right.'' Danielle soon confessed to her classmates at the hearth.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: By now you have probably said to yourself: O.K., great stuff, but is Eagle Rock replicable? Let's be straight about it, since it is what every visitor asks: it is not, at least not in its entirety. For starters, most schools have their students only six or seven hours a day. Here, by Burkhardt's own admission, ''it doesn't necessarily unravel at night, since we don't send the kids back to their poison -- a troubled family, a dangerous environment, drugs, poverty, abuse.'' But more to the point, Honda spends roughly $25,000 per student each year, a figure several times the average public-school expenditure. The school provides students with all their essential needs, from books to gym uniforms, as well as with some nonessentials, like long-distance phone time, which has led staff members to worry that some kids become quickly spoiled.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Eagle Rock doesn't expect to be cloned. Instead, the hope is that visiting educators will apply pieces of the school to their own situations. An alternative school in Topeka, Kan., now holds ''family meetings'' modeled after Eagle Rock's morning gatherings. A new private school in Boston, Shackleton Schools, reworked its educational model after viewing Eagle Rock's. And Glenbrook South High School, in an affluent Chicago suburb, now has some seniors do end-of-the-year presentations of learning.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: When Honda and Burkhardt designed Eagle Rock, they insisted it be a laboratory for educators, and so christened it the Eagle Rock School and Professional Development Center. Each year, as many as 2,000 teachers, principals and scholars pass through the campus, sitting in on classes and chatting with students, so many that the students occasionally complain of being in a fishbowl. Guests stay at a bunkhouse built specifically to accommodate them.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: ''We school people are really gifted and talented at finding reasons why the good things happening at another school can't possibly happen at my school,'' said Roland S. Barth, the founder of the Principals' Center at the Graduate School of Education at Harvard and a visitor to Eagle Rock. ''There's a lot of conversation now about character, about values, about teaching respect. It's often rhetorical. I don't think many schools are as intentional at developing community and really being clear about what the values are of that community as is Eagle Rock.'' It would be only fair to point out that its components -- smallness, teaching values, experiential learning, service requirements, presentations of learning -- are not new. Rather it is the chassis that Eagle Rock has welded with each of these parts that presents such a startling new design.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: Has Eagle Rock been successful? The school has wrestled with a high attrition rate. Nearly half the students don't finish, though most who leave do so voluntarily in the first few months, usually during the rugged wilderness trip. But many who spend only two or three trimesters at Eagle Rock return to their public schools with the skills and outlook to flourish. Nonetheless, with applications on the rise, the school has become more discriminating in whom it admits, seeking teen-agers who are making some effort toward reclaiming their lives. (One school official suggested that under these new guidelines, Jerry might not have been admitted; moreover, the school prefers admitting younger teen-agers, usually 15- or 16-year-olds.) But the school has become most concerned about those who are forced out because of bad behavior, and so has begun to consider alternatives to expulsion. Ten students who had committed nonnegotiables, including Willow and Danielle, spent this past January camped along a ridge that bounds the property to the east. Each student was given three sheets of plywood and a tarp to build a sleeping structure; they smartly chose to pool their resources and construct one large shelter. They heated it with a wood fire and built their own furniture. Staff members, who camped with them, conducted daily classes. What I found most telling is that each of these students could have gone home and reapplied for admission. It certainly would have made for a more comfortable winter. But each of them chose to spend January warding off the Rocky Mountains' single-digit temperatures and gale-force winds.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: ''We've been giving them three hots and a cot and access to the gym and all this kind of stuff,'' Burkhardt said, ''and now when they get back to it they're going to appreciate that a whole lot more.'' And besides, he added, his tone gentler, ''the level of intimacy these kids need is staggering.'' Which brings me back to Jerry McGinnes, whose own journey is testament to the school's power to transform.
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: The night before what would be Eagle Rock's largest graduation to date -- five students -- Jerry sat cross-legged on his unmade bed. He wore his painter's pants and a short-sleeved shirt patterned with dragonflies. The previous day he had given his final Presentation of Learning, in which he re-enacted his sentencing in court, and then, after exhibiting his artwork, told the 150 people present that at Eagle Rock ''you have teachers who care so much, they sometimes care more than you do.'' Jerry had framed the sketch from which he painted the mural and presented it to Burkhardt. They embraced. ''I'm not sure you understand how talented you are,'' Burkhardt told him. A psychologist to whom Jerry's parents had sent him was also present and, on the spot, offered Jerry a job as an assistant art instructor at a program he runs for troubled youth. Jerry, perched on his bed, told me he had accepted the position. But I wanted to talk with Jerry about something that had brought him to tears at his presentation. A staff member had asked Jerry, ''What advice would you give Jed now?'' Jed was one of the students expelled for the after-curfew assault; he had been for Jerry like a little brother. Jerry's voice again choked with emotion; he could barely respond. ''He was just like me,'' Jerry told me as he pounded his right fist into an open palm. ''What kills me is if I said, 'Jed, don't go,' he wouldn't have gone. Then I came to the realization that this kid's got to make his own decisions.'' Jerry stopped the pounding, and looked out the window at the snow-covered mountains. ''It's hard to be leaving this place. I kind of don't want to.''
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: At graduation the next day, Jerry, in a last act of defiance, wore white fluffy slippers given to him by two friends and sat onstage with his cap pulled low over his eyes. The gym was packed. Students. Staff. A dozen returning interns, as well as six returning graduates. Jerry, who was awarded a $1,000 college scholarship, got to the podium, leaned forward and blew out air. I could feel his nervousness. ''I can't believe I did it,'' he sighed. ''It's just amazing.''
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: It is. But Burkhardt, who can be these kids' biggest cheerleader, had a few days earlier cautioned me that ''Jerry's bought into a lot of the values here and they will flower over the next several years. They need nurturing with Jerry. And I'm hopeful that he will be in situations that he doesn't succumb to temptations. He may. But he's got a good start. He's got as good a start as we can give him.''
title: The High School at the End of the Road

text: When the partner of the San Francisco writer Armistead Maupin first heard of Hay-on-Wye, he shouted, ''And hold the mayo!'' He was not to know that Arthur Miller had made the same joke years ago. Miller, when first invited to go there, quipped: ''Hay-on-Wye? Is that some kind of sandwich?''
title: Say Hay

text: Hay-on-Wye should be self-explanatory: a town called Hay on a river named Wye. The little Welsh Borders market town sits at the foot of the Black Mountains, the long dark ridge that divides England from Wales. There may be prettier sights in the world than the 45-degree angle of Hay Bluff falling to the green meadows of the Wye valley floor. I just have not seen them.
title: Say Hay

text: At the end of every May, a throng of writers, readers, teachers and literary groupies descends on the town of 1,200 for the annual Hay Literary Festival. In the informal and intimate surroundings of a local primary school, enlarged by marquees during the Whitsun vacation week, they can sit at the feet of the likes of Alison Lurie, Toni Morrison, Muriel Spark, P. D. James, Maya Angelou, Jay McInerney, Stephen Fry or -- science being a big draw at Hay -- Stephen Jay Gould and Fred Hoyle.
title: Say Hay

text: As Hay's reputation has grown over the past decade, bigger and bigger international names have accepted the invitation of the festival's serene young director, the actor Peter Florence. Many Americans arrive without having a clue where they are. Wales, unlike Scotland or Ireland, does not rate high on the American ethnicity scale, and the Welsh Borders seldom appear on the tourist itinerary.
title: Say Hay

text: Once initiated, however, the celebrities tend to come back and back, especially if, like Arthur Miller and Lauren Bacall, they merit accommodation in the faux-baronial splendor of Llangoed Hall, Sir Bernard Ashley's five-star hotel with croquet lawn and helipad.
title: Say Hay

text: The stamp of approval of Hay as the most fashionable of British literary festivals has come from the Anglophile New Yorker magazine. For the past three years the editor, Tina Brown, seeing the Hay festival as the best place to meet the best of British writers, has flown in a team for a debate with The Sunday Times of London (the festival's sponsor) on a topic of burning interest. This year The New Yorker lost, not surprisingly, as its proposal -- ''That the private lives of public figures should remain private'' -- sounded dodgy coming from a magazine not shy of exposing politicians and stars.
title: Say Hay

text: To call Hay a ''market town'' is a bit of a touristic euphemism. Its market is secondhand books. Bookstores fill the town, occupying vacated premises, from a former cinema to a Victorian military drill hall. Increasingly narrow specialties are catered to. Balkan books, anybody? Try Marijana Dworski on Lion Street.
title: Say Hay

text: An eclectic architectural mix of Norman, Elizabethan, Georgian and Victorian, Hay is kind to its visitors. There is always paper in the public lavatory. But it is, and always has been, in a state of identity crisis. The English-Welsh border runs through the town, which has belonged, at various times over the centuries, to England, to Wales and to Normandy. Technically in Wales, its postal address specifies ''via Hereford,'' the big English city 20 miles away, which offers the nearest train connection (three hours) to London.
title: Say Hay

text: Truth to tell, Hay-on-Wye is teetering on the edge of self-parody. A never-never land waiting to be turned into a theme park, it has already been turned into a kingdom. In 1961, Richard Booth, a tall, portly Oxford man, spotted the low-rent potential of some vacant buildings here and opened the first of a string of bookshops. In 1977 he crowned himself King of Hay and threatened to secede from Britain. The predictable publicity followed.
title: Say Hay

text: The King, as his friends call him, is a genuine eccentric as well as businessman. He lives in the 13th-century castle in the center of town. He has no difficulty keeping a straight face when, wearing a gilt cardboard crown and carrying a scepter made of a plumber's ball cock, he delivers a monotone harangue against the Wales Tourist Board.
title: Say Hay

text: When the festival began in 1989, Booth turned his back. ''I never met an author who wrote a secondhand book,'' he said. Now mellowed by age, illness and success at founding book towns elsewhere, he has been spotted sitting in the festival audience and next year may even take part.
title: Say Hay

text: Feuds are endemic to Hay. King Richard's main opponent is Leon Morelli, a rival bookseller who moved into town, running his shops with less charisma but more discipline. The festival itself has split the town. When Peter Florence and his father, who founded the festival, proposed to build a permanent site along the Wye, local conservationists swiftly formed Friends of the North Bank. The Friends successfully fought to preserve unspoiled the view of Hay from the river as described by the Rev. Francis Kilvert, the Victorian diarist, writing from his rectory at Clyro on the opposite bank.
title: Say Hay

text: Kilvert's diaries, written between 1870 and 1879, have been called the finest diaries in the English language after Pepys. Kilvert, were he to return, would be surprised to find his walks in the Black Mountains now being retraced by devoted members of the Kilvert Society. Each year's festival opens with a Kilvert Walk. The bachelor curate would also be surprised to find pages from his diaries offered on the World Wide Web under ''Famous British Pedophiles,'' thanks to his vivid descriptions of farmers zealously chastising their nubile daughters.
title: Say Hay

text: Maybe this overhanging clerical presence is what gives the festival a theological preoccupation. Hay audiences -- white-haired middle-income Middle Englanders -- are great questioners. When some 1,000 pack the big tent to hear famous scientists talk about the origin of the universe, what they really want to know is whether the scientists believe in God.
title: Say Hay

text: This year Richard Dawkins, author of ''The Selfish Gene,'' was asked, ''Are you still as godless as you were?'' And, ''Is the human race still evolving?'' Dawkins's eyes rolled to the heaven he doesn't believe in, as for the zillionth time he heard the familiar questions. The answer to both was ''Yes.''
title: Say Hay

text: Stephen Hawking, the author of ''A Brief History of Time,'' got the same treatment. Did he recognize the importance of the spiritual side of people? The audience clearly expected that a man in Hawking's predicament might need the consolations of religion. He doesn't. Slumped like a folded bat in his motorized wheelchair, he croaked out his reply on his voice synthesizer: ''When the physical universe is fully explained by a Theory of Everything, we will not need 'nonphysical entities.' I hate mysticism. I like things crystal clear.''
title: Say Hay

text: What has swollen the festival from a few thousand to the 39,000 or so there in May, including about 1,000 Americans, is its intimate atmosphere: a combination of summer camp and religious retreat. Big-name musicians (Van Morrison last year) and stand-up comics also turn up to provide night life -- not otherwise Hay's strong suit.
title: Say Hay

text: There is no need to go to everything at the 10-day festival to come away with nuggets of wit and wisdom.
title: Say Hay

text: Peter Carey, on being an Australian novelist: ''Britain is the reality for former colonial countries. In Australia I grew up with a feeling of not being in the real place, that the real landscape was the green one, not the brown.''
title: Say Hay

text: Armistead Maupin on ''Tales of the City'': ''I'm a gay author. I don't like to mince words.'' (A pause, as laughter began to rise.) ''I don't like to mince at all.''
title: Say Hay

text: Helen Fielding on her best seller, ''Bridget Jones's Diary'': ''It's a singleness-of-Diana book: a woman trying to be independent and it not quite working out.''
title: Say Hay

text: Hay is worth a detour any time of the year for anyone who loves old books and doesn't mind rain or the smell of mildew. Even if you don't find the book you've long been searching for, its 36 bookshops are great places to come across the unexpected.
title: Say Hay

text: Local farmers used to scoff at the whole arty Hay-on-Wye scene. Now, with their beef banned on the Continent because of mad cow disease, and with the world turning vegetarian, they watch the rural economy decline. Malcolm Evans of Defynnog recently sent a poem to the local paper entitled ''What Have Farmers Done Wrong?'': ''Working hard and caring lots / They used to be enough. / Now I have to fight the law / Cos it can get real rough!''
title: Say Hay

text: Would Evans have turned to verse if Hay-on-Wye had not been taken over by the literati? My bet is that in a few years he and fellow farmers will find themselves selling secondhand books.
title: Say Hay

text: It is difficult to imagine a man less threatening than Herman Walker.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Slowed down by a stroke one year ago, Mr. Walker, 75, spends much of his time in his dingy one-bedroom apartment here, passing the hours with a Bible on his lap and stuffed animals scattered around him like throw pillows on a fraying couch.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: ''They're company,'' Mr. Walker recently said, his words slightly garbled. ''I look at them so much they're human to me.''
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: But according to housing officials in Oakland, Mr. Walker poses a danger to his fellow tenants in public housing. And if these officials have their way, he and his menagerie will have to find a new home.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Three times last year, the housing authorities said, they found cocaine or cocaine paraphernalia in Mr. Walker's apartment or in the possession of people who spent time there. Even though Mr. Walker told officials he was not aware of the drugs, they moved to evict him.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: A lawsuit that Mr. Walker and three others have filed in response to eviction actions illustrates a growing conflict between Federal officials, who have urged local housing agencies to crack down on illegal drug use, and some advocates for the poor, who say that innocent people are falling victim to a Draconian offensive in the war on drugs.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: A 1996 Federal directive, by President Clinton and the Department of Housing and Urban Development, ordered local agencies that administer public housing to enforce a law holding tenants responsible for any drug-related activity that occurs inside their apartments or outside the premises by people living there.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Earlier this year, the Eviction Defense Center, a nonprofit legal group, took the case of the four Oakland residents to Federal court in San Francisco to protest that directive. The case represents one of the most serious legal challenges yet to the policy, which has led to a sharp rise in drug-related evictions among the roughly three million Americans living in public housing.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: ''It's beyond unfairness,'' Ira Jacobowitz, one of the lawyers working on the case with the center, said of the policy. ''Somebody can be evicted whether or not they had any previous knowledge of, participation in, or ability to control the situation.''
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Mr. Jacobowitz also noted that tenants could be evicted even if the accusations of drug-related activity did not lead to criminal convictions.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Judge Charles R. Breyer of Federal District Court issued a preliminary injunction on June 19 against the evictions of the four plaintiffs in an opinion that questioned the prudence of the part of the policy related to drug-related activity outside an apartment.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: ''The policy on its face appears irrational,'' Judge Breyer wrote, ''since the tenant has not engaged in any such activity or knowingly allowed such activity to occur.''
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: A final decision on the lawsuit, which charges that the enforcement of the Federal directive deprives tenants of their constitutional rights to due process and freedom of association, awaits a trial sometime later this year. The resolution could have an impact on the aggressiveness with which housing officials around the country pursue these evictions.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Stan Vosper, a spokesman for the housing department, said he could not discuss the merits of the case. But he said that the directive, known as the ''one strike'' policy, was an effort to make public housing safer for all residents and that local housing authorities had been urged to use discretion on complaints.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Randolph W. Hall, a lawyer for the Oakland Housing Authority, said the eviction proceedings against the plaintiffs were justified because the plaintiffs, at least indirectly, brought drug-related activity into or near public housing.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: ''Look at who the victims are: these hundreds of thousands of mothers who lost their kids to drive-by shootings or can't take their kids to the sandboxes,'' Mr. Hall said. ''You have to balance their rights.''
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Mr. Hall said the Oakland Housing Authorities pursues dozens of these evictions every year, only a small percentage of which are contested.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Two plaintiffs in the lawsuit are grandmothers whose grandchildren, according to housing officials, were on the apartments' leases and were found with marijuana in a parking lot outside the apartments. Another plaintiff is a woman whose daughter and son were separately found with cocaine outside the apartment, housing officials said.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: In Mr. Walker's case, the people accused of having drugs or drug paraphernalia were a private caretaker and another visitor to his apartment. Mr. Hall said the multiple incidents showed Mr. Walker's failure to discourage the activity.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: But Judge Breyer cited the Americans With Disabilities Act in saying that Mr. Walker's right to home health care would be compromised by an obligation to supervise a caretaker's activities.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: Mr. Walker said there was a limit to his control over people who come to his apartment.
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: ''I don't know what you have on you,'' he said to a reporter who was visiting him. ''I'm not going to ask you, 'What do you have on you?' ''
title: A Battleground Without Winners in the War on Drug Abuse

text: There was nothing frail in his voice -- which neither broke nor cracked -- making Marcus Camby's first major move as a Knick injury free.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: He survived questions about his fragile past as a Toronto Raptor and his slip-ups on and off the court yesterday in his first full day as an official Knick. His first full day of not being Charles Oakley.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: ''No one is going to replace Oak,'' said Camby, who on Wednesday night was traded to the Knicks from Toronto for Oakley. ''He was the heart and soul and a team leader. He's irreplaceable. I just want to bring something different, a lot of versatility. I'm a guy who can play a number of positions and give this team a different outlook than it had in the past couple of years.''
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: The difference is, there is a future to the Knicks now. If Camby is not used in a trade to grab a point guard, he has a chance to find inspiration from the veteran Knick players who will surround him, and reach the star potential that is etched on his 6-foot-11-inch athletic frame. He can shoot the open jumper, rise like a flare to block a shot and lap the rest of the plodding Knicks in a race around the court. But there is his reputation for being soft. All of these characteristics -- good and bad -- make him the un-Knick.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: ''I think I can fit in,'' Camby said. ''Playing physical is not really one of my strengths, but I'm going to come here and add something different. I think we're going to try and run this year, make things happen and get it in the open court for some easy baskets.''
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: It sounds good, sounds fun. But Camby's flight plans will have to revolve around Patrick Ewing, just like the rest of his teammates'. Unlike in his life as a Raptor, Camby will not be a go-to man, but a next-to-last resort when Ewing, Larry Johnson or Allan Houston are covered.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: Maybe this new, less-pressured status is best. His two years as a star for an expansion team seemed to hinder Camby more than help him. Instead of rising above a difficult situation, Camby seemed to become a product of his environment in Toronto. He was inconsistent and prone to injury as much as the Raptors' franchise was unsettled and dysfunctional.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: ''There was really no stability,'' said Camby, who was the second overall pick in the 1996 draft out of Massachusetts. ''We had to worry about trades and who was going to be gone tomorrow. I think I'm in a stable franchise now with a lot of tradition.''
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: He has a firm footing, and no excuses now. If Johnson can play nearly an entire season on a badly sprained ankle, Camby can learn to play in pain, too. In Toronto, Camby called in sick because of everything from back strains to ankle sprains, from the flu to a jammed neck. Once, the former Raptors coach Darrell Walker -- in an attempt to force Camby to play through pain -- refused to send a trainer to aid Camby when he was wincing on the court.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: This is as good a time as any for Camby to shake the hypochondriac label and take a step toward maturity in his contract year. If this 24-year-old is to succeed, he cannot afford the missteps that have dogged his past. In college, he violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules after accepting cash from an agent. Last summer in Manchester, Conn., he was arrested and charged with possession of marijuana, a charge that was later dropped.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: ''I've been through a lot of adversity in my life,'' Camby said. ''There are always going to be doubters out there, people who doubt me as a person and as a player. My goal is to have the last laugh.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: ''I don't have to prove anything but to myself and to my teammates. What people say is not going to make or break me.''
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: No breaks, no cracks. Camby's first full day had a healthy glow to it.
title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In

text: By Barry James, International Herald Tribune
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: After four days of contentious talks, European Union agriculture ministers reached agreement early Friday on a wide-ranging package of agricultural reforms aimed at trimming Europe's bulging farm subsidies.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: Chief among the policy reforms was a decision to double the amount of arable land taken out of cultivation to avoid the buildup of a new grain mountain.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: But some analysts said that compromise fell short of the root and branch reforms to the EU's Common Agricultural Policy that will become necessary to rein in subsidies as the 15-nation bloc takes in countries in Eastern Europe with large rural populations.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: The EU agriculture council also adopted three other major reforms for bananas, olive oil and tobacco.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: In addition, it agreed to cut subsidies to hemp growers in an effort to curb a massive increase in production that has been fueled by the illegal cultivation of marijuana and has led to more than $30 million in subsidies last year.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: Jack Cunningham, the British minister, said the deal on grain prices and production was "the most significant" in years. The talks were led by Britain as the current holder of the revolving EU presidency.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies
