text: The ministers agreed to take out of production 10 percent of the land used to grow grain or oilseeds — up from 5 percent this year — in an attempt to lift prices and reduce the amount of money the EU spends to buy up surpluses.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: Officials said the measure would double the amount of land left fallow to about 1.5 million hectares (3.7 million acres), and reduce grain and oil-seed production by 8 million tons in the coming year. Grain production this year is expected to be about 201 million tons, with estimated stockpiles totaling 15 million tons. Officials said this could rise to 30 million tons within less than two years unless action is taken to reduce overproduction.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: Under rules agreed with the World Trade Organization, the EU cannot subsidize the export of its surplus wheat, which is more expensive than the world price. It therefore needs to take more land out of cultivation in order to keep production in line with the requirements of the market.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: The EU began setting aside arable land in 1992 in an attempt to reduce grain mountains. Farmers receive a compensating income to leave land fallow, or a guaranteed minimum price for grain they cannot sell on the open market.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: This year's price-fixing talks were almost derailed by a Spanish refusal to accept any changes until other countries agreed to make more money available to subsidize the production of olive oil. The ministers agreed on a compromise that is unlikely to please Spanish farmers, tens of thousands of whom have taken to the streets to contest the proposed economies.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: The European Commission, the EU's executive body, had sought to reduce olive oil production to drive up prices and reduce subsidies. The amount of fraudulent subsidy claims in this sector are believed to be high.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: The ministers decided on an overall quota of 1.777 million tons, attracting more than $2.3 billion in subsidies.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: The compromise with Spain opened the way to an overall farm deal that also resulted in a slightly less protectionist arrangement on banana imports intended to avert a trade dispute with the United States, which earlier this week threatened retaliation over the issue.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: The ministers agreed to increase the import quota of so-called "dollar bananas" grown in Latin America and marketed by U.S. companies such as Chiquita Brands International and Dole Food Co.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: The EU has sought to protect its own growers in the Caribbean and Canary Islands, where production costs are higher than in Latin America, as well as from producers in the former colonies forming the Asia, Caribbean and Pacific group.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: It set a duty-free quota of 857,700 tons from these areas, as well as approving subsidies for growers in the Canary Islands, Madeira and French Caribbean possessions. At the same time, the EU will allow imports of 2.5 million tons of so-called dollar bananas from Latin America at a tariff of 75 Ecus a ton,
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: Franz Fischler, the commissioner in charge of agriculture, said this agreement would enable the EU to defend its position at the World Trade Organization.
title: Pact Aims to Trim 'Grain Mountain' by Doubling Area Left Fallow : EU Agrees to Cut Farm Subsidies

text: THE SUPREME COURT: DOUBLE JEOPARDY
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: The constitutional protection against double jeopardy does not ordinarily apply to criminal sentencing, the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision that removed a legal cloud from the operation of some states' ''three strikes'' sentencing laws.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: The 5-to-4 decision, upholding a ruling by the California Supreme Court, means that a state can have more than one chance to prove that a previous conviction qualifies as a ''strike'' that counts against a defendant in calculating an enhanced sentence for a new offense.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: All 50 states have some form of enhanced sentencing for previously convicted offenders. Had the Court ruled that double jeopardy applied to sentencing, the operation of those laws could have been placed in doubt to the extent that a state permitted defendants to contest the validity of an earlier conviction.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: In California, a defendant can get a jury trial on the question of whether a previous conviction qualifies as a ''strike.'' Typically, not every previous offense counts. It must have been a serious felony that, in the case of an assault, for example, involved use of a dangerous weapon or great bodily injury to the victim.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: In this case, a man who was convicted of selling marijuana faced a doubling of his five-year sentence if the state proved that he had a single prior qualifying conviction. He said that his previous conviction, an assault in which he had hit someone with a stick, did not count. The trial judge held that the evidence of the previous conviction was insufficient. When the state tried to appeal, the California Court of Appeal ruled that a new trial on the allegation would amount to double jeopardy. The California Supreme Court, in turn, reversed that decision, holding that double jeopardy did not apply to sentencing.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: The Court today affirmed that ruling in an opinion by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor that was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Clarence Thomas and Stephen G. Breyer.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: Justice O'Connor said that historically, double jeopardy applied only to a determination of guilt or innocence, not sentencing. She noted that in 1981, the Court had made an exception to that rule in a death penalty case, Bullington v. Missouri, in which a murder defendant who had received a life sentence got a new trial in which, if found guilty, he faced a renewed chance of being sentenced to death. The Court ruled then that a defendant who had avoided the death penalty in an initial sentencing proceeding could not be forced to face it again in a resentencing.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: Justice O'Connor said today that the decision in the Bullington case had depended on the ''unique circumstances'' of the death penalty and should not be extended to other types of sentencing.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: In a dissenting opinion, Justice Antonin Scalia said he agreed with the conclusion that the Bullington case should not be extended. But he said that the current case, Monge v. California, No. 97-6146, should not be regarded as a simple sentencing case. Rather, he said, a sentencing enhancement was in effect a conviction for a separate crime, for which full procedural protections should apply. Justices David H. Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg joined Justice Scalia's dissent, while Justice John Paul Stevens dissented separately.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: In a separate case today, the Court refused without comment to hear a constitutional challenge to a Federal law, the Military Honor and Decency Act of 1996, which prohibits the Government from selling or renting ''sexually explicit material'' on military property. The effect of the law is to bar the rental of sexually explicit films and the sale of such popular magazines as Penthouse and Playboy -- previously sold by the hundreds of thousands of copies a year -- from the PX on a military base.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: The publisher of Penthouse, along with other plaintiffs, brought a First Amendment suit against the law and won an initial ruling in Federal District Court in New York. But late last year, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held that the law was constitutional as a reasonable restriction on speech in the particular context of a military base.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: The Supreme Court appeal, General Media Communications Inc. v. Cohen, No. 97-1535, said the law, and the ruling upholding it, ''will result in massive restriction of the First Amendment rights of our country's military personnel and their dependents.''
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: Military personnel may still own sexually explicit material and may buy it from sources other than the PX.
title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: Ex-Student Is Charged With Growing Marijuana

text: A 22-year-old Vineland man who dropped out of Rutgers University in April was arrested Wednesday on a charge of growing marijuana in a fraternity house on campus, the university police said yesterday.
title: Ex-Student Is Charged With Growing Marijuana

text: The man, Timothy Becker, a sophomore before he quit school, was arrested in Vineland at the William Consolo Produce Auction, where he worked, said Detective John O'Neal, a spokesmen for the Rutgers University Police Department. Mr. Becker has been charged with manufacturing and cultivating marijuana, a crime punishable by a maximum of 18 months in jail, and was released on $1,000 bail.
title: Ex-Student Is Charged With Growing Marijuana

text: The 30 marijuana plants were discovered last Friday by firefighters responding to a small fire at the Beta Theta Pi fraternity house.
title: Ex-Student Is Charged With Growing Marijuana

text: Marcus Camby is not known for breezing by in olive-colored shoes with a Derby to match or for retrieving a loose ball three rows back. He is not one to mangle metaphors, jumble cliches or mix it up with an elbow.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: He is not Charles Oakley at all. Not in style, effort or attitude. And the Knicks have decided Oakley is not their type anymore.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: It's youth or bust now. The Knicks traded Oakley's savvy and heart to Toronto for the athletic ability and unfulfilled potential of Camby in a deal that was completed late Wednesday night. Acquiring Camby does not fill the Knicks' most urgent need -- point guard. So the team could still use Camby in a deal to secure that position in the next week.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: For now, the Knicks are claiming the 24-year-old Camby as their own after giving the cash-poor Raptors their 44th pick in the draft, Sean Marks, and an eye-catching $5 million to help offset the $10 million that Oakley is scheduled to receive as a balloon payment in the last year of his deal.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: This is not a trade that was welcomed by all within the Knicks' organization. Although Patrick Ewing, who benefited from the barbed-wire protection he received courtesy of the aggressive Oakley for 10 years, gave his O.K. for the deal, there were those who questioned whether it was wise to disrupt the makeup of the club by sending their role player away.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: The anxiety of this decision was not lost on the Knicks' brain trust. But one thing kept them focused on Camby. There was the Indiana series, and the lasting images of how a tandem of young and athletic forwards -- Antonio Davis and Dale Davis -- left the Knicks looking more outdated than ever before as they bowed out in the second round of the playoffs.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: ''What drove this was, 'Are we a step behind or a step ahead of Indiana?' I asked Jeff and Ernie this question,'' said Dave Checketts, the president of Madison Square Garden, referring to Coach Jeff Van Gundy and the team president Ernie Grunfeld. ''As much as Knick fans are going to miss Oak, they have to ask themselves that question, too. We agonized over this decision.''
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: Part of the decision was also contract related. Oakley made it no secret that he wanted to re-sign for another three or four years after his deal expired next year, leaving the Knicks in a situation where they would have had to pay a 35-year forward in the sunset of his career. Camby, who also has a year left on his deal, gives the Knicks more options for the future. And more flexibility on the floor.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: Even so, the trade changes the image of a team that has been to the playoffs each of the 10 years that Oakley was there to grab rebounds and strike fear into anyone foolish enough to look for an easy layup. Oakley was the Knicks' interior defense enforcer.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: ''I think the trade injects some youth and flexibility,'' Buck Williams said. ''But I think that with Oak gone, the Knicks can't be looked at as this hard-nosed, bump-and-grind, dive-on-the-floor type of team anymore. That image was carved from what Oak did. Charles Oakley is irreplaceable.''
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: Camby has to forge his own identity. He will arrive as the former second overall pick in the 1996 draft out of UMass with a trail of off-the-court problems. When he was a student, Camby violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules when he accepted cash and gifts from an agent. Last summer, he was charged with possessing a small amount of marijuana, a charge that was later dropped.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: In a turbulent two years in Toronto, Camby alternately wowed and disappointed those with high expectations of him. The 6-foot-11-inch Camby has been fragile, missing more than 15 games each season with foot and ankle injuries.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: And while the Knicks intend to add weight to his spindly frame, it is likely that Larry Johnson will move over to power forward, while Camby fills the small forward position.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: Camby gives the team a jolt of energy, fresh legs, and someone who can take off in the open court. He adds speed to a team of plodders. And he is a shot-blocking force who led the league with 230 blocked shots this season. Other than this, his other numbers were down from his rookie year. He averaged 12.1 points a game, shot 41 percent from the field and 61 percent from the line.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: It was a curious downswing from a player that has been viewed as unmotivated by some general managers in the league. But maybe it was the environment of losing in Toronto that dampened Camby's finesse game.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: ''It takes young players longer to develop in certain situations,'' Grunfeld said. ''He was in a situation where the team was losing in Toronto. We want to put him in a good environment, around veteran leadership, and get the most of out him.''
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: The very veteran who could help Camby's most would have been Oakley.
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: ''I hate it so bad for him,'' Oakley's mother, Corine, said when phoned at her home in Cleveland. ''He'll be disappointed, I know. But he'll be fine. He'll adjust. He'll say something like, 'whatever . . . nothin' you can do,' and move on.''
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: ''We would never give up a guy who has done so much for this team and is still a very capable player to trade for someone we didn't feel could help us win now,'' Van Gundy said. ''We're not about winning down the future. So I don't think this is about potential.''
title: Youth or Bust, So Oakley Is No. 1 Victim

text: The truck driver involved in the fatal wreck of a commuter train last Thursday tested positive for marijuana immediately afterward, the authorities said today.
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: The 39-year-old trucker, Keith J. Lintz, was driving a double-trailer rig into a steel mill in Portage, Ind., 30 miles southeast of Chicago, when the truck, carrying three 40,000-pound steel coils, became trapped between two parallel sets of train tracks. Having stopped for a freight train that was passing in front of him on one set of tracks, Mr. Lintz watched with apparent helplessness as the Chicago-bound commuter train, on the other tracks, crashed into his rear trailer. The impact hurled one of the coils into the front car of the two-car train, killing three passengers and injuring six.
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: In an interview today, the Portage Police Chief, David M. Reynolds, said that newly determined results of urine tests administered after the accident showed marijuana in Mr. Lintz's system and that the results of blood tests were still pending. Chief Reynolds said he did not know how much marijuana the urine tests indicated or whether the drug had contributed to the crash.
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: ''Unlike some other drugs, marijuana stays in your system for quite a while,'' Chief Reynolds said. ''So it may be a case where he took some marijuana several weeks ago and it's just still in his system.''
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: In the last five years, Mr. Lintz, of Niles, Mich., has received two warning letters from the office of the Michigan Secretary of State for accumulating points on his license.
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: After the crash, he was cited for four violations related to it. The most serious were a failure to secure the big coils properly and an overweight violation, which meant that he should not have been pulling the second trailer.
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: Mr. Lintz has told investigators that the freight train passing in front of him and the crossing gates behind him boxed him in, preventing him from moving out of the way of the commuter train.
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: Chief Reynolds said evidence was being formally presented today to prosecutors who will make the final decision on whether Mr. Lintz faces criminal charges.
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board re-created the crash on Saturday. Matthew Furman, a spokesman for the agency, said preliminary findings from the re-enactment showed that the commuter train's engineer saw the trailer only five to seven seconds before impact. Applying the emergency brake, the engineer was able to slow the train to 43 miles per hour from 68 m.p.h. before it hit the trailer.
title: Marijuana Found in Trucker Involved in Fatal Train Wreck

text: WESTERN thought about sex -- from the story of Eve to Aristotle's belief that girl babies arise from cooler sperm -- has been tainted by the notion that the female is a kind of imperfect or unfinished male. Medical science, however, has gone from treating women as though they were simply smaller men to realizing that sex confers many more differences than those that are related to reproduction.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: In contrast to the feminist premise that women can do anything men can do, science is demonstrating that women can do some things better, that they have many biological and cognitive advantages over men. Then again, there are some things that women don't do as well.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: One of the less visible, but theoretically very important differences, is the larger size of the connector in women between the two hemispheres of the brain. This means that women's hemispheres are less specialized: a stroke that damages the left side of the brain leaves men barely capable of speech, while the same damage to a woman's brain is far less debilitating since she can use both sides for language. Although there is no hard evidence, the larger connector may also account for woman's tendency to exhibit greater intuition (the separate brain halves are more integrated) and man's generally stronger right-handed throwing skills (controlled by a left hemisphere without distractions).
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Mary Catherine Bateson, the cultural anthropologist and a former president of Amherst College, has described women as ''peripheral visionaries'' able to follow several trains of thought (or children) simultaneously. Men, by contrast, seem better able to focus intensely on single topics. Our strengths, then, come from our differences rather than from our similarities.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Science and medicine are finally realizing that the differences that exist between men and women necessitate developing distinct therapeutic treatments addressing the specifics of our physiology. For example, doctors like Dr. Susan G. Kornstein, at the Medical College of Virginia's department of psychiatry, are advocating the use of sex-specific assessment and treatment of psychiatric disorders, like depression.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: In a recent paper published in the Journal of Clinical Psychiatry, Dr. Kornstein points out that while depressed men seem to respond best to drugs that affect two neurotransmitter systems, those involving norepinephrine and serotonin, women respond better to drugs that affect only the serotonin system.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: These differences in the therapeutic benefits of drugs not only underscore the need for medicine to go beyond giving women tapered doses of whatever is being prescribed for men (a latter-day offshoot of the women-as-incomplete-men theory), but support the idea that men's and women's brains do not function the same way.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Indeed, it is not only our brain functions that seem to diverge, but just about every aspect of our physiology. The way we metabolize alcohol and drugs, the way our circulatory system works and how resistant we are to infection are all affected by our sex.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: In utero, girls and boys are chromosomally different; one might wag that the determinant of maleness, the Y chromosome, named for its shape, is ''missing'' something that the female determinant, the X chromosome, has. But they look identical. The development of characteristic male and female sexual genitalia at birth and of secondary sexual characteristics like breasts during adolescence, result from influxes of hormones, including estrogen and testosterone.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: But the hormones we once thought were important only for pregnancy, lactation and sexual drive have profound effects on just about every organ in the body. In fact, the reproductive organs, which from a biologist's perspective are our only reason for existing, control and contribute to everything from mood to how cholesterol is used in the body.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Assigning such an important role to the reproductive organs is not new to our belief system. In ancient Greece, women who were classified as having nervous or ''hysterical'' disorders were thought to be suffering from an upward dislocation of the womb. Treatment for nervousness and hysteria entailed, among other things, trying to repel the womb back into place by applying noxious-smelling odors to the mouth and nose.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: As a few women can testify today, the perception that the reproductive organs caused hysteria later manifested itself in the widespread use of hysterectomies and ovarectomies to treat behavioral disorders among American women during the early part of this century.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Science and medicine have historically used biologically-based sex differences to justify obvious acts of misogyny. It is not surprising, then, that a natural response has been for women to insist on equality implicitly based on the assumption that the sexes are essentially the same.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: But women may be just as ill served by a medical profession that treats men and women as equals as by one that follows what Dr. Rudolf Virchow, a famous 19th-century German doctor, believed. (He was the first to describe leukemia and is regarded as the founder of cellular pathology.) As Dr. Virchow put it, ''Woman is a pair of ovaries with a human being attached, whereas man is a human being furnished with a pair of testes.''
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Recent research demonstrates that while men begin to suffer from coronary artery disease earlier in life than women do, once they are afflicted women are more likely to die of coronary complications. Men are also more prone throughout most of their lives to high-blood pressure, but as women get older, this advantage disappears.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: The delayed onset of cardiovascular disease in women may be linked to the fact that the female hormone, estrogen, which is produced mostly by the ovaries, protects the circulatory system from disease. Differences in the quantities of estrogen, essential for organization and maintenance of tissues and organs in both sexes, plays an important role in brain development and appears to be the reason that men's brains are bigger, but women's brains have more neurons.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Estrogen makes blood vessels more elastic, stimulates them to expand and allow good blood flow, and prevents cholesterol accumulation on the inside of blood vessels. As women age, however, they lose the protective benefits of estrogen because, in a rather dramatic fashion, their bodies stop producing it.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: At the same time, some treatments that are used to prevent cardiovascular disorders -- aspirin, for example -- are less effective in women. Reporting in a recent issue of the International Journal of Fertility and Women's Medicine, Dr. Marianne Legato, of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, notes: ''Although aspirin use is associated with less frequent myocardial infarction in both men and women, it does not decrease the risk of stroke in hypertensive women, as it does in men.''
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: There are a number of naturally produced compounds that fluctuate more in women than in men: steroids, for example, which are infamous on the street for their simultaneous role in developing muscles and shortening tempers.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: It turns out that steroids, a class of compounds that includes sex hormones, may play an important role in the mood swings of menstruators. These hormones directly affect brain cells. The neuroactive steroid allopregnanolone, made from progesterone, dampens the sensitivity of brain cells; it works like benzodiazepine drugs, most familiarly Valium. When the progesterone level is high, a woman is calmer. When it is low, she may feel more anxious and irritable. Moreover, women with PMS become insensitive to the calming effects of Valium-like drugs.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: There is a growing consensus that these steroids produced by the sex organs are responsible for the greater incidence of mood disorders and depression in women. And a growing body of research is pointing to a role for other, similar steroids in memory, stress and alcohol abuse.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: In keeping with the increasing recognition that some of the most powerful mind-altering substances are internally produced by hormones, it is no wonder that adolescence is often a time of emotional turbulence. You cannot ''Just say no'' to your body's own genetically timed release of mood-altering sex hormones at puberty.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: What society considers ''recreational'' drug use, which often begins at adolescence, may sometimes be motivated by an effort to self-medicate, changing or reversing the effects of sex hormones and neuroactive steroids. The notorious mood swings of adolescents may very likely reflect the body's adjustment to new concentrations and combinations of these compounds.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Lester Grinspoon, an associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and an advocate of the medical use of marijuana, points out that marijuana has long been known as a palliative for the psychophysical pains of menstruation. Queen Victoria, according to her doctor J. R. Reynolds, used it for that purpose. Curiously (and although since disputed), one of the few medical studies on marijuana suggests that its use lowers testosterone levels in men.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Perhaps this drug, among others, interacts with or works in a similar way to the hormonal and neuroactive steroids. In any case women, who are twice as prone as men to depression, and who have a higher body-fat-to-muscle ratio and more hormonally distinct brains, cannot be expected to respond to drugs, legal or illegal, in the same way men do.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: The sexual distinction that biology traces to chromosomes and hormones also applies to culture and language. I recall, for example, being put in the girls' group at a day camp as a child because my first name was assumed to be female.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Evolutionists believe that the first sexual reproducers were unisexual cells that became involved in cycles of merging and separating. The first fertilizations probably occurred among starving microbes that cannibalized, but did not completely devour each other, becoming instead two-in-one cells.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: Sexual differences evolved gradually over hundreds of millions of years. With these differences came ways of recognizing them. In many species, including humans, the gametes, or sex cells, of the females became fewer, bigger and more sedentary while those of the males became smaller, more fast-moving and numerous. But in humans, while the female sex cells, or ova, are far larger than the male gametes, or sperm, full-grown men are bigger than full-grown women.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: The cultural ramifications of body size have been considerable, including the virtual absence of rapes committed by women. They may also have influenced the development of greater female cunning and social acumen to mitigate four million years of male bullying.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: In our patrilineal culture, the family name is usually that of the man. Biology tells a more matrilineal story: the tiny DNA-containing oxygen-using inclusions in all of our cells, called mitochondria, come solely from our mothers. Nonetheless, culture remains, for lack of a better term, male-dominated. The French psychoanalyst Jacques Lacan even argued that all speech is part of the ''symbolic order'' -- the largely negative, male realm of language and rules that supplants the original affirmative closeness of mother and child.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: The psychologist Theodore Roszak, who has been exploring what he calls the ''twisted sexual politics of modern science,'' argues that science insidiously reinforces a partial male perspective. ''Hard'' sciences, like physics and chemistry, Mr. Roszak contends, are venerated, while ''softer'' sciences, like anthropology and psychology, are disparaged.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: ''Macho science,'' he argues, leads to bizarre fictions like selfish genes and cannibal galaxies. Female perspectives, he says, offer science new balance and openness.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: From sex among equal single cells to male feminists offering cultural critiques of science's rhetoric, we have learned that the two sexes, subtly different, develop differently, respond differently to certain drugs and see the world in different ways. As the French say, vive la difference.
title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

text: The White House's top drug policy official today accused critics of the nation's zero-tolerance drug laws of pursuing an agenda to legalize drugs from marijuana to heroin and cocaine.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: In written testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the official, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, asserted, ''There is a carefully camouflaged, exorbitantly funded, well-heeled elitist group whose ultimate goal is to legalize drug use in the United States.''
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: While General McCaffrey named no names, he was clearly referring to a coalition of advocacy groups that argues that the global war on drugs has cost society more than drug abuse itself. Some of those advocates attracted attention last week with an open letter to the United Nations Secretary General as the General Assembly opened a three-day special session on drugs.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: The letter -- whose 500 signers included the former Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, former Secretary of State George P. Shultz and two former Senators, Alan Cranston and Claiborne Pell -- argued that by focusing on punishing drug users, the United States and other countries had helped create a worldwide criminal black market that wrecked national economies and democratic governments.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: The letter's signers also included George Soros, the billionaire investor and philanthropist, who has spent as much as $20 million supporting research and advocacy groups working to change Americans' views on how to deal with drug use. Mr. Soros said in an interview last week that he hoped that it would foster an open discussion of the issue.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: But General McCaffrey, the Clinton Administration's director of national drug policy, said the critics were disguising their true purpose because Americans overwhelmingly opposed legalizing drugs.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: ''Through a slick misinformation campaign,'' he said, ''these individuals perpetuate a fraud on the American people, a fraud so devious that even some of the nation's most respectable newspapers and sophisticated media are capable of echoing their falsehoods.''
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: His assertion prompted the Judiciary Committee's ranking Democrat, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, to propose hearings into the issue of legalizing drugs.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: ''Let's expose it for the fraud that it is,'' Senator Biden said.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: Mr. Soros could not be reached today because he was traveling in Sweden. But one of the most prominent advocates of less punitive approaches to drug use, Ethan Nadelmann, director of the Lindesmith Center, a drug policy institute in New York supported by Mr. Soros, called the general's criticism ''an attempt to smear what's a very responsible approach to dealing with drug abuse in our society.''
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: At the core of the disagreement is the concept of harm reduction, which to advocates like Mr. Nadelmann, means finding ways short of abstinence to reduce the harm that drug abusers cause themselves and society. Needle exchange, in which addicts are given clean needles to try to stem the spread of AIDS, is a prominent example.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: Kevin Zeese, president of Common Sense for Drug Policy, a group in Falls Church, Va., that also wants drug laws changed, said, ''The reason why there is an upsurge of people advocating reform is because the current policy is not making for a safer or healthier society,''
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: But General McCaffrey called harm reduction ''a hijacked concept that has become a euphemism for drug legalization.''
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: ''It's become a cover story for people who would lower the barriers to drug use,'' he said.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: Mr. Nadelmann responded, ''The majority of harm reduction advocates oppose drug legalization, and that includes George Soros.''
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: Until today, General McCaffrey had ignored the advocacy groups' lobbying, and so his sharp attack was a change in strategy.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: After testifying, he said he was suggesting a debate about legalization, not a witch hunt.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: ''It's a legitimate subject of debate in our society if you do it openly,'' said General McCaffrey, who is retired from the Army.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: He predicted that the notion would be ''rejected resoundingly'' once Americans discovered what was involved.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: Mr. Nadelmann said: ''I would welcome the opportunity to debate him anytime or anyplace. His trying to equate all forms of harm reduction with a free market approach to drug legalization is both false and duplicitous.''
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: But Mark A. R. Kleiman, a professor of public policy at the University of California at Los Angeles who follows drug issues, expressed concern that such a debate would detract from the more crucial task of finding ways to make the current anti-drug strategies work more effectively.
title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs

text: It is the time of year when Franz S. Leichter's colleagues in the State Senate ardently wish that he would disappear.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: As the legislative session lurches to an end and lawmakers try to rush through piles of complicated bills, Mr. Leichter, a Democrat from the Upper West Side of Manhattan, starts reeling off questions. On the last day of session, he is usually unstoppable, challenging bill after bill as the hours creep past and his colleagues roll their eyes.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: But lawmakers say they will suffer Mr. Leichter's last-minute tirades a little more gladly this year, because they will mark the end of an era. The session, which will probably end on Thursday, is his last. Mr. Leichter will retire in December after three decades in office, leaving the Legislature without one of its harshest critics and most staunchly liberal members.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Though his career as in-house gadfly has left him with few concrete legislative achievements, lawmakers say that without him the Democratic minority in the Senate will agitate less effectively and the Republican majority will breathe more easily.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: For his part, Mr. Leichter says the public has become so mistrustful of government, and his colleagues on both sides of the aisle so lethargic, that he is finally too frustrated to press on.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Mr. Leichter, 67, entered politics at a time when leftist philosophies were fashionable in Manhattan, though not in Albany, and won an Assembly seat in 1968. He used the platform to speak out against the Vietnam War, and he called in vain for the legalization of marijuana and changes to the notoriously secretive budget process in Albany.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: In 1974, he moved to the Senate, where he began writing damning reports on topics like campaign finance law, banking practices and corporate tax breaks.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: All along, Mr. Leichter, whose district snakes from Chelsea in Manhattan to Riverdale in the Bronx, has inveighed against pork-barrel spending, back-room deal-making and the rigidly hierarchical leadership system in the Legislature, which he says ''stifles initiative and productivity.''
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: In relinquishing his seat, Mr. Leichter says, he is relinquishing hope that the system will change in his lifetime. ''It's a tightly closed system that has crystallized and become even more of a way of life since I came here,'' Mr. Leichter said recently, eating baked fish at a restaurant near the State Capitol. ''This is not a time to be in government. Continuing to do the same thing is not going to accomplish much at this point.''
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: As a member of the minority party for his entire legislative career, Mr. Leichter has not been able to accomplish much, ever. But between his angry reports and his tireless voice, which almost never remains silent in the Senate chamber, he has frequently drawn attention to what he sees as Republican misdeeds. And on occasion, he has managed to bring about some measure of change.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: After Mr. Leichter revealed in the early 1980's that the state's Job Incentive Board had given Tiffany & Company a $5 million tax credit for expanding its store on Fifth Avenue, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo abolished the incentive program. And his reports that criticized fund-raising practices by members of the New York City Board of Estimate helped persuade city officials to create an independent campaign finance board in 1988.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: ''Franz is unique because he attacks the process like an outsider,'' said Blair Horner, legislative director of New York Public Interest Research Group, which has worked with Mr. Leichter on consumer and environmental issues. ''Instead of developing relationships with more powerful members, he has tried to generate public interest, which can have a much more powerful effect.''
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Although Mr. Leichter rarely stops hurling accusations and complaints, his colleagues describe him as one of the best-liked legislators in Albany. Even lawmakers who tangle with him on the Senate floor greet him warmly outside the chamber, and many even play tennis with him.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: ''Franz has a lot of respect across the board because he happens to be a warm and friendly person,'' said Senator Guy J. Velella, a Bronx Republican who was the subject of Mr. Leichter's wrath when he sponsored a bill to outlaw public defecation, which Mr. Leichter said discriminated against homeless people. ''He's one of the last beatnik types there is, thank God. But he is a good man.''
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Other Republicans, like Senator Ronald B. Stafford of Plattsburgh, are less charitable, but hardly vindictive toward their colleague from the 30th District. ''Well,'' Mr. Stafford said, ''he's certainly indefatigable.''
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: An immigrant from Austria whose mother died in a Nazi concentration camp, Mr. Leichter worked for Adlai E. Stevenson's Presidential campaign in 1956, while attending Harvard Law School. After graduation, he joined the reform wing of the Manhattan Democratic Party, which was challenging the Tammany Hall political machine that had controlled Democratic politics for decades.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: ''We were fighting against the boss-dominated party organization that existed in New York, which still exists, more or less, in Albany,'' Mr. Leichter said. ''I liked the openness. I was very idealistic.''
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: He raised enough hackles in the Assembly that the Republican majority tried to get rid of him, eliminating his seat when it redrew the state's legislative districts in 1972. Undeterred, Mr. Leichter moved his wife and two children seven blocks north to run in the new district.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Mr. Leichter decided to run for the Senate in 1974, when the Federal Government declared the reapportionment illegal and carved up his new district. The Republican majority again tried to thwart him, redrawing the Senate district so that he once again lived outside it. He moved a second time and astonished fellow lawmakers by defeating Senator Joseph Zaretzski, the Democratic minority leader, who had served for three decades.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Mr. Leichter would presumably have trouble drumming up votes in most other districts, though -- especially in recent years, with a Republican in the Governor's office and many voters favoring smaller government. In what his colleagues describe as a quintessential Leichter move, he introduced legislation in 1995 to repeal Gov. George E. Pataki's popular income tax cuts, saying they benefited only the wealthy. Not surprisingly, the bill died.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: So why spend hours extolling bills that have no chance of passage, and challenging others that will pass no matter how loudly Mr. Leichter protests? ''I just feel that is what I was sent up here to do,'' Mr. Leichter said. ''To fight against that sense of futility. I have a visceral dislike for the idea of putting these bills through without discussion. My colleagues say, 'What's the use? You get up and debate the bill and you get three votes against it.' But if nothing else, I want to know at least that I voted right.''
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: In appearance, Mr. Leichter is more neatnik than beatnik, wearing double-breasted suits, starched shirts and glasses with scholarly frames. He has worked for a law firm on Park Avenue since 1988, specializing in international corporate litigation. He likes movies about politics, books about economics and Wagnerian operas.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: He does not talk about his wife, Nina, who suffered from depression and committed suicide in 1995 by jumping out a window of their apartment on Riverside Drive.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Even his friends describe Mr. Leichter as a workaholic, and while he is leaving the Legislature, he has no intention of fading from view. He has sent his resume to Washington, where he is a candidate for a seat on the Federal Housing Finance Board. He is also considering teaching or working with advocacy groups.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Although Mr. Leichter's final legislative session has been one of the most uneventful in years, he has managed to carp with his usual flair. He introduced a campaign finance bill and has pressed for a bill that would speed the creation of Hudson River Park, which would stretch from Battery Park to 59th Street in Manhattan.
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: But over all, Mr. Leichter sums up the 1998 legislative session as depressingly stagnant, with lawmakers driven by polls and partisanship. ''The paucity of new programs and ideas, whether they come from the right or the left, shows how dispirited people are,'' Mr. Leichter said. ''I think we can say that the Legislature is brain dead.''
title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out

text: Like a first kiss, getting the car keys for the first time or walking into a bar and buying a first drink, gambling has become a rite of passage for young people on their way to adulthood.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: With casinos in 26 states and lotteries in 38, youths who have watched their parents choose from a hefty menu of legal gambling activities right in their backyards are going on dates, spending their prom nights and joining college classmates at the nearest casinos.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Along with this change in the American cultural scene, there is a growing concern among experts on compulsive gambling about the number of youths who -- confronted with state lotteries, the growth of family-oriented casinos and sometimes lax enforcement of wagering laws -- gamble at an earlier and earlier age and gamble excessively.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: These experts fear that the proliferation of youthful gambling will lead to more cases like that of a young Philadelphia man who became an addicted gambler as a teen-ager. For the young man, now 27, the ''bottom'' came after he had made two trips to prison for credit card fraud and writing false checks, attempted suicide and robbed his family.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''By the time I was 17, my parents had put a lock on everything in the house -- bedrooms, pantries, closets,'' said the man, Michael, who is in a treatment program for compulsive gamblers. Like other addicts in recovery progams, Michael agreed to be identified only by his first name. ''If I could take 30 towels out of the linen closet I would sell them for $10 to place a bet,'' he recalled.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: A study conducted last year by Louisiana State University found that one in seven Louisianians ages 18 to 21 were problem gamblers, some of them pathological -- youths with a chronic and progressive psychological disorder characterized by an emotional dependence on gambling and a loss of control over their gambling.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Dr. Howard Shaffer, a professor of psychology at Harvard University, recently conducted an analysis of nationwide studies of gambling addiction. He found that the rate of problem gambling among adolescents was 9.4 percent, more than twice the 3.8 percent rate for adults. ''Young people have been gambling since the beginning of time,'' he said. ''But I think now, for the first time, young people are growing up having lived their entire lives in a social environment where gambling is promoted and socially accepted.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''It used to be that young people said, 'I'm 21, let's go have a drink.' Now they say, 'I'm 21, let's go gamble.' ''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Children get their lessons in wagering all around them -- from the sports trading cards that they buy hoping to find one with an instant and large monetary value, to the chocolate chip cookie company that advertises during Saturday morning cartoons, offering $1,000 to the lucky child who buys a package with the chocolate chips missing. And although children have been gambling for years, the fundamental principle of gambling -- buying a chance to win more money -- is indeed more pervasive in the lives of young people than it has ever been, some experts say.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: The local governments that sponsor lotteries, as well as the casino industry and other businesses, do their part, whether intentional or not, to enhance gambling's appeal in the eyes of the young. Lottery scratch cards have bright, cartoonish graphics. Video poker machines resemble the video machines that a generation of children have grown up playing. Video arcades for children along the Boardwalk in Atlantic City include reconditioned slot machines that work just like the real thing but offer prizes instead of money. And the casino industry, by surrounding itself with amusement parks and attractions that appeal to the young, has given parents a reason to bring children along when they visit places like Atlantic City and Las Vegas, introducing adolescents to casinos and cultivating future gamblers.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''Market-savvy managers are grooming the next generation,'' said Marvin Roffman, a Philadelphia-based gambling analyst. ''The kids go to the amusement park for the day, and when the family gets back to the hotel room, Dad is talking about how he did at the blackjack tables and Mom is talking about how she did at the slots. The kids are listening and it's making an impression on them.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: With so many other things to worry about, like teen-age pregnancy, drug abuse and drunken driving, many parents and educators say they have not yet focused on gambling as one of their major concerns.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''I know we have students, probably a large number of students, who gamble,'' conceded William Steele, the principal of Atlantic City High School. On the desk in his outer office, there is a stack of pamphlets for students to read about compulsive gambling. And although the school's student resource center lists counseling for problem gambling as one of the services it provides, Mr. Steele admitted that little has been done to encourage students to seek help for gambling problems. ''It's not an area that we have taken a keen interest in,'' he said.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: It is true that like other rites of passage, gambling will prove harmless in the long term for most of the young people who try it. Dr. Shaffer said that many teen-agers experimented with gambling and lost interest as they became adults. One primary reason that teen-agers are so interested in gambling, he said, is that adults have failed to inform them of the dangers. ''I think it's because of the whole social milieu that we've provided these young people,'' he said.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Teen-Agers Losing Control of the Dice
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: While much is left to be learned about the long-term impact of gambling's pervasiveness, it is already quite clear that some youths are destined to have problems with their gambling. Gambling experts estimate that 10 to 15 percent of youths who gamble become ''problem gamblers,'' meaning they suffer some loss of control over their gambling behavior. And according to the Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, of those who experience more severe problems and become pathological gamblers, most are people who start gambling before they reach 14.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: One such case is that of Malcolm, a 17-year-old youth from Plainfield, N.J., who at 13 was playing craps in his neighborhood and wagering on pick-up basketball games and ''see-low'', a game played with three dice that is popular among teen-age gamblers.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''I always gambled, so I thought that I may have a problem,'' Malcolm said. After a recent conviction for marijuana possession, Malcolm was sent to New Hope Foundation, an in-patient addiction center in Marlboro, N.J. Compulsive gambling was diagnosed, and now he receives treatment for both drug and gambling problems.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Cole DiMattio, one of Malcolm's counselors at the center, said that it was Malcolm's interest in gambling that led him to drugs. ''All of his gambling,'' Mr. DiMattio said, ''looking for that crowd, brought him into the drug culture.'' When he was a child, Malcolm said in a recent telephone interview, his parents often played the state lottery and visited the casinos in Atlantic City. ''They didn't take me with them'' he said. ''But I wanted to go.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Valerie Lorenz, executive director of the Compulsive Gambling Center, a treatment program in Baltimore, said that while many teen-agers were compulsive gamblers, few sought treatment while they were still in their teens. ''It just takes a while for the addiction to develop,'' she said.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Michael is a case in point. He traced his interest in gambling back to growing up in Philadelphia, where he helped his grandmother pick lottery numbers at the corner store and joined her on frequent trips to Atlantic City, an hour's drive away. He recalled standing outside the old Playboy casino, peering through its gigantic window.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''I stood outside that glass and watched my grandmother and thought, all I ever want in life is to be on the other side of that glass,'' he said.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: He got on the other side before long, he said, and by 15 he had used fake ID's and was a regular at the casinos, receiving free limousine rides to and from Philadelphia and complimentary hotel rooms from casinos that rarely questioned his age. Betting $100 to $2,000 a hand on blackjack, he financed his gambling any way he could. He said he robbed local prostitutes several times and in a single week wrote $35,000 in bad checks at the bank where his father was a vice president.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''One of those prostitutes could have blown my head off,'' he said. ''But it didn't matter, as long as I was able to stay in action, that's all that mattered.'' He is now married, working at a bakery and living in southern New Jersey. He attends meetings of Gamblers Anonymous, he said, and has not placed a bet in four years.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: But not all young problem gamblers are able to withstand the travails wrought by their excessive wagering. Last November, just after running up a $6,000 debt betting on the World Series, Moshe Pergament, a 19-year-old college student from an affluent Long Island family, decided to end his gambling, and his life. He bought a toy handgun and drove erratically on the Long Island Expressway, causing police officers to stop him. When he was pulled over, he aimed the gun at the officers, who responded by shooting and killing him. The police said they found letters in Mr. Pergament's car that revealed the gambling debt and his intention of having the police shoot him, a phenomenon known as ''suicide by cop.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Officials Watch, Trying to Respond
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: In parts of the country where gambling has flourished especially fast, the problem with under-age gambling is particularly acute. In Louisiana, a state that has long had horse racing and back-room card games but over the last decade has added riverboat casinos, video poker machines, a state lottery and casinos operated by American Indians, officials were jolted into action after the Louisiana State University study found that youths there were three times as likely as adults to become problem gamblers. The study, conducted by the department of psychiatry, surveyed 12,066 adolescents grades six through twelve in public and private schools in the 1996-97 school year.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: The Louisiana State Legislature this year raised to 21 from 18 the minimum age for playing the state lottery and video poker machines inside more than 5,000 bars, restaurants and truck stops. Most states require lottery players to be at least 18. About half the states with casinos or video poker and slot machines allow 18-year-olds to play, while the other half, including Nevada and New Jersey, require those gamblers to be at least 21. The majority of states with parimutuel betting on events like horse racing, dog racing and jai alai allow 18-year-olds to bet.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: In Louisiana, after a local television reporter used an undercover camera recently to show that under-age gamblers were easily boarding the more than a dozen casino riverboats docked around the state, state gambling regulators are now threatening to rescind the licenses of casino operators who cannot keep under-age gamblers off their boats. In other states with legalized gambling, there are similar concerns. A citizen watchdog group in Illinois, for example, recently filmed under-age students drinking and gambling on the state's riverboats. The state gaming board then took steps to enforce age minimums.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''The truth of the matter is under-age gambling is a little like under-age drinking,'' said John Kennedy, Louisiana's secretary of revenue and a member of the state gaming control board. ''Minors, by definition, don't have the reasoning power of adults. If you don't have the reasoning power than you can't know your limits.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Still, many teen-agers simply do not want to wait until they are old enough to gamble. In Atlantic City last year 38,502 juveniles were escorted out of the city's 12 casinos, according to the state's casino control commission. An additional 52,364 under-age would-be gamblers tried to enter a casino and were turned away.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Too often, though, experts say, enforcement is lax.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: A familiar scene played itself out recently at the Tropicana Casino here. Madelyn Carabello was locked in a hypnotic trance as she dropped coins in a slot machine and watched the reels spin to a stop. After she had been playing for an hour and a half, a security guard approached her and asked for identification, then escorted her out. If her flawlessly youthful face, striped denim jeans and tennis shoes were not enough to tip the casino's security staff that it had an under-age gambler in its midst, surely the gold pendant around her neck was a dead giveaway. It was a large heart, surrounding the numeral 19, her age.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: But despite her age, it was not the first time that Ms. Carabello, a freshman at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City, had gambled in a casino.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: She recalled the eagerness with which she and 10 classmates boarded a gambling boat on their prom night in Miami.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''We heard that you only had to be 18'' to gamble on the boat, she said. ''I had heard how it was in a casino, that you could win money and stuff. I was like, 'Okay, let's do it.' ''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Youths gamble because they see everyone around them doing it, not because they care that lotteries are sanctioned by the state or that casinos are legal, said Henry Lesieur, president of the Institute for Problem Gambling in Pawtucket R.I.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''I don't think that kids are thinking at this level,'' he said. ''whether the state sanctions it or or not is irrelevant. What is relevant is that it is available in places like the grocery store and they can see it being advertised on TV.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: The casino industry, keenly aware of the potential for compulsive gambling to become the bane that nicotine addiction is to the tobacco industry -- and aware that a Presidential commission will issue a comprehensive report next year on the impact of gambling on the country -- has recently begun to acknowledge the problem and take pre-emptive steps. New programs to discourage under-age gambling are being paid for and implemented by the industry, and studies on compulsive gambling, particularly among under-age gamblers, are being conducted through research grants from the industry.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''Most of the under-age gaming going on in this country is not going on inside the casinos,'' said Frank Fahrenkopf, president of the American Gaming Association, the casino industry's lobbying organization. He pointed out that many young people gamble on sports and play lotteries. ''We are trying to reach out to that area of the population.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: The interest that children develop in gambling often starts long before they are old enough to sneak into a casino. A group of Long Island parents, concerned that their young children were hooked on sports trading cards, filed lawsuits against six of the major sports trading card companies in 1996, claiming that the companies have colluded to conduct an illegal gambling enterprise by inserting rare and valuable cards that could instantly be redeemed for cash. The lawsuits, filed in New York, New Jersey, Texas and California, are pending, although one claim in Texas was dismissed by the court there. James M. Schaefer, an anthropologist at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., who conducted research for the plaintiffs, visited card shops and sports memorabilia shows where the cards are bought and traded. What he found was that children as young as 6 were doing what is known as insert card chasing, spending $2 to $6 for a pack of cards, ripping them open, quickly flipping through them in search of the valuable inserts, discarding the ''garbage cards'' and buying more.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''The kids are driven to find a valuable insert card, and they'll spend all the money they have to find it,'' Mr. Schaefer said. Some gambling opponents have raised similar concerns about other seemingly benign products aimed at children, like the scratch-and-win promotions often offered by McDonald's, and a current promotion by Nabisco, which offers $1,000 to anyone who finds a bag of Chips a'hoy cookies without any chocolate chips. Ann Smith, a spokeswoman for Nabisco, denied that such promotions encourage gambling. ''They are purchasing the product,'' she said. ''It's a consumer promotion geared towards added value.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Coping in a Culture Of Gambling
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Many students in places like Atlantic City become familiar with casino games because they work after school or in summer at the casinos. Although customers must be 21, the minimum age for working at a casino is 18. Many young gamblers said that they had jobs and financed their habit using the same disposable income that other young people spend at the movies or the mall. However, gambling experts said that many of those who gamble at school or elsewhere come from affluent families and have more money than the average student. Casinos here and in other cities have created opportunities for young people. In addition to jobs, they provide a wide range of assistance to local teen-agers, from scholarships to mentoring programs. But with some of those same young people becoming increasingly fascinated with gambling, some communities are now questioning whether they should accept any largess from the casinos in their neighborhoods.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: In Louisiana, casino employees participate in career days at high schools, and casinos have donated to students everything from pumpkins for Halloween to playing cards emblazoned with casino logos. But now, after opponents of gambling complained that these donations were were only veiled attempts by the casinos to cultivate future loyal customers, gambling regulators are considering a ban on donations from casinos to students. ''We are trying to make a determination as to whether the stuff they do in the schools is marketing,'' said Hillary Crain, chairman of the state's gaming control board.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: Many experts said that the best method for dealing with the escalating interest in gambling among youths is to teach them more about the potential downside to gambling, and to get them to better understand probability, the ratio of the number of times that something will probably occur to the number of possible occurrences. If they better understood the extent to which the odds are against them, experts said, fewer children would be so anxious to gamble. Still, said Edward Looney, the executive director of the Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, ''Youngsters are youngsters, and gambling is an exciting thing for them to do because it's risky.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: But even as schools preach against gambling, in many places it has become a part of the culture of adolescence. Growing up in Warwick, R.I., where residents can bet on the state lottery, jai alai and dog races, play video lottery machines or drive to the Foxwoods casino an hour away in Connecticut, Seth Jackson anxiously awaited the day he would turn 21 and could step into a big, rambunctious casino to gamble to his heart's content.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''It was a big deal for me the first time,'' Mr. Jackson, 22, a senior at George Washington University, said during a recent ''senior week'' bus trip to Atlantic City, the gambling capital of the East Coast. ''Everybody around me gambled when I was growing up,'' he said, as he stood surrounded by classmates and slot machines inside the Tropicana.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: At Atlantic City High School here, students said that betting on sports and playing card games for money was common. Several students said in interviews that they knew of a fellow student who worked as a professional bookie, laying odds on games and collecting bets. ''The guy books bets right in school,'' said Tom Le, 16, a sophomore.
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: In May, on the night of the school's senior prom, one of the activities arranged for the evening was a mock casino, set up inside the cafeteria. Students received chips and played casino games like blackjack and craps. ''I was really astonished at how well they knew the games,'' said Mr. Steele, the principal. He said he believed that gambling had captured the fancy of young people because it made them feel like adults. ''I guess it's a nice feeling to go into the casino, play and receive complimentary drinks,'' he said. ''How can you tell them, here it is, it's exciting, but you can't do it? We have to face it, it's here to stay. It's a matter that's going to have to be dealt with. I don't know how. Just hope and pray that it's done on a small scale.''
title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

text: ''MY name is Jay, and I'm an alcoholic in recovery,'' said the young man, introducing himself. He listed low points in his life: smoking marijuana at 13, drinking alcohol at 14, dropping out of high school, drinking before work, getting fired from job after job, being arrested for armed robbery and attempting to hang himself in jail.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: A prison guard cut him down in time, Jay M. got counseling and began attending Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. ''Today, I take care of my kids and I do the responsible thing,'' he said. ''I don't have alcohol in my house.'' After applauding Jay's progress, members of the group talked about their own successes and failures at staying sober. It could have been any A.A. meeting except that it was held at East Hartford High School. In 1993, the school established a student assistance center offering alcohol and drug counseling, support groups, weekly A.A. meetings and treatment referrals as well as career planning, peer mediation and conflict resolution. Recently, the school was recognized by the Federal Department of Education for its success in helping troubled students.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''Alcohol is the drug of choice, because it's seen as socially acceptable,'' said the principal at East Hartford, Steven Edwards. ''It's a problem we deal with on a daily basis.''
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Recent studies indicate that some young people begin drinking alcohol as early as 11 years old, and middle and high school students in Connecticut drink at rates 10 percent to 12 percent above national averages. According to a 1995 public school survey conducted for the State Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services, 37 percent of 8th grade students, 51 percent of 10th grade students and 61 percent of 12th grade students said they had had a drink during the previous 30 days.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: In January, the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism in Washington, D.C., reported that people who begin drinking before age 15 are four times more likely to become alcoholics than those who wait until they are 21.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''Most kids never really want to admit it's a problem,'' said Terry Lynn Kelly, a substance abuse counselor at East Hartford High. ''They just get more and more comfortable getting high or getting drunk.'' But school officials recognize trouble when a student is arrested for possession, shoplifting or truancy, or they notice falling grades. ''Usually we see it first in the schools because of the grades,'' she said. Anyone who works in the school -- custodian to teacher -- may smell alcohol or drugs on a student and refer him or her for counseling.
