title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Who drinks and why? Jen H. of East Hartford and Rebekah K. of Brooklyn talked about their struggles with alcohol.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Rebekah is 16; she likes listening to reggae bands and writing poetry and essays. She says she has good parents. But Rebekah had her first drink at 13; it was vodka taken from the liquor cabinet at a friend's house.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''To start, it was just like a social thing,'' she recalled. Then, she turned to drink when she felt stressed. Before long, Rebekah said, she was drinking frequently and more often by herself. ''And then it was just all alone,'' she said.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Last fall, she left school with some older students. ''I ended up drinking until I passed out,'' Rebekah said. When she regained consciousness, she repeated the process. The older students took advantage of her sexually, she said. The binge lasted until the alcohol ran out three days later. When Rebekah called her parents, who had been frantically searching for her, she was taken to a hospital for treatment.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Today, she is ''trying very hard, still battling.'' How long has she been clean and sober? ''A couple hours,'' she replied. Rebekah takes medication for depression and anxiety attacks. She attends A.A. meetings two or three times a week and tries to stay sober one day at a time.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''I'll get clean for a couple months and then something will happen,'' Rebekah explained. Someone will offer her alcohol or drugs, and she gives in. ''Then I have to start all over. It's very, very frustrating,'' she said.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: At 17, Jen seems to have turned her life around, despite significant odds. Her father is in prison for stabbing a woman while he was high and drunk, she said. Recently, her mother, who is mentally ill and prone to problems with drugs and alcohol, tried to kill herself, she said.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Jen had her first drink in 6th grade. ''One day, I just drank alone at home by myself,'' she said. But the event scared her. Jen went to the student assistance center for counseling.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: After her younger sister got beaten up in a fight, Jen's mother suggested the girls study tae kwon do, the Korean martial art. Jen loved the discipline, thrived in competition and gained self-confidence. ''I wanted to be there all the time,'' she said. ''I didn't care if I missed a party any more.'' She regularly wins medals in regional and national competitions. Jen knows her family history puts her at high risk for substance abuse. ''I'll have to be very careful,'' she said.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Young people drink for many reasons.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''The No. 1 thing that we hear from kids is boredom,'' said Vicki Barbero, the program coordinator at Right Turn, an adolescent counseling center with offices in Willimantic and Danielson.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Many teen-agers drink between 3 and 6 P.M., when parents are at work, she said. Children facing mental health problems, family strife, financial distress, or attention deficit disorder are also more likely to use alcohol.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''Basically, they are not able to handle stress in an appropriate manner,'' Ms. Barbero said. ''There are kids who just drink because they like the buzz.''
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Many children have poor role models.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''They learn it at home,'' said Ms. Kelly. ''There are huge mixed messages.''
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Indeed, the state mental health study shows parents are far more likely to permit their children to drink alcohol than smoke cigarettes. Why? Adults in Connecticut have one of the highest alcohol use rates in the country; 96 percent of those age 18 and over have reported drinking at some time, said Jane Ungemack, one of the study's authors and an assistant professor at the University of Connecticut School of Medicine in Farmington. About 8 percent of Connecticut adults are alcoholics, Dr. Ungemack added.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: In 1997, the Connecticut Coalition to Stop Underage Drinking was established with support from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. The coalition aims to curtail underage access to alcohol, increase enforcement of current alcohol laws and policies, and reduce the influence of alcohol advertising that targets young people, said Dawn Homer-Bouthiette, the project director.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: This year, the organization successfully lobbied for passage of state legislation requiring registration of beer kegs and forbidding drive-through alcohol sales at convenience stores.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: The keg law, which goes into effect Oct. 1, means if a keg ends up at a party with teen-agers, ''not only can the underage drinkers be prosecuted to the full extent of the law, but so can the purchaser of the keg,'' said Ms. Homer-Bouthiette.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: The coalition is one of the sponsors for a June 16 law enforcement conference at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven about reducing underage drinking and for an event July 15-18 at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield sponsored by Mothers Against Drunk Driving.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: While East Hartford has an unusually extensive student assistance program, most middle and high schools have teachers who volunteer to help students and look out for alcohol and drug problems, said Barbara Westwater, a consultant for the State Department of Education.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: Many high schools now are staffed with licensed drug and alcohol counselors or contract for those services, Mrs. Westwater said.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: At Alcoholics Anonymous, the state public information committee has been receiving more requests for school speakers.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''We're probably going into 200 schools a year,'' said Richard W., chairman of the committee. Middle schools account for 20 or 30 of the visits, ''and that number is increasing,'' he said.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: David Peloski, a recovering alcoholic and drug addict who works at a methadone maintenance program in Waterbury, says parents should not abdicate their responsibility. Speaking at a recent coalition forum on underage drinking, Mr. Peloski recalled smoking marijuana at 11 and drinking his first fifth of vodka at 13 to ease his painful shyness.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''I think many people knew what I was doing and didn't do anything about it,'' he said. Even when his parents found him, at 15, passed out at home, there were no recriminations.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: He advised parents to pay more attention to their children and to take control if they suspect alcohol or drug use.
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: ''It's painful, but it's going to do a whole lot more than getting arrested,'' Mr. Peloski said. ''The system itself will not stop this problem.''
title: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

text: WHEN asked to describe himself in one word, Donald Everett Axinn was momentarily stumped.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Hesitantly, he answered: ''eclectic,'' ''opportunistic,'' ''pragmatic.'' Running low on one-word answers, he suggested ''not afraid to take chances'' and ''incurably romantic.'' Finally abandoning any pretense at brevity, he hit upon a phase that satisfied him.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: ''I'm a person who believes very strongly that we can do more than one thing.''
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Even a casual look at his resume suggests that Mr. Axinn has practiced what he preaches: from founding a real-estate development company that has built more than 2.5 million square feet of office and industrial space throughout Long Island, New Jersey and Florida, to serving as associate dean of Hofstra University's College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, where his gift of more than $1 million paid for the university's library, to being chairman of the Long Island Nature Conservatory.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: He also has forged a literary career of six volumes of poetry and two novels. The first novel, ''Spin,'' a coming-of-age tale with an emphasis on flying, arrived in 1991. Currently, he is working on a screenplay adaptation of the book.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: His second novel, ''The Ego Makers'' was published in January by Arcade Publishing. It is a tale of the downfall and rebirth of a successful Long Island real-estate developer. In minute detail it deals with the real-estate industry in the late 1980's, a period when the bubble began to burst.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Mr. Axinn did not set out to become a jack of so many trades, he said. Born on the Island and reared in both Hewlett and Arizona, where the family had to live because of his brother's health, Mr. Axinn graduated from Middlebury College in Vermont with a degree in English and went into the lumber business in Northport that his father, an immigrant from Russia, had started.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: ''I had no idea that I'd start to write until I was out of college,'' he said. ''I just started putting down lines of poetry and quickly got hooked. The whole process opened a new world to me.'' Mr. Axinn, 68, lives in Sands Point; Middlebury, Vt., and Daytona, Fla., with his wife, Joan. They have six children between them.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Even after he left the family business and, with a loan of $5,000 from a friend, started the Donald E. Axinn Companies based in Jericho, he continued to write poetry that appeared in magazines, literary journals and, from 1978, in slim volumes brought out by publishers like the Swallow Press and Grove Press.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Mr. Axinn does not deny that there are autobiographical elements in his fiction. For example, aviation figures prominently in both novels. An avid pilot, he owns three planes and has flown all over the Eastern Seaboard and to Alaska.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: He can accomplish all this and still run his company by ''departmentalizing'' his time, writing for three or four hours each morning before going to his office. ''I'm able to turn off and on, go from one to another,'' he said
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: In 1989, when Wenda Wardell Morrone discovered that she had ovarian cancer, she decided to do two things she had always wanted to do: become a redhead and write a murder mystery.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: The first goal was relatively easy to achieve, as soon as her heair began growing again after losing it all in chemotherapy. The second aim was harder to realize. It took seven years of writing, rewriting and searching for a publisher to produce ''No Time for an Everyday Woman,'' which St. Martin's Press recently brought out.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Not that the notion of writing a mystery novel came totally out of left field. A veteran journalist who has been the features editor of Glamour and has two non-fiction books to her credit, Mrs. Morrone often thought of trying her hand at fiction. She was especially attracted to the mystery genre, which she said, ''going back to 'Nancy Drew' was the only kind of fiction I have ever read with pleasure.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: ''There's a definite end in mysteries,'' continued Mrs. Morrone, 55, who has lived in Plandome for 29 years with her husband, John, and their two grown children. ''You know what happened and why. And I think that people who are heroes are important. I like stories in which people behave with courage and humor.''
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: For her first effort, which is more of a suspense novel than a whodunit, Mrs. Morrone started out with a locale, Merciful Valley, Mont., which she conceded is very much like that state's Flathead Valley near Billings, where the Nebraska-born writer spent much of her childhood. Both the real and imaginary areas are remote, ideal for growing marijuana. This clandestine crop plays a major role in her tale of murder and money-laundering.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Mrs. Morrone also began with a heroine, Lorelei Muldoon, a political campaign consultant and finance expert who, her creator said, ''is very much into the culture of numbers, with a realy good mind, but who, despite having phenomenal skills, is not very clever in other areas.''
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Along the way, however, Mrs. Morrone leads her heroine through a convoluted plot peopled with numerous characters. One of these subsidiary characters, Claud Willets, a mysterious middle-aged gambler who in the novelist's mind's eye ''looks exactly like John Goodman,'' took over the book. This almost-accidental development, Mrs. Morrone said, has left her with two heroes whom she will use in future installments of what she hopes will be a series of novels.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Unable to find a publisher, she entered the Malice Domestic Contest that St. Martin's Press runs. While her book was rejected because, she said, ''it had too much mayhem,'' one of the judges, Ruth Cavin, a St. Martin's editor, made her an offer for the novel that she couldn't refuse.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: With sales going briskly and her illness a thing of the past, Mrs. Marrone said, she is already well into a second Lorelei novel. And this time, she said, ''I'm getting better at writing the sex scenes.''
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Like many dutiful adult children, Bill Ervolino frequently travels from his home in Woodbridge, N.J., to visit his parents in Babylon. Along the way, he stops off to spend time with his brother in Smithtown or childhood friends scattered throughout the Island.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Only, sometimes when Mr. Ervolino, a columnist for The Record, a daily newspaper in northern New Jersey, shows up there are lulls in the conversation, followed by pleas of ''promise me you won't write about this.''
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: That these requests don't come more often is remarkable, Mr. Ervolino admitted. For during his visits, he usually jots down what is said and uses the conversation as fodder for the two humor columns he writes each week. One of them deals exclusively with the foibles of friends and family.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: For instance, he has written about how his father took speed at a bachelor party; how his mother bought heavily discounted items during her days as a department store clerk, and how his brother betrayed the family sports honor, previously confined to stickball and bocce, by taking up golf.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: '''They're all exceptionally good sports because even though I've skewered them unmercifully, they always seem to forgive me,'' Mr. Ervolino wrote in the introduction to ''Some Kind of Wise Guy,'' a collection of his columns recently published by Record Books.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: ''I see my life as a sitcom -- something entertaining,'' added Mr. Ervolino, a 43-year-old bachelor who got his start in journalism working for The Massapequa Observer while still a ''magna cum nothing'' student at Nassau Community College. He then went on to Long Island's Nightlife and The New York Post before joining The Record in 1990.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: When Mr. Ervolino first started writing about his family during his days at The Observer, he thought he was writing about a unique species of family -- the Italian family.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: ''Nobody else I knew went to Jones Beach the way we did,'' he recalled, ''loaded down with chests of food, dragging all this stuff across the sand like Lawrence of Arabia. Or in school, my friends had bologna sandwiches. I had eggplant parmigiana.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: ''Yelling and screaming were natural. Everything was emotional. I mean, I call my parents a few times a week. An Irish girl I know calls once a month.''
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: Eventually, Mr. Ervolino discovered that his family was not as unusual as he first believed. Readers began to associate their own traditions with his.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: ''I heard from Jews and Armenians, for example, about the emphasis on food,'' he said. ''Not the same foods, necessarily, but still an important element of their lives. Or once when I wrote about my mother making ravioli and spreading the noodles out on my bed, I heard from a Swedish guy who experienced the same thing, only with Swedish noodles.''
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: The universality of his experiences, he said, has turned his parents, Emilio and Louise Ervolino, into celebrities. When he goes out to promote his book, the audience always asks for them.
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: ''I did a reading in Paramus a few weeks ago,'' he said, ''and 300 people showed up to meet Emilio and Louise.''
title: Writer Finds the Time to Pursue His Muse

text: IF the war on drugs is indeed a battle of good versus evil, then Satan is gaining some impressive allies. An open letter to the United Nations Secretary General, on the occasion of the General Assembly's special session on drugs, asserts that ''the global war on drugs is now causing more harm than drug abuse itself.'' Among the signers of the letter were Javier Perez de Cuellar, the former Secretary General; Robert Strauss, the Democratic Party's lobbyist-lawyer; George Shultz, the former secretary of everything to Republican presidents, and even Walter Cronkite.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: More striking from the parochial perspective of this column, the list includes high-profile economists ranging from Milton Friedman (the Hoover Institution) to Jagdish Bhagwati (Columbia) to Gavin Wright (Stanford).
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: On second thought, perhaps it is not so surprising. Most economists these days are alert to the unintended consequences of regulation. And in the case of drug policy, they do not have to look far. ''The harmful side effects -- everything from the spread of AIDS to violent crime to abuse of civil liberties -- simply overwhelm the benefits,'' said Jeffrey Miron of Boston University.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: The only way to reduce illegal drug use is to reduce the supply or the demand. Consider supply-side strategies first.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: Common sense says the place to start is at the border, or even in farmers' fields. But in this case, suggests Peter Reuter of the University of Maryland's School of Public Policy, common sense is a ticket to frustration.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: Smugglers of low-bulk drugs have adapted easily to interdiction efforts, he says. Confiscation of large quantities at sea or at the border has only modest impact on importers since the value of the drugs outside the country is so much lower than the value once they cross the border.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: By the same token, discouraging drug production by subsidizing alternative crops is a fools' game. Drug entrepreneurs can always afford to pay more since the cost of the raw material is a minute fraction of the wholesale price of the delivered product.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: What about disrupting wholesale and retail markets on this side of the border? It can and has been done through policing efforts -- though at a cost that makes economists, as well as legislators and civil libertarians, wince. With more than a half-million arrests annually for marijuana possession alone, the bulk of police, prison and court resources is now devoted to drug law enforcement.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: Besides, Mr. Miron notes, for supply-side policies to work, drug prices must rise. And if, as most economists believe, the use of drugs is not particularly sensitive to price, the total value of drugs sold actually increases when enforcement is successful. This breeds ancillary crime as users steal to pay for their habits and dealers fight over turf.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: If supply-side antidrug policies create a vicious circle of higher prices and more crime, demand-side policies should lead to a virtuous one. Lower demand means lower prices, lower revenue and less incentive to steal and kill.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: By no coincidence, then, demand-reducing drug treatment and education have become the centrist politician's mantra. Mr. Reuter acknowledges that treatment is often cost-effective. But he doubts that even the most dedicated treatment policy would reduce addiction by more than one-third.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: Mr. Miron points to another problem: pushing addicts off illegal drugs all too often pushes them into legal ones -- methadone, alcohol and tobacco. ''You have to be skeptical that the benefits of treatment would exceed the benefits of simply minimizing the adverse side effects of illicit drug use,'' Mr. Miron said.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: For Mr. Miron the best of all possible worlds would be one in which dangerous drugs are legal, with their use discouraged with taxes and social pressure. But many people who buy arguments against the flat-out prohibition cannot stomach policies that would probably lead to greater drug consumption.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: For his part, Mr. Reuter argues that legalization has become a straw man that diverts attention from the messy task of reforming regulation. That might include the decriminalization of drug possession without making it legal to sell drugs for a profit. Or the quiet abandonment of expensive border interdiction. And it would certainly mean a more nuanced policy in which the use of marijuana by adults ceased to preoccupy the justice system.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: Is the world ready for a change in drug policy as usual? Ethan Nadelmann, the director of the Lindesmith Center in New York, which sponsored the open letter, is encouraged by the growing numbers of very important people ready to take a stand in favor of a fresh start. But he doubts that the United Nations' own drug bureaucracy can lead the way. ''It's hard to turn that big boat around,'' he lamented.
title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

text: Six drivers for the United Parcel Service were charged yesterday with participation in a theft ring that Federal prosecutors said stole more than $175,000 in jewelry, computers and other goods from delivery trucks and the service's midtown distribution center.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: A 74-count indictment unsealed yesterday, which stemmed from an undercover operation run by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, accused the six drivers in Manhattan of selling the stolen property to bureau agents. Company officials said it was the biggest theft ring involving its drivers in its history.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: Four doormen and two elevator operators who work in the Chelsea area, as well as a former truck loader in United Parcel Service's midtown distribution center, were also charged in the case.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: A law enforcement official who spoke on condition of anonymity said some of the property was stolen from company conveyer belts in the large distribution center at West 43d Street and 11th Avenue, and from trucks making pickups and deliveries.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: Because the Federal investigation paid only about a third of what the stolen property was actually worth, the official said, the actual value was closer to $750,000.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: The company first reported suspicions about a theft ring to the F.B.I. last year and has cooperated fully ever since, a company spokesman, Robert S. Godlewski, said by telephone from Atlanta.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: ''We take seriously all threats to the security of the 12 million packages entrusted to our care every day,'' Mr. Godlewski said. ''I've heard of the isolated incidents where you've got a driver who works in the hub who is taking stuff out of there -- penny-ante stuff. Man, this is unbelievable.''
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: In the yearlong investigation, an agent posed as a middleman who trafficked in stolen merchandise and worked out of a warehouse, whose location was not disclosed.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, and Lewis D. Schiliro, assistant director in charge of the bureau's New York field office, said in a joint statement that there were 67 instances in which stolen property was sold to an undercover agent or to a witness who was working secretly with the Government.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: The drivers were based in the company's 43d Street distribution center, which handles more than one million packages a week, and some held routes that took them through Chelsea, the indictment said.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: The role of the doormen and elevator operators was not fully described, but the law enforcement official said that in some cases, the drivers would entrust the stolen property to the doormen and elevator operators, who had access to areas in their buildings where the items could be stored.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: Among the drivers charged in the case, Robert Volpe, whose 19 years as a driver for the company was the longest service among those charged, was assigned a route that included West 19th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, the indictment said.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: Prosecutors charged Mr. Volpe with conspiring with a doorman at 16-20 West 19th Street, who was described in the indictment only as Ralph, to steal more than $90,000 in gold rings, New York State lottery tickets, jewelry, beepers, Swiss Army knives, watches and women's T-shirts.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: In some cases, Mr. Volpe and Ralph sold the stolen property directly from Mr. Volpe's delivery truck, the indictment said. Mr. Volpe and the doorman were also charged with offering to sell about 15 pounds of marijuana to the agent.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: In Federal District Court yesterday, a magistrate judge, Sharon E. Grubin, released Mr. Volpe on $75,000 bail. Others charged in the case were also released on bond. Mr. Volpe's lawyer, Leonard F. Joy, said that neither he nor his client would comment.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: The other drivers charged were Joel Gallo, Richard Correa, Kevin Kay, Andre Hemmitt and Mitchell Ayers.
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: Yesterday, as Manny Lopez, a driver for the company, was making his deliveries on West 19th Street in Chelsea, some customers were surprised to see him instead of Mr. Volpe. ''Everybody's saying, 'Where's Bobby? Where's Bobby?' '' Mr. Lopez said. ''I didn't know if he was on vacation or sick.''
title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service

text: A drug reform institute financed by the billionaire philanthropist George Soros has amassed signatures of hundreds of prominent people around the world on a letter asserting that the global war on drugs is causing more harm than drug abuse itself.
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: The signers include the former United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, the former American Secretary of State George P. Shultz, the Nobel Peace Laureate Oscar Arias of Costa Rica, the former CBS television anchorman Walter Cronkite, two former United States Senators, Alan Cranston and Claiborne Pell, and the South African human rights activist Helen Suzman.
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: The signers also include Mr. Soros, who has spent millions of dollars trying to change the way that Americans think about illegal drugs. In the past, he helped finance referendums in California and Arizona in support of medicinal use of marijuana and programs that distribute clean needles to those who take illegal drugs by injection.
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: The move was timed to coincide with the United Nations General Assembly's special session on combating drug abuse.
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: The letter was organized by the Lindesmith Center in New York, which advocates more liberal drug policies. It is addressed to Secretary General Kofi Annan, whose spokesman said today that he had yet to receive it. The letter also ran as a two-page advertisement today in The New York Times.
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: It says in part: ''Persisting in our current policies will only result in more abuse, more empowerment of drug markets and criminals and more disease and suffering. Too often those who call for open debate, rigorous analysis of current policies, and serious consideration of alternatives are accused of 'surrendering.' But the true surrender is when fear and inertia combine to shut off debate, suppress critical analysis, and dismiss all alternatives to current policies.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: The letter proposes no clear alternatives beyond asking Mr. Annan to take the lead in ''stimulating a frank and honest evaluation of global drug control efforts.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: Mr. Soros said in a telephone interview that he did not contribute directly to the cost of the Times advertisement but that the Lindesmith Institute, which he bankrolls, did.
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: ''I was happy to sign it,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''Firstly, it expresses my views and secondly, I hope it will foster an open discussion, which is very difficult. By having so many distinguished people sign on, it should make people want to discuss whether our policies are counterproductive or not.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: While he was not responsible for the campaign, he added, ''I'm happy that it happened.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: The Lindesmith Center's president, Ethan Nadlemann, was not reticent about taking credit for coordinating the letter, which he said drew roughly 600 signatures from around the world.
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: ''This was my initiative,'' Mr. Nadlemann said. ''George agreed to help, and sent out some letters in his name.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: Mr. Nadlemann said the letter had been assembled in the last couple of weeks and had collected roughly 600 signatures. ''If we had another week,'' he said, ''the number of names would have been off the charts.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: The language was deliberately broad to attract the largest number of people, he said, prompting some to complain that it was not strong enough. ''I think that when people look back on the U.N. drugs summit in 1998, it is not going to be because of the platitudes,'' Mr. Nadlemann said. ''It will be a moment at which the truly international movement for drug reform had begun.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: Mr. Annan's spokesman, Fred Eckhard, responded in a statement, ''The Secretary General invites anybody who has any suggestions, proposals or ideas which could help improve the international community's response to this problem to come forward.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: But the letter did not seem to sway participants at the General Assembly's special session. Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the Clinton Administration's director of national drug policy, called the letter ''a 1950's perception'' of the struggle against drugs.
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: Secretary of Health and Human Services Donna R. Shalala, who also accompanied President Clinton to the United Nations, said, ''There's no chance that we're going to throw up our hands and walk away from what we think is a predominantly public health issue.''
title: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help

text: GIVEN all the 20th-century icons who have been resurrected and paid homage to in the name of fashion, nothing is more curious than the pedestal erected for that hapless bungler of television fame Gilligan. Or so it would appear from last summer's vogue for the fishing hat, which Bob Denver almost never took off his head in the three years that ''Gilligan's Island'' ruled the airwaves.
title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual

text: Then again, Gilligan is the apotheosis of simple chic compared with those other castaways -- the movie star, the millionaire and his wife -- who packed an astounding amount of clothes for a three-hour tour. And Gilligan had the right idea: in tropical weather, a hat protects the head and neck from the sun. Moreover, given the natural impulse to dress down for summer in a lightweight jacket, polo shirt and khakis, a good hat adds a crucial bit of personality and polish to an otherwise lackluster outfit.
title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual

text: Even so, there is no reason the Gilligan hat has to go into reruns this summer. (Nor is it likely to, now that Mr. Denver's image seems slightly less jaunty following a marijuana arrest last week.) Even if one does not want to step out in a dandified straw boater, there are any number of summer hats less dowdy than Gilligan's.
title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual

text: At Barneys New York, a jaunty black straw hat made in England by Fred Bare, $60, is neat and crisp enough to wear with a suit, yet equally apropos of a short-sleeve shirt and shorts. A black striped straw hat by Rod Keenan, $265, also at Barneys, is less versatile but much more stylish. Made of a finer weave, it is also more comfortable and durable.
title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual

text: At Agnes B., on Greene Street in SoHo, a narrow-brim hat, $83, has an old-fashioned shape, but made in black leather, it has a sharp, rakish cool.
title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual

text: At the venerable milliner Worth & Worth, on Madison Avenue at 43d Street, summer hat styles range from a simple, smart cotton driving cap, $30, to a panoply of Panama hats in varying weaves, styles and prices. A Baku straw snap-brim is $145, while Panama Montecristi hats can cost up to $1,000, depending on the fineness of the weave and of the jipijapa, the straw from which Panamas are made.
title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual

text: At Bergdorf Goodman, the finest Panama hat is $495 and can be squashed in a suitcase, within reason, and still snap back into shape. A cowboy-style Panama with a leather hatband is $195 and has a novel charm.
title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual

text: For those who still cling to the Gilligan ideal but want to upgrade, Paul Stuart, on Madison Avenue at 45th Street, has a waterproof fishing hat in a sleek black oiled cotton, $27.50. And Prada sells a fishing-style hat in black or brown nylon for $214 -- perfect for those who feel marooned without a designer label.
title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual

text: With President Clinton and other world leaders coming here Monday for a special session of the General Assembly on the world's drug problems, the United Nations' top anti-narcotics official has submitted a two-pronged strategy that moves beyond the conventional approach of intercepting illegal drugs and arresting traffickers.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: Pino Arlacchi, the executive director of the United Nations International Drug Control Program, proposes the ambitious target of eliminating opium poppies and coca plants, the raw ingredients of heroin and cocaine, in 10 years as well as substantially reducing marijuana.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: To achieve this, he advocates so-called alternative development programs that would induce opium and coca growers to switch to less profitable legal crops by bringing roads, hospitals, schools and a better life into remote rural areas that depend on drug crops to survive.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: Mr. Arlacchi has also proposed that nations reduce the demand for drugs by half over the next decade through prevention and treatment programs. Neither idea is new, but he said they had proved promising enough to try on a broader scale.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: ''These two cards have not been played in full,'' he said in an interview.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: Alternative development has sometimes been viewed as costly and unrealistic, since opium and coca growers are reluctant to grow legal crops that would earn less income and be harder to take to market. Middlemen make the rounds of peasants to buy their raw opium and coca paste.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: What is needed, Mr. Arlacchi said, is political authority to enforce eradication and development involving more than crop substitution.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: ''We would propose an alternative way of life,'' he said. ''They can be rich peasants if they grow opium, but they can die if they don't have roads and hospitals.''
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: Peru and Colombia have tried alternative development, Mr. Arlacchi said, and Peru has reduced its coca fields by 40 percent in two years. Bolivia has promised to phase out its coca over the next five years, he said.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: Mr. Arlacchi said the cost would run far less than potential donors like the United States anticipate. He estimated that alternative development would require an additional amount of less than $250 million a year over the next decade. In comparison, the United States Government's annual drug control budget exceeds $16 billion.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the Clinton Administration's anti-drug chief, said that he agreed with demand reduction, but was not persuaded that it would be easy to get Afghans and Burmese, who together grow 90 percent of the world's opium, to change to other crops. But General McCaffrey added in a telephone interview from Washington, ''We're supportive of Pino Arlacchi's focused high-energy leadership.''
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: Mr. Arlacchi, whose enthusiasm belies a tough reputation earned fighting the Mafia in his native Italy, cited what he said were some conspicuous successes against drug trafficking in the last decade.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: ''We destroyed the myth of the invincibility of the drug cartels,'' he said. He said that the Medellin and Cali cocaine cartels in Colombia had been crushed and that some Asian opium warlords surrendered by striking deals with the military Government in Myanmar, formerly Burma, that let them keep their freedom and money. Thailand virtually eliminated opium production through alternative development, he added, and Pakistan had sharply cut back opium growing as well.
title: U.N. Aide Would Fight Drugs With a Better Life for Growers

text: The first showers of the rainy season have fallen across parts of Mexico and Central America but have failed to quench many wildfires that are destroying virgin forests and feeding a smoke cloud that is drifting across the southern United States, officials said today.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: Mexican and American officials predicted that some fires, which have consumed millions of acres of forest and grassland across the region, may continue to rage for several weeks. About 150 fires, 23 of them large, very destructive blazes, were burning this week.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: Agricultural Secretary Dan Glickman, who led an American delegation that flew over vast blazes roaring through one cloud forest in the states of Oaxaca and Chiapas in southern Mexico on Thursday, described them today at a breakfast with reporters here as ''a catastrophe.'' Another senior American official said they were the worst he had seen.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: ''This disaster in Mexico has to be the most serious of its kind in the world, including Indonesia,'' said Brian Atwood, director of the Agency for International Development. ''The duration of these fires, the complexity of fighting them and the danger to the firefighters, it's the most serious that we've seen.''
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: The United States delegation visited Mexico to coordinate a $5 million assistance program, which includes a heavy-lift helicopter and radios, as well as boots and other safety equipment for 3,000 Mexican forest rangers. Many Mexican firefighters have been wearing straw hats and sandals while battling flames with buckets of water.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: Despite the new equipment, Mr. Glickman said that because many fires were raging across virtually impenetrable mountain ravines and ridges ''rainfall will have as much to do with extinguishing the fires as anything else.''
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: Some of the fires began in January, then flared into an international conflagration in late April with the beginning of the traditional agricultural burning season. So far, seasonal rains that began this week have not been heavy enough.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: ''Light rains have begun in some areas but they're not sufficient to extinguish these fires,'' Mr. Atwood said. A spokesman for Mexico's Environment Ministry agreed today with that assessment.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: The American officials praised Mexico's battle to control the fires, in which more than 60 firefighters have died this year.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: ''They're doing an outstanding job fighting this thing,'' Mr. Glickman said. Those comments and praise by other American officials contrasted with statements by Mexican conservationists, who have argued that the Mexican and American Governments have been slow to react.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: In an interview today, for instance, Homero Aridjis, a prominent Mexican environmentalist, called the Mexican Government's response to the wildfires ''really exasperating.''
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: ''At first the policy was to minimize the fires,'' Mr. Aridjis said. ''And now that much of our ecological patrimony has been destroyed, the Government is still waiting for rains to put them out. This is like waiting for Godot.''
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: The Environment Secretary, Julia Carabias, defended herself and other officials today against a barrage of similar recent criticisms, saying her Government ''took precautions, sounded the alert, acted vigorously and continues to act.''
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: President Ernesto Zedillo, standing at Ms. Carabias's side on a visit to a mountain park burned by recent wildfires that roared through a Mexico City suburb, said, ''Our country has suffered what I would characterize as a true ecological tragedy.''
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: He said many, perhaps most, of the blazes had started as out-of-control agricultural fires, set by peasant farmers who prepare their fields for planting by burning the previous year's stubble. Also, forests have been set afire to clear plots for growing marijuana or opium, he said.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: ''There have been fires caused by narcotics traffickers,'' Mr. Zedillo said.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: A report that the American officials handed out describing fires in the region said Nicaragua had suffered the most. More than 13,000 fires there have seared nearly 2 million acres of land, compared with about 900,000 acres in Mexico. Managua's airport has been closed for eight days in the last three weeks because of smoke, the report said.
title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

text: For a look at the month ahead in video, one person to consult is Bob Helland of Asymmetrical Entertainment, a Brooklyn mail-order company that previews coming releases in its monthly bulletin. June looks moderately promising. While not overwhelmingly rich in big feature films -- ''Amistad,'' ''Wag the Dog,'' ''Welcome to Sarajevo'' and ''Wings of the Dove'' are among the better-known titles scheduled -- the list includes several older films that people have been waiting for.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: From Home Vision come ''Forever and a Day'' (1943), with a big British cast including Charles Laughton, Merle Oberon and Claude Rains, and ''Spitfire'' (1942), Leslie Howard's last film before he was killed when the plane he was aboard was shot down by the Nazis in 1943.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: Mr. Helland also recommends ''The Slapstick Encyclopedia'' from Kino. ''All good stuff that's never been out before, a lot of Fatty Arbuckle and Buster Keaton,'' he said.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: Many of June's old movies come in series. ''The best things are the Universals,'' he said, a reference to three sets of old movies -- literary adaptations, comedies and westerns -- from Universal. Perhaps the most awaited is ''All My Sons'' (1948), Irving Reis's film adaptation of the Arthur Miller play, starring Burt Lancaster and Edward G. Robinson.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: Then there is ''The Great Gatsby'' (1949), with Alan Ladd and Betty Field, the earlier of two movies based on the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel. ''It's not a great film, but Field is really fine'' as Daisy Buchanan, Mr. Helland said.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: The most important comedy is ''The Major and the Minor'' (1942), which starred Ginger Rogers and Ray Milland and was Billy Wilder's first feature film. There are two notable westerns, ''Man in the Shadow'' (1957) and ''Canyon Passage'' (1946).
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: '' 'Man in the Shadow' only because it has a long, offbeat performance by Orson Welles,'' Mr. Helland said, ''and 'Canyon Passge' because there are a lot of Susan Hayward fans out and because of the Hoagy Carmichael song 'Ole Buttermilk Sky.' '' Mr. Helland doesn't have time to discuss the releases with everybody, but he will mail you the catalogue. Information: (718) 237-6031.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: Mail order catalogues are ordinarily drab or drabber, so it's a pleasure, almost a shock, to open ''The Movie Lovers Video Guide'' from Facets Multimedia, a large Chicago distributor.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: Beginning with ''33 Directors to Watch'' (Arnaud Desplechin, Mike Leigh, Emir Kusturica, Peter Greenaway), the catalogue makes a striking case for itself by shuffling thousands of Facets listings into scores of categories: 50 silent masterpieces, 25 Shakespeare plays on video, 100 best British television titles, 25 films about the Holocaust, 100 cult classics, 100 best horror stories, 100 films that fell through the cracks (like ''Gas Food Lodging,'' ''Danzon,'' ''Big Night'' and other acclaimed films that never found large audiences in theaters), 25 great cultural documentaries, the 25 best dance videos, 50 top theater adaptations, the 5 best samurai epics and so on. Information: (800) 331-6197.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: Big films like ''As Good as It Gets,'' ''Tomorrow Never Dies'' and ''Starship Troopers'' lead current best-renter lists. Here are some top renters from Video Business magazine's list of smaller films (those that played on no more than 475 theater screens).
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: ULEE'S GOLD. A reclusive beekeeper (Peter Fonda) is forced by the demands of family to journey beyond himself and raise two granddaughters after his son lands in jail and their mother disappears. 1997. Orion. $100.96. 111 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: THE ICE STORM. Watergate and marijuana are in the air in Ang Lee's film, set at Thanksgiving time 1973, about suburban families struggling with a malaise that strands them on shifting moral ground. 1997. Fox. $104.16. 113 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: THE HOUSE OF YES. Marty (Josh Hamilton) takes his fiancee (Tori Spelling) home to the stately family seat, where she encounters Marty's spectacularly disturbed twin sister (and former lover), Jackie-O (Parker Posey), who roams the mansion dressed and acting like the former First Lady. 1997. Miramax. $104.16. 90 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: IN THE COMPANY OF MEN. In Neil LaBute's gutsy first feature film, a misogynous office worker named Chad (Aaron Eckhart) and a like-minded friend (Matt Malloy) take out their resentments on a deaf woman (Stacy Edwards). 1997. Columbia Tri-Star. $105.77. 97 minutes. Closed captioned R.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: MRS. BROWN. Before Queen Victoria (Judi Dench) got back to work as monarch after mourning Prince Albert, there was her relationship with the horse groom John Brown (Billy Connolly). 1997. Miramax. $104.16. 105 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.
title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick

text: In the 1970's San Francisco of ''Armistead Maupin's 'More Tales of the City,' '' the characters may be homosexual, heterosexual or transsexual, but they are all hopeless romantics. In the brash new comedy series ''Sex and the City,'' the heroine cultivates an anti-romantic pose that suits Manhattan in the 90's, with its post-politically correct attitudes. ''I'm a sexual anthropologist,'' says Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker), a newspaper columnist who writes: ''Welcome to the age of uninnocence. No one has breakfast at Tiffany's and no one has affairs to remember. Instead we have breakfast at 7 A.M. and affairs we try to forget as soon as possible.'' Though one is gauzy and the other hard-edged, both these shows alight on a particular patch of ground where their characters roam through a hyperrealistic landscape searching for the meaning of love.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: ''More Tales'' comes up with comforting but pat answers. Things have changed since the original ''Tales of the City'' appeared on PBS in 1994, to deserved acclaim and popularity. The series was distinguished by its matter-of-fact acceptance of all sorts of sexual desire, and it created a warm, enviable, almost innocent world centered around a house at 28 Barbary Lane. We should all have a landlady as wise and reassuring as Anna Madrigal (Olympia Dukakis) to call us ''dear.'' That she grew marijuana in her garden and used to be a man were mere details; the series' openhearted tolerance was one of its most winning qualities. Of course, that attitude evoked right-wing hostility. PBS quickly dropped plans for a sequel (unconvincingly citing the cost).
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: That sequel, now appearing on Showtime, has about half the charm and little of the freshness of the original series. There, Mary Ann Singleton (Laura Linney, who returns to ''More Tales'' even perkier than before), arrived from Cleveland and landed in San Francisco as if she were Alice down the rabbit hole. Agog at what she saw, she was the viewer's ideal guide.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: In the sequel, which picks up six weeks after the first story ended, Mary Ann is on a cruise to Mexico with her gay friend Mouse (Paul Hopkins, in one of several cast changes), wondering which of them a handsome man is making eyes at. Viewers are four years ahead of her, though. After ''Ellen,'' after hit films like ''The Birdcage,'' after the PBS-''Tales'' flap itself, ''More Tales'' has a slightly quaint air, despite its more explicit love scenes.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: It also has a different screenwriter (Nicholas Wright instead of Richard Kramer) and a script that lacks snap. And in the first few episodes, the Barbary Lane house and Mrs. Madrigal fade into the background. While Mary Ann is cruising, Mona Ramsey (Nina Siemaszko, replacing the more suitably abrasive Cloe Webb) takes a bus trip to Nevada.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: At the bus station she meets the one daring addition to the story, a wizened old brothel owner called Mother Mucca (from Winnemucca), who wears a red wig askew and calls everyone ''Dolly.'' Mona goes to work as a receptionist at the Blue Moon Lodge, the house Mother Mucca has run for 60 years. Neither sweet nor cuddly, Mother Mucca (played with fearless lack of sentimentality by Jackie Burroughs) is a character who repels and finally attracts viewers; she is just what this soft-focus memory piece needs.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: There are plot twists that may engage series fans but will leave newcomers wondering what the fuss was about. Mona's mother (Swoozie Kurtz) turns up. So does her father, which will not surprise anyone who has been following the clues. In one of the more satisfying turns, Thomas Gibson (now better-known from ''Dharma and Greg'') returns as the mean-spirited, secretly homosexual Beauchamp Day. Being closeted may be the one unforgivable sin in Mr. Maupin's world, and Beauchamp suffers a brutal comeuppance.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: ''Sex and the City'' has a narrower focus, but each slight, breezy half-hour is fresh and funny. The series is loosely based on Candace Bushnell's columns in the New York Observer but leaves behind the irritating, self-important tone. The series benefits greatly from Ms. Parker's engaging portrayal of a smart woman always searching for answers and never certain she has found them.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: In the opening episode, Carrie and a group of single female friends decide women can have sex as casually as men do. Carrie tries this out with an old boyfriend, and leaves feeling ''powerful'' but flustered enough to drop her handbag on the street. Fortunately, she drops it at the feet of a rich, handsome single man she calls Mr. Big (Christopher Noth), who serves as an instant reminder that her heart can still flutter. More than she realizes, Carrie is torn between her longing for romance and her knowledge that there is no free breakfast at Tiffany's.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: On the surface, Carrie's world of art dealers, trendy clubs and supermodels may seem hermetic, but her mating rituals have a universal resonance. The ''toxic bachelors'' she runs across have their counterparts everywhere. So do her friends, especially Cynthia Nixon as Miranda, a bitter lawyer with a functional haircut, and Kim Cattrall as Samantha, a slightly over-the-hill public relations woman who thinks she can be mistaken for a model. ''Samantha has the kind of deluded self-confidence that causes men like Ross Perot to run for president,'' Carrie says. Like so much of ''Sex and the City,'' that's not kind, but it's true.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: ARMISTEAD MAUPIN'S 'MORE TALES OF THE CITY'
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: Showtime, Sunday and Monday nights at 9
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: Teleplay by Nicholas Wright and based on the novel by Armistead Maupin. Pierre Gang, director; Kevin Tierney, producer; Terry Anderson, creative consultant; Serge Ladouceur, director of photography. Music by Richard Gregoire. Alan Poul, Suzanne Girard and Tim Bevan, executive producers.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: WITH: Olympia Dukakis (Anna Madrigal), Laura Linney (Mary Ann Singleton), Paul Hopkins (Michael Tolliver), Nina Siemaszko (Mona Ramsey), Jackie Burroughs (Mother Mucca), Swoosie Kurtz (Betty Ramsey) and Thomas Gibson (Beauchamp Day).
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: HBO, Saturday night at 9:45
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: Created and executive produced by Darren Star and based on a book by Candace Bushnell. Barry Jossen and Michael Patrick King, co-executive producers.
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: WITH: Sarah Jessica Parker (Carrie Bradshaw), Kim Cattrall (Samantha), Kristin Davis (Charlotte), Cynthia Nixon (Miranda) and Christopher Noth (Mr. Big).
title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not

text: Several television specials this year have commemorated the 50th anniversary of Nascar, the stock-car racing organization created in Daytona Beach, Fla., to bring order to what was up to then a chaotic, formless sport. Two of the latest will be shown tonight on TBS, one of a number of channels that now show Nascar's brand of stock-car racing.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: The first, a segment of ''National Geographic Explorer,'' beginning at 7 P.M., is a superficial look at the sport. That is followed at 9 by ''Nascar at 50: Good to Go,'' which offers a closer examination of some of the struggles in a sport trying to retain its aw-shucks charm while striving to scrape the blood off its knuckles and the grease from its fingernails.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: That's no small image rehab for a sport that began in the rural Southeast, on small dirt tracks usually bulldozed out of someone's farmland. One of the goals of William H. G. France Sr. in establishing Nascar (the acronym for National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing) in December 1947 was to make sure that the drivers of the postwar era -- many of whom had to be quick to deliver carloads of home-brew whiskey and still win the race against Federal agents to stay out of jail -- did not have to use fists or guns to collect their prize money before race-track owners could abscond with it.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: Nowadays, as the TBS program points out, drivers like Jeff Gordon, the 26-year-old star who is already a two-time Nascar champion, need only outrun all the fans wanting autographs on the millions of dollars' worth of souvenirs bearing the drivers' likenesses. ''They're accessible, they're open, they're modest, and they come out of a Southern culture that's respectful,'' said Neal Pilson, a former president of CBS Sports, in describing the stock-car racers' personality traits that attract many Americans who think that too many other pro athletes have lost the common touch.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: At a time when most sports leagues are experiencing flat or declining television ratings, Nascar racing has produced steadily increasing viewership. Last year, for example, CBS had an average rating of 5.7 for the six major races it broadcast, an increase of 16 percent from 1996. (Each rating point represents 980,000 homes.)
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: The races are now shown on a total of five broadcast and cable networks -- one more than National Football League games. And on July 4, Nascar will reach another milestone: the first live network broadcast of a race in prime time, the Firecracker 400 on CBS.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: The one-hour TBS show, by Turner Original Productions, illustrates the delicate balancing act that has brought Nascar to where it now is: operating a multimillion-dollar sport while maintaining the veneer of small-town charm. Charlotte Motor Speedway, in North Carolina, whose Winston Cup race last October is the setting for ''Nascar at 50,'' is the perfect symbol: a glittering track whose infield was once a landfill. One of the main subjects of the program is H. A. (Humpy) Wheeler, who, as president and general manager of Charlotte Motor Speedway, has turned it into what he terms the ''Taj Mahal of racing.'' Don't laugh. The condominiums overlooking the track went on the market in 1984 for $95,000, and 10 years later were selling for $375,000.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: At one point in the program, Mr. Wheeler sits in his plush office and holds up a jar of 140-proof moonshine, a reminder, he says, of where the sport has come from. ''This place has got to have a space for the person who works in the mill and the person who owns the mill,'' Mr. Wheeler says of his track.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: Mr. Pilson, who now works as a broadcast consultant for several Nascar tracks, said the average Nascar fan was more affluent than a typical mill worker. ''He's not at the highest level economically, like golf, but he is higher than the baseball and basketball fan,'' he said in a recent telephone interview from his Manhattan office.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: Some of those fans are also nomadic, traveling hundreds of miles several times a year to attend races. Roaming the countryside in motor homes, beat-up vans and resurrected school buses, they watch the same performers over and over: kind of like Grateful Dead fans without the marijuana.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: But what really attracts sponsors, Mr. Pilson said, is the Nascar fan's unique understanding that loyalty to a particular driver means allegiance to that driver's corporate sponsor. ''What's most important is that the fans are buying the sponsors' products,'' Mr. Pilson said.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: Excluding extravaganzas like the Olympics, the only sports programs that regularly deliver higher ratings than Nascar's Winston Cup Series (stock-car racing's big league) are professional football and the post-season playoffs in major league baseball and professional basketball, Mr. Pilson said. ''College football is about equal to Nascar, in terms of ratings,'' he said, ''and everything else is below Nascar.''
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: Strong ratings are especially crucial to stock-car racing. For years, the sport has thrived by skirting the ban on televised tobacco advertising, and R. J. Reynolds has spent tens of millions of dollars to see and hear the name Winston on all those broadcasts. If, as expected, any major liability settlement with the tobacco industry brings an end to cigarette sponsorship in racing, Nascar's big television audience will make it much easier to find a replacement sponsor.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: That sponsor will be buying the sort of viewer loyalty that is hard to find in an era of free-agent athletes who are million-dollar migrant workers. But it's a loyalty that may not be hard to understand after watching the ''Nascar at 50'' segment on Dale Earnhardt.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: Mr. Earnhardt, a seven-time Winston Cup champion, distills the Nascar driver's charm down to its 140-proof essence. When he was 17, he found his father, a talented driver as well, slumped over dead after suffering a heart attack while working on a carburetor. That seemed to toughen his resolve, and Mr. Earnhardt soon got to the top of his sport with the nickname the Intimidator for his willingness to knock aside any opponent who would not get out of his way.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: The segment begins with hundreds of fans lined up outside his car dealership waiting for him to autograph shirts, caps and even a windshield from one of his race cars. One female fan explains the attraction: Mr. Earnhardt commits the kind of mayhem on a race track that frustrated motorists like her can only dream about. ''Plus, he's an attractive man,' she adds.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: After a quick look at the horses, chickens and fish that live on his farm (with millions of dollars annually in souvenir sales, Mr. Earnhardt can afford to keep the fish in his pond well-fed, and they welcome his arrival as hungrily as his fans do), he displays almost two dozens bins of mail from fans seeking autographs. He will oblige all of them, apparently. Through it all, he comes across as a simple man aware of a simple truth: his wealth is derived directly from the deep emotional connection his fans feel for him.
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: That connection includes television executives, too. Mr. Pilson likes to tell a story about the time he was introduced to race drivers at a trackside chapel service as the man who first put the Daytona 500 on CBS, a decision made in 1979 that has greatly benefited Nascar and the network. ''The drivers got up and gave me a standing ovation, and they came up to me one by one and shook my hand,'' he recalled. ''Could you imagine that introduction getting that kind of a reaction someplace like an N.B.A. locker room?''
title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

text: New York City Police Commissioner Howard Safir's decision to hold all arrestees, including those for minor offenses, until a fingerprint check is verified defies logic (front page, May 28).
title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects

text: You report that completion of a criminal record check may take up to eight hours, and a fingerprint match takes 59 minutes. Arrest to arraignment time is 20 hours.
title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects

text: It is important to note a distinction between misdemeanor criminal offenses and violation offenses.
title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects

text: The parolee who shot Officer Anthony Mosomillo had been arrested on misdemeanor narcotics charges. Drinking in public, peaceful protest, jaywalking or possession of small amounts of (nonburning) marijuana are violations, not criminal misdemeanors.
title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects

text: Those arrested could spend up to 20 hours in a holding cell, often unsupervised, with both violent and nonviolent offenders.
title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects

text: Under the new policy, not only will first-time offenders spend almost a day in jail, guilty or not, but many of them will be assaulted, raped or worse.
title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects

text: Katonah, N.Y., May 28, 1998
title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects

text: The writer is a lawyer.
title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects

text: When the lone telephone in this mountain hamlet rang recently, it was the Archbishop of Oaxaca calling with bitter news: San Juan's parish priest, the Rev. Mauro Ortiz Ca rreno, was dead.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: To the black-shawled women and sandal-wearing farmers who live here, the details of Father Ortiz's death were almost as wrenching as his loss itself. The 42-year-old priest was seized on May 6 in Oaxaca's state capital and killed, mob style, with one shot to the head. The police found his body in the trunk of a car.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: No one has been charged in the case. In interviews, Father Ortiz's parishioners as well as church leaders familiar with his ministry blamed a gang that they say controls the drug industry in Oaxaca's Sierra Madre del Sur. When traffickers set mountain woodlands on fire this spring to clear new marijuana plantations, devastating virgin forests, Father Ortiz spoke out to denounce the drug culture and the torching of rich timberland, they said.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: The priest's slaying came as vast tracts of timber and grasslands were in flames. Corn farmers use fire to raze fields before planting, the authorities said, but traffickers have also been igniting forests to expand marijuana and opium poppy plots.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: This year, Mexico's drifting smoke cloud was intense enough to provoke health warnings across the southern United States.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: The official version of Father Ortiz's killing contrasts starkly with the view held by those who knew him. In an interview, Oaxaca's Attorney General, Roberto Martinez Ortiz, said the main suspect was a man to whose former wife Father Ortiz lent $1,250 last year.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: The priest had been pressing the woman to pay interest, Mr. Martinez said, and the authorities hypothesize that Father Ortiz was killed to cancel the debt.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: Statements by Archbishop Hector Gonzalez Martinez appeared to accept the government account. But other church authorities scoffed.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: ''Father Mauro was no usurer,'' Auxiliary Bishop Miguel Angel Alba said in an interview. ''This is a self-serving version invented by the government, so that no one will think drug mafias are operating in Oaxaca. We suspect that authorities ordered this murder.''
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: San Juan sits in a remote valley, shaded by stands of towering pine and spruce, five hours' drive south of the state capital, also called Oaxaca. Whether baptizing parishioners in the village's 17th-century chapel or instructing catechists in his cement-floored office, Father Ortiz was the center of San Juan's spiritual and intellectual life.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: As with most rural priests, his ministry involved travel to surrounding villages. He drove a Ford pickup, often wearing a jaunty straw hat.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: He was so beloved that Tereso Hernandez, San Juan's Mayor, said he feared a lynching if parishioners identified the killer. ''People are crazed with sorrow,'' he said.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: Guadalupe Aragon, a village council member, challenged the state government's portrayal of Father Ortiz as a greedy moneylender. Sometimes the priest responded to parishioners' pleas by lending a few pesos here and there, Mr. Aragon said, but he never sought to profit from the loans.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: So what could have provoked the killing? Father Ortiz aroused the anger of powerful people before, the village leaders recalled, for instance in 1992, when he denounced the embezzlement of timber-cutting fees by local officials of a previous administration, drawing death threats.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: But Gabriel Silva, San Juan's treasurer, drew nods when he voiced a stronger suspicion.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: Residents in San Francisco Ozololtepec, a bordering hamlet also in the priest's jurisdiction, Mr. Silva said, cultivate marijuana and patrol their plantations wielding rifles. In March, fires set by the traffickers to clear new plots spread into San Juan's forests, he said.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: The devastation angered the priest, and during a visit to San Francisco he urged parishioners there to replace their Mayor, Estanislao Ga llardo Roque, with someone who would crack down on the drug culture, Mr. Silva said.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: Weeks later, back in San Juan, Father Ortiz denounced the drug culture and the burning of forests in a sermon, Mr. Silva said.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: Church officials in the state capital outlined events leading to the priest's murder in similar terms.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: ''His preachings confronted the narcotics traffickers,'' said a report on the murder issued by the Rev. Wilfrido Mayren Pelaez, a priest who knew Father Ortiz. ''He denounced the burning of forests to plant marijuana and the enrichment of some people by poisoning others.''
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: Mr. Gallardo, San Francisco's Mayor, denied in a phone interview that marijuana was grown in his village, although he acknowledged that he spent a month in jail in 1980 on what he described as trumped-up marijuana charges.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: ''I have no idea how or why this priest was killed,'' he said. ''I hope they arrest the person who did it.''
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: Town officials in San Juan and the church authorities in the state capital said that the traffickers in the Sierra Madre were protected by a network that appeared to include state government officials.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: ''I don't know anything about any mafia,'' said Israel Jarquin Magno, the state government delegate with jurisdiction over San Juan and San Francisco. In a phone interview, Mr. Jarquin said he had no information about drug cultivation in the Oaxaca mountains. Enforcing narcotics laws is a federal responsibility, he said. ''Don't ask me about that,'' he added.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: Father Ortiz was buried in the village near the state capital where he was born. But following a tradition, his parishioners gathered on May 17, nine days after his burial, for an all-night memorial session to say the rosary.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: In San Juan's plaza at midnight, smoke from smoldering forests mingled with incense wafting from the chapel, where 200 peasants, many weeping, knelt before a bank of glowing candles. At dawn, musicians sounded an Indian dirge as villagers trudged up a trail to a mountaintop cemetery, bearing a wooden cross honoring the slain pastor.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: One woman in the procession, Severina Heredia, described the impact of the priest's death. ''Our world has turned black,'' she said.
title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder

text: John Stossel, libertarians' gift to television, takes up the cause tonight of people who are being punished for ''victimless crimes.'' They include pornographers, drug users and sellers, gamblers, ticket scalpers, prostitutes, homosexuals and sufferers in search of help in committing suicide.
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: It's a brisk tour that in pursuit of the theme of liberty conflates different sorts of legal and ethical issues. What the examples of lawbreakers being arrested for consensual activities have in common, Mr. Stossel argues, is society's habit of imposing certain moral views on those who don't share them. Moreover, he discerns hypocrisy and inconsistency in a state's efforts to suppress gambling while promoting its own lottery and to ban marijuana while permitting the use of alcohol and tobacco.
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: As for the famous war on drugs, which has filled the nation's prisons to little avail, Mr. Stossel observes concisely, ''It's what happens when you attempt to outlaw something that lots of people want.'' An advocate of euthanasia advances the proposition that assisting people into death is ''not abandonment, it's compassionate care.''
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'
