text: Mr. Stossel sums up with the rule that consenting adults ought to be allowed to do anything they want to as long as it's peaceful. That may not be the last word on such an array of disputed matters, but it might serve as a sound first word.
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: 'The World's Most Wanted Man'
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: (Channel 13, New York, at 9)
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: A victim-filled crime is the subject of tonight's report on Radovan Karadzic, the former commander in chief of the Bosnian Serb Army, who has been accused of instigating massacres, rapes, torture and other atrocities during the war in Bosnia.
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: Along with offering a profile of the sometime doctor, poet and military strategist who has so far escaped prosecution by the United Nations War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague, the 90-minute program also serves as an indictment of the United States and European governments for failing to act while thousands of Bosnians were tormented and killed.
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: The portrait by those who knew the Bosnian chieftain in his earlier years is not flattering. He is pictured as a vainglorious careerist and a hypocritical and ruthless politician, qualities that brought him to power in Bosnia after the death of Tito and the breakup of Yugoslavia.
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: While some minor figures are being tried in The Hague, Mr. Karadzic and his military right hand, Ratko Mladic, are still at large. Whether or not Mr. Karadzic is finally tracked down and tried, his career provides a darkly illuminating look at the history of the Balkans.
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: SEX, DRUGS AND CONSENTING ADULTS
title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'

text: Seeking a showdown with the Federal Government, the founders of three medical marijuana clubs in this area have defied orders to shut down, hoping to place their fate in the hands of a jury.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: Judge Charles Breyer of Federal District Court ordered six Northern California clubs closed on May 13 as part of a civil case brought by the Justice Department, which accused the clubs of distributing marijuana in violation of Federal law.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: Three outlets closed voluntarily. But clubs in Oakland, San Francisco and Marin County have remained open since the ruling, purposely inviting contempt of court charges, the clubs' owners said. Such charges would allow the owners to demand a Federal jury trial in California, where voters in 1996 approved a ballot issue legalizing marijuana for medical use.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: ''I'd trust a jury of Californians more than Federal bureaucrats in Washington,'' said one owner, Jeffrey Jones, who directs a marijuana outlet in Oakland. Mr. Jones invited print and television reporters on Thursday to watch him sell marijuana to customers in an overt challenge to the Government.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: The San Francisco club, which was founded by Dennis R. Peron, a co-author of the 1996 ballot issue, also defied the Federal court order, selling cartons of marijuana to its 8,000 members throughout the week.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: After the 1996 vote, at least 20 clubs sprang up around the state for the declared purpose of distributing marijuana to help people fight the debilitating effects of cancer, AIDS and other illnesses.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: Critics say the law did not cover mass distribution of the drug. Possession of marijuana is still a violation of Federal law, which takes precedence over state statutes.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: Michael J. Yamaguchi, the United States Attorney for the Northern District of California, has described the Federal Government's civil suit as representing a ''measured approach'' against California marijuana clubs.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: A Justice Department spokesman declined to comment on how the agency would respond to the defiance by the clubs but did not rule out bringing separate criminal drug indictments against the club owners.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: Federal agents raided a ranch rented by Mr. Peron north of San Francisco on May 15, pulling up at least 200 marijuana plants but making no arrests. A San Francisco Superior Court judge declared Mr. Peron's San Francisco club ''a public nuisance'' on Thursday, ordering sheriff's deputies to close the club's five-story building.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: The state rulings come out of a 1996 civil suit brought by Attorney General Dan Lungren, a Republican candidate for Governor and California's most vocal critic of medical marijuana.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: San Francisco's District Attorney, Terence Hallinan, has sharply criticized the Attorney General's opposition to the law, and is part of a coalition of elected officials who have suggested replacing the clubs with a state-sponsored distribution system. The group has scheduled a hearing for Tuesday in the state capitol to discuss adding such a proposal to a related Senate bill that is under consideration.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

text: Gov. Pete Wilson, Republican of California, has vetoed medical marijuana legislation in the past. But advocates of marijuana for medical purposes say the proposal by Mr. Hallinan and others could serve as a national model.
title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close

title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: ONCE upon a time -- in the 1960's and 70's, that is -- clothing for teen-agers seemed to serve a single purpose. One dressed either for or against the establishment, whatever that nebulous establishment might be. My mother read McCall's. I read ''Steal This Book,'' dressed accordingly and got precisely the reaction I craved.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: Those wild adult reactions (and instant peer recognition) are harder to come by these days, and they're not necessarily the point anymore. My 14-year-old daughter plays several sports and for years has worn little besides the same jeans and T-shirts we flaunted as rebels. At her age, it's a style with a simple message: ''Throw me the ball.''
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: I sometimes teach writing in high school, and then have a few thousand teen-agers to watch as well as my own. Recently, I met Luke, George, Alex, and Anna in the local Starbucks and asked the question ''What drives style now?''
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: ''There's nothing imposed on this generation -- there's no revolution, so we're taking bits and snatches from lots of things,'' said Luke, 15, who wore wire-rim glasses and curly hair below his shoulders. The hair, he said, is something his father ''really wants me to do.''
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: Although these youngsters live in Portland, Ore., they are as clued-in as young people in the East Village of New York. In these media-saturated days, every shift in the global Zeitgeist is relayed to every household at once in instantaneous electronic transmission.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: Lots of teen-agers, they agreed, wear a kind of generic American casual, the styleless style of jeans and T-shirts. (My own personal style, consisting largely of turtlenecks, is, they told me gently, ''for older people.'') If it's slightly put-together, this casual look turns into what they call no-waves preppy, the look a lot of parents want to find on the friends their teen-ager brings home. On boys, it says Gap; on girls, the Limited: neat khakis, new jeans and wool skirts. It's a kind of casual-Friday, Junior League anonymity.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: But the most successful brand name in high school seems to be Tommy Hilfiger; I see his nautical, almost militaristic, color-block style everywhere. The boring sameness of this brand gives me the ''I could do that'' reaction other people had to abstract art. Like Nike, Tommy Hilfiger clothing seems to be popular just because it's popular, in a perpetual motion of commercial success.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: It's a sign of Tommy's generic blandness that I see it mixed into the style I've come to call Puffy Daddy and others call Thug -- derivative of gangs and rap culture, but crossing several racial lines. These young men are tough-looking play actors, self-consciously casual, wearing thickly quilted nylon jackets and extremely wide and dangerously long pants.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: Luke suggested that the giant pants thing is a kind of self-defense. ''It says, 'I want to be bigger than I am.' ''
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: George agreed. ''It's wish fulfillment,'' he said. ''Someday, these clothes will be tight on me.''
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: Teen-agers of the 90's have grown up with the padded cynicism and self-absorption of their parents; they learned to comment on their culture, and themselves, by the time they learned to read. Irony -- and the kind of clever juxtaposition easily mistaken for irony in an addled world -- plays a significant part in what they wear. The conscious interbreeding of signals from multiple fashion codes may be the freshest thing around: it is essentially infinite, and each person makes up the rules.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: ''The only thing that seems really set is the vintage thing -- 60's and 70's,'' said Alex, a 16-year-old wearing a blue V-neck shirt, brown polyester slacks and Converse sneakers. When I asked him about his blue-with-brown fashion mistake, he brushed back his cheeklong hair and agreed that it was deliberate. A lot of teen-agers display various generic-hippie touches -- long hair, granny glasses, patched jeans. But a true counterculture expression requires what Luke calls ''unvarying adherence to standards,'' like natural fibers and vegetarianism. Luke was wearing bell-bottom jeans and a green polyester shirt. For him, polyester is a wash-and-wear guarantee that no one will mistake him for a flower child.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: Anna, a freshman, had on the same pale blue pointy glasses I despised in fourth grade, and a nose ring she's had ''since middle school.'' She was wearing jeans, a cowgirl shirt with a cupid necklace, big black shoes and white socks.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: I asked about her very short hair, an unnatural color of gold.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: ''I darkened it,'' she said. ''And I lightened it. It's a long story.''
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: As a teacher, I am at times most disconcerted by the style that reminds me of the 25-year gap in age between my students and me -- the one my son calls the Hootchie-With-a-B.A.: smart girls in tight jeans, midriff-baring spandex shirts or body-hugging knit minidresses. Mixed with little-girl pigtails, it becomes the one spit-in-the-eye style for girls: Lolita. These are the young women with eye-popping sexual confidence, showing so much skin, with such artless grace and innocence, that every adult in the room averts his or her eyes.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: Lolitas at least keep the class lively. Slackers make teachers want to cry. When they manage to get to class, they fall asleep, slumped and sprawled across their desks. These are tall, lean, strong fellows who are single-handedly keeping the baseball cap industry healthy. They are genetically and economically privileged, eternally bored. Besides the caps, worn both backward and forward in a changing code I've never cracked, their style is marked by the faint scent of marijuana and casually expensive athletic shoes.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: There are still lots of nerds in high school, universally wearing sweat pants and forgetting to comb their hair. This is nothing like one of the newest styles being pushed at young people: retro geek, with its $65 daisy-covered acrylic blouses, high-water pants and a knockoff of Dad's old zip-front jacket. Real nerds don't dress this way because it requires planning. Like all industry-determined fashions, it's full of rules. Like the new ''khakis swing'' ads from the Gap, it's too cute. Retro styles by designers, whole ''looks'' based on extremely recent cultural history, are always going to be more glib than ironic.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: The most interesting thing teen-agers do is try on various selves until they find one they like -- or get stuck with one they can't take off. I think that's why I like the unholy marriage of nerd, hippie and punk looks that teen-agers like Alex, George, Anna and Luke wear. They aren't looking for rules -- but they're not looking to break them, either. They simply ally themselves with a spectrum of other smart, questioning, cheerfully sophisticated young people who ignore determined styles simply because they're determined -- and create their own just for the sake of creating. They don't have a revolution, but they're still looking for a surprise.
title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?

text: Regardless of the outcome of the referendum on the peace settlement for this conflicted province, one sure winner is Mo Mowlam, Britain's Secretary for Northern Ireland.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: A new poll shows that the approval rating of the famously unceremonious and outspoken Ms. Mowlam exceeds even that of Tony Blair, who, a year after taking office, is still the most popular Prime Minister in British history.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Voters in Northern Ireland and Ireland make their yes or no choice in the referendum on Friday, and the ballots will be counted on Saturday, but the British public's view of her activities is already known.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Ms. Mowlam, 48, has achieved pop star status occupying what has long been viewed as the most frustrating and thankless job in the British Cabinet and swatted away early critics, most of them male, put off by her brash, unshrinkingly populist approach.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: In a dramatic and apparently welcome departure from the formality of much of British public life, she is apt to begin a conversation in restaurants and bars by stealing a french fry off a diner's plate or taking an uninvited swallow from a pub drinker's pint of beer. Aides reported one day that she had come to work in a Nike baseball cap and joked that it was evidence she was becoming more conservative.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: ''She was wearing it the right way round,'' they explained.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Not everyone was enchanted at first. Protestant leaders repeatedly called for her removal because of what they thought was her careless talk in a political arena in which precision of expression and choice of words are so vital. Her wide, smiling face once stared out from a wall mural in the predominantly Catholic Lower Ormeau neighborhood of Belfast above the painted legend ''Wanted for Fraud and Deception.''
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Andy Wood, a press officer she had dismissed, retaliated this month by publishing a scalding account of her ''compulsive'' use of language he described as ''still taboo to women on both sides of the Irish Sea.'' He also complained that she asked her Royal Ulster Constabulary bodyguards to buy tights, lipstick and tampons for her.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Ms. Mowlam reacted with typically disarming good cheer. ''It's my mission to civilize the Ulster male,'' she said.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: The verdict now is that while the hardened politicians of Ulster may not all like her, they respect her. Their grudging acceptance of her notoriously tactile efforts at persuasion emerged in a comment from an Ulster Unionist Party councilor. ''If you haven't been kissed by Mo in Northern Ireland,'' he said, ''you must have been running very hard in the opposite direction.''
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Sir Patrick Mayhew, her patrician Conservative predecessor with a manner as aloof as hers is intrusive, has praised her, and the private secretary who worked for both of them, Ken Lindsay, has stepped forth from the usual anonymity of the British Civil Service to say: ''She's pushy. She's done things other people wouldn't have done. We wouldn't have got where we are without her.''
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Her combative approach to life began early. Three months after her birth on Sept. 18, 1949, in Watford, she contracted pneumonia and nearly died. Both her parents worked in the post office, and the family moved to Coventry when she was 11. Her given name is Marjorie, but she has always been called Mo.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Her youth was overshadowed by the alcoholism of her father, who was unable to work in the last years before his death in 1981. She calls him a ''competent man who ruined his life through drink'' and says the experience turned her into a ''compulsive carer'' as she sought to help her struggling family.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: It also seems to have prodded her into being an early high achiever. She was the ''head girl'' and a star athlete at her grammar school and became the first member of her family to attend university.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: At Durham University, she studied social anthropology and led the liberated life of a 1960's student, covering her walls with posters of rock stars and smoking marijuana with no thought of not inhaling. When her boyfriend went to the United States to attend the University of Iowa, she went with him, eventually earning an M.A. and Ph.D. there.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: She became a political science instructor at the University of Wisconsin in Milwaukee and later at Florida State University before returning to Britain in 1979 to teach at Newcastle University.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: She had joined the Labor Party in 1969, and in 1983 became a volunteer in the successful party leadership campaign of Neil Kinnock, beginning an association that was to gain her a seat in Parliament from a district in Yorkshire in 1987.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Ms. Mowlam was an early and vocal supporter of Mr. Blair when the Labor Party leader, John Smith, died of a heart attack in 1994, and she became the opposition spokesman for Northern Ireland and then the minister for the province with Mr. Blair's election last May.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: During the election campaign, she became the brunt of a crude assault by Conservative tabloids, notably The Daily Mail, for having gained a large amount of weight. The papers suggested she had become slothful after giving up smoking and published cruel before-and-after pictures showing that the winsome blonde British men had pronounced ''fanciable'' had become bloated and jowly.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: She eventually revealed that in January 1996 she had been found to have a brain tumor, which was soon after discovered to be benign. She had become ''moon shaped'' and her hair had fallen out ''in chunks,'' she said, because of radiation treatments. The mousy hairdo that the tabloids had coarsely lampooned was in fact a wig. ''I hate the bloody things and have to carry two around with me because I kept losing one,'' she said.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: As with other apparent potential setbacks, she turned it to her advantage, shaming the tabloid editors and winning converts with her folksy response. Shortly afterward she brought an appreciative gasp from a group of London-based American correspondents when during a briefing about a coming trip to Washington she complained that the wig was hot and itchy and simply took it off, revealing her bald head. Well attuned to the effectiveness of the spontaneous gesture, she was to repeat the act often with other groups.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: She was given the medical all-clear 10 months ago and her hair is growing back, brown and curly now, wrapped in a bandanna that trails insouciantly over the shoulder of the pastel-colored caftans she favors.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Her personal life was, by her own description, ''spectacularly untidy,'' but she surprised skeptics in 1994 by marrying her live-in lover, Jon Norton, a divorced pro-Labor banker five years younger than she. If she has religious convictions, she does not discuss them.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: ''Just say she's a very secular person,'' an assistant said.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: In arguably the most dramatic act of the 26 months of talks that led to the peace settlement now up for a vote, she entered Northern Ireland's most fearsome penitentiary early this year to challenge an order that Protestant prisoners had delivered to the party representing them to quit the negotiations. She was roundly criticized for the decision, one that typified her style -- independent, defiant and trusting in the direct approach and her own personal appeal to tease resolution out of stubborn polarities.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: She was photographed sitting across from shaven-headed killers and bombers with lurid tattoos on their pumped-up arms. A prison official, Alan Shannon, said, ''Those are some of the hardest men in any prison in the world, and she put them at their ease in no time.''
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: After she left, they reversed a 2-to-1 vote of the week before and authorized their political representatives to return to the talks.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: -------------------- Clinton Urges a Yes Vote
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: WASHINGTON, May 21 (By The New York Times) -- At a White House Rose Garden ceremony this afternoon, President Clinton made what he called ''one last plug for the vote in Ireland and Northern Ireland.''
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: ''I hope that those fine people will lift the burden of the last 30 years from their shoulders and embrace a common future in peace,'' the President said in a ceremony in which he signed the instruments of ratification for the expansion of NATO.
title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done

text: Mexican officials sought today to belittle the results of a huge United States undercover operation that exposed the laundering of drug money in 12 Mexican banks.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: On Monday a Federal grand jury in Los Angeles unsealed three indictments against Mexican bankers and their clients in drug organizations based in Cali, Colombia, and Ciudad Juarez, Mexico. More than $72 million in drug proceeds was seized during the three-year undercover operation, which spread across six countries and involved about 200 agents from the United States Customs Service and other agencies.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: Three Mexican banks -- Bancomer, Banca Serfin and Banca Confia -- were indicted as institutions. United States Justice Department officials said they felt that the pattern of money-laundering through these banks was so systemic that it would not be enough to indict individual employees.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: The indictments dealt a shock to Mexico, disclosing a much easier and more pervasive movement of narcotics proceeds through the financial system than Mexican officials have been willing to acknowledge.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: The investigation showed gaping loopholes in American and Mexican laws that allowed traffickers to move their proceeds relatively easily despite an array of Customs regulations in both countries intended to insure monitoring of big cash transactions.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: Yet Eduardo Fernandez Garcia, the president of the National Banking Commission, Mexico's bank regulatory agency, dismissed the indictments as overblown.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: ''I didn't like the way the United States authorities announced this,'' Mr. Fernandez said in a television interview this morning. ''They made it seem as though they were announcing something terribly important. But I think this has been taken out of context. It seems much more important than it really is.''
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: Mr. Fernandez noted that none of the Mexican bank employees arrested were top-level executives. Most of the 14 bankers arrested since May 16 were local managers and executives who worked in Tijuana and Guadalajara.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: Finance Minister Jose Angel Gurria Trevino said that although millions of dollars passed through the money-laundering scheme, the amounts were not large enough to pose any risk to the banking system as a whole.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: The huge undercover operation exposed connections between several of Mexico's most important banks and the top financial operator for the Juarez organization, Jose Alvarez Tostado. Mr. Alvarez set up a network of willing bankers and stockbrokers across Mexico and eventually introduced them to undercover Customs agents who were posing as brokers for Colombian drug barons, Customs officials said.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: At the urging of the United States, Mexico is preparing an arrest warrant for Mr. Alvarez. His top deputy in the Juarez organization, Victor Alcala Navarro, was arrested in Las Vegas on Sunday.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: The operation started in 1995 when Customs agents in Colombia were approached by members of the Cali cartel who were looking for ways to bring home the profits from cocaine and marijuana sales in the United States, Customs officials said.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: The Colombians introduced the undercover agents to Mr. Alcala. Over time, as American agents gained the confidence of the Juarez traffickers, they were contracted to broker millions of dollars in drug proceeds from sales in Chicago, Miami, Houston, New York and Los Angeles, Customs officials said.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: ''We did not approach any bankers,'' a Customs official said. ''They all came to us.'' He said the Mexican bankers were all informed by the undercover agents that the money came from drug transactions in meetings that were secretly recorded on videotape. Because of this evidence, Justice officials say they are confident that the defendants will not be able to argue that they were illegally entrapped.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: The bankers stepped forward to offer their services to open accounts in Mexican banks for fictitious corporations they set up, a Customs official said.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: In the United States, operatives for the Colombian and Mexican drug organizations collected cash profits from street sales of drugs. Undercover agents then turned the money over to American banks in the United States that were cooperating with the sting. Bank of America in Los Angeles was one of the main American conduits.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: The American banks then sent the funds by internal bank wire transfers to the fictitious corporate accounts opened at banks in Mexico. Mexican bankers working with the drug organizations then converted the funds into cashier's checks made out to fictitious individuals.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: These checks are drawn on accounts belonging to the banks themselves, not to individuals, and so can be cashed all over the world. They were sent on to Cali drug operatives in Colombia, or were stashed away in secret Customs accounts. American officials acknowledged that to keep the operation going over three years without arousing the traffickers' suspicions, they were forced to complete laundering transactions worth millions of dollars for Mexican and Colombian dealers.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: Customs officials said that, in all, 20 cartel operatives and 22 bankers or money-launderers were arrested in the final stage of the operation in the last three days. The arrests include middle-level drug organization officials, many based in the United States, who helped in money-laundering operations. The suspects include 24 Mexicans who were lured to Las Vegas and San Diego in sting operations to avoid the time-consuming risk of asking the Mexican authorities to detain them.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: Julie Shemitz, an Assistant United States Attorney in Los Angeles, said that American officials did not share any information about the operation with Mexico while it was under way out of fear for the safety of the undercover agents.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: ''It's not that we don't trust the Mexicans,'' Ms. Shemitz said. ''We just didn't tell anyone. This kind of operation is so dangerous, and you can't play games with the lives of the officers.''
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: One Customs agent working under cover was shot and wounded in a shootout between narcotics traffickers and police officers in New York City on Aug. 6, 1997.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: Money transfers by wire between banks, even when they cross borders, are not subject to any of the tight regulations that govern other cash transactions, Ms. Shemitz said. Any transfer in or out of the United States of more than $10,000 outside of bank channels must be reported to Federal authorities.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: Mexican bankers are permitted to issue cashier's checks without demanding any kind of identification from the buyer.
title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting

text: By Don van Natta Jr.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Culminating a three-year undercover sting operation described as the largest case of laundering drug money in American history, a Federal grand jury in Los Angeles today charged three Mexican banks and 26 Mexican bankers with laundering millions of dollars in drug profits.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: The indictments were announced here by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Attorney General Janet Reno, who said the charges marked the first time Mexican banks and bank officials were directly linked to laundering United States drug proceeds for the Cali cartel of Colombia and the Juarez cartel of Mexico.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: The three Mexican banks that were charged are Bancomer and Banca Serfin, Mexico's second- and third-largest banks, respectively, as well as Banca Confia, a smaller institution that was recently purchased by Citibank. Both Bancomer and Banca Serfin have branches in New York and Los Angeles and could face sanctions by regulators here.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: In connection with the indictments, the Federal Reserve Board also announced today that it filed civil actions against five banks with branches in the United States. Besides Bancomer and Banca Serfin, temporary cease-and-desist orders were issued against Banco Nacional de Mexico, Banco Internacional, and Banco Santander of Spain.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: It was unclear how an American prosecution against these Mexican financial institutions would proceed. When pressed at the news conference today, United States officials said that the banks could face civil penalities by banking regulators.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Called ''Operation Casablanca,'' the investigation, led by the United States Customs Service, resulted in the arrest of 22 high-ranking and midlevel bankers from 12 of Mexico's 19 largest banking institutions after they traveled to the United States last weekend. Warrants for others were issued today. In addition, the authorities said that during the three-year inquiry they had seized $35 million in illegal proceeds from drug money, two tons of cocaine and four tons of marijuana.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: The Mexican bankers arrested Saturday had planned on a much more celebratory weekend. Agents had used several ruses to lure them to this country. Some had arrived in San Diego, where they had thought they would be attending a banking conference on money laundering. Others, with whom undercover agents had participated in money laundering activity, were told to come to a casino opening in Mesquite, Nev., where, they were told, their drug cash would be welcomed.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: ''By infiltrating the highest levels of the international drug trafficking financial infrastructure, Customs was able to crack the elaborate financial schemes the drug traffickers developed to launder the tremendous volumes of cash acquired as proceeds from their deadly trade,'' Mr. Rubin said today.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Although law enforcement officials stressed that today's action failed to cripple the drug cartels, Ms. Reno said that the arrests and seizures disrupted a major money laundering operation that had served as an engine of the international drug trafficking trade. ''Operation Casablanca built a road map that tracked the structure of the international drug cartels from the kingpins to the couriers and the bankers in between,'' she said.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Since its beginning in November 1995, the undercover inquiry was kept secret from the Mexican Government. The first Mexican officials learned of the investigation was from Ms. Reno today, when she notified her counterpart, the Mexican Attorney General, Jorge Madrazo-Cuellar, by telephone. Mr. Rubin also alerted his counterpart, Jose Angel Gurria Trevino, the Secretary of Finance and Public Credit in Mexico. Both pledged to cooperate with the inquiry, Ms. Reno said.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Mexican officials were largely taken by surprise by the indictments and were scrambling to prepare comments late today. Carlos Gomez y Gomez, the president of the Mexican Bankers Association, said the banks would cooperate with the United States authorities. He said the bankers do not expect to see their operations closed in the United States. The alleged crimes were committed by ''individuals,'' he said, adding, ''This is not a systemic practice of Mexican banks.''
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: The authorities said they found that nearly 100 bank accounts the United States had been used by drug traffickers to deposit laundered funds. Today, investigators froze those accounts, which they estimated held about $110 million. They also froze about $12 million in overseas bank accounts. However, the authorities said they had not found any evidence that officials from American banks had been aware of the source of the money that was transferred from Mexican banks.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: The inquiry began after the Customs Office in Los Angeles discovered that drug cartel members had laundered proceeds from American drug sales in branches of Mexican banks near the border. The investigation expanded to include the financial operations of the Ciudad Juarez cartel. Today, warrants were issued for the arrest of the cartel's money manager, Victor Alcala Navarro, and one of its leaders, Jose Alvarez Tostado, the authorities said.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: The investigation used Customs Service undercover agents who posed as middlemen between the cartel financial directors and the Mexican bankers, mostly middle-level executives, who agreed, for a fee of 4 or 5 percent, to launder the funds. The bankers had established phony accounts and used bank drafts to dodge money laundering regulations, the authorities said.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Raymond Kelly, the Treasury Department's undersecretary for enforcement who is awaiting confirmation as head of the Customs Service, described the case as ''extremely significant'' because of the amount of money involved and because it involved ''a systematic scheme to launder money via a large number of Mexican financial institutions.''
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: A spokeswoman for Citibank Mexico said the institution would make no comment because officials only learned about the indictments today.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Citibank closed the deal to purchase Banca Confia, a mid-sized retail banking group, on May 11 after months of negotiations.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: The indictments are a new blow to Citibank, which has already been at the center of several banking scandals in Mexico. Amy C. Elliott, who was a Citibank private banking vice-president, is under investigation in the United States on suspicion of drug money-laundering in accounts she handled belonging to Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of the former Mexican President.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Citibank has denied wrongdoing and is cooperating with authorities.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: Shortly after Citibank decided to buy Banca Confia, its flamboyant chairman, Jorge Lankenau Rocha, was indicted in a large-scale bank fraud in Mexico. Mexican banking regulators said Citibank was not involved, but the scandal made many Mexicans suspicious of Citibank's takeover of the Mexican bank.
title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds

text: We’re sorry, we seem to have lost this page, but we don’t want to lose you. Report the broken link here.
title: Anti-Business Youths Attack Fast-Food Outlets : Prague Protest Turns Violent

text: So, you've turned 13, and suddenly you feel as if you're in Death Valley. You come home from school and Oprah is on, talking about America's Youth in Crisis; your parents assail you after dinner with antidrug literature, asking what you've been experimenting with lately; and from every corner -- school, home, church -- you're being told: ''Be careful! These are four of the most important years of your life!''
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Well, relax. I've been there, and let me tell you: your teen years aren't that important at all. The important years come when you want them to. Ray Kroc was a two-bit, middle-aged, milkshake-machine salesman when he founded a little company called McDonald's. His most important years started right there.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: As for me, I'm a junior at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. Although I'm still in the thick of my teen-age years, I think I've learned a thing or two by now. And as far as I can tell, being a teen-ager is just like being a kid, except that you've got five extra niggling concerns: sex, money, smoking, drinking and getting into college.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: First things first: sex. You already know all about sex (at least the mechanics of it), so I'll spare the birds-and-bees stuff. The most important thing to remember about teen-age sex is that television is not a study guide. Watching ''Dawson's Creek,'' you get the idea that every American over the age of 11 has a steady boyfriend or girlfriend, and that sordid, love-triangle sex kicks in by age 15. The reality is far less lurid, I promise.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Your friends are an equally unreliable study guide. Starting at 12, their bragging begins: ''I did blah-blah-blah with so-and-so. As a general rule, take everything your friends tell you about sexual experience and cut it in half. Then you'll have a reasonably accurate picture of what's going on.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: As for dating, here are some tips. Boys: join a rock band. Or a sports team. Or anything. What girls are really attracted to is affiliation. Buff up your brooding skills and don't talk much. Never underestimate the repellent power of dandruff. When you find out a girl has a crush on you, act fast -- it'll last two weeks at most.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Girls: you'll never be rejected if you ask a guy out. He'll be so dumbfounded or thrilled that he'll just shut up and nod. Another thing: those quizzes in YM magazine are totally useless. And glitter makes you look messy, not cute.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Despite what I've just said, however, don't sweat the small stuff. Romance will eventually come your way. No matter how dorky you are, you'll most likely get your first kiss in the next four years, if you haven't already. Other people's mouths taste strange at first, but you'll get used to them. You'll go for a nice walk in the park; you'll fall deeply in luuuv; you'll do all the cute stuff. It will be fun.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Next up: money. Let's see, you're probably living rent-free, with free food and free clothes. In addition, you can earn extra cash by, say, working part time in a store. The next four years could be pretty profitable. Question is, how will you use your earnings?
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Most likely, you'll wake up Saturday mornings thinking you've been robbed, but soon realize that you've spent the week's money on the silly scraps of teen-age life: school supplies, movies, haircuts, T-shirts. Why waste it? As weak as it sounds, I say save your money. Wait until you can afford something really cool, then indulge. The $50 mini-backpacks can wait.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Now we hit the naughty stuff. In the next four years, you'll inevitably meet up with cigarettes and marijuana. You already know what smoking's like. Haven't you ever been stuck with a puffing relative at a family funeral? Smoking a cigarette yourself is similar -- it tastes nasty and burns your throat. As for pot, it shares smoking's characteristics with one extra benefit: it makes you act really dumb.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: But you've been told that before. All teen-agers have. Yet somehow they all end up at a party where somebody offers them a joint, and they have nothing to say but, Uh, sure. Well, here's what you say: Nah, I tried that stuff once; it really messed me up. Proceed to tell a ridiculous anecdote about the time you tried that stuff. If the story's funny enough to get everybody laughing, you'll slip out of the situation. Alternatively, simply shake your head, act uninterested and get into a conversation with somebody else. The quick, silent rebuttal is devastating.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Drinking is also a tricky issue. From an early age, you've seen ads that promise that the moment you crack open a beer, football players will magically pop up on your front porch with bikini-clad girlfriends in tow. Real teen drinking scenes are far less glamorous, I'm sad to say -- we're talking glassy-eyed party-goers slouched on couches. But there's an easy way to handle parties without getting stinking drunk. Take a drink -- anything, whatever they give you -- and walk around pretending to sip it. (You'll need a plastic cup for this trick to work. A glass will give you away.) After an hour, discreetly put the drink down on a table. Nobody will notice this sleight of hand. And it'll be entertaining to watch the inebriation (real or feigned) of others.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Finally, you've got to contend with college. Now, you already know what school is like: you come in; you keep quiet; you don't break anything; you leave. High school is the same, except on the horizon, looming over you, are these monstrosities: the SAT's, the Achievement Tests, college interviews. A word of advice: don't worry so much about college. To be sure, you can learn a lot at a university. At the same time, plenty of successful people -- Thomas Edison, Bill Gates, even my grandfather -- never went, or dropped out as soon as possible. At a high-pressure school like mine, teachers push the idea that your college will absolutely determine your future, but nothing is set in stone. If you want to go, go; but don't freak out about it.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: The media present adolescence as hell on earth, chock full of evil cliques (the cliques in grade school are worse), domineering parents and wrenching decisions that will determine the rest of your life. Nah. Adolescence is a time to sit back, make some friends -- and maybe discover what you're good at. Don't believe the hype.
title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!

text: Earl Manigault, a New York City playground legend whose superior basketball talent deteriorated with years of heroin use, depriving him of a chance for a professional career, died Thursday night at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. He was 53.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: The cause was congestive heart failure, said Richard Pallos, a spokesman at Bellevue.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: Manigault, who twice underwent heart surgery, entered the hospital two weeks ago with heart complications. Doctors said for years that he needed a heart transplant, but he had been rejected once because his health was so bad he was considered a poor candidate. Recently he resisted advice to get a transplant.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: ''All of my doctors are telling me that my heart is very weak,'' Manigault said last summer. ''They say I need a transplant, but I say I feel good.''
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: In the 1960's Manigault, who grew up on the Upper West Side playing along with Lew Alcindor, now known as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, established a playground reputation few have matched. Although he was relatively small at 6 feet 1 inch, he had a remarkable leaping ability that allowed him to soar over taller opponents, as well as an array of flashy moves under the basket.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: In storied matchups against other city stars like Alcindor, Connie Hawkins and Joe (the Destroyer) Hammond, Manigault (pronounced MAN-eh-galt) helped enhance New York's playground legend as a breeding ground for young stars.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: ''There weren't too many little guys back then soaring to the hoop and dunking on and blocking the shots of guys 6-9 and 6-10,'' Manigault said in a recent interview. ''I was a pioneer in that sense, that's why I became so popular.''
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: Manigault, nicknamed the Goat because a teacher once mispronunced his last name as Mani-Goat, was famous for his mid-air acrobatics. Thousands of people swear they saw him perform a move known as the Double Dunk, in which he would slam the ball through a net, catch it as it dropped through the cords and, still airborne, dunk it again.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: It was this kind of exhibition that sent fans flocking to any park where Manigault was playing, especially to places like Rucker Park in Harlem and the playground at 99th Street and Amsterdam Avenue that came to be known as Goat Park.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: It was there that Manigault honed his reputation as a showman and a hustler. He would win bets against those who refused to believe that the mighty springs in his legs could enable him to pick a quarter off the top of a backboard. He once dunked a ball backward 36 times in a row to win a $60 bet.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: ''Earl and I would get together on Saturday mornings and play a lot of three-on-three basketball in the park or wherever the real good games were being played,'' Abdul-Jabbar said in an interview several years ago. ''Earl was more of a street player than I was, so he never really got the same type of mainstream recognition that I got in high school.''
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: While Abdul-Jabbar was making a name for himself as an all-city basketball player at Power Memorial High School in midtown, Manigault became a star at Benjamin Franklin High School in Harlem. But in his senior year he was kicked out of school for smoking marijuana.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: He spent one season at Laurinburg Institute, a North Carolina prep school, where he drew the attention of schools like North Carolina, Duke and Indiana. Feeling he would not be able to meet the academic requirements of such schools, Manigault chose instead to attend Johnson C. Smith University, a predominantly black school in Charlotte, N.C.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: The move backfired. Manigault continued to struggle academically, squabbled with his coach about playing time and returned to the playgrounds of New York, where a drug addiction slowly began to destroy his great athletic ability.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: In 1969, the same year Abdul-Jabbar was made a rookie millionaire by the Milwaukee Bucks, Manigault was arrested for possession of drugs, and spent 16 months of a five-year sentence at Green Haven prison in Stormville, N.Y.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: Manigault is survived by his wife, Yvonne, and two sons, Darrin and Earl.
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: ''Growing up, Kareem and I were very close,'' Manigault once said. ''We both had talent and we both ended up taking separate roads in life.''
title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies

text: By Mike Zwerin, International Herald Tribune
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: On stage in a club in Atlantic City, New Jersey, Frank Sinatra was between songs, holding a glass of strong-colored liquid; a cigarette in the same hand was curling smoke. The room was full of smoking people wearing silk and expensive perfume.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: "A friend in need," Sinatra said, holding his breath, just long enough for suspense, "is a drag."
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: At the same time, he had a reputation for being generous with his friends. This dichotomy reflected his general schizophrenia. Was he a movie star or a singer? A pop or a jazz singer? A hipster or a gangster? A sweet and generous guy or a mobster?
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: As a movie star, he seemed to leave a certain sense of realism to be desired. For example, as he lay dead or dying (or perhaps getting ready to rise up and belt out a bridge) on the railroad tracks at the end of "Von Ryan's Express," it is hard to ignore the fantasy that his hairdresser got there just before the SS.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Maybe we should blame the director for that, but there was something to be desired any way you looked at it. In any case, the gift he will be remembered for long after the sensational unauthorized biographies are out of print is that it was all about listening, not looking. He was without doubt the most talented male singer of our lifetime.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Not many artists (probably not even one) have reached so many people on so many levels for so many years with such quality.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Lester Young was the ultimate swing era saxophone player. He was a master spinner of melody who was called "the Mozart of swing."
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Pres was not someone who had patience with commercialism. He went all the way every time and he judged everybody else on the same value system. He was also not, it should be added, the kind of musician who would ever have had the ambition, commercial appeal or the business smarts to lead a big band. Still, it meant something to a lot of people when Pres said that, if he ever led a big band, he would hire Billie Holiday and Frank Sinatra as his female and male singers.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Now this was a compliment that came from a highly respected place. It gives you some idea of the range of Sinatra's appeal. As far as his technique is concerned, opera singers have admired his famous breath control, which he learned from spying on Tommy Dorsey on stage from his seat behind the leader as the trombonist played melodies.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Dorsey sipped in breath from the side of his mouthpiece without opening his mouth, and he could extend phrases for many measures, as though he were circular breathing. Sinatra learned how to do that.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: In the 1956 Encyclopedia of Jazz, Sinatra was voted top male singer by 56 out of 120 musicians, black and white, of all styles and ages — among them Duke Ellington, Andre Previn, Benny Goodman, Nat King Cole, Miles Davis, Gerry Mulligan and Horace Silver.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: There were very few white musicians who could include "jazz" in their curricula vitae and not be questioned about the truth of it by black Americans. Sinatra was one, Stan Getz was another. Coincidentally or not, both of these gentlemen had difficult personalities. They seemed to take pleasure in being mean. And then leaving you to figure out whether they were acting or not.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Gillespie was once asked by a journalist whether it was possible for a person with an ugly personality to make beautiful music. Gillespie went right in the journalist's face and said slowly, deliberately and loudly: "Stan . . . Getz."
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Sinatra and The Beatles had one essential thing in common. They were both swamped by hordes of screaming adolescent girls. Different generations, but still. They were considered sexy.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: But is it also possible, just a remote possibility mind you, that these screaming girls understood true talent before the rest of us? Is it possible that this talent reached the innocence of youth first in its own weird way, and then we "mature" folk picked it up from there?
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: One way or another, they both went on to reach pretty much everybody. But even that further path was not dissimilar. Both of them had . . . let's just say outlaw qualities, as well as the ability to serve up sensitive and inventive music.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: The Beatles were on drugs. Their groupie action was heavy — Sinatra's too. He also drank a lot and smoked cigarettes. None of them were exactly interested in developing their pecs and working out and jogging. And just like Paul McCartney admitted that marijuana had something to do with the creativity of "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band," Julio Iglesias once claimed that Sinatra told him that smoking tobacco had a lot to do with the rich and funky quality of Sinatra's voice. In other words, can it be that tobacco is good for you?
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Well, we won't take that seriously. Still, this story of exquisite interpretation of love songs is laced with booze, brawls and miscellaneous vulgarity. At the least, Sinatra's lifestyle can be described as rude.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: This is not a new question. Benny Goodman was often tyrannical. When asked how he liked touring Russia with Benny Goodman, Zoot Sims replied, "When you play with Benny Goodman, every gig is in Russia."
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: But this "tyrant" played fine clarinet and had a wonderful orchestra. Michael Brecker, the saxophonist who has played with demanding pop acts like Steely Dan and Paul Simon, says he was never as nervous in a studio as he was backing Sinatra. With Frank, you got it on the first take or it could get rough. You could be asked to leave. He was only applying his own rules to others. He made it on the first take, why not the hired hands?
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: By the time he hit his 60s, some critics were saying he was losing his voice. Actually it was kind of aging, like fine wine. Whatever he lost in breath control, he gained in emotional depth.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: And as Gene Lees said about him in his book "Singers and the Song": "For a very long time, Frank Sinatra turned the singing of the American song into an art form."
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: A four-disk box, "Frank Sinatra; The Reprise Collection," was released in 1990. The novelist William Kennedy, who wrote the album notes, had heard him in concert earlier that year. Sinatra was in his 70s, remember. "How can anybody be so good for that long? " Kennedy asked.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: "You listen and you know that this is not Frank in his best voice ever but it does not matter. It's his sound, his cadence, his tune, him, and it's as good as it can be and that's still very, very good.
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: "You do not have to have Frank on video, or in a movie or on a TV show, or even invent conversation in person with this fellow who is a stranger. You really don't need these presences. All you need is the music the man has made and that has been with you all your life."
title: Booze and Brawls, Sure, but Always the Voice

text: Jonathan Shaw has been putting ink under people's skin for a quarter of a century. He is something of a tattoo celebrity; his work can be found on Kate Moss, the model, and Johnny Depp, the actor. When Mr. Shaw learned the art, it was practiced in basements and back rooms and had the same illicit thrill buying marijuana did, because tattooing was also illegal in New York City.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: But in the year since New York City relaxed its rules and once again allowed tattooing out in the open, he has found that he has lots of competition. As the ''featured artist'' at Fun City Tattoo on St. Marks Place in the East Village, he shares the street with several other parlors, including Tattoos, Tattoos; Electric Circus; Studio Enigma, and Village Tattoo and Piercing.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''This thing has multiplied exponentially to the point where it is totally alien to people like me,'' Mr. Shaw said.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''I scratch my head, look around, and wonder how much bigger this can get,'' he said on a rare daylight visit to the shop (normally, Mr. Shaw's clients arrive only after the plain-skinned are in bed).
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Tattooing in New York is coming of age, and so, predictably perhaps, it finds itself in the throes of an identity crisis. As the art form has evolved from drunken-sailor initiation rite to quirky fashion statement to all-but-pervasive youthful social insignia, New York has been left playing a game of catch-up.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Some aficionados here seem nostalgic for the underground allure of the bad old days. But others complain that the number and caliber of artists working in the city pale by comparison with San Francisco, Amsterdam, Berlin and other international centers of youth culture.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: And as the East Village, SoHo and Williamsburg in Brooklyn attract a new cottage industry, the question arises: Is the city threatened by a wave of mediocrity emblazoned across people's arms, torsos and backsides?
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: The debate is being underscored this weekend as New York City welcomes its first tattoo convention, a three-day extravaganza that began yesterday at the Roseland Ballroom. By 5 P.M., an hour after Roseland opened its doors on West 52d Street, more than 1,000 heavily adorned tattoo devotees had filed in, with a line of about a hundred outside still clamoring for tickets.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Tattoo conventions have become routine in several other cities, but organizers have avoided New York for the same reason that tattoo parlors like those on St. Marks Place were not so conspicuous until little more than a year ago. For 35 years, until March 27, 1997, tattooing was banned in the city, largely because of municipal worries about hepatitis and other health problems that never materialized.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: The result was that New York -- where sailors had flocked to early in the century to have battleships emblazoned on their chests, where electronic tattooing in its current form began in the 1920's -- was left behind during the 20 years when tattooing was transformed into a mainstay of youth culture, starting in the mid-70's.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: During that time, tattoos moved beyond peace signs for hippies and skulls for bikers. A recent fashion in tribal designs -- inspired by the work of American Indians and tribes from places like Borneo and Thailand -- is now displayed on the ankles and arms of Madison Avenue executives.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: New York City Health Department officials said 200 tattoo licenses have been issued since the ban was lifted. Still, according to the tattoo cognoscenti, not enough accomplished artists have taken up residence to give the city the stature in the world of tattoo art that it has in other art forms.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: During the years that tattooing was illegal, dozens of tattoo artists maintained a subterranean industry, working out of unmarked back rooms and apartment kitchens.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: But ''New York's problem is that the best artists were not interested in hiding in their basements or kitchens,'' said Laurie Levin, owner of New York Adorned, an elegant tattoo parlor and gift shop on Second Avenue five blocks south of St. Marks Place.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Her shop provides a reminder of tattooing's hidden past. Because it opened in 1996, before the ban was lifted, Ms. Levin ushers her clients behind a heavily shaded glass wall -- something that might have been concocted by Ian Fleming -- that is opened by a discreet electric switch. It was designed to conceal what was going on in the back room.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Among the more than 70 tattoo artists displaying and executing their designs at the convention are people from England, Germany, France and Iceland. ''The selection is huge, and it will help educate people about what can be done,'' said one exhibitor, Bob Roberts, owner of Spotlight Tattoo in Los Angeles.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''It is a celebration of legalization in the city,'' said Steve Bonge, a photographer for International Tattoo Art Magazine and one of the convention's principal organizers. ''The point is to put tattooing in a positive light, and what you are not going to see is a bunch of scratchers, or people doing unprofessional work.''
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: But some veterans of New York City tattoo culture bristle at the ''scratchers'' label. Some insist that life was more interesting and the general level of tattoo art was higher when it was kept underground.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''The argument is that because it is legal, just about anybody can hang out their shingle and the caliber of their art may not be very good,'' said Michael McCabe, a veteran tattoo artist whose 1997 book ''New York City Tattoo: An Oral History of an Urban Art'' has made him something of a resident scholar.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: He said the ban had created an atmosphere in which ''nobody could make a living as a lousy tattoo artist, because they had to rely on word of mouth to get customers.''
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: While the uninitiated may picture mostly eagles, anchors and hearts with ''Mom'' in the middle -- all rendered in the same steely blue -- serious tattoo fans say the range and quality of designs vary spectacularly. Color and definition are crucial, but one must also consider how the designs are affected by body movements, and how one style of image relates to others on the same body.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Practitioners say the soaring popularity of tattoos has had an uneven impact on their claim to be a form of art. While increased competition in New York and elsewhere has created higher benchmarks for the best artists, practitioners say people getting tattooed now sometimes make poor selections, choosing a fashion statement that is likely to become dated.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''People used to get tattooed to mark significant people, places and occasions in their lives, and they knew it was permanent,'' said Mike Bakaty, an artist for 21 years who owns Fine Line Tattoo on First Avenue near First Street.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''Now they are doing it just to get tattooed, and you wonder what they will think of the thing 20 years from now,'' he said.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Such worries, although still well founded, are less cause for outright alarm than they once were. During the years of the city's tattoo ban, medical advances in the use of lasers made it possible to remove most tattoos and do so with less pain than previous methods, which often did little more than reduce an artful image to a blotch of discolored skin.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''The previous methods caused scarring, and we now have much better lasers,'' said Robin Ashinoff, chief of dermatological and laser surgery at New York University Medical Center.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: But experts caution that such procedures do not always make tattoos disappear, and sometimes leave an outline of slightly discolored skin. And removing tattoos is far more expensive than having them created, which in the city ranges from about $50 for a small, simple image to far more than $1,000 for complicated work that covers large areas of a person's body.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''We have always had people coming to have them removed, and we still do,'' Dr. Ashinoff said. ''But the number having tattoos put on is astronomically greater.''
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Indeed, for many of those patronizing the city's now legitimate parlors, the decision is not where to have a tattoo applied but how many to choose, or even whether to cover existing images with something larger.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: Such was the case the other day in Ms. Levin's shop, where two of her associate artists, Chris Garver and Michael Ledger, were at work on elaborate designs covering large stretches of skin attached to Guido Baldini and Kevin Borowski. Both were in town to attend the convention today. Mr. Baldini is from Italy and Mr. Borowski is from Rhode Island.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''I am getting ready to cry,'' said Mr. Borowski as he settled into his chair, making clear that one aspect of tattoo culture has not changed: They hurt.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: His new image, under Mr. Ledger's electric ''tattooing iron,'' would eventually be a huge, fierce-looking character of Japanese myth known as a fudo. It would cover the front of his torso, from throat to belly button, in a 10- hour operation split into several sessions.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: If such devotion to tattoo culture is symptomatic of a social trend that continues to gain momentum, people on the East Village scene say they are happy to find that finally, people like Mr. Borowski are coming to New York.
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: ''New York has always been the center of our culture in so many ways that this is all very fitting,'' Mr. Shaw said. ''We are sort of stepping up to claim our rightful place as a cultural mecca.''
title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention

text: More than 25 years after hemp was last grown legally in America, a group of farmers and trade organizations will file suit against the Federal Government on Friday to make hemp a lawful crop again.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: The plaintiffs intend to argue in Federal District Court here that the illegal status of hemp, by definition of the Controlled Substances Act of 1972, violates a 1937 determination by Congress that the plant causes none of the psychoactive effects that its cousin, marijuana, does.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: The plaintiffs will say in their lawsuit, the first of its kind, that Congress had stipulated hemp, which has many commercial uses, was different from marijuana and that hemp's prohibition by the Drug Enforcement Administration violates the Constitutional doctrine of separation of powers of government.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: But the central thrust of the legal action is economics, with thousands of farmers throughout the South and Midwest looking at hemp as another crop to include in their annual rotations that now involve grains, vegetables and tobacco.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: For many farmers, particularly those here in eastern Kentucky who are almost wholly dependent on tobacco for their income, hemp would provide a viable hedge as a disease-resistant plant -- especially when the future of tobacco is so uncertain.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: As the region's most valuable crop, tobacco can generate as much as $5,000 an acre in gross sales. Most food crops like corn, soybeans and wheat do not have anywhere near that kind of return. But farmers like Jim Barton, whose family raised hemp when it was legal during a ''Hemp for Victory'' drive in World War II, predicted that an acre of hemp could gross as much as $1,200.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: ''Hemp is no more controversial today than tobacco is,'' said Andrew R. Graves, who will be a plaintiff in the suit as president of the Kentucky Hemp Growers Council, a group of 60 would-be hemp farmers. ''You go into any store and you can buy hemp products. But he and I as farmers'' -- he pointed to Mr. Barton -- ''get no portion of that money. That makes no sense to me.''
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: Terry Parham, a spokesman for the drug administration, said the agency had not seen the lawsuit and, as a result, would have no comment.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: The frustration of would-be hemp farmers and marketers in the United States -- and the basis of the lawsuit -- centers on the long-standing policy of the Department of Justice and the D.E.A. to make no distinction between hemp and marijuana because they contain the same psychoactive chemical -- delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol, commonly known as THC. Government officials fear that hemp would provide camouflage for growing marijuana.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: But the lawsuit will argue that Congress in 1937 recognized the differences when it passed the Marijuana Tax Act and excluded hemp from any prohibition. And scientists have determined that THC constitutes less than 1 percent of hemp's weight, not enough to cause any psychoactive effects.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: Despite the 1937 law that made a distinction between hemp and marijuana, hemp farming virtually died out over three decades that followed, except for the wartime program.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: The farmers' lawsuit will ask that the court rule that it was illegal for the executive branch of government to ban hemp, that chemical distinctions between marijuana and hemp should be recognized and that states should have the right to regulate hemp production.
title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

text: By Robert Mcg. Thomas Jr.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: Wesley A. Pomeroy, a peace-loving peace officer who maintained order with such friendly persuasion at the 1964 Republican National Convention in San Francisco that he was recruited by the Justice Department and who later became a counterculture hero as the benign and highly effective security chief at the 1969 Woodstock music festival, died on May 4 at a hospital near his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 78 and had retired in 1995 as head of the Dade County police review board.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: His family said the cause was heart failure.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: If Mr. Pomeroy had had his way, the revolutionaries of the 1960's would not have had much to rebel against. That was because Mr. Pomeroy, a member of the American Civil Liberties Union and an advocate of the decriminalization of marijuana, was a law enforcement officer who viewed protesters as citizens, not criminals, and whose approach to crowd control was to coddle, even if it meant sharing police communications systems with a rally's organizers and teaching angry counter-protesters how to set up picket lines.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: Mr. Pomeroy's theories first came to national attention in 1964 when, as Under Sheriff of suburban San Mateo County, he was put in charge of security for the Republican Convention at the San Francisco Cow Palace.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: With the party deeply split over a number of hot-button issues, there were fears that the convention, which eventually nominated Barry Goldwater for President, would disintegrate into factional clashes.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: But with Mr. Pomeroy in charge of a security force drawn from 18 police departments, the convention was close to a model of decorum. And when a group of teen-age girls did invade the hall, and went limp, Mr. Pomeroy had them carried out on stretchers, not dragged off.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: A native of Burbank, Calif., who attended Pacific Union College, Mr. Pomeroy, who later received a law degree from the San Francisco Law School, became a law enforcement officer largely on a whim. When he placed first on a civil service test he joined the California Highway Patrol. After serving with the Marines in the Pacific in World War II, he resumed his career and later joined the San Mateo County Sheriff's Department.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival
