text: His work at the 1964 convention was so impressive that in 1968 Attorney General Ramsey Clark made him a special assistant to coordinate Federal anticrime efforts, including security at the national political conventions. As he had four years earlier, Mr. Pomeroy helped make the 1968 Republican Convention a peaceful success, but when he tried to arrange cooperation between the Chicago police and various protest groups for the Democratic Convention, his efforts were rebuffed by Mayor Richard A. Daley, making the resulting notorious clashes all but inevitable.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: By the end of 1968 he had been named the Republican member of the three-member board formed to run the new Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, but soon after Richard N. Nixon took office in 1969, he was replaced.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: As a private consultant, Mr. Pomeroy, who later became a Democrat, was hired as security chief of the Woodstock festival in Bethel, N.Y., where his compassionate handling of hundreds of thousands of music lovers was credited with helping to make the festival the peaceful love-in it became known as.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: The work led to assignments as security chief at a Led Zepplin rock tour and other large events, but in 1974 Mr. Pomeroy returned to traditional law enforcement as Chief of Police in Berkeley, Calif.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: He returned to Washington in 1977, holding a series of posts in the Carter Administration, including assistant director of the Drug Enforcement Administration, something of an anomaly for a man who had been a board member of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, or Norml, and who continued to call for decriminalization, joining the Coalition Advocating Medical Marijuana as recently as last year.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: Before being named director of the Metropolitan Dade County Independent Review Panel in 1983, he served four years as Deputy Director of the Michigan Department of Mental Health; it was his long-held belief that the most efficient way to fight crime was to deal with poverty, mental illness and its other underlying causes.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: It was a reflection of his effectiveness as head of the the Dade County police review board that the mandatory retirement age for government officials was repeatedly waived so he could remain in the job until illness forced him to step down four years ago.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: Mr. Pomeroy, whose first marriage ended in divorce, is survived by his wife, Lonna Caroll of Hollywood, Fla.; three daughters from his first marriage, Nancy Bucher of Palm Springs, Fla., Virginia Pomeroy of Germantown, Wis., and Victoria Pomeroy of Germantown, Tenn., and 11 grandchildren.
title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival

text: A thousand law enforcement officials fanned out across New York City before dawn yesterday and struck what the authorities called a crippling blow to the Latin Kings gang, seizing 94 members and associates, including top leaders, on charges ranging from possessing guns and drugs to conspiring to commit murders.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: In what officials called one of the largest coordinated raids in the city since the Prohibition era, heavily armed Federal and city agents with search warrants hit gang homes and hideouts across New York at 5 A.M., hauled suspects away in handcuffs and confiscated caches of guns, drugs and other contraband.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: While the Latin Kings and their leader, Antonio Fernandez, alias King Tone, have sought to moderate the gang's image in recent years by renouncing violence and promoting Hispanic pride and self-help programs, law enforcement officials insisted yesterday that the group was still a dedicated criminal enterprise.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: ''In spite of the Latin Kings' attempts to portray themselves as a benign, community-oriented organization, this gang has always been, and continues to this day to be, a dangerous group of criminals,'' Police Commissioner Howard Safir said at a joint news conference with Federal and city officials.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: Citing long and recent criminal records, he added, ''While their leaders may speak of peace initiatives, day care and scholarships, our investigation shows that they continue to be involved in a wide range of very violent crimes that erode and destroy communities, rather than improve or build them.''
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: The officials said that Operation Crown, a 19-month undercover investigation by the police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, had found evidence linking gang members to arson, extortion, murder for hire, firearms and drug trafficking, kidnapping and other crimes in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: Since Jan. 1 in New York, Mr. Safir charged, the Latin Kings have committed 100 slashings, assaults, robberies, rapes and attempted murders. He said the inquiry and yesterday's raids had prevented several murders and had crippled the gang's top echelon.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: ''Today's arrests,'' the Commissioner said, ''have effectively dismantled the command structure of the Latin Kings organization by effectively removing the so-called supreme king, who supervised all of New York State, and each of the borough leaders, who are called crowns.''
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: His comments were echoed by Lewis D. Schiliro, the head of the F.B.I. office in New York; Bridget G. Brennan, New York City's Special Narcotics Prosecutor; Susan Gaffney, the Inspector General of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, and various Federal and state prosecutors.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: While the raiders seized 87 gang members and 7 associates in simultaneous raids, officials said, the primary suspect was Mr. Fernandez, 31, who was taken into custody at his Brooklyn home without incident and arraigned before Robert Levy, a Federal Magistrate Judge in Brooklyn, on charges of conspiring to possess and distribute heroin. He pleaded not guilty and was held for a bail hearing on Monday.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: In an interview later, Ronald L. Kuby, Mr. Fernandez's lawyer, called the allegations ''phony'' and said that state and Federal authorities had filed a series of false charges against his client in the last two years and that all had been dismissed. He said he expected that the latest charges would be dismissed.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: ''I anticipate,'' Mr. Kuby said, ''that a number of community activists are going to testify that over the past three years Antonio Fernandez has consistently told the Latin Kings to put down the guns, pick up the protest signs, put down the drugs and pick up the books. He's said that in the schools, in the churches and on the streets. He's also been very active in protesting police brutality, and his criticism has made him many enemies in the N.Y.P.D.''
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: The Latin Kings, founded in 1945 by Hispanic inmates in a Chicago jail, later established chapters in the Middle West and Northeast. The New York chapter was begun in 1986 by Luis Felipe, also known as King Blood, a charismatic inmate who directed his 1,500-member gang from behind bars while serving time for manslaughter. Convicted of ordering murders by mail, he was put in solitary confinement, but not before naming Mr. Fernandez his successor in 1996.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: In an interview with The New York Times last November, Mr. Fernandez, a former crack addict, spoke of transforming the Latin Kings from violence to community advocacy. ''One day, we're going to take over those bodegas that have been closed for drugs,'' he said. ''And we'll have other businesses, too. And we'll have health insurance and Medicaid.''
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: But Federal and city officials scoffed at such claims yesterday. Mr. Safir, citing written materials seized from gang members, said the Almighty Latin King and Queen Nation, as the gang calls itself formally, was tightly organized and had strict rules, codes of conduct and even applications for membership.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: He quoted one rule as saying, ''You are not to put God, religion, family or friends or parole before the Nation.'' The membership application, he said, asks such questions as ''How many times have you been in jail and why?'' and ''List your enemies.'' Commands to the members, he said, included ''B.O.S. -- Beat on Sight,'' and ''T.O.S. -- Terminate on Sight.''
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: Mr. Safir said that many of the 94 people arrested yesterday had extensive criminal records and a combined total of 400 arrests for crimes including rape, burglary and robbery. Two men, he said, had 29 arrests each. He did not say how many of the arrests had led to convictions. Earlier arrests in Operation Crown, he said, had prevented four murders and other crimes in the last year.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: While more than half of the state and Federal charges filed yesterday were felony charges, there were no homicide allegations, and many of the charges were for misdemeanors. Officials said the seized contraband included 43 firearms, 2 kilograms each of heroin and crack cocaine, 41 grams of marijuana, 3 bulletproof vests, 9 cellular phones and 1 police radio scanner.
title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

text: Re your May 10 and 11 front-page articles on the Dominican Republic, the Dominican community in the United States and the drug issue:
title: Fighting the Drug Trade

text: Less than 2 percent of people of Dominican origin living in the United States have been involved in drug-related crimes. Unfortunately, Dominican migration to the United States has, since 1965, coincided with the growing consumption of drugs in the United States. Thus, unemployed youth found illegal income opportunities in drug distribution.
title: Fighting the Drug Trade

text: As you note, two months ago the United States Government said the Dominican Republic was cooperating closely on drug investigation matters with the United States. While you quote a State Department official as saying that under President Leonel Fernandez ''not a single drug-related case has been prosecuted,'' drug-related arrests in 1997 exceeded 1,400, according to the State Department.
title: Fighting the Drug Trade

text: A United States Embassy survey estimates that only 35,000 Dominicans are users of cocaine and marijuana in my country -- less than 1 percent of our population over 12 years of age, as compared with a 6 percent equivalent figure for the United States.
title: Fighting the Drug Trade

text: ON the back lot of Universal Studios, hip-hop's rising star Canibus is lounging in a trailer parked in front of the clock-tower building best known from the set of the ''Back to the Future'' movies. On break from filming a video for ''How Come,'' a single he raps on from the Warren Beatty movie ''Bulworth,'' Canibus is waiting for a meeting with an executive at Dreamworks Records who wants to sign him to a publishing deal. In his back pocket is a cassette of a song that the teen-age singer and sitcom star Brandy wants him to rap on, and in his hands is a bottle of Hype, a natural energy beverage that he says he drinks to immunize himself from the hype constantly bombarding him. The drink, he says, keeps him from getting ''hype-notized'' and succumbing to ''hype-nitis,'' which occurs when you believe your own hype. It is a disease common among pop stars.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: ''I have cases and cases of Hype,'' Canibus said, a smirk spreading across his smooth, strong face. ''You will never catch me without one.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: Canibus, a 23-year-old from Jersey City, certainly needs the protection. He has released only one single, yet he has become one of the most talked about and respected rappers working today. Mike Tyson, in fact, was even willing to break his ban on speaking to print media to discuss Canibus.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: ''He's so intelligent, that's the reason I like him,'' Mr. Tyson said. ''He's fresh, he's new, and his delivery is perfect. He never makes mistakes.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: Canibus's fame comes not just from years spent building a reputation as one of the smartest, toughest and tightest rhymers on the underground or from the songs he has performed on by rappers like the Fugees, Common, the Lost Boyz and L. L. Cool J. It doesn't even come from the fact that his manager, Wyclef Jean of the Fugees, is a man much busier and more famous than he is. It is in large part because he has become embroiled in the biggest rap feud of the year. And nearly everyone in hip-hop is excited about this fight because it doesn't involve guns. It involves music.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: In rap's early days, disputes and challenges were often settled in battles -- neighborhood contests of disk-jockeying or rapping prowess that took place in parks and community centers. As rap became a big business and street gangs were lured by the power and money, insults were often responded to with fists, knives or guns. But late last year, when L. L. Cool J. railed against Canibus, spending an entire verse of the song ''4,3,2,1'' calling him a cocky, talentless upstart, Canibus struck back at his former idol on wax, recording a vicious, contemptuous single with extra vocals from Mike Tyson, ''Second Round K.O.'' It shot out of the underground and into the Top 40.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: Two weeks ago, L. L. Cool J. retaliated, releasing ''The Ripper Strikes Back,'' a taunting single that responds point for point to Canibus's barbs about his children, sexuality and fans. The exchange has music fans hoping that Canibus, on his debut album due in July on Group Home/Universal Records, will take hip-hop back to its more benign pre-gangsta roots in boasting and battling. But their hopes may be misplaced. Canibus has other intentions for hip-hop.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: ''People are interpreting me as bringing it back,'' Canibus said. ''Wrong, I'm from an entirely different era. Don't put me in a box and say I'm taking it back. I'm taking it forward! They just don't have enough to judge me on.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: Despite his confrontational, battle-hungry lyrics, Canibus's real agenda is to equate intelligence with toughness, to promote content over style and to, as he raps in one song, ''make you question any and everything you've ever believed in.'' He derived his name from that of the marijuana plant, he says, not because he advocates using the drug but because he likes to think of his lyrics as activating the mind in the way the plant does.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: A self-confessed computer junkie who can't stay away from the Internet, he doesn't fit the mold of most rappers. As his producer, Jerry Wonder, said, ''I think he's from another planet.'' In Canibus's thinking-cap raps, he compares himself to Einstein instead of, say, John Gotti and talks about picking up women on line instead of in bars. Where other rappers court legitimacy by bragging about gang warefare, drug-dealing and prison sentences, Canibus proudly says he was a hermit who never went out as a child, preferring to play Atari games and live in his head instead of the streets. In a world in which rappers thank God on their albums, Canibus says he places his faith in science over religion. In fact, he spent a year at DeKalb Community College in Atlanta studying computer science though his real ambition was genetic engineering.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: ''I was always an antisocial person growing up,'' he explained. ''I couldn't understand a lot of things people would do and say. And no one ever understood me. I always had a hard time in school. People always laughed and made fun of me because I couldn't find my niche.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: Born Germaine Williams to a Jamaican cricket player named Basil Williams, Canibus is a tough man with a soft heart. During the filming of the ''How Come'' video, he disappeared to buy a Nintendo 64 game console for the 10-year-old son of one of the women working on the set because, he said, the son was a thinker and a loner who reminded him of himself at that age.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: Canibus emerged from his shell in the early 90's, when he made his way into the rap world on the business side, helping start Group Home, the management company that represented the Lost Boyz. His real goal, however, was to become a rapper, and he started rhyming on underground mix tapes made by DJ Clue and putting himself through a training regime that he compares to Mr. Tyson's.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: ''Tyson gets in the ring and knocks people out,'' Canibus said. ''I get in the mike booth and knock people out. His training process is bananas; the stuff I go through is coconuts. People think I just sit home all day and scratch myself or go to a club every night and get drunk and stoned and then write rhymes. No, practice makes perfect. I sit for hours in front of the mirror and just look at myself when I rhyme, and I say certain words and I accent certain things. I read. I exercise my mind. Input equals output. That's a fact of life.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: One of Canibus's biggest breaks came when L. L. Cool J. invited him to appear on ''4,3,2,1,'' which explains why he was so upset when he heard the final version of the song and L. L. called him a ''little boy'' and ''amateur'' and threatening, ''Blow you to pieces/ Leave you covered in feces.'' It seems that L. L. Cool J. interpreted a line Canibus rapped during the recording of the song as an insult. (The line was about tearing L. L. Cool J.'s tattoo of a microphone off his arm.) But Canibus says it wasn't intended as derogatory and that L. L. Cool J. should have been familiar with his aggressive style. L. L. Cool J. declined to be interviewed.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: ''DURING the six months after the record was made, it was very difficult for me,'' Canibus said. ''My life was balanced on a scale right there, and it felt like a boulder dropping on one side against a rice grain. I live in Jersey, and it was difficult for me to just walk down the street to my block and go home because people were always coming up to me and asking questions.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: When L. L. Cool J. released ''The Ripper Strikes Back,'' accusing Canibus of, among other things, being an overnight sensation thanks to the feud, Canibus says he wasn't hurt this time. He was flattered. ''I got him to respond,'' Canibus said. ''I actually got him screaming my name on a record. That's what he wanted least of all. This is cooler than it being something violent.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: Canibus compares a battle to a chess game and constantly says that he lives his life in ''if-then statements,'' meaning that before he does anything, he runs through every possible outcome in his mind. Some friends call him paranoid and, in fact, he likens himself to Mel Gibson's cabdriver character in ''Conspiracy Theory.'' He can pontificate for hours about alien intelligence, government plots and J.F.K. assassination theses and has reams of computer printouts on these subjects.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: ''To me everything is a conspiracy movie,'' he said. ''When I get up in the morning, automatically I'm worried about what am I doing, what are you doing, what are you thinking, what am I thinking. What you say will cause me to think one way; if you say something else, it'll cause me to think another way.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: Somehow, this man who portrays himself as an intellectual loner in conversation has become one of the rap world's most watched figures. At dinner after the video shoot, Canibus was surrounded by stars and moguls, including Mr. Beatty, members of the Fugees and Jimmy Iovine, president of Interscope Records. In the middle of the meal, Mr. Wyclef shouted to Mr. Iovine: ''Watch this kid. He's going to be big. Real big.''
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: From the other end of the table, Canibus's business partner boasted: ''Canibus is going to change the face of rap. There's no one like him.'' Meanwhile, Canibus just sat slumped in his seat, smirking, as he lifted a can of Hype to his lips and took a long sip.
title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: 30 Suspects Are Arrested In Drug Sales to Youths

text: Thirty people were arrested yesterday in Gloucester and Camden Counties after a six-month undercover operation against a drug ring that sold thousands of dollars' worth of marijuana a week to teen-agers in southern New Jersey, prosecutors said.
title: 30 Suspects Are Arrested In Drug Sales to Youths

text: Brian Ayling, 20, of Glassboro, and Sean Porter, 19, of Washington Township, were accused of organizing a network of drug dealers that sold as much as 15 pounds of marijuana a week around schools and gathering places of teen-agers, said Debra Romano, a spokeswoman for Andrew N. Yurick, the Gloucester County Prosecutor. The two men, who were arrested on drug distribution charges, were also accused of selling cocaine, hallucinogenic mushrooms and LSD, Ms. Romano said.
title: 30 Suspects Are Arrested In Drug Sales to Youths

text: Question: What happens when you cross ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre'' with the Three Stooges?
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: Answer: ''Homegrown,'' a wacky farce noir about three babes in the woods shepherding a huge marijuana crop to marketable maturity when the murder of their wealthy boss fills their fool heads with dreams of becoming the millionaires next door.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: So, with Stephen Gyllenhaal as director and co-writer with Nicholas Kazan, ''Homegrown'' is off and romping with its spirited cast through a plot that mingles murder mystery, rustic comedy, outlaw sociology, plant husbandry, lusty romance and layers of old-fashioned avarice, which is to say old-fashioned business.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: The fun begins when John Lithgow, as Malcolm, the affluent magnate who owns the crop, decides to pay a flying visit to the Northern California forest primeval, where his stooges are doing some figurative flying as they tend the tall plants under their woodland canopy.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: But no sooner does the helicopter land than the pilot shoots Malcolm dead. The stooges, played by Billy Bob Thornton as the grizzled Jack, Hank Azaria as the horticultural expert Carter and Ryan Phillippe as Harlan, the naive newcomer to the trade, are convinced that the rub-out signals the start of a raid by so-called rippers, who hijack crops.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: So the stooges gather up whatever marijuana they can carry and make a beeline for the home of Lucy (Kelly Lynch), who isn't exactly Carter's girlfriend any more, but who, nonetheless, isn't exactly unwilling to go to bed with him, either. (And that's even after the filmmakers, in homage to Hitchcock, dispatch him with knife in hand into her steamy bathroom while she is in the shower.)
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: Lucy, the packaging and distribution arm of Malcolm's marijuana business, helps the stooges ready their haul for sale while at least temporarily under the impression that Malcolm is still alive.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: When the stooges learn that rippers have not stolen the crop, they bury his body, and Jack, supposedly the most mature, experienced and brainy of the lot, hatches the idea of pretending that Malcolm is still alive and arranges to sell the $3 million harvest to Danny (Jon Bon Jovi), one of the local wholesalers.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: In the meantime, Jack tries his hand at impersonating Malcolm on the telephone and finding out who killed him and why. Along the way, Jamie Lee Curtis turns up as Sierra Kahan, the doyenne of the local growers' association; Judge Reinhold as a police officer who pockets a bribe, and Ted Danson as a man whose name Jack mistakes for Johnny. The name is really Gianni. He represents a large criminal enterprise and likes toys and torture.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: Mr. Gyllenhaal, whose credits include ''Paris Trout''; Mr. Kazan, who wrote the screenplay for ''Reversal of Fortune,'' and the entire cast have a high old time huffing and puffing their through this happy sermon on the wages of greed.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: ''Homegrown'' is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes murder, shootouts, copious consumption of illegal substances, terrifying threats, nudity and sexual situations.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: Directed by Stephen Gyllenhaal; written by Nicholas Kazan and Mr. Gyllenhaal, based on a story by Jonah Raskin and Mr. Gyllenhaal; director of photography, Greg Gardiner; edited by Michael Jablow; music by Trevor Rabin; production designer, Richard Sherman; produced by Jason Clark; released by Tri-Star Pictures. Running time: 95 minutes. This film is rated R.
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: WITH: Billy Bob Thornton (Jack), Hank Azaria (Carter), Kelly Lynch (Lucy), Jon Bon Jovi (Danny), Ryan Phillippe (Harlan), Judge Reinhold (Policeman), Jon Tenney (Pilot), Matt Ross (Ben Hickson), Matt Clark (Sheriff), Ted Danson (Gianni), John Lithgow (Malcolm/Robert) and Jamie Lee Curtis (Sierra Kahan).
title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams

text: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * BUJU BANTON AND BERES HAMMOND, Radio City Music Hall, (212) 307-7171. Buju Banton started out as a dance hall toaster, boasting about girls, guns and macho exploits including an infamous song about gay-bashing. Then he changed his mind and his music, turning to songs about spirituality and an end to violence on one of the most important reggae albums of the 1990's, ''Til Shiloh.'' Beres Hammond has been singing love songs and message songs since the 1970's, but has come into his own in the 1990's. Tonight at 8; tickets, $35 to $45 (Jon Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * GARY BARTZ, the Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Mr. Bartz, an alto saxophonist, can pretty much play anything, from the jazz and funk he simmered in with Miles Davis to well-articulated be-bop. His own sets are marvels of intelligence, balance and power, and he connects tunes with interludes that make the sets a suite. While he's a brilliant improviser, the formal change takes his performance away from the average jazz set; you can't wait to hear what's coming up next. He'll be recording a live album, which means he'll have some surprises. Shows tonight and tomorrow night are at 8, 10 and midnight. The cover is $15 and the minimum is $10 (Peter Watrous).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: CALIFONE, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006, and Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-7788. Califone includes former members of Red Red Meat, and it continues their wanderings through a kind of dazed Americana. Califone's songs shuffle along and mumble quietly to themselves, never rushing or raising their voices as they create an aura of down-home mystery. Tomorrow night at midnight at the Knitting Factory, opening for June of 4; admission is $8. Sunday night at 8 at Tramps, opening for Modest Mouse (see below); admission is $7 (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * CARIBBEAN ALL-STARS, Radio City Music Hall, (212) 307-7171. One of New York City's traditions for Mother's Day is a calypso concert with major figures from Trinidad and Tobago and other islands in the English-speaking Caribbean. This year's event, on the night before Mother's Day, surveys calypso's last four or five decades. The bill includes the Mighty Sparrow, who transformed postwar calypso, and his contemporary, Lord Kitchener, along with Arrow from Monserrat (who had the international hit ''Hot! Hot! Hot!''), David Rudder, Chalkdust, Denise Plummer, Mystic Prowler and others. The exuberant beat of calypso and its faster kin, soca, carry political commentary, satire, history and incitements to party, sometimes all at once. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets, $35 to $40 (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * CLARENCE (GATEMOUTH) BROWN, KOKO TAYLOR AND BIG JACK JOHNSON, Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-7788. Three seasoned but still rowdy blues singers make up this triple bill. Clarence (Gatemouth) Brown's repertory spans blues, country and swinging jazz; Koko Taylor rasps and shouts through songs like ''Wang Dang Doodle.'' Big Jack Johnson is less renowned, but shouldn't be; he is a bona fide Mississippi bluesman whose voice is as as gripping as his guitar lines. Tonight at 8:30; tickets, $20 (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: SHEMEKIA COPELAND, Manny's Car Wash, 1558 Third Avenue, at 87th Street, Yorkville, (212) 369-2583. Shemekia Copeland, a 19-year-old blues belter, got an early start on the blues circuit touring with her father, Johnny Copeland, who died last year. With a gutsy but girlish voice, like Etta James's or Bonnie Raitt's, she sings about men and their many flaws, from indifference to infidelity, and she sounds as if she'll get what she wants sooner or later. She has just released her first album, ''Turn the Heat Up'' (Alligator). Tonight; three sets beginning at 9:30. Admission is $8 (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: MARILYN CRISPELL/BORAH BERGMAN/DANIEL RAYSKIN/ANDREI BITOV, CAMI Hall, 165 West 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 841-9500. Part of the second annual Sergei Kuryokhin International Festival, this bill brings together two expressive post-Cecil Taylor improvising pianists (Ms. Crispell and Mr. Bergman) and the Russian poet Andrei Bitov; it's in homage to the catalytic, mischief-making, category-destroying musicality of the pianist Kuryokhin, who died in 1996. The concert is Sunday at 3:30 P.M.; tickets, $12 at the door; $10 in advance; information about the rest of the festival: (212) 330-0688 (Ratliff).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: BO DIDDLEY, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-7880. When Bo Diddley plays his namesake beat and growls the metaphysical boasts of ''Who Do You Love,'' it's easy to hear the fire that made him a rock pioneer. Sharing the bill is Al Kooper, who founded Blood, Sweat and Tears and, while backing Bob Dylan, put the electric organ into folk-rock. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 and 10:30; admission is $25 (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * DAVE DOUGLAS'S MAHFOUZ, Knitting Factory, Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. When Dave Douglas cozies up to his reference points in literature, architecture or music, well-crafted composition flows out. The music of this new electro-acoustic quartet is inspired by the work of Naguib Mahfouz, the Egyptian novelist, and reports were positive from its premiere a few weeks ago; it includes the electronic drum programming of Ikue Mori as well as Mr. Douglas's trumpet, keyboards and a trap-set drummer. Through Sunday night at 8 and 9:30. Tickets, $10 with a one-drink minimum (Ratliff).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * MAHRAJAN AL-FAN: FESTIVAL OF ARAB WORLD CULTURE, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824 and the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, presented by the World Music Institute, (212) 545-7536. Two events in two boroughs bring some of the most celebrated performers in the Arab world to New York City. Tomorrow at Town Hall, the remarkable Syrian singer Sabah Fakhri performs classical Arabic music, a tradition in which stately melodies turn into ornate and fervent improvisations, marvels of power and subtlety. Mr. Fakhri and his orchestra take off in suites of songs that can change on a moment's notice, with the orchestra picking up his subtlest gestures. Sharing the bill are two Lebanese poets, Zaghloul al-Damour and Fayez el-Mograbi, who improvise sung poems. Tomorrow at 8:30 P.M.; tickets, $15 to $55. On Sunday afternoon, music is part of an Arab cultural immersion along with dance, poetry, crafts, children's events and, concluding the day, a screening of the film ''Heaven Before I Die,'' with its director, Izidore Musallam, in attendance. The music features two masters of the oud: Hamza el-Din, whose stark melodies and gentle singing fuse Nubian and Arabic traditions, and Simone Shaheen, who leads the Near Eastern Music Ensemble and who has won the National Heritage Fellowship. Sunday from 1 to 8:30 P.M., with concerts at 2 and 4:30 P.M.; admission is $12 for adults, $4 for children (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: MAYNARD FERGUSON, Blue Note, 131 Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592. The high-note trumpeter, revered by trumpeters everywhere, will be leading his Big Bop Nouveau band, a small big band with a hefty sense of humor and lots of ability. Shows through Sunday are at 9 and 11:30 P.M.; there is a $27.50 cover at the table with a $5 minimum; $15 at the bar with a one-drink minimum (Watrous).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: NNENNA FREELON, Iridium, 48 West 63d Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. Singing in jazz can be an extraordinarily dramatic act, and Ms. Freelon, whose abilities have bloomed over the last several years, knows drama. She brings a sense of play to her songs, laughing at the tunes a bit or worrying a word; it's self-knowing, and in her generosity, Ms. Freelon takes the audience into what she knows. Sets through Sunday are at 8:30 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight, with no third set on Sunday; the cover is $20, tonight and Sunday; $25, tomorrow night; with a $10 minimum (Watrous).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: KRISTIN HERSH, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Some artists have a gift for engaging music's animate core, the way its rhythmic physicality invokes the body's cadences, and its flow through time mirrors emotion's clock. Kristin Hersh, longtime leader of the band Throwing Muses, is expert at making these connections, unfolding the saga of her own changing mind and heart in some of the most intense, idiosyncratic and expansive rock of the last few decades. These shows support her new solo release, ''Strange Angels'' (Rykodisc), which continues in somewhat more subdued but still stirring tones her story of motherhood, womanliness and unreconstructed human subjectivity. Tonight through Sunday at 8 P.M.; tickets, $12 and $10 (Ann Powers).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: ELMORE LEONARD INTRODUCES THE STONE COYOTES, Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. It sounds like the story line of, you guessed it, an Elmore Leonard novel: Hollywood's favorite crime novelist begins a sequel to his best seller ''Get Shorty.'' This book, ''Be Cool,'' has everybody's favorite hustler, Chili Palmer, managing a band whose female singer he takes a shine to. Mr. Leonard scours Los Angeles for a musical prototype, studying the music of Alanis Morissette and dropping in on a Red Hot Chili Peppers rehearsal. Nothing clicks, until one fateful evening at the Troubadour, where he discovers the Stone Coyotes: a trio led by the singer-songwriter Barbara Keith Tibbles, with her husband, Doug, and his son Jon backing her up. Mr. Leonard is smitten. Negotiations ensue, and the Stone Coyotes provide the lyrics for five songs in the book, including a brand-new number that furthers the action. Determined to bring this fine band to a larger audience, Mr. Leonard holds a few club events at which he reads excerpts from the as yet unpublished novel and the Stone Coyotes play. The Coyotes reach superstardom (well, that part hasn't happened yet). Come listen to the plot thicken. With Malcolm Halcolmb; Mr. Leonard reads at 8:45 P.M. Tonight at 7:30; tickets, $10 (Powers).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: RICHARD LLOYD, BRENDA KAHN, Brownies, 169 Avenue A, at 11th Street, East Village, (212) 420-8392. Two survivors of the vicissitudes of the East Village share a bill in their own neighborhood. Richard Lloyd, famous for his role in reinventing guitar pyrotechnics as a member of Television, has lately been popping up in clubs around town with a fistful of new material. Brenda Kahn makes folky pop with a satiric edge that follows in the tradition of New York tough gals Dorothy Parker and Fran Lebowitz. With Stephonic. Tomorrow at 9:30 P.M.; tickets, $7 (Powers).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: LOUNGEVILLE, VOL. II: MANCINI AND MORE, at the 92d Street Y, Lexington Avenue, (212) 996-1100. With his regular Loser's Lounge shows at the Fez, Joe McGinty has been celebrating the craftsmanship of songwriters in and well outside the rock canon; this program takes his regulars uptown to honor melody, no matter how cheesy its original context was. Tomorrow night at 8 and 10; tickets, $30-$35 (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: MODEST MOUSE, Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 544-1666. Now that the excesses of grunge are forgotten (and, one hopes, forgiven), the Pacific Northwest has gone back to being what it always was: a healthy, wet seedbed for home-grown renegade rock. Modest Mouse, a trio all hopped up on its own anxious braininess, is one recent winner. Assembling bits of punk and indie history like pieces in a Lego set, Isaac Brock and his band mates capture the explosive energy that comes from being cooped up in an uncertain life under too much gray sky. With Califone, the latest project from members of Red Red Meat, and Jets To Brazil. Sunday at 8 P.M.; tickets, $7 (Powers).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: MR. T EXPERIENCE, Coney Island High, 15 St. Marks Place, East Village, (212) 674-7959. Every style that sweeps the air waves seems to have its little-known progenitor, and this mainstay of the San Francisco Bay Area punk world claims the title for the style of caffeinated pop-rock that put Green Day on the stadium circuit. The trio's eighth album, ''Revenge Is Sweet and So Are You'' (Lookout), zings with the comical, high-spirited high jinks that helped it take hard-core punk beyond the cacophonous rut it had hit in the mid-1980's. Still a bit too zany for the mainstream, the Mr. T Experience attracts a zealous cult of speed-loving, joke-craving kids. With the Teen Idols and Heartdrops. Tomorrow at 7 P.M.; tickets, $7 (Powers).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * ORQUESTA REVE, Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture, 450 Grand Concourse, at 149th Street, the Bronx, (718) 518-4455. A great Cuban orchestra is making a rare United States appearance in one of the better places in New York to hear this music. The group, founded in 1956, has been the training ground for some of the best musicians in Cuba and is credited with helping create the sound of modern salsa; the bands Los Van Van, Ritmo Oriental and Dan Den all come from Reve's incubator. The band's leader, Elio Reve, died last year, but the band has kept on going. The musicians mix the more traditional style of salsa with the harder, more modern sound of Havana. The concert's an event. The show tomorrow starts at 7:30; tickets, $20 and $15 (Watrous).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: MARC RIBOT'S LOS CUBANOS POSTISOS, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Marc Ribot has gotten serious about adapting the Cuban son montuno for his own purposes. More specifically, he's drawing on the work of the brilliant tres-player and composer Arsenio Rodriguez, who died in 1972. His new quartet merely scratches the surface -- there are many more ways to interpret Rodriguez's music -- but never before has Mr. Ribot's guitar-playing been more choppily arresting. Sets tonight at 10 and 11:30; price $10 (Ratliff).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * LEE PERRY WITH THE MAD PROFESSOR, at Wetlands, 161 Hudson Street, TriBeCa, (212) 966-4225. Lee Perry's quirks are inseparable from his inspirations. He is one of reggae's most important producers, using the studio to fill arrangements with distortion, ghostly echoes and disorienting silences. As a performer, he sings and rants, with lucid nuggets surrounded by malarkey as he discourses on space aliens, sex, the International Monetary Fund and marijuana. Backed by the Robotiks band, and with one of his disciples, the Mad Professor, at the mixing board, Mr. Perry can carry listeners into his sonic hall of mirrors. Tonight and tomorrow night, Spring Heel Jack will be DJ from 9 to about 11, followed by Mr. Perry sometime around 11:30; tickets, $30 (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: HOUSTON PERSON AND ETTA JONES, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, Greenwich Village, (212) 255-4037. Talk about underrated. Mr. Person, a tenor saxophonist, and Ms. Jones, a singer, are a reminder of a time when jazz had more of a relationship to entertainment. Mr. Person is a tough, big tenor-saxophonist who likes the blues. Ms. Jones is one of the great exponents of the singing lineage that runs from Billie Holiday through Dinah Washington; fans of Erykah Badu take note. Ms. Jones can bring tears to the eye with one dry, longing note. Shows through Sunday are at 9:30, 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., with no third set on Sunday. There is a $15 cover and a $10 minimum (Watrous).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: RAILROAD JERK, THOMAS JEFFERSON SLAVE APARTMENTS, Brownies, 169 Avenue A, at 11th Street, East Village, (212) 420-8392. In a country grown up from as many scattered seeds as America, the notion of ''roots'' can never be completely contained. The wild-minded songwriters who lead these two bands use the most irreverent definition possible, tapping into a history of rebels, drunks, anarchist and gutter poets to build a sense of heritage that arm wrestles sentimentalism to the floor. Marcellus Hall of the East Village-based Railroad Jerk holds court in the dirty card room of lowlife heroics, while Ron House extols adulterous traveling salesmen. With Astabula. Tonight at 9; tickets, $8 (Powers).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: * TRIBUTE TO ELIS REGINA, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824. Elis Regina's death in 1982 deprived Brazilian music of its most revered singer, who brought delicacy and emotional depth to bossa novas, jazz and Brazilian pop. In this tribute concert, Nana Caymmi, a leading Brazilian jazz singer, is to be accompanied by members of Regina's band. Tonight at 8; tickets, $15 to $25 (Pareles).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: SERGIO VARGAS AND JERRY RIVERA, Copacabana, 617 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 582-2672. A double bill of two of the bigger Caribbean acts. Mr. Vargas is a merengue singer with hits and a strong live act. Mr. Rivera, every salsa purist's biggest nightmare, is a teen idol who is all yearning, with not much singing and no improvisation. Oh well, parties come in all shapes and sizes, and this one will be filled with young women who like Mr. Rivera's romanticism. The show tonight starts at 11; there is a $20 cover. Mr. Rivera will sing tomorrow night, as well, with Johnny Rivera. That show starts at 11; there is a $30 cover (Watrous).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: VOCAL GROUP WEEKEND, Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, Harlem, (212) 749-5838. These two nights of crooning and swooning should satisfy anyone's cravings for smooth yet fiery musical confessions. Tomorrow's concert features the Stylistics, Philadelphia's best tool for 1970's back-seat Casanovas; the Dramatics, who put a groovy love-child stamp on the Detroit Stax sound with songs like ''Watcha See Is Watcha Get,'' and the Chi-Lites, whose delirious tributes to love gone right proved that music can make you high. Sunday offers the Intruders, who helped songwriters Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff anticipate disco with their lush, light sound; the Persuaders, whose ''Thin Line Between Love and Hate'' remains the standard-bearer for soul realism; the Originals, who dripped manly sincerity in 1970's hits like ''Baby, I'm for Real''; the Floaters, whose ''Float On'' was the lava lamp of 1970's soul hits, and more. Tomorrow at 7 and 11 P.M.; tickets, $41, $36 and $31. Sunday at 3:30 and 7:30 P.M.; tickets, $46, $41 and $36 (Powers).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: LINK WRAY, SOUTHERN CULTURE ON THE SKIDS, Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 544-1666. At nearly 70, the original practitioner of electric guitar mayhem still can start a ''Rumble.'' Last time he played this club, he brought down the sweaty house with his chicken-scratch solos and Mack truck power chords. This time he will be joined by Southern Culture on the Skids, a group that took his legacy of down-home craziness and made it even more unruly. Wild dancing should ensue; beer will be spilled. Dress accordingly. With the Woggles. Tomorrow at 9 P.M.; tickets, $15 (Powers).
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

text: We’re sorry, we seem to have lost this page, but we don’t want to lose you. Report the broken link here.
title: American Topics

text: Bruce Seldon, a former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts of child endangerment, admitting he engaged in sexual activity with a 15-year-old girl after taking sexually provocative photographs of her, prosecutors in New Jersey said.
title: Seldon Pleads Guilty

text: During his plea in Superior Court in Camden, Seldon, 31, told Judge Stephen W. Thompson that he met the girl on a street in Atlantic City last November and took her back to his home in Gloucester Township, N.J., where they smoked marijuana.
title: Seldon Pleads Guilty

text: Leonard Baker, Seldon's lawyer, said his client did not know the girl was a minor when they met and contended that the boxer had no intention of breaking the law. He thought she was 18 or 20 years old, Baker said.
title: Seldon Pleads Guilty

text: Seldon remains free on a $50,000 bond pending sentencing on June 26. He faces a maximum of 10 years in prison.
title: Seldon Pleads Guilty

text: Seldon (33-4 with 29 knockouts) last fought on Sept. 7, 1996, when he lost his W.B.A. title to Mike Tyson in a 109-second bout at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas, Nev. ALAN FEUER
title: Seldon Pleads Guilty

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: Fugitive Sex Offender Is Arrested in Maine

text: A convicted sex offender who escaped from a New Jersey prison 19 years ago was captured late Monday in Maine after the authorities who had arrested him four days earlier on drug charges discovered that he was a fugitive.
title: Fugitive Sex Offender Is Arrested in Maine

text: David Maul walked away from the former Leesburg State Prison in Cumberland County in 1979 while serving a 10-year sentence for sexual assault, said Detective Lieut. Carl Gottardi of the Sheriff's Department in Somerset County, Me.
title: Fugitive Sex Offender Is Arrested in Maine

text: Mr. Maul, 47, formerly of Elizabeth, was arrested with his wife on April 30 for having 3,000 marijuana plants in their Maine home. He was released on $500 bail when a records search using his alias, Clyde W. Trout, showed no outstanding warrants, Detective Gottardi said.
title: Fugitive Sex Offender Is Arrested in Maine

text: But the local authorities became suspicious after finding an expired trapper's license issued to David Maul and an address book listing Maul family members in New Jersey, Detective Gottardi said. Mr. Maul was arrested on Monday at his home.
title: Fugitive Sex Offender Is Arrested in Maine

text: If Europe gave out an award to politicians who shoot themselves in the foot, President Jacques Chirac of France might take the prize.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Two years ago, Mr. Chirac announced that France would like to rejoin the military structure of the NATO alliance 30 years after it pulled out.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Then he immediately made that impossible by demanding for France the senior NATO post in the Mediterranean, the Southern Command in Naples. It had always been held by an American admiral, since it would control the United States Sixth Fleet in wartime, and after Washington inevitably refused to give up the post, France decided to stay where it is: half in and half out of NATO.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Last year, Mr. Chirac -- whose conservatives controlled both houses of Parliament, the Government in Paris and most regional assemblies -- threw the electoral dice and called national elections in a gamble to win a mandate for austerity moves to get France ready for a common European currency.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: The move was one of the most colossal blunders in French political history. Voters threw out Mr. Chirac's Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, and voted for a leftist majority in Parliament, forcing Mr. Chirac to share power with a Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: This year, the Gaullist parties that brought Mr. Chirac to the presidency three years ago have collapsed in recriminations about accepting support in regional assemblies from the far-right National Front. Even Paris, a Gaullist fief that Mr. Chirac ruled as Mayor for 18 years, is now in danger of falling to the Socialists in the next municipal elections in 2001.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: The President has long been nicknamed ''the bulldozer.'' Franz-Olivier Giesbert, a biographer, once wrote of him, ''Jacques Chirac charges through politics without baggage or memory.''
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: And when European Union leaders gathered here over the weekend to decide to start the new European currency next year, the bulldozer went into action again, with results that had even some French officials shaking their heads in disbelief when the rubble settled at about 2 o'clock this morning.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Only a few years ago, Mr. Chirac opposed the common currency as an unacceptable diminution of French sovereignty.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: But for more than two years now, he has been telling his compatriots that Europe needed a strong new currency to face up to the dollar on world financial markets and end the virtual dictation of international trading terms by the United States.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Germany, which has the strongest European currency to lose when the euro replaces the German mark four years from now, was a bit uneasy about the bluster.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: But Chancellor Helmut Kohl, battling for a fifth term in elections in September, needs to be able to reassure German voters that the euro will indeed be as sound as the mark, so he insisted on a European central banker with impeccable anti-inflationary credentials to run it: Wim F. Duisenberg of the Netherlands, which has pegged its currency to the mark since 1983.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Mr. Duisenberg was enthusiastically accepted as head of the new European central bank's predecessor institution in Frankfurt by all 15 European Union central bankers, including the President of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: But Mr. Chirac was furious at what he saw as an attempted coup d'etat by technocrats that would pre-empt him and his fellow European politicians from making the final decision. The Socialist Government, which wanted more political control over the independent European central bank anyway, supported him.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Mr. Chirac was also determined not to allow a candidate to be imposed by the Netherlands, a country that gave Mr. Chirac fits when he briefly resumed French nuclear testing in the Pacific in 1995.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: The Dutch Prime Minister, Willem Kok, has also irked Mr. Chirac by demonstrating a lenient attitude toward marijuana and hashish in Amsterdam, where drugs easily find their way to France now that continental Europe has all but eliminated border controls.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Last year, Mr. Chirac nominated Mr. Trichet to run the new bank when it starts operations on July 1.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: He maintained the nomination even after it became clear this year that only France among the 11 countries that will adopt the new currency was not prepared to accept Mr. Duisenberg for a full eight-year term.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Mr. Chirac bulldozed on even after Hans Tietmeyer, the head of the German central bank, Finance Minister Theo Waigel and other German leaders warned that his dissension was weakening the European central bank, and potentially the euro.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: And he chugged into Brussels this weekend, his Socialist Finance Minister and Foreign Minister beside him, determined to force France's 14 European Union partners to agree to a compromise under which, if Mr. Trichet could not have the central bank presidency for the full eight years, he would at least have it for four.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: On Saturday, Mr. Chirac was relentless in 12 hours of what a spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain called ''hard pounding'' for the only solution France would accept: an accord to let Mr. Duisenberg have an eight-year term but agree to step down after four years and be replaced by Mr. Trichet.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Mr. Waigel and Mr. Kohl fought the move as a fatal weakening of the statutory independence of the central bank laid down in the 1992 European Union Treaty to protect it from precisely this kind of political interference.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: But in the end, they gave in, accepting a declaration by Mr. Duisenberg about his wish to retire before the end of his term that sounded like the kind of confession prisoners of war have been known to sign after prolonged torture.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: ''I want to underline that this is my decision and only my decision,'' said Mr. Duisenberg's statement, which was greeted with incredulous laughter by French, German and other journalists when Mr. Chirac and Mr. Kohl read it to them.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: French and Belgian officials attributed some of the fiasco to the way that Prime Minister Blair presided over the discussions. Britain, though not in the common currency, holds the rotating European Union presidency until July 1, and some Francophones thought perfidious Albion might have been trying to sabotage the euro before exhausted leaders finally proclaimed it in the wee hours this morning.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: ''It's not good at all for the European central bank to begin like that,'' said Jose Maria Gil Robles, the President of the European Parliament, one of many who warned that the credibility of the bank, and therefore of the euro itself, could be badly damaged by the battle Mr. Chirac waged to put a Frenchman at the bank's head after 2002.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: Some economists argue that if Mr. Chirac had deliberately set out to weaken the euro and strengthen the dollar, he could not have found a better strategy. Time and the money markets will tell.
title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

text: It was the pot smokers versus the baby toters in Greenwich Village yesterday, and the smokers lost. Nudged along by an imposing cadre of police officers, marchers at a pro-marijuana rally yielded Washington Square Park to mimes, face-painters and ponies at the first city-sponsored Family Day in the park.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: In a striking symbol of changed times, a corporate sponsor of the family event was Rolling Stone magazine, which provided a stunt-bicycle demonstration.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: For the last 27 years, May Day had been J-Day -- Joint Day -- in the park, where thousands of pot smokers rallied in support of their favorite controlled substance. But yesterday they massed nostalgically across the street, jeering sporadically at two video surveillance cameras that the police credit with helping run drug dealers out of the park.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: Later, the demonstrators shambled glumly downtown to Battery Park, where their Million Marijuana March had been relegated by city officials. ''Giuliani's a Dope. Pot Is an Herb,'' the posters read.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: ''It's '1984' in 1998,'' lamented Dana Beal, 51, the organizer of the pro-marijuana march, which he said this year had the added purpose of ''mourning the passing of the Village as we once knew it.''
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: Vince Strautmanis, 38, a stockbroker and father of six who was pushing a stroller past a marionette show, remembered coming to the park for the annual marijuana rally when he was a student. ''It was one big cloud,'' he said, sounding almost wistful. ''It was like Woodstock.''
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: Not anymore. More than 60 police officers -- on foot, bicycle and horse -- lined up outside the New York University Student Center before heading into the park. Most of the marijuana fans quietly watched the cheerleaders and jugglers, but whenever a knot of them gathered, police officers put barricades around them, much to the demonstrators' amusement.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: A police sergeant took one look at Sebastian Sabino, 17, who was wearing a mushroom around his neck, and told him: ''Battery Park.'' When Mr. Sabino asked the officer where that was, she replied, ''First Precinct.'' Mr. Sabino took it in stride. ''It's all about peace, man,'' he said.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: The day started with a vocabulary lesson for the kids, as George Miranda, 24, shouted an obscenity about Family Day when the master of ceremonies began his welcome. ''Those people took away our party,'' Mr. Miranda said as he stalked away. ''We should pack our bowls, spark up and invade the park.''
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: The park's signature -- an arch flanked by statues of George Washington -- is surrounded by chain link and scaffolding while it is restored. But the culture of the park itself has been under reconstruction since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took office in 1994 and instituted vigorous patrols and drug stings, and posted signs saying no drugs, no drinking, no biking, no skating, no pets, no radios. For good measure, another sign says, ''Quiet Zone.''
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: It worked, and on Friday Mr. Giuliani crowed about the very idea of a Family Day in the park. While acknowledging that some drug-dealing remains and that the Police Department ''has a lot more work to do'' there, Mr. Giuliani said, ''Decent people can now use Washington Square Park and not get assaulted.''
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: The authorities said Family Day drew about 8,000 people. The police said about 1,500 people attended the marijuana rally in Battery Park, while organizers put the figure at 5,000. At City Hall, Mr. Giuliani pronounced the march a bust. ''When you get this kind of small number in New York City, you virtually don't have a following,'' he said.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: Mr. Beal works out of a garret on Bleecker Street, where the faded paint outside still says, ''The Yipster Times.'' He and his followers have staged a marijuana rally in the park every year beginning in 1973 -- each time with a permit, except last year, when they held what a city spokesman called ''an illegal assembly.''
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: Robert J. O'Sullivan, co-chairman of a neighborhood group called Parents for Playgrounds, which sponsored Family Day with the city's Parks Department, decided that was not going to happen again. ''I told them straight out, 'We don't want you coming into the park,' '' Mr. O'Sullivan said.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: So yesterday the park was turned over to McGruff, a putting green and a soccer clinic. Paul De Rienzo, 41, a leader of the marijuana march and editor in chief of High Times magazine, denounced the parents for ''using their own children as props for their political agenda.''
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: The marijuana event drew Grateful Dead fans from throughout the East Coast, with a large contingent of high-school students from Westchester County and New Jersey.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: Many broke out their plastic bags and smoked marijuana openly when they first arrived at Battery Park, beneath the shimmering skyscrapers of the Financial District. But they mellowed out as police officers swarmed into the park, several wielding video cameras. Some of the demonstrators turned their own video cameras on the officers. Most just lay back in the grass and listened to the reggae music booming from a stage, interspersed with calls to legalize marijuana. At the end of the day, the police said they had made 69 arrests for possession of marijuana.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: Despite the event's ambitious name, the marijuana group said it had expected a turnout only in the thousands, and billed yesterday's rally as ''a full-dress rehearsal'' for May Day 1999, when they hope to finish the job. ''Go ye forth and bring us back a million people,'' Mr. Beal told the crowd.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: He said he planned to apply to use the Great Lawn at Central Park.
title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park

text: Hemp has grown on the public in recent years. Restaurants that cook with hemp byproducts, designers who weave the fiber into clothing and micro-breweries bottling hemp beer have tried to alter the image of the versatile crop, which is banned in the United States because of its association with marijuana. Now the Body Shop has entered the fray: it is offering to heal dry skin and foment a ''fiber revolution'' with a line of moisturizing products containing hemp-seed oil. It arrives in United States stores this month.
title: PULSE; Dry Times? Try Hemp

text: Hemp seeds, said Anita Roddick, the Body Shop founder, contain the highest concentration of essential fatty acids in the plant world, making them a natural for healing customers' dry skin. (No, it will not get them high.) Asked what she hopes to achieve with the line -- products include Elbow Grease and 3 in 1 Oil ($4.95 to $9.95) -- Ms. Roddick said, ''A change in the law and a nation of less-dry skins.'' Because of hemp oil's novelty, the Food and Drug Administration, which regulates cosmetics, says it has no information on it and cannot comment on its effectiveness as a moisturizer. But it is not listed in the International Cosmetic Ingredient Dictionary, the definitive source compiled by raw-material suppliers.
title: PULSE; Dry Times? Try Hemp

text: ON Sunday, April 5, the artist Ralph Steadman and the director Terry Gilliam, who are friends, met at Mr. Steadman's house in the English countryside to talk about Mr. Gilliam's new movie, ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,'' which opens on May 22. Based on the landmark 1971 document of American cultural disequilibrium that was written by Hunter S. Thompson and illustrated by Mr. Steadman, the film stars Johnny Depp as Mr. Thompson's alter ego, Raoul Duke, and Benicio Del Toro as his partner-in-lunacy, Dr. Gonzo, who go on a drug- and alchohol-fueled jaunt into the desert in a crimson convertible. To capture the 2 1/2-hour conversation, which careered from topic to topic -- the movie, the book, art, film, old times, drugs and the idiosyncrasies of Mr. Thompson -- Mr. Steadman set up four tape recorders and a video recorder. ''Appropriately, it is a work about paranoia,'' Mr. Steadman explained. Here are excerpts.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: RALPH STEADMAN. I was just going to read this to you, and then start: '' 'Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas' was never a book; it was, and is, one man's attempt to come to terms with the loneliness of pure perception. In his heroic attempt to escape the dark morass of America's screaming life style, he sold his soul to the Devil for one moment of happiness. Like Faust, he lives in mortal torment, but unlike Faust, he quite enjoys it.'' He would, wouldn't he?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: TERRY GILLIAM. When did you write that?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Oh, I wrote that some while ago. The book, to me, when I read it again, is so dense and so complete in itself that it defies you to make it into a film.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. No, that's exactly the problem. That's why we [Mr. Gilliam and Tony Grisoni] wrote the thing in eight days because -- I hate that book, because you sit there and you have this responsibility of taking this fantastic melange of stuff, with Hunter, who is dangerous and waiting in the wings. And you have got to try and make this thing into a film. So what do we do? We just work really fast. In fact, we try to do what he did, just go for it, and we just started grouting bits out of the book, sticking them together.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: I really hated the responsibility of trying to deal with that thing, because just by being totally disrespectful was the only way we could respect the thing.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: We made a structure because the thing does have structural problems, and then -- boom! -- it was finished. And every time I looked back at the book I got really depressed because there were all these bits that were left out. I just think films are really limited in what you can do.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Do you mean they are a kind of shorthand, do you think?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Yes, they are. They're getting crazier because they are really simplistic. The stories you can tell in a film are a fraction of what you can do in a book. What's irritating is that you then do these things, and films have their own kind of structure. The thing dictates certain paces, no matter what you do. That's only because we're trying to make a film that reaches people; I mean I don't try to make a film for me -- I can't. Well, I do make it for me, but it's trying to reach people, and the sense of this thing was to try to get people to have a sense of time and place that doesn't exist anymore. And so you come to the point at which you have got to communicate with the audience and you've got to keep them alive -- because I think it's about juggling balls.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Or maybe it's more or less like juggling chainsaws.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. But the more you read the book, the more intelligent it becomes. Its strength is in its reflectiveness.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. They were serious people. Hunter was a serious journalist, Oscar [Dr. Gonzo] was a serious lawyer, and the book, that's the thing they're famous for, and yet it seems to be more of a wild rant. I don't give a damn about it, because, you know, that's the book we were making. I think it is serious, but people don't see that when they first read it; they just get the thrills and the spills. But he lurches. I mean, bang, bang, bang, thought-blast, and then he stops there in panic, and then, pant, pant, he goes quiet, like a little animal sitting there and thinking.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. And so we said, Well, he's some kind of modern Christ, who has gone and suffered for the sins of our nation in some strange way.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. And practiced a few of them himself on the way!
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Well, let's say he's very much alive still. He was leaning over your shoulder there. Did you have to forget that, and say, Well, I am making up the film I want to make now, and did he have anything to do with the script, for instance?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. You showed it to him?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Yes. This is the problem with adapting a thing because there's Hunter, there's the book, there's all the people that have read it who have got their ideas about what it is, and then, well, what about me? I'm spending a year of my life making this thing. I've got to put me in it somewhere, or I've got to be like the conductor. There's the symphony, it's written -- say, Mozart wrote it -- but I have got to conduct it the way I want.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Sure, yes, but you see you've got to be true to yourself, but did you allow him on the set at all?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Well, I really did keep him at bay because I was nervous about him. Johnny was frightened about him. We were all scared because of this responsibility. We really respect him to the point that we don't want to disappoint him, but on the other hand it's like this scene at the end where this girl -- he was on the phone to me, it was the one bit in the script he didn't like. He said, ''It makes me look like, ah, a pederast!''
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. You have to be a dictator on your own set, haven't you? It's your picture. It's like your painting.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Yeah, its got to be, but it's weird. If you're doing da Vinci, if you are doing ''The Last Supper,'' I mean, on the one hand you are very respectful of it but on the other hand you are doing your version of it, and there's this war going on. So I had to become Hunter Thompson.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Using Johnny Depp as your tool, and you manipulate him.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. And you interpret all you're doing. It became a film full of artifacts and talismans, and Johnny was wearing Hunter's clothes. He was driving the Red Shark. He drove the Red Shark down and then, of course, we actually used Hunter's Red Shark in the film, but it's a '73 Chevy and the book was actually written in '71, and yet everybody was saying, ''Ah, the real thing!''
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. There came a time in your career -- I'm thinking now, after the Monty Python films; I guess ''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'' was the beginning of the blooding of you as a director.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. The beginning of the end!
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. It was ''either I'm going to be an artist or I'm going to be a film director,'' and then you did ''Jabberwocky'' and ''The Adventures of Baron Munchausen,'' which you thought about like an illustrator would think about.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: And then I thought, Well, I wonder if part of you, when you're working on films, is saying, Well, I wish I could be drawing. So, do you try to draw with the camera in that way?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. You do. You compose with the camera, let's put it that way. It's like a collage, but you're making a film, so you don't know all the bits. They're not all together till you actually get them together on the day with the actors, the costumes, the lights, the sets, and then you're trying to do it, and you've only got eight hours to do the scene. That's why the exercise is very different than drawing.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. You said the film is darker and funnier than the book.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. I think it is, but to be honest I haven't a clue.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Too close to it?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. At that point you can't see it any more, and I'm close, so I rely on other people, and I was getting it from other people that it was darker and funnier than the book. I wouldn't say it was funnier than the book, but they do, because there's a lot of physical humor in it. Johnny's funny.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. But what's so funny about it? I keep thinking it's an act, most of it. Hunter has to push it to the limit, he has to make it uglier, he has to make it more extreme. He has to make it more manic, more everything, because life isn't really as bad as that. He's actually had a pretty good life, and it's like he keeps pushing its real doom -- everything's all doom. But he's been one of the luckiest people on the planet, in a sense, and I share that and I think you do, too. We've all lived rather comfortable lives.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Well I think that's what Hunter goes for -- it's the jugular. It comes of guilt. He goes for it in everybody, which is why I have thought about this trick of his, which is a cathartic trick: he's trying to exorcise from himself the very thing he loves and hated in America. He both hated the lousy, cheap, taco front and he adores its frontier spirit, which still exists -- at least, it still exists in his mind.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. He is an outrageous romanticist, a huge romantic about America, and a hugely self-absorbed person as well. That's why he thinks he's the Messiah in a strange way. He's God, he's God.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. He's a Messiah of a kind.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. And they come to the mountain all the time, and he's stuck in there. I think that's a sad side of Hunter's: he's stuck in time. I keep saying the guy died around 1974, and the guy that's here is this mummified version of him. He has to keep living a life, and being here.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. To me it was all like watching, well, not Wonderland, but what I thought of as a screaming life style, and it was a remarkable world. I think that's why, now, you're making your film. It's so well-timed, because it's like putting a screwdriver in the back of a TV set to see if it'll do something else. That's what you are doing. You are jangling up a whole society with this film.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: And also, the film industry -- it's full of suited people who are not in any way wild enough to think back to the laid-back days of the 70's. Some of them are too young to remember anyway. You'll have two kinds of audiences. I think you are going to have a new young, and . . .
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: An audience our age -- and beyond. Old heavies, you know. Yes, I think so, and they're going to be loving it. They'll have to have special cinemas set aside for marijuana smokers -- you know: ''No smoking. Only marijuana''
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. What's so awful about making a film like this is that there's the book, everyone's got expectations, you write a script that you think captures it, then you start doing it, and we're working to a very tight schedule with all the problems of making a film, and no chance of going back, and then you run madly trying to do what you can do, and the day comes that you're doing the great magnum scene. Actually we had a wonderful location, which we couldn't get to, so literally this scene was about to be cut out of the film, the scene where he decided he's got to go back to Vegas, and we found these other rocks we hadn't seen, so we rushed down there.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: We were running up and down with this camera. The car got stuck in the sand. Johnny's not arrived yet. All this is going on, and the sun's going down ding, ding, ding behind a hill, and we're running higher and higher up this hill trying to get the last ray of sun.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. But we got the shot, and it's interesting because it's not what we intended to do, so the business of making a film and making it as cheaply and fast as we made this one means you never know if you've done it or if you've failed.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue
