text: STEADMAN. Yes, but you're not going to show it till you feel ready, and I don't want to see it till you are ready.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. I don't want you and Hunter and all those guys to be involved in the last bit because there are going to be so many things not there that you are familiar with.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. But I don't think I'll miss them, because I've forgotten so many things.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. And it's very strange. One of the things about the film that's interesting -- it's one thing to read it on the page, but another thing when you see it. And now that it's darker, when the [test] audience turns in their opinion cards, the vomiting is number one on the negative list.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. There's a scene where they find Lucy and Dr. Gonzo says, ''I have a powerful lust for bread, so I must go and find a seafood restaurant, and a powerful lust for red salmon.'' Then it just cuts to their driving away from the little Graceland wedding chapel in Vegas, with all these nice people getting married, and suddenly you cut from this chocolate-box kind of scene to looking right down a flamingo-colored toilet bowl, and a full stomachful going down -- pow! And it's running out of his eyes, and it's great!
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: It's trying to get visual nightmares going where it's not extreme psychedelia or distortion, it's real. And that was what was so awful about it, it was so real. Except that it's twisted. And that's why a lot of the stuff we have in it is real. The scene with the bathtub, there's nothing odd about it except that he's sitting there in his very expensive jacket with a tie on, and his underwear, and grapefruit rinds floating, and the color of the water, and the bathroom is pink, it's flamingo pink, so you've got this filth, and this guy trying to get this tie off, and so -- it's literal. It's just a man in a bathtub and the dirt is just there. The drug taking is so ugly and disturbing that I don't think it's going to add one more addict to the world out there. Nor will it take one drug addict away.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. It's a feature of the book though, anyway. It's always there; you pay and take the full ride, and if you want to do that you're likely to get in a bad way.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. As for my first reading that book -- I'd actually left the States by then and was living in England; I left the States in '67. And I'd left for many of the same reasons he wrote that book. The times changed in an ugly way. There were things like, Where do you go, or do you stay in there and confront it, and deal with it, like he did? Or do you escape like a coward, like I did? And end up coming to England and drawing cartoons. This is what I thought I was better at, rather than taking to the streets and waving placards like other people. When that book came out, it was, to me, incredibly powerful -- this incredible rereading, in a sense -- a powerful voice saying in some way what I was feeling, with all the humor and all the madness and all the despair all rolled into the one thing.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Nietzsche said, ''We possess art, lest we perish from the truth.'' It's like this book. It's art, so let's face it, it's art. And your film is art. It's not the truth, but, boy, it has elements of the truth because it's film.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. That's one of the things that bothers me about film: it seems real. It's more literal and naturalistic than any other art form we play in, I suppose. People think it's real and I hate that.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. But what I find you often do with your films is you've been wonderful at marrying a kind of Gothic fantasy with reality. You marry the two, and I think that's your way of storytelling, as if to say, Look, I want you to accept a little magic somewhere.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. But this film, how do you do the drug scenes? Well, you can do them in a very fantastical, phantasmagorical way, or you can just say, Well, there they are, and things are happening. I got obsessed with carpets when we first went to Vegas. It's the patterns of the carpets in Vegas. All I could see was these patterns. They were psychedelic. They were huge. They shouldn't be that big. And so I got a scene where he's checking in and he's looking down and the carpets are all tendrils beginning to move, and vegetal patterns that start moving and crawling up the walls.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: What I do, I start with the same thing, then I usually do little storyboards, so they're starting the thing, and then I make little sketches, then I've got to get all these other people and they come up with as many ideas as I do. That's a critical thing: you think I made the film; I didn't make the film; I was the filter if I am anything.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. And is the script a skeleton, or is it pretty well kept to?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. No, you keep to it. You've got to be organized. It's like an army. You've got all these departments, and they've got to keep marching.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. The stuff we've had to cut out: the whole scene with the D.A. from Georgia, we shot it and it's cut out of the film. This is a thing that happens, and it's a thing I'm still trying to get a sense of, and that's why you show it to audiences and get their reactions. At a certain point they can't take it anymore -- even the ones that are on our side. It becomes too much.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. A case of too much reality, as T. S. Eliot says, ''Man can't stand too much reality''
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. You don't want that. So that's where we are now, trying to find the balance. It makes me crazy, because it always happens at the time when you're most tired, and you're too familiar with the film.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. You know, there comes a point, I guess, when you've been so close to it, and particularly in post-production, when you can't see it any more, and you've lost the sense of judgment that you had perhaps and very clear, at the beginning. What I was amazed at was that you actually came up with a script in eight days. That was the most amazing.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Yes, well, we just worked so fast at it. It was just a way of dealing with the pain of being a scriptwriter. We became beastly to deal with. We actually wrote it even faster, and then we read it and didn't like it, and rewrote it in two days, and of course we've fiddled ever since. Either we've got it better or we've not. I just know we've made a choice, and the film is done, and that's kind of---- For 25 years it's been hanging around, and people not getting it done, for a variety of reasons.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. You wouldn't want to make it again in another format? You feel good about it?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. I'm fed up with it.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Yes, you are. You would be.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: But your films, would you say that they're first pure entertainment, and then, perhaps, have a message, or do you want them as pure entertainment?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. No, I don't think they're pure entertainment; rather they're impure entertainment. No, I want people to go in and sit there for a couple of hours. Entertainment, I always used to say, is like Mary Poppins, whom I believed in most of all -- a spoonful of sugar, etc. So we keep the sugar there, always engaged, I mean, you're trying to engage people and keep them interested and enjoying it enough, so that you can then hit them with things. I just like the idea of leaving shrapnel stuck in them after they leave the cinema, or little time bombs that are going to explode in them a couple of days late.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: You don't bore them though, you don't put them to sleep. It's like someone came out of ''The Fisher King'' -- a girl told me she walked home and she couldn't find her own home, she'd been walking in the wrong direction, and she'd done this route every day of her life. Something about that film possessed her and she just started walking. The great thing in New York was watching people coming out of that film and looking at New York again, looking up, looking at the skyline and at the great incredible city, because they hadn't seen it for a long time, looking up, down, everywhere.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. A lot of people have told me that's one of the greatest pieces of cinema they've ever seen.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Ridiculously romantic! I think that's one of the things we share in the same way, and certainly Hunter's in there. We were disturbed by life and disappointed by life, and angered by life. But we really want it to be wonderful.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: Did you see a film called ''Institute Benjamenta?'' [a surrealistic 1996 film by the Quay brothers]. It's feature length, and it's stunning to look at. Nobody went to see it. That's what I meant about people -- I just don't know how one communicates. It's trying to re-educate people; it seems to me the job to do.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. But then if you start to re-educate, you're telling them to do something.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Well, that's the problem, so maybe you don't re-educate them, you excite them, maybe, and they go on to educate themselves. Maybe you open a door for them.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. I mean, all you can do is to arouse curiosity, get someone to say Why is that doing that in that particular scene or that painting? If people have to ask why that train is coming out of the fireplace, then they don't understand surrealism, do they?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. But perhaps they will. You see, it should start in school. It's not taught as a serious subject, art appreciation, visual things.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Do you remember that huge exhibition at the Tate, maybe 20 years ago?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. It was the first time I'd seen Magritte in bulk, and then I saw he was a jokesmith, a brilliant jokesmith. The stuff was so funny, and I remember walking around and everything was so quiet, and if it were a church, as if art had become religion now, and these hushed tones, and I started laughing. I couldn't stop laughing. It was wonderful, and these people were so desperate to take it seriously, to worship the stuff, that they lost the joy of it all.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. Incidentally, I've tried to explain what Gonzo is in my book. As I've said, Hunter doesn't know what it is. He tried and can't do it. I've also said Gonzo was good, but if you produce a certain kind of Gonzo and make me sick, that's Banzo, that's bad. Banzo is bad and Gonzo is good.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. When I first met Hunter, there was a bottle of Chivas, a bottle of wine, a can of beer, I think. There was a tin of coke. He had his hash -- what else did he have?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: STEADMAN. He snorts whiskey, too. Have you seen him clean his nose with whiskey?
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: GILLIAM. Now, Johnny, Johnny was up in San Francisco accompanying Hunter and Hunter's back went out, so Johnny was stuck up there for a week in a hotel room and Johnny said, ''The world comes to Hunter.''
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: A man came, what was his name, something like Raimundo, and he said, ''I do things,'' and he gave him a card. And later on, they met at some bar, and they're all registered under false names, Hunter and Johnny; they're in the hotel room and Hunter's lying on his back, going crazy because he's in pain and can't move, and then he hears Dobermans in the hall and Johnny's freaking out and he goes out into the hall, and there's a card under the door: ''Raimundo. I do things.''
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: And they had no idea how he found them, which led to the paranoia being even greater, because they felt they were being surrounded. But paranoia is Hunter's meat, it's what he lives on.
title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue

text: IT seems like a movie now, that day in March when mankind was forced to drop its puny temporal concerns for a moment and contemplate the unthinkable: a reliable report that the end might be nigh. And like a movie, this brush with destiny had a happy ending. Within 24 hours of hearing the dark news that an approaching asteroid as wide as the Mississippi had an outside chance of hitting Earth in 2028, the world got word that the initial projections on the big rock's path had been off by, oh, 500,000 miles. In short, never mind.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: But the scare was real while it lasted, and if it wasn't quite the day the Earth stood still, it was a moment imaginations ran wild. Suddenly people were discussing, in earnest, extinction. They were fearing for the children, asking searching existential questions, falling back lamely on gallows humor about cashing out their I.R.A.'s. The refrain of the day came with a slow shake of the head: ''Can you imagine?''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: The answer, of course, was of course. Given a scenario, even a doomsday one, ordinary humans can be relied on somehow to be able to picture themselves in it. What images they come up with would naturally be as varied as the minds that conjure them, but they'd be vivid, and in the case of Armageddon, nightmarish; we're good at thinking the worst.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: Not that any of this does Hollywood any good. Hollywood exists to imagine for us. And given the proper tool, it will do all it can to be as graphic as mechanically possible, leaving no gaps that may tax the audience to fill. Today, the tool handed Hollywood is easily the most extraordinary one introduced there since the camera: C.G.I. That's studio talk for computer-generated imaging, known to the rest of us as the latest in special effects. And well we know them. Too well, perhaps.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: The wizards who produce the magic have been awing or amusing us for years, each time out with ever more amazing tricks. There were stampeding dinosaurs in ''Jurassic Park.'' There was a bottomless city in ''The Fifth Element.'' There were armies of insects in ''Starship Troopers.'' And who can be allowed to forget a certain sinking ship? The computer is king, and if there is one mantra in the houses that create the effects, it is this: If you can think it, we can make it.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: The products of such ingenuity unfailingly fill the screens in summer, when Earth and the Sun and supply and demand move into a kind of congenial alignment. Movies heavy in special effects are made mostly for the kids, after all, and come June, kids in the millions are in restless need of diversion. Then there is the general torpor of the season. As the theory goes, people just want to get out of the heat, sink back in one of those pleasantly springy multiplex seats, plunk a jumbo Pepsi in the cup holder, log off the brain and watch some action, any action.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: Now we're on the brink of another supposed season of sloth, and the movie moguls couldn't have asked for a more timely one. If planetary existence is a crapshoot, the appearance of the asteroid, from Hollywood's standpoint, came up a seven. In not one but two strokes of blind luck, the studios are rolling out a pair of cinematic imaginings of galactic collision, movies in the works long before the March headlines broke. One is ''Deep Impact,'' opening Friday; the other, ''Armageddon,'' waiting in the wings for July. Together they arrive as if to assure us that if we somehow failed to absorb the potential gravity, as it were, of the asteroid scare, Sister Hollywood will explain it all to us -- and show us exactly, through special effects, what might have happened.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: Indeed, the films' depictions of an ''extinction level event,'' as ''Deep Impact'' terms it, promise to be so convincing that they could well enter the collective imagination as definitive visions of how the world might end. And for those in the audience who have recurring nightmares about tidal waves, a truly awe-inspiring wall of water that curls over the peaks of Manhattan (moviedom's favorite concentration of sitting ducks) and swamps the Eastern Seaboard in ''Deep Impact'' may provide an indelible nocturnal leitmotif.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: IF that's not enough digital spectacle to occupy the masses this summer, there will be more. A 20-story-tall reptile will make Manhattan its stomping ground in a remake of ''Godzilla.'' Toy soldiers will wage war on a front lawn in ''Small Soldiers.'' A comic-book hero will draw blood from vampires in ''Blade.'' Then comes fall, and still more; the pipeline has a waiting list. Special effects have even spread to television, from prime time to commercials: see Merlin the magician converse with a mountain; see Wall Street become a rolling surf of asphalt.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: Will it ever end? Of course not. But that's no reason not to ask, Have we had enough yet? Which is to say, Are we not becoming bored with all this computer-generated excitement?
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: As to the first question, the box office numbers would seem to argue no. As to the second, there you get opinions.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: To hear Alan Caruba tell it, he speaks for the thinking filmgoer when he says the riot of special effects now dominating so many movies -- especially of the flesh-ripping, metal-crunching kind -- have become a bore. As the founder and sole member of the Boring Institute, a spoof of an enterprise with a serious intent based in suitably uneventful Maplewood, N.J., Mr. Caruba, a publicity agent by trade, monitors pop culture for the tedious, the trite and the shallow and skewers it in a newsletter that Hollywood reporters love to quote, especially around Academy Awards time. This year he singled out special effects for a yawn. ''I've done call-in radio shows all over the world, and I can tell you I haven't heard a dissent,'' he says.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: ''Nobody disputes that the effects are extraordinary,'' Mr. Caruba allows, ''but we seem to have a generation of filmmakers dependent on special effects as opposed to the basic staple of a good film, which is a good story. I can appreciate a good special effect if it's integral to the film. But this is an era of Hollywood that assumes the audience has the attention span of fungus.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: It may not be a stretch to say that the movies that peddle the digital pyrotechnics engage in a kind of technological pornography. That is, not only do the effects leave little to the imagination; they also never really satisfy, even though people may keep going back for more. And they often wind up repeating themselves from movie to movie (think of all those spaceships suggestive of engine blocks with wings), creating a whole new field of visual cliches.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: THIS isn't to say that all the effects are alike. Esthetically they run from cheesy and noisy to plain beautiful to behold. The best of them may even leave an imprint on the imagination: the biblically wrathful storms in ''Twister,'' the magnificent mother ship in ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind.'' But a barrage of even the most technically brilliant sights can leave you feeling only pummeled.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: ''I think special effects do become numbing,'' says the cultural observer and author Neal Gabler, who is completing a book entitled ''Life the Movie: How Entertainment Conquered Reality.'' ''But the analogy I would use is drug addiction. There's always a new drug that comes along because the old high isn't enough anymore. You want to ratchet up the experience somehow, going from marijuana to cocaine to heroin to PCP, saying, This is more intense, this is better. Special effects work the same way. We're constantly climbing the ladder of 'Can you top this, we've seen this, what can you do for me now?' ''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: In Mr. Gabler's view, then, it's the audience's need that drives the technology rather than the other way around. ''It's not so much a case of, 'We can do this, therefore we'll do it' as, 'This is what the audience wants, therefore we'll do it,' '' he says.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: And all the audience has to do is sit back and be a receptor. ''The audience doesn't have to do anything,'' Mr. Gabler says. ''In this sense films have colonized the imagination.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: The complaint is a longstanding one, coming into currency about the time film was invented. Movies, early critics said, would erode our wondrous ability, in communion with a writer, to piece together entire imaginary worlds from nothing but words on a printed page. The introduction of sound chiseled away even further at our imaginative powers, or so the skeptics said. Then came color, and on it went.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: The issue was alive in 1947 when the novelist and screenwriter Budd Schulberg wrote: ''To most Hollywood executives, the safest stories still seem to be those which do the people's dreaming for them. . . . Away from your troubles, away from your responsibilities and your punch-in-punch-out monotony, you sit there in the enveloping darkness and let DeMille or some other genius of mediocrity spin out for you a million-dollar dream.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: MOVIES were just one pop-culture product that the art critic Clement Greenberg had in mind 60 years ago when he drew a seminal distinction between art and kitsch, borrowing a German epithet for tacky excess. To Greenberg, movies, as examples of kitsch, gratified demands for pleasure without making demands of their own, and by doing all the work on behalf of the public, they betrayed art's duty to make people think.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: That may be an overly harsh judgment on the entire film industry. But it certainly may apply to ''Terminator 2: Judgment Day,'' which added morphing to the national lexicon in 1991, or even the hyped-to-the-heavens ''Independence Day.'' Here were movies in which special effects overwhelmed what story there was. A liquid alien in one film or an exploding White House in the other may have been fun to watch, but they supported narratives with about as much staying power as comic books, or video games. Should anyone care? Mr. Gabler does, as do others who believe that telling a story visually doesn't mean you have to show everything.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: ''The danger I see is to narrative storytelling itself,'' he says. ''If you don't have to worry about character, about plot development -- everything that has traditionally helped to elicit a response from us -- then we lose one of the great joys and values of artistic achievement, the narrative pleasure.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: Special effects also tend to loosen the joints of our willing suspension of disbelief, another staple of stage and screen, leaving the audience oddly alienated from the very drama, or comedy, to which it is asked to respond emotionally. As Mr. Caruba says: ''One part of our brain is simply admiring how they achieved this or that effect. You're always aware that this is coming out of a computer.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: The big-budget movie makers who showcase the effects say they agree that technology should never supplant story; they insist, though, that the ''visual enhancements'' are indispensable to the stories they're trying to tell. ''We couldn't make this movie without these effects,'' says Jerry Bruckheimer, the producer of ''Armageddon.'' ''But it's ultimately about characters. The special effects will just lure you in. Look at 'Independence Day': if it didn't have the Will Smith character, I don't think it would have been as successful.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: To Mimi Leder, the director of ''Deep Impact,'' the digital effects serve her story, not the other way around. ''This is about people facing the end of the world, facing awesome choices, and it forces you to ask, what would you do?''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: Could she have done the movie without special effects? ''Not a movie about a tidal wave,'' she says. ''You need the effects to support this kind of story.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: Even a producer and screenwriter with impressive art-house credentials like James Schamus tends to support Ms. Leder's position. ''Creating filmic worlds in which there are monsters and explosions and extraordinary weather is no more a deterrent to good storytelling than having to hire an actor for $20 million,'' he says.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: He points out that although audiences may not have noticed, special effects were used in two recent literary films on which he worked: ''Sense and Sensibility'' and ''The Ice Storm.'' ''We filmed the actual ice storm in August,'' he says. And in a stranded-buggy scene in ''Sense and Sensibility,'' a veil of mist upon an English pond was created digitally in a New York studio.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: ''I think we're talking about two kinds of films here,'' Mr. Schamus says. ''There are special effects that are used to enhance the image or the story line, to fix things or underscore some emotional aspect of the film, and there is the other side, when special effects are in fact the stars of the movie.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: ''In 'Titanic,' '' he says, ''you were seeing a movie starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Kate Winslet and Digital Domain,'' one of the big special effects houses that the studios hire.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: The digital factories have heard the complaints before, of course. Jim Morris, president of Lucas Digital, the corporate parent of another powerhouse special-effects studio, Industrial Light and Magic, both of which were brainchildren of the modern guru of the field, George Lucas, concedes that Hollywood may be thinking digitally too much. ''Any time there's been a new technology introduced to cinema,'' he says, ''there's been perhaps an overuse of it before it settles into a tool that serves story and character well.''
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: And that's to be expected of any medium ''in its infancy,'' Mr. Morris says. He likens many of Hollywood's special-effects extravaganzas to a roller-coaster ride -- an example of what he calls ''effects for effects' sake.'' Movies like these will doubtless be around as long as there are 14-year-old boys to watch them, but Mr. Morris believes that a more mature use of the technology is as inevitable as a child's growing up.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: His analogy reminds me of a day years ago when, swept along by the rush of teen-age hormones, a friend and I rode a roller coaster at a beachside amusement park at least a half-dozen consecutive times. The experience was harrowing at first, to be sure, but once we got used to it, the ride became simply hysterical fun, and we became commensurately fearless; we even stopped holding on. By the last time, though, even the laughter had ebbed and, having had enough, we went on to more serious pursuits, in the direction of girls on the boardwalk.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: I mention this story not because it's inherently interesting but because it finally isn't. I could try to describe those rides in thrilling detail, employing every pyrotechnic word I could think of, but in the end I would be offering just an account of bodies and contraptions in dizzying motion. On the other hand, had I found, let's say, impetuous love in the seat behind me on that roller coaster and embarked from there on an adventure of the heart -- now, that might have been a story.
title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects

text: The police said Everett Henriquez had gone to Van Cortlandt Park for the quietude, digging a pied-a-terre into the soft earth, stocking it with weapons and furnishing it with a mattress. There was a pond nearby. Everything was rosy, expect for the squawking birds.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: This little intrusion proved too much for the 27-year-old Bronx man.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: Two days ago, the police say, he took out a shotgun and blasted away at a flock of geese. Horrified workers on a nearby golf course called the police, but the shooter had already scurried back to his underground home. Yesterday he was arrested when he emerged again to shoot at the honking birds, the Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, said.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: Waterfowl are now the least of his problems.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: After he was arrested, Mr. Henriquez showed the police officers to his hideaway, a 3-by-8-foot cave nestled six feet below ground, between the Major Deegan Expressway and the second tee of the Van Cortlandt Golf Course. Inside, there was a mattress, three bags of marijuana, several pairs of women's shoes, weight-lifting equipment, a bow and arrow and a sock full of rocks, the police and park officials said.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: ''He clearly had spent some time there,'' Mr. Stern said, adding that he was still confused about the women's shoes. ''We don't know if they belonged to an accomplice, a victim, if he is a cross-dresser or a shoe collector,'' he said.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: Mr. Henriquez now faces a host of charges: criminal possession of a weapon, possession of a weapon in a park, possession of marijuana and stolen property -- and illegal camping, Betsy Herzog, a spokeswoman for the Police Department, said.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: The Parks Commissioner said that during his 11 years as head of the city's parks, there had been illegal poachers and a good number of illegal campers. But Mr. Henriquez, he said, was the only person he knew who had been shooting animals and living in a hole on park land.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: Mr. Henriquez told investigators that he lived with his grandmother, on University Avenue in the Bronx, but that he spent much of his time in what he called ''his park retreat.''
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: ''I assume he enjoyed the solitude, but he was clearly over the line,'' Mr. Stern said, adding that Mr. Henriquez's penchant for weapons probably left him out of the running for any comparison with Henry David Thoreau.
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: ''You cannot live in an underground cabin in the park,'' he said. ''It's improper use of the land and we discourage that sort of thing.''
title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested

text: In the back of every parent's mind, crowded in with worries about the job, the bills, the waistline and grandma, is a certain fear about the children -- that we haven't prepared them well enough, that their world won't be good enough, that we can't do anything about it. No wonder so many parents are glum.
title: The Children of the Glum

text: Fortunately, someone decided to ask the children how they are. A New York Times/CBS News Poll of about 1,000 children age 13 to 17 divulged its results this week. Some of the news, of course, is dismaying. Almost 60 percent of the teen-agers said they had cheated on some exam. Half said they knew someone who had attempted suicide. Almost 20 percent knew someone who had the AIDS virus or had died of it. More thought that drugs were a big problem in their schools than in 1994. Fewer were happy with the way they looked than kids were four years ago. But most of them won't be reading about it in this editorial, because about three-quarters don't read a newspaper most days of the week.
title: The Children of the Glum

text: What a staggering two-thirds of them do instead is watch television in their own rooms. It is their most constant companion, and they say they spend almost four hours a day at it. The Fox network is their favorite. But they now also say they spend more than half as much time in front of a computer, which at least requires minimal wrist and mental movements.
title: The Children of the Glum

text: There is a surprisingly large selfless dimension in the numbers. Half or more of those questioned say they usually attend church, do some volunteer work and some kind of labor for pay. They seem more sensitive to minorities than their parents do. More of them think African-Americans deserve affirmative action. Although half believe homosexuality is ''always wrong,'' they seem willing to coexist with it. Forty percent know someone gay.
title: The Children of the Glum

text: There may have been a parent hovering when the pollsters called by phone. Parents do that. But more than 90 percent of the children say they believe in God. Sixty percent say they typically have dinner with their families. Only about a third as many are worried about violence and crime as four years ago. Guns, pregnancy and abortion, drinking and AIDS have all shrunk as concerns. More than half think that teen-agers charged with violent crimes should be tried as adults.
title: The Children of the Glum

text: Only about one-quarter of them have had sex yet, and far fewer have smoked marijuana than think their parents have. Far more of them expect to go to college than their parents did, and yet many admire their parents more than anyone else. Most of them think we are in touch with their lives. They get on well with us.
title: The Children of the Glum

text: Bless them. It is a great relief. They are upholding the eternal promise of youth to age: that the world is a better place than we suspect, that their lives will be happier than we can know, and that we have done more for them than we think.
title: The Children of the Glum

text: Eldridge Cleaver, whose searing prison memoir ''Soul on Ice'' and leadership in the Black Panther Party made him a symbol of black rebellion in the turbulent 1960's, died yesterday in Pomona, Calif., at the age of 62.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: At the request of Mr. Cleaver's family, a spokesman for the Pomona Valley Hospital Center, Leslie Porras, declined to provide the cause of death or the reason Mr. Cleaver was in the hospital.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: In the black leather coat and beret the Panthers wore as a uniform, Mr. Cleaver was a tall, bearded figure who mesmerized his radical audiences with his fierce energy, intellect and often bitter humor.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''You're either part of the problem or part of the solution,'' he challenged, in one of the slogans that became a byword of the era.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: He became even more of a symbol when he jumped bail after a shootout between Black Panthers in Oakland, Calif., and the police and fled into exile in Cuba and Algeria, adding the causes of Communism and third world liberation to his repertoire.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: But after he returned to the United States in 1975, Mr. Cleaver metamorphosed into variously a born-again Christian, a follower of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, a Mormon, a crack cocaine addict, a designer of men's trousers featuring a codpiece and even, finally, a Republican.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: 'Soul on Ice,' Memoir as Manifesto
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: When ''Soul on Ice,'' was published in 1968, it had a tremendous impact on an intellectual community radicalized by the civil rights movement, urban riots, the war in Vietnam and campus rebellions. It was a wild, divisive time in the United States, and Mr. Cleaver's memoir from Folsom state prison, where he was doing time for rape, was hailed as an authentic voice of black rage in a white-ruled world. The New York Times named it one of its 10 best books of the year.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''Cleaver is simply one of the best cultural critics now writing,'' Maxwell Geismar wrote in the introduction to the McGraw-Hill book, adding:
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''As in Malcolm X's case, here is an 'outside' critic who takes pleasure in dissecting the deepest and most cherished notions of our personal and social behavior; and it takes a certain amount of courage and a 'willed objectivity' to read him. He rakes our favorite prejudices with the savage claws of his prose until our wounds are bare, our psyche is exposed, and we must either fight back or laugh with him for the service he has done us. For the 'souls of black folk,' in W. E. B. Du Bois's phrase, are the best mirror in which to see the white American self in mid-20th century.''
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: First printed in Ramparts, the quintessential radical magazine of the 60's, Mr. Cleaver's prison essays are angry, sometimes bitingly funny, often obsessed with sexuality. And they trace the development of his political thought through his prison readings of the works of Thomas Paine, Marx, Lenin, James Baldwin and, above all, Malcolm X.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''I have, so to speak, washed my hands in the blood of the martyr Malcolm X,'' Mr. Cleaver wrote after the assassination of the onetime Black Muslim leader who had moved away from separatism, ''whose retreat from the precipice of madness created new room for others to turn about in, and I am caught up in that tiny space, attempting a maneuver of my own.''
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: But it was a difficult space to reach. In one of the book's most gripping and brutal passages, he wrote:
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''I became a rapist. To refine my technique and modus operandi, I started out by practicing on black girls in the ghetto -- in the black ghetto where dark and vicious deeds appear not as aberrations or deviations from the norm, but as part of the sufficiency of the Evil of the day -- and when I considered myself smooth enough, I crossed the tracks and sought out white prey. I did this consciously, deliberately, willfully, methodically -- though looking back I see that I was in a frantic, wild and completely abandoned frame of mind.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''Rape was an insurrectionary act. It delighted me that I was defying and trampling upon the white man's law, upon his system of values, and that I was defiling his women -- and this point, I believe, was the most satisfying to me because I was very resentful over the historical fact of how the white man has used the black woman. I felt I was getting revenge.''
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: There was little doubt he went on, citing a LeRoi Jones poem of the time which expressed similar rage, ''that if I had not been apprehended I would have slit some white throats.'' But he was caught, and after he returned to prison, Mr. Cleaver wrote:
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''I took a long look at myself and, for the first time in my life, admitted that I was wrong, that I had gone astray -- astray not so much from the white man's law as from being human, civilized -- for I could not approve the act of rape. Even though I had some insight into my own motivations, I did not feel justified. I lost my self respect. My pride as a man dissolved and my whole fragile moral structure seemed to collapse, completely shattered.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''That is why I started to write. To save myself.''
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Troubled Childhood Ended at Prison Gates
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Leroy Eldridge Cleaver was born in Wabbaseka, Ark., south of Little Rock, in 1935, to Leroy Cleaver, a waiter and piano player in a local nightclub, and Thelma Cleaver, an elementary school teacher. When the father became a waiter on the Super Chief train, the family moved to Phoenix, a stop on the train's run from Chicago to Los Angeles. Mr. Cleaver later said that his father often beat his mother and that soon after the family moved to the Watts section of Los Angeles, his parents separated.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Mr. Cleaver had barely started Abraham Lincoln Junior High School -- where his mother was a janitor -- when he was arrested for bicycle theft and sent to reform school, where the older boys inspired loftier ambitions. Almost immediately after his release, he was sent to another reform school, for selling marijuana. A few days after he was released from that school, he was arrested for marijuana possession, and made the big time: two and one half years at Soledad state prison.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: He began reading widely and received his high school diploma at Soledad, forming, he wrote in ''Soul on Ice,'' ''a concept of what it meant to be black in white America.'' But a year later Mr. Cleaver was arrested for his rapes, convicted of assault with intent to murder and sent first to San Quentin prison and then Folsom for a term of 2 to 14 years.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: He became first a jailhouse Black Muslim convert, then after the split in the Nation of Islam followed Malcolm X. In mid-1965, eight years into his term, he wrote to Beverly Axelrod, a well-known white civil liberties lawyer in San Francisco asking for help in pleading for parole.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Ms. Axelrod took his essays to Edward M. Keating, Rampart's owner and editor. When Mr. Cleaver went before the parole board, he was a published writer with the support of literary lights like Mr. Geismar, Norman Mailer and Paul Jacobs.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Freed in December 1966, with a job reporting for Ramparts in San Francisco, Mr. Cleaver helped organize Black House, a cultural center, where he met Huey P. Newton and Bobby Seale, the co-founders of the Black Panther Party, which they called an organization for ''self-defense'' against the police.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Freed from Prison With a Radical Goal
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: The Panthers were a growing presence in Oakland, shadowing police patrols, whom they accused of brutalizing the black community, and openly displaying weapons. Mr. Cleaver quickly joined the party as minister of information -- chief spokesman and propagandist.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''We shall have our manhood,'' Mr. Cleaver declared. ''We shall have it or the earth will be leveled by our attempts to gain it.''
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Mr. Cleaver also began teaching an experimental course at the University of California at Berkeley in fall 1968, which infuriated then-Gov. Ronald Reagan, who declared, ''If Eldridge Cleaver is allowed to teach our children, they may come home one night and slit our throats.''
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: At the time, Mr. Cleaver regularly referred to Mr. Reagan as Mickey Mouse in his speeches. It is a measure of Mr. Cleaver's many changes that in 1982 he was booed and hissed by the Yale Afro-American student society for supporting Mr. Reagan.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: As tensions between the Panthers and the authorities rose, Mr. Cleaver was caught up in a shootout in April 1968 in which a 17-year-old Panther, Bobby Hutton, was killed and Mr. Cleaver and two policemen were wounded. Facing the revocation of his parole and new charges, Mr. Cleaver jumped a $50,000 bail late that year and fled into exile, first to Cuba and then to a home in Algeria, then a leftist haven.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Mr. Cleaver married Kathleen Neal in 1967, the daughter of Foreign Service officer. She followed him to Algeria, and they had two children, a son, Maceo, now 29, and a daughter, Joju, 28. The couple divorced in 1987, and Mrs. Cleaver is now a lawyer and teacher.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: At first Mr. Cleaver toured Communist countries triumphantly, hailing Kim Il Sung of North Korea, among others. But disillusion set in, and there was increasing friction between the Algerian Government and Mr. Cleaver's entourage. There was an internal struggle between Mr. Cleaver and Mr. Newton, too, and Mr. Cleaver broke with the Panthers in 1971.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Spiritual Awakening And Surrender to F.B.I.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''I had heard so much rhetoric about their glorious leaders and their incredible revolutionary spirit that even to this very angry and disgruntled American, it was absurd and unreal,'' Mr. Cleaver wrote later,
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: The family moved to France. There, Mr. Cleaver said, contemplating suicide one night with a gun in his hand, he suddenly had a vision in which his old Marxist heroes disappeared in smoke and a blinding light led him to Christianity. In 1977, he returned to the United States and surrendered to the F.B.I. under a deal with the Government by which he pleaded guilty to the assault charge stemming from the shootout. Charges of attempted murder were dropped, and he was sentenced to 1,200 hours of community service.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: But, Mrs. Cleaver said in a 1994 interview with The San Francisco Chronicle, ''he came back a very unhealthy person, unhealthy mentally, and I don't think he's ever quite recovered. He became a profoundly disappointed and ultimately disoriented person.''
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: Mr. Cleaver drifted in his enthusiasms. He opened a boutique for the trousers he created featuring what he called the Cleaver sleeve. He embraced various religions. He ran a recycling business for a while, but other recyclers accused him of stealing their garbage. He was treated for addiction to crack cocaine in 1990. A crack charge two years later was dropped because of an illegal search, but in 1994 Berkeley police found him staggering about with a severe, never fully explained, head injury and a rock of crack in his pocket. He proclaimed himself a conservative and ran, unsuccessfully, for various local offices as a Republican.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: His political turnabout was such that, in the 1980's, he demanded that the Berkeley City Council begin its meetings with the Pledge of Allegiance, a practice they had abandoned years before.
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: ''Shut up, Eldridge,'' Mayor Gus Newport told the man who had once been the fiercest emblem of 1960's radicalism. ''Shut up or we'll have you removed.''
title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62

text: By Laurie Goodstein With Marjorie Connelly
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: They carry beepers, prefer permanent tattoos to body piercing and are just about as likely to take lessons in shooting guns as they are to play musical instruments. Four in 10 personally know someone who is gay or lesbian, and 6 in 10 say distributing condoms in schools is a good idea.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Teen-agers today are worldly, shaped by exposure to a culture that has dropped many of its inhibitions, according to a nationwide poll of 13- to 17-year-olds conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Yet, the same poll suggests, in some ways they are as wholesome and devoid of cynicism as the generation that wore saddle shoes. They trust their government, admire their parents and believe it is possible to start out poor and become rich. Ninety-four percent say they believe in God. Strong majorities say they never drink alcohol and never smoke cigarettes or marijuana.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: On sexual matters, too, they display a notable conservatism. Almost half say sex before marriage is ''always wrong'' (53 percent of girls agree, and 41 percent of boys). Fifty-eight percent of boys and 47 percent of girls say homosexuality is ''always wrong.''
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Fewer than one in four say they have ever had sex, but 71 percent say ''a lot'' or ''some'' of the other students at their schools are having sex. And almost half of the same teen-agers who say they disapprove of premarital sex favor condom distribution in schools.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: ''People are going to have sex, and they should have protected sex,'' said Brett Adam Abel, a 15-year-old from Apopka, Fla., who participated in the poll and agreed to a follow-up interview. ''They should have the chance to prevent herpes, AIDS and stuff.''
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: When asked to name the biggest problem faced by teen-agers today, 39 percent said drugs, about the same percentage as in a poll of teen-agers conducted by The Times and CBS News four years ago. The number who said that violence or crime was the biggest problem facing their generation has dropped dramatically -- to 7 percent, from 22 percent in 1994. The drop may reflect an actual decrease in crime nationally, as documented by Federal statistics.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Still, when the youths were asked what they considered the biggest problem in their schools, 16 percent said violence, the most frequent response. The survey followed a wave of shootings at schools in recent months, most notably the killing of four students and a teacher in Jonesboro, Ark., in late March.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: ''Fights mainly, nothing with guns or anything,'' said Alison Brown, 14, who attends a public school in Cincinnati. ''They don't happen as much as they used to; now it's about once a week. There's less of it because our school has taken tighter control.''
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Guns are a part of many teen-agers' lives, the poll found. Nearly 4 in 10 say a member of their household owns a gun, and 15 percent say they themselves own one. Thirty-one percent have had instruction in shooting.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Only 2 percent said abortion or pregnancy was the biggest problem facing teen-agers. Only 1 percent said it was AIDS. Yet 18 percent said they personally knew someone who had tested positive for H.I.V., had AIDS or had died of AIDS.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: The poll, of 1,048 teen-agers, was conducted by telephone from April 2 through April 7 and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Many of the responses concerning behavior -- on smoking, drinking and sex, for instance -- varied widely between younger and older teen-agers. Only 13 percent of 13- to 15-year-olds said they had ever had sex, for example, as against 38 percent of 16- and 17-year-olds.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: The poll makes clear that the post-cold-war generation is coming of age free of preoccupation about nuclear weapons and the survival of the planet. When asked to think about their future, 28 percent said that what worried them most was getting a good job. Eleven percent said it was having enough money, and 9 percent said being successful. Only 3 percent said that what worried them most was the environment.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Defying a stereotype, these teen-agers were short on criticism of their parents. Fifty-one percent said they got along with their parents ''very well,'' and 46 percent said ''fairly well.'' Nearly two-thirds said their parents were ''in touch with what life is like'' for today's teen-agers. And 48 percent said they even enjoyed the same types of music as their parents.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: But 55 percent agreed that there were times when they had something they wanted to talk to their parents about, but did not. Of these, four out of five said the reason was that their parents ''won't understand,'' and most of the rest said their parents were simply too busy.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: When they go out, 89 percent said, they have to tell their parents where they are going.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: ''She's very protective, and sometimes that's a problem,'' Mary Spivey, 17, a high school junior in Jacksonville, Fla., said of her mother, ''but I know that it's really for the best. I'm glad I can't get away with what some of my friends do. She is in touch with what's going on with me, because I tell her a lot of what's going on. So she doesn't automatically say no on everything. She really weighs the consequences.''
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: When asked whom they admired most, 44 percent of girls and 18 percent of boys named their mother. Fathers did not rank as highly; 26 percent of boys and 8 percent of girls said their father was the person they admired most. Some named grandmothers or grandfathers. Five percent said they admired both parents. Nine percent of boys named a sports figure. Five percent of girls named a celebrity.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Girls have a lower self-image than boys: 39 percent of girls and 54 percent of boys said they felt very positive about themselves over all. When they were asked the one thing they would like to change about themselves, the most frequent answer from boys and girls alike was ''my looks'' or ''my body'' (36 percent of girls, 28 percent of boys). The percentage of teen-agers who wanted to change their looks or body was significantly higher than four years ago.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Steven Pyszka, a hockey-playing 17-year-old from Warrenville Ill., said he would like ''to be more physically fit, muscular-wise.''
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: ''I'm not the world's strongest person,'' Steve said. ''I would like to be more built in a way.''
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: On some political issues, teen-agers' views diverged sharply from those of their parents. Six in 10 teen-agers said that ''when there has been discrimination against blacks in the past,'' blacks should be given preference in the workplace and in college admissions. Only 35 percent of adults held that view in a Times/CBS News Poll in December.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Fifty percent of teen-agers said you could trust the government to do what is right always or most of the time; only 26 percent of adults agreed with that in January.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: A majority of the teen-agers approve of the way President Clinton is doing his job, and consider the Lewinsky episode a ''private matter'' for the President. Those opinions almost mirror those of adults.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: How the Poll Was Conducted
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: The New York Times/CBS News Poll of American teen-agers is based on telephone interviews conducted April 2 to April 7 with 1,048 teen-agers throughout the United States.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Fewer than 1 in 5 households contains a teen-ager from the age of 13 through 17. Thus, from September 1997 through March 1998, the poll asked on each of its regular adult surveys if a teen-ager lived in the home. The households saying yes were subsequently called for the poll of teen-agers. If a household had two or more teen-agers, one teen-ager was randomly designated to be surveyed.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: The original samples of telephone exchanges were randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: The results have been weighted to adjust for the number of teen-agers in the household, the number of telephone lines into the residence, region, race, sex, age, and education of parents.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the poll results will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American teen-agers. For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger.
title: Teen-Age Poll Finds a Turn to the Traditional

text: Three businessmen told the Senate Finance Committee today of Internal Revenue Service agents who, with guns drawn, broke down doors, terrified workers and forced teen-age girls to change clothes in front of male agents in raids at the men's homes and businesses that they said were unnecessary.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: These aggressive paramilitary tactics were denounced as intolerable and ''fascist'' by Democratic and Republican senators as the panel heard testimony for a second day in its second round of hearings on I.R.S. abuses of taxpayers.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: But the testimony by the three wealthy businessmen from Texas, Oklahoma and Virginia also showed that the agents had reason to suspect they had come across a $300 million tax fraud in one case and a drug operation in another.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Holes and contradictions in testimony by two of the businessmen prompted Senate Democrats to complain that the hearings were not a search for truth but a one-sided propaganda show by Republicans, whose polling data show that attacking the I.R.S. is their best strategy for raising money and winning votes.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Delaware Republican and the moving force behind the hearings, has refused to release the names of witnesses to Democratic senators until just before they testify and has not given Democratic staff members access to documents, breaking with routine practices for such hearings.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, said he was troubled that the Senate was scheduled to vote next week on a bill to restructure the I.R.S. when ''we have only heard one side of the story.''
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: ''We should hear both sides,'' Mr. Kerrey said.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Without knowing the full story, he warned, lawmakers may produce a bill that does not protect taxpayers and inadvertently comforts cheats. He called on Mr. Roth to seek confidentiality waivers so I.R.S. agents, three of whom witnesses named, could tell their side of the story.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Mr. Roth dismissed those concerns and said he would advise the three businessmen not to grant the waivers.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: One businessman, John Colaprete, told of I.R.S. raids four years ago on his two Jewish Mother restaurants in Virginia Beach and Norfolk, Va., his home and that of his associate.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: ''Armed agents, accompanied by drug-sniffing dogs, stormed my restaurant during breakfast, ordered patrons out and interrogated my employees,'' Mr. Colaprete said.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: He said that the front door of his home was ripped from its hinges, and, at the home of his associate, male I.R.S. agents made three teen-age girls change clothes while the agents watched, though female agents took part in the raid.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Mr. Colaprete said his problems began when he fired a bookkeeper, who had a criminal record, for stealing and she told the I.R.S. ''a fantastic tale of money laundering, gunrunning and drug dealing by my partner and me.'' He said agents were told that he had cocaine ''stacked like cord wood.'' Mr. Colaprete said the stories were untrue and a cursory inquiry would have shown that.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: A document filed in court by Federal prosecutors acknowledged that no criminal charges had been brought, and said evidence showed unreported income of no more than $10,000 to $20,000 annually. But it also said that drugs had been found at both homes, including ''a fairly sizable quantity of marijuana'' in Mr. Colaprete's house.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Prosecutors fabricated the statement that drugs were found, Mr. Colaprete's lawyer, Robert John Haddad of Virginia Beach, said in a telephone interview.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Another witness, W. A. Moncrief of Fort Worth, whose family owns an oil business, said 64 armed agents stormed his office in September 1994, seized all documents there and Ripped out walls looking for drugs. Mr. Moncrief testified that the I.R.S. never presented him with a tax bill, but ''extorted'' $23 million from him.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Mr. Moncrief's testimony that he owed nothing but paid just to make the I.R.S. go away was ridiculed by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: ''Take this $23 million. I want to get back to my golf,'' Mr. Moynihan said, chortling. ''I don't believe him.''
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Mr. Moncrief's written testimony was more restrained and indicated that he paid ''taxes and interest'' for 16 years ending in the late 1970's after his lawyer, Robert S. Bennett of Washington, negotiated a civil settlement of his taxes.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Privately, some Democrats questioned whether the I.R.S. gave the family a discount of more than a quarter of a billion dollars on taxes it owed because I.R.S. agents had overreacted by conducting an armed raid rather than making an appointment to examine records or issuing subpoenas for documents.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Testimony also showed that the I.R.S. had been investigating the Moncrief business for nearly a year before the raid and had signed an informant agreement with the family accountant, Billy W. Jarvis, promising him as much as $25 million if the I.R.S. collected more than $116 million in taxes and everything Mr. Jarvis said was true.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: Because of the confidentiality rules imposed by Congress, it could not be learned if the I.R.S. paid him.
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: The third businessman, Richard Gardner of Tulsa, Okla., said his tax preparation business was raided in March 1995, apparently ''to make an example'' of him. He said the Justice Department indicted him on 23 counts, then dropped them because the case was based on ''fabrication, false and nonexistent testimony.''
title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.

text: President Clinton said today that he would nominate a career diplomat, Assistant Secretary of State Jeffrey Davidow, as Ambassador to Mexico, a post vacant for almost 10 months because of wrangling between the White House and the Senate.
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: The President's first choice, William F. Weld, the former Governor of Massachusetts, withdrew his name last year after it became clear that the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms, would never allow the nomination to come to a Senate vote.
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: Senator Helms, a North Carolina Republican, accused Mr. Weld, also a Republican, of being too lenient on drug abuse. He said that Mr. Weld's support for legalizing marijuana for medicinal use and for a needle-exchange program for addicts made him an inappropriate choice as ambassador to a nation with serious drug-trafficking problems.
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: The choice of Mr. Davidow, a seasoned and well-respected diplomat who is now the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, suggested that the White House had no appetite for another battle with Senator Helms over the Mexico post. Mr. Davidow won Mr. Helms's backing in 1996 when he was nominated for his current job.
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: A spokesman for the Foreign Relations Committee, Marc A. Thiessen, said that Mr. Helms ''will give Mr. Davidow's nomination prompt and extremely thorough consideration.''
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: While Administration officials expressed confidence that the nomination would be approved quickly, they said they expected Mr. Davidow would be closely questioned about his involvement in enforcement of the so-called Helms-Burton Act, which calls for economic sanctions against foreign companies that make use of American property in Cuba that was seized by the Castro Government three decades ago.
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: Mr. Helms, the author of the 1996 legislation, has criticized the Administration for regularly waiving some of its toughest provisions.
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: Mr. Davidow, a former Ambassador to Venezuela and to Zambia, has also held diplomatic posts in Guatemala, Chile and Zimbabwe in a 29-year career in the Foreign Service. In his current post, Mr. Davidow, who speaks Spanish, oversees relations between the United States and all nations in Latin America.
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: He would succeed Ambassador James Jones, a former member of Congress and chairman of the American Stock Exchange, who stepped down in June 1997. Without an Ambassador in residence, the embassy has been headed for most of the last year by Charles Brayshaw, who had been Mr. Jones's principal deputy.
title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy

text: ON the day last month that two youths shot four students and one teacher to death in Jonesboro, Ark., a mother in Daly City, Calif., was arrested for suffocating her three children with duct tape. About 10 days after the three West Paducah, Ky., school killings in December, parents in Weston, W.Va., were arrested for burning down their house and murdering five children to collect insurance.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The paradox: school killings receive enormous attention not because they are routine, but because they are rare. The National School Safety Center estimates that of the 52 million students in school, about two dozen are murdered each year, a number that is not rising. By contrast, the National Commission on Child Abuse and Neglect reports that every year 2,000 to 3,000 children and youths are murdered by parents, a toll that is rising.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The public image of teen-agers is shaped by sensational crimes like the Jonesboro killings and by a selective use of statistics that make uncommon events like teen-age murder or suicide seem epidemic. At the same time, many experts are declaring that today's youths are more criminal, more suicidal, more stoned and less moral than their predecessors. John DiIulio Jr., a professor of politics at Princeton University, and William J. Bennett, a former Secretary of Education, for example, forecasted in their 1996 book ''Body Count'' that there is a growing ''population of teen-agers with higher incidence of serious drug use, more access to powerful firearms and fewer moral restraints than any such group in American history.''
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: It is hardly surprising, then, that the public stereotype of contemporary teen-agers is a hostile one. Deborah Wadsworth, the executive director of Public Agenda, a public-policy research firm, said its 1997 survey found that Americans tended to view young people with feelings of alarm or fear.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: There are those, however, who argue that adults berate teen-agers to excuse their own negligence. ''Today's young people are scapegoated by an adult generation that is abandoning them,'' said Lori Nelson, the youth and education issues director for the Los Angeles chapter of the National Conference for Communities and Justice. ''Race is a big reason. The kids people are scared of are kids of color.''
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: A sober analysis of the statistics renders many of the commonly held beliefs about teen-agers into myths that ignore broader contexts like socioeconomic conditions and adult behavior.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: MYTH NO. 1: While crime rates among adults are falling, youths are becoming more violent and criminally dangerous.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The facts: This popular myth confuses two different Federal Bureau of Investigation measures of crime. The first, violent crimes reported to police, rose from the mid-1970's to the early 90's and has since fallen. The second measure, violent-crime arrests, rose sharply among adolescents ages 12 to 17 (up 69 percent ) from 1975 to 1995. But during that same period, violent-crime arrests rose even more markedly among adolescents' parents' age group, namely adults 30 to 49 (a rate that is up 89 percent). Since 1995, arrest rates for violent crimes have declined for both teen-agers and adults.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: Meanwhile, youthful killers are not overrunning the nation. The United States Department of Justice reports that fewer than one-half of 1 percent of juveniles in the United States are arrested for a violent offense every year. And arrest statistics overstate teen-age crime. The F.B.I., for example, reported that in 1996, youths accounted for 15 percent of murder arrests, but only 8 percent of actual murders were attributed to juveniles. The reality is that adults commit 11 of 12 homicides, including three-fourths of the murders of children and teen-agers, statistics that are usually ignored in the furor over ''killer kids.''
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: Poverty strongly predicts violent crime-arrest levels among all ages and races and both sexes. Teen-agers are not more violent than adults; rather, poor people are more likely to be arrested for violent crimes than the rich or the middle class, and these days, youths are twice as likely as adults to be poor. When there is economic parity between adults and teen-agers, teen-age violence rates are lower than for adults in their 20's and 30's.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: Finally, the assertion that more teen-agers means more violence is contradicted by F.B.I. and Census Bureau figures.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: From its 1976 peak to the end of 1992, the teen-age population fell, but the nation's violent-crime rate rose by 60 percent. From 1992 to 1997, the teen-age population rose, but violent crime fell 20 percent.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: MYTH NO. 2: Today's teen-agers have little concern for their health or their well-being.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The facts: Teen-agers are healthier and taking care of themselves better than ever. Natural deaths have declined sharply. Rates of violent death (accident, suicide and homicide) are 15 to 20 percent lower among teen-agers today than in the 1960's and 70's, when their parents were growing up. The National Center for Education Statistics' 1997 Digest reported record levels of public school enrollment, fewer school days lost to injury or disease and higher student reading, math and science test scores today than in the 70's and 80's.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: MYTH NO. 3: Teen-agers are prone to suicide.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The facts: Teen-agers are less self-destructive today than in the past. The supposed doubling in teen-age suicides rates is a result of better identification and is not a real increase.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The most recent National Center for Health Statistics figures, from 1994, show that teen-agers have relatively low suicide rates: 1.7 suicides per 100,000 among 10- to 14-year-olds, and 11.1 among 15- to 19-year-olds. By contrast, the rates are 15.4 per 100,000 for people 20 through 49 years old, and 15.9 for those who are age 50 and over.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: Teen-agers are much less likely to die by their own hand than adolescents were in the 60's and 70's. The types of self-inflicted teen-age deaths associated with suicide (gunshots, drugs, other poisons, hangings, drownings and falls) declined sharply over the last 25 years. But in 1970, coroners ruled four-fifths of the 5,700 adolescent deaths from those causes as accidents. In 1994, 70 percent of the 3,800 deaths from these same causes were ruled suicides.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: MYTH NO. 4: Adult drug abuse is declining, but drugs remain a threat to young people.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The facts: Drug abuse among teen-agers fell markedly in the 70's and remains low today. Adult drug abuse, on the other hand, has skyrocketed. One statistic sums up the generational change: from 1970 to 1996, drug death rates fell 66 percent among teen-agers but rose 113 percent among their aging baby-boom parents, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. It is drug abuse among parents, not teen-agers, that is a crisis today.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The so-called teen-age drug epidemic consists of survey findings, like those of the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse, that 7 percent of 12- to 17-year-olds reported smoking marijuana once a month or more in 1996, twice the percentage in 1992. A 1997 review by the Lindesmith Center, a drug-policy research institute, of hundreds of studies, concluded that marijuana does not lead to use of harder drugs.
