Indeed, teen-agers' use of heroin, cocaine (including crack) and methamphetamine remains so low that surveys can barely measure it.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: MYTH NO. 5: Teen-agers are naturally rebellious and impulsive risk-takers.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: The facts: When scholars look for evidence that supports the stereotypes that teen-agers are reckless and defiant, they find that these prejudices, like those once held by scientists toward minorities, have no basis in fact.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: Decades of study by leading researchers, like the work by Daniel Offer, a Northwestern University psychiatrist, suggest that teen-agers' values and behaviors reflect those of the adults who rear them. ''Our youths are no healthier or sicker than us, their parents,'' Dr. Offer wrote. ''They reflect us.'' A 1993 research review of 150 studies, published in American Psychologist, also found that the perception of personal invulnerability to risk ''was no more pronounced for adolescents than for adults.''
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: Joseph Adelson, a professor emeritus of psychology at the University of Michigan and a top researcher on the behavior of teen-agers, said that his views that were reported in an article in Psychology Today in 1979 have not changed. ''Taken as a whole, adolescents are not in turmoil, not deeply disturbed, not at the mercy of their impulses, not resistant to parental values and not rebellious,'' he said.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: Whatever the evidence shows, the avalanche of negative information fuels public anger toward young people. The 1997 Public Agenda survey found two thirds of American adults label youths ''rude,'' ''irresponsible'' and ''wild,'' while only 37 percent of adults believe that when the current group of children grow up, they will make the United States a better place.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: Yet Public Agenda's survey could be evidence that teen-agers have healthier attitudes than grown-ups. While adults indulge in blanket, hostile stereotypes of young people, teen-agers judge adults more positively as individuals. The open-mindedness of most young people may turn out to be a crucial resource in an increasingly diverse America.
title: Five Myths, and Why Adults Believe They Are True

text: TRYING to label America's nearly 60 million teen-agers is about as easy as staying on the trail of a snowboarder in a whiteout. No definition can stretch far enough to include bubbly Hanson fans and moody Marilyn Manson devotees, marijuana-smoking homeboys and savvy junior entrepreneurs, born-again virgins and single moms, student activists and frustrated truants -- especially when one teen-ager might inhabit several of those identities. As adults circle, fascinated, teen-agers survive and thrive within these interlocking universes. If these teen-agers must be tagged, call them the Autonomous Generation, creating themselves in nobody's image but their own.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Nicole Hernandez is one such 1990's teen-ager. She lives in Elmhurst, Queens, but not with her parents. Fleeing a troubled home, she became an emancipated minor last year and moved in with her boyfriend and his mother. Nicole likes going to clubs and concerts, but spends most of her time juggling high-school classes, chores and a full-time restaurant job.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: ''It's hard,'' she said during a recent interview on her one day off from work. ''I have to help pay the rent, and if I don't pass all my classes I don't graduate. But then there are days when I just want to hang out with my friends and be young like I was a year ago.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Or consider Henry Gregoire, a 16-year-old from Prospect Lefferts Gardens in Brooklyn. Vehemently straitlaced about drugs and sex, busy with an architecture internship, which takes him to Manhattan three days a week, Henry cannot wait to grow up. ''I could almost say I have more adult friends than regular teen friends,'' he said. His father is a rap fan, but Henry prefers 12th-century Celtic music. ''My dad says, 'You and I are different people,' '' he reported. Henry has made another choice common among 90's teen-agers: to pretend that his adolescence does not exist.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Then there is Danny Stolzman, who is soon to graduate from Fieldston School, a private school in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Danny plays on the baseball team, acts in school plays and belongs to a group that collects pennies from schools that are used to finance inner-city social programs. He says his parents are ''fabulous.'' Yet Danny, who says he smoked marijuana in eighth grade, has already experienced enough to have grown cautious about reckless consumption. A few months ago, he quit cigarettes because he was worried about living long enough to see his grandchildren. ''We feel the doors closing,'' he said. ''It's up to us to grow up and to figure ourselves out.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: It's no wonder that teen-agers have become ''Titanic'' maniacs: for them, life can seem like a huge vessel veering out of control, a situation they must negotiate in spite of adults who alternately harass and ignore them. With many parents working or absent, schools sometimes in disarray and a future contingent on acquiring job skills, high grade-point averages and thick extracurricular resumes, adolescents often shoulder enormous responsibilities. At the same time, their freedoms are being restricted by authorities who think they are both dangerous and endangered.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Instead of talking back to adult assumptions, teen-agers would rather look to one another the way Jack and Rose did as the ship sank. They communicate across the Web in the language of hip-hop and skateboarding slang, and through the most effective form of pedagogy going -- peer education. When they make alliances with adults, they want them to act as peers, too. Acknowledge their power, engage their ideas. Just don't treat them like the teen-agers you think they are.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: In the 90's, stereotypes about teen-agers have been inflated to ridiculous proportions. Adolescents are causing trouble everywhere: getting sexual on ''Dawson's Creek,'' lurking in melodramatic movies like ''Kids'' and ''Hurricane Streets,'' scowling seductively in Calvin Klein ads and then seeming to bring the perversity of those images to life in shocking tabloid tales. The juvenile delinquent has become the superpredator. The troubled teen-ager needs Prozac. Lolita is Everygirl, pushing up adolescent birth rates in her hot pants and navel ring.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: The problem is that public conversation about teen-agers is dominated by adults, and it is pressing young people into their own spheres. Emerging as the largest age group in the United States, teen-agers recognize their own overwhelming presence on the American cultural landscape. Yet they often feel strangely uninvolved. ''Everything's geared toward people who are young, or people who want to feel young,'' Danny Stolzman said. ''We don't really have a way of rebelling.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Historically, adolescence has generated a healthy confrontation that Danny cannot find now, when young people banded together against their elders' status quos, and a balance was eventually struck. These days, teen-agers unite against the very idea of adolescence. While some certainly rebel in time-honored fashion, few relish being seen as young.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: ''I fit more into teen-age categories when I was in sixth grade,'' explained Louise Levy, a 14-year-old freshman at Stuyvesant High School, the most competitive public high school in New York City. ''Now I don't like teen-agers who are supposed to be teen-agers.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: More than ever, teen-agers feel compelled to reject the group identity that society imposes on them, and instead embrace a radical self-reliance that veers between proud pragmatism and frustrated isolation.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: This is not the nihilistic denial signaled by the suicide of the rocker Kurt Cobain, who was a generation older than this current one. It is a practical move, meant to clear space so that young people can get on with their lives. The typical teen-age problems -- existential uncertainty, shaky self-esteem, the struggle to master your own destiny -- persist, but teen-agers fear that their vulnerability will be used against them.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Kara Wentworth, another Stuyvesant freshman, feels this anxiety. ''I'm really not liking school at all, and I feel like it's time for a career change, but there's nothing I can do about it,'' she said. ''I feel like the only motivation to do well is so my parents and other people won't see me as a conventional kid.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: James Wagoner, the president of the social-service organization Advocates for Youth, often encounters such ambivalence. ''Young people have been portrayed almost universally as a set of problems to be managed by society: juvenile crime, teen-age pregnancy, drug use,'' Mr. Wagoner said. ''That concept has taken such deep root that various institutions are permeated by it. And there's not enough of the other view, of youth as an asset, a group of people with their own perspectives on things who do pretty well.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Teen-agers feel this lack. ''I'm not sure that I'd go for sitting down and being really polite with adults and telling them what we need,'' said Jonathan Berger, an 18-year-old who has been a students' rights activist since he was 12. ''It should be young people having the original idea, having complete control, but adults being there to assist them. That's the most valuable relationship I see.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Could this be the end of adolescence, which, after all, was an artificial life stage imposed when pubescent youngsters were taken out of the work force and placed into the adult-training programs known as high schools? For many teen-agers, it might as well be. They get nothing out of being squeezed between the role of the child and the adult. ''When I was in eighth grade, I had a little bit of the teen angst thing going on,'' Jonathan recalled. That was before he started selling his handmade pottery in stores, joined Act Up and began regularly attending New York City Board of Education meetings.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: The contradictions that teen-agers face come, in part, from their greater freedom. They have more mobility and privacy than ever before. And many parents, especially baby boomers who fought for their own rights as youths, are trying to develop more equal relationships.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: ''My father went to Columbia in the 1960's, during the student takeover,'' said David Pristin, another Fieldston senior. ''He had a much harder time with his parents. My parents have made a big point to tell me there's never a problem too big to go to them with. And I would fairly easily go to them.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Yet even liberal-minded parents like David's often fall prey to the aura of danger that surrounds adolescence today. ''There have been so many myths about teen-agers that most parents are afraid of raising them,'' said Lynn E. Ponton, a clinical psychologist and the author of ''The Romance of Risk: Why Teen-Agers Do the Things They Do.'' ''They react when they see the kid taking even tiny risks.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: David admits that he fears this response, especially regarding his romantic life, which he keeps private. ''I know one kid whose girlfriend's father kept telling them to use condoms, and they weren't even close to having sex yet,'' he said. ''I sometimes think parents expect the worst.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Responsibility is a gift some parents don't know how to give their children. Other parents simply relinquish it. Many young people must assume duties that the adults in their lives cannot handle themselves. The relationship Nicole Hernandez has with her boyfriend's mother is emblematic. ''She doesn't tell me anything,'' Nicole said. ''I cook for her and she cooks for me. It's equal. It's not like we're under her.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: NICOLE describes teen-agers like herself as ''little adults,'' juggling nearly as many responsibilities as people twice their age do. Their difficulties are intensified by the fact that usually they are still treated like children in the public sphere. A recent backlash has resulted in stricter curfew laws, restrictions on speech in high-school newspapers and on the World Wide Web and the threat of criminal prosecution for nonviolent offenses like smoking marijuana.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: ''The Fulton Mall won't let kids in during school hours, even if it's clearly a half day,'' complained 16-year-old Anesia DeFreitas, who attends Science Skills Center High School in Brooklyn, but lives in Jersey City, where her family moved recently. ''The library won't let you in during school hours. Nor will McDonald's. You can buy your food, but they won't let you sit down and eat it.'' (A Fulton Mall spokesman says there are no restrictions on teen-agers. The Brooklyn Public Library says it reserves the right to ask students why they are in the library during school hours. And McDonald's says it has no national policy but local restaurants may have one.)
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Shut out of the larger public, young people have created their own means of being heard. They have published their own manifestoes in photocopied fanzines, made their own music and shared it on cassette, designed their own fashions and arranged to have them sold in boutiques. These enclaves crop up in society's margins until the hungry marketplace co-opts them for wider consumption.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: But teen-agers confront larger issues than choosing sneaker styles. A far-ranging girls' culture, which includes bold young athletes, musicians, film makers and writers, is invigorating the discourse of women's liberation. Activist groups like YELL, an Act Up youth division, which counts Jonathan Berger as a leading member, have devised new approaches to safe-sex education.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Indeed, sexual identity in general has become a more talked-about subject. ''The children have come out earlier,'' said Verna Eggleston, who is the executive director of the Hetrick-Martin Institute, a Manhattan center for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender teen-agers. ''We have straight kids who have gay friends and want to be with them, or whose parents are gay or who just think this is a cool center. We have some who fall into the category of questioning kids. Some eventually choose to be gay, and some don't.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Today's youth culture is marked by a diversity that goes beyond tolerance. ''Their world is getting more raceless,'' said Susan Kaplow, the development director for Alloy, a popular catalogue and Web site that features a rainbow coalition of fashion models. ''Kids don't really think black and white.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Teen-agers nationwide may still move across boundaries more easily when shopping than when making friends, but in New York at least, the border crossings go deeper: all the youngsters who spoke about their relationships for this article said they had dated interracially.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: As their parents turn inward, concentrating on personal fulfillment and making money, young people are coming up with their own social vision. ''The baby-boom psyche is focused on the development of the self, whereas young people are preoccupied with multicultural diversity and globalism,'' said Donna Gaines, a sociologist of youth who teaches at Columbia and is the author of the 1985 book ''Teen-Age Wasteland: Suburbia's Dead-End Kids.'' But these positive trends are often ignored. ''We're busy with our inner-life project,'' Ms. Gaines said. ''We don't have time for them.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Where adults and young people meet is the proverbial mall. Teen-agers have always been a target market, but a strange thing has happened since the 60's. As consumers, many adults have retained an adolescent attitude. ''Nobody wants to get too much older,'' said Tamra Davis, a film maker whose credits include such young-adult favorites as ''Billy Madison'' and ''Half-Baked.'' Ms. Davis, who is 36, sees perpetual adolescence as particularly appealing to her own age group. ''All those people who were hippies and became yuppies seem like sellouts,'' she said. ''Our generation tries to figure out how to not make an extreme switch.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: IN the past, teen-agers had few freedoms, but what they chose to buy -- Elvis albums, for example, or zoot suits -- separated them, almost becoming a form of resistance. Now adults indulge in the same fantasies teen-agers have. Yet Ms. Davis has taken an extra step by cultivating high-school girls who are interested in becoming film makers; most others just buy from the teen-age world and then retreat.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: To make things even more complicated, forces outside the marketplace tend to condemn the very products sold to youngsters as harmful. Conservative assaults against gangsta rap and Marilyn Manson, ostensibly meant to protect youth, end up feeling like attacks, some kids say.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: ''You have kids doing all sorts of things with popular culture, but they have been reduced to consuming subjects, not citizens,'' said Henry A. Giroux, a cultural theorist whose books often examine the complicated interplay between selling youth culture and restricting it. ''When you say kids are overly influenced by the media, you imply that they are dupes unworthy of being citizens.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Since consumerism is the only kind of citizenship they are usually offered, young people use it the best they can, turning the rhymes of hip-hop into shared histories and transforming Internet chat rooms into impromptu community forums. Educators like Mr. Giroux believe that teachers and other adults should get in on this process not as voyeurs or as potential buyers, but as mentors.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Social-service organizations, like Advocates for Youth, which uses peer education as a primary channel in spreading a message of responsible sexual behavior, and the Girls and Boys Clubs of America, which held a national conference organized mostly by teen-agers, offer proof that this approach works.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Programs that treat teen-agers as people and not as problems allow them to feel safe enough to be vulnerable. This way, most turn out to be not too different from what teen-agers have always been: hopeful, daring, eager to be heard.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: ''Have you noticed how the kids are into really big items?'' Ms. Eggleston asked. ''Huge clothing, skateboards, hats. They want us to see and hear them. They've found their voices, unlike us. You've got 20-year-old talk-show hosts; you've got MTV.
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: ''We've expanded our technology to get to this point,'' she added. ''However, our hearts have not caught up to the technology. So they're screaming. We as adults would do best to listen.''
title: Who Are These People, Anyway?

text: Translated by Andrew Bromfield. 179 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: Viktor Pelevin has slowly been gaining a reputation as a post-Soviet satirist of Soviet life, a writer of absurdist extremes. His book ''Omon Ra'' was a parody of the glory of the Soviet space program. It centered on the idea that the Soviet Union had, contrary to appearances, not developed the ability to send cosmonauts into space and bring them back, which explains why the men recruited into the program were such heroes.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: Mr. Pelevin's newly translated novel, ''The Life of Insects,'' which was published in Russia in 1993, is both disappointing and interesting at the same time, a hit-and-miss parody whose execution unfortunately fails too often to match up to its darkly comic idea.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: It is a series of interconnected stories taking place at a derelict and tawdry Crimean resort town. Its characters have names like Sam and Arnold, Dmitri and Marina, drink champagne, play guitars and talk Samuel Beckett-like about the meaning of things. But these characters alternate between being humans and being insects: mosquitoes, moths, dung beetles, ants.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: In his poem ''The Fly,'' William Blake talked of casually brushing away the life of a fly and then asking: ''Am not I a fly like thee/Or art not thou a man like me?/For I laugh and dance and sing/Till some blind hand shall brush my wing.''
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: Mr. Pelevin, in writing his surreal and Kafkaesque tale, seems to have some similar notion of the narrowness of the distinction between man and fly, though the themes of ''The Life of Insects'' are too elusive to allow for any confident explanation of what Mr. Pelevin has in mind. But certainly one interpretation consistent with the events in the novel would have to do with the fragility of the human soul, its haplessness and terror in the face of the larger forces of God and nature, its accident-prone state and its puzzlement at the limitations of its vision. And, as in Blake, there is the theme of the commonality of all life, the spiritual anguish that draws insects and men into a shared fate.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: A stiletto heel attached to a gigantic red shoe plays the role of Blake's ''thoughtless hand'' in one of Mr. Pelevin's episodes. It comes crashing down without warning, unwittingly raining death on an insect below, an insect who was a father engaged at that very moment in teaching his son the skills he needed to survive.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: ''The boy cried out in terror and looked up,'' Mr. Pelevin's narrator says at this point. ''He glimpsed a shadow over his head, and for a moment he thought he saw a red shoe with a dark spot on the sole rising up into the sky, and then he thought that up in those ineffable heights into which the shoe had vanished the silhouette of an immense bird with its wings spread had appeared.''
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: There are other such powerful passages in ''The Life of Insects,'' which is marvelously translated from the Russian by Andrew Bromfield. And yet, despite its bright spots, Mr. Pelevin's newly published work often seems to drag through its own preciousness.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: One problem is that decades after Kafka and a long history of serious fantastical works, the absurdist idea behind ''The Life of Insects'' has lost some of its hold on the mind. A more serious problem is that for the most part Mr. Pelevin means to be funny. Sometimes he is, but often reading this book is a bit like watching one of those straining skits on ''Saturday Night Live'' that just doesn't make you laugh.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: There is a moment in ''The Life of Insects'' when Sam, a visiting American mosquito who talks like an aging hippie, has a love affair with a comely fly named Natasha. She is impressed that Sam has traveled to many places, including France, about which her mother has spoken a great deal.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: ''What were you doing there?'' she asks.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: ''The usual thing, sucking blood,'' Sam replies.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: ''That's not what I meant. Did you go just because you felt like it?''
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: ''Not exactly. Some friends invited me to the annual Proust festival in Combray.''
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: A little later, Sam and Natasha go to her mother's place to consummate their desire, and Mr. Pelevin produces a deformed version of the moment in Flaubert when Madame Bovary and her lover meet in an upper story of a village building while down below the honorable Mayor gives a speech full of the commonplaces of the time. In Mr. Pelevin's satire on the modern novelistic sex scene, Sam and Natasha make love with the anatomical apparatus of insects, even as Sam says things like ''Oh yeah, honey,'' and in the next room Natasha's unhearing mother recites passages of post-modernist literary criticism.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: Elsewhere, two marijuana-smoking Russian hipsters discover that the little pops they hear when they drag on their joints are actually small hemp bugs going up in smoke. The hipsters, running from the police, are then transformed by the surreal mechanism of Mr. Pelevin's fiction into two hemp bugs inside a pipelike structure with a fire raging at one end.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: Then there are the two moths named Mitya and Dima, dead ringers for Beckett's Estragon and Vladimir, who talk earnestly about the mysterious connection between the light one is drawn to and the instant of death. They also talk of other matters.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: '' 'But I can't see what I've found,' said Mitya.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: '' 'Because you've found what sees,' Dima replied, 'Close your eyes and look.'
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: '' 'Wherever you like.' ''
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: Mr. Pelevin's new book, broader and more encompassing than ''Omon Ra,'' carries with it the power of its author's antic vision.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: At other times, as in this Beckettian passage, it's hard to decide whether he is being imitative or simply incomprehensible for the fun of it.
title: Philosophical Bugs in Russia? Quick, Ivan, the Flit!

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: Son of Paterson Bishop Choked on Bag of Drugs

text: The son of a Paterson clergyman who died in police custody on Friday night choked on a bag of marijuana he had swallowed voluntarily, the Passaic County Prosecutor said yesterday.
title: Son of Paterson Bishop Choked on Bag of Drugs

text: According to the Paterson police, Franklin Pettiford Jr., 46, swallowed the bag while locked inside a car, refusing to surrender to narcotics officers who had seen him buying drugs. The prosecutor, Ronald S. Fava, said a preliminary investigation had confirmed the police account.
title: Son of Paterson Bishop Choked on Bag of Drugs

text: ''It would be almost impossible to force someone to swallow something of this nature,'' Mr. Fava said. ''The autopsy indicated none of the trauma that would be observed if you tried to force something like this down someone's throat.''
title: Son of Paterson Bishop Choked on Bag of Drugs

text: Mr. Fava, however, said the inquiry into Mr. Pettiford's death was not complete.
title: Son of Paterson Bishop Choked on Bag of Drugs

text: Mr. Pettiford's father, Bishop Franklin Pettiford, who is the pastor of the Greater Bible Way Church, said he was skeptical of the police reports.
title: Son of Paterson Bishop Choked on Bag of Drugs

text: ''We're going to try to find out as much as we can, and I think that I would be less than a father if I did not,'' he said.
title: Son of Paterson Bishop Choked on Bag of Drugs

text: Senate's Debate on NATO Shifts Into High Gear
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Senate reopened the debate on the future of NATO. Supporters favor the expansion of the military alliance as a way to unite and stabilize Europe, but opponents argue that it will antagonize Russia and perhaps ignite a nuclear calamity. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Frank Words on Sanction Laws
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton, speaking to Evangelical Christians, made unusually frank remarks about laws that automatically impose sanctions on countries for behavior that Americans find unacceptable, saying they put pressure on his Administration to overlook violations. The Administration has been criticized for ignoring violations to justify continuing to do business with certain countries. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Security Council decided to extend sanctions against Iraq. The United States had vowed to veto any lifting of sanctions until Iraq met a number of requirements, including verifiable disarmament and the return of prisoners and property seized in Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada met with Fidel Castro for several hours. Mr. Chretien obtained agreements on two economic issues, but on human rights, he failed to win any concessions. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: An Auxiliary Roman Catholic Bishop, Juan Gerardi Conedera, was reported to have been beaten to death two days after he presented a scathing report on human rights violations during the country's 36-year civil war. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Switzerland's highest court indicated that United States prosecutors suspected almost from the start of an investigation that Raul Salinas, brother of Mexico's former President, had raised money in a Swiss bank account by protecting major drug traffickers. The Swiss court papers also established for the first time that the money found in bank accounts in November 1995 totaled $132 million. A5
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: An Israeli court sentenced three Israeli paramilitary border police officers to prison after they pleaded guilty to charges of kidnapping and assaulting two Palestinians last August. The beatings occurred during a roundup of Palestinians who had entered Israel without permits after access was closed because of a suicide bombing. (Reuters)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Runoff in Key Russia Race
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Aleksandr I. Lebed, a former general who is seeking to become governor of the Krasnoyarsk region of Russia as a step toward a possible presidential candidacy, will be in a runoff for the governor's position. In final returns, he placed first among eight candidates, with 45 percent of the vote in Sunday's election, short of the 50 percent needed for outright victory. Valery M. Zubov, the incumbent backed by the Kremlin, had 36 percent and will also be in the runoff. (AP)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Federal Monitor Lets Hoffa Stay in Teamsters Race
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Federal monitor ruled that James P. Hoffa could remain in the race for the teamsters' union presidency, but also found that Mr. Hoffa engaged in improprieties in the 1996 union election. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Supreme Court heard arguments on a challenge to the President's line-item veto power, which Congress approved in 1996 and a Federal judge struck down as unconstitutional in February. A17
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Pentagon officials recommended exhuming the body of a Vietnam veteran at the Tomb of the Unknowns after concluding that new tests would probably show that the remains belong to one of two pilots shot down over South Vietnam on the same day in 1972. A17
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Scientists at Duke University have found evidence suggesting that vocal capabilities like those of modern humans may have evolved among species of the Homo line more than 400,000 years ago. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Limits on campaign spending by political candidates are an unconstitutional limitation on free speech, a Federal Appeals Court ruled. A14
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Clinton Administration, acting a day before Senate hearings on the I.R.S., sought to neutralize likely accusations of misconduct by promising an independent review and other steps to assure taxpayers that they would be treated fairly. A16
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Clinton Administration announced its opposition to a California ballot initiative that would end bilingual education in the state. A15
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Surgeon General, Dr. David Satcher, warned that increases in smoking by minorities, especially minority teen-agers, threatened to reverse significant declines in the incidence of cancer. A16
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The four largest manufacturers of the blood-derived product intravenous immune globulin said they would begin releasing production data to allow for better monitoring of the shortage of the drug. A12
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A shortage of affordable housing for poor people is growing in many suburbs, according to a report by the Department of Housing and Urban Development that will be delivered to Congress today. A14
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Prosecutors in the Whitewater investigation have obtained the credit records of Monica S. Lewinsky; her mother, Marcia Lewis; Kathleen E. Willey, and Nathan Landow, a lawyer for a credit-reporting agency said. A17
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Giuliani Backs Pataki On Vetoes of Budget Items
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Mayor Giuliani backed Governor Pataki's vetoes of more than $1.5 billion in state spending, including $202 million from the city's school construction budget and millions more that would have gone to teachers' salaries and educational programs. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The New Jersey State Senate and Governor Whitman agreed on a compromise auto insurance plan that promised a 15 percent rate reduction for most motorists but that put off until 2000 the highly contentious issue of how much more urban drivers could be charged. The Assembly must still approve it. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Solomon to Retire From House
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, 67, a 10-term Republican from New York who is chairman of the powerful Rules Committee, announced that he would retire from the House at the end of the year. B2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Pier 84 on the West Side, which is host to urban sunbathers, weekend concerts and expensive private cruises, was closed on Friday after inspectors discovered that marine borers had dangerously eroded pilings that support parts of the two-and-a-half-acre pier. B3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Marijuana and other so-called social drugs will be among the substances banned in Olympic competition. C5
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The stock market dropped sharply across-the-board as rising interest rates made investors reconsider their bets on the 1998 rally, which had pushed the major indexes up 16 percent or more in less than four months. The Dow was down 146.98 points, or 1.6 percent, and finished below 9,000. Other major indexes fell even more. D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Editorials: Mr. Pataki's misguided vetoes; a sham transition in Nigeria; shortsighted Medicare oversight; topics.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, A. M. Rosenthal.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The subject tomorrow night is marijuana: how easy to grow, how profitable to sell, how severe the punishment if you are caught growing or selling or even just using. The producers of ''Busted: America's War on Marijuana'' take no position on the debate over the laws that have filled prisons with people who have committed a nonviolent crime, but they do clear the air a little.
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: This ''Frontline'' report begins in Indiana, in the heart of what is labeled ''the marijuana basket of America,'' with the arrest of a suspected grower. Half of the marijuana used in the United States is domestically grown, and it serves quite a market; the program puts it between 10 million and 30 million Americans, more than those who use all other illegal drugs combined. With an ounce of marijuana going for more than an ounce of gold (now above $300) these days, it's quite a commodity.
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: The program's experts distinguish marijuana from drugs like heroin and crack cocaine: it is less addictive, is not known for killing anyone, and at least one former drug agent notes that the people arrested for marijuana offenses do not strike him as a criminal element. But he adds that the serious charge against growers and sellers, which has brought very heavy Federal sentences since 1986, is marijuana's reputation as ''a threshold drug, the drug that most children start out with.'' Use of marijuana by youngsters has been increasing, their age decreasing.
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: Some users argue for their right to use and even grow the drug for reasons of health (voters in California and Arizona have passed laws more or less agreeing with them), religion or, as one activist puts it, the ''right of consumption.'' But the argument is not so much about legalizing it as about making the punishment for marijuana offenses more flexible.
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: ''Yes, I did break a law,'' says a man who was sentenced to five years for growing, ''but I was no threat to the community or to my kids or to anybody else.'' The narrator explains: ''Because mandatory minimum sentences do not allow parole, Federal prisoners convicted on nonviolent marijuana charges sometimes serve more time than convicted murderers sentenced under state law.''
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: Replying to proposals that sentencing should take into consideration the conduct of the people arrested, for example whether they are involved in violence or are promoting the drug among the young, hardliners like Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the Senate Judiciary Committee and continues to support the mandatory sentences, says, ''We ought to lock them up and throw away the keys.''
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: Glimpsed in this many-sided report is a division in Americans' attitudes toward marijuana, evidenced by the contrast between the law's stern approach and the much lighter treatment in popular culture. Meanwhile the famous war on marijuana goes on, costing the country at least $10 billion a year. Further inquiry is invited.
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: Busted: America's War on Marijuana
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: (Channel 13, New York, at 9)
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: Written and produced by Elena Mannes; Ted Winterburn, editor; Libby Kreutz, co-editor; Will Lyman, narrator. For ''Frontline'': Michael Sullivan, executive producer; David Fanning, senior executive producer. A ''Frontline'' co-production with Elena Mannes Productions.
title: A Question of Flexibility, Not Legality, About Marijuana

text: TALKING MONEY WITH: BOOMER ESIASON
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: FOR Boomer Esiason, the cold shower came at the end of his first season as a professional quarterback. In June 1984, fresh out of the University of Maryland, he had signed a three-year contract with the Cincinnati Bengals, reaped an immediate $600,000 signing bonus and, three months later, received his first year's pay of $275,000.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: For a 23-year-old middle-class kid from Long Island who had always had to scrimp for spending money, the sudden riches were intoxicating. ''You gotta have a Rolex, gotta have a car,'' Mr. Esiason said recently over lunch at Cite, a midtown Manhattan restaurant, recalling his ebullience at the time. ''These are things that I wanted all my life. You want to have a nice TV, nice clothes. Your girlfriend needs jewelry. I ended up putting her through school, and before you know it, there is $4,000 left and we're in April. And I think: 'What is this? I can't live like this.' ''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''I had to go back to the bank and borrow to make it through that second season,'' he continued. ''If you are a football player, or an athlete in general, you think, 'Wow, I just made $1 million. How can this happen?' ''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Mr. Esiason -- who waved back through the restaurant's window at the occasional pedestrian who recognized his finely chiseled face and mop of blond hair -- made two mistakes in those early years. And both are almost a rite of passage for newly minted sports heroes and other celebrities: He bought almost anything that caught his fancy, and he neglected to calculate how much tax he would owe.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''When you make $10 million, you don't make $10 million; you make $5 million, and part of that is going to agent fees,'' he said. ''Ask most young athletes what their tax bill is, and I bet they don't know.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Today, 14 years after that disastrous spending spree, Mr. Esiason is sitting pretty. By the time he retired last December from a football career that took him from the Cincinnati Bengals to the New York Jets to the Arizona Cardinals and then back to the Bengals -- and, in the process, to a Super Bowl -- he had earned an estimated $24 million in salaries and endorsement fees for products ranging from Nike sneakers to Diet Coke. In February, he signed a five-year contract with ABC, worth a reported $9 million, to be the game analyst for Monday Night Football.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Associates say Mr. Esiason has accumulated a fortune worth $11 million to $14 million, conservatively invested in a portfolio that is about 50 percent cash and fixed-income securities and 50 percent stocks. He has had some big winners, including Pomeroy Computer Resources, a business-services stock that he bought on a tip in 1993 and that has more than quintupled in value. He has had some losers, too, notably a stock fund with too much exposure to Southeast Asia that slumped by nearly a fifth in value last year. But most of his money is in tried-and-true funds with respectable gains, like the Rainier Core Equity fund, based in Seattle, which returned 33.8 percent last year, outperforming the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by about half a point.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Mr. Esiason, 37, also owns a home in Manhasset, N.Y., on Long Island, worth an estimated $1.3 million, where he lives with his wife, Cheryl (the girlfriend he put through school), and their two children, Gunnar, 7, and Sydney, 5. He also has a half interest in a $1.5 million vacation bungalow in Carefree, Ariz., and has a home in Cincinnati, where the Esiasons lived when he was playing for the Bengals and that he is now trying to sell for $1.1 million.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Just how did Boomer Esiason smarten up? What matured a financial babe-in-the-woods who blew his first two big paychecks, lost a small fortune in tax shelters and was generally clueless about his cash?
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Quarterbacks are supposed to be the cleverest players on the team, and after a lackluster first season in the pros, Mr. Esiason quickly grasped that his money-making potential wouldn't last forever. ''It hit me that this would be harder than I thought, and the reality came that I might not do this for 10 years,'' he recalled. As a result, he resolved to start saving and investing.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Five years ago, a family tragedy stiffened that resolve. His son Gunnar, then 2, was found to be suffering from cystic fibrosis, a life-threatening disorder of the exocrine glands.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''I was out on the field, getting ready for my first practice session with the Jets'' in Hempstead, N.Y., Mr. Esiason recalled.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''Suddenly I got a call from my wife to fly back back to Cincinnati,'' he continued. ''She told me Gunnar was going into the hospital.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: At Cincinnati Children's Hospital, he found the boy curled up in bed, vomiting mucous, with intravenous tubes attached to his arms. Then and there, Mr. Esiason said, ''I made up my mind that Gunnar would never want for anything.'' (Today, he says, Gunnar is doing ''pretty well'' and is benefiting from a new drug called Tobi.)
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: MR. ESIASON may have had his bout with self-indulgence, but his upbringing pulled him in a different direction. His father, Norman, had little interest in money except as a means to hold the family together. The elder Mr. Esiason, now 75 and still living in the home where Boomer grew up, in East Islip on Long Island, worked for an insurance company in Manhattan, but his main purpose in life was clearly taking care of Boomer and his two sisters.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: (Boomer was born Norman Julius Esiason Jr.; his mother gave him the nickname because he kicked so much in the womb.)
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''My mother died of cancer when I was in kindergarten,'' Boomer Esiason said. ''My father made the most unbelievable sacrifices for us. If I needed $5 for a date, he would reach in his pocket and give it to me. I never knew what he did for his own enjoyment.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: If there was a Rangers game in Manhattan, his father would take the train back home to Long Island after work to pick up his son, then return to the city where he had spent the day.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: There was a lot of sharing, if not much to share. ''My dad didn't make a lot of money, but he didn't care,'' Mr. Esiason recalled.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: His father has fond memories of those days, too. ''I used to take Boomer fishing on his birthday,'' he said, ''until he was playing with the teams and I couldn't take him out of school anymore.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''We were very close,'' he added. ''I had to do more than the average dad, and Boomer and I discussed things perhaps more than the average father and son.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: With money tight, there was little opportunity for travel. Mr. Esiason remembers driving his red 1969 Oldsmobile Cutlass convertible to the University of Maryland, where he had won a football scholarship, and realizing with a shock that he had never before set foot outside New York State.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: College was a financial struggle. Though his scholarship paid for his tuition, room and board, Boomer had no allowance, and to earn spending money he worked ''as a bouncer at a white-tablecloth restaurant'' called Joe Theismann's, after the famous Redskins quarterback. In times of crisis, Boomer would engage in a little credit card mischief. His father had given him a card to buy gasoline for his pickup (he had by then traded in the Olds), and he would occasionally ask friends to use the card and reimburse him for their purchases in cash.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''I paid the bill, but I didn't lose my house or anything,'' the elder Mr. Esiason said kiddingly.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Years later, during his first season with the Bengals, Boomer Esiason returned the favor. His father refused his offer of a new house, but did let his now-famous son pay for renovations. And he accepted the gift of a new 1984 black-and-silver Cadillac Seville -- ''the worst car I ever had in terms of breaking down,'' he said with a laugh.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: IN the early years of his professional football career, Boomer Esiason had tastes that ran more to luxury than his father's: He flew first class to Acapulco with his wife and stayed at the costly Princess Hotel, for example.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: The same insouciance pervaded his investment strategy, such as it was. Mr. Esiason said he basically gave his accountant free rein, with a result that much of his money ended up in tax shelters, like limited partnerships that drilled for oil or acquired real estate or cattle. The deals were popular, like many others at the time, but ended up losing money or falling afoul of the Internal Revenue Service, or both.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''I was young,'' Mr. Esiason said, adding that his accountant was being courted ''by people who said: 'Let's get him into this apartment deal. Let's get into the tax-shelter deal.' I'm surprised I wasn't involved in Whitewater.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Mr. Esiason was clearly out of his element. Even today, he acknowledged, he lacks financial sophistication. ''I know how to read a profit-and-loss statement, but when it comes to the details, it is a special language,'' he said. ''I have learned the hard way. All you have to do is look at the bottom of the page and see if there are parentheses,'' he continued, referring to the symbol for losses.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: By 1986, Mr. Esiason was looking at losses of an estimated $200,000 from investments.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: About this time, Mr. Esiason linked up with a new financial adviser, Nina Mitchell, now with a firm called Financial Advisory Management Enterprises in Washington, which specializes in handling the portfolios of professional athletes. He was immediately impressed with her no-nonsense manner.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''She came on board and was pretty cold-hearted,'' he said. Her essential message? ''You gotta wake up now.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Ms. Mitchell's advice was simple. Forget about high-risk investments or complicated financial instruments and invest in liquid assets, including securities that can be traded easily. Interest rates were higher then -- those for one-year Treasury bills were about 7 percent, compared with just over 5.1 percent today -- and Ms. Mitchell put about 80 percent of Mr. Esiason's portfolio in tax-free municipal bonds.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''Boomer had been exposed to so much risk in tax shelters that we needed to preserve his principal,'' she said.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Ms. Mitchell also put her client on a strict spending budget and set financial goals for him. And Mr. Esiason fell into line. Here was a woman who clearly was not intimidated by celebrities.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''Lots of people will work for athletes for nothing,'' said Ms. Mitchell, now 39. ''But I didn't care about being with athletes. I took the job and worked six days a week. Once you are in their skin, they begin to trust you.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Mr. Esiason and Ms. Mitchell discuss all investments, though he generally follows her advice in deciding how and where to allocate his money. She says that today, half his money is in money-market funds and municipal bonds, and half in stocks, including mutual funds and privately managed accounts. She says the overall return on his investments in 1997 was in the ''mid-teens.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Aside from Rainier Core Equity, he also has money with Brandywine Asset Management, in Wilmington, Del., which invests in foreign companies, mostly in Europe, but has very little exposure to emerging markets like Southeast Asia. According to Ms. Mitchell, his Brandywine account showed a gain of 13.7 percent last year, compared with 1.8 percent for the Morgan Stanley Europe, Australia and Far East index, a common benchmark for such funds.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: He has also done well with J.& W. Seligman & Company, a money management firm in New York, which has put some of his money in small companies with high growth potential. That account gained 18.5 percent last year, compared with a 13 percent return for the Russell 2000.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: But Mr. Esiason had a bad run with another firm, Newgate Management Associates of Greenwich, Conn., which invested heavily in emerging markets. Though only 3 percent of his investments were with Newgate, his individual account there declined by nearly 18 percent last year, as the Southeast Asia crisis hit, Ms. Mitchell said, and he closed the account in January. Mr. Esiason also picks some stocks himself. He is especially proud of Pomeroy, a Cincinnati company that provides desktop computer products to businesses; he learned about it through a friend. His $60,000 investment in 1993 has increased more than fivefold.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Other stocks in his portfolio that have done well include Strayer Education Inc., which offers degree programs on nine campuses and which Ms. Mitchell suggested; it has also more than quintupled in value since he bought it, in July 1996.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Mr. Esiason continues to dabble in private deals, though none have paid off and Ms. Mitchell discourages the idea. He describes one such plan, dating to the early 1990's:
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''We had a novel idea that we tried to sell to Home Shopping Network,'' he said. ''It was a half-hour sitcom with story lines like 'Cheers' or those shows. There was a program with a dialogue going on between three or four actors like, 'What kind of a jacket is that? Well, that's a Cannali, man, and it's really great.' ''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: The cable network wasn't interested. ''It just never hit,'' he said. ''People want the straight sell.'' He consoles himself by noting that he sinks only small sums into such projects.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ONE investment he doesn't touch is that perennial favorite of aging ex-athletes, the franchise operation. There are no McDonald's or carwashes in Mr. Esiason's holdings. He gently mocks the rationale of some sports celebrities for going into such businesses. ''They say: 'Let's do a carwash because I like to get my car washed five times a week. There have to be some other lunatics out there.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Not only do these people overestimate demand, they tend to underestimate the effort required, in his view. ''If your blood sweat is not going to be invested, don't go near it,'' he said. ''You can't make money.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: But while he often goes with his gut, he never makes a move without consulting his financial guru, Ms. Mitchell. Though fewer football players get the kinds of astronomical deals that have put some basketball players in the headlines in recent years, top athletes like Mr. Esiason often have a panoply of advisers. Fred Fried, a partner at Integrated Sports International, a sports marketing firm in East Rutherford, N.J., handled his endorsement deals and the ABC contract, while Ms. Mitchell's firm, best known for negotiating Michael Jordon's contract with the Chicago Bulls, counsels him on personal investments. Jerrold Colton, a lawyer in Cherry Hill, N.J., arranged his final contract with the Bengals.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''Fred makes my money, and Nina saves it,'' Mr. Esiason said. ''Nina and I talk three or four times a week.'' While he also reads the financial pages and watches CNBC, he consults with Ms. Mitchell on everything from buying a home to getting a $600 check mailed to the gym where he works out.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Indeed, in his recent hunt for the perfect place on Long Island, he said, he fancied one house but Nina sided with his wife in favoring another. ''I told them, 'it's 2 to 1, you win,' '' he said.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Another woman plays a big role in his financial life -- Tami Amaker, the executive director of the Boomer Esiason Foundation, which he set up in 1993 to aid research for the disease that afflicts Gunnar. The foundation has paid out $3 million, about 85 percent of what it has raised so far.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: IS there some reason, Mr. Esiason is asked, that he entrusts so much decision-making to women? Perhaps, he replies, it is because he grew up with two sisters and just feels more comfortable around them. But it is more than that. ''I know guys, and sometimes I don't trust guys,'' he said.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: In Ms. Mitchell's view, Mr. Esiason is convinced that ''if you want something done, ask a woman to do it.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''Women will roll up their sleeves and get it done,'' she continued. ''Boomer has big ideas, but it takes someone to get him from A to Z.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Besides, she says, men in general are more willing to put their financial ignorance on display before women than in the company of other men. ''They can ask questions that for their ego, they might not ask a man because they would feel like less of a person,'' she said. ''With me, there is no ego.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: All in all, the performance of Mr. Esiason's portfolio has hardly been stunning -- but that hasn't been his aim. He wants slow, steady, predictable growth, he says.
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: ''Actually, I am doing really well,'' he said. ''I am just riding a wave. In the overseas markets I will take some hits. But the small caps are doing well. I am not backing a Brink's truck up to my house, but we are doing O.K.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: With the exception of the mortgage on his Long Island home, Mr. Esiason has no debt. ''I want peace of mind'' he said. ''Debt takes that away from you and I have two children. That is a legacy I don't want them to be stuck with.''
title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays

text: Domino's it wasn't, but the service was still swell -- at least until the police placed an order.
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: Such was the end of a Queens operation described by law enforcement investigators as a ''customer friendly'' full-service drug-delivery business. Clients, the investigators said, would call saying ''we're hungry,'' and cocaine or marijuana would arrive soon thereafter to satisfy their appetites.
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: ''They operated much like a pizza delivery service,'' an investigator, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said of the drug business. ''It was immediate gratification. And if a customer didn't like the batch he got, they would always discount the next. They wanted to keep the customer happy.''
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: The 13 people arrested included 2 brothers, 2 married couples, a retired correction officer and a man named Giuliani -- no, not that one.
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: All of them were charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance and conspiracy to sell it, the Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. If convicted, each would face up to life in prison.
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: According to the District Attorney's office, two suspects, Georgios Botonis and his brother, Lambrino, started their business around 1990 in the shadows of a larger operation known as the Michaelidis Crew. Hemmed in, the Botonis brothers and their minions sold small bags of cocaine and marijuana in Queens, their annual revenue topping out at a meager $250,000. But the brothers were able to expand their scope last June, when the police swooped down on the Michaelidis Crew, arresting 20 or so members, prosecutors said.
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: From their bases in Astoria and Long Island City, the Botonis brothers branched out into Flushing, Queens, and Westbury on Long Island, prosecutors said. With little competition, their revenues mushroomed to more than $2 million a year, they said.
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: Dealers employed by the Botonis brothers were supplied with pagers. When an order was placed, a delivery man would rush to the customer's location and hand off what the Botonis brothers apparently referred to as ''food,'' Mr. Brown said.
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: But the business collapsed Tuesday night when Queens detectives and investigators executed four search warrants. Among the properties searched was the Flushing home of Maurice Giuliani, 29, where officers found 1.5 kilograms of cocaine, prosecutors said. The District Attorney's office said that Mr. Giuliani appeared to be no relation to Rudolph W.
title: Police Say Drug Ring Imitated Fast-Food Delivery Style

text: After a brief court-ordered closing, this city's most famous medical marijuana club reopened today under a new name and director, once again thwarting efforts by the California Attorney General to shut it down.
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: The closing resulted from a ruling in San Francisco County Superior Court on April 15 that the Cannabis Cultivators Club, which opened in 1992 and has a membership of 8,000, was ''clearly engaging in the illegal sale of marijuana.'' The court also ordered the club's founder, Dennis R. Peron, to quit selling marijuana.
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: The ruling came out of a civil case brought by Attorney General Dan Lungren after a 1996 raid on the club by state drug agents. Sheriff's deputies closed the club on Monday, changing the locks on the club's five-story downtown headquarters and turning over the keys to the owner of the building.
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: But in a plan hatched last week and widely reported in newspapers here, Mr. Peron stepped down as director and turned over the lease to a member, a 79-year-old woman who proceeded to reopen the club today as the Cannabis Healing Center.
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: ''You can say it's all semantic mumbo jumbo,'' said Mr. Peron, who also said the club was operating lawfully under the 1996 state law legalizing marijuana for medical use, which he helped write. ''But they wanted to shut down the club on a technicality, and so we're going to go with the letter of the law.''
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: Mr. Peron promised to have nothing further to do with club management and devote all his time to his long-shot campaign against Mr. Lungren for the Republican nomination for governor. But Mr. Peron also faces criminal drug charges brought by Mr. Lungren across the San Francisco Bay, in Alameda County. And he is a co-defendant in a Federal civil case brought by the United States Justice Department seeking to close down six Northern California marijuana clubs.
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: Rob Stutzman, a spokesman for Mr. Lungren, said the Attorney General was considering action against the new center.
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: Legal questions remain for the future of the medical marijuana outlet.
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: In 1996, about 56 percent of California voters approved a state initiative, Proposition 215, legalizing the possession of marijuana for the seriously ill and their caregivers.
title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens

text: In the search to explain the spike in smoking among black teen-agers, a range of theories has evolved, from the proliferation of tobacco advertising in minority communities to the stress of adolescence to the identification with entertainment idols who appear with cigarettes dangling from their lips.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Teen-agers themselves, and some experts who have studied adolescent smoking, add another, less predictable explanation to the mix of factors: the decision to take up smoking because of a belief that cigarettes prolong the heady rush of marijuana.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: ''It makes the high go higher,'' said Marquette, a 16-year-old student at Saunders Trades and Technical High School here who, like other students, spoke about her marijuana use on the condition that only her first name be used.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: At Washington Preparatory High School in South-Central Los Angeles, Tifanni, also 16, said she took up cigarettes two months ago because, ''If the marijuana goes down and you get a cigarette, it will go up again.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Black teen-agers like Marquette and Tifanni are not unusual, according to interviews with dozens of adolescents around the country and various national surveys. These surveys show that blacks begin smoking cigarettes later than white teen-agers, but start using marijuana earlier, a difference experts say they cannot explain.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The surveys also show a sharp rise in both cigarette and marijuana use among teen-agers in recent years, evident among all races but most pronounced among blacks. White teen-agers still smoke cigarettes at twice the rate of blacks, but the gap is narrowing, signaling the end of low smoking rates among black youths that had been considered a public health success story.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: It is not clear how much of the increase in smoking among black teen-agers is due to the use of cigarettes with marijuana, and experts say advertising has been the main factor. But the marijuana-tobacco combination is notable because it is the reverse of the more common progression from cigarette and alcohol use to illegal drugs.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Many black teen-agers said in interviews that they were drawn to cigarettes by friends who told them that nicotine would enhance their high from marijuana, which has been lore and practice among drug users of all races for decades. And this is apparently no mere myth. Many scientists who study brain chemistry say the link between cigarettes and marijuana is unproven but likely true.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: ''African-American youth talk very explicitly about using smoking to maintain a high,'' said Robin Mermelstein, a professor at the University of Illinois at Chicago and the principal investigator in an ongoing study of why teen-agers smoke for the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. ''It's a commonly stated motivator.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Dr. Mermelstein said that in focus groups with 1,200 teen-agers around the country, about half the blacks mentioned taking up cigarettes to enhance a marijuana high, but no white teen-agers volunteered that as an explanation for smoking. ''Cigarettes have a totally different functional value for black and white kids,'' she said.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Even so, Dr. Mermelstein and others say that does not diminish the greater impact of advertising and other media messages in minority neighborhoods. ''Kids are extraordinarily aware of the entertainment media,'' Dr. Mermelstein said. ''They are very reluctant to see the link between any of these and their behavior. But the influence is undoubtedly there.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Tiffany Faulkner, a 15-year-old at Ida B. Wells High School in Jamaica, Queens, said, ''Tupac smoked and he's my man,'' referring to the slain rap star Tupac Shakur. ''But I didn't smoke because of him,'' she said. ''I have my own head.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Brand loyalty, however, suggests youths are more moved by the advertising than they realize, or are willing to admit. In general, Marlboro and Camel have white characters on billboards and are the brands of choice among white teen-agers, while Kool and Newport use minority images and are favored by African-American teen-agers, as they are by their parents. Outside Brighton High School in Boston, for instance, every black student in a group of smokers chose Newports. ''They're the cool cigarette,'' said Joey Simone, 18, a smoker since she was 11.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: A 16-year-old Chicago girl who tried cigarettes briefly said she is certain advertising is the key. ''When I was little I would see pictures of people standing around with a cigarette and it looked like fun,'' said Coleco Davis at DuSable High School. ''They were all having a good time and it didn't look like it could hurt you.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: This wave of new black smokers, drawn to a habit that kills more people each year than all illegal drugs combined, has researchers worried, because once teen-agers have experienced the booster rocket effect of cigarettes prolonging a marijuana high they often find themselves addicted to tobacco.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: ''Because I was getting high, I needed it,'' said Mary, 16, a student at Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan. ''The cigarettes made me more high. Now it's become a habit. I feel bad because there's nothing I can do to stop.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The crescendo of concern about teen-age smoking is behind pending Federal legislation that would raise the price of cigarettes, control advertising to young people and penalize manufacturers if there is not a gradual reduction in adolescent smoking. That legislation took center stage in Washington just as a new study earlier this month showed a steep rise in the smoking rate among black youths.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The nationwide Federal study showed overall smoking rates had increased by one third among high school students between 1991 and 1997. Most alarming to experts was the sharp rise among black youths: 22.7 percent in 1997, up from 12.6 percent six years earlier.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Charyn Sutton, whose Philadelphia marketing company conducts focus groups for Federal research agencies, said she first heard about the current progression from marijuana to cigarettes -- what she calls the ''reverse gateway effect'' -- during focus groups in 1995 involving black middle school students. Ms. Sutton already knew about blunts, cigars hollowed of tobacco and filled with marijuana. But now the teen-agers told her that a practice familiar to the drug cognoscenti as early as the 1960's and 1970's was popular in the schoolyard of the late 1990's -- enhancing the high of a joint with a cigarette.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: She tested what the teen-agers told her by talking to addicts in recovery, who concurred. And to be sure that the pattern she was seeing in Philadelphia was not a local anomaly, she interviewed young African-Americans across the nation. And, she said, she discovered that they were doing the same thing.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The enhancing effect that teen-agers describe is consistent with what is already known about the working of nicotine and THC, the active ingredient in marijuana. Both spur production of dopamine, a brain chemical that produces pleasurable sensations, said George Koob, a professor of neuro-pharmacology at the Scripps Research Institute in La Jolla, Calif. ''It makes a lot of sense,'' Dr. Koob said.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: At the National Institute on Drug Abuse, which funds most of the world's research on addiction, Alan I. Lesher, the director, went a step further, saying the anecdotal findings cried out for rigorous investigation. ''This is a reasonable scientific question,'' he said. ''And if enough people report experiencing it, it merits consideration.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: Researchers elsewhere have also taken note of strange glitches in substance abuse data comparing blacks and whites. For instance, Denise Kandel, a professor of public health and psychology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, found that while most substance abusers progressed logically from legal to illegal substances, ''the pattern of progression is less regular among blacks and nobody really knows why.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: In 1991, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 14.7 percent of students said they had used marijuana in the last 30 days; by 1995, the latest year for which data is available, that rate had jumped to 25.3 percent. Among white youths, the rate increased to 24.6 percent from 15.2. Among Hispanics, it shot up to 27.8 from 14.4 and among blacks to 28.8 from 13.5, vaulting them from last place to first in marijuana use by racial group.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The C.D.C. cigarette study, which tracks use through 1997, shows a parallel pattern. Among white students, 39.7 percent said they smoked cigarettes, up from 30.9 percent six years ago. Among Hispanic students, more than one third now say they smoke, up from roughly a quarter. Among black youths, 22.7 percent list themselves as smokers, compared with the 12.6 who said they smoked in 1991. Worst of all were the smoking rates for black males, which doubled in the course of the study, to 28.2 from 14.1.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The progression from marijuana to cigarettes among black youths was the most provocative finding in interviews in recent days with high school students in New York City, its suburbs, Los Angeles, Chicago and Boston, who consistently raised the issue without being asked. But their comments raised several other troubling issues, as well.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The students were perfectly aware of the health hazards of cigarette smoking. A 17-year-old at Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan said she was quitting because she might be pregnant. A 15-year-old at Saunders said she did not smoke during basketball and softball season but resumed in between.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: But most paid no mind to the danger.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: And despite laws prohibiting sales to anyone under 18, virtually all the teen-agers said they purchased cigarettes with no trouble at delis and bodegas.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The Federal legislation to curb teen-age smoking depends in large measure on steep price increases as a deterrent. Sponsors of the bill say that raising the price by $1.10 per pack would reduce youth smoking by as much as 40 percent. But talking to high school students suggests this prediction is optimistic.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: The adolescents said overwhelmingly that they would pay $3.60 a pack -- the current $2.50 charged in New York plus the additional $1.10 envisioned in the legislation. A few said that $5 a pack might inspire them to quit, or at least to try.
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: But faced with that high a tariff, 17-year-old Robert Reid, a student in Yonkers, had another idea. ''At that price,'' he said, ''you might as well buy weed.''
title: Young Blacks Link Tobacco Use to Marijuana

text: There was a strange contradiction at the Terrastock festival, a three-day marathon of underground psychedelic folk, pop, rock and experimental music that ended on Sunday at the Custer Avenue Stages here: the music celebrated drugs for an audience that didn't.
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: Mick Farren of the 1960's proto-punk band the Deviants began his set with a story about a time he had taken ''a whole lotta acid.'' Tom Rapp of the 60's acid-folk group Pearls Before Swine sang a new chorus he had written, ''Nothing wrong with marijuana/You should use it if you wanna.'' And Nick Saloman of the English rock band Bevis Frond, who publishes the magazine that sponsored the two-year-old festival, Ptolemaic Terrascope, introduced a song thus: ''This one continues the theme of drug-taking, and involves driving trains.''
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: Yet the audience at the festival, one of the few where bouncers and security forces weren't even a presence, seemed completely sober the whole time. Except for the gentleman who spent an hour videotaping a speck of dust on the floor, no one appeared to be on drugs or talking about drugs and there was no odor of marijuana smoke, a smell that is de rigueur at nearly any such concert. The audience and most of the bands Terrastock catered to were interested not in mind-expanding drugs, but in the musical exploration and the expansion of form that has resulted from musicians taking such drugs and trying to play their instruments.
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No
