text: Standing in front of immense, breathtaking video backdrops projected by Jeff Crane, performers played dense guitar jams (the bands Bevis Frond, Bardo Pond and Ghost), psychedelic folk (Damon and Naomi, Tom Rapp and Stone Breath), pop songs sabotaged by improvisation or nontraditional instrumentation (Olivia Tremor Control, Neutral Milk Hotel and Green Pajamas), rock music shot through with analog electronic instruments (Cul de Sac, the Lothars, Fifty Foot Hose and Silver Apples) and, the festival's specialty, minimal, droning, gently propulsive rock (Windy and Carl, Azusa Plane, Grimble Grumble and Roy Montgomery).
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: A few acts fit into no category, including the Spaceheads, an English duo that made bewitching abstract dance music using just trumpet and drums, and Kendra Smith, a reclusive former member of the Dream Syndicate who pursued her mystical, medieval, spiritual and Luddite obsessions through pump organ, a Bohemian lute and soft singing.
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: Perhaps because the music was somewhat retro, separated from its original cultural context, the audience was there just to listen (not to socialize or make a life style statement). After their performances, some band members expressed surprise that the crowd -- 800 people willing to spend as much as 14 hours each day in a warehouse watching nearly 40 bands -- was so quiet and attentive. Even most of the musicians who performed stayed all three days to listen to music and sit at tables in a back room selling their own CD's.
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: The message of underground music festivals like Terrastock can be summarized in two words: dig deeper. In some ways, the music at the festival, a mix of current underground bands and their obscure antecedents from the 1960's and 70's, wasn't any more experimental than elements of what the Beatles and John Lennon or Pink Floyd and its former leader, Syd Barrett, did. But as a rule it promoted the music that didn't get the acclaim, often because it was too bizarre or ahead of its time to win recognition.
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: Some performers at the festival stopped making music decades ago, thinking their time was up, and have gone in other directions. There was a musician-turned-lawyer (Mr. Rapp) and even a news announcer and ice cream truck driver (Simeon of the pioneering electronic hippie band the Silver Apples). Eddie Shaw of the Monks, a bizarre pre-punk concept band of American G.I.'s stationed in Germany in the 60's, was on hand to read from a book he wrote on the group. One of the most impressive aspects of Terrastock was the sheer perseverance of some performers. Bevis Frond has been making great psychedelic rock for 12 years; the Green Pajamas have been honing their bright pop songs in obscurity for 14 years, and the Young Fresh Fellows have been making quirky, eclectic pop and garage-rock for just as long.
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: Though their efforts have been rewarded by little more than a constantly fluctuating cult following, some of them still haven't hung up their dreams of success and all of them have songs capable of being hits. After all, it took similarly eclectic psychedelic-oriented bands like the Flaming Lips and the Meat Puppets more than a decade to score their first (and only) pop hits. Then again, it took the Silver Apples, Pearls Before Swine and the Monks over 30 years to build up just this tiny following.
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: But Terrastock is not a festival that rewards success. Popularity may disqualify a band forever from the hipster collector underground. Some see this as a sign of closed-minded obscurantism, in which the esoteric is lauded regardless of its merit. But the truth is that Terrastock and its audience are part of a necessary support system, because in a music business centered on the search for the next big thing, someone has to dig through record catalogues to discover the next good thing, or search the archives to rediscover the last lost thing.
title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No

text: TRAY was The Man,'' Junior Felix decreed as he mopped the dark stairway of a beat-up apartment building on East 159th Street in the Bronx. ''He showed mad love. He never used to flip. He just The Man.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: Actually, The Man was a dog. Tray was a pit bull, to be exact, which means that not everyone on the block in Melrose shared Junior's warm thoughts. On Jan. 6, fire marshals shot the dog after he chased one of them onto the roof of a car in a parking lot they use on the block, and he died several days later. Fire investigators deemed it a justifiable shooting, saying that the dog had menaced other marshals before and that no one was around that day to call him off.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: Anthony Garcia, the dog's owner, disputes that version. He insists that he was there shouting ''That's my dog!'' but refused to jump between his dog and marshals who had their guns drawn.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: He insists that his dog never bit anyone. In fact, among Mr. Garcia's buddies, the dog's reputation for friendliness and obedience is larger than life. Still is in death, too.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: A few weeks ago, Mr. Garcia commissioned a huge graffiti memorial wall -- the kind usually reserved for people -- to honor his dog. A perfect portrait of the sad-eyed pup is beside a banner that reads ''All Dogs Go to Heaven'' and his street name, Tray Bag, slang for a $3 bag of marijuana. So that no one forgets what happened, he made sure it was painted directly across the street from where the dog was killed.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''I put the mural there so every day when the marshals go out they see my dog,'' he said. ''That's how I'm paying them back.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: And each morning, Mr. Garcia goes to the wall to pay his respects.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''I get up and kiss the wall,'' he said. ''I tell people, 'Look at my dog. He's sitting over there. Tray, stay.' And he's sitting there. People think I'm crazy. But I love that dead dog.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: Oddly enough, even some of the fire marshals stationed in the neighborhood have taken a liking to the wall. ''It's beautiful,'' said one, who refused to give his name. ''It's a nice piece of work.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: In some ways, this was not an unusual shooting. In 1997, for example, the police fatally shot more canine suspects than human ones: 83 versus 20. Marilyn Mode, the Police Department's Deputy Commissioner for Public Information, said the number of fatal shootings has decreased in recent years, but added that officers were worried about drug dealers using attack dogs to protect their stashes. ''We train our officers to use other methods, but sometimes it is necessary,'' she said. ''I can assure you, no officer wants to shoot a dog.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: THERE certainly was nothing typical in this case about Mr. Garcia's response. In some neighborhoods, elaborate memorial murals are common sights on corners where young people died violently. But a wall for a dog?
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: Why not? said Mr. Garcia and his friends. People would always ask him about the dog before even saying ''hi'' to him, Mr. Garcia said. Friends would feed him hot dogs -- by hand, not thrown on the sidewalk. Others would put cans atop fences and watch the dog jump up and snatch them.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''Dogs are human, too,'' said Raul Fernandez, who used to be terrified of dogs. ''He didn't bite anybody even if you told him to. That dog took away all the fear I had of dogs. He wasn't a pit. He was one of us.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: But of course, he was a pit bull, which may have sealed his fate among some people. Defenders of the breed say its looks belie its inner beauty. With a mug like that, they have to work hard to win you over.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''People think pits are crazy,'' Mr. Garcia said. ''It's how you raise them. If you give a dog love and treat him good, he's not going to react and go crazy. If you beat and kick them, then they're going to return that. They'll get mad and snap.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: Mr. Garcia grows quiet, looks down to the floor of his apartment and bites his lip when asked how he feels about the dog. He ducks into his bedroom and emerges with a silver-colored bone medallion engraved with ''R.I.P. Tray Bag. We Love You.'' He also kept Tray's studded leather collar, still smeared with dirt and dried blood. In the living room, he keeps a wooden plaque that reads: ''Tray Bag. Will Allway Love You.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: And then there is the wall. He had first planned to have someone draw the dog's face on his bedroom wall. Then he decided to contact the TATS Cru, a trio that runs a business doing aerosol art advertisements on gates, walls and clothing. They have also done dozens of memorial walls in the Bronx and Manhattan.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''We hadn't done one in a long time, it feels good to say,'' said Hector Nazario, one of the artists, who is known as Nicer. ''At the same time, it was freaky to do one for a dog.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: They were reluctant, since some people thought a mural for a dog would demean the ones they have done for humans. But when they went to Mr. Garcia's apartment and listened to his story, it was as if they were hearing a tearful father talk about a dead child.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''You could tell he was really deep about this dog,'' said Wilfredo Feliciano, an artist better known as Bio. ''People find it funny. They can't see someone going to that extra step for an animal. But people who love pets can relate to it.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: They went the extra step to make their wall as realistic as possible, with all the details their human walls featured. In one corner, they painted a candle next to a plate of food.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''I put a chicken leg on the plate,'' Mr. Nazario said. ''But I had to change it to a steak.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''I told him a dog would choke on chicken!'' Mr. Feliciano said. ''He tried to kill the dog twice!''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: Now, the dog that Mr. Garcia carried in his heart is also on the wall. He walked outside a few days ago to look at it.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: ''This is my man,'' he said. ''Tray Bag.'' He leaned close and kissed the painted pup right on the nose. He surveyed the block, which is a bleak stretch. He'd like to get a job and move, he said. He used to have trouble with the law, he admitted, but he said he wanted to change for the sake of his 9-year-old son.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: He glanced again at the mural. ''See, he got a plate of steak,'' he said. ''No doubt. No doubt.''
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: As for himself, he has a new dog, a cinnamon-colored pit bull puppy. He plans to keep this one on a leash and in his sight. The dog's name? Rage.
title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog

text: MORISHIMA-Akira, MD, PhD, Associate Professor of Pediatrics. The Department of Pediatrics of the College of Physicians & Surgeons at Columbia University and the Pediatric Service and Alumni Association of Babies & Children's Hospital of New York, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, mourn the loss of their esteemed friend and colleague. A former Director of the Division of Pediatric Endocrinology (1968-1995), Dr. Morishima was an early leader in the field of genetics and did innovative work with his mentor, Melvin Grumbach, MD, in describing normal characteristics as well as disorders of the X chromosome. He also was involved in collaborative studies on the mutagenic properties of marijuana and other recreational drugs. Most recently, and most importantly, Dr. Morishima, through his insights from work with patients, elucidated in a very exciting way the role estrogen plays in bone growth and bone calcification and in normal pituitary-gonadal interactions in both sexes. Dr. Morishima maintained professional ties with Japan as a visiting professor and keynote speaker at professional meetings and was active in the Japanese-American communities in New York and New Jersey. In recognition of these activities, in 1975 he received the prestigious ''Presentation of a Favour'' from the Emperor and Empress of Japan. Dr. Morishima was an enthusiastic teacher and generous colleague. We are grateful for the guidance and insights he gave us during his long years of leadership in the Department and in the field of pediatric endocrinology. John M. Driscoll, Jr., MD Reibem S. Carpentier Professor Director, Pediatric Service Chairman, Dept of Pediatrics
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORISHIMA, AKIRA, MD, PHD

text: MORISHIMA-Dr. Akira. With fondness I will remember your clinical, academic and ethical standards, your quiet hospitality and your friendship. Rest peacefully Maribeth Southworth
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORISHIMA, AKIRA, MD, PHD

text: The news from the drug front discussed by A. M. Rosenthal (column, April 14) presents a mixed picture. Scientific data about the short- and long-term effects on the brain of drugs like cocaine and marijuana are increasing, as is our ability to treat addicts. We continue to learn more about the commonality of the way these drugs act and how they hijack the brain, eroding, but not erasing, the ability to control their use.
title: Fighting the Drug War

text: We are improving our medications and our behavioral interventions. Yet at the same time millions of dollars are poured into the fray by legalizers and their sympathizers -- who flood newspapers with letters whenever an anti-legalization view like Mr. Rosenthal's appears, helping cloud the issues of drug glamorization and the dramatic rise in adolescent drug use.
title: Fighting the Drug War

text: on Addiction and Substance Abuse
title: Fighting the Drug War

text: New York, April 17, 1998
title: Fighting the Drug War

text: Linda Eastman McCartney, the wife of the former Beatle Paul McCartney and a photographer whose portraits of 1960's rock stars have become classics, died on Friday in Santa Barbara, Calif., where the McCartneys were vacationing. She was 56.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: The cause was breast cancer that spread to her liver, said Geoff Baker, a family spokesman.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: Besides her work as a photographer, Ms. McCartney performed as a keyboardist and backup singer in two of her husband's post-Beatles bands, Wings and the unnamed ensemble that toured in 1989 and 1993. She was a staunch campaigner for animal rights and vegetarianism and, starting in the late 1980's, she turned her passion for vegetarian cooking into an industry. She published two cookbooks, ''Linda McCartney's Home Cooking'' in 1989 and ''Linda's Kitchen'' in 1996, and in 1991 started a line of frozen vegetarian dinners.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: As the wife of a musician who had long been a teen-age heartthrob and was the last Beatle to be married, Ms. McCartney first attracted the ire of her husband's fans, and eventually the respect of many of them. When the McCartneys were married in London on March 12, 1969, hundreds of crying girls packed the sidewalk outside the Marylebone Register Office. Later, when she toured with Mr. McCartney, she took considerable criticism for her modest keyboard and vocal technique.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: But the McCartneys' 29-year marriage was uncommonly steady by the standards of the celebrity world of which they were a part but from which they generally remained aloof, spending most of their time on a farm in West Sussex, England. They never spent a night apart, except for the 10 days Mr. McCartney spent in a Tokyo jail after he was arrested for marijuana possession; indeed, their disinclination to be separated was part of Mr. McCartney's reason for having his wife in his touring band.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: And Mr. McCartney, the composer of some of the rock era's most beautiful love songs, has consistently told interviewers that all his romantic ballads written after 1968 were about Linda. Those songs include everything from ''Maybe I'm Amazed'' and ''The Lovely Linda'' on his first post-Beatles album, ''McCartney'' (1970), ''Long-Haired Lady'' on ''Ram'' (1971) and ''My Love'' on ''Red Rose Speedway'' (1973) to more recent songs like ''We Got Married'' and ''Figure of Eight'' on ''Flowers in the Dirt'' (1989) and ''Somedays'' on ''Flaming Pie'' (1997), his most recent studio album.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: Mr. McCartney was not the first to compose a song about Ms. McCartney. Her father, Lee Eastman, was a prominent show business lawyer in New York and one of his clients, Jack Lawrence, wrote ''Linda'' for her in 1947 when she was 6. Buddy Clark had a hit with the song that year, and it was later recorded by Perry Como and Jan and Dean.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: Ms. McCartney also wrote a few songs, including the reggae-style ''Seaside Woman,'' which she and Mr. McCartney released as a single in 1977 under the name Suzy and the Red Stripes, and ''The White-Coated Man,'' which she wrote with Carla Lane and released (also as Suzy and the Red Stripes) on an animal-rights charity disk, ''Animal Magnetism,'' in 1994.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: She was born Linda Louise Eastman on September 24, 1941, and grew up in Scarsdale, N.Y. As she often pointed out, without ever dispelling the assertion entirely, she was not related to the Eastmans of the Eastman-Kodak photography empire. In fact, her father had changed his name from Epstein.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: She described growing up in artistic and materialistic surroundings, with a status-conscious mother and a father whose friends and clients included the artist Willem de Kooning and the songwriters Hoagy Carmichael and Harold Arlen.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: Ms. McCartney attended Sarah Lawrence College and the University of Arizona. While a student in Arizona, she married and had a daughter, but the marriage ended in 1963.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: Soon afterward, she took up photography, and in 1965 she returned to New York, where she began photographing rock groups, starting with the Dave Clark Five and the Rolling Stones. During the next few years she befriended and photographed dozens of rock stars, including Jimi Hendrix, the Doors, the Animals, Janis Joplin, the Mamas and the Papas, Bob Dylan, Frank Zappa, the Beach Boys and the Grateful Dead. A widely reproduced picture of the Beatles that she took at a press party for the release of ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' in 1967 captured the group on the eve of its greatest artistic triumph.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: Her photographs appeared in Rolling Stone and other rock magazines, and in 1992 she published several hundred of them as a book, ''Linda McCartney's Sixties: Portrait of an Era.''
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: Ms. McCartney met her future husband while photographing the Beatles in London in 1967, and the pair carried on an occasional romance for more than a year. In September 1968, Mr. McCartney asked her to move to London, from which point they became inseparable. Although she took some stunning pictures of the Beatles at work, she left most of them unpublished until she assembled her ''Sixties'' book. Her photographs of Mr. McCartney, however, adorned some of his post-Beatles album covers, and in one of his early television specials, ''James Paul McCartney,'' he is shown singing a medley of his songs while his wife did a photo shoot.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: In addition to Mr. McCartney and the daughter from her first marriage, Heather, Ms. McCartney is survived by three children from her marriage with Mr. McCartney: Mary, Stella and James; and by her brother John, who is now Mr. McCartney's lawyer and business manager, and two sisters, Laura and Louise.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: Besides ''Sixties,'' Ms. McCartney published several other books, including ''Linda's Pictures,'' ''Sun Prints,'' ''Photographs'' and ''Road Works.'' Celebrities were by no means her only photographic subject. Plants, animals, natural patterns on rock faces and people she encountered on her travels engaged her interest and were captured with a touching refinement in many of her pictures. Her work has also been the subject of exhibitions at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, the Royal Photographic Society in Bath, England, and at more than 50 galleries around the world.
title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56

text: N.F.L. DRAFT DAY '98: NOTEBOOK
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: It should not come as a surprise that the Minnesota Vikings made the controversial selection of Marshall wide receiver Randy Moss with the 21st pick in the National Football League draft. The team had been preparing to draft him for days.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: Moss's stock fell because of a number of off-the-field issues. Moss, a 6-foot-5-inch receiver with 4.3 speed, pleaded guilty to battery while in high school, tested positive for marijuana while in college and was arrested on domestic battery charges in 1996. These problems led teams such as the St. Louis Rams, the New Orleans Saints and the Giants to remove him from their draft board.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: The Vikings felt, as did some other teams, that while Moss's problems are to be taken seriously, there have been past first-round picks -- even picks in this draft -- who have resumes just as blotted.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: Minnesota began to take a serious look at Moss late this week. On Thursday, Coach Dennis Green had a long conversation with Moss's brother, Eric, a Vikings offensive lineman. Green did an extensive background check on Moss, and the Vikings also checked with the league's security office to make sure there was nothing they missed.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: ''We did our homework on this kid,'' Green said in a telephone interview. ''We think he made some mistakes in the past, but we are going to watch him carefully. The kid deserves a second chance. What should we do? Not let him ever play football again?''
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: The Vikings, with the help of Moss's brother, feel they can provide a support system for Moss that will keep him out of trouble.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: If so, the Vikings could possibly have one of the more explosive offenses next season. Cris Carter is regarded as a top receiver. Jake Reed has great hands. Now Randy Moss, who scored 53 touchdowns the past two seasons at Marshall, adds a deep threat.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: One of the things that makes the draft so interesting is what happens behind the scenes. Agents such as Leigh Steinberg plan every step of their client's progression from college star to professional on what is one of the most important days of his life.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: Here is a short diary of yesterday morning for Washington State quarterback Ryan Leaf, who was taken second in the draft by San Diego.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: *10 A.M. -- Leaf has breakfast with his family and friends at the Millennium Hotel in Manhattan -- all 30-plus of them. Leaf chats with Peyton Manning and his father, Archie, who are also at breakfast.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: *10:20 A.M. -- On the bus ride over to Madison Square Garden, Steinberg prepares Leaf for every possible scenario, from telling him where he will sit before he is selected to the possibility that the Indianapolis Colts, who have the first pick, still may select him.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: *10:30 A.M. -- The Leaf contingent arrives at the draft site. It is escorted by security guards to its own room. Leaf still has not smiled much.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: *11:45 A.M. -- Steinberg speaks with the Colts' owner, Jim Irsay, and finds out that Manning will be the first selection. Steinberg and Leaf are relieved, since Leaf wanted to play in San Diego. Still, neither is completely relaxed.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: *11:50 A.M. -- About 10 minutes before the draft, Steinberg briefs the family,saying that it looks like Leaf is going to the Chargers. He warns that the New York fans may boo Leaf because, well, they are New Yorkers and New Yorkers just like to boo.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: *Noon -- The draft begins. Leaf is seated on a couch, his face serious, as if he is about to face the Green Bay Packers. It is quiet in the room. Steinberg and his staff are still paying attention to the details.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: *12:11 P.M. -- The Colts select Manning and the room erupts. Leaf lets out a cheer, then gets up and goes to the bathroom. His family warns him to make sure he does not miss San Diego's pick.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: *12:14 P.M. -- Tick, tick, tick. The Chargers still have not made their pick. Leaf puts a Chargers pin on his gray suit.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: About a minute later, the Chargers make their selection. It is, of course, Leaf. Steinberg hugs him, then his father, John, then his mother, Marcia. Finally, the family can relax.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: The first round of the draft took 4 hours 39 minutes, which was the fastest time since 1992's first round, which was took 4:15. Twenty years ago, the first round took 2:10.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: The Ivy League got on the board early last evening when defensive end Mitch Marrow of Penn was taken with the 73d pick in the third round by the Carolina Panthers. Marrow's stock had gone up because of his performance in post-season workouts.
title: Vikings Are Careful in Picking Moss

text: Standing before a battery of television cameras on Thursday afternoon, Michael J. Bowers lightly touched his wife, Bette Rose, on her shoulder as they fielded questions about the most intimate details of their marriage -- and tried to salvage his campaign for governor after fresh disclosures about his 15-year affair with a former aide.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''We were blessed by almighty God, who reached out and said, 'I'm going to let you guys fall in love again,' '' Mr. Bowers said. ''And it is a very real thing. It is the most important thing in our lives today. And no matter what happens about this, this election, this primary, this whole political process, she and I will be together, we will be in love.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: It is a testament to an environment in which voters appear less judgmental and more forgiving of the private lapses of their public servants that Mr. Bowers's campaign has survived, though he has lost his standing as the favorite in the Republican primary on July 21.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: In interviews around the nation, dozens of politicians and candidates at the local and national levels, as well as voters and political strategists, reeled off names of politicians with checkered personal lives who would have been too ashamed to even contemplate running for office a decade or more ago. But these days, candidates offer their missteps to the voters as evidence that they have nothing to hide and have learned from their transgressions.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: The months, even years, of allegations about President Clinton's private life seem to have toughened -- and often exasperated -- an electorate that now has more realistic expectations and is not as quick to put politicians on a pedestal or expect them to be happily married. A result is that instead of retreating to the shadows, politicians and spouses are boldly fighting back -- telling voters that job performance, not personal conduct, is all that is relevant.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Borrowing from the Hillary Rodham Clinton playbook, some spouses are, literally, standing by their husbands. In February, Bea Romer stood quietly by as Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, acknowledged a 16-year ''very affectionate relationship'' with a longtime aide. His approval rating is still an impressive 68 percent.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: On Thursday, Mrs. Bowers confessed to a crush of reporters at the campaign's headquarters here: ''Quite honestly, our marriage hit rock bottom. After many hours of soul searching and discussion, we said there is enough of a fiber left not to get a divorce but to go forward.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: These changed public attitudes are not simply a response to an era in which Paula Corbin Jones and a roster of other women have been unable to topple Mr. Clinton. They have come about gradually, particularly since 1987, when Senator Gary Hart of Colorado quit the Democratic Presidential primaries after disclosures about his extramarital activities involving a young woman. ''We are all a little prurient about other people's lives,'' Mr. Hart said this week. ''But voters have been much more sophisticated in judging character and understanding that character is demonstrated over a lifetime in many, many ways -- all of one's personal relationships and the esteem of one's colleagues.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: One sign of what Mr. Hart described as ''a new age of maturity'' among voters is that the notion of an unmarried President -- something that once would have unnerved voters -- rarely comes up in speculation about the ambitions of two single Senators, Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, and Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: A New Tolerance, But Still More Scrutiny
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Even flagrant adultery does not always sink a candidate.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: In Florida, for example, State Senator John McKay, a Republican, was accused by his former wife of having an affair with a lobbyist who was promoting a bill he steered through the Senate. Mr. McKay married the lobbyist, and has since made amends with a state representative who had accused Mr. McKay of throttling him and threatening to kill him.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Yet Mr. McKay is undaunted. He appears headed for an easy re-election in November, mostly because he is viewed as a powerful Senator who has been skilled at pumping money into his southwest Florida district.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Despite a new tolerance, many politicians described an atmosphere in which, more than ever before, they must brace for the likelihood that the most sordid details of their private lives will surface, because the press and political rivals alike are more willing to raise such matters. That reality has caused some potential candidates to decide not to run.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''We'll never know what leaders we've lost out of this,'' Mr. Hart said.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: While voters may be less likely to turn on candidates who are willing to come clean about their messy private lives, politicians said, they are less apt to give their blessing to candidates whose conduct makes them appear hypocritical or who are not forthcoming about admitting their mistakes. Candidates say they have also found that voters often are more forgiving of a politician's personal misdeeds than financial improprieties, especially when Government money is involved.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: More than politics, the shift in attitudes may reflect a maturing culture in which Americans are more aware of the realities of private lives.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''Fifty years ago, everybody who was in politics was male and white and everybody who worked in the media was the same and 95 percent of the people were married,'' said Mayor Marc Morial of New Orleans, a Democrat. ''Now you just have a different climate.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: When Mr. Morial was elected in 1994, he endured a barrage of personal attacks for, among other things, fathering a child out of wedlock. But he said such matters ''never came up'' in his campaign this year because ''the public is smart enough to decipher through it -- I had a record and I had some personal credibility.'' He was re-elected in February with 79 percent of the vote.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Another Democrat who is banking on his credibility is Raymond L. Flynn, who recently stepped down as United States Ambassador to the Vatican and for years was the Mayor of Boston. He said an article late last year in The Boston Globe that described him as a longtime problem drinker -- which he vehemently denies -- reflected a new willingness by the press to pry into politicians' private lives but would not deter his run for Governor this year.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''People can identify with politicians as just regular people who have faults and who make many mistakes,'' he said. ''They don't look at them as puritanical icons. It's just the frailty of life.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat who disclosed his homosexuality in 1987, has had no trouble winning re-election since revealing two years later that he had hired a male prostitute.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''If you're a spouse beater, people are going to be concerned -- and they should be,'' Mr. Frank said. ''But the culture has moved away from an acceptance of rules that sex is only legitimate when two people are married to each other.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Here in Georgia, Mr. Bowers is hoping that he, too, will benefit from a more understanding public. He said the issue was ''a recognition of the frailty of mankind.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''People are very forgiving because they see their own story,'' Mr. Bowers said in an interview. ''This is America's dirty laundry, the tale of every family in some ways.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: He was heartened by a Kiwanis Club luncheon this week in the small, largely conservative town of Buford, north of here. No members asked him about his affair. That morning, the local newspaper had written about an article in George magazine in which Mr. Bowers's former mistress, Anne Davis, spoke out for the first time, saying he had sent her money to help with expenses even after the relationship had ended.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''When this first came out, I said, 'No -- I definitely will not vote for him,' '' Milton Califf, a furniture salesman who is treasurer of the club, said of Mr. Bowers. ''But I've had a change of heart. His views, what he wants to accomplish, is something we really need.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Mr. Califf, 56, said he would not have been understanding a decade or so ago. ''It would have been an open-and-shut case,'' he said. ''But you see so much of this nowadays -- from the Presidency on down. It's the tolerance thing.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Past Drug Use No Apparent Problem
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: As Mr. Bowers was trying to contain his trouble, State Senator Mark Taylor, one of several Democrats running for lieutenant governor of Georgia, unexpectedly found himself this week discussing his indulgence in cocaine and marijuana in the 1980's. The Macon Telegraph received, anonymously, court documents about the past drug use of Mr. Taylor, who said his ''casual, recreational use'' ended 15 years ago.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: The disclosure did not make big headlines here -- perhaps because it came the same day as the new disclosures about Mr. Bowers -- and his advisers were confident that Mr. Taylor could continue his campaign.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''I think we're well past the point where the admission of a youthful experimentation with drugs is an automatic disqualifer,'' said Alan Secrest, Mr. Taylor's pollster.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Mr. Secrest says he warns candidates to expect information on their private lives to seep out, but that such disclosures were far less likely than in the past to hurt a candidate.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''I sit in meeting after meeting these days with candidates at every level discussing information about opponents that would have destroyed their candidacy as recently as 8 to 10 years ago,'' Mr. Secrest said, ''but today might not be nearly so damaging a negative in voters' eyes. It's more difficult to shock people.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: One explanation for the inability to shock has nothing to do with voters' moral judgments and everything to do with the economy: several politicians and strategists said people were so pleased with the economy that they had less interest in a candidate's private life.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''The outrage of the American people toward the peccadilloes of their politicians is inversely proportional to the state of the economy,'' said Warren B. Rudman, the former Republican Senator from New Hampshire who headed the Ethics Committee.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Robust economy or not, many candidates this year still may find themselves in unexpectedly tough contests because of their private conduct. Disclosures about candidates' private lives are still most worrisome when their records are not well known to the voters, or their record smacks of hypocrisy.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: In Washington State, Democrats plan to attack Representative Rick White, a Republican, for divorcing his wife of 16 years. Mr. White may be on the defensive not because of the divorce itself but because he had aggressively presented himself to voters as a devoted family man.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Laura Ruderman, a former program manager at Microsoft who is seeking the Democratic nomination, said Mr. White's divorce would be an important element of her campaign.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: ''I absolutely believe it makes him more vulnerable,'' said Ms. Ruderman, who is also single. ''It's not the fact of the divorce -- it's the hypocrisy of running on how important your family is and then destroying it.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Ms. Ruderman said that while she will raise the issue directly ''at some point,'' she will not stress Mr. White's divorce when she announces her candidacy on Monday because, among other things, ''He has kids that are old enough to read about this in the paper.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Mr. White, in a statement after his divorce became official on Wednesday, said, ''I'm glad that these issues are now behind us so we can focus on raising our children.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: When a Haunting Past Cannot Be Put Aside
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: If there was any question that Mr. Bowers was in trouble in Georgia, there was no doubt this week when his campaign distributed to the press results of a poll in which 36 percent said he should drop out of the race. The rationale was that a larger proportion -- 64 percent -- said he should not quit.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Mr. Bowers, who is 56 and met his wife when he was a cadet at West Point 35 years ago, is especially vulnerable because of what he readily acknowledges was hypocritical behavior: he had drawn national attention as a straight-arrow conservative who, as the State Attorney General, successfully defended Georgia's anti-sodomy law before the United States Supreme Court.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Last summer, when he first acknowledged the affair with Ms. Davis, who once worked as a waitress in a Playboy Club, it was as if Mr. Bowers had written his own political obituary -- or handed his rivals a sound bite that was too good to be true. ''It's just hypocritical morally,'' he said of his behavior.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: But most disturbing for Mr. Bowers is that his disclosure last summer enticed Guy Millner, a wealthy businessman who narrowly lost previous campaigns for governor and the United States Senate, to enter the race. A poll shows that Mr. Millner is the heavy favorite for the Republican nomination.
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Yet even if Mr. Bowers confounds the experts and becomes governor, neither he nor other candidates whose pasts have haunted them are likely to recover fully from attacks on their character. Mr. Bowers was not entirely joking when he warned a Kiwanis Club member at the luncheon: ''You're in danger of ruining your reputation sitting next to me.''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: Mr. Flynn put it this way: ''You may survive it -- you may even win the election. But you're never the same. You don't have the high moral authority to govern the way you want to. Is the goal to survive? Or is the goal to be able to govern effectively?''
title: In New Climate, More Politicians Surmount Imperfect Private Lives

text: THE Kirov Opera's 17-day residency at the Metropolitan Opera, beginning on Thursday, figures to be a high point of the current musical season. The repertory consists of four Russian operas little known in the United States: Glinka's ''Ruslan and Ludmila,'' Borodin's ''Prince Igor,'' Tchaikovsky's ''Mazeppa'' and Prokofiev's ''Betrothal in a Monastery.'' And the venerable St. Petersburg company, long sheltered from homogenizing international influences by Soviet seclusion, lives and breathes these works, two of which -- the Borodin and the Prokofiev -- had their premieres at the Kirov's own Maryinsky Theater.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Under the stewardship of Valery Gergiyev, the once-cloistered Kirov has acquired a dual identity. The most nomadic of Europe's major opera troupes, it is at the same time the most localized. To be sure, St. Petersburg is not Leningrad: Verdi is no longer given in Russian at the Maryinsky. Kirov stars like Olga Borodina and Sergei Leiferkus sing in the major houses of Britain, Italy, France and Austria. And Placido Domingo appears with the Kirov. But a typical Kirov performance still features Russian opera given by a resident ensemble of Russian singing actors steeped in Russian musical theater.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: The Kirov, in other words, connects to an earlier time, when Gounod was given in German in Berlin and Wagner was sung in Italian in Milan, when distinctive traditions of vocal style and interpretation emerged in France, Germany, Italy and Russia. For the moment, at least, something like a Russian school survives.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: It is something to think about. Here in the United States, no American school materialized. There is no canonized repertory of American operas, no sustained American vocal type, no living tradition of opera in the vernacular. And yet opera in English enjoyed a surprisingly formidable American history throughout the 19th century. As recently as the 1970's and 80's, the Metropolitan Opera, no less, presented English-language stagings of ''The Bartered Bride,'' ''Bluebeard's Castle,'' ''Dialogues of the Carmelites,'' ''Hansel and Gretel,'' ''Jenufa'' and ''La Perichole'' -- not to mention the 1950's and 60's, when it offered English versions of such staples as ''La Boheme,'' ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' ''Eugene Onegin,'' ''Die Fledermaus'' and ''The Magic Flute.''
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: As it happens, one of the Met's most performed operas in English is the most performed Russian opera: ''Boris Godunov.'' Of 257 Met performances since its American premiere in 1913, 54 have been in English. My own first, adolescent experience of ''Boris,'' in the early 1960's, was of John Gutman's translation as presented on television by the enterprising NBC Opera, with the Chicago-born Giorgio Tozzi in the title role. (''Boris'' is the ideal opera for young people.) I was so stirred that I purchased a recording, which turned out to be a Metropolitan Opera version conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos, also in the Gutman translation, also with Tozzi as Boris. And in 1963, I attended my first Met ''Boris,'' Georg Solti conducting, with a cast of Americans headed by the inescapable Tozzi singing Gutman's inescapable words.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Gutman's ''Boris'' was nothing great. But it was a boon to American singers who today would more likely be expected to learn the original Russian by rote. It also usefully deposited in my youthful brain a permanent running English translation of Mussorgsky's libretto.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: If the Met's English-language ''Boris'' was nevertheless bland alongside, say, the Kirov's current ''Boris'' -- unveiled last summer at the White Nights Festival in St. Petersburg -- the problem was less one of language than of style. Presently on sale at local CD emporiums is the most gripping portrayal of Boris Godunov I have ever encountered. The singer is Hans Hotter, and he sings in German. The entire performance, as conducted by Eugen Jochum for the Bavarian Radio in 1957, is stylistically unified, but the style isn't Russian. Hotter's guilt-ridden Czar is crossbred with Wotan. Rangoni and Marina, as sung by Benno Kusche and Martha Modl, resonate with Klingsor and Kundry.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: In short, this powerfully Wagnerized, wrong-language rendition has an integrity of its own. By comparison, the wrong-language Borises I remember were stylistically adrift: not ''Russian,'' not ''American,'' not anything.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: The history of opera in English in 19th-century America -- a buried history only now being exhumed -- conveys a surprising message: that there actually was, if not an American style, a distinctive American orientation. This information comes from Karen Alquist's recent study, ''Democracy at the Opera: Music, Theater and Culture in New York City, 1815-60.''
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: In the 1830's, Ms. Alquist tells us, Bellini's ''Sonnambula'' was ''New York's sentimental hit.'' Sung in English, it meshed with a repertory including the Irish composer William Michael Rooke's ''Amilie'' and such ''Englished'' operas as Rophino Lacy's ''Maid of Judah,'' a Rossini pastiche interpolating spoken dialogue. As rendered by American and British singers, these were operas that pleased an eclectic audience. They were simple, direct and edifying. The virtuousness of the stories, and of the featured sopranos, secured their American appeal. What resulted was not grand opera but an entertainment overlapping popular theater and American and English ''ballad operas,'' with their mixture of speech and popular song.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: In subsequent decades, English-language opera grew in popularity. William Henry Fry composed the first grand opera by an American in 1845. More than 50 English-language opera troupes were touring the United States between 1840 and 1860. The Pyne and Harrison English Opera Company, from Britain, was an especially triumphant attraction during the 1850's. Traveling south to Mobile, Ala., and New Orleans, west to St. Louis and Cincinnati, it specialized in ''La Sonnambula,'' Donizetti's ''Daughter of the Regiment,'' William Vincent Wallace's ''Maritana,'' Michael Balfe's ''Bohemian Girl,'' Auber's ''Crown Diamonds'' and Lacy's ''Englished'' adaptation of Rossini's ''Cinderella.''
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Among the best-known American companies touring opera in English were those of Clara Louise Kellogg, our first self-proclaimed prima donna, and Emma Abbott, known as ''the people's prima donna.'' The largest itinerant troupe was the American Opera Company, which from 1885 to 1887 presented major works by Mozart, Wagner, Meyerbeer and Verdi, all in fresh English translations, with a first-rate orchestra and chorus under Theodore Thomas, and lavish costumes and sets.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: By this time, of course, opera in English no longer intersected with American and British theatrical entertainments. It had to compete with grand operatic spectacles in Italian and French, with such glamorous imported singing stars as Christine Nilsson and Marcella Sembrich.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: The American Opera Company's performances were praised for their thorough preparation. ''Never before has grand opera been presented in this city in so complete a manner as by this troupe,'' wrote a Boston critic. ''We have usually had a few good singers, a poor chorus of ancient singers, a meager orchestra of musicians who had but little enthusiasm for their work, and a poverty of scenic illustration that was often laughable. None of these faults could be laid at the door of the American Company.''
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: But the company's mainly American vocal roster proved fatal. In the absence of state subsidies, opera in America was dependent on individual patronage, and the individuals in question preferred foreign singers and foreign tongues. As late as 1885, thought was given to restructuring the Met as an English-language house specializing in German opera. As late as 1909, the dean of New York's music critics, Henry Krehbiel, predicted that English would inevitably become the dominant language for opera in the United States, and ''native talent'' would ''provide works and interpreters.''
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Instead, opera in English survived into the 20th century as a second-rung attraction, gamely sponsored by a Henry Savage or Boris Goldovsky, or by the enterprising New York City Opera. The synergy with ballad opera was long forgotten. The dream of an American repertory was necessarily abandoned. Stranded, English-language opera became an ersatz entertainment, ''Boris Godunov'' a la John Gutman being a perfect example.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Supertitles, beginning in the 1980's, and Met Titles, implemented in 1995, have complexly affected opera in America. For the better, supertitles have advanced appreciation of opera as theater. For better or worse, they have in many places dictated a decisive curtailment of opera in English translation.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: In New York, the City Opera retains a flexible policy on language matters. Though, unlike London's English National Opera, it has never opted exclusively for opera in the vernacular, the company remains a frequent if ambivalent showcase for opera in English. Next season, about one-third of the repertory is to be sung in English; in 1999-2000, about one-half will be, including works by Britten, Deborah Drattell, Humperdinck, Mozart, Aulis Sallinen, Virgil Thomson and Michael Torke. Meanwhile, Ravel is being given in French, with Rossini, Verdi, Puccini and Mozart (sometimes) in Italian.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Across the plaza, the Met has recently staged ''The Bartered Bride'' and ''Hansel and Gretel'' in English. The current season, however, offers nothing in English translation -- not even Janacek's ''Makropulos Case.'' ''Boris'' was given in Russian last fall, with Mr. Gergiyev, and a mix of American and Russian singers. And this, presumably, will become the house norm for Russian opera, now that Russian-based artists tour widely in the West, and Met Titles render exotic languages comprehensible.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: It doesn't take a purist to observe that this latest Russian-American ''Boris'' failed to ignite, or to sense the significance of the Kirov's mini-season. No Russian company has previously appeared at the Met with Met Titles. No previous visit of the Bolshoi or Kirov has so ambitiously featured important Russian operas falling outside the international repertory. And the Kirov's continued propagation of a Russian school -- which the repertory selection so obviously reflects -- seems an anomaly more precious than ever.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: IF Hans Hotter, the defining Wotan of his generation, is not remembered as Boris Godunov, it is partly because he sang the role only in German. And yet it was Fyodor Chaliapin -- the most influential Russian Boris -- whose mastery of opera as a dramatic art inspired the young Hotter to become an opera singer.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Mr. Hotter first sang Boris under Eugen Jochum in 1936. In 1957, Hotter and Jochum recorded ''Boris'' for the Bavarian Radio: a performance With a cast packed with important Wagnerian voices (Myto 3 MCD 953.131; three CD's), this German ''Boris'' is distinctive not only for its ''wrong language'' but also for its Wagnerian style. The outcome absorbingly demonstrates how four decades ago -- when major German singers might also sing Verdi or Puccini in German -- one operatic tradition could ''interpret'' another.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Mr. Hotter's Boris -- completely unlike Chaliapin's -- is a noble, compassionate and effective ruler. His undoing is a single lapse, when, through surrogates he hoped would shield him from the crime, he ordered the murder of the Czarevich. He shares Wotan's dignity, his tenderness toward his children, and a lust for power he lives to regret. His central monologue, no less than Wotan's in ''Die Walkure,'' attains an existential anguish. When he confides to Shuiski that he hallucinates, we are startled -- and moved -- by this confession of weakness. When he inquires why the Fool cries, he evinces sympathetic identification, not curiosity or fear; he stops his guards from arresting the Fool because he is weary of everything.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: At the end, when he exclaims, ''I cannot breathe,'' Mr. Hotter's vocal demeanor more signifies ''I cannot speak'': a moral rather than physical affliction. He dies quietly; in a staged production, this Boris, tortured by self-knowledge, could no more topple down a flight of steps than Wotan, in ''Gotterdammerung,'' could rouse himself to wreck Valhalla. Every nuance of Mr. Hotter's portrait is ultimately internalized, every invitation to excess denied. It is overwhelmingly tragic.
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: Hans Hopf and Martha Modl are a Grigori and Marina only a German could love, throaty and loud. Paul Kuen's Simpleton is a variant of his well-known Mime. Lorenz Fehenberger, Kim Borg and Kurt Bohme sing Shuiski, Pimen and Varlaam. Jochum's reading, complementing Mr. Hotter, utterly eschews bluster. JOSEPH HOROWITZ
title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English

text: When Ryan Leaf does New York, he really does New York. There was the cruise on a rainy afternoon up the Hudson River with other projected top draft picks like Peyton Manning. Leaf has also brought family from Great Falls, Mont., to Manhattan for the weekend.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Actually, family is not the right word; expansion team might be a better way to describe the 30 relatives with him.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: ''The entire population of Great Falls is in New York,'' said Leaf's agent, Leigh Steinberg.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Leaf may need his big family to help carry the fat paycheck he will earn after he is selected either No. 1 by the Indianapolis Colts or No. 2 by the San Diego Chargers in today's National Football League draft. Leaf, a West Coast guy who played at Washington State, is hoping for the latter.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Leaf will probably get his wish. Most people in the N.F.L. would be surprised if the Colts did not select Manning, the Tennessee quarterback. Indianapolis set a self-imposed deadline of 6 P.M. last night to make a decision. All indications point to Manning. ''We don't have to announce a decision until early Saturday and we won't,'' said Bill Polian, the Colts' general manager.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Manning-Leaf, Leaf-Manning is one of three main issues on what is sure to be an exciting first day of the draft, conducted at Madison Square Garden.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: THE CHARACTER QUESTION That has mainly to do with Marshall wide receiver Randy Moss. Moss is 6 feet 5 inches, and last month during a workout in a 25-degree windchill, he ran the 40-yard dash in a blistering 4.31 seconds. Normally, that kind of talent would make him a top-five pick.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Moss, however, does not have a sparkling resume. His off-the-field problems include two guilty pleas for battery in high school, a positive marijuana test in college and an arrest for domestic battery in 1996. Several teams have taken Moss off their draft boards because of these problems, including the St. Louis Rams. The Saints, who select seventh, say they will not draft him unless they move much further down in the first round.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: So where will Moss land? Two teams interested are Seattle at No. 15 and Miami at No. 19. Another possibility that emerged in the last 48 hours is the Minnesota Vikings, picking 21st. Coach Dennis Green has done an exhaustive background check on Moss in case he falls to the late first round.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Moss's older brother, Eric Moss, is a Vikings offensive tackle. Green spoke extensively with Eric Moss, and the Vikings think he could help provide a support system for the younger Moss should he end up in Minnesota.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: The Vikings are intrigued by the possibility of having Jake Reed, Cris Carter and Moss lining up as their receivers -- it would potentially be the most devastating group in the N.F.L.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Moss's stock is falling so fast, it is quite possible he could slip into the second round. As one high-ranking league official put it, the N.F.L. always chooses one draft pick with a troubled past to make an example of, and this year Moss could be that person.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: It is not unusual, however, for teams to say negative things about a player in an effort to reduce his value so they can draft him. That could be happening with Moss.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: THE MOVEMENT QUESTION Each team does several mock drafts to try to have an idea of how the draft will go. That is like throwing up a deck of cards and trying to predict the exact spot where the king of hearts will fall. In normal years, figuring out the draft is an inexact science. This year, it seems impossible.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: There could be as many as five trades in the first round. The Giants, Chicago, New Orleans, Oakland, Jacksonville and Baltimore, among other teams, are looking to make a move.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Some teams do not think this draft is as strong as the news media have made it out to be and are looking to go down in the draft.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Other teams, like New England, would love to move up and take a can't-miss player like Michigan's Charles Woodson, Penn State's Curtis Enis or Florida running back Fred Taylor.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: In fact, Jacksonville and Chicago were talking late last night about swapping positions.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: ''I think there will probably be some movement,'' Jets Coach Bill Parcells said. ''Teams coming up, teams backing out.''
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: THE QUARTERBACK QUESTION Leaf has the stronger arm and better potential and has proven to be much more mature and polished than many people thought. Manning can step right in and lead a team sooner and has an understanding of the game few college players have demonstrated in the 1990's. Most scouts think both will have brilliant pro careers.
title: Questions From Top Pick on Down

text: Re A. M. Rosenthal's ''Lean Back or Fight'' (column, April 14): As a neuroscientist, I study the effects of addictive drugs on the brain. The greatest risk factor for drug abuse and addiction is the availability of drugs. If marijuana and other drugs are legalized, more people will become addicted or suffer other drug-related problems.
title: Prohibition Won't Win Drug War; Two Separate Issues

text: Some medical benefits have already been demonstrated for THC, the active ingredient in marijuana. That does not justify across-the-board legalization of marijuana or even the use of marijuana per se as a medication. Those who favor legalization have hooked their wagon to those advocating compassionate use of marijuana for very sick people. As Mr. Rosenthal points out, this is underhanded and intentionally misleading. Let's analyze the two issues separately.
title: Prohibition Won't Win Drug War; Two Separate Issues

text: Winston-Salem, N.C., April 17, 1998
title: Prohibition Won't Win Drug War; Two Separate Issues

text: The writer is associate dean for research, Wake Forest University School of Medicine.
title: Prohibition Won't Win Drug War; Two Separate Issues

text: A. M. Rosenthal's notion (column, April 14) of ''backdoor legalization'' of drugs is odd. How could such a major change occur unnoticed? Ending prohibition would require votes taken in the halls of power or the ballot box -- the front door. Perhaps medical marijuana will spark a rethinking of drug policy. But open debate is the lifeblood of democracy, and should be welcomed, not feared or denounced.
title: Prohibition Won't Win Drug War; No 'Backdoor' Debate

text: FIRST things first: The hemp seeds used to make Hempen Ale do not contain tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana.
title: Sips; Cannabis Beer? Not What You Think

text: ''The hemp flowers and leaves contain as much as 2 percent THC, but the seeds do not contain any,'' said Steven Nordahl, brew master for Frederick Brewing Company, in Frederick, Md., which introduced the ale to the New York area last month.
title: Sips; Cannabis Beer? Not What You Think

text: What, then, does the hemp do?
title: Sips; Cannabis Beer? Not What You Think

text: ''The seeds add protein, and an earthy, slightly spicy flavor to the beer,'' said Kevin Brannon, the company's chief executive. The seeds are added to the mash, and are purchased sterilized, so they cannot be planted to reproduce the hemp plant, a controlled substance. ''From the seeds, we get a really frothy meringue-like head,'' Mr. Brannon said, ''and the head retention is incredible.''
title: Sips; Cannabis Beer? Not What You Think

text: The beer is a nicely bitter brown ale, clean and crisp with a gentle aroma and a hoppy aftertaste. As for its head retention, at a tasting last week, the creamy froth lasted 30 minutes.
title: Sips; Cannabis Beer? Not What You Think

text: Although brewers in Switzerland and Germany, and others in the United States, also make hemp beer, Hempen Ale appears to be the first to be sold in the New York market, said Jim Munson, the vice president of the Brooklyn Brewery, its distributor.
title: Sips; Cannabis Beer? Not What You Think

text: A 12-ounce bottle costs 99 cents at Pioneer Supermarket, 289 Columbus Avenue (near 74th Street); $1.59 at Strawberry Fields, 311 Bleecker Street (near Grove Street), and $1.75 at Lexington Avenue Market, 859 Lexington Avenue (near 65th Street). ELAINE LOUIE
title: Sips; Cannabis Beer? Not What You Think

text: ''It's nice to think that in another five or ten years maybe the right over one's consciousness, the right to possess and consume drugs, may be as powerfully and as widely understood as the other rights of Americans are.''
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: If that thought strikes you too as nice, you don't have to do much. Just lean back and enjoy the successes of Dr. Ethan Nadelmann, who said it in 1993, and other executives of well-financed ''drug reform'' foundations.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: Maybe he is a little optimistic about his timing. But he and others who would like now-illegal drugs to be a right certainly have made political headway since his pronouncement at the San Francisco conference to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the discovery of LSD.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: Still, perhaps the thought that narcotics will become a basic American right strikes you as plain horrible. Perhaps you have love for your children, or theirs, or for the mental, moral and civil stability of the country in which you live.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: Perhaps you will become worried about a new report from the Partnership for a Drug-Free America. It shows that marijuana use among children and teen-agers is increasing, and parents don't know it, and that children and teen-agers find it much easier to get, and parents don't know it, and that among the youngsters the fear of the risks of the drug is decreasing -- and parents don't know that either.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: Or, maybe you will be startled at the report's finding that parents think they talk to their children about drugs a lot more than their children recall hearing -- and wonder if the parents remember right.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: Or it could be that you are sick to the gorge of the press and TV accepting the flood of false compassion that reformers used to attain the triumph of ''medicalization'' of marijuana in California and Arizona. Perhaps you know the ''reformers,'' supported by benefactors like George Soros, Peter Lewis of Ohio and John Sperling of Arizona, plan to use the same weapon in other referendums across the country.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: Then, under any of those conditions, the time has come for you to get up and fight against drugs, instead of just looking worried. Here are three ways:
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: 1. With your votes, letters, mouths and religious and social organizations, pressure the people you elect to every level of government. Demand detailed exposure of backdoor legalization, its funders and techniques.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: Ask the President, again and again and again, to become the political, passionate leader against drugs that the country lacks and so terribly needs. Maybe he will never do it, which does not excuse us from saying it is his duty.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: 2. Join and support organizations that actively fight drugs and ask that Congress fully restore the funds it cut from their anti-drug education work. Pester newspapers and TV to give full hearings to the organizations and to the anti-drug case. And if the organizations are not on the Internet, tell them they are surrendering to the crowds of legalizers who are.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: (National Families in Action, an anti-drug organization, publishes ''A Guide to the Drug Legalization Movement and How to Fight It,'' a most useful book in which I came across Dr. Nadelmann's ''nice'' thought. Ten dollars, Suite 300, 2296 Henderson Mill Road, Atlanta, Ga. 30345; (770) 934-7137; www.emory.edu/NFIA).
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: 3. Any way you can, spread the truth that law enforcement, drug interdiction and therapy are all necessary to fight the war, and that therapy, especially in prisons, is not getting enough government funds. Help therapeutic communities like Phoenix House, Daytop Village and others.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: Expect no medals. Many journalists have used drugs, particularly marijuana, and having survived themselves think everybody can. And America's best-known writers are either cold to the drug war or apparently never heard of it. American pop stars would rather go bald than fight narcotics.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: But 87 percent of Americans are against legalization, which is why legalizers use euphemisms and back doors and have to depend on big donors, not little ones.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: If you help the huge anti-drug majority know its strengths and the backdoor techniques of the legal izers, then parents and their children will not only talk at home about drugs, but hear each other.
title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight

text: In an act of modest but authentic civic propriety, they changed their name from the Bullets to the Wizards. The owner spent $200 million for a modern arena, choosing not to build it in the suburbs, but rather downtown so that a broader commercial life might return. He then spent $105 million to hang onto the team's emerging star.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: And all along, the Wizards, playing in an overwhelmingly black city, took pride in having a black general manager and a black coach -- the only current team in the National Basketball Association to have both.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: The idea was to win, but there was hope, too, that the Wizards might reconnect with the District of Columbia's adults and children in a way they had not since their championships days of the 1970's.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: The team targeted schools like Adams Elementary in the northwest part of the city, where children would get free tickets. Kenneth Williams and Adrian Venzor, 13-year-old volunteers with the school recreation program, were open to the possibilities.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: But the imagined deal has gone sour, and the club's informal contract with the city has turned out to be worse than the empty cliche it has often been elsewhere.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: The Wizards have seemed to daily deepen their reputation as the league's leading troublemakers. They have been arrested and ordered into alcohol rehabilitation. They have had fistfights among themselves. One player was injured and lost for the season -- while making a movie, not a basket.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Most recently, two players, Chris Webber and Juwan Howard, were named in a criminal complaint by a woman who said they had sexually assaulted her. They have not been charged.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: The team, on the verge of being eliminated from the playoffs, was pelted with garbage at its new arena last week. The coach, Bernie Bickerstaff, has said he is exasperated. Wes Unseld, the frustrated general manager, has publicly told the players that they need to examine their consciences.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: And the 13-year-old boys at Adams Elementary's after-school program are fed up too.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: ''I just wish they would've stopped showboating and stuck to the basics,'' said Kenneth Williams, an eighth grader. ''Maybe then they would have made the playoffs.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Adrian Venzor said: ''Some of them stay out late at parties when they have to go to work the next day. They're always getting into trouble. Maybe they think because they're stars they can't get away with anything.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Folding his arms in disgust, he added, ''And Chris Webber should stop shooting threes, too.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: With a record of 38-40, Washington is on the brink of elimination from the post-season. In part because of the lure of a new arena, as well as visits by marquee teams like the Chicago Bulls and the Los Angeles Lakers, attendance has remained impressive even in the season's dying days.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: But for many fans in the city, the Wizards, rather than an example of rebirth, have been one more expensive failure.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: ''It's a collective disappointment,'' Bickerstaff said. ''Wes hurts. We hurt. The organization hurts.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Unseld arguably hurts worst. The former center and anchor to the franchise's 1978 championship team has clearly been humiliated by the bruising mix of bad play and misconduct.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: ''It has nothing to do with letting me down,'' Unseld said. ''Whether they've let themselves down, that's a different story.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Butch Beard, the former coach at Howard University in Washington who also once coached the Nets, said that by placing the arena downtown, the Wizards had made it possible for ''the black community to come to games.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: ''As for the players holding up their end of the bargain, well, we're talking about 24- and 25-year-old kids making $100 million who haven't grown up yet,'' Beard said.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: It used to be different for Washington's basketball team. With Unseld, Elvin Hayes and Bobby Dandridge, the Bullets regularly made the playoffs, and in 1978 they won their lone championship. But since 1979, they have had only one winning season.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: The team's owner, Abe Pollin, decided to try to repair the damage. In a city cynically known as the murder capital of the United States, he changed the name from Bullets to the Wizards this season. He signed the checks for a team composed primarily of young, black, potentially charismatic millionaires. Webber and Howard are two of the most glib players in the league, even capable of thoughtfulness and charm.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Pollin, meanwhile, also financed the $200 million MCI Center, which opened last Dec. 2 on his 74th birthday. It enabled the franchise to move out of the suburban building in Landover, Md., that had been an abject physical and marketing disaster for years.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Now he had a technodrome with food courts, luxury boxes and computer games for children.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: And it even looked to some as if the league had invested in making the Wizards work. When Howard signed a free-agent contract with the Miami Heat in 1996, the league ruled the Heat had circumvented salary cap rules. Pat Riley, the Heat president and coach, protested and theorized that the league had concluded that Washington's loss of Howard might devastate a large-market team trying to come back.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Clearly, a common belief emerged: forces were at work to help the Wizards and their two young stars prosper.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: And on paper they looked imposing -- as a promising, marketable team. No less an evaluator of corporate and athletic upsides than Michael Jordan called them a future force.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: It is disaster's force the team has felt most regularly, though.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards
