text: Billy Crystal, the actor, enlisted the services of the Romanian center Gheorghe Muresan, the tallest player in the league at 7 feet 7 inches, to play the title role in his recently released comedy ''My Giant.'' Muresan, one of the league's top shot blockers, strained a tendon in his right ankle during the off season while filming the movie. He has not played this season, and his career may be in jeopardy. Tim Legler, a 3-point specialist, has missed most of the season with a recurring knee injury.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Those, though, were the defensible misadventures.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Howard was charged with driving while intoxicated in November 1996 after being stopped for speeding in his 1995 Mercedes-Benz. The charge was dropped after Howard agreed to enter an alcohol rehabilitation and education program.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: In January, Webber was charged with second-degree assault, resisting arrest, marijuana possession, driving under the influence and other traffic violations when he was stopped by the police in Prince George's County, Maryland, while driving to a 10 A.M. team practice. According to the police report, he had no driver's license or registration at the time and presented a credit card as identification. A May trial is scheduled.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: The month before, Rod Strickland, the team's talented point guard, got into a fight with Tracy Murray in a Charlotte, N.C., hotel room in a dispute involving a women both men knew. Strickland played the Dec. 10 game with a taped left wrist, Murray with seven stitches in his face.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: The latest episode involved a party at Howard's home in Potomac, Md., early last week. A 24-year-old Bridgeport, Conn., woman called the police about 4:30 A.M. on Monday and said she had been sexually assaulted, naming Howard and Webber in her complaint. Both players have professed their innocence and were expected to speak with investigators this week.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: ''Let's just say their judgment has left something to be desired,'' Unseld said of the players last week.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Both Howard and Webber said they have been unfairly prejudged in the last incident. ''You're innocent until proven guilty,'' Webber said. ''That's what I've heard.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Howard said: ''The people that support us, the people that know us personally, they know we're not capable of doing anything like this. It's embarrassing not only for us but our families and our teammates. Yes, the fans are disappointed, but hopefully those who support us truly will be behind us 110 percent.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: There was no support for the Wizards in evidence last Thursday night at the MCI Center after the Detroit Pistons humiliated them with a barrage of uncontested dunks and layups in the first half. Boos cascaded as the Wizards fell behind by 60-29. It was 24 inept minutes of basketball that Bickerstaff, who was ejected in the second quarter, simply called ''the culmination of everything just coming down.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Afterward, before he ducked into a hallway, Strickland was hit with a wad of paper thrown from the stands.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: ''It's uncomfortable to even come here right now,'' said Legler, the injured player. ''You wonder who's pulling for you anymore.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Bickerstaff is befuddled. ''I'll just say this: There's more to winning than talent,'' he said.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: Jesse Jefferson, who runs the after-school program at Adams Elementary, said interest in the Wizards has dried up among the youngsters he works with.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: ''One of the things I stress is teamwork,'' said Jefferson, 60. ''I don't see that with the Wizards. The emphasis is on the dunk. They act up like crazy after a dunk, but then you look up at the scoreboard and they're losing by 19 points.
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: ''We tried to tell kids to look closer to home for their role models,'' but the players ''do have an obligation to maintain a certain behavior. These guys get treated like prima donnas from elementary school on up. I don't think they're good role models.''
title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards

text: THERE'S an illegal drug making huge inroads in New Jersey, trapping not only the most hardened of inner-city users, but also fresh-faced suburban youngsters who weren't even born when the nation started its war on drugs.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The drug is heroin: same old powerfully addictive opiate derivative, brand new pattern.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''The first time I tried it was at a party, when I was 17,'' said a 23-year-old from Belmawr, in suburban Camden County. ''This kid passed a little bit out. I sniffed it. We were playing cards, and the next thing I knew was -- My God, I feel good!''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: And the next thing he knew after that, he said, he was an addict, a dropout and a convict, prey to an obsession that has been ruining lives since the drug was developed around the turn of the century by scientists seeking a less addictive form of morphine.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''It's like being possessed by the devil,'' said one adult addict, a longtime user with a law degree and a master's in nursing who is now taking the first steps toward recovery. ''You have no freedom. You can't go anywhere or do anything. You can't have relationships. Everything is just about getting the heroin. It's a horrible way to live.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Changes in the international drug trade are bringing heroin within the price range of even a 12-year-old's pocket, and a much purer product means users are guaranteed a satisfying high without having to contend with fearsome needles.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Anecdotal evidence and accounts of law-enforcement officers and health department analysts make it clear that more young people in this state than ever before are becoming entangled in heroin. But while the experts agree on the trend, hard numbers are difficult to come by.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: That makes the magnitude of the problem a matter of serious debate. The experts agree that heroin is much less frequently abused than alcohol, nicotine, cocaine or marijuana, and some say that the horror excited by heroin only distracts the public from those larger problems. But others insist that the red flags are everywhere, and that ignoring them will lead to disaster.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''These kids will sprinkle it on Jell-O!'' said Raymond Farley, the superintendent of a Hunterdon County school district, where random drug testing was started two years ago, after a survey commissioned by Hunterdon Central Regional High School found that the 2,100 students at the school show drug-use rates, including heroin use, significantly higher than averages across the country -- which have been rising over the last few years. ''This is a national epidemic,'' Mr. Farley said.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Dr. Lynn Levine, a counselor at Clearview Regional High School, in Gloucester County, is more measured in her response.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''We have seen, over the past two to three years, a resurgence of heroin,'' she said. ''But it is not an enormous problem. This is not a problem we see with most of our kids. Even the ones stupid enough to be using cocaine are still afraid to use heroin.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Along with disagreement about the extent of the problem, there is controversy about what to do about it. People under 18 are usually not given methadone, long the standard treatment for addiction, and some are turning to a rapid detoxification procedure offered by a private doctor in Merchantville, outside Camden. But that process has come under fire, in part because it involves general anesthesia, making it more dangerous than other detox methods.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''I'm not convinced this will work,'' said a woman in the Merchantville waiting room, weeping intermittently as she described the torments of her 30-year-old daughter, who became addicted more than five years ago while pursuing a graduate degree in philosophy in Barcelona. ''But at this point, I'll try anything.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Law-enforcement agents say they began to notice heroin's return to New Jersey in urban areas like Newark, Paterson and Camden a few years ago. Up to that point, they say, heroin in the Northeast usually originated in Asia, imported by Chinese and Pakistani drug gangs, often via Sicily with the help of the Mafia.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: At every step, the drug was diluted with other powders to stretch the profits. When it hit the street it had less than 10 percent of its original strength. Addicts had to inject the drug directly into their bloodstream to feel any effect.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Then Colombian cocaine cartels started growing poppies in the Andes.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The cartels needed to buffer losses from a diminishing American market for cocaine, which has dropped, according to some studies, from more than six million users a decade ago to about two million. And they realized that a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of heroin took the same effort to smuggle, but had a street value of nearly $200,000, compared with about $30,000 for cocaine, according to Edward J. Hanko, the special agent in charge of the drug squad in the F.B.I.'s Newark office.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The cartels ship heroin into the Northeast on established cocaine routes, the law-enforcement officials say. The most common way is trucking it through Mexico. The drugs can also be flown and shipped into the Caribbean, where they are smuggled past United States Customs into Puerto Rico.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: From there, it is a relatively trouble-free ride. The drugs are ''body-smuggled'' -- swallowed in condoms or balloons -- by airplane passengers into Newark and the other regional airports, or hidden on cargo ships that dock in the Northeast.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The heroin is sold to middlemen, who hire urban youngsters to sell their ''brands'' -- for example, Greyhound, Homicide and New Jack City -- on the street. But the drug has gone through many fewer hands than the Asian product. The Drug Enforcement Administration has tested Colombian heroin at purity levels averaging over 60 percent and reaching highs of 80 percent.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: High Purity Means Needles Not Necessary
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: That is the key to the current drug problem. The higher the purity, the more users tend to snort it, rather than inject it. (Eating it on Jell-O, experts say, isn't effective.)
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''Purity is certainly one of the factors that's made heroin more attractive to young people,'' said Anthony Senneca, the special agent in charge of the Drug Enforcement Administration's Newark office. ''You don't have to pass this Rubicon of injecting.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The local distribution network includes parts of New York City, Newark, Paterson, Camden and Philadelphia, said Barry Goas, a deputy attorney general who supervises the Statewide Narcotics Task Force, a joint effort between the Department of Justice and the State Police. And the markets are often near major highways to increase access for suburban buyers.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: On a Sunday afternoon, five boys, no older than 14, cluster on a broken sidewalk at the edge of a red-brick housing project in Newark. To the north lies industrial emptiness; to the east, the McCarter Highway, with its links to Routes 280 and 3, the turnpike and the Garden State Parkway.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Cars, some shiny, some battered, slip off the highway and roll to a stop. That's all it takes: the boys leap to the driver's window, each thrusting a fist of vials forward and crying, ''Hey, look, look at this! Nickels, nickels, nickels.'' They're competing.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: In the vials are powdered cocaine and crack. Asked for heroin, one of the boys simply shifts the vials to reveal small, flat, white plastic rectangles cupped in his palm. ''Twenty dollars,'' he says, his urgent face framed by the hood of his sweatshirt. ''How many you want?''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The little packet is almost weightless, but the transaction isn't. Buyer and seller have committed felonies, and, because a school is near, could face years in prison. Statutes that took effect last week mean that sentences can reach 10 years for possession with intent to distribute within 500 feet of the state's parks and beaches.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Everyone knows buying and selling heroin is a crime. But there is no lack of buyers or sellers, who can avoid serious penalties until they are 18. Their adult employer would get the penalty -- if he were caught.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Much is know about how the heroin trade works in New Jersey, but no one can accurately answer one simple question: How many young people are using the drug?
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: There are national questionnaire-based surveys that purport to estimate numbers of users, like the annual National Household Survey on Drug Abuse and the Monitoring the Future report. The most recent household survey, using data from 1996, says that 4.3 percent of the nation's 12-to-17-year-olds and 13.9 percent of its 18-to-25-year-olds have used heroin at least once.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: But such studies are open to methodological criticisms, as well as to one simple flaw: respondents could be lying. ''When the friendly man from the government asks you about drug use, you just might not tell the truth,'' said David Boyum, a vice president at Botec Analysis Corporation, a private research group in Cambridge.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Defenders say the absolute numbers in the studies are less important than the trend of increasing heroin use they reveal, since the proportion of liars is probably stable from year to year.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Local measures have problems, too.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: There are about 10,000 heroin addicts in some form of treatment in New Jersey, according to John French, a supervisor with the Department of Health. But whenever the state finances a free detox program, ''We have to turn the people away,'' according to Carmen Moncrieffe, director of intake at the Essex Treatment Center, a private company that operates three methadone clinics.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The state medical examiner's office, after a painstaking, largely noncomputerized count, was able to say only that, of the 23,681 deaths from Jan. 1, 1997, to now, 729 listed the primary cause as drug overdose. Identifying which drug was impossible.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: New Jersey's Uniform Crime Report says there were more than 61,000 arrests in 1996 related to ''opium or cocaine and their derivatives.'' In 1992, there were 47,000 total arrests. Again, there is no way to separate the heroin from the cocaine cases.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The absence of solid numbers means that impressions tend to form around headlines, and that, some say, is a terrible measure.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: For example, there was the case last year in which a Toms River teen-ager, Daniel Bruce Tonkovich, driving through Newark after one of his regular heroin-buying trips, struck and killed a 7-year-old boy, and fled the scene. The teen-ager died of a heroin overdose last month, just before his trial was to begin.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''News for many editors and journalists is when they're at a cocktail party and the nephew of somebody's first cousin has gotten in trouble with heroin,'' said Michael Massing, the author of ''The Fix,'' a book on the nation's drug policy, to be published this fall by Simon & Schuster. ''And they'll focus on that, even though it doesn't represent the real growth in heroin use, most of which is consumed by people in the inner city, who add it to their cocaine habit. For most journalists, that's just old news.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Chemically, heroin is simply morphine on jet skis, zooming into the brain almost instantly. There, the opiate attaches to neural receptors, triggering euphoria.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''It's like a dream state,'' said the 23-year-old Belmawr addict. ''I was aware of my surroundings, but it was like I was dreaming. Like I was floating on water, floating on the top, like on sliding mirrors.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: After a few weeks of consistent use, the user's brain changes. Whenever its heroin receptors are empty, it releases a flood of noradrenalin. In normal quantities, the hormone helps start the ''fight or flight'' response, but at the higher quantities in heroin withdrawal, it causes diarrhea, muscle spasms, intestinal cramps, vomiting, hot and cold flashes, and insomnia.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Controversial Treatment Advertised on Billboards
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: To leapfrog that agony, Dr. Lance Gooberman, of Merchantville, has been offering an unusual rapid detoxification under general anesthesia, during which he implants a pellet that releases a monthlong dose of a heroin-blocking drug. An addict can try to relapse, but for that month, he or she will not succeed. ''It makes every bag a 'beat' bag,'' Dr. Gooberman said.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: On a recent Saturday morning, three men in their 20's and a 30-year-old woman came to his office, accompanied by family members, at 7 A.M. One by one, the addicts are prepared for anesthesia, lying in hospital beds in white cotton gowns. Unconscious, breathing tube in place, they are given a dose of of drug called naltrexone, which almost immediately knocks every trace of heroin off the neural receptors: withdrawal.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Dr. Gooberman makes an incision in the belly about an inch long and inserts the pellet by hand, pushing it deep under the skin. ''I don't want them trying to get this out,'' he said, his gloved hands bloody.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: By 2 P.M., the patients are awake, ready to go home, blearily hoping it might work.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The process costs about $3,000 to $4,000. It is advertised on billboards in Newark, Philadelphia, Baltimore and New York City and has been featured on the Montel Williams talk show. And it has many critics, who say that general anesthesia adds an unnecessary risk to detoxification, that other treatments are just as effective, and that Dr. Gooberman should pay for some independent studies that could establish a believable risk-benefit ratio.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Dr. Gooberman's own limited followup shows that a majority of his patients stay clean for months. A doctor performing the procedure in London has reported that 80 percent of his patients are clean at 90 days. But Dr. Gooberman says he does not pretend his treatment is a cure. ''Addiction is not a curable disease,'' he said. ''What I try to do is get people into remission, and keep them there a month at a time, until they can get in a 12-step program and learn to live a day at a time.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: In the last three years, Dr. Gooberman has performed the procedure 1,300 times, on doctors, lawyers, a kindergarten teacher, police officers. One patient was his own niece, Nicole Ollson. ''One man flew in on the Concorde,'' Dr. Gooberman said.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Some patients come back for additional implants. Franco Biano was back for his third. Mr. Biano, a 30-year-old truck driver who had a seven-year habit, said: ''I've been knifed, robbed, stabbed. I've had a gun down my throat.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Last Saturday was his 66th day off heroin, and, like many addicts who manage to escape their torment, however briefly, he was exuberant.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''I feel alive now,'' he said. ''I don't feel like I'm dead anymore.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Age 19, From the Suburbs and Heroin Addicts
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: They don't know why they are, but Nicole Ollson and Anthony San Felice, both 19, know what they are: heroin addicts.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Recovering, they say. ''I'm clean 82 days today,'' said Ms. Ollson, a tiny woman in a fuzzy sweater and dark lipliner.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''I'm almost two months,'' said Mr. San Felice, closely shorn and hiply baggy in Hilfiger. ''But I had nine months before, and I picked up.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: They are good kids, with loving families from nice neighborhoods: Cherry Hill and Westmont. They say heroin is easy to get and they know lots of people who use it. ''Some kids start at 12 now,'' said Ms. Ollson. ''That shocked me. I started at 17.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The two met last year. He had been using heroin since he was 14, paying for it by selling marijuana and cocaine to his classmates. That's common, they said. Some people they know even try to hook their friends on heroin to pay for their own habits.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Her habit was only a couple of years old, but it was ruining everything. First thing every morning, she and her friends headed over the bridge to Philadelphia. They were all dope sick, sweaty and cramping.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: The friends were supposed to come up with the money -- $10 a bag, and the $2 toll, plus gas -- because she had the car, her mother's white Mitsubishi Eclipse.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''Everybody knew that car in North Philly,'' she said, laughing. ''They'd see it coming and try to trap us.'' Not trap literally, she said. ''It means they tried to get us as a customer.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: One or two bags in hand, the people in the car would snort every particle within minutes. And they'd head back to Cherry Hill, and start scrounging money for the next hit. They went over six, seven times a day, she said: ''We could just never come up with much money at one time.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: They all stole from their families. ''My mom went through hell with me,'' Mr. San Felice said miserably. ''She had this ring, diamond and sapphire, her engagement ring from my dad. I sold it for $200.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Ms. Ollson nodded. ''I sold all of my mother's gold,'' she said. ''Somebody sold their mom's wedding ring.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: She held up her fingers: a tiny ring gleamed on one. ''That's how you can tell I'm not using,'' she said. ''I have gold on my hands.''
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Ms. Ollson eventually went to her uncle, Dr. Lance Gooberman, who gave her a controversial medical detoxification and then did the same for her boyfriend. Now the couple are counting the days, hoping they'll be able to stay away from drugs, and trying to rebuild their young lives. She says she's going to go to a community college in the fall. He's trying to get his G.E.D. and get into the Philadelphia Art Institute.
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: ''It's hard for people to trust me,'' said Mr. San Felice. ''I'm trying real hard to make it up to my mom. But my mom's scared. She's seen me get clean and throw it all away.'' ANDREA KANNAPELL
title: Heroin in Your Backyard

text: Traditional jurisprudence frowns on guilt by association -- unless the defendant is a plant called industrial hemp and the prosecutor is the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration. Recently a coalition of farmers, environmentalists and businesses petitioned the drug agency and the Department of Agriculture to stop treating this plant as a criminal just because it is related to marijuana, a controlled substance. Otherwise, America's farmers and entrepreneurs will be at a disadvantage as other industrial democracies try to exploit hemp's commercial potential and environmental benefits.
title: Marijuana's Much-Maligned Cousin

text: The revival of interest in industrial hemp, which has 1 percent or less of the delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol, called THC, that gives marijuana its psychoactive effect, flows from the versatility of its seed and fiber. The seed can be converted into food oil, animal feed, paints and cosmetics. The fiber can be turned into textile, rope, carpets, paper products and construction materials. In at least 10 states, farmers also want to assess its value as a rotation crop that is pest- and disease-resistant. Ford researchers abroad are studying it as a lightweight material for radiator grilles and other auto parts.
title: Marijuana's Much-Maligned Cousin

text: Neither the drug agency nor Barry McCaffrey, the President's drug policy adviser, find this persuasive. Legalizing hemp, his office says -- removing it from the D.E.A.'s controlled-substance list -- would confuse everyone, especially eighth graders, whose marijuana use has tripled in the last five years. Hemp, it warns, would provide camouflage for growing marijuana. But hemp and marijuana do not cohabit well. Hemp, grown mostly for its fibrous stalk, is planted in dense stands. Marijuana is not, since drug traffickers want a bush with leaves rich in THC, which added sunlight helps provide.
title: Marijuana's Much-Maligned Cousin

text: To ease law enforcement's fears, proponents have offered a compromise. The agency would revise its rules to legalize hemp but award jurisdiction to the Agriculture Department. Agriculture would distribute certified seed with a THC level of 1 percent or less to farmers it licensed; it would inspect fields too. The marketplace, not myopic rules, should determine hemp's future in America.
title: Marijuana's Much-Maligned Cousin

text: Northern Ireland Talks Reach a Landmark Pact
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Northern Ireland peace talks produced a landmark settlement that forged concessions from fiercely antagonistic Catholic and Protestant figures in an effort to settle the enduring conflict. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton was deeply involved as the talks concluded, cajoling and prodding both Republicans and Unionists to step out of their parochial interests. A4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The former United States Senator George J. Mitchell, the departing chairman of the talks, said that he had accelerated the pace of the negotiations because he feared the assassination of one of the prominent leaders involved in the talks. A4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: United States officials and private analysts said Pakistan's test of a new missile with a range exceeding 900 miles was based on technology smuggled from North Korea. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Officials of the Palestinian Authority and Hamas met to try to end their feud over who killed Muhyiaddin al-Sharif, a Hamas bomb-maker, but there was no sign that either side was prepared to back down. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Croatia Will Ask for Extradition
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Croatia will ask Argentina to extradite a former concentration camp director, Dinko Sakic, to stand trial for crimes he is accused of committing in World War II, Zagreb's ambassador in Buenos Aires said. The request gave Argentina legal standing to arrest Mr. Sakic if he could be found. Mr. Sakic admitted on Argentine television that he headed a concentration camp in the former Yugoslavia during the war. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: U.S. Seeks China Aid on Pol Pot
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Clinton Administration asked China for help in arranging an international war-crimes trial for Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader held responsible for the deaths of one million Cambodians in the 1970's. There were reports that the last Khmer Rouge stronghold had fallen to mutineers and Cambodian troops. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: U.S. Meets on Biological Arms
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Clinton and a dozen top administration officials met with biotechnology experts to discuss the national security dangers of biological weapons. The group addressed use of a new inspection system to strengthen the Biological Weapons Convention, which is designed to prevent the use of disease as a weapon. (AP)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Russian Parliament's lower house rejected President Boris N. Yeltsin's nominee for Prime Minister, Sergei N. Kiriyenko. But Mr. Yeltsin resubmitted Mr. Kiriyenko's nomination less than an hour later. The rejection of the 35-year-old former banker, political novice and Acting Prime Minister in the first round of balloting had been widely expected. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Gore Visits South, Where Storms Killed 44
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Vice President Al Gore toured parts of Alabama that were struck by storms this week. Officials said the death toll in Alabama, Mississippi and Georgia had grown to 44. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Smoking cigars can be just as deadly as smoking cigarettes, and the number of cigar smokers rose 50 percent since 1993, the Government said. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A van driven by a man wearing four bulletproof vests rammed a patrol car in Sacramento, Calif., not long after shots from the van struck a deputy sheriff in the back, the authorities said. The van and patrol car burst into flames after the crash. About 75 people in a square-mile area were evacuated after the suspect told officers pulling him from the burning wreckage that a pipe bomb and ammunition were in the van. Deputy Mike Butler's bulletproof vest protected him from two shots to the back and he suffered only a graze wound to the shoulder. The patrol car driver, Deputy Jared Beck, was hospitalized in good condition with sore ribs. Hospital officials said the suspect, who was not identified, was in good condition with cuts on his forehead and knee. (AP)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: More than 120 U.P.S. workers in 15 states have filed labor complaints with the National Labor Relations Board, alleging they suffered retaliation for failing to support the teamsters' union's two-week strike against the package deliverer last summer. The workers said they had faced internal union disciplinary charges and had been required to pay new initiation fees. Many also said they had been duped into believing that they had to pay full teamsters dues to work at U.P.S. A teamsters spokesman said the complaints amounted to ''a mini-campaign'' being waged by ''a front group funded by corporations.'' (AP)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: No Right to Youthful Sex
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A California appeals court has ruled that while many teen-agers are sexually active, minors do not have a constitutional right to have sex. The Court of Appeals for the First District, in San Francisco, ruled 3 to 0 on Thursday that a state law making it a crime for minors to have sex with each other does not violate their right to privacy. A 16-year-old boy, arrested for having sex with a 14-year-old girl in 1996, had challenged the state's statutory rape law. His lawyers argued that the right to engage in consensual sex was part of fundamental privacy rights. (AP)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Two Midblock Crosswalks Go Into Service in Midtown
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: New York City installed traffic signals in the middle of two midtown Manhattan blocks as part of an effort to ease conflicts between foot and vehicle traffic at busy corners. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The authorities in Morris County, N.J., said they had charged a 19-year-old man in the fatal shooting of a gas station attendant that was caught on a video surveillance system in the station. B2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Judge Opens Files to Reporters
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A State Supreme Court judge ordered New York City officials to allow news reporters to review records of the names and addresses of people who have left welfare, rejecting City Hall's contention that such access would violate state confidentiality rules. B3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Yankees opened their season at home with a 17-13 victory over the Oakland Athletics, the highest scoring game ever played at Yankee Stadium. C1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: 2 Share Lead in Masters
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Fred Couples and David Duval led at five under par (139) after the second round of the Masters. Tiger Woods, the defending champion, was in a five-way tie for fourth place. C1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Manhattan's annual spring week of major photography auctions ended with record sales at every participating house and record prices for works by several artists, among them Imogene Cunningham's ''Magnolia Blossom,'' which sold for $211,500. B7
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The F.C.C. said that at least some companies that provide telephone service over the Internet should be regulated in some of the same ways that traditional phone companies like AT&T are. D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A professional society of New York cancer specialists asked state officials to investigate complaints of long delays in payments by one of metropolitan New York's largest insurers, Aetna U.S. Healthcare. D2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The dollar tumbled against the yen in Asian trading as the Bank of Japan sold dollars for a second consecutive day to prop up the yen. D4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Stock, bond and commodity markets in the United States and many other countries were closed in observance of Good Friday. Markets in the United States will reopen on Monday, but most European markets will be closed.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Editorials: An Easter peace in Ireland; the politics of partial birth abortion; don't shoot -- run for mommy; marijuana's much-maligned cousin.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Columns: Frank Rich, Thomas L. Friedman.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Ten years ago, at the height of New York City's crack epidemic, a notorious drug gang called the Supreme Team brought in $250,000 a week selling crack in and around a southeast Queens housing project known as the Baisley Park Houses, ruthlessly mowing down those in their way.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: Now, years after the gang's leaders were sent to prison for murder and racketeering and the gang was effectively quashed, the police have arrested 15 men and 9 women who the authorities say called themselves the New Supreme Team, selling marijuana, crack and cocaine in and around the same housing project. They were arrested in a raid late Wednesday night by the police and officials with the Queens District Attorney's office.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: The police said that only one of those arrested this week, Damon Kearsley, a 26-year-old resident of the housing project who was twice convicted on drug possession and sales charges, was also a member of the original Supreme Team, one of several gangs that controlled the crack market in Queens in the late 1980's. In May 1995, the leader of the original gang, Gerald Miller of Queens Village, who used the street name Prince, was sentenced to life in prison for the murder of three Colombian drug traffickers. Several of his associates were convicted on murder, racketeering and drug charges and are also serving long prison sentences.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: At a news conference yesterday afternoon, prosecutors and the police said that although the activities of the New Supreme Team paled in comparison to the scope and the viciousness of the original gang, they expected that the new gang would take a turn for the worse.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: ''This group had the potential of being extraordinarily violent,'' Richard A. Brown, the Queens District Attorney, said. ''We believe we nipped this operation in the bud.''
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: The 24 people arrested face drug and weapons charges. No one has been connected to a murder or other incident of violence.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: Nevertheless, some neighborhood residents said that members of the new gang had behaved more recklessly than the old gang's members, who, they said, were generally courteous and respectful to residents of the projects. Over the last several months, the neighbors said, members of the new gang tried to intimidate many residents, sitting on people's cars and sometimes shooting at the apartment buildings and cars parked in the lot.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: The police said that they first learned of the New Supreme Team last summer; they estimated that the gang sold about $500,000 worth of drugs a year. The police said that during a four-month undercover investigation, they bought $10,000 in drugs from the reputed gang members, including six separate purchases from one man, Javier Reyes, 29, a resident of the project. He and three others -- Mr. Kearsley, Gabriel Reyes, 19, and Mark Haynes, 25 -- are charged with criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first or second degree. If convicted, they could be sentenced to life in prison.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: In the undercover operation, the authorities said, officers also bought three guns from two members of the group: William Gillard, 30, and Troy Smith, 26, both of whom were arrested on Wednesday on weapons charges. If convicted, they face up to four years in prison.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: Assistant Chief Charles Kammerdener, commanding officer of the Police Department's narcotics division, said officials from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were investigating where the guns came from.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: The police said that about half of the 24 people arrested lived in the Baisley Park Houses, including five members of the Reyes family and Mr. Kearsley's 31-year-old sister, Dionne, who was charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance in the first degree.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: Most of the others arrested lived nearby in southeastern Queens. One woman, Audrey Lee, 30, is from the Bronx; one man, Andrew Hobson, 25, is from Hempstead, N.Y.; and another, Damon Belk, 25, had a Connecticut address. All three face drug charges.
title: 24 Arrested on Drug Charges In Old Gang's Queens Territory

text: It is Thanksgiving 1973 in Ang Lee's film and life teeters on the brink in New Canaan, Conn. Watergate and marijuana smoke are in the air; car keys are for the picking at spouse-swapping parties, and the Hoods (Kevin Kline and Joan Allen) and the Carvers (Jamey Sheridan and Sigourney Weaver, above) struggle with a deadening malaise that strands them and their children on shifting ground. Despite a fatal accident, it is the distance between the characters and between them and viewers that remains ''an essential part of the film's disturbing power,'' wrote Janet Maslin in The New York Times.
title: New Video Releases

text: 1997. Fox. $104.16. Laser disk, $39.99. 113 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.
title: New Video Releases

text: In another Thanksgiving debacle, Marty (Josh Hamilton) takes his fiancee, Lesly (Tori Spelling) home to the stately family seat in McLean, Va. There to greet them is Marty's twin sister, the spectacularly disturbed Jackie-O (Parker Posey), who roams the mansion dressed and acting like the former First Lady.
title: New Video Releases

text: Fond illusions of Camelot take a beating as the twins, who were also lovers, recreate the Dallas assassination scene while their mother (Genevieve Bujold), every bit as crazy as Jackie-O, inveighs all with strange reflections. Much of the brittle, outrageous dialogue in Mark Waters's dark, screwball comedy is amusing (and not a little disturbing), ''but there are many gaping holes between the funny moments'' (Stephen Holden).
title: New Video Releases

text: 1997. Miramax. $104.16. Laser disk, $39.99. 90 minutes. Closed captioned. Release date: Tuesday.
title: New Video Releases

text: No sooner does Bobby Cooper (Sean Cooper) roll his Mustang into dusty Superior, Ariz., than he's caught up with the steamy Grace McKenna (Jennifer Lopez), who takes him home to meet her husband, Jake (Nick Nolte). Jake has a proposition for Bobby: kill his wife. And Grace has a job for Bobby: kill her husband. A complement of tacky characters (among them Billy Bob Thornton as an over-the-top auto mechanic) gather in Oliver Stone's film, which becomes ''a showcase for the filmmaker's terrific arsenal of visual mannerisms and free-association imagery'' (Maslin).
title: New Video Releases

text: 1997. Columbia Tri-Star. $105.77. Laser disk, $39.95. 125 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
title: New Video Releases

text: Alex Cross (Morgan Freeman), a veteran forensic specialist, teams with a young doctor named Kate (Ashley Judd) to track a killer who goes by the name of Casanova. Having escaped Casanova's rural North Carolina dungeon, Kate gets hot on the trail, but though she and Mr. Freeman radiate the smarts for a thriller a la ''Silence of the Lambs,'' it all falls flat in a film that opens with a good chase scene but then ''never replenishes its adrenaline'' (Holden).
title: New Video Releases

text: 1997. Paramount. $105.77. Laser disk, $34.98. 117 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.
title: New Video Releases

text: TWO years ago Social Security privatization probably had no more support in Washington than the legalization of marijuana. Today, the notion is being entertained by such heavyweights as Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee. Privatization has become a very real possibility in part because big budget surpluses are apparently available to help pay for the transition.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: ''Something labeled 'partial privatization' is bound to be included in any broad-based Social Security reform,'' predicted Sylvester Schieber, an economist at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a pension consulting company, and a member of the Government's Advisory Council on the system.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: But getting from here to there will be tricky. The seeming convergence on the idea of privatization masks deep differences of opinion. Consider the playing field:
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: THE LIBERTARIANS For some conservative intellectuals -- namely Carolyn Weaver of the American Enterprise Institute and Jose Pinera at the Cato Institute -- privatization is a matter of cutting Washington down to size. As long as the Government stands ready to play nanny, workers will have little incentive to plan for their own retirement. And as long as pension income amounts to a gift from Government, political coalitions will work to keep the checks rolling in.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: This is surely the oldest and most principled argument for privatization. Though legislators talk the libertarian talk, few really walk the walk. The libertarian stance does, however, offer a high-minded rationale for policies based on other considerations.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: THE ECONOMISTS -- To many technocrats -- Edward Gramlich, the former chairman of the Social Security Advisory Council who is now a governor of the Federal Reserve, comes to mind -- Social Security's ''crisis'' boils down to the collective failure to save enough to pay for the retirement of the huge baby-boom generation. Higher taxes, or bigger budget surpluses achieved through lower Government spending, would do the trick. But forced saving in personal pension accounts could prove more palatable since people would rather put away dollars in their own names than send them into the black hole of the Treasury.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: This argument for partial privatization apparently carries a lot of weight with the pragmatists in the Clinton Administration. And while he would hardly put it in these terms, the idea meshes with the proposal from John Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, to dedicate budget surpluses to private Social Security accounts.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: THE GENERATIONAL PEACEMAKERS -- While Social Security taxes and benefits create a tangled web of income redistribution, most of the transfer is from young to old. Not surprisingly, some politicos fear the losers will eventually take out their wrath on pensioners -- and on Washington. In this scheme of things, partial privatization would serve as a peace offering to the young and the restless.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: Senator Moynihan, for example, wants to cut payroll taxes and retirement benefits along with opening the door to tax-sheltered personal Social Security accounts. This would mean lower costs and subsidized savings for those not yet retired, and would make friends for the embattled public pension system.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: THE NEW DEALERS -- For some analysts, including the M.I.T. economist Peter Diamond and Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution, privatization is a solution in search of a problem. There is much right with Social Security, they say, and nothing that cannot be fixed with a few nips and tucks and modest tax increases.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: But, they reason, if you can't lick 'em, join 'em. The privatization could be transformed into something useful, namely a broader Social Security trust fund that includes private stocks, which have historically generated bigger returns than Government bonds.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: Most who favor private investment by the trust fund don't kid themselves that the shift would increase the total size of the economic pie. But it probably would give lower- and middle-income retirees a bigger slice, since Social Security accounts for a bigger portion of their retirement funds than it does of the wealthy. ''Why should the rich get all the benefit from the 'equity premium' that comes with taking modest risks in the stock market?'' asks Mr. Diamond.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: The lure of privatization has turned a no-win political debate about how much to cut benefits and how much to raise taxes into an exercise with interesting possibilities. That fact alone makes a major overhaul of Social Security more likely in the next few years.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: But the new form is hardly clearer than it was when privatization was just a gleam in the eyes of assorted libertarians. So much of the support for privatization is purely as a means to an end that policy makers inclined toward big changes will be deeply reluctant to clarify the issues.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: Something akin to a consensus on Social Security privatization is perhaps within reach. But the consensus is more rhetorical than real.
title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

text: By Philip Shenon and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: President Clinton has ordered the Departments of Defense, State and Justice to devise plans for the arrest and trial of Pol Pot, the shadowy Khmer Rouge leader responsible for the death of perhaps a million Cambodians in the 1970's.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: Clinton Administration officials and Western diplomats said that the Khmer Rouge appeared to be near collapse as a result of mass defections and internal fighting. Pol Pot and other Khmer Rouge leaders are said to be in hiding in the Cambodian jungle only a few miles across the border with Thailand.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: The Thai Government, diplomats said, has suggested it would be willing to take Pol Pot into custody as long as the United States agreed to spirit him out of Thailand within hours of his capture.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: Senior American military officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that intelligence reports from Southeast Asia showed that the Thai military had actually taken Pol Pot into custody late last week but then freed him.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: The Thai military, the officials said, may have feared that his capture would antagonize China, long an ally of the Khmer Rouge, and would complicate the foreign policy of Thailand's recently installed Government, which is already struggling with an economic crisis.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: Spokesmen at the Thai Embassy in Washington had no comment. Other American officials described the intelligence reports as sketchy and said it would be unfair to criticize the Thai military on the basis of such fragmentary evidence.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: While Administration officials cautioned that there was no guarantee that the ailing Khmer Rouge leader would be apprehended, they said that recent developments along the border were so significant that President Clinton issued a written order Monday to organize logistics for Pol Pot's capture and trial.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: Under one plan being discussed within the Administration, an American military plane would take Pol Pot from Thailand to a third country, possibly the Netherlands, where international tribunals are prosecuting war crimes carried out in Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: A military official said the Pentagon had drawn up a list of interim sites where Pol Pot might be held until a location for the trial was selected. These include the Northern Marianas Islands and Wake Island -- both American territories in the Pacific -- or the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: ''We've had many false alarms before with the Khmer Rouge, but this may be our best chance to get Pol Pot,'' said a Clinton Administration official who is involved in the planning. ''We're not going to be caught unprepared if he's made available to us.''
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: Another American official said that ''if we don't get Pol Pot this time, he may die before we ever have the chance to bring him to justice.''
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: The official said that despite the reports of Pol Pot's capture and release by Thai soldiers last week, the Thai Government ''is being cooperative, and their cooperation will be essential if we're to pull this off.''
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: Under President Clinton's order, officials said, the State Department has been directed to oversee negotiations with Thailand, the Netherlands and other nations that might be involved in the apprehension and trial. The Justice Department has been asked to review the legal authority that would be needed under international law for the United States to become involved in the detention of Pol Pot.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: Western diplomats said prosecutors at the international tribunals in The Hague had already tentatively agreed to organize a trial for Pol Pot for crimes against humanity, as long as the United Nations Security Council empowers them to oversee the prosecution. The diplomats said the United States, France and other nations had already begun drafting a Security Council resolution to deal with such a trial.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: From 1975 to 1979, Pol Pot, who is now in his 70's and in poor health, turned Cambodia into a vast labor camp. Millions of Cambodians, especially city-dwellers, were driven from their homes and forced to work in the fields under primitive conditions. Pol Pot labeled anyone with money or education an enemy of the revolution, and much of the middle class was killed during his four-year reign of terror or starved to death.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: The Khmer Rouge were toppled by a Vietnamese invasion in 1979. They resumed their guerrilla struggle in the jungle, where they have remained for two decades. They have armed and fed themselves with the proceeds of the sale of gems and timber harvested in areas of Cambodia under their control.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: The movement began to fall apart last year, when the followers of Pol Pot turned against him, apparently over his decision to order the assassination of the Khmer Rouge defense chief, Son Sen, and 14 relatives, including his grandchildren.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: After the killings, Pol Pot's former comrades tried him and sentenced him to house arrest. He is reported to be under the control of his former top military commander, Ta Mok.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: In interviews last year with an American reporter who observed portions of the trial, Pol Pot said that ''My conscience is clear.''
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: ''I came to carry out the struggle, not to kill people'' he explained. He insisted that estimates that millions had died during the Khmer Rouge reign were overstated. ''To say that millions died is too much,'' he said.
title: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

text: In the burned-out heart of a 200-year-old factory district here, a developer wants to pay the city for the right to build 64 town houses where for a generation there has been little but rubble and failure.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: Under the three-year-old proposal, the Regan Development Corporation of Yonkers, which has already carried out historical renovations in Paterson, would pay the city about $320,000 for the seven-and-one-half-acre site, whose last working factory burned in 1983 and whose only occupants are squatters. On March 24, the City Council voted 6 to 2 to approve the land sale.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: If this were any other poor, crowded city, a proposal to fill a gaping municipal wound with new homes and taxpayers might be expected to draw nothing but praise. But in this city it is more complicated than that. Ardent opponents warn that Paterson, which has lost so much since its locomotive industry died and its textile plants moved south, stands to lose its most important link with its industrial past, as well as its most scenic tourist opportunity, if the plan gets its remaining permits.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: ''Can you imagine the sun coming up over this area?'' Tom Piccoli, 61, a retired dry cleaner, said as he stood in the natural amphitheater created by the brownstone quarry that provided the foundations for the early mills. He stood in a vast field of charred beams, bricks and broken concrete. Above him were the cliffs of the 77-foot-high Great Falls, the waterfall whose potential inspired Paterson's formation as the nation's first planned industrial city.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: But decades of neglect have created what David Soo, an opponent of the Regan project, called ''an environment of desperation'' about the site. Fires have been a persistent problem; on March 23, a man was charged with murdering a sleeping squatter by pouring gasoline on him and lighting it.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: Mr. Soo, a ceramic artist who heads a tenant group in the neighboring Phoenix Mill housing, said Paterson's government had reduced demand for the site by failing to clear the rubble and not preparing a development study, which he said could have attracted a better proposal.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: ''We tried,'' responded United States Representative William J. Pascrell, who was Mayor from 1991 through 1996. The environmental cleanup and historical preservation costs scared off all developers except Regan, Mr. Pascrell said.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: The opponents of Regan's proposal say builders should focus on the blighted housing and vacant lots all over Paterson. They say Regan wants the Great Falls site because parcels that large are rare, and a bigger project means bigger profits. ''It really is a sprawling town-house development along the lines of a suburb,'' said Flavia Alaya, chairwoman of the Paterson Historic Preservation Commission. She and other opponents say they are not against development on the site, but want something more in keeping with the district's tradition.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: Bob Grant, a spokesman for Mayor Martin G. Barnes, said the city's response to the critics had always been: ''Show us the money.'' Regan is ready to begin what the city estimates will be a $24 million project when all public and private work is done. ''Do we keep 100-year-old ruins,'' Mr. Grant asked, ''or do we put something in place that's going to be productive to the city?''
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: Larry Regan, 35, who runs the company with his brother, Kenneth, said the opposition's vehemence pained him. His father, Daniel, who is retired, restored the adjacent Essex and Phoenix Mills as artists' housing 15 years ago. ''We have a tremendous amount of sensitivity to the historic district,'' he said.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: Mr. Regan said he was only doing what the city government ordered: combining historic sensitivity with taxable property, and family homes with tourism. His project, he noted, follows a 1996 historical study of the site for the National Park Service. Under the guidelines, the developer must preserve the river vista and many factory facades, including the front of the Waverly Mill, which will become part of a four-story commercial and apartment structure, and the walls of the former Colt gun factory, which will remain city property and be developed separately by the city. Regan is to build a walk along the river and clear the way for public sites, which could include artisan space and an industrial museum that would recreate and interpret the factories and the canal system leading from the falls that powered them.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: On this historically freighted piece of real estate, the debate sometimes seems dominated by ghosts: Alexander Hamilton, who in 1791 helped organize the industrial district; Samuel Colt, whose gun factory made the first Colt revolvers in 1836, and John Ryle, whose ribbon factory helped make Paterson the silk center of the nation. The ghosts of two major poets are there: William Carlos Williams, who made the falls the heart of his five-volume epic, ''Paterson''; and Williams's disciple Allen Ginsberg, a Paterson native who was threatened with arrest in the 1960's for smoking marijuana by the falls.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: The 119-acre factory district owes its survival to the late Mary Ellen Kramer, who led efforts in the early 1970's to block a planned riverside highway that would have cut through the district. In 1976, President Gerald R. Ford dedicated the 119 acres as a national historic landmark. A number of factories have been restored since then, including the former Rogers locomotive plant, which is now a museum, and the 54,000-square-foot Cooke mill, now a hospital clinic topped by subsidized housing. But fires devastated the area around the Colt factory.
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: ''We've had great history in Paterson, but that's something we can't live off of,'' Mayor Barnes said, adding: ''Alexander Hamilton, he wanted to build factories down there to make money. I don't know if we're too much farther away.''
title: Among the Ruins, a Move Against Redevelopment

text: Now that the big boys, the Mets and the Yankees, are back, we can afford to sweat the small stuff, the melting Rangers and the nicked Knicks and the shark attack on college sports. Baseball is still the national pastime; what other sport can offer us world-class, blockbuster, fascinating villains like Huizenga and Murdoch?
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: Poor hockey. The only owner we ever got to care about was the pink-cheeked John Spano, who conned the National Hockey League into thinking he had the money to buy the Islanders last year. This year, still sheepish, the ''coolest game on earth'' tried to recoup, to seem more like its younger, richer brother, the National Basketball Association, by sending its pros to the Olympic Games in Nagano, Japan. Not only were the men overshadowed by the style and spirit of the amateur women's team, they also managed to embarrass themselves on their own.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: Now, the most famous (coolest?) male hockey players on earth are UNKNOWN, the American Olympic team members who have been accused of vandalizing a hotel room, then refusing to turn themselves in. The United States Olympic Committee is so miffed that the entire hockey team has been disinvited to a White House reception on April 28 for the Olympic contingent.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: Under such circumstances, singling out Ranger management for its continued failings may be unfair, but that never stopped us before. Goodbye, Rangers. Have a pleasant summer killing fish on northern lakes just now melting. Remember that the last time you won a championship, 1994, might as well be 1940 because it was an aberration, not the product of a long-term plan.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: All those years when the Rangers should have been building a team for the future, grooming youngsters (forget about losing Eric Lindros), they were buying old samurai for one desperate assault on Lord Stanley's castle. Mark Messier and Coach Mike Keenan, two madmen with a shared obsession, drove a team to the top, where it burned out. Buying Wayne Gretzky was a slap in the fan's face, and the end of my own brief passion for the Broadway Blues; even the Beast in the upper deck knew it was all about sprucing up the Garden for sale, not about creating a contender.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: In retrospect, the Ranger management style unmasked itself well before that championship season -- in 1992, when it dumped the true spirit of the team, the cheerful little mugger Tie Domi, a journeyman player who skated surprisingly well but was encouraged to be a goon. He was so happy just to be in the big leagues -- he was rooming with Adam Graves, the Billy Budd of hockey, now in decline -- that he willingly allowed his stick to be turned into a cudgel.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: After the rare goal, Domi would ride his stick, a crude gesture constantly replayed by management. And then, sprucing up for another change of corporation, the Rangers dumped Domi. Years ago, Messier said that management had treated Domi like the drunk at the party who entertained with a lampshade on his head; as soon as the laughs fell away, the drunk would be shooed off, perhaps to drive himself home.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: Missing Messier may be at the heart of this rant. He is in Vancouver now, where exiles claim he is on a power trip; he deserves to be. Domi is with Toronto, where he is playing a much larger role than just a goon.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: Meanwhile, professional hockey's role model, professional basketball, has problems of its own. The testiness that N.B.A. executives flash at those curse words -- Latrell Sprewell -- is real; they are nervous.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: Basketball is on course, if it isn't there already, to supplant soccer as the international pastime. But will the N.B.A. be able to take advantage of the boom it helped create? Executives are concerned about ''brand equity,'' about the league's role in the new world order, its market share of the future. With Michael Jordan nearing retirement and no heir apparent, nothing could be more harmful than the perception that the N.B.A. is slipping back into its dark ages, the druggy, orgiastic 70's. Reports of widespread marijuana use and Sprewell as the symbolic out-of-control player are fueling that perception. Despite our fantasies, Chamique Holdsclaw is not going to save the league, nor will Jerry Tarkanian's greatest victory, last week's $2.5 million settlement for 26 years of harassment by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the Kenneth Starr of sports.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: Like the special prosecutor, the N.C.A.A. has inconvenienced many small fry, but hasn't been able to land the big fish. Tark the Shark is no Captain Dreyfus, but he's no Unabomber, either; because he works the badlands of academe with prospects who are suspects, it is easier to hector him than engage a corrupt system that the N.C.A.A. has helped maintain. Thank goodness baseball is here with major league scoundrels who buy teams, then pennants, then downsize. It should be a great summer, the Yankees winning, the Mets an easy ticket, nothing to worry about until the Rev. Reggie White returns in the fall when we find out whether God is really on his side or was just too busy wishing she were Michael.
title: Backtalk; A Few Parting Shots For the Rangers' Brass

text: Whether he was starring in a critically panned movie or holed up in a recording studio when he should have been working on his free-throw form, Shaquille O'Neal has been taken to task for caring more about his image than basketball.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: ''That's what people say, but I really don't care what people think,'' O'Neal said before he carved up the Nets for 50 points on Thursday night at the Meadowlands. ''I'm not worried about my image. I answer to only God, Jerry West, my parents, my coaching staff and my teammates. That's it.''
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Ah, but beneath that gruff 7-foot-1-inch, 330-pound veneer, is Sensitive Shaq, the gentle giant who spent one and a half hours meeting with producers at the N.B.A. Entertainment offices in Secaucus, N.J., before the Lakers-Nets game.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Three weeks before the playoffs begin, the topic was, of course, O'Neal's marketing strategy.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Perhaps worried that people would take shots at him again for paying close attention to off-the-court matters, O'Neal at first denied the meeting he and his agent, Leonard Armato, had with the producers and top management of the league's marketing arm.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: But he finally came clean and outlined his reasoning. ''I'm big, but I could be real big,'' he said. In other words, O'Neal is growing tired of a Shaq America. He sees a Shaq World.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: ''They've done a pretty good job, but I think they could put a couple more things together, like the way they do with Mike,'' O'Neal said. ''Whatever, you know, use each other. I have avenues they really don't get to. They have avenues I don't get to. Like they've got a deal with McDonald's and Coke and I got a deal with Pepsi. Maybe they can get a little from Pepsi and I can get a little from McDonald's.''
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: He may sound a few fries short of a Happy Meal, but Shaq and his agent have big plans. The marketing firm O'Neal employs initiated the meeting, O'Neal said.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Adam Silver, the president and chief operating officer of N.B.A. Entertainment, said Armato spoke to him about new marketing possibilities for O'Neal at the All-Star Game break.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: ''It's a way for us to get more story ideas and a way for him to see who we are and what exactly we do,'' said Silver, who added that many of the league's stars visit the offices during the season. ''I don't think Shaq was unhappy about how he's being marketed.''
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: At any rate, O'Neal's new theme will be technology. He said he had already committed to a pact with the Boys Club.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: ''I'm going to build 58 Shaq Learning Centers with computers, Internet access, all that stuff. I want to do things that are reality based. I was always taught to help people in need. I don't need publicity. I don't need cash. I don't need these guys to come in and make me look good.''
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Asked if he left enough time for basketball, he smiled and replied, ''Who are we playing tonight?''
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: As labor fireworks go, a three-hour meeting between Commissioner David Stern and Billy Hunter, the executive director of the players association, at a midtown Manhattan hotel on Wednesday was little more than a dud. No sparks. Just a cordial meeting between two N.B.A. power brokers.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: The meeting was the first since the owners exercised their right to reopen the collective bargaining agreement on March 23 in Dallas, a move that will very likely invalidate the remaining three years of the pact between the owners and the players.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Beyond making sure exorbitant salaries stay in concert with growing revenues, Stern is apparently interested in updating code-of-conduct clauses in the agreement. Surely, the litany of knucklehead moves by players this season triggered his concern.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: He is also said to be pushing for a more stringent drug agreement, one that would include testing for marijuana. Only generalities were discussed at the meeting, a union official said. The union and the league have until June 30 to compromise or players run the risk of the owners locking them out over the summer, a move that would result in the suspension of trades and free agency but not in any work stoppage.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Stern and Hunter plan to speak again over the next two weeks, but do not look for progress until May, when firm proposals from the league are expected to be submitted to the players association.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Michael Jordan attempted and converted a left-handed free throw against Atlanta last week. It was hailed as another signature moment by the game's greatest player in front of the second-largest crowd in league history.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: But what if Allen Iverson used his nonshooting hand to make a foul shot in a game his team was winning comfortably? Or Isaiah Rider? Are they lauded as impeccable showmen, giving the fans what they want? Or ridiculed as petulant young stars, showing off in front of everyone?
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Del Harris realizes how fleeting success can be in the coaching fraternity, but forgive the Lakers' coach if he is having trouble digesting the current predicament he and some of his more prominent peers are in this season.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Amid incredible expectations, Harris, Phil Jackson in Chicago, Gregg Popovich in San Antonio and George Karl in Seattle have directed their teams into the playoffs. But all four are rumored to be out of a job.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Jackson's situation is sketchy and tied to Chicago's rebuilding plans. Popovich, based on a remarkable turnaround, is in far less danger than others. But for Harris and Karl, especially, the reality may be Western Conference finals or bust. Maybe that does not even guarantee another season.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: ''I've come to expect it, having been around,'' the 60-year-old Harris said. ''But when all those rumors were flying around about me being out awhile ago, it did get crazy. Everywhere I would go, people would come up to me and say, 'Del, I'm sorry,' like I had terminal cancer or something.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: ''I would just tell them, 'I'm still here, so don't worry about me.' But deep down, you do worry. The thing is, you can't do much about it if people have made up their minds about you. That's the coaching business.''
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: Other than Miami and Indiana, the Bulls, Lakers, Sonics and Spurs are the only teams to win 50 games this season.
title: A Motto (and a Polished Business Plan) for O'Neal: Entertain and Prosper

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: Two Brothers Indicted In Thefts at Banks

text: Two brothers from Staten Island have been indicted on charges of stealing $3,600 from a bank in New Jersey and trying to steal from two other banks in 1994 and 1995, Federal prosecutors announced on Friday.
title: Two Brothers Indicted In Thefts at Banks

text: The brothers, Thomas Capace, 30, and Christopher Capace, 23, were accused in a Federal indictment of stealing the money from the Amboy National Bank in Old Bridge by ripping the night deposit box from the wall of the bank with a chain attached to the fender of a stolen car, said Aidan P. O'Connor, an assistant United States attorney. The brothers tried the same technique at two other banks, in Marlboro and East Brunswick, but were unable to get any money, Mr. O'Connor said.
title: Two Brothers Indicted In Thefts at Banks

text: Christopher Capace was arrested on March 13 on Staten Island. Friday, he was ordered held by Judge Nicholas H. Politan of Federal District Court in Newark after testing positive for marijuana use, Mr. O'Connor said. His brother is in a state prison in Fishkill, N.Y., where he is serving a sentence for murder. The brothers' lawyer, Lorraine Gauli-Rufo, a Federal public defender, did not return calls seeking comment.
title: Two Brothers Indicted In Thefts at Banks

text: The Supreme Court decided the issue a decade ago: union members have the right to claim refunds of portions of their dues not spent on collective bargaining. If your union leader wants to contribute to a bill legalizing marijuana, and you're against pot smoking, you can get back from the union that part of your dues that went to support what you oppose.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: That strikes most Americans as eminently fair. But try to assert your right in the real world; the shop steward will make you a pariah, and the Clinton Administration, dependent on money from unions, will refuse to enforce your constitutional right.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: A movement is sweeping the states to make that right a reality. In California, the initiative is called ''paycheck protection.'' It would remove the burden of asserting that right from the rank and file; instead, unions would have to disclose where political contributions are going, and workers could approve or say ''not with my dues money, thanks.''
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: The prospect of losing absolute control over directing union dues to liberal candidates and causes is driving John Sweeney's A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters up the wall.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: By loudly announcing a ''hit list'' of Republican candidates; by helping launder money through politics for Ron Carey's corrupt teamsters' campaign, and by boasting of labor's financial clout, labor's new left-wing leadership invited a backlash.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: It has arrived. Gov. Pete Wilson of California, who has regained his popularity in his final year of two terms, is leading the fight to return political decision-making to the rank and file. He sees paycheck-protection Prop. 226 as ''one of the great public services of my career'' because it will curtail union power to block his proposals for education reform.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: Nail-nibbling G.O.P. operatives worried that Wilson's crusade in the nation's largest state would unplug a deluge of dollars from A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters to defeat the referendum, perhaps burying Republican candidates on the ballot this November. Wilson neatly finessed that danger by putting the initiative on the primary ballot on June 2.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'
