text: Although union officials argue that businesses and executives out-contribute unions by 10 to 1, business money is split between both parties (about 55-45 percent favoring Republicans) while almost all union money rewards Democratic friends.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: What about stockholders who object to contributions by the companies they own? They are free to protest by selling their stock, but union members in a union-shop state cannot get out of paying union dues. (As saucier for the gander, I think corporations should be required to disclose all political contributions on their Web pages the day they are made.)
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: Sweeney & Co. is in a panic for good reason: polls show paycheck protection (a hard-selling description that union spinmeisters have failed to counter) running far ahead. The lead will surely narrow in the next two months as unions pour millions into attack ads (And you want this part of your dues back? Sue us) but Pete Wilson is ready for any ''seal pup ad.''
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: The seal pup is legend in California media politics, much as L.B.J.'s TV ''daisy spot'' is remembered for unfairly clobbering Barry Goldwater. Democrat Willie Brown knocked down reapportionment years ago with a last-minute spot showing a seal pup suffocating in an oil slick. The ad message: redrawing district lines would elect anti-environmentalists who in turn would murder the cuddly innocents. The con job worked.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: The paycheck-protection brigade seeks to inoculate voters -- especially loyal union members of whom a third are conservative -- against a seal-pup attack. The plan is to define the workers' free-speech issue early, and warn of last-minute smears orchestrated by desperate union bosses in D.C.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: The Sweeneyites in the nation's capital, backed by a Clinton veto promise, can block Federal legislation to carry out the Supreme Court's decision to protect the individual worker. But if labor's bosses do not stop paycheck-protection in the state of California in June, the prairie fire will spread through a score of states and consume Democratic control of union coffers.
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: Would such an outcome help ignite a Presidential campaign for the Governor who made it happen? Says Pete Wilson, whose voice is back: ''Shouldn't hurt.''
title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'

text: It wasn't quite the Maltese Falcon, but there was a treasure of gems: 33 colored diamonds, the largest a marquise-cut, intense blue stone weighing more than three carats. There was no Humphrey Bogart, but there were Federal agents and a manhunt. There was no Peter Lorre or Sydney Greenstreet. But there was Stephen Jenks of Largo (no Key), Fla.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: The jewels were confiscated by the United States Customs Service from Mr. Jenks, who was arrested in 1994 and pleaded guilty the next year to running a multimillion-dollar marijuana smuggling ring. They are to be auctioned at Christie's on April 6 and 7, the first time that Customs, and perhaps any Federal agency, has teamed up with a leading auction house to sell seized property, although the Government has used smaller auctioneers for years. Christie's estimates the total sale price at $400,000 to $500,000.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: ''It underscores the forfeiture process, taking the profit out of drugs for use by law enforcement,'' said Raymond W. Kelly, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Enforcement and a former New York City police commissioner. Mr. Kelly, soon to be nominated as United States Customs Commissioner, said that Customs has supplemented its enforcement budget by $20 million a year through such sales, but that this case stood out for its breadth and scope.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: This story of drugs and jewels emerged from interviews with Steve Trent, a special agent in charge of the Customs Service office in Tampa, Fla.; Pam McCullough, a Customs senior special agent in Tampa; Michael Sheehan, a Customs spokesman in Miami, and Michael Bunk, a deputy United States marshal in Tallahassee, Fla.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: Through his lawyer, Bill Jung of Black & Jung in Tampa, Mr. Jenks declined to be interviewed. But Mr. Jung said that Mr. Jenks, at his sentencing, agreed to ''the factual basis'' of the Customs account.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: In the mid-1970's, as Colombian drugs flowed to North America, Mr. Jenks, then in his 20's, was establishing himself in the marijuana trade. Heading a crew of four and piloting sailboats 80 miles off Florida, he connected with Colombian smuggling ships, loading tons of marijuana into his vessels. His biggest haul -- more than 8 tons -- came in October 1981. In all, Customs officials said, Mr. Jenks smuggled more than 27 tons of marijuana.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: But an informer tipped off investigators, and by 1981, Federal agents were on Mr. Jenks's trail.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: That October, the authorities in Illinois broke up a marijuana ring, and eventually traced the distribution chain back to Mr. Jenks in Florida. But he fled before agents there could charge him, disappearing in 1982 with Sandra O'Bryant, the wife of one of his crew members, John O'Bryant, known as Jake.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: The next year, Mr. O'Bryant was arrested in Annapolis, Md., on charges of possessing illegal weapons and false identification. He and several other former associates of Mr. Jenks's were convicted and sentenced to long prison terms.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: In 1986, the authorities in Florida had enough evidence to indict Mr. Jenks, charging him with smuggling 55,000 pounds of marijuana from 1978 to 1982. But there was no sign of him or Mrs. O'Bryant. Their former associates hinted that the two had fled to Europe. The trail went cold.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: Twelve years passed. In 1994 in Florida, the Marshals Service received an anonymous tip. Mr. O'Bryant, by now out of jail, had called Mr. Jenks from a pay phone in Brandon, Fla. Mr. Bunk, the deputy marshal in Tallahassee, traced the call to a telephone message center in Pahrump, Nev.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: Armed with a subpoena for the center's records, investigators traced the call to a subscriber whose bills were sent to a postal collection storefront in Fort Myers, Fla. They began a stakeout. On the second day, Sandra O'Bryant walked in.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: She led them to a nearby trailer park, Woodsmoke Campgrounds. On July 23, 1994, Mr. Jenks showed up and was arrested with false passports and other identification. He was 42.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: ''He made a comment he was glad, it was nice that it was over,'' Mr. Bunk said. He said he was tired of running, that every time he heard a footfall or the slam of a car door, he thought they had been caught.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: They had fled to Europe on an 80-foot motor sailboat called Tangier, Mr. Trent, the special agent from Tampa, said. Mr. Jenks had bought it for $450,000 and spent more than a million dollars to transform it into a luxury yacht with four staterooms and a top speed of 11 knots. ''It was the best I've ever seen,'' Mr. Sheehan, the Customs spokesman, said. ''It had everything -- bulletproof portholes -- and could motor from here to England and Australia on one fill-up of fuel.'' (Customs auctioned it in 1996 for $440,000.)
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: By Mr. Jenks's account, they had sailed first to Holland, and moved every six months or so between Switzerland, France, Spain and Portugal. They slipped back into Florida in 1993 when Mrs. O'Bryant's mother fell ill. They were living in Naples, Fla., but had learned that Mr. Bunk was on their trail and moved into a succession of trailer parks, the last one three days before their arrest.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: In April 1995, Mr. Jenks pleaded guilty to four counts of drug trafficking, conspiracy and tax evasion arising from the 1986 indictment, and was sentenced to three years in prison. Mrs. O'Bryant -- who had since become Mrs. Jenks -- was not charged.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: Now the part with the diamonds: As a condition of his plea, Mr. Jenks had to forfeit the gains from his drug dealing -- his yacht, $65,000 in cash from accounts in Switzerland and Liechtenstein, 36 acres of land in Florida, and 22 firearms and 10,000 rounds of ammunition.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: He also surrendered a rare-coin collection and the 33 colored diamonds. Among the stones was the blue diamond, a football-shaped stone of 3.04 carats, valued by Christie's at $120,000 to $160,000; a rectangular-cut deep purplish-pink diamond of 1.83 carats, valued at $60,000 to $80,000, and lesser stones in hues of purple, pink and yellow.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: There was other property in the possession of a Jenks associate that Customs agents tried but failed to recover, Mr. Trent said: a 44-foot yacht worth $150,000 and an Aztec Piper Cub airplane worth $50,000.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: When the Customs Service filed its forfeiture action against the property, the associate, who has not been charged in the case, came forward from Israel to claim the diamonds as his. But Mr. Jenks said he was holding the stones against money owed him.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: And now the end: The associate's claim was not legally pursued and the Government was awarded custody of the diamonds. Mr. Jenks spent two years in prison and got out last year. He has lost his hair and is in precarious health, battling hepatitis apparently incurred from impure water in Europe. He also has a multimillion-dollar tax lien against him.
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: ''I'd like to have had their life style,'' Mr. Trent said. ''Live on a million-dollar yacht in Lisbon.''
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: ''Yeah,'' Mr. Sheehan said, ''but with his Liechtenstein assets he wound up getting caught at the trailer park and now he's cutting grass in central Florida. Sooner or later everybody's day comes.''
title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests

text: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE
title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels

text: For years, government agents have used dogs to detect drugs in ships, planes and cargo at points of entry like airports and seaports. Now, drug-sniffing dogs are working at points of entry between New Jersey and New York City.
title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels

text: Five German shepherds, with olfactory senses that would give nightmares to the Cali cartel, were put on the beat of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey a week ago. Their patchwork jurisdiction includes three airports, major seaports, four bridges and two Hudson River tunnels.
title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels

text: With only five dogs to cover so much traffic and territory, officials don't expect them to nab more than a fraction of the drugs entering Manhattan. ''We think their mere presence will deter people,'' said Lieut. William Oorbeek, commander of the Port Authority's canine program. Authority officers use the dogs when making routine inspections of vehicles coming into the city, stopping those with missing plates or other violations, or when operating drunk-driving checkpoints during holidays.
title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels

text: ''The bridge and tunnel tollbooths are perfect because everyone has to slow down, giving us a chance to look them over,'' said Lieutenant Oorbeek, adding that people cannot be stopped randomly just because they seem suspicious. ''We can't use profiles,'' he said. ''It's against the law. We have to have a reason for stopping them.''
title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels

text: But once stopped, drivers had better not be concealing drugs, because Max, a 2-year-old German shepherd, will surely find them. On Thursday morning, Max patrolled the New Jersey side of the Holland Tunnel, rush hour traffic streaming by. ''Most traffickers operate at peak hours, when they're less conspicuous,'' said Lieutenant Oorbeek.
title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels

text: As he spoke, Max and his handler, Officer Tom Johnson, circled cars and trucks pulled over by the officers. Imported from Belgium for $2,400 and trained for $35,000, Max has already made two busts. He found marijuana at a Queens warehouse, ''shrink-wrapped with fabric softener, buried in axle grease, packed into Tupperware, sealed in plastic and taped in a box,'' said Lieutenant Oorbeek.
title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels

text: But some people, like Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, are concerned. ''We'll take a hard look at this program and monitor it closely,'' he said. ''The pretext is to stop people, but the real objective is to get around the Fourth Amendment.'' Still, Mr. Siegal conceded, the program is ''probably'' constitutional. DAVID KIRBY
title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: Building Linked to Drugs Seized by U.S. Marshals

text: A team of Federal marshals seized control of a 26-unit rooming house yesterday, saying that the building had served as a drug supermarket for the last three years.
title: Building Linked to Drugs Seized by U.S. Marshals

text: During the early-morning raid, Federal agents arrested the building's landlord, David A. Ginsberg, and charged him with taking money from drug dealers in exchange for allowing them to sell crack cocaine, heroin and marijuana from the building, prosecutors said.
title: Building Linked to Drugs Seized by U.S. Marshals

text: Mr. Ginsberg, 43, of Toms River, was charged in a Federal indictment with ''directly facilitating'' a trade in illegal drugs that took place in the rooming house, called Edgewood Manor, and on its grounds, which are within 30 feet of a school zone, said Stuart Rabner, an executive assistant United States attorney.
title: Building Linked to Drugs Seized by U.S. Marshals

text: According to a criminal complaint filed with the indictment, Mr. Ginsberg charged the dealers as much as $300 a week to conduct business from the rooming house. From 1995 to late last week, the complaint said, the police in Lakewood responded to more than 2,100 complaints that took them to Mr. Ginsberg's property.
title: Building Linked to Drugs Seized by U.S. Marshals

text: A witness in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial who had testified that he thought Ms. Brawley fabricated her story endured a withering cross-examination today after jurors were shown a televised interview in which he characterized the Rev. Al Sharpton with an expletive.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: Mr. Sharpton's lawyer, Michael A. Hardy, threw the expletive back at the witness, Officer Tommy Young of the Poughkeepsie Police Department, over and over again as he sought to discredit him.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: Mr. Hardy also asked Officer Young about his accidental shooting of a suspect in 1992, and Officer Young admitted that a drug test after the incident revealed traces of marijuana in his urine.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: Although an investigation into the shooting determined that the marijuana was not a factor, Officer Young was suspended without pay for 74 days.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: The tense exchange was prompted not only by Officer Young's negative appraisal of Mr. Sharpton, but also by his stated belief that Ms. Brawley, a black woman, had perpetrated a hoax with her story of being raped by a gang of white men in November 1987, when she was 15. Officer Young, who is black, conducted a brief, vague interview with Ms. Brawley at the time.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: Mr. Sharpton, C. Vernon Mason and Alton H. Maddox Jr. are being sued by Steven A. Pagones, a former Dutchess County prosecutor, for publicly saying that he was involved in an attack on Ms. Brawley. In October 1988, a special grand jury cited voluminous evidence discounting Ms. Brawley's allegation, and the panel specifically exonerated Mr. Pagones.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: Late Tuesday, during his third day on the witness stand, Officer Young had testified that after his interview with Ms. Brawley, he doubted her story. Officer Young talked to Ms. Brawley as she lay in a hospital bed.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: As defense lawyers attacked Officer Young's credibility today, emotions ran high. Mr. Hardy and Mr. Pagones's lawyer, William E. Stanton, traded barbed remarks as they argued over which portions of a 1988 television report including Officer Young's comments to show to jurors.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: In the television report, Officer Young addressed allegations by Mr. Sharpton, Mr. Mason and Mr. Maddox that law enforcement officials were covering up what happened to Ms. Brawley.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: ''There's no cover-up,'' Officer Young said in the report. ''That's in Sharpton's mind.'' Officer Young then used the expletive, which referred to a part of the anatomy.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: Mocking Officer Young's crude language, Mr. Hardy reiterated the expletive about a dozen times.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: Officer Young also conceded that he had no evidence that Mr. Sharpton, an adviser to Ms. Brawley and spokesman for her family, had participated in the fabrication of a hoax with Ms. Brawley.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: Officer Young finished testifying at the end of the day, paving the way for Mr. Pagones to take the witness stand on Thursday, barring unexpected delays.
title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked

text: By David Stevens, International Herald Tribune
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: The recent orchestral scene has been extraordinarily dense in musical substance, with no less than three Mahler symphonies, a lavishly cast concert performance of Strauss' "Elektra," and the first French hearing of a major new work.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: Two of the Mahler works, Nos. 3 and 6, were brought by the Boston Symphony and Seiji Ozawa on their European tour, with a substantial bonus in the form of "The Shadows of Time," commissioned by the orchestra from Henri Dutilleux, the dean of French composers.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: The Strauss opera and Mahler's Second Symphony were on the agenda for Semyon Bychkov's final Paris concerts with the Orchestre de Paris, after nine seasons as the music director, a period that has seen a generational change in the orchestra's personnel.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: The Dutilleux work, first performed last fall in Boston and New York, makes virtuoso use of the orchestra's different choirs in its five linked movements, beginning with a fanfare-like outburst in the brass and winding down at the end to a clockwork movement that recalls the beginning.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: The central movement of the 25-minute work, subtitled "Memory of Shadows," and the interlude that follows it fleetingly use three children's voices, the episode being dedicated to Anne Frank and "all the world's children, in all their innocence."
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: Mahler's gigantic symphonies do not share space easily, which may be why the huge apparatus of the Sixth Symphony, coming after the Dutilleux, remained earthbound. Far more successful was the Third, which was alone on the program of the second concert at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees. Florence Quivar was the superb mezzo soprano soloist, the Radio France choral forces did their duties well, and Ozawa stretched the passion of the final Adagio as far as it would go.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: Bychkov and a starry cast, headed by Hildegard Behrens in the title role, shook the Salle Pleyel to its foundations with Strauss' one-act horror story. The absence of stage representation was hardly missed as soprano and conductor built the musical-dramatic structure carefully to its climax.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: Reinhild Runkel was a juicily malevolent Klytemnestra, Elizabeth Meyer-Topsoe a radiant Chysothemis, Franz Grundheber the solid Orest, and Klaus Koenig the ill-fated Aegisth. The standing ovation that followed the performance was the real thing.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: The temperature was lower but the musicianship was on a high level for Mahler's "Resurrection" symphony, with Lynne Dawson and Marjana Lipovsek the excellent vocal soloists and Arthur Oldham's Orchestre de Paris chorus its customary solid presence.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: Bychkov will take the orchestra on tour in May to Vienna, Prague, Dresden and Bregenz, after which he moves on to posts with the Cologne Radio Orchestra and the Dresden State Opera.
title: Conductor Bids Farewell With Mahler and Strauss : An Orchestral Explosion in Paris

text: CAN March be almost over? Didn't they play the Super Bowl just last week? It sometimes seems that with each passing year, the days and weeks zip by more quickly.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: If you have ever had this feeling, you are not imagining it. Studies of human time perception show that age-related changes in the nervous system alter one's sense of time; it really does seem to move more quickly with age. At a meeting of the Society for Neuroscience in New Orleans in November, a psychologist, Dr. Peter A. Mangan, reported on a study in which he asked people in different age groups to estimate when three minutes had passed by silently counting one-one-thousand, two-one-thousand, three-one-thousand and so on. People in their early 20's were accurate within three seconds, and some got it exactly right. People in their 60's estimated that three minutes were up after 3 minutes and 40 seconds had passed. Middle-aged subjects fell in between but, like the older people, all underestimated the passage of time.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: This phenomenon has led some researchers to suspect that the brain contains a special clock that tracks time intervals in the range of seconds to minutes. A Duke University neuroscientist, Dr. Warren Meck, and a graduate student, Matthew Matell, have now proposed a model of this clock based on studies of human brain anatomy.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: According to their theory, a cluster of neurons in the midbrain collects time signals from all over the brain and coordinates those that occur at the same time and involve singular events or perceptions. The neurons also establish the start and finish of various time intervals that the brain is interested in measuring, such as how long it should take before a red traffic light turns green. Moreover, a brain chemical called dopamine regulates this clock. Add dopamine and the clock runs faster; take it away, and the clock slows down.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: Defects in this clock could help explain human ailments like dyslexia, hyperactivity, Parkinson's disease and schizophrenia. It could explain why, in an automobile accident, three seconds can feel like three minutes, why old people in nursing homes are often confused about time, and even how some drugs like cocaine and amphetamine give the sense of ''speed'' while others, including marijuana, subjectively slow down the passage of time.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: An American psychologist, Dr. Hudson Hoagland, first suspected the existence of an interval clock in the 1930's, when his wife ran a high fever. Mrs. Hoagland complained that her husband had been out of the room for a very long time when he had actually been gone for only a few moments. Curious, Dr. Hoagland asked his wife to estimate when a minute had passed. After 37 seconds, she said the time was up. And as her temperature rose, she counted faster.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: In further experiments, Dr. Hoagland found that he could retard an individual's sense of time by 20 percent by applying heat to the person's brain. Other researchers later found that lowering a person's body temperature by two or three degrees could speed up the subjective sense of time.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: The idea that there is a clock measuring intervals in the range of second to minutes (in addition to the circuits that measure tenths and hundredths of seconds and the circadian clock that tracks the length of the day) makes a lot of sense. The ability to estimate short durations of time is critical for learning and survival, said Dr. John Gibbon of the New York State Psychiatric Institute and Columbia University.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: People unconsciously monitor the timing of external events and respond to them. For example, Dr. Meck said, ''suppose you are sitting at a red light, waiting for it to turn green,'' adding: ''At a certain point, based on past experience, you will begin to put your foot on the gas in anticipation that the light is about to turn. Unconsciously, you are counting the seconds, without looking at your watch. But if the light fails to turn green in the expected amount of time, you start fretting, wondering if it is working properly. If enough time passes, you may decide to run the red light.''
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: People use interval clocks when engaged in music or sports. Basketball players, Dr. Meck points out, keep track of time in their brains, knowing that they will be penalized under certain circumstances if they hold the ball for longer than several seconds without dribbling or passing. Musicians simultaneously measure not just the beat but the phrase, the crescendos and innuendoes. When jazz players shade the time in violation of strict beats, it makes the music interesting, Dr. Gibbon said.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: In the case of the basketball player, different parts of the brain are working on different tasks. Cells in the visual system are looking for places to run or pass the ball. Cells in the motor system are controlling movements. Cells in the auditory system are listening for information from teammates on what to do next. Each of these specialized cell circuits carrying out different jobs tend to oscillate or fire at different rates. Some might be firing 5 times a second, others up to 40 times a second. It is as if they are operating independently on different time scales, yet the basketball player's brain must integrate them so that he or she can decide what to do with the ball.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: For this task of coordination, Dr. Meck and his assistant have nominated a structure in the midbrain called the striatum, which is loaded with spiny neurons, so called because their projections are thick with spines. Such neurons are well connected in that each one -- and there are thousands of them -- is linked to tens of thousands of other cells via dendrites coming from other parts of the brain. The dendrites are the slender spines that help brain cells communicate. They detect oscillations or cell firing rates that occur all over the brain, Dr. Meck said, ''and the question has been what the heck do they do with them?''
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: ''We think spiny neurons integrate these signals,'' Dr. Meck said, and, based on previous experience of what is important, select those that are beating at the same frequency and synchronize them. This collective timing signal is sent to higher cortical areas where, in a grand loop from the brain's basal ganglia to its frontal lobes, perceptions and actions are coordinated and acted upon. When a person is performing several tasks at once and needs to measure time, spiny neurons parcel out the tasks, Dr. Meck said.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: The key to how this clock works -- or fails to work -- is dopamine. When the brain notices something new or rewarding, dopamine made in a nearby region called the substantia nigra is released into the spiny neurons, which become excited and begin to integrate time signals. In this way, the brain learns to anticipate events seconds or minutes into the future.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: Animal and human experiments support the existence of the short-interval circuit, Dr. Meck said. For example, rats trained to press a lever at regular intervals to get food lose the ability when their dopamine-producing cells are removed. When the rats are given a synthetic form of dopamine, the ability is restored. In brain imaging experiments by Dr. Sean Hinton at Duke, people were asked to estimate when 11 seconds were up and to squeeze a ball just before and after this interval. The loop from the midbrain, where the source of dopamine and spiny neurons reside, to the higher cortex was activated each time they estimated 11 seconds had gone by.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: The interval clock has drawn the interest of medical researchers. Dr. Guinevere Eden of Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington said that dyslexia was basically a timing problem throughout the brain and that for dyslexics difficulty in learning to read was just one manifestation of a more widespread defect. Some dyslexics have a problem with time, she said. They come late to appointments and have trouble keeping rapidly moving events in proper chronological order.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: A study in the Feb. 7 issue of the British medical journal The Lancet found that people with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder tend to have smaller than normal frontal lobes and basal ganglia, the loop that Dr. Meck and his colleagues think is the interval time keeper.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: People with Parkinson's disease lose cells that make dopamine and their interval clocks are thrown off, Dr. Meck said. They have tremors, difficulty in starting movements, rigid muscles and problems perceiving time accurately, all of which can be reversed with drugs that supply dopamine to the brain.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: Researchers agree that drugs affect the brain's sense of time. Cocaine and methamphetamine both increase the amount of dopamine and speed up the interval clock or its equivalent elsewhere in the brain. A similar chemical cascade may happen during an accident, when dopamine and other neurotransmitters flood the brain, Dr. Mangan said. Time seems to stand still or move incredibly slowly. Conversely, drugs that reduce the amount of dopamine in the brain, like Haloperidol and Clozapine, used to treat schizophrenia, and marijuana, slow the interval clock, Dr. Meck said.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: It is in growing older that most people will experience the vagaries of the interval clock. Studies show that dopamine levels gradually begin to fall when people are in their 20's and decline through old age, said Dr. Mangan, a psychologist at Clinch Valley College of the University of Virginia in Wise, Va. As shown by the experiments reported by Dr. Mangan in New Orleans, the older you get the more you are going to feel that time is passing by quickly. The good news is that spring will come sooner and sooner.
title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain

text: Fed up with an economic climate that they contend is too favorable for the players, the National Basketball Association owners voted overwhelmingly yesterday to void the final three years of the collective bargaining agreement with the players' union.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: The vote of 27-2 at the league's board of governors meeting in Dallas comes after three years of labor peace and officially paves the way for negotiations that may alter the off season and beyond.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: Acting as anticipated, the owners exercised a clause in the agreement with the union that allowed them to reopen the agreement if it was not working to their satisfaction. Neither Commissioner David Stern nor Billy Hunter, the players' association executive director, would discuss the possibility of the first work stoppage in league history.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: The current deal will expire on June 30. Both sides have from April 1 until then to work out a new pact. Several team officials have suggested that if one is not reached, the league would most likely lock out the players during the summer and prohibit teams from signing free agents or making trades.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: Amid stalled negotiations and a decertification attempt by the union in 1995, Stern imposed a lockout before both sides headed off a potential strike and agreed to the current six-year pact before that season.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: ''There are obvious remedies available to all sides in a labor situation when parties do not agree, but we'll leave it to others to speculate on a worst-case scenario,'' Stern said yesterday in a conference call. ''Our goal is to reach a fair deal.''
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: Hunter said in a statement: ''It is unfortunate the owners have chosen to forfeit three years of guaranteed labor peace at a time when the industry is so obviously healthy.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: ''Based on our preliminary review of the N.B.A.'s financial materials, we agree with Commissioner Stern's statement today that 'business is great' -- TV ratings are up, attendance continues to increase and the league will enjoy a 140 percent increase in network TV revenues beginning next season. Nonetheless, we are prepared to negotiate with the understanding that every facet of the collective bargaining agreement is open for discussion.''
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: The issues up for debate include the league's current drug agreement, which does not include testing for marijuana and many other substances, and the feasibility of the three-year salary scale for rookies, something many owners and players have criticized.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: The fallout from the vote will be minimal until June 30. But if an agreement is not reached during the N.B.A. playoffs in either May or early June, today's decision may have an impact on the number of players who declare themselves for the June 24 draft.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: With no idea of how the current rookie salary scale will be affected, some of the nation's top college underclassmen might decide to remain in school for another season and improve their stock.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: Given recent instances of small-market franchises paying huge sums to keep their star players, and franchises struggling to maneuver around salary-cap rules, the reopening of the agreement was expected. It was even prophesied by Russ Granik, the deputy commissioner, last September at the league's annual meetings in Orlando, Fla.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: In explaining the owners' decision yesterday, Granik cited figures -- some of which are disputed by the players' association -- to bolster his argument that the current system is broken.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: Using the $23 million a year that each team will average in network television revenue the next four years from a recently signed pact, Granik said, ''Now if you're Minnesota and you've given Kevin Garnett $21 million a year, then essentially you've given away all of your network television revenue. Obviously you have other sources of income. But on a long-term basis, that's not a healthy situation.''
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: Granik said that four teams received revenue assistance from the league last season, with one franchise receiving the maximum $2.9 million allowance, and that half of the league's 29 teams would not turn a profit for the 1997-98 season.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: The current agreement calls for at least 48.04 percent of basketball-related income to be distributed to the players. Once that figure reached more than 51.8 percent in favor of the players, the owners were permitted to reopen the agreement. According to the league, the figure now stands at 57.2 percent, or, Granik said, $160 million over what the figure was supposed to yield.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: ''The current economic situation is not a workable one,'' he said.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: Though negotiations cannot begin until April 1, the league said it planned to immediately distribute comprehensive financial information to players.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: The possibility of using a hard salary cap like the one the National Football League has and limiting what each team can pay a single player have been discussed, but it was unclear exactly how the owners would propose to alter the current system. The goal seems to be geared toward making sure the increase in player salaries does not exceed the increase in franchise revenues.
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: Stern said he did not envision player pay cuts but, on the contrary, wanted salaries to rise in accordance with the league's prosperity. He said the N.B.A. would enter the negotiations with the notion ''that this time we'd like to agree with you on a fair split.''
title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement

text: JERRY TARKANIAN, who needs about 60 minutes to build an ethically challenged college basketball program, was offering his standard defense yesterday, the thin-plated armor of political correctness.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: He didn't understand what the furor over his players' season of criminal and foul behavior was about, as all he had done at Fresno State or in any other state was win a few televised games and save a few troubled souls.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: He could think of three current Bulldogs, who, with the help of the ''strictest drug policy in the country,'' had ''turned their lives around.'' Tarkanian also noted that he was down to seven scholarship players for tonight's National Invitation Tournament semifinal against Minnesota at Madison Square Garden. But that's life in the Division I fast lane. Take a few social risks, expect a few police busts.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: ''John Thompson takes Iverson, and he's a great guy,'' Tarkanian complained. ''If I take Iverson, I'm a bad guy.''
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: Different standards, established by double dribblers like the news media and the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Back in his glory days at Nevada-Las Vegas, Tarkanian managed to come across as someone who didn't really intend for society's ills to intrude upon his program. They inevitably did because it just so happened that Duke and Princeton never offered him a job in the most pristine academic environs. He went where he was wanted. He found renegade players willing to join him in creating the instant, imperfect power.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: ''We recruit the same as everyone else, the best players we can find,'' Tarkanian said yesterday, at least calling ''the players'' as he truly sees them.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: There have never been any illusions with Tark the Shark, an unpretentious man with hooded, untrusting eyes. His players have never been ''student-athletes,'' as the N.C.A.A. bureaucrats would have us describe them. Is this flaunting his negligence, or is he just telling the raw truth regarding the mission given him by Fresno State, his own alma mater, three years ago?
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: ''Coach, really,'' the junior point guard Rafer Alston said when asked what took him from New York City to a basketball backwater like Fresno. ''When he got the job, I knew it would be a good situation.''
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: It was, until Alston was convicted of misdemeanor assault early this season after attacking a female friend and two Fresno neighbors. Tarkanian conceded that this was not a positive development, but added that the victim in last week's arrest of two more players -- the redshirt Georgetown transfer Kenny Brunner and the now-dismissed center Avondre Jones -- may have embellished his tale of being held at gun and samurai sword point before being robbed.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: Everything else that turned the Fresno roster into a halfway hoop house this season was categorized by Tarkanian as part of ''the marijuana thing.'' He meant the half-dozen suspensions for players who violated the school's Student Athletic Assistance program, which Tarkanian said ought to assure parents of future recruits that drug rules will be enforced -- even if the odds at Fresno indicate that their sons are also likely to violate them.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: Following an excoriating piece on the Fresno State program by ''60 Minutes'' on March 15 and the arrests of Brunner and Jones, John D. Welty, the university's president, said one more incident would result in his pulling the team from the N.I.T. Days later, a Fresno judge vowed to penalize Alston for failing to complete community service resulting from his conviction. Welty must have changed his mind when Tarkanian's team won a trip to New York and at least one more game on ESPN.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: That's too much exposure to pass up, the way Tarkanian is too famous a coach for a recruit to tune out. He has won it all and sent stars like Larry Johnson to the pros. Welty and the other Fresno administrators knew whom they were getting when they hired Tarkanian. So this mess, on their hands, is for them to clean up.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: ''It's been a tough year,'' Tarkanian admitted. ''There were games where we knew if anyone got in foul trouble, we were dead.''
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: In Tarkanian's world, drug suspensions apparently have the same effect as muscle pulls. They ruin your depth, debilitate your season. ''We have to do a better job of disciplining ourselves,'' Rafer Alston decided. ''I think we're going to do a better job next year.''
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: He made it sound like improved free throw shooting, as if all the Bulldogs must do to reach the real Final Four is lower their percentage of samurai assaults and failed drug tests. It could happen, as long as they and the other Fresno State dreamers don't think Tarkanian can run anything but a basketball practice.
title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader

text: The unregulated atmosphere of the World Wide Web may be a boon to the First Amendment, but the international medical community might argue that freedom has its limits.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: The on-line promotion and sale of medicines and dietary supplements have health and consumer groups scrambling for regulation. International drug sales have never been simple, and the Web further complicates the situation.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: A prescription drug in one country may be a nutritional supplement in another, for example. And while the United States permits drug advertising to consumers, most of Europe does not. Disclaimers and disclosure information vary from country to country, as does sales licensing.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Meanwhile, the Web has increased the potential for medical fraud.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: ''In the old days, it was the snake oil salesman at the county fair. Now there's a tool where he can hit all the county fairs all the time,'' said Richard Barnes, director of Federal-state relations at the Food and Drug Administration's Office of Regulatory Affairs.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Although difficult to quantify -- no agency or organization tracks on-line drug sales -- much of the trade is in experimental and unproven substances. For example, dozens of sites sell nootropics, also called ''smart drugs,'' like Piracetam, Vasopressin and Hydergine, which are substances said to improve cognitive abilities. Many of these are hormones and amino acids, and if they were made in the United States, the F.D.A. might classify them as dietary supplements -- meaning there could be no claim of curing diseases nor could they be administered as drugs -- and would require disclaimers to that effect. But that is not the case in other countries, where the classification and availability of drugs vary.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: For example, manufactured L-tryptophan, an amino acid, was taken off the market in the United States in the early 1990's after it was associated with eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, a potentially fatal blood cell disease. Yet it is easily available from the Web site of Quality Health Inc. of London, as are Retin-A, Deprenyl and Proscar, all prescription drugs in the United States.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: More than the sale of risky substances on the Web, however, health agencies fear the lack of protocol for administering them.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: ''The smaller firms send these things out without any counseling or control, so if you order this stuff by fax you cannot be sure if it meets quality requirements,'' said Dr. Martijn ten Ham, the head of drug safety for the World Health Organization. ''It may say a dosage is 200 milligrams, but how can you be sure? And you cannot be sure of drug-combination problems without a doctor or pharmacist.''
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: There have been no reported cases of death from a medical product bought over the Internet, although the F.D.A. says drug reaction cases are underreported. If a patient was already suffering from a fatal disease, for instance, that disease would be listed as the cause of death.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Many sites sell controlled substances, but out of self-interest, most are careful about where they ship their products.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Amazing Nature of Nijmehen, the Netherlands, deals in marijuana seeds and hallucinogenic mushrooms, both legal in the Netherlands if sold in small quantities.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Henk van Velthooven, the company's owner, said, ''We try to keep strictly to the rules, because I think if I sold illegal things to the United States, I would soon be out of business.''
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Those with rare or incurable illnesses may find a world of new or experimental drugs on the Web. Yet if they are not approved in the United States, the world's most profitable market, there is usually a good reason, said Abbey Meyers, president of the National Organization for Rare Disorders.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: ''You may find a great epilepsy drug in Europe, but it's so toxic that its makers know the F.D.A. would never approve it,'' Ms. Meyers said.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Rumors of miracle cures spread more quickly on the Web, Ms. Meyers said, adding: ''There was lots of rumor on the Internet about vitamins that could help with Lou Gehrig's disease, so people were taking huge doses. Well, you can overdose on vitamins.''
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Still, the organization uses the Web, maintaining an on-line data base about rare diseases that receives a million visits a year.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: ''People are desperate for medical information,'' Ms. Meyers said.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: ''They don't want to take the doctor's word for it and go home and say, 'I've put my life in someone else's hands.' ''
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: The volume of commercially sponsored information on the Web, though, can make it difficult to find facts, said Lisa Hayes, a spokeswoman for Health Action International, a nonprofit consumer rights group based in Amsterdam.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: While consumers ''think they're getting objective information, what they're actually getting is promotion,'' she said.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: ''There might not be information on other treatments,'' she said, ''or that person might not even need a drug solution. Sometimes you can't even see who is sponsoring the Web site.''
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: United States pharmaceutical sites that promote drugs use technicalities to meet international laws, disclaimers such as, ''This site is intended for U.S. residents only'' -- a Web oxymoron -- or separate links for United States and non-United States residents.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: The F.D.A. steps in when it can if it discovers sales infractions. Last June it forced a company called Contraceptive Technologies Inc., in Bogota, Colombia, to stop selling do-it-yourself abortion and sterilization kits on line on the grounds that the products were dangerous when used without a physician's direction.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: The company's Internet service provider, Rapidsite Inc. of Boca Raton, Fla., voluntarily removed the ads after the F.D.A. notified it of its concerns. Rapidsite said that Contraceptive Technologies violated United States laws and, therefore, its contract with Rapidsite.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: According to Dwight Rawls, a special agent and operations manager of the F.D.A.'s Office of Criminal Investigations, if an offending site's service provider is outside the United States, the F.D.A. will notify the country of origin or try to stop incoming shipments of the drugs.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: The F.D.A. has also blocked on-line sales of two unapproved drugs: gamma hydroxybutyric acid, a drug producing the same effects as a steroid, and laetrile, a cancer treatment.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: Border controls can also be effective. United States residents may import up to a three-month supply of drugs for personal use unless they are illegal, known to be dangerous or are foreign versions of a drug produced in the United States.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: According to Brad Stone, an F.D.A. spokesman, the agency recently detained about 800 packages of unapproved substances, all from one overseas company, over five months. The problem is ''substantial,'' Mr. Stone said, although the F.D.A. does not have exact statistics.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: For its part, the World Health Organization is urging countries and organizations to increase monitoring, self-regulation and consumer education and is planning to develop full-scale guidelines for Internet drug sales and promotions.
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: ''We are not a police agency,'' Dr. ten Ham said. ''But we're afraid that if this goes on and proves to be a lucrative activity, then that will undermine all kinds of drug policies that are currently in place.''
title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web

text: By John H. Cushman Jr.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: A coalition of agricultural, commercial and environmental groups is pushing the Clinton Administration to overturn the prohibition on cultivation of all Cannabis strains so those that lack the intoxicating properties of marijuana can again be grown.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: Hemp has developed a reputation for being an earth-friendly crop with extensive uses in fiber products that draws high praise from some manufacturers. But officials at the White House drug office quickly dismissed that notion, branding it a subterfuge for legalization and they noted that the idea of allowing hemp farms had already been studied and rejected.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: ''Many of the people who are interested in hemp are interested solely as a means of legitimizing the production of marijuana for use,'' said David Des Roches, an official at the Office of National Drug Control Policy.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: Under the coalition's proposal, licensed farmers would be permitted to grow the crop and would have to use seeds genetically selected and Federally certified not to produce significant amounts of the mind-altering compound that turned the species from a commonplace cash crop years ago into a banned one.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: They said they would petition the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Department of Agriculture on Monday to write new regulations recognizing the difference between strains of the plant. But Federal officials said that was unlikely to happen unless Congress first changed the drug laws.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: The groups in the coalition are taking pains to distance themselves from those who would legalize marijuana for medical or recreational use, saying their goal is to revive industrial-grade hemp as a major domestic crop. To that end they have chosen a carpet manufacturing official, a Republican legislator from Hawaii, and a senior biologist from Indiana University to speak for their cause.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: The coalition includes representatives of the North American Industrial Hemp Council, which represents potential producers and consumers, and the Resource Conservation Alliance, an environmental group that favors alternatives to forest products.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: ''The fiber is better than any other natural product for our commercial markets, even to include wool,'' said Ray Berard, senior vice president of technology at Interface Inc., a $1.2 billion carpet manufacturer. ''I would like to be able to buy the material here in this country.''
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: The hemp advocates said the system they are proposing would accommodate law-enforcement concerns while allowing farmers to grow a crop that is harvested in dozens of countries, recently including Canada, Germany and Britain.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: Although marijuana and hemp are synonyms for the same plant species, the industrially useful strains have almost none of the psychoactive ingredient THC, or delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: The hemp plant, once widely cultivated in the United States, can be used for an array of commercial materials, like textiles, balms, paper, lumber, paints and oils.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: Typically grown without harmful chemicals, the plant is said to be environmentally benign, and its products, like industrial carpeting, are easily recycled and used in composts. Environmental advocates often see it as an alternative to conventional materials like wood pulp or cotton, or perhaps as a source of renewable energy.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: In recent years, a lively market for products made from hemp has emerged, from and natural-tone knitwear to ''Extra Strength Hemp Zap Vegan Analgesic Balm.''
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: But law-enforcement officials said that hemp's true cachet comes not from its earth-friendly image but from the perception that hemp products are hip, especially when they carry the readily recognized logo of the Cannabis leaf.
title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms

text: The Mayors of four California cities have written to President Clinton, urging him to halt a Federal lawsuit that threatens to close clubs that distribute marijuana for medical use.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: The letters follow an announcement this week by the San Francisco District Attorney that if the clubs close, city officials might distribute marijuana to patients who say they need it.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco wrote to Mr. Clinton: ''At stake is the well-being of 11,000 California residents who depend on the dispensaries to help them battle the debilitating effects of AIDS, cancer and other serious illnesses. If the centers are shut down, many of these individuals will be compelled to search back alleys and street corners for their medicine.''
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: The letters were sent to forestall a Federal court hearing here next week in a Government suit against six marijuana buyers' clubs in northern California.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: Mr. Brown called on the President to drop the suit and impose a moratorium on enforcing drug laws that ''interfere with the daily operation of the dispensaries.''
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: Mayors Elihu Harris of Oakland, Steve Martin of West Hollywood and Celia Scott of Santa Cruz sent the President similar messages.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: A White House spokesman, Barry Toiv, said the suit would move ahead as planned.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: ''The civil suits by the Justice Department were a measured step designed to make sure that everybody understands that distribution of marijuana is still a violation of Federal law,'' Mr. Toiv said.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: Federal authorities have locked horns with state and local officials over marijuana since 1996, when California voters approved Proposition 215, an initiative to legalize cultivation and distribution of the drug for seriously ill patients.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: In January, the Justice Department sued six clubs, in San Francisco, Oakland, Santa Cruz and Ukiah, contending that they had violated the Federal Controlled Substances Act. The six cases were combined into one suit, scheduled for a hearing on Tuesday.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: ''Until marijuana's medical value is proven and a mechanism is developed for its safe production and distribution, marijuana cannot be legally sold or distributed in California or anywhere else in the United States,'' said a spokesman for the Justice Department, Gregory J. King.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: Eighty percent of San Francisco voters supported Proposition 215.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: The city could soon become the first in the nation to provide marijuana to residents. This week, District Attorney Terence Hallinan said that if the suit to close the clubs succeeded, the city would continue to provide medical marijuana to patients who needed it, even if city officials had to distribute it themselves. Mr. Hallinan argued in court papers filed on Monday in Federal District Court that without the clubs, ''unregulated, and unregulatable'' street-corner drug dealing would only increase.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: A spokeswoman for Mr. Brown, Kandace Bender, said the Mayor supported Mr. Hallinan's plan, although the measure would have to be approved by the Board of Supervisors.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: ''If it were distributed through the Health Department,'' Ms. Bender said, ''that would be a way to monitor and control the distribution.''
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: State Attorney General Dan Lungren, while campaigning in the race for governor this week, said he would prosecute any city official who participated in such a distribution plan.
title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit

text: THERE are two commonly held beliefs about today's New York. No. 1: Things are good. No. 2: Everyone agrees about No. 1.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: The prevailing wisdom holds that the city is basking in a glorious period of renewal, evidenced and enhanced by a robust economy, a revitalized cultural scene and surging self-confidence.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: After all, the argument goes, Wall Street is up, crime is down and the sidewalks are cleaner than they've been in years. High-tech, media and financial businesses are growing, and theaters, bars and restaurants are packed. The Knicks are scrappy and even the Mets are showing promise.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: The optimism seems to be catching. A recent New York Times poll found that Americans see New York as a place more likely to be revisited than reviled. More than 60 percent described Gotham's image as good, compared with 43 percent two years ago.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: But in a city well stocked with skeptics, cynics and grumblers, some see this upbeat news as largely a creation of high-powered civic boosters -- financial, real estate, media and government elites -- who have a major stake in how the city is perceived. And, the critics say, the city's refurbished image has little to do with the lives of most New Yorkers.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: ''The question of whether the city has really improved depends on whom you ask,'' said Stuart Ewen, chairman of the film and media studies department at Hunter College and an expert on public relations. ''For many middle-class people, it's a pleasing time, and of course it's good to have a city where people can walk the streets safely. But for many other people, it's become a very hard place.''
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Indeed, for every cheery headline and giddy proclamation about the new New York, you can find equally dour assessments of the city's fundamental well-being. Welfare rolls may be down, but the number of food pantries is up. AIDS deaths have declined, but the incidence of heart disease is still, per capita, among the highest in the country. Wages may be up, but so are rents.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Even some optimistic economists say the good times, such as they are, may not last. ''The booming market is pulling the city's economy along by the nose,'' said Mark Zandi, chief economist of the Regional Financial Association, an economic consulting and research firm. ''If that were to falter, it would be a significant problem.''
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Mr. Zandi observed that the city's economy is more diverse than it was a decade ago, and less dependent on Wall Street. But he also pointed out that Manhattan was enjoying the majority of the new opportunities, the bulk of which benefit highly skilled workers. ''Manhattan is in the vortex of the boom,'' he said. ''It's blossoming well ahead of the boroughs.''
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: And even for those feeling the flush of success, there can be downsides.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: ''Everyone's so busy getting rich, they've forgotten how to have relationships, how to be good parents and how to live,'' said Dr. Herbert J. Freudenberger, a psychoanalyst on the Upper East Side who coined the term ''burnout'' in the 1970's. ''I'm seeing more discontentedness than ever before. The pressure to make money, to succeed and to keep up an expensive life style has become so intense, so all-consuming, that work has become the be-all, end-all.''
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: As stressed out as New Yorkers may be, the rest of America seems to think they're nicer than ever. The Times poll found that 41 percent of Americans now viewed New Yorkers as ''friendly,'' compared to 27 percent two years ago. But despite the impression that New York has become a kinder, gentler town, reports of anti-gay and domestic violence are on the rise.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: ''We'd be the first to admit that New York is not perfect,'' said Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for the Mayor. ''It's a work in progress. Still, there's no denying that homicides are down 71 percent, that 360,000 fewer people are on welfare and that 209,000 new jobs have come into the city over the past four years.''
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: ''And besides,'' Ms. Roche added, ''this is New York City. People will always find something to complain about.''
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Even some of the most hardened naysayers concede that in at least some respects, life in the city has improved over the last several years. But conversations with some three dozen New Yorkers -- from artists to executives, radicals to conservatives -- revealed a number of concerns, including the persistent notion that the recovery has largely favored the rich while neglecting some longstanding problems of the poor.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Others have more philosophical gripes. ''I'm thrilled that the hedges in front of my house have stopped getting stolen, but I'm not crazy about the Disneyfication of our city and the moral police trying to eradicate anything that encourages impure thought,'' said the author Gay Talese. ''Trash and that which offends are what makes New York the great city it is.''
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: In a town with such wild diversity, of course, consensus would be difficult, if not impossible. Here's a sampling of nits, crits and opinions from some who see the Big Apple as half-ripe:
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Author of ''Low Life: Lures and Snares of Old New York'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1991)
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Whenever people get really excited about boom times, I begin to get worried and these days really have an edge of hysteria to them. It's one thing to be recovering from the Depression in 1936 and sing ''Happy days are here again,'' but today the mood of congratulation is so strenuous. I'm especially suspicious because this unprecedented prosperity that seems to have affected everybody doesn't seem have affected anyone I know personally. Nobody is actually going hungry or losing their homes, but that possibility is never beyond the pale.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Performance artist currently performing in ''Sex, Subversion and New York Values''
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: The idea of New York as a cultural capital comes from the street up. Culture in New York starts on the street and not Madison Avenue. What made New York unique is that it was a big city made up of small distinct neighborhoods. Giuliani is making his bid for the big time by delivering the broken spirit of New York homogenized and sanitized to the rest of country. And even from a marketing viewpoint, that's killing the goose that laid the golden eggs that were in demand all over the world.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: There is a palpable difference in the city right now, a lifting of the sense of menace and an exuberance walking in street and riding the subways. I don't know whether or not you can measure prosperity with statistics. I don't know what the unemployment rate was in Florence in 1460, but I know it was a hell of a city.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Now, on the other hand, there's all kind of problems that are associated with this boom. The middle-class people who used to flee to New Jersey as soon as kids got to be 6 or 7 are staying in lot of districts, and that puts a tremendous crunch on housing, which allows these rotten filthy slime landlords to take advantage and charge $4,000, $5,000 for a warehouse space. The reason that's bad for the future is we don't know who is not coming to New York -- that's the statistic that doesn't exist.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: We don't know if we're losing kids who want to be painters, or actors or writers but can't afford to live here. Kids used to feel able to come and double up in apartments, but certainly nobody's going to come from the boondocks anymore and live in SoHo and be an artist. You can't afford to park there, let alone live there.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: President of Citi Habitats, Manhattan's largest residential brokerage firm
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: I've never seen the market so tight. They say the vacancy rate is around 1 percent, but that's an illusion. The vacancy rate simply represents the amount of time it takes a landlord to clean out and paint an apartment. These days, some apartments last an hour on the market before they're snapped up. Professionals making $75,000 a year are being forced to live with roommates or to ask their parents for help paying the rent. In any other city, these same people would be living in spacious two-bedroom apartments.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: The tight market is also making people rent-poor, forcing them to alter their life styles, making them live in non-doorman buildings, limiting how often they go out and forcing them into the outer boroughs. I had one couple from California come looking for separate apartments. They were engaged but were not ready to live together. Of course they couldn't afford to live apart.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Business may be good for us, but I feel bad for my customers. There's a lot more frustration and a lot more crying in the office. It makes our job more difficult because they are often angry and bitter.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Comedian whose one-man show ''Black Humor'' is running at the Cherry Lane Theater
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Here we are paying a gazillion dollars in rent, and most of us don't even have a thermostat in our apartments. New York is the only place on earth where you can't control the heat in your home. We're stuck with all these heavy metal radiators that we can't turn off. All my windows are open, and it still feels like I've got malaria. If I lived on my ledge, maybe then I'd feel comfortable.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: They talk about crime being down in New York. Well, I live on West 43d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenue, which was once the unofficial worst block in the city. Now that Disney swept 42d Street clean, my block is the official worst block. Drugs, prostitutes, you name it. We've got people running around whispering, conducting all kinds of business, but they don't have briefcases.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: And one more thing. The city thinks it's giving us a bargain by selling 11 subway trips for the price of 10. What kind of marketing is that? Buy two, get one free. Or buy four, get one free. But buy 10 and get one free? That's pathetic.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Step Right Up And Into the Cattle Car
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: The good news is that people are coming back to mass transit in droves. The bad news, however, is also that people are coming back in droves. There's been a 30 percent increase in bus ridership since the free transfer. It's crowding the buses and slowing service.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Have you taken the M-23 lately? It's my mother's bus. Every time I mention free transfers to her, she goes into a towering rage. ''Now it's like some cattle car,'' she says. There's not enough service, it's true, because people like me, who would walk a few blocks, now get on the M-23 because it's free. And there's a ton of us. People are virtually hanging on the sides. My mother is a senior citizen, and even she says it's a slow boat.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: I mean, it's a good thing they're flooded with customers, it's a good thing people are leaving their taxis and family car and rental black cars, but there's definitely not enough buses to deal with rising number of riders and now longtime riders say they're facing unpleasant traveling conditions. There's no such thing as free lunch or a free transfer.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Executive director, Transportation Alternatives, a bicycle advocacy group
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: The thing that makes New York so attractive to people is the fact that it's the only walking city in the country. But instead of cultivating that, Mayor Giuliani seems to be promoting a car culture, putting pedestrians behind barricades, ticketing jaywalkers and encouraging people to drive to megastores. There are now seven million car trips into the city every day, and congestion is costing millions of dollars in delays and lost business, not to mention the cost to our air quality and quality of life. Thirty years ago, Mayor Lindsay recognized the problem of too many cars in the city and blocked off Madison and Fifth Avenues one day each weekend.
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: Commercial fisherman, Jamaica Bay, Queens
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: I got no major complaints about the water. But you ever get in a car and drive? That never changes. They say the roads have gotten better, but come on, before you couldn't drive anywhere, so what's the diff? I'm a waterman, but I got to go in the morning to get gas for the boats, and from what I seen they could be handling this a little better. Like when someone breaks down, how about clear them off the highway so the rubberneckers don't slow down? Other cities take cars off the road. What's the problem? It's just mismanagement. I see a lot of those D.O.T. guys sitting on their rears not doing anything. I fish all my life. What are they doing?
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

text: President of the Regional Plan Association
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?
