''Marian came to hear Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers in Los Angeles in 1989, back when I was with the band,'' recalls the pianist Benny Green, another longtime fan who is performing at her birthday concert. ''She took my phone number and asked if I'd do the show someday. Well, she called a couple of weeks later: someone had bowed out at the last minute, and was I available? Now I'd never done any kind of radio interview, let alone something as important as 'Piano Jazz,' and on the way to the studio I was suddenly hit by a ton of stage fright. But as soon as I entered the studio, she put me at ease, she made me feel like I was supposed to be there, put all the weightiness of the occasion out of the way, allowed us to have a good time together.''
title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That

text: Ms. McPartland's inclination to draw back and let others shine may make her the perfect host, but it has also stood in the way of her winning the recognition as a composer that she unquestionably deserves. Her songs have been recorded by the likes of Tony Bennett, Peggy Lee and Sarah Vaughan, yet when praised for the poise and subtlety of such graceful melodies as ''Ambiance'' and ''Twilight World,'' she deflects the compliment. ''I never had all that much faith in myself as a composer,'' she says. ''I've never pushed my tunes on lyricists, or on other musicians. And I never wanted to play only my own things, either, the way some people do, though I now play a few of them more often than I used to. They've been tested now, and so I don't feel chicken about doing them.''
title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That

text: It is hard not to wonder whether Ms. McPartland's modesty about her accomplishments arises in part from the fact that she is a woman who has made her way in what for a very long time was almost exclusively a man's world. This diffidence stands in surprising contrast to the bright clarity of her piano playing, which grows more harmonically adventurous with each passing year. ''I've become a bit more -- reckless, maybe,'' she says. ''I'm getting to the point where I can smash down a chord and not know what it's going to be, and make it work. And though I'll never swing like Mary Lou Williams, I'm better at it than I used to be.''
title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That

text: But here as elsewhere, it is not necessary to take Ms. McPartland's self-deprecating word for it: One can instead turn directly to the 13 CD's she has recorded since 1978 for Concord Jazz, which reveal her to be among the freshest and most creative pianists in jazz. Perhaps the finest of them is ''Silent Pool,'' released last year, on which she plays 12 of her own compositions, sensitively accompanied by the exquisite string arrangements of Alan Broadbent. It is the high point of a deeply satisfying oeuvre, the late harvest of a lifetime's musical wisdom.
title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That

text: A harvest of another sort can be found in ''All in Good Time,'' the much-admired 1987 collection of Ms. McPartland's essays about jazz and its makers, which will be reissued in an expanded edition as soon as she finishes the four new chapters urgently sought by her editor. ''I'm trying to write a piece about Jimmy now,'' she explains, ''which is awfully difficult.'' Small wonder, for her off-and-on relationship with Jimmy McPartland, which began in 1944 when they met on a U.S.O. tour of Belgium, was the stuff of which double-decker novels are made. The McPartlands were married the following year and divorced in the 60's, thereupon becoming the closest of friends; they finally remarried in 1991, just before his death.
title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That

text: The house where they spent their last hours together, on a quiet block in the Long Island town of Port Washington, is cluttered with record albums, musical manuscripts and photographs by the handful, most of which seem to have Jimmy in the background, even as he is omnipresent in her conversation. ''I really miss him terribly,'' she says, ''even more than I thought I would.''
title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That

text: Asked what she would like to do that she hasn't yet gotten around to doing, Ms. McPartland admits she has always wanted to appear as soloist with the Boston Pops Orchestra. You can't help but smile at the anticlimactic nature of her secret ambition, but looking back at her extraordinary career, it makes more sense. A rich and memorable body of recorded work, a radio show that has opened the ears of a generation of young musicians, a lifetime of quiet service as the No. 1 role model for women in jazz -- what else could Marian McPartland possibly want or need to do at 80? The answer is simple: she wants to keep on playing.
title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That

text: ''I feel that working is the best thing anybody can be doing,'' she says, ''especially when you're doing something you like, and you're able to give other people some work, and generally be helpful all around. I certainly wouldn't want just to sit in the back yard and dig bulbs.''
title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That

text: Two Czech nationals were indicted yesterday on charges of running an international prostitution ring that brought scores of women from Eastern Europe to work in sex shops on the edge of Times Square.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: Milan Lejhanec of Ridgewood, Queens, and another individual whose identity was withheld by Federal prosecutors because he was at large, were charged with eight counts, including alien smuggling, visa fraud, and transporting and inducing women into prostitution. If convicted on all charges, they could face up to 50 years in prison.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: William Gurin, an assistant United States attorney in the Eastern District in Brooklyn, said prosecutors expected the second suspect to be arrested by early next week.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: Mr. Gurin said the indictment was the result of a yearlong investigation that culminated Wednesday afternoon when Federal agents and the city police raided Mr. Lehjanec's residence in Queens and two adult entertainment establishments on Eighth Avenue, the Playpen and the Playground. The prosecutor said the investigation began after Czech authorities uncovered the ring and notified his office.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: The raids also resulted in the arrest of 16 women who worked for Mr. Lejhanec and his accomplice at the Playpen, the authorities said. Until Wednesday, the women danced naked in booths up to 12 hours a day, six days a week, for patrons who paid $1 a minute, Mr. Gurin said. For an additional fee, he said, they allowed customers to grope them. A police spokesman, Deputy Inspector Michael Collins, said that constituted prostitution under state law.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: The women paid Mr. Lejhanec and his accomplice up to $600 a week out of their earnings, Mr. Gurin said. He said that it did not appear the women were being held against their will and that Mr. Lejhanec bought plane tickets home for those who did not want to work at the shops. The police also arrested 14 men, many of Sri Lankan origin, who worked for the shops. Officials would not say whether the owners or managers were among them.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: Mark Thorn, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said the 30 women and men were being held by the I.N.S., but he declined to comment on whether they would be charged or deported. Mr. Lejhanec was being held separately.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: The two shops remained open last night. Prosecutors said they were investigating whether the ring was operating out of other locations in the city. A lawyer for Mr. Lejhanec, John Servider, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: Seven weapons were seized from Mr. Lejhanec's residence, Mr. Gurin said. Officer John Giammarino, a police spokesmen, said agents also seized $250,000 in cash, 27 bags of marijuana and several weapons from the sex shops.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: Mr. Gurin said the ring began operating around 1996. The women were recruited through advertisements in newspapers and magazines in the Czech Republic. Mr. Gurin said the ring paid their air fare to New York and housed them in dormitory-style residences in Maspeth, Queens. They were shuttled each day to the sex shops and back, he said.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: The women were given tourist visas, which preclude them from working, by a Czech national at the United States Embassy in Prague. The State Department said that the employee has since been dismissed.
title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.

text: By Roger Tredre, International Herald Tribune
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: LONDON—  To outsiders, it might seem like a conspiracy — two London fashion colleges intent on world domination infiltrate their students into the prime jobs in international fashion.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: But Saint Martins and the Royal College of Art have been doing pretty well for years. It is the renewed focus on British designers that has brought their influence to the world's attention. Three of this week's must-see runway shows in Paris were the work of former Saint Martins students — John Galliano at Christian Dior, Alexander McQueen at Givenchy and Stella McCartney at Chloe.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Fifteen of the designers showing on the runway in London last month studied at Saint Martins or the Royal College of Art, including virtually all the hot names — Clements Ribeiro, Deborah Milner, Hussein Chalayan, Antonio Berardi, and Sonja Nuttall.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Why are these British fashion schools so good? Students past and present cite the emphasis on individual creativity and originality married with technical know-how.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Foreign students are lining up to join the courses. "Everyone knows it is the place to go," said Anne Bernecker, 27, a Saint Martins student from Frankfurt who completed her bachelor's degree last year. "You can learn all the basics and the tailoring in Germany, but for the creative stuff you need to come here."
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Saint Martins or, to give its formal title, Central Saint Martins College of Art & Design, usually gets the biggest plaudits. Most of the stars of the modern British fashion scene have emerged from the scruffy college building on London's Charing Cross Road.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Saint Martins has its own postgraduate course, but some students opt to go to the Royal College of Art, which only takes postgrads. From Donna Karan to Prada, fashion houses worldwide turn to the RCA first when they have a vacancy to fill in their design studios.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: "Our students may not be conspicuous, but they are the backbone of studios throughout the world," said James Park, head of the fashion and textiles school.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: The Royal College of Art benefits from long historic links with the clothing and textiles industry, ranging from the International Wool Secretariat to companies such as Missoni. First-year students are expected to participate in projects directly working with industry.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: By contrast, the teaching methods at Saint Martins famously defy analysis, although course heads claim the students' work is more structured than in the past. "It's not as free-wheeling as people say. We're always pushing the students for more," said Louise Wilson, director of the master's degree program. "But self-motivation is the key."
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: This politely sidesteps the truth that many students go to Saint Martins to have a good time. Even John Galliano did his fair share. "The social life is part and parcel of being at Saint Martins," he admitted.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: THE school's location, a few minutes from the bars, clubs and drinking dens of Soho, is tailor-made for temptation. In the early '80s, when Katharine Hamnett and other names of the future were hanging out, no one did much work before midday.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Attendance at Saint Martins or the Royal College of Art is a neat way to make contacts. Some students do not stay around once they have made them. The flamboyant British designer Bruce Oldfield quit Saint Martins after just seven months. In the late '90s, the colleges are turning into fashion versions of Oxford and Cambridge.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: "Hearing about McQueen and Galliano does make people want to be the Next Big Thing," said Sarah-Blue Farrier, 22, one of the most highly rated students on the Saint Martins master's degree program. "Here, they make you believe you can be."
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Do the British appreciate what they have got? Saint Martins is better known abroad than it is in Britain, said foreign students. "When I was a teenager in the '80s, I used to read i-D and The Face, and I thought Saint Martins must be the place to be," said Mariana Botey, 27, from Mexico City.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Founded in 1854, Saint Martins started out as a place where nice young people went to do genteel classes in art or illustration. At the end of the 1940s, Muriel Pemberton, a painter-turned-fashion illustrator, created a comprehensive fashion course, mirrored across town at the Royal College of Art. By the early '70s, would-be fashion designers were scrambling for entry.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Last year, 700 applications were received for just 120 places on the Saint Martins' BA course. "We've had so much worldwide press," said Wendy Dagworthy, the course head. "It's had a big effect on us."
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Not all the press has been positive. Recent reports highlighted the pressures on the young students, particularly following a controversial decision to select only the best students for the press show during Graduate Fashion Week.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Dagworthy is in her last year at Saint Martins. This fall, she crosses town to the rival Royal College of Art, where she will be professor of fashion.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: Hundreds more students will be turned away again from both colleges this summer, but college heads are reluctant to expand at too great a pace. "It would be a mistake to spread the teaching resources and expertise too wide," said Jane Rapley, dean of the fashion school at Saint Martins.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: ROGER TREDRE is features writer for The Observer.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: We’re sorry, we seem to have lost this page, but we don’t want to lose you. Report the broken link here.
title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success

text: The police invaded Shaunsia Patterson's apartment about 4:30 P.M. on Friday, Feb. 27. Ms. Patterson, who is eight months pregnant, and her two children, a boy, 3, and a girl, 2, were napping in the bedroom at the rear of the small second-floor apartment on Hull Avenue in the Bronx.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: Also in the apartment was Ms. Patterson's 15-year-old sister, Misty Patterson, who had just come in from school.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: ''First we heard a boom,'' said Shaunsia Patterson. ''Then there was a louder boom and the whole door was coming down.''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: The cops seemed to come in waves, some in plainclothes, some in uniform. There were about a dozen in all. They came in with their guns drawn and they grabbed Misty first.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: ''They threw me face down on the floor and handcuffed me behind my back,'' she said. ''Then one of the cops stepped on the side of my face and pressed my face into the floor.''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: Crying and nearly overwhelmed with fear, she tried to ask the cops what was going on. The reply: ''Shut the [expletive] up!''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: ''I thought my life was going to end,'' Misty said.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: Shaunsia was sitting on the side of the bed by the time the cops reached her. One of the officers pushed her onto her back and dove on top of her.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: ''I'm screaming, 'I'm eight months pregnant. Please!' '' she said.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: The cop rolled her over and cuffed her hands behind her. She was wearing only panties and a top. She was so terrified she urinated.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: ''I couldn't help it,'' she sobbed as she recalled the scene during an interview. ''I was so scared. I kept saying, 'What is going on?' ''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: With both of the women handcuffed, the cops, screaming obscenities and other forms of verbal abuse, began searching the apartment for drugs.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: ''They were tearing up the house,'' Shaunsia said. ''They broke my furniture, broke the refrigerator, ripped up part of the floor, and I'm saying, 'There's nothing in this house.' ''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: The women were kept handcuffed for more than two hours. Shaunsia spent the entire time sitting or lying in her soiled underwear on her soaked bed. She asked to see a warrant but the request was ignored. She asked if she could put on dry clothing and was told no. She wept as she listened to her possessions being smashed in the next room.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: ''How can you do this?'' she asked.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: It turns out the raid was a mistake. And the mistake happened on the same day that another contingent of cops, also looking for drugs, mistakenly raided the Bronx apartment of an innocent man named Ellis Elliott. Mr. Elliott was dragged handcuffed and naked from his apartment and was later forced to wear his girlfriend's clothes. He was arrested and taken to jail before the mistake was discovered.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: Neither Shaunsia nor Misty Patterson was arrested. Some two hours after the police smashed down their door, an officer announced: ''We got the wrong apartment.''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: Shaunsia, still handcuffed, said: ''That's what we've been trying to tell you from the beginning.''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: It is not clear how the foul-up occurred. The cops who raided the apartment had a valid no-knock warrant. When no drugs were found in the Patterson apartment, a warrant was obtained for a third-floor apartment in an adjacent building. A Police Department spokesman said a raid on that apartment yielded several arrests and 83 pounds of marijuana.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: Police sources who would speak only if they were guaranteed confidentiality said they did not believe such mistakes occurred frequently. ''This is bad,'' said a high-ranking department official. ''Two in one day -- that's bad. But I'll tell you what I honestly believe -- I don't think this happens that often. When you tell this story, try not to smear the 38,000 people in the department.''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: Joseph Kelner, a lawyer who is representing the Pattersons and Mr. Elliott, said none of them had previously been in trouble with the law. He said, ''The close proximity in time of the two incidents seems to indicate a pattern of misconduct by a tiny minority of police officers who have a 'don't care' attitude about the rights of individuals.''
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: It is difficult to overstate the terror that is provoked by these inherently dangerous commando-like raids on the premises of innocent people. It is the sort of thing you would expect from a totalitarian state, not the municipal government of a city like New York.
title: In America; Reprise Of Terror

text: AS of early January, Mike Nick was an unknown, just a stocky 21-year-old who could do crazy tricks like aerial spins and flips on short, fat planks that resemble miniature snowboards. Then he won the first-ever skiboarding contest at the winter X Games in Crested Butte, Colo., and he was mobbed by reporters. A dozen ringed him slopeside, and the announcer for ESPN -- which produces the X Games and broadcasts the alternative-sports Olympics on its two cable television channels -- informed a million-plus viewers that Nick, a junior at the State University of New York at Plattsburgh, was now ''the sensation of rotation.''
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: You could almost hear the cash registers going ka-ching. Skiboarding, a sport that didn't even exist until 1995, had suddenly become legitimate. Frontside Films, in Santa Monica, Calif., has secured financing to produce ''Skiboarding: The Movie.'' A six-stop professional skiboarding tour has been organized for next year, and Nick's sponsor, Line Skiboards of Albany, N.Y., instantly doubled its production staff.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: ''I was psyched,'' said Jason Levinthal, the company's 25-year-old founder, who built one of the first proto-skiboards in his parents' garage. ''I knew from the get-go that I had to get in the X Games. If you don't get on there, you're nowhere.''
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: Indeed. While high-risk, attitude-laden extreme sports like skateboarding, bicycle stunt riding and street lugeing might have once been about having fun and busting free of the confining rules of traditional sports, they are now increasingly about money. Mini-industries sprout up around each nascent sport the moment it's born, and the manufacturers, tour promoters and impresarios of Web sites like www.snakeboarding.com all desperately need ESPN.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: The summer and winter X Games, begun in 1995 and 1997, are by far the world's best-known alternative-sports festivals. And because the people tuning in to ingest the games' smorgasbord of ice climbing to barefoot water-ski jumping are, quite often, young men willing to risk their own necks, ESPN holds the power to make a sport chic.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: Consider snowmobiling. When snowmobiling made its debut at this year's winter X, Men's Journal magazine announced that the sport had gone sophisticated. ''Forget the old stereotype of dirty-fingered, chain-smoking rural gearheads,'' the magazine rhapsodized. It seemed quite possible that top snowmobilers would soon be negotiating million-dollar endorsement contracts. It also says something about how far these sports have strayed, or progressed, depending on your viewpoint, that an athlete like Shaun White, the nation's foremost 11-year-old snowboarder, has his own publicist.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: The genre of extreme sports takes its cues from early 1980's California skate punk culture, which proved that you could still be a gnarly athlete even if you had green hair and a spiky dog-collar-style bracelet. If there is a progenitor of extreme, it is Jay Adams, an almost mythic Venice Beach skate god who had a shaved head and a tattoo that read ''Team Pain.'' Adams said in a magazine article that he smoked marijuana voraciously, reveled in fistfighting and hopped fences to ride empty swimming pools. But he rose to prominence at roughly the same time as MTV, and it was inevitable that the rebel spirit he exemplified would be co-opted.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: It happened finally in 1993, when Ron Semiao, the program director for ESPN's hipper offshoot, ESPN2, stepped into a stationery store looking for, as he described it, ''the Sports Illustrated of extreme sports.'' To his surprise, there was no such thing.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: But there were scores of specialty magazines catering to everyone from health-conscious rock climbers to corn-dog-eating skate rats. Semiao bought every one of the magazines, and then reflected that AT&T, Old Spice deodorant and Ricoh copiers were all using extreme sports images to advertise to twentysomething consumers. If he could unify the magazines' myriad subcultures ''from the top down,'' he thought he would strike gold. So he envisioned the X Games and began choosing sports carefully.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: SEMIAO, who is now besieged with calls from marketers of fledgling sports like all-terrain boarding (think skateboarding on dirt), said he favors sports that ''have a whole culture attached to them, a specific attitude and a group of people who live and die for that sport.'' He chose skiboarding, he said, because its 20,000 or so American practitioners are what might be called ''Iran-Iraq'' rivals of snowboarders. It didn't hurt, he added, that a major ski manufacturer, Salomon, had already insured that skiboarding was more than a fad by introducing its own board.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: But it was ESPN's treatment that made the sport sing to viewers. The network's coverage in January was wonderful eye candy, a spectacle replete with splashy graphics, lightning-quick interviews and even stage direction: ESPN's producers had Mike Nick make his first-ever attempt at a 1440, a quadruple aerial spin, on his last run. The announcer crowed, ''Expect the spectacular!'' Nick whirled and crashed.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: It was ESPN at its best. Even more than the Olympics, the X Games are ultimately about theatrics and bathos. And in the spirit of the best television dramas, they deliver poignant moments. The X moment, as it might be called, is soul stirring yet somehow subversive. At this winter's games, for instance, we watched Nick triumphantly high-fiving the public. In previous games, viewers saw slo-mo replays of sky surfers spinning (on snowboards) in a vast, beautiful sky and skateboarders thumping their boards axelike on a ramp as the fading skate legend Tony Hawk twisted through what the announcers deemed ''the greatest run of his life.''
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: IT'S all enough to make skeptics like Kevin Thatcher feel sick. Thatcher is the publisher of Thrasher, a San Francisco-based skateboard magazine founded in 1981, and a friend of Jay Adams (who has now retreated to Hawaii, where he repairs surfboards for a living). ''I was down on the ground, hurt, when I first saw Jay,'' Thatcher recalled nostalgically. ''And he just skated by me like I was an obstacle. I respect him for that.''
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: Thatcher was invited to oversee the skateboarding contests at the first X Games, but declined. ''TV flattens skateboarding into one big ad,'' he said. ''You can't truly capture it unless you take the TV cameras away, close off a street and just let the kids go at it.''
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: Thatcher might be right, but he's not about to stop Semiao. ''A lot of these insider magazines,'' Semiao said, ''feel a moral obligation to trash the X Games because ESPN is a large corporation. But when I see more kids buying skateboards, and more skaters doing ads for Pepsi and AT&T, I think, that's a good thing for the skateboard industry. There's nothing wrong with it.''
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: ESPN, said its spokesman Josh Krulewitz, ''will continue to promote the X Games brand vigorously.'' The games' soundtrack is now available on a CD featuring alternative rock titans like Helmet and Bush. In April, ESPN's roadshow, ''Xperience,'' will begin a 10-city tour offering spectators a look at performing in-line skaters, bicycle stunt people and skateboarders, as well as a chance to visit booths of X Games ''gold sponsors'' like Taco Bell and the Marine Corps.
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: About the same time, the cable channel will make its first foray into extreme fashion. J. C. Penney will begin marketing a line of X Games T-shirts and hats. ''They're aimed at a young audience, you know, 12 through 34,'' Krulewitz said. ''They'll have a hip design, and I think they'll sell very well.''
title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper

text: What ripe material for an observant satirist: from the downtrodden ranks of the townies in a small Midwestern college community emerges a reluctant hero who demonstrates the superiority of common sense and simple living over the corruption and hypocrisy of academia. In ''Deconstruction Acres,'' Tim W. Brown lays out this promising setup, then doesn't take it much of anywhere. Caught smoking marijuana in his dorm room, Thomas Emmendorfer, known as Underdog, is expelled from Jasper College; at loose ends, he rents a room in an off-campus boardinghouse and finds a job at the college print shop. He also finds romance with two fellow townies, Judy Baine, an earthy landscaper and the daughter of his landlady, and Ione Twayblade, the alluring but troubled (and troublesome) cashier at the college credit union. Underdog competes for the affections of the latter with William (Race) Fletcher, whose book on the sitcom ''Green Acres'' (''Deconstruction Acres: Imploding the Myth of Rural Simplicity'') has won him wealth, some fame and a prestigious academic appointment. Underdog's struggle to defeat his hipper-than-thou nemesis and expose a financial scandal involving the corrupt college president prompts many wry observations. Unfortunately, they are undermined by characters who never quite come alive and stilted dialogue that often rings false. This Underdog, unlike his high-flying cartoon namesake, never gets off the ground. Michael Porter
title: Books in Brief: Fiction

text: What Middle-Class Americans Really Think About: God, Country, Family, Racism, Welfare, Immigration,
title: Common Ground

text: the Left, and Each Other.
title: Common Ground

text: Those 20-year-olds who danced naked at Woodstock did not just leave the planet when they grew up. They traded marijuana for martinis, bought Volvos and business clothes and moved to the suburbs, where they dashed frantically between work, home and P.T.A. meetings, got divorced, split custody of the kids and remarried. Reformed pot smokers could easily have tolerated a second term with George Bush. But the Republicans blew it in 1992 with an ideological war that blamed the Woodstockers for the fall of civilization and labeled Murphy Brown an enemy of the middle-class Christian state -- for having a fictional baby out of wedlock, on a sitcom.
title: Common Ground

text: Thumbing their noses at the extremist right, Americans elected a rascally Democrat who had smoked pot, cheated on his wife, dodged the draft -- and found it impossible to give straight answers about any of it. The message from the voters was clear: Keep religious extremism out of politics or we will punish you. The Christian Coalition has since put on a sunnier face, but if Alan Wolfe is right, Americans have been permanently turned off by their brush with hard-edged religion cloaked as politics. Unless the icons of the right modulate their tone, Wolfe tells us in ''One Nation, After All,'' they will follow 60's-style liberals into oblivion and irrelevancy.
title: Common Ground

text: In interviews with 200 middle-class citizens, many of them solidly conservative, Wolfe finds that revulsion at politicized religion extends well beyond graying hippies and the American Civil Liberties Union -- right into the Bible Belt itself. Americans have apparently developed a complex moral and theological style that holds fast to traditional values while embracing religious diversity. The people in ''One Nation, After All'' were profoundly disturbed by what some described as loud preachers ''meddling'' in politics. They favor ''quiet faith'' and morality with a small ''m.''
title: Common Ground

text: This suggests that religion may be washed up as a political weapon, at least for the foreseeable future. It also indicates that the ''culture war'' theory of America was a fiction, cooked up by right-wing intellectuals who projected their own petty squabbles onto society as a whole -- and got the Republican Party to buy the idea. Closer to home, the evidence in this book reveals that the news media -- which habitually portray the country as bitterly divided over moral, racial and social issues -- are profoundly out of touch, and perhaps even incapable of grasping the full complexity of what and how Americans think.
title: Common Ground

text: Alan Wolfe teaches sociology at Boston University but is best known for essays -- disguised as book reviews -- on race, values and social issues, published in The New Republic and elsewhere. Wolfe is studiously nonideological and has perfected at least the appearance of having no ax to grind. But he, too, has obsessions. He values in-depth interviewing over quantitative sociology, seeing the latter as a bean-counting exercise that fails to capture nuance. He is preoccupied with public morality, arguing that the role of the intellectual enterprise is not to preach down to people but to discover and explain the moral rules that folks already use. He especially dislikes ideologues who purport to know what the public thinks about this or that without ever having talked to anyone.
title: Common Ground

text: ''One Nation, After All'' is undisciplined and occasionally Pollyanna-ish. But it is a very rich book. If, like me, you are a sucker for Walt Whitman and Aaron Copland -- and the belief that Americans are basically a good and just people -- some of this stuff will make you weep.
title: Common Ground

text: The book is based on interviews conducted for what Wolfe calls the Middle Class Morality Project. The research was financed in part by the centrist Russell Sage Foundation and designed to illuminate what people actually think about, well, everything. In the Northeast, Wolfe focused on communities where the household income was between $45,000 and $100,000. For other parts of the country, he recalibrated the income brackets, allowing for variations in costs of living and so on. In the Boston area, the project included Brookline and Medford. In suburban Atlanta, it settled on conservative parts of DeKalb and Cobb counties. Near Tulsa, Okla. -- the heart of the Bible Belt -- it took in the suburban communities of Broken Arrow and Sand Springs. From the heavily Republican San Diego area, he included East Lake and Rancho Bernardo. The sample was heavily loaded toward conservative, religious communities, Wolfe says, to insure that godless liberal intellectuals did not dominate the results.
title: Common Ground

text: The people Wolfe and his colleagues talked to were more sympathetic to the poor, to civil rights, to women's rights, to religious diversity and to a great many other things than most commentators have traditionally allowed. Anything but moral relativists, those interviewed had firm views of right and wrong. But they also believed that no one person's religious beliefs were morally binding on everyone. The snarly language so common in the Christian right was nowhere in evidence, and the respondents spoke with dismay of the efforts to bring punitive religion into politics. Typical was George Slade of Cobb County, Ga., Newt Gingrich country, who said: ''I have good morals. I'm not hurting anybody. . . . I'm not doing things that are wrong. I don't like the trend toward 'If you're not a Christian, or their definition of a Christian, then you're just not worth it.' '' Or, as Jake Sandford of Sand Springs said of the Christian right: ''Them's the meanest people. They talk mean.''
title: Common Ground

text: People like Sanford have a complicated view of how religion should function in the public sphere. They think the state should be neutral when choosing among creeds. But they do not accept that the state should be neutral when choosing between religion and nonreligion. Since the believers are in the majority, these people say, the believers should be able to practice their beliefs wherever they are. This sounds sinister, until you listen to John Pollan, a fireman from Sand Springs, who says that every religion should have a turn at school. ''You could have a Muslim prayer, a Hindu prayer and a Catholic prayer and a Baptist prayer. You know, you could have all four of those in the span of five minutes and then go on about the day's chores.''
title: Common Ground

text: Far from being intolerant, the people in this book are profoundly comfortable with diversity, religious and otherwise -- much more so than liberal types give them credit for. Wolfe is right on the mark when he writes that ''conservative Christians are often more willing to acknowledge the degree to which America has changed since the battles over fundamentalism earlier in this century than are those adherents to the American Civil Liberties Union who act as if religious intolerance, rather than nonjudgmentalism, is still the dominant tone of the country's religiosity.''
title: Common Ground

text: Homosexuality is a somewhat different story, but no less complex. Three times as many people condemned homosexual behavior as were willing to offer positive acceptance. Even so, the respondents distinguished between homosexual acts and the human beings who practice them. Nearly three-quarters of the respondents said that homosexuals should be tolerated and allowed to do as they wish in their personal lives. As one respondent in Cobb County put it, ''You can hate the sin but love the person.''
title: Common Ground

text: For the most part, Wolfe suggests, Americans practice a kind of ''capacious individualism,'' trying to be faithful to their own values while, to the largest possible extent, respectful and nonjudgmental of others' values. But he is so overwhelmed by the goodness of common folk that he sometimes fails to question what they tell him. This is clearly the case in discussions of race, where people rarely express their most honest negative feelings -- and often don't know what those feelings are, given that the most crucial ones are subconscious.
title: Common Ground

text: Excessive optimism aside, ''One Nation, After All'' is a fascinating and often stirring tour through an America that the news media and would-be culture warriors seem not to know. The American people are not embroiled in a culture war, Wolfe explains. Rather, they are seeking a middle way, molding traditional moral presumptions to fit difficult modern realities -- and doing a damn fine job, if you want to know the truth.
title: Common Ground

text: The advertised price was $30 for an eighth of an ounce of ''Five Star Mexican Gold,'' and dollar bills were exchanged at a brisk clip today for plastic bags of marijuana. But, in deference to a new court ruling barring the sale of the drug by clubs, a hastily erected sign over the marijuana bar read: ''Remuneration Station.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: ''We are not selling marijuana anymore,'' Dennis Peron, founder of the Cannabis Cultivators Club, said today, explaining his latest strategy to keep open what looks like America's closest copy of an Amsterdam hashish bar. ''We are selling fertilizer, nutrients, lighting, pruning, the labor for production.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Not so, retorts Dan Lungren, California's Attorney General and a Republican candidate for governor. The state's roughly 20 ''cannabis clubs'' will have to close, he said, based on a State Supreme Court decision on Wednesday. The court let stand a lower court ruling that clubs, because they are not ''primary caregivers,'' cannot sell or give away marijuana to ill people. And on Thursday, a San Francisco County Superior Court judge issued a preliminary injunction, based on those same grounds, prohibiting Mr. Peron from selling, furnishing or giving away marijuana.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: In 1996, California voters approved a measure to allow primary care givers to administer marijuana to the ill, under a doctor's supervision.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Ignoring this week's court ruling, Mr. Peron's five-story emporium served about 1,000 members today. In his office, barely screened from the thick clouds of marijuana smoke, Mr. Peron vowed to ''wait for the tanks.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Behind his desk was a hand-sewn silk banner, resplendent with green marijuana leaves, announcing his campaign to win the Republican nomination for governor.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: ''I'm going to have to be governor, so I can pardon myself,'' joked Mr. Peron, who won his spot on the ballot two weeks ago under the state's new open primary law. Mr. Peron gleefully noted that the primary battle pitted him against his nemesis, Mr. Lungren, who shut down Mr. Peron's Cannabis Buyers Club for five months in 1996. The club reopened after the state referendum.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: On hearing that Mr. Peron planned to run against him in the June 2 primary, Mr. Lungren responded, ''If Dennis Peron is running for governor on the Republican ticket, he has smoked more marijuana than even I thought.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: The animus between the two men reflects how little was solved by the referendum in November 1996, when 56 percent of voters approved the medical use of marijuana.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Today, about 10,000 ailing Californians are thought to buy marijuana for medical use. Marijuana is used by AIDS sufferers to restore their appetites, by cancer and chemotherapy patients to control nausea, by people with multiple sclerosis to control muscle spasms, and by people with glaucoma to reduce blinding pressures in their eyes.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: ''I have been using marijuana every day for the last six years,'' Hazel Rodgers, a 78-year-old grandmother who has glaucoma, said today between puffs on her pipe at the Cannabis Club. ''It keeps the pressure down in your eyes. I also use it for arthritis.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: On Monday and Tuesday, the medical effectiveness of marijuana was debated at hearings in Washington conducted by the National Academy of Sciences. And the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy has commissioned a $1 million study on the issue, which is to be ready by December.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: In November, voters in Alaska, Colorado, Oregon, Nevada, Washington, D.C., and Washington State are expected to vote on medical marijuana measures like the ones passed in California and in Arizona in 1996.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: ''We believe we are going to have strong victories in those states,'' said Robert Kampia, a director of the Marijuana Policy Project, a group that lobbies for medical access to marijuana. National polls, he said, show widespread support for allowing ailing people to use marijuana.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: But state and Federal officials have shown their determination to prevent Northern California from becoming the nation's pot pioneer.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Last month, six of the cannabis clubs operating in the Bay area were named in a lawsuit filed by the Federal Government that sought court orders to close them for violating Federal laws against growing, distributing and possessing marijuana. Since then, three of the clubs have closed. In legal papers filed today, lawyers for the clubs contend that the Federal Government has no jurisdiction because all the marijuana the clubs distribute is grown in California and interstate commerce laws do not apply.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: But Michael Yamaguchi, United States Attorney for Northern California, said in seeking the court orders: ''Under our system of Federalism, laws passed by Congress cannot be overridden or supplanted by state law. Federal law continues to prohibit the distribution of marijuana at the cannabis clubs.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: In a warning to other medical marijuana clubs in California, Gregory King, a Department of Justice spokesman, said today: ''Our enforcement efforts are continuing. Charges may be brought in the future.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: In California, the suits have highlighted the legal gray area of medical marijuana.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: In conservative areas like Orange and Ventura Counties in the southern part of the state, sheriffs and local officials have closed clubs, acting as though the 1996 referendum never took place. In more liberal areas, local health and police officials have worked with cannabis clubs, encouraging such controls as standard medical forms from doctors and photo identification cards for members.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Until the Federal civil suits were announced, officials in San Mateo County, a coastal area south of San Francisco, were drawing up plans to provide marijuana to certified ill people through public dispensaries. North of San Francisco, in Mendocino County, local officials debated whether to use a vacant lot behind the Fort Bragg police station to grow marijuana, which city police would then distribute to registered sick people. Plans have since been suspended.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Local officials in Northern California reacted negatively to news of the lawsuits. In Santa Cruz and Oakland, the city councils unanimously passed resolutions condemning the Federal action and defending local cannabis clubs. In San Francisco, where the police and city attorneys have long tolerated the medical use of marijuana, Mayor Willie Brown Jr. attacked the suits.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: On another front, doctors and a lawyer in the San Francisco City Attorney's office have brought a class-action suit to prevent Federal authorities from punishing doctors who recommend the medical use of marijuana for patients.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Down at the Cannabis Cultivators Club, which sells about 30 pounds of marijuana a month, Mr. Peron considers the clubs closing around San Francisco and admits, ''Everybody has just panicked.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: His assistant, Randi Webster, recalled what happened to her, and to the club's ill clients, when the club closed in 1996.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: ''Marijuana makes the difference from me being here as a useful member of society and laying at home in the fetal position in constant pain,'' said Ms. Webster, whose illnesses include two kinds of arthritis. Ms. Webster, a 43-year-old who has decorated the club with her hand-folded origami swans, added: ''With marijuana, I can type 150 words a minute, fold origami, and walk without assistance. When the club closed, people died; I was paralyzed.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Nibbling on a Rice Krispie cookie laced with marijuana, Mr. Peron vowed that he and his 8,000 members would resist with civil disobedience if state or Federal agents ever tried to padlock his premises again.
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: ''If they get an injunction against us, we are going to stand in the doorway, and open again,'' said Mr. Peron, who smokes and eats marijuana to combat depression. ''If we can't sell here, we will sell on the sidewalk. They will have to throw all of us in jail.''
title: Moving to Semantical High Ground

text: Indians Vote, and Wait For a Momentous Decision
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: After a seven-week campaign, India's elections came to a tense end. Results start to emerge on Tuesday, as the nation chooses between Sonia Gandhi's vision of a secular India and a rival vision of a Government dominated by Hindu culture. 10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Spy Charges in Balkans Likely
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The British Government is expected to charge a British major, Milos Stankovic, with providing classified NATO information to the Bosnian Serb leadership during the war, senior diplomats say. He is said to have kept the Bosnian Serb military commander abreast of top-secret NATO plans and procedures. 3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A Knotty Suit in Israel
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: An Arab who lives in Israel and holds Israeli citizenship is suing to be able to buy land, posing a wrenching legal question at the heart of the conflict in Israel's claim to be both a democracy and a Jewish state. The issue arises repeatedly in many disputes but has never been fully tested in the area of the right to land. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Rebuilding Beijing, in a Rush
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Long delayed by China's isolation and poverty, urban renewal is unfolding fast, as real estate developers are remaking the face of the ancient city in just a few years. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The United Nations has cleared the way for Iraq to export more oil. But the nation is unable to take full advantage of the opportunity, because its equipment is so worn. 12
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Central Europe Dam to Proceed
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Hungary and Slovakia have confirmed plans to build a large hydroelectric dam on the Danube, thus setting off new protests in Budapest. 12
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Environmentalists Sue For Cleaner Water
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Lawsuits brought by environmentalists in about half of the states are demanding that state and Federal authorities to enforce a dormant provision of the Clean Water Act, move from controlling individual points of pollution -- like factories or waste-water treatment plants -- to improving larger watersheds. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: After a top Philip Morris executive testified before Congress in 1994 that the cigarette maker did not ''manipulate or independently control'' nicotine in its products, company scientists reported that they could produce ''enhanced'' nicotine effects on a smoker's nervous system, an internal company document shows. 25
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: At least one marijuana club remains open, despite a California Supreme Court ruling barring the sale of the drug by clubs. The state Attorney General says the 20 clubs, including the Cannabis Cultivators Club in San Francisco, must close. 18
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A free 30-second commercial during the Super Bowl, in which President Clinton urged racial harmony, is just one of the ways -- some large, many small -- that Mr. Clinton's much-touted and often-criticized race relations initiative has begun to permeate the Administration's thinking. 17
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Valujet has broken numerous safety rules but there is ''no evidence of systematic safety problems,'' the Federal Aviation Administration said. But the agency said its inspectors had had an unusual internal disagreement about the airline. 26
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The City University of New York is proposing a sweeping overhaul of the way it handles applicants who are not ready for college-level work. Under the plan, underprepared students would have to attend intensive remedial summer classes before being allowed to enter the university's 17 undergraduate colleges. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Future of 125th Street
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Harlem's street of dreams, 125th Street, is breaking a lot of hearts these days. Even as new projects like Harlem USA, a mall that will bring the area's first Disney Store and Gap, prepare to begin construction this spring, older businesses say they are struggling to compete. 1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A former scientist at the Brooklyn National Laboratory has charged that the lab has jeopardized local drinking water by draining millions of gallons of waste water into basins near an old but still potent radioactive ''hot spot.'' 27
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: In the past year, New York's Republican Party raised campaign money at an unprecedented rate and gave most of it to Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election fund, allowing his campaign to circumvent laws that limit contributions from wealthy supporters, campaign documents show. 27
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The doctor whose experiments on how insulin increases the body's use of blood sugars set new courses for diabetes research, was 87. 34
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The retired Pepsico executive who was the first black man to become a vice president at a major American corporation, was 79. 34
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: THE driver was late, the aide had the directions all wrong, and as Colombia's Ambassador rode up Capitol Hill the other day to defend his country's drug-fighting record before one more skeptical audience, his only armor was two copies of a thin, boring-looking Government report. For the emissary of a country whose drug-enforcement efforts had failed the United States' certification test two years in a row, the Ambassador, Juan Carlos Esguerra, was looking remarkably unperturbed.
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: ''When we didn't know what it would mean to be decertified, we were terribly worried that it would have catastrophic effects,'' Mr. Esguerra said, recalling the all-out lobbying campaigns that Colombia waged in past years in vain attempts to avoid the Clinton Administration's censure. ''Once you know the impact, you know you can handle it.''
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: The 12-year-old Federal law requires that, by the end of every February, the White House publicly evaluate the drug-control efforts of countries that produce or ship the cocaine, heroin, marijuana and methamphetamines that are consumed in the United States. And each year by the beginning of March, critics attack the process known as drug certification, mostly because of the anger and irritation it produces in American relations abroad.
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: Lately, though, the irritation has appeared to be mostly skin deep. For countries like Mexico -- which was fully certified again on Thursday despite a confidential assessment by the United States Drug Enforcement Administration that was stingingly pessimistic -- it has become clear, officials say privately, that considerations like trade will outweigh dissatisfactions over the drug issue. Similarly, the practice of recent years has shown nations like Pakistan and Lebanon that even if they are denied certification, their strategic importance to the United States is such that they can expect the White House to waive the penalties in the national interest.
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: Under the 1986 statute, the penalties include a mandatory halt to some American foreign aid, a requirement that the United States vote against their applications for multilateral development bank loans, and the possibility of trade and economic sanctions. But when the law was written, both the cold-war power of the United States and the promise of such sanctions had a fresher smell.
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: Last year, as the Administration and Congress wrestled with the question of whether to decertify Colombia for the second year in a row, the Government of President Ernesto Samper dispatched its police chief and half a dozen cabinet members to lobby in Washington. The issue was Mr. Samper himself, and the $6.1 million that American officials say he took as a campaign contribution from cocaine traffickers. But his Government nonetheless took out full-page advertisements in American newspapers to describe the sacrifices that Colombia's people had made, the blood that its soldiers and police had spilled. Brightly colored booklets detailing the country's anti-drug achievements inundated Congress.
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: This winter, the strategy changed. ''No publicity. No advertising. Absolutely none,'' Mr. Esguerra said. ''The certification issue has become less important.'' (Last week, in a gesture that American officials did not take seriously, Mr. Samper offered to resign a few months early if it would improve Colombia's relationship with the United States.)
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: At a Senate subcommittee hearing about certification Thursday, Senator Joseph Biden, the Maryland Democrat, spoke up for the process. It remains, he said, ''an effort to prod other governments into action -- actions they would not otherwise take.''
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: But in the past, American officials have been able to count on at least some flurries of police activity abroad as the judgment day nears: drug traffickers arrested, drug crops eradicated, drug shipments seized. Recent years have seen less and less of that kind of push.
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: More significant than the end of Colombia's lobbying are the issues on which it flatly ignored American appeals -- and threats of further decertification. In November, the Samper Government allowed the legislature it controls to reinstate its extradition treaty with the United States with the proviso that it would not apply retroactively -- and thus to the powerful Cali Cartel bosses who are serving relatively short prison sentences in Colombia but are wanted by American courts.
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: The frustration of American law-enforcement officials with Mexico has been harder for some in Washington to interpret: Last year, the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo has overhauled its anti-drug force, arrested some military and civilian officials on corruption charges and taken small but potentially important steps toward extraditing Mexican drug criminals to the United States. But at what is typically the busiest time of the law-enforcement year, American agents were reporting to their headquarters that the ''new'' Mexican police units were making no discernable effort to arrest the most important traffickers.
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: In Pakistan, the Government has steadfastly ignored American pleas for the release of a Pakistani employee of the Drug Enforcement Administration who is serving a five-year sentence at hard labor for helping American law-enforcement agents with an undercover operation that led to the jailing of two Pakistani air force officers on charges of heroin trafficking. The drug-enforcement aide, Ayyaz Baluch, was found guilty of ''seducing'' the officers to commit a crime. Pakistan's Ambassador to the United States, Riaz Khokhar, dismissed what he said had been open threats of decertification over the matter. ''We have lived with certain sanctions in the past,'' he said in an interview. ''Frankly, it won't bother us.''
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: Some American officials blame the toothlessness of decertification on the limits of the law. Colombian officials, for their part, noted that they have been authorized to receive more anti-drug aid since being decertified. In Washington, support is rising for a multilateral approach to setting drug-enforcement standards. But even if American legislators have an alternative, they may still have a problem. ''If you favor repeal of the certification statute, then you look like you're weak on drugs,'' said Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is the ranking minority member on the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ''And that's still an uncomfortable position for a politician to be in.''
title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades

text: The Clinton Administration does no favor to Mexico or its own credibility by certifying that Mexico is ''fully cooperating'' in the fight against drug trafficking. Compounding the damage, the White House Drug Policy Director, Barry McCaffrey, fatuously claims that Mexican cooperation is ''absolutely superlative.''
title: Certifiably Wrong on Mexico

text: A more truthful assessment can be found in the Drug Enforcement Administration's confidential evaluation, described by Tim Golden in yesterday's Times. The D.E.A. concludes that ''the Government of Mexico has not accomplished its counter-narcotics goals or succeeded in cooperation with the United States Government.'' Mexican trafficking has increased, the D.E.A. notes, and the corruption of its enforcement agencies ''continues unabated.''
title: Certifiably Wrong on Mexico

text: Though Washington finds it diplomatically inconvenient to acknowledge, Mexico has a chronic problem with drug traffickers who always seem able to secure the political influence they need to avoid arrest and prosecution. This drug corruption greases the flow of narcotics into the United States. Mexico's drug networks span the border, supplying cocaine, heroin and marijuana to American users.
title: Certifiably Wrong on Mexico

text: Mexico must face up honestly to its drug corruption problem as it tries to create a more democratic and accountable political system. The most flagrant abuses come from corrupt military and police officials who take payoffs to protect one set of traffickers at the expense of their rivals.
title: Certifiably Wrong on Mexico

text: President Ernesto Zedillo's Government has made efforts to reform drug enforcement, but with little visible result. He has not moved aggressively enough to clean up civilian police agencies and has relied too heavily on military officials, exposing them to the same temptations that led the civilians astray. A more vigorous cleanup might force a showdown with corrupt elements of Mr. Zedillo's Institutional Revolutionary Party, which would benefit Mexican democracy.
title: Certifiably Wrong on Mexico

text: Meanwhile, it is misleading for Washington to assert that Mexico is fully cooperating. The law mandates penalties, including reductions in foreign aid and limits on international lending, for countries found to be insufficiently cooperative. But these penalties can be waived in the interest of national security. That should have been done with Mexico.
title: Certifiably Wrong on Mexico

text: Certification is a clumsy tool for encouraging better narcotics enforcement abroad. The annual review process, now required by law, forces Washington into difficult choices between papering over problems or offending otherwise friendly countries. It should be eliminated. But as long as certification remains on the books, the Administration has a duty to report truthfully to Congress and the American people. It has failed to do so in the case of Mexico.
title: Certifiably Wrong on Mexico

text: Dorothy Dicent grew up surrounded by the cheerful commotion of five brothers and sisters in South Carolina. But she spent most of her childhood alone.
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Confused by voices that whispered in her head and a black hollow of melancholy inside her, she spent most of her time closeted away in her room, often battling suicidal urges. When she started cutting herself with a razor, her mother took her to a psychiatrist whose diagnosis was manic depression. She was 11 years old.
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Medication silenced the voices and soothed her despair, but she hated being the odd one out among her peers, who seemed carefree. When she was 14, her family moved to New York and, because she thought it would normalize her life, she stopped taking her medication. ''I wanted to blend,'' said Ms. Dicent, who is now 37. ''But I was ashamed of my mental problem.''
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Blending in meant smoking marijuana with her new friends, and cutting classes. ''I wanted to be with the crowd of people who claimed they were the coolest,'' she said. In 10th grade, she dropped out of school and started using cocaine. For the first time in her life, she felt ''on top of the world,'' she recalled, but what started as dabbling soon became a habit that needed feeding. She began stealing to get money for the drug.
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: On a recent Sunday afternoon, as she sat in the small room in Far Rockaway, Queens, that she has made her home, Ms. Dicent could have been telling the story of another woman. Articulate and well groomed, she talked of the future with optimism and an inviting smile.
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: She does have regrets, however. Her son, Terrence, was born in 1985 with cocaine in his system, and her mother became his legal guardian to avoid intervention by child welfare officials. He has lived with his grandmother in South Carolina ever since.
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Devastated by the loss, Ms. Dicent sought solace the only way she knew how. ''I was like, 'Wow, I don't have anything to live for now,' '' she remembered. ''I thought, 'Maybe these drugs are just going to let me forget all these problems.' ''
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: She married in 1991, thinking it would make her more secure. For two years, she hid her mental illness and her drug habit from her husband. He found out about both when she pawned her wedding ring to buy crack. He was sympathetic at first, but his efforts to help her change failed, and she moved out in 1996.
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: With no income and nowhere to live, Ms. Dicent went to the Brooklyn Women's Shelter. ''I told one of the caseworkers that I felt like killing myself, and at one point I felt like killing other people,'' she said. ''And the shelter staff told me about T.L.C.''
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Housed in the same building as the shelter, the Transitional Living Community is part of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Services, one of seven charities sponsored by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which will end its annual appeal on Saturday. The T.L.C. program assists homeless women with mental illnesses. ''The goal is to get them out of the shelter and help them become independent,'' said Godfrey Gillette, Ms. Dicent's caseworker.
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Mr. Gillette introduced her to Narcotics Anonymous, as well as a MICA -- Mental Illness and Chemical Addiction -- support group, in May 1996, and she has attended ever since. ''For the first time, I really wanted help,'' Ms. Dicent explained. ''I said to myself, 'I have to start praying to God. I believe God's going to bring me through this.' And I got down on my knees and cried like a baby.''
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Last February, she moved out of the shelter to Far Rockaway, and she recently celebrated a year of drug-free living. She speaks to Terrence every day on the phone and is working to make her life stable enough for him to move back in with her. ''I never stopped loving him, but I just didn't know how to love him at the time,'' she said. ''I didn't know how to love myself, either.''
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Action, instead of crack, is the new answer to her problems. With regular medication, her manic depression is under control, and she is studying for her G.E.D. She participates in a women's group, and regularly organizes workshops for the MICA program, which she attends five days a week. She plans to apply to college next year.
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: ''The sky is the limit now,'' she said. ''I find that there isn't anything I can't do once I put my mind to it.''
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: Checks payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund should be sent to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087, or any of these
title: The Neediest Cases; Overcoming Despair and Drug Abuse to Find Hope

text: BROOKLYN BUREAU OF COMMUNITY SERVICE

text: Mariana Spinello, 13, was 45 minutes late to school yesterday. Chesley Charles fretted about his son Kadeem, 2, who waited past sundown for his father at a day-care center. And confusion reigned at subway stations in Manhattan and Queens and on Roosevelt Island as commuters on the B and Q trains turned to token sellers and one another to figure out where to go and how.
title: Confusion Upsets Subway Riders at Start of 15-Month Repair in 63d Street Tunnel

text: So it went as work began on a 15-month project to replace 3.2 miles of track in the tunnel between Long Island City and the East Side of Manhattan. Until the $44 million effort is completed, the B and Q trains that run between 21st Street-Queensbridge and Brooklyn will end at 57th Street and Seventh Avenue. There, riders can transfer to N and R trains downtown and Brooklyn or they can walk to the station at 57th Street and Avenue of the Americas to transfer free to a downtown B or Q. Either way, said a spokesman for the Transit Authority, Termaine Garden, trips to and from Queens and Roosevelt Island are most likely to take an extra 30 minutes.
title: Confusion Upsets Subway Riders at Start of 15-Month Repair in 63d Street Tunnel

text: Crews are replacing two tracks eight years after the tunnel was built. The $868 million tunnel used a design that officials considered innovative, but that has proved faulty.
title: Confusion Upsets Subway Riders at Start of 15-Month Repair in 63d Street Tunnel

text: ''I wouldn't say it was a boondoggle,'' Mr. Garden said of the design, which called for laying the rails in shallow epoxy-and-sand pads instead of on top of conventional ties. ''It was an innovative design at the time.''
title: Confusion Upsets Subway Riders at Start of 15-Month Repair in 63d Street Tunnel

text: For many commuters, the day turned out to pose major inconveniences. Some riders complained of a lack of officials to direct passengers. When the trains from Queens and Roosevelt Island unloaded passengers in Manhattan in the morning, recounted Miles Phillips, 25, a carpenter headed for Park Slope in Brooklyn, many passengers wandered about the station and wondered: ''Do we transfer? Is there a shuttle? Do we take the bus?''
title: Confusion Upsets Subway Riders at Start of 15-Month Repair in 63d Street Tunnel

text: Brenda Williams, 22, who travels from Queens to 63d Street every day, also complained. ''You had passengers asking other passengers how to transfer,'' she said.
title: Confusion Upsets Subway Riders at Start of 15-Month Repair in 63d Street Tunnel

text: In the afternoon, Mr. Charles, a warehouse supervisor in Long Island City, paced at the Queensbridge station. Kadeem was waiting at the day-care center near the family's home in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. The center charges for every extra half-hour. ''Right now,'' he said, ''it's going to be a problem for me. I'm going to be very, very late.''
title: Confusion Upsets Subway Riders at Start of 15-Month Repair in 63d Street Tunnel

text: ''Where's Jelani? Where's Jelani? Where's Jelani?''
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: There were better places for the U.C.L.A. Bruins to appear this afternoon than Cameron Indoor Stadium. The Duke students, the Cameron Crazies, do not recognize privacy when opponents pass through these doors. So the absence of Jelani McCoy, the former Bruin center who attributed his resignation from the team a week ago to news media scrutiny, was treated with a different spin.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: Dozens of pieces of green construction paper, carefully cut into large leaves, were waved at the visiting bench, a taunt stemming from news reports that McCoy had been suspended for marijuana use. The U.C.L.A. players glared toward the taped headband on the forehead of the Blue Devil mascot. ''Smoke the Bruins,'' it read. And that was precisely what happened.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: The soon-to-be-top-ranked Blue Devils scored the most points by any opponent in U.C.L.A.'s 79-year history. Duke's 120-84 victory raised serious questions about the direction of the Bruins' season and completed a dramatic two-day swing that may have altered the Atlantic Coast Conference balance of power. With the return of the powerful freshman Elton Brand, less than two months after he broke his left foot, restoring Duke's balance, and with North Carolina's loss at home to North Carolina State on Saturday, the A.C.C. race just became more interesting. Duke is 13-1 in the conference, North Carolina is 12-2, and each has two games remaining -- with the finale against each other Saturday at Duke.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: Duke, 25-2 over all, matched its second-highest regular-season victory total. The three previous Blue Devil teams with 25 or more regular-season victories reached national championship games, including the back-to-back winners in 1991 and 1992.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: Brand, a 6-foot-8-inch, 260-pound forward whose return this season was considered unlikely by Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski as recently as 12 days ago, scored 14 points with 7 rebounds in 16 minutes. His appearance at the scorer's table, 6 minutes 2 seconds into the game, inspired an ovation.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: ''It's a feeling you don't have very often,'' Brand said.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: He had been concerned that his return would disrupt the rearranged combination that had taken shape in Duke's previous 15 games. ''Actually,'' Brand said quietly, ''the game escalated a little bit.''
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: Brand's return came during the end of a 19-3 run that gave Duke a 13-point lead. For the 3:28 before Brand came out, the three Duke field goals were on 3-point shots, with the defense forced to concentrate on the inside threat. Brand moved freely, and said there had been no pain. Late in the first half, he challenged Baron Davis, a freshman guard, and made a steal on the perimeter. ''I felt his foot was O.K. when he does that kind of stuff,'' Krzyzewski said.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: ''The more he improves, the better our team is,'' said Roshown McLeod, a Duke senior forward, who scored 23 points.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: Trajan Langdon, a junior guard, equaled his career high with 34 points; his afternoon included 6-of-10 3-point shooting, 6-of-6 free throw shooting, 5 rebounds, 4 assists and no turnovers. Shane Battier, the resourceful freshman forward, had 8 points, 7 rebounds and 2 blocked shots, and created three Bruin charging fouls. Steve Wojciechowski, a senior point guard, had 11 points and 7 assists without a turnover.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: Steve Lavin, the U.C.L.A. coach, saw a reinforced Duke inside game that contributed to 15-of-28 3-point shooting for the Blue Devils. ''Just his physical presence,'' Lavin said of Brand, ''his size, is what is going to help Duke in the tournament.''
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: U.C.L.A., now 20-6 and ranked 12th, is running out of time to correct a mounting set of problems in the stretch drive. The 36-point margin of defeat was the fifth-largest in school history, with two of the top five coming this season. Its defense often appeared indifferent, the offense a series of plodding isolation moves. U.C.L.A. trailed, 57-33, at halftime.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: J. R. Henderson, who as a freshman played an essential role in the Bruins' 1995 championship season, returned to the bench and kicked a water bottle after his third foul, just 6:37 into the game.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: ''I've never done that before,'' Henderson said. ''I'm sure you can read something from that. Things got so bad, you're forced to laugh.''
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: The Duke students would agree with that. Duke's mascot entered the floor surrounded by a cardboard cutout of a sport utility vehicle labeled the ''Baron Davis-mobile.'' Such a vehicle had been at the center of an investigation involving the recruitment of Davis. The National Collegiate Athletic Association ruled that there had been no impropriety, but the Crazies waved car keys when Davis stood at the foul line, and in the final minutes, they chanted: ''Start the Blazer. Start the Blazer. Start the Blazer.''
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery
