text: With 3:56 to play and the Duke lead at 32, the Crazies had moved on to other business, such as the arrival of the North Carolina Tar Heels on Saturday. Duke was already headed from the No. 2 position in the polls to No. 1. And U.C.L.A. was moving, too, a team returning west, its season heading south.
title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK
title: 4 Arrested After Delivery In the Bronx of Marijuana

text: Four men who accepted delivery of 700 pounds of marijuana from Mexico were arrested in the Bronx on Friday night, the police said.
title: 4 Arrested After Delivery In the Bronx of Marijuana

text: Acting on a tip from officials of the shipping company, Roadway Express Van Lines, who had become suspicious of the cargo, the authorities tracked the truck after it cleared customs in El Paso, Tex., and made the three-day trip to Brooklyn, said Lieut. Lebro Burnette of the Brooklyn North Narcotics Division. The marijuana in the truck had a street value of $4 million, the police said.
title: 4 Arrested After Delivery In the Bronx of Marijuana

text: In Brooklyn, the driver, who had been told he was delivering videotapes and compact disks, turned the truck over to the police. Undercover officers took it to 460 Zerega Avenue in the Bronx, the police said. The suspects were identified as Jimmie Colon, Jesus Rivera and Guillermo Perez, all of the Bronx, and Ramon Caba of Manhattan.
title: 4 Arrested After Delivery In the Bronx of Marijuana

text: I was disturbed to read the comments of George Vecsey (''Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal,'' The Times, Feb. 13). Not only does he miss the mark on Ross Rebagliati, the snowboarder who used marijuana, but he vilifies International Olympic Committee officials who were upholding a sense of decency in an event intended to speak to our highest ideals and he trivializes the issue of drug use.
title: On Marijuana

text: Marijuana is a drug. That many in the 60's and 70's used it does not change that fact. It is also an illegal drug in this country and in Japan. Yes, the I.O.C. should have done a better job of making their position on nonperformance-enhancing drugs clear. But, was it wrong for taking a stand to say that using drugs is wrong and they will not allow a drug user to be seen as a role model on their watch?
title: On Marijuana

text: I appreciate the message the I.O.C. tried to send both as a professional and as the parent of two young sons. I understand the legality of the reversal, but I am not happy about it.
title: On Marijuana

text: Regarding his column about Ross Rebagliati: George Vecsey is way off base when describing Whistler, British Columbia. Whistler is far from a mecca for pot-smoking skiers and snowboarders. It is rather subdued and geared for the serious winter athlete. At Whistler, the happy hour is O.K., but by 10 P.M. during the week it's lights out. Although the locals do seem as if they were from an episode of ''Northern Exposure,'' everyone is friendly. If you visit the place, you'll only find majestic views and great skiing.
title: A Subdued Place

text: ILLEGAL drugs are a big problem for Garry M. Ritzky: too many of his job applicants use them. Mr. Ritzky, risk and human resources director for Turner Brothers Trucking Inc., a transportation and oil services company in Oklahoma City, is having a hard time finding candidates who are clean of cocaine, marijuana and heroin.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: ''We have an oil pipe operation that uses unskilled laborers, and we're seeing more positive drug tests,'' he said. ''We had three last week.'' The number of positive drug tests among applicants for low-skilled jobs at Turner Brothers has doubled in the last year, Mr. Ritzky added.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: Such evidence, while mostly anecdotal, runs counter to the decline in positive drug tests that most businesses have seen the last decade. Yet with the unemployment rate at a 25-year low and the economy continuing to grow, more human resource managers say they are starting to see a small but disturbing increase in the number of job applicants who fail screening for drug and alcohol abuse.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: One reason for that increase, they say, is that as the supply of potential employees continues to shrink, those with drug and alcohol problems probably represent a larger portion of the labor pool. Some also say a number of products now available to beat drug tests are encouraging some job applicants to take chances. And marijuana, they say, is again in vogue.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: According to a study released late last year by the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse, 16 percent of unemployed people used illicit drugs in 1994. When the data were collected, unemployment was at 6.1 percent. Today, with unemployment at 4.7 percent, qualified job seekers are harder to find.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: ''Employers are finding it harder to find people who are not using drugs,'' said James G. Lipari, public health adviser for the Federal Government's Center for Substance Abuse Prevention. ''Since there are more employers using testing and other prevention means, there are more people who are unemployed for that reason, which makes the pool of unemployed who are using drugs great.''
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: But these apparent trends are not yet reflected in the data. When drug testing first became widespread, in the late 1980's, about 18 percent of the tests showed signs of drug use, according to SmithKline Beecham Clinical Laboratories, one of the nation's largest drug-testing labs. That number, which represents mostly screening of applicants and a small amount of tests for workers already on the job, fell steadily, to 8.8 percent in 1991, and then began to decline more slowly. In 1996, about 5.8 percent of the tests showed signs of drugs.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: ''Over the past 10 years, we've seen a dramatic decrease in positive tests,'' said Thomas Johnson, a spokesman for SmithKline Beecham. The lab is expected to release the results for 1997 in the next few weeks.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: ''Early indications are that they will continue to decline,'' Mr. Johnson said.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: One drug that is coming back, however, is marijuana. Of the people who failed the SmithKline drug test in 1996, almost 60 percent had traces of marijuana in their urine. That is up from 52 percent from 1995.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: Marijuana use was in the spotlight two weeks ago when the Canadian snowboarder Ross Rebagliati had his Olympic gold medal withdrawn after he failed a drug test. Mr. Rebagliati said he had not smoked marijuana since April 1997 and that any residue in his urine was from second-hand smoke. With somewhat less-than-clear Olympic rules on the penalty for marijuana use, he was later allowed to keep the medal.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: The accuracy of drug tests has been questioned by groups including the Society for Human Resource Management, based in Alexandria, Va. It says data provided by companies like SmithKline Beecham, while accurately reflecting a downward trend, must be taken with a grain of salt. ''Some people have since learned to beat the system,'' said Barry K. Lawrence, a spokesman for the society.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: Several companies advertise on the Internet, for example, selling products to cover up traces of drugs in urine or hair. One company, Test Clean Drug Testing Solutions in Oklahoma City, boasts that its product, Klear, which can be bought for as little as $30, ''is the smallest most potent, undetectable urine purifier sold today.''
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: Mr. Johnson of SmithKline acknowledged, ''It's like a cat-and-mouse game.'' But, he said, laboratories are catching on and are starting to test for those adulterants as well.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: Most experts agree that drug testing has cut drug and alcohol abuse in the workplace, but its greatest impact is on casual users.
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: ''It eliminated use among individuals who could stop, who had more at stake and didn't want to lose that,'' said Ellen Weber, director of national policy for the Legal Action Center, a nonprofit group based in New York that is involved in drug, alcohol and H.I.V. employment issues. ''Drug testing, in my mind, was never an effective tool for people who are dependent on drugs.''
title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

text: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE LAW
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: A Vermonter who had lived for a while in a back-to-nature community, Laura Kross was called to give a deposition when the Federal Government sued to take over the property on the ground that people were growing marijuana there. Ms. Kross lied; asked whether she had seen residents smoking marijuana on the property, she said, ''Uh-uh.''
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: For that, Ms. Kross was indicted, tried, convicted and sentenced. In recalling the case, Gregory L. Waples, an Assistant United States Attorney in Vermont, said she had been prosecuted ''because she committed perjury.''
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: So, yes, it happens. Lying in a civil case is perjury, and it gets prosecuted, though rarely.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Some of President Clinton's supporters argue that the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, is using his investigation to criminalize conduct in a separate civil matter, namely the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit. But legal experts are pointing out that lying in a civil lawsuit has always been a crime and occasionally has sent people to jail.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: ''I've been distressed by the number of former prosecutors who have gotten on TV and said it doesn't count,'' said Richard Underwood, a law professor at the University of Kentucky who has written extensively on perjury prosecutions.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Stephen Gillers of New York University Law School said: ''Using phrases like 'virtually never' says to the public that the likelihood of getting charged with perjury in civil cases is like getting struck by lightning. You don't have to worry about it. That's the wrong message, factually wrong and morally wrong.''
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: The issue in Mr. Starr's investigation is not just whether Monica S. Lewinsky or Mr. Clinton lied -- Ms. Lewinsky in an affidavit and Mr. Clinton in a deposition 10 days later -- in denying they had a sexual affair. Mr. Starr is also investigating possible subornation of perjury, obstruction of justice and other Federal crimes in connection with the Jones litigation.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Most serious, probably, are reports that Ms. Lewinsky played some role in trying to influence other potential witnesses in the Jones case, that she got help in finding a job, possibly in return for her silence, and that she returned items -- said to be gifts from Mr. Clinton -- to the White House after they were subpoenaed.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: ''The objective of all these statutes is to punish people who keep the courts from getting reliable information,'' Mr. Gillers said. ''It could be by perjury, by suborning perjury, by encouraging a witness to leave the jurisdiction or encouraging a witness to get rid of objects that might be subpoenaed.''
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: In investigations involving this broader range of laws, prosecutions are not so uncommon: two former executives of Texaco Inc., for example, were indicted last year for obstruction of justice in connection with documents requested by plaintiffs in a race discrimination suit. And in 1996 a former county prosecutor in New Jersey, Nicholas L. Bissell, was convicted of perjury, as well as many fraud and misconduct charges, for making false statements in a civil suit in which he was a defendant.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Nonetheless, legal experts agree that in ordinary civil suits, lying is rampant and prosecution for lying is rare. There have been at most a few dozen published court decisions over the last decade that concern perjury and civil cases, though the total number of prosecutions could be considerably higher.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: ''There's perjury going on in every civil case in depositions, far more than in criminal cases,'' said Joel Cohen, a Manhattan lawyer who has written on the issue. And getting prosecutors to act on it, he added, is all but impossible.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: ''They say, 'I'm not a collection agent for you,' '' Mr. Cohen said.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: ''Another thing a prosecutor would not do,'' he said, referring to Mr. Starr's impact on the Jones suit, is try to help a litigant in efforts to harm someone politically.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Given the huge practical problems and limited resources that prosecutors have in bringing such cases, perhaps the best the court system can do is pursue the occasional well-chosen perjury indictment for its deterrent effect.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: ''What you'd like is not for prosecutors to go after everything but for people to think they do,'' said William Stuntz, a University of Virginia law professor. ''It's good if people are nervous when they raise their right hand.''
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Mr. Waples, the Federal prosecutor in Vermont, said that if his office received a complaint about perjury in a deposition, he would not treat it less seriously just because it concerned a civil case. But he also said that in 20 years as a prosecutor, he had never received such a complaint. The Kross case, he said, was the only perjury case involving a civil suit that he had ever handled, and Ms. Kross's prosecution stemmed from a suit his office was already handling.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Even more rare is a criminal investigation, like Mr. Starr's, of possible perjury in a civil case that has not been concluded.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Writing in the current issue of The New York Review of Books, Lawrence Walsh, who was the independent counsel in the Iran-contra investigation, observed: ''In 60 years of practice, I have never known this to happen. Most civil lawsuits begin with exaggerated allegations by the parties, which are narrowed and corrected as discovery and depositions proceed.''
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Finally, if there is any matter that invites lies and discourages prosecutions for lying, it is sex.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: If the conduct at issue is adultery, said Anne Coughlin, a University of Virginia law professor, ''it's a lie by definition.'' And given the ''implicit adulterous agreement'' that both parties will cover it up, she said, ''it might be difficult to determine whether conversations about hiding the affair were just part of that ordinary agreement or whether these were special conversations about trying to obstruct a legal case.''
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Ideally, Mr. Stuntz said, such concerns should not limit prosecutors. ''The real mistake a lot of folks have made,'' he said, ''is in leaping to the conclusion that because they're rare, that must mean that we as a society have decided that this is not serious misbehavior.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: ''There's a much bigger reason, and that is that proving guilt is real hard. It's real costly, as Kenneth Starr is finding out. Prosecutors do not go after high cost prosecutions unless it's a very, very big deal.''
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Nevertheless, in cases of simple perjury, the prosecutions have arisen from some not very big deals. Those prosecuted in recent cases have included a plaintiff in a sex discrimination case who lied in a deposition about how she had calculated income she reported in her job application, and two police officers, also plaintiffs in a job discrimination suit, who lied about whether they had falsely called in sick.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Divorce cases, which lawyers agree are rife with lies, have drawn virtually no prosecutorial interest.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: There was, however, the case of Nellie O. Browne of Broome County, N.Y., prosecuted 54 years ago for a false affidavit in a divorce that was not even her own.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: Apparently trying to help the wife in the case, she arranged for a young woman to take a job as a maid in her friend's house ''for purposes,'' the court said, ''of being observed in a compromising position'' with the husband. Ms. Browne swore in the affidavit that she had not engaged in any ''collusive practices'' in connection with the divorce action. Her indictment was upheld.
title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare

text: FOR nearly a decade, school districts throughout the state have been expelling students for behavior not on school property but nevertheless deemed by school boards to be ''seriously disruptive of the educational process.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: That aggressive use of a state policy sanctioned by the Attorney General's office in the late 1980's and put into law by the General Assembly two years ago is meant to allow schools to keep gang leaders, drug dealers and violent teen-agers out of classrooms and hallways. Under the policy, schools have had considerable discretion in expelling students for off-campus acts seen as endangering students and school staff. (It is generally accepted that schools have been able to expel students for disruptive behavior or criminal activity on school grounds.)
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: But now the policy regarding off-campus acts is in serious jeopardy.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: A Superior Court judge recently reversed a school district's decision to expel a student for possession of marijuana off school grounds and has ruled the state's expulsion law unconstitutionally vague. The ruling has sent shock waves through the state and is being appealed to the State Supreme Court by the Board of Education in the town of Thomaston, with the support of the State Attorney General's Office and the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education. The higher court has decided the issue is important enough to expedite the case and hear arguments sometime next month.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: Meanwhile, the recent ruling by Litchfield Superior Court Judge Walter Pickett regarding a 17-year-old student at Thomaston High School has school boards and superintendents in limbo.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''Right now, everything is up in the air, nobody knows what they can or cannot expel a student for and that could have a devastating impact in schools across the state,'' said Patrice McCarthy, deputy director and general counsel for the Connecticut Assocation of Boards of Education, which represents 144 of the state's 166 school boards. ''We hope and expect the Supreme Court to uphold the state law . . . if they don't, it could have far-reaching consequences.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: But some say the law gives local school boards far too much power.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''The statute is so vague and gives far too much discretion to local school boards enforcing it that it is clearly unconstitutional and the judge's ruling must be upheld,'' said the Torrington lawyer William A. Conti, who successfully argued the case on behalf of Kyle P. Packer, who returned to school following the ruling after missing just a few weeks. ''I believe the judge made a courageous decision,'' Mr. Conti said, ''but it is a ruling that had to be made.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: Mr. Conti said while the law mandates automatic expulsions for such behavior as selling or distributing drugs or being in possession of a weapon, it gets a lot more vague and confusing when connected to other offenses like simple possession of drugs -- his client was in possession of two ounces of marijuana at the time of his arrest. (Possession of four or more ounces is considered a felony.)
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: But Ms. McCarthy argues that ''school boards need the authority to decide on a case-by-case basis whether students should be expelled. That's what this law allows them to do.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: Lawyers and educators disagree about the impact of the judge's ruling in the short run but agree the long-range results could be dramatic if upheld by the Supreme Court.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''This was an outrageous ruling that is completely unfair and not based on what is best for students, teachers and schools,'' said the Thomaston superintendent of schools, George Counter. ''Local school boards and principals,'' he said, ''which have a much better grasp about particular students and how their out-of-school activities can adversely impact other students, must be allowed to make these kinds of decisions to keep schools safe.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: Mr. Counter said the judge's decision, if allowed to stand, sets a potentially ''dangerous precedent'' that could have an impact on urban and suburban school districts across the state.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''We rely on that law to help maintain order in our schools; ruling it unconstitutional was a terrible decision and who knows how much damage it's going to cause,'' said Nicholas A. LaRosa, assistant superintendent of schools in Hartford, the state's largest school system with more than 24,000 students.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''Providing a safe environment for our students and staff is absolutely imperative to providing a good education,'' Mr. LaRosa said, ''and without this law that would be seriously in jeopardy.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: The Bridgeport schools superintendent, James. A. Connelly, said that in the state's largest city and second-largest school system about three quarters of the 30 to 40 expulsions each year are for actions off school property, with 67 of the last 85 expulsions related to off-campus offenses.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''For us, this law has been very significant because it has allowed us to keep out dangerous students,'' said Mr. Connelly. ''We don't use the policy in a casual way, but it has been invaluable and a tremendous weapon in our battle to keep our schools safe.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: As he sees it, ''To take away a weapon that has worked so effectively in keeping dangerous criminals out of our schools would be complete folly.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: But Mr. Conti says that violating the constitutional rights of students cannot be sacrificed in the process.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''Wanting to keep order in the schools doesn't give you the right to violate the constitutional rights of children; it's that simple,'' said Mr. Conti. ''You can't have a law that gives local boards so much power and the right to expel a student in one town, but not in another. That's not what this country is all about.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: Indeed, the law had its critics before the judge's ruling. In a comprehensive report recently issued by the General Assembly's Legislative Program Review and Investigations Committee, it was found that the law ''provides little direction to public school districts in the implementation of the law and policy'' and that ''the language is vague and does not clearly focus on the issue of school safety.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: The panel goes on to propose changing the statute to include language such as ''the unlawful activity may reasonably be considered to be an interference with school purposes or an educational function,'' or ''the student's removal from school is necessary to restore order or to protect person on school property.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: The State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, disagrees that the law's wording needs to be changed and says he expects the Supreme Court to reverse the lower court's ruling. Mr. Blumenthal pointed out that there is a formal procedure school districts must adhere to before expelling a student, which includes allowing the student legal representation.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''The ruling took us all by surprise,'' said Mr. Blumenthal, ''because this is a statute that has been used effectively in Connecticut now for years, and I don't see any justification for calling it unconstitutional.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: He continued: ''The ruling has already caused widespread confusion and consternation across the state, and if it is permitted to stand will send the wrong message to students regarding the importance of their out-of-school behavior.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: But some state officials believe the spirit of the law could still be salvaged even if the judge's ruling is upheld by the higher court.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''The law may have to be rewritten by the legislature and school districts may have to work a little harder to provide evidence to support their expulsion cases'' . . . ''and both of those things are not necessarily bad,'' said Mark Stapleton, chief of the state's Department of Education's Office of Legal and Government Affairs.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''I don't believe the law is unconstitutional and was surprised by the breadth of the judge's decision,'' said Mr. Stapleton.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''But because of this ruling school districts may have to change the way they develop their cases'' . . . ''they may have to do more homework to ensure that their case is stronger.''
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: Mr. Stapleton also says that if the Supreme Court upholds the lower court's ruling, the General Assembly could act swiftly to enact a similar law that is less vague.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: ''To put things into perspective, I believe that even in a worst-case scenario, a similar law could be worded so that it would pretty much guarantee local school boards the same authority as the present law,'' he said.
title: At Issue: Discipline Off School Grounds

text: By Robert Mcg. Thomas Jr.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: Anton Rosenberg, a storied sometime artist and occasional musician who embodied the Greenwich Village hipster ideal of 1950's cool to such a laid-back degree and with such determined detachment that he never amounted to much of anything, died on Feb. 14 at a hospital near his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 71 and best known as the model for the character Julian Alexander in Jack Kerouac's novel ''The Subterraneans.''
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: The cause was cancer, his family said.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: He was a painter of acknowledged talent, and he played the piano with such finesse that he jammed with Charlie Parker, Zoot Sims and other jazz luminaries of the day.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: But if Mr. Rosenberg never made a name for himself in either art or music -- or pushed himself to try -- there was a reason: once he had been viewed in his hipster glory, leaning languidly against a car parked in front of Fugazzi's bar on the Avenue of the Americas, there was simply nothing more he could do to enhance his reputation.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: For as Kerouac recognized, Mr. Rosenberg in his 20's, a thin, unshaven, quiet and strange young man of such dark good looks that he was frequently likened to the French actor Gerard Philipe, was the epitome of hip, an extreme esthetic that shunned enthusiasm, scorned ambition and ridiculed achievement.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: It was Kerouac's friend Allen Ginsberg who discovered Fugazzi's and its coterie of hipsters of such bedrock cool that he dubbed them the subterraneans, a term Kerouac adopted as the title of his book published in 1958.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: Like other Kerouac works, the book, which was written in 1953, is the most thinly disguised of fictions, one whose most striking deception was shifting its locale from New York to San Francisco to protect the publisher from any libel action by the very real Greenwich Village regulars who populated its pages under fictitious names. To Kerouac, they were cynosures of cool.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: ''They are hip without being slick,'' he wrote. ''They are intelligent without being corny, they are intellectual as hell and know all about Pound without being pretentious or talking too much about it, they are very quiet, they are very Christlike.''
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: As for Mr. Rosenberg, or Julian Alexander, as he was called, he was ''the angel of the subterraneans,'' a loving man of compelling gentleness, or as Kerouac put it: ''Julian Alexander certainly is Christlike.''
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: By the time he made the Greenwich Village scene, Mr. Rosenberg, a native of Brooklyn whose father was a wealthy industrialist, had served a year in the Army, studied briefly at the University of North Carolina and spent a year in Paris, ostensibly studying art on the G.I. Bill but in reality soaking up the Left Bank bohemian atmosphere and haunting the Cafe Flore and the Cafe Deux Magots with James Baldwin, Terry Southern and other incipient icons of American cool.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: Back in New York by 1950, Mr. Rosenberg opened a print shop on Christopher Street and plunged into the hip world centered on the San Remo at Bleecker and Macdougal Streets.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: He lived for a while in the East 11th Street tenement Ginsberg called Paradise Valley and had such an instinct for future chic that he was one of the first artists to move to an industrial loft in a bleak neighborhood below Canal Street years before it became the fashionable TriBeCa.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: In a different life, Mr. Rosenberg might have used the loft to turn out masterpieces. But as an ultimate hipster he had other priorities, which became apparent one famous Halloween night when the crew, alerted to a shipment from the Exotic Plant Company of Laredo, Tex., peeled off from the San Remo and congregated in the loft for an all-night peyote party cum jam session.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: Drugs, of course, were more than an accouterment of hip. They were its very essence. And while marijuana, then an exotic drug used only by jazz musicians, was universal among the stoned cool hipsters, it was heroin that set the subterraneans apart.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: Mr. Rosenberg, who appears as a character in William Burroughs's book ''Junkie,'' was an addict for most of his adult life, which might help explain why he never made a name for himself in art or music or held a regular job after his print shop failed in the 1960's.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: Fortunately, Mr. Rosenberg, whose survivors include his wife, Joan, and a brother, Ross, of Orlando, Fla., had the foresight to marry a schoolteacher so enamored of his charming, creative ways that she cheerfully supported the family while Mr. Rosenberg continued to paint, play music, amuse his friends and family. He also served as a surprisingly effective role model for his three sons: Shaun, a Manhattan restaurateur who owns Orson's on Second Avenue; Matthew, a computer consultant from the Bronx, and Jeremy, of Manhattan, a New York City police detective who specializes in drug enforcement.
title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71

text: IT seems like a very long time ago during the Edo Dynasty, I believe it was -- that I wrote that the 1998 Winter Games were now official because the Great Gretzky and the Mighty Kwan had arrived.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: Turns out I was barking up the wrong palm tree. (My guide book tells me there are palm trees right here in Nagano Prefecture. I never saw one, but maybe I was always sitting on the wrong side of a hellish number of press buses.)
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: The Mighty Kwan did not win a gold medal and the Great Gretzky did not win a medal at all, but their search for gold was surely a major theme in these dramatically skewed Winter Games -- the indoor games and the outdoor games, the downtown games and the mountain games.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: I did my best to cover these Games in my Florsheims on my own loopy theory that Gretzky and Kwan were the hot tickets, but I kept hearing reports of the Herminator, a human cannonball of a skier who won two gold medals. I never met the man. I was always on a bus.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: What I am trying to say, my brain numbed by the mysterious white anti-flu powder they dispense at the media center infirmary, is that the Winter Games now sprawl unglamorously for 16 very long days.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: What are we going to do with these Winter Games? I don't really care if CBS made a good investment in paying for all these lugers and bobsledders -- and being here, I didn't have to watch any of it -- but I do wonder if the Winter Games are going in the right direction.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: Tell me if I'm crazy, but isn't the appeal of the Winter Games rooted in a simpler time? When I hear names like Chamonix and St. Moritz and Lake Placid and Garmisch-Partenkirchen, I conjure up imagines of athletes in bulky sweaters twirling and flying outdoors in elegant ski resorts, far from the grime and bustle of civilization. Sonja Henie. Dick Button. Peggy Fleming. I actually think the Olympic movement still sells the Winter Games on that dated premise of elegance and simplicity.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: The Winter Games have got big and bloated as more nations, to say nothing of female athletes, have discovered the joy of whacking other people with sticks or flying through air with boards strapped to their feet. The Games now need thousands of technicians, system-support people, camera luggers, brutes wielding boom microphones. All of these people need rooms, need food, need transportation, need places to work. The Winter Games now need moderate-sized cities just to support the wretched foot soldiers who schlep from site to site so people in New York and Vancouver and Sydney and Tokyo and Berlin can watch in their appointed time zones.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: The Nagano Games were closer to the equator than Winter Games had been before. Sometimes there was too much snow up in the hills, but down here in Almost Heaven, West Nagano, the weather has been soupy and temperate enough to provide an ideal breeding ground for a bronchial flu that is sure to circle the globe as we hack and wheeze our way homeward. The endless buses of news media were its principal petri dish.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: I could write an entire column about the hospitality of the people in Nagano -- in fact, I'll do that tomorrow -- but the gracious locals could not control the weather. They could only shell out yen and more yen, as the Japanese economy went skittish, to build handsome new buildings to house corporate weasels from Olympic sponsors. ''I see the children of Japan feeling happy for the success of our athletes,'' said Taka Fukushima, a priest at Zenkoji Temple, who once lived in Michigan.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: Fukushima smiled at hearing the English colloquialism, ''white elephant,'' and suggested that it might be best to tear down some of the buildings, to save further taxes and maintenance.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: The Summer Games just might have become big and brawling, a potential drain on unsuspecting host cities. This year the International Olympic Committee included snowboarding in the Winter Games, and a Canadian gold medalist tested positive for a minuscule amount of marijuana. He insisted he contracted it by taking deep breaths around his buds at a party months ago. If the bloke were American, he could become President by telling stories like that with a straight face.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: The I.O.C. also imported a legion of 125 professional hockey players to represent their homelands. I take great delight in today's final game -- the Czech Republic against Russia for a mythical Alexander Dubcek Memorial Trophy -- while the Yanks and the Canadians are long gone with no medals at all.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: The downside to this deal with the devil is that a few loutish Yanks tore up their suite in the Athletes Village. You bring in surly millionaires for a midwinter sabbatical, and you take your chances. Did Dick Button ever trash a suite in St. Moritz or Oslo? I kind of doubt it.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: The Winter Games keep reaching. In four years, Salt Lake City will become the biggest city to be host to the Winter Games. Presumably, the Hessians from the National Hockey League will be back, and so will the snowboarders with their vapid smiles. The hosts are optimistic about providing an urbane base for the Winter Games, but then there are the long hauls up to the mountains. I can only wonder what kind of exotic 2002 Winter Games flu bug will spawn on those endless bus rides up and down the Wasatch Valley.
title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?

text: AFTER having so much trouble at the Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan, because of snow, rain and slush, the last thing CBS needed was a problem with a swoosh.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: But it got one. Critics questioned CBS's decision to have its announcers for the games, who work for the sports division, wear ski jackets prominently displaying the swoosh, the internationally recognized symbol of Nike, the giant sports equipment and clothing manufacturer.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: The criticism got more intense when it was discovered that CBS News correspondents, including Bob Simon, Harry Smith and Bill Geist, had worn the Nike-emblazoned jackets in reports taped before the games began. CBS News reacted quickly when it learned its correspondents were on the air advertising Nike, ordering that no news personnel wear the jackets.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: But the CBS Sports personnel have worn the swoosh-wear throughout the 18 days of the games. Clearly, the worlds of sports and news on television have different standards. CBS News now acknowledges it was a mistake to broadcast news reports featuring correspondents in clothes bearing a company's marketing logo. Jonathan Klein, the executive vice president of CBS News, said: ''We have standards that forbid this. It was really a no-brainer. Once we saw our people with the Nike logos on, it was pretty clear we had to make sure they didn't wear them anymore.''
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: But is there any problem at all with CBS Sports announcers displaying the Nike logo for hours each night?
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: Far from being defensive about the Nike tie-in, CBS Sports executives dismissed the criticism as cheap-shot tactics coming from critics out to pick on CBS for every move the network makes with these Olympics.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: ''There is not one real person out there who gives a darn about this so-called issue,'' said Leslie Anne Wade, the spokeswoman for CBS Sports. ''Absolutely no one would care if the news people hadn't worn the jackets.''
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: In the sports world, she said, this is a totally accepted practice. ''Everybody on television is wearing clothes supplied by somebody.''
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: She noted that the CBS host for the games, Jim Nantz, wore clothes supplied by Donna Karan, and the designer received an on-air credit every night. She also said that for the Olympics in 1992, CBS announcers wore clothes supplied by the company North Face, and in 1994 they wore clothes supplied by another apparel company, Columbia, both of which had their names spelled out on the CBS jackets.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: In addition, she said, announcers in other sports, like football on NBC and Fox, wear clothes provided by the company Pro Players. In all cases (except the Donna Karan sports jackets, of course) logos are visible on the jackets on the air.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: Indeed, one senior sports executive at a competing network conceded: ''This is completely routine. When you have these huge budgets for sports you look to save money any way you can. If somebody is going to give you clothes for free, you take them.''
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: And the practice is not confined to American television. Dave Mingey, a manager of corporate communications for Nike, pointed out that Eurosport, which broadcasts the games in Europe, has announcers wearing clothes from DeScent, a Japanese company. Even the head of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaranch, opened the games wearing a jacket emblazoned with a logo from Mizuno, another Japanese company.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: So is there any reason to single out CBS for wearing Nike on its sleeves?
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: At least one senior network executive, with long ties to sports negotiations, thinks so. ''When I saw the Nike symbol I was horrified,'' the executive said, speaking on condition of anonymity. He pointed out that unlike the other companies CBS was involved with, Nike is not simply a sports apparel company, but the biggest, most aggressive sports marketer in the world, with interests in sports equipment and associations with both athletes and teams from countries around the world.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: ''You can't equate these other companies with Nike,'' the executive said. ''Nike has its hands all over sports. You are inevitably going to run into stories you have to cover where Nike's self-interest is involved.''
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: An example that was widely discussed in the television industry during the games was a CBS report on a cross-country skier from Kenya, Philip Boit. The report was a typically moving Olympic story -- a distance runner who had transformed himself into a skier to get to the Olympics. Mr. Boit spent two winters training with the Finnish team. What the report did not say was that Nike paid for Mr. Boit's room and board in Finland. Nike has a partnership with the Kenyan Olympic Committee.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: Mr. Mingey emphasized that Nike had nothing to do with the CBS report on Mr. Boit. He finished last in his race, but five other racers quit before they finished and the champion, Bjorn Dahlie of Norway, embraced Mr. Boit at the finish line, calling him a champion as well. (Mr. Dahlie is not a Nike athlete.)
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: Mr. Mingey described the CBS deal as a ''simple financial transaction -- we supplied clothes in exchange for commercial time during the games.'' He added that Nike had targeted Nagano as a place to launch a push into winter sports and winter sports equipment.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: That push made impact in several areas during the Olympics. Beyond the Boit story, Mr. Mingey noted that Nike had other involvements with athletes who made news at the games.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: Nike lent support to Picabo Street, the gold medal-winning American skier, when she was recovering from a devastating knee injury. She even moved to Portland, where Nike has its headquarters, to train with a Nike-supplied specialist at the Nike Bo Jackson Fitness Center.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: Mr. Mingey added that Chris Witty won two speed-skating medals on new clap skates manufactured and provided by Nike. And Nike was also a sponsor, he said, of the Canadian Snow Boarding team, one of whose members made news at the games when he briefly lost his gold medal because traces of marijuana turned up in his blood.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: CBS noted none of these connections in its reporting, which Mr. Mingey said was evidence that Nike was not trying to influence CBS's coverage by supplying a pile of jackets.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: But a better question might be whether CBS might ever have felt constrained to leave Nike out of potentially controversial stories because of its Nike deal.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: Ms. Wade, of CBS Sports, said that was nonsense. ''I don't think there is anyone who could name a single sport that was covered any differently because of this deal.''
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: But would such a question even come up if CBS had not been wearing the logo of a company with such broad influence in sports? While it is apparently common for network sports divisions to wear clothes on the air with corporate logos in exchange for commercial support, Nike may be, as some critics suggest, a different animal.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: The connections Nike had with athletes in Nagano seem to prove that when you get in bed with Nike, it may get awfully crowded -- and that increases the chances of getting kicked.
title: Ideas & Trends: Is That a Logo on Your Pocket?; No, It's Just for the Goddess of Victory

text: So George Vecsey (column, Feb. 13) thinks it is O.K. for an Olympic champion to have smoked marijuana, by his own admission, as recently as 10 months ago, to have friends who smoke it and to have attended a going-away party where it was smoked, just before the Olympics.
title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; Marijuana Generation

text: Last time I checked, marijuana was illegal. And rightly so, despite the fact that we now have two generations compromised by ''experimenting'' with drugs and a President who ''did not inhale.''
title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; Marijuana Generation

text: White Plains, N.Y., Feb. 17, 1998
title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; Marijuana Generation

text: As an athlete who was subject to drug screening, I found George Vecsey too cavalier on Ross Rebagliati (column, Feb. 13). The rules on drugs are intended to prevent an unfair advantage and to protect the health of vulnerable athletes. Banning an athlete from smoking marijuana before careering down a mountain at high speed makes sense. This is true for other sports that require the agility and clear mind that drugs hamper.
title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; A Safety Issue

text: Clarifying a zero-tolerance policy is necessary. To not do so because marijuana is part of the ''dude'' character of the sport, as Mr. Vecsey suggests, is dangerous.
title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; A Safety Issue

text: In his otherwise reasoned column on Ross Rebagliati (Sports of The Times, Feb. 13), George Vecsey urges the International Olympic Committee and its member federations to ''formulate a rational policy toward marijuana.'' Good idea, but I rather doubt that the I.O.C. will have any better luck than our own Federal Government.
title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; In Search of Rationality

text: Ventura, Calif., Feb. 17, 1998
title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; In Search of Rationality

text: A new salary cap and a new general manager have not changed the Giants' basic operating principle when it comes to dealing with its young, most promising players.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Yesterday, the Giants locked up the All-Pro linebacker Jessie Armstead through the 2002 season, restructuring and extending the contract of the team's top defensive player with a five-year deal worth $15 million. The contract had four years remaining.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: The new pact doubles his salary and brings Armstead's pay more in line with the team's other highly paid defensive players, cornerback Jason Sehorn and defensive end Michael Strahan. The deal is most likely structured to give the Giants some cap relief this year.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: ''This disproves the myth that you have to be a free agent to get the contract you deserve,'' Armstead's agent, Drew Rosenhaus, said. ''Here's a guy who overperformed, and the Giants just ripped up his contract and gave him a new one.''
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Since Armstead is the core of the defense and the most dominant personality in the Giants' locker room, it also made good business sense to get the 27-year-old under contract for as many years as possible -- especially with salaries expected to escalate within a ballooning salary cap in years to come.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: ''He deserves to be rewarded,'' General Manager Ernie Accorsi said. ''He isn't the type of player to ever be satisfied.''
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Armstead led the Giants with a team-record 134 tackles last season and had 2 interceptions, one that he returned for a touchdown.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: ''We're a team headed in the right direction,'' Armstead said. ''And I'm glad I'm going to be a part of that.'' BILL PENNINGTON
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Packers Lose Evans To Lucrative Offer
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: The Carolina Panthers lured Doug Evans from the Green Bay Packers yesterday with a five-year, $22.5 million contract that puts him among the National Football League's highest-paid cornerbacks.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: ''We feel this will give us one of the best coverage combinations in the league,'' Coach Dom Capers said of teaming Evans with Eric Davis, who was voted to the Pro Bowl in two of the past three seasons.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Evans, 27, has yet to be voted to a Pro Bowl. His contract, which includes a signing bonus of $7.5 million, will put him in the average annual salary neighborhood with Dallas's Deion Sanders and Atlanta's Ray Buchanan. (AP)
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Green Bay Packers running back Travis Jervey faces a March 10 court date following his arrest on charges of speeding and possession of marijuana.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Jervey, 25, a Pro Bowl selection as a special teams player, was taken to the Charleston County jail in South Carolina Tuesday night after the police said they found marijuana during a traffic stop. He left about an hour later after posting a $435 bond, authorities said. (AP)
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Burris's New Deal: 5 Years, $20 Million
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: The Indianapolis Colts signed cornerback Jeff Burris yesterday, apparently making him the second-highest-paid defensive back in N.F.L.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Burris, a 1994 first-round draft pick by the Buffalo Bills (27th over all), agreed to a $20 million, five-year contract, news reports said. The deal included a $5 million signing bonus.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Burris, a former all-American from Notre Dame, earned $647,500 last season with Buffalo. (AP)
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: Defensive end Jeff Lageman, one of the first free agents signed by the Jacksonville Jaguars, re-signed with the team. A 30-year-old former Jets first-round pick, Lageman has played in 121 games and has 47 career sacks. In three years with Jacksonville, he has started 39 games and recorded 12.5 sacks. . . . The Pittsburgh Steelers, who have made a habit of losing players to free agency, re-signed nose tackle Joel Steed, the key to their defense, to a four-year, $17 million deal, making him their highest-paid player. Steed made $1.2 million last year. . . . Defensive tackle Dan Owens signed with the Detroit Lions, rejoining the team he left two years ago after signing with the Atlanta Falcons. Terms were not disclosed. Owens had a career-high 8 sacks and 69 tackles last season, starting 15 games for the Falcons.
title: A Longer and Sweeter Contract for Armstead

text: They have canceled John Hall Day, which was scheduled for Saturday at Port Charlotte High School in Florida.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: Hall, the place-kicker who was one of the Jets' surprises last year as a rookie, was arrested on Monday night in North Port, Fla., about 30 miles south of Sarasota, and charged with possession of marijuana and drug paraphernalia.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: Lieut. Kevin Sullivan of the North Port police said Hall's car was stopped when a police officer, checking the license plate, noted that it did not belong on the car Hall was driving. He was test-driving a 1990 Ford Bronco, but the plates belonged to a 1984 BMW, Hall's car.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: According to the police report, Hall was found with five grams of marijuana -- about one-sixth of an ounce -- and a pipe that had ''burnt residue.'' According to the report, Hall admitted he had been smoking marijuana earlier in the evening.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: He was arrested and released on $250 bail. His arraignment will be on March 13.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: Jets Coach Bill Parcells would not comment on the arrest, nor would the National Football League.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: But the league's policy on such incidents is clear: whenever a player is involved in any situation involving a banned substance, including marijuana -- whether or not he is convicted -- it triggers an evaluation. The incident will very likely result in Hall's entering some sort of league-mandated program.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: Hall was arrested under the most serious misdemeanor level listed in Florida. But because he has no prior record, if he is convicted he will most likely have to serve community service and attend counseling and can eventually have the incident expunged from his record.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: Still, the high school will not be retiring Hall's No. 22 this weekend. The official announcement from the school was that ''a scheduling conflict'' created the postponement.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: Elliott Says Line Can Improve
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: The Jets can do even better than last year's 9-7 record, if they pick up some solid offensive linemen, John (Jumbo) Elliott, the left tackle, said yesterday.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: ''I think our coaches saw what the Broncos could do in the Super Bowl behind a line that wasn't that great, but that played smash-mouth football,'' Elliott said after another day of rehabilitation. He tore an Achilles' tendon in Game 13 against Buffalo and has since spent five or six days a week getting ready to come back. He says he is about ready to play.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: As for improvement in the Jets' line, Elliott believes it can come up the middle, at the center and guard positions -- the areas the Jets are concentrating on among free agents.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: ''I know we took a lot of blame for the sacks,'' Elliott said. ''But when a quarterback plays a year and a half and takes 30 sacks he's responsible for, that doesn't help the team.''
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: Neil O'Donnell was sacked 45 times last year while attempting 460 passes. In 1996, O'Donnell also suffered about 1 sack for every 10 passes when he was dumped 18 times while throwing 188 passes. ''The biggest thing now is to get the quarterback situation intact,'' Elliott said.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: O'Donnell was replaced as the starter by Glenn Foley in midseason last year, but Foley then got hurt. The quarterback situation remains unclear. A $2.75 million advance on next season's salary is due to O'Donnell on Friday, but the Jets are getting an extension from O'Donnell and his agent, Leigh Steinberg. The sides are working on restructuring the deal in case O'Donnell does return.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: And Elliott? ''I'll start the season, without a doubt,'' said the 300-pounder, who will be 33 years old when it begins.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: All's Quiet on Free-Agent Front
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: Whatever the Jets are doing about free agents, it is hush-hush. They have told the agents of players they are interested in not to mention whether their players are coming in for tryouts or interviews, or even whether they have had contact with the Jets.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: But an N.F.L. source familiar with the Eagles and their well-regarded guard, Joe Panos, said yesterday that the Jets are pursuing him, or at least expressing interest. Panos's agent, Ralph Cindrich, said he had ''a great meeting'' with the Jets yesterday and was hopeful that the Jets would make an offer.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: This much is clear. The Jets are working harder to try to fix up their offensive line before they figure out whom it will be blocking for.
title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges

text: During the cold war, the Berlin Film Festival had loads of money and a strong political mission. Today it is hard up and struggling to find a new identity. Not that it has many options. At the world's main film festivals, business has long since supplanted art or even politics as the main concern. Berlin, it seems, has had little choice but to go commercial.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: As in recent years, the big American studios have again used Berlin as a European showcase for movies already released in the United States, among them ''Good Will Hunting,'' ''The Boxer,'' ''Jackie Brown,'' ''Wag the Dog'' and ''The Gingerbread Man.'' The festival provides the films with a good deal of free publicity, but they will all soon be in theaters here.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: But when it comes to finding new films with box office potential, the shadow of Cannes in May already hovers over Berlin in February. A good many producers prefer to gamble on their movies being picked for Cannes rather than to accept a slot in Berlin's official competition. Until this year, Italian films were even boycotting Berlin to favor the summer film festival in Venice.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: Still, at this 48th Berlinale, which closes on Sunday with the screening of Peter Hewitt's new ''Sliding Doors,'' at least three new films have been enthusiastically received by critics and Berlin audiences and seem likely contenders for the festival's Golden Bear awards this weekend: the Coen brothers' latest movie, ''The Big Lebowski''; Neil Jordan's adaptation of the Irish novel ''The Butcher Boy'' and Walter Salles's ''Central Station'' from Brazil.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: Set in Los Angeles in the early 1990's, ''The Big Lebowski'' is a Raymond Chandler-inspired comedy of errors that plunges a chronically lazy marijuana smoker who calls himself the Dude (Jeff Bridges) and his manic Vietnam veteran pal Walter (John Goodman) into a tale of kidnapping, extortion, double-crossing and seduction when they would both prefer to be bowling with their friend Donny (Steve Buscemi).
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: Thanks to ''Barton Fink'' and ''Fargo,'' Joel and Ethan Coen seem to be fast acquiring the cult adulation previously reserved in Europe for Woody Allen. And the proof was the most crowded post-screening news conference of the festival so far. Since the brothers are not famous talkers, however, the questions were often longer than the answers. Asked about one scene that seemed to have no rhyme nor reason, Joel Coen, the film's director, explained that it was ''what we call a 'Kafka break.' '' And to the question of whether the movie had any purpose beyond laughing at Nazis and ''Hispanic pederasts'' (a reference to a character played by John Turturro), he paused at length and then offered, ''I guess you hit the nail on the head.''
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: ''The Butcher Boy,'' a dramatic switch for Mr. Jordan after ''Michael Collins,'' is also full of humor though it tells a darker story, of a 12-year-old boy growing up in a small Irish town in the early 1960's. Francie Brady, played by Eamonn Owens, lives in a fantasy world peopled by the Lone Ranger and the Virgin Mary (Sinead O'Connor). When this world is disturbed by a meddling neighbor, Mrs. Nugent (Fiona Shaw), Francie goes from being naughty to seriously nasty.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: The film, in which Stephen Rea plays Francie's drunken father and provides Francie's own voice recounting the story 20 years later, is remarkably faithful to the novel, which was a finalist for Britain's Booker Prize in 1992. ''The book is one of those extraordinary books that is so local that it is not even Irish,'' Mr. Jordan said. ''I just wanted to show the series of disasters that occur to this boy and lead his mind to becoming unhinged.''
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: In picking Eamonn Owens for the challenging role of Francie, Mr. Jordan said he followed his belief that ''if you cast a child, you're better off casting one who has done no acting.''
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: Mr. Salles belatedly reached the same conclusion in ''Central Station,'' auditioning some 1,500 boys before picking Vinicius de Oliveira, a 10-year-old shoeshine boy in Rio de Janeiro, to play one of the two lead roles, Josue.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: In the movie, which was well received at this year's Sundance Film Festival, Josue sees his mother killed by a bus outside Rio's main railroad station. Homeless and destitute, he is befriended by Dora (Fernanda Montenegro), a retired schoolteacher who now writes letters dictated to her by illiterates passing through the station (albeit posting only those of which she approves). Eventually, the two set off by bus for Brazil's impoverished northeast in search of Josue's father.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: ''Central Station'' stands out for its realistic depiction of the lives of ordinary Brazilians. It also offers evidence of a rebirth of Brazil's movie industry thanks to new investment incentives. Last year's Berlinale presented Bruno Barreto's ''Four Days in September,'' which was nominated last week for an Oscar for best foreign-language film.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: In contrast, with the exception of ''The Butcher Boy,'' Europe's offerings were modest here this year. Nick Hurran's ''Girls' Night'' is a tears-and-laughter story of two middle-aged working-class British women, played by Branda Blethyn and Julie Walters, who share their bingo winnings and head off to Las Vegas for a final fling after one of them is diagnosed with terminal cancer.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: For the official competition, Germany offered only ''The Big Mambo,'' a lighthearted first movie by the actor Michael Gwisdek in which he and his wife, Corinna Harfouch, star as an actor and actress trying to make their first movie. Jeroen Krabbe, a well-known Dutch actor, chose to make his first film, ''Left Luggage,'' in English, although it is set in Antwerp's Jewish community.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: But after Jacques Doillon's perennial French love triangle, ''Trop (Peu) d'Amour,'' provoked sniggers and yawns from one festival audience, it took the veteran French director Alain Resnais to show that life remains in the European movie industry. In ''On Connait la Chanson'' (''Same Old Song''), his trick is simple but effective: in a light tale of love and intrigue, his characters keep breaking out in song, lip-synching popular French songs with straight faces to hilarious effect.
title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission

text: By Paul Moor, International Herald Tribune
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: On opening night of Jonathan Miller's production of Verdi's "Falstaff" at the Staatsoper, its conductor, Claudio Abbado, got an ovation he will not soon forget from an audience obviously regretful to see him go.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: Shortly before the performance, he had dropped a bombshell, offhandedly mentioning in a tabloid interview his intention not to extend his contract as conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic beyond the year 2002 — ostensibly to have more time for "reading, sailing and skiing."
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: His debut appearance conducting at the Staatsoper provided Berliners their first opportunity to express their affection and show how they feel about that.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: Musicians worldwide tend to rate the Berlin Philharmonic the world's best, making its conductorship the ultimate accolade. Abbado's predecessor, Herbert von Karajan, had a lifetime contract; before him, the legendary Wilhelm Furtwaengler died in office.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: The Abbado era has brought Berlin the benefit of exceptionally rich cross-pollination: Abbado's band frequently welcomes the Staatsoper's music director, Daniel Barenboim, as guest conductor, and Barenboim's friendly reciprocation has brought us a "Falstaff" worthy of any opera house anywhere.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: Miller's psychological concept departs strikingly from the customary view of this geriatric miracle (Verdi composed it at 80) as a leering Anglo-Italian variation on French bedroom farce. This Falstaff, in fact, evokes Shylock's "If you prick us, do we not bleed?" The fat, fatuous old goat's eventual humiliation and degradation make him more a figure of compassion than fun. The merry wives' malicious conspiracy derives more from unconventional realism than from comic ribaldry.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: Opening night began with a disheartening announcement: Ruggero Raimondi, eagerly anticipated as Falstaff, would save the premiere in spite of severe indisposition. For a man indisposed, he came through with a remarkable performance, vocally as well as dramatically.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: He had superlative support: Dorothea Roeschmann (visually and vocally ravishing as Nanetta), Marjana Lipovsek (Dame Quickly, more restrained than customary), Soile Isokoski (Alice), Lucio Gallo (Ford), Marcelo Alvarez (Fenton, dramatically a bit pallid), with Panza-like Anthony Mee and the towering Andrea Silvestrelli a Mutt and Jeff version of Bardolfo and Pistola.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: Herbert Kapplmueller's sets rang changes on M.C. Escher's perspective trickery, pushing much of the action almost into the orchestra pit. Clare Mitchell's costumes reached their pinnacle in the randy old popinjay's tatterdemalion but still cocky finery when he struts out a-courting.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: By post-performance consensus, the orchestra (known during its concert series as the Berliner Staatskapelle) played as rarely before, with transparency and pinpoint accuracy recalling what Toscanini got out of his super-virtuoso NBC Symphony. The players got a thoroughly deserved ovation when they appeared, in full force, for their curtain call.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: BUT the most thunderous ovation of all went to Abbado, movingly showing him how much his Berlin fans hate to lose him. Now starts the customary international conductors' game of musical chairs. Abbado's stewardship has substantially reduced the average age of the Philharmonic. Names of appositely younger conductors bandied about and already in good standing with those finicky men and women who choose their boss: Metzmacher, Nagano, Pappano, Rattle, Salonen, Thielemann and Welser-Moest.
title: And a Thunderous Ovation for Abbado in Berlin : Rare Compassion for 'Falstaff'

text: The decision to let Ross Rebagliati keep his gold medal despite testing positive for marijuana was the right call (Sports pages, Feb. 13). Had the arbitration panel ruled against Mr. Rebagliati and upheld the International Olympic Committee, a message would have gone out to youngsters that marijuana is considered a performance-enhancing substance by the Olympics. In the absence of any proof that its use enhances performance, athletes need not be tested for it in the first place.
title: The Return of the Gold

text: Northampton, Mass., Feb. 13, 1998
title: The Return of the Gold

text: It was hardly a crime to attract much attention in a hard-bitten urban environment. Four teen-agers high on drugs and alcohol encountered two brothers, both around 30 and both drunk, in a tough neighborhood of St. Louis one November night in 1986.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Name-calling, quarreling and a rumble ensued. Three of the youths took off with a few stolen dollars. Reginald L. Powell, at 18 the eldest of the attackers, stayed behind to finish off the victims with a knife.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: He was arrested the next day, tried in March 1988, found guilty of first-degree murder and sentenced to death. He is scheduled to die by lethal injection on Feb. 25 at Missouri's maximum security prison at Potosi.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: But behind this seemingly open-and-shut case of murder and justice lies a remarkable story that supporters of Mr. Powell believe qualifies him for clemency and commutation of the sentence to life without parole.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: His lawyer, a woman then 35 years old, became emotionally involved with Mr. Powell, who is mildly retarded, while she was preparing for the trial. Later, she had sexual relations with him in a holding cell at the state circuit court building in St. Louis.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: His present lawyer, Bruce D. Livingston, a Federal public defender, says this emotional involvement contributed to mistakes that the lawyer made in presenting the case, among them not having him plead guilty in exchange for a life sentence and not putting him on the stand.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: The lawyer, Mary Ann Marxkors, subsequently gave up law, but she has continued to see Mr. Powell in prison. Ms. Marxkors does not dispute the criticism and argues that in her efforts to help Mr. Powell she fell into a situation beyond her control.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''It was my first death-penalty case, and I spent a lot of time with him to gain his trust,'' Ms. Marxkors said in a tearful telephone interview from her home in St. Louis. ''I came to know a lot about where he came from, what his life had been. Yet, he was always caring toward me.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''It was such an intense sort of thing,'' Ms. Marxkors, who was a state public defender, said of the trial period. ''It became physical when the judge told me he was going to sentence Reggie to death. I went and told him, and I cried and he kissed me, and we ended up making love.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: At the next hearing, when the sentence was formally issued, they again made love in the holding room. ''It was several months before I began to ask myself, 'What the hell am I doing?' '' Ms. Marxkors said.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Mr. Powell, now 29, said in a telephone interview from the prison that he considered his death sentence unfair because his lawyer ''didn't have the skills to get me a life sentence.'' But he said they remain friends and that she visits him often.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''We are human,'' he said, ''so we all make mistakes. Unfortunately, this might cost me my life. But we don't hardly talk about what's going to happen to me.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Ms. Marxkors added: ''I continue to see him, to write to him, to talk to him. I love him.'' She said she will be there on his execution night, if he wants her to be.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Both Mr. Livingston and Ms. Marxkors said the only hope for Mr. Powell now is that Gov. Mel Carnahan, a Democrat, will respond to Mr. Livingston's clemency petition by commuting the sentence or granting a stay of execution.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: The United States Supreme Court refused in January to accept the case for review, which Mr. Livingston said ended all judicial possibilities.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea
