text: Mr. Livingston, who became Mr. Powell's lawyer in 1995 as the case was going into the Federal appeals process, said that because Mr. Powell is mentally slow and has had little support from his own destitute family -- his mother and grandmother are dead -- he became unduly dependent on Ms. Marxkors, one of the few people to show long-term interest in him.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Mr. Livingston also said he was outraged that a well-educated woman of a mature age could not better handle her dealings with a vulnerable young man who ''doesn't have a real comprehension of the mistakes she made.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Mr. Livingston also emphasized Mr. Powell's difficult childhood. ''He was born to a 14-year-old mother,'' Mr. Livingston said. ''His grandmother, who was 30, wouldn't go to the hospital for his birth because the bars were still open.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: As a child, Mr. Powell was given marijuana even before he became a teen-ager and eventually was placed in a state home for boys ''in response to the impassioned plea of a school principal,'' Mr. Livingston added.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''But he was put out a year later because of overcrowding,'' Mr. Livingston said. ''He changed schools 16 times.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Ms. Marxkors's mental health has also played a role in the case. She said that she has been in therapy off and on for about 15 years but was not in therapy at the time of the trial. Mr. Livingston said that in the clemency petition he had tried ''to make a persuasive case that this woman is troubled.'' He said that the petition was accompanied by a videotape of her talking with an Illinois state psychiatrist.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''A stack of amazing letters from her was confiscated from Reggie's death-row cell,'' Mr. Livingston said. ''They varied in tone from that of a junior high school romance to the smutty and obscene things you might read in Penthouse or some other magazine.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: It was the discovery of those letters by prison authorities in 1988 that set off the chain of events surrounding Ms. Marxkors.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''Love and emotions can be so powerful,'' Ms. Marxkors said in her defense. ''Anyone can be blinded. The initial physical part was very emotional and driven by vulnerability and this shared thing.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''It certainly wasn't anything I ever planned.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Ms. Marxkors was warned by the bar association that her conduct was ''inappropriate,'' but she was not formally admonished or disbarred.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Now working with troubled children while studying for a master's degree in social work, Mrs. Marxkors said she realized that there was a great gap in the way she saw Mr. Powell and his crime and the way the jury and judge looked at him and the crime.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: She said she approached the case from the position that the two killings were not premeditated and that conviction would be for manslaughter, not first-degree murder.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''When I first interviewed him and noticed his retardation I thought that he couldn't even premeditate going to the bathroom,'' she said.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: She also said it was not Mr. Powell who brought the knife that night, but another youth who handed it to Mr. Powell at some point in the fight, further suggesting the absence of premeditation.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Ms. Marxkors said she had not put him on the stand to testify in his own behalf and plead remorse for the killings because she had used his mental impairment as an important aspect of her defense and feared that while on the stand he might not seem as impaired as he was.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''Reggie would talk about wanting to testify,'' she added, ''but it wasn't the way I had planned to do it, so I pooh-poohed that idea. I didn't even tell him he had a right to testify.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: She said she had not tried to plea bargain for a lesser sentence because the state delayed a considerable time before making an offer and when it was made, it was for four consecutive life sentences. She opposed the offer, believing that Mr. Powell would be convicted only of manslaughter, which would have resulted in a lesser sentence.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''Even the prosecutor told me at one point not to worry so much because they would never kill this kid,'' she recalled.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Mr. Livingston said the state public defender who took over the case after the trial challenged the effectiveness of her representation. But a number of procedural barriers at both the state and Federal level had prevented consideration of the merits of the case in the appeals process, Mr. Livingston said.
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: ''The U.S. Supreme Court,'' he added, ''sees its job as correcting the mistakes of the state courts. But if lawyers make mistakes in presenting information to state courts, that does not get reviewed.''
title: Lawyer-Client Intimacy Prompts Death Row Plea

text: Re ''These Games Are a Lesson in Chemistry'' (Sports of The Times, Feb. 12): The restoration of the gold medal to the Canadian snowboarder Ross Rebagliati, who had been found to have 17.8 nanograms of marijuana traces in his system when 15 is the legal limit, is not so much a lesson in chemistry as in how fast science is outstripping the ability of nonscientists to comprehend the repercussions of the new tools available to them.
title: The Return of the Gold

text: At a time when the eating of a poppyseed roll can put a measurable quantity of opiates in your system, the International Olympic Committee has to decide the level at which drugs are ''performance-enhancing'' at the time of the performance as well as the acceptable levels of others, like steroids, that might be used to attain a superhuman performance.
title: The Return of the Gold

text: The writer is an assistant professor of chemistry, Bronx Community College.
title: The Return of the Gold

text: Warning: These Olympics can cause severe disorientation, prompting such existential questions as ''When an event is delayed, and the telecast of that delay is delayed, does it all become 'live'?''
title: February 8-14; The Olympics: Tales of the Tape

text: Take Thursday night. TV viewers knew the men's downhill skiing had been delayed for days by winter weather (what do they expect in winter?). But there, on prime time, it was delayed again. The previous night, after endless CBS teasing, viewers finally saw Picabo Street win the super giant slalom -- a victory they'd already read about in the morning paper. So this ''delay'' in the men's downhill had to be another tease, right? No, this time it was live.
title: February 8-14; The Olympics: Tales of the Tape

text: Ross Rebagliati of Canada was stripped of his snowboarding gold medal for testing positive for marijuana, though the amount involved was far less than smoking a single joint. Then, after 32 hours, the forces of forgiveness provided an unscheduled event: The return of Rebagliati's medal. HUBERT B. HERRING
title: February 8-14; The Olympics: Tales of the Tape

text: As soon as golf's leading logos, Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, stepped up to the moral tee, the case of Casey Martin got interesting. Until then, it just seemed like a silly squabble over using a cart during the later rounds of tournament play.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: Sure he should use a cart, but who knew the subtext? Maybe country-club owners were concerned about their grass; maybe golfers who walked fast or carried their own clubs would want to be rewarded with strokes; maybe there was fear that the greens would be invaded by a new generation of pot-smoking turf-boarders and sand-lugers.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: So there was relief last week when a Federal judge, citing the Americans With Disabilities Act, ordered the PGA Tour to allow Martin his cart; the circulatory ailment that has made walking painful, dangerous and sometimes impossible was thus ruled an official handicap. The PGA said it would appeal, but then, noting public opinion, made a show of welcoming Martin back to the Tour until the case was in court again. Palmer, in interviews, stepped back, too, perhaps concerned about his image.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: But it was too late to erase that picture of Palmer and Nicklaus speaking up for the status quo, their status quo. Among the rare other recent events that have brought them together was an ad for an 18-karat gold Rolex watch.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: Their professional and personal rivalry is legendary. Arnie was more important and more beloved, but Jack was better. I do believe the story of Arnie walking up to people wearing Nicklaus's polo shirts, pinching the embroidered golden bear and the flesh underneath, and saying, ''Whatcha doin' wearing that pig on your shirt?''
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: Over the years, as blacks and women were discriminated against in almost every amen corner of golf, one sometimes wondered what might happen if Arnie and Jack stood up in their green blazers and complained, even mildly. What a fantasy; not only were they profiting from the status quo, they hardly ever did anything in concert, that is, until they came together to discriminate against disabled people.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: That's what this is about. With the same logic that offers special parking to the handicapped and allows blind people to bring a dog into a no-animal zone, Martin, so long as he is deemed disabled and he qualifies for the event, legally deserves a cart. It's about as vivid an example of ''leveling the playing field'' as you will find. All the other chatter, about walking, about stamina, about golf as an athletic contest, is easily dismissed by the use of carts in the qualifying rounds and in Senior Tour events, and by the fact that walking or carrying one's own clubs does not seem to be part of the official scoring.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: Will others want carts? Why not? Should they get them? Only if they qualify for golf's two definitions of handicap -- shooting well enough and being disabled.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: Casey Martin may end up a far more lasting symbol than Tiger Woods, so heavily, hilariously, marketed as golf's proof of multiculturalism. The Martin case will become an important one in the blooming field of sports ethics (I've been invited to two university-sponsored sports ethics conferences, and I'll go if they show me the money). Sports ethics is eventually going to be as hot as medical ethics and business ethics and for much the same reason -- unless health care, corporate policy and sports create moral climates for themselves, the real world will try to regulate them, perhaps at cost to autonomy and the bottom line.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: Keeping Casey Martin out, like judging Latrell Sprewell or flip-flopping on a snowboarder's Olympic medal, are all examples of SportsWorld making, breaking and bending rules for its own profit, often in defiance of the real world's rules, certainly flouting the rules of fair play.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: There is a reason sports has lost much of the moral facade with which it helped sell itself through most of the century. No one believes there is a moral center there anymore. But sports is emblematic of the good times in America right now, and perhaps the noise of the appreciative crowd helps drown out the Cassandras of health care and education.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: Sprewell should have been charged with criminal assault and taken to the hoop of the justice system. Was the National Basketball Association afraid of what we would learn about its inner workings in an open court of law, especially now when criminal trials are TV's real wide world of sports? Did the Olympics have a silly drug policy that was violated, or did it reverse itself on stripping Ross Rebagliati of his gold medal because it was afraid of alienating a new youth audience?
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: That new audience, younger and less frightened of people who may be different, might just tune in to those interminable TV weekend tournaments (how you watch them without marijuana beats me) to see Casey Martin drive the fairways before he drives the ball.
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: Then the real race will begin. Who gets to market the new and improved Handi-Cart for disabled golfers? Can Nike do it? Or, will the legendary logos join forces again to sell the Lexus Course-Cruiser bearing Jack's golden bear under Arnie's umbrella?
title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey

text: The juxtaposition may be unintentional, but the promotional spots for the Daytona 500 stock car race that CBS has been running throughout its coverage of the Winter Olympics have an uncanny similarity to many of the events in Nagano. Both are filled with crashes and collisions and the anxiety that someone is going to ruin a lifetime of training by making a disqualifying mistake.
title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano

text: That may not provide the noblest of reasons to watch the Olympic competition, but after a week of viewing it is clear that the potential for crushing failure is one of the things that draws viewers to what can only be described as a collection of some of the world's oddest sports.
title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano

text: CBS, eager to exploit any chance to elevate its anemic ratings for the Nagano Games, has sometimes wallowed in accidental violence. Cameras paused for agonizing minutes on the Dutch speed skater Erben Wennemars, who separated his shoulder in a collision in the 500-meter race. His screaming and writhing were too much to bear, but CBS stayed with the scene as trainers pinned the skater to the floor and tried to snap his shoulder into place.
title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano

text: Bodies seemed to be flying everywhere, from cartwheeling wipeouts during the men's downhill to falling figure skaters. Athletic brilliance is the signature of all the events, but the fact that every sport in Nagano is contested on a frozen surface makes the likelihood of calamity and disappointment much higher than in the Summer Games.
title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano

text: Figure skating, particularly after the Tonya Harding-Nancy Kerrigan confrontation four years ago, remains the most popular attraction for American viewers, so much so that CBS minimized live broadcasts of several events to show every phase of the figure skating competition. The women's round next week, with the possibility of an American sweep, promises to be one of the memorable moments of these Games. If would be a relief if Scott Hamilton, the CBS broadcaster and former gold medalist, didn't groan at every fall.
title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano

text: Still, there has been plenty of time for newfangled sports, like freestyle skiing and snowboarding, the latter a new Olympic entry. If the competition looked suspiciously like a high-octane version of the teen-age stunts now commonly encountered on American ski slopes, that seemed to be the point. The sport is a cross between skateboarding and surfing on snow, and only slightly less incongruous as an Olympic event than ultimate Frisbee would be if introduced at the Summer Games.
title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano

text: The contestants, who clearly would be more at home at a keg party than a champagne reception, cut a swaggering figure in Nagano. One of them, the Canadian Ross Rebagliati, almost lost his gold medal in the snowboarding giant slalom after testing positive for marijuana traces. In the absence of clear regulations about marijuana use at the Olympics, Mr. Rebagliati was sensibly allowed to keep his medal in the end. But his reverse-Clinton defense -- he inhaled, but didn't smoke -- deserved a separate medal for cheekiness.
title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano

text: As long as the Nagano Games last, Americans eager for a respite from the twin perils of Monica Lewinsky and Saddam Hussein don't have to go see ''Titanic'' for the 14th time. But they shouldn't turn to the Olympics for sweetness and light. The sporting equivalent of the Titanic sinking can happen any minute. Just keep an eye on large hill ski-jumping.
title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano

text: Pledging to ''live and to share the fundamental values that my parents instilled in me,'' David Satcher, the son of poor farmers from rural Alabama who grew up to become one of the nation's most prominent doctors, was sworn in at the White House today and became the first Surgeon General in more than three years.
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: ''There's no doubt,'' Vice President Al Gore said as President Clinton and Dr. Satcher's family looked on, ''that from today forward, all Americans will truly be able to say that the doctor is in.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: After the Vice President had administered the oath in the Oval Office, Dr. Satcher, who until today was director of the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said, ''It is a privilege to have this opportunity to give back to America what America has given me.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: The ceremony came on the heels of a bitter confirmation battle in which conservative senators led by John Ashcroft, Republican of Missouri, attacked Dr. Satcher for opposing a ban on ''partial birth abortion'' that did not provide an exception to protect a pregnant woman's health. A bipartisan coalition nonetheless won Senate confirmation for the nominee on Tuesday, and in his remarks today Dr. Satcher thanked the senators who had supported him.
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: ''I want to especially applaud the Senate for conducting such a lively and healthy debate,'' he said, drawing laughter. ''I feel good about that.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: Dr. Satcher had earlier sailed through his confirmation hearing, and at a brief news conference after the ceremony he said he had been caught off guard by the ensuing controversy in the full Senate. He pronounced himself happy to have ''survived the debate.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: The bearded, bespectacled Dr. Satcher wore the distinctive navy blue uniform of the Surgeon General, with its double-breasted jacket, gold buttons and gold-striped cuffs. It was a particularly triumphant moment for the 56-year-old family-practice physician, sickle-cell expert and medical school president, who overcame the poverty and segregation of his years as a black youth in the rural South. He pledged to ''make the greatest difference for those with the greatest need, regardless of race, color or creed.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: ''The American dream does not end when it comes true,'' he said. ''Achieving this dream presents a new challenge to give others the chance to achieve their own American dream.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: He quoted Robert Frost -- his wife, Nola, is herself a poet -- saying, ''I have promises to keep, and miles to go before I sleep.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: The Surgeon General's term is five years, and so Dr. Satcher should have two years into the next Presidential administration to keep those promises.
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: Dr. Satcher said it was too soon to know what his top priorities would be. He said he wanted first ''to listen for a while'' to the health concerns of the American people. But, sounding familiar themes, he said he would spread awareness of the importance of physical activity, good nutrition, avoiding drugs and shunning tobacco, ''our leading killer.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: The Surgeon General's job has become a political lightning rod, with incumbents tackling such delicate matters as teen-age sexuality and the idea of distributing clean needles to drug addicts. The most recent Surgeon General, Dr. Joycelyn Elders, was dismissed by President Clinton in December 1994 for making impolitic remarks about masturbation and other matters, including her suggestion that decriminalization of marijuana be considered.
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: Dr. Satcher, who gamely confessed today to having read Dr. Elders's autobiography, is widely expected to avoid that kind of controversy. Indeed, when Sam Donaldson, the White House correspondent for ABC News, tried to bait him into talking about marijuana, Dr. Satcher deftly avoided the decriminalization question.
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: Mr. Donaldson, undaunted, pressed on.
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: ''No,'' the new Surgeon General finally said, ''I don't have the information that would lead me to favor decriminalization.''
title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled

text: THEY owe the kid another ceremony. All the craven officials with their blazers and their badges and their bungled drug policies ought to summon Ross Rebagliati to Central Square one of these nights and bow down and kiss his medal in public and utter that traditional Japanese phrase, ''Gomen nasai.'' I am so sorry.
title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal

text: They hung the kid out to dry, with their gibberish and their void. The blond dude won a gold medal in snowboarding and then had his name flashed around the world as the drug fiend from hell who tested positive for, good grief, cannabis. The federations and the associations made him fear for his gold medal, and forced him to ''cooperate,'' as the saying goes, with the Japanese police, which could not have been a lot of laughs, considering that the host country will slam you in jail or banish you for life for minimal amounts of dope.
title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal

text: Eventually, the appeals process worked and now Ross Rebagliati may proudly wear his medal in public for the rest of his life.
title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal

text: He demonstrated no anger yesterday when he made his media tour. An American would have had O. J.'s phalanx of litigators with him, but Rebagliati flashed a weary, fixed smile and said: ''I won my medal two times. They made a decision. They lost. That's the end of the story.''
title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal

text: It is not exactly the end, however. The kid was in jeopardy because the assorted groups that make up the Olympic hierarchy have no uniform policy on marijuana. The snowboarders, those strange nonconformists who somehow all look and sound alike, have a marijuana policy of don't ask, don't tell. They were forced to enter these Winter Games under the mantle of the world skiing federation, which permits a minimal limit of 15 nanograms of marijuana per milliliter. The kid chipped in with a horrifying 17.8 nanograms. The International Olympic Committee has no limit, but it is vaguely against marijuana. This leaves a lot of room for mischief, much of it perpetrated on Ross Rebagliati. Carol Anne Letheren, the chief executive officer of the Canadian Olympic Association, said she was told by drug authorities back in Canada that ''if you smoked a joint,'' the measurement would be 400 nanograms. And if you were ''in a room with eight to 10 people for one hour a day for six days,'' the reading would be 100 nanograms. Rebagliati said he hadn't smoked a joint since April 1997 and the Canadian association saw no reason to challenge him. According to Letheren, marijuana is not considered a performance-enhancing drug for a sport like snowboarding, which consists of strapping both feet to one curved board and performing tricks that nobody in his right mind would attempt. Letheren also informed us that marijuana would be considered performance-enhancing if used to alleviate fear by somebody like Eddie the Eagle, the fabulously incompetent British ski jumper. Did this mean that Eddie the Eagle had been zonked while botching his jumps in past Winter Games? Letheren said she was not suggesting anything of the sort.
title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal

text: The hip young snowboarders have been courted by the I.O.C., eager to fill up the gaping holes in the Winter Games calendar and attract a younger audience. But if you want snowboarders, they should get their acts together. ''The I.O.C. gave us a list and marijuana was not on it,'' Rebagliati said yesterday, adding that he had ''learned a lot,'' whatever that means, but he was in no mood to preach to others. ''I might have to wear a gas mask,'' he said, but he added that he would never give up his friends.
title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal

text: Rebagliati was asked about Letheren's statement that the marijuana cultivated in the hills of his hometown of Whistler Mountain, British Columbia, is four times as potent as anywhere else. He shrugged and said: ''What can I say? The potency of alcohol differs, depending on what you buy. I just happen to live where it's strong.'' The tourism board of Whistler might now fear that visitors to the designer golf courses and the glitzy ski resorts might get busted. But visitors can always claim they inhaled the stuff while walking down the main street. The dog ate their homework, too. You'd like to think the I.O.C. learned something from this, but so far it has been ducking for cover. If it is going to bring in the dudes with their navel rings and their leopard-spotted thatches of hair and their slippery syntax and their goofy kids-just-wanna-have-fun smiles, then it had better get its stuff together.
title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal

text: The I.O.C. and its member federations urgently need to hold a summit conference to formulate a rational policy toward marijuana. I propose they hold it in Whistler, downwind.
title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal

text: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: SNOWBOARDING
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: Darren Chalmers, who began these Olympics as Ross Rebagliati's roommate and soon became one of his many defenders, labeled the controversy, ''As the Snowboard Turns.''
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: But unlike any genuine soap opera, this tale had a quick and decisive ending, and by late Thursday afternoon Rebagliati had rescued his gold medal from his front pocket and put it back around his neck.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: Approximately 32 hours after the International Olympic Committee's Executive Board had stripped the Canadian snowboarder of his medal in the giant slalom because he had tested positive for marijuana, an arbitration panel announced it had overturned that decision.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''I won the gold medal twice,'' a relieved Rebagliati said at a news conference this morning.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: The three-member panel, an ad hoc division of the Court of Arbitration for Sport, concluded that although ''cannabis consumption is a matter of serious social concern,'' there was no legal basis for punishing the Canadian because the rulebooks of the I.O.C. and International Ski Federation were not explicit enough about the proper sanctions for marijuana.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''What we are concerned about for sure is that this could potentially send out a mixed message, but I think what's important here is that this athlete is treated fairly in this competition,'' said Carol Anne Letheren, chief executive officer of the Canadian Olympic Association, which had appealed the I.O.C.'s ruling.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: Rebagliati has said he used marijuana for the last time in April 1997, and had attributed the relatively minute traces of marijuana in his urine sample to the effects of inhaling second-hand smoke in his hometown of Whistler Mountain, British Columbia.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''I'm definitely going to change my life style,'' he said. ''Unfortunately for you, I'm not going to change my friends. My friends are real. I'm going to stand behind them and support them. I'm not going to deviate from that. I might have to wear a gas mask from now on, but whatever.''
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: The decision to strip Rebagliati of the medal met with strong opposition from his fellow snowboarders, whose sport made its Olympic debut in Nagano.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: In the men's halfpipe event on Thursday morning, Mike Michalchuk of Canada held up a banner at the finish of his qualifying run that read: ''Ross is the champion. Give the gold back!'' Michalchuk's directive would soon become reality.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''We were eating dinner when we found out the news,'' Michalchuk said. ''About three-fourths of the team were there, and we were all cheering.''
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: There was significantly less applause for the I.O.C.'s handling of the issue. If there had been better communication between it and the International Ski Federation, known by its French acronym FIS, the matter could have been resolved without becoming a global conversation piece.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: The I.O.C. medical code does not penalize the use of marijuana unless a specific sports federation penalizes its athletes for using the drug. FIS guidelines state that a penalty may be imposed for a positive test, but Letheren said that the FIS president, Marc Hodler, informed the arbitration panel that FIS considered snowboarding's giant slalom an event in which marijuana testing was neither necessary nor relevant.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''The FIS said marijuana was in their guidelines to help protect the health and safety of athletes who might take the drug to overcome fear in sports where that might be important,'' Letheren said. ''They quoted ski jumping as an example. They said they were not at any time asked if they wished to have marijuana tested for in snowboarding, and that if they had been asked, the answer would have been no because it is no advantage in giant slalom.''
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: Asked if this meant that the entire controversy had been much ado about nothing, Letheren replied, ''I think that clarification early on in these Games would have certainly helped everybody.'' Asked whether it would have helped if Hodler, an I.O.C. vice president, had attended the executive board meeting and explained FIS's position clearly from the beginning, she answered: ''Yes, perhaps.''
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''I think the anti-marijuana rule is good in principle,'' said Tapio Videman, a professor of sports medicine at the University of Jyvaskyla in Finland and a member of FIS's medical committee.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: As for Rebagliati's claim that he was a victim of second-hand smoke, Videman said that, to date, urine studies have not been performed on this possibility. ''Therefore, it is possible things are as he says,'' Viderman said. ''So, I am glad he got his medal.''
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: An I.O.C. spokeswoman, Michele Verdier, declined to respond to questions about the decision's reversal. ''The I.O.C. does not comment on legal decisions,'' she said.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''FIS and the I.O.C. made a huge mistake not knowing what rules they passed out; there was a huge lack of information on the whole thing,'' said Chalmers, Rebagliati's friend and a giant-slalom rider.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: The first Olympic snowboard competition in history was no sunlit, smooth-running showcase for this resolutely free-spirited sport. All four of the medal events were contested in inclement weather.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''I might as well have just jumped in the pool,'' Michalchuk said.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: While Michalchuk rode through the rain, finishing eighth, Rebagliati was being questioned at the police station in Nagano. When word reached him that his medal had been restored, he took it out of his pocket for the first time in three days.
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: ''Officially, it was supposed to have been taken away from me, but it wasn't,'' he said. ''I had it in my front pocket the whole time. I wasn't able to look at it because I didn't know if it would be mine or not. All I wanted was for it to be close to me.''
title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back

text: President Clinton is expected to set a goal of cutting in half the demand for illegal drugs by the year 2007, White House officials said today.
title: National News Briefs; President to Set a Goal Of Cutting Drug Demand

text: The goal, to be announced in Mr. Clinton's radio address on Saturday, will be accompanied by setting a target of also cutting in half the flow of drugs into the nation from abroad by that year, the officials said.
title: National News Briefs; President to Set a Goal Of Cutting Drug Demand

text: Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House drug policy chief, said in an interview today that the Administration thought it was important to set specific goals. General McCaffrey said the key to reducing drug demand in the United States was to discourage and prevent high school students from getting involved with alcohol, marijuana and cigarettes while in their teen-age years.
title: National News Briefs; President to Set a Goal Of Cutting Drug Demand

text: General McCaffrey said studies consistently showed that if someone grew up without using marijuana, alcohol and cigarettes from about the 8th to the 12th grade, ''we have saved them from being drug-prone for the rest of their lives.''
title: National News Briefs; President to Set a Goal Of Cutting Drug Demand

text: The White House budget for battling narcotics is about $17.1 million this year, about 12 percent of which is to be used to discourage young people from using drugs.
title: National News Briefs; President to Set a Goal Of Cutting Drug Demand

text: BATTLE OF SURVIVAL -- Jean-Luc Cretier of France won the gold medal today in a men's downhill that may be remembered as much for those who fell as for those who won. After the event had been delayed for five days because of bad weather, 43 skiers started down the treacherous course, but only 28 finished it. Among the unfortunate was the Austrian star Hermann Maier, whose gold-medal hopes vanished in a spectacular crash in which he flipped 30 feet in the air and blew through two fences. But he walked away. Page C1.
title: The Olympics: Chaos and Controversy

text: MEDAL RETURNED -- Ross Rebagliati, the Canadian snowboarder who had been disqualified after he tested positive for marijuana, will get to keep his gold medal after all. Page C2.
title: The Olympics: Chaos and Controversy

text: Ask Tricia Zwilinske why she used to smoke marijuana every day, why she failed all her classes or why rebellious behavior led to her being dismissed from four high schools and all she offers is a wan smile and a sheepish shrug. ''Everyone else was doing it,'' Tricia, 15, said haltingly as she played with her bangs. ''It was the thing to do.''
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: In some ways, Tricia managed better than many peers, some of whom became addicted to major drugs, gave up on school or ended up in jail. Her last boyfriend is in jail for dealing crack. In fact, none of her friends at Sheepshead Bay High School, she said, made it to graduation. ''Everyone is running wild,'' she said.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: That account is not uncommon in a nation where nearly 30 percent of the eighth graders said in a study last year that they had tried illegal drugs, mostly marijuana. At 11, Tricia was drinking, and by 12 she had smoked her first marijuana cigarette. Her mother recalled that she could not understand why Tricia's grades were plummeting or why she would arrive home at night sullen and moody. ''One minute she'd be fine and the next she'd be screaming and punching holes in the wall,'' her mother, Lori Zwilinske, 38, said. ''I knew something was bothering her. But she wouldn't talk about it.''
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: Perhaps it was because Mrs. Zwilinske was juggling attending nursing school with raising four daughters and a newborn grandchild, all in the family house in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn. ''I think Tricia got lost in the shuffle,'' Mrs. Zwilinske said. ''Maybe she wasn't getting the kind of attention she deserved.''
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: Instead, Tricia received attention from older men, sometimes 10 years older. Her boyfriends, for the most part, were abusive.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: ''I guess I let guys walk all over me,'' said Tricia, who could easily pass for a 20-year-old. Stammering in a voice that seemed trapped in her throat, she told about a boyfriend who pushed her from a moving car and left her in a dangerous neighborhood miles from home.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: Mostly the abuse was verbal, but sometimes she covered the bruises with makeup before going to school.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: In July, Tricia hit bottom. She considered suicide, she said, and started picking fights with other girls, spending more time with drug dealers and frequently finding herself in menacing situations. One night in July, a teen-ager jabbed a gun in her stomach and stole her bicycle.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: Later that month, after having taken ecstasy at a rave, an all-night dance party, Tricia read a magazine article about how hallucinogenic drugs could impair a woman's ability to have children. ''That really freaked me out,'' she said. The next day, she confessed everything to her mother and begged for help.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: On the recommendation of a family friend, Tricia was referred to Break-Free, a program run by the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services that helps adolescents with substance-abuse problems. The board, an affiliate of the UJA-Federation of New York, is one of the seven charities that The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund supports.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: When Tricia went to her first counseling session, she had trouble talking about her problems. ''It was almost like she was mute,'' her social worker, Lisa Gallagher, said. In addition to once-a-week therapy, Tricia joined a peer group that meets four days a week. ''Having other kids say how dangerous your behavior is really brought her down to earth,'' Ms. Gallagher said.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: It has been nearly three months since Tricia has used drugs. Her aggressiveness has vanished, and she plans to return to school this month. She also has a new boyfriend, who does not keep Tricia under his thumb. ''If anything, she's in control,'' her mother said. ''He even does her laundry for her.''
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: For the first time, Tricia said, she can imagine a future, adding that she wants to teach in a nursery school, and to run her own someday. That is a huge step for someone who used to pepper her conversation with, ''I know I'm stupid, but. . . .''
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: Yesterday, Break-Free held a graduation ceremony for members of its peer-counseling group. Mrs. Zwilinske baked a cake for the event, in the agency's office in nearby Brighton Beach. After passing a glass bead around the room, Tricia put it on a string around her neck and giggled. Then she stood up and fumbled for words.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: ''Thank you for getting me through this rough time,'' she said, looking at her feet. ''I don't know if I would have made it without you.''
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way

text: Checks payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund should be sent to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087, or any of these
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way
