text: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: NOTEBOOK
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: Six years younger than John Elway, four years the junior of Michael Jordan, Alberto Tomba blew into Olympic Land today, sounding more like a man waiting for his pipe, paper and slippers than one in the prime of his athletic life.
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: The 31-year-old Italian heart throb, who is at his fourth Olympics and looking for a sixth medal, is also looking for a woman who doesn't just want to ''look good next to me.''
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: ''I thought I saw her here earlier,'' Tomba said, scanning the audience. ''She must be here.''
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: Claiming that his ski racing career is close to running its course, Tomba predicted for himself a future in ''action films and love stories,'' though he did not say the love stories would be confined to the screen. He has already received offers, he said, but first he must finish the business of being the most popular ski racer in the world.
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: Tomba burst onto the Olympic scene in 1988 at Calgary, Alberta, winning two golds. He won gold and silver at Albertville, France, four years later and added to the legend in the 1994 slalom at Lillehammer, Norway, with a stirring second run that carried him from 13th place to a silver medal.
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: ''I know I cannot live off the memories, but I've won everything there is to win,'' he said. ''I'm very tired right now. I'm tired of the snow.''
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: That said, he was not counting himself out of medal contention for the two races he will ski in next week, particularly his specialty, the slalom. Tomba has won two races this season, but is not considered a favorite here. Younger skiers have dominated the World Cup circuit.
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: Tomba had praise for the super-G gold medalist Picabo Street, said it was not his job to judge athletes who get caught smoking marijuana, and wondered why anyone would want his opinion of President Clinton's extramarital life.
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: ''What do I have to do with this?'' he said.
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: Good question. Let the races begin.
title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next

text: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: SNOWBOARDING
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: An arbitration panel met today to decide whether to return a gold medal to a Canadian snowboarder or to uphold the International Olympic Committee's decision to take the medal away because the athlete tested positive for marijuana.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: No decision had been reached by late morning.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: Ross Rebagliati of Canada had his gold-medal-winning performance nullified on Wednesday after the I.O.C.'s medical commission voted, 13-12, and the I.O.C.'s executive board voted, 3-2, against him.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: The Canadian Olympic Association appealed, noting that the rules of the international ski federation say that a penalty may be imposed for a positive marijuana test but do not stipulate that a penalty is mandatory.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: ''Is, or should, the I.O.C. be a social police force?'' asked Carol Ann Letheren, an I.O.C. member from Canada. ''That is the question around this drug.''
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: There has long been a debate in the I.O.C. about whether marijuana should be on the banned substances list because it is not generally considered a performance-enhancing drug, as are anabolic steroids.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: ''If it's not performance-enhancing, and it's a social drug, you wonder why it is included,'' said an I.O.C. official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''But it's a question of, do you follow the rules or don't you? How do you tell your children not to use drugs and then say it's O.K. if it's a gold medalist?''
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: The case has spawned wicked humor worldwide and serious interest by the Japanese police. Kyodo, the Japanese news service, said that the Japanese police would question Rebagliati and would ask the I.O.C. to turn over the results of his drug test. Possession of marijuana can carry a sentence of up to five years in jail, Kyodo reported. Michele Verdier, a spokeswoman for the I.O.C., said she did not know if the committee had turned over the test results to the police.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: ''I see no reason why the I.O.C. would not cooperate with local authorities,'' Verdier said.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: Letheren said that Rebagliati told officials he had not smoked marijuana since April 1997 and that he believed the drug had entered his system through second-hand smoke.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: In the Canadian press, the case has spawned ''Up in Smoke'' headlines and such one-liners as ''Oh, Cannabis!''
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: The rescinding of Rebagliati's medal has also underscored the chaotic nature of drug enforcement within the various sports federations that make up the I.O.C. Not every federation tests for marijuana. And some believe that the I.O.C. is embarrassing itself by disqualifying an athlete for a drug that is not considered performance-enhancing when it does not even have certified tests for two drugs that are performance-enhancing and are suspected of widespread use -- human growth hormone and erythropoietin, or EPO.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: Mark Fawcett, a close friend and teammate of Rebagliati's on the Canadian snowboarding team, said: ''This whole thing is a farce. Nobody can understand what happened. As athletes, we have never been informed that if we are in a situation where someone is smoking weed, we should leave.''
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: Michelle Kwan, the American figure skating champion, said: ''Rules are rules. You've got to follow them. I'm surprised to see an athlete busted for that.''
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: Frank Carroll, her coach, said: ''I know it is a destructive thing. If you are an athlete, you have to make a decision. Are you going to do that sort of thing or be an athlete? I don't think there is room for both.''
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: The abitration panel deciding Rebagliati's case is part of the Court of Arbitration for Sport, an independent body based in Lausanne, Switzerland, that is set up to decide legal arguments that arise during the Winter and Summer Games.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: Three arbiters deciding the case are Richard Young, an attorney from Colorado Springs, Colo.; Jan Paulsson of Sweden, and Maria Zuchowicz of Poland. They were chosen for their experience in arbitration and sports law.
title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands

text: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: SNOWBOARDING
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: ''ROSS IS THE CHAMPION. GIVE THE GOLD BACK!''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: The words were written in black marker on a linen hotel napkin, and the young man holding that napkin up in the drizzle at the bottom of the snowboarding halfpipe run this morning was the Canadian rider Michael Michalchuck.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: ''I made it last night because I believe in Ross,'' said Michalchuck, a 20-year-old from Calgary.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: Ross Rebagliati, the Canadian snowboarder who has been stripped of his gold medal in the giant slalom by the International Olympic Committee after testing positive for marijuana, was not one of the spectators today at the Kanbayashi Snowboard Park. But he was unquestionably the central figure as the men's and women's halfpipe riders made their Olympic debuts.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: ''Ross won fair and square; he is the gold medalist and no one can deny him that,'' Michalchuck said. ''I don't understand why this is happening. He is a friend of mine, and he should be given the gold back. I saw him before this, and he was on top of the world. This should never have happened to him.''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: Michalchuck decided to make his very public appeal on Wednesday night, and when he finished his opening run, he unstrapped his board, took the napkin from his girlfriend and calmly held it up to the photographers and television camera operators waiting in the finish area.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: ''I think the Olympics are good for snowboarding, but I don't think this whole deal is,'' he said.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: ''Marijuana is not a performance-enhancing drug, and Ross did not smoke it; he was just subjected to it,'' he added. ''Marijuana is present in every sport. If it happens to be more present in snowboarding, it may be just because it's a younger generation. A lot of us do not smoke it, but I'm not denying that a lot of my friends do. You're not going to change a friend because they do.''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: Michalchuck was not the only Canadian to take an activist stance.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: ''In the spirit of snowboarders, we're not going to sit down on this,'' said Mark Fawcett, one of Rebagliati's fellow giant-slalom riders. ''We're going to try to take the scar and put it back on the I.O.C. To come right back at them.''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: Cara-Beth Burnside of the United States said: ''Everyone was furious. Everyone was, like, Ross won the gold no matter what. It wasn't anything that was affecting his performance. I mean, come on, they're kicking people out for cough medicine.''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: Others were more circumspect. ''Well, marijuana is on the list,'' said the Norwegian Anne Molin Kongsgaard, who added that the disqualification was ''very sad.''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: Some riders also expressed dismay that after waiting for years to get the chance to show their moves in the Olympics, this issue was now much more interesting to the world than whether they had just performed a McTwist.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: ''It's a weird day,'' said the Canadian team spokesman, Paul Rivard. ''Because the riders know everybody wants to talk about something other than their run, and they want to stay focused.''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: The rain that began falling just before the start of the women's qualifying run certainly did not do much to lighten the mood. Nor did the Olympic organizers' questionable decision to allow a relatively small number of fans access to the area bordering the halfpipe. The bulk of the several thousand fans were instead relegated to a field far down the slope, their view of the halfpipe obstructed by television commentary booths.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: ''Usually everybody is right up next to it,'' said Adam Merriman of Vail, Colo., who traveled to Japan to watch his girlfriend, Barrett Christy, compete in the halfpipe. ''But then usually there aren't this many television cameras or people around, either. So I guess that's good.''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: The teen-age and twentysomething Japanese fans who lined the front row of the roped-off field did not seem to mind their poor seats. Snowboarding is currently in fashion with Japan's trend-conscious youth, and there was no shortage of wool caps, baggy pants, Airwalk boots and dyed orange hair.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: But there were other, clearer indicators that this was a land far removed from the cradle of snowboarding. Next to the chairlift that transported the competitors to the top of the run, the organizers had written a delightfully cryptic message in the snow in bright red script that read, ''What's a cool you are!''
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: Farther up the hill, the most powerful message of the day needed no English translation.
title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal

text: TECHNOLOGY giveth and technology taketh away. The athletes of the Winter Games don't mind when the latest technology gives them clap skates that rocket them to faster times, nor do they mind when technology discovers ways to wax their skis for improved traction.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: But hey, dude, it's no fun when technology picks up a few extra nanograms of a controlled substance in the body of a gold-medal winner at the Winter Games. Then, technology is inhumane and cruel and capricious.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: That's what happened to a young Canadian snowboarder named Ross Rebagliati. He won a gold medal in the men's giant slalom on Monday and then was busted for having 17.8 nanograms of marijuana traces in his system when 15 is the legal limit. The International Olympic Committee stripped away his gold medal and then his appeal was sent to a panel of special arbitrators. A decision was expected today.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: On sympathy alone, Rebagliati would have got his medal back from the appeal, since the amount of marijuana was minimal, and because marijuana is not a performance-enhancing drug. It's hard to go barreling down a mountain under control with a major toot on. Still, ''rules are rules,'' said another Olympian, Michelle Kwan, the figure skater. ''You've got to follow the rules.''
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: The story put out by Rebagliati and the Canadian Olympic Association is that he must have inhaled some second-hand marijuana smoke at a going-away party a few weeks ago. Given what we are learning about second-hand smoke wreaking havoc with innocent people's lungs, that's all too possible.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: In the circuit where Rebagliati performs, there are no house detectives shuffling around handing jars to the medalists. The snowboarding circuit has sprung up on its own, with its own sense of anarchy and independence and style, and the snowboarders are not used to being told to produce a sample. They are not used to being told to do anything, it seems.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: The best snowboarder in the world, Terje Haakonsen of Norway, did not come to these Games because he compared the I.O.C. to the Mafia, and he told a Norwegian magazine, ''The bigwigs ride in limousines and stay in fancy hotels, while the athletes live in barracks in the woods.''
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: The snowboarders who rebel against the I.O.C. are a far cry from the vaguely political and idealistic youth of the late 60's. In that exotic era, I personally never inhaled -- honest -- but there were times when I went to the Fillmore Auditorium in San Francisco to listen to Santana or B. B. King, and was the recipient of rather expensive second-hand smoke. If anybody had run me through a grass detector, I would have set the bells to ringing, and I would have smiled and said, ''Hey, that's cool.''
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: For some bizarre reason, athletes are considered important enough to be tested. I'd be tempted to let everybody ingest whatever they want, and if they grow a second head, well, then, they lose at the game of life.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: Young Master Rebagliati may indeed be the victim of the technological battle. Our chemists are better than your chemists. That's the best rivalry in sports these days -- not the Yankees and the Mariners or the Bulls and the Knicks.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: We know people cheat because every so often somebody's stash breaks open in public. The Chinese swimming team was trying to lug a lifetime supply of human-growth hormone into Australia recently. If they hadn't got caught at customs, one courier on that team would have been singing bass in their local commune's rendition of ''The East Is Red.''
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: Now the I.O.C. has come up with a spectrometer, worth $500,000, that can detect tiny amounts of drugs in the system, including chemicals taken weeks earlier. There will also be enhanced testing for human growth hormone. Many federations warned their athletes to be clean, but the American bobsledder Michael Dionne was dropped from the Olympic team when traces of ephedrine were found in his system. The appeals panel said it believed his contention that he took it for a cold, and allowed him to remain with the team although not to compete.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: By the way, the snowboarders are not the only new faces in these formerly amateur Winter Games. The National Hockey League is closing down shop for two weeks and sending 125 hard-core professionals here. If even one of these wealthy brutes should test positive for something, even a common over-the-counter cold medicine, the N.H.L. players just might decide not to take this interesting little winter sabbatical four years hence.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: New technology and new faces in the Winter Games. May the best chemist win.
title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry

text: TRUST AT HIGH SPEED -- Four years ago a skier on Herwig Demschar's team died on a downhill course, a tragedy that drove the coach away from the Austrian program. Now he is the American women's coach, and Picabo Street's belief in him brought her a gold medal in the super-giant slalom. Page C1.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: SNOWBOARDING APPEAL -- As a panel considered whether to return the Canadian snowboarder Ross Rebagliati's gold medal, which was taken away after he tested positive for marijuana, a teammate gave a very public display of support. Page C1.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: A SAFER TRIPLE -- Michelle Kwan will put the triple toe loop back into her short program in women's figure skating. It replaces the more difficult triple flip, which she used at the national championships to protect an injured toe. Page C2.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: DRESSED FOR EXCESS -- Can Ilya Kulik of Russia, a favorite in men's figure skating, sail to a gold medal on gossamer wings? The wings adorn his costume for the short program, and his black-and-yellow ensemble for Saturday's long program has drawn even more comment. Page C2.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: ON TELEVISION, DAY-OLD EVENTS -- As viewers watched taped coverage of the pairs figure skating Tuesday night, Picabo Street was winning her gold medal in the super-G. But CBS waited nearly 24 hours to show Street's victory. Page C8.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: Soon after he won the first gold medal in Olympic history for snowboarding on Sunday, Ross Rebagliati of Canada said he realized his sport was getting important because drug testing had been introduced.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: Today, his gold medal for snowboarding's giant slalom was taken away because he had tested positive for marijuana, Francois Carrard, director general of the International Olympic Committee, said.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: Rebagliati said he had not used marijuana since April 1997, according to Carol Anne Letheren, the chief executive officer of the Canadian Olympic Committee and a member of the I.O.C.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: ''I've worked too hard to let this slip through my fingers,'' Rebagliati said in a statement read by Canadian Olympic officials.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: The Canadian Olympic Committee immediately announced that it would appeal the decision to an arbitration court that will render its decision within 24 hours, Carrard said.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: Rebagliati, 26, was the first gold medalist to be stripped of his title since Ben Johnson of Canada was penalized in the 100-meter dash at the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, after testing positive for anabolic steroids.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: The Canadian delegation said it would base its appeal on the wording of rules of the International Ski Federation. The rules applied in today's action state that ''penalties may be imposed'' when marijuana is found in a urine sample. The rationale for the appeal is that while penalties ''may'' be imposed, they are not mandatory.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: Letheren said that Rebagliati admitted using marijuana in April 1997 but had not used it since. He may have acquired trace amounts of marijuana in his system, she said, at a going-away party on Jan. 31 at which marijuana was used by others.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: The Canadian team leader, Michael Wood, said that ''Ross is very devastated'' by the ruling and that he will stay in the Nagano area during the appeal.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: Letheren said that the medical committee voted by 13-12 to disqualify Rebagliati and then sent its findings and its recommendation to the I.O.C. Carrard said that the I.O.C. board voted by 3-2, with two abstentions, to take away the medal.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: The I.O.C.'s other option, Carrard said, was a serious warning. When asked if marijuana should be considered a performance-enhancing drug, like steroids or amphetamines, he said: ''There is quite a discussion about marijuana. I am told in some situations it could be performance enhancing. It could affect the behavior of some athletes.''
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: Thomas Prugger of Italy will move up to take the gold medal. Ueli Kestenholz of Switzerland will get the silver and Dieter Krassnig of Austria the bronze.
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: Snowboarding was added to the Olympics this year, in part to attract a younger audience. Rebagliati, a native of Whistler, British Columbia, said after his victory, ''I always wanted to be a surfer, but I didn't live anywhere near any waves.''
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: Rebagliati dedicated his victory to a friend named Lumpy who, he said, died with six others in an avalanche. ''I went for it,'' he said. ''I'd rather have no time than a slow time.''
title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test

text: A 360 AND A GOLD -- Jonny Moseley of Tiburon, Calif., used his soaring helicopter turn to capture the gold medal in the men's moguls. Page C1.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: FASTEST MAN ON ICE -- Hiroyasu Shimizu became an instant national hero, winning Japan's first gold medal with an Olympic record in the 500-meter speed skating. Page C1.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: CANADIAN STRIPPED OF MEDAL -- Ross Rebagliati tested positive for marijuana and his snowboarding gold medal was taken away. Page C1.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: CHANGE PARTNERS AND WIN -- Artur Dmitriev won pairs figure-skating gold with Oksana Kazakova, becoming the first man to win gold medals with different partners. Page C5.
title: Olympic Highlights

text: The front pages were filled with lurid stories about -- me! Strangers were rifling through my closet and leaving with my skeletons. I was mortified to have the entire country reading about the time I . . . well, never mind about that.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: I had fallen asleep after George Stephanopoulos had ominously warned Sam and Cokie that White House allies were considering the ''explosive'' strategy of opening up every sexual closet in the city -- Congressmen, reporters, pundits.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: ''The President said he would never resign and I think some around him are willing to take everybody down with him,'' he said.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: A sexual Armageddon, a bedroom doomsday strategy. If Bill Clinton has to have his dirty linen aired before the House Judiciary Committee, the Clintonites will insure that there is no clean linen anywhere.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: The former Clinton aide, whose candor about the President's lack of candor has deeply stung his fellow War Room veterans, dubbed this the ''Ellen Rometsch'' strategy.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: ''She was a girlfriend of John F. Kennedy who also happened to be an East German spy,'' he said. ''And Robert Kennedy was charged with getting her out of the country and also getting John Edgar Hoover to go to the Congress and say 'Don't you investigate this, because if you do, we're going to open up everybody's closets.' ''
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: This is even more brutally disgusting than the Clintonites' he's-notperfect-but-we're-fighting-against-Starr's-fascism-and-protecting-Our-Issues routine. If his Presidency is damaged, it will be a season of wrath. An apocalypse of scandal.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: It will be simple enough to show Bill Clinton isn't the only guy in town who likes to have young female staffers do ''clerical tasks'' for him.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: Still, it makes me queasy to think of Bill and Hillary's Torquemadas -- a vast left-wing conspiracy -- rooting around. Will they try to pin down the peccadillos of Helen Thomas? It was bad enough hearing Roy Romer's true confessions. Do we really want to delve into Bob Barr's sex life?
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: This is just the latest step down on the Clinton moral escalator.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: First the feminists do loop-the-loops to rationalize his demeaning treatment of women. (Carol Moseley-Braun implied on ''Meet the Press'' that the Lewinsky story could be seen as a triumph of Democratic diversity efforts: ''Not so many years ago, a woman couldn't be a White House intern.'')
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: Now, confronted with the prospect of House impeachment hearings on Kenneth Starr's information, the Clintonites are going from defending the President's privacy to threats of invading others' privacy.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: Their G. Gordon Liddy fangs are already frightening Republicans, who don't want their bedroom curtains yanked open and who hardly relish the prospect of having Mr. Starr drop his case in their laps. While the President zooms toward 100 percent approval, gaining four or five points with every damaging disclosure, Republicans sense that the public will not be as kind to them, given the greater family values hypocrisy on their side of the aisle.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: Mr. Clinton has long had an aggrieved notion that his personal life is scrutinized more than other politicians -- past, like John Kennedy, or present, like Bob Kerrey. ''Because he's single, nobody cares who he's [expletive deleted],'' he whined to Gennifer Flowers on tape.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: Some in the Clinton crowd foresee a game of chicken, where politicians will have to decide if they should tell about affairs or wait to get caught -- just as they did with the touchy boomer issues of marijuana and the draft.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: They suggest that the sex inquisition, which they prefer to call ''the coming dialogue,'' will help develop cultural norms. Just as certain weasel phrases sprang up to excuse drug use (''I experimented but I didn't enjoy it'') and avoiding the draft (''I did not serve but I did not get inappropriate help to stay out''), so pols will develop semi-apologies on sex (''I experimented but I didn't enjoy it. And she was my own age.'').
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: I shudder to think of the rush to confess when the National Conversation on Indecency begins. I shudder even more to think of Dick Gephardt's press conference where he eagerly professes that he's never done anything with anyone of any age at any time.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: And the really terrifying thing is -- I'll believe him.
title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy

text: On the day he attacked a staff member at a Minnesota juvenile detention center, menacingly wielding a fork against the man's neck, Adam Sipe crossed an irrevocable line.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: For Tyrone Winkelman, the moment came when, at 16, he and other teen-agers forced a friend's mother to the basement at knifepoint, tied her up with telephone cord and stole her car.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Duane Nelson reached the tipping point after he got into a bloody fight with four high school students, pummeling and kicking them so hard he broke his own ankle while cracking open one boy's skull.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Normally, the criminal justice system here, and in most other states these days, would have looked at these teen-agers' records and the latest charges against them and concluded that although they were juveniles, they should be tried as adults, spend time in adult prison and emerge with adult criminal records.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: But three years ago, in a groping effort to figure out how to deal with youths like these, Minnesota fashioned a different approach that is catching on in other states.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Called a blended sentence, Minnesota's system gives certain juvenile offenders -- usually those who have committed violent, but not extreme or murderous crimes -- both a juvenile sentence and an adult one. If they comply with the terms of the juvenile sentence, which includes longer and more intensive supervision than a typical juvenile sanction, they will eventually be released without the stain of an adult criminal record.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: The idea is to give a young offender some rope, enough to yank himself out of a life of crime -- or to hang himself and wind up in prison.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: ''It's one last bite of the apple,'' said Ann Jaede, director of juvenile research and planning for the Minnesota Department of Corrections. ''You're still holding the kid accountable, and you have this string over his head saying 'You mess up kid, that's it.' ''
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: At a time when juvenile offenders present the most persistent crime problem, some states are embracing blended sentencing as one effort to carve some gray area into a criminal justice system many believe has become too black and white.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: In the last few years, according to the National Center for Juvenile Justice, about a dozen states, including Kentucky, Oregon, Kansas and Connecticut, have added some type of sentence that intertwines adult and juvenile systems. In January, the Illinois Legislature overwhelmingly passed a bill including such sentencing. This week, Ohio's juvenile justice officials are getting advice from Minnesota officials. And in North Carolina, a panel is expected to propose similar legislation.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Minnesota officials say that early results of its law, which took effect in January 1995, seem cautiously promising, with fewer teen-agers than expected ending up in adult prisons.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: ''There's this tug of war going on between those who believe we've been too soft on juveniles -- you do an adult crime, you do adult time -- and those that feel we treat juveniles differently because we believe they can be reformed and rehabilitated,'' said John M. Stanoch, the chief juvenile court judge for Hennepin County, which encompasses Minneapolis. ''So it's really a marriage of convenience between those that want to punish more and those that want to give kids one more chance.''
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Neither New York nor New Jersey has blended sentencing. In New York, teen-agers 16 and older are tried as adults. In New Jersey, youths under 18 can be transferred by a judge to adult court.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Juvenile violent crime has only recently begun to decline, lagging behind the persuasive decreases in adult crime over the last several years. But many experts are bracing for another juvenile crime wave over the next decade as the number of teen-agers grows by 15 percent.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Faced with these statistics and with a number of sensational murders committed by children barely out of grade school, many states began lowering the age at which juveniles could be tried as adults and lengthening the list of crimes for which adult penalties might apply. The United States Senate is soon expected to take up a bill passed by the House of Representatives to give states Federal money for treating more juveniles as adults. Some experts believe juvenile courts have become overburdened and ill-equipped to handle most kinds of juvenile crime.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: But there is also broiling debate about whether the push to treat young offenders like adults keeps youths from committing more crimes or merely reinforces early criminal tendencies. A study in Florida found that juveniles tried as adults reverted to crime more quickly after release and committed more serious offenses than those tried as juveniles. And youths in adult prisons are more likely to be sexually or physically assaulted by other inmates, and less likely to get education and treatment.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: ''People are really struggling with coming up with the right options,'' said Pat Torbet, a senior research associate at the National Center for Juvenile Justice. ''There's a sense you need this continuum of sanctions, continuum of services.''
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: In several states, these middle-ground laws have broad political support. For the most part, prosecutors believe they allow room for being tough on juvenile offenders and protecting public safety. In fact, the Illinois bill was written by prosecutors and sponsored by a Republican former prosecutor. Public defenders, as well, support the laws because they keep some youths out of prison and also guarantee them adult rights, like a lawyer and a jury trial. Judges appreciate the greater flexibility they have with individual cases.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Some academic experts, however, are not enthusiastic. Several see blended sentences as weak-kneed steps, politically expedient distractions from the real need to either beef up the juvenile justice system or virtually eliminate it.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: In Minnesota, teen-agers between the ages of 14 and 17 who commit serious crimes can be sentenced as ''extended jurisdiction juveniles,'' with a specific adult sentence of, for example, four years that is suspended as long as they comply with a juvenile sentence. If they do not comply, a judge can impose the adult sentence. The juvenile sentence -- some combination of detention, therapy and probation -- lasts until they turn 21, two years longer than the sentences imposed on regular juvenile offenders, who are paroled at 19. Those who successfully complete the juvenile sentence are free from any obligations to the adult system.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Many officials say that more important than the Sword of Damocles of adult prison hanging over their heads is the extra treatment and scrutiny these teen-agers receive. Minnesota has put state money into this; Illinois plans to marshal existing programs.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Of the 339 teen-agers sentenced in the Minnesota program's first 20 months, 42 have so far violated their juvenile sentence and been sent to adult state prisons, Ms. Jaede said. A few others may have ended up in county jails or work programs for adults.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Judge Stanoch said many of those sent to adult prison have been tripped up on small probation violations -- things like smoking marijuana, quitting a job or not showing up for appointments -- a sign, he said, that the extra supervision catches teen-agers before they commit new violent crimes.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: While it is still too early to know, so far, several youths have shown apparent improvement in the juvenile phase.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Jason Bergstrom received a blended sentence at 16, when, just hours after he was released from a juvenile home, he pointed a gun at a man, threatened to blow his head off, and then ran from the police. Jason, whose family includes a brother imprisoned for armed robbery and an uncle imprisoned for murder (''I'm the good one out of the bunch,'' Jason said) had spent his early teen-age years stealing cars and guns, using and selling marijuana and other drugs.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Now he is an 18-year-old senior at a St. Paul high school, having completed 18 months of detention. He attends a weekly probation meeting, counsels youths at a juvenile home, and expects to graduate in June.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: ''There are times,'' he said, ''when I think that I just want to have a joint, have a drink, make some money somehow, but I just think, it'll pass.''
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Duane Nelson, who beat up the four teen-agers, may have the most inspiring story. In December, after 19 months in a detention center, where he learned the rewards of good behavior and to control his anger by lifting weights, he began working for Commissioner Penny Steele of Hennepin County, typing memos and filing papers, and will go to college in March.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: ''I got a nice job. I'm in college. I got people depending on me,'' he said, ''and I don't want to let them down.''
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Still, clearly some teen-agers have hardly been scared straight. In fact, some said in interviews that they would have preferred adult prison where their sentence might have been shorter and would involve fewer probation meetings and treatment sessions.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Tyrone Winkelman gave the blended sentencing program no chance, throwing a toaster at a member of the juvenile detention staff, bruising her severely, he said. At 17, his juvenile sentence was revoked and he was ordered to serve the 48 months of his adult sentence and was sent to St. Cloud prison, a maximum security facility that looks like a medieval fortress. Although one of the youngest inmates, he has already spent months in solitary confinement because he flooded his cell, spit on guards, and fought with inmates. So has Elliott Pierson, another teen-ager who flunked his juvenile blended sentencing by committing an armed robbery while on probation.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: ''I knew right away I was going to end up here,'' said Tyrone, in shackles in St. Cloud's visiting room. ''It's a setup.''
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Critics of blended sentencing say it will fail because of that kind of attitude.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: ''It's country club criminology, what sounds good on the Back 9,'' said Barry Krisberg, president of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency. ''Kids in some communities expect to go to prison.''
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: For now, the fate of most youths in Minnesota's program is a question mark.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Adam Sipe, for example, with a prior record of planting a bomb in a mailbox and burning down a Christmas tree farm, is in the state's most intensive juvenile detention center, a turreted building in the Mississippi river town of Red Wing, about 40 miles southeast of St. Paul.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Now 18, his record here shows he has gotten in trouble for talking about drugs and writing letters containing gang symbols. But these are not as serious as his problems at other institutions, which included cutting security alarm wires with a potato peeler and escaping by stealing a series of cars.
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: ''I heard about prison and no way I'm going there,'' said Adam, who faces a year and half in adult prison. ''You get one more last chance before you go to the big house.''
title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice

text: Cohen Finds Gulf Nations Hostile to Military Action
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said that although Persian Gulf nations supported United States efforts to force Iraq to cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors, he had failed to win new support for military strikes. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Members of a White House panel warned President Clinton that a potential link between the illnesses of Persian Gulf war veterans and exposure to poison gas should be of concern as the United States threatens to bomb Iraqi poison gas sites. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan urged all parties to be more flexible in finding a peaceful solution to the Iraq crisis. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The commander of a squadron of jets like the one that severed cables on a ski lift in Italy last week was relieved of his command on Friday because he had told crews under his command to destroy potential evidence in an accident investigation, the Marine Corps said. A9
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: New Threat to Irish Talks
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Protestant leaders moved to have Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., expelled from the Northern Ireland peace talks, citing two killings attributed to Roman Catholic guerrillas within 24 hours. Officials and experts said that without Sinn Fein the peace talks would be unlikely to produce an agreement ending the sectarian warfare. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Nigerian troops seized control of suburbs of Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, from forces loyal to the military junta that overthrew Ahmed Tjan Kabbah, Sierra Leone's elected President, last May. The Nigerian troops were fighting to restore the President to power. A8
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Pope John Paul II held a private meeting in the Vatican. Their discussion included subjects like the celebrations for the year 2000, but not a Papal visit to Russia. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: American officials said that several San Diego gang members had been indicted in connection with the killing of a Roman Catholic Cardinal in Mexico in 1993. Indictments were unsealed saying that the Arellano Felix drug-trafficking organization of Tijuana, Mexico, had recruited gang members from San Diego to assist in protecting gangsters and in enforcement. Juan Jesus Cardinal Posada Ocampo was killed by crossfire in Guadalajara in May 1993. (AP)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Peru Court Rules for Fujimori
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Peru's Supreme Court cleared a legal hurdle to a possible third term for President Alberto Fujimori. The Constitution prohibits more than two consecutive terms, but supporters of Mr. Fujimori argue that the rule is not applicable because it dates from the new constitution, which was written during his second term. (Reuters)
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Lewinsky's Mother Appears Before Grand Jury
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The mother of Monica S. Lewinsky, Marcia Lewis, was summoned before a Federal grand jury. Mrs. Lewis would not discuss her testimony when she left the jury room, but the office of the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, has tape recordings in which Ms. Lewinsky tells a friend, Linda R. Tripp, that she consulted her mother about an affair she said she had with Mr. Clinton, said lawyers who have listened to the tapes. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Nancy V. Hernreich, one of Mr. Clinton's most trusted and longest-serving aides, has been subpoenaed to testify before the grand jury. A22
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Report on China and Campaign
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Illegal campaign contributions to the Democratic National Committee in the 1996 election originated in bank accounts in ''the greater China area,'' according to the final report of Republican senators investigating campaign finance abuses. But the committee said it could not establish that the Chinese Government had ''funded, directed or encouraged the illegal contributions.'' A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Jurors at the court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney heard a tape-recording of him coaching a young female staff sergeant to tell Army investigators that their contact had been limited to conversations ''about career development and that kind of stuff'' and involved ''no inappropriateness at all.'' The woman has said Sergeant Major McKinney tried for years to persuade her to have a sexual relationship with him.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Dr. David Satcher, the 56-year-old director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, won Senate confirmation as Surgeon General, becoming the first person in more than three years to fill a post that has become a lightning rod in the nation's battles over abortion and family values. A20
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The Environmental Protection Agency has discovered that hundreds of thousands of modern heavy-duty diesel truck engines run cleanly during the agency's mandatory performance tests, but give off much more pollution in normal highway use, Federal officials said. A16
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Scientists described new pictures by the Hubble Space Telescope that show the shock wave from an exploding star, or supernova, illuminating a knot of gas some 100 billion miles wide. They predicted that this close examination of what is in the ring could reveal telling clues to the events that lead up to a supernova.
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A former naval midshipman testified at her murder trial and contradicted her written confession, in which she said she had ordered her former fiance to kill a romantic rival. A20
title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Three teen-agers from Manhattan pleaded guilty to charges in the kidnapping, robbery and killing of a New Jersey businessman, Nelson G. Gross, above. The plea agreement called for them to be sentenced as adults, with probable prison terms of 30 years without parole. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Governor Pataki endorsed legislation that would permit higher wholesale prices for milk. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Governor Whitman of New Jersey proposed a $17.9 billion budget that recommended nearly $1 billion in new spending for public schools, state colleges, open space preservation and some other programs. B
title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Ross Rebagliati of Canada, the first Olympic snowboard champion, tested positive for marijuana and was stripped of his medal, the International Olympic Committee said. C1

text: Jonny Moseley won the first gold medal for the United States by winning the men's moguls. C3

title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: New York State is introducing new standardized tests in English and mathematics for fourth and eighth graders, state officials said. B14

text: American households have more of their assets invested in the stock market than at any time in the last 50 years -- and perhaps ever. But with so much in stocks, a sharp market decline could seriously erode the financial well-being of Americans. A1

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK
title: 2 Arrested After Police Find Cocaine in Car

text: Two men from Richmond, Va., were arrested yesterday after a Port Authority police officer discovered approximately $80,000 worth of cocaine in their vehicle during a routine traffic stop in Manhattan on a ramp to the George Washington Bridge, the authorities said.
title: 2 Arrested After Police Find Cocaine in Car

text: Ivory McClure, 24, and Detrich Jenkins, 24, were each charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance in the first degree and intent to distribute, said Lieut. George Leather of the Port Authority police.
title: 2 Arrested After Police Find Cocaine in Car

text: About 4:15 P.M., Port Authority police officers on a traffic enforcement detail on the Amsterdam Avenue ramp to the George Washington Bridge stopped a Jeep Cherokee because the driver and passenger were not wearing seat belts, Lieutenant Leather said.
title: 2 Arrested After Police Find Cocaine in Car

text: Officer Brian Porter searched the vehicle and arrested Mr. Jenkins and Mr. McClure after he smelled raw marijuana and spotted a package on the rear seat, Lieutenant Leather said. The two men had seven and a half pounds of cocaine, a small amount of marijuana, and $10,000, Lieutenant Leather said.
title: 2 Arrested After Police Find Cocaine in Car

text: Karl Malone, last season's most valuable player, said yesterday that his leaving Utah to join the Knicks is not as farfetched as it sounds.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''Absolutely not,'' Malone said at the All-Star Game practice at the Jacobs Javits Center. ''Not out of the realm at all. A lot of things would have to be perfect as far as me leaving Utah.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''But I'm also good friends with Dave Checketts,'' Malone said, referring to the president of Madison Square Garden. ''He drafted me in Utah.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: Malone, who is under contract with the Jazz for the next two seasons, is considered a basketball icon in Utah. ''On one hand, I don't like the big city, but if it's my decision to come to New York, I'll make the most out of it,'' he said. ''That's the way I am.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: The chance that the Jazz management would either trade or let go of Malone is even more of a reach than his being a Knick.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''We're good friends and I've known Karl for a long time, but he's under contract with Utah and that's where he belongs,'' Checketts said. ''He's been there a long time. He's the franchise and that's where he belongs.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: Spurs Might Gamble on Sprewell
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: With the possibility that Latrell Sprewell may be available to resume his career this season, several teams in need of a shooting guard will have to make a tough decision on whether to pursue him.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: According to a Golden State player who requested anonymity, one of the teams likely to take a gamble on Sprewell is the San Antonio Spurs. That is not exactly a news flash, given the fondness that Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich has for Sprewell as a player and the fact that the two got along well while Popovich was at Golden State under Don Nelson.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: But the Warriors player said Popovich had indicated to several Spurs players that he might add Sprewell if his one-year suspension were reduced after his arbitration case against the N.B.A. and Golden State.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: Given the lack of real talent in their backcourt -- Vinny Del Negro has a hard time guarding anyone and point guard Avery Johnson chips a lot of paint off the rim with his shot -- there is also speculation that the team would pursue Sprewell if he were available next summer.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: But it is unlikely that Sprewell could end up in Miami.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: One reason Golden State traded Tim Hardaway to the Heat was because he had a nasty feud going with Sprewell.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: But Sprewell does not rule out the possibility of playing in Miami.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''There are a lot of places where I can fit in,'' said Sprewell, who was attending a meeting of the National Basketball Players Association.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''Seattle, San Antonio, D.C., Atlanta, Miami. There are a lot of teams that I can fit in with.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: Twenty player representatives from the National Basketball Players Association met yesterday to rally around Sprewell and discussed several issues that will likely be sticking points when and if the collective bargaining agreement is opened by owners this summer.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: One topic was marijuana. The league wants marijuana added to the N.B.A. drug policy; currently it is not a prohibited substance. The union agrees it is an issue, especially after a few players were linked with the drug last summer. But Billy Hunter, the players association's executive director, said the players are not prepared to accept penalties they deem too harsh.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''The marijuana discussion probably took longer than most of the others today,'' Hunter said. ''What we've agreed to do is to remain open. Our concern is that the league doesn't use marijuana as another vehicle to constrain and control players.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''I think marijuana is treated in society, in general, much different than any other drug,'' Hunter added. ''I'm not aware of anybody who goes to jail for smoking marijuana. So now if you're talking about suspending a player for five, six or seven games -- if you take 1/82 of his salary for each of those suspensions, and you have a guy who is making several million a year, it becomes significant when you look at how it's treated in society.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: Several union members are expected to begin informal discussions concerning the collective bargaining agreement in the next two or three weeks.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: More pressing right now is the outcome out the hearing involving Sprewell.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''I think the N.B.A. miscalculated,'' Hunter saod. ''In a way, it's a blessing for the union. I don't think anything has caused the players to unify around Latrell and the union as much as that issue. It's sort of been a windfall for us in that it's gotten everyone's attention.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: Garry St. Jean, having endured about as much as anyone can in his first year on the job as the the Golden State Warriors' general manager, thought he had finally caught a break. Scheduled to testify in the Sprewell hearing, he flew to New York last Sunday and checked into the Plaza. ''I figured with all this craziness going on and our team not doing very well that, at least I could stay at the nicest place in New York and really pamper myself a little,'' he said. ''And about 7:30 in the morning, I hear this crazy racket going on next door, like some drug bust or something. I don't know what it was.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: St. Jean was staying in the room next to the actor Daniel Baldwin, who was taken away in handcuffs by the police and then to a hospital on Monday morning after reportedly overdosing on drugs. Baldwin reportedly was screaming at the top of his lungs with the television volume turned all the way up.
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: ''I barricaded myself in the bathroom and shut the door,'' St. Jean said. ''I thought I was going to get shot through the wall or something. It was some scary stuff.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: St. Jean heard a knock on the door later in the day. It was a reporter from The Daily News. ''I thought, 'Oh, no, they found out where I was staying for this Sprewell thing,' '' he said. The reporter wanted to know about the Baldwin incident, however, and asked St. Jean his name. In the News the next day, this paragraph appeared: ''Another hotel guest, in the room next door, said: 'It scared the hell out of me. It's not a lot of fun hearing somebody scream while security is trying to tell him, 'We want to help you.' The guest would not give his game.''
title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY
title: Mother Is Investigated In Death of Son, 13

text: The Gloucester County Prosecutors' Office is investigating whether the mother of a 13-year-old boy found dead in his bed on Tuesday caused the boy's death by providing him with illegal drugs.
title: Mother Is Investigated In Death of Son, 13

text: Prosecutors are handling the death of the boy, Daniel Tobin, as a potential drug overdose after discovering a hypodermic needle in his bedroom, Andrew N. Yurick, the Gloucester County Prosecutor, said.
title: Mother Is Investigated In Death of Son, 13

text: Daniel's mother, Mary Alice Tobin, was arrested Wednesday on charges that she distributed cocaine and marijuana to four Washington Township youths who were acquainted with Daniel. Investigators are trying to determine whether Ms. Tobin, 40, also provided her son with drugs, he said. Under state law, whoever supplies a lethal dose of illegal drugs can be held responsible for the death.
title: Mother Is Investigated In Death of Son, 13

text: At a time when the public is clamoring for tougher school discipline, many educators across the nation are edging into the role of policing not just what goes on within their own buildings, but off-campus problems as well, from fistfights at the mall or sexual harassment on the school bus to drinking, smoking or drug use in students' homes.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Many schools now have codes of conduct barring the use of alcohol, drugs or tobacco by athletes and others who participate in extracurricular activities. Many also have policies requiring suspension or expulsion when a student is arrested, and some intervene even when the police have not been contacted.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Generally, schools have broad discretion on how to handle out-of-school behavior that may disrupt school life. And many school officials say that to maintain a healthy atmosphere in school -- and to respond to community concerns about young people lacking adequate family supervision -- they cannot ignore what happens off campus.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: The increasing number of suspensions can be traced in part to Federal laws mandating zero tolerance of weapons or drugs in school, laws that have spurred schools to a more active role in policing outside behavior that could spill into school.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''We're seeing more of these disciplinary actions than in the past, in part because society is looking so desperately for some source of supervision for kids who are seen as out of control,'' said Steven Shapiro, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union. ''Schools are, by default, what people look to. And when the Supreme Court O.K.'d drug testing of student athletes in 1995, which is really testing for drugs that were taken out of school, that was seen in some places as a green light for getting involved in behavior that takes place out of school.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: But some parents feel that the extension of school discipline into weekends and evenings -- and their own homes -- encroaches on their parental authority.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: In Liverpool, N.Y., last November, 13-year-old Ryan Kellogg was suspended for the rest of the school year for leaving a message on a classmate's tape machine, mixing goofy remarks like ''I feed you ice'' with graphic sexual threats about shoving a Remington semiautomatic and a box of cornflakes into her private parts.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: His mother, Ann Coghlan, does not defend his action, but she is far more upset about the school's intervention.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''This happened off school grounds, out of school time, on a weekend,'' she said. ''It's up to me to discipline Ryan for what he does at home. That's my job as a parent.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Liverpool school officials say they were obliged to act under Federal antidiscrimination laws requiring schools to maintain an atmosphere that is not sexually hostile.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''This girl, understandably, was scared by the phone message, and worried about being around the boy who left it,'' Dennis O'Hara, the school district's lawyer, said. ''Under Federal law, we are liable if we have a sexually hostile school environment. And state law clearly supports our right to suspend students whose off-campus misconduct may cause problems in school.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: But the authority of schools is often challenged.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: In Connecticut last month, a state judge said a 1995 law giving schools the power to expel students whose conduct off school grounds violates their policies and ''is seriously disruptive of the educational process'' -- a typical standard for such laws -- was unconstitutionally vague. The court overturned the expulsion of a Thomaston High School student, Kyle P. Packer, who had been charged with possessing marijuana.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: The Thomaston Superintendent, George Counter, defended the law. ''If there's gang violence or a drug bust or a shooting at the mall,'' he said, ''and the student can walk back in the door Monday morning as if nothing happened, it sends kids the wrong message. We need discretion to decide what the response should be, depending on how serious the offense is, how it's going to affect things at school and whether the kid is one who's always in trouble.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: In Florida, an appeal has been filed on behalf of Zachary Moser and Marc Crawley, two St. Petersburg High School students who were suspended last year after they left school early in the morning to smoke marijuana and on their return were confronted by school officials.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''These boys did something in the privacy of their homes,'' their lawyer, Meredith Wester, said. ''One of them came to school two and a half hours after smoking, the other one five hours after smoking. There was no evidence that they were under the influence. How far should this go? If a student has a beer at home one night, can they be suspended when they get to school the next day?''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: In White Plains last fall, Elana Nightingale, a 16-year-old who is a photo editor on the White Plains High School newspaper -- and a smoker -- refused to sign a code of conduct under which students who use or possess tobacco, alcohol, marijuana, cocaine or steroids are automatically suspended from participating in sports or other extracurricular activities. The policy, originally written so broadly that it would cover even students who sipped Communion wine, said, ''These standards of behavior are in effect both in and out of school, including 24 hours/day.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: With help from the local civil-liberties union, Ms. Nightingale won the right for students with ''principled'' opposition to instead sign a statement acknowledging that they have read the rules.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''It's a delicate balance,'' said Ann Majestic, a North Carolina lawyer who represents schools. ''School systems are feeling pushed more and more to extend their authority, but they worry that if they do it in one case, and parents see that their authority extends beyond the school grounds, they will become responsible -- and liable -- for everything that happens outside. You can't police everything. I tell my clients that they have to be able to show how the outside behavior directly affects what happens in school.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: In the 9,200-student Liverpool district bordering Syracuse, where Ryan Kellogg lives, the number of suspensions serious enough to warrant a hearing -- any in which a suspension longer than five days is considered -- doubled in the last four years, to about 135 last year.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''It isn't so much a change in our policies; it's that we're dealing with worse student behavior,'' the Superintendent, John Cataldo, said. ''We're having more problems with student-to-student interaction, as kids walk to school or wait for the bus. That's everything from a shove to sexual harassment.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Most parents support the discipline policy, Mr. Cataldo said, adding that few students are suspended for as long as Ryan was and that only a handful of suspensions have been appealed in the last four years.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Still, Ryan's case has generated a heated debate, with extensive local news media coverage. Ms. Coghlan and Carol Parrillo, another mother, whose 10th-grade son was suspended for five days in November for an off-campus fistfight, have collected more than 300 signatures on a petition to the school board from those who ''do not agree the district has the right to police our children when school is not in session.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''In my son's case,'' Ms. Parrillo said, ''the fight didn't happen at school, the other kid doesn't even go to the same school, we paid for the broken glasses and I just don't see any way that it affects school.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: In Ryan's case, Ms. Coghlan said she wished the girl's family had called her directly to complain, rather than go to school officials.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''I would have agreed Ryan had done something wrong and had him apologize,'' said Ms. Coghlan, a respiratory therapist who works in a sleep laboratory all night. ''And I would have grounded him from using the phone, which is what I did do. Or the school could have called me in to talk about it. But they have no right to punish him for what he does in this house. If they want to tell me how to discipline my kid on weekends, they can pay child support, too.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Ms. Coghlan, a single mother, dismissed her son's conduct as a silly, though obnoxious, prank.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: ''Years ago, people made all kinds of phone calls, but nobody did anything about it because there weren't any tapes,'' she said. ''Now everything's a Federal offense, and kids can't be kids anymore. As far as I'm concerned, this is just a one-time incident. And at 13, when they're just exploring sexual issues, the school's overreacting to treat it this way.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: But because of the Federal law, sexual harassment cases pose special problems for administrators. ''Schools are really boggled about how they're supposed to deal with the kind of case where there's no physical assault, but there may be a boy making calls every night,'' Ms. Majestic, the lawyer who represents schools, said. ''And I don't know what to tell them. Of course, girls need an atmosphere where they can learn, but that doesn't mean every immature teen-age boy making crude sexual remarks should be treated like a criminal.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Ryan, a capable student, has had other disciplinary problems: even before the taped message, he had been suspended twice this school year, once for throwing grapes and once for breaking pencils, and had been in trouble many other times for various forms of vulgarity and disruptive behavior.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: When the school called about the current suspension, Ms. Coghlan said, ''I looked out the window and saw him walking around the backyard in circles with his backpack on his back. But I had to go to work soon, so there was no time for me to get into it with him.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Last month, the school board rejected Ms. Coghlan's appeal of the suspension, but said that if Ryan got therapy -- and if his family authorized the therapist to discuss his progress with the school -- the board would support any modification of the penalty that the administration recommended. But Ms. Coghlan said that even if Ryan did go into counseling, she would not want it discussed with the school. She said she would further appeal the suspension.
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Ryan now attends a tutoring program in the morning and spends long afternoons at home. He mostly looks at his feet when asked questions about his phone message and his suspension. ''I'd rather be back at school,'' he said. ''I think I could do fine.''
title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives

text: Steve Earle respects the country-music staples: road songs, love songs and outlaw songs. It's just that in his songs, the road usually leads nowhere, the outlaws get caught and the romances can be summed up with, as one song puts it, ''Nothing ventured, nothing lost.'' Often, Mr. Earle's music gives his words a buoyant backdrop, full of twangy guitar hooks and clear-cut choruses. But his voice -- a hoarse, crumbling rasp full of bitter experience -- offers no false comforts.
title: No Fool for Happy Endings

text: Mr. Earle's set at Tramps on Wednesday night, the first of two sold-out nights, was roots-rock with widespread roots. In a generous set that stretched more than two hours, Mr. Earle played most of his new album, ''El Corazon'' (Warner Brothers), along with unflinching songs from his previous albums. Between songs, he alluded to the drug addiction he overcame in the mid-1990's and offered self-deprecating aphorisms. ''In affairs of the heart,'' he said, ''trust absolutely nobody, and least of all me.''
title: No Fool for Happy Endings

text: Mr. Earle is steeped in country traditions, from stoic Ernest Tubb two-beats to twangy Bakersfield honky-tonk. But his fondness for country doesn't exclude other styles: folky Appalachian finger-picking, British invasion pop-rock, Tex-Mex rock-and-roll and folk-rock. Mr. Earle also reconnected country to Celtic music in songs like ''Copperhead Road'' (which he started on Wednesday by playing a jig on mandolin) and ''Devil's Right Hand'' (with his manager, Dan Gillis, on penny whistle).
title: No Fool for Happy Endings

text: Many of Mr. Earle's best songs are terse narratives without happy endings; like Bruce Springsteen, he is a master of succinct detail. In ''Taneytown,'' a black boy is attacked by white toughs, stabs one and learns later that another black boy was lynched; in ''Copperhead Road,'' the son of a moonshiner grows up to be a marijuana farmer. If anyone else sang them, some of Mr. Earle's other songs could be mistaken for professional Nashville country fare, with well-placed guitar hooks and neatly phrased observations about love. Instead, his singing corrodes the usual Nashville weaknesses of complacency or self-pity.
title: No Fool for Happy Endings

text: Mr. Earle's band gave his songs a lean but dynamic drive. He often started out strumming or picking alone, with the band arriving like the cavalry for the final verses. Buddy Miller, on lead guitar, provided low-slung Duane Eddy lines or gnarled Celtic phrases.
title: No Fool for Happy Endings

text: Mr. Miller and his wife, Julie, opened the concert backed by Mr. Earle's rhythm section. They perform together but record albums separately, revealing two distinct approaches. Mr. Miller is a honky-tonk classicist, singing about all the ways his heart has been broken with a voice whose tension and amusement hark back to Lefty Frizzell. Ms. Miller, breathy-voiced and gentle, writes more enigmatic songs, full of uncertain desires, angels and intimations of sin and death. For Mr. Earle, both are kindred spirits.
title: No Fool for Happy Endings

text: Mr. Earle's tour continues tonight at the Trade Winds in Seabright, N.J.
title: No Fool for Happy Endings

text: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK CITY
title: Man Fleeing the Police Jumps From Fourth Floor

text: A Brooklyn man jumped out of a fourth-story window on Tuesday night with 700 pounds of marijuana in his bedroom and police officers knocking at his door, the police said.
title: Man Fleeing the Police Jumps From Fourth Floor

text: The man, Gerald Dennis, 36, was listed in stable condition at Kings County Hospital Center after the plunge, said Detective Joseph Pentangelo, a Police Department spokesman. Detective Pentangelo said Mr. Dennis was arraigned at his bedside and charged with criminal possession of marijuana and criminal possession of a weapon.
title: Man Fleeing the Police Jumps From Fourth Floor

text: The officers had gone to Mr. Dennis's apartment in Crown Heights shortly after 7 P.M. to arrest one of his roommates on a Federal evidence-tampering warrant, the police said. But when officers broke down the door, the police said, they found a loaded .38-caliber semi-automatic pistol resting on a living-room table, a strong odor of marijuana coming from the bedroom and Mr. Dennis about to jump out of a window.
title: Man Fleeing the Police Jumps From Fourth Floor

text: After obtaining a search warrant, officers discovered 700 pounds of marijuana hidden in boxes in the bedroom, the police said. They said the drugs had an approximate street value of $1 million.
title: Man Fleeing the Police Jumps From Fourth Floor

text: 321 pages. Pantheon Books. $25.
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: What is appealing about the views of Stanley Crouch, a columnist for The New York Daily News and a jazz critic, is that he fully acknowledges the worst about the contemporary American scene yet remains deeply optimistic about the country's future.
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: For instance, in his new book, ''Always in Pursuit: Fresh American Perspectives, 1995-1997,'' he writes that he doesn't accept that ''the verdict in the O. J. Simpson double-murder case and the heated counterpoint of celebration and condemnation mean the country is now in greater racial trouble.''
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: ''Such occasions,'' he continues, ''inevitably work out for the national good because they demand that we face the complexities of our nation and grow up.'' In any case, despite whatever racial divisions the case may have deepened, ''It is also true that since the most popular people in today's America are probably Colin Powell, Michael Jordan and Oprah Winfrey, we don't seem to have lost much ground because of a hypnotic murder trial. Not one of them seems to have lost a single white admirer since the verdict was read.''
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: Such figures can be popular, he argues, in part because the country is undergoing what he calls cultural miscegenation, or a blending if not of bloodlines then of personal styles, facial expressions, our manners of speech, our gestures, the way we talk.
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy
