text: He writes: ''I do not think that the question of race will disappear or that we will be closing in on some paradise in which color means absolutely nothing, but I do think that we will become far and away more comfortable with human commonality and variety than we are now.''
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: For Mr. Crouch, the single greatest expression of this commonality is the American vernacular art of jazz, through which, he writes in an extended essay on Duke Ellington, one can meet, ''in ever greater detail, the black, brown, beige and bone people whose suffering, whose celebration, and whose spiritual integrity formed beacons of tragic optimism for our culture.''
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: Through such prose riffs, Mr. Crouch offers perspectives on the American scene that are often bracing. He writes that he didn't get the reaction to the tragic death of Diana, Princess of Wales: ''What Diana benefited from was her public manipulation of an outdated concept of aristocracy, an idea of bloodline importance that I find repulsive in our time.'' He deplores the decline of civility: ''What the horrifying stories of humiliation during slavery have done, it seems to me, is lead to a confusion between service and subservience, which results in people of all races giving you bad service in order to prove that they aren't inferior to you.''
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: He captures eloquently how Louis Armstrong elevated kitsch art. ''Papa Dip, the New Orleans Prometheus, became famous for his ability to change the maudlin popular song into a work of art through bending it, leaving some notes out and adding others, slyly and wryly making fun of the mushy lyrics in his verbal asides or gargling them in his throat then spewing out percussive, wordless flights of pulsation that suddenly tore out the heart as they became transcendently lyrical.'' As Mr. Crouch sums up the striking variety of his targets: ''Mountain ranges and ticks are equally real; one group stands up next to heaven; the other swells itself on our blood.''
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: The problem is that too much of ''Always in Pursuit'' resembles his previous collection, ''The All-American Skin, or, The Decoy of Race.'' Both books focus on the same subjects: jazz, the American cultural gumbo and the folly of black separatist movements, among others. They praise the same heroes, the composer Duke Ellington, the writers Ralph Ellison and Albert Murray and the film producers Albert and Allen Hughes. And they express their similar ideas in similar language.
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: Such a criticism will strike Mr. Crouch as quibbling. He sees himself as a jazz artist, ''looking for fresh ways to organize the material, to set up ideas, to work on thematic variations, to shift and play with rhythms.'' He accepts William Carlos Williams's advice that by exploring the specific thoroughly enough one can achieve the universal.
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: Yet by repeating so many ideas, he drains them of their surprise and forces the reader to pay closer attention to the form in which they are expressed. You become more aware of his tendency to attenuate his long sentences merely for the sake of rhythm, putting you to sleep before they end. You becomes more sensitive to the way his metaphors tend to mix themselves. For instance, of the way the characters in a book he admires try to adapt to the places they find themselves in, Mr. Crouch writes, ''If not, they might snap the running legs of their spirits in the gopher holes of desperate nostalgia, in the demon cups of booze, in the Never-Never Land clouds of marijuana, in the snorted up lines of white powder laid out on a mirror that reveals no more to the whizzing onlooker than disembodiment.'' )
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: Without the slap of fresh ideas, you grow weary of such prose after a while. In his introduction, Mr. Crouch writes also that he believes an essay ought to ''give the impression that one has read a much longer work.'' He means of course that ''it ought to have the poetic power capable of summoning and projecting a larger feeling and a greater sense of information and engagement than the number of pages would suggest.'' But unhappily too many of the essays here seem long in a sense the author didn't intend.
title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy

text: MASKET-David C., 67. Died on February 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Joan Gellinoff Masket, loving father of Steven and Elaine Masket, Mary-Ellen and David Stein, Elizabeth and Jonathan Sommer. Adored grandfather of Willy, Alex, Dana, Adam, Matthew and Allison. Devoted brother of Darcy Greher and brother-in-law of Judy Levy and Harold Greher. Cherished uncle and friend. You will be in our hearts, always. Contributions can be made to the Calhoun School, 433 West End Avenue, NYC 10024 or the Guild for the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, NYC, 10021. Services will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, February 5, at 12:30 P.M.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.

text: MASKET-David C. The Hunter College Commuity mourns the loss of David Masket, husband of Hunter alumna Joan Gellinoff Masket. Mr. Masket, former Chairman and former Vice Chairman of the Board of Maidenform Worldwide, joined his wife in supporting the College in many ways. He served as a member of the President's Corporate Advisory Council and was a member of the Friends of the Hunter College Library and the Friends of the Hunter College Art Galleries. He also supported Mrs. Masket, a Trustee of the Hunter College Foundation, in her many endeavors to benefit the College through her work with the Alumni Association and as founding Chair of The Guild for the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Mrs. Masket and her family. David A. Caputo, President, Hunter College Allan H. Kurtzman, Chair, The Hunter College Foundation
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.

text: MASKET-David. The Calhoun School deeply mourns the passing of David Masket, former President of the Board of Trustees, father of graduates Mary-Ellen Stein '74, Elizabeth Sommer '76, and grandfather of Matthew Sommer, Calhoun second grader. With his wife Joan, he was an active member of our school community for thirty years. David served in a number of capacities over that long span of time, never faltering in his dedication, loyalty and belief in Calhoun. His wise counsel and leadership were marked by both wit and humanity, and we will never forget that David Masket was one of us. It is difficult to express in words the depth of sympathy that we feel for Joan, their children and their grandchildren. Mariana S. Leighton, Head of School
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.

text: MASKET-David. The Board of Trustees of The Calhoun School records with deep sorrow the loss of Trustee and former President, David Masket. Longtime colleague and dear friend, David was a tower of strength and a leader who inspired others by his quiet, dignified manner and sound judgment. Kind, compassionate, and intelligent, he will be greatly missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Joan, his children and grandchildren, and all in his family who grieve his passing, as do we. Ronald M. Foster, Jr., President
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.

text: MASKET-David C. The entire staff of the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College mourns the loss of our dear friend David C. Masket, founding member of our Guild and husband of our beloved chairperson Joan G. Masket. We will miss his strength, his guidance, his warmth, his good humor and his unfailing confidence in our future. Joseph A. LoSchiavo, Director Kate Mennone, General Manager
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.

text: MASKET-David C. The friends of the Masket family who served with Joan on The Guild for the Kaye wish to express deep sorrow at the death of David Masket, a true booster of The Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse and everything Joan did for her alma mater. His advise, counsel and good-hearted participation will be missed by us all. Members and Staff of The Guild for the Kaye
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.

text: MASKET-David. Our cousin, our friend. David epitomized those qualities that distinguished outstanding people, brilliance, compassion, generosity of spirit, caring, high ethical values, love of family and friends. We will remember him with love. Grace Griffenberg, Susan Trovati, Stuart Griffen
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.

text: MASKET-David. Whitehall Tenants Corp extends condolences to Joan Masket and the entire family on the untimely passing of our former President. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Horace Bullard, President Ludwig Bravmann, Vice President
title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.

text: Bam Morris's story is one of those that makes anyone who has followed it shake his head. Sadly, it has become an all too common one in football, and in sports in general.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: In 1994, Morris was a rookie running back with the Pittsburgh Steelers. That season he rushed for over 800 yards -- 146 of them in a single game against the Giants.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: For someone who was so heavy, a bulky 240-plus pounds, Morris showed great moves and a surprising burst of speed. He was being called the next Earl Campbell.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: The next season, Morris rushed for 188 yards and four touchdowns in the post-season alone, including 73 yards in Super Bowl XXX against the Dallas Cowboys.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Then there were the final seven games of the 1996 season, when he was with the Baltimore Ravens. Morris led the American Football Conference with a spectacular 618 yards rushing during that span. Only Barry Sanders had more rushing yards (756) in the last seven games of the season.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: But along the way there were severe problems for Morris, the biggest involving drugs. Still, because of his talent, he got second chance after second chance after second chance.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Morris was arrested in March 1996 after police in Texas found six pounds of marijuana in his car. He pleaded guilty to misdemeanor marijuana possession, avoiding a prison sentence, but the Steelers released him later that summer.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: The Ravens signed him for the 1996 season knowing he would have to serve a four-game drug suspension, and he still led them in rushing.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Last season, he led them in rushing again despite serving another four-game suspension for testing positive for alcohol, a violation of the league's policy for drug offenders.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Three weeks ago, however, his football career may have hit its lowest point when Morris began serving a four-month prison term for missing meetings with his probation officer.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: His situation has raised questions -- mainly, why? Why does an athlete who has everything -- plenty of money, a potential Pro Bowl career -- throw it away?
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: ''I just think that, sadly, he did not display sufficient responsibility in his everyday life,'' said Art Modell, the owner of the Ravens.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: ''I think he always thought people would take care of him. He had a nose for finding the holes in the line but also for getting into trouble.''
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: The Ravens wanted Morris to succeed, yes, because he was a valuable commodity who could help the team. But Modell had also formed a personal relationship with Morris. And Baltimore did everything it could to help Morris, including having him attend counseling sessions for his drug use.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: One day last season, Modell told Morris that if there was one more incident involving the running back, he would have to let him go. Then came an embarrassing scene in which Morris's girlfriend got into a fight with another woman at a teammate's party. Soon after that, Modell knew it was time for Morris and the Ravens to part ways.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: ''He became a major distraction for the team,'' Modell said, ''and a major distraction to the city of Baltimore.''
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Will Morris play in the N.F.L. again? Modell thinks he will.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: That may be part of the problem: one team's distraction can be another team's hope. Once Morris gets out of prison, there will be a team waiting to take a chance, thinking it will be the one that can turn him around.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: ''I wish him well,'' Modell said. ''I really do.''
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Knowing that a growing number of coaches and players are beginning to see the Pro Bowl game as a complete waste of time, the league recently sent a memo to every head coach asking them to say nothing but positive things about it. The National Football League is trying to head off any negative publicity.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: But coaches are still complaining about their players participating in the game -- they're just doing so privately.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: The big concern for them? Getting a key player injured. Imagine if Barry Sanders breaks a leg in a game that means nothing.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: More on the Pro Bowl, which is played tonight. The Giants sent two players, linebacker Jessie Armstead and the defensive lineman Michael Strahan. Both players spoke all season about how much they appreciated the effort put out by their defensive coaching staff. Then the players showed it. Armstead paid for the air fare to Hawaii and hotel stay of his position coach, Mike Haluchak, and Haluchak's family, as did Strahan for his coach, Denny Marcin, and Marcin's family.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Then both players chipped in equally to pay for defensive coordinator John Fox and his family to join them all.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: The Washington Redskins may use the franchise tag -- again -- on defensive lineman Sean Gilbert. New England might do the same with their star linebacker, Willie McGinest. If it is used, the tag would assure each player of the average of the top five salaries of their respective positions, at least $3 million a season.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Doesn't sound that bad, right? So why do some players and agents hate the franchise label so much?
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Here's why. Any player who is a franchise player or a transition player -- a transition tag guarantees a player the average of the top 10 salaries -- gets the average of last year's salaries. But this year's numbers, because of the new eight-year, $18 billion television agreement, are expected to skyrocket.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: If, for example, McGinest doesn't have the franchise tag and hits the free-agent market, with all of this new television money in the mix, he would get a much larger salary than any he would receive if New England slapped him with the franchise designation.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Plus, with a franchise tag, players don't get signing bonuses.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: The franchise tag lasts for only one season, and under the current collective bargaining agreement, a team can use it as much as it wants for a particular player.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: So when teams lock up your favorite player with the franchise tag, don't look for him to be ecstatic, even though he is guaranteed a salary of millions of dollars.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: For those undergoing Super Bowl withdrawal, here is one last item. Denver running back Terrell Davis is known as one of the most humble players in the N.F.L., and two things that happened after he was named the game's most valuable player prove just that.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: First, instead of going to the team party after Denver's victory, Davis went back to his hotel room and spent time with his family.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: The next morning, the N.F.L. told Davis that as a result of winning the award, he had to choose between two Ford cars.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: Davis was shocked. He had no idea the most valuable player got a car.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: What did Davis do? He let his brother decide. And then Davis let him keep the car.
title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)

text: The family of a man who was shot and killed by a police officer on Christmas Day has begun legal proceedings against the city, the Police Department and the officer, the family's lawyer said yesterday.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: On Friday, a Brooklyn grand jury cleared the officer, Michael J. Davitt, of any wrongdoing in the slaying of William J. Whitfield 3d, who was unarmed.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: ''The family was shocked, the family was hurt,'' the Rev. Al Sharpton, who has acted as the family spokesman, said yesterday at a news conference in his headquarters in Harlem. ''But they are determined that William Whitfield did not die in vain.''
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: The Whitfield family's lawyer, Michael A. Hardy, said he had filed a notice of claim, a step necessary for the lawsuit to proceed, with the City Comptroller's Office on Friday evening. He said the family intends to seek $100 million in damages.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: Mr. Sharpton assailed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for not criticizing the way that the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, presented the case to the grand jury, and he called on the United States Attorney, Zachary W. Carter of the Eastern District, to begin investigating whether the shooting violated Mr. Whitfield's civil rights.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: ''In this case, there is no gray area,'' Mr. Sharpton said. ''There is no gun, there is no weapon. And the record is on the police.''
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: Jack Deacy, a spokesman for the Mayor's office, said Mr. Giuliani would not comment on Mr. Sharpton's remarks. ''The grand jury has acted and we should respect their decision as part of the criminal justice process,'' Mr. Deacy said.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: Tracy Manley, a spokeswoman for Mr. Hynes, said: ''The investigation by the grand jury was thorough, swift and fair; any suggestion its decision was based on politics is without substance or merit.''
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: Standing with Mr. Sharpton as he spoke were Mr. Whitfield's mother, Eunice Bracey, his fiancee, Larrell Williams, and his 1-year-old son, William 4th. Mr. Sharpton said he would organize a march on Times Square on April 4, the 30th anniversary of the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: A police spokesman, Detective Walter Burnes, said Officer Davitt was placed on administrative duty after the incident and had not been placed on full duty as of yesterday. He said the Police Department is conducting its own investigation.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: Mr. Whitfield, 22, was shot and killed on Dec. 25 inside a Canarsie supermarket by Officer Davitt, a 15-year police veteran who had fired his gun nine times in action, more than any of the other 38,000 officers on the police force.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: His death sparked angry protests and renewed outrage against police brutality, especially in the city's poorer neighborhoods. It also prompted Police Commissioner Howard Safir to institute a program to monitor the 250 police officers who have fired their weapons on three or more occasions.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: Mr. Whitfield had gone to the Glenwood Houses on Dec. 25 to visit Ms. Williams and their son, who turned a year old two weeks after Mr. Whitfield was killed. Mr. Whitfield was on his way to use a pay phone outside the Milky Way supermarket around 1 P.M. to arrange a Christmas dinner with his mother when he encountered a swarm of police officers responding to a complaint of a domestic dispute and a report of gunfire.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: The police said Officer Davitt and his partner, Officer Michael Dugan, both of the Brooklyn South Task Force, spotted Mr. Whitfield near Ms. Williams's apartment building at 1658 Ralph Avenue. They said that after deciding that Mr. Whitfield was behaving suspiciously, the officers ordered him to halt. But instead, the police said, Mr. Whitfield, who had a record that included charges of resisting arrest, robbery and assault and three outstanding warrants for his arrest and was possibly carrying a small amount of marijuana in his pocket, darted into the supermarket.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: The officers chased him and ordered employees and customers out of the supermarket. Officer Davitt shouted, ''Drop'' and fired one shot, the police said. The shot struck Mr. Whitfield in the chest. No weapon was found on or near his body.
title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City

text: A police officer who shot and killed an unarmed man in a Brooklyn grocery store last month was cleared of all criminal charges yesterday by a grand jury that found his actions justified under a law governing the use of deadly force, the Brooklyn District Attorney said.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: After hearing 24 witnesses -- 13 civilians and 11 police officers -- over three weeks in a case that had ignited protests and prompted a change in police procedure, the panel refused to indict Officer Michael J. Davitt in the death of William J. Whitfield, 22, in a confrontation in Canarsie on Christmas Day.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: While the grand jury disclosed no details, officials said it apparently placed the shooting at a confluence of unusual events and misperceptions: a report of shots fired that had brought many officers to the scene, Mr. Whitfield's happening by and his ignoring an order to halt, possibly because he had some marijuana and because there were three outstanding warrants for his arrest and he faced the holiday in jail if he was picked up.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Moreover, witnesses said, he had seemed to act suspiciously, darting into the store and moving behind shelves as Officer Davitt and his partner stalked him with drawn guns. Then, at a crucial moment, Mr. Whitfield was said to have risen up suddenly from a crouch -- with a key ring and a strap in his hand that might have been mistaken for a gun -- and was fatally shot in the chest.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: ''The grand jury reviewed all the facts and circumstances in the incident,'' the prosecutor, Charles J. Hynes, said late in the day. ''Notwithstanding the tragic circumstances which led to the death of Mr. Whitfield, the grand jury concluded that the actions of this police officer were justified under the law governing the use of deadly physical force.''
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Legal experts said the issue before the grand jury was twofold: whether the officer believed he or others were in imminent danger of death or grievous harm, and if so, whether that belief was reasonable. The jury apparently found that the officer had such a belief and that it was reasonable.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: After the shooting, the police disclosed that Officer Davitt had fired his gun 9 times in action in 15 years on the force, the most of any of its 38,000 members, and Police Commissioner Howard Safir instituted a program to monitor the 250 officers who have used their weapons on three or more occasions.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: The grand jury's decision yesterday was applauded by Marshall Trager, a lawyer for Officer Davitt, who said his client, who testified, was ''extremely pleased,'' and added, ''This case represents a prime example of why it is important that there be no rush to judgment, particularly as it relates to police officers who must make split-second decisions.''
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Mr. Whitfield's family, fiancee and neighbors responded with expressions of sorrow, anger and disappointment, and the family lawyer, Michael A. Hardy, said the case was far from over. He said a civil suit charging wrongful death would be filed, and that the United States Department of Justice might be asked to investigate the shooting as a civil rights violation.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: ''Obviously, we are disappointed,'' Mr. Hardy said. He declined further comment, saying he was seeking more information about the decision. But he added, ''We're going forward, no matter what, with the civil suit'' on behalf of Mr. Whitfield's mother, Eunice Bracey; his fiancee, Candy Williams, and their 1-year-old son, William Whitfield Jr.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who has acted as the Whitfield family spokesman, said of the decision, ''They're saying that police can shoot without any reason, without any justification.''
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: ''It appears that the prosecutors are incapable of a police brutality prosecution,'' added Mr. Sharpton, who is planning to hold a news conference today with members of the Whitfield family to discuss the case.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: While there was no evidence that the shooting was racially motivated, race has been a subtext of the case, with Mr. Sharpton and others noting that Officer Davitt is white and that Mr. Whitfield was black. At marches and rallies at the Glenwood Houses, where Mr. Whitfield was visiting his fiancee on the day of the shooting, and at the Sumner Houses in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where he lived at 824 Park Avenue, many residents contended that he was slain without justification and that young black men had more to fear from white officers than from the streets.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Amid the protests, Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani appealed for calm and urged New Yorkers not to leap to any conclusions until the facts were in.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Officials said the confrontation that led to Mr. Whitfield's death began shortly before 1 P.M. on Dec. 25 with the most common of police calls, a domestic dispute at the Glenwood Houses, a city project of six-story buildings at Ralph Avenue and Glenwood Road in Canarsie.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: As four officers arrived to investigate, they heard what sounded like shots from the roof of a project building; looking up, they momentarily saw a young black man at the parapet. A call for assistance went out, saying a young black man had been spotted, and a score of officers from the 63d and 69th Precincts and other commands raced to the scene.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Mr. Whitfield, who had been visiting his fiancee and their son at 1658 Ralph Avenue, apparently had nothing to do with any shooting in the area, but just as the police were arriving went out to find a pay phone to arrange for Christmas dinner at his mother's home.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Officer Davitt, 36, and his partner, Michael Dugan, of the Brooklyn South Task Force, drew up on Ralph Avenue and saw Mr. Whitfield walking from the direction where the shots had been reported, and behaving suspiciously, officials said. He changed direction twice and then ignored the officers' order to halt, darting into the Milky Way, a grocery store at 1669 Ralph Avenue.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: It was never clear why he did not stop. He had a record that included charges of resisting arrest, robbery and assault, and was wanted on outstanding warrants for failing to appear in court to answer misdemeanor assault and drug charges. He also had a little marijuana in his pocket, officials said.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Officers Davitt and Dugan followed Mr. Whitfield into the store, with guns drawn, but did not see him. He had gone to the rear and seemed to be hiding. The officers ordered employees and customers out. Suddenly, then, officials said, Mr. Whitfield rose from a crouch and Officer Davitt, less than 10 feet away, shouted ''Drop!'' and fired once.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: It was unclear if the officer's single word was intended as a call to his partner to get down, or as an order to Mr. Whitfield to drop whatever was in his hand.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: The officer's shot struck Mr. Whitfield in the upper left chest and came out of his lower back. No gun was found in the victim's possession, but a blue knit cap, a ring of keys and a nylon strap 4 inches long were found near his body. Officer Davitt was said to have believed that Mr. Whitfield had a gun and that he and his partner were in mortal danger.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Officer Davitt was placed on administrative duty after the shooting. His lawyer, Mr. Trager, told The Associated Press yesterday that his client had been restored to full duty after the grand jury's decision. But the police said he would remain on administrative duty, at least until the department's own internal investigation was complete.
title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting

text: Following is the Republican response last night by the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, to President Clinton's speech, as recorded by The New York Times:
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Tonight I'd like to share with you our plans, here in the Congress, for a safer, stronger and more prosperous America.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Those plans are shaped by our commitment to family, to faith and to freedom. And they highlight some real differences between the Republican Party and the President, concerning what government should do and how much of your money government should take.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Big Government or families? More taxes or more freedom?
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We believe the choice is clear. The first priority of your representatives in Washington must be to fight for the interests of the American family.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: That's why one of the first things, that's why one of the first things we'll tackle is real reform that's necessary for the I.R.S. I'll have more to say about the I.R.S. later on, but the bottom line is this:
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We're going to stop the abuses the I.R.S. has been inflicting on the American taxpayers.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: You've got our word on it.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Also, we'll be building on the progress of the last few years, when our Republican Congress, working with the nation's governors, took some first historic steps.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We took the first step in transforming welfare into workfare.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We started reducing taxes, especially for families with children. And with considerable difficulty, we finally worked out a long-term agreement with the President for a balanced budget.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We protected Medicare. And in that same way, we're going to protect Medicare, this year, against any changes that would imperil its financial stability.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We strengthened education opportunities for disabled youngsters, launched a long overdue reform of the nation's troubled foster care system, made adoption easier, and encouraged alternatives to abortion.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We proved that people of good will and of strong faith can work together to deal with the problems that face our nation and our neighborhoods.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But we have only just begun the difficult job of stopping Big Government, making it more responsive, and, perhaps hardest of all, rebuilding the trust you used to have in your elected officials.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: That's especially important when it comes to education, to taxes and to the twin plagues of drugs and crime.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Those are the three areas where the American people are most dissatisfied and where our freedom is most threatened.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Parents, and good teachers as well, are dissatisfied with schools where kids don't learn, and in many cases, where they aren't even safe. When one-quarter of our children -- 1 out of 4 -- in the high schools can barely read, isn't it obvious that the current system just isn't working?
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: I know we're all fed up with the criminal justice system that has tragically failed to halt the poisonous epidemic of drugs that is undermining family life in our country. Violent crime is turning the Land of the Free into the Land of the Fearful.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Today's workers and today's savers are angry and disillusioned with a tax code that benefits only tax lawyers and Big Government.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Let's take a look at the typical family budget.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: The typical family pays more than 38 percent in its income in taxes.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: That's nearly 40 cents of every dollar. That's not just bad policy. It's immoral. Our tax system should not penalize marriage, hard work or savings, not to mention your efforts just to keep up with the cost of living. We believe these high taxes mean less freedom over all.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: And yet President Clinton now wants the Government to spend billions of dollars more. But I don't have to tell you, if the Government spends more, you'll wind up getting taxed more.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: You know that. He knows that.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Instead, Republicans want you, the people who work hard for the money, to keep more of what you earn. The President seems to think that Big Government can solve all your children's problems if you'll just give Government more of your money -- and more control over your lives. I think that's nonsense!
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We think the best things for safe, healthy children are healthy, stable families, not more Government programs that require parents to work longer, to take home less, and to spend less with the -- time with the kids. That's why we fought for a $500 per child tax credit last year.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Once again, the choice is really quite clear:
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: More taxes? Or more freedom?
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: The American people elected us in the Congress to listen to you and then to lead. So while we listen respectfully to the President's ideas, we cannot wait on them.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: One example is the drug crisis. With all due respect, for the past five years, we've had all of the wrong kinds signals.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: It took the President four years to admit the need to reduce the tax burden on the American people, as we finally did in the Balanced Budget Act in 1997. That was a welcome reversal of the pile-on-the-taxes approaches in his first four years in office.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But you know that Americans are still overtaxed, overregulated and overgoverned.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: This chart shows how the income of the Federal Government, over the last 30 years, has gone up almost 1,000 percent. But during the same period, family incomes rose only half as much. Government has gotten fat, while families are working overtime just to stay where they were.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We believe hard-working Americans deserve a break. So our focus in 1998 will be to increase family income by cutting taxes and making Government more accountable for the way it spends your money.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But tax relief is only the first step.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: As I said earlier, the only way to limit Government and expand individual freedom is to eliminate the I.R.S. as we know it today.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: It is morally wrong for a free people to live in fear of any Government agency.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: It is morally wrong for a citizen in a democracy to be presumed guilty until proven innocent. And that's the way it is at the I.R.S.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But I.R.S. reform alone is not enough by itself.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: The real problem lies with the tax code.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: It is too complicated and it's simply unfair.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: It punishes you -- punishes you if you are achieving things. It discourages work and savings and innovation.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: As Republicans, we pledge to replace the tax code with a new system that is fair, consistent, easy to understand and less frightening to the American taxpayer, a tax code that will end the fear and encourage more savings and investment.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Because the Republican balanced-budget plan is working now, we should commit here and now, not to spend any budget surplus on unnecessary Government programs.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: If there is any surplus, our priority should be used to -- use part of that to pay down the national debt, and return the rest to you, the taxpayer. After all, it is your money.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Like those proposals, our education plan proposes fundamental change from what we now have. And as a father, and a prospective grandfather, I realize that nothing is more important than the education of our young people.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Washington today has more than 750 education programs, in 39 different bureaucracies.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: That just doesn't make sense.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: And it doesn't make sense for Washington to tax the people in your community and then give the money back with strings attached, of course. We want to cut those strings and to remove the out-of-date rules and restrictions that hold back our schools from the future.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: For example, if your community needs to build new schools or rehabilitate old ones, you should be able to do that.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: If you want to offer merit pay for great teachers, you should be able to do that too.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We've heard a lot from the President about testing.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But he thinks Washington should administer the tests. Wrong again.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We think that you -- the parents, the teachers, the local officials -- should do the job.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Republicans in Congress strongly support that kind of state testing, just as we support an even more important kind: Periodic testing for teachers. Now, you won't hear much about that from the President. On this subject, the President disagrees with us. And we disagree with him.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But good teachers -- like my mother, bless her heart, who taught public school for 19 years -- don't object to testing. They want it. They say, teacher testing will be a key step in implementing the kind of merit pay program that attracts star teachers.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: They also say, even the best teachers can't get good results when their school is a dangerous, and violent place. We hope the President this year will finally see the wisdom in our proposal to give freedom of choice to low-income families whose children are stuck in dead-end, drug-ridden schools.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Because we care so deeply about those families, we want them to have the same option exercised by President Clinton and Vice President Gore, who chose the schools for their children.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Parental choice and involvement are absolutely essential, but choice in education doesn't mean abandoning our public schools.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: It simply means moving decision making away from Washington, and back to you at your family's kitchen table.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: That's the first and most important step to launching an era of education renewal that will equip our schools and our students to lead America and the world into the new century.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But don't forget, today's young people confront a danger even worse than poor education. Teen drug abuse has become epidemic, and there are no safe havens from this insidious modern plague. Over all, teenage drug use has nearly doubled since 1992, and perhaps most frightening of all, nearly half of all 17-year-olds say they could buy marijuana in just an hour's time.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Like the President, I want to stop youth smoking, but narcotics is the problem that is a far greater threat to teenagers.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: First, to solve the drug crisis, we have to start with the family, the school, and with our churches and synagogues.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Studies clearly show that teens in families that eat together, play together, and, yes, pray together are the ones least likely to try drugs.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: When the battle against drug abuse is first waged at home, the war is half won.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Second, schools must be drug-free. We must demand absolute accountability and zero tolerance for any drug abuse on school grounds.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: And third, there is the critical role for the Federal Government. We simply have got to be more aggressive in guarding our national borders. Along with that, we must be more vigilant in arresting and prosecuting anyone -- yes, anyone -- who sells this poison to our young people.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: And fourth, it's time to get tough on society's predators.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We must end parole for violent criminals, crack down on juvenile criminals, increase prison capacity, and make the death penalty a real threat, and we need to impose mandatory penalties for crimes committed with a gun.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: If we are honestly committed to protecting the innocent, we must do more to punish the guilty.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: By combining national leadership here in Washington with community activism, we can, and we will, save America, one child and one neighborhood at a time.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We don't pretend to have all the answers here in Washington, in fact we don't have them. But I guarantee you we will ask the right questions this time.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: For example, there is the issue of child-care. We say, give families more flexibility in the way they work and care for their children.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But how do we do it?
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: *Well, first and foremost, cut the tax burdens on the American family. Don't force both parents to work, and work longer hours, when they could have more time at home with their kids.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: *Give stay-at home parents the same tax breaks and benefits available to parents who use day care. After all, all moms work, whether at home or in an outside job.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: *Let employees negotiate with their employees for flex-time and comp-time arrangements. Help small businesses provide on-site day care. And make it easier, and more profitable, for older Americans to provide child care for growing families.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We're talking about common-sense approaches here because, as parents and grandparents ourselves, we've learned it takes parents, and parental choice, to raise a child in today's world.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Of course, there are dangers in today's world that demand strong national leadership. You know, just last week, Pope John Paul's visit to Cuba reminded us once again that, despite the collapse of Communism, the future remains very uncertain over much of the globe.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: And let me make one thing perfectly clear tonight to Saddam Hussein -- or anyone else who needs to be told: Despite any current controversy, this Congress will vigorously support the President in full defense of America's interests throughout the world.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: By the same token though, we will ask the President to work with us in considering ways to stop the threats of terrorism, international narcotics, and the spread of weapons of mass destruction.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: You know, as hard as it is to believe, right now, our country has no national defense against missiles carrying nuclear, chemical, or biological warheads.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Those who hate America most -- in Iraq, in Iran, and elsewhere -- they know that.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: President Clinton, I urge you to reconsider your opposition to having a national missile defense for America. Join us in taking the steps that will actually deploy a national missile defense system for the United States.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Now there are at least a dozen other important subjects that Congress will deal with in the months ahead. For example, ending the the dreadful practice of partial-birth abortions. I urge our Democratic colleagues in the Senate to help us override the President's second veto of that legislation.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: In addition, we're committed to more positive reforms in health care, protection of worker's rights and their paychecks, reform of bankruptcy laws, and legislation to combat teen smoking.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: All the while, we're going to concentrate on what we call oversight in the Congress, which means finding out why you aren't getting your money's worth from Government. And why so much of your hard-earned money goes for programs filled with fraud and abuse.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: For instance, last year, the Administration admitted it paid out $23 billion dollars in ineligible Medicare claims -- that's in one year alone -- and spent another $5 billion dollars in improper payments in just one welfare program.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: We intend to make Government accountable. From the classrooms to the courts. From the clerks to the President's Cabinet. From the post office to the Presidency.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Now, this isn't a matter of Republicans versus Democrats. No. It's a question of whether we will learn from past mistakes, in order to restore the great institutions and cherished values -- family, faith, and freedom -- that for so long have held us together as a nation.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: The President was right tonight to point out our heroes , but there's some others who should not forget about. Twenty-five years ago next month, a small band of Americans returned home after long captivity in Southeast Asia.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Some were broken in body but never broken in spirit, those returning prisoners of war reminded us, through our cheers and our tears, just how precious we hold our freedom.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Now the world has changed greatly -- and greatly for the better -- in those 25 years.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: But we must remember why it changed, why we can now look to the century ahead with high hopes, and just why we are the envy of the world.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: The reason is that Americans, we the people, have been willing to sacrifice everything to protect our families, to practice our faith, and to defend our freedom.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: What those heroes fought to preserve, we must now work to recover and to strengthen:
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: By renewing American education. Restoring the security of the American family. And rebuilding the kind of Government that works with you, and for you. The kind of Government you can trust.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: Thank you for listening. Good night. And bless you all.
title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address

text: John D. Feerick, the dean of Fordham Law School, will begin to hear testimony Tuesday on Latrell Sprewell's one-year suspension by the National Basketball Association and the termination of his contract by the Golden State Warriors.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: Sprewell was punished for attacking and threatening to kill his coach, P. J. Carlesimo, last December, touching off a public debate on issues from player-coach relations to labor relations to race relations.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: As the league's grievance arbitrator, Feerick will have 30 days from the completion of the hearing to make a ruling. Not only will he decide when Sprewell will be eligible to play again, but his decision could weaken the power of N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern to impose such long penalties and could influence the direction of contract negotiations between the league and its players.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: ''I think we're going to re-evaluate the absolute power that David Stern has, how he has become judge and jury,'' said Buck Williams, the Knicks' veteran forward, who is a former president of the N.B.A. Players Association. ''At the same time, I think it should open up some dialogue about the relationships coach and players have in communicating and trying to get along harmoniously, which I think has been a huge problem.''
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: The Warriors suspended Sprewell, a three-time All-Star guard, for 10 games on Dec. 1, the day he attacked Carlesimo at a practice. On Dec. 3, the team terminated the remaining $25 million of Sprewell's $32 million contract. A day later, Stern handed down the harshest suspension in league history for an offense that did not involve drugs.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: Many of the Warriors' players are expected to testify here, although a team official said he did not expect that to happen until Wednesday, after the team's game against Portland on Tuesday night. There is a chance some of the coaches will testify on Tuesday. The hearing is expected to continue here until Friday, with additional days set aside for next Tuesday and Wednesday in Manhattan. That means Sprewell's hearing will nudge up against the league's annual All-Star Game weekend, Feb. 6-8 in New York.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: The hearing comes right after detailed talks by the players about the prospective reopening of the collective bargaining agreement. In April, the league has the right to reopen the agreement unilaterally if players' salaries and benefits exceed 51.8 percent of a designated portion of the owners' revenue.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: A summer labor war may be unavoidable, and whatever Feerick decides may push the pendulum to one side. If the union is successful in considerably reducing the suspension, Stern's authority will be eroded. If the one-year suspension is upheld, the commissioner's action will be seen as a precursor to a new get-tough policy toward players with behavior problems.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: ''The question, in view of that,'' said Billy Hunter, executive director of the players association, ''is whether the arbiter is going to be inclined to look at the legal issues that have been raised -- and the law in support of the legal issues -- and make a decision based upon a narrow view of the readings, without letting all of this other stuff permeate the decision-making process.''
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: Sprewell's legal team plans to argue that the league's 48-hour investigation was not thorough enough, and to challenge the league's finding that the second part of Sprewell's attack -- when he returned to the arena after being thrown out of practice -- was premeditated. That action was the main reason that Stern's punishment was so severe, but Sprewell insists he did not return to the practice with malicious intent.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: Although Feerick has politely declined interviews leading up to the arbitration, some of his writings and case histories might indicate that the players association has reason for optimism, some legal experts say.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: ''His sentiments are clearly for individual liberties,'' said Denis McInerney, senior counsel at the Manhattan firm of Cahill & Gordon and a longtime friend of Feerick's. ''He's very sensitive to due-process issues. His lectures and writings attune to individual freedoms.''
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: In one of his decisions since he became the league's grievance arbitrator last year, Feerick ordered the Los Angeles Clippers in November to return $107,000 of a $167,000 fine that the team had levied against center Stanley Roberts for failing to participate in summer workouts and physical therapy sessions, and for cursing at Coach Bill Fitch.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: In the other three grievances he has heard, he has found in favor of the league. He refused to overturn the league's suspension of Portland's Isaiah Rider after Rider was arrested on a marijuana charge; he ruled for San Antonio in a case brought by Charles Smith over a knee injury, and he found in favor of the Nets after Chris Childs, their former point guard, contended the team owed him money under an oral agreement.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: Feerick, who is 61, has been an arbitrator for other high-profile cases in recent years, including labor disputes at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and the 1994 New York City transit negotiations. From 1993 to 1995, he was an arbitrator of disputes involving the National Football League salary cap.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: Johnnie Cochran, who sat at a table with Sprewell's advisers during a news conference a week after the attack, will not be in Portland. Cochran, one of the lawyers who defended O. J. Simpson, may be retained if Sprewell loses his grievance case and chooses to pursue a lawsuit.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: Because the incident involved a black player and white coach, the issue of race relations in the league was widely discussed after the attack. Hunter has refused to discuss race in connection with the case. But he says that he believes there are issues involved beyond the altercation, issues that Feerick will have to take into account.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: ''Sports, in many ways, is similar to the military complex within the country,'' Hunter said. ''You have all the patriotism, rah-rah, the following of the orders, the whole nine yards. Here it is, one of the last bastions of discipline. And the perception is now that athletes are rising up, so that they begin to challenge authority. For a lot of old heads, that's a problem.''
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: He continued his point, adding: ''A guy in major league baseball can get caught smuggling a pound of cocaine into the country and he'll get suspended for a while and then they'll talk about reinstating him. In the scheme of things, that's more horrendous than someone who puts their hands on somebody's throat in the presence of 15 people and the guy coming away with some scratches.
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: ''It's something about our ethical system, about some of the institutions we have built up,'' Hunter said of Sprewell's predicament. ''When, in reality, you survey history and you discover he is just one of many athletes to get into it with an authority figure.''
title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case

text: At the Sundance Film Festival, where young white audiences predominate and much of this year's emphasis was on antic white characters having trouble with their love lives, two big winners were films about black men in prison. Top dramatic honors went to Marc Levin's ''Slam,'' made in a muscular documentary style and featuring a strong performance from Saul Williams, who plays a young man from the ghetto who is jailed on a marijuana charge. Punctuated by tough, galvanizing outbursts of rap poetry, ''Slam'' tells a not entirely unpredictable story in newly energetic fashion.
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: In this year's much stronger documentary category, a Grand Jury Prize went to ''The Farm,'' a lucid and affecting look at life inside America's largest maximum-security prison. Filmed in Angola, La., by Jonathan Stack and Liz Garbus over the course of a year, it concentrates closely on six inmates and their varied problems. In a radical change of pace, ''The Farm'' shared this prize with ''Frat House,'' by Todd Phillips and Andrew Gurland, a cool look at the staggering stupidity, obscenity and brutishness of fraternity hazing, with one of the filmmakers even experiencing Hell Week firsthand. ''And after going through it, one question still remains,'' he says as narrator: ''Why is it that some guys are so afraid of standing out that they are willing to do almost anything to fit in?''
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: Another documentary, Penelope Spheeris's ''Decline of Western Civilization, Part III,'' with its fond but pitying portrait of homeless teen-age punks in Los Angeles, received the festival's Freedom of Expression award. And the prize for best documentary direction went to Julia Loktev for ''Moment of Impact,'' her first-person account of the devastating car accident that injured her father and forever altered the life of her family.
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: At the festival, in Park City, Utah, which ended yesterday, the prize for dramatic direction went to ''Pi,'' a bizarre and ingeniously mathematical paranoid thriller, the first film by Darren Aronofsky. The day before, Mr. Aronofsky, whose parents are scientists, said that he, too, had considered a science career. ''But I decided to get into something less competitive, like filmmaking,'' he said.
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: Democratically distributed Sundance prizes include the Filmmakers Trophy, awarded by movie makers to one of their own. This year, their dramatic prize went to ''Smoke Signals,'' a gently sardonic look at contemporary American Indian life, directed charmingly by Chris Eyre from a distinctive screenplay by the poet and fiction writer Sherman Alexie. Its documentary counterpart went to Steve Yeager's ''Divine Trash,'' which chronicles John Waters's collaboration with Divine. Mr. Waters describes his ''Pink Flamingoes'' star as a performer ''who started his career playing a homicidal maniac and ended it playing a loving mother -- which is a pretty good stretch, especially when you're a 300-pound man.''
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: The prize for documentary cinematography went to Tom Hurwitz's intimate cinema verite camera work for Barbara Kopple's ''Wild Man Blues,'' which amusingly and perceptively follows Woody Allen on a European concert tour with his jazz band. Mr. Allen's travel habits alone are enough to make this one of the festival's standouts.
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: The dramatic cinematography prize went to the expert Declan Quinn for ''2X4,'' a film about Irish immigrants living in the Bronx and working construction jobs in Manhattan. Jimmy Smallbone, who collaborated on the screenplay, is the film's director as well as its star.
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: Lisa Cholodenko received the Waldo Salt screenwriting award for ''High Art,'' her film about the exploring of love and ambition through the close relationship between two women, one a famed and reclusive photographer, the other her 24-year-old neighbor. Though Sundance does not automatically present acting awards, a special jury prize went to the Scottish actress Andrea Hart, who appears in ''Miss Monday'' as a bulimic woman who becomes a screenwriter's strange muse. And the Latin American Cinema Award went to the Mexican film ''Who the Hell is Juliette?''
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: Short films honored included the top winner, Debra Granik's ''Snake Feed,'' and an honorable mention winner, ''Human Remains,'' by Jay Rosenblatt. Not honored, but arguably the most entertaining short, was Matthew Harrison's ''Bystander From Hell,'' a humorous one-scene look at a pest on a film set. He's on the outside looking in, dying to be part of the excitement. There's no concept that festivalgoers at Sundance better understand.
title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners

text: ''Part stripper, part English professor's egghead daughter,'' Sarah, a k a Tabitha, reads Harper's Magazine before bed and leafs through Playboy between shows. Diana Atkinson's first novel, ''Highways and Dancehalls,'' is told as the journal of Sarah's first year on the road, dancing in western Canada's motels and bars. Sarah writes whenever she can, setting down stark observations that illuminate her life like a strobe light. In this intimate form, her portraits of the other dancers are also strikingly effective. Whether they're backstage sewing sequins on their costumes, getting high on cocaine mixed with marijuana or curling up together on the bus, these strippers are all too real. But the egghead aspect of Sarah's character is more scrambled. Frequent flashbacks give us glimpses of her childhood, marked by a near-fatal illness, but her troubled family history remains murky. Her feelings of resentment toward her mother are palpable but unexplained, and her sister, who suffered from the same illness Sarah did, is not mentioned until the final pages of the book. While Atkinson never tells us which half of Sarah she thinks is the better one, in the end the professor's daughter is frustratingly unrealized -- utterly outstripped by her roadhouse counterpart. ''Everybody has to fall for something,'' Sarah comments at the close, and readers, though left in the dark by her scattered forays off stage, may well fall for the exquisitely abject world of the strippers she has brought so unsettlingly to life. Aoibheann Sweeney
title: Books in Brief: Fiction

text: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE
title: Waiting for Courtyard Lock

text: There is no lock on the gate leading to the courtyard for the apartments at 253 East 77th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, a fact that tenants there feel anxious in mentioning because it may be an open invitation to criminals.
title: Waiting for Courtyard Lock

text: But, they say, they are tired of schoolchildren smoking marijuana in the courtyard, homeless people defecating in hallways and strangers doing private business, possibly drug deals, in the courtyard's blind spots. And they are tired of what, they say, is the landlord's dragging her feet in installing the lock.
title: Waiting for Courtyard Lock

text: Except for several burglaries, no one can remember a rape, robbery or other serious incident in the last 10 years since the decorative wrought-iron gate went up, without a lock. ''The gate should have a lock, especially with the East Side rapist still running around,'' said Margery Westin, a photographer who has lived there for nearly 20 years. The rapist has attacked at least 11 women in the last two years between 64th and 90th Streets east of Lexington Avenue.
title: Waiting for Courtyard Lock

text: For her part, Gertrude Felder, the landlord, said she was soliciting estimates for a locked gate and planned to install one. Ms. Felder said that her family had owned the complex, which has 24 one-bedroom apartments, since the 1940's, but that tenants did not appreciate her concerns about the costs of a new gate and the intercom system that would also have to be installed. Most of the tenants in the rent-controlled and rent-stabilized complex are working class or on fixed incomes, she said.
title: Waiting for Courtyard Lock

text: Rents are as low as $542 a month, Ms. Felder said, while costs for a new gate and intercom are likely to reach several thousand dollars, with maintenance costs in the hundreds of dollars if the system is vandalized. ''There is no law that compels me to do this, but I will because I want to keep everybody happy,'' she said.
title: Waiting for Courtyard Lock

text: The Coconut Grill restaurant shares a hallway with the apartment complex's open courtyard. Rebecca Braunschweig, the restaurant's manager, said strangers had been found in its basement and that she suspected the open gate had allowed them in. ANTHONY RAMIREZ
title: Waiting for Courtyard Lock

text: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE LANGUAGE
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: Among the avenues of scrutiny in President Clinton's denials of sexual affairs is the precision of his language in insisting on his innocence.
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: The White House has maintained that Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign denial of an extramarital affair with Gennifer Flowers was ''not at odds'' with the testimony he offered under oath on Jan. 17 in his deposition in the Paula Corbin Jones sexual misconduct lawsuit.
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, was asked on Thursday why the public should believe the President on this subject of extramarital affairs, in the face of reports that Mr. Clinton had confirmed a liaison with Ms. Flowers in the sealed deposition he gave on Jan. 17, six years after he had first denied the affair before voters.
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: ''The President knows that he told the truth in 1992 when he was asked about that relationship,'' Mr. McCurry responded, ''and he knows that he testified truthfully on Saturday, and he knows his answers are not at odds. That's all I can say on that subject because of the order of the court that we not provide any additional information on the deposition.''
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: The answer raised the question of whether Mr. Clinton had again denied, not confirmed, the Flowers affair in the recent deposition, given under oath. But Mr. McCurry, citing the confidentiality order in the Jones lawsuit, has declined to further discuss or flatly answer the question.
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: Mr. Clinton denied an involvement with Ms. Flowers while under fire in the 1992 Presidential primary campaign, when he appeared on the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' and made comments that proved to be a turning point in gaining the nomination. He made two points: He acknowledged ''causing pain in my marriage'' when asked the general question about whether he had ever committed adultery. And he responded negatively to the question about Ms. Flowers's claim of ''what she calls a 12-year affair with you.''
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: ''That allegation is false,'' Mr. Clinton said. Critics suspected the reference to 12 years might have offered an opportunity for technical denial. In response to a follow-up question, the President, when asked whether he was ''categorically denying'' an affair with Ms. Flowers, said, ''I've said that before.''
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: Ms. Flowers, commenting on the new accusations that President Clinton had an affair with a White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, maintained in a television interview this week that she did, indeed, have a long-running affair with Mr. Clinton.
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: ''It sort of surprises me at this point,'' Ms. Flowers said on CNBC. ''With all of the problems and the scandals and the 'Gates' that have come up during his terms, that he would be foolish enough to do something like this at this point. You'd think the boy would learn.''
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: Speaking on the condition of anonymity, a partisan in the Paula Jones civil suit against the President said his side heard Mr. Clinton finally confirm the Flowers affair under oath in his deposition on Jan. 17. But a White House official said the President's testimony certainly did not confirm the affair and that the record was ''at the least, ambiguous.''
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: In the 1992 TV interview, Mr. Clinton was asked if he felt like he had ''leveled with the American people.''
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: He replied, ''I have absolutely leveled with the American people.''
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: Any confirmation that Mr. Clinton did not tell the truth in 1992 could undermine his current denial, now being investigated by Federal prosecutors, that he had an 18-month affair at the White House with Ms. Lewinsky.
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: The President has also denied accusations that he or Vernon E. Jordan, his close friend, counseled Ms. Lewinsky to lie under oath to protect him. The precise language of Mr. Clinton's denial Wednesday -- ''There is not a sexual relationship'' -- has left critics once more parsing his precise statements for evasiveness.
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: ''The President is not being cute in some Nixonian way,'' a White House official insisted today, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: The scrutiny of Mr. Clinton's language, normal for any President, has been intense since his earliest days on the campaign trail. Notably, observers carefully tracked his handling of campaign questions about whether he had ever used recreational drugs when he was young. Initially, Mr. Clinton said that he had never broken the anti-drug laws of his state or of the United States. A reporter pondered his precise wording and, realizing the candidate had been a Rhodes scholar at Oxford, carefully rephrased the question. Mr. Clinton then responded: ''I've never broken a state law. But when I was in England I experimented with marijuana a time or two and I didn't like it. I didn't inhale it and never tried it again.''
title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen

text: Re ''Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.'' (news article, Jan. 20): The exemptions from United States wage and immigration laws that Saipan is trying to protect are much like those Guam was lobbying the Clinton Administration to gain, while Guam citizens and interests were contributing nearly $1 million to the Democratic National Committee.
title: Tariff-Free in Saipan

text: At least Saipan brought members of Congress and their aides to the Northern Marianas to see the situation on the ground.
