Would Saipan be having problems with the Democrats and the Clinton Administration, which support a bill that would limit immigration and raise wages in Saipan, if citizens there had contributed to the D.N.C.?
title: Tariff-Free in Saipan

text: Weston, Fla., Jan. 20, 1998
title: Tariff-Free in Saipan

text: While I was pleased to see your Jan. 20 news article on human rights problems in the Northern Marianas and the related ''Congressional fact-finding,'' I was disappointed that it did not focus more on the horrific status of the international contract workers in the commonwealth.
title: Tariff-Free in Saipan; Workers' Plight

text: When I was human rights advocate for the Diocese of Chalan Kanoa, I witnessed and documented the plight of garment factory workers there recruited from China. I met with Chinese workers forced to sign a contract with their Government that denied them the right to strike and subjected them to civil or criminal penalties for ''illegal political or religious activities.''
title: Tariff-Free in Saipan; Workers' Plight

text: Working under an oppressive contract system and monitored by Communist Party agents, these workers are fearful to complain about inhumane conditions. Their story, and that of thousands of other contract workers from the Philippines, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh, deserves to be told.
title: Tariff-Free in Saipan; Workers' Plight

text: With a toughly worded speech designed to frame both the legislative session and his re-election campaign, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday ridiculed the notion that societal factors were to blame for violent crime and pledged to push for bills this year that would make it easier to imprison and, in some cases, execute criminals.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: Speaking to a group of district attorneys in Manhattan, Mr. Pataki described as ''nonsense'' the argument that a criminal's actions stemmed from ''a culmination of social factors beyond his control.''
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: ''The root causes of crime are the criminals who engage in it,'' Mr. Pataki said in a 20-minute speech marked with conservative themes and scolding language. ''And I've repeatedly made that point to the Legislature.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: ''And I've also made it clear to the members of that distinguished body -- in no uncertain terms -- that we, as servants of the people, are not charged with carrying out a sociological study. We are charged with maintaining public order and saving lives.''
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: As it happened, Mr. Pataki's appearance before the District Attorneys Association of New York came shortly after he attended the funeral of a police officer shot in the Bronx earlier this week, and that set an emotional backdrop to Mr. Pataki's appeal yesterday.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: The Governor chose a sympathetic audience to offer a mix of a few new ideas with a stack of old ones, along with a muscular recitation of what his aides said would be one of the two dominant themes of his campaign for governor. The other will be tax cuts.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: Mr. Pataki again urged an abolition of parole for all violent felons. He said he would propose legislation under which people convicted of multiple misdemeanor drug infractions -- such as selling small amounts of marijuana in a park -- could be charged with a felony.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: He said he wanted to make it easier to impose the death penalty by allowing the families of victims to make statements to juries, permitting prosecutors to sum up last and providing jurors with a defendant's complete criminal record. He also said prosecutors should be allowed to appeal bail or prison terms they considered too low.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: Mr. Pataki, speaking yesterday at an interview with Gabe Pressman to be broadcast Sunday morning on WNBC-TV, predicted that election-year pressures would make it difficult for Democrats to resist such proposals this year, as they have often done in the past. But his aides suggested that the mere act of fighting such battles would inevitably help his re-election bid -- regardless of how the bills ultimately fare in Albany.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: In his speech, Mr. Pataki approvingly quoted Ben Wattenberg, the conservative columnist, who observed that ''A thug in prison can't mug your sister.'' Mr. Pataki said the biggest challenge to passing legislation in Albany was convincing ''every member of the State Legislature to embrace what -- for you and I -- is an incredibly simple principle: That criminals cause crime.''
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: Pat Lynch, the spokeswoman for Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, said that the Democratic-controlled Assembly had repeatedly approved criminal justice initiatives since Mr. Pataki took office, including the death penalty. She said she had no doubt why Mr. Pataki was raising these issues now.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: ''What is offensive about the Governor's current statements about crime is that to many members of our house, he's trying to find a sound bite when realistic answers are more complicated,'' Ms. Lynch said. ''There's a time to govern and there's a political season. He would accomplish much more if he refrained from the sound bite and the politics of the issue and really worked in a nonpartisan way to find meaningful solutions.''
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: As it happened, Mr. Pataki's audience yesterday included one of the Democrats who is seeking to challenge him this year, Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney. Mr. Hynes disputed the Governor's claim that he deserved credit for the reduction in crime during his first term.
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: ''He really has as much to do with the crime rate reduction as he has to do with the bull market -- which is nothing,'' Mr. Hynes said. The Brooklyn District Attorney said that Mr. Pataki ''obviously is going to make crime an issue -- and that's fine with me.''
title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society

text: In his bid to become the top Federal prosecutor in the Southern District of Texas, Roland Garcia Jr. presents some impressive credentials. He is a partner in a prestigious law firm here, a director of the Houston Bar Association and a past president of the Hispanic Bar Association. The Democratic members of Congress in the Southern District have officially recommended him for the post.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: But with his name now before President Clinton, the 39-year-old Mr. Garcia is finding his campaign for the United States Attorney's job clouded by something he neglected to disclose, at least initially, to the Congressmen here: His younger brother is in Federal prison, convicted of involvement in drug-running and of the murder of an associate who crossed him on a deal.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: The story of Edgar Arnold Garcia's descent into crime is a painful family tale, one that seems to stand in stark contrast to the achievements of the rest of his siblings: two lawyers, including Roland Garcia, an investment banker and a singer.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Roland Garcia was in tears last August when he spoke to a Federal judge in Florida who was considering his 37-year-old brother's sentence. Roland Garcia told the court, ''I also want to say, on a personal note, that I love my brother, that I believe in my brother, that I personally long for the day that he can come back to the family, that his children can hug him and be with him again.''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: In his office at the Houston law firm of Liddell, Sapp, Zively, Hill & LaBoon, Mr. Garcia said in a recent interview that he had no idea then that just months later, he would be in line to be a United States Attorney, pledging vigorously to uphold the nation's tough drug laws. In any event, as even the prosecutor in the Florida case notes: ''He was speaking as a brother, not as a lawyer. He made that very clear.''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Nonetheless, his brother's case, Roland Garcia's apparent plea for leniency and his failure to raise the matter when he was approached about the United States Attorney's post are all part of a swirl of contention surrounding Mr. Garcia's potential nomination, even as his many advocates here have redoubled their efforts in recent weeks to secure him the post.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: The matter is a complicated one for the White House, fraught with both ethnic politics (Mr. Garcia has wide support from many minority groups here, and there are few Hispanic United States Attorneys anywhere in the country.) and the politics of the White House's fight with the Republican-controlled Senate over the slow pace of approvals for both Federal judges and Federal prosecutors.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: At the core of it all, though, are some basic questions, all variations on the essential issue of being a brother's keeper. Is it relevant at all that his brother is in prison? Are his comments to the judge relevant? (''If I were a prosecutor, I would have done the same thing the prosecutors did in his case,'' Mr. Garcia says. ''But I was not the prosecutor. I was the brother.'') Did he have an immediate responsibility to bring up the matter when asked whether he wanted to be a prosecutor?
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Mr. Garcia now says he wished he had simply disclosed the matter before he was asked about it by the local news media. ''Yes, I wish it would have occurred to me to bring up the issue of my brother, to take it off the table early on.'' But, he added: ''I have not thought my brother to be relevant to my professional career in all these years that I have been practicing law. It simply does not occur to me to tell people, 'Oh, by the way, I have a brother in jail.' ''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: In any event, he insists, offering a sentiment echoed by several Congressmen here and other supporters, his nomination should not be derailed because of the disclosure issue. ''I know I have good judgment as a trial lawyer,'' Mr. Garcia said. ''I may not have the best judgment as a public relations expert, but I'm learning every day.''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: But to at least some of those reviewing the issue in Washington, his failure to bring up the matter is troubling.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: ''There really are two questions here,'' said a Senate official in Washington involved in the screening process. ''Do you knock him out of contention simply because of the fact that his brother was into murder and drug dealing and the answer is, probably not, not simply because he's got a black sheep in the family.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: ''But the second point is the question of honesty and disclosure,'' said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''Somebody at the White House is going to have to look very hard at the ceiling and visualize the hearing at which he is asked a long series of very difficult questions. And it will be, what did you know and why didn't you say it?''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Under Senate procedures, the two Senators from Texas, Phil Gramm and Kay Bailey Hutchison, wield all but veto power in the approval process. Neither has taken a public position on Mr. Garcia, and neither is likely to do so until -- or unless -- he is officially nominated. Mr. Garcia has served for nearly three years as a member of Ms. Hutchison's advisory committee on Hispanic affairs.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: The Democratic Congressmen in the Houston area, who offered Mr. Garcia's name for the post, said they were disappointed that he had not told them about his brother early on. Described early and forthrightly, they say, it could have made his own case all the more compelling.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: ''I said to him, 'Roland, it would have been nice if I had known about this,' '' said Representative Gene Green, a Democrat who represents a largely Hispanic district in Houston and is supporting Mr. Garcia. ''He should have said, 'Look, I have a brother in prison.' ''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: ''I personally believe that qualifications override the lack of disclosure,'' Mr. Green said. ''I'd like Roland to have a fair chance to explain it to the Senate. Certainly, there are no other warts or problems that have come up other than this. If somebody were to oppose him, this is the only reason.'' Mr. Green and other members of the South Texas Democratic delegation in Congress voted informally to stand by Mr. Garcia even after the disclosure issue emerged.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Mr. Garcia is also the object of a strong lobbying campaign by supporters, including many Hispanic groups and the leader of the Houston area chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus is expected to adopt a resolution later this month calling on Mr. Clinton to nominate Mr. Garcia.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: The White House is expected to make a decision within weeks.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Belen B. Robles, national president of the League of United Latin American Citizens, known as Lulac, sent a letter to Mr. Clinton last month in which she urged that Mr. Garcia be nominated. Referring to the ''criminal misdeeds'' of his younger brother, she wrote that ''this should not be held against Mr. Garcia; on the contrary, Mr. Garcia's first hand knowledge of the adverse effects of drugs on a family will provide him with the background he will need.''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Roland and Edgar Arnold Garcia were very close as young brothers, Mr. Garcia said, but they drifted apart as the elder brother went to college at Baylor University in Waco and earned a law degree at the South Texas College of Law in Houston. The younger brother dropped out of high school, made contacts in the drug world and eventually became enmeshed in a South Texas drug-smuggling organization, said Greg McMahon, chief of special prosecutions in the Eighth Judicial District of Florida.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: In June 1991, Mr. McMahon said, the younger Mr. Garcia went to a motel in Chiefland, Fla., tracking down an associate, Phillip Martin Cryer, who had failed to deliver proceeds from 100 pounds of marijuana. Mr. Garcia shot the man nine times, killing him, Mr. McMahon said.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Edgar Arnold Garcia fled to Canada. He was extradited last year, but only after Florida officials, who had wanted to seek the death penalty for the killing, agreed not to do so. Mr. Garcia pleaded guilty to charges of Federal conspiracy to commit drug trafficking and weapons violations and was sentenced to 30 years in prison. He also pleaded guilty to a state charge of second-degree murder; under a plea bargain, his 17-year sentence is to run concurrently with his Federal sentence.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: As he was sentenced in August, when Roland Garcia spoke on his behalf, Edgar Arnold Garcia addressed the court. ''I have spent so many nights crying and praying for this man,'' he said of the victim. ''I pray for the repose of his soul. I hope that God has him in his company.''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: Roland Garcia has not seen his brother since that day, and he expressed surprise when a reporter told him recently that the brother, in what Federal prison officials said was a routine transfer, had been sent to a prison in Beaumont, Tex.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: In the interview, Mr. Garcia offered a succinct way of summing up his feelings about his brother's criminal life. ''I love my brother,'' he said. ''I detest what he did.''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: In any event, he insisted, he did not believe that the family trauma would have any negative impact on his ability to be the top Federal prosecutor in South Texas.
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: ''I will zealously prosecute anyone who violates the law, and I have no problem at all seeking the maximum criminal penalties,'' he said. ''I know exactly how families can be hurt and traumatized by the evils of drugs. And I will redouble my efforts to make sure that doesn't happen to another family.''
title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor

text: At least five members of Congress and dozens of Congressional aides have traveled a grueling 9,000 miles, crossed nine time zones and endured serious jet lag, all in the name of diligent fact finding.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Their destination: Saipan, a volcanic island and capital of the Northern Marianas, a chain of 14 islands in the western Pacific that is a commonwealth of the United States. The islands, which are about 3,500 miles west of Hawaii, boast crystalline lagoons, balmy climes, championship golf courses and, for the free-market minded, relaxed wage and immigration rules.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: The bills for the journeys, which can run as high as $5,500 for one person for one week, were paid by the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, which is trying hard to keep its exemption from Federal minimum wage and immigration laws.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: ''You have people coming here who, before they came on the trip, couldn't find Saipan on the map and have no direct responsibility over it, no history of involvement,'' said Representative George Miller of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Resources Committee who is a vocal critic of the commonwealth's low wages and labor policies. ''It's just a pure and simple lobbying job.''
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: For the past year and a half, the office of the commonwealth's Governor has conducted an ambitious public relations campaign, paying millions of dollars for fact-finding trips and in fees to Washington lobbyists, particularly the law firm of Preston, Gates, Ellis & Rouvelas Meeds.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: What sets this lobbying strategy apart from others is the success that the Marianas government has had in convincing Congressional Republicans that Democrats are wrong in pushing a bill that would raise wages and curtail immigration there.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Over the New Year's holiday, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip who has been a staunch supporter of the commonwealth's policies, made the trip to Micronesia with his wife, his daughter and three aides. He stayed for five work-filled days but also found time to play two rounds of golf on a pristine seaside golf course. Upon his return, Mr. DeLay proclaimed the Democrats' legislation dead.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: The government-paid trips, first reported by Roll Call, the Capitol Hill newspaper, have become especially popular in the last year, when the former Governor of the Northern Marianas, Froilan Tenorio, sensed a threat from the Clinton Administration to the islands' status quo. The Administration has described the laws as exploitative to workers.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Called to action, the Washington lobbyists hired by the commonwealth got to work. They extended invitations to nearly all members of Congress and their aides, as well as to officials of conservative research centers and newspaper editorial writers, to ''educate'' them about the Northern Marianas, said Jack Abramoff, the Preston, Gates lobbyist who arranged the trips. As many as 80 Congressional staff members, most of them Republicans who espouse free-market beliefs and dislike Democratic labor policies, have visited the island courtesy of the government.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: ''They don't have a Congressman or a delegate to the United States,'' Mr. Abramoff said. ''It's the farthest territory from the United States. Nobody knew anything about it. And the Federal bureaucracy, which for so long had a paternalistic and almost colonialist rule over these guys, said let's make a move on their economy.''
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: After World War I, Japan controlled Saipan and the Northern Marianas under a League of Nations mandate. Saipan, which was the site of a Japanese air base in World War II, was seized by United States forces in July 1944 after a three-week battle in which 3,400 Americans and 27,000 Japanese were killed. The island, 13 miles long and about 5 miles wide, then became a base for air attacks on the Japanese home islands.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Saipan and the other Northern Marianas voted to become a commonwealth in 1975. To help stimulate industry, the United States agreed to exempt it from Federal minimum wage and immigration laws.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Now Democrats say the exemption should be revoked. Most of the garment factories are not owned by American citizens. The workers hail mostly from China, Bangladesh and the Philippines, brought in for one or two years and paid $3.05 an hour, compared with $5.15 in the United States. So many workers have arrived -- 35,000 -- that they outnumber Saipan's permanent residents.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: To the Democrats' chagrin, the clothing can be shipped to the United States with labels that say ''Made in the U.S.A. With Imported Fabric,'' because Saipan is American soil. Earlier this week the bipartisan United States Commission on Immigration Reform deplored what it described as systematic labor and human-rights violations relating to the treatment of workers there.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: But Congressional visitors on Government-paid trips return home with a rosier picture of the islands, said Allen Stayman, an Interior Department official and critic of commonwealth policies.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Saipan is ''essentially being taken over by Asian garment interests who are exploiting it for their own greed,'' said Mr. Stayman.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: At least five members of Congress have made government-paid trips to Saipan in the past year and a half, but the island's most illustrious Congressional visitor was Mr. DeLay, the Texas Republican, who came at the invitation of the former Governor, Mr. Tenorio. Mr. DeLay's trip was arranged by Mr. Abramoff, a friend who, along with his wife, contributed $4,000 to Mr. DeLay's 1998 re-election campaign.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: To be sure, Mr. DeLay's official itinerary was chock full of meetings. He met with the former Governor and the new Governor, Pedro P. Tenorio, a relative of his predecessor. Mr. DeLay sat down with members of the legislature and with the Roman Catholic Bishop of Saipan, who touched on human rights.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: But there was time for regaling and relaxing, too.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Mr. DeLay was honored and entertained every evening. One reception was given by a Hong Kong businessman, Willie Tan, who agreed in 1992 to pay $9 million in back wages for his companies' failure to pay garment workers overtime.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: And Mr. DeLay, an avid golfer, twice played on one of Saipan's finest golf courses, the Lao Lao Bay Golf Resort. He and his family also visited Managaha Island, a 10-acre island in the lagoon that is known for its snorkeling.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: When he returned to Washington, Mr. DeLay spoke glowingly of the commonwealth's economic policies and renewed his vow to block legislation that would tinker with its wage and immigration policies.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Mr. DeLay's press secretary, John P. Feehery, who accompanied him, said the Congressman wanted to see for himself whether Saipan's purported sweatshop conditions were as outrageous as the Democrats say.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: '' 'Tis the season to cry junket,'' Mr. Feehery said. ''He would not travel 30 hours for some fun in the sun. That's not what he's about.''
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: By and large, Republicans maintain that Mr. Stayman and other Democrats are simply doing the bidding of American labor unions. Saipan's policy, they say, has been fruitful and effective at making the islands increasingly self-sufficient.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: It is an opinion they have honed during their visits to the Marianas.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Representative Phil English, Republican of Pennsylvania, just returned from his own trip to Saipan, where he represented Congressional Republicans at the new Governor's inauguration.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Other guests of the Marianas government have included Representatives Dana Rohrabacher, who later gave a complimentary speech about the commonwealth on the House floor, and Brian P. Bilbray, both California Republicans. Mr. Rohrabacher took his fiancee along, and Mr. Bilbray took his wife.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Because the commonwealth is the equivalent of a state government, the Congressmen did not have to disclose the trips in the same way as those paid for by private businesses. At least four Democrats have made the trip, but the Marianas government did not pay the expenses of three of them. Mr. Miller, who introduced legislation to change the wage and immigrations laws, visited the island this week. His expenses were paid for by taxpayers because he traveled on committee business.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: The same will apply for Representative Don Young, the Alaska Republican who leads the Resources Committee, which has jurisdiction over the commonwealth, and 10 members of the panel, who plan to visit Saipan in February. But one of Mr. Young's aides took a trip there earlier this month, paid for by the commonwealth.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Some members of Congress are distancing themselves from the Pacific voyages.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: ''You can't make a decision here in Washington that affects the Northern Marianas with your head stuck in the sand,'' said Ken Johnson, press secretary for Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who decided this week not to take the February trip.
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: ''That said,'' Mr. Johnson continued, ''there have been instances where staff members have been shielded from seeing and talking to people who would be able to shed some light on what is happening over there. You're only going to see what they want you to see.''
title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

text: Jimmy Chang moved to Camden last fall, taking over the family takeout restaurant just as the nighttime gatherings near his corner were winnowing down to what some people here call the ''children of the night.'' And there they remain on freezing January nights -- drug dealers and their customers, girlfriends and hangers-on -- picking up chicken wings and fried rice until the metal grates come down at 1 or 2 A.M.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: Mr. Chang also arrived, it turns out, just in time to walk into a constitutional question. After many months of public complaints and one false start, the Camden City Council narrowly passed an ordinance this month requiring food-service businesses that do not have seating for at least 15 people to close at midnight -- the goal being to deprive people like Mr. Chang's customers of their dead-of-night hangouts. And a group of restaurant owners is challenging the measure in court, contending that the city is punishing them unfairly in its endless war on drugs.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: The dispute will test the reach of a local government's power to regulate businesses in the name of protecting the public welfare. The fight also lays bare the conflicts between two struggling groups in a struggling city: the residents who say they are hostage to criminals in their row-house neighborhoods and the smallest of entrepreneurs, almost all of them immigrants, who are scratching out a livelihood.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: ''We'd like to be in the suburbs, or Chinatown in Philadelphia, but we don't have that kind of money,'' Mr. Chang said, waving an arm toward his counter, which is separated from the tiny waiting area in his restaurant, Great Taste 5, by a wall of Plexiglas. ''We have no choice but to live in a dangerous area. Owners here work 15, 18 hours a day to make a living, and the City Council is cutting them down? It's not fair.''
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: In less desperate circumstances, many other New Jersey cities, though far from most, already restrict business hours to control noise and loitering, but how far they can go is not clear. Two crucial court decisions, both in challenges brought by convenience stores, have drawn a wiggly line between restrictions that are permissible (in Springfield Township, a 9 P.M. closing time for retail businesses near residential zones) and those that are too intrusive (in Montvale, a requirement that all retail businesses close at 11 P.M.).
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: Finding a solution that curbs public nuisances without discriminating against legitimate businesses ''is like playing the piano with mittens on,'' said George T. Dougherty, a municipal-law specialist in Lawrence Township who was Trenton's city attorney when that city curtailed late-night businesses in the mid-1980's.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: Most of these measures exempt commercial areas and sit-down restaurants, and Trenton's ordinance, for one, does not apply to businesses that were operating before it was enacted. In most places, too, the nuisances are on the order of irritating traffic at the 7-Eleven or teen-agers drinking in parking lots.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: But in Camden, the term nuisance takes on different dimensions: in its recitation of the quality-of-life problems it addresses, the ordinance lists ''homicide and the random discharge of weapons.'' A police detective speaking at the City Council meeting told of finding open bottles of Bacardi and crack vials at one takeout place.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: ''People are scared to go out because of the drug dealers,'' said LaVerne Williams, who was cheering the bill's supporters. ''They use those places to go in and smoke blunt'' -- cigars hollowed out and stuffed with marijuana.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: But the solution, the law's opponents say, is to police the offenders, not the restaurants. ''This is absurd on its face,'' said Councilman Michael Devlin, who with two of the other six council members argued that the ordinance was constitutionally suspect. ''Is it the act of selling a hoagie over the counter creating crimes? Are people engaging in that activity because they had a hoagie or an egg roll?''
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: And if they can't sell hoagies and egg rolls, the owners contend, many will shut down. The law's challengers say more than 60 of the city's 400 licensed food vendors will be affected. Mr. Chang, for one, estimates that 20 percent of his business comes after midnight. If he had to close earlier, ''it wouldn't make sense to stay here,'' he said.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: The same is true for most owners, said Frank Fulbrook, a neighborhood association president who is joining the owners' lawsuit. ''The business you do after midnight might represent 20 or 30 percent of gross revenues, but that can represent 100 percent of your profits,'' he said. ''That's why it's devastating.''
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: While the plaintiffs seek a temporary restraining order in Camden County Superior Court -- the ordinance is to take effect next month -- some owners have begun to look at new locations. Sam De Pasquale, a co-owner of Lou's Steak & Pizza, said he was looking in neighboring Haddon Township, where he might draw the same hospital employees, police officers, and postal and sanitation workers who now stop in after midnight. If he goes, Mr. DePasquale said, so do his 11 employees and his $14,000 in property taxes. And he's not optimistic about finding a buyer for his old building.
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: All of which, if it came to that, would raise another problem for Camden. ''If these properties are turned into vacant, devalued buildings,'' Mr. Fulbrook said, ''the quality of life is only going to be worse.''
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food

text: For now, Mayor Milton Milan's administration is dismissing that threat in the face of what it says are bigger ones. ''To say that losing a few hours is going to make you lose your business is stretching it,'' said Keith A. Walker, a spokesman for the Mayor. ''There are people making sacrifices now, and those are the residents. Benjamin Franklin said that our rights exist to the point where they become a curse to our neighbors. Well, that's what happened here.''
title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food
